title: When Building Up Leads to Breaking Down
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Torreon Journal; Parched Region Invokes God and Blames Humans
description: Maria Torres Garcia turned on a faucet in her home here one recent morning and watched a little trickle run into the bucket she uses to collect water during the few hours a day when water still flows into homes here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALGIN, PAUL, M.D.
description: DALGIN-Paul, M.D. Medical Associates of Stamford mourns the death of of our colleague and friend, Dr. Paul Dalgin. He will be dearly missed by all those whose lives he touched. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Judy and his daughters Shara and Danielle. Leonard Vinnick, M.D. Robert Plansky, M.D. Inga Tuluca, M.D. Lynn Morris, M.D. and Staff

title: Reporter's Notebook; Parting Shots in South Africa Contest
description: There was a last-gasp volley of election salvos on Sunday night, the closest that South Africa's second post-apartheid election campaign has come to a debate.

title: African-American Culture Celebrated
description: The living were praised and the dead remembered once again in dance and song on Saturday afternoon with the Dance Africa festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The event has grown more sophisticated over its 22 seasons. This year's show, presided over by the genial, irrepressible Chuck Davis, artistic director and ''founding elder'' of the festival, celebrated African-American culture with an enjoyable balance of styles and perspectives.

title: Quick Recovery Undercuts South Korea's Quest to Bail Out Banks
description: South Korea's efforts to enlist foreign capital and expertise in an overhaul of its rickety financial system have become bogged down in, of all things, the country's stunning recovery from economic crisis.

title: Sultry Singer on the Verge of Stylized Madness
description: The German singer and theater star Ute Lemper does much more in her new cabaret show at Joe's Pub than merely sing a challenging program that leans heavily toward Friedrich Hollaender and the collaborations of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill.

title: Yeltsin Picks Familiar Reformers For 2 Top Economic Positions
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin placed two familiar and reform-minded fiscal experts in top economic posts today.

title: As Summer Nears, The Mighty Flea Reports for Duty
description: ''Fleas,'' the textbook states, ''are highly specialized parasitic insects belonging to the order Siphonaptera.'' That order name tells it all: Fleas have a siphon, a Draculian mouthpart that sucks the life blood from whatever animal their genes have programmed them to latch onto. Or, failing to find their predestined host, they will dine on any available red-blooded creature.

title: Politics Keeps a Satellite Earthbound
description: As spacecraft go, it is small, inexpensive and normally would hardly stand out among the dozens of satellites and probes NASA is planning to send into space. But Triana, because of its unusual origin and mission, has attracted a lot of attention. And it is in trouble because of it.

title: Is Spy Scandal Fueled by Racism or Justified Concern?; Echoes of McCarthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, ROBERT JUSTIN
description: McCORMACK-Robert Justin. Of Harding Twp, N.J. on Sunday, May 30, 1999. Husband of Mary Alexis McCormack. Father of Robert, Christian and Alexandra. Son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. McCormack. Brother of Eileen Harte, Mark McCormack, Justin McCormack, Catharine Totman and Mary Eisenhardt. Funeral Mass Thursday, June 3rd at the Church of Christ the King, Blue Mill Rd, New Vernon, NJ, 11AM. Donations may be made in Bobby's memory to the Delbarton School Scholarship Fund, Mendham Rd., Morristown, New Jersey 07960. Inquiries to the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown.

title: Brack Still Taking Victory Laps On the Day After the Indy 500
description: They are auto racing's odd couple, Kenny Brack and A. J. Foyt. Brack is from Sweden; Foyt is from Texas. Brack is soft-spoken; Foyt is loud and abrasive. Brack likes yogurt; Foyt prefers pork chops.

title: Favored Kuerten Eyeing A No. 1 Ranking, Too
description: These days Gustavo Kuerten is a vision in black and lime, no longer cloaking his lanky frame in the blue-and-yellow dazzle of his national flag the way he did when he became a Grand Slam champion here two years ago. But there seems little dispute that the blood pulsing through his veins is still the color of red clay.

title: Patterns
description: Debut of a Bridal Collection

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: S.E.C. Is Making Lawyers Walk in Clients' Shoes
description: Two lawyers who have nimbly defended prosperous Wall Street professionals stood before judges with lawyers of their own in recent weeks.

title: Wolves Are Establishing Strong Roots in Rockies
description: Experimental restoration of the gray wolf to Montana, Idaho and Wyoming has been so successful since 1995, Federal officials say, that the first steps toward a single, integrated wolf population in the Northern Rockies have now been taken.

title: Belmont Filly Likes the Grass
description: Soaring Softly, a 4-year-old filly who was switched from the dirt to the turf after injuries and illness last year, continued her remarkable turnaround yesterday at Belmont Park, where she won the Sheepshead Bay Handicap by 5 1/2 lengths.

title: Monet's Endless Valedictory of Light and Waterlilies
description: If the rest of the world is allowed to indulge in Monetmania, why not also Paris? So, after ''Monet in the 20th Century'' drew 566,000 visitors to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston last fall and a further 813,000 to London's Royal Academy this spring, it is now the turn of the Musee de l'Orangerie on the Place de la Concorde to offer its own crowd pleaser, ''Monet, the Waterlily Series.''

title: Chicago Museum Reopens And Tutankhamen Reigns
description: The Oriental Institute reopened to the public this weekend after three years of reconstruction, allowing museumgoers to come face to face -- or rather face to knee -- with a colossal statue of Tutankhamen that was made the centerpiece of the new Egyptian gallery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTLEMAN, LEONARD, M.D.
description: CASTLEMAN-Leonard, M.D. Dedicated physician for almost fifty years. At home on May 29th. His body was donated at his request to the Anatomical Gift Program at Downstate Medical Center. His survivors include his wife, Anita; his grandchildren, Ben and Rachel; his daughters, Janet and Nancy, along with her partner, Marc.

title: E-Commerce Concerns Select New Agencies
description: Three E-commerce companies have named agencies to handle accounts.

title: The Sabres Earn a Rare Trip To the Stanley Cup Finals
description: For the first time in 24 years and for the second time in their history, the Buffalo Sabres are going to the Stanley Cup finals. They clinched the Eastern Conference championship tonight in the Air Canada Center with a 4-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, winning the four-of-seven-game series by 4 games to 1.

title: Ramirez Raises Brows Behind His (Hot?) Bat
description: Poor Manny. His friends have abandoned him. The large groups who used to sit in the upper stands on the third base side of Yankee Stadium do not go there anymore. At least that is what he says.

title: Playwright Takes Roles Of Performer And Reporter
description: He came upon the notion of a monologue about Israel, David Hare explained, when it became clear to him that the Holy Land far exceeded the possibilities of conventional fiction. It is a perception that has only been reinforced by what has happened since he took his one-man play, ''Via Dolorosa,'' onto Broadway, including the stunning defeat of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Is Spy Scandal Fueled by Racism or Justified Concern?; Playing Us for Fools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G. JR.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G. Jr. A gathering of friends celebrating remembrances of his life. The Chapel at Saint Bartholomew's, Park Avenue at 50th Street, 4:30 P.M., Wednesday, June 2nd, 1999.

title: Kin of the Dead Seeking Inquiry On Tiananmen
description: Ten years after army troops and tanks were used to smash pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, more than a hundred relatives of the dead have petitioned the Government to open a criminal investigation of the responsible officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUM, JEAN HOUSTON
description: PLUM-Jean Houston. On May 28, 1999 in Orlando, FL. Former New York Hospital Patient Ombudsman and volunteer for various health care causes. She is survived by her children: Michael of Bloominburg, N.Y., Christopher of Natural Bridge, VA. and Carol of New York; and by her former husband Dr. Fred Plum also of New York. Contributions in Jean's memory may be made to a favorite charity. A private memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Parade Grounds: Home of Once and Future Mets?
description: The city is looking at one of its most famous sandlots -- where youthful players like Sandy Koufax and Joe and Frank Torre perfected their games -- as a site for a New York Mets farm team while it waits for a permanent stadium to be built in Coney Island.

title: BRAZIL MAY CUT SPENDING
description: Brazil said it would cut spending or raise taxes to trim its budget deficit and shore up investor confidence if the nation's highest court strikes down a new $1.2 billion Social Security tax. The pending ruling threatens to derail a major plank in the Government's effort to trim its $72 billion budget deficit. Just months ago, investors concerned the Government could not afford the cost of financing the shortfall ignited an outflow of capital ago that led to January's currency devaluation. The Government would more likely cut spending before raising taxes if it were to lose the court battle and the 2 billion reais ($1.2 billion) of revenue budgeted for this year, a Finance Ministry spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, MICHAEL
description: HABER-Michael. Passed away at the age of 87. He will be missed by his wife Ida, his loving children Rona Haber Mittleman and Robert Haber. He was adored by his loving grandchildren Zachary and Jaime Mittleman, Andrea and Lauren Haber. Michael was a kind and loving man who enjoyed life's simplicities. He lived each day and enjoyed each one to the fullest. He was a man of dignity who looked for and found the best in each human being and in each day. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services Tuesday, 1:30PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Steroid Use by Teen-Age Girls Is Rising
description: Whether trying to reach stardom in high school sports, working to achieve a fashionable lean-but-muscular look or suffering from a deep psychological disorder, teen-age girls are using illegal anabolic steroids in sharply increasing numbers, health authorities say.

title: No Apologies as Solomon Takes Eagerly to Lobbying for G.E.
description: For 20 years, Gerald B. H. Solomon represented the 22d Congressional District in New York with such probusiness gusto that environmentalists called him ''the Congressman from General Electric.'' It was not meant as a compliment, but Mr. Solomon, a former marine, wore the sobriquet as proudly as a medal.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: For Leiter, Some Queries, Many Theories
description: Thirty minutes after the Mets had lost their season-high fourth consecutive game, a 5-3 decision to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday afternoon, their clubhouse was almost deserted, the sign of a struggling team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, JAMES ALLEN
description: BARNETT-James Allen, age 90. On May 26, 1999. Quietly at home in Portland, Oregon. He was retired from a long career as a marketing and advertising executive. He married Jane Dodge of Philadelphia with whom he had two daughters, Fayal B. Greene of New York and Lucy B. Campbell of London, England. He subsequently married Harriet Brownell Pope of San Francisco and had four stepchildren, George A., Peter T., and Guy B. Pope, and Val Pope Hanna. Private memorial service at a later date. Donations to The Nature Conservancy, P.O. Box 165, Sun Valley, ID 83353.

title: MEXICO RESTRICTS DEPOSIT GUARANTEE
description: Mexico said it would phase out unlimited protection of bank deposits from 2003 to guarantee deposits of no more than $105,000 by 2005, a move to prompt banks to beef up capital and big depositors to share some risk. The Government will first lower its maximum guarantee per bank account to about 25.5 million pesos ($2.6 million) starting Jan. 1, 2003, before lowering it to 12.7 million pesos at the start of 2004. The target limit of 1.02 million pesos will begin January of the following year, said Mexico's Bank Deposit Insurance Institute. ''Large investors and corporate clients will bring more discipline to the market, in entrusting their resources to stronger institutions,'' the institute, a Government-run agency, said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIEREN, STANLEY
description: SCHIEREN-Stanley. 5/20/14-6/1/86. Beloved husband, father, brother, uncle. Forever mourned, forever remembered, forever loved. Anne, Rebecca, Alma Schiere

title: Dr. Atkins Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Indians Are Putting the Yankees on the Alert Early This Season
description: THERE'S nothing on the Yankees' uniforms to indicate that they are World Series champions. Just the intertwined ''NY'' on the chest, each player's number on the back, and a small ''5'' on the left sleeve to memorialize Joe DiMaggio's death. It's as if nothing needs to be said about the Yankees' 24th World Series reign.

title: Teaching Values Without Taking a Page From the Bible
description: The nation's public schools, which taught the Bible routinely for generations but retreated from explicitly moral education in the individual-rights boom of the 1960's, are under growing pressure to offer ethics instruction as a way to promote safe learning free of harassment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, WILLIAM
description: HALPERIN-William. Died unexpectedly May 30, 1999 surrounded by his family, just 22 weeks after his beloved wife, best friend and partner of 61 years, Lynn Muller Halperin. All father could ever be to Jane and Robert Willis, Mary and Martin Marlowe and Barbara Selling. Incredible, loving Grandpa to Carolyn, David and Susan Willis, Jennifer and Andrew Bender, Julie and Lisa Freiman, Gregory and Daniel Selling. Devoted son of the late May and Elias Halperin. Dearest brother of Ben and Shirley Halperin. Long-time Vice President of Ideal Toy, presently employed at the Dime Savings Bank. Family historian, student of the Torah and the finest of men. Services at Temple Beth El, Great Neck, Wednesday, June 2nd at 12:30. Shiva at the Marlowe's, Spruce Pond (Shelter Rock Road), Manhasset through Sunday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Caring Committee of Temple Beth El.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, MILTON
description: HESS-Milton. Loving husband of the late Bernice for fifty-one years. Cherished father of Risa, Janet and Charles. Dear father-inlaw to Patti. Brother of the late Howard. Beloved grandfather of Allison, Anya, Justin and Quintin. Devoted friend of Helaine. Proprietor for over forty years of Mr. Hess, Inc., Wantagh, L.I. and an active supporter of many local civic organizations. A generous man who enlivened everyone who knew him with his incomparable wit and wisdom. Service 1PM today, Gutterman's, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Hypothermia
description: Q. If a body temperature of 107 degrees Fahrenheit is nearly always fatal, what low body temperature is generally fatal?

title: In Time for the Beach, New Sunscreen Rules
description: The Food and Drug Administration recently issued new regulations for labeling, testing and manufacturing sun protection products. The rules do away with terms like ''sun block,'' ''waterproof'' and ''all-day protection.'' All over-the-counter sun protection products will be called ''sunscreen.'' Those that resist water will be classified either as ''water resistant'' or ''very water resistant'' on product packaging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, RHEA
description: GOLDFARB-Rhea. On May 31, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David Goldfarb, loving mother of Joel and Lloyd Goldfarb, cherished grandmother of Lisa, Michael, Carrie, Robin and Adam Kvelling. Great grandmother to Eric and Samantha. Devoted sister to Eileen Radlauer Mellinger and the late Lou Mollot. Funeral services on Wednesday, June 2nd at 10:30AM at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck at 150 Hicks Lane.

title: Still Chic? The Hamptons Feud and Fret, but Keep On Beckoning
description: James Brady, the Parade magazine columnist, was driving toward his white-clapboard home on Further Lane in East Hampton, telling funny stories about his rich and famous neighbors, when his eyes fell upon the hulk of an abandoned, unfinished home that had all the grace of a prison wing, only with larger windows.

title: China Detects Racism in U.S. Report on Spying
description: China today issued its broadest attack yet on the Congressional report that says China stole nuclear and missile technologies, calling the document a tissue of half-truths, conjectures and lies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERRY, CHRISTOPHER A.
description: SHERRY-Christopher A. Survived by his wife Eileen Coughlin, a son Christopher A., Jr., a brother James A. III, and his mother Janet. Visiting on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass at Resurrection Church on Wednesday, 10AM.

title: William Ringel Is Dead at 97; A Zesty Figure on the Bench
description: William E. Ringel, who ruled Andy Warhol's ''Blue Movie'' obscene, lectured civil rights protesters on the evils of anarchy and sent a parade of slumlords, thieves and vagrants to jail in 25 years as a judge in Criminal Court and other lower courts in New York, died on Thursday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 97.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A little-known way to profit by playing yen against dollars is again tempting the risk takers.
description: ONE of the main culprits in the global financial crisis of 1997 is sneaking back into the financial markets.

title: Early Notes by a Young, Still Undiscovered Sondheim
description: For Sondheim groupies, the in place to be these days is a utilitarian theater on the campus of a little-known college in a nondescript Chicago neighborhood. That is where ''Saturday Night,'' a 45-year-old musical with a book by an author of ''Casablanca'' and a thoroughly enchanting score by a young man who was yet to make his mark on the musical theater, is having an understated -- and long overdue -- American debut.

title: Life at Age 100 Is Surprisingly Healthy
description: Until recently, very few people lived to be more than 100. But with the number of centenarians rocketing upward, statisticians and scientists have begun studying them -- and challenging some of the conventional wisdom about the very old.

title: Court Finds a Condo's Board Made Too Many Demands
description: As Manhattan condominium boards increasingly try to sound more like co-op boards, demanding everything from income tax statements to canine reference letters, an appeals court has ruled that one condominium board, at least, went too far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVINGER, JOSEPH N.
description: DAVINGER-Joseph N. On May 30, 1999, at age 92. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Bruce and Barry. Adoring grandfather of Tara Glicksman; Nicholas, Christopher and Jennifer Brandaleone, and Steven and Bethany Davinger. Great-grandfather of Alexandra Glicksman. Dear brother of Pauline Spiegel. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 1:30 PM. Interment private.

title: As Tournament Nears, Ticket Sales Are Brisk
description: The third Women's World Cup will be staged in 17 doubleheader events, and with 18 days to go until the opener, 400,000 tickets have been sold. Officials of the tournament announced that 62,000 tickets have been sold for the opening-day doubleheader at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., that will feature the United States against Denmark and Mexico against Brazil.

title: Young & Rubicam Names Executive
description: Two agencies are naming new top executives.

title: Russian Arrears Deepening On Debts to Foreign Group
description: On Wednesday, Russia will default on roughly $900 million in interest payments on debt it owes the so-called London Club, a group of major foreign banks and investors that lent money to commercial entities of the former Soviet Union.

title: Gone, and Mostly Forgotten, Veterans Lament
description: Fifty-five years later, Murray Gaile vividly remembers the 123 days that he spent surviving at Anzio, in the Allied invasion of Italy in 1944. As a mortarman, he supported Army Rangers who were scythed down by German gunfire on one of the bloodiest beachheads of World War II.

title: Weeding Out Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Childs Sends Message to His Team: He's Reliable
description: On practice floors and inside the coach's office, Chris Childs and Jeff Van Gundy have yelled at each other like two drivers arguing over a fender bender. No disagreement has been major, no damage has been irreparable.

title: Chief Technology Officer At Microsoft Takes a Leave
description: Nathan Myhrvold, Microsoft's chief technology officer, will take a yearlong sabbatical to pursue his own scientific research and travel, the company announced today.

title: That Extra Musical Ingredient, Fright
description: The amateur soprano has reasons to fear Beethoven's Missa Solemnis. Professional choristers don't take it lightly either. It is the inner segments -- the Gloria, the Credo and parts of the Sanctus -- that make palms sweat and throats turn dry. The high B's, B flats, A's and G's keep coming, incessant, like battering rams.

title: An Urban Journey From Slum to Cultural Acropolis
description: Robert Moses, the city's Parks Commissioner and master builder, was devising a slum clearance project on the West Side.

title: Brazil Devaluation Changes The Trading Bloc Picture
description: For generations of Argentines, the quality of the meat they produce has been not just a source of pride but part of their national identity. So it is not hard to imagine the consternation that greeted a recent piece of news: the country is now importing meat from Brazil.

title: Is Spy Scandal Fueled by Racism or Justified Concern?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spandex Nation
description: Despite knowing about the dangers of obesity and the introduction of a new diet drug every few months, the average American is still overweight. Why are we so fat when we know we should lose weight?

title: Money Can't Buy Happiness. Er, Can It?
description: A few weeks ago my wife and I finally gave in to the pressures of modern life and acquired a cell phone. But it turned out that once we had the thing we had a few questions -- questions we couldn't get answered, because customer service was swamped with similar calls from the thousands of other people who had recently signed on.

title: Athletes Test Strength and Endurance
description: For many adults, the mention of the President's Physical Fitness Test conjures up images of sprinting between two chalkboard erasers and doing sit ups to exhaustion. For those with fond memories of this grade school gym class standard there is now a grown up version of it called Strend, a challenging six-event contest that is attracting more and more competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ALTON E.
description: PETERS-Alton E. Beloved husband of Elizabeth, father of Emily and Rachel and grandfather of Madeline and Isobel Fletcher. The funeral service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, at 11AM on Thursday, June 3. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Metropolitan Opera Guild or the Phillips Exeter Academy Library.

title: U.S. Concern Solicits British Investment Funds
description: On a sunny midday in Golders Green, Simon Benarroch is offering lox and champagne to celebrate the opening of the first office in London of Edward Jones, the American retail investment broker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINA, STANDISH FORDE JR.
description: MEDINA-Standish Forde Jr. On May 29, 1999. Dearly beloved husband of Kate and father of Nathaniel, loving son of Stan and Hope, and brother of Meredith and Jeremy; devoted partner of Debevoise & Plimpton. Service to be held at St. James's Espiscopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. (71st), Wednesday, June 2nd at 5PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Forde's memory to The St. Bernard's School and to The Collegiate School in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERL, BERNARD
description: SHERL-Bernard. On May 30, 1999. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Mildred Bernstein. Dearest father of Jane Rosenblum (Michael) and Robert. Loving grandfather of Gregory and Rebecca. Brother of the late Ely Scherl. A graduate of City College and Brooklyn Law School, he worked for the I.R.S. and subsequently went into private practice and became a prominent tax attorney. He overcame many obstacles to achieve the respect of his peers and the love of his family. He chaired many tax study groups, was an acting Village Justice in Lake Success, New York, was an avid golfer, a voracious reader and had a constitution which would not give up in the face of adversity. Courageous and proud to the end, he will be sorely missed.

title: 1946 Killing Of 4 Blacks Is Recalled
description: In 1945, returning from the Pacific after four and half years in the Army, George W. Dorsey got off the bus in Monroe, east of Atlanta, and walked down a dirt road to his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, HELEN ROSE (NEE HENDERSON)
description: WALLACE-Helen Rose (nee Henderson), on May 30, 1999 in her 81st year. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, she was devoted wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, sister, aunt and friend. Beloved wife of the late Arthur M. (Ret. Battalion Chief, FDNY). Loving mother of seventeen children: Mary Compton, Michael, Margaret Brady, Helen Welling, Patricia Candaras, Arthur, Elinore Harmon, Eileen Schiano, Kathryn, Daniel, Ann, Rita Brantl, William, Thomas, Patrick, Jean Mealia and John. Devoted sister of Evelyn Lancaster and Alice Robinson. Cherished grandmother of fortyfour and great-grandmother of fifteen. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Funeral Thursday 8:30AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 9:30AM at Our Lady Help of Christians R.C. Church. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5PM and 7-10PM. In lieu of flowers, donation may be sent to Family of Firefighters in Need, FF Thomas Elsasser Fund, C/O Kevin Gallagher, 204 East 23rd Street, New York, New York 10010.

title: Decision on Trademark Rights for a Rum Spurs a Global Dispute
description: Cuba cannot sell rum in the United States, but an American court ruling over Cuba's rights to the Havana Club trademark has President Fidel Castro so mad he is threatening to market his own brand of ''Coca-Cola.''

title: Two Dutch Designers Take Couture to the Surreal Side
description: Haute couture, let's face it, is hardly anyone's idea of a happening concern. Sure, one has the Miller sisters to hold up as the inevitable example of new blood, and of course there is Isabella Blow. Ms. Blow -- Izzy to her friends in London, where she is a kind of muse -- is so crazy about couture that during the semiannual showings in Paris she will change her outfit two or three times a day.

title: Three Companies Making Acquisitions
description: Acquisitions in advertising are continuing with deals for an agency, a publishing company and a software company, all for undisclosed terms.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Some Early Campaign Donors Play the Odds in Both Parties
description: As Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer faced off last year in New York's divisive Senate race, David G. Lambert decided to take a side. Make that two sides.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of our longtime friend, a man of great personal dignity, who is highly respected in the world of finance and Jewish communal affairs. With his wife, Dina, he was a Guardian of Yeshiva University. Through his creative vision and concern for the future of Jewish scholarship, he established the Recanati Courses in Kabbalah at Yeshiva University and at its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary he established the Raphael and Dina Recanati Israel Exchange Student Fellowship. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Dina, and to his sons, Oudi and Michael, and his grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Min Hashamayim Tenuhamu! Dr. Norman Lamm, President, Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Yeshiva University

title: INSIDE
description: Unusual Objects Seen in Sky

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDA, LEV N.
description: LANDA-Lev N. On May 29, 1999. A prominent scholar & author, he developed a theory of algorithims that was internationally recognized. Born in the U.S.S.R., he emigrated to the U.S. in 1976. Beloved husband of Maria. Devoted father of Boris. Dear brother of Aron. Loving grandfather of Zachary and Simone. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76 Road), Forest Hills.

title: Midlife Hits Lincoln Center With Calls for Rich Face Lift
description: Across Lincoln Center's 18-acre expanse, granite paving blocks are spider-veined with cracks. Missing tiles mar the reflecting pool that frames Sir Henry Moore's signature sculpture. An uncomfortable crush of patrons often jams the undersize lobby of the Metropolitan Opera House, and its metal ceiling is turning green from oxidation. Calls for sweeping renovations of Avery Fisher Hall and the New York State Theater are growing more insistent.

title: Going Beyond the Obvious For a Safer Summer Camp
description: Why does a tragedy always seem necessary to alert people to consider safety issues that should be a matter of course? Such a tragedy occurred last summer when 10-year-old Jeremy Scheinfeld of New Rochelle, N.Y., drowned while attending an upstate sleep-away camp.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: At the Box Office, a Force Is With 'Phantom Menace'
description: ''Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace'' dominated the box office over the holiday weekend with an estimated $64.8 million in ticket sales, passing the $200 million mark faster than any film in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, DAVID C.
description: BALSAM-David C. On May 30, 1999. Cherished son of Elizabeth and Gerald Balsam. Loving brother of Judy Gray. Dear uncle of Ian and Jared. Service today 1 PM, at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTHSTEIN, ROSE
description: LOTHSTEIN-Rose. Of Hollywood, FL, passed away on May 30, 1999. She is survived by her loving children, Leslie and Arthur Lothstein. Services will be held in Florida on Wednesday, June 2nd. RiversideGordon, 1-800-759-1151.

title: DDB Worldwide hopes to build on the legacy of 50 years of industry innovation.
description: WHEN is an anniversary not just an anniversary but the start of an ambitious brand image campaign? When it is commemorated on Madison Avenue.

title: Pearl Harbor And a Debt Still Unpaid
description: AS always, Memorial Day took Leonard Purifoy back to Dec. 7, 1941, back to Pearl Harbor, back to the boundless realm of terror and the cold iron touch of death.

title: Conrail Chugs Off Into the Sunset; CSX and Norfolk Southern Take Over
description: The companies about to divvy up the huge Conrail system have certainly tried to do their homework.

title: Virginia's 26 Seasons of Frustration Melt Away
description: After decades of disappointment for the University of Virginia in general and for Coach Dom Starsia in particular, the Cavaliers won the national championship in men's lacrosse today with a 12-10 victory over Syracuse, which had thwarted the Cavaliers in the past.

title: 500 Mourn Mother and Sons Killed by Train
description: Julia Toledo de Urgiles lay in her coffin with her youngest son, Pedro Andres, 3. Two other sons, Jose Francisco, 10, and Angel Gabriel, 6, shared one, too. Carlos Enrique, 11, had his own. On top was a white T-shirt he had won from a drug abuse prevention program, but had not had a chance to collect before his sudden death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEINBAUM, BEN
description: SHEINBAUM-Ben. On May 22, 1999 at age 77. Beloved teacher, friend, husband, father, brother and uncle. Taught at George Washington, Bronx Vocational and Morris High Schools and at JHS 171. Goodbye dear friend, we will never forget you.

title: EURO REGAINS GROUND
description: The euro rose against the dollar for the first time in four days yesterday as comments by European Central Bank officials and reports in British newspapers fueled speculation that the bank may use some of its $248 billion of foreign currency reserves to buy euros to halt the currency's decline. The Bundesbank president-designate, Ernst Welteke, said the euro's 10 percent drop since its introduction merits ''observation,'' while other central bank officials said the euro was poised to rise. Much of the euro's recent drop came after the European Union's decision last week to let Italy have a budget deficit of as much as 2.4 percent of gross domestic product this year, higher than its original target of 2 percent.

title: Astronomers Detect New Category of Elusive 'Brown Dwarfs'
description: Ambitious new surveys of the sky are surprising astronomers with mystifying discoveries in recent weeks, including an entirely new cosmic category of dim, reddish objects that scientists are calling ''methane brown dwarfs.''

title: Dr. Ornish Defends Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing, Smits And Playing With Pain
description: LARRY BIRD has heard all about Patrick Ewing the Warrior, Patrick Ewing playing so hurt he should be in traction in an emergency ward, Patrick Ewing so bruised and beat up that he appears to have been run over by shoppers at a bargain-basement sale. Larry Bird says he's buying none of it.

title: CLINTON DECLARES MOST WAR CLEANUP IS EUROPE'S TASK
description: On the eve of a key NATO decision on how to assemble a large peacekeeping force for Yugoslavia, President Clinton said today that Europeans would contribute most of the force and most of the money needed to rebuild the country.

title: Ganging Up on Blood Clots With a New Drug Cocktail
description: Adding a ''super aspirin'' to a standard clot-dissolving drug is a more effective treatment for heart attacks than either drug alone, according to an international study being published today.

title: Treasury Sale Is Limited to Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Valentine's Quandary: Who Plays in Outfield?
description: On the day Bobby Bonilla returned from the disabled list, Manager Bobby Valentine made it a point to take aside each of his five current outfielders yesterday and try to explain the situation to them.

title: Drive-by Shooting Kills Girl On Bronx Street With Father
description: A 3-year-old girl died early yesterday after being hit in a drive-by shooting as she stood with her father on a Bronx street corner, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Killed, 4 Injured in Weekend Boating Accidents
description: Two men were killed and four people were injured in three separate boating accidents over the Memorial Day weekend in New York and New Jersey, the authorities said.

title: The Diverse Creatures of the Deep May Be Starving
description: Hordes of creatures living in the hidden depths of the deep sea are in danger of starving to death, scientists report. This remote part of the planet is believed to harbor millions of undiscovered species, an unknown number of which may be in crisis.

title: Northeast Antismog Efforts Imperiled
description: As the Northeast begins its smog season -- when sunshine, warmth and pollution combine to sting eyes and strain lungs -- state environmental officials from Maryland to Maine are reeling from a series of court rulings that have derailed Federal plans to cut the flow of air pollution across state borders.

title: Can New York Forgive a Fallen Hero, Yet Again?
description: To the Editor:

title: Car Jumps Curb and Hits Mother and 2-Year-Old
description: A woman and her 2-year-old son were hit and seriously injured yesterday by a car that jumped onto a sidewalk in Harlem, the police said. The driver of the car was charged with driving while intoxicated.

title: Bird Remaining Calm After Pacer Meltdown
description: Without much worry, Larry Bird calmly fielded inquiries yesterday about how to fix things for his basketball team. Reflecting his stoic sideline demeanor, Coach Bird addressed the Pacers' problems with all the exuberance of a farmer watching wheat grow.

title: Favored Ways to Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: A Judge Moves to Strike A Blow for Legal Decorum
description: Lawyers who play hardball. Make threats. Go overboard with aggressive tactics. Is this an episode of ''Ally McBeal'' or ''The Practice''? Try the hallowed halls of the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan.

title: Col. W. R. Lawley Jr., 78, World War II Hero
description: Col. William R. Lawley Jr., who won the Medal of Honor in World War II for flying a crippled bomber with wounded crewmen safely back to England despite his multiple wounds, died on Sunday at a hospital in Montgomery, Ala., his hometown, He was 78.

title: Welcome Aboard, Belle Bids a Sailor
description: With thousands of sailors in town for the annual Memorial Day display of ships and starched uniforms known as Fleet Week, almost anything can happen.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Should Day Traders Have All the Fun?
description: The race is on to be the first to offer late-night stock trading. The New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq and a number of small electronic competitors have the same brilliant idea -- let people trade stocks until 10 P.M. If television networks think nighttime is prime time, why should Wall Street be any different?

title: Farmers' Right to Sue Grows, Raising Debate on Food Safety
description: Every week, it seems, brings a new food scare. And each scare, whether valid or dead wrong, has the potential to jolt the nation's diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUTNER, MILTON S.
description: MAUTNER-Milton S. Age 85, on May 29, 1999. Loving and dearly loved husband for 30 years of Peggy (Margaret Park) Mautner. Widely read, musically engaged, he was a man of fine intellect, wit, talent, goodness and dignity. He was for many years a writer and editor and was a veteran of World War II. In addition to his wife he is survived by an aunt Abeline and two nieces, Jean Ann Fineberg and Ellen Joan Fineberg. Irreplaceable and already missed. For further information please call Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

description: LAX-Michael. Age 69, of NYC and Bridgehampton, NY, on May 25th, 1999. Beloved father of Jennifer and Rebecca. Cherished partner of Kirsten Childs. An exceptionally gifted and caring man. He will be greatly missed.

title: Scaling Back to the Salon, For Audience and Quartet
description: Whenever chamber music is presented in public -- the very thing the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center was founded to do three decades ago -- a tension exists, if not a contradiction in terms. The relative intimacy of a salon -- a grand one, to be sure, when most of the classic works of the standard repertory were created -- is typically replaced by an impersonal concert setting: utterly transforming in halls like Avery Fisher or Carnegie, somewhat more accommodating in Alice Tully Hall, where the society holds forth.

title: The Citizens' Right to Know
description: After years of talk from the Labor Party about ending Britain's culture of secrecy, Tony Blair's Government has just proposed a sadly inadequate law governing the disclosure of government information. In effect, Britain is bucking a trend that has helped citizens elsewhere learn what their governments are doing and prevent official misconduct.

title: Staff of F.T.C. Is Said to Oppose Barnes & Noble Bid to Wholesaler
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has concluded that the planned merger between the nation's largest bookseller and its largest book wholesaler violates antitrust law and has recommended that the full commission step in to block Barnes & Noble's $600 million acquisition of Ingram Book Group, a person involved in the deal said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, SOLOMON
description: ZUCKERMAN-Solomon. Died on May 29, 1999. Resident of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Queens County, NY. Retired Judge of Civil Court, Queens County and practicing attorney for more than 50 years. Devoted, loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and loyal and caring counselor to countless. Survived by Mildred, wife of 55 years; son Alan (Rita Bernstein); daughter Evan (Andy Bernstein); grandchildren Seth, Whitney, Joanna and Tyler; brother David and sister Muriel Folkoff. We will always love you. Contributions in Sol's memory to Hospice By The Sea, Inc., 1531 W Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton FL 33486

title: Yankees' Praise of the Indians Has a Hollow Ring
description: Through grins, the Yankees acknowledged that they were thoroughly outplayed by the Cleveland Indians yesterday. They conceded their own failures, the poor performance of Orlando Hernandez and their lack of clutch hitting. Nobody suggested that the Indians didn't earn their 7-1 victory before 46,605 at Yankee Stadium.

title: Spurs Take Their Time, And Game As Well
description: Sean Elliott knew he had no business shooting the basketball. He was hot, yes, but he was also off balance, nearly out of bounds and peeking at an open David Robinson from the corner of his eye. But the five 3-pointers Elliott had made, the invincible feeling he had played with all day, and the gravity of the moment were conspiring against logic.

title: Trial for Campaign Reform
description: It was hard enough to keep a straight face when House Speaker Dennis Hastert declared that there was no time for campaign finance reform, especially since he said it while the House was preparing for its vacation. Even funnier was the sanctimonious lecture last week by Tom DeLay to the half-dozen Republicans who defied Mr. Hastert and signed a petition to force the Shays-Meehan reform bill to the floor of the House. Mr. DeLay seemed to suggest that by standing up for principle, these reformers were committing lese-majeste against their Speaker. But the issue here is not Mr. Hastert's dignity. It is whether his party has a soul.

title: By Design; Denim, Right Down to the Toes
description: Denim has made such a strong comeback that it is being used for many things other than jeans. There are dresses, shorts, shoes and bags in different shades of blue.

title: In Plea for His Life, Kurdish Rebel Offers to Halt War
description: On the first day of his trial on treason charges, the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan apologized for his past and said he would call for an end to guerrilla violence if the Turkish authorities would give him the chance to turn his army into a civilian political party.

title: An Aria for the Arts at a Harlem School; Rigorous Training Fills a Void and Nurtures Dreams
description: Up to now there have been no musicians in the family of Willie Boy Morales Medina, an aspiring singer from Queens who is 17, husky, almost 6 feet 3 and still growing. His mother loves music but can't sing a note. ''She's the only female bass I know,'' he said recently.

description: Timber wolves from Canada are unlikely to recolonize the northeastern United States on their own, leaving the politically more contentious course of deliberate reintroduction as the best strategy for restoring the wild wolf's howl to the region, a new study sponsored by New York's Wildlife Conservation Society has found.

title: Reform Jews Mirror Return to Ritual
description: For Maron L. Waxman, practicing Judaism has been a series of deepening experiences. She began lighting Sabbath candles after her children were born, in the 1970's. In the next decade, she started studying Hebrew. And from once having attended synagogue only infrequently, Ms. Waxman has been going twice weekly of late. She also serves as president of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, a Manhattan congregation affiliated with Judaism's Reform movement.

title: CATHAY FLIGHTS CANCELED
description: A labor dispute at Cathay Pacific Airways has forced the airline to cancel about one-third of its flights each day since Saturday. Pilots at Cathay Pacific, a Hong Kong-based carrier, are calling in sick to protest pay reductions they are being asked to accept as part of a cost-cutting campaign. Cathay Pacific has given the pilots until June 11 to accept a plan, which would cut pay by 7 percent in return for stock options. The airline is owned by Swire Pacific. Mark Landler

title: Refugees Cheer Bombing Across Border

title: Foreign Affairs; Are You Ready?
description: About a year and a half ago I interviewed John Chambers, the president of Cisco Systems -- the company that makes the black boxes that connect the Internet. Mr. Chambers declared that, though most people did not grasp it yet, the Internet was about to change ''everything'' about how people work, invest, learn, shop and communicate. I wrote down what he had to say, but thought of it as the sort of overstatement one could expect from an Internet exec.

title: An Evening of Tchaikovsky, Classically and Simply
description: The message of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2,'' presented by the New York City Ballet in an all-Tchaikovsky program on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, is that the essence of ballet classicism is a timeless, simple formal grandeur.

title: Correction

Neither paper has cut back its coverage. (One of four Times correspondents assigned there left temporarily, to complete a report about the purging of Kosovar Albanians by Serbian forces. The Post plans to keep at least four correspondents there.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. The President, the Board of Trustees and entire Montefiore Medical Center community deeply mourn the death of our dear friend and supporter, Jerome L. Greene. A devoted and active trustee since 1972, he had an extraordinary impact on the quality of health and life of thousands of Montefiore patients and residents of the Bronx and Westchester. Combining his skills as a lawyer with his belief in Montefiore as an instrument of social responsibility, he led the medical center in the founding, 18 years ago, of the Mosholu Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit community development support corporation that has, with his guidance, saved housing, revitalized neighborhoods and created innovative projects such as moderate income housing, a community newspaper that serves 15,000 households, the first and only NYC business improvement district sponsored under the auspices of an academic institution, a vast program of graffiti removal and a youth job training program-all of which have played a role in the Bronx's nationally recognized resurgence. He believed in the crucial role of academic medical centers such as Montefiore in advancing the health of communities through research, education and provision of high-quality care, and with his beloved wife, Dawn, he helped Montefiore create the Jerome L. and Dawn Greene Medical Arts Pavilion, a state-of-the-art building that opened in 1997 offering a full range of general and specialty services in an ambulatory care setting. More recently, he and his wife have been generous benefactors of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, scheduled to open in 2001. In 1991, at its annual Celebrate Montefiore dinner dance, the medical center honored this remarkable man of vision and commitment for his exemplary stewardship. This year, Montefiore nominated him for the United Hospital Fund's 1999 Distinguished Community Service Award. The medical center has lost one of its greatest friends. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving wife, Dawn, and their entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

description: Back in 1995, my mother felt that Al Gore needed a little boost.

title: Louima Case Defense Rests With No Officer Testifying
description: After a month of often graphic accounts and a surprising midtrial guilty plea by one defendant, testimony in the Abner Louima police brutality case sputtered to an end yesterday when the only officer who had said he would take the witness stand changed his mind.

title: Mexico Clears a Top Official of Graft, but Doesn't Convince the U.S.
description: Earlier this year, as President Clinton prepared to visit Mexico, law-enforcement officials there disclosed what they cast as an extraordinary break from the country's long tradition of immunity for those at the highest levels of power.

title: Bozell Hires Ford Executive
description: A marketing executive from the automotive industry is joining a big agency.

title: Alabama Acts to Limit Huge Awards by Juries
description: For more than a decade, no issue has divided Alabama politics like that of tort revision, the effort to limit the enormous damage awards that have made the state's juries fabled for their generosity to plaintiffs. Even the issue of civil rights has been pushed aside as the defining question for Alabama's politicians, whose source of campaign money largely depends on their position on jury verdicts.

title: In Medicine as in Fashion, You Pay for Quality; Illness Affects Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; Reshaping Retail Space And Making It Pay Off
description: In late 1995, the owners of Paramount Plaza, a 2.4-million-square-foot office building at 1633 Broadway, were looking for ways to reinvent about 100,000 square feet of multilevel retail space. Now, more than three years later, the renovated space between 50th and 51st Streets has three new tenants -- the Mars 2112 restaurant, Cosi Sandwiches and the Equinox Fitness Club -- in 65,000 square feet.

title: On Campus; Graduate from college in Maryland receives the $43,238 Sophie Kerr Prize for a poetry portfolio.
description: Over a million students graduated from American colleges this spring, but it is a safe bet that few enjoyed the day more than Luke Owens.

title: Wrong Time, Wrong State
description: In discussing Hillary Clinton's plans for the Senate race in New York, the ''Will she or won't she?'' question should now give way to, ''Should she or shouldn't she?''

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 13 about a Cincinnati obscenity prosecution involving the publisher Larry Flynt misstated the outcome. Charges against Mr. Flynt were dismissed. A plea of guilty to two counts of pandering obscenity was entered by Hustler News and Gifts Inc., an Ohio corporation that owns a store that sold sexually explicit videos. While his brother is the president of that company, Mr. Flynt is not an owner or employee of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MARTHA
description: COHN-Martha. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Hannah Kubatzki on the loss of her beloved sister, Martha. A Golden Founder and longtime supporter of our Annual Dinner and Concert, she was a righteous woman who personified the qualities of elegance, grace and extraordinary dignity. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, MADELEINE
description: EDELSTEIN-Madeleine. On May 31st at West Palm Beach. Dear sister of Evelyn and Roland. Proud and loving aunt of Frederick, Mark and Gordon. Adoring great aunt of Marlene, Noah and Lawrence.

title: It's Long, Hard Stares For Yanks and Indians
description: Derek Jeter desperately tried to jump back from Steve Reed's tailing fastball in the eighth inning, but it clipped him on the left thigh. Jeter knew it was a payback pitch. Roger Clemens had already drilled Kenny Lofton in the right elbow, and Jason Grimsley's fastball had found Wil Cordero's back. So someone on the Yankees was due to be targeted.

title: Fruitless Search for Body of I.R.A. Victim Frustrates Family
description: The family of Jean McConville, a mother of 10 who was killed by the Irish Republican Army in 1972 because she comforted a dying British soldier, waited and hoped today that her remains would be found by Irish police.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The Return Of Mighty Mice; After 18 Months in the Cellar, Small-Capitalization Stocks Inch Up on Their Big Cousins
description: Small-cap stocks are on a tear, but can they make up all the lost ground of the last few years?

title: Study Shows Drug Does Not Build Muscle
description: A surprising new study found that the drug Mark McGwire said he used on his way to breaking the single-season record for home runs did not build muscle but did increase the risk of heart disease, pancreatic cancer and breast enlargement.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Chinese Flatbread

title: Defense Cites Compassion, Not Greed
description: Mario Manuel Reyes Burgueno, a lawyer charged with smuggling Mexican babies into the United States, is well known throughout this community on the Mexican border as a devout Roman Catholic and a staunch opponent of abortion. And his lawyers say his efforts to get Mexican children adopted in the United States were motivated by religious conviction and humanitarian compassion and not by greed.

title: Dulce de Leche
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Gore Enlists the First Lady for Women's Support
description: With his support among women lagging, Vice President Al Gore today sought the help of Hillary Rodham Clinton to spark excitement for his Presidential candidacy -- even at the risk that her star power would upstage him.

title: Spurs Seem to Hold Spell The Blazers Can't Break
description: None of the players and coaches involved wants to admit it, but there is a sense of predestination looming over the Western Conference finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEIER, FERDINAND
description: SPEIER-Ferdinand. Beloved husband of the late Ruth and the late Mickey. Devoted father of Janet and Burt Cohen and Peter and Janyce Speier. Cherished grandfather of David, Lisa, Eric, Cindy, Andrew, Jessica, Samantha, Justin and Ryan. Loving great grandfather of Remi, Hailey, Jordan, Joshua and Allison. Services Thursday, 11 AM, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Water Main Break Leads to Evacuation
description: A water main break on the Lower East Side opened up a 15-foot-deep sinkhole yesterday and forced the temporary evacuation of six apartment buildings, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUTNER, MILTON S.
description: MAUTNER-Milton S. Age 85, on May 29, 1999. Loving and dearly loved husband for 30 years of Peggy (Margaret Park) Mautner. Widely read, musically engaged, he was a man of fine intellect, wit, talent, goodness and dignity. He was for many years a writer and editor and was a veteran of World War II. In addition to his wife he is survived by an aunt Abeline and two nieces, Jean Ann Fineberg and Ellen Joan Fineberg. Irreplaceable and already missed. For further information please call Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: Of Difficulties In Downloading
description: I like to think of myself as pretty competent with technology. I can set alarm clocks, program VCR's, make bids on items in Ebay and mix cake batter without getting any on the walls. When it comes to listening to music on the Internet, I'm what statisticians call an early adapter, working with an Internet radio station blaring or downloading free songs onto my MP3 player with customized skins and cool visual plug-ins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDON, RICHARD
description: PADDON-Richard, age 78 of Berkeley Heights, NJ. Died at his home, May 29th, 1999 after a brief illness. Born to Harry L. and Mina (Gilchrist) Paddon of Northwest River, Labrador, Canada. Survived by his wife, Mary Werthmann Paddon, children, Richard L., Elizabeth G., James R., Katherine F., stepdaughters, Christine and Katherine Werthmann. Brother of John and nine grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Lydia Babbott Paddon, brothers, Tony and Harry Paddon and a grandson. During World War II, he served in Europe with the Royal Canadian Naval Volunteer Reserves 29th MTB Flotilla attaining the rank of Lieutenant and Command of the MTB. Following the war, he completed his education at Trinity College, Hartford, CT. He spent his career with Hansen and Tidemann Inc., steamship agents, and became a Senior Partner and a Managing Director. A funeral service will be held June 12th, 2 PM at Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Vassar College, Lydia Babbott and Richard Paddon Scholarship Fund, Atlantic Hospice, 33 Bleeker St., Millburn, NJ, 07041 or the Seamen's Church Institute, NYC, NY.

title: Raphael Recanati, Philanthropist, Dies at 75
description: Raphael Recanati, an Israeli-American shipping and banking figure better known in New York for his philanthropic largesse -- particularly as a mainstay of Beth Israel Medical Center -- died last Friday in the medical center. He was 75 and lived on the Upperast Side and in Herzliyah, Israel.

title: BRAZIL SURPLUS JUMPS
description: A rise in exports of manufactured goods and commodities contributed to a tenfold increase in Brazil's trade surplus in May, to $312 million, compared with $30 million in April. The Government figures reflect successful efforts by many Brazilian companies to take advantage of the 30 percent decline of the Brazilian currency's value this year, which has made Brazilian exports more competitive. However, the numbers are still considered disappointing. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have had attorneys come here and offer me $100 for every child I give to them for adoptions. I tell them my children are not tomatoes for sale, and that I never want to see them on my property again.''

title: Peace in Kosovo: Uncertain at Best; Ignoring Africa?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Courts' Perilous Right Turn
description: Conservative politicians often complain about the decisions of liberal Federal judges who, they say, do not respect the judgments of elected officials. For example, they object to judges who have struck down laws restricting abortion and regulating sexually explicit materials.

title: From Lawsuits to Tea Bags, Challenges to Commuter Tax
description: Looking to eliminate the New York City commuter tax, elected officials from New Jersey and Connecticut unleashed an assortment of lawsuits, legislation and tea bags today in an effort to demonstrate that the tax discriminates against out-of-state commuters.

title: Fatigue and the F.A.A.'s Metabolism
description: Pilots, airlines and safety experts have long prodded the Federal Aviation Administration to modernize its 1985 rule requiring pilots to get at least eight hours of rest in the 24 hours before the end of their flight duty. Since 1989 the National Transportation Safety Board has urged the agency to develop new standards that better reflect research findings about sleep, the body's circadian rhythms and fatigue countermeasures. Yet throughout this decade, the F.A.A.'s efforts to draft new rules have floundered. The one action the F.A.A. can, and should, take immediately is to outlaw two practices known to contribute to fatigue.

title: Step in Storage Of Atom Waste Is Costly Error
description: After spending 16 years and $489 million on a crucial step in its plan for the safe storage of millions of gallons of highly radioactive waste, the Energy Department has abandoned the procedure because it produces explosive gases.

title: After Three-Month Recess, Microsoft Trial Resumes
description: After a three-month recess and unsuccessful efforts to reach a settlement, the rebuttal phase of the Microsoft antitrust trial opened today with a concerted attack on the previous testimony of the company's chief economic witness.

title: C. F. McErlean, 87, Ex-President Of UAL, United Airlines' Parent
description: Charles F. McErlean, a former vice chairman of United Airlines and president of UAL Inc., its parent, died May 21 at his home in Oak Brook, Ill. He was 87.

title: Spinning the Wheel of Fortune
description: Life used to be much simpler for Se Ri Pak. Early last year, she would arrive at tournaments attracting little attention, an unfamiliar face in the crowd.

title: Red Roof Opens New Inns
description: Red Roof Inns Inc. said today that it planned to open 34 additional inns throughout the United States in 1999. The lodging chain said it had already opened 16 properties this year. The company attributed the growth to aggressive franchising efforts. Red Roof, based in Hilliard, Ohio, had 1998 revenues of $375.3 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: New Diet Drug Sells Well, But It Didn't Set a Record
description: After one month on the market, the diet drug Xenical, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, will not go down as the most successful new pharmaceutical in history, but analysts remain confident that it will become a best seller.

title: Liberty Media Agrees to Acquire Associated Group
description: Liberty Media Group, the television programming operation controlled by John C. Malone, expanded into the wireless communications business yesterday by agreeing to acquire Associated Group Inc. in a deal worth perhaps $2.8 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME
description: GREENE-Jerome. On behalf of the Board of Trustees and staff of 13/WNET, we wish to extend our most profound condolences to Dawn Greene and family. We share your loss at the passing of Jerome Greene. A member of 13/ WNET's Board of Trustees, he played a long and active role in guiding the station to a position of great productivity and national prominence. As a Chairman of the Real Estate Committee, he led the historic effort to move the station to its new digital headquarters. For many years, his leadership, philanthropic contributions and his esteemed counsel have anchored 13/WNET's success. We join New York in mourning a man of extraordinary vision and generosity. He will be greatly missed. Steven R. Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRIS, YETTA
description: AGRIS-Yetta. On June 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel. Devoted mother of George, Pearl and Judith. Dear sister of Margaret Edelstein. Cherished grandmother of David, Stuart, Joann, Cheryl, Robert and Andrew. Loving great-grandmother of Laura, Nathan and Max. Services Thursday, 12noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Common Foe Helps Rivals To Agree, For a Change
description: It did not represent an armistice, or even a major thaw in a quarrel that has left New York's two Republican potentates speaking to each other about as often as distant relatives (and then only through gritted teeth). But Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to appoint Herman Badillo, a confidant of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as chairman of the City University of New York shows that under certain conditions, the two can agree, and even be almost gracious about it.

title: BIDDING WAR INTENSIFIES
description: The British company Cable and Wireless P.L.C. sweetened its bid for International Digital Communications Inc., the Japanese international long-distance carrier, in the latest round of a bidding war with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. Cable and Wireless made its formal takeover bid in early May, offering 107,732 yen a share for 82.3 percent of International Digital. On Monday, Nippon disclosed that it had made a bid, reportedly worth about 108,974 yen a share. Yesterday, Cable and Wireless raised its bid to 110,577 yen a share, or 69 billion yen ($568 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, MURRAY
description: ROSE-Murray. On May 31, 1999. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of David and daughterin-law Cora. Dear brother of Ruth Habib and the late Irving Rosen, Jack Rose, Lily Seltzer, Sally Korn, Anne Fried. Devoted grandfather of Michael and Melissa. Service on Wednesday at 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOST, HERBERT HANDLER
description: FOST-Herbert Handler. Of Westfield, N.J. Devoted husband of the late Lillian M. (Shapiro) Fost. Dearest friend of Lillian Block. Beloved father of Nancy Segal of Scituate, MA., and Ronnie Kanarek of Sudbury, MA. Cherished grandfather of Eric Segal and Michael Kanarek. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral serivce at the Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Avenue, Westfield, N.J. on Thursday, June 3, at 12 Noon. Interment Temple B'Nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey. Donations in his memory to Facing History and Ourselves would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADAS, ANNE E.
description: HADAS-Anne E. Age 97. Died May 29, 1999 in New York. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Gershon Hadas of Kansas City, Missouri. She is survived by her daughters, Hedva Glickenhaus and Judith Florman, grandsons, Lee H. Glickenhaus, Alan Glickenhaus, David A. Florman, and Jonathan C. Florman, and seven great-grandchildren. Interment was private in Kansas City.

title: 3 Arrested in Shooting Death of Bronx Girl
description: Three men were arrested last night in the fatal drive-by shooting of a 3-year-old girl who was standing on a Bronx street corner with her father on Memorial Day, the police said.

title: CALENDAR
description: East Meets Southwest

title: Budig Has Talk With Wright
description: Cleveland pitcher Jaret Wright met yesterday with the American League president, Gene Budig, about Budig's concern over Wright's deportment on the mound.

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing Cast As Linchpin Of the Knicks
description: AT one point near the end of the first half, Patrick Ewing drew his third foul and went to the bench to the accompaniment of the chanting of an obscenity, courtesy of some 16,000 fans in Market Square Arena. Ewing raised his great wingspan to encourage them and wiggled his lengthy fingers as if to say, sticks and stones can break your bones but -- well, you ain't hurtin' us.

title: MILOSEVIC LETTER SHOWS TWO SIDES REMAIN FAR APART
description: Germany today received a letter from the Yugoslav Government in which President Slobodan Milosevic said he was ready to withdraw forces from Kosovo and accept a ''United Nations presence'' in the Serbian province.

title: Forecasting a Bland Fall
description: The early word on the overall look of the next television season: bland shows and much more chaotic schedules than network executives would have you believe.

title: ALLIED DOMECQ DENIAL
description: The world's second-largest liquor company, Allied Domecq P.L.C., which also owns the Dunkin' Donuts and Baskin-Robbins chains, denied press reports that it was in talks to merge its spirits division after a $3.84 billion deal last week to sell its 3,600 British pubs to Whitbread P.L.C. Allied stock rose 3.59 percent, to 619 pence, before falling back after British newspapers said Pernod Ricard S.A. of France, the Brown-Forman Corporation and the Bermuda-based Bacardi & Company were interested in a deal. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Dow Jones in Link With Germans as Rivalry Grows in Europe
description: Hoping to fend off The Financial Times of London in Continental Europe, Dow Jones & Company announced an alliance today with Germany's biggest daily business newspaper.

title: Miscellany
description: * Havas Advertising, Paris, formed a division concentrating on sports advertising and marketing, Havas Advertising Sports, by combining operations of three specialized communications agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, CHARLES W., MD.
description: FRANK-Charles W., MD., 100 years old. Pre-deceased in 1975 by his beloved wife of fifty years, Mabel Reinschreiber Frank, and in 1998 by Mae Frank. Father of Ruth Deutsch and Janet Fox (Alan). Grandfather of Kenneth and Nancy Deutsch, Martin and David Kalt. Great-grandfather, brother of Sofia and the late Sam, Ben, Lou and Sol. Bronx physician, 1925-1970. He loved and nurtured us, and taught us the meaning of family values and traditions. He left us memories to cherish for a lifetime. His humor, wisdom and love will guide and protect us and we will miss him forever.

title: At the New Daniel, Invention Meets Restraint
description: THE oxtail terrine at Daniel tells you nearly everything you need to know about Daniel Boulud. It arrives on the plate like a geological sample, a dark sedimentary slab with a fat vein of foie gras and slices of black truffle like seams of coal. The thing looks coarse. And then it reaches your mouth.

title: The Anti-Drug Campaign's Missing Link
description: Gen. Barry McCaffrey, President Clinton's director of national drug policy, has declared flatly that under-age drinking is the single biggest drug problem among adolescents, and is intimately linked to the use of illegal drugs. But as things stand now, the $195 million national media campaign that General McCaffrey is running this year to dissuade youngsters from using illicit drugs will not spend a penny in Federal funds to warn teen-agers about the dangers of drinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATOVSKY, RABBI NAFTALI
description: PLATOVSKY-Rabbi Naftali. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its member, Ronald Platovsky. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, BRADLEY
description: SLATTERY-Bradley. On May 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Carolee Sepik. Loving brother of Dr. Louis Slattery. Cherished grandfather of Mark B. Webb. Visitation Wednesday, 25 and 7-9PM at the ''Forest Park Chapel'', 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Graveside service Thursday, 11AM, at Maple Grove Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Notebook; Enforced Retirement
description: Mary Daly, a feminist theologian who was granted tenure at Boston College 30 years ago, has long battled the college over her refusal to allow men in her courses. Ms. Daly says the presence of men inhibits class discussion; the college says her refusal violates college policy and Federal law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, HELEN ROSE (NEE HENDERSON)
description: WALLACE-Helen Rose (nee Henderson), on May 30, 1999 in her 81st year. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, she was devoted wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, sister, aunt and friend. Beloved wife of the late Arthur M. (Ret. Battalion Chief, FDNY). Loving mother of seventeen children: Mary Compton, Michael, Margaret Brady, Helen Welling, Patricia Candaras, Arthur, Elinore Harmon, Eileen Schiano, Kathryn, Daniel, Ann, Rita Brantl, William, Thomas, Patrick, Jean Mealia and John. Devoted sister of Evelyn Lancaster and Alice Robinson. Cherished grandmother of fortyfour and great-grandmother of fifteen. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Funeral Thursday 8:30AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 9:30AM at Our Lady Help of Christians R.C. Church. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5PM and 7-10PM. In lieu of flowers, donation may be sent to Family of Firefighters in Need, FF Thomas Elsasser Fund, C/O Kevin Gallagher, 204 East 23rd Street, New York, New York 10010.

title: Salmon but Not Wine
description: To the Editor:

title: REYNOLDS METALS WILL LOOK FOR ACQUISITIONS OR MERGER
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the second-biggest United States aluminum producer, will pursue acquisitions or a ''merger of equals'' to compete better around the world, its chairman and chief executive, Jeremiah Sheehan, told analysts yesterday. Reynolds and other aluminum producers have been trying to find ways to expand to challenge Alcoa Inc., the world's No. 1 producer, which already led the field before acquiring Alumax Inc. of Atlanta and Inespal S.A. of Spain last year. Reynolds's shares rose $3.50, to $56.3125, and other aluminum stocks also rose.

title: Six-Year Battle, No End in Sight; Principal's Fight for Job Spotlights Sluggish System For Disciplinary Actions
description: For the last six school years, Joanne Falinski has collected $100,000 as an elementary school principal, but she has not been allowed near a classroom. Instead, she has been doing clerical work for the school district while it pursues a disciplinary case against her that has no end in sight.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Clemens's Streak Gets An Assist From Jeter
description: More than a year has passed since Roger Clemens was charged with a loss, but he is not kidding himself. Clemens embraces the responsibility inherent in being the ace of a staff, and his legs are not as strong as he wants them to be, he is not pitching as well as he expects, or as long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDEN, REBA
description: SHELDEN-Reba. Of Brooklyn, NY, on May 31. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Devoted mother of Paul and Aaron. Loving motherin-law of Pamela and Diane. Adored and adoring 'Nana Reba' of Seth Victor, Loren Rose Helen, and Victor Benjamin Shelden. The last of her generation of Shapinskys-the late Sarah Rosenthal, Laka Horowitz, David Shapinsky, Fanny Sklar, Ray Rosen, and Azar Shapinsky-she was the cherished aunt to three generations. She respected, and was respected by, everyone who knew her and whose paths she crossed. A ''gu'te neshoma.'' Services Wednesday, June 2nd at 1:15 P.M., Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar fell against the yen and euro, as drops in United States stocks and bonds soured traders on the dollar. In New York, the dollar fell to 120.56 yen, from 121.43 on Friday.

title: Harnischfeger Shares Decline by 62%
description: Shares of Harnischfeger Industries fell 62 percent today after the company, a maker of mining machinery, reported a wider second-quarter loss and said it was short of financing needed for the next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HARRY
description: COHEN-Harry. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations extends its condolences to our esteemed and devoted friend, Roy Cohen, on the passing of his beloved brother. We extend to Roy, Joan and the entire Cohen family our prayers that they will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm I. Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINA, STANDISH FORDE JR.
description: MEDINA-Standish Forde Jr. On May 29, 1999. Dearly beloved husband of Kate and father of Nathaniel, loving son of Stan and Hope, and brother of Meredith and Jeremy; devoted partner of Debevoise & Plimpton. Service to be held at St. James's Espiscopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. (71st), Wednesday, June 2nd at 5PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Forde's memory to The St. Bernard's School and to The Collegiate School in New York City.

title: Intrastate Shipments
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULVER, SAUL
description: PULVER-Saul. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Saul Pulver. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Whose Decision?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Draws Foul, and the Pacers Draw Even
description: It was him again. Out on the perimeter, Indiana's Reggie Miller held the ball cocked on his right hip with Chris Childs within a breath of his wiry frame as the seconds spun to single digits on the game clock and the noise shook the joint.

title: Metro Business; Utility Retains Consultant
description: CTG Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had retained Paine Webber Group Inc. to advise it on strategic alternatives.

title: The Sabres Cross Over The Border to Finals
description: When travelers cross the border between Canada and the United States, the customs and immigration officers usually pose the same set of questions, including: How long have you been in the other country? Did you acquire any goods? Do you have anything to declare?

title: Commencements; Missing Woman's Family Sits In for Her at Baruch
description: Kristine Kupka was to graduate with Baruch College's class of '99 yesterday, but instead, her Bachelor of Arts degree was honorary.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 25 about the restoration of the flag that inspired Francis Scott Key to write ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' misstated the size of the donation toward the project by the Pew Charitable Trusts to the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History. It was $5 million, not $3 million.

title: Eaton to Build in Mexico
description: The Eaton Corporation said today that it would spend more than $100 million to build a truck-transmission plant in Mexico to meet the demand for commercial truck parts. Eaton, based in Cleveland, makes products for the industrial, vehicle, construction, commercial, aerospace and semiconductor markets. The new plant is expected to employ 400 to 500 workers.

title: Russia Says U.N. Inspectors Left Chemicals in Iraq
description: Keeping pressure on an agency that Russia has criticized for months, Moscow's representative here today accused the United Nations Special Commission responsible for disarming Iraq of endangering Iraqis by leaving behind dangerous chemicals in its Baghdad laboratory.

title: F.T.C. Ending Inquiry Into Cisco Systems' Partnership Talks
