description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it was ending its nine-month investigation into partnership discussions that Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of data communications equipment, held in recent years with two rivals, Lucent Technologies Inc. and the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada.

title: Omnicom Units Forge Alliance
description: The Dallas-area offices of two Omnicom Group divisions in New York have created an alliance to offer clients direct branding and marketing services.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Prices of crude oil dropped to an eight-week low after European refineries cut the quantities they process because of narrowing profit margins. In New York, July contracts fell 50 cents, to $16.34 a barrel.

title: Counterfeit Policemen Rob Midtown Store
description: Two men posing as law enforcement officials talked their way into the office of a midtown Manhattan clothing store yesterday, handcuffed some of the employees, pistol-whipped one and made off with a safe containing $5,000, the police said.

title: PILOTS ISSUE THREAT
description: Pilots at Cathay Pacific Airways said they might vote to walk out if the carrier, Hong Kong's only long-haul airline, carries through its threat to dismiss pilots who do not sign a new contract by June 11. The Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association, which represents 1,000 of Cathay's 1,300 pilots, said it would hold a strike ballot if any pilots were dismissed for rejecting the contract, which includes pay cuts for senior employees. Cathay says the pilots will still be among the highest paid in the industry even after the proposed cuts.

title: NATO Presses Attack, and Plans for Peace
description: NATO military planners heard today how many troops and tanks the allies and other countries would provide for the beefed-up, 45,000-strong peacekeeping force planned for Kosovo if diplomacy brings a settlement there. But allied officials said Russia, a key diplomatic player, was keeping its distance.

title: Wiesel, a Man of Peace, Cites Need to Act
description: Elie Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner, began a three-day tour of refugee camps today, at the request of President Clinton.

title: Kurd Rebel's Offer to Honor Turkish State Perplexes All Sides
description: When the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, finished his extraordinary testimony on Monday, the first day of his treason trial, he left many Turks and Kurds dazed and surprised. His abject apology for years of war and avowed determination to reinvent himself as a democrat seemed dubious but also tantalizing.

title: And Lo, Unto Them He Said, 'Hasta la Vista, Baby!'
description: ''Dat's my 'Gone Vit da Vind,' '' the muscle-bound film star with the heavy Germanic accent declares in ''Thy Kingdom's Coming!,'' a shrill poke by the actor-turned-playwright Jeff Daniels at Hollywood's obsession with pecs and violence.

title: How Can We Help Teen-Agers?
description: To the Editor:

title: HICKS RAISES OFFER
description: The Dallas-based investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Ltd. said it would increase its offer for Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C., the maker of Typhoo tea and a variety of other products, to at least $:534 million ($854.4 million), topping an offer of $:530 million from Candover Partners Ltd. Hicks, Muse, which controls 26.9 percent of Hillsdown, will not offer less than 146 pence a share, up from 141 pence. The bid exceeds Candover's earlier offer of 145 pence, which was endorsed by the board on Friday.

title: Data Suggesting Inflation Risk Help to Push Treasuries Lower
description: Bond prices slumped yesterday, pushing yields to their highest in more than a year, after a report pointing to manufacturing strength stoked concerns the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates.

title: New York's Quarterbacks Play Through
description: Danny Kanell, who used to be a Giants quarterback, looked up and smiled as Neil O'Donnell, who used to be a Jets quarterback, passed him today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about support by rival political candidates in Argentina for shoring up the currency misidentified the Argentine stock index. It is the Merval. (Bovespa is the Brazilian index.)

title: My Kind Of Town. Or So I've Heard.
description: My abduction is set for the last week of June, when I will be snatched from the comfort of my home and transported to the local airport. There I will be deposited on a 747 destined for New York City. The kidnappers will be my wife and our 10-year-old son, and I will be seated between them for the duration of the flight.

title: Gasoline Prices Lower
description: The average retail price of gasoline in the United States fell 1.3 percent, to a two-month low of $1.111 a gallon, the last week. The 1.5-cent drop was the second consecutive weekly decline, according to an Energy Department survey of 800 service stations. Gasoline has fallen in four of the last seven surveys since reaching $1.14 a gallon in April, the highest price since December 1997, but prices are still 24 percent higher than they were three months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATLAS, CELIA
description: ATLAS-Celia. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Govenors and Overseers, Faculty, Administration and Students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, records with profound sorrow the passing of Celia Atlas, beloved widow of Professor Samuel Atlas, revered teacher of generations of rabbis. Celia Atlas was an exemplar of grace and elegance and brought deeper meaning to the phase, ''aishet hayil''. We shall not see her kind again. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her beloved family. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Govenors Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Dr. Paul M. Steinberg, Special Asstnt to the President

title: Race Dominating 'Ho Hum' Vote in South Africa
description: Even on the eve of South Africa's second post-apartheid elections, race is still a dominating factor: Thabo Mbeki, who is virtually certain to become this country's next President, put out an open letter, not to all South Africans, but to whites.

title: Cairo Journal; It's Barbie vs. Laila and Sara in Mideast Culture War
description: It's not just that she's a blue-eyed blond. Nor is it just the revealing clothes that show off her famous figure. The real trouble is that Barbie has a boyfriend.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Tapas by Size

title: Business Travel; On-line hotel booking services can usually make it easier to find out what a room really costs.
description: BUSINESS travelers who arrange their own accommodations know that that it's seldom a simple matter to find out how much a hotel room actually costs. A room rate can differ significantly on any given day, depending on such variables as the current occupancy level, discounts invoked, and even the ability or inclination of a customer to haggle.

title: Mysterious on the Outside, Friendly on the Inside
description: IT's easy to walk right by Junno's without noticing it. In the best tradition of using mystery to draw attention, the sign for this six-month-old Japanese-Korean fusion restaurant is hard to spot, and the eye overlooks the sedate windows to focus on the bright lights of a McDonald's nearby. This sense of exclusion, combined with the minimalist lines of the dining room and the wealth of good-looking young people at the bar, is enough to signal an attitude alert.

title: Peace in Kosovo: Uncertain at Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALISE, LUCILLE V.
description: MALISE-Lucille V. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of Jed and Joanne. Loving sister of Martin Shapiro and the late Edythe Blynn and Roslyn Wertheimer. Adored grandmother of Ezra Beaver and Kirsten and Johanna Malise. Services today, 12:30PM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC.

title: AMSOUTH TO BUY FIRST AMERICAN FOR $6.3 BILLION
description: AmSouth Bancorp, Alabama's third-largest bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the First American Corporation, a bank company based in Nashville, for $6.3 billion in stock, doubling its assets. AmSouth said it would exchange 1.871 of its shares for each share of First American, valuing it at $53.09 a share. Shares of AmSouth fell $3.9375 yesterday, or 13.9 percent, to $24.4375. First American rose $2.8125, or 6.9 percent, to $43.625. After the takeover, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, AmSouth, based in Birmingham, will have assets of about $40 billion, 680 branches and the largest network of automated teller machines in the Southeast.

title: NEWELL ELIMINATES 400 POSITIONS AT ITS RUBBERMAID UNIT
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., maker of Berol pens, Levolor blinds and other consumer products, said yesterday that it had cut 400 jobs from its recently acquired Rubbermaid unit. Newell also lowered its second-quarter profit outlook because of promotional costs and a prolonged regulatory review of the purchase of Rubbermaid, the well-known maker of plastic food containers and garbage pails. Shares of Newell Rubbermaid rose $2.50 each, to $43. The Newell Company, based in Freeport, Ill., bought Rubbermaid in March. Newell Rubbermaid said it expected to earn 39 cents to 44 cents a share in the second quarter, excluding charges. Analysts had expected 48 cents.

title: How Can We Help Teen-Agers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Barnes & Noble Prepares Plan B if U.S. Kills Deal
description: With its planned $600 million acquisition of the nation's largest book wholesaler in jeopardy, Barnes & Noble is poised to carry out what its top executive calls ''Plan B.''

title: At the Root of the Weed, a Secret Ingredient
description: ON most farms and suburban lawns, burdock is the enemy, a tenacious, burr-covered weed. But that's only what burdock reveals of itself above ground. Below, as good cooks are coming to realize, is a wonderful root.

title: Peace Above Earth
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Japan, Never on the Pill, Seems Ready to Try It
description: In a major step toward ending Japan's ban on the birth control pill, the nation's top medical advisory council suddenly reversed itself today and recommended allowing the pill to be sold.

title: Judges at The Hague Refuse To Halt the NATO Bombing
description: Judges at the International Court of Justice in The Hague refused today to order NATO countries to halt their bombing of Yugoslavia. The judges also declined to discuss Belgrade's demand to be paid for war damages.

title: A War Out of the Night Sky: 10 Hours With a Battle Team
description: The War Wizard lumbered through the sky over Albania as its battle staff began another long night of directing air strikes against the Serbian military.

title: Pakistan Frees Journalist It Held for Sedition
description: The Pakistani Government dropped sedition charges today against a journalist who has been highly critical of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and it released him after almost a month of detention and interrogation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISBRANDTSEN, WALDEMAR
description: ISBRANDTSEN-Waldemar (Walter). Son of the late Gertrude and Hans Isbrandtsen, died peacefully May 26 in West Babylon, New York. Surviving are his children, Lynne, Dirk, Carl, Jeff & Michelle; sister, Niel Rising; brother, Jakob C. Isbrandtsen; grandchildren, Janace, Josh, Erik, Michael, Kelley, Ashley and Samantha. Funeral private. Memorial contributions may be made to The Long Island Maritime Museum, 86 West Avenue, West Sayville, NY 11796. For more information, contact the White-Voltz Funeral Home, Bay Shore, New York.

title: Book Retailer Ends Bid for Wholesaler
description: Facing a likely challenge from Federal antitrust officials, Barnes & Noble Inc., the nation's largest retailer of books, abandoned its plans today to acquire the Ingram Book Group, the nation's biggest book wholesaler, in a $600 million deal that had provoked widespread complaints from other booksellers, large and small.

title: Texaco Rejects Chevron's Merger Proposal
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected a merger proposal from the Chevron Corporation and ended all takeover talks.

title: A Printer With Pink Accents Lends a Barbie Touch
description: It used to be that little girls would accessorize their Barbie dolls with Barbie clothes, Barbie shoes or, if their parents couldn't say no, Barbie's Dreamhouse. Now 7-year-olds with parents who can't say no will have the chance to accessorize their computers with Barbie peripherals.

title: MCLEODUSA IN ACQUISITIONS TO EXPAND SERVICE IN WEST
description: McLeodUSA Inc., which sells telecommunications services in the Middle West, said it had agreed to buy Access Communications Inc. and SJ Investments Inc. for stock worth worth about $101 million and $50 million in cash. Under terms of the agreement, which was announced late Tuesday, McLeodUSA will also assume about $97 million in Access debt. McLeodUSA, which is based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, will add Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon and Washington to its 16-state region. The company also said the purchase would expand its voice and data-communications market by 23 percent. Access, based in Salt Lake City, serves about 30,000 long-distance telephone customers. McLeodUSA's stock fell 18.75 cents, to $53.125.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Better Redder

title: Two More Favorites Are Left Blowing in the Wind
description: The summer sizzle, the museums and the subway system were all out of commission and on strike in Paris today, and so were the seeded stars who took to the clay for their quarterfinal assignments at the French Open. Gustavo Kuerten and Alex Corretja did a disappearing act that left a bizarre men's semifinal round peopled by three unseeded gate-crashers and one very veteran master of ceremonies in 13th-seeded Andre Agassi.

title: PLUS: OLYMPICS; E.U. Adopts Anti-Doping Policy
description: The sport ministers of the European Union agreed yesterday in Paderborn, Germany, on a strict anti-doping policy that calls for an unconditional suspension of at least two years for athletes who test positive for drugs. The results of this two-day informal meeting, the second in the last five months, are intended to put pressure on the International Olympic Committee and world sports federations to increase vigilance in monitoring and disciplining athletes who ''dope'' themselves before competition. ALAN MAIMON

title: The Boom in Medications Brings Rise in Fatal Risks
description: Helen McLaughlin was 73 years old when, relatives say, a mix-up in prescription drugs took her life. In death, she became a statistic that is causing increasing anxiety among health care experts and Federal regulators: the tens of thousands of Americans who are killed each year not by illness, but by medication intended to treat it.

title: Still Hoping for Dad's Love, Even if You Strike Out
description: BATTLE CREEK

title: Shouting 'Iceberg!' in Hospitals' Rough Seas
description: AS a Chicago-bred Roman Catholic, Kenneth E. Raske would not seem to favor the interjection ''oy.''

title: Metro Business; Prison Operator Expands
description: The Cornell Companies Inc., which operates prisons in 12 states, said yesterday that it planned to buy two nonprofit treatment companies with sites in New Jersey and Delaware.

title: A Modern Master's Spirit Soars Anew
description: NOT long after Eliel Saarinen's brand of kiln-fired, loom-woven, handcrafted modernism was elbowed aside by the harder-edged International style, development all but stopped on his architectural masterwork: the ensemble of museums, schools and design academy now known as the Cranbrook Educational Community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROBIN S.
description: WEINSTEIN-Robin S. A dear and cherished friend, our hero. The Robins

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is pushing supermarkets to sell a new brand of bottled water, with a twist.
description: IT is a seemingly incongruous image: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. -- crusading environmental lawyer, member of the famous Kennedy dynasty and potential political candidate -- in a meeting with local supermarket executives to persuade them to distribute a new product.

title: Spilling Our Nuclear Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS TO RAISE INTERNET TELEPHONE ROLE
description: Texas Instruments said yesterday that it would acquire Telogy Networks Inc., a provider of communications software, for $435 million in stock to strengthen its position in the Internet telephone market. Texas Instruments said the combination would advance its ability to make products that send voice and data simultaneously over a single line, resulting in improved phone service. Telogy Networks is a closely held company based in Germantown, Md. The stock of Texas Instruments, which is based in Dallas, rose $4.3125, to $110.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLMAN, BERNARD
description: KELLMAN - Bernard. Beloved husband of the late Lillian Lembeck Kellman. Cherished father, father-in-law, and grandfather of Harvey, Sharon, Meredith, Jennifer, and Faith. Love is never lost. Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York, Thursday, June 3, 1999, 11 AM. Donations to Hadassah in lieu of flowers.

title: Fight for Japan Phone Carrier Becomes Test on Open Markets
description: One of the largest shareholders in International Digital Communications, the target of a takeover fight between the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and Cable and Wireless P.L.C., of Britain said today that price would not be the sole determinant of its allegiance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDICH, ANNA
description: BENDICH-Anna. We mourn the passing of our cherished greataunt whose loving devotion, caring, intelligence and integrity will be forever missed. Our hearts are with great-uncle Hy, Al, Pam and family. Adrianne, David and Family

title: How We Can Save Teaching Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Turn Up the Volume for E-Mail
description: THE best thing about E-mail: it's not a phone call. No jarring rings jolting you out of a nap, no on-the-spot replies required, and if you're not interested, the Delete button is just a few inches away.

title: Clipping Together A Zeppelin
description: There's a persistent mystery to the way flat patterns fold up into full ones. That, along with economy of design, lends fascination to a new family of hanging lamps from Artecnica, designers and manufacturers in Culver City, Calif. These spherical and zeppelin lamps, which sell for $30 to $45, take shape from polycarbonate panels that assemble quickly with clips. Like certain high-tech buildings, they make a fetish of the cleverness with which their parts join. The result has the quality of a puzzle. Information: (310) 559-3555.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, PENELOPE
description: SCHINDLER - Penelope. Of Quogue and New York City, on June 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Paul, devoted mother of Alexandra, adored daughter of Evangeline and the late Charles Pericone, dear sister of Christine Weingart. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, NY. Graveside services 11 A.M. Saturday at the Quogue Cemetery, Lamb Avenue, Quogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to either of the following: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Strokes, Building 31, Room 8A06, 31 Center Drive, Bethesda, MD 20892-2540, Attn: Gerald Fischbach, Director, ''In Memory of Penny Schindler'' (for Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Research) or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978, ''In Memory of Penny Schindler.''

title: CBS TO BUY STAKE IN SWITCHBOARD, AN INTERNET DIRECTORY
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 35 percent equity stake in Internet-directory concern Switchboard Inc. from Banyan Systems Inc. in exchange for $135 million in promotion and advertising. Switchboard, which is based in Westboro, Mass., runs Switchboard.com, which provides phone listings, electronic-mail addresses and postal addresses. Switchboard will rename its Web site CBS Switchboard. Banyan, based in Westborough, Mass., has been under pressure from investors to sell Switchboard.com, its most valuable asset, in an initial public offering.

title: Sitting Pretty
description: Candy is dandy, but George Nelson's 1956 Marshmallow sofa is a kind of sweet revenge on those who thought mid-century modern furniture would never become a serious collecting market. An example in orange vinyl is coming up for sale on Monday at William Doyle Galleries, at an estimated $18,000 to $20,000. For those who are just soft on the way it seats, Herman Miller, the company that originally manufactured the 18-pad icon, is putting it back in production, available in September by order, for a suggested $3,750 (ABC Carpet and Home, 888 Broadway, at 19th Street).

title: Privacy? In a Loft? Wide Open Spaces Face Subdivision
description: THE loft, it has been changing.

title: KOREAN CEMENT BATTLE
description: The world's secondlargest cement maker, Lafarge S.A. of France, is competing with Blue Circle Industries P.L.C. of Britain to buy the Halla Cement Manufacturing Corporation of Korea for at least $345 million, according to executives at the companies. Lafarge and Blue Circle have already examined Halla's finances in advance of a possible purchase, said Kim Kyung Yong, a spokesman for Halla Group, which became insolvent in late 1997.

title: Clinton Warns Serbs To Cut Their Losses
description: President Clinton urged the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, to ''cut his losses'' by bending to allied demands for ending the NATO attacks on his country. The alternative, Mr. Clinton said in an address to graduating Air Force academy cadets in Colorado, is the military and economic devastation of Serbia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the opinions of Presidential candidates on whether the next President of the United States should get a pay increase misstated the attitude of Elizabeth Dole. Rather than being one of five Republican candidates declining to comment on the President's salary, Mrs. Dole told Speaker J. Dennis Hastert in a letter last week that Congress should reject a proposal to raise it to $400,000. She said the current figure of $200,000 was ''fair and appropriate,'' considering the many perquisites of the office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, DAVID I.K.
description: HECHT-David I.K. On May 30, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Anne. Loving father of David. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: MOSCOW AND WEST MAKING HEADWAY ON A KOSOVO PLAN
description: Russia and the West narrowed their differences today over the measures required to end the war in Kosovo, limiting the room for President Slobodan Milosevic to maneuver and increasing the pressure on him to reach a settlement.

title: Chief of Panel Seeks Increase For Medicare
description: The head of a Federal advisory commission, an influential Republican, said today that Congress should increase Medicare payments for certain nursing home and hospital services because budget cuts appeared to be harming the quality of care for some patients.

title: They're Unmanned, They Fly Low, and They Get the Picture
description: As the NATO air campaign grows into nearly nonstop bombing, the light unmanned aerial vehicles known as drones are crisscrossing the skies over Kosovo, acting as electronic scouts, finding and filming elusive targets, especially Serbian troops hidden in bunkers or woods, and sending those images immediately to fighter jets overhead.

title: It's Not G.I. Joe's Biceps That Should Worry Us; What Madison Meant
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilgrim Baxter Removes Manager of Funds
description: Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Ltd., a money-management firm with $11 billion of assets, has removed James McCall as manager of four mutual funds after contesting his right to take a job at Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Books on Tape, Minus the Tape
description: More than 20 years ago Stevie Wonder produced a hit album called ''Talking Book.'' It hardly talked, but it did keep a mean beat. Now, Audible Inc., an on-line distributor of audio content in Wayne, N.J., has turned the tables by producing a portable audio player that doesn't keep a beat so well but is, for all practical purposes, a talking book.

title: Rebel Kurds Back Leader In Peace Offer To the Turks
description: Two days after the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan said he wanted to end his 15-year war against the Turkish Army, his guerrilla group announced today that it supports his call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEVY, RUTH
description: KEVY-Ruth. Of Fort Lee. Beloved wife of Jack, devoted mother of Audrey Wilner and Larry Kevy, mother-in-law of Alfred Wilner and the late Marlene Kevy, dear sister of Lillian Schaffel, Saul Rosenblatt, Phyllis Kirschner and Lenore Perry, loving grandmother of Michael, Jayne, Stewart and Matthew and great-grandmother of Maddie and Katy. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack on Thursday at 10 AM. 800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ALTON E.
description: PETERS-Alton E. Beloved husband of Elizabeth, father of Emily and Rachel and grandfather of Madeleine and Isobel Fletcher. The funeral service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, at 11AM on Thursday, June 3. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Metropolitan Opera Guild or the Phillips Exeter Academy Library.

title: Philippine Family Planners Stymied by Powerful Opposition
description: MANILA  MANILA

title: City Ballet Turns to American Composers and Finds Itself in a Playful Mood
description: First came Stravinsky, then Tchaikovsky, and now it's on to American music for the New York City Ballet in this 50th-anniversary celebration season. The company opened a three-week mini-festival devoted to American composers on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with four ballets that were playful and even a little nutty, danced to music performed with an extra verve.

title: Are They for Real?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton Deplores the Condition of New York Public Schools
description: Signaling a likely theme for her potential Senate campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday deplored the condition of New York City's public schools, asserting that they had been undermined by political infighting and underfinancing by City Hall.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a fire in Florida misstated the location. It was near Venice, in west-central Florida on the Gulf of Mexico, not in the Okefenokee Swamp, which is partly in northern Florida.

title: PPG BUYS SEALANT UNIT OF AKZO NOBEL FOR $513 MILLION
description: PPG Industries, which makes glass and chemicals, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an aircraft-paint and sealants unit of the Dutch chemical maker Akzo Nobel N.V. for $512.5 million in cash. The Akzo unit, PRC-DeSoto International Inc., makes sealants that are used on airplane fuel tanks, glass and undersea cable. It has annual sales of about $240 million. PPG, based in Pittsburgh, also makes glass and chemicals and had sales last year of $7.51 billion. PPG's shares fell 75 cents, to $62.6875, and the American depository receipts of Akzo rose $1.0625, to $42.5625.

title: It's Not G.I. Joe's Biceps That Should Worry Us
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN STEEL TALKS
description: Shares in British Steel jumped by more than 20 percent after a Dutch steel concern said the two were in merger talks. Royal Hoogovens N.V., Europe's eighth-biggest steelmaker, said the merger talks would be ''accompanied by a return of value'' to British Steel's shareholders, and promised further details by next Monday. Shares in British Steel, Europe's fourth-biggest steelmaker, gained 28 pence, to 161.75, pence in London. Alan Cowell

title: POLISH CABLE ACQUISITION
description: United Pan-Europe Communications N.V., Europe's No. 2 cable company, agreed to buy At Entertainment Inc., owner of Poland's largest cable television network, for $1.15 billion, which includes $400 million in assumed debt, extending its push into the Eastern European pay-TV market. United Pan-Europe Communications, of which the Microsoft Corporation owns about 8 percent, will pay $19 for each At Entertainment share. The shares of At Entertainment, based in Hartford, rose $5.5625 each, to $18.0625.

title: E-Mail on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Spilling Our Nuclear Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, AUGUSTA
description: GOETZ-Augusta. The entire Long Island College Hospital family mourns the passing of Augusta Goetz, beloved mother of our esteemed friend and highly respected colleague, Diane Person, Ph.D., a member of the Board of Regents for many years. To Diane and her family, and to all of Ms. Goetz's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John D. Wren, Chairman Board of Regents Peter A. Kelly, Interim President Sandra Phillips, Ph.D. Chief Operating Officer Daniel D. Ricciardi, President Medical Staff

title: Ex-Yale Head Being Courted To Run CUNY
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the former Yale University president, would be a good candidate to become the next chancellor of the City University of New York, but people close to Mr. Schmidt said that he would not take the job.

title: Behind Happy Interface, More Complex Reality
description: NOT long ago on a visit to Disney World, Neal Stephenson saw something that struck him as unusual even by the standards of the Magic Kingdom.

title: Those Deep Wall Streeters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. The Boys Town Jerusalem family mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a cherished member of its International Board of Directors. Mr. Recanati, together with his wife Dina, were Chair Founders and established the Recanati Scholarship Fund at Boys Town as a major perpetual endowment. Mr. Recanati's philanthropic benevolence has benefited disadvantaged Israeli youth at Boys Town for four decades, providing them with an outstanding academic, technological and religious education. His tzedakah helps Boys Town fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. The individual and collective achievements of Boys Town's students will endure as a lasting tribute to his memory. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Recanati family and pray that they will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec VP

title: In Spanish and Portuguese, Web Growth Spurt
description: IN January, Anna Spinello, a clothing designer in Buenos Aires, set up a Web site to help boost sales of her spring line. By clicking on a little flag, a viewer can see the site in English, Spanish or Portuguese.

title: Catamaran Explorer Sets a New Pace
description: Explorer, the 86-foot catamaran that sailed around the world in 1993 in a record 79 days, has established a new time to beat from Miami to New York. The co-skippers Bruno Peyron of France and Cam Lewis of Lincolnville, Me., arrived at Ambrose Light, a buoy off Sandy Hook, N.J., yesterday afternoon in completing a 1,076-nautical-mile trip from Miami in 2 days 22 hours 50 minutes. The boat's average speed was 15.2 knots. The voyage marks a new pace for the East Coast route, which has no official sailboat record for the trip.

title: Tracking the Very Model of an Expanding Universe
description: The on-line universe is expanding but, as a new Web site from NASA makes clear, it's not expanding as fast as the real universe. Hubbleconstant.com is a compendium of astronomy news and historical insights into the age and size of the universe (www.hubbleconstant.com). Named for the Hubble constant, the formula used to determine the velocity distant objects appear to be receding from our galaxy, the site also features pictures from the Hubble telescope and information about the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

title: Ten Essentials: Sleek, Spare, Easy
description: David Metzger, a Brooklyn cabinetmaker, kept running into clients who asked him for furniture that was at once minimal and generous in function. His response was Ten Essentials, a collection of pieces whose prototypes were displayed at the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair here. Most of that function is containing things. Mr. Metzger even managed to fit six storage drawers in a bed (above, $2,450.) His most striking piece, a dresser with a ziggurat front (left, $1,500), suggests Mayan Art Deco or Heywood-Wakefield mass-market modern, but the tilting drawer fronts are functional, too: they were the only way Mr. Metzger could provide grips.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THURNAUER, MARIA
description: THURNAUER-Maria. There will be a memorial service on Monday, June 14, at 4 PM, at Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Rd, Teaneck, N.J. for Mrs. Thurnauer, who died May 27 at the age of 87. Donations may be sent to Jewish Community Center on the Palisades, 411 E. Clinton Ave, Tenafly N.J. 07670

title: Fighters Search For Redemption
description: There is not a catchy name for the heavyweight bout between Shannon Briggs and Francois Botha. But the promoter Frank Warren came up with an apt description of the bout. ''It's two guys who nearly did it in their last fights,'' Warren said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Federal Jury Deadlocked In Genentech Patent Case

title: Ultimate Specialist: The Long Snapper
description: Bill Parcells does not have too many obsessions once you get past the first 50 or so.

title: Sweet Nothing
description: How you been?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, BERDIE
description: BERGER-Berdie, passed away peacefully at the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late Hilliard, loving mother and mother-in-law of Sheldon & Elaine, Bob & Andrea. Devoted sister of Anita and Belle, sister-in-law of Charles & Gilbert, much loved by her grandchildren, nieces and nephews, family and friends. Funeral service Thursday, June 3, 12PM at Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, New York.

title: In the Sky With Diamonds
description: New York's diamond district, 47th Street from Fifth to Sixth Avenues, has long been hiding in plain sight, an entire block devoted to one trade but without a unifying visual marker. Now, however, the district is distinguished with the installation of diamond-shaped lights at both ends of the block. Howard Abel of Abel Bainnson Butz, the Manhattan architectural firm that designed the lights, said that the fixtures were made of two sheets of translucent acrylic, into which more than 5,000 glass marbles were placed ''so that the lights really sparkle like diamonds.'' The cost, about $250,000 for four, was paid by the city. Eli Haas, president of the 1,800-member Diamond Dealers Club, says every merchant he has spoken with is pleased about the instant landmarks. Meanwhile, less fanciful high-intensity lights have been installed along the entire block. ''It's lighted up like Times Square,'' Mr. Haas said.

title: The Inaugural Meet Is Facing Adversity
description: The Track and Field Association, a new for-profit organization, is staging its first meet Sunday on Long Island with some of the world's leading athletes. The path has not been smooth.

title: Awaiting Albany; BUDGET '99: 64 DELINQUENT DAYS
description: The Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, met yesterday with Gov. George E. Pataki and Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader, but no progress on the budget was reported.

title: Hotel Group Agrees to Modify Directory
description: The Leading Hotels of the World, a reservations and marketing alliance of 315 luxury hotels in 70 countries, said yesterday that in response to recent complaints from the American Jewish Congress it would no longer publish a separate Middle East edition of its directory.

title: 'DEPRAVED' NIGHT DETAILED AT CLOSE OF LOUIMA TRIAL
description: On the first day of closing arguments in an explosive case of police brutality in New York City, a Federal prosecutor declared yesterday that four police officers had brutalized Abner Louima in a night of violence and terror that ended in a vicious assault by two of them in a police station restroom.

title: 'Going Out Shopping' Takes On a New Meaning
description: Tired of trudging around the Web trying to find the best price on something? Power shopping just got easier, and you don't even have to be in front of your computer anymore. If you have a Palm VII, you might just be able to save money and mouse clicks from wherever you are with Pocket Shopper, the new My Simon application for 3Com's latest edition of its popular personal digital assistant. My Simon is an E-commerce hub that specializes in on-line comparison shopping with a constantly updated database of 10 million products from 1,300 merchants. The Pocket Shopper program can be downloaded from www.mysimon.com or www.palm.net.

title: U.N. Finds Proof of 'Ethnic Cleansing' in Kosovo
description: The leader of a United Nations mission to Kosovo has found what he called ''indisputable evidence'' of Serbian ''ethnic cleansing'' of Kosovars, as well as ''ample evidence'' of ''serious'' damage caused by NATO's air strikes.

title: Gateses Give Record $5 Billion Gift to Foundation
description: In what is considered the largest gift ever by a living person to a foundation, the chairman of Microsoft, William H. Gates, and his wife, Melinda French Gates, today announced a gift of $5 billion to the William H. Gates Foundation.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUTNER, MILTON S.
description: MAUTNER-Milton S. Age 85, on May 29, 1999. Loving and dearly loved husband for 30 years of Peggy (Margaret Park) Mautner. Widely read, musically engaged, he was a man of fine intellect, wit, talent, goodness and dignity. He was for many years a writer and editor and was a veteran of World War II. In addition to his wife he is survived by an aunt Abeline and two nieces, Jean Ann Fineberg and Ellen Joan Fineberg. Irreplaceable and already missed. For further information please call Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: Sports of The Times; The Horse Lives Up to His Name
description: HE favors his great-grandfather. It is amazing how the genes come through.

title: Reveling in Rhythm Without Succumbing
description: Just as some experimentalist composers have deemed the 12-pitch scale to be a limiting Eurocentric construction, so the first free-jazz drummers in the early 1960's understood rhythmic patterns in semipolitical terms. The sustained rhythmic pattern, with its familiar entrances and exits, its decorum and history, was seen as a sort of cruel imposition on individual will. A more natural way to make music, the logic held, was to mimic the heartbeat and the nervous system, which can speed up and slow down, screech with alarm and hum contentedly, according to the feeling of the moment.

title: Police Kill Unarmed Driver After Interstate 80 Chase
description: An unarmed driver was shot and killed in a burst of 27 police bullets on Interstate 80 early today, after leading officers on a 15-mile chase and then ramming two patrol cars that had pinned his car against an embankment, the authorities said.

title: Woman and Boy Die in East Orange Fire
description: A woman and a 4-year-old boy trapped in a top-floor apartment in a burning building in East Orange, N.J., died yesterday minutes after being rescued, officials said.

title: People
description: * Tom Jones, associate publisher at Computer Shopper magazine, New York, published by the Z-D Publishing unit of Ziff-Davis, was promoted to publisher, succeeding Al DiGuido, who becomes executive vice president at Z-D Publishing.

title: Actors With Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: How We Can Save Teaching Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, RUTH
description: HABER-Ruth. Wife of the late David Haber, passed away on June 2nd, 1999. Loving mother of Carol and Paul, Roy and Marilyn, and adoring grandmother of Larry and Cybille, Clifford and Jeannie, Tina and Jeffrey, and Ashley and Shoshanna. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: A Fierce Bidding War for a Five-Star Refuge in Bangkok
description: Have a drink in the tranquil lobby of the Regent Hotel here, beneath palm fronds and the hand-painted silk ceiling, and you would scarcely guess that this five-star refuge is the object of one of the most lively and improbable bidding wars in Asia.

title: How We Can Save Teaching Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Final Arguments in Officers' Trial in Louima Case
description: Following are excerpts from the closing arguments yesterday in the Abner Louima police brutality trial:

title: Kashmir, The Imperiled Paradise
description: For more than 50 years, India and Pakistan have been arguing and periodically coming to blows over one of the most beautiful places in the world, Kashmir, which the Mughal emperors thought of as Paradise on earth. As a result of this unending quarrel, Paradise has been partitioned, impoverished and made violent. Murder and terrorism now stalk the valleys and mountains of a land once so famous for its peacefulness that outsiders made jokes about the Kashmiris' supposed lack of fighting spirit.

title: INSIDE
description: Japan Moves Toward the Pill

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAX, LILLIAN
description: MAX-Lillian. On June 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Devoted mother of Leslie (Bonnie) & the late Linda (John). The caring sister of George, Sidney & Miriam. Revered Nanny of Jennifer, Daniel, Benjamin, Leanna and Peter, and great-grandmother of Lindsay, Jacey and Ethan. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, on Thursday at 9:30AM. 1-800-322-0533.

title: LEWIS-HOLYFIELD TALK PREMATURE
description: Milton Chwasky, a New York lawyer who represents Lennox Lewis, said an announcement by Don King last week that a rematch between Lewis and Evander Holyfield was arranged and would be held at Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas, Nev., in November was premature.

title: E-Mail on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Documents Show Gift-Giving to I.O.C Before Atlanta Won '96 Games
description: The chairman of the House Commerce Committee that is investigating Atlanta's bid for the 1996 Summer Olympics said ''a number of concerns'' were raised yesterday when bidders released documents showing that lavish gifts, favors and payments were made while attempting to secure the Games.

title: Franco Finds the Latest Way to Lose
description: John Franco knew he was not going to go the whole season without blowing a save. It was the timing of his first one last night that shook both him and the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BEATRIZ BERMEJILLO
description: MOORE-Beatriz Bermejillo. On May 25, in Mexico City, at age 83. Beloved mother of George Moore, New Canaan, CT, and grandmother of George and Tanya.

title: For Israel, Lebanese Ally's Withdrawal Is Test for Peace
description: If all goes as planned, members of the Israeli-backed militia that has long occupied this pretty mountaintop town will head south in the next few days, completing their withdrawal from an enclave that has served for 14 years, in proxy, as Israel's deepest penetration into Lebanon.

title: As the Euro Falls, Some in Europe Fault German Growth and Leadership
description: During his campaign a year or so ago to reassure anxious Germans about adopting a new European currency, then-Chancellor Helmut Kohl insisted at almost every opportunity that the euro would be ''as strong as the Deutsche mark.''

title: Booting Up In 'Safe Mode'
description: Q. What's so safe about Safe Mode in Windows? What exactly does it do when you restart in Safe Mode?

title: Does Baby Want a Browser?
description: AFTER his first grueling day as a software tester, Matthew Moore went home, had a snack and an early bath, and was asleep by 7:30, snuggled under his little quilted green blanket. At the time, Matthew was 1 year old.

title: Chinese Layoffs Putting Millions on the Streets
description: HONG KONG  Once a workers' paradise, China is fast becoming a land of lost jobs.

title: Essay; T-Day Plus 10 Years
description: ''The press in China was freer then,'' recalls Wei Jingsheng, the dissident forced into exile in the U.S., of the day exactly a decade ago when Beijing's rulers massacred Chinese students and workers demonstrating for democracy.

title: Party Paper in China Makes Rare Mention of '89 Protests
description: The Communist Party's flagship newspaper made a rare reference today to the 1989 democracy movement in Tiananmen Square, calling the violent crushing of those demonstrations essential to the protection of national stability and economic progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMSIG, JACK
description: EMSIG-Jack. Age 85, in Florida. One of the founders of Emsig Manufacturing Corporation. We will miss him. From the Officers and staff of Emsig Manufacturing.

title: FRIEDE GOLDMAN TO ACQUIRE OFFSHORE OIL SERVICES RIVAL
description: Friede Goldman International Inc., which builds and services offshore drilling rigs, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, Halter Marine Group Inc., for $218 million in stock. Halter Marine, based in Gulfport, Miss., builds and repairs offshore rigs. The new company, to be called Friede Goldman Halter Inc., will have annual revenue of about $1.5 billion. Each Halter Marine share will be exchanged for 0.4614 shares of Friede Goldman. The deal valued Halter Marine's shares at $7.56 each. Friede Goldman will also assume $240 million in debt. The stock of Halter Marine fell 39.0625 cents, to $6.921875. Shares of Friede Goldman, based in Jackson, Miss., rose 56.25 cents, to $16.9375.

title: Genentech Trial on Patent Ends With Jury Deadlocked
description: A Federal jury deadlocked today in a lawsuit contending that Genentech Inc. had infringed a University of California patent in developing its first big product, human growth hormone.

title: Charles Pierce, 72, Impersonator of Screen Divas
description: Charles Pierce, a female impersonator who found fame in his witty satirical sendups of stage and screen icons, died on Monday at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 72.

title: Accounts
description: * D&E Communications, Ehprata, Pa., to White, Good & Co., Lebanon, Pa., to handle the account of the voice and data communications company, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Under Criticism, Bank of Scotland Reassesses Robertson Deal
description: After squirming under public criticism of a banking venture with Pat Robertson, the conservative American television evangelist, the Bank of Scotland said today that it was reviewing its relationship with him.

title: These Shades Are More Than Just a Fashion Statement
description: Now you see it, now no one else does.

title: The Code of Silence
description: Narrowly speaking, Alan Vinegrad's job yesterday was simply to convince a jury of the guilt of four New York police officers.

title: Car Showrooms Give Way to Cultural Showcases
description: The mantra of the American West may once have been, Expand: luxuriate in wide open spaces far from the city cacophony. But at century's end cities are calling pioneers to come and commune to an urban beat, whether it is in Philadelphia, Anchorage or Gillette, Wyo.

title: Harassed in Class
description: To the Editor:

title: For Uproar Ltd., On-Line Games Are More Than Just Trivial Matter
description: BUDAPEST  The setting is not the business headquarters one might imagine for a company that one analyst calls the No. 1 Internet trivia game site.

title: Pacers' Criticism Shifts To Praise
description: In 1994, his Game 7 tip-in against Indiana sent the Knicks to the finals. A year later, his finger roll off the back iron allowed the Pacers to advance.

title: Spilling Our Nuclear Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Artists Sells Its Concert Business
description: Community Concerts, which presents about 1,800 concerts a year to pre-organized audiences around the country, has been sold by Columbia Artists Management Inc., to another agency, Trawick Artists, for an undisclosed sum.

title: GEON TO BUY O'SULLIVAN AND EXPAND VINYL PRODUCTS LINE
description: The Geon Company, a plastics maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the O'Sullivan Corporation, a maker of vinyl products, for $191 million. The deal calls for Geon to pay O'Sullivan shareholders $12.25 a share in cash. O'Sullivan makes and sells vinyl covers for automotive, medical and office-supply products. The company, based in Winchester, Va., has plants in four states and had 1998 sales of $163 million. O'Sullivan's stock was up $2.8125 a share, or 30 percent, to $12.1875. Shares of Geon, based in Avon Lake, Ohio, rose $2.375, to $34.0625.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONOWITZ, GEORGE
description: ARONOWITZ-George. Boast thee Death, thou hast amongst thee a lad unparalleled. We miss you so much. Love, Lydia, Steve, Julie, Merrill, Andy

title: A Boom Built on Big Wheels; Sales of Light Trucks Drive the Auto Industry's Expansion
description: Craig J. Thomas stands near the end of DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s assembly line in Fenton, Mo., and waits for a spindly orange robot to lower a pickup bed to meet the rest of a Dodge Ram truck. Then, 37 times an hour, 300 times a day, he bolts the bed to the truck and waits for the next pickup to reach him.

title: Sports of The Times; For Ewing, Much Agony, No Ecstasy
description: PATRICK EWING missed another critical shot Tuesday night, but this time you felt there would be redemption. The Knicks' younger, faster legs seemed to have the Eastern Conference finals in control: they stole the opener in Indiana and Games 3 and 4 were at home. You knew the Big Fella would have one more chance. But there will be no redemption. Not this season. Dr. Norman Scott, the team physician, says the partial tear of Ewing's left Achilles' tendon will mend without surgery; Coach Jeff Van Gundy, who rode his warrior center hard, like a workhorse, referred to Ewing's being in uniform for ''a few'' more seasons.

title: APL Helsinki Gets Finlandia Account
description: Primalco Ltd. in Helsinki, Finland, which makes Finlandia vodka, said yesterday that it had awarded the brand's worldwide account outside the United States to APL Helsinki, part of the Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings on the account, which had been handled by DDB Helsinki, were estimated at $30 million.

title: Milosevic Gets Draft
description: Russian and NATO envoys delivered an incomplete draft of a peace settlement to President Slobodan Milosevic today, and after a two-hour meeting, Mr. Milosevic said he and his Government would study the proposals overnight and meet the envoys again at 9 A.M. Thursday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SOARS. Sugar prices rose to a two-month high as Russian importers accelerated purchases to avoid a tariff increase on Aug. 1. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.25 cent a pound, or 4.8 percent, to 5.49 cents.

title: Microsoft Attempts to Show It Had 'Scary' Competition
description: The Microsoft Corporation once again tried to show in court today that the company was facing potentially lethal competition, even presenting as evidence an E-mail message from one of its employees who called the competitive situation ''a very scary thing.''

title: Is MOMA's Garage Sale a Breach of Trust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harris Is Selling Most of Chip Business
description: The Harris Corporation, the electronics and office-equipment company, agreed today to sell most of its semiconductor business to an investment firm for $700 million as it focuses on its communications-equipment business.

title: 'For Sale' in the Garden of Good and Evil
description: Dr. Dorothy Williams Kingery, owner of the most famous -- some say infamous -- house in Savannah, walked down her front steps and past a family of tourists who were clutching guidebooks and wearing cameras like bandoliers. ''Excuse me, ma'am,'' the man said, stepping forward and making an almost imperceptible bow, ''but could we get a tour?''

title: Ewing Out and Knicks Lose a Center of Gravity
description: After months of hearing he was a barrier to the Knicks' grand ambition, Patrick Ewing painfully stepped off the court yesterday. He left an opening for his younger, quicker teammates to run the floor without waiting for a limping 7-footer to catch up.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Can Clapton Play On Your Album?

title: Stop Bombing, China and Russia Insist
description: China and Russia repeated their demand today that NATO air strikes be halted before political talks to resolve the crisis in Yugoslavia begin.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; MCI Statement About Skytel Is Questioned
description: When is the truth not the whole truth? That is the question reverberating through the offices of MCI Worldcom.

title: Moscow Set To Back UN Resolution On Kosovo
description: PARIS  NATO leaders believe that Moscow is now ready to back a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for an imposed Kosovo settlement if Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader, refuses to accept the peace plan that was being pressed on him Wednesday by emissaries of Russia and the European Union, according to officials in Washington, in European capitals and at alliance headquarters in Brussels.

title: Substance, Not Looks
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank Says Poverty Is Increasing
description: The number of people living on less than $1 a day appears to be rising and will reach 1.5 billion by year-end as a result of the economic crisis in Asia and its aftermath, the World Bank said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, MADELEINE P.
description: MICHAEL-Madeleine P. On May 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Marvin. Loving mother of Marguerite Michael Beaser & Marianne Culich. Adoring grandmother of Michael, Andrew and Daniel Beaser and Caroline and Jonathan Culich. Dear sister of Robert Podell and Carol Vinson. Private services and interment have taken place.

title: Elderly Vote for Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: After Years Adrift, Treatment in Jail; Advocates Seek Another Chance for a Schizophrenic Inmate
description: As a child growing up in foster care in Atlantic City, Nathaniel Preston was always in special education classes and at 10 was treated in a New Jersey psychiatric hospital. As a teen-ager, he slit his wrists and was hospitalized again.

title: Many Hold Second Post-Apartheid Vote as Dear as First
description: Wrapped in blankets against the cold, South Africans began lining up today even before the sun came up, many of them giddy with the excitement of voting for only the second time in their lives.

title: Hsing-Hsing the Panda Is Severely Ill
description: He looked as cute as ever today, perched against the back wall of his feeding room at the National Zoo, munching on bamboo shoots.

title: Spotlight On an Outpost Of Black Talent; A New Jersey Theater Steps Onto the Big Stage
description: For Ricardo Khan, the road to a Tony Award began with a matinee performance of ''Hello, Dolly!'' in 1967. Mr. Khan, then a gawky 16-year-old theater buff, still remembers the awe he felt as the curtain went up in the St. James Theater to reveal Cab Calloway and Pearl Bailey in roles that had been radically recast by the producer, David Merrick.

title: INVESTMENT IN PERUVIAN AIRLINE
description: The future of Aeroperu, Peru's troubled flagship carrier, improved after Continental Airlines acquired a 49 percent share, following negotiations with the Peruvian Government and the airline's creditors. Burdened with $174 million in debt, Aeroperu had suspended all flights in March, leaving the tourism-dependent South American nation with just one domestic carrier. Delta Air Lines and Aeromexico had each held 35 percent shares in the carrier but relinquished their stakes early this year. Larry Rohter

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Census Ruling Is Said to Cost $1.7 Billion
description: The Clinton Administration has asked Congress for an additional $1.7 billion that it said would be needed to conduct the 2000 census as a result of a Supreme Court decision sharply restricting the Census Bureau's ability to use statistical sampling.

title: How to Make Life Harder For a Foundering Declarer
description: Exactly 60 years ago the first Goldman Pair Championship was won by the legendary Oswald Jacoby and has been played ever since at the annual Eastern Regional Championships. The latest names on a distinguished roster of winners are Sam Lev of Forest Hills, Queens, and Albert Rahmey of Brooklyn. Playing Saturday and Sunday at the New York Marriott Financial Center Hotel in lower Manhattan, they outdistanced a strong field to take the title. The runners-up were Glenn Milgrim and Jared Lilienstein.

title: New York's Top Judge Urges Fee Rise for Volunteer Lawyers
description: The top judge of the state's highest court yesterday recommended raising the fees paid to private lawyers assigned to defend clients too poor to hire their own lawyers.

title: Through a Glass, Tourists
description: The Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., has been a quirky gem since it opened in 1951. Back then, a towering 200-inch glass disk cast in 1934 for the Hale telescope at Palomar Mountain near San Diego was the collection's jewel. Now, after a $62 million expansion, the hope is that a new orientation and exhibition center, designed by the New York architects Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson, will become even more of a magnetic draw. With an entrance of layered sheets of glass standing on edge, left, and a theater with glass walls, the 117,400-square-foot center makes glass innovations as integral to the architecture as it is to the museum, which opens June 19.

title: The Only Relief Is Comic as Indians Outlast Yanks
description: One pitcher was afraid to hit anybody, the other pitcher seemed scared to throw the ball over the plate, and the plate umpire was philosophically opposed to calling strikes. What resulted at Yankee Stadium last night merits a place in posterity only because it serves as a stiff reminder that truly bad baseball is possible at all levels.

title: In America; A Historian's View
description: ''There was just chaos at Parkland Hospital,'' said the historian William Manchester. ''A member of the Kennedy team called Vernon Oneal and asked him for a coffin. And he said, 'Well, I have coffins in many different ranges.' And he was told, 'Well, send your best one.' ''

title: Celestial Touches Bring Sweet Dreams To Earthly Children
description: WHO'S afraid of the dark? A bounty of light-hearted, inexpensive accessories for children's rooms has just landed, and among the cloud and moon shapes are brand new glow-in-the-dark sheets and carpeting. They'll surely lead to sweet dreams for the little ones, as long as you don't read them ''The Shining'' before tucking them in.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When we came to a stop I looked over my shoulder and saw a fireball coming down the aisle. I thought, 'Forget the purse, woman, get out of the plane.' ''

title: Merry-Go-Round Sites
description: A GOOD life can be modeled after a good carousel. Since you are destined to go around in circles and end up where you started, you ought to make the trip with music, beauty, romance and fun.

title: Ewing to Miss Rest of Playoffs With a Torn Achilles' Tendon
description: After enduring excruciating pain to help put the Knicks one step away from the National Basketball Association championship series, Patrick Ewing sustained another blow in his 14-year pursuit of a title yesterday when tests showed a partial tear of his left Achilles' tendon.

title: Nathan S. Ancell, 90, Ethan Allen Co-Founder
description: Nathan S. Ancell, a co-founder of Ethan Allen Inc., who pioneered the concept of selling furniture in room-style settings, died Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 90.

title: The House That Eileen Gray Built
description: Restoring the mystique -- and the leaky roofs -- of unsung houses may be the most rewarding offshoot of the post-modern era. To think that Pierre Chareau's poetical Maison de Verre in Paris ever went unnoticed is now nearly unthinkable. Eileen Gray's E.1027 on the French Riviera, the Irish designer's first house, is another such touchstone: a modern house, circa 1929, made luminous through ingenious, fuss-free thinking. (Why not shelves made of string nets?)

title: Governor Bush Finally Emerges
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who became the favorite for the Republican Presidential nomination without ever leaving Austin, has begun to emerge from his self-imposed seclusion. The people of Texas are probably grateful that Mr. Bush refused to campaign until their Legislature had finished its business. But meanwhile the expectations that have grown up around him have gotten so high that he may find them impossible to meet. His first foray to Iowa and New Hampshire later this month will be a kind of political Groundhog Day, with spectators waiting to see whether Mr. Bush becomes unnerved by the reality that greets him when he pops out of his burrow.

title: SCHWAB LINK TO TOKIO
description: Ending months of speculation about whom it would team with in the Japanese retail brokerage business, the Charles Schwab Corporation agreed in principle to build a full-service brokerage firm in partnership with the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, the only Japanese insurance company with a AAA credit rating. Starting next fall, the new company will offer customers trading of United States stocks and bonds and Japanese and offshore mutual funds over a Web site and a 24-hour telephone service center, with one branch office in Tokyo. Stephanie Strom

title: Spilling Our Nuclear Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: Elderly Vote for Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, WILLIAM
description: HALPERIN-William. Died unexpectedly May 30, 1999 surrounded by his family, just 22 weeks after his beloved wife, best friend and partner of 61 years, Lynn Muller Halperin. All father could ever be to Jane and Robert Willis, Mary and Martin Marlowe and Barbara Selling. Incredible, loving Grandpa to Carolyn, David and Susan Willis, Jennifer and Andrew Bender, Julie and Lisa Freiman, Gregory and Daniel Selling. Devoted son of the late May and Elias Halperin. Dearest brother of Ben and Shirley Halperin. Long-time Vice President of Ideal Toy, presently employed at the Dime Savings Bank. Family historian, student of the Torah and the finest of men. Services at Temple Beth El, Great Neck, Wednesday, June 2nd at 12:30. Shiva at the Marlowe's, Spruce Pond (Shelter Rock Road), Manhasset through Sunday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Caring Committee of Temple Beth El.

title: Rail Link From Midtown to Kennedy Wins Pivotal Approval
description: Plans for a $1.5 billion rail line linking Kennedy International Airport to local trains and subways won overwhelming approval from two important City Council committees yesterday, putting the much debated and long awaited ''Airtrain'' just one vote away from final approval.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about companies that own small newspapers misstated the ownership of Media General. It is independent, not part of Cox Communications.

title: A New Language May Ease Web Use
description: THE latest browsers understand it, undergraduates are signing up for classes to learn it, and -- ultimate cyberspace compliment -- start-ups are forming around it.

title: Subway Victim Says He Harbors No Anger
description: Five weeks after a mentally ill man randomly pushed him in front of an oncoming subway train that severed his legs, Edgar Rivera said yesterday that he harbored no anger toward his attacker and had no desire for revenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, FRANCES G.
description: KATZENSTEIN - Frances G. (Fran), on June 1, 1999. Cherished daughter of Rhoda and the late Alan. Loved sister of Joy Levy and Paul. Adoring aunt of Sarah, Andrew, Jeffrey and Hannah. Her loving and generous spirit will be greatly missed. Funeral service Thursday at noon at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, CHARLES
description: PIERCE-Charles. Beloved impressionist, comedian, entertainer and friend. His star quality and tenderness was a gift to all. We will deeply miss his warmth, compassion and outrageous sense of humor. Tom Roberts, Shelley Ackerman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIGAN, ALEX J.
description: McGUIGAN-Alex J. On June 1, 1999. Adored husband of Maire Byrne. Loving father of Kevin, Thomas and the late James. Cherished grandfather of Krissy. Dear brother of John and Cathleen Carmichael. Reposing at Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43 Avenue, Elmhurst, NY. Funeral Mass 10:15 A.M. Friday at St. Joan of Arc Church, Jackson Heights, NY. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. Sleep softly, sweet prince, and angels carry thee to thy rest.

title: Frank Spencer Is Dead at 58; Anthropologist Studied a Hoax
description: Frank Spencer, an anthropologist who rummaged through the bones of controversy to theorize about the identity of the mastermind behind the Piltdown Man hoax of 1912, died on Sunday. He was 58 and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Exhibition, Discussions And a Tour
description: Brooches for Albright

title: The Big City; Scalping Law Trims Wallets Of Knick Fans
description: IF you wanted to see the Knicks play the Pacers in Indianapolis Tuesday night, you could have bought a seat for $65 from a ticket broker. But if you'd like to see them play this weekend in Madison Square Garden, expect to pay at least $250.

title: Home Sales Unexpectedly Rose in April
description: Sales of new homes unexpectedly rose in April to the second-highest level ever, driving prices to a record high and giving Federal Reserve policy makers another reason to consider raising interest rates, Government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINSKELE, ALBERT M.
description: BRINSKELE-Albert M. Died on Tuesday, May 25, 1999. He was born in Brooklyn, New York, a Veteran of W.W. II and attended New York University where he received his Bachelors and MBA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONDSCHEIN, MURRAY
description: MONDSCHEIN-Murray. On May 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Gusti. Loving brother of Edith Laufer. Brother-in-law of Jack Laufer. Also survived by his nephews Lee, Bill & Sam. Granduncle to Hannah, Joshua, Daniel and Maximillian. Services 12 noon Friday at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Should friends desire, memorial contributions may be made to The American Friends of The Anne Frank House, P.O. Box 730, NL-1000, AS Amsterdam, The Netherlands.

title: Mr. Silver's Silence on Reform
description: The fight to overhaul New York State's rigid Rockefeller-era drug laws took a depressing turn recently when Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said the Assembly would not take up Gov. George Pataki's proposed changes. Mr. Pataki's tepid proposals deserve criticism, and this may have been Mr. Silver's way of expressing it. But the Speaker seems also to have foreclosed debate on an issue that badly needs an airing, and broader reform.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about tensions between ethnic Albanians and Macedonians in a Macedonian village referred incompletely to the Macedonian language. While it is Slavic, Macedonian is also an Indo-European language, like Albanian.

title: At Auction, Everything But the Blue Suede Shoes
description: For sale: One pair of used Army fatigues.

title: How About Facing Yanks Later?
description: A sweaty and satisfied Bobby Valentine finished throwing batting practice to some Mets pitchers yesterday and playfully chirped about how effective he had been. Valentine returned to the dugout and continued chatting about the most routine baseball exercise. It was typical Valentine; he likes to talk and embraces the attention.

title: Drive-By Shooting of Girl, 3, Is Said to Stem From Rent Fight
description: The drive-by shooting that killed a 3-year-old girl in the Bronx on Memorial Day apparently resulted from a quarrel over rent and not a drug dispute, as had previously been thought, police officials said yesterday.

title: Game Distributor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the flurry of initial public offerings among new-media companies based in New York misstated the reason senior executives are often unable to sell their stock for several months after the start of trading. The practice is dictated by contracts between the companies and their underwriters, not by Federal regulations. The article also misidentified the headquarters of Lycos Inc., an Internet company. Although it has a sales and marketing office in Manhattan, it is based in Waltham, Mass.

title: Economic Scene; The new welfare rules may be tested in the next recession.
description: PROPONENTS of the 1996 welfare law are finding plenty of reasons to feel smug these days. Republican leaders held a news conference last week to proclaim a triumph after releasing a study by the General Accounting Office that showed plunging welfare rolls, soaring employment rates among former recipients and no burst of homelessness, as many of the law's opponents had predicted.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO., Cincinnati, plans to sell its Attends adult incontinence products business in Europe and North America to Paper-Pak Products Inc., La Verne, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Engineered for the Aquarium, But Will They Take the Bait?
description: Engineers in Japan appear to be getting into the robot business these days: first, Sony announced the arrival of Aibo, the robotic dog. Now Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is developing robotic fish.

title: The Challenge for South Africa
description: The slums in South Africa are as bleak as any in the world -- miles of single-room hovels, each holding a huge family or two, with no electricity or water and only a bucket for waste. Apartheid forced millions of blacks into these slums, and many have not been able to leave. The most important task facing Thabo Mbeki, who will become president following the African National Congress's apparent election victory yesterday, is to improve life for these poor.

title: A Tiny Sparrow Is Cast as a Test Of Will to Restore the Everglades
description: Stuart Pimm stepped from a helicopter in the middle of a saw-grass prairie, took off his heavy white helmet and as the chopper pulled away began to sift the air for the call of a sparrow, his educated ear sorting the feathery whistles and clicks rising in the dawn.

title: Compgeeks in an Offering
description: Compgeeks Inc., a company that sells computers and related products on line, will seek to raise as much as $61 million through an initial public offering. The company, based in Vista, Calif., represents a rarity among electronic commerce businesses: it has been profitable since starting up in 1990. Compgeeks has generated these profits while relying on word-of-mouth advertising. The number of shares to be sold and their price will be disclosed in a supplemental filing.

title: Albany Leaders Urge Spending Far More to Cut Use of Tobacco
description: The leaders of both houses of the Legislature have called for a major increase in state spending on anti-tobacco advertising and education, and Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would not be averse to such an increase.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Man, Down Through The Ages (His Own)
description: When the stressed-out Manhattan mother in ''Infancy'' started reciting the alphabet, the multiplication tables and the boroughs of New York to her infant son, all I could think of was Diane Keaton's showing flash cards to her toddler in ''Baby Boom'' -- and of lots of competitive 1990's parents in real life. But this play is set in Central Park in the 1920's, and the idea seemed to be to calm the baby rather than prepare him early for the S.A.T.'s.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS FURTHER. The euro fell to its lowest level against the dollar after officials signaled that the European Central Bank would not buy euros to bolster the price. The euro fell in New York to $1.0355, from $1.0442 Tuesday.

title: 9 Dead and 80 Are Hurt as Jet Crashes in Arkansas Storm
description: An American Airlines jet carrying 145 people touched down in a furious thunderstorm late Tuesday, slid off the runway and was sliced open as it hit a lighting tower. Nine people were killed in the fiery crash, including the captain, and more than 80 people were injured, some with severe burns.

title: Indonesia's Quiet Candidate Is Gaining Momentum
description: Though it was clearly the last thing he intended, it was Suharto who launched the candidacy of his most likely successor as Indonesia's next elected leader -- his longtime nemesis, Megawati Sukarnoputri.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees-Mets: What 6 Games Might Mean
description: PAUL O'NEILL didn't want to talk about the Mets' three-game visit to Yankee Stadium that begins tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHILDS, THEODORE QUENTIN
description: CHILDS-Theodore Quentin Jr. December 8, 1956-June 3, 1998. We love you and miss you. Lucy Lee, Beryl, Martha, Edward & Henr

title: NEWS WATCH
description: DOG IN THE WINDOWS -- It seems that Sony has found an untapped market for robotic dogs. Within 20 minutes of opening on-line sales on Tuesday, the company sold out its 3,000 units of Aibo, a programmable pup, on the Japanese market. Sales of the robot in the United States weren't quite as brisk -- about 1,000 of 2,000 robots on the market were sold by the end of the day. But Tod Freeman, a spokesman for Sony, said that demand was high. ''For the first two and a half hours, our server was so overloaded it was inaccessible,'' Mr. Freeman said. Aibo, which is selling for $2,500, can be purchased only on line.

title: IRISH INVESTMENT IN SINGAPORE
description: Ireland's largest banking company, the Allied Irish Banks will purchase 25 percent of the shares in the Keppel Tatlee Bank of Singapore, that country's fifth-largest bank. Allied Irish already operates treasury, private banking and investment management services in Singapore through its AIB Govett Asia subsidiary. The investment in Keppel, to be made over the next three years, is is valued about $882 million. James F. Clarity

title: Commencements; Defense of CUNY Plays a Role in Ceremonies at Several Colleges
description: There were the usual beach balls and personalized mortarboards -- even a funk band at one ceremony. But such is the climate at the City University of New York that the usual commencement mirth was mixed yesterday with impassioned defenses of the university.

title: Metro Business; Marketing Company To Eliminate 90 Jobs
description: Boron, LePore and Associates Inc., a drug marketer in Fair Lawn, N.J., said yesterday that it would have a loss in its second quarter and would cut 10 percent of its staff, or about 90 employees, and consolidate offices.

title: Vehicle Sales Increased by 5.3% in May
description: Auto executives were exuberant today as May's car and truck sales propelled the industry toward its best year ever.

title: 'Fishing' for Ransom, Colombian Rebels Cast Net Wide
description: The school Melba Martinez's daughter attends doesn't go on field trips anymore. Alirio Lopez no longer returns to the village where he was born to visit his parents on weekends. Elber Espino leaves his new car at home and switches to his wife's old compact anytime he has to drive out to the countryside.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: At the Women's Open, New Talent, Old Issues
description: On the course, it has been another interesting year for women's professional golf. Karrie Webb leads the L.P.G.A. money list and has already won four times. Kelli Kuehne, a two-time United States Amateur Champion, won her first professional tournament last month.

title: Listening To Sounds Of a Wave
description: AMERICANS bought more than 58 million radios for the home last year. In fact, the Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Association reports that most homes have at least eight of them. If car radios are included, that number rises to 9 or 10 per home, making radios easily the most ubiquitous consumer electronics device in the nation.

title: Diabetes Drug Is Promising In Insulin-Cell Transplants
description: Scientists reported yesterday that they had cured diabetes in monkeys by giving them transplants of insulin-producing cells along with an experimental drug that prevented rejection of the donor tissue.

title: CLUB MED PURCHASE
description: Club Mediterranee S.A. agreed to buy Jet Tours Holding, France's third-largest tour operator, for 485 million francs ($77 million). The transaction makes Club Med France's largest tour operator, with 20 percent of the national market and annual sales of more than 10 billion francs. The purchase forms part of its two-year recovery strategy in France and will help to expand its activities, particularly into tour operation.

title: A Delayed Seniors Career Is Still Sweet for Holtgrieve
description: Few golfers can spend 15 years away from the game after a distinguished amateur career and come back to put themselves in position to challenge for a title as a professional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, JOHN CLARK
description: MATTHEWS-John Clark, Ed.D. Professor emeritus at Adelphi University, of Garden City, New York, on Sunday, May 30th, following a long illness. Former chairman of Adelphi Department of Education. Survived by his devoted wife Margaret, sister Carrie of New Brunswick, Canada, and loving children Clark, Thane, and Nancy. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Fairchild Chapel, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, N.Y. Memorial service 8 P.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Dr. Matthews' name to the Parkinson's Disease Research Team at New York-Presbyterian Medical Center, Sergievsky Center, (212) 305-9086.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCELL, NATHAN S.
description: ANCELL-Nathan S. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are saddened by the loss of Nathan S. Ancell, a beloved leader and cherished friend who was deeply committed to the Jewish people. A compassionate humanitarian, he earned enormous admiration for his extraordinary generosity and wisdom. Through his leadership and support of UJA-Federation, he helped alleviate human suffering and enhance Jewish educational and cultural programs.
