An honorary officer of UJA-Federation, he formerly served as a member and honorary co-chair of our Board of Directors. He was also an honorary board chair of the Mid-Westchester YM-YWHA and a past associate board chair of the Associated YM-YWHA's of Greater New York, both beneficiary agencies of UJA-Federation. We extend our sincerest condolences to his daughters, Susan Darley and Penny Randall, and his grandchildren, Leigh, David, Edin, Jackie, Lea, and Piper. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Clinton, in Air Force Address, Warnes Milosevic to 'Cut His Losses' and Accept NATO's Terms
description: President Clinton today urged Slobodan Milosevic to ''cut his losses'' by bending to allied demands for ending the NATO attacks on Yugoslavia.

title: Another Former Official Pleads Guilty to Stealing From City Workers' Union
description: The ousted first vice president of a union local representing 23,000 New York City clerical workers pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $50,000 from the union.

title: ESSAY; Greetings and Solicitations: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: EVERYONE gets spam for ''XXX hotpics!'' and get-rich-quick schemes. Like most people, I usually send it straight to the trash, unopened. But I must admit, sometimes I do read it, and sometimes I'd like to reply. Of course I haven't, yet. That might encourage them. It would be hard to imagine, but I might get even more, even worse junk E-mail. So, although I can never send them, just writing these replies did make me feel better.

title: Taking the Old Baedeker Into the Next Century
description: IN ''Leading the Blind,'' his study of nineteenth century European guidebook travel, the writer Alan Sillitoe traces the emergence of guidebooks like Baedeker's and Murray's to the increasing popularity of travel among those outside of the strictly leisured classes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URIBE, LUIS ENRIQUE
description: URIBE-Luis Enrique. June 1, 1999. Husband of Irma, father of Adelaida Uribe Bennett and her husband Edward G.R. Bennett and Maria del Pilar Uribe, grandfather of Edward, Elisa and Pilar Bennett. Friend of many years to Mercedes Guzman and Fernanda Macieira. A renown ophthalmologist and attending surgeon at both Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital and Beth Israel Medical Center. Memorial service Friday, June 4, 10:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration, 120 Wall St., 3rd Floor, NY, NY 10005. He was a caring and dedicated gentleman to his patients, friends and family.

title: Beyond Neon: Electronic Ink
description: GUTENBERG would turn over in his grave. Not at the notion of electronic ink, which can rearrange itself in response to electrical charges, allowing a page of text to change from ''Hamlet'' to ''Windows 98 for Dummies'' at a programmer's whim. No, he would turn over at some of the first words in the new ink to reach the public.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; George Washington Gardened Here
description: AT this late date, the 200th anniversary of his death, you might think that anything and everything about George Washington had long been chewed over. But wait: what was the connection between the beautiful, whoppingly productive gardens of Mount Vernon and those famous false teeth? And by the way, what could our first President eat?

title: Metro Business; Company to Cut 100 Jobs
description: The PRT Group Inc., an information technology and software services provider, said yesterday that it would cut about 100 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, as it reorganized to save money. The company employs about 900 people.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Giuliani Files Lawsuit Challenging Tax Repeal
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sued the state yesterday in an attempt to reverse the commuter tax repeal, saying that state lawmakers should have asked the city's permission before abolishing the tax last month.

title: How We Can Save Teaching Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Canoeist Goes to Court, Fighting for Right to Curse
description: If Timothy J. Boomer had kept his balance in a canoe, an obscure Michigan law against swearing in front of women and children might not be tested now.

title: U.S. Military Chiefs Firm: No Ground Force for Kosovo
description: On the eve of their first meeting with President Clinton since NATO's air war against Yugoslavia began, the Pentagon's senior commanders remain strongly opposed to mounting a ground invasion to drive Serbian forces from Kosovo, defense officials said today.

title: 9 Die as Plane Skids In Landing in Storm
description: An American Airlines jet with 145 people aboard slid off the runway as it landed in Little Rock, Ark., during a heavy thunderstorm, then was ripped open by a lighting tower. Nine people were killed in the fiery crash, including the captain, and more than 80 people were injured, some with severe burns.

title: Misconduct Complaint Against Coach Dismissed
description: The United States Figure Skating Association has dismissed a sexual-misconduct complaint against the top American coach, Richard Callaghan, ruling that his accuser did not lodge a grievance within the federation's allotted time period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLOCK, RANDOLPH
description: BULLOCK-Randolph. The staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art notes with sadness the passing last week of Randolph Bullock, a Curator Emeritus, Department of Arms and Armor who served The Museum from 1927 through 1968.

title: Celebrating Copland, a Native Son
description: Plans for ''Copland 2000,'' a worldwide celebration of Aaron Copland's music and contributions to American culture, were announced this week. Copland, who was born in Brooklyn, would have turned 100 on Nov 14, 2000. He died in 1990.

title: Charismatic a 2-1 Pick In Triple Crown Bid
description: Charismatic flew through thunderstorms into New York yesterday morning for the final scene in his Triple Crown drama, accompanied by three horses who will try to snatch the Belmont Stakes from his grasp and shepherded by his trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, who was wearing a big white cowboy hat and keeping a wary eye on his celebrated horse.

title: Breast Cancer Study on Alternative Therapy
description: Women with breast cancer who seek alternative therapies like herbs or acupuncture in addition to standard treatment may be unusually worried and depressed and in need of extra help in coping with their fears about the disease, a study says.

title: A Concrete Arts Bunker on the Thames Awaits the Kiss of Life
description: Audiences inside the collection of theaters and concert halls along the south bank of the Thames that make up the world's largest cultural complex are regularly transported to the realm of the sublime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. The Executives and Staff of Peter Sharp & Co, Inc., deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed business associate and friend. We will miss his leadership, wisdom, and friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dawn, and the entire family. The Executives and Staff of Peter Sharp & Co, Inc.

title: Kosovo Crossroad
description: Bill Clinton and Slobodan Milosevic face critical decisions this week about the war in Yugoslavia. If intensifying diplomatic efforts produce a political settlement, military operations could end quickly, followed by the rebuilding of Kosovo and the return of ethnic Albanian refugees this fall. If Mr. Milosevic refuses to make peace, months of additional bombing are likely and Mr. Clinton and his NATO allies will have to decide soon whether to prepare for an invasion later this year.

title: Two Years Later, Williams Repeats
description: In a repeat of her performance two years ago as a sophomore, Aleah Williams of Montclair High swept the 100-meter and 200-meter sprints yesterday at the New Jersey State high school track and field championships at Jost Field in South Plainfield.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about China's trade status with the United States referred incorrectly to the action expected today regarding renewal of that country's trading privileges. What is expected is Mr. Clinton's renewal request, not a vote by the Senate.

title: G.O.P. Official Backs Bid By Giuliani Foe for Senate
description: Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, the only black Republican in Congress, came to Long Island today to encourage his Republican colleague, Representative Rick A. Lazio, to run for the Senate.

title: Teamsters Reach an Accord With Haulers of New Cars
description: Averting a strike that would have disrupted the Big Three auto makers, the teamsters' union and trucking companies that haul new cars to dealers reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday in negotiations that were the first big test for James P. Hoffa, the union's new president.

title: Shares Slip but Rebound; Nasdaq Up, Other Gauges Flat
description: Stocks slumped in early trading yesterday but rebounded somewhat after bargain hunters stepped in to scoop up shares of Internet and other high-technology issues. By the close, the Nasdaq composite index had reversed course and posted a solid gain, but the other main gauges were flat.

title: YAHOO IN ACQUISITION TO EXPAND USE OF ITS DIRECTORIES
description: Yahoo Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Online Anywhere, which formats Internet pages for hand-held devices, for $80 million in stock to move beyond Internet directories that are limited to personal computers. Yahoo said the acquisition would let it transmit its Internet directories to pagers, cell phones and hand-held computers such as 3Com Corporation's PalmPilot, as well as Web-TV services that allow simultaneous use of Internet features and television programs. It did not disclose details of the purchase. Shares of Yahoo, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $4.3125, to $142.50.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Aspects of Daily Life: The Toothbrush, the Blessings
description: Happiness, as we all know but usually forget, is a state of mind. Take, for example, Winnie, Beckett's indomitable spirit whose hymn to the minutiae of daily life forms the basis of ''Happy Days,'' his last full-length play. ''Not a day goes by that there's not a blessing,'' Winnie muses, rummaging happily through her handbag, then adds as an afterthought, ''in disguise.''

title: Nintendo Characters Show Darker Side
description: NINTENDO has always been considered the kinder, gentler console. When Sega's Mortal Kombat was splashing gore across the screen, Nintendo had Mario. The Playstation is home to gun-slinging Lara Croft and the industrial destruction zone of Metal Gear Solid. Nintendo has the Legend of Zelda, a magical adventure set in the verdant kingdom of Hyrule.

title: Arkansas Pitcher Is Drafted
description: David Walling, a tall, lean pitcher from the University of Arkansas who got away from the Mets, was selected by the Yankees in the first round of yesterday's amateur draft. He was the 27th pick over all.

title: Third Ameritrade Stock Split Planned
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, the No. 6 on-line brokerage firm, declared a 3-for-1 stock split today of its class A and class B common stock, its third split in the last year, as the company's shares have risen more than tenfold.

title: China Opens Another Door To an Isolated North Korea
description: North Korea's No. 2 political leader arrived in Beijing today for the first high-level meeting between the two Communist allies in eight years, talks that will be closely watched by the United States and China's Asian neighbors.

title: Publicis Acquires Stake in Burrell
description: In another effort by a mainstream agency company to expand in the growing realm of advertising to minorities, Publicis S.A. in Paris said yesterday that it had acquired a 49 percent interest in Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, which specializes in campaigns aimed at black consumers. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MILDRED
description: ROSENBERG-Mildred. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Georgine Chase and Marian Abbey. Loving mother-inlaw of Martin Abbey and the late Joseph Chase. Adored grandmother of Mark Abbey and Bari Chase and Daniel Kalin and greatgrandmother of Skylar Kalin. Graveside services 11AM Thursday at Beth David Cemetery.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: The Surreal World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, MYRON
description: WEINER-Myron. Professor of Political Science, MIT. Died at his home in Moretown, VT, June 3, 1999. He is survived by his wife Sheila Leiman Weiner, his daughter Beth Datskovsky of Bala Cynwyd, PA, his son Saul J. Weiner of Chicago, IL and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Central Vermont Home Hospice, RR 3, Box 6694, Barre, VT 05641 or UNICEF.

title: Refugees Are Skeptical of Pledges
description: When the loudspeakers at this refugee camp broadcast the news today of a potential peace agreement for Kosovo, Ahmet Sharifi burst out laughing. ''Milosevic is lying again,'' he said.

title: Colonial Myth And Reality
description: Thomas Jefferson was taking questions from the audience, all reverential, about the Louisiana Purchase, his interest in wine making and the men who shaped his mind. (Sir Isaac Newton, Sir Francis Bacon and John Locke, he replied.) Skittish about breaking the weird decorousness of the event at Colonial Williamsburg, which was a supposed conversation with the retired third President, I nonetheless raised my hand and asked if Jefferson had changed his opinion about the newspapers of his day after they printed the ''scurrilous rumors'' about Sally Hemings, the slave with whom he is thought by many modern historians, on the basis of DNA evidence, to have fathered a child.

title: City Budget Showdown
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the New York City Council have reluctantly scaled down an array of proposed tax cuts that seemed certain to be approved earlier this year. Their action was forced by the loss of revenues when the State Legislature repealed the commuter tax last month. Now the Mayor and Council need to reach agreement on other issues in the $35 billion budget. They should first restore Mr. Giuliani's proposed cuts in libraries, after-school programs, cultural institutions and legal services for the poor.

title: Theater, With Book By Lost Boys
description: ''PETER PAN'' it wasn't, not that anyone thought it would be. You don't go to Rikers Island expecting Broadway song and dance.

title: THAILAND BIDDING WAR
description: The takeover struggle for one of Thailand's most prestigious hotels reached a peak, as Goldman, Sachs & Company and an American-born Thai entrepreneur made final tender offers for Bangkok's Regent Hotel. Goldman, whose equity investments in Asia are supervised by Henry Cornell, above, is now offering 48 Thai baht, or $1.29, a share, which values the hotel at about $55 million. The entrepreneur, William E. Heinecke, raised his bid for 10 percent of the shares to 43 baht, or $1.16, from 42 baht.

title: Kirsten Ralov, 77, Ballerina Known for Bournonville Roles
description: Kirsten Ralov, one of Denmark's greatest ballerinas and an authority on the unusually sparkling Danish style of classical dancing, died on Sunday at her home in Copenhagen. She was 77.

title: A Life-or-Death Plot, for Dreams and for Teen-Agers
description: At first glance, a group of teen-agers growing up in a desert town so far off the beaten track that television remains something of a mystery might not seem like interesting company.

title: Mexican Investigation
description: To the Editor:

title: Irregular Settings Found in Plane That Crashed
description: Devices to slow a plane on the runway appear to have been deployed irregularly just after an American Airlines jet touched down in Little Rock, Ark., on Tuesday before crashing, killing nine people on board, an air safety official said.

title: TO SAVE MONEY, MERITOR SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 300 JOBS
description: Meritor Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 300 jobs, or just less than 2 percent of its work force, in an effort to save money. Most of the cuts will be in the light vehicle systems unit, where Meritor, a car-parts supplier based in Troy, Mich., will close a sun roof plant and consolidate some other manufacturing operations. The rest will come from the heavy vehicle systems unit, it said. Meritor employs 18,000 people. The revamping is expected to reduce operating costs by $7 million in fiscal year 2000 and by $9 million in fiscal year 2001. Costs associated with the revamping will lower earnings by $17 million, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter ending June 30.

title: Hobbled Ewing Lights a Fire Under His Undermanned Team
description: The Knicks had just finished stretching on the practice floor when they drifted toward Patrick Ewing and huddled in front of him as if they were at a bonfire.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, LARRY
description: WILLIAMS-Larry, 48. A photographer, film director, and artist died on May 31 in Los Angeles, CA. He suffered a heart attack while hiking with his dog, Ed. He began his career as a photographer in London and New York. He was one of the original photographers to be exhibited at the Light Gallery, and has shown at The Museum of Modern Art, Centre Beaubourg in Paris, The Santa Barbara Museum of Art, The Chrysler Museum and The Chicago Center of Contemporary Photography. In addition to receiving a National Endowment for the Arts grant, Mr. Williams has taught at Bard College, Manhattanville College, and Chelsea College of Art in London. As a commercial freelance photographer his photographs have appeared in many magazines including Rolling Stone, Esquire, The New York Sunday Times Magazine, The London Sunday Times Magazine, New York, House and Garden and Metropolitan Home. He went on to direct music videos for artists such as Prince, Iggy Pop, Keith Richards and Paul Simon. In recent years Williams worked with his wife and partner Leslie Libman, collaborating and co-directing music videos and television commercials, and an award winning series of short films that premiered on MTV. They went on to direct television episodes for the acclaimed NBC series Homicide: Life on the Street and the HBO prison drama Oz. Their first feature film followed, Path to Paradise: The Untold Story of the World Trade Center Bombing, for HBO/ NYC. Williams, son of the late Bennett Williams, is survived by his wife, Leslie Libman; his children Bennett and Sidney, of Los Angeles, CA; his mother Gloria Williams; grandmother Mae Singer; sister Phyllis Williams of York, PA; and his sister Marjie Williams of Cambridge, MA. A memorial service will be held at Temple Israel in Hollywood, CA, Friday, June 4 at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made to organizations working to control gun violence.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Space for Middle-Income Market
description: Weeks before Queensway -- a 122-unit middle-income rental building in Woodside, Queens -- was completed last month, it was fully leased, reflecting the demand for housing for people with annual incomes of $35,000 to $80,000.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Michael Joo

title: Blink of the Eye, Tremor of the Soul
description: The audience, for the moment, is the mirror for the exasperatingly pretty young woman who is standing in the center of the stage. She gazes into the darkness where we sit, rearranging her waist-length hair with fascinated preoccupation, intensely focused, it would seem, on the vision of her own face and body. She is a study in rapturous self-communion that somehow goes way beyond vanity.

title: Sports of The Times; NEW YORK'S TRIPLE CROWN
description: Don't do it. Make believe Ed Koch is still the Mayor and repeat after me: ''Don't even think of trying it,'' with heavy Kochian emphasis on the ''think.''

title: A Democrat Exits for the Undeclared Clinton
description: Saying she was convinced that Hillary Rodham Clinton was running for Senator from New York, Representative Nita M. Lowey abandoned her own bid for the position yesterday, announcing her decision in a telephone call to Mrs. Clinton at the White House. Mrs. Clinton made no attempt to dissuade her, and the First Lady's aides later said she is likely to form an exploratory committee in July.

title: Feeling Rich? Don't Get Smug Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HERBERT S.
description: COHEN-Herbert S. On June 2, 1999. Cherished husband of Marion. Loving father of Marsha, Edward and Nadine. Devoted grandfather of Reuben and Daniel. Services Friday, June 4, 10:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NATO Envoy on Talks With Milosevic
description: Following are excerpts of a statement made by the Finnish President, Martti Ahtisaari, in Bonn yesterday, and of a news conference held by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in Washington, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company in Washington.

title: Album of the Week
description: RANDY NEWMAN: ''BAD LOVE'' -- (Dreamworks) -- It's been 11 years since Randy Newman last released an album of new material not connected to a musical (''Faust'') or a movie (''Toy Story''), but the intervening years have only refined his understated composing style and sharpened his droll wit (particularly when applied to the materialistic or small-minded).

title: Candidate Is Giving 3d Party a 2d Look
description: When Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire began talking a few weeks back about possible formation of a third party that would be a new home for disgruntled hard-right Republicans like himself, he insisted he did not plan to lead such a breakaway effort because he was a candidate for next year's Republican Presidential nomination. All he was trying to do, he said, was to warn Republican leaders that if they did not hew closer to the conservative line, they ran the risk that other unhappy conservatives in the party might create their own party.

title: Casino Visions, And Fears; Man's Plan to Donate Land To Indians Riles Hamlet
description: For years, longtime residents and weekenders from Manhattan treasured this woodsy hamlet as the closest thing to rustic paradise, a place where the streams made more noise than the residents, where slender country roads rolled past old stone walls, where the number of general stores (1) dwarfed the number of traffic lights (0). One could sigh, and sigh again, when contemplating the crisp air, the clear-day vistas of Connecticut and, perhaps most precious of all, the leisurely and utterly predictable cadence of life.

title: Netscape Chief's Testimony Is Re-examined by Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation promised it would question the credibility of key Justice Department witnesses during the rebuttal phase of the antitrust trial that began this week, and today a company lawyer introduced several documents that did just that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. The officers, members and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound regret at the loss of Raphael Recanati. A supporter of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, the ATS and Israel, he established an academic chair and the Recanati Israel Floor of the Advanced Computer Center at the Technion. The Center has helped meet the needs of students with state-of-the-art equipment. Our heartfelt condolences to the Recanati famlty American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive V.P. Jonathan Sohnis, New York Metro Region Chair Joseph Huber, New York Metro Region Director

title: As Charismatic Seeks the Triple Crown, ABC Expects Good Ratings
description: Silver Charm proved it. So did Real Quiet. If you're a horse, and you've won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, you can boost ABC's Belmont Stakes ratings by showing up and looking competitive. You don't even have to win, although the Triple Crown means nice cash and plenty of gourmet oats.

title: Trapped in House, Firefighter Is Critically Injured in Queens Blaze
description: A fire captain was fighting for life last night after he got trapped in the junk-filled basement of a burning home in Queens, inhaled smoke for several minutes, and went into cardiac arrest, the Fire Commissioner said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZ, FANNIE
description: HOLTZ-Fannie. Died peacefully on June 2nd at age 97. Loving wife of the late Morris Holtz. Devoted mother of Lucille (Howard) and Myron (Barbara). Proud grandmother of Jeffrey, Robert (Mary) and Eric (Shannon) and greatgrandmother of Tyler. Funeral on Friday, 10AM, Kirschenbaum Bros., 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Alliance Eases Bombing but Awaits Verification of Serbian Troop Withdrawal Before Ending Raids : Ahtisaari Briefs Summit (folo)
description: President Martti Ahtisaari briefed the European summit meeting Thursday on the results of his two-day mission to Belgrade, which led to hopes that the conflict, which began during a previous EU summit, in Berlin on March 24, was nearing its end.

title: Robert Sobel, 68, a Historian of Business, Dies
description: Robert Sobel, a prolific historian of American business life whose topics ranged from the economic philosophy of President Calvin Coolidge to the influence of the junk-bond financier Michael Milken, died on Wednesday at his home in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 68.

title: MILOSEVIC YIELDS ON NATO'S KEY TERMS; 50,000 ALLIED TROOPS TO POLICE KOSOVO
description: On the 72d day of NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, President Slobodan Milosevic accepted an international peace plan today to end the Kosovo conflict and allow nearly one million ethnic Albanian refugees to return to what is left of their homes.

title: U.S. and Canada Agree on a Plan to Restrict Catches of Endangered Salmon
description: Seeking to end a long-festering international dispute that has imperiled salmon stocks and once provoked an angry blockade of Alaska-bound ferries by Canadian fishermen, the United States and Canada announced a comprehensive plan today to set quotas on salmon catches along thousands of miles of the Pacific Ocean coast and establish a conservation fund to help protect the fish.

title: Not Penmanship, Cultural Treasure
description: Chinese art has enjoyed V.I.P status in New York in the past few years. The Met opened its ultra-deluxe new Chinese galleries. The Guggenheim's ''China: 5,000 Years'' exhibition and Asia's Society's recent showcase of contemporary work, ''Inside Out,'' were high-profile events.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: In Beijing, Reminders of '89 Protest Are Few
description: Next to a busy intersection tonight, about eight miles west of Tiananmen Square, hundreds of retirees were practicing a traditional flag-waving dance to the pounding of drums.

title: Fruit of Miscalculation
description: From the start, this has been a war of miscalculation.

title: Presidential Hopeful Displays Humanity
description: Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio was about to arrive for one of those meet-and-greet coffees that New Hampshirites throw for their favorite Presidential hopefuls. Then, at the last moment, the host, Linda Kaiser of Amherst, realized she had forgotten to pick up extra ice.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Finding Music In the Air

title: Foreign Affairs; Good News, Bad News
description: What should we think of yesterday's news of a potential deal in Kosovo? We should think there is potential good news here and potential bad news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, RANSOM
description: NOBLE-Ransom. Of Ridgewood, N.J. Died at age 89 on May 8. Beloved person, wise and gracious, he loved life and nature. Those whose lives he touched will cherish him always. At Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY, he was Professor of History for 30 years and Dean of Liberal Arts and Sciences for 15 years before retiring in 1975. Predeceased by his wife Lois, he is survived by his sons James and Richard, daughter Jean Noble, his sister-in-law Jean Cole Noble, and friend Pauline Tish.

title: Support Shrinks for China's Trade Status
description: President Clinton briefly acknowledged the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square killings today and argued, with logic that is meeting increasing skepticism on Capitol Hill, that only by pushing ahead on expanding trade with Beijing can the United States remain ''a force for social change in China.''

title: ARCHIBALD CANDY IS BUYING STORE CHAIN FROM NESTLE
description: The Archibald Candy Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Laura Secord chocolate-store chain from Nestle S.A. for about $42 million. The Laura Secord chain has 175 stores in Canada, with the majority in Ontario and Quebec. The purchase will make Archibald, which is based in Chicago, the largest chocolate store owner in North America, with about 750 outlets. Archibald acquired the Fanny Farmer brand in 1992 and Sweet Factory last year. Archibald, which is closely held, said it would finance the Laura Secord acquisition by issuing debt and using existing cash.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Without Detail, China Curbs Foreign Transfers of Its Currency
description: Chinese authorities announced today that they were tightening control over international transfers of the yuan, the nation's currency.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Cindy Sherman

title: Relationships Are Hard (But Easy to Talk About)
description: Mafia boss, sex columnist and sports agent are not likely to turn up on anyone's list of most admired professions. But these careers have been very good to HBO. Even before ''The Sopranos,'' with its mobbed-up family values, emerged as last season's best and most talked about show (weekly repeats begin on Wednesday), HBO had built two first-rate series around characters whose jobs are full of satiric possibilities.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLIDES SOME MORE. The dollar gained against the euro as European officials again signaled no commitment to stop the currency's decline. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0343, down from $1.0355 on Wednesday.

title: Commencements; At Hunter, Badillo Asks for Support in CUNY Job
description: As Hunter College graduates collected their diplomas yesterday under cloud-dappled skies in Central Park, they were not allowed to forget the battles over remedial education at the City University of New York; most of the speakers directly or indirectly touched on the subject.

title: Officer Accused of Visiting Brothel During Bike Patrol
description: A police officer was charged with official misconduct yesterday after a four-month investigation revealed that he had been frequenting a Queens brothel while in uniform on bicycle patrol, prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a fatal apartment fire in East Orange, N.J., used an incorrect given name in some copies for a 4-year-old boy who died. He was Jonathan Ingram, not James.

title: A Proven Peacemaker: Martti Ahtisaari
description: Geography, history and some stubborn Nordic patience gave Martti Ahtisaari, 61, the President of Finland, a reasoning power with Slobodan Milosevic and his Russian advocates that no other European leader could match.

title: Are Schools Forced To Play Big Brother?; No Privacy Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE BOOK VENTURE
description: The Softbank Corporation has hooked up with the 7-Eleven Japan Corporation, which is 50 percent owned by the Ito-Yokado Company, and two other Japanese companies to create an Amazon.com-like Internet company to sell Japanese-language books. The venture, named E-Shopping Books, will start service in November with some 1.4 million Japanese titles. Softbank will own 50 percent, while 7-Eleven will own 30 percent. The Tohan Corporation, one of Japan's largest publishers, and the Yahoo Japan Corporation, an Internet directory service owned by Yahoo Inc., will own the rest.

title: The Surreal Eye
description: ''Surrealism: Two Private Eyes,'' a major exhibition of Surrealist art drawn from the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi collections, is at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. It has more than 700 works, including ''The White Race,'' below, a 1937 painting by Rene Magritte.

title: Don't Speak English? No Tax Break, Alabama Official Declares
description: As a vibrant center for space and technology research, this city in northern Alabama owes much of its character to an immigrant, Wernher van Braun, the German rocket scientist who helped create the Marshall Space Flight Center here after World War II. Proud of its international heritage, the city greets visitors today with flapping roadside banners that welcome newcomers in a variety of languages.

title: Factory Orders, Minus Planes, Rise 5th Time in Six Months
description: Orders placed with manufacturers other than airplane makers rose in April, suggesting that a record peacetime expansion may be picking up speed.

title: Web of Expectations Snares Mets
description: About those plans to watch the Subway Series in October, better plan instead to watch the Mets and the Yankees this weekend and July 9-11 and save October for watching the leaves change colors.

title: Accounts
description: * AT&T Wireless, Los Angeles, part of AT&T Corp., to Bravo Group, San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle its local branding account aimed at Hispanic consumers. Billings were estimated at $5 million. Bravo, AT&T's agency of record for Hispanic advertising, was awarded the assignment after resigning a competitive account, Radio Shack, Fort Worth, a unit of Tandy Corp., which was recently awarded to Dieste & Partners, Dallas.

title: NBC Cites Progress In Getting Ads
description: NBC Sports is 60 percent of the way toward meeting its advertising targets for the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, after selling $85 million in new commercial time on Wednesday, said Dick Ebersol, chairman of the division.

title: What Do We Do With Serbia Now?
description: Bombing was easy now the hard work begins. Even a cursory glance at the text of the peace agreement voted upon by Serbian deputies yesterday shows that Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader, has accepted NATO's demands in full.

title: Clearing Firms Under New Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, seeking to combat manipulation of small, thinly traded stocks, said today that it would require clearing firms to report signs of suspicious trading activity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, PENELOPE
description: SCHINDLER - Penelope. Of Quogue and New York City, on June 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Paul, devoted mother of Alexandra, adored daughter of Evangeline and the late Charles Pericone, dear sister of Christine Weingart. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, NY. Graveside services 11 A.M. Saturday at the Quogue Cemetery, Lamb Avenue, Quogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to either of the following: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Strokes, Building 31, Room 8A06, 31 Center Drive, Bethesda, MD 20892-2540, Attn: Gerald Fischbach, Director, ''In Memory of Penny Schindler'' (for Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Research) or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978, ''In Memory of Penny Schindler.''

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Militia Linked To Israel Quits An Enclave In Lebanon
description: Tanks and armored personnel carriers from an Israeli-backed militia rumbled through this town in darkness early today to complete a retreat from the Jezzin enclave, a mountainous, battle-scarred swath of southern Lebanon the militia had held for 14 years.

title: Tracing 30 Years Of Gay Life
description: ''I never heard of the word lesbian, but I knew enough to hide,'' says a woman from North Carolina in ''Before Stonewall,'' the 1984 Emmy Award-winning film by John Scagliotti, Robert Rosenberg and Greta Schiller. Like dozens of homosexuals reared in the 20's and 30's who were interviewed for the documentary, she hid her differences as best she could in the decades before June 27, 1969, when a police raid on the Stonewall Inn in New York City touched off three nights of rioting and effectively launched the gay movement.

title: He's Such An Animal, But Not A Lamb
description: Big thespian guns are rolled out to lay down a barrage of philosophical popcorn in the psychological mystery ''Instinct.''

title: An Insult to Campaign Reform
description: The latest indication of the G.O.P. Congressional leadership's indifference to cleaning up a corrupt campaign financing system is its attitude toward an upcoming vacancy on the Federal Election Commission. Instead of scouring the country for a distinguished individual with a passion for reform, Senate Republicans are said to be considering an Ohio law professor whose writings make plain his hostility to the agency he would be joining and the campaign finance laws it is supposed to enforce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, THOMAS A.
description: LARKIN-Thomas A. (Former member of Goodbody & Co.) on June 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Manning. Loving father of Maureen L. Watson & Edward J. Dear grandfather of 13 and 9 great grandchildren. Visiting on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., McLaughlin & Sons, 3rd Ave at 97th Street. Mass of Christian burial on Saturday 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mount Manresa Jesuit Retreat House, 239 Fingerboard Rd., Staten Island, NY 10305

title: Paine Webber's New Role
description: Paine Webber Group replaced Bankers Trust in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index yesterday after the stock market closed, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said. Deutsche Bank is expected to complete its $10.1 billion acquisition of Bankers Trust today. Shares of the New York-based Paine Webber, the fifth-largest United States securities firm, rose 93.75 cents, to $42.75. Companies' shares typically rise when they join the S.& P. 500 because many mutual funds that try to mimic the performance of the index must buy the shares.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Christopher Cockerell, 88, Inventor, Dies; Father of Hovercraft and Marconi Devices
description: Sir Christopher Cockerell, the creator of the hovercraft, who often came to feel that invention was the mother of frustration, died on Tuesday at his home in Hythe, Hampshire, England. He was 88.

title: A Reunion, Then Racing
description: Fifty years after upsetting Harvard and ending a 14-year winning streak by the Crimson, the 1949 Yale rowing team will return to the site of that victory today and again row down the Thames River in New London, Conn.

title: Moscow Says Its Envoy Was a Key To Success
description: Despite its outspoken criticism of allied bombing raids, Russia played a vital role in advancing NATO's peace plan for Kosovo, Western diplomats and Russian officials said today.

title: Merchants of Violence
description: When President Clinton announced an investigation this week into whether the entertainment industry was irresponsibly marketing violence to teen-agers and young children, he read aloud a few promotional slogans to show why such a study might be in order. ''Kill your friends guilt free,'' an advertisement for one video game promised. Another ad enticed players to ''get in touch with your gun-toting, cold-blooded murdering side.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, GABRIELLE
description: BLUESTEIN-Gabrielle. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Gabrielle (Gaby) Bluestein, a cherished friend who will be greatly missed. She generously supported the Jewish community through her involvement in our Women's Campaign and our Thrift Shop, which was founded by her late husband, Milton. We extend our deepest sympathies to her daughters, Barbara Bluestein and Marion Galison; her grandchildren, Mia, William, and Peter; and her six greatgrandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Colorado Democrats Press Case on Guns
description: Republicans control both houses of the Colorado Legislature and in recent sessions have steamrollered Democratic opposition to bills written to ease the purchase and ownership of guns. In fact, just before the shooting at Columbine High School in Littleton on April 20, Republicans pushed through a bill that barred Colorado cities and towns from filing lawsuits against gun makers, a favorite new tactic of anti-gun forces around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHFELD, FRANCES (NEE ROSENBLUM)
description: HIRSHFELD - Frances (nee Rosenblum). On June 1, 1999, died at home after a valiant struggle with cancer. Holocaust survivor, wife of late Julian J. Hirshfeld, mother of Margaret H. Velard, (Maxime) and Max S. Hirshfeld (Nina), and loving grandmother of Hanah, Julian, Chloe and Justine. Contributions to the United States Holocaust Museum or the American Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated.

title: Ready to Dazzle
description: Annual workshop performances offer students at the School of American Ballet a chance to display their promise. This year's workshops start tomorrow.

title: FUTURELINK AGREES TO BUY EXECUTIVE LAN FOR $51 MILLION
description: The Futurelink Distribution Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Executive LAN Management Inc. of Irvine, Calif., for about $51 million in cash and stock plus future payments. Futurelink, which provides computer equipment, training and maintenance, is to pay $12 million in cash and 6 million shares for Executive LAN, a distributor of server-based computing systems that operates as Micro Visions. Depending on future profit, Futurelink, based in Calgary, Alberta, will pay as many as 2.4 million more shares, valued at $15.5 million at Wednesday's closing price. The shares of Futurelink, which had 1998 revenue of $2.4 million, rose $1.53, to $7.97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGAN, PETER M.
description: PAGAN-Peter M. Died Wednesday, June 2, 1999. Born in Australia and U.S. citizen for many years. Peter had a distinguished acting career and was a man of great dignity, charm, wit and humor. He will be deeply missed by friends around the world. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Actors' Fund of America, 729 Seventh Ave, NYC 10019, would be appreciated. No service planned at Peter's request.

title: Greater Demands Now Fall on Dudley, Camby and Thomas
description: The crowd of reporters milled close by today while Chris Dudley clanged free throw after free throw around the rim, then shuffled behind him when he moved to get water. Patrick Ewing had left the Knicks after their practice, figuratively and literally. Now it was Dudley -- Ewing's likely replacement in the starting lineup on Saturday, although Coach Jeff Van Gundy would not say for sure -- who drew everyone's attention.

title: Poised Agassi Is Talk of Paris
description: His recent divorce from Brooke Shields may be the talk of Hollywood, but here in Paris, it is Andre Agassi's solo act at Roland Garros that has become the talk of the town. The fans perform the wave for him, he responds with air-blown kisses, and now he is in his first French Open semifinal since 1992.

title: Rio Journal; The Ultimate Indignity: Fabled Beaches Are Soiled
description: To the six and a half million people who live in Rio, Copacabana and Ipanema are not merely beaches, but also the soul and main calling card of this city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIPHANT, MOLLIE
description: OLIPHANT-Mollie. On June 2, 1999, at age 94. Adored mother of Jane, Tony, Steven and Peter. Loved and loving grandmother to Matthew, Simon, Seth, Wendy, Jenna, Hanna and ''Nana'' to her loved great-grandson, Benjamin. Cherished by Cathy Green, Linda Glasser, Judy Yanover, her daughters-in-law. A woman of infinite kindness. Services will be held Sunday 10AM at the Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OMERON, GUENETH C.
description: OMERON-Gueneth C. Memorial Service Thursday, June 10, 1999, 11AM, Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLATTERMAN, ANNE
description: GLATTERMAN-Anne. On June 2, 1999. Most devoted sister to brother Abe and the late Morris, Esther and Aaron. Most devoted aunt to many nieces & nephews and most devoted friend to many. May she rest in eternal peace. Service Friday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 Reporters Are Ordered to Jail Over Suspect in Olympic Blast
description: A Federal judge in Atlanta yesterday ordered two reporters for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution to be jailed for refusing to reveal who told them that Richard A. Jewell, a part-time security guard, was a leading suspect in the bombing at the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

title: Brooklyn Academy Gala Honors Retiring Chief
description: After 32 years at the Brooklyn Academy of Music characterized by impeccable taste and shrewd showmanship, Harvey Lichtenstein went out last night in a hyperbolic blaze of impeccable taste and shrewd showmanship billed as ''The Harvey Gala'' at the academy's Opera House.

title: Gauges Mixed in Anticipation of Jobs Data
description: Stock prices meandered to a mixed finish yesterday as traders and investors awaited today's release of the Government's monthly report on the job market, which will provide the first broad look at the economy's performance in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, LEONARD
description: DUBIN-Leonard. On June 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Alan and Rose. Devoted grandfather of Lisette, Justin, Zachary, Olivia and Brandon. Served in U.S. Army Air Corps 1942-1943 and awarded Purple Heart for wounds received in action. He will be with us always. Service Sunday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Exiled Leaders of Tiananmen Gather to Mull Errors and Accomplishments
description: For the first time since soldiers drove them at gunpoint from Beijing's Tiananmen Square 10 years ago, the top leaders of China's democracy movement gathered at Harvard University today, like alumni converging for a reunion on the leafy New England campus.

title: Telmex Sells $1 Billion in Convertible Bonds
description: Telefonos de Mexico, the nation's biggest phone company, sold $1 billion of five-year bonds today that can be swapped for stock. It was the largest convertible-bond issue by a Latin American company.

title: Memories of June 4 Fade, Stunted by Public Silence
description: While emotional memorials to the 1989 Tiananmen massacre were held in cities from Hong Kong to New York this week, on the streets of Beijing there was nervous silence.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about social class as a predictor of health misstated the correlation between employees' perception of job control and employment grade. It was a direct correlation, not an inverse one: the higher the grade, the more perception of control, and therefore the better predictor of good health.

title: Testaverde And Palmer Draw Cheers
description: Vinny Testaverde, who created golf memories for himself today, and Arnold Palmer, who evokes memories for his fans every time he plays, teamed up in the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic, in which football players join the pros on the PGA Senior Tour.

title: Leah Ray Werblin, Singer, 82
description: Leah Ray Werblin, a vocalist in the Big Band era and later, with her husband, the owner of the Elberon Farm in thoroughbred racing, died in her sleep May 27 at her home in Rumson, N.J. She was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LURAY, MARTIN
description: LURAY-Martin. You remain a loving part of our lives, forever. Edith, Jennifer, Jo

title: In Washington, Wary Reaction But Also Relief
description: President Clinton cautiously welcomed word of Yugoslavia's apparent acceptance of international peace terms for Kosovo today, and top officials of the White House, State Department and Pentagon all publicly echoed his skepticism about whether President Slobodan Milosevic would carry out the terms.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: William Anastasi

title: South Africa's Lost Generation
description: My brother called me last week from South Africa to tell me that my favorite uncle had been shot by a young man who wanted his cell phone. It drove home how out of control crime and violence have become in my homeland. Still, I have reason to hope that Thabo Mbeki, Nelson Mandela's successor as President, will redress the injustices that are partly to blame for the upward spiral of crime and violence that threatens the future of South Africa's fragile democracy.

title: Luck, and What Bush Made of It
description: To the Editor:

title: CATHAY PACIFIC CANCELLATIONS
description: Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong's only long-haul carrier, canceled 56 of 117 flights, the largest number since pilots began calling in sick almost a week ago in a contract dispute with the airline. But Cathay replaced 27 of the canceled flights with aircraft chartered from 10 other carriers. The airline expects the disruption to continue at least until June 11, when senior pilots must either sign new contracts cutting their pay or take early retirement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, HYMAN
description: GOTTLIEB-Hyman. On June 3rd, 1999 of Wyncote, PA, formerly of Oceanside, NY. Husband of Sylvia (nee Berlin), father of David Gottlieb, Martin Gottlieb, Rose Sluzas and Susan Collings, brother of Seymour Gottlieb and Esther Gilbert. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial services will be announced at a later date in Oceanside, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Joint Distribution Comm. of the UJA. Joseph Levine & Son, Philadelphia.

title: Three Ring Is in Acorn
description: Three Ring survived the Kentucky Derby and lived to race another day -- today, against her own sex, in the Grade I Acorn. In the roughly raced Derby, the filly perhaps had the roughest trip of all when she was crushed coming out of the No. 1 post position and her saddle slipped around her neck. She ended up last in a field of 19 horses, 20 lengths behind Charismatic.

title: The Persistent Mystery: How Many Died in 1989?
description: It remains a mystery to this day: How many people were killed in the crackdown near Tiananmen Square on the night of June 3-4, 1989?

title: City Games, With a Dash of Mustard
description: There will be pressure on the Mets to emerge from their deepest slump of the season against a superior team in enemy territory. There will be pressure on the Yankees to show they are the best team in the five boroughs and to satisfy George Steinbrenner. There will be pressure for three hectic days at Yankee Stadium because it is New York against New York in baseball and there is really nothing else that compares.

title: Painting Packs a Million-Dollar Surprise
description: The Museum of Fine Arts in Houston has paid $1.25 million for a still life painting that for years covered a hole in the wall in an Indiana home, its value unknown to the owner and its existence unknown to art experts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSYNS, ANNE
description: COSYNS-Anne, French translator and former haute couture model. Loving and devoted daughter, survived by her son, died with dignity May 29, 1999. Memorial for our much loved friend on Friday, June 4th, 6-9PM at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC. Interment in her homeland Belgium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSKY, IDA
description: PINSKY-Ida. On June 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Nat. Loving sister of George Morris. Dear aunt of Judge Judith Kaye, Dr. Arnold Tein, Allen Smith and Allen Pensky. Also survived by grandnieces and nephews. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; CEMENT DEAL
description: Cemex S.A. de C.V., the world's third-largest cement producer and one of Mexico's largest companies, bought nearly 12 percent of Cementos Bio-Bio S.A., a Chilean cement manufacturer, which has the capacity to produce 2.25 million metric tons of cement a year. The $34 million investment in Bio-Bio is the first time Cemex, which also has operations in Venezuela, Colombia and Panama, has invested in Chile. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: At most restaurants, diners ask for the wine list. At two-month-old Blackbird, they want the cocktail list. Dale DeGroff, whose cheflike approach to cocktails turned the Rainbow Room's Promenade Bar into holy ground for the martini set, has picked up where he left off, this time shaking his shaker behind Blackbird's large, marble-topped horseshoe bar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, PHILIP H., JR.
description: REISMAN-Philip H., Jr. TV and screen writer of Larchmont, NY. Died June 1st. at Sound Shore Medical Center, New Rochelle. He was 82. Husband of Anna T. Reisman and father of Christopher, Peter, Philip III, the Rev. Catherine T.R. MacDonald and Irene M. Biada. Memorial service 10:30 a.m. Saturday at Larchmont Avenue Church, 60 Forest Park Avenue, Larchmont, NY. Contributions may be sent to the church.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Roche to Pay $4.2 Billion For the Rest of Genentech

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCREYNOLDS, ALICE BROOKE
description: McREYNOLDS - Alice Brooke. Died peacefully at home in New York City on May 30, 1999. Survived by a niece, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Miss McReynolds was a noted collector of Chinese snuff bottles and Oriental porcelains. A memorial service will be held on June 15th at 11:00 AM at Trinity Church Cemetery, 770 Riverside Drive at 153 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Brooklyn Botanical Gardens or The Salmagundi Club would be gratefully appreciated.

title: Orioles Claim Yankee Catcher
description: The Baltimore Orioles claimed Mike Figga off waivers from the Yankees today, 10 days after he was designated for assignment.

title: Foote, Cone Gets Regus Account
description: Regus Business Centers P.L.C. in London, which owns and leases staffed and equipped office space in 43 countries, has awarded its account to the London and New York offices of Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide, part of True North Communications. Billings for the account, which had been handled by various small agencies on a regional basis, were estimated at $40 million.

title: New Vienna (Circa 1900)
description: ''To the Age, It's Art'' was the rallying cry of the Vienna Secessionists in 1900, when the architect Josef Hoffmann and the other founders of the Secession were proclaiming the need for a new style for a new era. They had rejected the historicism of the late 1800's, when the Emperor Franz Josef commissioned a Greek temple Parliament, a Gothic City Hall and Baroque apartment houses on the Ringstrasse, the wide boulevard that circles Vienna. The Ringstrasse became a metaphor for everything antiquated and passe, and helped galvanize a design revolution.

title: Stalemate on State Budget Eases as Assembly Yields
description: Prospects for approving a state budget moved today from abject stalemate to the realm of serious negotiation as Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver agreed to cut his house's spending proposals by $1 billion or more, the first significant movement by any side in three months.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Superflex and Martin Walde

title: Flying in the Face of Convention
description: It was a sweltering July afternoon and Bob Baffert thought he was done buying horses. Before he climbed in his car, however, he caught sight of a bay filly ready to enter the sales ring. She wasn't on his shopping list. When he took a closer look, he noticed her knees were off center. But the California trainer was bowled over by her athletic look.

title: Luck, and What Bush Made of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, FLORENCE
description: ABRAMS-Florence. On June 3, of NYC. Beloved wife of Reuben W. Abrams. Cherished mother of Marc Ira Abrams. Dear mother-inlaw of Toni Abrams. Graveside services Sunday, 1:00 PM at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital Fund, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bx, NY 10461

title: Child Seat Program
description: CHRYSLER and Mercedes-Benz dealers will begin a new service later this year: inspecting child safety seats for problems with size, installation or wear.

title: Coleman Signs One-Year Deal
description: The Washington Redskins signed the free-agent defensive end Marco Coleman to a one-year, $400,000 contract with a $600,000 signing bonus.

title: Broadway Holds Its Breath
description: Forget the stock market. Never mind the Belmont. If you have a farm, bet it.

title: Procter & Gamble to Trim Jobs and Close Plants
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is expected to announce next week that it will cut thousands of jobs worldwide, close several underperforming plants and take a huge charge to become more competitive and improve profits, according to analysts and institutional investors who have met with management.

title: Feeling Rich? Don't Get Smug Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: On Eve of Main Event, Belmont Feels All Abuzz
description: Belmont Park is ready -- from the eight busloads of extra security people and mutuel clerks shipping in from Saratoga, to the steeplechase horses jumping and the fillies running, to the strolling bands and the street festival, to the $2 million in purses, to the parking valets decked out in tuxedos to greet the customers as they arrive tomorrow to see, for the third consecutive year, if a horse can sweep the Triple Crown.

title: Free and Confused by Infinite Possibility
description: WHO'S IRISH

title: On My Mind; Meeting At Tiananmen
description: Anniversary statement time. For a few days, in America and Europe, politicians will express sorrow at the murder of the young Chinese shot down in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, because they had gathered to cry out for freedom.

title: Gambling Panel to Call for Array of Limits
description: After two years spent studying the social and economic effects of the gambling industry's vast growth, a Federal commission completed its work here today and prepared to deliver a list of more than 70 recommendations to President Clinton, Congress, governors and Indian leaders.

title: Defense in Louima Brutality Case Maintains Torturer Acted Alone
description: In the final day of arguments in the Abner Louima police brutality case, the lawyer for a police officer charged with holding Mr. Louima down while Justin A. Volpe tortured him declared yesterday that his client was the victim of an unjustified attempt to widen the case beyond ''one sick, depraved'' officer.

title: Bergman Continues His Story
description: ''In the Presence of a Clown'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3, 1998. The film opens today at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, BENJAMIN
description: EISEN-Benjamin, on June 3, 1999. Devoted father of Linda. Funeral services private.

title: Opposite of Gloom: Time to Be Gaily Gay
description: If asked to describe the mood of the 11th Annual New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival based only on its opening and closing features, this year's events might be characterized as Giddy Gay Lite. Both Rose Troche's ''Bedrooms and Hallways,'' which opened the festival last night, and Jim Fall's ''Trick,'' which closes the series on June 13, partake of the same heady spirit that has characterized recent semi-mainstream films like ''The Opposite of Sex'' and ''Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss.'' In the world of Giddy Gay Lite, gay liberation is almost a fait accompli, the AIDS epidemic barely exists and rampant homophobia is somewhere else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLO, VIRGINIA
description: GALLO-Virginia. Of Somers, NY, on June 2nd, 1999. Wife of the late Fred. Mother of Fred, Jr., Steven, Michael and Nancy. Grandmother of Andrew, Stephanie, Michelle, Nicholas and Geoffrey. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Saturday, 1 to 4 PM Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ann's Church, Yonkers, on Monday, June 7th, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Meals-on-Wheels, P.O. Box 236, Lincolndale, NY 10540.

title: Daredevils And Directors Defy Death!
description: As pretty as a gas-station calendar, as covered with sponsors' names and insignia as a stock car, ''Extreme'' is the latest of the Imax films that uses the couch potato's favorite medium, the screen, to deify those who thrill to the challenges of the great outdoors.

title: DEAL FOR HILLSDOWN
description: After a fierce bidding war, the Dallas-based investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst emerged as the likely victor in a battle with Candover Partners Ltd. to acquire Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C., a food-and-furniture business. Hicks, Muse, which controls 29.9 percent of the company, raised its bid to 147 pence ($2.35), 2 pence higher than Candover's last bid. The deal values Hillsdown at $859.2 million. Hicks also assume more than $456 million Hillsdown debt.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Mayoral Adviser May Head West

title: NEC SAYS MORE JOB CUTS ARE POSSIBLE AT PACKARD BELL
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's largest maker of personal computers and chips, said yesterday that its unprofitable United States subsidiary Packard Bell NEC Inc. had lost more money than expected in April and May, and that more job cuts could be made at the unit. Packard Bell, based in Sacramento, Calif., was the biggest drag on NEC's performance in the year ending March 31, as slumping sales and the cost of reorganization at the subsidiary caused NEC a record loss of 157.9 billion yen ($1.29 billion). NEC cut Packard Bell's work force by 3,000 and reduced its number of computer models last year in a bid to shrink the subsidiary's losses.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Loose Ends Off Broadway

title: 2 Charged With Insider Trading On Takeovers
description: For two years, a junior investment banker at Salomon Smith Barney and his former boss at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Trust Company thought they had devised a foolproof plan to make millions through insider trading. But yesterday they were charged with criminal securities fraud and conspiracy by the United States Attorney and civil insider-trading violations by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with 13 potential and announced takeovers.

title: Agreement Is Near on Proposal To Move Some Police to Streets
description: City Council leaders and the Giuliani administration are nearing agreement on a plan to move 500 to 950 police officers from administrative jobs to street duty, officials involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Undermining a Myth
description: When it comes to restaurants, no part of New York is as maligned as the Upper West Side. Yes, few high-end restaurants prosper there, and the star hangouts are decidedly elsewhere, but there is no shortage of enjoyable places to eat. Here are a dozen. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: EUROPEAN UNION VOWS TO BECOME MILITARY POWER
description: The leaders of 15 European countries decided today to make the European Union a military power for the first time in its 42-year history, with command headquarters, staffs and forces of its own for peacekeeping and peacemaking missions in future crises like those in Kosovo or Bosnia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUMBARD, JOSEPH EDWARD JR.
description: LUMBARD-Joseph Edward Jr. 97. On June 3, 1999. Husband of the late Polly Poindexter Lumbard. Father of Abigail of Seattle, and Thomas of Washington, DC. Grandfather of Thomas E. Bosworth of Olympia, WA; David Bosworth of Monroe, WA; and Sarah E. and Joseph E. B. Lumbard of Washington, DC. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Lumbard Fund of the New York Community Trust, 2 Park Ave., NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROBIN S.
description: WEINSTEIN-Robin S. A dear and cherished friend, our hero. The Robins

title: MORE ON THE PLAN
description: TROOP MANEUVERS -- The first of nearly 50,000 NATO troops will begin moving into Kosovo within days of a final agreement. Yugoslavia's Army, police and paramilitary forces are to withdraw in stages over seven days. Page A21.

title: To Lava Woman, Earth Is a Molten Wonder
description: THE concepts of time, of beauty, of dramatic narrative have a meaning for Rosamond Kinzler that many earthlings would consider unconventional. But to her, they are profoundly conventional, withstanding the trade winds of trend since their origins are about 4.5 billion years old.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Big Board Will Delay Its Decision On Late Hours
description: After hearing concerns from big investment firms, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would delay any extension of its trading hours until at least the second half of 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, REV. MSGR. ARTHUR J.
description: KANE-Rev. Msgr. Arthur J. on June 2, 1999. Founding Pastor of St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, Melville, NY. Former Spiritual Director St. Vincent de Paul Society for the Diocese of Rockville Centre. Chaplain Melville Fire Department, Former Curate of St. Ignatius Martyr, Long Beach, NY and St. Teresa's, Woodside, NY. Devoted son of the late John A. Kane and Helena McDonald Kane. Loving brother of Helen Moloney of West Hempstead, NY and the late John, Mary and Dr. Edwin P. Kane. Revered brother-in-law of John Moloney and Mary Kane. Cherished uncle of Arthur Moloney of Floral Park, NY, Mary Ellen Lohne of Garden City, NY, Bernadette McKinney of Mt. Lakes, NJ, Helena Finn US Embassy Ankara, Turkey, Katherine Markiewicz of New Canaan, CT., Dr. Mary Kane-Goldstein of Palo Alto, CA, Joan Dougherty of Huntington, NY, Dr. Edwin P. Kane II of Ridgewood, NJ, John Kane of Huntington, NY, Regina McNamara of Easton, CT. Adored great uncle to nine grandnieces and nine grandnephews. Also survived by many cousins. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Friday and Saturday 2-5, 7-9 pm. Sunday 3:30pm at St. Elizabeth's until Mass of Transferral 8pm. Funeral Mass Monday 11am at St. Elizabeth's. Interment Calvery Cemetery Woodside,N.Y. Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Monsignor's name to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o Mr. Ray Murphy, St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, 175 Wolf Hill Road, Melville, NY 11747.

title: Justice Dept. Is Said to Be Close to a Decision on Indicting a Chinese Company
description: In a diplomatically sensitive case, the Justice Department is nearing a decision on whether to indict one of China's most powerful state-owned corporations, law-enforcement officials and lawyers say.

title: Leaps of Faith In the Future
description: The journey to the stage starts with a plie, one arm resting on a ballet studio barre. Month by month, year by year, ballet classes get harder and the stakes higher. At last come a first few experiences in a theater as a tiny, nervous cog in the huge machinery of a ballet production.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Christian Schumann

title: Crombie Taylor, 85, Architect Who Helped Champion Bauhaus
description: Crombie Taylor, an architect and teacher who helped spread the influence of the Bauhaus to American architecture during the 1940's, died on May 24. He was 85 and lived in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: $253 Million Sanctions Sought in Beef Fight With Europe
description: A trans-Atlantic fight over hormone-treated beef intensified today when United States and Canadian officials asked the World Trade Organization to approve $253 million in retaliatory trade sanctions and the European Union countered by demanding arbitration that it hopes will lower the overall amount.

title: Murdered Blacks Were Martyrs to Racial Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Feeling Rich? Don't Get Smug Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: For Pacers, Opposing Load Isn't Lighter
description: Reggie Miller said winning the Eastern Conference finals may be more difficult for the Indiana Pacers now that Patrick Ewing is out for the year. Antonio Davis chimed in that the Knicks may be more motivated after losing the cornerstone of their franchise.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Ideal Time For Wilde?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. January 9, 1931-May 6, 1997. Happy Anniversary, Handsome. I love you, Beautiful

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/ Safety; More Trucks on Road: Should Rules Change?
description: DRIVERS of cars may have the impression that there are more big trucks competing with them for space on the highway, and recent Government statistics confirm that their perception is correct. And although road fatalities are down over all, those involving heavy trucks are fairly level, at more than 5,000 a year.

title: Pataki Picks Abortion Foe As New State Health Chief
description: After a protracted search, Gov. George E. Pataki nominated Dr. Antonia C. Novello, the former United States Surgeon General, as New York's Health Commissioner today, drawing cries of betrayal from the abortion rights movement because Dr. Novello, unlike the Governor, opposes abortion.

title: A Buoyant May at Retailers As Shopping Spree Goes On
description: United States retailers posted robust sales in May as consumers continued to show great confidence in the economy by snatching up everything from wardrobes in summer white to pool furniture.

title: Inquiry Ordered Into Killing by Police
description: The Morris County Prosecutor today ordered a grand jury investigation into the actions of four police officers who fired 27 bullets at a stopped car on Interstate 80 early Wednesday, killing an unarmed man who had led them on a high-speed chase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HELENE B.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Helene B. Died on her birthday at age 67 Thursday, June 3. Wife of her husband of 43 years, Joe Goldstein and mother of sons Robert, Adam and Jared. Services today 10:30 at Garment Center Congregation, 205 West 40th St. Interment following at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens. Shiva calls at residence, 5 Treadwell, Old Westbury, New orkY following graveside service and on Sunday.

title: Kosovo Problems Just Beginning
description: Even if the agreement reached today with Slobodan Milosevic ends the bombing of Yugoslavia, staggering problems lie ahead, first among them the repatriation of nearly a million Kosovars to the land of ashes and graves that was their home.

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail biography of Herman Badillo on Monday, with an article about his appointment as chairman of the City University of New York, misspelled the name of the Manhattan high school he attended. It was Haaren, not Haaran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, ERNEST M., D.P.M.
description: WEINER-Ernest M., D.P.M. The Officers and Board of Trustees of the New York State Podiatric Medical Association mourn the passing of a former president of the Association. A gifted and respected practitioner, and an esteemed colleague and friend, he was a tireless and forceful advocate for his profession and for the advancement of podiatric medical education. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ethel, and to his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATNER, FRANK
description: LATNER-Frank. Mannes College of Music mourns the untimely passing of our colleague, Frank Latner, beloved teacher and longtime mentor of so many of our students.

title: Making Mincemeat of Boomer Values
description: It comes as only a small surprise that a character in ''Hurrah at Last'' suddenly breaks into an Italian aria, since the scale of Richard Greenberg's eccentric new comedy, which opened last night at the Gramercy Theater, is nothing if not operatic.

title: PUB TAKEOVER BATTLE
description: A closely held British pub company, Punch Taverns Group Ltd., said it planned to make a hostile all-cash offer of about $:2.6 billion, or $4.2 billion, for Allied Domecq P.L.C.'s British pubs business. The offer exceeds a friendly bid by the food-and-liquor giant Whitbread P.L.C., which is valued at $:2.4 billion ($3.8 billion) in stock.

title: Trolling the Mind's Nooks and Crannies for Images
description: No one could accuse Nesuhi Ertegun (1917-1989) and Daniel Filipacchi of lacking focus as collectors. Over the years, they translated their passion for Surrealism into hundreds of acquisitions ranging from paintings to beautifully bound books. The roster of artists includes such expected names as Max Ernst, Salvador Dali and Giorgio de Chirico along with lesser lights like Clovis Trouille, whose 1946 painting, ''Oh! Calcutta! Calcutta!,'' inspired the title of the Broadway musical and became the image for its poster. Today, their humongous holdings are enough to pack the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum from ceiling to lobby with a powerful exhibition, ''Surrealism: Two Private Eyes, the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi Collections.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA SOARS. Prices for cocoa rose more than 10 percent on speculation that West African growers have few supplies left after a selling spree. In New York, cocoa for July delivery rose $97 a metric ton, to $1,023.

title: Europeans Impressed By Their Own Unity
description: Gerhard Schroder, the German Chancellor and current president of the European Union, opened tonight's news conference in Cologne with the words, ''This is a good day for Europe.''

title: On Your Mark: A Runner Gets Back on His Feet, Racing
description: After racing frequently for more than two decades, I lost my taste for competition three years ago and went into racing exile. I cut back my running while expanding cross-training endeavors like bicycling, swimming and pool running. Health and well-being, not peak performance, became my focus. I used to run 40 miles a week. Now I run 40 miles a month.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Information Gaps

title: Van Strikes and Kills Priest From Honduras
description: A Roman Catholic priest visiting Manhattan from his missionary posting in Honduras was hit by a van and killed yesterday in midtown, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLATT, FAY
description: GLATT-Fay. On June 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Max, loving mother of Estell. She will be missed by many. Service Friday 10:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 4 in Brooklyn Accused Of Prostituting Teen-Ager
description: Two men and two women were arrested yesterday on charges that they forced a 15-year-old runaway to work as a prostitute, and the police said they expected to charge the suspects with forcing several other girls to do the same thing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the moderate weather in New York City for much of May misstated a statistic about rainy May days in past years. This was the third May since 1969, not the first, with only seven days of measurable rainfall.

title: Talking About Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexander Cuts Staff And Travel
description: After months of watching Republican dollars bypass Tennessee in a mighty rush toward Texas, Lamar Alexander moved to hoard his disappointing campaign treasury today, laying off four top staff members and curtailing his travels.

title: Kosovo Peace Accord: 10 Steps to a Verifiable End of Violence
description: Following is the text of the international proposal to end the Kosovo conflict that was accepted today by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. The text was provided by the State Department.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Are Schools Forced To Play Big Brother?; Let Congress Step In
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVANCED IN $117 MILLION DEAL FOR 2 INTERNET COMPANIES
description: Advanced Communications Group Inc. is buying two Internet companies for about $117 million in stock to transform itself from a Midwest phone-service provider into an Internet yellow pages and advertising company. It said it would issue about 12.5 million shares to buy YPTel Corporation, a Toronto company that publishes yellow pages and operates the Internet phone directory Worldpages.com, and Big Stuff Inc., a Web-page producer. Advanced, of St. Louis, is selling its phone business, with $114 million in sales last year, and will change its name to Worldpages.com. Its stock rose 56.25 cents, to $9.9375.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLAIN, RALPH E.
description: CHAMBERLAIN-Ralph E. Died on June 2, 1999, at his home in Fly Creek, NY, age 72. A well-known businessman and philanthropist, he was Founder and Chairman of the Board of several businesses, including Precise Kit Promotions, Inc. and Holland Estill, Inc. Mr. Chamberlain dedicated much of his life to education, health and arts programs, including Hartwick College in Oneonta, NY, Bassett Healthcare and Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, NY, and the Metropolitan Opera. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him.
