Survived by his wife, Ellen; his three daughters, Sharon Wagner of Pompton Lakes, NJ, Elizabeth Richards of Seabrook Island, SC and Samantha Chamberlain of Fly Creek; his two sons, Ralph E. Chamberlain, Jr. of Westwood, NJ and Richard Chamberlain of Fly Creek; his stepdaughter, Elisabeth Smith of Northampton, MA; his stepson, Peter Smith of Burlington Flats, NY; his motherin-law, Agnes (Peg) Harrington of Cooperstown; eleven grandchildren; his two brothers, Robert Chamberlain of Depew, NY and Rev. Charles Chamberlain of Thomasville, NC and Castleton, VT; and several nieces and nephews. Funeral service, 2 PM, Sunday, June 6, at Christ Episcopal Church, Cooperstown. Friends may call at Connell, Dow & Deysenroth Funeral Home, 82 Chestnut Street, Cooperstown, Saturday, 7-9 PM. Interment, Lakewood Cemetery, Cooperstown. Donations in his memory may be made to the Ralph E. Chamberlain Memorial Fund for the benefit of Bassett Healthcare, Glimmerglass Opera and Hartwick College, P.O. Box 414, Cooperstown, NY 13326-0414 or Catskill Area Hospice and Palliative Care, Inc., 542 Main Street, Oneonta, NY 13820 or the Salvation Army, National Headquarters, 615 Slaters Lane, P.O. Box 269, Alexandria, VA 22313.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mary Lucier

title: EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY FLORIDA TV STATION
description: The Emmis Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy WKCF-TV, a WB Network affiliate in Orlando, Fla., from Press Communications L.L.C. for $191.5 million. Emmis said WKCF agreed to extended its relationship with the WB Network until 2009. Emmis Communications also said the acquisition ''in no way detracts'' from the company's primary business, radio. Emmis Communications, based in Indianapolis, also has interests in magazines.

title: Nets Might Withdraw Offer To Jackson and Hire Casey
description: Having had Phil Jackson shake his head at what would be the richest coaching contract in National Basketball Association history, the Nets are leaning toward giving the interim coach, Don Casey, the head job on a permanent basis, a Nets official said.

title: Roche Exercises Its Option For All Genentech Shares
description: Roche Holding A.G., the European drug maker, said today that it would exercise its right to buy the 33 percent of Genentech Inc. it does not already own.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Circus Parade Hid Another

title: An International Banking Panel Proposes Ways to Limit Risk
description: The top global banking regulator introduced proposals today that would strengthen protections against bad loans and subject the risk-assessment operations of big international banks to greater supervision.

title: Faulty Warning Labels Add to Risk in Prescription Drugs
description: The computer printout that Pat and Ben Christen picked up along with their son's medicine included a string of warnings: Dry mouth. Constipation. Blurred vision. Drowsiness. Dizziness. These were just a few of the side effects of the drug imipramine, which a psychiatrist had prescribed for the Christens' 7-year-old son, Cory, who suffered from attention deficit disorder.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN D.
description: GERSON-Ivan D. ''A unique man.'' Your 5th birthday in heaven. We love and miss you so much. Happy Birthday and Rest Peacefully, Our Dear Ivan. Hugs and Kisses. Mom, Dad and Adrienne

title: The Kosovo Peace Plan
description: Unless Slobodan Milosevic is playing diplomatic games, the war in Yugoslavia is ending. Thanks to the resolve of NATO and constructive peacemaking by Russia, Mr. Milosevic yesterday accepted settlement terms that he had repeatedly rejected. Assuming critical details can be worked out with Belgrade, more than a million displaced ethnic Albanians should be able to return home safely later this year and ethnic cleansing in the Balkans will stop. If so, the most dangerous military conflict in Europe since the Second World War will conclude as a victory for the principles of democracy and human rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCELL, NATHAN S.
description: ANCELL-Nathan S. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of esteemed benefactor and devoted friend, Nathan Ancell. For over six decades, Mr. Ancell was a pillar of the Jewish community who provided his tireless leadership, energies and talents, as well as meaningful support to a wide range of vital Jewish causes both here and in Israel. Nathan Ancell was particularly attracted to Bar-Ilan University's concept of combining excellence in academic studies with Judaic Studies. He was a valued member of the University's Presidential Founders Society and also supported scholarships for students at Bar-Ilan. His generosity, leadership and warm-hearted spirit set a meaningful example for others to emulate. He will be deeply missed by all those who had the privilege to know him. May the entire family derive solace from inspiring memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman Chancellor Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive VP, Mrs. Leora Halevy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALATAN, BELLE
description: GALATAN-Belle. Beloved wife of the late Robert Maurice Galatan. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Glen, Harris and Helga, Hayley and Arnie. She will always be in our thoughts. Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, New Jersey, Friday, June 4, 1:45 PM.

title: Excerpts From Closing Arguments in Louima Trial
description: Following are excerpts from the closing arguments in the case of the torture of Abner Louima. The final two defense lawyers summarized their cases yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Stephen C. Worth is the lawyer for Officer Charles Schwarz, who is charged with restraining Mr. Louima while another officer shoved a stick into his rectum, and with beating Mr. Louima in a police car. John Patten is the lawyer for Sgt. Michael Bellomo, who is charged with trying to cover up the beating in the police car.

title: An Intellectual Guerrilla: Thabo Mbeki
description: As Winnie Madikizela-Mandela shouted recently to a cheering crowd in a black township: ''I'm sick and tired of white-controlled media who say they don't know Thabo Mbeki. Who cares?''

title: Weary and Wary, the Serbs Are Bitter
description: It was hard to find anyone in Belgrade today who expressed support for President Slobodan Milosevic, but with the news of a peace deal, the recriminations came unusually swiftly.

title: $2.6 Million To Settle Suit Over Sexual Harassment
description: A family-owned alcohol importer based in New Rochelle, N.Y., has agreed to pay $2.6 million to 104 women who charge that they were sexually harassed by the 79-year-old owner and president of the company, according to the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Gorillas in the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about commencement at the City University of New York misstated City College's admission requirements. Students must have at least an 80 grade-point average and must have taken specific Regents-level courses in high school; a high school diploma is not the sole criterion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 27 about the arrest of the chairman of the Dutchess County Republican Party on extortion charges misidentified the municipality that is the center of a continuing Federal and state investigation into corruption. It is the Town of Poughkeepsie, not the City of Poughkeepsie.

title: Damaged, and Stranded on an Island
description: Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant in ''Notting Hill'' may be the year's most adorable screen couple. But in evoking a burgeoning, thorny grown-up relationship laden with heavy baggage, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and David Strathairn run rings around them in John Sayles's powerful, boldly discursive film ''Limbo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, PAULA R.
description: BERGER-Paula R. Passed away June 2, 1999 (19th Sivan, 5759). Beloved wife of the late Saul Berger, loving mother of Stephen Berger and Bonnie GraBois, adoring grandmother of Dr. Melissa DelBello, (David), Andy GraBois, Robin Berger and Diana Berger. Devoted mother-in-law to Stuart GraBois and Cynthia Wainwright. Born in Poland, she came to New York City at the age of 6-seized its offerings & in turn contributed to its betterment. Political reformer, dedicated to her family, faith and community. Funeral service Friday at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in lieu of flowers, Community Synagogue, 325 East 6th St., NY NY 10003.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: Affairs of the Human Heart, Tangled in a Forest of Fairies
description: A Midsummer Night's Dream

title: Rivlin, No. 2 Official to Greenspan, Quits at Fed
description: Alice M. Rivlin resigned today as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, leaving the No. 2 job empty at the central bank as it confronts a tough call on whether to raise interest rates.

title: Going Modern in Mexico And Trying to Solve Life
description: In a letter Tina Modotti wrote Edward Weston in 1925, she said: ''I cannot -- as you once proposed to me 'solve the problem of life by losing myself in the problem of art' -- Not only I cannot do that but I even feel that the problem of life hinders my problem of art.'' She went on, ''Life is always struggling to predominate and art naturally suffers.''

title: African National Congress Re-elected in Landslide
description: The African National Congress won a second term today in a landslide victory that will probably give South Africa's next President, Thabo Mbeki, control of more than two-thirds of Parliament.

title: Are Schools Forced To Play Big Brother?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, DAVID I.K.
description: HECHT-David I.K. On May 30, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Anne. Loving father of David. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Mets, Hoping to Fix Outfield, Look Bonilla and McRae's Way
description: In a move seemingly loaded with wishful thinking, the Mets have asked irrevocable waivers on outfielders Bobby Bonilla and Brian McRae, officials of three other clubs said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are three things to watch as this unfolds. First, the war isn't over until the bombing stops. Second, it's not a success until the refugees return. And third, it will not hold until the K.L.A. is disarmed.''

title: Willes Resigns as Publisher Of The Los Angeles Times
description: Mark H. Willes, chief executive of the Times Mirror Company and publisher of its flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, has for the last 19 months used the publisher's job to advance his argument that the newspaper business can thrive if only it is willing to reinvent itself. Yesterday, he resigned as publisher, saying his corporate duties require his full attention.

title: A Cuban Band's Testament To the Powers of the Music
description: The most incandescent moment in Wim Wenders's exhilarating documentary portrait of the Cuban ensemble Buena Vista Social Club is a concert performance of the song ''El Cuarto de Tula'' filmed last July at Carnegie Hall. Sung by the band's septuagenarian lead singer, Ibrahim Ferrer, who is described as a Cuban Nat (King) Cole, the song is a sexy musical fire alarm alerting the world to a blaze in the bedroom of a woman who forgot to blow out a candle before falling asleep.

title: New Video Releases
description: Gods and Monsters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATOVSKY, NATHAN, RABBI
description: PLATOVSKY-Nathan, Rabbi. The administration, faculty and students of the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourn the passing of Rabbi Nathan Platovsky, beloved Brother of Arie and Hebrew Studies Principal Sara Platovsky. Deepest sympathy to the entire family.

title: Am Streetwise, a Little Naive, Will Travel
description: If you can accept the artifice of a movie that deftly compacts several overlapping genres, ''Finding North,'' the newest film to feature that comically mismatched couple du jour, a gay man and a straight woman, has its small wacky charms.

title: Peacekeeping Force of 50,000 Allied Troops to Enter Kosovo as Yugoslav Forces Withdraw
description: The first of nearly 50,000 NATO troops will begin moving into Kosovo within days of a final agreement, taking over the ravaged province as Yugoslavia's Army, police and paramilitary forces withdraw in stages over seven days, American and European officials said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Murdered Blacks Were Martyrs to Racial Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Teresita Fernandez

title: Sports of The Times; The Ending No Athlete Could Want
description: IF the Knicks can take a most improbable run to a championship climax, at least Patrick Ewing will have his ring, even if he is on the sidelines for most of the last two legs. At least he will have been part of a team that would be long gone from the playoffs if it weren't for him.

title: An offbeat campaign for Amtrak introduces a new rail service.
description: THERE'S the midnight train to Georgia and the last train to Clarksville, the A train and the soul train, not to mention the Chattanooga Choo-Choo and the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe. Now an unconventional campaign seeks to add another name to the list of familiar rail monikers: Acela.

title: Taxing the Treasury's Patience; Gimme Shelter: The Unwritten Corporate Theme Song
description: The first clue was an obscure reference in a corporate financial statement to a sizable tax benefit, a possible tipoff to a new form of tax shelter.

title: Old Guard and Young Blood To Meet in French Open Final
description: Anybody else would be in traction by now, or resting on her grand collection of Grand Slam laurels. But Steffi Graf, with her aching spine and 29-year-old legs banished to the background while a 22d career Grand Slam singles title comes ever closer, has never been one to take a shortcut when there is a more treacherous route available.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, TOD ANDREW
description: ROBERTS-Tod Andrew. Beloved husband of Gail Ommerle Roberts and loving father of Katherine Elizabeth. 55 years old. Suddenly, on June 2, 1999. Funeral services Monday, June 7, at 11 AM, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Lewisboro (NY) Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

title: Top Activist For Rights In Turkey Is Imprisoned
description: Turkey's best-known human rights advocate entered prison today to serve a nine-and-a-half-month sentence for giving speeches judged subversive.

title: Kuehne's 64, a Course Record, Leads by 1 in U.S. Open
description: It was 90 degrees in the shade, but Kelli Kuehne's performance was even hotter.

title: Palestinians' 'Day of Rage' Is Punctuated by Calm
description: Hundreds of Palestinians marched down a hilltop here today, trampling though rocks and bramble toward a neighboring, and expanding, Jewish settlement.

title: Tentative Deal Would Delay Voucher Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would postpone his plan to bring school vouchers to New York City next fall under a tentative compromise reached in closed-door budget negotiations, city, education and union officials said yesterday.

title: Strange In His Day And Now
description: Perhaps as part of some larger millennial celebration conspiracy, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted its second summer retrospective of a neglected if not disdained fin de siecle European painter. Last year it was Sir Edward Burne-Jones, the English Pre-Raphaelite. Now comes Gustave Moreau, the French painter who ignored the art of his own time and, firing his imagination with story lines and stylistic tips from past cultures, created an art for the future.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Vistas Latinas 2000'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ALTON E.
description: PETERS-Alton E. The loss of a close friend-and Alton was certainly that-is irreversible and devastating. Only the memory remains, of shared experiences, endeavors undertaken together and perhaps successful, of journeys maybe, certainly of fun-laughter was important to Alton. He was a friend of this family in those senses but in at least one other as well. He was a Trustee of the Harewood House Trust, full of positive advice and wisdom, and incidentally with the best record of attendance of any of us. Details in the garden at Harewood will always remind us of him because they were planted on his advice and all sorts of schemes went forward with important input from him. To his family goes our deepest sympathy. For our part, we'll miss his friendship, his intelligence and warmth, and without him New York will never seem the same. George and Patricia Harewood David and Diane Lascelles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. The City Athletic Club mourns the death of our member Jerome L. Greene and extends heartfelt condolences to his family City Athletic Club Board of Governors

title: Luck, and What Bush Made of It
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KROLL-O'GARA CO., Fairfield, Ohio, a provider of security services, bought Buchler Phillips Group, a British firm that helps restructure financially troubled companies, for $19.4 million in cash and stock.

title: East River Tinseltown
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, DR. ROBERT
description: SOBEL-Dr. Robert. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Robert Sobel, Professor Emeritus of Business History. Dr. Sobel taught at Hofstra for forty years holding the Lawrence Stessin Distinguished Professorship in Business History. Upon his retirement in 1998, he accepted the position of Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute in Santa Monica, California. Dr. Sobel, author of more than fifty books covering the histories of many corporations, was a graduate of C.C.N.Y. and received his M.A. and Ph.D. from New York University. A remarkable member of the Hofstra community, Dr. Sobel will be remembered for his dedication to the University and students he taught. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Carole; a daughter, Barbara; a son, David; a daughterin-law, Linda; two granddaughters, Lauren and Elizabeth; his mother, Blanche; and brother, Alan. A memorial service will be held at Hofstra University on Monday, September 13, 1999. Call 516-463-6818 for details and directions. The family has established the Robert Sobel Memorial Scholarship Fund. For information and donations, contact the Office of Development, 101 Hofstra University, Hempstead, N.Y. 11549. In tribute to the memory of Professor Sobel, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTY, DAVID
description: SIROTY-David. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Beverly and Alan Karasik, Susan Siroty and Howard Baker. Adored grandfather of Ira, Adam, Lucas, Hannah, and Sarah. Dear sister of Dorothy Harwood. Graveside services Sunday, 11:15 A.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I. For more information, contact I.J. Morris Funeral Chapel.

title: A Deal on Kosovo, but Did Anyone Really Win?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Asia Airlines See Progress In Labor and Money Crises
description: The skies may soon become smoother for two Asian airlines buffeted by labor disputes and financial problems.

title: Milosevic Remains, Souring A Victory
description: Like the war in the Persian Gulf, the war in Kosovo appears to be ending with major issues unresolved, not least the future of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and what the United States ought to do about him.

title: A Police Shooting Death, a Study in Contrasts
description: On a busy corner in the heart of town, a makeshift memorial sits on the sidewalk, surrounded by candles, two small American flags and a forlorn pink mylar balloon. At the center is a photograph of a smiling middle-aged woman, a blowup from a newspaper clipping, whose caption reads, ''Margaret Laverne Mitchell, a college educated ex-bank worker.''

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, HOWARD
description: GOODMAN-Howard. Six years and we miss you and honor you at Temple Emanu-El, Palm Beach, FL, with your Agam sculpture. Roni, Mara, Mom Ella, The Kulick & Goodman Families

title: As Airlift Ends, Refugees Weigh Lure of U.S. Against Pull of Home
description: With the Yugoslav Government having agreed to withdraw military and police forces from Kosovo, the United States will stop its emergency airlift of refugees to this army base, Administration officials said today.

title: Awaiting Albany; Budget '99: 66 DAYS DELINQUENT
description: There were no meetings of state legislators or their top aides yesterday.

title: Merrill Lynch Moves to Settle Some Discrimination Claims
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would begin settlement discussions or seek additional information on about one-third of the 904 sexual discrimination claims filed against it by current or former employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, TOD ANDREW
description: ROBERTS-Tod Andrew. Oh, Tod, our world will never be the same without your spontaneous wit, your zest for life and your joyous spirit. You gave to us all. Janet and Michael Dontzin

title: Sports of The Times; Struggling To Move Beyond O.K.
description: DEPENDING on your rooting interests, the Mets-Yankees subway series comes at a curious time. If you're pulling for the Yankees, it couldn't come at a better time. After a pair of losses to Cleveland, the Bombers could use the Mets to regain momentum. If you're pulling for the reeling Mets, the timing doesn't matter. You need a victory or at least a sign of life.

title: LeFrak Interested In Buying Team
description: Samuel J. LeFrak, the real estate developer, is interested in buying the Jets from the estate of Leon Hess, according to Edward Cortese, a spokesman for the Lefrak Organization. He did not say if LeFrak had discussed his interest with Goldman, Sachs & Co., the investment firm handling the sale.

title: The Air-Safety Flaw We Could Fix
description: Wind shear is a deadly weather phenomenon that has claimed more than 500 lives in airliner crashes in the last quarter century. Yet, incredibly, New York City's two major airports still do not have a basic technology that could help prevent wind-shear accidents.

title: Bombing of Serbs Could End This Weekend, U.S. Says
description: President Clinton declared today that he was ''anxious to end the bombing'' in Yugoslavia, and the Pentagon said the 10-week-old air war could end as early as Sunday if Serbia begins a troop withdrawal from Kosovo.

title: Jet Co-Pilot Gives Account Contradicting Crash Data
description: In his first interview with Federal safety officials since the crash of a jet in Little Rock, Ark., the plane's first officer, Michael Origel, today said that he had felt the airplane hydroplane over the rain-slicked runway just before it crashed late Tuesday, killing nine people.

title: 15 Injured on Turnpike When Van Overturns
description: Fifteen people were injured yesterday, two seriously, when a van struck a tractor-trailer on the New Jersey Turnpike and turned over several times, the state police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a judge's order to jail two Atlanta Journal-Constitution reporters, for refusal to reveal who told them that Richard A. Jewell was a leading suspect in the bombing at the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta, misstated the jurisdiction of the judge, John R. Mather. The judge, presiding over the libel suit by Mr. Jewell against the newspaper, sits in a state court in Fulton County, Ga., not in Federal District Court.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The dollar rose against the yen on the belief that American economic strength could induce the Fed to raise interest rates. In New York, the yen settled at 122.22 to the dollar, up from 121.66 on Thursday.

title: A Deal on Kosovo, but Did Anyone Really Win?
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Return van Gogh to an Heir
description: In a decision that should open the way for returning other artworks seized by the Nazis, the German foundation that runs many of Berlin's most prominent museums agreed today to return a van Gogh drawing to the heir of a German-Jewish collector who was forced to auction off the work shortly before the outbreak of World War II.

title: Microsoft Undercut in Effort To Depict Rival as Thriving
description: Trying to defang the Government's antitrust charges against it, the Microsoft Corporation introduced a host of evidence this week to show that the Netscape browser was still healthy and thriving, despite Microsoft's all-out assault on the browser market.

title: INSIDE
description: Hastert Changes Strategy

title: Allied Signal and Honeywell Said to Be in Talks
description: Allied Signal Inc., the diversified manufacturer, and Honeywell Inc., the maker of electronic controls, are in merger discussions, people close to the companies said yesterday. A combination of the two, which could be announced as early as Monday, would create a company with revenue of more than $24 billion.

title: House Speaker to Shift Tacks on Spending Bill
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, his bills stymied and his control of the House insecure, has decided to rewrite Republican spending plans and shift some money for increased military spending to ease cuts in social programs like health and education, key aides said today.

title: Live, at Chicago's City Hall: It's the 'Jerry Springer Show'
description: Jerry Springer, the talk show host whose guests have a penchant for punching, kicking and hurling chairs at one another, appeared before the City Council here today to speak on the issue of whether actual assaults and other criminal offenses are committed on his program.

title: Deutsche Bank Seals Bankers Trust Deal
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., sealing its position as the world's largest bank, completed its acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation yesterday and effectively put an end to the Bankers Trust brand name.

title: Vodka Sheds Proletarian Chains; Russian Distillers Courting a Higher Class of Drinker
description: In a large second-floor room of the Rossiya movie theater in this shabbily genteel town, Vladimir Shabalin teaches people how to drink vodka.

title: Rivers to Become Magic Coach
description: Glenn (Doc) Rivers reached agreement yesterday to become the Orlando Magic's head coach, an Eastern Conference team official confirmed last night.

title: Albanian Rebels Complicate NATO Planning on Kosovo
description: Once Yugoslavia withdraws its forces from Kosovo, NATO envisions disbanding the Kosovo Liberation Army and transforming its fighters into civilians, many as police officers. Western officials are already scouring refugee camps in Albania and Macedonia for recruits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAUM, NATHAN
description: ZAUM-Nathan. Age 79. On June 3, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Blanche. Devoted father to Amy, Fran and Eric. Proud grandfather of Jared and Matthew. Services Sunday, 1 P.M., at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, Long Island.

title: Senator Assails F.B.I. Over Letter Signed by New York Agents
description: A United States Senator who has sharply criticized the F.B.I.'s investigation into the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 has written to the agency's Director, Louis J. Freeh, condemning the leadership of the New York office of the bureau, which he said was ''out of control.''

title: Political Notes; 2 Take Credit for a Near-Candidacy
description: It had to happen. With the prospect of a Hillary Rodham Clinton candidacy for the United States Senate becoming increasingly real, New York Democratic leaders are stepping forward to claim credit for the idea -- producing a memorably strained moment on a ''Larry King Live'' program this week.

title: PHILIPPINE RATE CUT
description: The Philippine central bank cut overnight interest rates to their lowest in more than three and a half years, as the latest data on consumer prices showed inflation continuing to slow. Beginning on Monday, the central bank will pay 9.625 percent to borrow overnight from banks, down from 9.875 percent. In addition, the overnight lending rate will fall to 11.625 percent from 11.875 percent. The latest rate cut, the 16th this year, is meant to spur lending and hasten the recovery from recession.

title: Big Errors and Delays Snarl Vote Count in South Africa
description: Votes came on to the huge digital board here, and then they came off. One million of them, at one point.

title: Manakamana Journal; Wishful Thinkers Climb in Comfort to a Goddess of All Things
description: Since the 17th century, Hindus in search of their heart's desire have ascended a steep and rocky mountain to the temple of Manakamana, the wish-fulfilling goddess. It is quite a hike, actually, four to eight hours depending on the strength of the climber and whether he or she is bringing along sacrificial goats or chickens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BEATRIZ BERMEJILLO
description: MOORE-Beatriz Bermejillo. The Board of Directors and friends of The Spanish Institute mourn the passing of Beatriz Moore, longtime board member and wife of Institute founder George Moore. Mrs. Moore was a great friend of Spain and strong supporter of the Institute, and we extend our deepest condolences to her family.

title: F.B.I. Searches King's Offices
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents swept through the promoter Don King's offices in Deerfield Beach, Fla., yesterday morning, searching for information as part of an investigation by the United States Attorney's office in Newark into alleged illegal payments and kickbacks for rankings in the International Boxing Federation.

title: Ruth Whitney, 71, the Editor Who Made Glamour Relevant
description: Ruth Whitney, the editor who steered Glamour magazine for 31 years and influenced several generations of women during three important decades in American feminism, died yesterday at her home in Irvington, N.Y. She was 71.

title: A Quiet Tiananmen Anniversary in China
description: More than 70,000 people turned out here tonight on a balmy summer evening to hold candles, sing songs, and pay respects to those who lost their lives a decade ago at Tiananmen Square.

title: Letter by Dead Woman Tells of Body in Cooler
description: A week after a Jersey City podiatrist hanged herself in a Pennsylvania jail cell, preventing Hudson County prosecutors from questioning her about the death of her sister-in-law, investigators have received a letter she wrote about the death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEWSKI, CHARLOTTE
description: PALEWSKI-Charlotte. On June 3, 1999. Wife of the late Stephen. Devoted mother of Lillian, Stephanie and Jeanne. Grandmother of five. Great-grandmother of three. For information call 516-732-1112.

title: Authorities Suspend Operations at a Major Japanese Insurer
description: Financial authorities suspended operations today at the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company, only the second major insurer in Japan to go out of business since World War II.

title: Not Really a Wallflower, But Quiet and Tender
description: When Ron Sexsmith sings, he rarely places a note squarely on the beat. He eases into it a little ahead of time, or hesitates and lets it drift in late. Then he holds it with a slow-quivering vibrato that wobbles around the pitch as if he's not quite ready to commit himself. The tone is hesitant, uncertain, like a wallflower trying to slip into a party unnoticed. That self-effacement carried into Mr. Sex smith's deadpan patter when he performed on Wednesday night at the Bowery Ballroom. Mentioning his new album, ''Whereabouts'' (Inter scope), he asked: ''Do you like it? Is it all right? It's all right if you don't.''

title: Judge Says Local Officials Can Force AT&T to Share Cable Lines
description: In a decision that could have far-reaching implications for consumers and the telecommunications industry, a Federal judge in Portland, Ore., ruled yesterday that a local government could force the AT&T Corporation to share its cable lines with competing Internet service providers.

title: Yankees Show the Mets How to Win in New York
description: Partisan angst manifested itself in the top of the first inning, when a flow of tension started burbling from the field and 56,175 fans established their allegiances, reminding the players that turf war is serious business. Either you love the Mets or the Yankees. Either way, fans left Yankee Stadium hoarse and breathless after a night of delicious possibility.

title: Crowded at Top: Trevino Shares Lead
description: After nine holes today, Lee Trevino's appearance in the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic had the look of another forgettable round, one that would make him a postscript to a tournament he once dominated. Heading to the back nine at the Upper Montclair Country Club, Trevino was sent off with no more than polite applause from the gallery, something that came as little surprise to Trevino, a winner only once on the Senior Tour in the last three years.

title: Prosecutor and 4 Sheriff's Deputies Are Acquitted of Wrongfully Accusing a Man of Murder
description: A former prosecutor and four sheriff's deputies were acquitted today of conspiring to put an innocent man on death row in the murder of a 10-year-old girl.

title: Abroad at Home; Proof Of the Pudding
description: Has Slobodan Milosevic really capitulated to NATO's demands? The test will be straightforward: Will the expelled ethnic Albanians return to Kosovo?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: COMPLAINT ON MEAT BAN
description: The European Commission called a United States ban on poultry and pork imports from all European Union countries ''disproportionate.'' The United States Agriculture Department issued the ban on Thursday after meat from Belgium was found to contain the toxic chemical dioxin. Amid concern the chemical may also be present in Belgian beef, the Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland, Canada and Hong Kong have joined the United States in restricting Belgian food imports. The European Commission has said it will ban the sale of chicken, pork, beef and dairy products from around 1,000 Belgian farms.

title: Bronx Woman Is Killed and Her Grandson Is Hurt by Speeding Car
description: A Bronx woman was killed and her 7-year-old grandson critically injured yesterday afternoon when they were hit by a car that ran a red light as they crossed the Grand Concourse, the police said.

title: For Van Gundy's Gripes, a Rebuttal
description: As expected, Jeff Van Gundy's portrayal of the Pacers as whimpering whiners did not go over big in Indiana. Before they left for New York, Mark Jackson and Reggie Miller were among those Pacers who fired verbal shots at the Knicks.

title: Rewriting The Book On Capitalism; Now Cooperative Innovation Steals Competition's Thunder
description: Capitalism, every undergraduate student of economics learns, thrives on competition. The brilliant virtue of the invisible hand of competition is that it forces firms to reduce costs, cut prices and thereby enrich consumers. This engaging tale has buttressed every economics narrative since Adam Smith lucidly explained 200 years ago how competition channels the natural greed of individuals into serving the social good.

title: Charismatic Is Fully Prepared in His Bid for the Triple Crown
description: It was 5:30 on a clear, cool and quiet morning at Belmont Park. D. Wayne Lukas led Charismatic out of his barn as the first horse entering the track on the day before battle -- just as he expected Charismatic to be first in the 131st Belmont Stakes today before a crowd of more than 80,000 at Belmont Park, and complete his dramatic surge from claimer to the Triple Crown.

title: Art Is Made to Be Seen
description: To the Editor:

title: Indicted Ex-Sergeant Says He Knows Who Bombed U.S. Embassies
description: A former United States Army sergeant accused of conspiring in terrorist acts told the F.B.I. after last year's embassy bombings in Africa that he knew the people who carried them out, but he refused to identify them, according to court documents released in New York yesterday.

title: EQUILON ENTERPRISES SELLING TWO MIDWEST REFINERIES
description: Equilon Enterprises L.L.C., a refining and fuel-selling joint venture of the Shell Oil Company and Texaco Inc., agreed yesterday to sell oil refineries in Illinois and Kansas to focus more on its gasoline stations and pipelines. Clark USA Inc. will buy Equilon's refinery in Wood River, Ill., which can process 295,000 barrels of oil a day, for an undisclosed price. The Frontier Oil Corporation agreed to buy Equilon's 110,000-barrel-a-day refinery in El Dorado, Kan., for about $170 million. Wood River is the Houston-based Equilon's largest refinery. It and the El Dorado refinery account for almost half of Equilon's total capacity of 835,000 barrels a day. Equilon also agreed to buy 12 refined-product storage terminals in the Midwest and Texas from the closely held Clark, which is based in St. Louis.

title: Memories of a (Perhaps) Princess
description: If only Kenneth MacMillan's ''Anastasia'' were a novel. Then one could skim over its loquacious bits and finally be gripped by a thrilling conclusion. But ''Anastasia'' is not a novel. It's a three-act ballet that entered American Ballet Theater's repertory on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. And it cannot be skimmed.

title: Novel Antipollution Tool Is Being Upset by Courts
description: A quarter-century after Congress gave citizens broad powers to enforce environmental laws through private lawsuits, judges across the country are cutting back on those suits so deeply that environmental groups have lost much of their power in court, legal experts on both sides of the issue say.

title: AVERY DENNISON AGREES TO PURCHASE STIMSONITE
description: The Avery Dennison Corporation, based in Pasadena, Calif., a maker of adhesive labels for packaging, mailers and other items, agreed yesterday to buy the Stimsonite Corporation for $14.75 a share in cash, or a total of $137 million. Stimsonite, based in Niles, Ill., makes reflective safety products for the transportation industry. Avery said Stimsonite's micro-replication technology had extensive applications beyond the highway safety industry, including home entertainment, computers, architectural lighting, medical products and textiles.

title: PATENT FRAUD COMPLAINT AGAINST VISX DISMISSED
description: Visx Inc. won an unexpected legal victory yesterday that sent its shares to an all-time high, as a judge dismissed a Government complaint accusing the company, the maker of vision-correction lasers, of patent fraud. Stuart A. Levin, a Federal Trade Commission judge, rejected F.T.C. staff contentions that Visx violated antitrust laws by withholding crucial information from patent examiners. Visx shares jumped $17.125, to $71.875. The decision, which can be appealed to the F.T.C.'s four commissioners, protects a patent that is crucial to the popular Lasik vision-correction procedure.

title: Suspected Breeder Held In Dumping of Rabbits
description: The police arrested a suspected rabbit breeder yesterday in connection with the dumping of nearly 150 dead or ailing rabbits in a local park.

title: No Misty Glen for This 'Pelleas'
description: The new production at Glyndebourne of ''Pelleas et Melisande,'' sponsored by the Glyndebourne Association America, belongs squarely in a modern tradition of locating Debussy's opera not in a land of crumbling castles and fairy tale princes but in the here and now, or at least the here and then. Graham Vick and Paul Brown, the director and the designer, have everything unfold within a grand salon from around the time of the opera's composition, 100 years ago. A spiral staircase rises in the middle of the room, and under the undulating glasslike floor are thousands of red, orange and yellow chrysanthemums, aptly symbolic of confinement and death.

title: Police Get Good Ratings From Most, but Not All, New Yorkers
description: Most New Yorkers are satisfied with the work done by the Police Department, although the percentage is far higher among whites than blacks, according to a new national survey by the Department of Justice.

title: Still No Room For Dissent
description: My closest friend in Beijing, Jiang Qisheng, was taken away in the middle of the night by the Chinese Government on May 18. His wife said their small one-bedroom apartment was ransacked by at least a dozen police officers for two hours after they took him away.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about President Clinton's reading habits misstated the publication year of Dean Acheson's memoir, ''Present at the Creation.'' It was 1969, not 1987.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWAN, MARCY H.
description: COWAN-Marcy H. Of Brooklyn, New York, May 25, age 94. Retired Principal of P.S. 270, Lawyer, husband of late Jennie E. Taleisnik Cowan, brother of A. Halsey of San Diego and late Alvin R., father of Edward, Neil, Richard, grandfather of eight.

title: Who Makes Our Laws?
description: To the Editor:

title: Australia Beats India in 2d Round
description: Australia defeated India by 77 runs in the opening second-round match of the Cricket World Cup in London.

title: Hillary Clinton Confirms a First Senate Step
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that in July she would take the first formal step toward running for Senate, registering an exploratory committee with the Federal Election Commission. Her aides said that would almost certainly lead to her becoming the first First Lady to run for Federal office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUIDA, FRANK
description: GUIDA-Frank. Age 79, of Mt. Kisco, N.Y. and Port St. Lucie, FL, died June 1, 1999. Photographer with Hans Van Nes Studio, NY, NY and Frank Guida Photography Inc., Stamford, CT. Retired. Survived by wife Ragna, six children, eight grandchildren.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: A New Measure of Little League Success
description: They say that in baseball you can come up with statistics for just about anything. Well, we've come up with a new statistic that tells a lot about both players and coaches -- Little League players and coaches.

title: Reception In Moscow For Accord Is Scalding
description: The Kosovo peace agreement that was struck on Thursday with the consent of President Boris N. Yeltsin and his special envoy got a scalding reception in its first review here today, not merely from politicians, but from some of Mr. Yeltsin's own officials.

title: William Schuyler Pettit, 90, President of Ursinus College in 1970's
description: William Schuyler Pettit, president of Ursinus College until a dispute with the faculty led him to resign in 1976, died on May 25 at a nursing home in Naples, Fla. He was 90.

title: Captain Killed in Blaze Helped Firefighters Cope With Death
description: A veteran New York City fire captain, who for years worked to insure that firefighters got the support they needed when a colleague was killed in the line of duty, died himself yesterday after collapsing Thursday night in the burning basement of a Queens home.

title: Man Charged With Murder In Shooting of Woman, 34
description: An 18-year-old high school student was charged with murder yesterday in the fatal shooting of a Morningside Heights woman two months ago when she tried to keep him from stealing her purse, the police said.

title: Ex-Psychologist, Falsely Accused, Is Awarded $16 Million
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan has awarded a former state psychologist $16.6 million in damages after concluding that he was the victim of false allegations, orchestrated by another employee, that he had sexually abused mentally retarded patients in a treatment center in Brooklyn.

title: A Beat That Lingers in the Mind After a Triple Bill
description: Most of Steve Coleman's music sounds as if it begins life as drum patterns. He is an alto saxophonist whose connection to Charlie Parker is always clear in darting movements and clear articulation, and his greatest departure from the main line of jazz esthetics currently is in the hard, slapping Afro-Cuban drumming that lies behind his work. It's partly an interpretation of Yoruban religious music, the kind that accompanies Candomble and Santeria ceremonies, and it replaces the airy netting of swing and bop rhythm with a kind of beautifully detailed concrete wall.

title: HALLIBURTON TO GAIN ALL OF PES INTERNATIONAL
description: The Halliburton Company, the world's largest oilfield-services company, agreed yesterday to buy the 74 percent of PES International Ltd. it does not already own for about $132 million in stock. Halliburton said it would issue as many as 3.07 million new shares to pay for the stake. Halliburton bought a 26 percent interest in the closely held PES in 1997 for $33.6 million. PES, based in Aberdeen, Scotland, sells products and services that help produce oil. It will complement the existing businesses of the Dallas-based Halliburton.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORMAN, HELEN
description: NORMAN-Helen. God gave us his most precious gift of your love. You are in our hearts into eternity. We love you more than the universe. Always and forever, Janet and Brend

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, PAULA R.
description: BERGER-Paula R. Passed away June 2, 1999 (19th Sivan, 5759). Beloved wife of the late Saul Berger, loving mother of Stephen Berger and Bonnie GraBois, adoring grandmother of Dr. Melissa DelBello, (David), Andy GraBois, Robin Berger and Diana Berger. Devoted mother-in-law to Stuart GraBois and Cynthia Wainwright. Born in Poland, she came to New York City at the age of 6-seized its offerings & in turn contributed to its betterment. Political reformer, dedicated to her family, faith and community. Funeral service Friday at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in lieu of flowers, Hi Tech School, C/O Community Synagogue, 325 East 6th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: New Jersey Justice Will Retire, Allowing Whitman to Expand Her Legacy on Top Court
description: Justice Alan B. Handler of the New Jersey Supreme Court announced today that he would retire in September. His departure will open the way for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to make her fourth nomination to the state's highest court and will assure that her imprint is stamped on one of the nation's most respected benches for years to come.

title: For Everyone, Non-Russians, Too, There's a Personal Pushkin
description: To Russians, Aleksandr Pushkin is the heart and soul of their literature. ''Pushkin is our everything,'' said a fellow Russian poet.

title: A Relief Plan for Yugoslav Neighbors
description: Officials from the United States, the European Union and international aid agencies stepped up their planning today for the formidable job of repairing the physical and economic damage wrought throughout the Balkans by the conflict in Kosovo.

title: Amazon Asks Court to Clear Use of Times Best-Seller Lists
description: The leading on-line bookseller, Amazon.com, sought a legal ruling in Federal court yesterday to allow it to continue posting the New York Times best-seller lists after the newspaper had demanded in a letter that the company stop publishing the lists in the absence of a licensing agreement.

title: A Deal on Kosovo, but Did Anyone Really Win?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving the Honor, Seeking the Obvious; Publicity Hounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending to Stop Smoking
description: New York lags woefully behind states like California and Massachusetts in combating smoking, the leading preventable cause of death and disease. More than 30,000 New York residents die annually from tobacco-related illness. Yet the state spends a pittance -- $6.5 million annually, or 37 cents per person -- on anti-smoking efforts.

title: Unemployment Falls Again, But Job Growth Is Moderating
description: America's unemployment rate dropped to 4.2 percent in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday. That matches the 29-year low first reached in March and is just the latest sign that the nation's labor market remains remarkably robust.

title: Three Ring Captures the Acorn
description: Three Ring bounced back from her last-place finish in the Kentucky Derby yesterday, survived a disputed decision by the stewards not to disqualify her for apparently bumping in the homestretch and won the Acorn Stakes, the first race in Belmont Park's Triple Tiara series.

title: Giving the Honor, Seeking the Obvious
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe's New Military Aspirations
description: The air war over Yugoslavia, though successful, brought renewed attention to one of NATO's oldest problems. While 19 countries belong to the alliance and take part in its political decision-making, most of the military power comes from just one of these countries, the United States, as does much of the political leadership. More than two-thirds of the NATO planes used against Kosovo and Serbia were American. This week the European Union, which includes most of NATO's European members, adopted a plan aimed at partially redressing the balance. That is a welcome development. But European governments will have to overcome many obstacles if the plan is to have any practical effect.

title: Shift in Targets Let NATO Jets Tip the Balance
description: After 10 long weeks of bombing, NATO finally broke the will of President Slobodan Milosevic by finding new ways to destroy the Yugoslav military in the field while escalating attacks on strategic targets like command bunkers and power stations with virtual impunity, allied commanders said yesterday.

title: Jury in Police Brutality Case Begins Deliberations
description: The jury in the Abner Louima brutality case began deliberations yesterday, quickly turning to the most serious charge remaining and asking to have testimony read concerning a police officer's alleged role in the torture of Mr. Louima in a Brooklyn station house.

title: U.S. to Seek $264 Million For Building Of Embassies
description: The Clinton Administration, responding to criticism that it had failed to protect American diplomats from terrorist attacks, said today that it would ask Congress for an additional $264 million next year to build new, more secure embassies.

title: First the Commuter Tax, Now the Water
description: The suburbs are preparing to give New York City another kick in the teeth, to follow up the repeal of the commuter tax. Dog Bites Man: it's a familiar story. What's surprising is the way city politicians almost always take such assaults lying down.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: DISNEY STOCK GAINS ON SPECULATION OF SPINOFF
description: The Walt Disney Company's stock price rose 5.6 percent yesterday amid widespread speculation that the giant entertainment company planned to spin off its Internet-related assets into a separately traded tracking stock, . Disney owns 43 percent of Infoseek, a search engine company, and it has created Web sites for a variety of its businesses including ESPN.com, ABC.com, ABCnews.com, and Disney.com. A Disney spokesman refused to comment on whether Disney planned a spinoff. Disney has been under pressure to lift its sagging stock price, which closed yesterday at $30.625, up $1.625. That is well below its high of $40.313 last July but up from its low of $22.50 on Oct. 9.

title: In 'Giselle,' 2 Parts With Many Faces
description: When danced with dramatic sincerity and technical skill, ''Giselle'' cannot fail to be poignant. The leading roles, Giselle and Albrecht, can have many interpretations, as American Ballet Theater demonstrated in two fine performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: INTO THE UNKNOWN
description: Exploration and the quest for knowledge have been special legacies of this millennium, but where does today's explorer go to find uncharted ground? In a special issue of The Times Magazine, the third of six to reflect on the last 1,000 years, writers and photographers embark on a series of expeditions, some following in the footsteps of earlier adventurers, some scouting the territory for a glimpse into the remaining great unknowns -- the ocean floor, the urban wilderness, the human mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOERGER, DR. ERIC
description: STOERGER-Dr. Eric. On June 3, 1999. Devoted husband of Marga. Beloved uncle of Richard, Jack, Jim, Janet, Sue, Bob and Peter. Services Sunday, June 6, 10:30AM, at the Hebrew Tabernacle, corner 185th St. and Ft. Washington Ave.

title: CITY NATIONAL BUYING AMERICAN PACIFIC STATE BANK
description: The City National Corporation, a bank-holding company, agreed yesterday to acquire American Pacific State Bank for $89 million in a move to continue expanding in Southern California. The deal will create a combined company with assets of $6.7 billion. City National, based in Los Angeles, has 40 offices throughout Southern California and assets of $6.3 billion. American Pacific, based in California's San Fernando Valley, operates eight bank branches and has assets of $414 million. Under the agreement, City National will acquire American Pacific's 5.5 million outstanding shares for $15.65 a share. Shares of American Pacific did not open yesterday; it last traded at $12.875 on the Nasdaq stock market. City National's stock fell 50 cents, to $39.75.

title: First Lady Takes Big Step For Campaign
description: After months of conjecture and nearly a dozen visits to New York State, Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that in July she would take the first formal step toward running for Senate, registering an exploratory committee with the Federal Election Commission. Her aides said that would almost certainly lead to her becoming the first First Lady to run for Federal office.

title: Peacekeepers' Commander to Meet Serb Officer Today
description: After a faxed request from the chief of Yugoslavia's armed forces to discuss arrangements for a pullout of all Serbian forces from Kosovo, NATO said today that the designated commander of its 45,000 peacekeepers would meet the Yugoslavs on Saturday morning on the border of Kosovo and Macedonia.

title: Finally, Mr. Hormel Gets the Job
description: President Clinton took an appropriate stand against bigotry yesterday by giving James Hormel a recess appointment as the nation's Ambassador to Luxembourg. Mr. Hormel's nomination had been blocked for 20 months by a handful of Senate Republicans disturbed by his sexual orientation.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday tracing American combat deaths in military actions since 1982 misstated the year of the Persian Gulf war. It was 1991, not 1998.

title: Surprising Lesson: Bombing Can Work
description: Slobodan Milosevic boasted that a high-technology bombing war would never force Serbian soldiers out of Kosovo. ''You are not willing to sacrifice lives to achieve our surrender,'' the President of Yugoslavia proclaimed five weeks into the 10-week conflict. ''We are willing to die to defend our rights as an independent sovereign nation.''

title: Irked Clinton Defends Effort On Gun Bills
description: With his commitment to gun control challenged today on national television, President Clinton delivered a stinging lecture on achieving the politically possible in a Republican-controlled Congress.

title: Jones to Defend His I.B.F. Title
description: Roy Jones Jr. will face Reggie Johnson tonight in Biloxi, Miss., headlining a card that includes two other world championship bouts.

title: F.A.A. to Enforce Requirement That Pilots Get 8 Hours of Rest
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would soon begin strictly enforcing a 1985 regulation requiring airline pilots to have at least eight hours of uninterrupted rest in the 24 hours before finishing their flight duty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLAIN, RALPH E.
description: CHAMBERLAIN-Ralph E. The extended Bassett Healthcare family joins us in mourning the loss of our esteemed trustee and benefactor Ralph E. Chamberlain. As president of the Friends of Bassett and later as chairman of Bassett's first capital campaign, Ralph helped establish an enduring philanthropic tradition, cultivated from years of experience as a distinguished fund-raising executive. A consummate gentleman, he used his considerable oratorical and persuasive abilities to advocate Bassett's mission of accessible, quality health care at every opportunity. Ralph backed up his words with personal commitment, donating generously to support many projects. We acknowledge our profound indebtedness to our beloved friend and neighbor. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Ellen and to each member of his family. William F. Streck, M.D. President and Chief Executive Officer Thomas Q. Morris, M.D. Chairman of the Board of Trustees Bassett Healthcare Cooperstown, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUMBARD, J. EDWARD
description: LUMBARD-J. Edward. 97. On June 3, 1999. All the lawyers who served with him when he was United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and whom he referred to as partners, mourn the passing of a great lawyer, a fine teacher, an outstanding United States Attorney and a brilliant Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. It was a privilege to have served with him. The Lumbard Association

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BONGIOVANNI, RAYMOND
description: BONGIOVANNI-Raymond. June 5, 1996. ''To fall from the mastered emotion into the guessed-at, and onward.'' Rilke.

title: Kane Grabs a Share of the Lead With a Torrid Round
description: One day after Kelli Kuehne shot a 64 at the United States Women's Open, Lorie Kane and Becky Iverson did the same.

title: Fossett Sets Record for Bermuda Trip
description: In his quest to leave no long-distance sailing record unturned, Steve Fossett set a new pace yesterday for the 635-mile Atlantic Ocean route from Newport, R.I., to Bermuda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARALL, MILTON
description: BARALL-Milton. On Tuesday, May 25, 1999, of Washington D.C. Beloved husband of the late Grace Barall, father of James Barall of Alexandria, VA, brother of Irving Barall (Margaret) of New York City. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons 5130 Wisconsin Ave at Harrison Street, NW, on Sunday, June 6, 2-4/7-9PM. Services will be held at Ft. Myer Chapel, Arlington National Cemetery, interment in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: A Domestic Angle
description: There will be no foreign-born players in the lineup for the MetroStars tonight when they play the Dallas Burn at Giants Stadium, and their fans will probably have to wait another week or two for the marquee foreign-born players the MetroStars are pursuing after opening two more spots for such players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RICHARD M.
description: COHEN-Richard M. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend Richard M. Cohen and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Marshall L. Hess, Secretary

title: Ford Discount on Volvos
description: The Ford Motor Company, the world's second-largest auto maker, will allow employees and retirees in the United States to buy or lease Volvo cars at a discount beginning with the 2000 model year. Ford acquired Volvo's car business for $6.45 billion earlier this year. Ford's employees and their families are already able to buy Ford cars and trucks for less than what the company charges its dealers.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the resignation of Mikhail M. Zadornov, Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister for financial matters, misidentified Gennadi A. Zyuganov, a politician who commented. He is the head of the Communist Party, not the Speaker of the lower house of Parliament.

title: RUDDICK, SEWING THREAD MAKER, IN BRITISH PURCHASE
description: The Ruddick Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., a maker of sewing thread, said it would acquire a British rival, Hicking Pentecost P.L.C., for $93 million in cash to gain overseas customers and sell a wider range of products. Ruddick, a holding company that makes thread for Gap Inc. jeans and Ethan Allen Interiors Inc. chairs, also operates 139 Harris Teeter supermarkets. Ruddick will expand in countries like South Africa, India and Italy with the purchase, its chief financial officer, Richard Brigden, said.

title: Lilly Expanding Buyback
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that it would buy back an additional $500 million in stock, expanding its share-repurchase plan by 50 percent. The pharmaceutical company had earlier announced a $1 billion buyback, which it expects to complete by the end of the year. Lilly had 1.1 billion shares outstanding as of June 1. The repurchased shares will be canceled or used for employee stock plans, the company said. Shares of Lilly rose $3.3125, to $75.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is an enormous opportunity to be seized here.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE TUMBLES. Futures prices fell sharply after meteorologists foresaw little chance for frost in Brazil, the world's largest grower, in coming days. In New York, arabica coffee for July delivery fell 3.05 cents, to $1.20 a pound.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about NATO's peacekeeping force for Kosovo referred incorrectly to American units that are expected to take part. They are three heavy armored battalions and one lighter infantry battalion -- not three heavy armored divisions and one lighter infantry division.

title: IDEX ACQUIRES ITALIAN REFINISHER FOR $62 MILLION
description: The Idex Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Fast S.p.A., an Italian manufacturer of refinishing equipment, for $62 million in cash. Fast, based in Cinisello Balsamo near Milan, makes refinishing and color-formulation equipment for paints and dyes. The company's refinishing equipment includes stirring lids, mixing racks and machines for automotive and industrial refinishing applications. In addition to its Italian business, Fast has operations in Princeton, N.J.; Telford, England, and Barcelona, Spain. Idex, based in Northbrook, Ill., makes a range of pump products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTMAN, KALLMAN
description: GITTMAN-Kallman. On June 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Rebecca for 64 years. Cherished father of Stella Cole, (Gene) and Dr. Elizabeth Gittman Arnel, (Victor). Dear brother of Anna Rottenberg. Adoring grandfather of Debbi (Lawrence); Leni, (James) and Alan; Stephen, (Joanne); Leslie (Eric), and Sherry. Great-grandfather of Eliana, Danielle, Shaun, Todd, Alison, Tyler and Chase. He was the greatest! Service Sunday 11:15AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCELL, NATHAN S.
description: ANCELL-Nathan S. It's very simple! I will not permit you, Nat Ancell, to walk out of my life and the lives of Daytop's youngsters without notice! Those sunrise breakfast sessions at Mill Road in Eastchester brought teacher and student together. And I, the attentive listener, soon learned how much goodness, combined with the strong faith of a young Rabbinical candidate and a driving vision, could transform a deep concern for the well-being of the American family into a monumental effort to bring the young back from the streets with their friends into the family living rooms. The attraction - warm, comfortable furnishings. Ethan Allen was born! And, more recently, he descended upon the living rooms of Daytop's Kids and wept as he heard syllables of hope and raw courage from the lips of wounded youngsters. And our world at Daytop became brighter overnight. Heaven welcome home a Native Son! Our prayerful support for Susan and Penny and the Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Medvedev, a Finalist at the French Open, Can Feel the Love
description: First the course of true love finally did run smooth for Andrei Medvedev, the decidedly romantic giant from Ukraine who reunited with his longtime paramour, Anke Huber, just before the French Open began. And once his heart felt lighter, Medvedev's moribund career took a turn for the brighter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: School Vouchers Still Divide Council and Giuliani
description: For yesterday's ceremonious announcement of a negotiated $35.3 billion city budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took his place with Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and 30 other Council members, all arranged like candlepins on the marble steps of the City Hall rotunda. But in this forced, cozy setting, the Mayor remained very much alone.

title: Clinton Appoints Gay Man as Ambassador as Congress Is Away
description: Over Republican objections, President Clinton today appointed James Hormel as Ambassador to Luxembourg, employing a rarely used executive privilege to make him the nation's first openly gay envoy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP., Wayzata, Minn., a distributor of food for vending machines, sold its Alimentos Super-S unit, an agriculture and animal-feeds business, to La Caridad Group, Caracas, Venezuela, a poultry producer, for $27.5 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CUFFE, EDWARD W.
description: CUFFE-Edward W. 2/16/36, Fall River, Ma.-6/5/96 at market close, NYC. Knowing the evening's empire had all turned into sand, he went to where savage indignation could no longer lacerate his heart. Go traveler. Try and imitate him if you can. He served liberty. Rage on, wherever you are. The Ding Ansich Dynasty

title: Refugees Face Hard Choice: Go Home, or Find New One?
description: Both families face the same decision. After being forced from their homes, herded onto trains or pursued over mined mountain passes, they spent weeks crowded into this sweltering refugee camp. Now they must choose whether to return to a ravaged Kosovo or to seek a new life in another country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rally as Investors Expect a Fed Rate Increase

title: In Milosevic's Government, Resignation Over Pact, Confidence in His Strength
description: As soon as Russia agreed with NATO on the principles for a peace settlement for Kosovo, President Slobodan Milosevic understood that he had no choice but to accept the terms put in front of him, senior Yugoslav officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, WILLIAM P.
description: PRICE-William P. On June 4, 1999. Loving husband of Terry (nee Schwab). Loving father of Steven Price, Susan Price and Allyne Price. Devoted grandfather of Daniel Waldman. Funeral service at 11 A.M. Sunday at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York.

title: Reno Calls a Mexican Drug Inquiry Valid
description: Attorney General Janet Reno moved today to assuage Mexican officials by clearing the name of the private secretary of President Ernesto Zedillo.

title: Giving the Honor, Seeking the Obvious; Ambiguous Jefferson
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Hearts, True, False And Broken
description: The best is saved for last in Series C, the final segment of Marathon '99, Ensemble Studio Theater's 22d annual festival of one-act plays.

title: Global Prosecutor Would Be Held in Check
description: To the Editor:

title: Benitez Again Holds Ball, and Martinez Has the Bat
description: When Armando Benitez was announced as the new pitcher for the Mets in the eighth inning last night, he was booed incessantly by the fans at Yankee Stadium. They remembered how he pinned a fastball between the 2 and the 4 on Tino Martinez's back while he was with the Baltimore Orioles 13 months ago. Benitez expected to be bathed in boos the first time he pitched again at the Stadium, and he was.

title: A Drummer Gets Lucky With Water
description: The violinists have it easy. When other members of an orchestra step forward to play solos, as several did on Thursday at the New York Philharmonic, they face harder choices.

title: CANADA JOBLESSNESS
description: Canada's economy lost 14,000 jobs in May, the fourth consecutive month with no growth in employment, Statistics Canada reported. Nevertheless, the national unemployment rate dipped to 8.1 percent, from 8.3 percent in April, because 49,000 people withdrew from the labor force. Ruth Getter, chief economist at Toronto Dominion Bank, said all the jobs lost were for full-time work in the private sector, while public sector employment continued to grow. Statistics Canada also reported that the consumer price index was 1.7 percent higher in April than a year ago, the largest annual increase since October 1997.

title: Welsh Captures Fast 1,600 Meters
description: Dylan Welsh of Saratoga Springs won the 1,600-meter run in an impressive 4 minutes 10.09 seconds and Jason Morgan took the 400 and anchored Long Island Lawrence's winning 1,600 relay in boys' events yesterday in the Class A competition of the New York State outdoor high school championships at Dietz Stadium in Kingston.

title: Blacks at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deal on Kosovo, but Did Anyone Really Win?
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Leader Is Moving to New Security Post
description: Javier Solana, who as Secretary General of NATO pressed strongly for the Kosovo bombing campaign, was named today by European Union leaders as the first foreign policy and security czar of the union.

title: Michael Lax, Designer, Dies at 69; Sculptor of 60's Icons
description: Michael Lax, an industrial designer best known for the craftsman-like appreciation for texture and color that he brought to such household icons of the 1960's as the Copco teakettle with the bent teak handle and the Lightolier sphere-resting-on-a-cube mini-lamp, died on May 28 at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Zachary Fisher, 88, Dies; Helped Alter New York Skyline
description: Zachary Fisher, a leading New York builder and philanthropist who virtually willed the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum into existence at its Hudson River berth, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Blacks at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, GABRIELLE
description: BLUESTEIN-Gabrielle. Beloved wife of Milton Bluestein, Gabrielle Alexander Bluestein was the matriarch of her family serving as its shining benevolent center. She will be missed by her daughters Barbara and Marion; her grandchildren Peter, William and Maria; and her great-grandchildren Sam, Eyck, Sarah, Finn and Elodie. Services will be held on Sunday, June 6 at 11:30 AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at Madison Avenue and 82 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, REV. MSGR. ARTHUR J.
description: KANE-Rev. Msgr. Arthur J. on June 2, 1999. Founding Pastor of St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, Melville, NY. Former Spiritual Director St. Vincent de Paul Society for the Diocese of Rockville Centre. Chaplain Melville Fire Department, Former Curate of St. Ignatius Martyr, Long Beach, NY and St. Teresa's, Woodside, NY. Devoted son of the late John A. Kane and Helena McDonald Kane. Loving brother of Helen Moloney of West Hempstead, NY and the late John, Mary and Dr. Edwin P. Kane. Revered brother-in-law of John Moloney and Mary Kane. Cherished uncle of Arthur Moloney of Floral Park, NY, Mary Ellen Lohne of Garden City, NY, Bernadette McKinney of Mt. Lakes, NJ, Helena Finn US Embassy Ankara, Turkey, Katherine Markiewicz of New Canaan, CT., Dr. Mary Kane-Goldstein of Palo Alto, CA, Joan Dougherty of Huntington, NY, Dr. Edwin P. Kane II of Ridgewood, NJ, John Kane of Huntington, NY, Regina McNamara of Easton, CT. Adored great uncle to nine grandnieces and nine grandnephews. Also survived by many cousins. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Saturday 2-5, 7-9 pm. Sunday 3:30pm at St. Elizabeth's until Mass of Transferral 8pm. Funeral Mass Monday 11am at St. Elizabeth's. Interment Calvery Cemetery Woodside,N.Y. Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Monsignor's name to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o Mr. Ray Murphy, St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, 175 Wolf Hill Road, Melville, NY 11747.

title: Dudley Urged to Look Tough, but Don't Touch
description: Chris Dudley is a well-traveled center, master of the hard foul, a wise and crafty veteran who can be valuable in a limited role.

title: As Management Wavers, Mets' Troubles Increase
description: Hours before they were to begin their series with the Yankees, the Mets found themselves facing a huge distraction involving two of their veteran outfielders, one that seemed to compound the crisis in which the Mets already found themselves.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a technical error, a picture in Weekend yesterday showing Gao Fenghan's album page ''In Wind and Snow'' (1737), from the exhibition ''The Embodied Image: Chinese Calligraphy From the John B. Elliott Collection,'' at the Art Museum of Princeton University through July 3, was reproduced upside down and in mirror image. The flowers should have appeared at the lower right, below the writing.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN PHONE USE
description: The Federal Telecommunications Commission of Mexico reported increased use of mobile phones in May after a system that charges callers was put into effect. The agency disputed a report by Salomon Smith Barney that cellular phone use fell 50 percent in May. One beeper company in Mexico also attributed a recent 30 percent increase in clients to frustration with costlier cellular phones. When the ''caller pays'' system went into effect for mobile phone users on May 1, the Government also authorized higher rates, as high as 75 cents for a three-minute call, and added complicated dialing procedures. Rick Wills(NYT)

title: A Plethora of Pollen; Allergy Sufferers Don't Need a Machine to Tell Them -- Achoo!
description: On top of a building in downtown Brooklyn -- with nice views of the harbor on one side and Manhattan on the other -- sits a little monitor of human misery called a Rotorod Sampler, Model 140.

title: Mets Remain Mired In Their Confusion
description: The Mets were deep in confusion and controversy before their clubhouse opened three and a half hours before last night's monumental game with the Yankees. Reporters scurried through the door in search of Bobby Valentine, Brian McRae and Bobby Bonilla and initially found nothing -- except for Al Leiter standing alone in his long underwear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, ABRAHAM
description: MALKIN-Abraham. Beloved huband of Sherry. Devoted father of Barbara and Sam. Caring fatherin-law of Steven and Barbara. Loving brother of Sol and Rosie. Adored grandfather of Lawrence, Lori, Suzanne and Karyn. Services were held on Friday.

title: J. J. McKeithen, 81, Governor Of Louisiana, 1964 to 1972
description: John J. McKeithen, Louisiana's first Governor to serve two consecutive terms, who practiced moderation at a time of intense racial conflict in the Deep South and gave New Orleans the Superdome, died yesterday at a hospital in Columbia, La. He was 81 and lived in Columbia.

title: Mayor and City Council Leaders Reach Budget and Tax Agreement
description: After two weeks of relatively painless negotiations, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders agreed yesterday on a $35.3 billion budget that takes advantage of record high tax revenues and contains only a smattering of tax cuts.

title: Russians and NATO Negotiating Pact Details
description: American leaders and NATO officials said today that Slobodan Milosevic has yet to take concrete steps to back up the peace accord for Kosovo and warned that the deal could still slip away.

title: U. of Chicago President to Return to Teaching
description: The president of the University of Chicago, Hugo F. Sonnenschein, whose moves to expand and modernize one of the nation's most revered universities became controversial, announced yesterday that he would step down next year and return to teaching.

title: BRAZILIAN NATURAL GAS PROJECT
description: As part of the Brazil's effort to increase the use of natural gas as an energy source instead of petroleum, a group of state-controlled energy companies and regional administrations announced plans for two gas pipelines to fuel the electric energy grids of three far-flung Amazonian states. Led by the state oil and gas company Petrobras, the group, which also includes Eletrobras, a state holding company for energy investments, plans to invest about $860 million in the project. The pipelines are part of a larger push by federal authorities to improve infrastructure in some of Brazil's most remote regions. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; For the Buddhist Calendar, Quite a Busy Few Weeks
description: As the number of Americans practicing or at least interested in Buddhism grows, so, not surprisingly, do the number of public events associated with Buddhism, and the attention paid it by the news media and book publishers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a Federal crackdown on computer hackers referred incorrectly to a statement by F0rpaxe, a group claiming ''massive attacks'' on Web sites. The statement was sent to the Hacker News Network, an Internet-based clearinghouse for hacker-related information, not to the Web site Anti-Online, which reprinted it.

title: Firefighter Was Seeking Victims Who Had Escaped
description: Fire officials said yesterday that the death of Capt. Vincent Fowler came after he had become trapped in the fiery basement of a Queens home Thursday night during a fruitless search for victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMOON, SIMON
description: SHAMOON-Simon. Beloved husband of Angele. Beloved father of Harry, Alan, and Sandra. Beloved grandfather of Evan, Mark, Michael, David, Elisabeth, Tina, and Benjamin. Cherished father-in-law of Rona, Kathleen and Robert. Beloved brother of Marcelle and Niazi. Shivah will be held at the family home in Great Neck, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday from 2-5 P.M. and prayers at 8 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the charity of your choice.

title: ISLANDERS
description: Zigmund Palffy, the Islanders' only remaining box-office draw, may be the next player traded, probably before the June 26 entry draft, as the team's massive payroll cuts continue.

title: Shares Rally, Indicating Investors See Higher Interest Rates
description: Stock prices rallied yesterday and bond prices moved slightly lower as investors signaled that they were ready for the rate increase that many expect when Federal Reserve policy makers meet at the end of this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, NORMAN
