description: BERNSTEIN - Norman. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member Norman Bernstein and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Rita and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Martin Kay

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, RUTH
description: WHITNEY-Ruth. The Board and Staff of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund mourn the loss of our board member and friend, Ruth Whitney. A lifelong advocate for women and girls, Ruth Whitney brought wisdom, grace and commitment to her membership in the NOW LDEF Board. We benefited from her feminist leadership, her boundless creativity, and her down-to-earth good sense. We are grateful for her legacy, and we will miss her. We extend our sympathy to her family, especially her son Philip.

title: Some Unrest In Indonesia As Election Approaches
description: In a reminder of the dangers that surround Indonesia's parliamentary election, a whiff of violence came to the capital today as the police fired warning shots to halt an attack on supporters of the ruling party.

title: Nelson Is Out Until August
description: Jeff Nelson, a crucial part of the Yankees' bullpen for the last three seasons, will have surgery next week to remove bone chips from his right elbow and will not return until August at the earliest.

title: Blacks at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Occupancy Falls Slightly As Hotel Room Prices Rise
description: Despite the tourist boom, the occupancy rate for New York City hotels has dropped for the first four months of this year compared with the same period last year, in part because the average cost of a night's stay has climbed above $200 and because more hotels have opened.

title: A Race for the Riders
description: Chris Antley moved Charismatic down the backstretch in the Preakness, hopeful but not confident that he could capture the second leg of the Triple Crown. As he reached the half-mile mark, the jockey felt trapped by what he believed was a struggling Stephen Got Even on his outside.

title: Helms to Start Four Hearings On Holbrooke On June 17
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee announced today that the panel was ready to hold hearings on the long-stalled nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as the chief American diplomat at the United Nations. But the Senator made it clear that the nomination was anything but a sure bet.

title: Cards' Triple Crown Winner Specializes in 'Impossible'
description: In bridge, the triple crown belongs to a player who has won the World Team Olympiad, the Bermuda Bowl and the World Pairs. One of the six living owners of that title is Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., who specializes in making ''impossible'' contracts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
description: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on Monday, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher

title: About New York; Through Rain, Sleet and Bites From Dogs
description: THE Ryder post office on East 45th Street near Flatbush Avenue is the busiest in Brooklyn, and on Thursday morning the talk among the men and women in gray and blue was of dogs. There are about 350,000 dogs in Brooklyn and only 2,200 mail carriers, a ratio that helps explain why the United States Postal Service this week ranked Brooklyn fifth on its annual list of Top 10 Dog Bite Cities.

title: Editorial Notebook; Contemporary Art in a Factory Setting
description: From a window on the second floor of Mass MOCA, the newly opened museum of contemporary art in North Adams, Mass., you can look out over a side street in that once-industrial town. Water slides from a storm drain into a massive concrete spillway that is actually one branch of the Hoosic River. Above the spillway there is a row of old-fashioned two-story houses whose porches have gone slack with time. A grocery-store clerk walks down the block gathering stray shopping carts and stacking them in the back of his pickup. Beyond the block, the hills rise sharply in the near distance, as they do everywhere in North Adams, which is set in a deep crease in the northern Berkshires.

title: Helen Huang, Stephen Kuster
description: Helen Hui-ling Huang, the daughter of Pi-yu and Min-nan Huang of Madison, Wis., was married yesterday to Stephen Lawrence Kuster, a son of Patricia and Thomas Kuster of Scotia, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth J. Fiedler performed the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Madison.

title: Scene of the Crime Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: May 30-June 5; 9 Die in Arkansas Crash As Plane Lands During Storm
description: An American Airlines jet crashed on landing in Little Rock, Ark., killing eight passengers and the pilot. Investigators first began concentrating on the severe weather, which may have blown the plane off the runway, but it soon became clear that the reason for the incident may be far more complex. Federal officials said some of the plane's braking devices did not appear to have been properly set up. Although the pilot was experienced, he had been on duty near the maximum of 14 hours. DAVID FIRESTONE

title: Neighbors Say Ballplayers' Cars Park Too Close to Plate
description: Two weeks ago, Michael Cohen, a 30-year-old insurance underwriter, was bicycling home from work though East River Park, when a car drove up behind him going about 30 miles an hour.

title: Hey, Philadelphia, You Call That a Cheese Steak?
description: IF you are from Philadelphia, you had best flip the page. Or set down the paper and take a walk or putter in the garden for a while. The next words you read will be heresy.

title: In a Reflective Mood
description: Mirror, mirror on the cloth, who is the brightest dresser of them all? Since Cleopatra looked at her reflection, mirrors and fashion have been inseparable. This season, designers have put bits of mirrors on their clothes as decoration. The hippies and flower children of the 1960's decorated their psychedelic and tie-dyed clothes with bits of mirror. Today, the mirrored accessories are brightening up the understated look, as the vocabulary of fashion recycles itself to the drumbeat of a new generation. The mirrored clothes are coming from thrift shops and designer boutiques in the East Village and SoHo and on Madison Avenue. No one worries about bad luck when the mirrors break.

title: The Case for a Rate Increase is Still Strong
description: INVESTORS, it seemed, were ready to concede that the Federal Reserve would have to raise interest rates to slow growth and curb inflation.

title: The World: Democracies Built on Rays of Hope; In Indonesia, The Voting Is Only A First Step
description: WITH drums, whistles and war whoops, with dancers, tumblers and female impersonators, Indonesians have grasped the first great truth about free elections: They can be lots of fun.

title: Selling Reminders of 2 Sisters' Spirit
description: The memento seekers who lined up at the two-story brick home at the end of a cul-de-sac today were a mixed crowd of women and men, black and white.

title: 5 Law Officers Acquitted of Plotting to Frame Man in Killing
description: A former prosecutor and four sheriff's deputies were acquitted on Friday of conspiring to frame an innocent man in the murder of a 10-year-old girl, sending him to death row for 10 years.

title: Creating a Comeback at Nissan
description: ''SOMETHING special is happening,'' intones the trim, energetic middle-aged man in a gray V-neck sweater. ''You can feel it.''

title: A Nigerian Discovers America
description: The road from Nigeria to Texas is a long one, and for Murphy Popoola it leads to this small Houston apartment with a dirt-encrusted bathtub and a pile of telephone books that pass for a table. Oil country, Texas and Nigeria: hard places, but there, thinks Popoola, the similarities end. A slender figure, he is slumped in an armchair opposite a television set. A politician is talking about America's unquenchable spirit -- the men and women who went West in their wagons, put us on the moon and will lead us into the next century.''

title: Q and A
description: Canada for Children

title: Return to Naples
description: A TENT IN

title: Call of the Wild Is Ever Clearer
description: HIKING is wildly popular these days, as are rafting and bicycling. So Backroads, a travel company in Berkeley, Calif., did not need a computer program to grasp that a combination would sell. According to Megan Gaynor, a spokeswoman, these trips, begun only in 1997, are the fastest growing in the company's catalogue.

title: All the Places That Stay Open After Brokers and Lawyers Leave
description: To dispel the myth that a) there are only a handful of amenities in lower Manhattan, and b) that handful is closed on weekends, the Downtown Alliance has published ''Destination Downtown: A Guide to Lower Manhattan.'' The pamphlet lists names, phone numbers and addresses of more than 1,100 businesses and services from Chambers Street to Battery Park: museums and messenger services, Caribbean restaurants and community organizations. Establishments that remain open on weekends are marked. The publication is free and one can get a copy by visiting http://www. downtownny.com or calling (212) 835-2767. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Cohen Is Putting No Time Limit on U.S. and Other NATO Forces in Kosovo
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that there was no time limit on the deployment of NATO forces, including 7,000 American troops, in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, GABRIELLE
description: BLUESTEIN-Gabrielle. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Gabrielle Bluestein, a dear friend and very generous supporter. For many years she and her late husband Milton, supported the annual Bluestein Leadership Conference in Washington, DC and provided inspiring leadership to ADL's Palm Beach Regional Office. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughters Barbara and Marion, her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Civil War re-enactors misidentified a re-enactor unit that participated in an event in Riverhead in mid-May. It is the 15th New York Engineers, not the 5th.

title: Oh, My Aching Flippers! Masseur Makes Aquarium Calls
description: When Anthony Guglielmo, a licensed massage therapist, goes to the New York Aquarium for his twice-monthly visits, he is greeted with loud barks of delight. The warm welcome comes from his 1,800-pound aquatic patient, an 18-year-old Alaskan walrus named Nuka.

title: Local Heroes
description: THE MIRACLE

title: As a Town Opts For Open Space, Not All Rejoice; Somers Says Limiting Lot Sizes Will Save Small-Town Life. But Developers and Others Say Their Rights Are Sacrificed.
description: AT the historic Town Hall here, in a faded red brick hotel erected more than 175 years ago, Supervisor Mary Beth Murphy is braving the ire of property owners and the threat of lawsuits to pursue what many believe is an impossible dream: preserving a small-town way of life in one of the few remaining places in Westchester where it still exists.

title: Historians Fight to Save Cleveland's Ore Unloaders
description: It may seem hard to imagine now, but Cleveland's four Hulett automatic ore unloaders used to mount a mesmerizing show on the lake front, west of downtown. From 1912 until 1992, these 96-foot behemoths lumbered along the shore, leaning forward and sinking their jaws into the bellies of Great Lakes ships, taking 17-ton bites of iron ore and spitting them into nearby rail cars. They looked like a family of grazing dinosaurs as they dipped forward, reared back again, and rumbled their odd, metallic song.

title: A Script for the Senate Race
description: It is not surprising that almost all the discussion about the upcoming Senate race in New York concerns personalities. The cast of characters is, after all, larger than life. First Lady Hillary Clinton has all but officially announced her candidacy, as has Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. If Mr. Giuliani has to fight for the Republican nomination against Representative Rick Lazio of Long Island, chances are that the Mayor's combative persona will be the focus of that primary as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAKAS, THEODORA
description: VAKAS-Theodora. Age 81. On June 4. Devoted wife of the late John; beloved sister of Demetrios and Vilma Caraley; loving aunt of David Caraley, Lisa Paterson and Anne Caraley; adoring great-aunt of Wyatt James and Lucy Belle Paterson. Viewing 10:30AM and service 11:30AM Monday, June 7, Prophet Elias Church, 15 Leroy Ave., Yonkers. For information 212-942-4000

title: At 55, a Newly Minted Physician
description: His silver hair glinted in the sun, and a tear glistened in his eye. At the commencement ceremonies for Albert Einstein College of Medicine last week, Robert J. Lopatin looked like any of the proud fathers watching their children start medical careers.

title: Correction
description: A correction in this section on May 23, referring to an April 11 article about Alfred Hitchcock, was published in error. The name of an actor about whom Hitchcock spoke highly was correct in the original article -- Roscoe Lee Browne, not Brown.

title: Warming Up To Summer
description: Benefits for children and culture, plus three views of fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALCOFF, FRANCES DANZIG
description: WALCOFF-Frances Danzig. Devoted wife of the late Abraham H. Walcoff, beloved of Arnold Danzig, Dale Nadel (Harry) Jodi Danzig, Dana Frank (Chad) Lawrence Nadel, Richard Nadel, Casey, Tanner and Juliette Frank. You will be in our hearts forever. Graveside services today, June 6, 1 PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, ELLIOT
description: LEVINSON-Elliot. On June 4, 1999. Beloved son of the late Irving and Gladys Levinson. Dear brother of the late Michael Levinson and cherished uncle. A fabulous friend to thousands and beloved by all. He will always be remembered for his generosity, friendship, goodwill and for his many, many acts of kindness. From his family, friends, ''buddies'' and neighbors. Services Monday, June 7, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: When Megan's Law Proves Effective
description: ''Trying to Sort Out Legalities of Megan's Law'' cited some people who thought that community notification about sex offenders is mostly ineffective. While the most sensible strategy for protecting the public from sexual predators is proper assessment, treatment and increased supervision of sex offenders before and after their release, community notification is working effectively in many places across the country.

title: Janice Miller, Edward Baig
description: Janice Renee Miller was married last evening to Edward Charles Baig at Temple Israel in Canton, Ohio. Rabbi John Spitzer performed the ceremony.

title: Lisa Stanger, Gregory Colodner
description: Lisa Anne Stanger and Dr. Gregory Colodner are to be married today by Rabbi Lester Bronstein at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Prosecution That Spared Espy Leaves a Top Aide in Ruins
description: At first glance, Ronald H. Blackley, a high school graduate who says he never earned more than $30,000 a year back home in Mississippi, does not seem like the kind of target Congress had in mind when it created special prosecutors.

title: Yanks' Trophy Case Adds Subway Series As Mets' Skid Hits 8
description: Searching for a cure for their losing streak, the Mets veterans Robin Ventura and Brian McRae suggested the players wear their pant legs higher in yesterday's game with the Yankees. What a simple and comical way to ease tension, to bond as a team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, THEL WELLES
description: BURKE-Thel Welles. 78. Died Saturday, June 5, 1999 in Richmond, VA after a brief illness. She is survived by her husband, Russell E. Burke, 2nd of Richmond, VA; daughter Martha Burke Deprez of Portland, ME; sons Russell E. Burke, 3rd of NYC and Laurance G. Burke of Richmond; seven grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Interment private.

title: Filming the Drama Between the Novelist's Lines
description: WHEN he re-read Graham Greene's ''End of the Affair'' some six years ago, the screenwriter and director Neil Jordan was struck, as he had been years earlier, by its wrenching evocation of the dark forces that drive human behavior. Movie rights to the story, about a tragically thwarted love affair in London during World War II, had long been owned by Columbia Pictures, which had made a film of ''The End of the Affair'' in 1955, two years after the book was published. But the movie, which starred Deborah Kerr and the American musical-and-Western star Van Johnson, was widely considered a dud, and it quickly faded into merciful obscurity.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Prospect Street NYC Discovery, a venture capital fund created with New York City tax money, misstated its performance. In the four years ended March 31, the fund's internal rate of return averaged 100 percent a year; it was not 108 percent cumulatively.

title: Sympathetic Brutes In a Pop Masterpiece
description: THE absurdist view of history, the version that probably makes the most sense in the age of Monicagate and the Washington follies, suggests that it's people's little quirks and kinks that make big things happen. Modern wars and coups are really the products of mood swings and temper tantrums.

title: When the Cure Becomes the Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: Call Off the Death Watch for Brokers
description: IS the full-service stockbroker going the way of the dodo bird?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, FLORENCE
description: ABRAMS-Florence. On June 3, of NYC. Beloved wife of Reuben W. Abrams. Cherished mother of Marc Ira Abrams. Dear mother-inlaw of Toni Abrams. Graveside services Sunday, 1:00 PM at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital Fund, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bx, NY 10461

title: White House Seeks Ruling on Private School Aid
description: Raising the stakes in the debate over public aid to parochial schools, the Clinton Administration is asking the Supreme Court to review a Federal court's finding that it is unconstitutional for public schools to provide computers and other ''instructional equipment'' for use in religious school classrooms.

title: Film Violence: No Hollywood Defense
description: For years, Hollywood moguls and studio chiefs have sought to use their influence, voices and money for numerous political and social causes, from apartheid, AIDS and migrant farm workers to Democratic candidates for state and national office.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALDIMER, BLEU
description: VALDIMER-Bleu, 30, of NYC. Family and friends mourn the loss of a devoted son and friend. As an entrepreneur, designer and cofounder of Project Dragon, Bleu's generosity, talent and warmhearted spirit touched the lives of countless individuals. He will be deeply missed by all those who had the privilege of knowing him-especially his father Ed, his mother Terry, his sister Leigh, his partners Stash and Futura, and Missi, the love of his life. He will always be in our thoughts. Funeral service Sunday at 1:45 PM, at Riverside Memorial. ''When you coming home Dad, I don't know when, but we'll get together then.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, PAULA R.
description: BERGER-Paula R. Passed away June 2, 1999 (19th Sivan, 5759). Beloved wife of the late Saul Berger, loving mother of Stephen Berger and Bonnie GraBois, adoring grandmother of Dr. Melissa DelBello, (David), Andy GraBois, Robin Berger and Diana Berger. Devoted mother-in-law to Stuart GraBois and Cynthia Wainwright. Born in Poland, she came to New York City at the age of 6-seized its offerings & in turn contributed to its betterment. Political reformer, dedicated to her family, faith and community. Funeral service Friday at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in lieu of flowers, Hi Tech School, C/O Community Synagogue, 325 East 6th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Jennifer Payzant, Jeremy Evans
description: Jennifer Rae Payzant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Payzant of Hampton, N.H., was married yesterday to Jeremy Andrew Miles Evans, the son of Ruth Oliver Morley of Cambridge, Mass., and the Rev. John Miles Evans of Davidsonville, Md. The bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Mattapoisett, Mass.

title: The Eponym
description: To the Editor: How could anybody write about Rosenblatt Stadium in Omaha (''What's Doing in Omaha,'' May 16) and fail to mention that Johnny Rosenblatt, a former mayor of Omaha, was a local hero and remains so?

title: In the Region / Long Island; Plans Afoot to Stem Flight of the Young Labor Pool
description: AFTER looking for a year and a half for a house in the East Meadow area where they grew up and where their parents still live, James and Jane Klobus finally found one -- a 45-year-old four-bedroom ranch priced at $190,000. They found the property through Atanas Realty in Williston Park.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OMERON, GUENETH C.
description: OMERON-Gueneth C. Memorial Service Thursday, June 10, 1999, 11AM, Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Opera and Dance, Siblings Too Often Estranged
description: MARK MORRIS'S 1989 staging of Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' deserves a prominent place on any list of major operatic productions of the last quarter-century. Mr. Morris himself danced the double role of Dido, Queen of Carthage -- first flamboyantly sexual, then wild with grief -- and the evil Sorceress who destroys her, and his show-stopping performances are deeply etched in the memories of theatergoers here and abroad. Yet they left little impression on New York opera buffs, for the simple reason that few of them saw ''Dido.'' It has only been shown here for two brief runs (in 1990 and again last spring), both times at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where it was reviewed for the most part by dance critics and attended almost entirely by dance lovers.

title: May 30-June 5; Japanese Officials Move To Lift Ban on the Pill1
description: In a major step toward approving the birth control pill, Japan's top medical advisory council suddenly reversed its position and recommended allowing the pill to be sold. Japan is the only industrialized country to ban the pill, and the issue has been debated for decades. Some feminists argue that the ban reflects male domination of Japanese society and politics.

title: Don't Call It Doo-Wop: His Cause Is 'Street-Corner Harmony'
description: Ronnie I.'s Clifton Music is stacked with albums by groups like the Sparrows, the Cameos and the Fabulaires. The owner, Ronnie Italiano, has dedicated his store, and much of his life, to what he calls ''the group harmony cause.'' Mr. Italiano, better known as Ronnie I., has been host of radio, cable television, and live shows dedicated to early rock-and-roll and also produces and distributes CD's made by current vocal groups. He recently spoke about his the music.

title: Fire Control Report
description: A task force appointed by County Executive Andrew J. Spano to review persistent problems at the county's fire control center in Valhalla has recommended that a countywide department be established to coordinate fire, disaster and emergency medical services.

title: For Charismatic's Camp, an Afternoon of Pain and Shock
description: It wasn't the type of picture Bob Lewis and D. Wayne Lukas had wanted nine hours earlier, when they gathered their friends for a photograph in front of Barn 10 on the backstretch of Belmont Park. At 8:45 A.M. the owner and trainer were full of hope. Their horse, Charismatic, was one and a half miles and 11 horses away from making history as the 12th Triple Crown winner.

title: Ashlee Bunt, Peter Cumello
description: Ashlee Elizabeth Bunt, the daughter of Arlene Bunt of Fairfield, Conn., and James Bunt of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Gregory Cumello, a son of Elizabeth and Charles Cumello of Coral Springs, Fla. The Rev. Henry K. Yordon performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Officially, a Father-Son Suicide, But Mobster's Death Stirs Doubts
description: There was no note, no sign of illness or depression, and no apparent motive for suicide. But there was a folding chair kicked over on the floor, a half-empty bottle of Johnnie Walker Red nearby and two bodies -- one of them a convicted gangster -- hanging from a ceiling beam.

title: Blowing the Fuse On Family Squabbles
description: THE Schoolhouse in Croton Falls, N.Y. has unearthed lost plays to potluck effect. But ''Precious Sons,'' an eight-week Broadway failure in 1986, is its coming-of-age production.

title: More Wealth, More Stately Mansions
description: THE beige, three-story mansion fills a one-acre lot on Clover Street in Memphis. Roof turrets, tall windows, columns that frame the front door at the head of a majestic, sloping driveway all heighten the impression of a palace incongruously placed in an ordinary suburb. The ranch house next door seems, by comparison, like a shack. It is empty, however, soon to be torn down so that another mansion can rise. And a neighborhood of small homes on large leafy lots gradually becomes a neighborhood of million-dollar mansions cheek by jowl.

title: The Desktop Follies
description: Ah, the age of the computer. Remember the dream? The computer would be a work saver, a herald of the paperless office, a docile servant eager to lift burdens, solve problems, increase productivity and leave time for creative thinking. But some dreams, it appears, include comic nightmares.

title: Seafood Tartars That Are Easy Enough to Make at Home
description: SEAFOOD tartars have become as familiar on restaurant menus as oysters or shrimp cocktail. Yet they are dishes people do not normally attempt at home.

title: Post-Race Coverage Sensitive and Strong
description: There have been post-game interviews with players, coaches and managers devastated by losing. Most are de rigeur ''How do you feel?'' affairs without much substance or heart. But few in recent memory matched the interview yesterday by ABC's Charlsie Cantey with the jockey Chris Antley, minutes after he dismounted from Charismatic, who broke down after finishing third in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDWIG, ARTHUR WARREN, M.D.
description: LUDWIG-Arthur Warren, M.D. 80, on June 4, 1999. Assistant Professor Clinical Medicine Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Son of Irving and Anna; beloved husband for 39 years of Laura (nee Ecker); devoted father to Amy, Andrew and Lisa Ludwig Kahn. For over 50 years in research and private practice, much beloved by his patients and friends for his compassion, warmth and humor. WW II combat service, Lt. Surgeon USNR, Alpha Omega Alpha, Sigma Xi. Funeral private; memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I., COL., USAF (RET.)
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I., Col., USAF (Ret.) Formerly of New York City, now of Leander, TX, and West Shokan, NY, died of complications following a stroke in Austin, TX, on Friday, June 4, 1999, at the age of 82. He held BS and MS degrees from New York University, and was one of the first religious school teachers certified by the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. He was long associated with Temple Israel of the City of New York, and after moving to Texas, he and his wife, Rena, became members of Congregation Beth Israel in Austin. He served as a pilot in WWII, flying with the B-24 ''Our Baby'' crew, which he considered his ''second family,'' in the 453rd Bomb Group, 2nd Air Division of the 8th Air Force. He elected to stay in the Air Force reserve, without remuneration, ''because it was his civic duty.'' Eventually promoted to Colonel, he completed his service as Commander of the 9212th Air Reserve Squadron in New York City. He headed his own advertising agency, and was a past President of the League of Advertising Agencies in New York City. A member of the New York Fencers Club, he served on its Board of Governors. Most important to him however, was serving civic organizations dedicated to helping others, and he gave generously of his time-a past President and Trustee of New York Lodge No. 1, B'nai B'rith; a member of ADL's National Commission; past Chairman of the ADL New York Regional Board; past Chairman of the Board of the Metropolitan Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty; a member of the Management Assistance Program of UJA-Federation of NY; and a past President of the New York Society for the Deaf. Somehow, between his business, athletic and civic activities, he found time to marry Rena and spent 45 wonderful years with her. Beloved son of Minnie and William (both deceased). Beloved brother of Manny (deceased) and his wife Fay. Cherished ''UNK'' of Bill and Fran Sonnenreich, Mike and Linda Sonnenreich. Granduncle extraordinaire of David and Sharon Sonnenreich, Wes Sonnenreich, Diana Sonnenreich, Peter Sonnenreich, Nina and John Gafni. Great-uncle of Rachel Sonnenreich and Adina Gafni. Held in great affection-as ''Uncle Joe''-by Camp High Pointers. Treasured cousin of members of his mother's family-affectionately known as the ''Goldberg Clan'' (nee Karachik in Russia). First, last and always, adored husband-partner-best friend of Rena. Visitation and funeral at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue (please call for dates and times). Interment will be at the Temple Israel Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the organization or charity of your choice in his memory.

title: $400 Worth of Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Mina Hwang and Jordan Feig
description: Mina Hwang, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Won T. Hwang of Binghamton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jordan L. Feig, a son of Arlene Shapiro of New York and Stephen Feig of Babylon, N.Y. Rabbi Ari Fridkis performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Worker Exonerated
description: A former worker at the Schnurmacher Nursing Center in White Plains has been found not guilty of abusing a 91-year-old resident, said his lawyer, Matthew S. Spencer of Hawthorne.

title: Free Events Highlight Vocal Music Programs
description: FOUR free (or almost free) concerts emphasize vocal music this week. The almost free event is the Music, Wine and Cheese concert today at 3 P.M. at the New Rochelle Pubic Library, where a $2 donation is requested for an program of songs by Haydn, Schumann, Brahms and several American composers, performed by the Connecticut-based chamber chorus Musica Plenti, under its founding director, Robert Puleo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, RUTH
description: WHITNEY-Ruth. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Society of Magazine Editors mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Ruth Whitney. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to her son Philip, daughter-in-law Christina and members of her family. Jacqueline Leo, President Marlene Kahan, Exec. Director American Society of Magazine Editors

title: Time to Ship Off the Parents To Camp for the Summer
description: FOUR years ago, the Snowshoe Mountain ski area in West Virginia looked into ways to tap the rich markets of the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states in the off season. Mike Valache, a manager, settled on a mountain-biking camp for 12- to 18-year-olds.

title: Veronica Miele And Anson Beard
description: Veronica Evelyn Miele, the daughter of Evelyn Shaw Miele of Whitehouse Station, N.J., and the late Anthony P. Miele Jr., was married yesterday to Anson Hill Beard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anson McCook Beard Jr., of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Ronald P. Stark performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi in New York.

title: Roy Jones Becomes Undisputed Champion
description: Roy Jones Jr. showed again tonight why he is the most dazzling boxer in the sport today. With a punishing display of ring genius against Reggie Johnson, a two-time world champion, Jones took a 12-round unanimous decision and became the first undisputed light-heavyweight champion of the world in 14 years.

title: New Ballet Director
description: Graham Lustig, the London-born choreographer, teacher and former dancer, has been named artistic director of the American Repertory Ballet and the Princeton Ballet School. Mr. Lustig succeeds Septime Webre, who has headed the New Brunswick-based troupe and its adjunct school, the state's largest, for six years.

title: Jennifer Martinez, David McCrystal
description: Jennifer Lynn Martinez, a daughter of Helen and Joseph Martinez of Blauvelt, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Michael McCrystal, a son of Pamela and James McCrystal of Chapel Hill, N.C. Msgr. William Belford performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Uptown Girl
description: 1185 Park Avenue

title: School Hot Line
description: Plagued by bomb threats -- 35 since the school shootings in Littleton, Colo. -- Yonkers school officials have set up a confidential hot line for tips about potential campus violence. The district, which is the fourth largest in the state with 25,000 students, has also offered a $1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of anyone making a bomb threat.

title: Now, the Sport Utility Scooter
description: FIRST, Lincoln Mercury moved to Southern California to take the pulse of trendsetters. Now it is offering the Mountaineer, its version of the Ford Explorer, with a New Age take on banks' free toasters for new accounts.

title: Companies' Tax Breaks
description: After more than six months of negotiations, the New Castle Town Board has unanimously approved a $14.3 million reduction in the assessed value of Reader's Digest's 113-acre Chappaqua campus, to $18.5 million from $32.8 million, Stephen Morello, a spokesman for the publishing company, said last week.

title: Some Room at the Inn
description: Among the saddest to see Robert E. Rubin step down as Treasury Secretary are the employees at the Jefferson Hotel in Washington, where Mr. Rubin has made Room 214 his home for the last six years. Mr. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, kept his permanent residence in New York, where his wife, Judy, remained. His Jefferson suite includes office, living room, exercise room and bedroom. Next door is an office for his Secret Service agents, who are the ones lingering, but never drinking, at the hotel bar while Mr. Rubin dines.

title: Ideas & Trends; Building a Cosmic Tape Measure
description: THROUGHOUT the century, scientists have had to rely on maddeningly oblique methods, laden with assumptions, for measuring the size of the universe. They've had to guess, from purely theoretical considerations, how bright a star or galaxy really is. Then, from its apparent brightness, dimmed by the journey of the light through space, they judge its distance.

title: NOT Because it's There
description: I had, until recently, what you might call a secondhand sense of the power and inspirational character of mountains, gleaned through the usual art and books. I'm neither a skier nor a hiker, and probably the closest I ever came to experiencing what the English writer John Dennis in 1688 called the ''delightful Horrour'' and ''terrible Joy'' of mountains was when I got lost, briefly, in the Green Mountains of Vermont as a 12-year-old at summer camp.

title: Food; Going to Extremes
description: Under a magnifying glass, the tongue is a rugged landscape dotted with thousands of peaks. In the swampy valleys between these summits lie most of our taste buds, sensors equipped to detect the sweet, sour, salty and bitter flavors that pass our lips. Biologically, one of their functions is to warn us of danger. Yet as anyone inclined to adventure knows, danger can be alluring, inspiring us to push the frontiers of safe taste.

title: Hospitals Can Cut Costs, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Belle Burden And Henry Davis
description: Flobelle Fairbanks Burden, the daughter of Amanda M. Burden of Manhattan and the late Carter Burden, was married yesterday to Henry Patterson Davis, a son of Eleanor C. D. Sackett of Groton, Mass., and Rodman T. Davis of Norwalk, Conn. Judge Kimba M. Wood of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the home of the bride's stepmother, Susan L. Burden, in Water Mill, N.Y.

title: For Women, Satisfaction in Rowing
description: THE last thing Barbara Gardner wants to do is catch a crab on the Norwalk River. It's a distraction, she says, from her main goal of rowing an ''eight,'' a sporting activity that is gaining popularity among Connecticut women. They are taking to the state's numerous rivers, pulling an oar and relishing the challenges -- crabs and all.

title: 'Adopting' Masterpieces: Touch of Class or Crass?
description: Getting your name on something at an art museum usually requires a fat bank account. Leonard A. and Evelyn Lauder donated $5 million to have the Whitney Museum of American Art's fifth floor named after them. Samuel J. and Ethel LeFrak gave $10 million to have their names put on the rotunda of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, simply endowing a curatorship costs more than $500,000.

title: Mexico Sets Entry Fee For Most Tourists
description: Starting July 1, Mexico will begin charging foreign tourists 150 pesos, about $15.50 at recent exchange rates, to enter the country.

title: A Place Where Swords Go With Ploughshares
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Kingsbury, Mr. VanDusen
description: Elizabeth Davie Kingsbury, the daughter of Lesley D. DeVoe of Long Branch, N.J., and Frederick H. Kingsbury 3d of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Philip Campbell VanDusen, a son of Carolyn and Bruce VanDusen of Pennington, N.J. The Rev. Paul S. Johnson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Barley Sheaf Farm, an inn in Holicong, Pa.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''CUNY has the chance to be the model for great public urban universities for the next century, the way land-grant institutions were in the last century, and it's absolutely vital to make it right.''

title: The Interest-Rate Watch Continues
description: Until the unemployment report on Friday, investors, worried that the economy might be growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, appeared to be playing ring around the rosy. But before anyone could fall down, markets rebounded in the United States and overseas.

title: Jailed Until Proved Not Guilty; Man's 19-Month Confinement Shows Plight of Those Too Poor to Post Bail
description: The verdict was the one Jose Padro had longed for: not guilty. The sentence, though, was irreversible: 19 months in jail.

title: Patricia Small and A.J. Bellia
description: Patricia Louise Small and Anthony Joseph Bellia Jr. were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Winchester, Mass. The Rev. J. Donald Monan, the chancellor of Boston College and a great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Jane Hunter And Mark Walsh
description: Jane Allen Hunter and Mark Dalton Walsh were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederic Reynolds at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester, N.Y. The Rev. J. Robert Yeazel, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUDERS, A.E. (BILL) JR.
description: LUDERS-A.E. (Bill) Jr. Memorial service will be held Friday, June 11, 4:00 P.M. at the Church of Holy Spirit on Schofieldtown Road, North Stamford, CT.

title: Till You Drop
description: WHY WE BUY

title: American Women at the Wheel; By Blazing a Coast-to-Coast Trail, She Helped Put a Nation on the Road
description: IT was a soggy bon voyage. Alice Huyler Ramsey stood in the rain outside the Maxwell auto company's New York showroom on the Upper West Side, holding a bouquet of carnations and posing for photographers as she waited impatiently to climb into her car for a cross-country drive. The trip would not merit attention today, but Ramsey, who left for San Francisco 90 years ago this week, was intent on becoming the first woman to drive across America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, JOHN A.
description: DOUGLAS-John A. 74. Died suddenly April 12, 1999 in Naples, FL. He is survived by his beloved wife Donna; seven children; seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. He was co-owner and CEO of Colonial Art Decorators, Inc. for 40 years and served on the Board of the Master Painters Association of America. A memorial service is being held on Saturday, June 12, 1999 at the Holy Family Church in New Rochelle.

title: Sports of The Times; Bit Part Behind Him, Camby Does Star Turn
description: THIS was a magical night at the Garden. For all the drama at the end, for the thunderous roar, the Knicks' lightning in a bottle -- half of it contained in spots -- was finally let loose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMA, STEVEN
description: TOMA-Steven. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Steven Toma, associated with The Times from 1964 until retiring in 1981.

title: A Himalayan War Threatens All Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: New Parks Patrol Will Skate After Offenders on Wheels
description: The Parks Department plans to send out a ''skate patrol'' in two of the city's busiest parks this summer. Its mission: to rein in aggressive in-line skaters and reckless cyclists.

title: Gimmicks Won't Teach Children Character; Abuse vs. Growing Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Bengali Woman Writes Book, Takes Heat
description: Mina Saha Farah, a Bengali dentist who lives and works in Queens and has written for Bengali newspapers, insists that when she started out to write a book last November, she planned it as a critique of organized religion.

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Note-worthy column since the 1998 Holiday Books issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, HAROLD, M.D.
description: FAY-Harold, M.D. Died on May 30, 1999 in FL at age 99. Survived by wife Celeste and son Allen. First wife, Helen died in 1980.

title: Bloomsbury's Secret
description: Duncan Grant

title: Regents a Barrier to Vocational Education
description: MICHELLE CALDRON starts every school day at North Babylon High School, but afternoons she goes to the Lewis A. Wilson Technological Center in Dix Hills, where she studies video production.

title: Computers for 'Star Wars' or Just the Stars
description: WHAT do big Hollywood special-effects movies have in common with a multicolored graphic that simulates a black hole in space?

title: Ideas & Trends: Painting by Numbers; My Renoir Beats Your Vermeer
description: SUMMER is blockbuster season, from the multiplex to the august halls of culture. That's one way to explain a big van Gogh show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Or ''Impressionists in Winter,'' the first exhibition to assemble the snowscapes of Monet, Renoir, Gauguin and others, served up by the Brooklyn Museum of Art in the city's hottest months.

title: Q&A/Edwin T. Merritt; A Superintendent Who Has Learned Unwanted Lessons
description: EDWIN T. MERRITT has been an educator for more than four decades, the past 14 years as superintendent of schools in Trumbull.

title: Found in the Woods
description: There is a wood I know, deep, airy and old, a virginal forest where I roamed one evening not long ago, and then stopped and made my camp, content to have the city at last behind me, to be edified, instead, by trees -- spiring hemlock, oak, maple and sweet gum, trees undisturbed by ax or saw since the Siwanoy and Weckquaesgeek Indians hunted there.

title: Chilling Out With B.T.U.'s
description: THE SETTING -- The streets of the Bronx and everywhere else in the city were hot and steamy Tuesday evening, but it was steamier still in the basement of the Sears store at 400 East Fordham Road. A steady stream of people complained about sweaty days and sleepless nights, and sought respite in a corner of the basement where a dozen air-conditioners were arrayed. Savoring the cool air, shoppers compared prices, energy efficiency ratings and horror stories as the machines hummed.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Shandara Durkee, Donald Dawes
description: Dr. Shandara Lynne Durkee, a daughter of Marilyn R. Durkee and Robert K. Durkee, both of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Donald Murray Dawes, a son of Suzanne and David Dawes of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. Joseph C. Williamson, the dean of religious life and the dean of the chapel at Princeton University, performed the ceremony there.

title: Cleaning and Restoring Wood Decks
description: AFTER prolonged exposure to the elements, the color of the wood in outdoor structures, like decks, lawn furniture and gazebos, will turn from a warm brown to a dingy gray. Fortunately, a number of products, called deck cleaners or deck revivers, can be used to restore the natural color of wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HELENE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Helene. The New York Road Runners Club mourns the passing of Helene Goldstein, a dear friend and supporter of this Club and of the New York City Marathon for more than 20 years. She was an inspiration and a guide to her beloved husband, Joey, who served as our Public Relations Representative, and to her three sons, Robert, Adam and Jared. New York Road Runners Club Allan Steinfeld, President

title: And 6 Hours Later, A Gracious Word From Saint Laurent
description: THE first and by no means only foul-up at the Council of Fashion Designers of America's annual awards gala last Wednesday was that hardly any of the guests at the Lexington Avenue armory could see one another. This was crushing: 1,200 of New York's most glamorous people poured into a kind of holding room for cocktails and -- sink! -- it looked like a cave. Somebody had draped the room in black and dimmed the lights. You had to be practically on top of a person to see who it was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, PENELOPE
description: SCHINDLER - Penelope. The Headquarters Committee of The New York Junior League is deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague. Penny was an adoring mother, devoted wife and dedicated volunteer. We will forever miss her warmth and enthusiasm. Elizabeth King and Margie Orenstein, Chairmen

title: Great Pains
description: HOW ANIMALS MATE

title: FILM; The Spy Who Came In From the Cool Is a Bit of a Yankee
description: I HAD been missing the 60's world -- one so special that the word ''shag'' could mean a carpet, a hairdo and a carnal act. Where was short-cropped, tiny Twiggy, slouching in a sheath, batting her Yardley eyes? Where were the moptops in their narrow Nehrus? And why were Mod velvet suits and ruffled collars today seen only at a certain kind of formal wedding? These were questions that made a wistful Anglophile wonder exactly when England stopped swinging like a pendulum do and totally lost its mojo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSKY, IDA
description: PINSKY-Ida. On June 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Nat. Loving sister of George Morris. Dear aunt of Judge Judith Kaye, Dr. Arnold Tein, Allen Smith and Allen Pensky. Also survived by grandnieces and nephews. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Baryshnikov's Sly And Witty 'Quixote'
description: 'Don Quixote'

title: Praise to the Coaches Of Little Girls of Spring
description: To the Editor:

title: Old-Fashioned but Not Jerky: Lab-Coated Soda Spritzers
description: At the Victory, a two-month-old cafe and takeout spot in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, customers who sidle up to the counter are served a dose of tongue-in-cheek theatrics with their old-time drinks. Servers in lab coats measure out fruity homemade soda syrups in glass beakers, and mix them with carbonated water spritzed from silver-spouted blue bottles ($2.75).

title: Speeding Up a Passport (Before Panic Sets In)
description: ANDREW SCHWARZ, a New York real estate executive, was at a meeting in Atlantic City last month when he got the call. His office wanted him in Tokyo that weekend.

title: Belnord Vacancy but Not for Long
description: For years, the storefronts in the landmark Belnord apartment house on Amsterdam Avenue between 86th and 87th Streets were occupied by small shops like Aquarius Hardware and Houseware and the DH Gourmet Deli. But what was once a row of six storefronts has been empty for months now. Though CVS has been planning for more than a year to open a new drugstore there, many neighborhood residents are wondering why the space is still vacant.

title: Man Killed and 10 Injured When a Speeding Truck Crashes on the Upper West Side
description: One man was killed and 10 people were injured on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last night when a pickup truck sped through a busy intersection and struck four cars and two pedestrians, the police said. The driver was arrested on suspicion of drunken driving.

title: Classic French Fare, Stately Surroundings
description: AFTER a short hiatus (the result of damage caused by the demolition of the adjoining Hyperion Theater), the Union League Cafe in New Haven has reopened. The good news is that the interior is as attractive as ever, polished, sophisticated, comfortable and inviting.

title: Cooking
description: THIS could be the Summer of Salt Cod. Even if you never thought such an unpromising ingredient would enter your kitchen, the season's most talented and enthusiastic cookbook writers are determined to have you soaking pieces of milky gray, dried white fish as cheerfully as you husk corn into paper bags -- and whipping it into garlicky, creamy brandade. Of course, your summer cooking plans may involve only what you can get at the farm stand, but here are some suggestions about what to do when you feel like turning on a burner, and what to read when you don't.

title: Interest Rebate Card Dies
description: As the Cornerstone Mastercard program of Mellon Bank comes to an end, customers are being freed from a dubious, though superficially attractive, bargain.

title: At Silvermine, a Single Judge's Choices for Art of the Northeast
description: THE Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan has been host to an annual competition that began in 1949 as the New England Exhibition, but is now called Art of the Northeast. In the beginning the show had judges drawn from many areas of the art world; now a single judge chooses the works, a circumstance that certainly produces more interesting results than a committee would.

title: Twiggy and Noel Coward Take One More Turn
description: HIS name notwithstanding, he missed being born on Christmas by more than a week. His name notwithstanding, he was a brave man, brave enough to fire off epigrams for the West End in London in the wake of Oscar Wilde.

title: Children's Books
description: SKELLIG

title: Ms. Moran, Mr. Harrington
description: Alexandra Moran and Michael Harrington were married yesterday in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Dr. John Randolph Price performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church.

title: Sidewalk Widening Plan Is Widely Opposed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, NORMAN H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Norman H. Of Roslyn Heights. Died unexpectedly on June 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Janet and Craig Hoffman, Alan and Darcy Bernstein, Gary and Dale Bernstein and Robert and Lesley Bernstein. Proud grandpa of Adam, Jason, Ethan, Geoffrey, Stuart, Zack, Kerri, Max and Spencer. Services today 10 AM, Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn, Roslyn Rd., Roslyn Heights.

title: Sports of The Times; A Play Maybe Nobody Had Ever Seen Before
description: WITH one overhand heave of his black leather glove (with the ball in it) to throw out a runner at first base, Orlando (El Duque) Hernandez did what so often happens in a baseball game and what is baseball's eternal charm. He did something you've never seen before.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILFORD, JACK
description: GILFORD-Jack. July 25, 1908June 4, 1990. Remembered and loved forever. Madeline and all the Gilfords

title: On the Road With God's Fool
description: The road from Assisi to Gubbio is sometimes a footpath, a horse track, a Roman street and now, a gravel road that winds through a roller-coaster landscape of treeless peaks and deep stream-cut valleys all dotted with tiny farms and fortresslike monasteries where 13th-century travelers could spend the night. It is called the Sentiero Francescano della Pace because it is the path that Francesco di Bernardone -- better known as St. Francis -- is believed to have taken after he stood naked in Assisi's central piazza, renounced family and friends and set out on the journey that effectively defined the rest of his life as wanderer, seeker, ultimately saint.

title: Talk Your Way Out of This
description: Some people who claim that they do not have to pay income taxes are being hit with tough penalties by United States Tax Court judges.

title: Florio Flashes His Weapon, And James Carville Appears
description: It was just the week before the Israeli elections last month and James Carville, the Democratic consultant who was serving as an adviser to Ehud Barak, was already thinking about his next race, in, of all places, New Jersey.

title: Handicapping Wall Street As Old Line Goes on Line
description: IN hindsight, rather than extolling the Internet, maybe securities firms should have advised customers to stay away.

title: Ms. Richardson And Mr. Vigdor
description: Elizabeth Anne Richardson and Jacob Lawrence Vigdor were married yesterday by the Rev. Timothy E. Crellin at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: May 30-June 5; Reporters Ordered to Jail In Olympic Bomb Case
description: An Atlanta judge ordered two reporters for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution to be jailed for refusing to reveal the sources who told them that Richard A. Jewell, a part-time security guard, was a leading suspect in the bombing at the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta. Another man has been charged in the bombing, and Mr. Jewell is suing the newspaper for libel. Peter C. Canfield, the attorney for the newspaper, has filed an appeal.

title: May 30-June 5; Barnes & Noble Withdraws Offer to Buy Ingram
description: Barnes & Noble, the nation's biggest bookseller, decided to withdraw its $600 million offer to buy the Ingram Book Group, the largest book wholesaler, after Federal officials prepared to challenge the deal on antitrust grounds.

title: Schulhofer Horse Matures in a Hurry
description: On Friday, the trainer Scotty Schulhofer took a look at Lemon Drop Kid and thought back to how he felt before sending Colonial Affair out to victory in the 1993 Belmont Stakes.

title: SOAPBOX; Spend It or Lose It
description: WHAT would you do with $7,500?

title: Brazilian Visas
description: To the Editor: We took a cruise from Buenos Aires to Barcelona on the Pacific Princess this spring. Preparing to embark on March 27, to our surprise we were asked for visas for Brazil. We learned that all American citizens must have them even if they are not planning to disembark.

title: 1492: The Prequel
description: From the sea, the tiny East African island of Pate, just off the Kenyan coast, looks much as it must have in the 15th century: an impenetrable shore of endless mangrove trees. As my little boat bounced along the waves in the gray dawn, I could see no antennae or buildings or even gaps where trees had been cut down, no sign of human habitation, nothing but a dense and mysterious jungle.

title: Former Insider Still Hopes Leaders Will Rethink the 1989 Tiananmen Crackdown
description: Since last year, Bao Tong, a former senior Communist Party official, has been prodding and exhorting China's leaders to rethink their verdict on June 4, 1989, when soldiers used guns to quash a massive pro-democracy protest, killing hundreds in and around Tiananmen Square.

title: Returning to Long Beach Because of Its Schools
description: I grew up in Long Beach [''Long Beach, Young Again,'' May 16], attended college out of town and vowed never to return. Twenty years later, here I am raising my own family.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an erroneous Sunday Evening program grid appears on page 22 of the Television section today in regional copies distributed outside New York City. In order, the first eight channels shown should be labeled 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11 and 13.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the New Jersey section today, about the varied personalities of shore resorts, misspells the surname of a former Philadelphia mayor who spent time in Longport. He was William J. Green, not Greene.

title: Salon With a Snarl
description: THE other day at Mud Honey, a hair salon on Sullivan Street that caters to a rock 'n' roll clientele, the five members of the Toilet Boys, whom their manager likes to call ''gorgeous East Village gutter trash,'' were getting their hair trimmed and touched up. After touring in Canada to promote an upcoming CD, ''Sinners and Saints'' (Cold Front), the long nights in smoky clubs had taken their toll on Miss Guy, the cross-dressing lead singer. His hair was an insipid shade of tobacco yellow instead of his signature platinum blond.

title: A Sandy Stage For Many A Character
description: IN the summer of 1915, World War I rendered Europe a risky destination for American artists who considered the expatriate experience an essential rite of passage. That summer, many artists and writers, including an obscure young playwright named Eugene O'Neill, instead sought exile in Provincetown, Mass. They were drawn to the tip of Cape Cod by Provincetown's pure northern light, the raven-haired exoticism of its Portuguese fishing population and, perhaps most importantly, cheap rent.

title: A New Wave on Connecticut's Shore
description: THE Connecticut shoreline between New Haven and Old Saybrook has traditionally featured two kinds of restaurants -- the fried fish shack and the Yankee inn. Fortunately, that has changed, and there is a new breed of informal, reasonably priced restaurant serving good food. Some are bistros (and label themselves as such); others are more formal.

title: Social Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Swept Away
description: GODFORSAKEN SEA

title: Ya-Ya Sisters in Retailing
description: THEY are 27 years old, grew up in Virginia and are both Libras.

title: A Roadhouse With a Sophisticated Touch
description: COLIN AMBROSE turns undistinguished coffee shops into memorable restaurants. He did it in Amagansett by transforming Estia, a storefront coffee shop, into a serious restaurant with a relaxed milieu and now he's done it again in spades to what was until recently Tony's Coffee Shop, at 1615 Sag Harbor Turnpike. Mr. Ambrose, a former magazine editor and self-taught chef, followed a simple formula at Estia: creative cooking, low prices, swift, obliging service, casual atmosphere and the freshest of ingredients from an organic garden behind his restaurant (his two-hour salads, from ingredients picked no more than two hours before their use, are an East End legend).

title: Agreement Issued to Build Light Rail Line in South Jersey
description: A long-delayed light rail commuter line between Trenton and Camden came closer to reality last week as New Jersey Transit agreed to award a contract to build the line and to pay for right of way on a stretch of track.

title: Black Like Huck
description: The idea was for Richard Ford and me to retrace the voyage of Huck and Jim down the Mississippi, traveling in an open boat on the big liquid serpent that has been such a magical, monstrous force in the biography of our nation. We were to begin near Hannibal, Mo., Mark Twain's hometown, and make our way down to Cairo, Ill., -- Huck and Jim's destination. But we didn't get nearly that far. One November day was it.

title: Add Cosby to the List Of 'Pussycat' Performers
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl, Of Sorts, For Finals
description: If the Stanley Cup finals were a Presidential campaign, the National Hockey League's ticket would be balanced. The Dallas Stars, who qualified by beating Colorado on Friday night, are an older team from a southern state that borders Mexico. They were the top-seeded team in the Western Conference, they play in an older arena due to be replaced and their coach never played professional hockey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, SOPHIA MILLER
description: CORWIN-Sophia Miller. NY abstract-expressionist painter, sculptor, and printmaker, died May 31, 1999 at 84. Completed 17th solo exhibit at NoHo Gallery in March. Showed her work in N.Y. for over 50 years. She'll be missed for her wit, her adventurous spirit, and her art, by her friends, husband, Jack, daughters, Lauren and Aleka, grandkids, Panchali, Arianna, Miranda, & son-in-law, Bill. Memorial will be held at NoHo Gallery.

title: Meghan Corwin and David Moore
description: Meghan Bette Corwin and David Miller Moore, both architectural designers in New York, were married last evening in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Ujjala Schwartz, an interfaith minister, officiated at Cornwall Landing.

title: PULSE; Riding the Decor Shuttle
description: What's a NoLIta boutique owner to do when she wants to furnish her store in Wallpaper style on a ''This Old House'' budget? Take the shuttle to Elizabeth, N.J., and hunt bargains at Ikea. Kari Sigerson and Miranda Morrison were thinking Capellini, the Italian modern designer, for their shoe shop on Mott Street, but went with the Swedish alternative and used Ikea's Timra coffee tables to display high-priced sandals (below). Just up Mott Street, in the Hedra Prue clothing shop, Steve Kosinski, an interior architect, wanted to build a counter that would have cost $6,000. Instead, he customized a sideboard from Ikea's Bonde collection, adding steel legs. ''Though it's knockdown furniture, if you glue it together, it's really structural,'' said Mr. Kosinski, who also used an Ikea shoe storage unit to house Hedra Prue's underwear inventory. On Mulberry Street, Malia Mills mixed her high-end swimsuits with rock-bottom-price decor: stacked Ikea Vajer bureaus (left). ''We don't want the atmosphere to say to people that there's only expensive things here,'' said Ms. Mills, who assembled the bureaus herself. MARK BORDEN

title: Julie Preston, Matthew Lehman
description: Julie Elizabeth Preston, the daughter of Joan and David Preston of Boston, was married yesterday to Matthew Daniel Lehman, the son of Judge Linda Rocker Silverberg of Cleveland and Harry Lehman of Columbus, Ohio. The bridegroom's mother officiated at the Ocean Edge Resort in Brewster, Mass.

title: Restaurant Reviews Should Range to the South
description: To To the Editor:

title: South Africa: The Voters Realign the Opposition
description: When South Africa's 15,000 polling places have been cleaned up, the white and blue election commission flags taken down and the final votes counted, it may look as if nothing much happened in this week's elections.

title: Kosovo Rebel Force Will Be Serbian Province's New Power Broker
description: The Kosovo Liberation Army, the Albanian separatist movement that remains heavily armed and deeply divided, is likely to become the new power broker in the southern Serbian province under any deal worked out between NATO and Belgrade.

title: $50 Million Farewell For Employees
description: CMP Media, whose trade publications include Computer Reseller News, Information Week and Windows magazine, has long had a reputation for generosity toward its employees. It was one of the first companies on Long Island to set up day care and fitness programs; Working Woman magazine has called it one of the best companies to work for.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DOING THE DEAL -- A special report.; A Long Struggle That Led Serb Leader to Back Down
description: Slobodan Milosevic kicked off the negotiations with his usual historical harangue.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Private Investors Replace REIT's in Office Market
description: OVER the last year, as real estate investment trusts moved to the sidelines as aggressive purchasers of office buildings, private development firms, pension funds and foreign investors have moved in to keep the pace of buying in the state at a healthy, albeit reduced, level.

title: When Cotton Was King In New Orleans
description: Nights in 19th-century New Orleans were famously racy, notorious for drinking, dancing and gambling; by day there was more serious business -- most notably cotton. Before the Civil War, the city was one of the busiest cotton ports in the world; boatloads of cotton poured into the city and created the wealth that built many of the mansions that still grace the Garden District.

title: Conducting Stravinsky: His Own Reading vs. Others'
description: RECORDINGS of Igor Stravinsky conducting his own music date from as early as 1928, when he was 46 and had few doubts about his own significance. The composer continued to record his works until 1966, five years before his death. He was especially active in the studio during the 1950's and early 60's, when Columbia invited him to record virtually his complete operatic, orchestral, choral and larger chamber works under optimal conditions as a lasting legacy.

title: G.O.P. Seeks to Retake Control of County Board
description: WAS it an aberration in 1997 when for the first time ever the Democrats took control of the County Board of Legislators, or is it something more permanent?

title: City Slickers, Lions and Tigers
description: You probably know little about tracking leopards, warding off mosquitos, even handling a rifle (for protection only, of course), much less an elephant's eating habits (300 pounds a day).

title: Price Is No Object.com
description: WHAT'S the modern way to buy a corporate jet?

title: Bookshelves to Grocery Shelves
description: Soft-spoken and even timid in public, Louis Borders, the founder of Borders Books and Music, has entrepreneurial visions that contrast with his demeanor. At a ribbon-cutting ceremony on Wednesday in Oakland, Calif., flanked by Jerry Brown, the city's animated Mayor, Mr. Borders traded literature for food and drink, and bricks and mortar for a virtual storefront, in starting Webvan, a new competitor in the on-line-only grocery store business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGAN, PETER
description: PAGAN-Peter. Our beloved friend Peter died on June 2, 1999 leaving a unique void in all our lives. His special wit and grace will be remembered always. The love he gave us all will be sorely missed. We deeply mourn his passing but celebrate his extraordinary life. Ellie and Dick Marshall Jim, Lorri and Peter Marshall

title: Woman, 36, Killed Near Park When Gunman Misses Target
description: A 36-year-old woman was killed by a stray bullet near a Bronx park on Friday night when a gunman missed his intended victim, the police said.

title: POSTINGS: Yale Robbins Buys Monthly Publication; The Cooperator Is Sold
description: The Cooperator, a monthly publication dealing with condominium issues that also sponsors reference books and an annual day of seminars and exhibits, has been sold to Yale Robbins, a real estate information publishing company. The purchase price was not disclosed. Spinoffs of the 19-year-old publication, with a circulation of more than 32,000, were also part of the deal. Included were rights to two books (''Co-op & Condo Ownership'' and ''The Official Directory of Co-op and Condo Services''), monthly seminars, a Web site (cooperator.com) and a popular annual daylong event, Co-op & Condo Expo.

title: Commercial Property/Environmental Conservation; Economics, Pro and Con, of Making Buildings Green
description: TEN years ago one of the nation's premier environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council, bought an old industrial loft building at 40 West 20th Street and decided to demonstrate its contention that constructing a building designed to be environmentally sound could be financially sound as well.

title: Popular, Yes, but Naive? Not by a Long Shot
description: SINCE the 1940's Selden Rodman of Oakland has been collecting and writing about what is sometimes called naive or folk art, especially from Haiti, where he lived for many years. He prefers to call the art that interests him ''popular art,'' which in fact seems like a better, more flexible designation. Whatever the name, his collection includes some of the best of it. ''Artists in Tune With Their World,'' at the Monmouth Museum here, is a selection of 70 works, about half of them Haitian. Most of them are works Mr. Rodman has donated to Ramapo College of New Jersey; a few remain in his private collection. The show was organized by Carla Rodman, his daughter.

title: Fishing
description: As much as baseball or golf writing, the fly-fishing memoir has become a literary commonplace in which middle-aged American men are encouraged to go on at length, if only sideways, about their feelings. Like the arc of possibility in a clean, sweet single or a well-struck 4-iron, the clockwork gesture of casting a fly somehow moves men to metaphor and memoir. As the big-water, big-tackle enthusiast Herman Melville once wrote, ''Meditation and water are wedded forever.'' Perhaps this is why there has never been a Great American Bowling Novel.

title: A Corporate Parent With Too Big a Family
description: HOW'S this for a strategy? Spot some societal or business problem, and set your scientists to inventing a solution. Buy a company with marketing expertise in the field, and merge it with the nascent technology. Give the scientists-turned-entrepreneurs options on the combined company's stock and sell, or ''spin out,'' a chunk to the public, but hold onto as much as 80 percent yourself. Then use the proceeds to do it again and again.

title: The Nation; Mental Illness Hits The Money Trail
description: SHOULDN'T people with mental illnesses, which can destroy lives and families, be entitled to the same amount of insurance coverage as those with physical illnesses? On the face of it, that sounds like a fairly simple question.

title: Kayla Schwartz and Bud Burridge
description: Michaela Esther Schwartz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tony Schwartz of New York, is to be married this evening to Hollis John Burridge Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burridge Sr. of Johnson City, Tenn. Rabbi Jack Bemporad will officiate at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: 'Precious Sons' on Stage at the Schoolhouse
description: THE Schoolhouse has unearthed plays to pot luck effect. But ''Precious Sons'' by George Furth, an eight-week Broadway failure in 1986, is its coming-of-age production.

title: To Pleasantville Voters, Reject School Proposal
description: Regarding proposed changes to Bedford Road School: Yes, the school is the center of the community. But what really is the issue?

title: When a Son of Matisse Courted a Godfather
description: FOR 60 years, Pierre Matisse, the youngest son of the painter Henri Matisse, shaped American taste in modern art through his gallery in New York. He was the first dealer to show the works of Miro, Balthus, Giacometti and Dubuffet and championed many others artists, including Chagall, Rouault, de Chirico and Tanguy. Among the collectors who sought him out were James Thrall Soby (from 1933), Wright Ludington (from 1934), Edward G. Robinson (from 1935), Walter P. Chrysler Jr. (from 1935) and Joseph Pulitzer Jr. (from 1936). Matisse's particular appreciation of Soby, later a trustee and benefactor of the Museum of Modern Art, is recounted in the following excerpt from ''Matisse: Father and Son,'' a biography by John Russell published this month by Harry N. Abrams, Inc.

title: STRINGS ATTACHED -- A special report.; For Subjects in Haiti Study, Free AIDS Care Has a Price
description: The impoverished patients who step from the dirt sidewalk into the modern AIDS research clinic run by Cornell Medical College in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, are offered a seemingly simple arrangement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, SALLY FRANCES
description: GOODMAN-Sally Frances. 6/5/499/2/82. Sally studied classical ballet at Juilliard. At Tel Aviv University she learned to read and write Hebrew; graduated from Schiller College, Germany (Paris campus) Outstanding Student in French Literature; received a degree from the Sorbonne, Paris; an MS in Library Science from Queens College, NY. All who knew her can remember the joy she brought to them. We celebrate her life. David, Bunny and Tom Goodman

title: For Diverse Palates In the East 20's
description: CENA ***

title: Topless in Tahiti
description: Iolani

title: Sasha Nemecek, Daniel Zalewski
description: Alexandra Leigh Nemecek, the daughter of Dorothy Nemecek and Dr. Stephen M. Nemecek of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday in Williamsburg, Va., to Daniel Edward Zalewski, a son of Dr. Andrew A. Zalewski of Olney, Md., and the late Linda S. Zalewski. JoAnn McGrew, a marriage commissioner, officiated in the chapel of the Wren Building at the College of William and Mary.

title: PULSE; Oh, to Rub Out That Cellulite
description: When it comes to cellulite, no treatment is too expensive, or ridiculous sounding. One of the latest is endermologie, which involves wearing a white nylon jump suit while a technician massages afflicted areas with a vacuum hose hooked up to a machine that resembles Woody Allen's orgasmatron. Women are blocking out appointments at doctors' offices and beauty salons for the 35-minute sessions, which cost up to $120 each. How does it profess to diminish puffiness, dimpling and other unmentionables? Dr. Jeffrey Brande, a plastic surgeon who offers the procedure in his offices on the Upper West Side, says it increases blood flow to cellulite-ridden areas, improving their appearance. Researchers like Dr. Bruce Shack of Vanderbilt University Medical Center, who examined the effects of endermologie on pigs, have attributed these results to increased circulation and collagen production, but they don't know how long the effects will last. The proof is in the posterior, which takes a while to assess; at least 16 to 20 visits are needed to show results. MARTHA McCULLY

title: Endpaper; Bad Trips
description: No matter how great the adventure, at certain inglorious moments an explorer is liable to wonder why he -- or she -- ever left home. Some low points of the millennium:

title: Calpers Will Start to Invest In Money Managers It Hires
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the giant pension fund known as Calpers, will invest in some small money management companies it hires to manage its assets.

title: Marlo Hall and Arthur Stern
description: Marlo Jennifer Hall, the daughter of Ronna and Robert Hall of Penn Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Arthur B. Stern, a son of Iris Seydel of Princeton, N.J., and the late Arnold Stern. Rabbi Bradley Bleefeld performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Oars Put Medals on the Wall
description: The boathouse for Beach Channel High School's crew team is an old ammunition shed on the outskirts of Floyd Bennett Field, with makeshift locker rooms, a leaky tin roof and no running water. About 400 yards away is the Mill Basin channel, where the team trains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, JULES
description: EPSTEIN-Jules. Devoted husband of Adele, beloved father of Robert, Barbara and Richard, cherished grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. His agile mind and his charm remained intact until he left us at the age of 90.

title: The World; New U.S.-Iran Dialogue: Psst. Mumble. Huh?
description: TEHERAN is abuzz again, divided now over whether America really is still the Great Satan. And as usual, the ferocity of Iran's internal power struggles make it hard to know just what is going on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDZERIS, THEODORE
description: ALDZERIS-Theodore. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Theodore Aldzeris, associated with The Times from 1980 until retiring in 1987.

title: Residents Hold the Cards In Land War With Bank
description: In a state that loses 25,000 acres of land to development each year, local battles to preserve open space are about as common as Fourth of July picnics.

title: Julie Cheu, Jochen Schapers
description: Julie Yukiyo Kasama Cheu and Jochen Rainer Schapers were married yesterday morning by the Rev. Haywood Spangler, an Episcopal priest, at the Hopkins Inn in New Preston, Conn.

title: End It
description: To the Editor:

title: Selections That Evoke the Sea
description: MENTION Massapequa and the conversation invariably turns to Jerry Seinfeld, Joey Buttafuoco and other famous former residents. Now Clearwater, a new restaurant, is getting some of that attention.

title: The Feminist Mystique
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Castlebaum and Mr. Rona
description: Susan Debra Castlebaum, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Castlebaum of West Caldwell, N.J., is to be married today to Jeffrey Andrew Rona, the son of Nicole Rona of Flushing, Queens, and Otto Rona of Budapest. Rabbi Norman Patz is to officiate at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell.

title: The View From/Armonk; Through Generations, Love of Music Binds a Family Together
description: DONALD E. DUPONT and his father, Roland DuPont, used to play trombone together in the Ed Sullivan Show Band. ''Whenever I had a solo to do, after I had finished, he'd knock my knee with his,'' Donald DuPont recalled recently. ''It was his way of saying I had done well. I don't remember ever not getting my knee knocked.''

title: On the Wild Side
