description: To the Editor: The article ''On the Wild Side in the Camargue'' (April 25) reminded me of May 1952 at Stes.-Maries-de-la-Mer, when my 14-month-old's elegant plaid baby blanket disappeared from the beach where we camped during the annual Gypsy gathering. All sorts of people were there for the excitement, the dancing, the wildly received repetitions of ''Mira! Mira!''

title: At the King Ranch, a Way of Life Is Riding Into the Sunset
description: CROSSING a shady creek bed in South Texas nearly 150 years ago -- in the middle of what many people called the Desert of the Dead -- Captain Richard King had a vision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JUDITH
description: FRIEDMAN-Judith. On June 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Alexander Friedman, dear sister of Anne Rothenberg and Joseph D. Becker, loving stepmother of Joan August and Lucy Peck, devoted grandmother of Edith, Karen, Deborah, Hilary and Adam. Services were held.

title: Missing Hoops
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: May 30-June 5; European Nations Vote To Become Military Power
description: The European Union's 15 member nations decided to become a single military power and to appoint a single foreign and security policy official.

title: Drawn Knives Over Sushi
description: Neighbors fighting a Japanese restaurant planned for East Ninth Street have accused the landlord of submitting false documents to the city's Department of Buildings, and the Manhattan District Attorney's Office is looking into the charges.

title: Annapolis to Newport, Via Sydney
description: With a new sailing season in the Northeast comes the Annapolis to Newport Race, the first major offshore regatta of the year. With it comes a lingering ill wind from the Sydney-to-Hobart Race, an Australian regatta in which six yachtsmen died last December. But a fresh breeze of caution is filling sails in the aftermath.

title: The Greatest of Unease
description: I'M not sure what I was thinking when I decided to fly the trapeze. In retrospect, it seems, I wasn't thinking at all.

title: The Group
description: IT was the second Tuesday in September, and all the women arrived at Jackie's apartment in Great Neck, N.Y., before the scheduled starting time of 7:30 P.M. They traded a minimum of sociable comments as they picked up their decaf coffee and seated themselves in the living room. By 7:45 everyone was ready, coffee on one knee, Paul Auster's ''Moon Palace'' on the other. Greta, a slender woman with short auburn curls, had chosen the book for the group and thus was the one to introduce it. She committed herself with her opening words: ''I loved it.''

title: Lora Phillips, Robert Gray Jr.
description: Lora Ballou Phillips, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Phillips of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Daniel Gray Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Gary P. Brown performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Stamford.

title: A Conditional Surrender
description: Are we witnessing a diplomatic victory that will bring peace to the Balkans? Or will President Clinton win the Neville Chamberlain memorial umbrella trophy for accepting a phony peace? Let us hope for the former -- although much evidence suggests the latter will come to pass.

title: Financial Revolution For Cities and States
description: New York City will have to dust off decades-old files to determine the value of the Brooklyn Bridge. California will have to value hundreds of miles of eight-lane freeways. And hundreds of cities will struggle to tally up the cost of schools, jails and sewers built many years ago.

title: What They Carried
description: Forget Gore-Tex and polar fleece. For most of this millennium, all an explorer needed was a compass, a buckskin jacket and a plate of lichen.

title: Calling Home
description: To the Editor: Jeff Silverman's article about calling his parents from Greece in 1973 (''The Day the World Shrank,'' May 9) reminded me of my efforts to talk on the phone to my parents in 1948, 25 years earlier.

title: Where's Miller? All by His Lonesome
description: One of the greatest clutch players in the National Basketball Association plays for the Indiana Pacers, and his name is not Mark Jackson. But that fact has been hidden at the ends of Games 1 and 3 of this Eastern Conference final series.

title: Roberta Oster And Noah Sachs
description: Roberta Ellen Oster and Noah Matthew Sachs are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Wayne M. Franklin at the Fernbrook Inn in Bordentown, N.J.

title: The Swiss Maligned
description: To the Editor:

title: Constitution Time Warp
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Theater Folks Look Awfully Famous
description: Last year, right after the Tony Awards were broadcast, people were talking. When a radiant Natasha Richardson rose to accept her award as best actress in a musical for ''Cabaret,'' did her handsome husband, Liam Neeson, look not quite happy enough for her? Did he, in fact, appear downright grumpy? Was he still pouting over not even having been nominated for his portrayal of Oscar Wilde in ''The Judas Kiss''? Or was he thinking about whether playing a Jedi knight in a ''Star Wars'' sequel had been a good move? Had anyone ever seen a better unguarded star moment at the Oscars?

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: TOM DAVIN
description: As the chief operating officer for Taco Bell, Tom Davin makes it part of his job to keep workers enthusiastic about wrapping burritos and cleaning tables. When he visits restaurants, his Tumi briefcase is full of inspirational tools.

title: New Hampshire's Shakers And Their Simple Gifts
description: I VISITED two restored Shaker villages in New Hampshire one weekend in April and left wishing there were more Shakers in the world.

title: Setting Sail for San Francisco
description: As part of the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the California Gold Rush, a parade of barques, schooners, square-riggers and other tall ships from around the world will sail under the Golden Gate Bridge and into San Francisco Bay on July 2, beginning at about 1 P.M. It will be one of the largest collections of tall ships to converge on San Francisco since the Gold Rush, when a virtual armada bore thousands of miners to California.

title: Newark Doubles Income From Rent for Airport
description: Newark should receive $59.6 million from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey this year for rent on Newark International Airport and Port Newark, more than twice the $26 million it received last year, according to William Cahill, a Port Authority spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCREYNOLDS, ALICE BROOKE
description: McREYNOLDS - Alice Brooke. Died peacefully at home in New York City on May 30, 1999. Survived by a niece, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Miss McReynolds was a noted collector of Chinese snuff bottles and Oriental porcelains. A memorial service will be held on June 15th at 11:00 AM at Trinity Church Cemetery, 770 Riverside Drive at 153 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Brooklyn Botanical Gardens or The Salmagundi Club would be gratefully appreciated.

title: Tax Breaks of $25 Million for Media Conglomerate
description: The Giuliani administration has struck a tentative deal to give Bertelsmann A.G. a $25 million package of tax breaks and other subsidies for a new office tower at Broadway and 55th Street to house the company's Random House publishing division, city officials and company executives say.

title: Gloom in Belgrade
description: The sudden end of the Yugoslav war leaves Serbs relieved, angry, proud, disgusted and resigned. With NATO's planes no longer popping the sound barrier, Belgrade is indulging in Slavic pessimism, the other side of the mordant humor it has displayed in this unequal battle.

title: May 30-June 5; Merrill Lynch to Offer Trading on the Internet
description: The thundering herd just made a sharp U-turn. For more than two decades, Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest stock brokers, scoffed at ''do it yourself'' discount investing.

title: Refining the Language Of Dance
description: I enjoyed your Long Island Journal of May 16 [''Working for the Sake of Art, and Artists''] about the actress Shirley Blanc Romaine. Having seen ''The Divine Flame,'' the life and times of Isadora Duncan, mentioned in the piece, I must take exception to the writer's choice of the word ''flounced'' to describe the performance. I found the program exceptional, the movement beautiful, well performed and very true to the spirit of Duncan. I realize that words can mean different things to different people, but as a dance aficionado and enthusiast, I couldn't let this one go by unchallenged.

title: When Spirits Are Getting Low
description: THE bottles were lined up along the bar like army recruits waiting to be examined for their fitness to serve. Joe Ficarra lifted each one and placed it on an electronic scale. Then Michael Hoffman recorded each bottle's weight on a laptop.

title: Collisions of the Sexes
description: From executive offices to offshore oil rigs, workplaces that were virtually men only just a decade ago have opened their doors to more and more women. Men and women alike have adjusted and adapted -- at times awkwardly, at times thoughtfully. The resulting tales can range from uproarious to touching. Send yours to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THEY SAW THE FUTURE: Oracles, Psychics, Scientists, Great Thinkers, and Pretty Good Guessers. By Kathleen Krull. Illustrated by Kyrsten Brooker. Anne Schwartz/Atheneum. $19.99. (Ages 10 to 14) Smart kids feeling millennial anxiety? This handsome and provocative book describes the lives and work of a dozen visionaries and ''their talent to predict.'' They are a mixed group, beginning with the oracle at Delphi and the sibyls and moving briskly past the Maya, Leonardo da Vinci and Nostradamus, to Jules Verne and H. G. Wells, and on to Edgar Cayce, Jeane Dixon and Marshall McLuhan. The text is clear and thoughtful (''Mixed in with all the science, writing, thinking and paying attention was a lot of luck''), and there is a helpful bibliography. The collage and oil-paint illustrations are sophisticated.

title: Singularly Diverse
description: To the Editor:

title: For Teen-Age Girls, It's Cool to Be a Scout
description: LEANING her long, thin frame against the flip chart, Theresa Mantello, 16, of Hicksville looked every bit the modern teen-ager. Her blond hair was haphazardly clipped back in a ponytail. She was sporting a tight white shirt with just a hint of bellybutton exposed above low-slung bell-bottom jeans. But when she started writing topic headings on the chart with a Kelly green marker for a women's issues forum, it became clear that Theresa was a Girl Scout.

title: Both Head and Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Wagner's Antichrist Crashes a Pagan Party
description: THEY probably didn't plan it that way, but San Francisco's leading classical-music organizations will come into an interesting collision this week. At the War Memorial Opera House, the San Francisco Opera will stir up pagan ecstasy with several complete cycles of Richard Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelung,'' beginning on Wednesday. Meanwhile, beginning on Thursday across the street at Davies Symphony Hall, and in a couple of other spots around town (including a Roman Catholic church), Michael Tilson Thomas and the San Francisco Symphony will celebrate the life and times of Igor Stravinsky, who loved to bill himself as Wagner's Antichrist, and for whom the ''Ring,'' with its ''miasmic vapors'' and its labyrinth of leitmotifs, amounted to nothing more than ''a sort of vast musical city directory.''

title: Mapping the Millennium; Points of No Return
description: For most of the last thousand years, any adventurer setting off for parts unknown faced the distinct possibility of a death far from home. More than one explorer fell victim to hostile natives who didn't take kindly to being ''discovered,'' much less exploited and enslaved. Storms at sea, scurvy, malaria and mutinous crews cut short plenty of other careers.

title: All Wrapped Up in Pashmina
description: Celia Chen had been to two pashmina parties in one week, and she was moaning. ''I'm going to have to get a second job with my shawl habit,'' said Ms. Chen, a fashion public relations executive, who is a regular guest at Erika Falconeri's shawl-selling gatherings, a kind of Tupperware party for the fashion set. Earlier this year, Ms. Falconeri, a model based in Milan, started Ananda, a company that imports Indian pashmina shawls, the must-have accessory of recent seasons, made from the fur of the Himalayan Kashmir goat. While her wraps are carried at boutiques like N Peal Cashmere (56th Street and Madison Avenue), Ms. Falconeri makes most of her sales at the parties she holds in friends' homes. There, black-clad women -- actresses, fellow models and media executives -- socialize and share epiphanies about the possibility of wearing vibrant colors, then shell out $200 to $300 a shawl.

title: Gardening
description: The season is already later than you think, and still you find yourself wandering around like Willy Loman with seed packets and a flashlight in the dark or, worse, quoting Willy as if the words themselves were your enemy, saying: ''I've got to get some seeds, right away. Nothing's planted. I don't have a thing in the ground.'' Well, there's no comfort here. By June, a gardener has to choose between having information and having time. Better to err in the garden for lack of information than to lose a moment of this brief season, and there is only information -- antipode of time -- to be found in what follows.

title: Siena Cherson, Mark Siegel
description: Siena Carfagano Cherson, the daughter of Rosana C. Cherson of New York and the late Samuel B. Cherson of San Juan, P.R., was married yesterday to Mark Robert Siegel, a son of Marie Claire Yvain Siegel and Edward Siegel of Ste.-Maxime, France. James Mullen Jr., a justice of the peace, officiated at Ridge Hill Reservation in Needham, Mass.

title: De Anne Harris, Gregory Collier
description: Dr. De Anne Elinor Harris, the daughter of Monica and Glenroy Harris of Royal Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Gregory Holland Collier, a son of Barbara Klein of Palm Beach Shores, Fla., and Charles Collier 3d of Baltimore. The Rev. Dr. Richard Cromie, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: When the Air Gets Bad, Transit Fares Will Fall
description: Getting New Jersey commuters out of their cars and onto public transportation has never been easy. After all, this is the state that gave the world the first drive-in movie.

title: Giving Air An Air of Cleanliness
description: FOR some people, spring means washing windows, scrubbing floors, discarding junk, hosing down lawn furniture and airing out the house. But spring is also a good time to air out the air.

title: The Costs of Saving Other People's Taxes
description: Does that special tax break that Archer Daniels Midland gets for making alcohol fuel for cars burn you up? Well, it's not worth the postage stamp it takes to complain to your senator. The break costs each of the 94 million couples or individuals who file a Federal income tax return about 16 cents, says Martin A. Sullivan, who writes for the magazine Tax Notes.

title: Corrections
description: A summer highlights listing on May 23 for the East End misstated the dates of the Hamptons Greek Festival, at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons, St. Andrews Road in Southampton. It is July 8-11, not June 8-11.

title: As Welfare Rolls Shrink, Cities Shoulder Bigger Load
description: Welfare rolls are shrinking more slowly in big cities than elsewhere in their states and, as a result, welfare recipients are increasingly concentrated in urban areas, state and local officials and welfare policy experts say.

title: An Uneasy Standoff in a High-Fashion War
description: WHAT the Gucci Group really wanted was to get clean away from the dreaded embrace of Bernard Arnault. What it got was the uncomfortable prospect of a future with his company, its biggest rival, as its biggest minority shareholder.

title: How Art Museums Help Children Learn
description: ABOUT 20 elementary students sat in rapt attention at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven before an 18th-century painting of a family drinking tea and working jigsaw puzzles. There was no accompanying video and no loud music. And the only fast-action scenes were of alternating arms shooting into the air when Paula Brown, a docent for the gallery, asked the students a question. ''They're drinking tea,'' said Ms. Brown. ''Where does tea come from?''

title: A Marriage of Opposites, a Merger of Equals
description: ELISA MONTE is hardly the first dancemaker to marry her muse. George Balanchine, in the final tally, exchanged vows with four of his best ballerinas. But Ms. Monte, who left Martha Graham's company in 1982 to run her own troupe, has taken an unusual step by sharing artistic direction equally with her spouse, the former Graham dancer David Brown.

title: Turbulent Times For Tourism in Greece
description: WITH tourism throughout the Balkans suffering as a result of the air war against Yugoslavia, it was perhaps inevitable that Greece would be among the victims. But travel agents and tour operators say that a bad regional situation has been made considerably worse by a spate of terrorist attacks in and around Athens.

title: Nicole Ornstein And Grant Toch
description: Nicole Cally Ornstein, a daughter of Jane Moritz of New York and J. Alan Ornstein of Southampton, N.Y., was married last evening to Grant Aaron Toch, the son of Linda and Jules Toch of Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at the home of the bride's father.

title: How Chinese-Americans' Lives Have Changed
description: THE more than 10 million Chinese-Americans have had a dynamic influence on American society, and a conference on Saturday will explore how that society has shaped their lives. The daylong conference at Hunter College, sponsored by the China Institute, is called ''Traditions, Tensions and Togetherness: The Chinese Family in America.''

title: Seeing the Earth With an Astronaut's Eye
description: For centuries, people have looked up at the sky and watched the stars and planets. This week the American Museum of Natural History will present a view of the earth as it would look from the bay window of a space shuttle in orbit.

title: Davida Pines, Louis Brenner
description: Dr. Davida Beth Pines and Dr. Louis Brenner were married last evening by Rabbi Bernard H. Mehlman at Temple Israel in Boston.

title: INSIDE
description: Mel Torme Dies

title: THE GUIDE
description: All-Breed Dog Show

title: Our Towns; Growing City Is Counting Its Decibels
description: ROBERTO CABRERA has a $3,000 stereo in his 1990 Toyota Corolla, including a separate 600-watt amplifier just to make that big bass speaker boom. So Mr. Cabrera might want to start worrying about a new city policy that rests on the following formula: SPL = 20 log P in db over Po, where Po = 0.0002 microbars. On second thought, maybe Mr. Cabrera doesn't have all that much to worry about.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Nothing but Net, And Disbelief for Bird
description: THE look on Larry Bird's face said nothing. But his reaction to a championship dream possibly going up in smoke was there. It was there, in living color, on the back of Bird's neck. It had suddenly turned a fleshy, furious shade of red.

title: Baedeker Never Made It Here
description: NUDE IN TUB

title: Ms. Jerome, Mr. Rosenthal
description: Lauren Beth Jerome, the daughter of Leslie and Stephen Jerome of Cresskill, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Herbert Rosenthal, the son of Ilene and Thomas Rosenthal of White Plains. Rabbi Frederick Pomerantz officiated at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Giving a French Touch to Vineyards
description: PAUL PONTALLIER, the director general of Chateau Margaux, sipped hearty coffee in a large French-style cup, the Mark Hotel's buttery Parisian-style croissants at hand, and meditated on Long Island wines and the art of grape growing.

title: City Begins Rebuilding, But the Despair Lingers
description: With the sudden and apparent end of NATO's bombing war against Yugoslavia, Serbs are relieved, angry, proud, disgusted and resigned, probably in that order, suggested Slobodanka Bogic, as she stood this morning in her still-windowless house, helping workers repair the damage.

title: POSTINGS: Residential Developer Vs. Community Groups on Upper East Side; A 31-Story Building, or Two 8-Story Buildings?
description: A battle is shaping up on the Upper East Side.

title: Gorillas' Best Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: They Lived to Tell the Tale
description: They call it armchair adventure, this kind of reading, where the misery of desperate castaways contrasts with the comfort of the reader's goose-down puff, where a bookmark halts Titus Oates in his selfless act of leaving Scott's tent for death in the Antarctic storm, or holds the physician-missionary Dr. Grenfell marooned on a Newfoundland ice floe hoisting his grisly distress-signal mast of sled-dog tibia.

title: A Larchmont Spot for Celebrity Watching
description: SUPERSTITION seems to bring Joe Torre, one of New York's best loved celebrities, to La Riserva. Although as a rule not one to avoid ladders and black cats, Mr. Torre has noticed that before a Yankee game, taking a meal at this restaurant often presages another successful game for his team. Of course, the magic does not always work, but the hope that it will may be one of two reasons to eat here. Catching a glimpse of the celebrated manager may be the other.

title: When Megan's Law Proves Effective
description: ''Trying to Sort Out the Legalities of Megan's Law'' [May 16] presented a skewed perception of sex offender recidivism rates and was unbalanced because it failed to include statistics and other opinions supporting community notification of the whereabouts of high-risk sex offenders.

title: Compassion For Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Streetscapes /Readers' Questions; Echoes of a Union Hall; Artificial Sunlight
description: 209 East 85th Street

title: America's Sweetheart
description: MARY PICKFORD REDISCOVERED

title: May 30-June 5; Teamsters Strike Averted
description: James P. Hoffa, the teamsters' new president, had his first chance to demonstrate that he could be a heavyweight at the bargaining table like his famous father, James R. Hoffa. The younger Mr. Hoffa received respectable marks for negotiating a contract for 12,800 workers who haul new cars to dealers. In an era when companies are cutting retirement benefits, he won higher pensions, health coverage for workers who retire at age 55 and prescription benefits for retirees over 65. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: Don't Rush to Vengeance in Police Abuse Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A table on May 23 with an article about Joseph E. Stocke, portfolio manager of the Evergreen Select Special Equity fund, referred erroneously to two conditions for buying its retail shares. There is no minimum purchase and no front-end load, or sales charge.

title: Correction
description: A picture on May 23 with an article about restaurants with water views was printed in error. It showed the Bank Street Breweryin Stamford, not the Paradise Bar and Grill there.

title: Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Moose?
description: ''WILL we see a moose?'' My younger daughter's wary question was answered in the parking lot at Roaring Brook campground, where we started our hike in Baxter State Park in Maine last July. My wife, Beth, and our daughters, Ruth, 16, and Elaine, 14, and I hadn't even gotten our packs to the sign-in station when a young but impressively large moose clumped past not 20 feet away. Ignoring us, it stopped to snack on a shrub at the side of the ranger's cabin. Then it turned down the trail to Russell Pond, where we had reserved space for a three-night stay in the Maine woods. We decided to wait a few minutes more before starting out.

title: When the Cure Becomes the Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit of the Wild Comes to Goshen Farm
description: RESIDENTS of Connecticut's heavily forested northwest corner, long accustomed to sharing their turf with wild creatures, barely blink when they spot wild turkey, deer, coyote or even the occasional bobcat staring back from the side of the road.

title: So, Just Who Goes Where When Going to the Shore?
description: THE season is getting serious now.

title: Circumcision Denies Respect for a Healthy Body
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks' Blueprint for Victory is Johnson's 4-Point Plan
description: Larry Johnson was near the left sideline last night with the ball in his hands, the clock ticking down and the anxiety of an impossible situation cascading down on his sculpted shoulders. At that instant, he remembered what it was like to be in this position, to be the star.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 6, 1999
description: Weeks

title: May 30-June 5; Worries Over Muscle Drug
description: Scientists were surprised -- and concerned. Iowa State University researchers conducted tests on androstenedione, the drug Mark McGwire said he used on his way to becoming baseball's home run king. And around which a multimillion-dollar business sprung up on claims that it builds muscle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOBLOVE, STEVEN
description: JOBLOVE-Steven. Born 7/21/55. Deceased 6/6/94. Loved and missed everyday. Mom, Dad, Vicki, Gordon, Sam, Nickie.

title: The Year Broadway Became the Boonies
description: WHEN did Broadway become the provinces?

title: F.Y.I.
description: Flags, and More Flags

title: Making Scents Visible
description: Eugene P. Grisanti, the chief executive of International Flavors and Fragrances, thinks he knows simpatico when he sees it -- for instance, in Marilyn Monroe's global sex appeal and the sensuality of the fragrances his company makes, behind the scenes, for the likes of Dolce & Gabbana, Emporio Armani and Clinique.

title: Costly Battle Over a 'World-Class' View
description: The top of the Empire State Building hints at the view of midtown Manhattan as its art deco spire peers from above Weehawken's bluffs. But the real moment of visual impact comes moments later -- many moments, if traffic is bad -- as motorists enter the oval viaduct that siphons cars, trucks and buses down and around into the Lincol Tunnel's arching maws.

title: Moscow Shows Its Irritation As Allies Continue Bombing
description: Despite the apparent imminence of a peace deal, NATO kept up the bombing of Yugoslavia today -- an act that allied diplomats said riled Russia so much that Moscow delayed a meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright of the United States and the foreign ministers of the six other leading industrial nations.

title: New York Mark Set In Girls' Pole Vault
description: Amy Linnen of Long Island's Mount Sinai High School posted a state record yesterday in the pole vault when she won the event at 12 feet in a Class B competition at the New York State Interscholastic Championships at Dietz Stadium, Kingston.

title: Summer Reading
description: THIS list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 1998. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.

title: Maria Freitas and Spyros Panos
description: Maria Augusta Freitas and Dr. Spyros Nikolaos Panos were married yesterday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Damaskinos Ganas performed the ceremony at the Kimisis Theotokou Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Literacy Program Teaches the Teachers
description: FAIRFIELD UNIVERSITY and a Bridgeport social service agency have created an alliance that not only helps the community, but also gives valuable lessons to the student volunteers, too.

title: Child Abuse Is Something That Can't Be Overlooked
description: SOME say you can measure a society's greatness by the reach of its art or the openness of its government. Here's another suggestion: You can measure a society's greatness by its willingness to confront its darkest, ugliest aspects head-on.

title: Democracy Is Taking Root in Thin Soil in Nepal
description: In the Hi malayan kingdom of Nepal home to some of the world's highest mountains, mightiest rivers, thickest jungles and poorest people -- His Majesty King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev is 53, democratic government is nearing 10 and the Maoist rebellion in the countryside has just turned 3.

title: Searching for a New Way to Treat Bulimia
description: WHETHER it was prompted by the pressures of growing up in an upper middle-class suburb, or whether it was genetic or just bad luck, somewhere along the line a 41-year old Greenwich woman lost the ability to deal with stress, feelings and problems.

title: A $1.5 Billion Renewal of a Chicago Neighborhood
description: THIS city has bulldozed architectural masterpieces and burnished them. Never before, however, has it set aside a 16-story landmark for safekeeping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
description: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on Monday, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher

title: Tax Can Curb Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Flights Rescheduled
description: Northwest Airlines has rescheduled its earliest morning flight from Westchester County Airport to comply with a voluntary restriction on flights between midnight and 6:30 A.M. The Northwest flight to Detroit, which had been scheduled to depart at 6:15 A.M., is now leaving the gate at 6:29 A.M.

title: Olivier Debre, 79, a Leader Of France's Abstract Artists
description: Olivier Debre, one of France's best-known abstract painters of the postwar era, whose large-format works include the stage curtain at the Comedie Francaise, died here on Tuesday. He was 79 and lived in Paris.

title: Crossing Swords
description: THE FENCING MASTER By Arturo Perez-Reverte. Translated by Margaret Jull Costa. 245 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $24.

title: Still Feeding An Internet Frenzy
description: THE ink on the first draft of the history of the Internet stock boom isn't yet dry, and the revisionists are already having their say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, ALIDA
description: LOEB-Alida. Beloved sister of Joel T. Loeb and Constance L. Melnik. Loving aunt of Victoria L. Brown, Rosalind M. Goldfarb, Nicholas H. Loeb, Charlotte S. Melnik and Robert L. Melnik. Devoted great-aunt of Benjamin and Emma Brown, David and Paul Goldfarb. Died on Wednesday, June 2 at her home. She was a very dear, devoted, generous, curious, frank, loving and forthright friend who will be sorely missed. She was a past Regent of the Quaker City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution and formerly a volunteer at the Children's Heart Hospital. There will be a memorial service for the family at a later date.

title: When the Cure Becomes the Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFUR, MARY (MAE)
description: LANGFUR-Mary (Mae). Beloved mother of Helaine Bayer and the late Bert Langfur. Loving grandmother of Caren Bayer Davi, Scott and Dr. Steven Bayer, Hal, Meg and Susan Langfur, adoring greatgrandmother. You will always be remembered with love.

title: American Women at the Wheel; Explorer Sport Seems to Have What They Want
description: WHEN I entered the working world full time in the late 1970's, I couldn't wait until I'd saved enough from my meager paychecks to buy my first brand-new car. I wanted something small, nimble, sleek and sporty. And red.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 6, 1999
description: Weeks

title: NEW ENGLAND; Beyond the Bay in the Ocean State
description: MY city has become a film set. Its skyline sparkles like a brace of quartz crystals as the camera pans overhead in the opening credits of the NBC television series ''Providence.'' Throughout the show images pop up with iconic regularity: the majestic gates of Brown University; the brick sidewalks and Colonial homes of Benefit Street; the sleekly relandscaped Providence River, flowing into a postcard-blue expanse of Narragansett Bay.

title: Chasing Fireflies and Making Friends
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon, Charrice Snipes, 10, and Zoe Lipner, 6, reminisced about the night last summer when they chased lightning bugs. ''We put them in the bottle, and then we felt sorry and we let them go,'' Charrice said. ''We were going to catch more, but we forgot. We were too busy doing other things.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, ARTHUR J., REV. MSGR.
description: KANE-Arthur J., Rev. Msgr. on June 2, 1999. Founding Pastor of St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, Melville, NY. Former Spiritual Director St. Vincent de Paul Society for the Diocese of Rockville Centre. Chaplain Melville Fire Department, Former Curate of St. Ignatius Martyr, Long Beach, NY and St. Teresa's, Woodside, NY. Devoted son of the late John A. Kane and Helena McDonald Kane. Loving brother of Helen Moloney of West Hempstead, NY and the late John, Mary and Dr. Edwin P. Kane. Revered brother-in-law of John Moloney and Mary Kane. Cherished uncle of Arthur Moloney of Floral Park, NY, Mary Ellen Lohne of Garden City, NY, Bernadette McKinney of Mt. Lakes, NJ, Helena Finn US Embassy Ankara, Turkey, Katherine Markiewicz of New Canaan, CT., Dr. Mary Kane-Goldstein of Palo Alto, CA, Joan Dougherty of Huntington, NY, Dr. Edwin P. Kane II of Ridgewood, NJ, John Kane of Huntington, NY, Regina McNamara of Easton, CT. Adored great uncle to nine grandnieces and nine grandnephews. Also survived by many cousins. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Saturday 2-5, 7-9 pm. Sunday 3:30pm at St. Elizabeth's until Mass of Transferral 8pm. Funeral Mass Monday 11am at St. Elizabeth's. Interment Calvery Cemetery Woodside,N.Y. Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Monsignor's name to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o Mr. Ray Murphy, St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, 175 Wolf Hill Road, Melville, NY 11747.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THE thrills of STAGE FRIGHT (1950) may rank as second-level Hitchcock, but the film is nearly always interesting. This time the suspense master teases us with a backstage murder. In one amusing scene at the center of the picture, Marlene Dietrich, who plays a musical star, languidly warbles Cole Porter's ''Laziest Gal in Town.'' Jane Wyman does very nicely as the plucky daughter of a sleuth, played by Alastair Sim, but the most intriguing performance is that of a surly maid, played by Kay Walsh. The film rather skittishly hops over London and the suburbs, sprinkling red herrings and setting up a conclusion that may come as no surprise - Friday at 8 P.M. on TCM.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about the plans of Robert A. M. Stern, dean of the Yale School of Architecture, to move into the Chatham, a condominium tower he has designed on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, misstated its address. It is on East 65th Street at Third Avenue, not on East 85th Street.

title: In a Famous Brother's Shadow
description: FREDDY COLE still remembers the day he got DiMaggio's autograph. Mr. Cole was 14 years old and had recently arrived in New York from his native Chicago to spend the summer with his brother, Nat, who at 26 was already a star attraction on the Kraft Music Hall radio program, broadcast from Rockefeller Center. The Yankees were about to play the Red Sox in a home game. The youngest of four Cole brothers, all musicians, he waited by the dugout and waved a ball when his hero appeared. Fifty-three years later, Mr. Cole says he treasures the old memento and feels heartened when he reads the signature between the stitching: Dominic DiMaggio.

title: PULSE; Words of Love, Set in Stone
description: Taking signet rings to new heights, some altar-bound New Yorkers are having romantic hidden messages inscribed on their engagement diamonds. ''Couples today want to make the ring more personally symbolic,'' said Antoinette Matlins, a jewelry consultant and the author of ''Engagement and Wedding Rings: The Definitive Buying Guide for People in Love'' (Gemstone Press, 1999). Her clients have had initials, hearts and their wedding dates inscribed on diamond perimeters. Jewelers send the stones to the Gemological Institute of America and the International Gemological Institute, both in New York, for the laser engravings, which cost an average of $50 for 15 characters. The microscopic message can also serve as an identifier if the ring is lost or stolen, and can be buffed off without affecting the value should love not be forever. LINDA DiPROPERZIO

title: Port Authority Won Uphill Battle to Build Train to the Plane
description: In its all-out campaign to win approval for a rail line linking Kennedy International Airport to local subways and trains, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey recently treated some City Council members to a bus ride through Queens. It even provided some entertainment along the way: a brief clip from an old ''Seinfeld'' episode.

title: The Inn at Quogue: A Name Worth a Fight
description: THEY buy sunglasses and floppy hats to hide from the paparazzi, and gas up their convertibles for the race to the Hamptons. But when celebrities call ahead to book a room at the Inn at Quogue this summer, they could face yet another nuisance: their beloved haunt may seem to have disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDWEHR, ANN
description: LANDWEHR-Ann. An outstanding lady and beloved mother of Sheldon Landwehr, passed away in her 96th year. Services were held in May. She will be missed.

title: Have Duvet, Will Travel
description: Whether her destination is Marrakech or Mars, the woman of the future is a creature of comfort.

title: May 30-June 5; Mrs. Clinton Edges Closer
description: The curtain lifted a few more inches on Hillary Rodham Clinton's plans -- though not, it would seem, by the First Lady's choice. Representative Nita M. Lowey, the Westchester Democrat who had said she would run for the Senate from New York if Mrs. Clinton did not, called Mrs. Clinton to inform her that she was giving up and would instead run for the House.

title: Strike Zone Change Hurts Braves' Aces
description: In spring training, before pitchers and hitters knew how umpires would adjust to the strike zone edict from the commissioner's office, a couple of pretty good pitchers were expressing their views on the subject.

title: 1950's Scandinavian Design From a Swedish Exposition
description: In 1955, Halsingborg, Sweden, was the site of H55, an exposition celebrating modern architecture and design that featured many leading Scandinavian designers like Stig Lindberg, Sven Palmqvist and Arne Jacobsen.

title: In Defense Of the Single and Childless
description: IMAGINE working for a company that bases compensation on family status. If you have a spouse and children, you are paid more, even though single, childless employees seem to work longer hours. Singles hardly ever reach the highest levels of management. And the company does just about everything it can to discourage single employees from mating.

title: Crew Urges 'Reinventing' City Schools
description: With the city school system under fire from the Mayor and from a new report on the failings of the City University system, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew proposed a series of initiatives yesterday, including cash incentives for teachers and principals who agree to work in troubled schools and a new unified curriculum and testing program that would take children from kindergarten through city colleges.

title: INVESTING WITH: Karen E. McGrath; Strong Blue Chip 100 Fund
description: KAREN E. McGRATH, manager of the Strong Blue Chip 100 fund, grew up on a farm, where her family's philosophy was not to put too many eggs in one basket. So it is a comfort to her that the fund's $425 million in assets are divided between two portfolio strategies.

title: By, for and About Women
description: Taking its name from what was once a derisive term for intellectual or literary women, a bookstore specializing in works by, for and about women opened last week, with a small stage for readings and performances. The shop, Bluestockings, at 172 Allen Street, is the only such bookstore in the city, said its owner, Kathryn Welsh, 23.

title: Hitting the Trail With an Empty Wallet
description: ''Beware of enterprises that require new clothes.'' -- Thoreau, ''Walden''

title: One If by Land, Two If by Sea, Three If by Rollerblade....
description: When they weren't slithering through bat guano or leaping off waterfalls, competitors in the first Elf Authentic Adventure -- a 360-mile race for ''genuine adventurers'' across and between the Philippine islands of Samar and Leyte -- were supposed to be thinking about cultural exchanges with the locals. ''These nature lovers fully accept the principles of respecting cultures and the environment,'' declared Gerard Fusil, who created the competition. The event last April required several modes of transit: hacking through jungles, tramping over mountains, swimming through underground lakes, kayaking between islands and covering 60 miles of rough road on in-line skates. But each team was also required to undertake a socially beneficial project. The organizers offered suggestions: renovate a school, hand out books, ''pick up some nonbiodegradable waste.''

title: Bonding With an Aloof King of the Urban Jungle
description: ROVER moved in five weeks ago, and still we haven't bonded. I had expected by now that Rover would be gratefully eating out of my hand, gazing at me adoringly while I shaved, listening raptly to my rants and innuendoes. In fantasy, Rover perched on my lap as I wrote and stared unblinking at the computer screen. If he punctuated a paragraph with a purr, I'd save it. A hiss meant delete.

title: Unveiling the Belly Dance World
description: Ever wonder what makes a dance a belly dance? Or where in New York you might witness those mesmerizing gyrations, veiled hips and clanging cymbals? Or perhaps you want to swap that double-layered red chiffon skirt for, say, a black Egyptian coin bra. A Web site begun more than two years ago by a woman on West 57th Street with a passion for Middle Eastern dance probably has the answer.

title: Kathryn Hintz, Philip Murphy 3d
description: Kathryn Susan Hintz and Philip Augustine Murphy 3d were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Galen Goodwin at the Chatham United Methodist Church in Chatham, N.J.

title: Prospect of Triple Crown Draws a Crowd
description: The prospect of witnessing racing history brought out the biggest crowd in the history of Belmont Park yesterday -- a record 85,818, which erased the previous mark, 82,694 in 1971, when Dust Commander ended Canonero II's bid to win the Triple Crown.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Dozens of Workers Keep Fair Wheels Going
description: RALPH SILVESTRI put in 42 years with Consolidated Edison before he retired.

title: The View From/Westport; Police Try to Make Roads as Pleasant as the Town
description: THE 55-year-old Westport man, a baseball coach and the owner of a small company, had reached his limit. The car in front of him was blocking his so he couldn't get out of the parking lot.

title: Running as Insurgent, Officer Wins Police Union Presidency
description: A 35-year-old officer from Brooklyn who campaigned as an insurgent reformer will become the next president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the largest union representing New York City police officers.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 16 about the Art Loss Register, which maintains a database of stolen and missing artworks, misstated the name of the organization with which an expert, Constance Lowenthal, is affiliated. It is the Commission for Art Recovery of the World Jewish Congress, not Council.

title: Credits
description: Picture research by Maggie Berkvist and David E. Brown.

title: Mayor's Task Force Says CUNY Is Adrift and Needs an Overhaul
description: Saying that the City University of New York is ''an institution adrift'' and is ''caught in a spiral of decline,'' a mayoral task force is calling for a total restructuring of the university.

title: Has Anyone Seen Our Deck Furniture?
description: IT'S been nice to sit out on the deck during these beautiful early summer days: nice, but not comfortable because we have no chairs out there. Our new deck furniture is missing in transit, somewhere between Alabama and Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPA, ANTHONY ROLAND
description: KRUPA-Anthony Roland. Died at home in New York City on June 1, 1999. Mr. Krupa was born on December 20, 1929 in Pawtucket, R.I. The son of Michael Krupa and Nancy Bociek Krupa. Known as Tony Krupa, he was a graduate of Parsons School of Design in NYC and worked with Jacques Fath in Paris. Tony Krupa was a noted apparel designer and Vice President and Director of Design for I. Appel Corporation until his retirement in 1993. He was a recipient of the Tommy Award. Mr. Krupa is mourned by friends around the world. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, June 9 at 10AM at St. Francis Assisi Church, 135 West 31 Street, Manhattan, N.Y.

title: The Effort to Save Indian Site in Dobbs Ferry
description: ''Decade of Fighting to Preserve a Village's Open Space'' with its beautiful pictures of the Lenape Indians coming back to the Hudson River Valley was held up at the Dobbs Ferry Village Board meeting on May 10 to hearty acclamation.

title: Tax Can Curb Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Take a Leap or Take It Easy? Yermolinsky Decides to Soar
description: There comes a time in a game when a player, pressing hard to win, reaches a crisis position, when he has to take a leap to attack or else fold his tents and drift into the mediocrity of a draw. That occurred in the fourth-round encounter between the grandmasters Alexei Yermolinsky of Euclid, 0hio, and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh in the Foxwoods Open Tournament in Mashantucket, Conn. Yermolinsky did not shirk but ventured a fascinating knight sacrifice that his opponent could not cope with.

title: Meaning Found in Layers, in Clusters, in Folk Life
description: James Fischetti Deborah Fisher

title: Heart on Sleeve, the Pope Goes Home
description: Pope John Paul II arrived today in the birthplace of the Solidarity movement that he sparked with his first papal visit 20 years ago, this time offering Poles ''the greeting of a fellow Pole who comes among you to fulfill the needs of his own heart.''

title: Posters That Inspired Students at Lyndhurst
description: We read with interest the article about the Lyndhurst education program [''At Lyndhurst, Students' Skits Revive History,'' May 9]. We were pleased to see two posters from our Jackdaw Photo Collection, ''Child Labor: Shame of the Nation,'' being used in the program. They were simply referred to as ''old photographs,'' which they are. However, they also are our publications. Each poster has a caption, and upon close examination, our logo and name are visible at the bottom of each poster.

title: Q&A/Joy Masoff; Children's Books About Heroic Life Savers
description: WHAT is it really like to be a firefighter, to carry around 68 pounds of gear and go into fires that generate three times the amount of heat as an oven baking cookies? What is it like to be part of an emergency medical service team, which provides life-saving care with little time to spare?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLATSCHEK, RUTH
description: POLATSCHEK-Ruth. Age 87, of Miami, formerly of New Rochelle. Survived by son Jan of Miami and grandson Jason Wiesenfeld of NY.

title: PULSE; Innocent Nights
description: Tired of club theme nights with dark, weird undertones, Trang Chuong and Kathy Szwedzinski have been holding parties with rotating gimmicks evocative of teen-age sleepover parties on Monday nights at Veruka, 525 Broome Street (Thompson Street). There's an ESP party with Tarot cards and palm readings. On Singles Night, bar patrons wear ''Hello My Name Is'' tags with corny jokes penned in, and they play Twister.

title: He's Taking a Walkabout on the Wild Side
description: Pity the poor creature that slumbers in the path of Steve Irwin. With his wife, Terri, and a four-man camera crew in tow, the host of the Australian nature program ''Crocodile Hunter'' gleefully invades the personal space of any wild animal he encounters, bringing to mind a toddler in pursuit of a puppy.

title: Ruth Langer Lawrence, 77, Who Boycotted '36 Olympics
description: Ruth Langer Lawrence, who as a 15-year-old Austrian Jewish swimmer refused to compete in the 1936 Olympic Games in Nazi Germany, died on May 2. Lawrence, who lived in London, was 77.

title: The Wanderjahrs
description: In Britain it's the gap year, in Germany, the Wanderjahr. As long as there have been agreeable parents and disposable income, the postadolescent adventure has been a rite of passage in the West. In various eras, youthful travelers have worn different paths across the globe. During the 19th century, Americans and Britons ''did'' the grand tour of Europe. Early in this century, many went to Paris, and a hardy few, like Joseph Conrad, ran away to sea. Others, like Teddy Roosevelt (admittedly, well past his teens), went abroad for a splendid little war.

title: Doyle Leads By Four Strokes
description: Allen Doyle, a sensation on the Senior PGA Tour this year, broke from a crowded group of leaders yesterday with a 66 to take a four-shot lead over Lee Trevino heading into today's final round of the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic in Clifton, N.J.

title: Wax as a Medium and a Message
description: ABOUT nine years ago, Gail Stavitsky began to notice objects with surfaces or encaustic, or wax, cropping up more and more in galleries. She connected the dots, and what emerged is ''Waxing Poetic: Encaustic Art in America,'' a landmark exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum, where Ms. Stavitsky is chief curator.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Natural Law

title: Mel Torme, Velvet Voice of Pop and Jazz, Dies at 73
description: Mel Torme, the fluent pop-jazz singer who earned the nickname the Velvet Fog for his smooth, soft vocal timbre, died yesterday of complications from a stroke he suffered in 1996. He was 73 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Torme was rushed early yesterday from his home to the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center, said his publicist, Rob Wilcox.

title: Ms. Harrison, Mr. Peixoto da Silva
description: Tracy Caroline Harrison, a daughter of Barbara Harrison of Washington and Terrence R. Harrison of Yakima, Wash., was married last evening to Jorge Henrique Peixoto da Silva, a son of Maria Lucia Peixoto da Silva of Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Jose Henrique da Silva of Rio de Janeiro. The Rev. Lawrence J. Madden performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Celebrating the Planet In Water, Air and Fire
description: SINCE the advent of Earth Art some three-plus decades ago, a plethora of expressions cultivating new ways of experiencing the planet have emerged. In the exhibition at the Hudson River Museum here, ''Drip, Blow, Burn: Forces of Nature in Contemporary Art,'' three elements: water, air and fire, continue to inspire some of today's most visionary artists, focusing on contemporary forms of object-specific Conceptual Art.

title: Nina Stechler and Sean Hayes
description: Nina Stechler, a daughter of Pirkko Stechler and Ronald J. Stechler of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Sean Erik Hayes, a son of Britt-Marianne Hayes and Dr. Joseph G. Hayes of Manhattan. The Rev. Sara Ericsson, a Lutheran pastor, performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery in Manhattan.

title: As Buildings Rise, So Do Their Rents
description: MONEY was not the main problem for Andre Abucham, a 23-year-old from Brazil, when he went apartment shopping in Manhattan a few months ago.

title: You Can Go Home Again
description: FIVE years ago, Joseph and Joyce Ensminger moved from their home state of Kansas to Green Valley, Ariz., a retirement community about 20 miles south of Tucson.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a technical error, a picture with the On the Towns listing on page 13 of the New Jersey section today, showing an untitled 1983 artwork by Diane Neumaier, is reproduced in mirror image. The handwritten words on the work should appear at the right.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Footlights column last Sunday about scheduled productions of Alfred Uhry's play ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo'' referred incorrectly to a comment by Peter J. Loewy, producing director of the Forum Theater in Metuchen.

title: Vanguard's Windsor Is Shaking the Blues
description: No less an authority than John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group, has inveighed against market-timing -- switching in and out of the market in hopes of catching rallies and avoiding drops. A ''fruitless pursuit,'' he has called it.

title: Does Champagne Have a Y2K Problem?
description: DEBBIE BRUNNER placed several bottles of wine and liquor on the checkout counter at Crazy Billy's Wines and Spirits in Deer Park, telling the checkout clerk it was for a communion party.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEBLER, MILTON (MILTY)
description: GREEBLER-Milton (Milty). Fifth yahrzeit. I thank ''Hashem'' for lending you to me for the wonderful years we shared together. As long as we live, you live. Your Faygie and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, MYRON
description: WEINER-Myron. Professor of Political Science, MIT. Died at his home in Moretown, VT, June 3, 1999. He is survived by his wife Sheila Leiman Weiner, his daughter Beth Datskovsky of Bala Cynwyd, PA, his son Saul J. Weiner of Chicago, IL and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Central Vermont Home Hospice, RR 3, Box 6694, Barre, VT 05641 or UNICEF.

title: A Man Who Lives by the Sword
description: ''You have to surrender and open up,'' said Johnny Fox, a lithe 45-year-old with pierced ears, dark, curly hair, and dark, friendly eyes, as he sat in the storefront downstairs from his apartment on the Lower East Side the other day. What he has surrendered to, in order to overcome it, is fear. What he has opened up is his throat.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WENDER, LEONARD L.
description: WENDER-Leonard L. 6/9/17. Happy Birthday. With love, always Sylvia, Stephen, Sharon, Toby Alison, Matthew, Jaim

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about organizing charity events misspelled the name of an event planner. She is Barbara J. Saler, not Saylor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMOON, SIMON
description: SHAMOON-Simon. Beloved husband of Angele. Beloved father of Harry, Alan, and Sandra. Beloved grandfather of Evan, Mark, Michael, David, Elisabeth, Tina, and Benjamin. Cherished father-in-law of Rona, Kathleen and Robert. Beloved brother of Marcelle and Niazi. Shivah will be held at the family home in Great Neck, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday from 2-5 P.M. and prayers at 8 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Q. & A.
description: A Noisy Restaurant Downstairs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, IRENE (NEE WOLLMAN)
description: FINK-Irene (nee Wollman). Of Coral Springs, FL on June 4, 1999. Wife of Steven Fink; mother of Ethan; daughter of the late Ruth and Kurt Wollman; sister of Arnold and Edward Wollman; niece of Cecile Schwartzman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, FRIEDA (FRITZI) LANGER
description: HOLLAND-Frieda (Fritzi) Langer. 92, on June 4, 1999, in Philadelphia, PA. Formerly of NYC, she is survived by her daughter Judith von Scheven of Philadelphia, granddaughters Emily and Anne, a great-grandson, and many nieces and nephews. Services private.

title: Coming to a Small Screen Near You
description: Get ready for another season of spotting local landmarks like the Meadowlands, Jersey City cemeteries and Satriale's (fictional) meat market on HBO. ''The Sopranos,'' the series about the mobster Tony Soprano, his life in the Jersey suburbs and his therapy sessions, has been renewed for a second season starting in January. If you can't wait for a fix, don't despair: the original 13 episodes are going into reruns, starting this week, on Wednesdays at 9 P.M. (Related articles, Arts & Leisure, page 23.)

title: Water Early and Often, and Cut Roses
description: Don't depend on rain for transplants, annuals or container plants. Plants without enough water will be under stress and subject to marauding insects. Insufficient water will also encourage the growth of surface roots, making plants vulnerable to drought.

title: Pullout Talks Start, but Pact is Delayed
description: After meeting for more than five hours with NATO officials on the border of Kosovo, Yugoslav military officers failed today to agree to the terms of their withdrawal from the southern Serbian province, saying they needed more time to check with leaders in Belgrade.

title: The World: Tug of War; Now, Onward to the Next Kosovo. If There Is One.
description: IF the goal of the allied bombing of Yugoslavia was to force Slobodan Milosevic to pull his troops out of Kosovo and cede control of that unhappy province to NATO, it appears to have been a success, and more -- a refutation of the common wisdom that air power alone could never make a despot back down.

title: There Is Another Face To Friends of Wickers Creek
description: The article ''Decade of Fighting to Preserve a Village's Open Space'' on May 9 painted a sympathetic portrait of the Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site, or Fowcas, in its battle to stop the construction of some town houses in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Ideas & Trends: The $2.9 Million Cup of Coffee; When the Verdict Is Just a Fantasy
description: HERE'S another story about America's out-of-control courts: Southern Pacific Railroad was so besieged by frivolous lawsuits in one Texas county that it ripped up 28 miles of track and shut down operations in the early 1990's.

title: Rebecca Seigel, Christopher Browne
description: Dr. Rebecca Rae Seigel, the daughter of Carol and Irwin Seigel of Freeport, N.Y., is to be married today to Christopher Robert Browne, a son of Dr. Flavia Alaya of Paterson, N.J., and the late Rev. Dr. Henry J. Browne. Rabbi Oren Postrel is to perform the ceremony at the Onteora Mountain House, an inn in Boiceville, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Sometimes Humans Put These Animals at the Edge
description: FIVE times in 64 days. When they throw around slogans like ''the road to the Belmont'' and ''the road to the Triple Crown,'' anybody who bets or just yells ''Go, baby, go!'' ought to keep in mind that the road is brutal for fragile animals that are born to run, at least until something hurts.

title: In America; It Could Happen
description: She's gotten through the health-care debacle, Whitewater, the Lewinsky scandal and the impeachment of her husband. Now Hillary Rodham Clinton is packing her carpetbag and preparing to run for the U.S. Senate in New York. Welcome to the post-traumatic stress campaign.

title: Electronica Goes Straight To Ubiquity
description: THE usual trajectory for a new form of pop music is from underground sound to mainstream omnipresence, followed by eventual banalization as the style filters into television commercials and background music. That's what happened with grunge. In 1991, after a decade brewing in the indie-rock margins, the sound exploded onto the pop charts with bands like Nirvana and Pearl Jam. Within a year, grunge's fuzzed-up guitars were part of the soundtrack for television commercials like the Subaru Impresa advertisement that featured a scruffy slacker hailing the car as ''just like punk rock.''

title: In Michigan, a Grand Gathering of Movers, Shakers and Policy Makers
description: Every state has its insiders, its striding embodiments of wealth or power, and Michigan is no different. But in no other state do so many of them -- 1,400 this year -- gather at a single schmoozefest like the one held here each summer.

title: Ms. Miller, Mr. Copperman
description: Susan Gail Miller and Michael Lewis Copperman were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Howard Shapiro at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan.

title: Kimberly Ziev, Paul Niehaus
description: Kimberly Anne Ziev, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Ziev of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Paul Robert Niehaus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Niehaus of Chesterfield, Mo. Rabbi Shimon Berris officiated at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. James Harris, a United Methodist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Hingis Is Undone By Graf And Hooting
description: On the verge of being defeated by Steffi Graf, a war horse she had dismissed as being past her prime a year ago, in a bizarre and bad-spirited French Open final, top-seeded Martina Hingis delivered an underhand serve on Graf's first match point today. The underhanded move won Hingis a reprieve. But it was only temporary.

title: Philip H. Reisman Jr., 82, Writer of Documentaries and Dramas
description: Philip H. Reisman Jr., a versatile screenwriter who worked in early television and motion pictures, specializing in dramas and documentaries, died on Tuesday at a hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Arab Disunity Stands in Way Of Negotiations With Israelis
description: The election of a new Israeli Government has rekindled Arab hopes for renewed Middle East peace talks, but an enduring rift between Syria and the Palestinians has blocked an effort to forge a common Arab stand.

title: Capturing a Cuban Sound Before It Could Die Out
description: A SADNESS permeates Wim Wenders's new film, ''Buena Vista Social Club.'' The documentary covers the lives and recent unexpected success of a group of elderly Cuban musicians -- nearly forgotten in their own country -- who banded together under the direction of the American musician Ry Cooder and did the improbable: they recorded an international hit album.

title: State May Allow 10-Year-Olds To Hunt With Muskets
description: The New Jersey Fish and Game Council will decide later this month whether to extend the right to hunt deer with muzzle-loading rifles and smooth-bore muskets to children ages 10 through 13.

title: The Village Filmmaker
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE is really just a few dozen crooked blocks in downtown Manhattan. But its quaint confines have drawn many influential figures: artists and anarchists, poets and politicians, musicians and muses. Now a filmmaker, Karen Kramer, is documenting the story of this singular neighborhood and the people who made it that way.

title: Susan Doherty, LeRoy Dampier
description: Susan Elizabeth Doherty and LeRoy Edward Dampier, both chefs, were married on Wednesday on Martha's Vineyard. The Rev. Robert L. Hammett, an Episcopal minister, officiated at a house rented for the occasion in Chilmark, Mass.

title: Its Radio Days Over, Coda for WQXR's Cozy Auditorium
description: At the end of this month will be the final curtain call for the WQXR auditorium, where Vladimir Horowitz and Jascha Heifetz judged the musical talents of the city's high school students, where the gospel group Take 6 gave a free concert and where Peter Schickele delighted radio listeners with the quasi-musical antics of P. D. Q. Bach. For many years, an in-house duo, Leonid Hambro and Jasche Zayde, performed regularly on a pair of pianos in the auditorium.

title: The Real Knicks Team, and the One That We Fantasize About
description: Every generation gets the Knicks team it deserves, actually the Knicks team we fantasize about. Already, I am becoming defensively nostalgic for this team. Who knows how the world will turn this week? We already know fate is an Achilles' tendon, a questionable call, a finger roll away. You go to sleep with Jeff Van Gundy biting your leg and you wake up to find Phil Jackson meditating at the foot of your bed. Now and Zen. We might deserve that, too.

title: Their Man in Havana
description: HAVANA BAY

title: Harold F. Grumhaus, 96, Former Chief Executive of Chicago's Tribune Company
description: Harold F. Grumhaus, a former executive of the Tribune Company who began his career as a loyal lieutenant of the legendary publisher Robert R. McCormick and later helped dismantle some of his conservative mentor's political and managerial legacy at the company and its flagship newspaper, died May 29 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 96.

title: At First, No Answers; Then for Some, No Job
description: The mood in the visiting clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday was predictably somber before the Mets boarded their buses to go back to Shea Stadium.

title: Martee Hensley, Ted Szatrowski
description: Dr. Martee Leigh Hensley and Dr. Ted Paul Szatrowski were married yesterday at Willow, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BARBARA DEEN
description: SCHWARTZ-Barbara Deen. 54, of Dunwoody, GA, passed away Monday, May 24, 1999 after a brief illness. She was born in Pittsburgh, PA on February 3, 1945, the daughter of Lawrence Deen and Mary (Mellon) Schwartz. Ms. Schwartz was a graduate of Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, CT and attended Western College in Miami, OH. She was formerly employed for many years at Jordan, McGrath, Inc., New York, NY as an office administrator. She is survived by her sisters, Virginia S. Breeden of Keedysville, MD and Sarah S. Wey of Mt. Pleasant, SC, and four nephews. Graveside funeral and committal services will be held in the Cherry Valley Cemetery, Cherry Valley, NY on Saturday, June 12, 1999 at 11AM with Rev. Alvin Burnworth of Grace Episcopal Church, Cherry Valley officiating. Burial will follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Ms. Schwartz's memory may be made to Hospice/Atlanta, 1244 Parta Vista Drive, Atlanta, GA 30319. For further information contact the Ottman Funeral Home, Cherry Valley, NY, 607-264-8141.

title: The Kremlin Looks West
description: When the war in Yugoslavia started nearly 11 weeks ago, it threatened to rupture relations between Russia and the West. Instead, it brought Moscow and Washington closer together as they collaborated on a diplomatic settlement. Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin should find ways to build on the partnership. The Kremlin's willingness to part company with Slobodan Milosevic and throw its influence behind the West's peace terms in Kosovo is one of the more hopeful international developments since the end of the cold war.

title: Holly Gabal, Lawrence Boes
description: Holly Benet Gabal, a daughter of James Gabal of Westport, Conn., and the late Judith Gabal Fey, was married yesterday to Lawrence Elward Boes, a son of Joan and Lawrence Boes of Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. Bruce Comiskey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Stowe (Vt.) Community Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSMITH, JULIUS, MAC.
description: GOLDSMITH-Julius, Mac. Two years today, we miss you. Helen, Andrea, Robin, Bryce and Syd

title: Calming The Butterflies
description: Q. Help! I've just been promoted to a position that will require me to give presentations to clients, trade organizations and even our board of directors. Unfortunately, I'm one of those people who freezes in front of a group. I've tried picturing the audience in its underwear and a half-dozen other tricks, but the moment the spotlight falls on me, I start babbling. I'm thinking of signing up for public-speaking lessons, but I've got a big speech to get through in a couple of weeks. Any survival tips?

title: Philip Hsia and Anita Lee
description: Anita J. Lee, a daughter of Dr. Jung Min Lee and Sang Yeol Lee of Cleveland, was married on Friday to Philip H. Hsia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fu-Ben Hsia of Denville, N.J. The Rev. Peter Magnan, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Child-Care Center Central
description: Elissa Tabak-Lombardo, child care director of the South Mountain Metro Y.M.C.A. of the Oranges, in Maplewood, says some parents she has met with are in tears out of frustration about a lack of information. ''They don't even know what to ask,'' she says. She has tried to dry the tears with ''The Caring Parent's Guide to Child Care,'' (Prima Publishing, $150), which is, as far as she knows, the only book solely about day-care centers. Her book includes help on choosing a center but also concentrates on issues that evoke tears in children, like making the transition to a center, discipline problems (biting is a common one) and so on. Ms. Tabak-Lombardo, who lives in Short Hills, says that the latest figures, from 1995, showed that of the more than 13 million children in the United States in child care, 31 percent were at day care centers. She thinks the number has grown and will keep growing; after all, she says, businesses and government can't finance and monitor nannies.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: SELF-DRIVE BRITAIN -- Through Dec. 14, CIE Tours International offers ''Go As You Please Britain,'' with a rental car and nightly accommodations in England, Scotland and Wales. Daily rates start at $63 a person for two traveling together or $58 a person for four. This includes a Hertz manual-shift car (Ford Fiesta for two, Ford Escort for four) with unlimited mileage, local taxes and stays at any of more than 2,300 bed-and-breakfasts (with full breakfast). Also thrown in is 24-hour roadside assistance. Insurance is extra, and prices are based on a minimum seven-day stay; for first-class hotels, rates start at $85 a person. Call CIE at (800) 243-8687.

title: Putting Flowerpots in Order for Summer
description: IT is time to put the flowerpots, window boxes, tubs and other portable forms of gardening, more popular than ever, in order for the summer.

title: Hilary Coller, Leonid Kruglyak
description: Dr. Hilary Ann Coller and Dr. Leonid Kruglyak, medical researchers at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, are to be married this evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler will officiate.

title: Putting a Price on the Brooklyn Bridge
description: New York City will have to dust off decades-old files to determine the value of the 116-year-old Brooklyn Bridge. California will have to value hundreds of miles of eight-lane freeways. And, hundreds of cities will struggle to tally up the cost of schools, jails and sewers built many years ago.

title: Jane Marder, Matthew Martin
description: Jane Alison Marder, a daughter of John G. Marder of Easthampton, N.Y., and the late Barbara Sand Marder, is to be married today to Matthew Justin Martin, a son of Frances and Robert P. Martin of Scarsdale, N.Y. Frederic S. Berman, a retired acting justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, is to officiate at the TriBeCa Grill, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Wayne and O'Hara
description: To the Editor:

title: Studying Abroad
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article about study abroad (Practical Traveler, May 16) listed such problems as availability of financial aid, a decrease in foreign-language study and continued contact with home in English via the Internet.

title: Don't Rush to Vengeance in Police Abuse Case
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Potentially a Model of Excellence': Excerpts From the Report
description: Following are excerpts from a report by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's task force on the City University of New York:

title: James Lai and Julia Cron
description: Dr. Julia Anne Cron, the daughter of Catherine and Joseph Cron of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Maxwell Lai, a son of Eula Mae Lai and Dr. Maxwell Lai of Forest Hills, Md. The Rev. John Baran performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Pius X Church.

title: Peace Deal Benefits Gore in Campaign and Shows Split Among the Republicans
description: If a possible peace settlement in Kosovo has any effect on Presidential politics in 2000, it highlights an advantage of being the sitting Vice President and the disadvantage of a fractious mass of opposition candidates vying for attention.

title: Charismatic's Bid Ends in Injury and Defeat
description: Charismatic, standing on the threshold of sweeping the Triple Crown, missed his date with history yesterday when he ran third in the Belmont Stakes behind the 29-1 long shot Lemon Drop Kid. And, worse, in a stunning finish to the saga of the colt who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness at long odds, Charismatic fractured two bones in his left front leg as he crossed the finish line.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Williamsbridge, the Bronx; Neighborhood Striving for a Better Future
description: LUTHER JONES likes to call Williamsbridge the crossroads of New York City. Although the Bronx neighborhood is nearly an hour's subway ride to midtown, it is just minutes away from several of the city's major thoroughfares and a 20-minute drive from New Jersey, Westchester, Long Island or upper Manhattan.

title: Word for Word/Trivia Marathon; Pulling an All-Nighter at This College Means Acting Out 'Nietzsche in Love'
description: COLLEGES celebrate the end of the academic season with traditions peculiar to their institutions. Perhaps the defining word is peculiar. Wellesley seniors dress in their graduation gowns and roll wooden hoops around the campus. At Columbia, the marching band parades through the library on the night before the organic chemistry final, probably to help concentrate the mind.

title: New Seasons of Chamber Recitals
description: TWO of the state's longest-running summer chamber series are returning this week: the Connecticut Early Music Festival begins its 17th season while Music Mountain opens its 70th.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LAWSON F.
description: BERNSTEIN-Lawson F. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 11th at 4PM at Columbia University's St. Paul's Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 117th Street. Reception at Chapel follows.

title: Polls Are Open Tuesday For Primary Elections
description: New Jersey voters will have a chance on Tuesday to vote in primary elections to select their party's candidates to run in November for state, county and local offices.

title: Travel
description: IT'S been almost 20 years since Paul Fussell, in a curmudgeonly book called ''Abroad,'' declared that travel writing was a genre on its last legs, ready to go the way of courtship novels and pastoral eclogues. It had to, for the world had shrunk and the adventure of travel itself (picture Lord Byron setting sail for the Greek islands, draped in tragic glory) had been replaced everywhere by its degraded facsimile, tourism (picture herds of cruise ship passengers setting sail for those same islands, draped in Hard Rock Cafe T-shirts).

title: A Hand-Me-Down 'Ring' Attracts A Star Director
description: ONCE again, the Wagnerites are descending on San Francisco for the four-day spiritual adventure that is the ''Ring of the Nibelung,'' offered in four overlapping cycles, beginning on Wednesday. The production, unveiled in 1985, last saw service in 1990. Of the original principals, the Wotan of James Morris remains. Along with the new cast of other gods, giants, dwarves and assorted demigods -- among them, the redoubtable Jane Eaglen as Brunnhilde -- the current edition also introduces a new director, Andrei Serban.

title: Johnson Takes the Game Into His Hands
description: Jerry Tarkanian winced yesterday with 2 minutes 31 seconds left. He was on his couch in Fresno, Calif., watching Game 3 between the Knicks and the Pacers on television. One of his favorite players, Larry Johnson, had just resorted to an old habit with the game in the balance.

title: When the Cure Becomes the Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: Among the Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring the Lenox Lounge to Its Uptown Opulence
description: Alvin M. Reed knew he was meant to own the Lenox Lounge the moment he saw the classified advertisement for the historic restaurant and club in The Amsterdam News in 1988.

title: Belmont Park, on the Line; Track Hopes to Parlay Triple Crown Excitement Into a Revival of the Era When Big Crowds Roared There Every Day
description: ''YOU gotta be here'' is Belmont Park's current advertising slogan, though it shouldn't take much inducement for thousands of horse racing fans to heed the call this weekend, with Charismatic vying to capture the fabled Belmont Stakes to round out his upset wins in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness and become the first Triple Crown winner in 21 years.

title: Tenant Dispute Becomes Battle Of Bedsheets
description: Tenants of two buildings on the same gritty block in Washington Heights are waging a battle of the bedsheets. At 515 West 174th Street, residents have draped spray-painted bed linens from their fire escapes accusing a community advocate, Victor Morisete-Romero of trying to evict them. Two doors over at 503 West 174th where Mr. Morisete-Romero is the well-liked building administrator, the sheets defend him as honest and capable.

title: New Arts Space Keeps Faith With White Plains
description: THE Westchester Arts Council has had many homes here: a cramped second-story walkup, the balcony of a train station, a converted armory, a corporate high-rise and a quaint Victorian house, isolated amid a sea of parking lots in the backyard of the business district.
