Now the council, a private, nonprofit organization serving hundreds of arts groups, artists and schools, has settled into its latest White Plains headquarters: a historic bank building in the slow-paced heart of the city.

title: Parking Lot Wins a Round
description: The operator of a parking lot on 10th Avenue and 36th Street has won another round in a legal skirmish with the owner of the property, who has vowed to continue pressing the operator to change or get out.

title: Concerned by Loss of College Students, State Tries to Makes Rutgers Alluring
description: When Jessica Roberts was considering colleges, Rutgers University was the last place she thought about. Like many high school seniors in New Jersey, she was planning to go out of state.

title: L. Joseph Butterfield, Pioneer In Neonatology, Is Dead at 72
description: Dr. L. Joseph Butterfield, whose innovative care of newborns earned him a reputation as a pioneer of modern neonatology, died on Tuesday at his home in Denver. He was 72.

title: The World: Turkish for Dummies; Speaking of Kurdish Problems, Don't
description: BEFORE the Kurdish guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan went on trial last Monday, Turkish officials decided to assure that the official press would choose its words carefully.

title: The Way of the Dodo
description: FLIGHT MAPS

title: Babies' Teeth and Radiation's Path
description: AFTER finding high levels of the radioactive carcinogen strontium-90 in baby teeth collected on Long Island over the past three years, some organizations have appealed for more teeth to study the phenomenon more closely.

title: Wage Scale
description: To the Editor:

title: On and Off Stage, Town Backs 'Music Man'
description: TO Nancy Haywood-Semcken, who plays the mother of Marian the librarian in ''The Music Man'' in Yorktown Heights, the difference between performers on Broadway, where she has appeared frequently, and the mostly volunteer actors and actresses in the theater company called Yorktown Stage is this: ''The ones who made it just pursued and pursued their careers. The others have just as great a wealth of talent, but since the career pressure is off, they are nicer, more relaxed, more interested in giving than getting.''

title: Racers Express Shock At Italian's Suspension
description: Far from the Giro d'Italia, 116 bicycle riders were starting their own race this morning when the news about Marco Pantani's disqualification there for failing a drug test swept through their ranks.

title: BACKTALK; A 15-Year Playing Career Is Quieted but Not Her Voice
description: The 1999 Women's National Basketball Association draft had been billed as the draft of a lifetime. With the American Basketball League going bankrupt, 90 players from the A.B.L. were in need of jobs and the W.N.B.A. needed quality players. So I thought May 4 would surely be an historic moment for women's professional basketball in America, and for me. After contact with several W.N.B.A. teams, my agent predicted I would go in either the late first round or early second round. It was now heading toward the fifth round, and I was waiting to exhale.

title: May 30-June 5; On Anniversary of Massacre, Silence and Introspection
description: Beijing marked the 10th anniversary of the massacre at Tiananmen Square with a nervous silence. Over the last decade, there has been little public discussion of the incident, which began on the night of June 3, 1989, and lasted until the morning of June 4.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WECKER, BARRY
description: WECKER-Barry. Deeply loved and never forgotten. Jason, Debbie, Roni, Cody and Howard

title: Laurence Guillen and Reid Stowe
description: EVER since Reid Stowe's teen-age summers on the North Carolina coast, he has spent almost more time at sea than on land. At 19, he sailed around the South Pacific for a year in a tiny wooden sloop. He later went up the Amazon in a homemade catamaran. And in the late 1980's, he dared the Antarctic, sailing between icebergs.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS/HARLEM; Some Call It Prayer, Others Noise
description: Doreen Coghlan leaned over the kitchen table in her apartment on East 105th Street as she described the noise she said had blared from a revival church around the corner for the last two summers.

title: Crocker Snow, Early Pilot And Air Expert, Dies at 94
description: Crocker Snow, a pilot and aviation official whose aerial adventures spanned more than seven decades, from the biplane era to the jet age, died on Tuesday at his home in Ipswich, Mass. He was 94.

title: May 30-June 5; If a Picnic Is Too Much Trouble
description: New York's cultural resources seem unlimited, but if you ask a New Yorker to name the greatest thing about living in the city, the answer may not be the theater or the museums, but the takeout food. With a telephone call, New Yorkers can get almost any kind of meal delivered to their door, from sushi to tandoori chicken to pozole to anything Chinese. The convenience is apparently worth the clutter of takeout menus strewn about apartment vestibules, and the risk of being mowed down by a speeding delivery bicycle.

title: A Himalayan War Threatens All Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A correction in this section on May 23, referring to an April 11 article about Alfred Hitchcock, was published in error. The name of an actor about whom Hitchcock spoke highly was correct in the original article -- Roscoe Lee Browne, not Brown.

title: The Road to the Tonys
description: WHAT does a producer do? That depends on the producer.

title: In the Region /Westchester; For White Plains Stores, Expansions and Additions
description: ALREADY known as the shopping hub of Westchester County, this city is undergoing a retail revitalization of sorts with a plethora of new projects, both proposed and under construction, that could add more than half a million square feet of new retail space.

title: A Debut for Internet Futures
description: Not everyone is upset by the recent volatility in Internet stocks. Consider the Kansas City Board of Trade, which began trading futures contracts on the ISDEX index of 50 Internet stocks last Tuesday.

title: ART / ARCHITECTURE; A Garage of a School Designed to Promote A Freewheeling Life
description: WHEN the Harley-Davidson Motor Company decided that training dealership managers and mechanics should be done at its headquarters here, it converted part of a landmark former motorcycle factory and warehouse to accommodate its new Harley-Davidson University. In its unabashed celebration of the motorcycle, the building and its interior may at first look as if it is more concerned with entertainment and corporate boosterism than anything. But the design is smarter and more subtle than that. It is also intended to create an effective place for adults to learn.

title: Reading, Writing and 'Pocket Monsters'; At Least That's How the Students See it, But Principals Crack Down on Latest Fad
description: OUTSIDE the Ina E. Driscoll school in Wilton, 7-year-old Jared Rapoport and his second-grade buddies knelt in a circle by the blue and yellow jungle gym. Head down, Jared checked out a student's collection of Pokemon trading cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, DAVID I.K.
description: HECHT-David I.K. On May 30, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Anne. Loving father of David. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Long-Stemmed Cosmos for an Armful of Beauties
description: COSMOS, a reliable summer bloomer, is usually available in garden centers. The plants are often part of the dwarf Sonata series in shades of pink, lilac, rose, white or mixed.

title: Pros and Nons
description: To the Editor:

title: Bennington
description: There's a spirit of renewal pervading Bennington, Vermont's first chartered town. It is celebrating, as T-shirts proclaim, its bicenquinquagenary (250th anniversary), which comes at a time when the town is undergoing some major improvements.

title: Looking Good While Everybody Sweats
description: AS he struts along the basketball sidelines, screaming out plays while wearing a Giorgio Armani suit, P. J. Carlesimo feels blessed. But sometimes he also feels foolish.

title: May 30-June 5; The Myth of the Starving Student
description: College. One little word that can make parents weep (if the joys of the teen-age years haven't reduced them to tears already). They hunch over calculators, muttering darkly that if they mortgage the dog and wear designer hand-me-ups from the kids, maybe, just maybe, they can pay for it.

title: A Buoyant Agassi Completes Trip to French Final
description: When the skies parted at noon today as if on cue, Andre Agassi, the balding optimist from Las Vegas who began growing a French Open victory beard as soon as he negotiated his opening-round hurdle here, quickly completed his rain-delayed semifinal against Slovakia's Dominik Hrbaty.

title: Dogs' Night Out
description: Some members of the audience at the Community Theater in Morristown are now listening to concerts from under the seats. Performances by the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, the Colonial Symphony and the New Philharmonic of New Jersey, all based at the theater, are training sessions for Seeing Eye dogs and their new masters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUCCI, SERAPHINE (NEE GIUNTA) SALLY
description: CARUCCI-Seraphine (nee Giunta) Sally. Beloved wife of the late Anthony. Devoted mother of Frank and Donald, Sr. Loving grandmother of Anthony and Donald, Jr. Dearest great-grandmother of Christian Mateo. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Sunday and Monday 2-5, 7-9:30 PM. Funeral mass Tuesday, 10 AM at Our Lady of Pompeii Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Jeanne Noonan, Eric Eckholdt
description: Jeanne Noonan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Noonan of Garden City, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Eric Joseph Eckholdt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Eckholdt of Metairie, La. The Rev. Robert B. O'Connor will perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: The Feminist Mystique
description: To the Editor:

title: No Sets, No Script, But Still Musical Theater
description: FUNNY, isn't it? If Betty Buckley wanted security, she could have had a steady paycheck for going on 17 years now. And eight times a week, she would be stopping the show in ''Cats'' with her own 11 o'clock number, ''Memory,'' which is called her signature song.

title: Under the Tongue of the Ocean
description: One thousand and forty-three feet below the sunny, sparkling waters off Chub Cay in the Bahamas, the external world presents the darkness of the womb or the tomb. There are four of us down here, sitting in the dark, and to me at least, it's plain we don't belong. If we tried to leave the narrow limits of our deep-sea submersible, we would suffocate far short of the surface. Here, inside the vehicle, the artificially controlled pressure is the same as that at sea level, or one atmosphere. At 33 feet below sea level -- about twice the distance a moderately intrepid teen-ager would dive to retrieve her ankle bracelet -- atmospheric pressure doubles.

title: Contemplation.com
description: Feeling that the world was too much with me, I took myself off, last summer, to Laos; the more my private moments seemed to be invaded by beeping faxes and ringing phones and half-unwanted chirps of ''you've got mail,'' the more I felt drawn to a place that was said to be the sleeping beauty among nations -- the currently favored adjective 'underdeveloped' would be an unwarranted compliment,'' Time had opined some years before.

title: Liberties; Rudy in Reverse
description: Even at this distance, you can almost hear Rudy raving, the shrill sound of one Mayor carping:

title: Soul Music
description: FOR THE LOVE OF IT Amateuring and Its Rivals. By Wayne Booth. 237 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $22.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 23, about budget lodging, misstated the telephone number for Hostelling International-American Youth Hostels. It is (202) 783-6161.

title: Habitats/West 66th Street; A Co-op That Bans Dogs Makes an Exception
description: IT is hard to imagine a creature more admirably self-controlled than a guide dog. Let a cute and pesky little thing run up and sniff, looking for a playmate and nothing happens. The dog is out working.

title: Oversight Agencies Give Program Scant Review
description: Cornell's research in Haiti, like all Federally funded studies, is subject to extensive Government rules intended to protect patients from abuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADUM, JOHN
description: BADUM-John. December 24, 1952-May 30, 1999. Exuberant, generous, creative, insane, hilarious, bossy, big-hearted and totally fabulous. Everywhere you walked, you left a trail of glitter and hilarity. We will always love you. Your friends

title: Columbine Students Seek Answers in Their Faith
description: Beyond this Denver suburb, public figures from Vice President Al Gore to Gary Bauer, the conservative Republican running for President, have praised Cassie Bernall as a symbol of everything that is right with young people today.

title: In The Same Boat
description: There's a memorable moment early in Mark Twain's ''Huckleberry Finn'' -- a strikingly modern moment -- in which this seminal if not great novel suddenly raises its homey, clear-eyed gaze and sees all the way across a hundred years -- sees us, really -- and envisions both a source and a cure for our country's least curable social disease. Young Huck, the ''ignorant village boy,'' has been assumed murdered, but is actually on the run from his cruel father and from the forces of coercive small-town propriety. Adrift on the Mississippi River in a canoe, he takes refuge on lonely Jackson's Island, but soon suspects mysterious strangers are sharing the island with him. Darkness falls. He is fearful. Exhausted. Alone.

title: Hook, Line And Sinker
description: WHEN the United Fishing Association held its annual dinner last fall at the Water Club on the East Side of Manhattan, a highlight of the event was supposed to be speeches by some of the country's foremost fishing experts. But during a talk by Vin Sparano, the director of the United Fishing Foundation, the attention of the audience began drifting to the East River, visible through the windows in the room. Anglers on two small motorboats were drifting by, and soon the entire room was watching them as they pulled up fish after fish, said James Gilmore, a State Department of Environmental Conservation official who attended the dinner.

title: Far from Andes or Alps, Celebrating Small Peaks
description: I'VE always been attracted by a large kind of smallness. Short stories that, disdaining minimalism, pack a hard emotional punch. Chamber music, like Bartok's, that a chamber can't contain. Countries, like Ireland, that have won a place in the world out of all proportion to their modest size. States -- the New England ones I call home, with as much variety in their compact triangles and squares as in many states five times as large. Streams that, in springtime, flow as exuberantly as the Mississippi.

title: Cambodia Costs
description: To the Editor: Referring to the letter from Ted Peck about the cost of a trip to Cambodia to visit Angkor Wat (May 9), it need not cost a fortune. My wife and I made our arrangements through a Vietnamese travel agent, Ann's Tourist in Ho Chi Minh City, fax (84-8) 832-3866. Our trip cost $600 a person and included flights from there to Phnom Penh to Siem Reap to Bangkok plus a night at the Sofitel Cambodiana Hotel in Phnom Penh and two nights at the Ta Phrom Hotel in Siem Reap. And we had a private car and guide for three days.

title: Elis Capture Varsity Race
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew erased boat-length deficit to win this four-mile race yesterday at Gales Ferry, Conn. It was the 134th rowing of the event, which began in 1852. NORMAN HILDES-HEIM

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, ROBERTA
description: LIPMAN-Roberta. We cannot believe it's been five years. The impression which you brought to each of our lives remains strongly with us all. We miss you every day. All our love, always. Sandy, Donna, Larry, Beth and Reed

title: Rambling Blues Detouring to Cuba
description: CHARLIE MUSSELWHITE: 'CONTINENTAL DRIFTER'

description: LIEBERBAUM-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Louis Lieberbaum. Devoted mother of Sheldon (Carol) and Michael (Cynthia). Grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Joshua Nickerson, Kathryn Helne
description: Kathryn Eugenia Helne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antti Anselmi Helne of White Stone, Va., was married yesterday to Joshua Bailey Nickerson, the son of Nancy Bailey Riegel of Duxbury, Mass., and William Henry Nickerson 3d of Barnstable, Mass. The Rev. Hugh White performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Irvington, Va.

title: On the Silk Road
description: To the Editor: The Q & A column of May 9 directed readers to five Silk Road travel agencies. We would like to offer a sixth, one that we found nurtured us from the Hunza Valley in northern Pakistan over the Karakoram Highway, an old Silk Route, into China, or, if travelers prefer, just to China. It is Concordia Expeditions, Pakistan with Pakistanis, Post Office Box 4159, Buena Vista, Colo. 81211, (719) 395-9191.

title: Start Sprewell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Praise for Ewing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Last Slam Title Now In Reach For Inkster
description: Juli Inkster looked amazingly fresh in the suffocating heat as she climbed the slight hill to the seventh tee at Old Waverly Golf Club, her eyes darting immediately to the green where yet another pin was tucked in a remote corner. But try as they might, tournament officials could put no pin out of Inkster's reach in today's third round. And try as they might, no one might be able to keep her from finally winning the United States Women's Open on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. We extend our sincerest condolences to Dina Recanati and sons, Oudi & Michael, on the loss of their beloved husband and father. Throughout his life, together with his wife Dina, Mr. Recanati was a benefactor to a myriad of organizations and institutions in the State of Israel that strengthened, educated and healed its people. We will be forever grateful for the Recanatis' vital role in providing state-of-the art technology and compassionate medical care to the people of Israel. May the warm memories of this special individual bring solace to the entire family and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

title: Will Pixar Be the Hero Of Hollywood Animation?
description: A THINKING person's cult stock: That may seem an odd characterization for Pixar, the maker of ''A Bug's Life,'' the 1998 animated children's film that featured 750 computer-generated ants. But some analysts say its technical and creative prowess makes it one of the few pure high-technology media plays, as well as a favorite to win the Hollywood animation wars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINCOTT, BETTY
description: WINCOTT-Betty. Died June 3 in Florida. Survived by two sons Gerald, and his wife Rita, and Stephen, and his wife Stephanie, fourteen grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, and two great-greatgrandchildren. Funeral services are Sunday, 10 AM at Sherman Funeral Chapel in Brooklyn.

title: Co-op President Deserves Sympathy in Tree Case
description: To the Editor:

title: As Vote Nears, Indonesia Braces for Result
description: Indonesia steps into the unknown on Monday with a highly complex parliamentary election in which, even if everything goes smoothly, the outcome is sure to cause confusion and protests.

title: Roses, Ponds and Much More
description: THE theme of this year's festival to benefit the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport is ''Art in the Garden of Earthly Delights'' (the first such event took place in 1997), and it all begins with a tour of six private gardens. There are also lecture-workshops, boutiques, a lunch and a preview party for the opening of an art and flower exhibition.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATOVSKY, NAFTALI
description: PLATOVSKY-Naftali. We mourn the passing of our father, Rabbi Naftali Platovsky. He was a man of few words with a great sense of humor. His strength of character assisted his family through the hardships encountered in Eastern Europe. He fulfilled his lifelong dream by transporting his mother's remains from Siberia to Israel for reburial. He will be loved and remembered by his family and all of the people whose lives he touched. Gerald, Daniel and Ronald

title: Among Educated Russians, Relief Is Mixed With Suspicion of U.S.
description: When Genrikh A. Borovik was running the Novosti news agency's North American operations from New York in the late 1960's, he was a tough critic of the Vietnam War. His friends back in the Soviet Union saw it a bit differently: ''America was a role model,'' he recalled this week. ''There were plenty of emotions, sure. But at the same time, people said, 'Nevertheless, America is a very free place.' ''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-25

title: Park Plan All Wet, Some Say
description: A little more than a month after he stood on stage at a Staten Island town hall meeting with Borough President Guy V. Molinari and opened his jacket to reveal stickers that said ''Ballfields Now!'' and ''Parks for Play,'' Mayor Giuliani announced on May 28 that he had approved a plan for a 38-acre recreation complex, with soccer and baseball fields, tennis and basketball courts and a parking lot, on the eastern side of heavily wooded Bloomingdale Park. The Parks Department estimates that the complex will cost at least $10 million.

title: The Son Who Created A Hit, 'The Sopranos'
description: DAVID CHASE, the creator of the HBO phenomenon ''The Sopranos,'' picked me up at noon. We were driving to Elizabeth, N.J., for lunch at Manolo's, a restaurant he used as a location in the series -- one that the mobster Tony Soprano torches.

title: From a Reisling, Echoes of Thomas Mann
description: Good estates named Prum abound along the sedate Mosel River, but only Joh. Jos. Prum belongd both to Germany's and the world's winemaking elite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERL, BERNARD
description: SHERL-Bernard. Pop, I'll love you forever. Love, Jane

title: Journey to the Center of My Mind
description: At a few minutes after 4 on a Sunday afternoon in January, when most of New York was tuning in to the playoff game between the Jets and the Broncos, I had something else on my mind. More precisely, I had something around my mind, namely the 1.5-ton magnet of the magnetic resonance imaging (M.R.I.) machine at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. I wasn't there for medical reasons; I was there to embark on an adventure. My journey would take me no farther than this laboratory on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and yet I was going somewhere very few people have been.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Into the Unknown, Pursuing the Knowable
description: The quest for knowledge is the special legacy of this millennium, one that began with Leif Ericsson sailing west from Europe and ends with a robot landing on Mars.

title: The Home Front
description: THE ORPHAN GAME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNGOLD, HERMAN
description: KORNGOLD-Herman. Of Scarsdale, NY. On June 5, 1999 at the age of 86. Survived by his wife, Gerda. Also survived by one son Peter (Arlene) Korngold, one brother Henry Korngold, sisters Carla Rogers and Jean Gossett, one granddaughter Rachel Korngold. Funeral service Monday at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Please call for time of service: 914-949-0566. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Ms. Brodlieb, Mr. Williams
description: Elizabeth Phoebe Brodlieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brodlieb of Huntington, N.Y., is to be married today to Ather Williams 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Wendel W. Meyer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Why We Go
description: When I was just beginning to write, my husband and I lived in Philadelphia. Summers were hot there. We wished we were cool. A friend offered to teach us to kayak. Once he'd hooked us on the pleasures of slipping along the water's surface, steering with a flick of the double-bladed paddle, he began to prepare us for bigger rivers and wilder rapids.

title: The World: Democracies Built on Rays of Hope; It's Nigeria's Turn to Keep The Promise
description: AS Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo waited to be inaugurated as Nigeria's new President a week ago, a man he used to visit in prison sat a few seats to his right: President Nelson Mandela of South Africa.

title: Pursuing the Job of an Incumbent Coach Is Not Covered in the Rule Book
description: Two weeks ago in the wake of Dave Checketts disclosing that he had met with Phil Jackson, the name of Glenn (Doc) Rivers surfaced in connection with the Knicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, SALLY ANN
description: MOORE-Sally Ann. Formerly Mrs. Lawrence C. Puchta, on June 4, 1999. Survived by her children Alexandra P. Brown, Lawrence G. and Anthony L. Puchta, and Jennifer P. Berkeley, and her husband James I. Moore, Sr., and stepchildren, his sons, James I., Jr. and John H. Moore; five grandchildren and five step-grandchildren. Interment in Spring Grove Cemetery, Cincinnati, Ohio. Family service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New York Special Olympics, 211 E. 43 St., New York, NY 10017.

title: Marisa Nightingale, Todd Edelman
description: Marisa Ottolenghi Nightingale and Todd Eric Edelman were married in Washington last evening by Rabbi Joseph Weinberg at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Mets Shake Up Staff, Dismissing 3 Coaches
description: Just hours after playing in Yankee Stadium, home of the revolving door through which more pitching and hitting coaches have departed in the past 25 years than anywhere else, the Mets dismissed half their coaching staff last night.

title: Water in the Basement
description: Christopher Lamb spent much of last season sloshing around his basement in New Milford with his two young sons -- eagerly. That was his locale of choice for practicing ''Concerto for Water Percussion,'' composed for him by Tan Dun and introduced by the New York Philharmonic last week, with one more performance on Tuesday. ''Everything starts out in my basement,'' said Mr. Lamb, the principal percussionist.

title: Crazy for Adventure
description: It is a steamy August afternoon off the coast of Hawaii, and the Feathered Serpent III-Ophir, Gene Savoy's 73-foot-long catamaran, is carving gracefully through cerulean waters. Squinting into the equatorial sun, the 72-year-old Savoy slicks back his shoulder-length brown hair with a comb, replaces his skipper's cap and, gripping the ship's wheel, barks orders into the ocean spray. His crew -- six shirtless middle-aged men with little sailing experience and badly sunburned shoulders and backs -- respond by hustling around the mahogany deck, coiling ropes and tying knots. In the cramped, unlighted galley below, a tattooed sailor with Popeye biceps stacks cans of pinto beans and Meister Brau beer.

description: ME AND

description: To the Editor:

title: Lifting Up an African Hero to Mythic Status
description: ANY American old enough to have been even vaguely aware of world events in the late 1950's will remember the name Patrice Lumumba. He was the young firebrand African politician who led the independence movement in what was then the Belgian Congo and pushed hard for the strength-in-numbers ideal of a pan-African unity.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Making Polluted Land Come Alive Once More
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS and the forces of economic development have seldom agreed, but in a curious marriage, they have joined together in the aging mill towns of the Naugatuck River Valley to restore polluted industrial properties and make them available for development again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELL, DAVID E.
description: EDELL-David E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David E. Edell, associated with The Times from 1953 until retiring in 1982.

description: Here are two safe predictions: The pace of business and of life will keep accelerating, and a keyboard will figure in an ever larger share of the communicating we do, commercial and personal alike.

title: On Language; Adventurer
description: The word adventurer has been through a half-millennium of exciting times.

title: Ruth Silman, Timothy Clark
description: Ruth Hilary Silman, a daughter of Roberta and Robert Silman of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married today in New Marlborough, Mass., to Timothy Andrew Clark, a son of Esther Clark of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Arthur Clark of Taos, N.M. John D. French, a friend of the bride's family and a civil marriage celebrant, is to officiate at Gedney Farm, an inn.

title: All American MetroStars Don't Play Like All-Americans
description: Foreign-born players usually provide star power and stability to Major League Soccer teams, but the MetroStars did not have any foreigners for tonight's game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTY, DAVID
description: SIROTY-David. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Beverly and Alan Karasik, Susan Siroty and Howard Baker. Adored grandfather of Ira, Adam, Lucas, Hannah, and Sarah. Dear brother of Dorothy Harwood. Graveside services Sunday, 11:15 A.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I. For more information, contact I.J. Morris Funeral Chapel.

description: PRATS-Lucas of Chisholm Prats Gallery, NYC. 10/30/48-6/6/89. Ten years of peaceful resting, at his much beloved home in Ibiza among the olive, almond and orange trees, warm, fragrant Mediterranean breezes and ancient Phoenician tombs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTMAN, KALLMAN
description: GITTMAN-Kallman. On June 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Rebecca for 64 years. Cherished father of Stella Cole, (Gene) and Dr. Elizabeth Gittman Arnel, (Victor). Dear brother of Anna Rottenberg. Adoring grandfather of Debbi (Lawrence); Leni, (James) and Alan; Stephen, (Joanne); Leslie (Eric), and Sherry. Great-grandfather of Eliana, Danielle, Shaun, Todd, Alison, Tyler and Chase. He was the greatest! Service Sunday 11:15AM at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPER, HOLLY ROSS
description: DRAPER-Holly Ross, 82. Died June 4 in Hanover, NH. Born October 17, 1916, the daughter of Adeline and Thomas Ross of Brooklyn, NY. She graduated Swarthmore in 1937. She was predeceased by her husband, Ernest MacLoughlin Draper. Survivors include three sons and five grandchildren.

title: Tipper Gore Keeps Cautious Watch at Door She Opened
description: TIPPER GORE was tense.

title: Microsoft to Offer Rebuttal On I.B.M. Executive's Charge
description: In its antitrust trial, the Microsoft Corporation is expected to introduce documents this week intended to contradict testimony by an I.B.M. executive who said Microsoft would offer the computer maker a favorable price on its Windows operating system only if I.B.M. agreed to ''eliminate or drop'' its competing operating system, OS/2.

title: Oops, No D.H.
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre considered playing both Chad Curtis and Shane Spencer, right-handed hitters, against the Mets left-hander Al Leiter last night. So Torre approached designated hitter Chili Davis and asked if he might want to take a day off and be well rested for tonight's game in Philadelphia.

title: Battle Begun on Internet Ad Blocking
description: An emerging category of World Wide Web software that blocks advertising is challenging the Web industry and rankling the nerves of some Internet executives.

title: Competition in the Name Game
description: Network Solutions Inc. will face its first competition in the multimillion- dollar business of registering Internet domain names today when a New York company, Register.com, plans to become the first company to go live in the federally sanctioned test for breaking the monopoly the Government helped to create.

title: Wall St. Victim or Young Rogue?; Christian Curry Found Trouble at Morgan Stanley
description: If family and friends had taken a poll when Christian Leigh Curry joined the Wall Street powerhouse Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in the summer of 1997, they might well have voted him black banker most likely to fit in.

title: Drugs and the Law: Confusion Abounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Cisco and Motorola Make Wireless Deal
description: Trying to deliver high-speed Internet links without wires, Cisco Systems Inc. and Motorola Inc. plan to announce today that they have agreed to acquire a subsidiary of the Robert Bosch Corporation of Germany that is developing advanced wireless technology.

title: A Revival of 'Salesman' Takes 4 Tony Awards; 'Side Man,' 'Fosse,' Judi Dench and Brian Dennehy Win Top Honors
description: And may the best salesman win.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANZER, MARTIN (NEE PANZERONI)
description: PANZER-Martin (nee Panzeroni). On June 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Elliot, Adam, and Gary. Loving brother of Joyce Fentin. He will live in our hearts forever.

title: Balkan Warfare Retains Its Fury As Refugees Wait for a Final Pact
description: The intention may be peace, but war raged as fiercely as ever today along the rugged border of Kosovo and Albania, forcing about 1,000 people from a northern Albanian town -- many of them refugees fleeing from fighting for at least the second time.

title: Sports of The Times; The Box Score: Clemens, L; The Ghost of Hubbell, W
description: MOST people are afraid of ghosts, but baseball people cherish ghosts and the best players chase them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, FRANK LANNEAU III.
description: FULLER-Frank Lanneau III. Age 80, of Pawlet, VT, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, NY, died June 4, 1999. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree at the University of Virginia 1940 and completed the University of Virgina Law School in 1948. Frank was a Captain in the U.S. Army and served in Italy during WWII. He was a member of the First Troop, City of Philadelphia. In 1956 he joined AT&T Company in New York, NY, where he became the General Tax Attorney of the Bell System. Mr. Fuller is survived by his wife of 56 years Martha (Ely) Fuller; a daughter Elizabeth Ely Fuller, Ph.D., of Medford, MA; a son Frank L. Fuller IV, FAIA, of Oakland, CA; his brothers Thomas Cornelius Fuller II of Raleigh, NC, and Williamson Whitehead Fuller of Portland, OR. For information, Brewster Funeral Service, Manchester, VT. A memorial will take place at a later time and place to be announced.

title: A Much Bigger Census Bill
description: The Census Bureau says it will cost $1.7 billion in addition to the $2.9 billion already requested to comply with a Supreme Court ruling that prohibits the use of statistical sampling for apportioning Congressional seats among the states. The new money is needed to pay for 400,000 more census takers. Yet this expense may not improve on census accuracy or solve the political problems of the Republican Party, which opposes sampling.

title: Health Insurance Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSLER, FRIEDA
description: STRASSLER-Frieda, 92. June 6. In Salisbury, CT. Beloved mother of David H. Strassler of Great Barrington, MA, and Robert B. Strassler of Brookline, MA. Sister of Beatrice Gilman of Manalapan, NJ. Grandmother of Abbie, Gary, Alan, Matthew, and Karen Strassler. Four great-grandchildren. Widow of Samuel A. Strassler. Funeral today at 12 noon at Hevreh of Southern Berkshire, 270 State Road, Great Barrington, MA. Donations to Westport Chapter of Hadassah, Box 11, Westport, CT 06881 or Aston Magna Foundation for Music, Box 750, Great Barrington, MA 01230. Fifty-year resident of Westport, CT.

title: A Sneak Preview Of a Violin As Film Star
description: John Corigliano has certainly put the movie music he composed for ''The Red Violin'' to efficient use. Before the 66-minute film score was even complete, Mr. Corigliano had fashioned a 17-minute concert work from the materials: ''Chaconne'' for violin and orchestra, which was performed last season by the violinist Joshua Bell in concerts with the Boston and San Francisco Symphony Orchestras. The Sony Classical recording of the complete film score, with Mr. Bell as soloist and the Philharmonia Orchestra conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen, has just been released.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, THEO WELLES
description: BURKE-Theo Welles. 78. Died Saturday, June 5, 1999 in Richmond, VA, after a brief illness. She is survived by her husband, Russell E. Burke, 2nd of Richmond, VA; daughter Martha Burke Deprez of Portland, ME; sons Russell E. Burke, 3rd of NYC and Laurance G. Burke of Richmond; seven grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Interment private.

title: No One Is Planning a Parade as a War's End Nears
description: The end of NATO's war on Yugoslavia seems to be in sight, but among a group of Americans who have been following the news, there is little exultation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Cars section on May 19 about automobile names misstated a proposal by the poet Marianne Moore for the vehicle that ultimately became the Edsel. Her recommendation was Utopian Turtletop, not Divine Turtletop.

title: Media Talk; Dow Jones Journalists Protest Pension Cuts
description: Six weeks ago, a large group of journalists at Dow Jones & Company decided to assemble in an unusual venue -- the company's annual meeting -- to express their dismay over proposed cutbacks in their pension benefits. Last week, another group of Dow Jones journalists decided not to assemble in a usual venue -- the CNBC studios -- to make the same point.

title: CUNY Study Could Be Tool Or Weapon, Officials Say
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani created an advisory task force last year on the City University of New York, some CUNY defenders expected it to be little more than a political hit squad, since some members shared the Mayor's oft-stated view that CUNY was a mess.

title: A Consolation for Williamses
description: Venus and Serena Williams, just the third pair of sisters to reach a Grand Slam doubles final, became only the second pair to capture a Grand Slam crown with a 6-3, 6-7 (2-7), 8-6 victory over Martina Hingis and Anna Kournikova at the French Open.

title: I'm Wall Street's Worst Nightmare
description: I may be the only person who has ever invested in Dell Computer and lost money. Three weeks ago I purchased my very first stock, buying $3,000 worth of Dell that's worth $2,300 today. As of now, a darling stock of the delirious market has me $700 in the hole.

title: More Hope Than Ruin At Belmont
description: Horse racing is often pictured as a troubled sport, sinking from sight. But the throng of 85,818 at Belmont Park on Saturday, and the threads of the drama of this year's Triple Crown, should offer it much more hope than despair.

title: Amid Doubts, Police and Public Mix
description: This is what Donald P. O'Donnell, the commander of the 71st Precinct in Brooklyn, saw yesterday when he looked across the football field at George W. Wingate High School: his men flipping hamburgers, his recruiters handing out job applications, dozens of children of many races lining up for pony rides, his officers being treated with respect, and a world that looked sunny and fine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVY, NATHANIEL A.
description: LEAVY-Nathaniel A. On June 5, 1999. He is survived by his children, Matthew, Bruce, Amy, Stacey and Eric; and his sister, Sylvia Hack; and many grandchildren.

description: A partial list for this week.

title: Zions to Buy First Security, A Rival, for $5.9 Billion
description: Trying to establish banking supremacy in the Western United States, the Zions Bancorporation said yesterday that it was buying the First Security Corporation, its longtime rival in regional consumer banking, in a deal worth $5.9 billion.

title: Drugs and the Law: Confusion Abounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Narrowing the Electronic News Gulf
description: It was noontime on the East Coast on Thursday, and in one office after another, workers headed to their usual lunch spots on the World Wide Web -- abcnews.com, cnn.com, msnbc.com, nytimes.com, usatoday.com, washingtonpost.com, yahoo.com. The special on all these menus was peace.

title: Casting Too Wide a Net?; Critics See Internet Board Overstepping Its Authority
description: They are mysteriously appointed, they meet behind closed doors and they have questionable public accountability. Yet members of the interim board of the Internet's new oversight body are beginning to make decisions and shape policy that could ultimately affect everyone who uses the global network.

title: Low Voter Turnout Cited by School Board Foes
description: The New York City school board elections last month drew the lowest voter turnout in their 29-year history, according to preliminary results released last week, prompting the Giuliani administration to renew its call to abolish the boards.

title: Europe Steel Merger Seen
description: Royal Hoogovens N.V. said today that it would give details on Monday about its plans to combine with British Steel P.L.C. and form Europe's No. 2 steelmaker. Analysts say the transaction could be worth more than $1.87 billion. British Steel, which disclosed last week that it was in merger talks with Hoogovens, said only that it would make a statement on Monday. Neither company has discussed terms, but analysts think British Steel, with a market value of $5.15 billion, will bid for Hoogovens, which has a market value of $1.87 billion, continuing a trend of consolidation in the European steel industry.

title: Silencing Citizens in Egypt
description: The rise of citizens' organizations working for civil liberties, environmental protection or religious freedom has given people an important new way to monitor their governments and defend their rights. Unfortunately, Egypt passed a law late last month that puts nongovernmental organizations more firmly under state control and allows the Government to shut down any group it wishes. The law is a leap backward for Egypt, the Arab world's most democratic nation. It needs immediate repeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, ROBERT S.
description: LINKER-Robert S. Just about the finest, most decent person we have ever known, Bob died Saturday in Florida, age 80, after a three month battle with bone cancer. Services at Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave. (Avenue L), Brooklyn, NY, Tuesday, June 8, at 10 AM. Our sincere condolences to Fran, Steve and Carrie, and the entire wonderful Linker family. Lawrence and Susan Kadish

title: African National Congress Drawing Mixed-Race Support
description: It was just an Election Day spat between a drunk who was harassing voters and a cranky fruit-juice seller, but it encapsulated the split in the ''colored'' vote, the crucial bloc in the Western Cape province, which contains lovely, touristy Cape Town, its vast suffering townships and dozens of fishing and farming villages.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; As the number of their viewers declines, television networks are testing the Internet to sell products from their programs.
description: FOR television executives, the notion of sharing viewers with the Internet has been about as palatable as showing reruns of the news during sweeps week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDENBERG, HARRY
description: EIDENBERG-Harry. On June 5, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sally. Loving father of Karen and Joyce. Father-in-law of Bill. Devoted grandfather of Tim and Lindsay. Dear brother of Belle and Ruth. Funeral services today at Hirsch Funeral Home at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
description: FISHER-Zachary. The partners of Fisher Brothers mourn the passing of our founder and partner Zachary Fisher and express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Fisher family. Zachary was a proud American, a leading real estate developer and a wonderful person. He helped to build New York City's skyline while devoting much of his life to the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces. A recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Zachary founded the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum; the Fisher House Program, which provides lodging for families of hospitalized military personnel; and the Fisher Armed Services Foundation, which makes contributions to military families who lose loved ones in tragic circumstances. Zachary also established the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Disease Research at Rockefeller University. He touched and enriched many lives and will be sorely missed. A private memorial will be held aboard the Intrepid on today, June 7. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Intrepid Museum Foundation, 46th Street at 12th Avenue, New York City 10036. Fisher Brothers Larry Fisher Richard L. Fisher M. Anthony Fisher Arnold Fisher Kenneth Fisher Steven Fisher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARK
description: COHEN-Mark. On June 6, 1999. Beloved fiance of Marcia Levine. Loving son of Bessie and the late Alexander. Dear brother of Helen Schoemaker and father of David Cohen. Grandfather of Jake. Service noon, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in Mark's memory to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY.

title: Doyle Beats Both Back Pain And the Field
description: When the spasms flared in Allen Doyle's back during Saturday's third round of the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic, he was asked if he thought the pain and discomfort could ever be bad enough that he would withdraw from the tournament's final round today.

title: Breakdown Seen as Sign That Serbs Will Not Abide by Pact
description: Clinton Administration officials said the breakdown in talks over the withdrawal of Serbian troops from Kosovo was a sign that President Slobodan Milosevic was unwilling to abide by the terms of a peace agreement he accepted last week.

title: Microsoft Binds Office Software More Tightly to Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation's power and influence in the computer industry stems not only from its dominant Windows operating system, but also from its office productivity software. And on Monday, Microsoft will announce that it has begun retail shipments of a new version of its office productivity ''suite,'' Office 2000, that all but eliminates the distinctions between a PC document and Internet data.

title: Jones Is Undisputed Champion, But His Future Grows Uncertain
description: Reggie Johnson had an explanation for why he was so thoroughly dominated by Roy Jones Jr. in their light-heavyweight unification bout on Saturday night at the Mississippi Gulf Coast Coliseum in Biloxi.

title: Treasury's Auction Schedule Is Minimal
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.41 percent and a six-month bill was 4.74 percent.

title: Police Union Critics Are Now at the Helm
description: It was a bitterly cold February morning in 1998 when Police Officer Patrick Lynch, a young, dissatisfied delegate in the city's police union, met with a small group of like-minded dissidents outside the union's headquarters in lower Manhattan to demand a look at its financial records and to call for new leadership.

title: Kosovar Attack on Gypsies Reveals Desire for Revenge
description: For a moment, it seemed as if the mob of Albanian refugees would literally tear the 7-year-old Gypsy boy apart, limb from limb, said three aid workers who saw the attack on Saturday night. Minutes earlier, 15 to 20 enraged Kosovo Albanian refugees had beaten the boy's older brother and father, whom they accused of collaborating with the Serbs and killing Albanians inside Kosovo last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVIN, GEORGENA K.

title: Media Talk; ABC Alters Policy on Paying for Videos
description: ABC News has ordered a change in its policy regarding the purchase of materials like videos and photographs from nonnews sources. From now on, news shows using such materials must disclose on the air that they were purchased.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day last Monday about companies that own small newspapers misstated the location of The Evening News, owned by Community Newspaper Holdings. It is in Jefferson, Ind., not in Alabama. The article also misstated the surname of the editor and publisher of The Cullman (Ala.) Times. He is Edward C. Darling Jr., not Dowling.

title: Randolph Bullock, Curator Of Armor Exhibit, Dies at 96
description: Randolph Bullock, a curator emeritus of arms and armor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art who helped build its collection into one of the world's finest, died on May 28 at a hospital in Oceanside, N.Y. He was 96 and lived in Wickford, R.I.

title: Those Words That Echo . . . Echo . . . Echo Through Life
description: How do I write? Why do I write? What do I write? This is what I am writing: I am writing ''Mr. Potter.'' It begins in this way; this is its first sentence: ''Mr. Potter was my father, my father's name was Mr. Potter.'' So much went into that one sentence; much happened before I settled on those 11 words.

In lieu of flowers, your contribution to charity would be appreciated. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, CHRISTINE
description: FRIEDLANDER - Christine. Be loved mother of Eva and David, grandmother of George Koudjo, died June 6 in New York City. Her gentle and giving nature made her a wonderful mother, a true friend and delightful companion. Her deep and abiding concern for peace and justice, and her love of art and beauty guided her throughout life. We will miss her always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

description: Steve Phillips said he did not anticipate that Bobby Valentine would quit as the Mets' manager when he learned that half of his coaching staff, including two of the three members he has been closest to, were being fired. But the possibility did cross the general manager's mind. ''There was a thought that was quickly dismissed,'' Phillips said.

But if a crucial game was still undecided in the final two minutes, well, the ball was going to Bird; he had no qualms about phasing everyone else out.

description: A father in a small Texas town won a verdict of $250,000 against a hospital after his daughter was decapitated by an inadequately medicated former psychiatric patient. But in 1996 the Texas Supreme Court overturned the decision and the hospital paid nothing.

description: KLETZ-Blanche. June 5, 1999. Beloved wife of Sidney. Cherished mother of Steven and Diane Kletz, Michelle and Marc Scher. Devoted sister of Doris and George. Loving aunt and friend. Most adoring grandmother to Nancy, David, Matthew, Michael, and Sam. Memorial services June 7, 12 noon, Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, New York. Donations in her memory may be made to Don Monti Cancer Foundation, NSUH, 300 Community Dr., Manhasset, NY 11030.

The chestnut, who was injured Saturday after running a game third in the Belmont Stakes, is expected to recover fully and live well as a high-priced stallion.

Billings on the account, for which there was no previous agency, have not been determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I., Col., USAF (Ret.) Formerly of New York City, now of Leander, TX, and West Shokan, NY, died of complications following a stroke in Austin, TX, on Friday, June 4, 1999, at the age of 82. He held BS and MS degrees from New York University, and was one of the first religious school teachers certified by the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. He was long associated with Temple Israel of the City of New York, and after moving to Texas, he and his wife, Rena, became members of Congregation Beth Israel in Austin. He served as a pilot in WWII, flying with the B-24 ''Our Baby'' crew, which he considered his ''second family,'' in the 453rd Bomb Group, 2nd Air Division of the 8th Air Force. He elected to stay in the Air Force reserve, without remuneration, ''because it was his civic duty.'' Eventually promoted to Colonel, he completed his service as Commander of the 9212th Air Reserve Squadron in New York City. He headed his own advertising agency, and was a past President of the League of Advertising Agencies in New York City. A member of the New York Fencers Club, he served on its Board of Governors. Most important to him however, was serving civic organizations dedicated to helping others, and he gave generously of his time-a past President and Trustee of New York Lodge No. 1, B'nai B'rith; a member of ADL's National Commission; past Chairman of the ADL New York Regional Board; past Chairman of the Board of the Metropolitan Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty; a member of the Management Assistance Program of UJA-Federation of NY; and a past President of the New York Society for the Deaf. Somehow, between his business, athletic and civic activities, he found time to marry Rena and spent 45 wonderful years with her. Beloved son of Minnie and William (both deceased). Beloved brother of Manny (deceased) and his wife Fay. Cherished ''UNK'' of Bill and Fran Sonnenreich, Mike and Linda Sonnenreich. Granduncle extraordinaire of David and Sharon Sonnenreich, Wes Sonnenreich, Diana Sonnenreich, Peter Sonnenreich, Nina and John Gafni. Great-uncle of Rachel Sonnenreich and Adina Gafni. Held in great affection-as ''Uncle Joe''-by Camp High Pointers. Treasured cousin of members of his mother's family-affectionately known as the ''Goldberg Clan'' (nee Karachik in Russia). First, last and always, adored husband-partner-best friend of Rena. Visitation and funeral at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue (please call for dates and times). Interment will be at the Temple Israel Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the organization or charity of your choice in his memory.

title: Van Gundy and Camby: Knicks' New Playoff Pals
description: Maybe Jeff Van Gundy's method of making Marcus Camby earn his time brought out the dominant side Camby has shown in the playoffs. Or perhaps Van Gundy's unwillingness to trust Camby initially hid the talent that was there all along.

title: In Crash at Crowded Intersection, A Violent End to a Steady Life
description: Just as the Upper West Side was starting to heat up Saturday night, Isaac Speight was headed for bed.

title: Indonesians Vote, Opening a New, Unpredictable Era
description: The world's fourth most populous country, freed from the grip of its longtime dictator, marked a new era of political freedom today with its first free election in four decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHOUET, DAVID J.
description: CAHOUET-David J. Of New York City fomerly of Bernardsville, NJ died at his family's home in Princeton, NJ on Tuesday, June 1, at age 30. Born with hemophilia he was later infected, through clotting factor transfusions with HIV and officially diagnosed by New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center 1987. We pay homage to the many thousands of hemophiliacs, now dead of AIDS, as David was fortunate to have lived so long in relatively good health. A graduate of the Far Hills Country Day School, the Salisbury School, Salisbury, CT and Lake Forest College, IL. Class of 1991, David was beloved and respected by all who knew him for his love of music, sense of humor, strength of character and infinite wisdom. His stoicism in dealing first with hemophilia and then with HIV is our inspiration. He is survived by his parents James and Jean and locally by his grandmother Margaret W. Taylor, his aunts and uncles; Professor Ann Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. M. Douglas Watson and Robert G. Fairburn. Also, by Mrs. Richard L. Fogarty of Bowie, MD, Reverend Ralph H. Cahouet O.P., New York City, John J. Cahouet of Boston, MA and Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Cahouet of Pittsburgh, PA. A memorial service for family and friends will be held June 12, The First Presbyterian Church New Vernon, NJ at 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Hemophilia Association of NJ, 37 West Prospect Street, East Brunswick, NJ 08816 are welcome.

title: Fraud Alleged at Mine-Clearance Center
description: PHNOM PENH  Cambodia's efforts to remove the millions of land mines scattered throughout its battle-scarred rice paddies and jungles are in disarray, with allegations of fraud and embezzlement plaguing the agency coordinating the mine-clearing programs.

title: Dan Reeves, the Heart Missionary
description: The scene spins easily in Dan Reeves's mind.

title: No Work for a Bicycle Thief: Children Pedal Around Less
description: These are exquisite days to ride a bike in this all-American, middle-American boyhood home of Mark Twain. Children can ride to school, to the Tom Sawyer Cave a couple miles south of town, to fish on the banks of the Mississippi, to play pitch-and-catch in a park.

title: INSIDE
description: Indonesia's Open Elections

title: Drugs and the Law: Confusion Abounds
description: To the Editor:

title: At La Guardia, Closings Of Runway to Continue
description: La Guardia Airport closed one of its two runways this weekend for a construction project that will require similar runway shutdowns throughout the summer, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: More Chaos to Come?
description: Albanian refugees in Macedonia set upon members of a Gypsy family suspected of collaborating with the Serbs, nearly beating them to death. The incident illustrates the chaos NATO could face when refugees return to Kosovo.

title: Disney Said To Consider Web Spinoff
description: The Walt Disney Company is considering a spinoff of its Internet-related operations, several people close to the discussions said yesterday. The details of any plan were not clear, but Disney has stakes in several Internet businesses that could become part of any spinoff. A Disney spokesman declined to comment.

title: J. Edward Lumbard Jr., 97, Judge and Prosecutor, Is Dead
description: Judge J. Edward Lumbard Jr., whose career as a lawyer, prosecutor and jurist spanned eight decades, highlighted by his 1955 appointment by President Dwight D. Eisenhower to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, died on Thursday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPER, STEPHEN J.
description: KARPER-Stephen J. Died June 3, 1999, at his home on Nantucket. Survived by his wife Diane Hoyt Karper of Nantucket; son S. James Karper, Jr., of New York, NY; daughter Annabelle H. Karper of San Diego, CA; and his mother Rose S. Karper of Miami Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the end of September in New York City. Contributions towards the Stephen J. Karper Lung Cancer Research Fund can be made to the Thoracic Oncology Service, MSKCC, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Recent Shootings Put School Rifle Teams Under More Scrutiny
description: Some school-sponsored rifle teams and officer training programs have come under scrutiny in recent weeks as administrators redouble efforts to rid their schools of guns in the wake of the Columbine High School shooting.

title: Media Talk; Investors Grumble About Barnes & Noble
description: In the months since Barnes & Noble Inc. announced its effort to buy the wholesaler Ingram Book Group, some Wall Street analysts and investors have grumbled that gleaning information from the company can be as difficult as finding a precious out-of-print book.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 15 about a merger of the Healtheon Corporation and WebMD misspelled the name of a Healtheon founder. He is Dr. David Schnell, not Schell.

title: KOSOVO TALKS BREAK DOWN AS SERBS BALK OVER DETAILS; NATO WILL STEP UP BOMBING
description: After two days of tense negotiations, talks between NATO and Yugoslav military commanders broke down early this morning over how and when Serbian forces would withdraw from Kosovo, throwing into doubt the peace deal reached last week by political leaders.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, C. CHESTER
description: BRAUN-C. Chester. On June 6. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father, loving grandfather, and cherished brother. And a great bridge player.

title: Pope Tells Poles of Modern Martyrs
description: Visiting a part of his homeland that was annexed into the German Reich during World War II, John Paul II reminded Poles today that Christian martyrdom continued well into this century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARK, DOROTHY
description: PARK-Dorothy. On May 26, 1999. Her family and many friends mourn her passing, she will be deeply missed.

title: For Albright's Mission, More Problems and Risk
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright flew to Europe tonight for what she hoped would be something of a victory lap. In fact, it is a risky mission, and could be rather muted.

title: Timorese Looking Ahead, to August Vote
description: In stark contrast to the election fervor in Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, voters in the troubled territory of East Timor are cool about prospects for change as a result of the historic election on Monday.

title: Bruno Caravaggi, 83, Co-Owner Of the Fashionable Quo Vadis
description: Bruno Caravaggi, the suave co-owner of Quo Vadis, one of New York's most fashionable Continental restaurants for almost four decades before its demise in 1984, died on May 30 at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: In Wall St. Wrangle, A Victim or a Rogue?
description: Christian Curry might have been considered the black banker most likely to fit in at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Instead, he and the firm are caught up in a legal dispute involving claims of racism, homophobia and conspiracy to break into a computer system. Behind this dispute is a question: Is Mr. Curry a victim or a rogue, or a little of both?

title: Paul S. Newman, 75, Prolific Comic-Book Writer
description: Paul S. Newman, who was listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the most prolific comic-book writer of all time, died on May 30 in Columbia, Md. He was 75.

title: War Crimes Investigators Prepare for Kosovo
description: Investigators of the international tribunal in The Hague are preparing to enter Kosovo with the multinational peacekeeping force to insure that they can gather the freshest possible evidence of war crimes, tribunal and Western officials say.

title: Accounts
description: * Planned Parenthood of America, Washington, to Benenson Janson, Los Angeles, to handle its account, which had been at Public Media Center, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

title: Allied Signal And Honeywell To Announce Merger Today
description: As expected, Allied Signal Inc., the diversified manufacturer, and Honeywell Inc., the Minneapolis-based maker of electronic controls, will announce today that they will merge, in a stock swap valued around $14 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBROW, OSCAR
description: DUBROW-Oscar. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Oscar Dubrow, beloved husband of Sylvia. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on May 18 about global air patterns reversed the strength and direction of the Arctic winds that affect storm tracks in the North Atlantic region. The stronger Arctic winds from the west result in more intense storm tracks across the region; the weaker Arctic winds from the east result in weaker storm patterns.

title: The Future of CUNY
description: Benno Schmidt's task-force report on the City University of New York documents the failures of an urban education system that badly needs a clearer mission and more coherent management. Often called the gateway to a better life for immigrants and those who cannot afford private college, CUNY is described as being ''adrift'' or caught in a ''spiral of decline.'' Some of this drift has a political undercurrent as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have criticized CUNY and cut its budget. However, Mr. Schmidt's ambitious report ducks the hazards of New York politics and instead offers thought-provoking suggestions of ways CUNY could become the model for a public urban university system.

title: Affirmative Action Ban Meets a Wall in Florida
description: Ward Connerly, who campaigned successfully to end affirmative action in government hiring and school admissions in California and Washington State, has now aimed his crusade at Florida, to the sound of slamming doors.

title: Health Benefits Bill Shows Power of the Disabled
description: Alana Theriault, who earns less than $1,000 a month working part time as a benefits counselor, is back in school to learn computer programming. Her instructors say she has a special aptitude, and when she gets her certificate soon, she says, she expects to be offered a programming job paying as much as $50,000 a year.

title: Pacers Still Wearing Loss on Their Sleeves
description: The Indiana Pacers strode into Madison Square Garden nearly a half-hour after their practice was scheduled to start yesterday, and it was hard to say what had accounted for the delay -- city traffic or the players' slow, disappointed gaits. After a brief conference, they seemed even more despondent as they trudged back to the court, the disaster in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals replayed on videotape.

title: When Fame Comes Before Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; When the Sound of a Dial Tone Is Ominous
description: Leo Mondale has been working on the project for years, but he still sounds a little awe-struck. ''This is quite a marvel,'' he says. ''We do have truly global coverage. We can serve customers at the poles, in the Himalayas, in the suburbs, wherever'' regular cellular phones cannot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, ELLIOT
description: LEVINSON-Elliot. On June 4, 1999. Beloved son of the late Irving and Gladys Levinson. Dear brother of the late Michael Levinson and cherished uncle. A fabulous friend to thousands and beloved by all. He will always be remembered for his generosity, friendship, goodwill and for his many, many acts of kindness. From his family, friends, ''buddies'' and neighbors. Services Monday, June 7, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, HENRY ''HUCK'' EDWARD
description: JENKINS-Henry ''Huck'' Edward. Age 73, in New London, NH, on June 4, 1999. Husband of Margaret (Hulst) Jenkins of New London, NH. Services on Friday, June 11, at 11AM at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, New London, NH. Memorial contributions may be made to Lake Sunapee Region Visiting Nurse Association, P.O. Box 2209 or New London Hospital Ambulance Service, 270 County Road, both New London, NH 03257. For information, Chadwick Funeral Service of New London, NH.

title: In City's Ballet's Footsteps, Students Exhibit the Joy of Dancing
description: Young dancers who can surmount the pressures of the annual School of American Ballet Workshop Performances can probably survive anything. The highly competitive atmosphere of what is a combination graduation, audition and professional performing experience can show in somewhat grim, stiff, do-or-die dancing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Begins Shipping Revamped Office Software

title: Patents; A 'labor assister' and other odds and ends aimed at making things better for new parents.
description: SINCE the first forceps were invented in the 17th century, childbirth has been a ripe field for innovation. In this century, pregnant women have been helped -- or, some have argued, hindered -- by many new gadgets and procedures, ranging from epidurals to contraptions for exercising the pelvic muscles.

title: An Identical Twin's Dance Toward Independence
description: Jennifer Brackenridge looked into her mirror as she prepared for the prom. Glitter adorned her eyes. A gossamer-thin layer of powder rested on her already perfect complexion, and a clip in the shape of a butterfly, a creature of flight, guarded her upswept hair. When all was done, she sought the final verdict from the reflection that stared back at her. The mirror was her sister's eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNGOLD, HERMAN
description: KORNGOLD-Herman. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi

title: Woods Has The Long And Short
description: Open season has officially begun, and for Tiger Woods the only fear is that he may have peaked too early. With victories in his last two tournaments, Woods will go into the United States Open at Pinehurst next week riding momentum and stoked with more confidence than ever before.

title: Shuttle Lands After Stocking And Repairing Space Station
description: Seven astronauts were getting their land legs back today, after an unusual night space shuttle landing capped their 10-day mission to stock the new International Space Station.

title: Manger Considers His Future
description: The day after three of his coaches were dismissed, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said that he deserved to follow them if the team does not improve within the next third of the season.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MARTIN
description: BRENNER-Martin. On June 5, 1999. Of New York City. Beloved and cherished husband of Leah. Adored father of Michele. Loving brother of Claire Sturmer, Leona Bochert and brother-in-law of Jack Sturmer. Also survived by his nephews Ricky, Jeffrey, and Kenny. Services 9:30 AM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, GABRIELLE
description: BLUESTEIN-Gabrielle. Beloved wife of Milton Bluestein, Gabrielle Alexander Bluestein was the matriarch of her family serving as its shining benevolent center. She will be missed by her daughters Barbara and Marion; her grandchildren Peter, William and Maria; and her great-grandchildren Sam, Eyck, Sarah, Finn and Elodie. Services will be held on Sunday, June 6 at 11:30 AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at Madison Avenue and 82 Street.

title: Eddie Stanky, 83, Spark Plug On 3 Pennant-Winning Teams
description: Eddie Stanky, the combative infielder whose inspired play helped bring pennants to the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Boston Braves and the New York Giants, died yesterday at a hospital in Fairhope, Ala. Stanky, who had homes in Mobile, Ala., and Fairhope, was 83.

title: Col. Lloyd Burke, 74, Medal of Honor Winner
description: Col. Lloyd L. Burke, who won the Medal of Honor in the Korean War for killing 100 Chinese Communist soldiers in a five-and-a-half-hour battle to capture a hill, died on Tuesday at his home in Hot Springs, Ark. He was 74.

title: How to Help Spouses Who Are Also Caretakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Allies Say Bombing Will Intensify After Serbs Balk at Signing Pullout Proposal
description: The NATO alliance said on Sunday that it would intensify its bombing of Yugoslavia, now entering its 76th day, as talks on a peacekeeping mission in Kosovo stumbled when Yugoslav military negotiators raised new objections.

title: Ralph Chamberlain, 72, Businessman and Salvation Army Captain
description: Ralph E. Chamberlain, a philanthropist and businessman who raised the profile of the Salvation Army with national television and magazine campaigns in the 1970's, died on Wednesday of pancreatic cancer at his home in Fly Creek, N.Y., a spokesman for the Salvation Army said yesterday. He was 72.

title: For Talbott, Kosovo Was Time to Test His Many Skills
description: PARIS  As the U.S. point man in the diplomatic endgame with Belgrade, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott emerged as the foreign policy strategist and operator whose skills are appreciated among fellow professionals but rarely publicized to the world at large.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about retail leasing at Paramount Plaza, at 1633 Broadway between 50th and 51st Streets, included an outdated reference to an office tenant, the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization. It is now at 1065 Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street.

title: To the Men: Game, Set, Money
description: PARISWell, well, well. More talk about equal prize money in professional tennis. The folks at Wimbledon recently rejected a request to give the female players the same amount that the male players get. In fact, the U.S. Open is the only Grand Slam event that pays the men and women equally.

title: Bank Cancels Deal With TV Evangelist
description: The Bank of Scotland P.L.C. said over the weekend that it had canceled a proposed joint banking venture with the television evangelist Pat Robertson after a public outcry over Mr. Robertson's disparaging remarks about Scotland and gay people.

title: An Injured Falcon Finds That New Yorkers Can Be Friendly
description: Wendy J. Gorman was on her way to lunch yesterday when she saw a large bird staring into a store window at the corner of 44th Street and Madison Avenue, the kind of sight that deserves a second look.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the editors of a newsletter for fans of British television misspelled the name of the program that helped inspire the newsletter. It was ''The Forsyte Saga,'' not Forsythe.

title: Account Decisions By On-Line Services
description: Three on-line services have made decisions involving accounts.

title: A Playwright Lays Claim To Parts of Hare's 'Via'
description: A Los Angeles actor and playwright has charged in a Federal lawsuit that David Hare's latest play, ''Via Dolorosa,'' which features the author as performer and has enjoyed critically acclaimed runs in London and New York, misappropriated its ideas, structure and some dialogue from a play written by the plaintiff.

title: I.B.M. Expands Sales to Others In Its Industry
description: I.B.M. plans to announce an $8 billion technology sales agreement today with the Acer Group of Taiwan, representing another big step in I.B.M.'s accelerating effort to market its leading-edge technology to companies that are often its competitors.

title: Market Place; Notes on corporate culture and possibilities as MCI Worldcom meets two years after its creation.
description: JUST as legal concerns began to percolate last Wednesday about whether MCI Worldcom Inc. misled investors as it negotiated its deal to buy Skytel Communications, the company convened its first meeting for analysts and investors in more than two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WURTZ, TESSINA
description: WURTZ-Tessina. On June 5, 1999. She is survived by her loving husband Charles, brother Robert Ferrar, sister Alice Scala, numerous nieces and nephews and grandnieces and nephews. Services to be held on Tuesday, June 8, 11 AM at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC. For further information, please call 212-744-3084.

title: Fatal Adventures Bolster Sales of Magazines
description: When John Rasmus, the editor in chief of National Geographic Adventure, introduced his magazine this spring, he was pleased to include an article titled ''Trouble in Shangri-La'' about a kayaking expedition in Tibet that ended in the death of a research chemist from Salt Lake City. In the second issue, Mr. Rasmus had an article investigating the deaths of cave-diving enthusiasts in Florida. And in the coming issue, he hopes to have an article about George Mallory, the explorer whose body was found on Mount Everest last month.

title: The Big City; Suitable Men: Rare Species Under Study
description: ANYONE who has planned a dinner party has encountered the great mystery of modern New York society: where are the men? The shortage of presentable unmarried heterosexual males has long baffled the finest minds on the singles scene. But on Friday evening, two field researchers began to provide answers.

title: How to Help Spouses Who Are Also Caretakers
description: To the Editor:

title: First Lady Could Build a Race on Her Best Issues, Allies Say
description: As she inches closer to running for senator from New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton is preparing to build a campaign around education, family and health care issues -- the areas where she has the clearest record of accomplishment, and failure, Democrats close to the First Lady say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, PEGGIE
description: ISAACS-Peggie. Of Boynton Beach, FL, on June 5, 1999, in Stamford, CT. Beloved mother of Jed P. Isaacs of Stamford, and Madeline Noveck of New York City; loving sister of Alex Jaffee, New York City. She is also survived by six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Funeral Monday, June 7, 1999, at 11AM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford. Burial Beth El Cemetery, Stamford. Memorial contributions to Camp Edward Isaacs, Central Queens Y.M.H.A., New York, NY.

title: For North Koreans, Paradise and Lunch
description: With a thaw in the frosty relations between the two countries, North Korea has arrived to prepare for the Women's World Cup and a first-round match against the United States. Team officials sat in a restaurant here today, wearing identical blue blazers with the North Korean star flag etched on the breast and lapel pins bearing the likeness of President Kim Jong Il. They spoke as stiffly as they dressed.

title: Agassi Revival Reaches a Peak In French Open
