description: Andre Agassi played the first two sets of the most important match of his life like a petrified pretender today. Then, when the shock and embarrassment failed to destroy him, he gathered his wits about him and played like someone who deserved to be in the company of Rod Laver, Fred Perry, Roy Emerson and Don Budge.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; The 'Nice Guy' Who Touched Off McCarthyism
description: THE REDHUNTERA Novel Based on the Life of Senator Joe McCarthyBy William F. Buckley Jr.421 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $25.

title: Mets Stop a Losing Streak as Clemens Stops Winning
description: Before facing Roger Clemens and the Yankees, most teams convene their coaches and review scouting reports. The Mets tried a novel approach, dismissing coaches and reviewing their various personality conflicts. But despite all the turmoil, the Mets managed to end three significant streaks with a 7-2 victory over the Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Protecting Students
description: To the Editor:

title: When Fame Comes Before Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ajaccio Journal; A Powder Keg as Big as a Mountain: Call It Corsica
description: A gentle breeze from the Mediterranean cools the cafes along Napoleon Boulevard, which is named, of course, for the island's most famous son. People are heading for the unspoiled beaches. A happy springtime scene, perhaps, were it not for the angry graffiti on Ajaccio's historic walls.

title: McMichael Is Ready To Return to the Mets
description: Greg McMichael is apparently finished with his minor league rehabilitation assignment. McMichael, who has been on the disabled list since spring training with rotator cuff tendinitis, pitched on consecutive days for Class AAA Norfolk this weekend and said yesterday that he felt fine.

title: An Unusually Difficult Hand Clobbers a Favored Team
description: After fighting for five days, teams led by Adam Wildavsky and Alan Miller reached the final of the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Team Championship played yesterday at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, Manhattan. Wildavsky, with Martin Fleisher, Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian, won his semifinal on Saturday by 27 imps against a group headed by Richard DeMartino. In the other match, Miller, teamed with Alex Ornstein, R. Jay Becker, Ira Herman, Aaron Silverstein and Brady Richter defeated Jeff Aker and his squad by 97.

title: Train to Kennedy Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: New Meet Sees Small Crowd But Some Big Performances
description: Despite a nasty wind down the homestretch, the athletes were happy. The small crowd watched one good competition after another and seemed happy. Melissa Morrison, the self-styled ''smallest hurdler in the world,'' was very happy because she won a $100,000 jackpot for less than 13 seconds of work.

title: Fighting Fire with Fire
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Some Dismay in Honeywell's Hometown
description: Honeywell Inc.'s merger with Allied Signal would result in the loss of a corporate headquarters here, the loss of up to 1,000 local jobs, and the migration of one of the region's leading philanthropic institutions.

title: A Dubious Choice as Health Chief
description: Gov. George Pataki's decision to name Antonia Novello as New York State's new Health Commissioner has drawn angry responses from Planned Parenthood and other abortion rights groups -- and for good reason. In selecting Dr. Novello, a strong opponent of abortion rights, to oversee the state agency in charge of insuring access to the full range of reproductive health care, the ostensibly pro-choice Governor was plainly thinking more about improving his standing in the national Republican Party than his duty to protect the reproductive freedom of New York women.

title: Serbs Shell Border Town, Rekindling Kosovar Fears
description: One shell exploded in a family's living room, blasting a hole through the ceiling, embedding shrapnel in the carpet and freezing the decorative clock hanging from the wall at 2:58 A.M.

title: Anxious House Braces for Fight On Gun Control
description: Members of the House of Representatives returned from a weeklong recess today and girded for a battle over gun control that was even more fraught with political anxiety than it had been when they left.

title: Faith After Columbine
description: To the Editor:

title: Heat Lifts Electricity Costs
description: Electricity prices surged in the Midwest and Northeast yesterday, quadrupling in some areas, after a blast of hot weather increased air-conditioning use and utilities asked customers to cut back. Air-conditioning demand this week is expected to be about twice normal levels in Chicago, New York, Detroit and Cleveland, according to Weather Derivatives in Belton, Mo. Temperatures, already in the 90's, will be above or much above normal throughout the region, the National Weather Service said. Electricity prices paid by some utility companies in those areas rocketed $247.23, or 356 percent, to $316.67 a megawatt-hour. Utilities cannot pass higher costs for wholesale electricity along in their electric bills.

title: A Translator Of Visions; Writer for Film Directors Puts His Ideas Into Plays
description: In any accounting of the most important people in the performing arts this century, Luis Bunuel and Peter Brook would figure prominently. Because he is far less well known, Jean-Claude Carriere would probably not make the list. But he is the primary writer behind the vastly different directors: Bunuel, the creator of dreamlike reveries on eroticism and society; Mr. Brook, the ensemble explorer of cultural myths.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Tools for Destruction, but None for Turning Back
description: THE FIRST WORLD WAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, KENNETH B.
description: KELLY-Kenneth B. On June 5, 1999. Son of the late James F. and Elizabeth M. Loving brother of James Leonard, Mary Duffy, Donald and Raymond. Loving uncle of 13 nieces and nephews and four great-nieces and great-nephews. Former press officer of the U.N. Former Sgt. USMC. Reposing at Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 63-17 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. Visiting Tuesday 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Funeral mass Wednesday 10:45AM. Resurrection Ascension R.C. Church. Interment Calverton National cemetery.

title: When the Innocent Go to Jail, Society Must Pay; Passive Grand Juries
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Tony Awards broadcast on Sunday night included an incorrect reference in some copies to a musical number from ''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues.'' As reported in the arts pages today, the number was dropped from the broadcast because of time limitations.

title: Mexico TV Host Slain in Ambush Near Studio
description: In a gangland-style ambush outside a major broadcast studio, gunmen fired automatic rifles and killed a popular television host and a bystander today. A reporter and other bystanders were wounded.

title: Depending on Kindness of Friends
description: Halfway through ''Tennessee Williams Remembered,'' Eli Wallach recalls a 300-pound woman who auditioned for a role in ''The Rose Tattoo'' in 1951. When the director asked her to read a scene, she replied: ''I no read. My daughter reads.'' Whereupon Anne Jackson, as the daughter, fairly crouches behind Mr. Wallach, playing the actress, reading lines that the actress repeats in explosions of exaggerated emotion unrelated to what she is saying. When the uproar of laughter from the audience subsides, Mr. Wallach, looking bewildered and amused, says, ''She got the part, too.''

title: Listeners Love Samuel Barber? Well, So What?
description: Samuel Barber was both a comfortable and a peculiar choice as the subject of the third installment of the 20th-Century Masters mini-festival at the Kaye Playhouse, a series of concerts and lectures that ran from Wednesday through Saturday. The selection was comfortable because his music is widely loved, and peculiar for pretty much the same reason.

title: Sports of The Times; Rose's New Role Is Now Knick Problem
description: LARRY BIRD was surrounded by reporters yesterday morning. The buzz of the day was that Jeff Van Gundy, the Knicks' head coach, had scrapped a monthlong winning formula and elevated Latrell Sprewell to the starting lineup.

title: A Closer Look at Those Who Stay Slim
description: The National Weight Control Registry is keeping tabs on more than 2,500 people who have lost weight, and researchers are looking for more volunteers to join the study. Participants must have lost at least 30 pounds and kept it off for at least one year.

title: W.N.B.A. To Add Four Teams
description: The Women's National Basketball Association, which began play two years ago with eight teams, will add teams in Miami, Indianapolis, Seattle and Portland, Ore., for the 2000 season, bringing the total to 16, the league announced yesterday.

title: Getting Waiting Rooms to Run on Time
description: The crowd was growing larger and its mood was turning ugly. People were muttering to each other, picking up magazines and tossing them aside, checking their watches, snarling at the personnel behind the check-in counter.

title: Reorganization at Lazard Freres Includes the Replacement of Its Top U.S. Executive
description: Lazard Freres & Company, the boutique investment banking partnership, announced plans yesterday to integrate its London, Paris and New York operations and to reshuffle its executive ranks in New York.

title: Holders' Suit Over MCA Deal Is Dismissed
description: A Federal appeals court dismissed a shareholder class-action suit yesterday against the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.

title: A Better CUNY or an Elitist One?
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Hollywood Salutes Itself, Saying No One Else Will
description: It is an incubator for the next generation of black filmmakers, a chance to network and a respite from the business and art conundrum. The Acapulco Black Film Festival in Mexico, now in its third year, is also gaining a reputation for putting a high gloss on hard work.

title: Optimism, and More Realism, On Talks About Withdrawal
description: Administration officials expressed hope today that the snags in talks about Serbia's withdrawal from Kosovo would be resolved within days.

title: For the Shaky Mets, a House Divided Can't Even Play This Game
description: Whether or not Casey Stengel ever actually said of the neophyte Mets, ''Can't anyone here play this game?'' the idea still applies to the team 37 years later, except now the question can be asked about everyone besides the players, from the owners on down.

title: Op-Art; The Baked Apple
Graf and Agassi Find Paris to Their Liking
description: In the end, it was all about leaving Paris with no regrets.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
description: Firing the latest volley in the battle to transmit phone calls using Internet technology, the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada plans to announce today that it is developing almost a dozen new products to help corporate customers integrate their phone and data communications networks.

title: Smaller Families to Bring Big Change in Mexico
description: Like many old-style Mexican matriarchs, Emma Castro Amador bore so many children that she can't keep their birthdays straight. Sometimes she even loses track of whether Oscar, her 10th, came before David, her 11th, or vice versa.

title: Man Dressed as Ninja Is Charged in Dart Attack
description: A sword-wielding man clad in black ninja attire who was arrested in Central Park on Sunday evening was charged yesterday with using a blowgun to shoot a metal dart into the head of a man walking through the park, the police said.

title: Ground Zero Adds To Work for Resorts
description: Sun International Resorts on Paradise Island, the Bahamas, has expanded its relationship with Ground Zero in Santa Monica, Calif., by awarding the agency the account of the Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, which is reopening after a renovation. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Man Shot by Driver He Scolded for Speeding
description: A Long Island man was shot in the left shoulder yesterday after he banged on the window of a car and shouted at the driver for going too fast on a street near a school, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the move by media companies into 24-hour journalism on line misspelled the surname of the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition. He is Rich Jaroslovsky, not Jaroslavsky.

title: John Paul, at Home in Polish Academia, Defends Copernicus
description: In 1543, the Polish astronomer Nicolas Copernicus sent his revolutionary thesis on the movement of the planets to Rome with a poignant letter seeking understanding from Pope Paul III. He never received a reply.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Federal antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation referred incorrectly to the Thursday testimony of a Government witness, Franklin M. Fisher. Reacting to an apparent conflict between the testimony of a previous witness, James Barksdale of the Netscape Communications Corporation, and internal company documents, Mr. Fisher said he thought the documents were exaggerations; he did not say Mr. Barksdale had exaggerated.

title: Almost Time to Pick Partners in France's 3-Bank Dance
description: When Andre Levy-Lang , the chief executive of Paribas, runs into Claude Bebear these days he asks him whether he has made up his mind.

title: Courting Russians, Allies Delay Bombing, but Strike Overnight
description: While talks were under way today in Bonn, NATO held back on carrying out threats to intensify its bombing of Yugoslavia if Belgrade did not promptly accept allied terms on Kosovo. But near midnight explosions and antiaircraft fire erupted in the capital, which had been quiet for several nights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDWIG, ARTHUR W., DR.
description: LUDWIG-Arthur W., Dr. The faculty members of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Mount Sinai Hospital, a division of Mount Sinai N.Y.U. Health, mourn the loss of our dear colleague, Dr. Arthur W. Ludwig. After graduating from Columbia College and N.Y.U. School of Medicine, Dr. Ludwig came to Mount Sinai Hospital as an intern and subsequently spent his entire professional career here, interrupted only by his service in the U.S. Navy in World War II. He returned to Mount Sinai as an Assistant Resident in Medicine and then took a Fellowship in Pathology. In his earlier years at Mount Sinai, he was an integral part of the Endocrine Division, active both in Clinical endocrinology as well as in research on the effects of hormones on connective tissue. He was a devoted teacher and beloved by his patients. He was a warm, brilliant, cultured, and gracious physician with a ready smile and wit, always anxious to be of service. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Laura and to his children, Andrew, Lisa, and Amy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIGIOVANNI, CONSTANCE
description: DIGIOVANNI-Constance. 6/7/6012/3/94. Happy Birthday in heaven to my beautiful little sister, my forever friend. June brings sadness and life persists. I see your lovely face and hear you laughing. I want more

title: Treasuries Close Unchanged After an Early-Session Rally
description: Bond prices faltered yesterday after rising earlier in the session for the first time in more than a week as the higher yield level for Treasuries attracted investors.

title: The Refugees Of a Past War Still Suffer
description: For five years they have lived, four adults in a single room, in this drab compound of makeshift huts on the outskirts of Belgrade. The Sehovac family, Serbs who fled Sarajevo in 1994, are sunk in a world of depression and bitterness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENKIN, ALVIN
description: CHENKIN-Alvin. Age 80, formerly of Teaneck, NJ, now of Media, Pennsylvania died peacefully on Sunday, June 6, 1999 after a very courageous struggle with congestive heart failure. His family wishes him a good journey-we will miss him but he gave us the tools we need to go on without him. He was predeceased by his beloved and cherished wife, Beatrice Glotzer Chenkin whom he never stopped missing. He is survived by his children, Shura, Debbie and Carl, his in-laws, Joseph Sullivan, Donald Steele and Sarah Whitcher Chenkin and his beloved grandchildren, Elise, Sam and Beatrice. He worked for 38 years at the Council of Jewish Federations in New York City and was proud to have served as President of Union Local 107, a constituent of District Council 1707. A man of unbending will, strength of character and extremely wry sense of humor-he will be deeply missed by his family. Funeral services will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Jewish Labor Committee or the Jacob Zukerman Fund of the Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring. Information: Wien and Wien Funeral Home.

title: INSIDE
description: Push on Mental Health

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, GABRIELLE
description: BLUESTEIN-Gabrielle. Beloved wife of Milton Bluestein, Gabrielle Alexander Bluestein was the matriarch of her family serving as its shining benevolent center. She will be missed by her daughters Barbara and Marion; her grandchildren Peter, William and Maria; and her great-grandchildren Sam, Eyck, Sarah, Finn and Elodie. Services will be held on Sunday, June 6 at 11:30 AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at Madison Avenue and 82 Street.

title: Equal on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia's Heady Election: Early Returns Show Politics May Be Turning Upside Down
description: A top official of Indonesia's ruling party said today that early returns in national elections suggested that ''we are losing'' and that the party would need to fight for a place in a future government coalition.

title: RUSSIANS BALKING AS GAINS ARE MADE ON KOSOVO TALKS
description: After eight hours of negotiations, Russia balked today at approving a resolution to be sent to the United Nations Security Council on the future of Kosovo and the role of 50,000 peacekeepers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALCOTT, LEONORE WHITNEY
description: TALCOTT-Leonore Whitney, 93. Of Greenwich, CT, daughter of the late Livingston Whitney and Amy Jessup Whitney, and wife of the late Charles Hooker Talcott, Jr., Architect, died on June 6, 1999 at Nathaniel Witherell in Greenwich. Mrs. Talcott was an active volunteer, working with Civil Defense and the Republican Party in Greenwich. She was instrumental in developing the picture cart at the Greenwich Hospital, and also volunteered with the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, CT. and the Community Answers program in Greenwich. She is survived by a sister, Elizabeth Whitney Evans of Willoughby, OH, a daughter, Amy Talcott Adkins of Haymarket, VA, step-daughters Anne Talcott Groth of Wilbraham, MA, and Alice Talcott Benet of Concord, MA, eight grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, many friends and devoted caretakers. A graveside service will be held on Friday, June 11, at Cedar Hill Cemetery in Hartford, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary. Information: Fred D. Knapp & Sons Funeral Home of Greenwich.

title: Israel's New Parliament a Coterie of Many Colors
description: Ahmed Tibi, a longtime adviser to Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, pledged his allegiance to the state of Israel today. A healthy white carnation gleamed on his lapel.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE DROPS SHARPLY. Prices for coffee fell almost 7 percent as warmer weather in Brazil eased concern that a frost would cut output there. In New York, coffee for July delivery fell 8 cents a pound, to $1.12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOK, JOSEPH, MD.
description: BLOK-Joseph, MD. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express with great sorrow the passing of Dr. Joseph Blok, esteemed and dedicated member of the Department of Surgery for four decades. To his wife Claire, son Jeffrey, daughter Jenise and his entire family, we extend our profound and heartfelt condolences. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Sheldon S. Berman, MD, Sr. Vice President and CMO Richard J. Fogler, MD, Chairman Surgical Services Malcolm Z. Roth, MD, President, Medical Staff Arthur Kay, MD, President, Medical Board

title: Camp David For Kashmir
description: As tensions between India and Pakistan over the disputed territory of Kashmir once again boil over, world security is threatened by the very real possibility that war will break out between two politically unstable nuclear powers. This week, air strikes by Indian helicopter gunships and MIG jet fighters further increased the chance that Kashmir could spark yet another, and far more dangerous, confrontation.

title: What Else To Say But 'Fusion'?
description: Gabrielle Lansner

title: University Officials Yield To Student Strike in Mexico
description: After seven weeks of a grueling student strike at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, the largest institution of higher education in Latin America, the administration backed down today before the students' protests, opening the way for a settlement.

title: Metro Business; Least-Favored-State Status
description: New York is the least favorable state in the country for doing business while Texas is the most attractive, according to a survey of corporate officials.

title: Sophocles Gets a Twist in Paris, by Way of West Africa
description: The underlying themes of the Greek tragedies have easily survived the 25 or more centuries since the plays were written: power versus morality; laws of man versus laws of God; reasons of state versus reasons of the heart. Indeed, their very universality makes them ever topical and easily adaptable, and that perhaps explains why a West African version of Sophocles' ''Antigone'' has just been presented to acclaim in Paris.

title: A Better CUNY or an Elitist One?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AUTOCYTE INC., Burlington, N.C., a medical device company, agreed to acquire Neopath Inc. of Redmond, Wash., for about $106.5 million in stock.

title: Study Exposes Craven Motive of the Brave Meerkat Sentry
description: While his compatriots scuffle about in the sand for delicious scorpions or fat, tasty mice, one meerkat stands alone, bolt upright on an exposed perch, scanning for hawks with dark eyes wide, ready to call out at the first sign of danger. Like other such guards in the animal kingdom, these endearingly vulnerable meerkat sentinels have long impressed biologists as true altruists -- creatures willing to forgo food and brave danger to protect others.

title: With Trains This Fast, Who Needs to Fly?
description: A RAPIDLY expanding network of high-speed trains is setting the pace for travel within Europe. Speeds of up to 300 kilometers an hour have cut journey times by at least half between major cities, making the train often a faster way to travel from city center to city center than the plane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSLER, FRIEDA
description: STRASSLER-Frieda. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Frieda Strassler, beloved mother of David H. Strassler, ADL's Honorary National Chairman. We extend our deepest condolences to David, his brother Robert and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: It's That Time Again: Pay Raise Debated for City Officials
description: Every four years, the world stages a Summer Olympics. Every four years, the United States elects a President. And every four years, a mayoral commission in New York City recommends pay increases for the city's elected officials.

title: Speaker Plans Speech to Unite House G.O.P.
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert will meet with House Republicans on Tuesday in what is being described by party members as a very pointed political pep talk and an effort to strengthen his own position as a leader.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Society That Runs Bronx Zoo Turns to Corporate World to Get a New Leader
description: Christopher H. Smith has not been to the Bronx Zoo since the 1940's, when he went there as a child to see a duckbilled platypus. But yesterday, he was elected president of the august organization that runs the Bronx Zoo, as well as other city zoos and 320 conservation projects in 52 countries.

title: Sports of The Times; Like Camby, Knicks Keep Reappearing
description: SO now that the Knicks have surrendered the home-court advantage they worked so hard to get, the only logical assumption is that they have the Indiana Pacers right where they want them. Thinking they are going back home, in the clear.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Find Shortcuts to Federal Appeals by State Inmates Unacceptable
description: The Supreme Court shut the door tighter today on state inmates' access to Federal court, ruling that prisoners who have not first appealed to their state's highest court forfeit their right to Federal court review even if it was evident that the state appeal would be fruitless.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the oversight body known as the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers misstated the surname of its interim president and chief executive. He is Michael M. Roberts, not Rogers.

title: Account Changes By 3 Companies
description: Three packaged-goods advertisers have made changes involving their accounts.

title: Not Every Problem Is Mental Illness; Chemistry or Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ben-ny, Ben-ny and the Mets Get on Track
description: The Mets desperately want some normalcy to return to their season. After three coaches were dismissed last Saturday and Manager Bobby Valentine was sent an obvious message about his own status, after the draining weekend series with the Yankees and after finally ending their eight-game losing streak on Sunday night, the Mets would love to focus on baseball and nothing else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATIENCE, EDWIN S.
description: PATIENCE-Edwin S., 91. Of Bloomfield, husband of Virginia (Ziemienczyk) Patience and the late Helene Patience, died on Thursday, June 3, 1999 at Hartford Hospital. He was born in Brooklyn, NY and had lived in Garden City, NY for over forty years before moving to Bloomfield in 1993. Prior to his retirement, in 1966, Mr. Patience was Financial Vice President and Director of Borden, Inc of NY where he worked for 35 years. Besides his wife he is survived by his daughter Joy Edwards and her husband Thomas of Garden City, NY, his step-son, Mark Ziemienczyk and his wife Betsy of Granby, CT. There will be a Memorial Service, Saturday, June 26, 1999, 4:30 PM at The First Congregational Church in Bloomfield, 10 Wintonbury Avenue, Bloomfield, CT with the Reverend Richard A. Smith officiating. Burial will be private and at the convenience of the family. There will be no visiting hours. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Salvation Army, 855 Asylum Ave. Hartford, CT 06105. Information: The Dillon-Baxter Funeral Home, Wethersfield, CT.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lazard Freres to Integrate U.S. and European Units

title: In Search Of a Way To Bolster The Sperm
description: With a bit of fanfare but limited hard evidence, a Maryland pharmaceutical company has begun marketing a dietary supplement said to improve sperm quality to couples having trouble conceiving.

title: Procter & Gamble Reshuffles Accounts
description: The Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati, in another in a recent series of worldwide brand realignments, is reshuffling several creative accounts among its largest agencies. Billings were estimated at $200 million or more, but the company said that ''the net result of all changes is not financially material to any agency.''

title: 12 of 48 Parties in the Election Have an Islamic Orientation : Muslim Vote Watched in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA  As the results of Indonesia's parliamentary elections flood in, politicians, business interests and foreign governments are watching to see whether Islamic political parties gain ground in the world's largest Muslim nation.

title: Americans Struggle On Defense
description: Defense wins championships, and the Americans will have difficulty winning the Women's World Cup if their defense is as vulnerable as it was in their 4-2 victory over Canada on Sunday. It was the United States team's last game before the tournament starts June 19.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Patterns
description: Life After Tocca

title: Where to Go When You're Finished With Paris
description: PARIS  The countryside surrounding Paris is an unparalleled concentration of French history, landscape, artistic achievement and of course some good food and wine tossed into the mix. Within a two-hour's drive of the capital are not only traces of both world wars, Joan of Arc, Richard the Lionhearted and the French kings, but also Gustave Flaubert, the playwright Pierre Corneille, the Impressionists, hard apple cider, calvados and odorous livarot cheese.

title: Researchers Seek Volunteers To Test a New AIDS Vaccine
description: Newark and New Jersey have begun casting their nets for test subjects for the world's first full-scale clinical trials of an AIDS vaccine.

title: In Battle Against Heroin, Scientists Enlist Heroin
description: Taking a bold approach to addiction, researchers at Columbia University are offering free heroin to addicts and paying them to use it under a Federally authorized program aimed at finding a cure for their drug habits.

title: Silver Revises His Offer To Cut Spending Demand
description: Last week's apparent progress toward a state budget evaporated today as Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver appeared to retract his offer to cut his house's spending demands by as much as $2 billion.

title: Drill-Like Mechanism in Spread of Tumors Is Revealed
description: A delicate but destructive machine, a kind of molecular power drill deployed by tumors to punch their way through the body's compartments, has been visualized for the first time by biologists at Sweden's Karolinska Institute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHOUET, DAVID J.
description: CAHOUET-David J. Of New York City fomerly of Bernardsville, NJ died at his family's home in Princeton, NJ on Tuesday, June 1, at age 30. Born with hemophilia he was later infected, through clotting factor transfusions with HIV and officially diagnosed by New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center 1987. We pay homage to the many thousands of hemophiliacs, now dead of AIDS, as David was fortunate to have lived so long in relatively good health. A graduate of the Far Hills Country Day School, the Salisbury School, Salisbury, CT and Lake Forest College, IL. Class of 1991, David was beloved and respected by all who knew him for his love of music, sense of humor, strength of character and infinite wisdom. His stoicism in dealing first with hemophilia and then with HIV is our inspiration. He is survived by his parents James and Jean and locally by his grandmother Margaret W. Taylor, his aunts and uncles; Professor Ann Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. M. Douglas Watson and Robert G. Fairburn. Also, by Mrs. Richard L. Fogarty of Bowie, MD, Reverend Ralph H. Cahouet O.P., New York City, John J. Cahouet of Boston, MA and Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Cahouet of Pittsburgh, PA. A memorial service for family and friends will be held June 12, The First Presbyterian Church New Vernon, NJ at 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Hemophilia Association of NJ, 37 West Prospect Street, East Brunswick, NJ 08816 are welcome.

title: Pacers Even Series As Knicks Fall Flat
description: Whatever energy and euphoria the Knicks had left from their improbable victory in Game 3 Saturday dissipated in a flat performance at Madison Square Garden last night. Undermined by turnovers and unable to create any offensive consistency, New York lost to the Indiana Pacers, 90-78, in Game 4.

title: Parma  a Tasty Slice of Medieval Italy
description: PARMA, Italy  If you take the trouble to come here, you can be sure of tasting Parma ham at its succulent and aromatic best, and Parmesan cheese so moist and soft that it melts in your mouth like butter.

title: Tradition, Tradition: Spanish With Dignity
description: Andrea Del Conte Danza Espana

title: Disney Considers Buying Internet Search Service
description: In a series of moves intended to expand its role on the Internet, the Walt Disney Company confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to buy the 57 percent of Infoseek that it does not already own.

title: Nisource Discloses $5.7 Billion Hostile Bid for Columbia
description: Nisource Inc. disclosed a hostile $5.7 billion cash offer for the Columbia Energy Group, yesterday and Columbia's chairman responded that while his company was not for sale and was not interested in any merger transaction he would present the bid to the board.

title: Jousting With Belgrade
description: Slobodan Milosevic is a master at using delay, surprise and confusion to divide his opponents, and he is now using all three to undermine the peace agreement that he accepted in Belgrade last week. NATO will prevail in this diplomatic contest if it remains faithful to the peace deal, retains a reasonable degree of Russian cooperation and keeps military pressure on Serbian forces until Mr. Milosevic orders them removed from Kosovo.

title: Gores and Clintons, Relaxed and Intent, Turn to Initiatives on Mental Illness
description: The Gores and Clintons shared a stage for two hours at the White House Conference on Mental Health today, and took turns interviewing people who have struggled with mental illness as a patient, parent or researcher.

title: In South Africa, Winner Almost Takes All
description: Final election results in South Africa showed today that the ruling African National Congress was returned to power with even more votes than it won in 1994. But it fell just one seat short of a two-thirds majority in Parliament.

title: Mexico's Ambassador Of Elegance Beyond Huaraches
description: It takes courage to open a designer boutique on Madison Avenue that doesn't have a recognizable name. It takes even more courage if the name belongs to a dead designer who won't be around to charm potential customers. But Elisa Salinas, who is opening the Enrique Martinez boutique in the fall at Madison Avenue and 67th Street, doesn't seem the slightest bit daunted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMOON, SIMON
description: SHAMOON-Simon. The Members of the Board, the Administration and the children and families of OHEL, Bais Ezra and the Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved father of Alan, a dear friend of OHEL's foster children and a man of compassion for those with disabilities. We extend our condolences to the entire family, and may they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman, OHEL President David Mandel, Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRABKIN, MIRIAM
description: DRABKIN-Miriam, Friedman of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Israel, devoted mother of William and the late Susan Gardner. Loving grandmother of Jerry, Caren, Esther and Lydia. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 11:00am. (1-800-378-1892)

title: Morgan Stanley Answer to Bias Suit: Ex-Worker Abused Expenses
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter yesterday accused a former employee who filed a discrimination suit against it of brazenly stealing the firm's money through systematic false expense claims, and said that the employee's contentions of racism and homophobia at the firm amounted to an ''extortion scheme.''

title: The Salmon's New Chance
description: The decline of the once-great salmon populations off the Pacific coasts of Canada and the United States ranks high on the list of the 20th century's environmental disasters. But 1999 may well turn out to be the year when the fish finally caught a break. In March, acting under the Endangered Species Act, the Federal Government set in motion a regional plan to restore salmon runs throughout the Pacific Northwest. Then last week, following years of fruitless negotiations, the United States and Canada announced a plan to set new limits on salmon catches and establish a conservation fund to further protect the fish.

title: CNBC's Mr. Cool, When the Market Is Hot
description: RON INSANA, the fast-talking CNBC anchor, is best known for his unflappability. It's why he gets to interview the big guns of the money world: Soros, Galbraith, Rubin; senators, C.E.O.'s, reclusive hedge fund titans. His publicity agent actually called him Mr. Cool when describing him.

title: BRITISH STEEL PURCHASE
description: British Steel agreed to buy Royal Hoogovens for 2.32 billion euros ($2.39 billion) in stock and assumed debt to expand production outside Britain, where a strong pound left the company with an implied loss of $:160 million ($257.6 million) for the six months ended in April. The deal creates Europe's second-largest steelmaker, with a market capitalization of 4.62 billion euros ($4.8 billion). Holders of Hoogovens, which has debt of 546 million euros ($$566.9 million), will own 38 percent of the new company, implying a price of 2.32 billion euros ($2.41 billion). British Steel holders get a cash payout of 35 pence (56 cents) a share.

title: VARLEN BOARD REJECTS $700 MILLION OFFER BY AMSTED
description: The Varlen Corporation, a maker of train and auto parts, said its board had rejected as ''inadequate'' a $700 million hostile tender offer from Amsted Industries. Varlen urged stockholders to hold their shares as it considered talks with potential buyers, including Amsted. Varlen is based in Naperville, Ill. Amsted, an employee-owned company in Chicago that is a leading maker of train wheels, offered last month to pay $35 a share in cash and assume $94.9 million in Varlen debt. Varlen shares rose $1.4375, to $39.25.

title: Hillary Brooke, 84; Actress in Movies
description: Hillary Brooke, an actress who appeared in some 50 films as well as in the early 1950's television series ''My Little Margie,'' died on May 25 at a hospital in Fall Brook, Calif. She was 84 and lived in Bosnall, Calif.

title: A Songbird That Works a Lifetime to Keep Its Song on Key
description: Among songbirds, the zebra finch is a one-hit wonder. It learns a tune in its youth, and then is condemned to repeat it forever, like an aging pop star on the oldies circuit.

title: I.B.M. Official Has Harsh Words for Microsoft
description: Referring to documents and recalling first-hand experience, an I.B.M. executive today provided the most detailed allegations yet to arise in the Microsoft antitrust trial of how the big software maker wielded its market power to put pressure on personal computer makers to favor Microsoft's products.

title: God as a Running Mate
description: Vice President Al Gore's speech to the Salvation Army on May 24 makes fascinating reading. It purports to be an explanation for why ''ordinary Americans'' have been ''turned off to politics.'' And it offers a cure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, ELIZABETH HITE
description: JENNINGS-Elizabeth Hite. The Board of Trustees, Board of Managers, Administration and Medical and Dental Staff of The New York United Hospital Medical Center mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Betsy Jennings, a cherished member of The Hospital's Community for over 65 years. Her loyal friendship to The Hospital, her advocacy of its Medical Programs and her superb leadership will be greatly missed. The United Hospital Community will always treasure the memory of her warm and gracious nature, which she shared so generously with others. We extend to her family, our deep condolences and pledge to continue the tradition of excellence which she helped to establish. Frank R. Noonan, Chairman of The Board of Trustees Kevin W. Dahill, President and CEO

title: Tricky Point For Serbs: No Mention Of U.N. Role
description: The military talks intended to seal the withdrawal of Serbian forces from Kosovo stalled in part because the Yugoslav military balked at the absence of any reference to a United Nations role in the peacekeeping force for Kosovo, according to NATO officials and Western diplomats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZONANA, FELIX
description: ZONANA-Felix. Born Cairo, Egypt, January 22, 1915; died June 6th, 1999 in Hallandale, FL. He is survived by his loving wife, Nelly, son Victor and daughter Joyce.

title: Departing U.S. Attorney Quietly Makes an Imprint, if Not a Name
description: In a city full of chanticleers who credit their own crowing for the sunrise, Zachary W. Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, normally would be a candidate for celebrity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELITOFF, GOLDIE
description: WELITOFF-Goldie. Of Jersey City. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Bernard. Devoted mother of Lynda Sloan and the late Steven. Mother-in-law of Nat and Norma. Loving grandmother of Karen, Steven and Danielle. Services Tuesday. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: SKY FINANCIAL IN $285 MILLION DEAL FOR MAHONING
description: Sky Financial Group Inc. of Bowling Green, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mahoning National Bancorp of Youngstown, Ohio, for about $285 million in stock. Mahoning shareholders will receive 1.66 shares of Sky Financial for each of their shares in a tax-free exchange, representing a 54 percent premium based on Friday's closing prices. Yesterday, Mahoning shares rose $10.75, or 34 percent, to $42.25. Sky Financial shares fell $2.0625, to $27.25. After this and two other pending acquisitions are completed, Sky Financial will have $7.7 billion in assets and 230 branches in Ohio, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Michigan. Mahoning has assets of $809 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, ROBERT G.
description: MALONEY-Robert G. Of Park Ridge, New Jersey, died suddenly on Sunday, June 6, 1999. Robert, the son of the late Robert and Mary Maloney and brother of the late John T. Maloney, was born in Mentor, Ohio, and grew up in the Cleveland area. He was a graduate of John Carroll University in Ohio and Columbia University in New York. He is survived by his children: Maura, of Kingston, TN; Sheila of Gold Hill, CO.; Eileen Triplett of Hyannis, MA; Sean of Seattle, WA; Deidre Cutler of Bedford, NY; and Donal and Robert, both of Park Ridge, NJ. His loving grandchildren include: Rebecca, Erin, Leah, Siobhan, Elizabeth, Christopher, Shaynna, Brendan, and Wesley. His wife, Virginia, and two children, Thomas and Siobhan, predeceased him. He met his wife Virginia and many lifelong friends at the Newman Club at Columbia University. Bob worked as a financial analyst on Wall Street, most recently with Wood Gundy, and retained a keen interest in financial matters in retirement. He was an active member of the Interstate Hiking Club and the Frost Valley Trail Walkers. Noted for his quick Irish wit, he made friends easily. An avid hiker, his final moment came at Harriman State Park, NY a place he would have chosen and among people whose company he enjoyed. May he rest in peace. Bob's wake will be at Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, New Jersey, Wednesday, 7 to 9 PM; Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. The funeral Mass will be at 10 AM, Friday, June 11, at Our Lady of Mercy Church in Park Ridge. Final resting place will be at St. Mary's Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to Covenant House, 347 West 17th Street, NY, NY 10011; or The Nature Conservancy, 570 Seventh Ave., New York, New York 10018.

title: Sprewell Gets a Start But Doesn't Produce
description: He was blazing downcourt, ahead of everyone else, trying to get Chris Childs's attention before the series was tied, the home-court advantage was lost and the questions began all over again. Cutting along the baseline, behind the Indiana defense, Latrell Sprewell finally saw the ball headed in his direction.

title: Music Teacher Accused Of Molesting Students
description: A music teacher was being held in $1 million bail yesterday after Bergen County authorities arrested him on suspicion of sexually assaulting young girls who had gone to him for piano lessons.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO HITS NEWEST LOW. The European single currency fell to its lowest level yet against the dollar as negotiations to end the Balkan war faltered. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0286, down from $1.0362 late Friday.

title: YELLOW TO BUY JEVIC TRANSPORTATION FOR $200 MILLION
description: The Yellow Corporation, the long-haul trucking company, said it had agreed to acquire Jevic Transportation Inc. for $200 million to increase its regional transportation services. Yellow, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., will pay $14 in cash for each Jevic share, a 30 percent premium to Jevic's closing price on Friday, and will assume about $40 million in debt. Jevic, based in Delanco, N.J., will strengthen Yellow's service in the Northeast and upper Midwest. Yellow said that the acquisition would immediately add to earnings and that there would be no job cuts after the purchase. Jevic shares rose $3.0625, to $13.8125; Yellow gained 12.5 cents, to $17.625.

title: N.I.H. Plan For Journal On the Web Draws Fire
description: The director of the National Institutes of Health has touched off a passionate debate by proposing that scientists disclose and disseminate the results of biomedical research on the Internet, making the full text of their reports available at no cost to anyone with a computer anywhere in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHEIM, PHILIP G.
description: BERNHEIM-Philip G., 88. Survived by beloved wife Gioia, children Thomas and Lynn Reese, brother Richard, three grandchildren, five great-grandchildren. Died June 4, 1999 in Tequesta, FL. Also resident of Red Bank, N.J. and formerly NYC. He graduated from Wisconsin, Phi Beta Kappa and was V.P. of R. Neumann Co., an avid golfer and loved by all who knew him.

title: Big Brother Wants You To Quit Smoking
description: In the future, cigarette smokers will have to hide their addictions as if they were criminals (not just pariahs, as they are now). Office workers will sneak away from their desks and escape to skyscraper roofs to enjoy the legally banned pleasures of lighting, inhaling and exhaling glorious nicotine. A single cigarette may sell for $10. Fellow addicts will know one another but never speak of it where they might be overheard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JOSEPH HOWARD
description: KATZ-Joseph Howard. On June 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Marion (nee Langsan). Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews in Atlanta and NYC. Service Tuesday, 10AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 St and Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, IRENE M. (NEE LANSING)
description: MATTHEWS-Irene M. (nee Lansing). On June 6, 1999 of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Beloved wife of John A. Matthews. Dear mother of John A. Jr., Robert T. and Doreen M. Beswick. Cherished grandmother of five. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc. 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Thursday at 11 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury.

title: HARNISCHFEGER SEEKS COURT PROTECTION FROM CREDITORS
description: Harnischfeger Industries, a manufacturer of mining and paper-making machinery, filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. The company, founded in 1884 as a machine shop, said it had assets of $2.87 billion and debts of $2.27 billion. As part of a two-year agreement with lenders, it will get $750 million in financing to run its business during the reorganization. Two months ago, Thomas Taylor, the company's third-biggest shareholder, criticized management for ignoring a takeover bid from an unnamed suitor. Harnischfeger, which is in St. Francis, Wis., a Milwaukee suburb, ran low on cash as prices for metals and pulp tumbled.

title: Systems Designed to Hold a Homemade Sun
description: Scientists have developed a variety of devices and systems in which they hope to be able to compress hydrogen to the densities and temperatures needed to sustain thermonuclear fusion reactions. These are among them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, IRVING L., DR.
description: FISHER-Irving L., Dr. Of Fort Lee. Beloved husband of Madeline. Devoted father of Diane Rudd and Kenneth. Dear brother of Annette Weber. Loving grandfather of Philip, Elizabeth, Samuel and Benjamin. Services at ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, New Jersey, Tuesday at 1 PM. 1-800-322-0533

title: Belgium Adds Butter to Suspect List : Markets in Asia Ban EU's Farm Products
description: BRUSSELS  Asian markets struck European farm products off the menu as Belgium's food scandal widened Monday with the addition of butter and other animal fats to the list of items banned from sale because of possible poisoning by a cancer-causing chemical.

title: 3 Advertisers Move on Accounts
description: Three advertisers have made decisions involving accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, GAYNOR I.
description: JACOBSON-Gaynor I. It is with great sadness that HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, notes the passing of our dear friend and former executive vice president (1968-'81). His leadership, dedication and lifelong contribution to assisting Jews worldwide was inspirational and profound. His outstanding service, internationally recognized, was incomparable, as was his wise counsel. Honored by many nations including Brazil and Israel, he received numerous awards and held top positions in both the Jewish community and immigration organizations. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Florence, and his two daughters. Neil Greenbaum President Leonard Glickman Executive Vice President

title: Humiliation for a Scottish Bank
description: The Bank of Scotland has emerged thoroughly embarrassed from its ill-fated effort to get into consumer banking in the United States in partnership with Pat Robertson, the television evangelist and politician.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCELL, NATHAN
description: ANCELL-Nathan. The Geriatrics Advisory Council of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health mourns the passing of longtime member, Nathan Ancell, and extends our sympathy to his entire family. Christine K. Cassel, M.D., Chair Henry L. Schwartz Dept. of Geriatrics & Adult Development

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELGIORNO, MARIE
description: DELGIORNO-Marie. Of Southbury, CT. Passed away June 6, 1999. She is survived by two sisters and two brothers. For more funeral information call: 914-941-0838.

title: SOUTHERN UNION IN $385 MILLION ENERGY DEAL
description: The Southern Union Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pennsylvania Enterprises Inc. for $385 million in stock and cash to enter the Northeast energy market. The offer was valued at $35 in stock and cash, an 18 percent premium to Friday's close. Southern Union will also take on about $105 million in debt. Pennsylvania Enterprises stockholders will get 1.4798 Southern Union shares and $3 in cash for each of their shares. Buying Pennsylvania Enterprises, which is based in Wilkes-Barre and has 153,000 customers in northeastern Pennsylvania, would help stabilize the profit of Southern Union, which is based in Austin, Tex., and has a million customers in Texas, Missouri, Florida and Mexico. Southern Union shares lost 25 cents, to $21.375, and Pennsylvania Enterprises rose 87.5 cents, to $30.5625.

title: De Bruin Loses Ban Appeal
description: Michelle de Bruin, who won three gold medals in the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, lost an appeal yesterday to lift a four-year ban for tampering with a urine sample in a suspected effort to mask the presence of banned drugs. The ban will keep her out of the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia, as well as the world championships in 2001.

title: In a Small Java Village, a Big Step Toward Democracy
description: As the ballot counting began today in this fishing village west of Jakarta, a crowd of eagle-eyed locals encircled a makeshift polling place as workers unfolded and called out each vote. Tedious work, but no one complained.

title: Song Into Speech And Speech Into Song
description: Urban Bush Women

title: Not Every Problem Is Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Vivendi to Acquire Pathe, France's Largest Producer of Films
description: Vivendi S.A. of France is to acquire Pathe S.A., France's biggest film producing and distribution company, for $2 billion in stock, in a complex deal that promises to push forward the consolidation already under way in the European television business.

title: With Crisis in Mind, Center Opens
description: Ridiculed only a year ago as an overpriced skybox ''bunker'' built to shield Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his top aides from physical and perhaps verbal abuse, the city's $13 million emergency crisis center officially opened yesterday with a blaze of activity simulating a biological attack on New York.

title: Legato to Acquire Vinca
description: Legato Systems Inc., which makes software that helps prevent the loss of computer files, agreed to buy the Vinca Corporation for $94 million in cash and stock to add products that speed access to data. Adding Vinca would broaden Legato's share of the market for ''high-availability clustering'' products, which make it easier to use computer programs and information. Legato's product, Networker, backs up operating systems and insures that workers can retrieve files.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the testimony of the television talk show host Jerry Springer before the Chicago City Council misspelled the name of an alderman who accused Mr. Springer of having shown up only to enlarge his audience. The alderman was Burton Natarus, not Mitarz.

title: Reporter's Notebook; High-Profile Police Trial Shifts to Mundane Waiting
description: Whether it is a trial that has received no public notice, or one where the public spotlight has been brilliant, the final stretch is usually the same -- an agony of suspense in which the defendants sweat it out while 12 strangers decide whether the result will be acquittal and freedom.

title: Q & A
description: Beta Blockers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREGER, PHILIP
description: KREGER-Philip. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Philip Kreger and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Sarah and family. Ber and Frances Nisenbaum

title: A Better CUNY or an Elitist One?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LILI
description: MORRIS-Lili. On June 4, 1999. Loving wife of the late Chester. Cherished mother of Kenton. Beloved sister of the late Joyce K. Ward. Fond stepmother of Col. Brooks (Laura) Morris, U.S.A.F, Retired. Dear friend of Lori, Kira, Elizabeth, Jillian Bennett and Betty Smith. Memorial visitation Tuesday, 6-9 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Actors' Home would be appreciated.

title: VITAL SIGNS: THERAPIES; Vitamin E Disappoints as Skin Healer
description: In a recent study, researchers were surprised to find that vitamin E oil, generally recommended to help wounds heal more smoothly, was not effective. ''We were shocked,'' said Dr. Leslie S. Baumann, the director of cosmetic dermatology at the University of Miami School of Medicine, who conducted the research. ''We thought we had proven how great vitamin E was. Instead, it was obvious that it was worse than the placebo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOPHER, MARGARET A. (NEE GORMAN)
description: CHRISTOPHER-Margaret A. (nee Gorman). On June 6, 1999. Beloved wife of Patrick J. Loving daughter of the late Patrick and Ellen. Cherished mother of Patricia and Gerald. Dear sister of the late Mary Roeben, Joseph, and Helen Bross. Repossing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St. New York City, Tuesday & Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of of Christian Burial on Thursday 10AM, St. Veronica's R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Christian Brothers Auxiliary, Lincroft, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HAROLD
description: KRAMER-Harold. Of Clifton, NJ age 90, died in his home June 6, 1999. He was a successful businessman, humanitarian and philanthropist. Active in the construction industry all of his life, he was one of the founders and president of the Home Builders Assoc. of Northern NJ and elected into the NJ State Builders Hall of Fame. He served as deputy mayor of Passaic NJ and president of the Passaic Chamber of Commerce. He served on the board of trustees of Passaic Beth Israel Hospital and Temple Emanuel, Passaic. Along with his wife, he was a major contributor to the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Holocaust Museum, the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the Daughters of Miriam Center of the Aged and the Jewish Community Center in Clifton, NJ, Temple Emanuel in Passaic, NJ and Temple Emanu-el in Palm Beach, Fla., the Schepins Retina Eye Institute in Boston, Ma., the Passaic Beth Israel Hospital and the Morse Geriatric Center in West Palm Beach, Fla., the Simon Weisenthal Center in Los Angeles, Ca. He was a man of integrity, loved and respected by all who knew him. His philosophy was not loving what you get but loving what you give. He will live on in the hearts and memories of his family. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Adeline Feinberg Kramer; loving children George and Carole, Arthur and Nancy, and Frederick; adoring grandchildren Larry and Catherine, Andrew and Deborah, Alexander and Lori, Susan, Allison, Joshua, Jonathon and Oliver; and great-grandchildren Alexandra, Abigail, Hannah, and Isaiah; a sister, Nina Wolff. Services will be held Tuesday at 1:30 pm, the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ 973779-3048. Contributions may be made to Temple Emanuel, 181 Lafayette Ave., Passaic, NJ 07055

title: Not Every Problem Is Mental Illness; Appearances Can Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: China Seeks to Win Over Dissenters on Joining Trade Group
description: China's top trade official, acknowledging for the first time that many lower-level Chinese officials oppose the nation's proposed entry to the World Trade Organization, said in a newspaper report published today that the Government would begin a broad campaign to try to temper the internal discord.

title: Inquiry Grows As Rolls Fall For Medicaid
description: Concerned over the steep declines of the Medicaid rolls in New York, Federal officials are studying whether local governments across the state are improperly preventing the poor from signing up for health benefits under the program.

title: Learning From Rifles
description: To the Editor:

title: Welser-Most Will Lead Cleveland Orchestra
description: The Cleveland Orchestra announced yesterday that Franz Welser-Most would become its music director in 2002 on the departure of Christoph von Dohnanyi, who has held that position since 1984.

title: Fewer Viewers, More Commercials
description: What's the hottest phenomenon on television today? For the public, it might well be a hit show like ''Ally McBeal'' or ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' but for the broadcast networks, it is something more fleeting: those brief interludes known as commercial time.

title: Infidelity and Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Meredith Publishing Group, New York, a unit of the Meredith Corp., which publishes magazines like Better Homes & Gardens and The Ladies' Home Journal, to Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, New York, owned by top executives and Omnicom Group, to handle its branding account, which had been at Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Billings were estimated at less than $2 million.

title: Budget Passes, Focusing on the Young and the Old
description: The City Council yesterday unanimously approved a $35.3 billion budget that uses the city's record tax revenue to provide a number of modest tax cuts and includes substantial spending increases on services for children and the elderly.

title: Nassau Jail Ends Strip-Searches for Minor Offenses
description: Faced with an order from a Federal judge and a growing number of class action suits, the Nassau County jail has ended its practice of strip-searching people who are charged with misdemeanors and minor crimes, lawyers and jail officials have said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRALIA, MARIO L.
description: PETRALIA-Mario L. Passed away June 6, 1999. Loving partner of Richard Rodrigues, caring father of Joan and Paul, devoted grandfather of Ji and Chris. All mourn his passing. Reposing at the Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23rd Street, NYC Tuesday. Hours 2-5, 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection will be Wednesday, June 9 at 10:00 AM at The Church Of The Guardian Angel, 10th Ave at 21st St. Interment will follow in Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDELSON, FRANCES, NEE ANISH
description: JUDELSON-Frances, nee Anish. On June 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Mother of Robert and Larry. Devoted grandmother of Rebecca, Amanda, Jonathan, Adam, and Christopher. Funeral service Wednesday, 11:00 A.M., Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: BRAZIL-ARGENTINA SUMMIT
description: In an effort to rebuild confidence in the future of Mercosur, the South American customs union consisting of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, the Presidents of the bloc's two largest countries called for increased economic coordination among its members. In a meeting in Buenos Aires, Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Brazil's Fernando Henrique Cardoso agreed to put pressure on the European Union to ease restrictions on agricultural imports and to negotiate final details on Mercosur's automobile production. The two leaders also discussed mutual currency policy. Simon Romero

title: Tyco in Talks to Buy Fire-Extinguisher Maker
description: Tyco International Ltd., the world's largest maker of electronic-security and fire-detection systems, said today that it was in talks to buy Williams P.L.C. of London, the biggest maker of fire extinguishers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENKRANTZ, RENEE
description: BLUMENKRANTZ-Renee. Born in Belfast, Ireland. Wife of the late Harris Blumenkrantz. Devoted mother of David & the late Steven. Dear grandmother of Katie and Michael. Dedicated volunteer for Long Island Jewish Medical Center for 30 years. Donations may be made to Schneider's Children's Hospital, New Hyde Park, LI or Hadassah of Roslyn, 110 Poplar Drive, East Hills, New York.

title: Kosovo Refugees Cautious After Recent Seesaw on Peace
description: When he heard the news of a peace deal between NATO and the Yugoslav Government last week -- a deal that might send him back home after two months as a refugee -- Ismet Memaj reacted by celebrating.

title: The Dow Rises 109.54 Points as Merger News Continues
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, lifted by a brace of merger announcements and an apparent sense that any move by the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates would be a one-time event rather than part of a prolonged tightening of policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELBAUM, ROCHELE
description: ELBAUM-Rochele. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved sister of their devoted member, Harriet Kalischer and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Fellow Bouncer at Club
description: An off-duty Newark police officer working at a nightclub here early yesterday morning mistook a fellow bouncer's flashlight for a gun and shot him dead, officials said yesterday.

title: For Whitman, Move to Right May Be Sole Way to Move Up
description: It would seem easy to predict how Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, one of the nation's most prominent Republican moderates, would deal with a string of conservative proposals that may be headed her way in the next few months.

title: A Better CUNY or an Elitist One?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gonorrhea Vaccine Is Tested in Mice
description: Researchers working with mice have developed a vaccine for gonorrhea that is delivered through the nose and reduces vaginal colonization of gonorrhea bacteria. The findings were reported last week in Chicago at a conference of the American Society for Microbiology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I., COL.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I., Col. The Members of the Board of Directors of the New York Society for the Deaf mourn the passing of our dear friend and former President, Colonel Joseph I. Sonnenreich. His leadership, his wisdom and his commitment to service will be greatly missed by us all. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Rena and to his entire family. Stephen E. Adler, Chairman Paul L. Kohnstamm, President Pearl I. Johnson, Exec. Dir.

title: Judge Places Restrictions on Games in a Backyard Ball Field
description: A judge said today that the man who built a major-league baseball diamond in his backyard for his son must cut back on the number and types of games played on the field. But the judge stopped short of ordering the much sharper limits on play that neighbors and the town had sought.

title: Reviving Quest to Tame Energy of Stars
description: In its heyday it was a palace among physics laboratories, with an enviably fat budget, ample support staff and the prestige that comes to research institutions working at the cutting edge in solving global problems. But today, the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory, still a leader in hydrogen fusion research, is so short of cash that it can no longer afford even a receptionist.

title: Experts Ask Why So Few Take Drugs for M.S.
description: Four months ago, Valerie Millerick finally made a decision that she had been putting off for years: She began taking weekly injections of a drug called Avonex, to treat multiple sclerosis.

title: SCHOTTENSTEIN OFFERS BURNHAM PACIFIC $560 MILLION
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust that owns strip shopping centers, received a buyout offer from the retailer Jay Schottenstein for $560 million in cash, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offer is through Mr. Schottenstein's closely held real estate investment firm, the Schottenstein Stores Corporation, which would also refinance about $575 million of Burnham's debt. Mr. Schottenstein, the chairman of Value City Department Stores Inc., has accumulated an 8.2 percent stake in Burnham, which is based in San Diego, and is offering to buy its stock for $13 a share. Burnham shares rose $1.50, to $12.625.

title: 3 Firms Plan To Develop New System For Trading
description: In a deal indicating that even the largest Wall Street firms are unsure how or where stocks will be traded in the not so distant future, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that they had joined with Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, a large stock trading firm, to form Primex Trading N.A., an alternative stock trading system.

title: 'Blues' Protests a Cut in the Tony Show
description: The morning after the Tony Awards ceremonies, it wasn't the winners that theater professionals were talking about. It was the musical number from ''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues'' dropped from the CBS broadcast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUILTY, DAN
description: QUILTY-Dan. The entire NYU community mourns the passing of its beloved and esteemed longtime athletic director. His relationship with the University lasted some fifty years, beginning as a student who played on the highly regarded NYU basketball squads of the late 1940's and culminating in his long tenure as athletic director. He was a key developer of the University's current athletic facilities and programs, and he was an originator of the University Athletic Association, the league in which NYU now plays. He always worked to elicit achievement from his athletes, emphasizing scholarship ahead of athletics. He dedicated his professional life to this institution and its students, and his spirit, friendship and presence will be sorely missed. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman

title: The Issue of Free Speech, The Voice of Big Money
description: Bill Moyers begins ''Free Speech for Sale,'' tonight's vigorous assault on the power of moneyed interests in American politics, with the story of Cindy Watson, a Republican member of the North Carolina General Assembly who took on the state's hog farmers. When her constituents complained about the odors of hog waste and its effect on drinking water, she pushed for restrictions on the growth of hog farms, the state's biggest agricultural industry, until they cleaned up their act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, HELENE
description: DIAMOND-Helene, age 99, died Sunday, June 6, 1999, at the Jewish Home and Hospital, Bronx, NY. Interment Wednesday, 2 PM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a sense of elation and a sense that change has got to come. Before, everybody had to vote for the ruling party. Not any more.''

title: Boy Dies Three Days After Being Hit by Car
description: A 7-year-old boy who was struck by a hit-and-run driver on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx on Friday died yesterday at New York Presbyterian Hospital, the police said.

title: Harold S. Fawcett, 82, Navy Photographer
description: Harold S. Fawcett, a Navy photographer who captured memorable scenes of the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, died on Saturday at a hospital in Grafton, W. Va. He was 82 and lived in Bridgeport, W. Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, STANLEY E., M.D.
description: BRADLEY-Stanley E., M.D. Of Wynnewood, PA, on June 5, 1999, aged 86. Husband of Dr. Geraldine Bradley (nee Powell), father of Dr. Jane Alavi. Funeral service will be held Bringhurst Funeral Home, at West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, PA, Friday June 11th at 11 A.M. Memorial donations may be made to Bradley Fellowship, Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory, Salisbury Cove, ME. 04672.

title: SIGNS OF GRADUAL RECOVERY FOR BRAZIL
description: Brazil's industrial production fell in April, though the decline was less than expected. Industrial output fell three-tenths of 1 percent from the previous month. The Government figures are the most recent data illustrating a gradual economic recovery from the currency crisis earlier this year. In recent weeks, inflation has slowed, unemployment has declined slightly and overall economic growth has resumed. Simon Romero

title: Falls by Elderly, a Perilous Yet Preventable Epidemic
description: Tom tripped over an untied shoelace, fell into a closet that should have been closed and broke his arm when he landed on a shelf.

title: CLINTON WILL SEEK A MEDICARE CHANGE ON DRUG COVERAGE
description: President Clinton will soon propose revamping the Medicare program to offer prescription drug coverage to all beneficiaries, and he will contend that such coverage can actually save money for the Government by reducing the need for hospital stays and nursing home care, Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAX, JEREMIAH
description: TAX-Jeremiah. Died peacefully at home on June 5, 1999. He is mourned by his beloved children Judith and Nancy, Nina and Greg, Karen and Mark and his precious granddaughter Leslie and a large circle of family and friends. He was the former Executive Editor of Sports Illustrated Magazine and continued to serve as an editorial consultant until his death. Jerry was a devoted, caring and loyal friend. He will always be remembered for his generosity, humor, good will and countless acts of love and kindness. Memorial services will be held 10AM Tuesday, June 8 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Bigwigs Hobnob With Wild Ones

title: Consumer Borrowing Increased in April
description: Borrowing by consumers increased in April, led by auto loans and credit card debt, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Injection Of Cells Aids Mice
description: In a possible glimpse at the brain surgery of the future, biologists have partly cured mice of a disease resembling multiple sclerosis by injecting restorative cells into their brains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, KURT
description: FRIEDLANDER-Kurt. Of New York City & Westport, Connecticut, passed away at Mount Sinai Hospital, on Sunday, June 6th, from complications of pneumonia. Adored and adoring husband to Kay, wonderful and very loving father to Suzy, beloved brother and uncle to Ilse Thorner and Dr. Michael Thorner of Charlottesville, VA. In lieu of flowers, your contribution to charity would be appreciated. Interment private.

title: Travel Can Cause Pain and Injury : Protecting Your Back
description: THE HEALTHY TRAVELER

title: Funeral of Faith and Anger for a Police Shooting Victim
description: After a funeral combining expressions of faith and bitterness, the unarmed motorist killed in a barrage of police gunfire early Wednesday on Interstate 80 was buried here today, about a quarter mile from his home.

title: Awards Broadcast Falls in Ratings
description: Without a big musical or Rosie O'Donnell to attract viewers this year, the Tony Awards broadcast fell sharply in the Nielsen ratings.

title: Rod Stewart, Muse for a Country Girl
description: Country music's reigning royal couple took a weekend getaway to New York, where Tim McGraw played a relaxed surprise opening set before Faith Hill's headlining show at the Beacon Theater. ''That was my husband,'' Ms. Hill slyly gloated after Mr. McGraw departed. ''He looked so good up there, you almost didn't see me tonight!''

title: King Asserts Office Raid By F.B.I. Was Unnecessary
description: Three days after the F.B.I. raided his Deerfield Beach, Fla., offices searching for information that will link him to a racketeering investigation being conducted by the United States Attorney's office in Newark, the promoter Don King said that he would have gladly given authorities any information they wanted if they had subpoenaed it.

title: Lincoln Center Face Lift
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Take Hold of Game 4 and Don't Let Go
description: There was no faith healer in the figure of Larry Johnson to put his hands on a dire situation, to bring life to the Knicks and leave the crowd to exult, ''Hallelujah!''

title: Mullin Answers The Call In Style
description: He was supposed to be too old and too slow, a relic of a player who could give the Indiana Pacers nothing against the high-rising, fleet-footed Knicks. A 35-year-old former Olympic Dream Team member and five-time All-Star, Chris Mullin was said to have little value in this series. Why, some wondered, did Coach Larry Bird continue to start him?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADISON, ALBERT (BIG AL)
description: MADISON-Albert (Big Al). Suddenly on June 4, 1999. Beloved son of Bartlett and Willa Mae Madison and brother of Carolyn Madison Burke, Al is survived by his devoted nephew, Alan B. Burke, niece, Constance J. Burke, Alan's wife Sonya, Godson Earl Davis, Jr. and ''brothers'' Earl Davis, Sr., Bob Wilson, Jr., and Richard Jennings. Al will be sadly missed, but held in the hearts of all who loved him. Contributions may be made to the United Negro College Fund, 120 Wall St., 9 Fl, NYC, NY 10005. Private interment. Memorial services in NYC held at future date.

title: Citing Task Force Report, Giuliani Seems to Soften His Position on CUNY
description: Waving the report on the City University of New York published by his advisory task force, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested yesterday that he might be ready to move beyond tearing down the university to rebuild it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENG, TIN AN
description: CHENG-Tin An. On June 6th, 1999 at age 91. Beloved husband of Jundy Cheng. Loving father of Wanla Cheng, Anla Cheng Kingdon and Linna Cheng Ernst. Adored grandfather of Samuel, Jessica, Raphael and Jason. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, June 10th, 1:30 PM. Interment at St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, PEGGY
description: ISAACS-Peggy. The Board of Directors, staff and members of the Central Queens YM & YWHA record with deep sorrow the passing of Peggy Isaacs, wife of our esteemed benefactor and former president, the late Edward Isaacs. The Isaacs family's generosity has enabled generations of Jewish campers to attend our resident camp, Camp Edward Isaacs, which is honored to bear the family name. To her children, Jed Isaacs and Madeline Noveck, and their families, we extend our deepest sympathy. Craig Goodman, President Judith Friedman Rosen, Chairman of the Board Irving Shillman, Chairman, Camp Edward Isaacs Ethel Liebeskind, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, ROBERT S.
description: LINKER-Robert S. Just about the finest, most decent person we have ever known, Bob died Saturday in Florida, age 80, after a three month battle with bone cancer. Services at Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave. (Avenue L), Brooklyn, NY, Tuesday, June 8, at 10 AM. Our sincere condolences to Fran, Steve and Carrie, and the entire wonderful Linker family. Lawrence and Susan Kadish

title: Age Is No Obstacle as Mullin Answers Call
description: Chris Mullin was supposed to be too old and too slow, a relic of a player who could give the Indiana Pacers nothing against the high-rising, fleet-footed Knicks. Dale Davis, despite his perpetually hard-nosed play, was said to be too nice and in need of a killer instinct. Antonio Davis? Well, he was the one who fouled Larry Johnson on the improbable 4-point play that gave the Knicks the victory in Game 3.

title: Not Every Problem Is Mental Illness; Overlooking Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Time to Dream Again, NASA Says
description: The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has a message for the country's astronomers: stop hugging the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Sports of The Times; Rose's New Role Is Knicks' Problem
description: LARRY BIRD was surrounded by reporters yesterday morning. The buzz of the day was that Jeff Van Gundy, the Knicks' head coach, had scrapped a monthlong winning formula and elevated Latrell Sprewell to the starting lineup.

title: Ernie Wilkins, Jazz Saxophonist And Composer, Is Dead at 79
description: Ernie Wilkins, a jazz saxophonist and one of the important arrangers and composers for the Count Basie band of the 1950's, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Copenhagan. He was 79 and lived in Copenhagen.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL
