title: Brooklyn Man Is Arrested In '97 Hospital Robbery
description: A 28-year-old man was arrested yesterday in connection with the 1997 armed robbery of more than $260,000 from the payroll office of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, the police said.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Turbocharged Lizards

title: Electric Restraint's Use Stirs Charges of Cruelty to Inmates
description: Last June a Municipal Court judge in Long Beach, Calif., decided that a defendant, Ronnie Hawkins, was being disruptive at the defense table. The judge issued an order to a court officer, and, by remote control, Mr. Hawkins was zapped with 50,000 volts of electricity from a stun belt that guards had placed around his waist before he entered the courtroom.

title: When the Innocent Go to Jail, Society Must Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Painful Syndrome Found Among Athletes
description: For Jasmine Belanger, the mysterious leg pain started about a year and a half ago, after she had been running regularly for six months.

title: HYUNDAI OFFERING
description: Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest shipbuilder, said it would list shares on the Korea Stock Exchange in August. The offer should be worth at least 500 billion won ($422 million). It will help the company's parent, Hyundai Group, reduce debt and meet Government debt-reduction goals.

title: The Power of Love: Transformations Abound
description: 'Giselle'

title: Life's Assembly Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Bao Tong, the most senior Chinese official imprisoned during the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen democracy movement, misstated the title of Zhao Ziyang. He was general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, not President of China.

title: Foreign Affairs; Cochran and Kosovo
description: You don't need to be Clausewitz to figure out what finally brought Slobodan Milosevic to the negotiating table on NATO's terms and why he is now stalling again. The answer to both questions is Russia.

title: Channel-Surfing for Sound Bites From the Subway Series
description: If the Mets-Yankees series provided a battleground for bragging rights -- and how long will the Mets boast of bombing Roger Clemens on Sunday? -- it also offered a clash of commentary Friday night when Channel 5's Tim McCarver and Bobby Murcer and Fox Sports New York's Howie Rose and Fran Healy called the game. Here is an inning-by-inning analysis:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Merger Made In Heaven And Cheered On Wall Street
description: Now here's a deal that Wall Street really seems to like.

title: For Black Taxi Company in Miami, a County Law Is the Latest Threat
description: On a slow Sunday morning, with a warm rain drumming softly against the iron awnings of the last taxi company in Liberty City, Al Hooks and Charles Richardson stood on a sidewalk and counted off the men who were shot to death while driving for Society Cab.

title: Revered Serb Sees No Kosovo Peace
description: Dobrica Cosic, a former President of Yugoslavia and a figure revered among Serbian nationalists, says that any peace in Kosovo will be illusory, and that the reputation of the current President, Slobodan Milosevic, will suffer badly because of Serbia's defeat.

title: Urban Streets Carry Echo Of Africa
description: IF you want to know how New York City takes after an African village, stick around. It has nothing to do with Hillary Rodham Clinton's views on child-rearing.

title: The Problem With Diet Pills
description: To the Editor:

title: McCormick Plans Cuts, Largely in Britain
description: McCormick & Company Inc., the world's largest spice maker, said it would dismiss 300 workers and consolidate three British plants into two to free more money for new products and advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
description: FISHER-Zachary. The Board of Directors of the Police Athletic League mourn the loss of Zachary Fisher, a dear friend and outstanding human being whose magnificient generosity meant so much to the 65,000 boys and girls we serve. We extend our condolences to our fellow Director, Larry Fisher, who has been a long-time supporter of PAL, and to the members of the Fisher family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman of the Board Police Athletic League

title: Louis Guirandou-N'Diaye, 76, I.O.C. Aide
description: Louis Guirandou-N'Diaye, a member of the International Olympic Committee from the Ivory Coast in West Africa, who was censured for inappropriate behavior during the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, died Friday. He was 76.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the oversight body known as the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers misstated the surname of its interim president and chief executive. He is Michael M. Roberts, not Rogers.

title: For Cooler Climes, Head to . . . Houston?
description: An unseasonably miserable front of hot and humid weather enveloped the Northeast and Atlantic Seaboard yesterday, establishing single-day record high temperatures from Washington to Newark to Portland, Me., and making the region seem about as pleasant as a sponge bath inside a baking oven.

title: By Design; Better Than Vine Leaves
description: Hair doesn't always look its best after a day at the beach or pool, but it can be prettified with summery hair ornaments.

title: A Better CUNY or an Elitist One?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gloves Off as Dallas and Buffalo Open Tonight
description: On the eve of the Stanley Cup finals, the Dallas Stars and Buffalo Sabres exchanged psychological thrusts and parries today. The Sabres talked about how those Stars cheat on face-offs and how maybe the officials should be aware of it. The Stars mentioned that Buffalo goalie Dominik Hasek sometimes gets upset when he is bumped and how maybe he should worry about the Stars' bumping him -- legally, of course. And what about Mike Modano's comments about the finals being anticlimactic?

title: Yanks Come Up Short in Ninth, And Now Must Tackle Schilling
description: Sweat glistened on every face and arm at Veterans Stadium tonight, but the heat seemed to have a special effect on the Yankees. They played most of tonight's game as if they had been locked in a sauna for half the day, and they are in jeopardy of getting kicked in the teeth by the Phillies this week.

title: Casting a Ballot for New Freedoms
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Anne Miller, 90, First Patient Who Was Saved by Penicillin
description: Anne Sheafe Miller, who made medical history as the first patient ever saved by penicillin, died on May 27 in Salisbury, Conn. She was 90.

title: Imparting a Spirit of Discovery and Feeling the Pulse of Young Blood
description: Those who planned this season at Carnegie Hall could hardly have anticipated that a devastating run of traumas would lie at its center or that a sense of renewal would be so much needed now, at its end.

title: Belgium Is Castigated as Dioxin Scare Spreads
description: BRUSSELS  European Union health ministers vented anger Tuesday over Belgium's inability to give accurate information about a massive contamination of animal feed by the cancer-causing chemical dioxin, which is causing an increasing number of countries to turn back European farm goods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, WILLIAM J.
description: JOHNSON-William J. Sr. On June 7, 1999 of Massapequa, New York. Beloved husband of the late Helen (nee Lloyd). Loving father of Gerard, William, Virginia Kelleher, and the late Eugene. Also survived by nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Retired financial analyst, Citicorp, 1964 and Marine Midland, 1968. For further information please contact D'Andrea Bros F.H., Copiague, NY 516691-5700. Please omit flowers.

title: City's Water Supply Must Be Above Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Perfect Cut for the Grill
description: THERE may be no meat better for grilling than boneless leg of lamb. This is a cut that cooks reasonably quickly, usually in less than half an hour, but still develops an irresistibly crunchy crust. Even better, that crust can be flavored in minutes before it is cooked with any of a dozen combinations of seasonings. Marinating is unnecessary, as the meat itself has exquisite flavor and really needs no more than salt.

title: A Quarrel and a Mystery In Realistic African Heat
description: George Antheil's satirical one-act opera ''Venus in Africa'' is set in an outdoor hotel cafe in North Africa. And that's where the cast and audience must have felt they were when Encompass Music Theater gave the New York premiere of the work on a double-bill with Britten's dramatic cantata ''Phaedra.''

title: Lou Dobbs, 'Moneyline' Anchor, Quits CNN for His Own Web Site
description: Lou Dobbs, one of the most important executives and on-camera personalities for the Cable News Network, is leaving CNN to start his own Web site, CNN announced yesterday.

title: MICROSOFT AND INPRISE REACH $125 MILLION AGREEMENT
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had paid $125 million for a stake in the Inprise Corporation, the rights to use the software developer's technology and a settlement of longstanding patent and technology issues. The agreement between the two companies included a $25 million purchase by Microsoft of preferred stock in Inprise, which was formerly known as Borland International Inc. Microsoft, which did not disclose the issues that were being settled, said it had also paid Inprise $100 million to use Inprise-patented technology in its products. Shares of Inprise rose $1.125, to $5.125.

title: Asian-American Programs Are Flourishing at Colleges
description: The historian Evelyn Hu-DeHart sees a paradox for Asian-American college students: they are flocking to campuses in greater numbers, but see little of themselves in the curriculum.

title: For Acquitted Officers, Their Department and the City, Legal Action Is Far From Over
description: The verdicts issued yesterday involving four police officers in the Abner Louima brutality case did not end the legal proceedings against those acquitted in the trial or against the Police Department.

title: HONEYWELL IS IN DEAL FOR SECURITY-PRODUCTS COMPANY
description: Honeywell Inc., which had announced Monday that it would be bought by Allied Signal, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held C&K Systems for an undisclosed price to bolster its security-products division. C&K Systems, which makes sensors, control panels, radio-frequency operations and closed-circuit television systems, sells products in 61 countries through partners. The company, based in Folsom, Calif., has more than 1,700 employees worldwide.

title: THEATERS WILL ASK TO SEE PHOTO ID'S FOR R-RATED FILMS
description: Egged on by President Clinton, representatives of movie theater owners across the country announced today that they would begin requiring teen-agers to present photo identification cards when they showed up without an adult to see an R-rated film.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Notebook; A Limit on Honors
description: Since the 1970's, many universities have been faced with grade inflation. Harvard Law School has taken a small step to combat the problem.

title: Kosovo Battle Appears to Be Ending on NATO's Terms, U.S. Says : Allies and Russia Agree on UN Text
description: Western countries and Russia announced agreement Tuesday on the text of a United Nations Security Council resolution that American officials said would help end the Kosovo conflict on NATO's terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, SEAN
description: WADE-Sean. Native of County Mayo, Ireland. Peacefully died at home on Monday evening, June 7, 1999. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Rosaleen (nee O'Shea), his children, Rory, John and Ann Marie, and his five grandchildren whom he adored. He owned and managed Andy's Meat Market in Washington Hts. for over 25 years where the friendship, jokes and love were gratis. Mass Thursday, 11AM, St. Anthony's Church, Northvale, NJ. Visiting Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Pizzi Funeral Home, 120 Paris Ave., Northvale. 201-767-3050.

title: Coroner Says 9-Year-Old Boy Died of Neglect
description: The Medical Examiner has ruled that a 9-year-old Queens boy who died last month after his appendix ruptured was the victim of neglect, and officials are weighing whether to charge his parents in the death, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Independence For Kosovo
description: If war is the continuation of policy by other means, then it helps to know what the policy is and whether it makes sense. Most of the debate about Kosovo until last week concentrated on military and moral issues -- the need for ground troops, the justifiability of bombing, and so on. Even during the now stalled peace talks, questions about the long-term political future of Kosovo have received little attention. Yet these are the most important questions of all.

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: All the Comforts of Home, Plus Waiters
description: I WAS sitting on a plush velvet sofa, a low oval coffee table before me, in a room with a low ceiling and dim random lighting. It was no different from a living room, a very nice living room, where I would have been happy just to sit and relax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUSTAV, MORRIS
description: GUSTAV-Morris. Ninety years old, died at home on June 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Spence Gustav and Bonnie Gustav Golub, and father-in-law of Dr. Sheldon Golub. Beloved grandfather of Justin, Nathaniel & Beryn. Dear brother of Gertrude and brother-in-law of Emanuel, Aaron & Marilyn Lubin. Graveside services, 10:30 A.M. on Friday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey.

title: Minnesota's Governor To Serve a Full Term
description: When Jesse Ventura, running as the Reform Party candidate, was elected Governor of Minnesota last year, he gave the party a needed lift. Not since its founder, Ross Perot, finished a surprising strong third in the 1992 Presidential race had any of its candidates enjoyed such success.

title: China Has Reservations About 2 Provisions of Peace Plan
description: Asserting that the United Nations Security Council is not a ''rubber stamp,'' China's representative here made clear today that Beijing has serious reservations about the peace plan for ending the Kosovo conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESHOVER, PHYLLIS
description: MESHOVER-Phyllis. On June 7, 1999. Of Bridgewater, CT. Beloved wife of Michael Steiner, devoted mother of Isabel, loving daughter of George and Pearl. Services Wednesday, 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: In a Cozy Cabin Amid the Shooting Stars
description: THE Fisher Island oysters, a local product, come wrapped in a buttermilk batter,'' the waiter intones. ''When you bite into one, the briny flavor simply explodes on your palate.'' Goodness me. And the scallops? ''They are harvested by divers,'' the waiter says. ''Most scallops are machine-harvested, which traumatizes them.''

title: Study Shows Importance of Preschool and Child-Care Quality in Education
description: A national study that has been tracking the educational progress of young children for four years has found, not unexpectedly, that those with higher-quality preschool classes did better in language and math skills than those in low-quality preschools. But as the children moved into the second grade, the report said, ''the difference between the language skills of children in high- and low-quality care decreased.''

title: Officer Is Guilty in Torture of Louima
description: One police officer was convicted yesterday of joining in the torture of Abner Louima in a Brooklyn station house, but three others were acquitted in the case, which turned the plight of a Haitian immigrant into a national symbol of police brutality.

title: Videotapes Said to Show Assaults on Students
description: Videotapes that are said to show a 60-year-old piano teacher sexually assaulting some of the children who came to his Teaneck home for piano lessons were found in a weekend search of the man's house, investigators familiar with the case said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Jockeying for Position In First 2000 Contests
description: The new war between the states -- the competition to schedule the first Election 2000 primary or caucus -- is escalating.

title: Think of It as $37,500 a Quarter
description: The New York Knicks recently raised the price of a regular-season front-row seat at Madison Square Garden to $1,500 a game. This, of course, is outrageous. The price is much too low.

title: The Accord's Blank Spaces
description: European foreign ministers and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pronounced themselves well satisfied today after haggling for 12 hours over the draft of a United Nations Security Council resolution on Kosovo.

title: In Protest, Senator Blocks All Nominations
description: All civilian Presidential nominations before the Senate were blocked indefinitely today by a conservative Republican senator in protest of President Clinton's decision to name a gay philanthropist as an ambassador without Senate confirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWIEBEL, ISIDOR
description: ZWIEBEL-Isidor. Beloved husband of the late Rose Zwiebel. Beloved father and father-in-law of Ann and D. Bernard Hoenig and Marilyn and Gideon Ferber. Beloved brother, grandfather and great grandfather. Funeral today, 12:30PM at Boulevard Chapels, Hewlett, New York.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS
description: When the Serbian Parliament voted on an international peace proposal last Thursday, it omitted one footnote on NATO's participation in the security force that would enter Kosovo, while approving the rest of the proposal. The footnote is also missing from the Security Council resolution drafted today in Germany. Following is the footnote from last week's proposal:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKUN, ABRAHAM
description: OKUN-Abraham. Of Delray Beach, Florida, formerly of Teaneck, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Devoted father of William and his wife Alane and Stephanie Podvesker. Brother of Hyman. Grandfather of Howie, Michael, Jennifer, Hughie, Amy, Lori and Richie. Devoted companion of the late Lucy Toplansky; he had a loving relationship with Lucy's daughter Renee Hoffman and Lucy's grandson Michael. Graveside service 11AM Thursday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation. ''He will live on in the hearts and memories of his family forever.''

title: SODA DEAL IS BLOCKED
description: In the latest blow to the Coca-Cola Company's proposed $1.1 billion purchase of soft- drink brands from Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., maker of Dr Pepper and Crush, Australian regulators denied approval of a revised plan that also involved the sale of some local Coke brands to Cadbury. Regulatory resistance has caused many European countries to be dropped from the deal, which does have approval in Britain.

title: Beat Officers Hope Verdicts Close an Ugly Chapter
description: For the New York City police officers who walk beats and patrol in radio cars, there was some hope yesterday that the verdicts in the Abner Louima brutality trial would mark the beginning of the end of what many described as one of the ugliest episodes in the Police Department's history.

title: Fugitive Mexican Tells of Huge Payment to Ruling Party
description: For years, the governing party in Mexico has tried to keep its finances cloaked in secrecy. Industrialists who have profited from Government contracts and insider dealings have donated huge sums to underwrite the party's 70-year domination of Mexican politics.

title: Clinton's Nominees Face a Senate Block
description: Accusing President Clinton of a ''flagrant abuse of the recess appointment power'' for naming a gay philanthropist Ambassador to Luxembourg without Senate confirmation last week, a conservative Republican Senator vowed to block all civilian nominations now before the body.

title: Both Sides Endorse Bush in Louisiana
description: Whatever date Louisiana Republicans finally choose for their Presidential caucuses next spring, maybe they should let Democrats join once the caucusing starts. Consider:

title: After 'Go,' Moby Went
description: The year was 1991, and American youth had just begun to wake up to the electronic dance music -- techno -- that the British had appropriated from the Chicago and Detroit club scenes. Though the New York disk jockey Moby was far from the nation's first techno musician, he was its first great hope.

title: City's Water Supply Must Be Above Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: At Site of the Serbs' Identity, Fears Over Albanians' Wrath
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Calm Election Spurs a Rally In Indonesia
description: A day after Indonesia held its first democratic elections in four decades, the joyful clamor of voters gave way to a resounding rumble of approval from the financial markets.

title: Team Adds 2 Elusive Elements to the Periodic Table
description: In a discovery that came as a complete surprise to most nuclear chemists, an international team of scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California has added two new elements to the periodic table.

title: California Olive Oil: Promising, but Pricey
description: AS the waiter at Babbo in Greenwich Village set a plate of sea bass before us, he offered a little extra olive oil, crisscrossing the fillets with a thin and aromatic stream of greenish gold. When I asked what oil this very Italian restaurant was pouring, the waiter replied, ''Our house oil is DaVero, from California.''

title: Mattiace and Zoeller Lead 7 Into Event
description: Len Mattiace, a regular on the PGA Tour, tore up the Canoe Brook South Course in Summit, N.J., with a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to lead seven qualifiers in the field of 81 for next week's United States Open. Mattiace's 65 came after a 73 in the morning on the North Course as he finished at 138.

title: Authentically Basque
description: PIPERADE is a quintessential Basque dish that combines the signature ingredients: tomatoes, onion, garlic, chilies, and controversy,'' reads the headnote to a recipe in Gerald Hirigoyen's book, ''The Basque Kitchen'' (HarperCollins, $35).

title: Half-Measures for Poor Nations
description: In 1996 the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund began a program that was supposed to help the world's poorest nations escape their debt traps. Dozens of nations spend up to 60 percent of their budgets for interest on foreign debt that will never be retired -- leaving little for the basic health care and education needed to reduce poverty. But the debt reduction program has been too stingy. This month the world's richest countries will decide how much to increase it. The proposals offered fall far short of real relief.

title: Overtures From Iran Ignite a Bitter Debate Among Arab States
description: After years united by worries about Iran, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have become embroiled in a bitter dispute over the idea of reconciliation with Teheran.

title: Citywide Reading and Math Test Scores Decline Sharply
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew released citywide reading and math test scores yesterday that showed a sharp decline from a year ago.

title: Aided by NATO Bombing, Rebels Position Themselves to Become Kosovo's New Army
description: When the separatist rebels of the Kosovo Liberation Army mounted what they called a major offensive near here two weeks ago, the strategy was basic: to open a supply corridor from Albania into Kosovo and to cut off a highway so that Yugoslav troops could not move between two major cities in southern Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, GRACE
description: CAMPBELL-Grace, 84. Passed away on June 6, 1999, after a long illness. We mourn the passing of our beloved aunt. Calling hours will be held on June 9th, 1999, 3-6 P.M. at Scarr Funeral Home, Suffern, NY. Funeral Mass, June 10, 1999, 11 A.M. at The Church of the Sacred Heart, Suffern, New York.

title: Isringhausen Triumphs For First Time Since '97
description: When the Mets raved about Jason Isringhausen four years ago, it was because they believed he would be a reliable starter for them for the next decade. When the Mets talked about the pitcher during the last three years, it was usually because they were giving injury updates. So when the Mets discuss Isringhausen these days, they do it very cautiously.

title: Knoblauch's World Turned Upside Down
description: Chuck Knoblauch arrived at the visitors' clubhouse and glanced at the Yankees' lineup, posted on a wall. What he saw stopped him.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about software that can prevent ''banner'' ads from being displayed with Web pages, referred incorrectly to limits imposed by some sites on such ads. Yahoo, America Online and many other site operators have restricted the file size -- not memory size -- for banners on their sites.

title: Kosovo Obligations Remain Unfulfilled
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. July 2, 1920June 8, 1999. Formerly of Great Neck, resided Boynton Beach. W.W. II veteran with the 511 Engineers European Campaign. Founder of Lisbeth Fabrics and active in the garment industry for thirty years. Past president Cold Spring Country Club. He will always be remembered for his generosity, friendship and wonderful sense of humor. As patriarch of a large family he will forever be loved by all. He is survived by his loving wife, Millicent, three sons, Martin (Sara), Robert (Lynn), Brad (Carol) and four grandchildren. Funeral will be held in Tamarac, Florida.

title: THE CHEF
description: I'VE named this salad after those crocks of marinated green beans, garbanzo and kidney beans in every American salad bar. But my three-bean salad is really something entirely different, a simple composition of dried beans and fresh beans: a base of pureed white beans is infused with truffle oil, topped with a mixture of fresh beans in a vinaigrette and finished with field greens or fresh herbs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RALLIES. The euro rose against the dollar after a larger-than-expected increase in growth in Germany suggested that the nation's economy might be rebounding. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0458, up from $1.0286.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRULOVIC, HELEN
description: STRULOVIC-Helen. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its longtime member and extends its heartfelt condolences to her husband, daughter and the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Dale Polakoff Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Howard J. Wolf, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREPEL, RUTH
description: TREPEL-Ruth nee Parkoff, after a full life. Beloved wife of Arnold, mother of Gene and Alan Brody, grandmother of Jessica Nagy, Leslie Brody, Lise Brody, Dylan Brody; great-grandmother of Summer, Devon, Lee, Alex, Jocelyn. All of us and many others will miss her greatly. Graveside service, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Long Island, at 11 A.M. Sunday.

title: Fighting Sprawl, Oregon County Makes Deal With Intel to Limit Job Growth
description: When county officials sat down with the Intel Corporation to develop a package of tax incentives that would keep the state's largest private employer here, the two sides struck a deal that had some fairly standard provisions. Intel would invest up to $12.5 billion in new equipment and plant upgrades over the next 15 years, and the county would grant $200 million in property tax breaks.

title: Kosovo Obligations Remain Unfulfilled; Don't Isolate Serbia
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprewell Fits Company's Image
description: Inside the company that markets Latrell Sprewell as ''The American Dream,'' sneakers are strewn on stained carpeting, jammed against walls and hung from cork boards. The top executives wear baggy shorts, T-shirts and sneakers, speak in street lingo and try to get in a daily run of hoops.

title: Even After Volpe's Guilty Plea, Jurors Doubted Louima's Word Alone
description: Two weeks ago, when Officer Justin A. Volpe pleaded guilty to plunging a stick into Abner Louima's rectum, prosecutors believed they had been given what they needed to convict other New York police officers accused of violating Mr. Louima's civil rights.

title: Asian Airline Has to Cancel More Flights
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. grounded more than half its flights today in an increasingly bitter dispute with pilots who have been calling in sick over a looming deadline to accept pay cuts at the big Asian airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDNER, DAVID
description: SEIDNER-David. The Board, Staff and Volunteers of the Community Research Initiative on AIDS (CRIA) mourn the passing of our friend, advocate and Board Member, David Seidner. One of the earliest champions of CRIA's efforts to find new AIDS treatments, David's innate scientific curiosity and strong sense of urgency could always be counted on to make critical contributions to our research program. He lent both his time, talent, and boundless creativity to numerous CRIA fundraising efforts. David's keen eye for perfection, forthright honesty and zeal for living will be sorely missed in our lives and in our work. Ross Bleckner, President J Daniel Stricker, Exec. Dir.

title: 3 Safety Features Absent At Airport in Little Rock
description: Whatever error or malfunction may have caused the crash of an American Airlines flight last week in Little Rock, Ark., an unlucky series of circumstances may have made the outcome worse.

title: Chefs Join a Drug Company Promotion
description: IN a new twist in celebrity endorsements, some well-known New York chefs have teamed up with a pharmaceutical company to promote a low-fat diet that is part of the company's campaign for a new anti-obesity drug.

title: Panasonic in Deal to Make Digital Recorders for Replay
description: Replay Networks, one of two makers of digital video recorders, has signed an agreement with the Panasonic Consumer Electronics Company to make its new systems, the companies announced yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Fresh Look At A Syntax Skewer
description: On a blinding hot day in 1908, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas climbed a hill above the Italian town of Fiesole, where both were spending the summer. There was tension in the air, a powerful attraction; there were unanswered questions. Stopping in the heat, the two had a conversation. In the onrush of feelings, in the way of people newly in love who want to make a clean break from the past, they told each other about the people they had loved before.

title: Microsoft-Sprint Deal on Data System
description: The Microsoft Corporation is working with the Sprint Corporation to combine phone and data services on a single computer for small businesses, Microsoft announced.

title: PLUS: TENNIS -- SENIORS; McEnroes Ousted
description: When John McEnroe was in his prime, his older brother, Mark, would hear tennis analysts talk about how John and anybody are the best doubles team in the world.

title: Budget Rift Grows Wider As Legislators Trade Insults
description: On a day when New York's budget became the third latest in history, the Capitol's power players reinforced today how far they are from an accord, digging in their positions, heading off in divergent directions and insulting one another.

title: BRAZIL RATE CUT
description: Brazil cut interest rates for the eighth time in three months to help stoke a slow-going economic recovery. The central bank reduced its main overnight lending rate to 22 percent from 23.5 percent in a move that many investors had been expecting. While further rate cuts are expected to take the key rate below 20 percent soon, concern is growing over the effect of the reductions. The real, Brazil's currency, has weakened in recent weeks as foreign investors have reduced holdings of Government securities. Today, the real fell a half percent, to 1.75 to the dollar, its lowest level since March. Simon Romero

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Sees Evidence of a Serbian Pullback
description: NATO has seen signs that the Yugoslav military is preparing to withdraw at least some of its 40,000 troops from Kosovo, the Pentagon said today.

title: ANALYST FORECASTS LOSS OF 10 CENTS A SHARE FOR COMPAQ
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has too many personal computers in its inventory and will have to write down the value of the machines, which could lead to a loss in the second quarter, an analyst said yesterday. Compaq has four weeks of inventory with distributors and four weeks in its own warehouses, said Ashok Kumar, an analyst at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray. He said the loss could be more than 10 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had forecast that Compaq would earn 22 cents in the period. Mr. Kumar's current estimate is for a profit of 3 cents. Shares in the Houston-based Compaq fell 93.75 cents, to $22.9375. Jim Finlaw, a Compaq spokesman, said, ''We have provided no statements or guidance on earnings or inventory,'' but the company declined further comment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Alexander Treks Uphill In Faltering Campaign
description: The last time he ran for President, Lamar Alexander saw no need to parade before voters his membership in the elite fellowship of Eagle Scouts. To any son of the modest, contented town of Maryville, in the hills of eastern Tennessee, it would have been a vainglorious declaration, made creaky by the rustle of ancient merit badges.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Wall Street Bonanza: Free Chocolate With Coffee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, MBE, IRA DAN
description: KAYE-MBE, Ira Dan. Ira, we loved you and will miss you. Stuart, Sandra, Alison, Eric, David and Tali Roth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: In Vouvray, A New Vibrancy
description: The last time I was here, 14 years ago, the railroad was planning to run its new high-speed train through the town's vineyards. The winemakers were up in arms, and one of them, Gaston Huet, explained it all to me over a bottle of his 1947 Vouvray, an unforgettable wine the color of burnished gold.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS AGREES TO SWEETENED SARA LEE OFFER
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to a sweetened takeover offer of $238 million in stock from the Sara Lee Corporation, ending a seven-week standoff. The deal, worth $11 a share for Chock Full o' Nuts shareholders, came seven weeks after Chock Full o' Nuts had rejected Sara Lee's initial offer of $225 million, or $10.50 a share. Sara Lee, which is based in Chicago and makes food and consumer products, would add the nation's fourth-largest coffee roaster with the acquisition. Sara Lee already makes Continental and Gold Coast coffees. Chock Full o' Nuts shares fell 12.50 cents, to $10.625, and Sara Lee rose 31.25 cents, to $24.875.

title: Commercial Real Estate; National Company Tries Out New York
description: By many measures, the Trammell Crow Company is among the largest real estate-services companies in the country. But it has been conspicuously absent from New York, the nation's largest market.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sips column of the Dining section on May 19 about Knappogue Castle Single Malt, an Irish whisky now being marketed by an American, referred incorrectly to the 1990 vintage. It is still available.

title: A Neighborhood Identity Crisis; Transformation Brings Anxiety in Brooklyn's Dumbo
description: Sometimes, the walls can talk.

title: U.N. Resolution on Kosovo: Establishing the Principles of a Political Solution
description: Following are excerpts from the draft of the United Nations resolution on Kosovo, as provided by The Associated Press:

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: Macarchuk Is Leaving the Fordham Program
description: Stony Brook University on Long Island has size (30,000 students) and prestige.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREEMAN, RALPH LEWIS
description: FREEMAN-Ralph Lewis. 4/25/196/9/96. Beloved Dad, Grandpa. We miss your love of the sea, thirst for knowledge and great conversations. Love, Cindy, Paul, Ali, David

title: Wellpoint Added to Index
description: Shares of Wellpoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, rose yesterday after an announcement that its shares would be included in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index after the close of trading yesterday. The shares rose $2.6875, to $86.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company will replace Harnischfeger Industries, the world's biggest mining-equipment maker, in the index. Harnischfeger filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday. Companies' shares often rise when they are added to the S.& P. 500 because many mutual funds that try to mimic the performance of the index must buy the shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKEY, ROGER ANDREW
description: HICKEY-Roger Andrew, Jr. Of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, died June 6. Ladenburg Thalmann employed him from 1965 until his retirement in 1990. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Lloyd, whom he married in 1952; son, Mark and wife, AnnMarie with children Christina and Laura; son Laurence and wife, Honorable Nancy Smith and children, Conor and Margaret; brother, John F. Hickey of CO.; sister, Ann Sollas of Bay Head, N.J., and numerous nieces and nephews.

title: Ambitious Plan to Rebuild Staten Island Ferry Hub
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected today to announce an $81 million project to rebuild the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry as a sleek new transportation hub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUER, IRVING
description: MAUER-Irving, MD. Practiced orthopedic surgery for fifty years in Queens and was on the staff of the Orthopedic Institute and Parkway Hospital. He organized physicians to volunteer their services at Hadassah Hospital in Israel from 1964 to 1973. Many of these physicians including Dr. Mauer came to Israel during the 1973 Yom Kippur War to operate on wounded Israeli soldiers. He also worked in Indonesia under the auspices of C.A.R.E. teaching orthopedic surgery to Indonesian doctors. He was a NYC police surgeon since 1968. He is survived by his wife, Annette, daughters, Eve Morrow and Judy Mauer, sons-in-law, Dr. Richard Morrow and Ilya Slovesnik, two grandchildren, Rebecca and Jack Morrow, brother, Leonard Mauer and sister, Constance Lazarus. Funeral will be Wednesday, June 9, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, New York at 1:30PM.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about Indonesian voters in the fishing village of Dadap located the site incorrectly. It is west of Jakarta, not east.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile last Wednesday about Candace K. Beinecke, a partner with the Manhattan law firm of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, referred imprecisely to the precedent set by her appointment to head the firm. Another sizable firm in New York, Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, was managed from 1990 to 1997 by a woman, Antonia Grumbach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFGOT, SALOMON D.
description: HELFGOT-Salomon D. Beloved husband of Rosa Perla Resnick Helfgot. Devoted father of Dalia Hay, Ruben and Nathaniel. Service 10AM on Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MOSCOW AND WEST AGREE ON KOSOVO; PLAN GIVEN TO U.N.
description: An end to the war in Kosovo crept closer today with agreement among the United States, six allies and Russia on a plan to send peacekeepers into the shattered Yugoslav province, perhaps in a week.

title: Ball Hits Stottlemyre in Head
description: Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach, was hit on the head by a line drive during batting practice and suffered a deep cut above his right eye. Stottlemyre, 57, was taken to an area hospital, where he received 11 stitches and tests. A doctor who saw Stottlemyre at Veterans Stadium said he did not think the coach had any serious injuries.

title: Kosovo Obligations Remain Unfulfilled; More Weak Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: CANADIAN RESTAURANT DEAL
description: Canada's largest franchisee of KFC restaurants, Scott's Restaurants Inc., agreed to sell itself for $247 million (Canadian) or about $168 million (United States) to a private company controlled by John Bitove, a Toronto businessman whose family has extensive food service operations. KFC outlets are part of Tricon Global Restaurants. Mr. Bitove has been active recently in sports. He helped found the Toronto Raptors professional basketball franchise and he is chief executive of Toronto's bid for the 2008 Olympic Games. Scott's has 345 KFC outlets, and 50 other restaurants operating under the names Wendy's, Tim Horton's and Mr. Sub. Scotts shares gained 6.9 percent, to $9.25 (Canadian), or $6.29 (United States), on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Timothy Pritchard

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I hope what comes out of my case is change. What happened to me should not happen to any human being, to my children or anybody else's children.''

title: Choice of a Successor to Yellen Is Called Near at White House
description: White House officials said today that President Clinton would most likely nominate Martin Baily, a partner at McKinsey & Company, to succeed Janet L. Yellen later this year as head of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Tastes of India: Expect a Surprise Instead of a Curry
description: TIFFIN, an Indian restaurant named for the vegetarian snacks of south India, opened six weeks ago on a nondescript block in the shadow of the World Trade Center. Perhaps it's the lightly traveled locale, but on three recent visits the dining room was almost empty.

title: Myron Weiner, 68, Expert on Child Labor in Developing Lands
description: Myron Weiner, a political scientist whose studies of migration, ethnic conflicts and child labor in the developing world reflected moral purposes and influenced practical policy, died last Thursday at his home in Moretown, Vt. He was 68.

title: Sabres Stun the Stars On a Goal by Wooley
description: Ed Belfour, the Dallas goalie, goes by the nickname the Eagle, and he wears the image of the bird on his head gear. Dominik Hasek, the Buffalo goalie known as the Dominator, wears an old-fashioned mask often called a ''bird cage.'' This aviary rivalry goes back a decade, and Hasek flew highest tonight in the opening game of the Stanley Cup finals as his Sabres stunned the Stars, 3-2, in overtime at Reunion Arena.

title: Smoking: From Divine To Disgusting
description: ''Coughs due to smoking disappear! Parched throat clears up! That stale, smoked-out feeling vanishes!'' Those claims for a miracle cure can be found in ''The Last Cigarette,'' a witty but deliberately choke-inducing documentary by Kevin Rafferty and Frank Keraudren about the mystique of smoking in America. The real miracle turns out to be somewhat different: those claims were once used to promote even more smoking, with the promise that ''when you change to Philip Morris you'll feel better.'' And that the glamour of the cigarette habit has been so successfully manufactured for so long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLEM, LEATRICE
description: OLEM-Leatrice. Loving wife of Oscar, devoted mother of Alan and Nancy (Lee) Feldman, sister of Natalie Weinstein and devoted aunt. Funeral services Thursday, 11:30 AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, NY. Donations may be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society or the American Diabetes Association.

title: Faulted Hospital Closes
description: On April 21, a few hours before Ed Bradley's hourlong special report on abuses of children in the nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals was to be broadcast on CBS News's ''60 Minutes II,'' the chain sought a restraining order to block CBS from showing the report. A judge denied the request on the spot.

title: Remedial Help Urged for 4th Graders Who Failed English Test
description: New York State's Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, released a proposal today that would require school districts to provide remedial instruction to all fourth graders who failed the new English test given in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN MURRAY
description: GALLAGHER-John Murray. On June 8, 1999, of Danbury, CT. Beloved brother of Eileen Poczatek, Michael Gallagher, Maureen Gibbons, Maraline Murphy, Joan Murphy, Nannette Meyers and Regina Adams. Dear uncle of forty-five nieces and nephews; fortyone survive. Also survived by forty-two great nieces and nephews. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY today 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Thursday, 10 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment, Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers friends may make contributions to Dathr Rehabilitation Institute (Loving Tribute), 135 Old State Road, P.O. Box 5189, Brookfield, CT. 06804.

title: Business Travel; US Airways is requiring passengers to board at least 10 minutes before scheduled departures.
description: LAST-MINUTE passengers on US Airways risk being left at the gate as the carrier has begun to follow the industry standard of requiring that they board planes at least 10 minutes before scheduled departures. The reason, the airline said, is that customers expect and deserve dependability, and on-time departures are necessary for achieving that result.

title: INSIDE
description: Reassurance on Estrogen

title: Rising Long-Term Interest Rates Dampen Stocks
description: Long-term interest rates hit 6 percent for the first time in more than a year yesterday after two Federal Reserve officials made comments that suggested the central bank would raise interest rates at the end of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIGSBERG, NATALIE
description: KONIGSBERG-Natalie. On June 8. Beloved wife of the late Stanley. Loving mother of Fran (Martin) Harris; Don (Jane) Konigsberg; Robert (Rosalind) Konigsberg. Adored grandmother of nine, cherished great-grandmother of six. A wonderful, caring woman whose enthusiasm, kindness, warmth and sense of humor touched all who knew her. Services on Thursday 1:00PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Louima Verdicts
description: The United States Attorney, Zachary Carter, said it best yesterday as he stood outside the Brooklyn Federal Courthouse and assessed the latest verdicts in the Abner Louima case. The most important lesson New York police should learn from the Louima trial, he said, is that their ''worst betrayal'' is not testifying against a fellow officer. It is betraying their oath of office out of ''a false loyalty'' to colleagues.

title: Prescription Mix-Ups
description: To the Editor:

title: Averting Strike, Lay Teachers Agree to Archdiocese Contract
description: Lay teachers at 11 high schools run by the Archdiocese of New York agreed to a new contract last night that grants them a 10 percent raise over three years and averts a threatened strike.

title: Lucent Planning More Takeovers
description: Richard McGinn, the chairman and chief executive of Lucent Technologies Inc., said today that Lucent, the maker of phone equipment, plans to make more acquisitions after completion in two weeks of its $24.2 billion purchase of the Ascend Communications Corporation.

title: David Seidner, Fashion Photographer, Is Dead at 42
description: David Seidner, a photographer known for his highly stylized fashion shots inspired by moments in art history, died on Sunday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 42.

title: REGULATORS IN EUROPE DELAY INITIAL RULING ON EXXON DEAL
description: European Union regulators said yesterday that they would delay their initial ruling on the Exxon Corporation's planned $88.7 billion takeover of the Mobil Corporation by up to two weeks as they decide whether to let British authorities review the terms of the purchase. European Union officials have said they are likely to start an in-depth inquiry into the purchase when they make their initial ruling, pushing a final decision back to mid-October. They began reviewing the purchase on April 30. In addition to Europe's approval, the merger also needs clearance from the United States Federal Trade Commission.

title: Man Dies After Leaping In Front of Subway Train
description: A 44-year-old man was killed instantly yesterday when he jumped in front of an L train as it pulled into the Bedford Avenue station in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, police and transit officials said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Washington Lawyer Faces S.E.C. Charges
description: Even as the markets have soared in the last few years, most sophisticated investors have enough wits to beware of anyone who promises to double their money within two weeks in risk-free investments in a secretive global trading market backed by the Treasury.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN BUILDER IN TROUBLE
description: One of Mexico's largest construction companies, Bufete Industrial S.A., said it would lay off 15 percent of its workers as a $100 million bond payment looms. The company's shares fell 22.5 percent in reaction. Analysts said Bufete, a company closely connected to the petroleum industry, faces an uphill struggle to avoid defaulting on the bond payment, which is due July 15. Like Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A. de C.V., a large steel company that defaulted on two debt payments in April, the cash-short Bufete has had little access to credit. Rick Wills

title: Our Towns; Grandmother With Babies On the Move
description: EVERY workday morning, three small yellow buses crisscross the patchwork of fields, woods and villages around Ulster County, stopping at farms to pick up dozens of infants and young children whose parents plant and harvest corn, asparagus and other crops.

title: At Last, Japan Gets the Pill. Is This Good News?
description: More than 35 years after the birth control pill was introduced in the United States and other Western countries, an advisory council to Japan's Ministry of Health and Welfare finally decided in early June that it was safe enough for Japanese women to use. Japanese couples currently rely on condoms, the rhythm method and abortion (which is nonetheless frowned upon by both Buddhism and Shinto) to avoid unwanted pregnancies.

title: Five Win Japanese Arts Prize
description: The German painter Anselm Kiefer, the American sculptor Louise Bourgeois, the Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, the Canadian-born jazz pianist Oscar Peterson and the German director and choreographer Pina Bausch are the recipients of the 11th Praemium Imperiale Awards, presented by the Japan Art Association for outstanding achievement in the arts. The recipients are to be announced by Shigeaki Hazami, chairman of the award's executive committee, at a ceremony this morning at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Flatbush Immigrants Call Result Neither Outrage Nor Triumph
description: When the Oprah Winfrey show was interrupted by a news bulletin announcing the verdict in the Abner Louima trial, Charmaine Dreckette took a quick break from washing a customer's hair in the back of St. Cecile's Unisex Salon on Church Avenue in Brooklyn and turned up the volume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone, Rev. Canon, D.D. Age 76, of Southport, CT, former editor of The Living Church Magazine, and a revisor of the Episcopal Church's present Book of Common Prayer, husband of Violet Monser Porter, died on Saturday, June 5, 1999. Burial Service will be held Friday, June 11, 1999, at 11:00 AM in Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Living Church Magazine, 816 East Juneau Avenue, Milwaukee, WI 53202.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, IRVING L.
description: FISHER-Irving L., Dr. The executives and staff of Allied Office Supplies wish to express our deepest sympathy on the passing of Dr. Irving L. Fisher, the father of Kenneth M. Fisher. We wish to extend our heartfelt condolences to Ken and his entire family. Howard L. Brown and Staff

title: Moscow Envoy's Peace Efforts, Praised in West, Are Panned at Home
description: When Russia's special envoy, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, went to Belgrade last week with the President of Finland to help resolve the Kosovo conflict, he was seen in the West as a heroic statesman.

title: Jumping the Gun for Tomatoes
description: ANYONE who is panting for the local tomato season to begin has already missed its opening. For true tomato fans, the season begins when the first green tomatoes arrive at the markets. And they have.

title: Brussels Journal; Food Scandal Adds to Belgium's Image of Disarray
description: The chicken definitely came first in Belgium, then the egg -- followed by pork, veal, beef, and now even milk, cheese and butter.

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnival to Spend $700 Million on Ship
description: The Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise operator, is likely to spend at least $700 million on its so-called Project Queen Mary, an effort to build the largest luxury ocean liner ever constructed, its chief financial officer said.

title: Pacers Overcome the Worry Habit
description: Mark Jackson was perched on the scorer's table, throwing his head back and laughing. Chris Mullin lounged a few feet away, his arms draped over the back of a chair.

title: Sips; An Inn's Own Brews (Just Remember Which Door You Came In)
description: TO cosset their guests, some innkeepers bake their own bread, make their own jams or grow their own mesclun. Tim Wilson, an owner of the Jasper Murdock Alehouse at the Norwich Inn in Norwich, Vt., brews tasty, full-bodied beers -- from hoppy pale ales to thick, creamy stouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, IRENE M.
description: MATTHEWS-Irene M. (nee Lansing). On June 6, 1999 of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved wife of John A. Matthews. Dear mother of John A. Jr., Robert T. and Doreen M. Beswick. Cherished grandmother of five. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc. 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Thursday at 11 A.M. at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury.

title: Six Shows Are Closing As Dust Settles From Tonys
description: Faced with wilting box office numbers and scant success at the Tony Awards, four Broadway productions announced yesterday that they would close Sunday. Among them is the musical ''The Civil War,'' which producers say will have lost an estimated $8 million in its two-month run at the St. James Theater.

title: When Juries Are Too Generous
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL CORP., Irving, Tex., a finance company, agreed to sell its credit card payment processing unit, Network Transaction Services, to Alliance Data Systems of Dallas, for an undisclosed price.

title: Of Tears and Dreams, Heartbreak and Hope
description: A calm bass riff undulated slowly between two chords, swaying as gently as a hammock. Beth Orton, onstage at Roseland on Thursday night, sang a recurring phrase, ''Could you please knock me off my feet,'' followed by a pause and an afterthought: ''for a while.'' Her voice rose to a tense, imploring trill on ''please,'' turned feathery in ''knock me off my feet,'' then grew sober and wary with ''for a while.'' The song, ''Galaxy of Emptiness,'' hovered between mantra and confession, meditation and desire; the immediacy of longing was suspended in contemplation. That transformation occurs again and again in Ms. Orton's songs, and it held her Roseland audience entranced.

title: Sports of The Times; Hogan Room Speaks for Quiet Man
description: AS she walked around the Ben Hogan Room from one exhibit to another, Valerie Hogan seemed to be reliving their 62 years together. Here were her husband's trophies, his awards, his 1953 irons in a leather golf bag, his books, even the sports jackets and shirts that were in his locker at the Shady Oaks Country Club near their Fort Worth home when he died in 1997.

title: Notebook; Teacher Testing Criticized
description: Most states' teacher-licensing tests are so easy that high school students could answer the questions, and the scores needed to pass are laughably low, says a recent report by the Education Trust, a nonprofit organization in Washington that seeks to improve education for the poor.

title: Torture of Disabled Man Leads to Indictments
description: In what officials say is the country's first prosecution of a bias crime involving a victim with a mental disability, eight people have been indicted in the kidnapping and torture of a Monmouth County man in January.

title: Yankees Are Jolted Back to the Present, Losing a 5-Run Lead
description: Tony Tarasco was among the last to escape the pall of the Yankee clubhouse. He walked up to a reporter and jammed a fist against his chest, as if to insert a sharp object into the sternum. Tarasco twisted his wrist, back and forth, back and forth.

title: Broadway Hero? It's Letterman
description: David Letterman's ''Late Show'' on CBS rode to the rescue of the Broadway show ''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues'' yesterday, offering a home for the production number from that musical that was bumped from the network's Sunday night broadcast of the Tony Awards.

title: Plucky in a Battle Against Frailty and Tormentors
description: THE ARTIST'S WIDOW

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Born in Berlin on May 22, 1905, died on June 7, 1999 at his home. He was Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Columbia University. He is survived by many nieces and nephews residing in the United States and Europe. Service 2:30PM Wednesday at ''Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations to the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of Columbia University would be appreciated.

title: Kosovo Obligations Remain Unfulfilled; No Guaranteed Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Sentenced to Life In Killing of Daughter
description: A 20-year-old West Orange man was sentenced to life in prison yesterday after he admitted torturing, sexually assaulting and killing his 16-month-old daughter, officials said yesterday.

title: Veteran Judge Is Nominated To High Court
description: Saying that she intended to create a more diverse Supreme Court, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today made her second nomination in four months to the state's highest court, picking Virginia Long, a presiding judge in the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title: People Power Takes Root in Indonesia
description: Slow election returns left Indonesia in suspense today about the shape of its political future. But whatever the outcome of Monday's vote, a fundamental shift in power already seemed to be taking place: people were choosing their leaders.

title: G.M. AND CLEAR CHANNEL BUY STAKE IN XM SATELLITE RADIO
description: XM Satellite Radio Inc., a company hoping to broadcast radio programs directly to vehicles by satellite, said yesterday that it had sold a $250 million stake to a consortium that includes the General Motors Corporation and the radio giant Clear Channel Communications. Shares of XM Satellite's parent, the American Mobile Satellite Corporation of Reston, Va., surged 20.52 percent, or $3.4375, to $20.1875. XM Satellite seeks to provide radio listeners nationwide with music, news and entertainment through its satellite-to-receiver broadcasting service. The news is a setback for the company's rival, CD Radio Inc., which, like XM Satellite, is trying to build radio networks to transmit broadcasts from satellites to special receiving equipment in consumers' vehicles.

title: Amid 11 Medals for Excellence In Decade, Charges of Brutality
description: The police career of Charles Schwarz, the 33-year-old officer convicted yesterday of holding down Abner Louima while Justin A. Volpe shoved a stick into his rectum, was one of extreme highs and lows.

title: A Hitch to Marital Web Bliss; Excite@Home Is Often at Odds With Its Cable Parents
description: It is early in the honeymoon for the At Home Corporation, a provider of fast Internet access through cable lines, and Excite Inc., the country's second-largest Internet portal, which it just bought for $6.7 billion. But Excite may already feel like the bride who finds that her in-laws are bent on undermining the marriage.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Auto Makers and Union Eager for Long-Term Deal

title: AUCTION OF KOREAN INSURER
description: Eight companies have submitted bids for the Korea Life Insurance Company. The Financial Supervisory Commission, South Korea's financial watchdog, said the bidders included five foreign financial institutions, among them the Regent Pacific Group of Hong Kong and the AMCO Insurance unit of Allied Group of the United States. Korea Life is the first of several wobbly life insurers that the Government is trying to sell to help revitalize the debt-laden financial sector. It hopes to raise $1.7 billion from the sale. Sheryl WuDunn

title: Senate, 93 to 4, Passes Spending Bill for Pentagon
description: The Senate tonight passed a $265 billion appropriations bill for the Pentagon by a 93-to-4 vote. It includes a pay increase for military personnel and the authority to lease luxurious executive jets for generals.

title: Notebook; Offensive E-mail at Stanford
description: A two-paragraph message filled with racial slurs aimed at black and Hispanic students turned up in 25,000 Stanford University E-mail accounts over the Memorial Day weekend. The note, sent to students, professors and others, prompted an outcry on campus, including an open letter from the university's president, Gerhard Casper, who denounced the ''appalling epithets.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
description: FISHER-Zachary. The shareholders of 50 Sutton Place South Owners, Inc. mourn the passing of our friend and neighbor, a member of the Fisher Brothers Company, who was actively instrumental in the construction of 50 Sutton Place South, who helped assure the proper management of the building and who was a valued resident of the building from the time it was completed until the time of his death. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and to the entire Fisher family. The beauty of our building and the high quality of life in it are a fitting tribute to our former neighbor.

title: Amid Scare, Asians Extend Bans on Food From Europe
description: HONG KONG  The European Union sought Tuesday to prevent its growing food scandal from turning into a trade dispute with Asia as countries across the region imposed or extended bans on the import of European food.

title: Fresh Look At A Syntax Skewer
description: On a blinding hot day in 1908, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas climbed a hill above the Italian town of Fiesole, where both were spending the summer. There was tension in the air, a powerful attraction; there were unanswered questions. Stopping in the heat, the two had a conversation. In the onrush of feelings, in the way of people newly in love who want to make a clean break from the past, they told each other about the people they had loved before.

title: Bank of New York Is Selling Lending Operation to G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation agreed today to buy the Bank of New York's commercial lending unit for $1.8 billion as the auto maker diversified its holdings and the bank continued to specialize its operations.

title: US AIRWAYS WARNS PROFIT MAY BE 16% LESS THAN FORECAST
description: The US Airways Group Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit might be as much as 16 percent less than analysts had forecast because of higher costs and fewer travelers than expected in May. US Airways said profit would be about $1.80 to $1.85 a share, less than the $2.15 forecast by analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation and the $1.95 it earned a year earlier. Its shares fell $2.6875, or 5.2 percent, to $48.875, leading a decline in other airline stocks. The warning follows a similar announcement last week from the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines.

title: Serbs Raise An Obstacle To Return Of Refugees
description: Putting up another obstacle in military talks on Kosovo, Yugoslav officials are trying to exercise control over which Kosovo Albanian refugees will be allowed to return.

title: Blaze Kills 2 Queens Boys And Leaves 16 People Hurt
description: Two young boys were killed yesterday in an early morning fire in Queens after smoke detectors apparently failed to sound in their home, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him at services on Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30AM. We will also be at Riverside tonight, Wednesday evening, June 9, from 6-9 P.M. to welcome friends and reminisce about Joe, in loving remembrance of his life. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Liberties; Puppy Love Politics
description: I know exactly how the Republicans feel.

title: New Showdown on Gun Control
description: There is plenty of reason to be skeptical about the pledge by Speaker Dennis Hastert last month to support ''common-sense'' gun control legislation in the House. After all, the Republican leadership has tried every technique to gut or block gun control in the past. Yesterday, in a highly unusual parliamentary move, Mr. Hastert said he would bypass the Judiciary Committee, where most Republicans are hostile to gun control, and bring the legislation directly to the floor. If the Speaker really means to carry out his pledge, he needs to allow open debate and constructive amendments from both sides of the aisle. Given a chance, the House could improve on the Senate bill approved last month.

title: A Time for Calm in Ireland and a New View of Friel
description: After 26 years of neglect, the Abbey Theater is enthusiastically reviving Brian Friel's most political play, ''The Freedom of the City,'' set in the sectarian warfare of contemporary Northern Ireland. The play has been well received by audiences and critics in a Friel festival at the Abbey and will move to the Lincoln Center Festival on July 7 for a brief run.

title: From Sibelius's Civility to Contemporary Stress, at a Gathering of Finns
description: Far-flung, numerous and sublimely dissimilar, Americans have a hard time understanding the national impulse of smaller countries. We are happily different among ourselves. For Finland and places like it, being one identifiable thing is a means of survival.

title: Hastert Warns Disunity May Mean Defeat
description: Pleading for unity, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert told fellow Republicans today that they must stick together and pass the party's major bills or risk losing their majority in the House.

title: Forbes hustles to build its Web brand, and pitches it to an audience with a decided attitude.
description: TO put its two-year-old World Wide Web site on the map, Forbes Inc. is waging its biggest ad campaign ever.

title: Pataki Nominates a Democrat for a Judgeship
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday nominated State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., a Democrat who crossed party ranks to endorse the Republican Governor last year, for a judgeship on the State Court of Claims.

title: Not Exactly Starting Over: Writer's Choices
description: HANNAH PAKULA set her condition for speaking with Public Lives: attention must be paid to Human Rights Watch. Its 10th annual film festival begins tonight with a benefit screening of ''The Parallax View,'' the 1974 political thriller directed by Alan J. Pakula, Ms. Pakula's husband, who died in a car crash on the Long Island Expressway in November.

title: Drug Makers Skeptical on Plan for Elderly
description: Drug industry and insurance executives reacted with skepticism yesterday to reports that the White House was planning a new prescription-drug benefit for all elderly Americans. Under the proposal, Medicare recipients would pay $10 to $25 a month in addition to the current Medicare premium of $45.50, which does not cover drugs.

title: Another Father Is Ejected As Daughter Plays Match
description: The father of Jelena Dokic, a promising 16-year-old Australian, was ejected during her tennis match at a tournament here today and later picked up by the police after lying in the middle of a road.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. '''Life' was such a 'lovely' game to play, when you were near and not so far away, oh I believe in yesterday.'' Happy Birthday, Sweet Boy. Love, Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Young & Rubicam Joins Clarant Venture
description: Seeking to expand its Internet and electronic commerce capabilities, Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had contributed the assets of the New York office of its interactive unit, Brand Dialogue, to the Clarant Worldwide Corporation in Dallas, which is being formed from eight Internet and high-technology agencies and companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Born in NYC on May 18, 1932. Survived by his wife Arlene of 46 years, his son Scott and wife Susan, daughter Lynn and husband Daniel Mosner and two granddaughters Blair and Hilary Mosner. He was predeceased by his son Brad; beloved brother of Natalie Fluger and Naomi Prufer. He owned Wilmot Chemists in Scarsdale, NY. He was a successful real estate broker in NY and Chicago. He brought innovation and integrity to all of his endeavors. He was a great storyteller and comedian. He was an admirer and collector of arts and fine crafts, an avid scuba diver who found great pleasure in teaching others the sport about which he was so passionate. He was determined and courageous in his long battle with cancer and other illnesses. He was big hearted, generous, humorous and had a great flair for life. His warmhearted spirit touched the lives of many people and he will be deeply missed by all those who had the privilege of knowing him. Funeral service will be at the Rye Community Synagogue on Thursday, June 10 at 11A.M. For further information contact William H. Graham Funeral Home, 914-967-0129.

title: AVNET TO SELL COMPONENTS UNIT FOR $380 MILLION
description: Electrocomponents P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Allied Electronics Corporation Ltd., which sells electronic components through catalogues, from Avnet Inc. for $380 million. Electrocomponents, based in Britain, said the takeover marked its entry into the United States catalogue distribution business. It distributes electronic and mechanical components and health and safety products. As part of the deal, Electrocomponents is entering a strategic alliance with Avnet, which is based in Phoenix and distributes electronic components and computer products.

title: OPTIMISM ON DIAMONDS
description: A large rise in diamond sales is expected at De Beers, which controls 70 percent of the world's diamond market. Analysts said the company would sell about $457.5 million worth of gems this week -- an increase of almost a third over the sale held at this time last year -- largely because of rising demand in the United States. De Beers is locked in a dispute with South Africa's Government over export taxes. The dispute has led to a 10-week blocking of exports of gems from the country, one of the world's biggest producers. Diamond stockpiles worth close to $5 billion held by De Beers in London will enable it to keep supplying the global market.

title: It Was a Whole New Game, and the Stakes Were High
description: The players union of the Women's National Basketball Association overwhelmingly ratified a labor contract last month, the first in women's professional team sports in the United States. The players won increased salaries, year-round health coverage, including maternity leave, a matching 401(k) program and limited job security for veterans.

title: Gallic Charm of the Terminally Restless
description: Crossed connections, missed connections, misconnections, disconnections: these are all unavoidable elements of human existence at the end of this century. They are also, as it happens, basic ingredients of classic farce, and for Jean-Claude Carriere, the French dramatist and screenwriter, these parallels are irresistible. So is the new comedy in which he exploits them.

title: 26 Are Arrested in Drug Smuggling Network Using Mohawk Reservation
description: Police officers today managed to cripple but not quite destroy the largest cocaine smuggling and selling operation in northern New York State in a series of rapid early morning raids, state and Federal officials said. The raids netted a few prize suspects, including a 24-year-old Mohawk man who, the officials said, ran the drug network from his home here.

title: Sprewell and Houston: Dysfunction Loves Company
description: Once their insecurities with one another dissolved near season's end, Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston formed a happy couple on the court. It did not matter if they liked the same music or shared the same barber, because they had success in common.

title: Lawyers' Group Recommends Sharing of Fees With Others
description: A special panel at the American Bar Association rocked the legal profession yesterday by recommending that lawyers toss out decades-old rules that have prevented them from setting up partnerships with accountants, consultants and other professionals.

title: Overnight Talks Yield No Pact
description: Two days after a first round of talks ended in deadlock, NATO and Yugoslav generals met here again in talks that dragged on into this morning to discuss the withdrawal of Yugoslav and Serbian forces from Kosovo.

title: India and Pakistan to Discuss Flare-Up in Kashmir
description: For the first time since fighting erupted in the disputed province of Kashmir last month, senior Indian and Pakistani officials agreed today to discuss ways of defusing the tension, Pakistan announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOPHER, MARGARET
description: CHRISTOPHER-Margaret A. (nee Gorman). On June 6, 1999. Beloved wife of Patrick J. Loving daughter of the late Patrick and Ellen. Cherished mother of Patricia and Gerald. Dear sister of the late Mary Roeben, Joseph, and Helen Bross. Repossing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St. New York City, Tuesday & Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of of Christian Burial on Thursday 10AM, St. Veronica's R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Christian Brothers Auxiliary, Lincroft, N.J.

title: The Absence Speaks Louder Than Losing
description: As strategies go, Jeff Van Gundy has come up with better ones than starting Latrell Sprewell. The Knicks' coach was predictably weathering the usual criticism and second-guessing yesterday for not staying with his bigger lineup in Game 4, as if a dynasty featuring Kurt Thomas at power forward was suddenly in danger of crumbling.

title: State Workers Threaten Whitman With a Strike
description: New Jersey's 27,000 unionized state employees have voted to authorize a strike if Gov. Christine Todd Whitman does not meet their demands to increase wages, freeze workers' health care costs and preserve the civil service seniority system, union officials announced today.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Rubes' Hail From Outer Boroughs
description: MARK JACKSON thought he was a gym rat until he met up with Chris Mullin. Then he discovered how far he was down the rodent chain.

title: Why Ignore Alcohol?
description: To the Editor:

title: Captain Killed in Fire Is Called a Hero by Those He Inspired
description: There were some here among the 8,500 firefighters attending Capt. Vincent Fowler's somber funeral who admitted that they did not know him. But so many more, it seemed, withstood the sweltering heat so they could tell of a laugh, a lesson or even a reproach they had received from him years ago, and never forgotten.

title: Agbayani Living A Dream
description: There is proof that Benny Agbayani is human after all. Agbayani was talking about the incredible journey he has taken from being a minor league player that the Mets and 29 other major league teams did not want last season to being a shocking mainstay in Bobby Valentine's lineup. And for a few seconds, Agbayani's emotions overflowed.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA SOARS. Cocoa rose almost 9 percent on expectations that a surge in sales by Ghana, the second-biggest grower, has left it with few beans to market. In New York, cocoa for July delivery rose $90, to $1,139 a metric ton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SFRAGA, GRACE
description: SFRAGA-Grace. On June 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Julio Sacramone. Loving mother of Rocco Sacromone. Dear sister Ms. Edythe S. Lodato and Ceaser Louis Scotti. Funeral services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, IRVING
description: RAPPAPORT - Irving. Beloved husband of Leanore. Devoted father of Barbara Kurzman, Carol Gewandter, and Stephen. Loving grandfather of Andrea, Erica, Heather, Jennifer, Matthew, and Brett. Respected father-in-law of Michael, Peter, and Linda. Services today at 1:00 PM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, N.Y.C.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Cooler Theater Lures Stars Away

title: A Study Plays Down Estrogen Link to Breast Cancers
