description: Whether to take estrogen or not is the dilemma faced by millions of women at menopause who want the hormone's protection against heart disease and osteoporosis, and yet fear that it may also increase their risk of breast cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNETZ, LOU
description: DUNETZ-Lou. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed and devoted member and expresses heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: OFF THE MENU
description: St. Barts on the Terrace

title: Apologizing to China for Bombing Is a Delicate Undertaking
description: Finding a way to talk to China is difficult enough for the Clinton Administration these days. Finding a way to apologize to China is turning out to be just about impossible.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Butter Goes Gently Into a Good Batter

title: CALENDAR
description: Strawberries and Folk Songs

title: Republicans to Move Gun-Control Bill Directly to House Floor
description: House Republican leaders said today that they would bring gun-control legislation to the House floor next week without holding a previously scheduled meeting in the House Judiciary Committee, a change in strategy that demonstrated their acute sensitivity to the potency of gun control as a political issue right now.

title: I.B.M. Executive Testifies On '97 Microsoft Proposal
description: At a private meeting in March 1997, a Microsoft executive told I.B.M. that the computer maker would pay a lower price for Microsoft's Windows operating system if it did not ship a competing Internet browser, an I.B.M. executive testified today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOKE, BERTHA M.
description: COOKE-Bertha M. On June 7, 1999 of Bellerose, New York. Beloved wife of the late Len. Loving mother of Len, Jr. Cherished grandmother of six and greatgrandmother of seven. Visitation at the R. Stutzmann & Son, Inc. Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY, Thursday, 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM. Service at the Funeral Home, Thursday 8:00 PM. Funeral, Friday 10:00 AM. Interment in Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Richard Shelby Is No Robin Hood
description: Shortly before the Memorial Day recess, Senator Richard Shelby started to pick the pockets of both California and New York State. The Senate Appropriations Committee voted overwhelmingly to impose the Alabama Senator's 12.5 percent ceiling on what any one state can receive of the annual total of Federal rapid-transit aid. That would siphon off some $200 million to $300 million that would ordinarily go to New York or California in fiscal 2000 and redistribute it in equal shares to the other 48 states for mass transit.

title: Auto Negotiations Are Likely to Aim for a Longer Pact
description: With General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler scheduled to begin talks next week with the United Automobile Workers, it appears increasingly likely that negotiators will seek a national labor contract lasting four or more years, the longest such deal since the 1950's, auto executives and union officials say.

title: Searching for Home
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sony Music Plans to Test Use of In-Store Digital Kiosks
description: Sony Music Entertainment said yesterday that it had struck a deal that would let consumers buy music through digital vending machines in music stores.

title: Dow Retreats 75.35, to 10,690.29, as Computer Issues Help Nasdaq Post Solid Gains
description: A late surge of interest in computer-related stocks lifted the Nasdaq composite index to a solid gain yesterday while the Dow Jones industrial average continued to slide.

title: Trickle Down Lifts Up Johnson
description: The trickle-down effect of adding Latrell Sprewell to the starting lineup has left Larry Johnson in the familiar role of sacrificial lamb.

title: U.S. Adds 6 Chinese Sites to List That Alerts Computer Sellers
description: In an effort to prevent sensitive technology from being used by the Chinese military, the Commerce Department has told exporters that shipments to six missile and nuclear sites in China will require Federal approval.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKER, BEATRICE
description: STOCKER-Beatrice. On June 9, 1999. Born in 1909. Very beloved by Jule, husband of 67 years; daughter Maida, son Michael, Sarah & Rebecca, granddaughters. An influential and innovative speech clinician and teacher at Queens College. Recipient of the Professional Achievement Award and a Special Citation by the N.Y. City and State Speech, Hearing, and Language Association; inventor of the Stocker Probe Technique for Diagnosis & Treatment of Stuttering. A lifelong devotee of the Visual Arts and a continuing student at the NYU Institute of Fine Arts. No funeral. Memorial to be set. In lieu of flowers donations to the Beatrice Stocker Fellowship Fund at the NYU Insitute of Fine Arts, 1 East 78 St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Whitman's Court Nominee To Appear Before Bar Panel
description: The president of the New Jersey State Bar Association said today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new nominee for the State Supreme Court has agreed to appear before the association's judicial review panel for an interview despite the Governor's decision to bypass the procedure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRITZER, ROY
description: KRITZER-Roy. 89 on June 10, 1999 at home. Beloved husband of Rebecca (Bergman) Kritzer. Loving father of Charles and Benjamin. Brother of Irene Sher. Also survived by three grandchildren: Anne Elizabeth Epstein, Jason and Bradley Kritzer; one great-grandson, Warren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services today at 9:00 AM at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Avenue, Manalapan, NJ. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: MARC Acquires Ryan Drossman
description: As part of continuing national expansion efforts, MARC USA in Pittsburgh said yesterday that it had acquired Ryan Drossman & Partners, a New York agency with 48 employees working on accounts with billings estimated at $62 million for clients including A&P and Bear, Stearns.

title: Mexican World Cup Team Reaps Benefit of America's Special Export
description: It has required no slight adjustment for the Mexican-American players who make up half the roster on Mexico's team for the Women's World Cup. In contrast to the well-oiled machinery of United States women's soccer on and off the field, the simple act of catching the Mexican team bus can turn into an action movie.

title: Outdoor Floors to Go, Ready for the Chaise Longue
description: AN outdoor floor used to be forever. To install a terrace, patio or deck meant waiting on professionals, with their own inscrutable timetables. Now, with do-it-yourself kits and loose-lay flooring, you can just about bring home the deck and put out the lounge chairs.

title: 2 Generals' Remarks on Pullout Pact
description: Following is the announcement by Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Jackson of Britain of an agreement between NATO and Yugoslav generals on the withdrawal of Serbian forces from Kosovo, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company. Also following is the statement by Col. Gen. Svetovar Marjanovic of Yugoslavia on the agreement, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: China Pushes Its Campaign To Modify Peace Plan
description: China tried today into the late evening to secure the Security Council's agreement on changes in the Kosovo peace plan.

title: Delays in Vote Count Have Indonesians Worried About Cheating
description: Two days after the national election, the talk of the town today was not about who won or lost but about the fact that nobody had any idea of the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURMANKIN, JOSEPH
description: GURMANKIN-Joseph. We express our condolences to our collegue and friend, Robert Gurmankin on the passing of his beloved father. May the memory of his life serve to comfort you and Elise, and his grandchildren, Jeffrey, Hannah and Zachary in the days and years ahead. Roanna Shorofsky, Director Terry Ann Krulwich, President The Abraham Joshua Heschel School

title: Discovery of a Body Cancels A Park Reopening Ceremony
description: A woman was found dead early yesterday morning in a park in Cambria Heights, Queens, just hours before the city's Parks Commissioner was to rededicate the park after a $1.6 million renovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COFFEY, HELEN RIZSAK
description: COFFEY-Helen Rizsak. On June 3, 1999 of Plainfield, N.J, formerly of Passaic, N.J. Mother of Barbara Gubelman, grandmother of Helena, Mary and Ronald, great grandmother of Veronica and Samuel. Memorial services to be announced at later date. Donations in her name to Center for Hope Hospice, 176 Hussa Street, Linden, N.J, 07036 will be appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Has the Global Fever Broken?; Stock and Bond Markets Read Different Thermometers
description: Is the financial crisis that first erupted in the global economy about two years ago really over? Or is there a lighted stick of dynamite somewhere out there just waiting to explode?

title: Sorry, Mom and Dad
description: AS getting into a co-op becomes more and more like an obstacle course, with less and less chance of success, many co-op boards in Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn have raised the hurdle even higher: they have stopped letting parents guarantee their children's apartment purchases.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Prices for gold fell 1 percent on speculation that small central banks are following the example of larger counterparts and selling reserves. In New York, gold for August delivery fell $2.70 an ounce, to $261.10.

title: Costs of Psychotherapy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Photos Show Ground Work at Suspected Site of Mass Grave
description: Photographs taken by United States spy satellites seem to show that Serbian forces dug up the bodies of their victims to hide evidence of a massacre in Kosovo, the chief Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Unknowns Of Dioxin:No Dose Rated Safe
description: PARIS  Dioxin, the carcinogen that has contaminated Belgian eggs, chicken and other foods, is a chemical with a notorious past.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN IS A BIT WEAKER. The dollar edged up as traders locked in gains from the Japanese currency's rise on Tuesday amid talk that Japan's economy is recovering. In New York, the dollar settled at 118.93 yen, up from 118.88.

title: Conviction In Cosby Case Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday overturned the conviction of Autumn Jackson, who went to prison for threatening to tell a supermarket tabloid that she was Bill Cosby's out-of-wedlock daughter unless he paid her $40 million.

title: Woolley Finds a Home With Buffalo
description: After playing for Michigan State, the Canadian Olympic team, three minor league teams and two National Hockey League teams, Jason Woolley found himself in his late 20's with the serious concerns faced by most young married men. His wife was expecting their first baby and he needed financial security.

title: G.O.P. Sees Privacy Threat in Democrats' Bid for Documents
description: In a move that has touched off a furor on Capitol Hill, Democratic strategists are seeking reams of official documents in a search for grist to use against Republican senators up for re-election next year.

title: School of the Second Chance; Turning Troubled Students Around at Wildcat High
description: From the outside, Wildcat High School in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx looks like what it is: a school for some of the city's toughest kids.

title: Connors Prevails In the First Round
description: Jimmy Connors, the No. 1-seeded player on the Worldwide Senior Tennis Circuit, used his trademark baseline game and consistent serve to defeat Gene Mayer, 3-6, 6-0, 10-7, last night in the first round of the Citibank Champions tournament at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

title: MEGGITT OF BRITAIN ADDING U.S. MAKER OF AIRCRAFT PARTS
description: The British aerospace company Meggitt P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Whittaker Corporation, a Simi Valley, Calif., maker of specialized parts for civilian and military aircraft, for $28 a share, or around $380 million. The move enhances the British company's position as a supplier to industry titans. Whittaker, which had sales last year of $131.5 million, makes fluid-control and fire safety systems for aerospace and industrial applications. The offer represents a premium of about 4 percent to Whittaker's closing price on Tuesday of $26.875. The shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $27.50.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It means that the war has ended.''

title: Bettman Issues a Warning to the Islanders
description: If the Islanders trade Zigmund Palffy while trying to reduce their payroll, they had better get some hockey value for him and not just a large sum of money.

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP WEIGHS SALE OF RADIO UNIT
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc., is considering a public stock offering or outright sale of its radio unit in an effort to lift its stock price. Sinclair, which owns 51 radio and 58 television stations, said Tuesday that it might seek to raise $175 million to $200 million in a public offering that would include only its radio assets. It said it would use the proceeds to pay down some of its $2.3 billion in outstanding debt. The Baltimore-based company said it would also consider selling the radio business. The shares, which rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $16.25, are down almost 50 percent from their 12-month high.

title: Springtime Drag-Racers Prompt a Crackdown
description: Capistrano has its swallows. Francis Lewis Boulevard in Queens has drag-racers.

title: Should Doctors Sacrifice One Life to Save Many?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
In a new campaign for Motorola, Leo Burnett hopes to make 'Digital DNA' a household phrase.
description: MOTOROLA INC. has decided that some of its products are simply too clandestine. While pagers and cellular telephones are well known and branded with the Motorola ''wings'' logo, few know that the company deals in something called ''embedded solutions.''

title: Disrupted Rail Service Draws Complaints
description: Some shippers have begun reporting major disruptions in service, including delayed trains and lost rail cars, since the CSX and Norfolk Southern railroads took over Conrail on June 1.

title: Success Is in Sight, But Where's The Vision?
description: YOU could smell the plywood at the Library of Congress, where ''The Work of Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of Invention'' recently opened. At the exhibition of the two American designers' multifaceted achievement, the cheap board they made beautiful has a fresh, resourceful smell that makes you believe anything is possible, because the world might be as pliable as new plywood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Engineering Food, And Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: How Deep Is Your Rug?
description: There's nothing quite like a good shag.

title: Should Doctors Sacrifice One Life to Save Many?
description: To the Editor:

title: 8-Run 6th Helps Lift Yankees Into First
description: A player lowered his voice in the Yankees' clubhouse here today and asked a question that will gain relevance if this team keeps its current mediocrity for much longer: ''What does George think?''

title: To Enter the World of E-Mail, Just Insert Batteries and Plug In
description: A simple and inexpensive device will now let the computerless get E-mail, too.

title: Virus Fighters on 24-Hour, Global Guard
description: JUST outside the security door to the Symantec Antivirus Research Center in Santa Monica, Calif., is a wall-length mural depicting engineers like those inside as superhumans and film noir detectives.

title: A Chaplain Counsels Humility as Healing
description: TO see a revered religious leader suddenly go all mumbly and humble, try complimenting Imam El Hajji Izak-El Mu'eed Pasha of the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Harlem.

title: No Bikes, No Fun, No Adventure; Problem With Helmets
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Tailors Legacy But Kosovo Isn't Fabric
description: Six weeks ago, as NATO leaders met in Washington, commentators and White House officials described the war in Kosovo as big casino for Bill Clinton -- the pivotal moment of his Presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: SERB MILITARY ACCEPTS ACCORD, CLEARING WAY TO HALT BOMBING
description: The Yugoslav military tonight acceded to an agreement that will permit a military force commanded by a NATO general with sweeping powers to occupy Kosovo, clearing the way to an end to the Western alliance's first war.

title: Crew Outlines Plan To End Promotions For Failing Pupils
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew presented a broad proposal yesterday to halt the practice of promoting students with failing grades beginning next year, saying it would tax the school system's resources but move it toward higher academic standards.

title: G. S. Dillon, 81, Former Official Of Air Reduction
description: George S. Dillon, a former president, chief executive and chairman of the Air Reduction Company, died of cancer on Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, his son Peter Dillon said. He was 81.

title: CANADIAN BANK HEADS SOUTH
description: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce will move into retail banking in the United States this fall in about 200 Florida supermarkets owned by Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. of Jacksonville. CIBC, Canada's second-largest bank, is awaiting approval for a national banking license from United States regulators. Winn-Dixie has 1,180 stores in 14 states, and offers financial services in 450 locations through other banks. CIBC will set up in the Florida stores that do not already have banking, beginning in Orlando, said a Winn-Dixie spokesman, Mickey Clerc. Timothy Pritchard

title: A Search Engine With an Eye For the Emerging Communities
description: What do inflatable sumo-wrestling suits and machine shops in Taiwan have in common? They are the subjects of communities of linked Web sites, communities so obscure or ill-defined that many Web directories don't list them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, age 80, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Lecter Returns, and One of His Victims Is Out for Revenge
description: HANNIBAL

title: Neutral Language
description: To the Editor:

title: COX ENTERPRISES INVESTS IN MP3.COM, A MUSIC WEB SITE
description: Cox Enterprises Inc., which controls Cox Communications Inc., a leading cable operator, said it had invested $45 million in the on-line music company MP3.com Inc. Under the deal, Cox Enterprises' Interactive Media unit, which runs a network of Web sites focused on individual cities, will take an undisclosed equity stake in MP3.com, which is based in San Diego and named for a popular technology used to distribute music over the Web. Cox, based in Atlanta, wants to offer a broader range of content to subscribers who use cable lines to connect to the Web. MP3.com's Web site lets users download thousands of songs free and provides links to other music sites.

title: MEYER INTERNATIONAL IN DEAL FOR RENTX INDUSTRIES
description: Meyer International P.L.C., the big British distributor of building materials, said yesterday that its Meyer U.S.A. Inc. unit had agreed to buy Rentx Industries of Denver for $98.7 million in cash and assumed debt to expand in the construction and industrial tool rental market. Rentx, which rents tools and party equipment, had sales of $55.4 million in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. Meyer International is trying to increase its presence in the United States to offset a drop in prices for timber and building products in the British market.

title: A Family That Goes On 8 Feet and 8 Paws
description: THOSE citronella eyes, set in a velvety gray pelt, stare out from every corner of the Wegman studio, a sprawling converted nursery school in Chelsea. It is also the family home of William Wegman, the conceptual artist and dog-theme merchandiser, whose fans respond to his outpouring of videos, PBS programs, books, commercials, posters and kitchen magnets as if answering the siren call of a high-pitched dog whistle. He is just now finishing a memoir (to be published Oct. 1) of life with Fay Ray, one of the Weimaraners who inspired him.

title: As Mexico Mourns TV Figure, Cocaine Clouds the Picture
description: In his 30-year television career, the round-faced comedian popularly known as Paco Stanley charmed millions of Mexicans with his jocular but razor-edged way of clowning and mocking, of putting them down and exhorting them to be good.

title: Volpe Can Clear Second Officer, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for Justin A. Volpe, who pleaded guilty to torturing Abner Louima in a station house restroom, said yesterday that Mr. Volpe was willing to take a polygraph test to establish that another police officer was wrongly convicted on Tuesday of helping carry out the attack.

title: A Financial Stop on the Way To Elective Cosmetic Surgery
description: In the category of things-you-hadn't-expected-to-do-on-line, a new entrant: a Web site where you can apply for a tummy tuck loan.

title: GREEK BANK DEAL
description: EFG Bank Group offered 443 billion drachmas ($1.4 billion) in cash and shares for control of Ergo Bank S.A., Greece's No. 5 bank, to create the country's second-largest bank, in alliance with Deutsche Bank A.G. The Geneva-based EFG Bank Group owns EFG Eurobank S.A., Greece's No. 3 bank, and is buying an additional 30 percent of Ergo Bank. Deutsche Bank, which also owns a 10 percent stake in EFG Eurobank, bought a 5 percent stake in Ergo Bank yesterday and will act as a strategic partner in the new Greek banking group, EFG Bank Group said. EFG is also owned by Greece's Latsis family, which made its fortune in shipping and now has interests in banking, real estate and the energy business.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DELLA ROCCA, DOMINICK
description: DELLA ROCCA-Dominick. Happy First Anniversary in Heaven. We miss you. Community Mayors of New York

title: Lou Dobbs, Leaving CNN, Says He Won't Join a Rival
description: The day after resigning from CNN, Lou Dobbs, the best-known business-news journalist in television, said he had no intention of joining another television network.

title: Virtual Variety Stores: Aisles of Free Files
description: IN the Midwestern town where I grew up, there was a store called Soukup's, which sold just about everything: nested mixing bowls, ''No Trespassing'' signs, sidewalk chalk, badminton birdies and -- if you took the creaky elevator to the third floor -- an enviable variety of colorful fishing lures. My mother still treasures the egg timer shaped like a chicken (its wings moved when it ticked) that I bought for her birthday when I was 10.

title: An Old Craft Learns New Tricks
description: OUTSIDE the windows of the Steinway & Sons piano factory in Long Island City, Queens, ventilators blow petals of wood shavings into the air, creating what looks like a light snowfall all year round. Down a hallway of administrative offices, several doors feature bumper stickers crowing ''I Love Wood.''

title: Met Minor Leaguers Are in Hot Water
description: The manager and three players for the Capital City Bombers, the Mets' Class A farm team, have been suspended after a confrontation with fans during a game in Charleston, S.C., on Tuesday.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP -- DAVIS CUP; Sampras Rejoins Team for Doubles
description: Pete Sampras, who had been saying since December that he would not play in the Davis Cup competition this year, has changed his mind, the team captain Tom Gullikson announced yesterday.

title: A Cushion for Breakables Almost as Light as . . . Air
description: Polystyrene peanuts, watch out. Rapid Fill and Fill Air bags (left) will not stick to clothes or flutter out of the shipping crate. The bags were first produced in France, said Jim Mix, vice president for sales at the Sealed Air Corporation in Danbury, Conn., a company that also makes Bubble Wrap. The inflatable packing bags come in eight sizes and add almost no weight to a package.

title: From Light to Dark, Allusive to Literal
description: American Ballet Theater's new triple bill, with familiar works by Paul Taylor, Jiri Kylian and Twyla Tharp, comes as comic relief after the gloom of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Anastasia.''

title: No Bikes, No Fun, No Adventure; Reward for Pedaling
description: To the Editor:

title: Encryption Products Found To Grow in Foreign Markets
description: Commercial data-scrambling technology that is made outside the United States has become significantly more available in the last 18 months, according to researchers at George Washington University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Move on Racial Profiling

title: Australia Stays In Contention
description: Australia beat Zimbabwe by 44 runs in a World Cup Super Six match at Lord's to stay in contention for a place in the semifinals.

title: Henry J. Kurth, 81, Lighting and Set Designer
description: Henry J. Kurth, a theater lighting and set designer who created scenery for Martha Graham, Erick Hawkins and Doris Humphrey, died on Sunday at his home in Cleveland. He was 81.

title: For Serbs in Belgrade, a Night of Celebration
description: The street lights came on in downtown Belgrade tonight for the first time in 10 weeks.

title: Intel Will Raise the Ante in Chip-Manufacturing Technology
description: The Intel Corporation, the largest maker of computer chips, said today that it would upgrade its manufacturing plants to produce far more powerful processors while significantly cutting manufacturing costs.

title: Engineering Food, And Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: P.& G. to Cut 15,000 Jobs And Shut Down 10 Plants
description: In an effort to loosen its stiff corporate culture and free more cash for product development, Procter & Gamble said yesterday that it would cut 15,000 jobs worldwide -- or 13 percent of its work force -- close 10 plants and take nearly $2 billion in charges linked to the reorganization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: For Kosovo's Scattered Refugees, the Internet Is a Lifeline
description: Twice a day for the last week, 52-year-old Ramize Bajrami has walked up the metal steps into the makeshift Internet trailer here, hoping to find news about family members she left behind in Kosovo. She sits down at one of the trailer's 12 computers and begins to scroll through Web sites, her gray hair pulled back in a white kerchief. Her hazel eyes search the screen for names she has written on a crumpled paper she clutches in her hands.

title: Paul Kristeller, 94, Scholar Of the Renaissance, Is Dead
description: Paul Oskar Kristeller, a leading authority on Renaissance philosophy, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Kenneth Dodson, 91; Wrote War Novels About Life at Sea
description: Kenneth Dodson, who wrote best-selling books about his experiences as a seaman in World War II, died on May 24 at his home in Stanwood, Wash. He was 91.

title: 4 Premieres, And All Bursting With Energy
description: Monte/Brown Dance made movements slice through space when it opened a two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. The company, formerly known as Elisa Monte Dance, offered four new works by its artistic directors, Ms. Monte and David Brown. All were remarkable for their ferocious energy.

title: NATURAL GAS JOINT VENTURE
description: Sasol Ltd. of South Africa and the Chevron Corporation agreed to form a joint venture for converting natural gas output from remote deposits into diesel and other fuels. The plan, scheduled to be completed by 2003, calls for a $1 billion plant in Nigeria to make 30,000 barrels of synthetic crude oil from the 350 million cubic feet of gas produced each day by Chevron's Escravos plant.

title: Hunting for Kernels of Wit In MTV's Golden Popcorn
description: Every now and then the camera at the MTV Movie Awards settles on a strange man in the audience: shoulder-length auburn hair and long beard, blue-tinted granny glasses, hands full of silver rings, smoking a cigarette. He looks like he has been hiding out in a tattoo parlor for 20 years only to emerge, like some biker version of Rip Van Winkle, at a show dominated by hip-hop and glitz.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page picture yesterday showed Lamar Alexander, a Republican presidential candidate, speaking to a small group of people in Elizabethton, Tenn. The caption, a cross-reference to an article in section A about his uphill struggle for financial backing, said Mr. Alexander had ''yet to arouse many voters.''

title: Pataki Names Roosevelt Island Chief to Human Rights Post
description: Dr. Jerome H. Blue, whose three-year tenure as chief executive of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation was marked by controversy and charges of racism among island residents, will leave the corporation to become the state's Human Rights Commissioner, state officials said yesterday.

title: Singapore Purges Food Stocks After Belgium's Dioxin Scare
description: The free-range chicken is gone, the Camembert is dwindling and there's only enough foie gras to last the week. Beyond that, the future looks bleak to Justin Quek, chef of Singapore's most exclusive French restaurant, Au Jardin.

title: Bad News Is Good News
description: By his own words and those of his agent, Sprewell has not been the biggest supporter of Coach Jeff Van Gundy at times this season. When asked why it is the Knicks respond each time another ''Van Gundy-will-be-fired'' story hits the newsstands, Sprewell replied: ''If that's the case, I would like to see more of that. We obviously want to win -- not that I want to see Jeff out or anything -- but if it's going to make us win, I'll take it.''

title: Energy Secretary Delays Disciplining Staff Over Spy Case
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has put off for at least a month disciplining or firing any Energy Department employees as a result of the mishandling of the espionage investigation at Los Alamos National Laboratory, department officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Wells's Bags Packed, And He's Ready to Go
description: It could happen in another month or two or it might not happen at all. The Blue Jays have insisted that they will not trade David Wells because they can still contend for the wild-card berth, but that could change swiftly if they continue to sputter. That is why the Mets watched Wells even more closely as he squelched them until their dramatic rally in the ninth inning and wondered if they will wind up pursuing the portly pitcher. They are not alone.

title: 3 Companies Seen Moving to Resolve Vitamin Price-Fixing Lawsuit
description: Three of the world's largest pharmaceutical and chemical companies are negotiating to pay as much as $850 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that charges them with conspiring as an international cartel to fix the prices of vitamins for more than a decade, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: A Change Of Page
description: Q. How can I permanently change the starting page of my Web browser?

title: Suspending Disbelief Gladly for 'Boheme' in Central Park
description: ''La Boheme'' begins with two penniless young men, a painter and a poet, in a claptrap Paris garret on a chilly Christmas Eve in the early 1830's complaining to each other about how cold they are. Not the most likely story for a sticky June night in New York City. But on Tuesday on the Great Lawn in Central Park, there stood the tenor Marcello Giordani as Rodolfo the poet and the baritone Earle Patriarco as the painter Marcello, wearing white tuxedo coats, perspiring under the hot lights of the makeshift stage and singing earnestly of their chronic poverty and lack of fuel wood for the idle iron stove.

title: CHINA CUTS RATES
description: China's central bank announced a cut in interest rates, effective June 10. Bank lending rates will fall by an average three-quarter point, making the benchmark rate on one-year loans 5.85 percent, the bank said. It is the seventh time interest rates have been cut in China since May 1996, and is aimed at promoting consumption in an economy that is slowing slightly. Inflation in China is low -- negative 3.1 percent in the first four months of the year -- while the growth rate is expected to fall to 7 percent this year, compared with 7.8 percent in 1998. Seth Faison

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Murdoch and Wife Agree on Divorce

title: A Place to Browse While Waiting For van Gogh
description: Aficionados of Vincent van Gogh may have felt like cutting off their own ears lately: the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam has been closed for renovations since September 1998. So for those who could not get through the spring without ''The Langlois Bridge'' or ''The Potato Eaters,'' the museum put much of the collection on its impressive Web site (www.vangoghmuseum.nl).

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Trivia Format to Rival Channel Surfing
description: THE opening screen is black, with a white triangle filled with television snow. Over the hiss and squeak of lousy signal reception, the voice of Austin Powers's arch nemesis is audible:

title: Allstate Sets $1.2 Billion Pact to Buy CNA Business
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the personal insurance business of the CNA Financial Corporation for $1.2 billion, expanding its business with independent insurance agents who sell auto and homeowners policies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SINGER, REBECCA REBBETZIN
description: SINGER - Rebecca Rebbetzin. Loved and missed greatly each day. Love, Vivian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDELMAN, ROSLYN
description: RANDELMAN-Roslyn, on June 10th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Hal and Mary. Proud grandmother of Craig and Nicole. Dear sister-in-law of Evelyn Rifkin and Beulah Glickman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, June 13th, 7-9 PM, with service on Monday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Constructing Peace in Kosovo
description: Now that NATO and Serbian military commanders have agreed on a plan to cease hostilities in Kosovo, the war is rapidly coming to an end. The latest round of diplomacy and military talks was difficult, but leaves NATO's core goals intact. Though Kosovo has been devastated by the brutal Serbian assault, the peace plan effectively strips administration of the province from Slobodan Milosevic and opens the way for the safe resettlement of the ethnic Albanian refugees.

title: House G.O.P. Pushes Bills to Increase Patient's Rights but Keep Curbs on Suing H.M.O.'s
description: With Democrats stepping up the pressure for Congress to overhaul the managed-care system, several influential House Republicans introduced a package of legislation today that would increase the rights of patients but would not remove the high hurdles to suing managed-care providers.

title: With Signs Of Retreat, Raids Slow To Near Halt
description: With the formal agreement by the Yugoslav military to allow an international peacekeeping force to enter the embattled Kosovo province, NATO air strikes came to a virtual halt this morning.

title: Footprints May Be Oldest In Europe, French Say
description: In the darkness of an underground cave lined with prehistoric paintings, French scientists believe they have discovered the oldest footprints of humans in Europe.

title: The Big City; Health Law That Exceeds The Need
description: LAST July, shortly after Rubyat Islam, a 6-year-old girl, immigrated from Bangladesh, a blood test showed she had an abnormally high level of lead. In November, after studying the case, the city's Department of Health ordered some changes at Rubyat's home, a one-bedroom apartment in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILAR, M. THELMA
description: VILAR-M. Thelma, Retiree of Sperry Gyroscope. Devoted daughter of the late Rachel and Manuel. Survived by her brother Vincent and sister-in-law Muriel. Loving sister of the late William Lopez, Violet Kane and Eunice Sposato. Loving aunt and greataunt. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, New York City, Saturday and Sunday, 25 and 7-9 PM. Interment Monday, Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIUME, SOL
description: FIUME-Sol. With deep sorrow we mourn the passing of Sol Fiume, a dear friend of the Home. Beloved husband of Sarah. Loving father of Darryl and Gayle Fiume and Valerie and Roberto Carvalho. Devoted grandfather of Sammantha, Steve, Shane and Spencer. Sol and Sarah received the 1991 Couple of the Year Award for their commitment on behalf of the elderly. We extend sincere condolences to Sarah and the entire family. Officers and Board of Directors of Sephardic Home and Ladies Auxiliary (LASHA) Robert A. Cohen, President Ralph J. Kamhi, Chair of Board Michael New, Exec Director Marion Crespi, President LASHA Reggie Goldberg, Ch Brd LASHA

title: Sports of The Times; Togetherness Can't Offset Camby's Flair
description: LATRELL SPREWELL rambling across the lane and finding Larry Johnson spotting up in the right corner for an open 3. Allan Houston penetrating and hitting Marcus Camby for an acrobatic stuff. Patrick Ewing watching his team light up Market Square Arena for 36 fourth-quarter points and turning to shake his head and tell those loud-mouthed fans behind the Knicks bench, ''We're not coming back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Growing Real Gherkins

title: Coming Of Age In Palo Alto
description: IN 1981, while doing postdoctoral field work in cultural anthropology, Bonnie A. Nardi lived with villagers in Western Samoa, trying to understand the cultural reasons that people there have an average of eight children.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of a front-page article about diplomatic efforts to end the conflict over Kosovo reversed the identities of two men shown with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov of Russia was at the right; Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany was in the center.

title: Man Tortured Wife for 7 Hours, Police Say
description: A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with torturing his wife for seven hours at their home in Bay Ridge, critically injuring her, the police said.

title: Clinton Faults House G.O.P. Gun Measures
description: President Clinton assailed House Republicans' gun-control proposals today as flawed measures that had been ''plainly ghostwritten'' by the National Rifle Association, which he said was successfully whittling away at the modest new restrictions on firearms approved by the Senate last month.

title: China Suspends Cultural Exchanges After NATO's Embassy Attack
description: After years of negotiations with Chinese cultural representatives, the American Ballet Theater was close to a deal last month to piggyback five performances in Beijing onto a July tour of Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISIN, ALBERT
description: RAISIN-Albert. Age 77. On June 9, 1999. Our Dad and beloved husband of Audrey. Entrepreneur, aviator and instigator. His warmth, humor and love will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Carrie Bellware, Steven and Matthew Kaiser

title: Quantum Code: Secrets in the Light
description: THE world of codes, ciphers and secrets has always been a bit of a battleground for the mathematicians and the physicists. The mathematicians, who have dominated the realm recently, have offered to keep E-mail, credit card numbers and other Internet traffic safe with a set of elaborate equations that are just too complicated for anyone to ever break.

title: Motorola and Sun to Build Joint System for Fast Net Access
description: Motorola Inc., one of the world's largest makers of wireless communications equipment, and Sun Microsystems Inc., which is best known for its Solaris operating systems and the Java programming language, said today that they were teaming up to create a new wireless network to provide high-speed Internet access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, STANLEY E., MD.
description: BRADLEY-Stanley E., MD. Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and New York Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of Stanley E. Bradley, Bard Professor Emeritus of Medicine. His long distinguished career with Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center began as an Assistant Professor of Medicine in 1947. An esteemed colleague and teacher, he served Columbia-Presbyterian for more than eleven years as Samuel Bard Professor and Chairman of the Department of Medicine and Director of the Medical Service of The Presbyterian Hospital. Recognized throughout the world as an outstanding scientist and clinical investigator, he made many outstanding contributions to medical education, research, and clinical care, particularly in the field of nephrology and hepatology. He was a trusted advisor to generations of medical students and faculty. A long-time friend and colleague whose many contributions enriched the Department of Medicine, he wiil be greatly missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Dr. Geraldine Bradley, and his daughter, Dr. Jane Alavi. Herbert Pardes, MD Vice President for Health Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons David B. Skinner, MD Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of New York Presbyterian Hospital Myron L. Weisfeldt, MD Samuel Bard Professor of Medicine and Chairman of the Department of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and Director of the Medical Service at Columbia Presbyterian

title: Crafts Fair And Work By Artists
description: Crafts Festival

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: City Hall Memo; When It Comes to Humor, Giuliani Takes His Job Seriously
description: So this guy walks into a strip club.

title: Internet Anxiety Seizes Britons
description: It's a mad world, book publishing, that's bound to go down. At least it always views itself in tatters. Surely, for instance, the invention of bookstore chains means the end of independent sellers. (Just as the idea of selling books in supermarkets meant the end of bookstores.) Or that huge author advances would kill off publishers. Or that international publishing conglomerates would kill off the huge advances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: It's June: Class Trip to the White House
description: The Yankees will be honored for their 1998 championship at the White House on Thursday, nearly eight months after Scott Brosius fielded the final out of the World Series. Each member of the team has his own perspective on the visit, of course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: A Phone for the Internet: More Speed, Less Glare
description: Last year, Infogear, a start-up company, introduced its iPhone, a phone for the Web with built-in E-mail and browsing software. The new generation, the iPhone Series 2000, is a marked improvement.

title: Pacers Being Shown Glimpse of the Future
description: As he was about to shoot and make a free throw to seal Game 5, Latrell Sprewell was hit with a barrage of chants from the less-than-tactful Market Square Arena crowd. ''Choke! Choke! Choke!'' the crowd yelled, an obvious reference to the incident that led to Sprewell's exile from pro basketball last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, PAULA
description: POLLACK-Paula. Beloved sister of Ruth Hoffman, Irene Shulkin and the late Miriam Engel and Marty Pollack. Adored aunt of Fran Swirsky, Richard Hoffman, Linda Brenner, Martin Engel and Renee Shulkin. Devoted grand aunt and great grand aunt. Energetic, sharp and independent to the end. Aunt Paula, we will love & keep you in our hearts forever.

title: Plastic Cuffs for Prisoners in Hospital
description: The New York Police Department took steps yesterday to protect its officers from a little-known peril: the danger that they could be electrocuted while guarding hospitalized prisoners who are defibrillated while handcuffed to metal bed frames.

title: For Couples Stuck on 'Something Old'
description: For brides who cherish the old and one-of-a-kind instead of the new and mass-produced, Basil Lawrence, an antiques store on the Upper East Side, has opened a bridal registry. The idea came from a friend who bought some of her wedding porcelain there, said the owner, Lawrence Santorelli. (The Basil in the shop's name comes from a dear-departed Jack Russell terrier.) Whimsical eight-inch 1920's ceramic teapots (drawn left and right) are $40 each. A 10-inch French cream-colored ceramic ladle (right, $50) dates from the 1930's. Basil Lawrence is at 1103 First Avenue (60th Street). Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., Monday through Friday; and on Saturday, by appointment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSEN, GAYNOR
description: JACOBSEN-Gaynor. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Gaynor Jacobsen of Phoenix, Arizona. Gaynor's work saved lives and played a critical role in Jewish history. Principled and esteemed, his contribution and sacrifice will never be forgotten. Our condolences to his wife, Florence and the family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Executive VP Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, Chairman of Board

title: Some Kosovar Albanians Doubt They Will Ever Go Home
description: There may be a relative peace in the Balkans, but the 120,000 Kosovar Albanian refugees who have staggered across the border into this hot, dusty and rubble-strewn mountain town are still anxious about how they will ever safely go home again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, HERMAN S., MD.
description: ALPERT-Herman S., MD. On June 10, 1999. Distinguished psychiatrist in private practice since 1947. Member of the attending and teaching staff of Mt. Sinai Hospital and School of Medicine. Beloved husband of Harriet and the late Eileen. Loving father of Cheryl Alpert Sofer, Jeffrey Alpert, Marjorie Lesnik Karp and Peter Lesnik. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services Sunday 10 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Department of Psychiatry of Mount Sinai Hospital or Temple Shaary Tefila.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Vision Gear For the Dark And Stormy
description: AFTER a long day of work as a mechanical engineer, Tom Malphus likes to hop onto his mountain bike and head into the hills around San Diego to blow off steam. Mission Park provides a rugged setting, with off-road trails, wide-open spaces and wildlife. And even after dark, Mr. Malphus sees it all, with the power of his night vision goggles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ST. LOUIS, MARIE
description: ST. LOUIS-Marie. Of New York, passed away June 10, 1999 after a brave struggle with cancer. She is survived by her son Marc St.Louis, her daughter-in-law Patrice Rushen and grandson Cameron, and her brother Jack Barrow. Born in Boston on April 5, 1928, attended Girls' High School and Simmons College. She worked for 37 years for Festival Productions, Inc., the company who created the Newport Jazz Festival among other major international jazz festivals. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 16 at 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., N.Y., N.Y. Burial is private in Great Barrington, MA. Donations in the name of Marie St. Louis may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: William E. Ryan, 78, Prosecutor Who Aided Case on Hoffa in '64
description: William Everest Ryan, a Federal prosecutor who in the 1960's helped obtain the criminal conviction of James R. Hoffa, the teamsters' president, died on May 28 at a health care center in Baltimore. He was 78 and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Ex-Chief of Yale Appointed As Vice Chairman of CUNY
description: Having presented a sweeping new blueprint for the future of the City University of New York, Benno C. Schmidt Jr. will now join its board of trustees as vice chairman. The appointment, announced yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki, will give Mr. Schmidt the unusual opportunity to try to shape the university along the lines he suggested in a just-released report as chairman of the Mayor's task force on CUNY.

title: A Virus Charts a New Course Using E-Mail and Chat Rooms
description: Another virus bent on rummaging through your electronic address book has turned up in recent weeks. Pretty Park, like the notorious Melissa, finds its new victims by picking up E-mail addresses that are stored in an infected computer's address book and sending itself to dozens of your friends and family members.

title: Cable and Wireless Wins Fight for Japan Phone Carrier
description: Japan's first hostile takeover battle pitting a foreign suitor against a domestic corporate titan ended in victory today for the outsider, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, which gained enough support to guarantee it majority control of International Digital Communications, a struggling telephone carrier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Teen-Ager Held in Murder Escapes From Bronx Detention Center
description: A 16-year-old Manhattan youth who was being held on murder charges escaped Tuesday night from a recently opened juvenile detention center in the Bronx, officials said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Orders Investigation On Possible Racial Profiling
description: Declaring racial profiling ''morally indefensible,'' President Clinton today ordered Federal law-enforcement agencies to compile data on the race and ethnicity of people they question, search or arrest to determine whether suspects are stopped because of the color of their skin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: William Hess, 82, Microbiologist and Expert on African Swine Fever
description: William R. Hess, a microbiologist and a leading expert in African swine fever, died on May 29 at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. He was 82, and lived in Tuftonboro, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Prudential Set To Buy Vector
description: Prudential Securities said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Vector Securities International, a full-service investment banking firm specializing in health care and life sciences.

title: State Trooper Is Cleared Of Misconduct Charges
description: A state trooper who had been accused of pressuring a motorist to bare her breasts was acquitted of all charges yesterday.

title: A Different Kind of Mouse To the Ergonomical Rescue
description: The latest entrant to enter the carpal tunnel battle is a mouse that looks as if it has a pen stuck into its back. The device, called Dr. Mouse, looks more like a World War II movie fighter's joystick than a standard mouse, with a handle sticking up and mouse buttons instead of a trigger.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEPPARD, DR. H.L.
description: SHEPPARD-Dr. H.L. (Shep). 6/11/ 92. 7 years. Remembered with love today and everyday by all who loved you.

title: LVMH TAKES LEGAL ACTION
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. is filing two separate legal actions against Gucci Group N.V. and Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A. in Amsterdam, reigniting its battle for control of the Italian fashion company. In a suit filed in Amsterdam District Court, LVMH is seeking to annul an alliance that gives Pinault 42 percent of Gucci. It is also appealing to the Dutch Supreme Court to overturn the Enterprise Chamber of the Amsterdam Court of Appeals' decision on May 27 to uphold the alliance. Gucci issued a statement saying it ''notes with regret'' LVMH's action and said it was designed to take the sheen off of Gucci's first-quarter results.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pat

title: No Bikes, No Fun, No Adventure
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; An Appeal for Repeal
description: Amendment II: A well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ARTHUR G.
description: LEWIS-Arthur G. On June 9, 1999 of Setauket, L.I., NY. Beloved husband of Karin Perley Lewis. Cherished father of Michele and James Lynch, Arthur, Jr. and Mary Lewis, Amy and Robert Howard and Matthew and Patricia Lewis. Dear grandfather of Ashley, Zachary and Matthew. Reposing at O. B. Davis Funeral Homes, 48-39 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, L.I. Visitation Thursday 2-4 and 7-10. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30AM at St. James RC Church in Setauket. title: Narita Journal; Thanks to Farmers, Airport Grows Like Bonsai
description: When he feeds his chickens or tends his eggplants beside the huge jumbo jets at Narita International Airport, Shoji Shimamura seems a puny, Quixotic figure with all the chance of victory of a mosquito challenging an elephant.

title: U.S. TIMBERLANDS UNIT BUYING BOISE CASCADE FOREST LAND
description: The U.S. Timberlands Company said yesterday that its U.S. Timberlands Yakima L.L.C. unit would buy 56,000 acres of forest for $60 million from the Boise Cascade Corporation, the paper producer, to increase the range of wood types it offers. U.S. Timberlands, based in New York, had revenue of $71.3 million last year. It expects the purchase to increase its holdings by 23 percent. The forest consists mostly of Douglas fir and ponderosa pine trees. Boise Cascade said that the timberland represented about 4 percent of its holdings in the Northwest and that it would use the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt. Shares of U.S. Timberlands rose 62.5 cents, to $13.50, while Boise Cascade was unchanged at $40.75.

title: Approaches to Vulnerability Seal a Tournament Victory
description: After a week of concentrated effort for those who survived, the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship ended in Manhattan on Sunday in a victory for Adam Wildavsky, Martin Fleisher, Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian. In a well played final at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, they won by 25 imps against Alan Miller, Alex Ornstein, Aaron Silverstein, Brady Richter, R. Jay Becker and Ira Herman.

title: A Tour In the Gardens
description: Roses and Tropicals

title: Childs Makes a Prediction
description: Most of the Knicks were playing it close to the vest before the pivotal Game 5, but Chris Childs was his usual blustery and confident self. The Knicks' reserve point guard predicted his teammates would come out more hungry than they did in Game 1, a New York victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEK, PRISCILLA MCKNIGHT
description: MEEK-Priscilla McKnight, 99, died June 6, 1999, of natural causes. Born August 15, 1899, Mrs. Meek not only watched but participated in some of the world-changing events of the last century. As head of the Greenwich, CT, Foreign Relief Committee during World War II, she spearheaded the effort to send thousands of tons of clothing and medical supplies in the famous Bundles for Britain war effort. She also was an active member of the Red Cross Motor Corps of Greenwich during the war and showed great compassion toward those less fortunate with her efforts over the course of 30 years as a member of the Refugee Committee of Christ Church. Through her work, hundreds of refugees were housed and employed. Born in 1899 in Stonington, CT, to Ormesby McKnight and Elizabeth Philips Mitchel, she married Samuel Williams Meek, who would become an advertising legend, on October 14, 1921. Mr. Meek, a Vice President at the J. Walter Thompson Company, oversaw a huge 39-year foreign expansion at the company, with Mrs. Meek beside him all the way. After years abroad with JWT, they settled in Greenwich, where Mrs. Meek continued her passion for good works and the outdoors, becoming a grand dame of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and an active member of the Audubon Society. Her husband, who died in 1981, served on the board of the Connecticut Bank & Trust Company and was elected to the Advertising Hall of Fame. Mrs. Meek is survived by three daughters, a son, 17 grandchildren and 30 great-grandchildren. Her life will be celebrated in July with a memorial service to be held at Christ Church in Greenwich. Donations in her memory should be made to The Nature Conservancy, 1815 N. Lynn St., Arlington, VA 22209; or the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue, New York, New York.

title: Editorial Observer; How Long Does It Take to Make a New Yorker?
description: New York's infant United States Senate race has no official candidates, but it does have an issue. Hillary Rodham Clinton has fewer local roots than a giant cactus, and her potential opponents are already playing the carpetbagger card. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani keeps demanding to know how Arkansas voters would feel if he ran for their Senate seat -- a question that probably depends on how many Arkansans have seen pictures of the New York City Mayor's performance in drag as ''Rudy/Rudia.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLL, FLORENCE (NEE YONDORF)
description: KROLL-Florence (nee Yondorf). On June 10, 1999 at the age of 80 of Rye, NY, formerly of Bayside and Bedford NY, and Cranbury, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Herman, loving mother of Daniel, Nancy Kroll Margolis, Susan Kroll-Smith, and Jules, adoring grandmother of Aimee, Kara, Seth, Nicholas, Vanessa, Dana and Jeremy, devoted mother-in-law of Paul, Terry and Lynn, cherished sister-in-law of Bea and Hy Michaels. A fine, compassionate, unpretentious woman, Florence was warm and funloving with great inner strength and a keen sense of humor. She achieved her fondest amibitions: to be a good wife, mother and grandmother. She was a Vice President of Bayside Jewish Center Sisterhood. She was an artist, and in her youth a beauty queen and a member of the Jamaica High School Swim Team. Florence was a beautiful woman in face and spirit and had a strong, independent character. She never complained and always did her best. She was loved by all who knew her. She will be loved and missed by her family with every passing day and will be in our hearts forever. Service Friday, at 12 noon at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Internment will follow at Beth Moses Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Hospice Of Westchester or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Republicans Revive Bid to Bar Peacekeeper Funds
description: House Republicans, backed by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, today revived attempts to bar funds for American peacekeeping troops in Kosovo.

title: Zone by Zone: 11 Days to Serbs' Withdrawal and Occupation by NATO
description: Under the provisions of the Balkans military agreement reached today, Yugoslavia is to withdraw its 40,000 troops from Kosovo along four designated routes within 11 days to permit the rapid entry of a NATO security force into the besieged province.

title: RICHFOOD TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $883 MILLION
description: Supervalu Inc., one of the country's largest distributors of food to supermarkets, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Richfood Holdings Inc. for about $883 million in cash and stock to build its mid-Atlantic business. Under the deal, Supervalu would pay $18.50 a share in cash and stock for each Richfood share and assume about $642 million in debt. Richfood, a big food distributor in the mid-Atlantic region, also runs about 100 supermarkets in Maryland, Virginia and Washington. The company, based in Richmond, had $3.2 billion in revenue in the 1998 fiscal year. Supervalu, based in Minneapolis, said the combined company would have about $20.8 billion in annual sales, and would operate 36 distribution centers, 296 supermarkets and 151 limited-assortment stores. Shares of Richfood rose $2, to $16.875; Supervalu gained 50 cents, to $24.8125.

title: Train (and Taxi) to Plane
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MICHEL, MARY
description: MICHEL-Mary. 13 years, and we still miss you so much. Girls searching in Mexico. Love, all of us.

title: Los Angeles Reinvents Itself, Adopting New City Charter
description: Voters have approved the most sweeping changes in Los Angeles government in three-quarters of a century, discarding the 1925 city charter in favor of a new document that increases the power of the mayor, creates a system of neighborhood advisory councils and gives local communities some control of planning and zoning.

title: Bankers Trust Staff Leaving Deutsche Bank
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. has shed some top Bankers Trust executives and traders after completing the $9 billion purchase of the bank last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Equitable Coverage for Mental Illness
description: President Clinton has announced that he will require Federal employee health plans that cover nine million people to provide the same coverage for mental illness and substance abuse that they do for other diseases. Congress should expand upon that sensible and humane step by requiring mental health parity in all group insurance plans.

description: There was a driving layup by Latrell Sprewell that glanced off the rim and hung in the air like a bubble. The ball was right there, for anyone who wanted it.

title: By Gehry: Creased, but Sleekly
description: The architect Frank O. Gehry crumpled some silver paper to design an anodized aluminum chair named FOG (his initials). ''We wanted to have an indoor-outdoor chair that reflected his current views on architecture -- read, 'Bilbao,' '' said Carl Magnusson, director of design at Knoll. The chair was introduced this week at Neocon, the office furniture show in Chicago. It can be ordered in September, armless ($625) or with arms ($725); (212) 343-4000.

title: An Urban Oasis for Confucius to Ponder
description: TO understand the profound beauty of the New York Chinese Scholar's Garden, you must leave your Western mind at the gate. Do not go looking for masses of flowers and spectacular color in this garden, which opens on Saturday at the Staten Island Botanical Garden. It is a study of shadows on white walls, stones rising to the sky and the ripple of sunlight on water.

description: Managers from Cathay Pacific Airways and representatives of the Hong Kong airline's pilot union spent more than eight hours today in pay negotiations that industry analysts said were unlikely to avoid a wave of pilot resignations and dismissals on Friday.

Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Education and Resources Program of the New York University School of Medicine are profoundly saddened by the passing of Zachary Fisher. Mr. Fisher's generosity, personal kindness and vision enabled the creation of our program which has permitted us to articulate a new science of Alzheimer's Disease management and to disseminate this information worldwide. All victims of Alzheimer's Disease and their loved ones have lost a true and wonderful friend and ally. Barry Reisberg, M.D., Dir. Sunnie Kenowsky, D.V.M., Co-Director Emile Franssen, M.D. Liduin E.M. Souren, R.N., M.S.N. and our fellow program scientists

title: Hillary Clinton, Visiting Binghamton, Praises Technology
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped gingerly into her apparent political campaign today, taking questions from workers at an electronics plant and mixing with contributors at a fund-raising reception for a Democratic Congressman. It was Mrs. Clinton's first trip to New York State since she announced plans to form an exploratory committee to consider running for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, ALPERT, M.D.
description: HERMAN-Alpert, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our beloved colleague and dedicated member of the Department of Psychiatry for over 50 years. Dr. Alpert was a founding member of the Division of Group Psychotherapy and had a distinguished career in the army as a psychiatrist in World War II. He continued to play a major role in the area of Group Therapy and was also actively involved in teaching residents and students at Mount Sinai. He will best be remembered for his thoughtfulness, sense of humor and great spirit. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Testing, The Easy Target
description: In case you missed it, the Federal Department of Education may have signaled the end of standardized testing, from college boards to elementary school assessments. This certainly seems the intent of guidelines issued last month by the department's Office of Civil Rights warning of the potentially discriminatory impact of ''high-stakes testing.'' If the guidelines are approved, it will be hard to justify using tests to sort students at any age for any purpose.

title: Woman Dies in Brooklyn As Cement Truck Hits Her
description: A 71-year-old woman was hit and killed yesterday morning in Brooklyn by a cement truck carrying an illegally heavy load on a street that is off limits to trucks, the police said.

title: Aura of Invincibility Shrinks Gifts to Bush Rivals
description: Fund-raising is a bountiful feast for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas while most of the other Republican Presidential contenders are fighting among themselves for table scraps.

title: North and South Korea Boats Confront Each Other in a Standoff
description: For the second day in a row, North Korean and South Korean military vessels confronted each other in a standoff today. Each side accused the other of intruding into its own waters.

title: JAPAN'S ECONOMY GROWS
description: Akitaka Saiki, a spokesman for Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, left, told reporters that the Ministry of Finance had told him on an informal basis that the Japanese economy grew slightly in the first quarter. His comment coincided with revised forecasts for economic growth for the January through March period from several major financial institutions, as economists factored signs of somewhat more robust corporate spending into their models. The Economic Planning Agency will release first-quarter gross domestic product figures today. Stephanie Strom

We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: If Elected, Bush Says, He'll Oppose Tax Increase
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has broken with his practice of keeping his views on controversial national issues under wraps until he officially begins his Presidential campaign by promising that if he is elected President, he will try to block any proposed tax increase.

title: Global Chip Sales Are Expected to Rise
description: Global semiconductor sales are expected to rise 12.1 percent this year, marking the first time the industry will post double-digit percentile growth since 1995, a trade group said.

title: BACTERIAL FALLOUT
description: A theory of progress says that for every technological advance, there is an unintended consequence. Some researchers recently discovered some particularly unsavory reverse effects. Bug-zappers, the devices hung around backyards in barbecue season, do kill flies and mosquitoes, but they also cause airborne bacteria and virus-laden particles from the insect's surface area and digestive canal to rain down. ''We're finding really significant amounts on the surface of the fly will survive,'' said James Urban, an associate professor of biology at Kansas State, in a press release.

title: Fisher Will Yield as Kodak's Chief Executive
description: In a statement whose timing, if not its content, surprised many, the Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that Daniel A. Carp, 51, would succeed George M. C. Fisher as chief executive on Jan. 1. Mr. Fisher, who is 58, will remain chairman until his contract expires on Dec. 31, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members.
