His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Microsoft Trial Witness Undergoes Tough Cross-Examination
description: Under sharp questioning by a Microsoft lawyer, an I.B.M. executive conceded today that none of the Microsoft contract proposals he read had stated that I.B.M. must stop shipping its OS/2 operating system to get a favorable price for Windows, Microsoft's competing operating system.

title: RENTAL SERVICE, UP FOR SALE, AGAIN SPURNS HOSTILE BID
description: The Rental Service Corporation, a leading equipment-rental company, said yesterday that it was for sale and again rejected a hostile offer by the rival United Rentals Inc. as insufficient. Rental Service, of Scottsdale, Ariz., said it had authorized its advisers to provide confidential information about the company to interested third parties, and again asked shareholders to reject the United Rentals bid. On April 5, United Rentals, based in Greenwich, Conn., offered to pay $22.75 a share, or about $553 million, in cash and assume $810 million in debt. At the time, the bid was a 32 percent premium to Rental Service's share price. The shares closed yesterday at $23.6875, down 18.75 cents, while United Rentals slipped 43.75 cents, to $25.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARASEK, FLORENCE ERB
description: KARASEK-Florence Erb. Of Toms River, NJ on Monday, June 7. Age 71. Mother of Dave Evan, dear sister of Elaine McBride, mother-in-law of Wilann Spiccia, loving grandmother of two grandchildren, and special friend of Beatrice Handell. Memorial service Sunday, June 13 at 12 PM at the art studio at Rossmoor, Route 32, Jamesburg, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the Monroe Chapter of Hadassah or the Rossmoor Jewish Congregation. For more information contact BelkoffGoldstein Funeral Chapel, Lakewood, New Jersey, 732-364-0900.

title: Panel Studies Freshman Eligibility in Basketball
description: Since 1972, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has allowed freshmen to play on varsity teams in all sports. That may change for major schools, which play in Division I, because college officials are concerned that fewer male basketball players are graduating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDNER, DAVID
description: SEIDNER-David. The American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) mourns the loss of our talented and generous friend, a leading light in the world of art and fashion, and an outspoken advocate in the fight against AIDS. A world - renowned photographer, David was an early supporter of Art Against AIDS and donated numerous works to benefit amfAR. His moving portraits of famous people living with HIV/AIDS also helped build awareness and galvanize support for the Foundation's AIDS research programs. His creative energy and generosity of spirit will be sorely missed. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D. Founding Co-Chair and Chairman of the Board American Foundation for AIDS Research

title: Lockheed Says Profit May Fall Significantly In Next 2 Years
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, has had a streak of bad luck in the air. Orders for its C-130J cargo plane -- the one seen delivering arms and supplies to global hot spots -- are sagging and its satellites have been launched, and then flopped.

title: One's Relaxed and Soulful, The Other Restless and Sharp
description: Joe Lovano and Greg Osby have very different approaches to playing single notes, which affect their rhythm and their whole sound. Mr. Lovano's tenor saxophone notes are relaxed and smeary, and his phrases tumble out naturally, with meaningful pauses and weight; he's the kind of player you don't hesitate to call soulful. Mr. Osby's alto saxophone notes come in sharply defined, self-contained dots, and in fast improvisations he keeps altering his flow, catching himself and reversing whatever pattern of strong and weak beats that he has just established.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Starring in Your Own 'Rear Window'
description: THE real moon never shines into our bedroom in Murray Hill, but Manhattan gives us a moon of a different, more predictable kind, and my wife and I designed our bedroom around it. We positioned our headboard against the north wall so that as we drifted off to sleep we could see the Empire State Building, in Technicolor, reflected at night in the glassy wall of a high-rise a couple of addresses away.

title: France's Vivendi in Polish Joint Venture
description: In a major new challenge to Poland's dominant telephone company, Vivendi S.A. of France has agreed to invest about $750 million in a joint venture with Elektrim S.A.

title: A Bit of the Renaissance for a Harlem Preschool
description: A new preschool in Harlem has a Renaissance-inspired garden. Appointed with a fountain and contemplative benches, it is verdant with ferns, bamboo and clematis.

title: Light Touch of Danish Greats Sets Tone for a Downtown Shop
description: Lisbeth Rasmussen abandoned acting to open Lisbeth & Company downtown, specializing in American and European design of the 1920's to the 1940's. Classics from her native Denmark include Kaare Klint's 1930's leather sofa (she's sitting on it, left, $7,500) and his safari chairs, both new and vintage (above, $840 to $1,600). A 1930's French letter holder, below, is part of a desk set ($295); a 1940's Italian silver plate coffee set is $395. The shop, at 259 Elizabeth Street (Houston Street), is open noon to 7 P.M., except Monday: (212) 966-9559.

title: Resetting Household Chips
description: To the Editor:

title: Designers Sell Flowers And Tables to Put Them On
description: ''We're called the Roberts,'' Robert Palomo said. He and his business partner, Robert Bardin, provide party design, flowers (to customers like Bergdorf Goodman and Sotheby's) and, now, old and new furniture at their west Chelsea storefront. They moved into the former taxi garage last month, keeping the concrete floor and putting concrete over the walls, for coolness. A 450-pound granite table, 42 by 90 inches, left, on a stainless steel base is $9,000. The five-foot-tall wrought-iron candlesticks, circa 1900, are $800 for the pair. Metal planters, right, are $200 to $400; ceramic vases are $50 to $300. The shop is at 524 West 19th Street; (212) 989-6113.

title: Newark Joins Cities Suing Gun Makers
description: The City of Newark sued 29 gun makers yesterday in the United States and abroad, joining Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland and New Orleans in the growing list of municipalities that have sought reparations from gun manufacturers.

title: Chase Manhattan Relocation Puts 2,000 L.I. Jobs in Doubt
description: Chase Manhattan Bank plans to relocate two customer service centers from Jericho, N.Y., to cities in Texas, Arizona and Florida, bank officials said yesterday, in a move that leaves 2,000 workers in doubt about their future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, MURIEL LEVINSON
description: STEINBERG-Muriel Levinson. On June 9, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Nathan Steinberg. Loving mother of Gail and Michael Hasson. Devoted grandmother of Dr. Loren and Dr. Bruce Frankel and David Fleisig. Cherished great-grandmother of Brendon and Hanna. Funeral Friday 11AM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: Office 2000 Is Well Connected
description: OFFICE 2000, which hit the shelves this week, is a complete overhaul of Microsoft's suite of so-called productivity applications and offers many new features -- and, predictably, a few new irritations. But its most remarkable innovation is the way the entire family of applications seamlessly interacts with the Internet, in essence recasting cyberspace as the World Wide Hard Drive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: A $25 Piece of Molded Plastic Turns a Monitor Into a Canvas
description: Sure, the iMac looks great out of the box, but once it's covered by Post-It notes and coffee cups, it starts to resemble other desktops. A new product can give a desktop, iMac or not, the curved, cluttered look of more expensive computers.

title: Writing About Race, Walking On Eggshells
description: The topic was ''Blasphemy: What You Can't Say Today in America.'' The setting was a panel sponsored by the writers' organization PEN, and blasphemy was being quite broadly defined as irreverent or insulting treatment of anything held sacred. But we are such a disparate, segmented society that there is no such thing as one standard. One group's blasphemy is another's piety. Trouble comes when you offend someone with the legal, financial or cultural power to censor and ostracize you.

title: Again, Talk of a Charter Revision Panel
description: The City Charter was once a document that city officials dared tinker with only once or twice a decade, for fear that they might disturb the delicate balance of power that it laid out for the municipal government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: BellSouth May Buy Larger Qwest Stake
description: The BellSouth Corporation, which provides local phone services in nine Southeastern states, said it was considering buying Qwest Communications International Inc. or increasing its stake in the long-distance phone company.

title: Lawsuit Dismissed Against Claiborne
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday accusing Liz Claiborne Inc. and a union of defrauding a supplier of sweaters for Claiborne.

title: AT&T Small Business Plan
description: The AT&T Corporation introduced a calling plan for small businesses today that offered a flat monthly rate for five to 50 users. The plan, called Group Calling, is available through three service plans, with prices starting at $49.99 per month per subscriber. It includes wireless voice mail with text messaging and caller ID at no additional charge. AT&T said Group Calling would be available in all major markets by the end of the year. The new calling plan will compete directly with Nextel Communications Inc., which serves business users.

title: For Serbs in Kosovo, Frustration and Anger
description: Todor is a soldier, a factory worker from northern Serbia who volunteered to come here to Kosovo and defend it for his country.

title: From Racial Guilt to Political Score-Settling, Onstage in Chicago
description: A traditional liberal arts education is the bill of fare at fictional Belmont College, the prudently progressive New England institution at the center of Rebecca Gilman's play ''Spinning Into Butter.'' Yet there is one subject in which the school excels that is not advertised in the course catalogue: white guilt.

title: Russian in Cologne Provides the Key to Unlock Macedonian Impasse
description: The deadlock between Yugoslav and NATO military officials negotiating in a tent on the barren Macedonia border was finally broken after some sharp exchanges nearly a thousand miles away in an elaborate 15th-century meeting hall.

title: On the Internet, Fame Becomes Fortune
description: The two most important business terms of the late 1990's seem to be ''brand'' and ''Internet.'' The application of either term seems to naturally generate success, while combining the two often appears to be a recipe for instant wealth.

title: Enormous Haze Found Over Indian Ocean
description: Scientists have discovered to their surprise that a haze of air pollution about the size of the United States covers the Indian Ocean in the wintertime, and they say it may have important implications for global climate and the regional environment of both Asia and the tropical ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIASBERG, KATHERINE (MCMAHON)
description: ELIASBERG-Katherine (McMahon). Beloved wife of the late Robert and the late Tiffany Thayer. Loving sister of Maureen Croom-Johnson and late brothers John, James and Frank. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, June 11th, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday June 12th, 10:30AM, St. John the Evangelist, 1st Avenue at 55th St.

title: Intelligent Microwave Ovens Would 'Zap' Food to Perfection
description: KIT KEITH YAM, a food-science professor at Rutgers University, is not impressed with today's microwave ovens. They do an acceptable job of warming a cup of coffee, he said, but they fail miserably at cooking food that requires different heating levels for different time periods. And it is a rare day when they can pop popcorn without leaving a layer of stubborn kernels at the bottom of the bag.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; INFLATION SLOWS IN MEXICO
description: Mexico's May inflation of six-tenths of a percent was the smallest monthly increase in consumer prices since November 1994, the month before the country's economy was devastated by an abrupt 40 percent currency devaluation. The peso's strength against the dollar and low energy prices have contributed to this year's falling inflation, and the central bank's forecast of 13 percent inflation in 1999 seems more realistic now than at this year's start, economists say. Except for several years in the early 1990's, annual inflation in Mexico since 1982 has been double digit, and at times, triple digit. Rick Wills

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: 2 Shops Involved In Stock Sales
description: Two agencies were involved yesterday in sales of stock.

title: Corrections
description: Articles yesterday and last Friday and Saturday about Capt. Vincent Fowler, a firefighter who died in a burning Queens building on June 3, misstated his age. He was 45, not 46 or 47.

title: 80 Years Later, Moscow Declares Four Romanovs 'Not Guilty'
description: More than 80 years after they died at the hands of Bolshevik executioners, the son of Czar Aleksandr II and three other members of the Romanov dynasty were cleared of wrongdoing tonight by the Prosecutor General, Russia's chief law enforcement officer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Goldman Sachs Fills Post
description: Frank J. Governali, a noted telecommunications analyst from Credit Suisse First Boston, left the securities firm yesterday to go to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. A Credit Suisse First Boston spokesman confirmed Mr. Governali's departure; Goldman officials and Mr. Governali were not immediately available for comment. Mr. Governali -- whose title was managing director -- had covered high-profile companies from AT&T to Global Crossing Ltd.

title: In America; Children in Crisis
description: If you want to see something shaky, take a look at the health of the homeless kids in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts pages yesterday about an exhibition of works by winners of the Pritzker Architecture Prize omitted the site. The show is at the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LILLY INDUSTRIES, Indianapolis, a maker of industrial paints and other coatings, said it would close three United States plants and eliminate 75 jobs, or about 3.3 percent of its work force, by mid-2000 to reduce costs and improve profit.

title: Shocked Pacers Lamenting Another Blown Opportunity
description: The Indiana Pacers slunk out of their own gym tonight, amazingly unnoticed by what remained of their fans, who were preoccupied with booing the jubilant Knicks.

title: Economic Scene; A political remedy for Medicare could become economic poison.
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S plan to revamp Medicare is shaping up as a clever device for election-year politicking. But whether it succeeds as health care policy is unclear.

title: It's Time for the New-Look W.N.B.A.
description: Chamique Holdsclaw had just been made the first pick in the Women's National Basketball Association draft last spring, and already the technicians were scurrying around her. Within five minutes, she was looking into a camera as her carefully styled hair, makeup and wardrobe were beamed out for a league that will use her to launch it on a new trajectory when its regular season opens tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Reuters in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about a possible sale of Global Industrial Technologies misstated the share of Global's stock owned by the WHXCorporation, which has made a hostile takeover offer. About 41 percent of the shares of Global have been tendered to WHX, and 10 percent are owned by WHX; it does not own 41 percent.

title: Evolving Militias; Bring Your Own Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Engineering Food, And Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Fourth Straight Victory Is Stunning
description: The Mets lost Benny Agbayani to a freakish injury in batting practice yesterday, but they didn't need him last night as they staged a stunning comeback for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: CRACK'S LEGACY: A special report.; In States' Anti-Drug Fight, A Renewal for Treatment
description: A thief, a burglar, a gang member, a drug dealer and a mother stepped into a windowless room in this overbaked city one Tuesday afternoon, strip-searched of pride and any material possession that made them somebody outside the brick-walled room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENOWITZ, SOPHIE
description: MENOWITZ-Sophie (1914-1979). Gone but not forgotton these many years. We think of you always. Love from your family who meant so much to you.

title: COACH IN TALKS TO BE BOUGHT FOR AROUND $1 BILLION
description: Coach USA Inc., the charter bus and tour operator, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell itself for about $1 billion. Coach, which did not identify the potential buyer, said the possible transaction would value it at $42 a share, or 35 percent more than Tuesday's closing price of $31.0625. The shares rose $2.4453 yesterday, to $33.50, before trading was halted in late afternoon pending a possible announcement. Coach, based in Houston, had 1998 sales of $803 million.

title: Playing to the Camera Or Right to the Audience; Actors Calibrate Their Craft to the Medium
description: Throughout the Broadway revival of ''Death of a Salesman,'' Brian Dennehy's fingers keep worrying his brow, as if trying to relieve or erase all the burdens bearing down behind it.

title: New Leaders Face a Violent and Splintered Nigeria
description: The trouble began when the 95-year-old Emir died in November after ruling this town in northern Nigeria for 40 years.

title: Digital Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert J. McDonald, Tax Law Expert, 83
description: Robert J. McDonald, a tax lawyer for many years at Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York-based law firm, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Rogues' Gallery; Sneaky Software
description: The first virus known to hit personal computers was called the Brain. Distributed via floppy disks in the mid-1980's, the Brain was relatively innocuous and easy to track. Today, there are an estimated 40,000 computer viruses, many far more harmful. Here are some recent viruses; all of them can be blocked by antivirus software.

title: Strength-Training for Both Body and Mind
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Boy's Battle With AIDS Underlines Hope
description: One of the most beautiful sights you'll see on television this month is the face of Travis Jeffries. All the joy of youth, and some of the wisdom of age, glows from his 200-watt eyes.

title: Terry Winters -- 'Graphic Primitives'
description: Matthew Marks

title: Brawls and Bruises as Stars Even Finals
description: The Stanley Cup finals surged into high gear tonight with a dramatic Dallas victory amid a series of serious developments. The Stars beat Buffalo by 4-2, the winning goal a slap shot by Brett Hull past Dominik Hasek with 2 minutes and 50 seconds remaining to break a 2-2 tie. Their victory evened the four-of-seven-game series at one victory apiece and guaranteed that the championship round would last more than four games for the first time since 1994.

title: Christian Coalition Loses Its Tax Break
description: The Christian Coalition is losing its tax-exempt status because of its political activity and is reorganizing in an effort to retain its influence. The group has been a powerhouse in the Republican Party for a decade, rallying voters behind candidates who support the causes of religious conservatives. But the influence of the coalition has seemed to wane in the last couple of years, and it has had trouble raising money.

title: A Band Clearly From Earth (More Precisely, France)
description: The progressive rock of the 1970's was a magnificent paradox: meticulously ordered music that carried out some of rock's most off-the-wall impulses. It threw together romantic pop and modernist dissonance, complex structures and stretches of improvisation, ethereal reveries and earthy stomps, all in arbitrary proportions that showed off musicians' memories as much as they served the songs. Magma, a French band that played its first New York concert since 1973 at Wetlands on Tuesday night, took those attributes to its own extreme.

title: NATO Expects Separate Kosovo, Without Yugoslav Police or Taxes
description: Although the political future of Kosovo is left vague in the settlement that ended the war, American and NATO officials say they envision an international protectorate that will in theory be part of Yugoslavia but that may well, after a few years, become independent.

title: After Six Failures, Test of Antimissile System Succeeds
description: After a succession of well-publicized failures, the Pentagon announced today that a 20-foot missile had slammed into a test rocket high above the New Mexico desert this morning, a potential breakthrough in the ''Star Wars'' technology intended to protect the United States from missile attack.

title: Show Time for Reluctant Soccer Superstar
description: Every time Mia Hamm steps onto or off a soccer field, the young girls are waiting. They are wearing her No. 9 jersey. Their hair is pulled back into a replica of her ponytail. The cumulative effect is of nesting dolls, each one opening to reveal another inside that is smaller but identical.

title: A pair of large agencies are revamping in an effort to better serve clients around the world.
description: TWO big agencies are embarking on reorganizations that are indicative of the changes being made by Madison Avenue to meet the needs of clients who market products and services globally.

title: SOUTH KOREAN CURRENCY
description: South Korea will require its commercial banks to buy more than $2 billion on the local foreign exchange market to help stem the appreciation of the won, which the Government fears could hamper an export-led economic recovery. Provisions against bad loans denominated in foreign currencies, which are now set aside in won, will have to be converted to dollars or other foreign currencies starting late this month or early July, central bank officials said. The won has risen by about 20 percent against the dollar in the last 12 months. It closed yesterday at 1,167 to the dollar.

title: Price of Night at Movies Is Up 6 Percent, City Says
description: A night out at the movies is steadily becoming more expensive -- and not just because many theaters in Manhattan raised their ticket prices to $9.50 earlier this year. In New York City, a family of four will spend an average of almost $40 for tickets and snacks to see a first-run movie, up 6 percent from last year, according to a survey released yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: While a Roman Gallery Remodels, Caravaggio Visits Hartford
description: Whatever their inconvenience to the local public, museum renovations are great for the circulation of masterpieces. They enable people who live elsewhere to see works that might otherwise elude them.

title: For the Most Hopeful, Plans and Celebration
description: An ebullient Mustaf Domaneku arrived at the main border crossing into Kosovo at 8:45 A.M. today, determined to return home in front of the NATO troops. Nine-year-old Burhan Ferati packed up his toys and clothes in his tent in a refugee camp this morning and announced to his mother, ''I'm preparing to go to Kosovo.''

title: No Headline
City Has Plan to Tame the Traffic in Herald Square
description: After 30 years of failed attempts to tame the traffic in Herald Square, the city is planning to widen sidewalks, add crosswalks, eliminate a lane of traffic and extend islands to make it safer, and a little less nerve-racking, for the 100 million pedestrians who cross the square each year.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Remarks on Balkan War: 'We Have Achieved a Victory'
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's statement on the end of fighting in Kosovo as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Man Accused in Nazi Case Leaves Country
description: A 74-year-old Sullivan County man accused of concealing his wartime past as a guard at three Nazi death camps in Poland renounced his American citizenship and is now living in Germany, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: INTERNATIONAL STRATEGY AND INVESTMENT INC., New York, named James E. Moltz vice chairman. He had been chief investment officer at Deutsche Bank Securities Inc.

title: On My Mind; Fruits of Victory
description: But -- why aren't we celebrating?

title: Sandra Cinto
description: Bonakdar Jancou Gallery

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Pal Helps Out On New Magazine

title: Yield on 30-Year Treasury Keeps Climbing, to 6.06%
description: Argentina's Under Secretary of Finance said yesterday that foreign investors still seemed to be uncomfortable about Latin America, leaving interest rates ''unusually high'' in the region.

title: INSIDE
description: Two Views of Test Results

title: With Boldness and Daring, Van Gundy Is Still Standing
description: Jeff Van Gundy parked his Honda Civic and hustled through a hallway last week, a rumpled bag in his hand that contained a sandwich he bought from the back of a wobbly lunch truck.

title: With Clubhouse Feud Chafing, Mets May Just Release Bonilla
description: In the wake of an intensifying dispute between Manager Bobby Valentine and Bobby Bonilla, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips acknowledged yesterday for the first time that releasing the outfielder is an option the team would have to consider.

title: The Light Says 'Check Engine,' But Just What Does It Mean?
description: SOME drivers call it an ''idiot light,'' and a recent study found that when it lights up on the dashboard people may, in fact, act like idiots.

title: Military Called Needy
description: Prime Minister Sergei V. Stepashin told Parliament today that the military was in ''catastrophic'' condition and in need of money to improve its readiness and the condition of defense industries.

title: Mrs. Clinton May Steal Mayor's Yankee Fan Base
description: Now she's really hit a nerve.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Minnesota Sues U.S. Bank on Privacy Data
description: The State of Minnesota has filed a lawsuit against a unit of U.S. Bancorp contending that it violated Federal and state consumer protection laws by providing customers' financial information to a telemarketing company.

title: Don't Blame Birth Control for Society's Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Cape Town Region Bucks Trend, Thwarts A.N.C.
description: Despite winning the largest share of the vote in the province surrounding Cape Town, the African National Congress has been largely shut out of power there as two traditionally white parties formed a coalition with a tiny religious party.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Energy Department's handling of the Los Alamos nuclear espionage case misidentified the news program on which Ed Curran, the department's chief of counterintelligence, attacked the role of the Senate Intelligence Committee in the situation. It was ABC's ''This Week'' on May 30, not NBC's ''Meet the Press.''

title: 68 Clerics Face Judgment Over a Same-Sex Union
description: When leaders of the United Methodist Church's Northern California and Nevada region meet here on June 15, they will begin grappling with the unusual decision of whether to charge 68 ministers with violating church law for having jointly blessed a same-sex union in January.

title: Leasing-Firm Executive Convicted of Stock Fraud
description: Patrick R. Bennett, the businessman accused of orchestrating one of the largest financial swindles in American history, was convicted yesterday of fraud and money laundering by a Federal jury in Manhattan -- but not of running a Ponzi scheme, a charge that was at the heart of the indictment against him.

title: Shop Smart, and Play Keep-Away
description: Every couple of weeks or so, the Yankees' general manager, Brian Cashman, touches base with other general managers, to see what they are looking for, to see what they are offering. Checking traps, he calls it.

title: Amgen Shares Fall In a Patent Dispute
description: Amgen Inc. shares fell 7 percent today after Transkaryotic Therapies Inc. said it was seeking to reopen a patent dispute over its potential rival to Amgen's blockbuster Epogen.

title: Connecticut Passes Sales-Tax Rebate as Session Ends
description: Reveling in flush times, the Connecticut Legislature adjourned today after passing a $50 sales tax rebate for every adult taxpayer in the state, with checks scheduled to begin arriving in October.

title: Beyond Sushi
description: Japanese restaurants are ever popular in New York and come in many guises. Here are a dozen of the most interesting. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Political Briefing; Imperial Wizard's Popular Voter List
description: Former Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana was quick to criticize Gov. Mike Foster a few weeks back after reports that Mr. Foster had bought a voter mailing list from David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader, during the 1995 governor's race. Mr. Roemer was one of 15 candidates defeated by Mr. Foster in that year's Republican primary.

title: A Rebellious Young Weed, and How He Grew
description: MOAB IS MY WASHPOT

title: South Africa Gains Semifinals
description: South Africa became the first team to qualify yesterday for the World Cup semifinals after a 74-run victory in its Super Six match against New Zealand at Edgbaston in Birmingham, England.

title: Pledge Leads House G.O.P. To Pass Bill For Pentagon
description: President Clinton promised tonight to ask Congress to finance security troops in Kosovo. His last-minute maneuver stopped House Republicans from barring money for the force.

title: Bush to Open in Iowa, Amid Texas-Size Hoopla
description: As big and noisy as the annual Pork Expo is for Iowa this weekend, the arrival there of Gov. George W. Bush as a front-running Presidential candidate who has yet to make his first major national speech is looming even larger.

title: Issues of Gender, From Pronouns to Murder
description: THERE is no really right, widely accepted pronoun for Riki Anne Wilchins. Nor is there the right honorific.

title: Allies Begin Effort To Rebuild Kosovo;Beijing Abstains On UN Resolution : NATO SUspends Air War Amid Serbian Pullout
description: NATO's punishing air war against Yugoslavia ended Thursday, and the 19-nation alliance launched a massive and open-ended effort to secure and rebuild war-ravaged Kosovo.

title: Studio Rivals to Merge
description: The Todd-AO Corporation, the award-winning video- and sound-editing studio that worked on the movie ''Titanic,'' said yesterday that it would merge its New York unit with a rival, the Sound One Corporation, to edit more films made in the city. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Sound One, the New York-based movie sound studio that has worked on films like ''Fargo'' and ''You've Got Mail,'' will keep its name after the combination.

title: Getting the Facts on Racial Profiling
description: President Clinton has made it clear that he finds racial profiling, the targeting of suspects by race or ethnic background, morally indefensible. On Wednesday he ordered Federal law enforcement agencies to find out ''exactly who is being stopped and why'' by collecting more precise data on the race and gender of the people they stop to question.

title: Giuliani Suggests Using Private Schools for Summer Sessions
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested yesterday that the Board of Education cope with a looming problem of overcrowding in the summer schools by sending some public school students to parochial and private schools and to private tutoring centers next year.

title: EMI SWAPS LICENSING DEAL FOR 50% OF MUSICMAKER.COM
description: EMI Group P.L.C., the London-based music company, said yesterday that it had bought 50 percent of Musicmaker.com, which creates custom-made compilation compact disks for sale over the Internet, in return for a five-year license to put EMI recordings on Musicmaker CD's. Terms were not released. The transaction, the first between a global music company and a custom compilation service, is part of EMI's effort to sell more music on the Web. It also means Musicmaker, a privately held company based in Reston, Va., will have the largest song library of any custom compilation company.

title: U.S. Warns H.M.O.'s on Recruiting of Medicare Clients
description: For years, Federal officials say, they have heard reports that health maintenance organizations try to recruit healthy elderly people by marketing insurance at sports clubs, dance halls and places inaccessible to the sick and disabled.

title: Trade Can't Stop War
description: To the Editor:

title: Stoical War Heroes Who Endured
description: ''Return With Honor,'' Freida Lee Mock and Terry Sanders's gripping documentary film about American pilots shot down over North Vietnam, signifies a major shift in the screen image of the Vietnam veteran. Until recently, that image, formed by dozens of Hollywood films steeped in antiwar angst, tended to portray the Vietnam veteran as a tormented lost soul, the permanently damaged survivor of a nihilistic hell too terrible to be put into words.

title: Album of the Week
description: CHICK COREA and ORIGIN: ''CHANGE'' -- (Stretch/Concord).

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: For the Cautious, Hesitation and Skepticism
description: There were shouts of joy in the refugee camps last night as Kosovar Albanians crowded around radios to hear news of peace in the Balkans. But on this morning after, most said they were too frightened to rush back across the border for now.

title: SAGA BID RAISED
description: Norsk Hydro and Statoil, two of Norway's top oil companies, raised their bid for a smaller competitor, Saga Petroleum, to about $2.56 billion in stock and cash, topping an offer from Elf Aquitaine of France by $191 million. The two state-controlled companies will add cash to Hydro's May 10 offer of one Hydro share for every three Saga shares, valuing the bid at 135 kroner a share, up 11 percent from their last bid and 10 kroner more than Elf's all-cash offer. Either buyer would also assume about $2.3 billion of Saga debt.

title: Mavs and Kings Fined $25,000 Each
description: The N.B.A. fined the Dallas Mavericks and Sacramento Kings $25,000 each for providing expense-paid trips to their players, violating salary cap rules and other provisions of the collective bargaining agreement.

title: Third-Highest Police Official Is Resigning From the Force
description: Louis R. Anemone, an architect of the New York Police Department's successful but often criticized crime-fighting tactics, said yesterday that he was resigning from the force.

title: A Bit of Defiance Amid the Sweetness and Light
description: ''Outlaw'' is not a term that obviously applies to Natalie Merchant. This 36-year-old singer is no gender-bending blasphemer; most parents probably feel blessed when her soothing alto emanates from their children's bedrooms. Yet from the moment she emerged shrouded in a hot-pink veil to begin the second of five concerts at the Neil Simon Theater on Wednesday, Ms. Merchant gave her own definition to defiant artistry.

title: 'Happy Peace to Us All,' Milosevic Tells the Serbs
description: President Slobodan Milosevic spoke to his people today in a televised address, wishing them a happy peace and calling the servicemen who died heroes who gave their lives for freedom and dignity.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell more than 4 percent after an industry report showed a larger-than-expected increase in supplies. In New York, natural gas for July delivery fell 10.5 cents, to $2.355 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Results of New Reading Test Stir Debate
description: Did New York City public school students do better or worse this year on standardized reading tests?

title: MGM Grand Details Stock-Buyback Plan
description: MGM Grand Inc., the casino company controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian, said today that it would offer $300 million to buy back as many as six million outstanding shares to increase its share price.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing; Leases Without Wear-and-Tear Fees
description: EARLY one of every three consumers who lease cars or trucks incur substantial charges for dings, dents and chips when they return their vehicles, because the damage is considered beyond what the leasing company considers normal and reasonable.

title: A Long, Hot Summer School
description: Each day seems to bring more dreary news about New York City's public school system. Unfortunately, these excruciating details about how poorly many of the city's students fare on new standardized tests or how badly they perform after graduation have produced more criticism and plans than promises of extra resources.

title: Trade Can't Stop War
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Are Being Outrun
description: Reggie Miller was at the podium and talking somberly after the Pacers had crumbled to lose Game 5 to the Knicks when some startling words slipped out of his mouth: when the Knicks get out and running, Miller said, it is hard to beat them.

title: Killing Highlights Lebanon's Palestinian Problem
description: No one yet knows exactly who fired Kalashnikov rifles into a courtroom here two days ago in a massacre that killed the chief judge and three other court officials. But the attack has focused attention on a problem that Lebanon has long done its best to ignore.

title: RUSSIAN INDUSTRIAL GROWTH
description: Russian industrial output grew in April, returning to levels of the first quarter of 1998, according to the monthly Russian Economic Trends. Output increased by 1.7 percent from the previous month, but it was still lower than the average level in 1997. Inflation also grew at its lowest rate since the economic collapse in August 1998, increasing in May by 2.2 percent, which compared with 3 percent in April. Still, continuing inflation began to erode consumer spending, which fell 2 percent in April from March. Russians' real wages fell 1.8 percent in April from March.

title: Mental Health Workers Dismissed by County
description: Nearly 100 case managers who supervise most of Nassau County's mental patients have received layoff notices as part of a restructuring that county officials say is intended to cut costs, but that workers and county labor leaders have described as union-busting.

title: Cup Poised for a New Summer
description: The essential goodness in hockey comes out on these soft summer evenings during the Stanley Cup finals. The players dream of more than money or personal glory or just plain winning. They dream of taking the cup back home.

title: Half of U.S. Peacekeeping Force Already Staging in Macedonia
description: More than 3,000 American ground troops poured into dusty, makeshift camps near the airport here today, as the United States scrambled to amass its contribution to a peacekeeping operation in Kosovo fraught with risks and having uncertain support back home.

title: A Pocket Monster Mash
description: If your children are forever saying ''Pikachu'' and ''Raichu,'' don't respond with ''Gesundheit.'' They're not catching colds.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * NATO suspended its 78-day air campaign after confirming that Yugoslav troops had begun withdrawing from Kosovo. But allied warplanes continued patrolling the skies over Kosovo.

title: A Millennial Gift to Developing Nations
description: About 700 million people the very poorest -- are held in debt bondage by the rich countries. The so-called Highly Indebted Poor Countries are a group of 42 financially bankrupt and largely destitute economies. They owe more than $100 billion in unpayable debt to the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, regional development banks and donor governments, often reflecting the failures of past development loans.

title: Tapia's Promoter Looks Ahead to Hamed
description: Johnny Tapia (45-0-2), the World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, does not want to look too far ahead of his June 26 showdown in Las Vegas, Nev., with Paulie Ayala (27-1), the No. 2 contender.

title: G.M. Is Jumping Into the Roadster Market
description: General Motors' Opel unit says it will build the mid-engine, two-seat Speedster concept it displayed at the Geneva auto show. The car will have an aluminum chassis, composite body and a new four-cylinder engine said to be capable of racing to 60 m.p.h. in less than 6 seconds. The car will be available in Europe by the end of 2000; G.M. says American sales are not planned (though it would fit neatly in Pontiac's sporty lineup).

title: New Video Releases
description: Dancing at Lughnasa

title: 2 Parties Act on Social Security
description: Republicans and Democrats took a first, tentative step today toward negotiating a deal to shore up Social Security, agreeing that the House Ways and Means Committee would meet in private sessions to explore whether the two parties can bridge their differences.

title: Intense Spirit in an Age of Innocence
description: ''Women should be someone and not something,'' the American artist Mary Cassatt (1844-1926) once wrote, emphatically underlining her words. And she dedicated a long career to fleshing out this conviction through art.

title: Suspect Found Fit To Stand Trial In Subway Attack
description: A homeless man accused of pushing a commuter in front of a subway train at rush hour was found competent yesterday to stand trial on charges of attempted murder and assault.

title: Net Concerns Name First Agencies
description: Several Internet companies have named the first agencies to handle their accounts.

title: Boredoms Try Repetition And Get a Gospel Effect
description: The Boredoms, from Osaka, Japan, were semi-demi-famous in the early 1990's for playing miniatures -- writhing, howling, spasmic, cartoon art-punk built on split-second timing. But even the most outre rock band in the world has become more patient with age: it's now after continuity and profundity, and the Boredoms have figured out that repetition is the quickest route to the profound in popular music.

title: AUSTRALIAN AIRLINE
description: News Ltd., the Australian arm of the News Corporation, has suspended talks on selling its 50 percent stake in the Australian airline Ansett. Singapore Airlines said yesterday that it was disappointed by the decision, saying it ''had looked forward to part-ownership in the Australian airline.'' News Ltd. had agreed in March to sell its interest in Ansett to Singapore Airlines for $315 million, but Air New Zealand had a pre-emptive right to buy the stake. Air New Zealand owns the remaining 50 percent of Ansett, and its chairman, Selwyn Cushing, has said he would like to buy the rest.

title: Challenges and Magic in a Reunion of a Duo
description: The concert at the Mercury Lounge on Tuesday night took place on the other side of pop's looking glass. There, Robert Forster and Grant McLennan are superstars of a music scene founded on complex yet beautifully lucid music and words that penetrate instead of perpetrating cliches. The Go-Betweens, the band the Australian duo fronted throughout the 1980's, rules the era's Hall of Fame. Famous peers and devoted fans flock to shows like this one to honor them.

title: The Word Is: Not a Word
description: April Grace is understandably thrilled at getting the biggest break in her acting career, a part opposite Tom Cruise in the movie ''Magnolia,'' and she expresses delight at being able to talk with a reporter about her breakthrough.

title: New Infection Kills Software Through E-Mail
description: Computer researchers today reported a malicious computer program that is spreading rapidly through the Internet by E-mail and destroying documents created by widely used Microsoft software programs.

title: 3 Mexicans Are Convicted In Money-Laundering Case
description: A Federal jury delivered a split verdict today in one of the biggest efforts to crack international drug money laundering, convicting three Mexican bankers and businessmen of conspiring to conceal millions of dollars in profits for traffickers. The jury acquitted three others.

title: LONG-TERM CREDIT BANK
description: Japanese authorities raided the headquarters of a failed Japanese bank, the Long-Term Credit Bank, to search for evidence related to allegations that its top executives had hidden bad loans to pay illegal dividends. The regulators also searched the home of the former president of the bank, which was nationalized last fall, to investigate his role in preparing purportedly misleading financial statements. Meanwhile, the Government is still trying to sell the bank's remaining viable operations, and several foreign investor groups have expressed interest.

title: Debts Troubling Moscow's Mr. Fix-It
description: In a nation where not much seems to work, the all-powerful Mayor of Moscow, Yuri M. Luzhkov, has earned a reputation as Mr. Fix-It.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Again Duels With Web Browser Witness
description: With the Government's final witness on the stand in Federal court this afternoon, lawyers for the Microsoft Corporation were obviously eager for an opportunity to mount a demonstration of how it was impossible to remove the company's World Wide Web browser from its Windows 98 operating system.

title: Rick Fields, 57, Poet and Expert on Buddhism
description: Rick Fields, a journalist, poet and leading authority on Buddhism's history and development in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Fairfax, Calif. He was 57.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new generation of chip-making plants being built by Intel misstated the increase in surface area achieved by using 12-inch silicon wafers instead of 8-inch ones. The gain is 125 percent, not 225.

title: NISOURCE SAYS BIG COLUMBIA SHAREHOLDERS BACK TALKS
description: Nisource Inc., owner of Indiana's largest natural gas utility, said yesterday that stockholders representing more than 30 percent of Columbia Energy Group common shares wanted Columbia to hold talks on Nisource's hostile bid. On Monday, Nisource offered to buy Columbia for $5.7 billion in cash, or $68 a share. On Wednesday, Nisource said it might raise the bid if Columbia agreed to negotiate. Columbia says it is not for sale, though it will present the offer to its board. Six of Columbia's eight biggest shareholders support talks between the two companies, Nisource said. Shares of Nisource fell 6.25 cents, to $27.625. Shares of Columbia rose 18.75 cents, to $62.

title: Mortgage Rates Increase
description: The benchmark home mortgage rate advanced this week to the highest level in more than one and a half years, a weekly survey by Freddie Mac showed today. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 7.51 percent in the week that ends Friday from last week's 7.41 percent. This week's rate is the highest since 7.53 percent in the week ended Sept. 12, 1997, Freddie Mac said. ''Looking over the next few months, we'll see very strong numbers for home sales, but we won't be setting any monthly sales records,'' said Frank Nothaft, deputy chief economist at Freddie Mac.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I can report to the American people that we have achieved a victory for a safer world, for our democratic values, and for a stronger America.''

title: Mind and Body Cavorting In Stylish Nonstop Motion
description: There was excited talk of superb dancers as the audience drifted into the night after a performance by Monte/Brown Dance on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. Elisa Monte and David Brown gave their dancers almost too many chances to shine in four premieres and a repeat from the opening program the night before.

title: After Tourists Go Home, Love Remains
description: Will Micki and Roberta become lovers? Will Micki and Roberta be together when ''Out of Season'' reaches its conclusion?

title: 'Sampling'
description: Ronald Feldman Gallery

title: 4 Are Killed as Woman Stabs Husband and Daughter and Sets House on Fire
description: A mother of four stabbed her husband and 8-year-old daughter this morning and set the family house on fire, killing herself, her husband and two children. The other two children were critically injured.

title: Casey Closer to Being Head Coach
description: It appears now more than ever that Don Casey will be named head coach for the Nets next week. Casey, who guided the Nets through the second half of last season on an interim basis, met yesterday with Lewis Katz and Finn Wentworth, the managing owners, to discuss the club's coaching vacancy. It was the two parties' first formal discussion on the matter since the season ended last month.

title: Enough Preaching, Noah! Where Are the Life Vests?
description: Logorrhea isn't just a word in a spelling bee.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BRERA CAPITAL UNIT IS BUYING 64% STAKE IN CABLE COMPANY
description: The cable operator Classic Communications Inc. said yesterday that a subsidiary of Brera Capital Partners L.P., a New York-based private equity firm, had agreed to invest $100 million in it through the purchase of common stock. The investment will be used to finance Classic's $300 million acquisition of Buford Group Inc., a cable operator based in Tyler, Tex., as well as to upgrade the company's cable systems. The transaction will result in Brera's holding 64.4 percent of Classic's common stock. Classic Communications, based in Austin, Tex., has about 190,000 subscribers in eight states.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the naming of a new chief executive at the Eastman Kodak Company omitted a scale in some editions for the company's net income. The figures were in billions.

title: Don't Blame Birth Control for Society's Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Pickford, Power Broker
description: She was ''America's sweetheart,'' all right, but under those golden curls Mary Pickford, often cast as the tragic waif, had one of the hardest heads in Hollywood. ''By 1914 or 1915, she was pulling the strings, making the rules,'' said Elaina Archer, the manager of the Mary Pickford Library in Los Angeles.

title: Foreign Affairs; What's Your IQ?
description: My favorite Internet commercial these days shows this man checking into a cheap motel. The desk clerk is a bored young woman. As the man is checking in, he asks the clerk whether he can get movies on his room TV. And the clerk answers matter-of-factly: ''All rooms have every movie ever made in every language, any time, day or night.''

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture by Reuters on Wednesday showed a Serbian policeman pointing a rifle from the shattered window of a bus in Kosovo. The Reuters caption said the policeman aimed his rifle during a clash with guerrillas.

title: British Forces Delay Entry in Kosovo, as Serb Pullout Lags
description: NATO tonight scrubbed plans for a dawn entry into Kosovo by British paratroopers on Friday, suspending its peacekeeping operation for at least 24 hours.

title: Peru's Chief Scolds American Airlines
description: President Alberto Fujimori of Peru said today that American Airlines was ''impertinent'' on his latest trip to the United States, and he called for greater competition in flights to and from Lima.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Red Cat is as appealing as its name. It sounds like a shady 1920's nightclub, but there's nothing louche about this little shoe box of a restaurant poised between residential Chelsea and the cluster of new art galleries in the far west 20's. It's a perky neighborhood joint for an undefined neighborhood, serving reasonably priced American-Mediterranean bistro cuisine to a young, mostly local crowd.

title: Robert Lapham, 77, Magazine Executive
description: Robert J. Lapham, who served as president of Conde Nast Publications from 1974 through 1986, died June 4 at a nursing home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 77 years old and lived in Corona del Mar, Calif.

title: Trash Firm Sues Virginia To Block Import Limits
description: A company that wants to export New York City's trash to Virginia filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday seeking to reverse restrictions imposed by Virginia on trash imports.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Accounts
description: * Infineon Technologies Corp., San Jose, Calif., a semiconductor maker, to the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson West, part of the J. Walter Thompson unit of the WPP Group P.L.C., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $30 million. The office was also awarded two other accounts: Interact Accessories, Brisbane, Calif., part of the Recoton Corp., a video game accessory maker, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million, and Busybox.com, San Francisco, which distributes visual media over the Internet, with billings estimated at $10 million.

title: For $500, the Renoir Can Be Yours (Sort Of)
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby's Rejuvenation Helps Save Lost Season
description: In late March, with the Knicks floundering, Coach Jeff Van Gundy spoke to his players before a practice in Sacramento, Calif. The one Knick singled out most for sacrificing playing time in the name of the team was Marcus Camby, the 24-year-old forward who privately wondered if he would have a chance to show off his skills.

title: Vote Sample in Indonesia Shows Strength for Opposition Party
description: An unofficial vote sample issued today showed that the opposition party of Megawati Sukarnoputri was likely to emerge from Monday's election in the strongest position to form a coalition government.

title: Mets' Woes Are Hard to Conceal
description: The Mets' version of Inspector Clouseau, that master of disguise, could be in trouble. Bobby Valentine is under investigation by the National League for donning sunglasses and a fake mustache -- or was it a strip of black tape? -- and returning to the dugout after his ejection from the game Wednesday night.

title: PP&L RESOURCES IS BUYING CONTROL OF CHILEAN COMPANY
description: PP&L Resources Inc., owner of Pennsylvania's second-largest electric utility, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy stakes in Empresas Emel S.A. for $100 million in cash to gain control of the Chilean power distributor. Grupo Espigas, a Chilean investment fund, and some of its shareholders are selling a combined 29.2 percent of Emel. PP&L already owns 37.5 percent of the Santiago-based company. PP&L, which has 1.3 million customers in Pennsylvania, expects to complete the purchase this month.

title: Ghosts From a Long-Ago Poorhouse in City Hall Park
description: The distant and sorrowful past of New York City continues to resurface in the soil of City Hall Park.

title: Fallout From Scandal Claims Two Top Lawyers at Morgan Stanley
description: The chief legal officer at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company stepped down from her job and a senior in-house lawyer resigned yesterday in connection with a $10,000 payment to a police informant, as the Wall Street giant sought to end what two top executives said in a statement was ''a difficult time for our firm.''

title: Flirting With the Tango
description: One of the oddities of learning to tango is how much time you spend walking, endlessly, forward and backward, this way and that in the merciless glare of the dance studio mirrors. The instructor glides on an invisible balance beam; the student teeters and galumphs. It is like starting chess by steering the rooks back and forth across the board, again and again.

title: Friend of Victim Charged In Queens Park Slaying
description: The day after a 34-year-old woman was found shot to death on a park bench in Queens, a friend of hers was charged yesterday with murdering her.

title: For $500, the Renoir Can Be Yours (Sort Of)
description: To the Editor:

title: Forging Link For Russians In the Chain Of Command
description: Western nations are considering new arrangements for military command to ease Russia's concerns about its place in the NATO-led security force in Kosovo, allied officials said today.

title: Forsaking the Angels For Devilish Hilarity
description: James Ensor, the Belgian painter of hallucinatory masks, skeletons and devils, had an expansive imagination. His most famous painting, executed in 1888 in vehement response to the formalism of Georges Seurat's ''Sunday on the Grande Jatte,'' is a crowded, carnivalesque vision of Christ entering Brussels that measures 8 1/2 by 14 feet. But Ensor also concentrated his comically mordant imagination into exquisite, small etchings, an excellent selection of which is now at Shepherd & Derom Galleries.

title: Don't Blame Birth Control for Society's Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Twiggy Does Noel Coward
description: ''If Love Were All,'' a musical revue based on the friendship of Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence, opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater with Harry Groener as Coward and Twiggy, above, as Lawrence. Though the two stars were known for their dry, sparkling sophistication, the show almost never fizzes. But when the resplendently blond Twiggy wraps her sinuous self around a number like ''Twentieth Century Blues,'' it's hard not to fall in love.

title: Tax-Exempt Status Rejected, Christian Coalition Regroups
description: The Christian Coalition, a powerhouse in the Republican Party for the last decade, has been denied tax-exempt status because of its political activity, officials of the organization said today, and is reorganizing in an effort to retain its influence.

title: Ex-Police Officer Files Discrimination Lawsuit
description: A retired New York City police officer filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing the employees of a gas station on the New Jersey Turnpike of failing to serve him because he is black and then having two state troopers chase him down after he complained and drove off.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Bringing Home A World Of Injustice
description: ''Cabaret Balkan,'' Goran Paskaljevic's garishly expressionistic portrait of life in Belgrade before the NATO bombing, is introduced by a leering kohl-eyed master of ceremonies who appears to have arrived straight from a production of the musical ''Cabaret,'' After announcing that he's going to play nasty games with our minds, the ''show'' that follows -- a series of ''La Ronde''-like vignettes -- does exactly that.

title: Agbayani Not Hurt Seriously
description: Tests yesterday confirmed that Benny Agbayani, a pleasant surprise in the Mets' outfield, escaped serious injury in a freakish batting practice accident at Shea Stadium on Wednesday afternoon. He could be back in the lineup tonight.

title: Airlines Agree on Pledges To Make to Their Customers
description: Fourteen passenger airlines have agreed to a ''customer service commitment'' that is intended to pre-empt legislation pending in Congress. But a news conference called this morning at the Air Transport Association to announce the plan was canceled by the airlines, apparently because of a disagreement with lawmakers that occurred minutes before the briefing was supposed to begin.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Lobo's Injury Casts a Pall As Liberty Wins Its Opener
description: The Women's National Basketball Association season opened last night. For the Liberty's Rebecca Lobo, one of the league's showcase players, the season may have ended 42 seconds after it began.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: True to 60's Rhythms and Jewish Culture
description: Twelve albums after the start of John Zorn's quartet Masada -- not to mention a few recent false announcements of disbanding -- and how does the band sound? Quite similar to how it sounded on its first recording, in 1995. Mr. Zorn compartmentalizes his music into projects, and each has its set of rules. These imposed limitations are what separates Masada -- a group influenced by Jewish music in its melodies and by Ornette Coleman's harmonic and rhythmic concept of the early 60's -- from the main body of jazz.

title: Three Organizations Honor Agencies
description: Honors were presented last night by three organizations in New York for achievements in advertising and public relations.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The single European currency received a lift as NATO forces prepared to halt an 11-week bombing offensive in Yugoslavia. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0489, up from $1.0465 on Wednesday.

title: Tracey Emin -- 'Every Part of Me's Bleeding'
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: Kosovar Serbs See No Future As They See Convoy Pass By
description: As the long army convoy roared out of Kosovo today, beginning a defeated Serbia's painful retreat from its historical heartland, a military policeman in his black beret snapped a salute to each passing vehicle, tears streaming down his face.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Lachemann Named Pitching Coach
description: Marcel Lachemann was named pitching coach for the United States team in the Pan American Games from July 24 through Aug. 2 in Winnipeg, Canada.

title: Waiting for a Final Resting Place; Friends Seek Proper Burial for a Former Tunnel Dweller
description: For 13 years, Jose Camacho lived in the cavernous dark of an abandoned Amtrak railroad tunnel under Riverside Park, part of a subterranean clan of homeless people who scavenged their existence from the city's leavings. He died last month at 54 in a sunny one-bedroom in the Bronx that he finally secured in 1996 through the kindness of strangers and a rare Government subsidy.

title: Provincials In the Theater Of Politics
description: THE Tony Awards show this week was not a good omen for Hillary Rodham Clinton in her nascent race for a United States Senate seat from New York. Outlanders fared quite badly.

title: The Girls All Go for His Euphemism
description: There may come a time when even Austin Powers tires of the words ''Oh, behave,'' but it isn't here yet. The sequel with the fab title ''Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me'' is several love beads short of its predecessor, but some of that was bound to happen once Austin's novelty dimmed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: E-Mail 'Worm' Spreading And Destroying Documents

title: States and Cities Are Told To Alter Their Bookkeeping
description: Despite protests from public officials, the accounting board that sets the rules for how cities and states keep their books approved a plan yesterday that will require governments to include the value of roads, bridges and other infrastructure in their financial statements.

title: Morgan and Vulcan Invest in 2 Electronic Trading Systems
description: The race on Wall Street to build and expand computer-based trading systems is picking up speed. J. P. Morgan & Company and the venture capitalist Paul G. Allen each announced new investments yesterday in the fast-growing services.

title: Japanese Yet Not Japanese
description: On April 15, when most Americans were preoccupied with taxes, more than 400 citizens of Nagoya, Japan, were lining up to be the first to enter their city's new museum, the Nagoya/Boston Museum of Fine Arts. In a novel arrangement, Nagoya has built a contemporary, flexible museum space and is paying the Boston museum each year to borrow works of art that curators of the two museums choose to show for limited periods.

title: Fallout When Mars and Venus Collide
description: For those who can't get enough of the romantic and sexual travails of 20- and 30-somethings in the customary half-hour television sitcom format, the super-size version has arrived under the title ''Just a Little Harmless Sex.''

title: Excerpts From Loitering Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today overturning a Chicago ordinance on loitering. The vote in Chicago v. Morales was 6 to 3. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority opinion, which was signed by Justices David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote a concurring opinion, which was also signed by Justice Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote a concurring opinion. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a dissent, as did Justice Clarence Thomas. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Scalia both signed Justice Thomas's dissent. Where italics are used, they follow the emphasis of the original.

title: Bombing Ends as Serbs Begin Pullout
description: NATO suspended its bombing of Yugoslavia today after Serbian troops began withdrawing from Kosovo, halting an assault that rained 23,000 bombs and missiles on Serbia without losing the life of a single NATO fighter.

title: Notification Bill for Abortions Passed by Assembly in Trenton
description: New Jersey moved closer today to enacting its first significant restriction on abortion in decades as the Assembly passed a bill that would require girls under 18 to notify their parents before they can receive an abortion.

title: Residential Real Estate; Where Jet Crashed in 1960, a Condo
description: A Manhattan developer is advancing plans to turn a slice of Seventh Avenue and Sterling Place in Park Slope into a 19-unit condominium that will combine new construction with the renovation of an existing brownstone and be designed to blend with the neighborhood's 19th-century character.

title: Exuberant Americana That's Not All-American
description: On Wednesday Christopher Wheeldon made his debut in ''Fancy Free'' at New York City Ballet, and Jose Manuel Carreno appeared for the first time in ''Push Comes to Shove'' at American Ballet Theater.

title: In a Show of Historic Treasures, History May Be Beside the Point
description: Occasionally an exhibition makes you reach for your abacus. ''Photographs From the Collection'' at the National Gallery of Art is such a show. The 63 black-and-white works in this show, drawn mostly from recent acquisitions, span nearly the whole history of photography and are arranged in roughly chronological order. But for some reason history flows strangely here. It is too still. Why? Maybe a look at the photographers would help.

title: 'Wall Drawings'
description: Lance Fung Gallery

title: Facing Dismissal, Cathay Pacific Pilots Accept Pay Cuts
description: Less than a day before a deadline to sign new contracts or be dismissed, pilots at Cathay Pacific Airways agreed today to pay cuts in return for being let back into the cockpits of Cathay's cargo planes for the first time in almost four years.

title: FORD LAYOFFS EXTENDED
description: The Ford Motor Company's Brazilian unit extended layoffs for 2,000 workers at its main plant by three months because of weak sales, unions said. Ford's metalworkers, who were laid off at the beginning of the year, were expected to return to the assembly line this month. The workers are still receiving 80 percent of their salaries, the Metalworkers Union said. Ford officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Littleton's Legacy of Pranks and Fear
description: From the moment I knew I was pregnant with my son, I've taken my studies of parenthood seriously. I read Penelope Leach and T. Berry Brazelton. I've been to child-rearing seminars as well as P.T.A. meetings. I know about logical consequences and positive discipline. None of it prepared me for the last two weeks.

title: Students First, Athletes Second
description: Basketball is the richest college sport, with a television contract worth nearly $2 billion. It is also the most troubled college sport. Player-students fail to graduate in alarming numbers. Others transfer to other schools repeatedly in search of more playing time. Still others leave early to seek professional careers.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stockholders Will Get a Gift As RJR Parts From Nabisco
description: To ease the separation anxiety investors may feel when R. J. Reynolds leaves RJR Nabisco behind, the company is planning to dispense a generous dividend.

title: Woman in Cosby Case Is Released From Prison
description: A woman who claims to be Bill Cosby's illegitimate daughter was released from a California prison yesterday after an appeals court in New York overturned her 1997 conviction for trying to extort $40 million from the entertainer.

title: HEINEKEN BUYS SPANISH BREWER
description: Heineken, the Dutch brewer, said it had agreed to buy Spain's biggest brewer, Cruzcampo, from Diageo for 145 billion pesetas ($914 million). Buying Diageo's 88.2 percent of Cruzcampo gives Heineken control of about 40 percent of the market when combined with its own El Aguila, which has a market share of about 16 percent. Heineken is using acquisitions to build leading positions in established beer markets as beer sales stagnate in its traditional strongholds. Diageo is trying to focus on internationally known brands, such as Guinness.

title: Alfredo Castaneda -- 'Our I and My We'
description: Mary-Anne Martin Fine Art

title: Spicing Up the Abstraction With Humor and Relevance
description: A program designed by Martin Luther King Jr. High School to give students a chance to work with professionals got off to a good start at the school's handsome auditorium with a performance by three well-chosen veteran modern-dance troupes.

title: AT&T Cable Unit to Carry NBC Programs
description: NBC, the No. 2 television network, said yesterday that it had reached an eight-year agreement with the AT&T Corporation to carry its broadcast and cable programs, digital services and the Olympics.

title: Medpartners in Accord on California Sale
description: Medpartners Inc. reached a settlement with California regulators that allows it to sell its physician-practice-management operations in the state.

title: MESSAGEMEDIA ANNOUNCES 2D ACQUISITION THIS WEEK
description: Messagemedia Inc., an E-mail direct marketing provider, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held Decisive Technology for $50 million in stock to enable its clients to monitor feedback from their customers. This is Messagemedia's second deal in two days as it seeks through purchases to broaden its services to companies like E*Trade Group Inc. and Yahoo Inc.'s Geocities unit. Shares of Messagemedia rose $1.5625, to $12.9375. Messagemedia said on Wednesday that it planned to acquire the closely held Revnet Systems Inc., a supplier of software to manage E-mail lists.

title: Loitering Law Aimed at Gangs Is Struck Down by High Court
description: Chicago's anti-loitering law, which other cities looked to as a model for reclaiming the streets in gang-infested neighborhoods, was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court today on the ground that it gave the police too much discretion to single out innocent people. The vote was 6 to 3.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: No. 1 in Its Bankruptcy Class; A Company in Thailand Starts to Get Its Act Together
description: For Robert B. Mollerstuen, the Asian economic crisis hit home on a sultry Sunday evening in July 1997, three weeks after Thailand let its currency plunge in value and set off a panic from Singapore to Seoul.

title: Political Briefing; Political Soap Opera Rivets Mississippi
description: In the episodic matter of love, liaisons and Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi . . .

title: From President, Victory Speech And a Warning
description: President Clinton declared tonight that NATO had ''achieved a victory'' in the war in Kosovo and warned the people of Serbia that as long as Slobodan Milosevic remained their leader, they would get no help to rebuild their bomb-scarred land.

title: All Aboard for Cooperstown
