description: The special two-car excursion train chugged cautiously along rusty tracks into sleepy Cooperstown, N.Y. It had been 18 vexing miles from Colliersville, a dicey journey across a railroad spur virtually unexplored since the turn of the century.

title: Nation Is Falling Short Of Health Goals for 2000
description: The United States has met only about 15 percent of its health goals for the year 2000, set 20 years ago, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today, but progress has been made on 44 percent.

title: Learning That Karate's Blows Go Hand in Hand With Manners
description: I admit to having aimed a premeditated kick at the head of a lawyer named Brent Stevens. He promptly hit me three times.

title: Correction
description: The May 10 Editorial Observer, on racial profiling, erred in saying that a Federal judge in Boston had chastised the police for an unjustified traffic stop of a car carrying a black man. The judge held that the stop was justified, but in sentencing the man, who was charged with weapons possession, she took into account that previous convictions may have resulted from racial profiling.

title: Stepping Into the Jazz Age with Noel and Twiggy
description: It seemed as if the 1960's would own her forever in memory, since she bore roughly the same relationship to that decade as the Statue of Liberty does to the United States. Yet Twiggy, the saucer-eyed fashion model whose name became a byword for clothes-hanger skinniness and swinging London, has repeatedly proved that her face, and perhaps her heart, belongs equally to the age of flappers, Fitzgerald and Art Deco.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEWPORT NEWS SHIPBUILDING INC., Newport News, Va., the largest maker of nuclear aircraft carriers, said it planned to buy back $100 million, or about 10 percent, of its common shares outstanding during the next year.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway to Ballroom, All Flavored by Gershwin
description: It's easy to care quite a lot about ''Who Cares?,'' especially when it's danced as marvelously as it was by the New York City Ballet on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Verdict in Cannibalism Case Is Set Aside
description: Albert Fentress, a former Hudson Valley teacher who tortured, killed and cannibalized a teen-ager 20 years ago, will remain in a state psychiatric hospital in Suffolk County despite a jury's decision that he should be set free, a state judge has ruled.

title: Security Council Backs Peace Plan and a NATO-Led Force
description: After more than a day of frantic diplomatic maneuvering, the United Nations Security Council approved a resolution today sending a large NATO-led force into Kosovo to keep the peace and placing the United Nations in administrative charge of the province.

title: EXXON-MOBIL MERGER
description: European Union regulators extended their inquiry of Exxon's planned $88 billion takeover of Mobil, possibly until October, as they examine antitrust concerns involving everything from oil exploration to gas stations. The European Commission, the union's executive agency, said it would study the combined company's potential dominance of European markets for oil and natural gas production, lubricants, fuel sales and natural- gas-to-liquids technology. That could delay a final ruling until mid-October. Its initial one-month period expired Wednesday.

title: Serse
description: Barbara Mathes Gallery

title: Christina Foyle, 88, the Queen Of the London Bookstore, Dies
description: Christina Foyle, London's best known bookseller and the creator and hostess of Britain's most famous literary luncheon series, died on Tuesday at her country home, Beeleigh Abbey, near Maldon in Essex. She was 88.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the creation of two new elements misstated the atomic numbers of lead and krypton. The nucleus of the most common isotope of lead contains 82 protons, not 208. Krypton has 36 protons, not 86.

title: Sports of The Times; Team Effort Includes The Coach
description: AROUND the witching hour tonight, it just might be appropriate for Dave Checketts to burst into a news conference and blurt, ''Jeff Van Gundy, you're a gosh-dang good coach.'' It's happened before, where a sports executive had to eat crow in public. I once witnessed the legendary Branch Rickey making nice to Johnny Keane, the baseball manager he had schemed to dismiss. In sports, all things come around.

title: FORD IN DEAL FOR ADMINISTRATOR OF SERVICE CONTRACTS
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Automobile Protection Corporation for $180 million as part of its push to keep customers after they buy a car or truck. Ford will pay $13 a share for Automobile Protection, which has 200 employees and will retain its management. The company, based in Atlanta, is the administrator of Easy Care Vehicle Service contracts sold mainly through dealerships. The move comes after Ford bought Kwik-Fit Holdings P.L.C., Europe's largest independent car service chain, for $:1.01 billion ($1.63 billion) in April. Ford shares fell 25 cents, to $55, while Automobile Protection shares rose 43.75 cents, to $13.1875.

title: Shaping Restless Planet Earth
description: Over more than a century, scientists and explorers from the American Museum of Natural History have searched the world and returned with arresting examples of life in all its diversity: dinosaurs from Montana to Mongolia, birds and butterflies, artifacts of exotic cultures from here to the South Sea. For the last four years, their quest has been to collect the stuff of Earth itself and bring it back for a new exhibition illustrating the planet's 4.5 billion-year history.

title: H. B. Porter, 76; Revised Episcopal Prayer
description: The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, an Episcopal theologian and liturgical scholar who played a leading role in modernizing the church's Book of Common Prayer in 1979, died on Saturday at Bridgeport Hospital in Connecticut. He was 76 and lived in Southport, Conn.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Peace and the K.L.A.
description: The quality of the peace that NATO can bring to Kosovo in the coming months will depend in large measure on the cooperation it receives from the commanders and fighters of the Kosovo Liberation Army. The settlement terms fall short of the K.L.A.'s goal of an independent Kosovo. But more than 11 weeks of NATO bombing have won Kosovars a high degree of political autonomy and made it possible for more than a million displaced people to return safely to their homes. The K.L.A. should demobilize its guerrilla units, surrender its heavy weapons and trust NATO peacekeepers to provide physical security for all of Kosovo's people.

title: Rich Cable Deal Lessens Isles' Misery
description: The evidence of the Islanders' misfortune is apparent on the ice, where the team has failed to make the Stanley Cup playoffs for five seasons, and in the boardroom, where John Spano is in prison for defrauding his way to own the team in 1997 and the current ownership pegged its 1998-99 losses at $20 million.

title: A New Look At the Modern
description: In anticipation of the first cycle of ''MOMA 2000,'' a 17-month series of exhibitions that begins in October, the Museum of Modern Art has reconfigured its third-floor galleries, and in the process has reinstalled a portion of its permanent collection.

title: That Old Fiddle Sure Got Around
description: A film score can artistically make or break a movie, especially one -- like ''The Red Violin'' -- that aspires to a loftier-than-average cultural tone.

title: In Brooklyn, No Plea Deals For Defendants in Gun Cases
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday that he planned to stop making plea bargains with people charged with carrying an illegal firearm or possessing a gun without a license.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK IS SELLING 460,000 ACRES OF TIMBERLAND
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 460,000 acres of timberlands for about $400 million as it focuses on more profitable consumer and health care lines. The sale of the Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee timberlands to Joshua Management L.L.C., a closely held investment firm in Brookhaven, Miss., completes Kimberly-Clark's plan to sell its 529,000 acres of Southeastern timberlands and related operations. Kimberly-Clark, the Dallas-based maker of Kleenex and Huggies diapers, plans to close its pulp mill in Mobile, Ala., in September and use the proceeds from selling related assets to expand its tissue, personal care and health care businesses. Kimberly-Clark shares rose 62.50 cents, to $58.375.

title: Warsaw Journal; First Lady's Armor: Elegance, Tact, and Backbone
description: The First Lady of Poland said she gave Hillary Rodham Clinton some helpful hints when they first met in Cracow three years ago.

title: Speaker Shifts His Position On Pressing for Gun Control
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said today that he would not pressure House Republicans to vote for new restrictions on firearms, a sign of disarray and deep divisions within the party and an omen that the House might not be able to pass gun-control legislation.

title: Chip Maker Posts Fifth Straight Loss
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported its fifth consecutive quarterly loss today, but its results essentially met analysts' expectations.

title: U.N.'s Rights Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: City to Add Machines That Sell Metrocards
description: Metrocard vending machines will be installed in 12 more subway stations by the end of the summer and in each of the system's 468 stations by the end of next year, according to New York City Transit.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ain't Nothin' But a Flap
description: If only the television show had been this interesting . . .

title: Dow Drops for Third Day As Interest Rates Edge Up
description: Stocks staged a broad retreat yesterday as long-term interest rates climbed another notch.

title: EZ-Pass Would Have Helped
description: A lot of plays seem to be set in bars this season: ''The Weir,'' with its charming Irish storytellers; ''The Iceman Cometh,'' with its motley assortment of the down-and-out, and now, several blocks from Broadway, ''Exact Change.'' This three-character play by David Epstein is a mixed bag, awkward at first but coming together near the end, not particularly deep but consistently well written.

title: Judge Upholds Claim Against TV Station
description: A judge upheld a jury verdict yesterday in the case of a former television anchorwoman who was forced to take a disability leave after she was injured, but reduced the amount of money she will receive, saying the jurors had made a mathematical error.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aviation Security Purchase
description: The Titan Corporation, a satellite communications and information technology company, said today that it had acquired the closely held System Resources Corporation for an unspecified amount. Titan also said it had secured a $190 million financing agreement, $75 million of which is a loan that was partly used to buy System Resources, a Boston-based company that provides computerized systems for use in airports, aviation and security.

title: Japan Grows 1.9%, to Economists' Disbelief
description: After nearly two years of recession, Japan's dormant economy leaped to life in the first three months of the year, according to official figures so strong that they were played down by some of the Government's own economists.

title: Political Briefing; 99% Margin of Error On Polls' Relevance
description: Dan Quayle, speaking last Saturday about his low standing in polls testing Republican Presidential hopefuls: ''These polls are totally irrelevant right now.''

title: Britain Cuts Interest Rate to a 20-Year Low
description: The Bank of England unexpectedly cut Britain's benchmark interest rate today to its lowest level in more than 20 years to weaken the pound and spur one of Europe's slowest-growing economies.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about new standards in New York City schools referred incompletely to the scores on reading tests announced earlier in the week. When compared with students nationwide, those in New York City public school ranked lower on reading tests this year than last. But when the results were adjusted to take into account the increased difficulty of this year's tests, and rising results nationwide, city reading scores were one percentage point higher than the previous year, not down sharply. An article explaining the two ways of viewing the results appears today on page B6.

title: Can This Peace Put Kosovars on Solid Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: China Is Sentencing Dissidents To Jail Terms of Up to 4 Years
description: A businessman and former Government planner who distributed a pro-democracy manifesto last year was sentenced today to four years in prison, the latest in a series of harsh steps taken against dissidents in the past month.

title: In Rare Talks With Libyans, U.S. Airs View On Sanctions
description: In their first official meeting in 18 years, the United States told Libya today that it would not support the complete lifting of sanctions until Libya stopped supporting international terrorism and met other conditions required by United Nations resolutions, diplomats said.

title: Lineup Changes Agree With O'Neill
description: How is Albert Belle hitting? Paul O'Neill asked before tonight's game. When told Belle's average was sinking below .250, O'Neill thought about this.

title: Clinton to Republicans: 'Lighten Up'
description: President Clinton said tonight that Republicans opposed his policies because they were frustrated that a Democrat had won the White House and taken up all of its perks, like parking spaces, and he suggested that they ''lighten up.''

title: Crime Bill Sags Under Piggybackers Like Gun-Control Items
description: House Republicans and Democrats began to file more than 200 amendments today to a juvenile-crime bill that has become a vehicle for the kind of modest but bitterly divisive gun-control measures that the Senate approved last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARENTEAU, FRED H., JR.
description: PARENTEAU-Fred H., Jr. 78. Of Larchmont, NY. A retired sales executive with Clark Equipment Company and a World War II naval aviator. Died June 10, 1999. Husband of the late Ellen Jacobsen Cahill. Loving father of Fred H. Parenteau III and Suzanne Shacteau. Dear brother of Mrs. Virginia Devlin and Betty Boothroyd. Proud grandfather of Christopher and Alexander Parenteau. A memorial mass will be held Monday, 10 AM, at Sts. John and Paul Church in Larchmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Famed Legal Team Hired In Police Killing on I-80
description: The family of an unarmed driver who was fatally shot by police officers after a 15-mile chase on Interstate 80 last week has hired nationally known lawyers Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., Peter Neufeld and Barry Scheck to investigate the shooting, Mr. Scheck said yesterday.

title: Crash Victim Is Recalled As a Quiet Man With Flair
description: Every year at Christmastime, Isaac Speight, the superintendent of the apartment building at 107 West 68th Street in Manhattan, stopped by to toast the New Year with Juan Diaz, a tenant of 24 years. But last year, one thing came up, and then another, and months slipped by. Finally, three weeks ago, after Mr. Speight insisted, Mr. Diaz pulled out the coquito, a Puerto Rican cocoanut-and-rum egg nog, and clinked snifters. ''To another great year!'' Mr. Diaz remembers saying.

title: Prospect of Rise in Interest Rates Takes Toll on Equities
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday for a fourth consecutive day after economic reports deepened investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month. Internet shares like America Online and CMGI slumped.

title: The Scourge Of New Jobs
description: The news that officials in Portland, Ore., have imposed a $1,000-per-job ''growth impact fee'' on Intel if it creates too many new jobs confirms that America has arrived at an unprecedented social moment. It is surely strange when a state director of economic development says (as Oregon's did), ''We aren't just interested in jobs, jobs, jobs.''

title: Peacekeepers' Commander Warns of Tough Job Ahead
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the NATO commander, told allied ambassadors today that the peacekeepers who were to begin moving into Kosovo soon would try to ''hold Kosovo together'' until international aid agencies could set up relief operations there.

title: How to Win at Match Points: Double the Bold Part Scores
description: Regular practice is needed to maintain a good standard of performance, so someone who plays just once a year cannot win in a large field.

title: At Missouri Base, Clinton Hails Power of Weaponry and Diversity
description: President Clinton came to the home of the B-2 stealth bomber to extol American air power today, but he devoted as much of his speech to praising American-style race relations, asserting that NATO's victory in Kosovo had been one of ethnic diversity over ''ethnic cleansing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Former Knick Is Arrested
description: The Nashville police arrested Dontae' Jones, the former Knicks and Boston Celtics player, yesterday in Memphis and accused him and another man of shooting and injuring seven people in April outside a Nashville nightclub.

title: Duval Burns His Hand but Will Play
description: David Duval, the world's No. 1-ranked golfer, sustained second-degree burns on his right thumb and forefinger yesterday, but he hoped to play in the United States Open, which begins Thursday in Pinehurst, N.C.

title: Japan Announces a Plan To Create 700,000 Jobs
description: The Japanese Government today announced a plan to create more than 700,000 jobs but failed to say how much it intended to spend, leaving the plan's potential power to stimulate the economy somewhat mysterious.

title: Bush's Tort Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: N.R.A. Is Using Adversity to Its Advantage
description: After years of drift and disarray, the National Rifle Association finds itself right where many of its leaders want it to be: under attack.

title: Marie St. Louis, 71, Jazz Festival Chief
description: Marie St. Louis, a jazz festival talent executive who booked such artists as Duke Ellington, Louis Armstrong and Ella Fitzgerald during a 37-year career, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Gun Games in the House
description: With the gun control issue careening toward a probable showdown on the House floor next week, Republicans need to decide whether their fealty to the gun lobby will lead them to ignore the public's demand for strong Congressional action to keep guns away from children and criminals. Americans will not be fooled by halfway measures, some of them watered-down versions of the provisions approved last month by the Senate. The gun package introduced by Representatives Henry J. Hyde and Bill McCollum requires significant strengthening if the House Speaker, Dennis Hastert, is to fulfill his promise of last month to make meaningful progress on gun control. Yet Mr. Hastert seems reluctant to confront Republicans trying to further weaken the proposal.

title: The Multiplex Isn't the Villain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: RUSSIANS ENTER KOSOVO EARLY BUT MOSCOW CALLS IT A MISTAKE; BRITISH LEAD NATO'S VANGUARD
description: Breaking Moscow's assurances to Washington, a long column of Russian troops entered Kosovo and its capital early this morning amid wild celebration by local Serbs.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, HERMAN S., MD.
description: ALPERT-Herman S., MD. On June 10, 1999. Distinguished psychiatrist in private practice since 1947. Member of the attending and teaching staff of Mt. Sinai Hospital and School of Medicine. Beloved husband of Harriet and the late Eileen. Loving father of Cheryl Alpert Sofer, Jeffrey Alpert, Marjorie Lesnik Karp and Peter Lesnik. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Brother of Alma Goodsite of Tucson, Arizona Services Sunday 10 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday 79 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Department of Psychiatry of Mount Sinai Hospital or Temple Shaaray Tefila.

title: 7 Plead Guilty to Rigging Property Auctions
description: Seven people pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to rigging bids on foreclosed houses that were auctioned off from the steps of the Kings County Courthouse in Brooklyn, Federal antitrust officials said.

title: Twilight Racing Makes a Comeback
description: Twilight racing returned to Belmont Park yesterday afternoon, with the New York Racing Association offering a menu of stand-up comedians, half-price drinks and live music in addition to a later post time in an effort to attract a wider audience to the race track.

title: 2 Institutions Faulted for Tests on Children
description: Federal research-ethics officials have faulted the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Research Foundation of the City University of New York for the way they conducted psychiatric experiments that injected hyperactive children with the now-banned diet drug fenfluramine.

title: Implausibly, Into the Finals
description: Allan Houston surveyed the stands, looking for his wife, looking for friends, looking for anyone he knew to share in his euphoria. He stretched his arms out as far as they could go as Madison Square Garden erupted in pandemonium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REASER, BERNICE DALZIEL
description: REASER-Bernice Dalziel, a pianist and teacher for more than 60 years, died June 5, 1999 at Abbey Delray, Delray Beach, Florida. Born in Algona, Iowa, she was the daughter of Harry and Julia Tellier Dalziel. She graduated from the Fort Dodge, Iowa schools and attended Grinnell College. She was a pupil of E. Robert Schmitz and of Abby Whiteside. In 1925, while teaching in a Fort Dodge music school directed by Jennie Ringland Smeltzer, she was married to Robert Alden Reaser, artist-son of Willbur A. Reaser, New York portrait painter. After some years of European study, Mrs. Reaser was given her first hearing at the Minneapolis home of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner T. McKnight, early patrons of the Minnesota Orchestra, for whom their concert hall is named. She gave the first of many New York recitals in 1945 at Town Hall. Mrs. Reaser collaborated with her husband in an original entertainment called ''Recitals in Black and White'' in which they portrayed the action of several ballets by means of swift line drawings, music, and commentary. These programs were successful in schools and colleges during the Depression Years and were presented in New York at Carnegie Recital Hall and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Reasers also taught music, art, and sailing at ''Pomemah,'' a girls' summer camp in Kent, Connecticut. In Florida, Mrs. Reaser was active in the Palm Beach Music Teachers' Association, had taught for a time at Gulf Stream Private School, directed music at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, and had recently given many recitals at Abbey Delray, where she has lived since 1986.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, JAMES J.
description: BRADY-James J. Age 91. Died June 10, 1999 at Norwalk CT. Memorial Mass Monday, 9 AM, Saint Joseph's Church, 85 South Main St, Norwalk. Inquiries Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave, Norwalk, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETTMANN, HILDA K., MD.
description: BETTMANN-Hilda K., MD. Died June 8, 1999 at the age of 91 at her home in North Middlesex, VT. Formerly of White Plains, NY. Funeral services will be held Sunday, June 13, 9AM in Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains. Interment will follow in Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY.

title: At Home Abroad; When Praise Is Due
description: Bill Clinton held firm. That was a crucial fact in the Kosovo war, and it should be recognized. Under savage criticism at home and abroad, the President stuck to his policy. And it prevailed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILAR, M. THELMA
description: VILAR-M. Thelma, Retiree of Sperry Gyroscope. Devoted daughter of the late Rachel and Manuel. Survived by her brother Vincent and sister-in-law Muriel. Loving sister of the late William Lopez, Violet Kane and Eunice Sposato. Loving aunt and greataunt. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, New York City, Saturday and Sunday, 25 and 7-9 PM. Interment Monday, Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: South Korean Navy Patrol Boats Ram 3 Ships From the North
description: South Korean patrol boats rammed at least three North Korean vessels today, raising tensions in the five-day standoff in the Yellow Sea.

title: COCA-COLA BUYS FRANCHISEE
description: Coca-Cola said it had bought out its Singapore-based franchisee for seven Asian countries in exchange for shares of Australia's Coca-Cola Amatil valued at $271.3 million. It is buying the stake in the franchisee, F&N Coca-Cola, from Fraser & Neave. With the sale, Coke gets control of its franchises in Brunei, Cambodia, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Singapore and Vietnam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Jackson Atop Lakers' List for Coach
description: Though an agreement has yet to be signed, Phil Jackson appears to be homing in on taking over the Los Angeles Lakers for a deal believed to be worth nearly $30 million over five seasons.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: OUTER AND INNER
description: The words ''health'' and ''beauty'' are so entwined that many confuse them. But they are not a natural match, as Gina Kolata explains in a special section, Women's Health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Until we see the Americans come, we won't know it's really over.''

title: Inquiry Faults Hospital's Emergency Room
description: Federal health care regulators say they have found serious problems with the way Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx runs its emergency room, which is the city's busiest. Their criticisms include poor assessment of the urgency of cases, waits of several hours before patients see doctors and shoddy records on what happens to many patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISENCO, CLAIRE SYLVIA
description: LISENCO-Claire Sylvia. On June 11, 1999 of Flushing, New York. Wife of Yasha. Mother of Peter, Nina & the late Jonathan. Mother in law of Kathy. Sister of Estelle Greenberg. Grandmother of Krista, Joshua and Rachel. Services at 12:15 P.M., Sunday at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations in Claire's memory be made to ''Hale House'' New York City.

title: Ancient Art Of Mexico May Depict The Unborn
description: Was it Roe v. Wade, circa 900 B.C? The breaking of an ancient taboo or an expression of spiritual transformation? Or some other yet-to-be-explained convergence of art, science and religion?

title: MALAYSIAN LOAN TALKS
description: Malaysia is negotiating with 30 foreign banks to borrow up to $1 billion to be used to help restore its ailing banking system and lift its economy from recession. Terms of the loan are to be discussed at a meeting between the central bank and the lenders next week, bankers said. An initial agreement is being rewritten because the cost of borrowing for the Malaysian Government has fallen since the nation sold $1 billion of bonds last month, bankers said.

title: A Short Pause, Then the Allies Start Moving In
description: NATO troops entered Kosovo today as dawn was breaking, hours after Russia's surprise entry into Pristina, the capital, a city that the allied forces plan to make their headquarters for returning a million local Albanians to their homes.

title: No Computer Can Hold the Past
description: Does the Internet help college students learn? Enthusiasts proclaim that it has made a world of information available to any freshman with a computer. Skeptics warn that cyberspace is so full of junk that research in it will never amount to anything more than garbage collecting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: ION BEAM AGREES TO PURCHASE OF STERIGENICS
description: Ion Beam Application S.A., a leading maker of particle accelerators, agreed to buy Sterigenics International Inc., which uses irradiation to sterilize food and medical products, for $214 million, as Ion Beam expands its product range. Ion Beam, based in Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium, will pay $27 a share for Sterigenics. Shares in Sterigenics, which is based in Fremont, Calif., rose $6.25, to $25.75. Ion Beam's stock rose 3.03 euros, to 64.15 euros. Ion Beam's particle accelerators are used to create radioactive substances to treat cancer and to sterilize food.

title: The Multiplex Isn't the Villain; Danger Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERMAN, MAX
description: OBERMAN-Max. Of Stamford, CT on Friday. Husband of Sadie Saltzman Oberman. Father of Lana Oberman, Anita Pettengill, Debbie Oberman and Edward Oberman. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral service will be held Sunday, 12 noon at Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Ave., Stamford.

title: A Subway Line Extends to Hollywood
description: For a brief moment this morning, the cream of the Los Angeles political establishment could be found deep underground, doing something that residents of this sprawling, car-crazed city hardly ever do: riding the subway. And not just any subway, but the spanking new stops under Hollywood that, after two decades of striving, setbacks and billions of dollars, have finally brought the system to just over 11 miles of subterranean track.

title: Male or Female? Take a Look at the Blueprint
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia's Tentative Democracy
description: After 44 years of scripted elections and stultifying military rule, the people of the world's fourth-largest country, Indonesia, got their chance at real democracy this week. They grasped it enthusiastically. Fears of violence proved unfounded. Press coverage was admirably free. On Monday more than 100 million Indonesians, 90 percent of those eligible, cast ballots for Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAME, EDMOND M.
description: BEAME-Edmond M. Age 68. Of Dundas, Ontario. On June 10, 1999. Father of Paul Beame of Seattle, and Carl Beame of Ireland. Son of Mayor Abraham D. Beame of New York. Brother of Bernard Beame of Pleasantville, N.Y. Grandfather of Kathryn and David. Services and burial in Ontario, Canada. Donations to the Leukemia Society of America would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTER, MARGARET
description: SALTER-Margaret, 80, died June 9, of a recurring lung disease. Born Pittsburgh, raised in Knoxville, played a season at Barter Theater, MA in French at UT, the first woman air traffic controller in the tower at La Guardia, WWII, acted in TV ads, sang G&S with Chartok Company, studied dance under Jean Erdman, taught speech and theater at Monmouth University WLB, widow of John, d. '75, presented for the IPA Convention, Washington, Board member Amateur Astronomers, Cranford, a Springfield Telescope Maker, helped build McGregor Observatory, died Morristown Memorial.

title: N.L. Gives Valentine Fine and Suspension
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine was suspended for two games and fined $5,000 by the National League yesterday for violating a league rule by not staying in the clubhouse after he was ejected from the game Wednesday night. Valentine appealed the suspension and may keep managing until his case is heard by the league's president, Leonard Coleman, early next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: City Hall Notes; From Alongside Giuliani To Side of Mrs. Clinton
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton acquaints herself with New York -- so that she can perhaps move here, win a Senate seat and move back to Washington -- she has sought out certain people to educate her about local issues and to be with her for photo opportunities. Among them has been a man who, until very recently, was considered an ally of her likely opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew.

title: MetroStars Seek a Foreign Influence
description: The MetroStars are rebuilding for the second time in three months. They have used a league-record 74 players in their four seasons in Major League Soccer, and they will have at least three new players joining them in the near future.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about a strategy meeting of Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee about the juvenile-justice bill misidentified one participant. She was Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut, not Representative Nita Lowey, Democrat of Westchester County, N.Y.

title: Companies Marshal Defense Against Computer 'Worm'
description: Large corporations worldwide scrambled yesterday to halt the spread of a malicious computer program that began infecting computers in Israel on Monday and spread rapidly to Europe and the United States, carried by E-mail.

title: The Multiplex Isn't the Villain; ID Plan Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * NATO peacekeepers began moving into Kosovo early today, just hours after a Russian armored column entered Pristina, the Kosovo capital, in what Russian officials called a mistake.

title: Jubilant, at First, but Then Jobless
description: As they take the stage this weekend for the final performances of ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown,'' Kristin Chenoweth and Roger Bart will very likely be looking back on one of the more unusual moments of the theater season.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFS: AMERICAS; PROBLEMS AT BIG MEXICO BANK
description: Share trading in Mexico's third-largest financial group, Serfin, has been suspended because of its deepening financial problems. Serfin said it planned to look for new investment. The bank's shares have dropped 55 percent since early April and fell 18.2 percent on Thursday. Serfin, which has more than 500 branches in Mexico and is partly owned by HSBC Holdings, has $1.8 billion in off-balance-sheet liabilities. Despite its four-year struggle to attract investors and increase lending, bank executives said between $1 billion and $4 billion in fresh investment was still needed. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: Report Is Said To Clear Safir Of Violations In Oscars Trip
description: City lawyers have concluded that the New York Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, showed poor judgment but violated no ethics rules or laws by accepting a free junket to the Academy Awards from a corporate executive for Revlon, according to officials familiar with a draft of a report on the trip.

title: About New York; At $13 a Clip, Some Advice For the Mayor
description: LIKE all the best barbers, Carlo Fargnoli understands that advising a customer to consider a new look can be a delicate matter. He might offer gentle nudges -- ''How about a little gel?'' he asked one balding regular, who declined -- but Mr. Fargnoli does not push too hard. Many men choose to go to the same barber not because they want to change, after all, but because they want to stay the same.

title: ACCESS TO BRAZIL OIL
description: Brazil's Government will proceed with its first auction of licenses allowing companies other than the state-controlled Petroleo Brasileiro to explore the country's oil reserves. The go-ahead came after the authorities overturned a preliminary court decision blocking the plan. The auction, which takes place next week, will open access to Brazilian oil reserves to some of the world's largest oil companies. Over nationalist objections, a gradual easing of Brazil's oil monopoly has been taking place during the last two years.

title: Janitors' Union Settles Dispute With Citibank
description: New York City's largest janitors' union announced yesterday that it had settled a long-standing dispute with Citibank, with the bank agreeing to use only cleaning contractors affiliated with the union.

title: Troubled Airlines Cut Costs, but Are They Cutting Corners?
description: KUALA LUMPUR  It has long been assumed, or at the very least hoped, that when airlines talk about cutting costs, they don't mean cutting corners on safety. Cash-strapped Asian airlines have in the past two years announced plans to cut back on meals and in-flight service, but spending on maintenance and fuel has remained  at least publicly  sacred.

title: Chief Rabbi of Poland Is Asking a Favor of 'Mr. Pope'
description: Seizing his moment in a receiving line, Poland's Chief Rabbi brushed past protocol today to ask Pope John Paul II to remove a large cross at the walls of Auschwitz.

title: Does God Belong In U.S. Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: From Doctors to Diplomats, They Chase Piano Dreams
description: Juanita Madland, a schoolteacher from Los Alamos, N.M., walked purposefully across the brightly lighted stage of the Ed Landreth Auditorium at Texas Christian University, smiling a little sheepishly at the audience, and approached the great black hulk of the Steinway concert piano dominating the space.

title: ARRIVA IN DEAL TO SELL ITS AUTOMOTIVE BUSINESS
description: Arriva P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its automotive fleet-management business to the General Motors Corporation's finance unit for $:235 million ($376 million). The finance unit, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, will also assume $:278 million ($445 million) in debt. The fleet management unit, Arriva Automotive Solutions, is one of Britain's biggest fleet companies, managing 70,000 cars for the retailer Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the mortgage lender Halifax P.L.C. and others. The move comes as GMAC expands beyond its main business of financing car loans. On Tuesday, it agreed to buy the Bank of New York's commercial finance business for $1.8 billion, and last month it agreed to acquire the mortgage lender the Contifinancial Corporation. G.M. already has a small fleet of lease vehicles in Britain through the finance arm of its Vauxhall car-making unit.

title: Albright In Skopje To Visit Refugees
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who had made the return of Kosovo Albanian refugees the major mission of the conflict, met them face to face for the first time today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones Average Drops On Interest Rate Concerns

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TANDYCRAFTS INC., Fort Worth, a maker of picture frames and office supplies, said it would lay off as many as 400 workers, or 18 percent of its work force, and close a California plant to reduce costs at its picture-frame unit.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RUSSIAN AUTO MAKER RISES
description: Shares in the Russian car maker Gorkovsky Avtomobilny Zavod climbed 22 percent this week after the decline in the value of the ruble increased sales of domestic models. Gorkovsky shares closed at $30.50 and are up 71 percent since mid-May. Gorkovsky produces the Volga, a large car that was once favored by the K.G.B. and was only available in black, although now it comes in a range of colors. Basic models of Russian cars now sell for $3,000 to $5,000, compared with a range of $7,000 to $15,000 for foreign cars.

title: Strong Consumer Spending Worsens the Interest-Rate Jitters; Data Convince Many That Fed Will Move; Yield Climbs to 6.16%
description: American consumers, the backbone of the second-longest economic expansion ever, are not showing any signs of pinching pennies. And their spending spree is putting continued upward pressure on market interest rates, with long-term yields jumping to a 19-month high yesterday.

title: Whitman Reportedly Asks Illinois Man to Lead Police
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has reportedly offered the job of New Jersey State Police superintendent to an Illinois law enforcement commander, state officials said today. If he accepts the position, he will become the first black to hold the top office in the department, which has been tarnished by complaints of racial discrimination.

title: A Simple Downtown Look
description: Streamlined, uncluttered and complex in conception despite a deceptive simplicity, Trisha Brown's production of ''L'Orfeo'' comes directly out of the experimental dances she has composed since the 1960's. As choreography, her work here is a brilliant innovative synthesis and transformation of ideas past. One might have wondered how a choreographer who disdained narrative and music for decades and prided herself on creating movement that had no specific connotation, could direct and choreograph an opera.

title: California Woman Arrested As a Successor to Heidi Fleiss
description: Six years after the police here titillated the country with the arrest of Heidi Fleiss, who became known as the Hollywood Madam, the Los Angeles Police Department said today that it had arrested one of her main rivals, Jody Diane Gibson, known as Babydol, and charged her with running a high-level international prostitution ring.

title: Torn Ligament Ends Lobo's Season Early
description: The news on Rebecca Lobo was bad and good yesterday.

title: Knicks Shrug Off Adversity Once Again to Reach Finals
description: There was the final buzzer and the signal to rejoice over what seemed more impossible than ever last night. But a Knicks team that was once fractured has come to treat adversity and misfortune like emotional allies, and it used the image of Larry Johnson exiting Game 6 in pain as one more reason to live.

title: Garden-Variety Delirium As Knicks Win a Big One
description: Horns were blaring, pedestrians were howling and traffic was at a standstill around Madison Square Garden late last night but no one seemed to be complaining.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Strong Consumer Spending Worsens the Interest-Rate Jitters; Once Again, Wall St. Worries About Hedge Funds
description: Investors stung by falling bond prices and a strengthening Japanese yen fled the Treasury market yesterday, driving the 30-year bond yield up to 6.16 percent, its highest level since November 1997.

title: The Multiplex Isn't the Villain; Killer Sonnets?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Police Say Teen-Ager Poisoned Aide's Coffee
description: A 15-year-old high school student in Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with assault after he tried to poison a school aide by spiking her coffee with rubbing alcohol, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Plans To Begin Its Inquiry At Once
description: An advance team of F.B.I. agents will go to Kosovo this weekend to assess the forensic needs of the international authorities who are about to start the most thorough inquiry into war crimes since World War II, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, SAMUEL (SYDNEY)
description: RUBIN-Samuel (Sydney). Age 87, of Allendale, NJ formerly of Cliffside Park, NJ, on June 10, 1999. Survived by his wife Rose; daughters, Judith and Joel Dorfman and Joan & Irwin Leib; brother, Henry; five grandchildren, Eric, Dana and Craig Dorfman and David and Jennifer Leib; two great-grandchildren, Alexa & Noah Dorfman. Services 2:00PM, Sunday, graveside at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. For information, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Big Bank Says It Won't Share Customer Data
description: As concern about consumer privacy issues heightens, the Bank of America Corporation, one of the country's largest banks, said yesterday that it was adopting new rules about the use of personal information by its customers.

title: 3 Democrats Lead the Senate in Wealth, Records Show
description: In financial disclosure reports released today, the Senate's leaders, whose salaries are the highest in the chamber, revealed that their earnings and assets pale in comparison with some of their multimillionaire colleagues'.

title: Film Company Sued by Holders
description: American Film Technologies Inc., which pioneered the colorizing of black-and-white movies, and its chief executive, Gerald Wetzler, have been sued by shareholders who contend that Mr. Wetzler has squandered corporate assets and driven the company into the ground.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the resignation of Louis R. Anemone from the New York City Police Department misstated the date on which he was shown with Police Commissioner Howard Safir. It was in April, not yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATIS, ROBERT S.
description: MATIS-Robert S. Beloved husband of Eileen S. Devoted father of Nina, Louis and Lyn Matis. Adored grandfather of Garson Fischer, Jessica, Elizabeth and Emily Matis. Dear brother of Mildred Lazarus. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 12:30PM Sunday. Donations to the Brain Tumor Society, 84 Seattle St., Boston, MA. 02134-1245 would be appreciated.

title: Pakistan Earns Spot In the Semifinals
description: Pakistan clinched a place in the World Cup semifinals with a 148-run victory over Zimbabwe, sealed by a hat trick by Saqlain Mushtaq, yesterday in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Two Men in Texas Are Subpoenaed to Testify in Bin Laden Case
description: Two Muslim men from Texas have been subpoenaed to testify next week before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan investigating Osama bin Laden, who is a suspect in the American embassy bombings in Africa last year and other terrorist acts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Corpse Under Motel Bed Identified as New Yorker
description: A man whose body was found stuffed underneath a motel room bed was identified yesterday as a New York City resident who had been stabbed to death two days earlier, the authorities said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, RABBI EUGENE J.
description: SACK-Rabbi Eugene J. The entire community of Congregation Beth Elohim mourns the passing of our beloved Rabbi emeritus, Eugene J. Sack who will long be remembered as a great spiritual leader. He was a man of grace and style whose eloquence, compassion and concern for social justice enriched us all. Our sincere condolences to the Sack family. Services at Congregation Beth Elohim Eight Avenue and Garfield Place Brooklyn, Tuesday June 15th 10:30 am. Gerald M. Spielman, Pres. Gerald I. Weider, Rabbi

title: John Whiting, 90, of Harvard, A Child-Growth Anthropologist
description: John Wesley Mayhew Whiting, a professor emeritus of social anthropology at Harvard who studied learning processes and child development in varying societies, died on May 13 at home in Chilmark, Mass., in the house where he was born on Martha's Vineyard. He was 90.

title: JAPAN'S SOFTBANK TO GET 30% OF GLOBAL SPORTS
description: Global Sports Inc., the operator of electronic-commerce sites for sporting goods retailers, said yesterday that Japan's Softbank Corporation would take a 30 percent stake for $80 million. The company also said that it planned to sell its non-Internet assets, including its Ryka and Yukon athletic-shoe brands. Global Sports said last month that it would run the Web businesses of retailers including Sports Authority Inc. and Athlete's Foot through its Global Sports Interactive unit. Global Sports, of King of Prussia, Pa., said the investment would allow it to increase Internet marketing and international operations.

title: Beliefs; The leader of Kosovo's Muslims, himself a chief victim of the terror, sees reason to hope for a lasting reconciliation in the Balkans.
description: Dr. Rexhep Boja, the Grand Mufti of Kosovo, left New York last Sunday for Istanbul. Yesterday he was heading for the refugee camps in Albania and Macedonia so that he could be with people as they faced the joys and terrors of returning home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: State Set to Give Giuliani Power to Cut Speed Limits Sharply
description: State lawmakers are likely to give the Giuliani administration the blanket authority it has sought to lower speed limits on New York City streets to as low as 15 miles per hour, a power the Mayor says the city needs to make side streets safer for pedestrians.

title: Planes vs. Park
description: To the Editor:

title: As Federal Prosecutor Quits, Aspiring Successors Rush In
description: Among those seeking to become the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York when Zachary W. Carter steps down next month is his chief assistant. But others who work or have worked in Mr. Carter's office, and lawyers in private practice, have also expressed interest, other lawyers say.

title: Pumpernickel in My Purse
description: ''This bread is sensational!'' my husband said at dinner one night. ''Where did you get it?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, PHILIP
description: SCHNEIDER-Philip. Beloved husband of the late Helen, devoted father of Paul and George, fatherin-law of Cathy and Linda. Cherished grandfather of five. Dear brother of Isidore.

title: Ron Link, 58, Director Known For His Theatrical Experiments
description: Ron Link, a director known for his work off Off Broadway in the 1970's and 80's and later in experimental theater in Los Angeles, died on Monday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 58 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the criminal conviction of a Syracuse businessman, Patrick R. Bennett, referred incorrectly in some copies to the types of fraud the jury found he had committed. They were money laundering, bank fraud and securities fraud involving promissory notes -- not stock fraud.

title: Walton And Pals Will Be Missed
description: There are people who can't stand Bill Walton.

title: Giles S. Rich, Oldest Active Federal Judge, Dies at 95
description: Judge Giles S. Rich, the oldest active Federal judge in the country's history, who helped draft the nation's patent laws and later, as a patent judge, became a powerful advocate for the rights of inventors, died Wednesday night at a hospital in Washington. He was 95.

title: Man Convicted of Murder May Get Death Penalty
description: A 22-year-old man was convicted yesterday of murdering an off-duty police officer and the owner of a Queens check cashing business during a robbery in 1996, and could face the death penalty.

title: DeForest Kelley, 79, Creator Of Dr. McCoy on 'Star Trek'
description: DeForest Kelley, the crotchety country doctor who healed countless human and nonhuman patients as Dr. Leonard McCoy on the science fiction series ''Star Trek,'' died yesterday at the Motion Pictures and Television Fund Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 79, and had last donned a space uniform in 1991 for yet another ''Star Trek'' film sequel.

title: As Task Force Chief, U.N.'s No. 2 Official Is Put to Test
description: It is midafternoon in Kosovo when Louise Frechette's forces assemble here each morning at 9 sharp.

title: For the Moment, No Rush to Return to Kosovo
description: A few eager refugees came back to the border here today. No one tried to go home, and it was not hard to see why: bombs are no longer falling, but smoke rose from two villages on the Kosovo side. Photographers with long lenses said two corpses floated on the far side of the lake.

title: DIAMOND MERGER REJECTED
description: Share holders of Ocean Diamond Mining Holdings and Trans-Hex Group, two South African diamond mining companies, rejected a proposed merger of the two companies. The combined company would have had a market value of at least $100 million and produce more than 177,000 carats a year in South Africa and Namibia, Niel Hoogenhout, the Trans-Hex managing director, said.

title: Sports of The Times; Manager Issued a Foolish Challenge
description: ACCORDING to yesterday's National League edict, Bobby Valentine, the Mets' manager, has been suspended for two games for ''the violation of rule 5.1'' during Wednesday night's 4-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays in 14 innings -- not remaining in the clubhouse until the game ended after having been ejected. He also was fined $5,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Beirut Journal; Beautiful Beaches and Bronzed Men, but No Bathing Belles
description: Ah, summertime, and Beirut is flocking to the beach.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Does God Belong In U.S. Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Word, Culture Means Anything, Bad as Well as Good
description: There is a villain at large in the land. What led to the horrendous behavior of the convicted policemen in the Abner Louima case? What caused the killings of high school students in Littleton, Colo.? Why did welfare often fail to change the underclass into the working poor? Why has Microsoft been so ruthless? And why do so many American students perform so poorly on standardized tests?

title: Editorial Observer; Coming to Terms With Kosovo's 'Old' Hatreds
description: In the annals of American Presidents and the Balkans, an arc can be traced from Bill Clinton back to Woodrow Wilson. At the Versailles peace conference following World War I, Wilson arrived after reviewing European history and then helped establish a new southern Slavic state to fill the vacuum created by the collapse of the Ottoman and Austrian empires. There is a famous moment in which Wilson, the idealist, squatted on the floor with his experts over a gigantic map of places he had never been. His wife walked in and commented that they looked like boys playing a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: INSIDE
description: Special-Education Overhaul

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, SHIRLEY
description: LIEBMAN-Shirley. Devoted and beloved sister of Carolyn Dorman, Howard Liebman and the late Arnold Liebman. Cherished sister-inlaw of Marilyn and Martha Liebman. Adored aunt of Allison, Phyllis, Judith Liebman, Cindy, Amy and Talia Amoyal. the sun and the moon will shine less brightly without Shirley. Funeral Sunday June 13th, 1:30PM at Gutterman's, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: John Calhoun Baker, 103; President of Ohio University
description: John Calhoun Baker, president emeritus of Ohio University, who guided it through the burgeoning enrollment when the veterans of World War II surged in under the G.I. Bill, died on Wednesday at a retirement community in Hightstown, N.J., where he moved three years ago. A former resident of Essex Fells, N.J., he was 103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLL, FLORENCE
description: KROLL-Florence. We mourn the passing of Florence Kroll, beloved mother and grandmother, and extend our sincere condolences to Jules and Lynn Kroll and the entire family. The Solomon Schecter School of Westchester, M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of the National Semiconductor Corporation omitted the given name and title of the company executive who provided some of the explanation for its results. He is Brian L. Halla, president and chief executive.

title: Conservatives Say Pamphlet On Testing Goes Too Far
description: The Department of Education has come under fire for suggesting ways that school districts and colleges could avoid being sued over standardized tests, with conservatives accusing the department of trying to do away with the tests altogether.

title: Delta to Defer Plane Orders In Rift With Pilots Over Pay
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would defer an order for 11 Boeing 777 aircraft and that it would put two 777's that it already owns on the market because it could not reach an agreement on pay scales for flying the airplanes with its pilots.

title: Ethical Issues Arise in Boom in Pet Microchips
description: Wilbur ran away one day last summer. Distraught, Debbie and Jim Pittman tried everything to find him. They put up ''lost dog'' fliers on hundreds of telephone poles, and they checked with nearly every pound around Puget Sound. Nothing. ''But we never gave up hope,'' Mrs. Pittman said. ''We knew he had his microchip.''

title: TELECOM SHARE SALE
description: SK Telecom, a leading South Korean mobile telephone service provider, said it planned to sell shares and raise about 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) to upgrade and expand its telephone network. SK Telecom shares have almost doubled in the last three months and the foreign ownership limit in most domestic telecommunications companies is due to increase to 49 percent from 33 percent July 1.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL SOARS. Oil products rose on news of a pipeline explosion in Washington State and a possible strike in Venezuela. In New York, the July contract was up 2.10 cents, or 4.9 percent, to 44.85 cents a gallon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, JAN JAFFE
description: KAHN-Jan Jaffe. Died June 10 at 2:45AM of multiple myeloma. With her were her husband Ron and her daughters Laura and Sasha. She was a screenwriter, playwright and novelist of extraordinary sensitivities. Graveside services Sunday, June 13th, 1 PM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to The Myeloma Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Sports of The Times; This Drama Has Only One Hero
description: FEW events can reduce New York to small-town giddiness, but these new Knicks have broken through the sophisticated veneer of the city and shrunk it to a quaint village mad about its local team. Now, with a 90-82 victory last night, the team is Eastern Conference champion, and this cool city known for its aloofness is going absolutely wild.

title: Like Father, Like Daughter in Indonesia, Or So Sukarno's Faded Loyalists Hope
description: To enter Supeni's sun-dappled home here is to be transported to a different time -- a newsreel era in which Indonesia was young and a brash soldier named Sukarno ruled.

title: Sports of The Times; If His Old Friend Red Could See Them Now
description: MORE than 50 years around the game, Fuzzy Levane said, and he has never seen anything like this. He's never seen a basketball team remake itself in a New York minute, and then keeping winning the way these Knicks have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: AEROSPACE MERGER
description: DaimlerChrysler Aerospace of Germany and Spain's state-owned aircraft company Construcciones Aeronauticas announced in Madrid their plan to merge and create a European aerospace giant with combined sales of 9.7 billion euros. The new company would own 42.1 percent of Airbus Industrie.

title: Ty Cobb Never Got Cheered for Striking Out; Winning Isn't All
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera Made Whole With Dance
description: Opera can be looked at as a race between music and theater in which the contestants want desperately to finish in a dead heat. The odds against it are long. The progress of music is slow, depending on patterns that transform gradually and double back on themselves. Theater runs more by the clock, people speaking and moving in real time. The dilemma for opera producers is theater arriving prematurely at the finish line, drumming its fingers and waiting for music to catch up.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, GILBERT
description: MERRILL-Gilbert. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife Julia, and family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Combat Plane From '50s Plays Vital Role in Kosovo : A Long-Lived U.S. Workhorse
description: PARIS  When NATO needed more punishing ground strikes midway through its air war in Kosovo, General Wesley Clark could not overcome the political objections to using Apache anti-tank helicopters and turned instead to Spectre gunships  one of the enduring configurations of the C-130 Hercules, the world's most flown military aircraft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, MICHAEL HARRISON
description: COHEN-Michael Harrison. WE LOVE YOU & WE MISS YOU. Love Mom, Dad & Charles

title: In Belgium's Food Crisis, Bad Luck or Bad System?
description: BRUSSELS  Was it bad luck, or was Belgium's food contamination scandal a symptom of a dysfunctional political system?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the worldwide spread of a malicious computer program included a company erroneously among those affected. Executives of Symantec, a maker of antivirus software, said their company's computers were not affected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Kremlin vs. Its Army
description: The arrival of Russian troops in Pristina before dawn today raises disturbing questions about the Kremlin's control of the military.

title: Commuter Tax Law Is Called Unfair in Court
description: Lawyers for New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut charged in court yesterday that the new law repealing the commuter tax only for New York State residents was politically motivated and unfair.

title: College Applicants Of '99 Are Facing Stiffest Competition
description: The signs have been evident for several months: top high school seniors rejected by colleges of their choice, second-tier institutions overwhelmed with excellent applications, state universities raising admission requirements.

title: An American in Warsaw; U.S. Businesswoman Challenges Old Phone Monopoly
description: The lobby of the Sheraton Hotel here was packed with dark-suited bankers last Wednesday, when Barbara J. Lundberg blazed in.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 1 about Memorial Day observances in New York City referred incorrectly to the service record of Bronislaw Bartkowski, who lives in Queens. He served during World War II in the First Polish Army Division, which was under the command of the British Army -- not in the United States Army. He was awarded Poland's Cross for Valor and several British medals, but not the Medal of Honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Under Federal Threat, Albany Seeks to Overhaul Special Education
description: Legislative leaders are nearing an agreement on overhauling the state's special education program to discourage schools from placing disabled students in segregated classrooms, legislative aides from both parties said today.

title: Incoming Executive Hints at Where Nissan Is Heading
description: Carlos Ghosn, the former Renault S.A. executive who will soon be helping manage the Nissan Motor Company, today gave reporters a peek at where he hopes to help steer the troubled Japanese car maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Mets Toss Aside Piazza's Comeback Script
description: The Mets, who seem to thrive on stress lately, nearly pulled another one out of the confusion last night on another day of chaos at Shea Stadium. But this time they wound up deflated after a ninth-inning comeback and lost, 3-2, to the Boston Red Sox in 12 innings.

title: News Corp. Seen in Talks For Publishers
description: The News Corporation's HarperCollins is in discussions to acquire the Hearst Corporation's Avon Books and William Morrow & Company, a person close to the talks confirmed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Miller Goes Quietly Into the Night
description: This time there were no deadly 3-pointers, no 8 points in 8.7 seconds, no choke sign. No heartbreak for the Knicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Does God Belong In U.S. Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page credit yesterday with a picture of the soccer player Mia Hamm misspelled the name of the advertising agency that supplied the television commercial in which she was seen. It is Foote Cone & Belding, not Foote Tone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURO, HEATHER ROSE
description: BURO-Heather Rose. Bright, sunny, loving and incredibly courageous as she fought her dread disease for two years. She left us on June 10, at age five. To her parents, our niece and nephew, Barbara and Edward Buro, and her grandparents, our sister and brother-in-law, Ruth and Eugene Czeisler, we stand in awe at their extraordinary commitment and tenaciousness in their battle to cure and comfort Heather. We grieve for them and for Heather's sister, Alyssa, her brother, Justin, grandparents, Rose and Patrick Buro, and the entire family. May they take comfort in the memory of this remarkable child. Herbert Rubin, and Justice Rose L. Rubin

title: Ty Cobb Never Got Cheered for Striking Out
description: To the Editor:

title: NVEST TO BUY KORICK FUNDS MONEY-MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: Nvest L.P. said that it had agreed to acquire Kobrick Funds L.L.C., a money-management firm partly owned by the Cendant Corporation, for an undisclosed amount. Nvest said it had signed the agreement late Thursday to purchase all of Kobrick Funds, the manager of three mutual funds with about $200 million of assets. Both companies are based in Boston. The agreement includes a contractual commitment by the funds' top manager, Fred Kobrick, to continue running the funds for about seven years, the company said. The biggest Kobrick fund, Kobrick Capital, was up 12.4 percent this year as of Thursday's close.

title: Albanians, Still Fearful, Awaiting U.S. Troops
description: Up a pitted dirt road on the outskirts of town, near a still-smoldering house and the sun-baked remains of looted shops, two Albanian men, clearly frightened, rose from their raw plywood table and ducked through a doorway, leaving their playing cards behind.

title: Human Error Is Blamed In Sinking of Clam Boat
description: Human error led to the sinking of a clam boat off southern New Jersey in January, the United States Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: Hoping the Web Will Rescue Young Professors; In the Publish-or-Perish World, Can They Live on the Internet?
