description: Gregory S. Brown, an assistant professor of history at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, is by almost any standard an outstanding young scholar. His dissertation adviser at Columbia University, Isser Wolloch, called him ''certainly one of the very best students I've had.'' The dissertation committee, Mr. Wolloch said, judged Mr. Brown's thesis on the status of French writers during the Enlightenment as ''extremely original, creative, insightful.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO STRENGTHENS. The dollar had its worst week against the euro since the currency was introduced in January, falling 1.6 percent on rate fears. In New York, the euro settled at $1.05350, up from $1.0490 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Male or Female? Take a Look at the Blueprint
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Plans to Raise Tuition by 4.4 Percent
description: The Rutgers University Board of Governors yesterday approved a 4.4 percent tuition increase for undergraduates this fall.

title: At Spoleto, the Novelty Is Still Novel
description: The elderly theatergoer was eager for enlightenment. ''Why do you have that masking tape on your back?'' she asked an actor sporting a black strip on his costume, between the shoulder blades. ''It represents our skin color,'' replied the actor, whose job it was to mingle with the audience just before the curtain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, DOUGLAS R.
description: NICHOLS-Douglas R., 104. Of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ died June 6, 1999. Mr. Nichols was the son of the late Mr. & Mrs. E. Remington Nichols of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, New Jersey. His maternal grandfather was Mr. James Mitchell, the first Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Nichols was the oldest Alumnus of Princeton University, Class of 1917, at the time of his death. He is survived by his son & daughterin-law, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas R. Nichols, Jr. of Gulf Stream, Florida and a granddaughter, Mrs. Susan N. Ferriere of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAIT, HAROLD
description: MAIT-Harold. 4/3/45-6/12/97. We cherish your spirit and our memories. Love you & miss you. Kisses Janet, Josh, Jenny, David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: City Charges Several Dozen In a Scheme On Benefits
description: A police detective, four schoolteachers and a New York City Transit employee were among dozens of government employees and others accused yesterday of cheating the city out of more than $1.4 million dollars in housing subsidies or welfare benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: 8 Charged With Getting Kickbacks at 31 Buildings
description: In the latest round of indictments arising from an investigation of bid-rigging and kickbacks by apartment managers and contractors, the Manhattan District Attorney yesterday charged the owners of three real estate companies, a building superintendent and four managers with systematically stealing money from the residents of 31 buildings.

title: Chicago Expresses Annoyance but Understanding Over Decision on Loitering
description: For more than 20 years, Bennie Meeks watched out his apartment window as gang members routinely occupied the nearby street corner. Sometimes they sold drugs. Sometimes they merely intimidated, by their very presence. Either way, Mr. Meeks, a community leader in the Austin section, on Chicago's West Side, wanted them out of there.

title: Does God Belong In U.S. Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDELMAN, ROSLYN
description: RANDELMAN-Roslyn, on June 10th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Hal and Mary. Proud grandmother of Craig and Nicole. Dear sister-in-law of Evelyn Rifkin and Beulah Glickman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, June 13th, 7-9 PM, with service on Monday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: U.S. Leaders Are Shocked But Accept Russia Story
description: The White House was first stunned and then bewildered tonight to learn that Russian troops had rolled into Pristina, the Kosovo capital, after receiving assurances from Moscow all day that its troops would not move in until NATO had given them a green light.

title: Two U.S. Utilities to Sell British Unit
description: PP&L Resources Inc., owner of Pennsylvania's second-largest electric utility, and the Southern Company said today that they had agreed to sell their British power-supply business to London Electricity for about $256 million.

title: Police Intensify Patrols As Girls Report Intruder
description: The police say they are increasing patrols and staking out a neighborhood in central Woodbridge after three reports of a man breaking into the bedrooms of young girls.

title: Modano's Status A Playoff Mystery
description: In hockey's grand tradition of playoff obfuscation, Mike Modano's injury is listed as a sprained left wrist, and his recovery is projected as day to day. Literally, this time frame is true. But the day of return just might be October, when next season begins. Or, it could be Saturday night, when the Dallas Stars meet the Buffalo Sabres in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Big Dream Batters A Small Orchestra; A Tanglewood in Dutchess Leads to Lawsuits and Red Ink
description: Although they make no claims that their orchestra rivals the New York Philharmonic or the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the musicians and patrons of the Hudson Valley Philharmonic can dream as gaudily as anyone. A year ago, they dreamed of creating a summer home for the orchestra that might become another Tanglewood.

title: Stepping Outside The Family, but Not Straying From It
description: THE country musician June Carter Cash owns 200 sets of china, and her husband, Johnny Cash, has described her reverently as having ''a black belt in shopping.'' But perhaps the urge to collect something like china -- a simple, everyday object executed with such care and craft as to raise it to a fine art -- is just in her blood. She is, after all, a Carter, the musical family that collected, arranged and recorded hundreds of American traditional, spiritual and folk songs in the 1920's and 30's and laid the foundation for modern country music. With the release of her new album, the deeply felt and deceptively simple ''Press On,'' the 70-year-old Ms. Cash has demonstrated once again what makes the Carters, and traditional country music, such a moving voice of the American experience.

title: Rambling Walton
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. Anderson And Mr. Edmands
description: Francesca Guthrie Chiara Anderson, a daughter of Francesca and Bradley Anderson of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at her parents' summer house in Southold, N.Y., to Benjamin Bruce Edmands, the son of Susan B. Edmands of Stamford, Conn., and Bruce W. Anderson of Waban, Mass. The Rev. William Grimbol, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Steven Eichenauer, Susan Schieffer
description: Susan Neville Schieffer, a daughter of Patricia and Bob Schieffer of Washington, was married last evening to Steven Ward Eichenauer, the son of Constance and H. W. Eichenauer of Georgetown, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Dean McDonald performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington.

title: Q&A/Dr. Barnett S. Meyers; Fighting the Idea of Old Age as Depressing
description: THE idea that being old means being depressed is a myth propagated by the young to make themselves feel better, said Dr. Barnett S. Meyers, a gerontologist who is chief of specialized services for older adults at New York Presbyterian Hospital Westchester division in White Plains.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, LESTER M., DR.
description: GOLDEN-Lester M., Dr. On May 30, 1999. Son of Frank and Julia Golden and brother of Shirley Krause. Services were held June 3rd. He will be missed.

title: Alarm Sounds in Longwood
description: The Longwood neighborhood has come a long way from the era of empty lots and burned-out buildings, when the local police precinct was known as Fort Apache. But the neighborhood, now a thriving residential and commercial area, is still the site of a grisly number of traffic accidents.

title: Katie Rosenberg, William Lynch
description: Katie Rosenberg was married on Thursday evening to William E. Lynch. Rabbi Judith S. Lewis officiated at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum in New York.

title: Jaime Bachrach, Timothy Clew
description: Jaime Bachrach, a daughter of Catherine and William Bachrach of Kent, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy William Clew, the son of Joy and Harvey Clew of Haddam, Conn. William Huffstetler, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at the Ruffle House at Wesleyan University in Middletown.

title: Lukewarm Response To New Lyme Vaccine
description: WHEN SmithKline Beecham announced last winter that it had won approval for a vaccine against Lyme disease, doctors and patients hailed the news with excitement and relief. Despite that initial flush of enthusiasm, however, hundreds of thousands of doses of the vaccine, called Lymerix, are sitting unused in doctors' offices.

title: The Revenge Of the Bean Counters; Studios Yell 'Cut!' As Costs Spiral For Filmmaking
description: TEN years ago, the stars, and their agents, ruled Hollywood. Duds like ''Legal Eagles'' and ''Family Business'' were packaged by talent agents for clients like Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman and Sean Connery, and the studios, without batting an eye, paid lavish sums to make them.

title: Anne Akers, Adam Klyver
description: Anne Davis Akers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Akers of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Adam John Klyver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Dan Klyver of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Broadcast Coverage Focuses on an Exciting U.S. Team With Candid Audio
description: The Women's World Cup is not as venerated or historic as its male counterpart, which was played for the 16th time last year. But in its third edition, the women's tournament has an advantage that ESPN and ABC can relish: the United States team is arguably the world's best and is a favorite to win. There are no tales of the United States women's team struggling to meet the talent levels of the Brazilian, Argentine, German or Italian teams.

title: Bookend; Hebrew for Swingers
description: THE week of Israel's election, the nonfiction title heading the best-seller list of the national daily Haaretz was, appropriately enough, ''Days of Netanyahu,'' a scathing account of the Netanyahu administration by a respected political analyst. But perhaps even more revealing was the fiction list: this is where you find the Israel that dealt the Likud and its gloom-and-doom vision of Israel's predicament its setback. Five of the top 10 titles were stories of illicit or complicated love affairs -- for example, ''Early Grace,'' a tale of a 50-something teacher enjoying a tempestuous liaison with his 20-something student, which made the list for the 13th week in a row.

title: The Hermitage Sees The Future, and It Works
description: IRA KONORSKAYA, a Ukrainian schoolgirl, was making a tour of the Hermitage musuem with her grandmother recently when she spotted a bank of computers at the museum's new educational center. Curious, she took a seat and within minutes was intently dragging images from a painting by the 16th- century Venetian master Titian across the screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BERNICE (NEE SCHNALL)
description: SHAPIRO-Bernice (nee Schnall). 77, of Hollywood, FL, and Freeport, NY, died suddenly Saturday, June 12. Wife of Lee Shapiro; mother of Hally (Richard) Schwartz and Barrie (Marc) Lazarus; grandmother of Jonathan; and sister of the late Pearl Beckmann. Her love, wit and humor will always be an inspiration to us. Private services.

title: Blame It on Chile
description: THE NANNY AND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYERSON, DONALD S.
description: RYERSON-Donald S. June 8, 1999. Cherished brother of Doris Zaphiropoulos and her husband Miltiades. Funeral private.

title: To Every Fete, There Is a Season
description: NONE of the old friends, and there were quite a few -- Nancy Kissinger, Lynn Wyatt, Dominick Dunne, Bill Blass, Casey Ribicoff, Barbara Walters, Johnny Galliher and Pat Buckley -- who showed up for Fete de Famille on Wednesday night probably expected the annual tent party to be the same now that Glenn Bernbaum is gone.

title: Getting My Tuneup, So to Speak
description: BOTH my car and my stomach have shown signs of wear recently. The car is balky, slow, uncomfortable and noisy, and the stomach is much the same. With more than 150,000 hard miles on it, the car doesn't warrant any big investment on repairs, and I feel the same way about my digestive system. As my mother always says, there's no point in throwing good money after bad.

title: Michigan Term Limits Bring Reversal of Roles and Power
description: Mary Ann Middaugh had been an aide in the Michigan Statehouse for a quarter-century when her husband, State Representative James Middaugh, was forced out of office after 16 years by the state's term-limits law. Mr. Middaugh left last year, but she stayed: after all, she won the race to replace him.

title: Foundation Puts Lawyer On the Trail of $2 Billion
description: A charitable foundation has hired a lawyer to try to recover nearly $2 billion entrusted to a Greenwich securities firm that is under F.B.I. scrutiny.

title: Book Clubs? I'm a Reader, Not a Follower
description: ON the floor next to my bed are three books: a book about ''talent education'' by Shinichi Suzuki (of the Suzuki music method), a book about child development by Stanley Greenspan, a psychiatrist, and ''The Puttermesser Papers,'' a novel by Cynthia Ozick.

title: How Do You Say Rickshaw in French?
description: Visitors to Paris have a new way to tour the city: three-wheeled black-and-yellow velo-taxis, or taxi-bikes. These rickshaws have fiberglass passenger carriages and 21 gears. The 20 taxi-bikes, operated by bilingual students, follow a three-mile circuit beginning and ending at the Place de la Concorde. The trip lasts an hour, and passes the Jardin des Tuileries, Place de l'Opera, Place de la Madeleine, Place Vendome, the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay. Passengers can request stops for photographs.

title: Sally Jacobson, Thomas Gittleman
description: Sally Anne Jacobson and Thomas Noah Gittleman are to be married today by Rabbi Jeffrey Summit at Willowbend Country Club in Mashpee, Mass.

title: Bonnie Segall, Justin Soodek
description: Bonnie Lynne Segall, a daughter of Kathy and Joel A. Segall of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Justin B. Soodek, a son of Roberta and Jerry Soodek of Paradise Valley, Ariz. Rabbi Albert Lowenberg officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: For This 'Lost' Artist, It's Paradise Regained
description: THAT poor guy, he was exactly like me,'' said Alex Echo, running his hand along the large boulder that is Jackson Pollock's headstone at the Green River Cemetery in East Hampton. ''Zero self-esteem. Unsure of his own artwork. A drunk, a well-publicized drunk. He lived in paradise and couldn't see it.''

title: Even the Tennis Court Has a Glass Ceiling
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Changed, but Who Deserves the Credit?
description: ''People say I look like a monkey,'' the President of Indonesia, B. J. Habibie, told an audience of schoolteachers not long ago. ''But I don't care.''

title: My Heart Belongs to Da
Introduction
description: Readers were riveted by Michael Winerip's report on how we are failing the mentally ill -- and how that failure may be putting all of us at risk. Letter writers welcomed our salute to women of the millennium, but some contended that the issue could have been more representative of women's true diversity.

title: Lives; Beneath the Falling Bombs
description: In a moral universe full of shadows and grief, I have been an American correspondent working in a country at war with America.

title: Primary Day Was a Good One For Assembly Incumbents
description: Only one of the 80 Assembly members running in last week's primary election lost his bid for re-election. Louis Romano, who wanted to run for a fifth two-year term, lost the party nomination to West New York's Mayor, Albio Sires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUKATCH, ANNE
description: PUKATCH-Anne. Age 91, on June 12, 1999. Devoted mother of Steve, and Donna Citrin. Dear mother-inlaw of Phyllis Pukatch and Charles Citrin. Beloved grandmother of Kelly Citrin. Loving aunt, great aunt, and ''super tante'' of Seymour Auerbach. Funeral service Monday, June 14, 12 noon at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Interment to follow at the Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DOORS

title: Athletes Are Told To Be More Vocal
description: George J. Mitchell, the former United States Senate majority leader who headed a commission that criticized the International Olympic Committee, told Olympic athletes yesterday to be more visible and vocal in urging that the I.O.C. make significant reforms in the wake of the Salt Lake City vote-buying scandal.

title: Ms. Harris, Mr. Mueenuddin
description: Rachel Jeanne Harris and Daniyal Neyan Mueenuddin were married yesterday in Elroy, Wis. James Hayes, who is the court clerk of Grant Township, Wis., and the bride's great-uncle, officiated at Millard's Prairie Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: An Engaging Restaurant Giving Way to Sameness
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinching for Growth, Spraying for Pests
description: Keep up with weeding. Continue pinching chrysanthemums and asters to increase flowering and prevent them from becoming lanky. If you haven't been patiently pinching new growth on each stem all spring, shear up to one-half of the height now. Pinching sedum will make stems sturdier and better able to support the weight of late-summer flower heads. Remove most old flower stalks from Siberian iris, but leave some to develop seed pods for winter interest.

title: Norway's Rivalry With U.S. Is Intense
description: When Norway won the 1995 Women's World Cup, one of every four Norwegians watched the championship match on television, team officials said. When the players returned from the tournament in Sweden, their plane was escorted into Oslo by two F-16 fighter jets. The 1999 world soccer championship begins next weekend, and Norway is taking no chances that it will be caught off guard in defending its title by either the heat or the time difference in the United States.

title: Bedlam on the Streets
description: Michael Winerip's article (May 23) on Andrew Goldstein and his chaotic existence within (or without) the mental-health system is the most scathing indictment of that system I've seen. I read it with tears and anger. I've had one sibling struggle with and die from cancer. I've had another struggle with and die from mental illness. No end of help was given the brother with osteosarcoma. Little to no help was available for the delusional brother who eventually committed suicide. The pain of watching someone lose his mind is more than I can describe. What must it be like to be that person?

title: Interleague Thrills Are Coming From Unexpected Sources
description: A primary attraction of inter league games is supposed to be the opportunity they afford fans to see stars from the other league they normally wouldn't see: Ken Griffey Jr. in Denver, Larry Walker in Arlington, Tex., Barry Bonds in Seattle, Greg Maddux in Boston, for example.

title: Playing Poker With the Medicis
description: I DON'T know about your fantasy of Venice, but mine has never involved video poker. Yet there I sat on a balmy afternoon in May, slumped over a computer screen, watching aces and jacks materialize in unfruitful combinations. Out the door, canals and gondolas beckoned. Was I tempted? Nah. I continued to shove bills into the machine, oblivious to the men and women in commedia dell'arte garb sauntering past me and the object of my unprofitable fixation.

title: The Unmaking of a Secretary
description: Unvanquished

title: Penny Windle and John Kline
description: Sarah Pennyquick Windle and John Robertson Kline were married yesterday at the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Richard H. Downes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: On Co-ops And Disability
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEXT GENERATION; A Vision Takes Child Far Beyond His Vision
description: When Vikram Modi shakes your hand, he hangs on to to it. If you stand more than six inches from his eyes, you are a shadow to him. His skin is soft and as white as a lily, and it matches his hair. His quiet voice says good-bye, but he waits for you to let go, and when you finally do, you feel as if you have left behind a richer world than the one he can't see.

title: Plants That Make Life Easier for Water Carriers
description: IF house lots were all designed by efficient gardeners, there might never be a need to carry water in a bucket to a thirsty plant. All ornamental beds would be within easy reach of a sprinkler.

title: Ms. McFadden, Mr. Gilbert
description: Jeanmarie McFadden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. McFadden of Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to William Bruce Gilbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gilbert of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Robert G. Gentile, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony at Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Americans Turn Loss Into a Success Story
description: No one ever wants to lose, especially the United States women's soccer team, but some defeats can be instructive and revelatory. A 1-0 defeat to Norway in the semifinals of the 1995 Women's World Cup was a short-term calamity but a long-term benefit.

title: Among the Elephants
description: To the Editor:

title: Misplaced Blame In Ring Accident
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Crime
description: Ian Rutledge, the shellshocked Scotland Yard detective in Charles Todd's haunting post-World War I mysteries, takes his troubled conscience to a Dorset village in SEARCH THE DARK (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $24.95) to investigate the death of an unknown woman and the disappearance of her two children. Although the victim was beaten beyond recognition, public opinion has it that a deranged veteran (a ''shabby stranger with frantic eyes'') killed the entire family in a fit of insane grief, because they reminded him of the loved ones he lost in the war. Only Rutledge, himself heavily burdened with survivor guilt, has the compassion to recognize the man's innocence and the insight to search for the true murderer among the locals, a striking collection of insular individuals.

title: When Athletes Are One Sex, and Coaches Are the Other
description: IN our central New Jersey town, as in suburban communities all over the country, soccer fields are filled with girls kicking up mud. Girls' high school basketball tournaments draw capacity crowds, and female track stars earn athletic scholarships to prestigious universities.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99; Gays and Monsters
description: Some of Abner Louima's most vocal supporters want Justin Volpe's lawyer to apologize -- but for what, exactly? Surely we don't hold him responsible for the actions of his client, the New York cop who sodomized Louima with a broomstick after a brawl. Nor do we expect him to say he is sorry for accusing Louima of lying about it: that's what lawyers do in defense of defenseless clients. No, it was Marvyn Kornberg's lurid explanation for Louima's injuries that precipitated a furor. Louima, he argued, had not been tortured in the station house, but had engaged in consensual anal intercourse earlier that night at Club Rendez-Vous: he had sex with a man. Al Sharpton called this accusation ''a second rape.''

title: Homegrown or Expatriate, Photographers in Aid of Modernism
description: TWO arenas of early Modernism in which photography played a vital part are presented in evocative exhibitions at opposite ends of Connecticut.

title: 'Elementals'
description: Crocodile Tears

title: Diversity On Boards Increases
description: MEMBERS of racial and ethnic minorities have captured more seats on corporate boards than ever before, Korn/ Ferry International, an executive search firm, reported last week. They are now on 60 percent of American boards, while women are on 73 percent of boards, up from 72 percent in 1998, the firm said.

title: Researchers Shine a Night Light on a Possible Link to Cancer
description: BY keeping night at bay, the electric light fostered today's round-the-clock society. But now scientists are asking whether there might be a dark side to so much brightness.

title: Column on Jackson Heights Ignored Important Element
description: To the Editor:

title: To Pete Seeger, It's Still the Song of the River
description: YOU would think after turning 80 last month that Pete Seeger, the balladeer and folk music icon, would want to slow down. But he is enjoying his garden, where he picks asparagus, and his mountainside log cabin he built about 50 years ago in Beacon and says he is very much booked for the near future.

title: Q and A
description: Affordable Spas

title: Byram Hills District Deserves a Yes Vote
description: As a 40-year resident of the Byram Hills School District and a former member of the school board, I am deeply disturbed with the discord manifesting itself over the scheduled June 23 bond vote.

title: Mountain Biking Without Fear
description: WHEN my daughter went off to summer camp she learned several new songs as well as the back float. When I went off to camp -- Adult Dirt Camp -- I learned a whole new way of riding my bike.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on May 23, about Venice, misstated the relationship between Coosje van Bruggen and Claes Oldenburg, whose work will be shown at the Biennale. The exhibition is a collaboration between Ms. van Bruggen and Mr. Oldenburg; she is not his assistant. The column also misstated the exhibition's title. It is ''Claes Oldenburg Coosje van Bruggen,'' not ''Large Scale Projects.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINTER, BENJAMIN
description: WINTER-Benjamin. On the 55th anniversary of his death, we remember with love our dear father and grandfather-June 16th, 1944.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Eugene Kalbacher, Jazz Journalist, 47
description: Eugene Kalbacher, the publisher and editor of Hot House, a small monthly magazine covering the jazz world, died on May 25 at his home in Rockaway Township, N.J. He was 47.

title: To Go Where No Woman Has Gone Before
description: For the best female soccer players in the world, the passion play of a lifetime begins on Saturday at 3 P.M. with the start of the third FIFA Women's World Cup of soccer. The United States will play host to the quadrennial tournament, culminating in the championship game at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on July 12.

title: Really, There's No Need to Thank Us
description: Contrary to what most New Yorkers must think, most of us in Arkansas are far from chagrined that Hillary Rodham Clinton will forsake this state once and for all and almost certainly take up quarters in New York to run for the Senate. In fact, most of us can be philosophical about it.

title: Sailing to the First Tee
description: ON a late August morning, I arrived with my golf clubs and a touch of trepidation at No. 10 Packhuskajen, on Goteborg's waterfront, to embark on a weeklong golf cruise along the Gota Canal. Like most American golfers, I knew almost nothing about golf in Sweden. I knew even less about the Gota Canal, a series of interconnected waterways that allow passage across the width of Sweden, from Goteborg on the North Sea coast to Stockholm 250 miles away on the Baltic.

title: Breast Reconstruction: All at Once or Not at All?
description: AT a recent medical conference, a plastic surgeon proudly showed a slide of a woman with breast cancer who had undergone a mastectomy and then a reconstruction of her breast. The surgeon challenged the audience to detect which breast was natural and which he had created in the operating room. Few could tell.

title: Miss Funsten and Mr. Whitmer
description: DeLancey Meade Funsten and Robert Foster Whitmer 4th were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomason Newcomb, an Episcopalian minister, on Salter's Point in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Jason James and Lisa Tovin
description: Lisa Faith Tovin, the daughter of Beatrice and Frederick Tovin of Bayside, Queens, was married last evening to Dr. Jason Seth James, a son of Linda James and Dr. Geoffrey James of Miami. Rabbi Jay Rosenbaum officiated at the Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center in Aventura, Fla.

title: Over Edom Will I Cast Out My Shoe
description: MOAB IS MY WASHPOT

title: Instability in Moscow: Who Is Giving Orders?
description: There are but two conclusions that can be drawn from Russia's abrupt and befuddled deployment of troops in Kosovo, neither of them reassuring. One is that President Boris N. Yeltsin no longer has full control of his Government. The other is that he does.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Questions for Capt. Joseph Hazelwood; Clean and Sober
description: Q: What did you feel the moment the Valdez ran aground?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Night Bloom

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DWORKIN, LEONARD
description: DWORKIN-Leonard, in loving tribute. To Lenny who made his transition on June 5, 1998. Born in the Bronx, at 10 he established a legendary basement workshop where he created ingenious objects. Inventing in the tradition of bricolage, Lenny built the first strobe lights for entertainment use. Educated at City College and NYU Graduate School of Psychology, Lenny brought wit, humor, and joy to many. Your friends.

title: June 6-12; 25,000-Year-Old Footprints
description: In a cave in Southern France, scientists have found human footprints that they believe are the oldest in Europe. They estimate the four imprints on the moist soil belonged to a boy of about 10 years old who walked there 25,000 years ago.

title: Proposed Cell Antenna Bill Opposed
description: FEARFUL that some property owners might be lured by easy money at the expense of the safety and esthetics of the community, many local governments in Westchester have joined to fight a state proposal to usurp their right to decide where antennas for cell phones may be put up.

title: INVESTING WITH: Arden Armstrong; MAS Mid-Cap Growth Fund
description: ARDEN ARMSTRONG, lead manager of the $887.6 million MAS Mid-Cap Growth fund, cheerfully acknowledges the growth-oriented nature of her investing discipline. She asks only that her style not be confused with the methods of other growth-fund managers. ''We like to find quality growth,'' she explained from her office in West Conshohocken, Pa. ''We're not momentum or growth-at-a-reasonable-price investors.''

title: Megan Lawrence, Kevin Kern
description: Megan Elizabeth Lawrence and Kevin Michael Kern, actors in the Broadway production of ''Les Miserables,'' were married in Brooklyn on Monday. The Rev. John H. S. Austin, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: King

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGINBOTHAM, PAUL
description: HIGINBOTHAM-Paul. The family and friends of pianist, G. Paul Higinbotham, are deeply saddened by his death on May 10, 1999. Born in 1920 in Victor, NY, Paul received a Bachelor of Music from Oberlin Conservatory of Music in 1949 and toured Europe with the Mozart Trio in the 1950's. Later he was a ballet rehearsal pianist and vocal coach/accompanist in Dallas, Washington, D.C., and NYC. Interment: Boughton Hill Cemetery, Victor, NY. Memorial service in NYC, June 19, 1 P.M., at Rutgers Presbyterian Church.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Vacations in the Country Aided Self-Confidence
description: The scene is one of late 1980's urban decay. Somewhere in the southern Bronx, a 9-year-old boy shuffles past burned-out buildings and people loitering on the sidewalk.

title: Seeking Help for the Body in the Well-Being of the Soul
description: EARLY Sunday mornings in a chapel at Riverside Church in New York, a service begins with meditation enhanced by aromatherapy and music. The communion includes laying on of hands, an ancient rite for the sick. Finally, congregants gather in the church's new Wellness Center, where they discuss topics like nutrition and cancer.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THIS week's cinema menu, including a comedy-drama about a physician, a stylish melodrama, a good Broadway adaptation and a solid Hollywood musical, features some familiar faces in unfamiliar roles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, JOHN CALHOUN
description: BAKER-John Calhoun. Died June 9, age 103. President of Ohio University, Athens, OH, for 16 years (1945-1962), he oversaw post-WWII expansion, upgraded academic standards, instituted Ph.D. programs, enlarged and enhanced the physical plant, and established University branches for educational outreach. He served as U.S. Representative to the Economic and Social Council of the U.N. (1953-56), and undertook educational fact finding missions for the U.S. Government to Iran, Cambodia, India, Colombia and elsewhere. Before the Ohio post, he was Assistant Dean and Professor of Business Administration at the Harvard Business School and Associate Dean of Harvard University and Assistant to the President. After retirement he and his late wife Elizabeth helped found peace education courses of study at Ohio University, Juniata College, Dartmouth College and Bethany Theological Seminary. He is mourned by his three daughters and two grandchildren. Instead of flowers, donations to Baker Peace Studies Program, c/o Ohio University Foundation, or Baker Peace Institute, Juniata College, Huntingdon, PA. Memorial service June 16, 11 AM, U.N. Chapel, 44th Street at 1st Avenue.

title: Elizabeth Brown, Hagen Scutt
description: Elizabeth Anne Brown, the daughter of Rita and Robert W. Brown of Lima, Ohio, was married there last evening to Hagen Scutt, the son of Leena and Der Scutt of New York. The Rev. Richard L. Sheffield officiated at the Market Street Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Eugene E. Utrup, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bride, took part in the ceremony.

title: Courthouse Upsets Neighbors, but Where Can They Turn?
description: Every weekday morning traffic descends on East 161st Street like a platoon of soldiers entering a skirmish. Trucks and cars line up to get on the Major Deegan Expressway. Busloads of prisoners and carloads of court officials head to the borough's court complex. And at the Yankee Stadium subway stop, a stream of people get on and off as they head to work. Meanwhile, children warily zigzag toward three nearby schools between double- and triple-parked cars.

title: Not Quite One-Way or Two-Way
description: In Atlantic City, the street named South North Carolina Avenue actually runs east to west.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGER, FRIEDA
description: FINGER-Frieda. Formerly of North Bergen, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Finger. Devoted step-mother of Robert and Leah Finger. Services Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ on Sunday at 10:30 AM. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: For Poor Nations, Debt Is Bondage
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Raising Money for Losers
description: THE guest list was top drawer, headed by President Clinton and both of New York's Democratic Senators. But even with that political star power, hardly anyone wanted to come to Geraldine A. Ferraro's $1,000-a-person fund-raiser to pay off her campaign debts. So late last month, just 48 hours before curtain time, she called the whole thing off.

title: A Walk To the Past Demands Good Shoes
description: ''MOST people experience architecture at 30 m.p.h.,'' the architect Robert Venturi has often said. Reading a building at 3 m.p.h. on a walking tour offers an ideal opportunity for both social storytelling and esthetic appreciation. From the sidewalk, history is within arm's reach.

title: Despite Initial Interest, Lyme Vaccine Isn't Used
description: When SmithKline Beecham announced last winter that it had won approval for a vaccine against Lyme disease, doctors and patients alike received the news with excitement and relief. Despite that initial flush of enthusiasm, however, hundreds of thousands of doses of the vaccine, called Lymerix, are sitting unused.

title: The Nation; In Jet-Age Politics, A Buggywhip Tactic
description: THE future leadership of the American Embassy in Luxembourg, a landlocked European duchy with about as many people as Oklahoma City, might seem an unlikely issue to pit the White House against the United States Senate.

title: Social Security
description: Call it Introduction to Miss Manners. The Etiquette School of the Palm Beaches has scheduled three mother-daughter weekends this summer, designed to teach girls who are of high-school age the finer points of social protocols, as well as reinforce parent-child bonds.

title: For Duval, Practice Is a No. 1 Priority
description: David Duval, the world's No. 1 ranked golfer, spends far more time practicing his chipping and putting than practicing his driving.

title: Arizona District Profits From Charter Schools
description: The transformation of the Higley Elementary District, a tiny one-school district out where Phoenix's sprawl gives way to cows and corn, began two years ago with an unlikely plan to build a school whose central feature would be a hockey rink.

title: Stacey Motland and Jeffrey Low
description: Stacey Frost Motland, a daughter of Randall K. Motland of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Frost Motland, was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to Jeffrey Keenleyside Low, a son of Penny and Josiah O. Low 3d of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Lynne Kramer, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: My Sisters' Place
description: My Sisters' Place, the Westchester agency providing services to battered women and their children, has named Amy R. Paulin as its interim executive director, effective tomorrow.

title: Ms. Bantivoglio, Mr. Magliocco
description: Barbara Bantivoglio and Joseph J. Magliocco were married yesterday at the Church Center at the United Nations in Manhattan. The Rev. Karl Gillmeister, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Coming to Terms With Grief After a Longtime Partner Dies
description: THERE are moments, such as when she hears the solemn opening chords of the second movement of Dvorak's ''From the New World'' symphony, when Joan Kindy feels the rush of 30 years of memories and the pain of nearly two years without her husband, Hal.

title: Jordan Shows His Hand
description: Having dealt his way out of a job by turning Westinghouse, the appliance maker, into CBS, the network, Michael H. Jordan has dealt his way back into another job, and in a manner in keeping with the times. Last week, the Clarant Worldwide Corporation, which aims to help major corporations and new Internet ventures do business on line, filed for a $150 million-plus public offering, for 30.7 percent of the company, with Mr. Jordan as chairman. Clarant, based in Dallas, will be formed from eight companies that it has agreed to acquire.

title: Beyond the Horror Stories, Good News About Managed Care
description: MOST health plans these days are some form of managed care. And for most families, it is the mother who decides which one to use.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: What Her Body Thought A Journey Into the Shadows. By Susan Griffin. HarperSanFrancisco, $24.

title: A Glass of Raspberries
description: Alba, in Italian, means dawn. Rudy Marchesi, an owner of Alba Vineyard, saw light when the idea of making red raspberry wine popped into mind.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Column on Jackson Heights Ignored Important Element
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Melissa Pearl Friedling, Syracuse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: June 6-12; Look. Up in the Sky. It's a . . .
description: As a young man, George Bush had to bail out of a Navy fighter he was piloting over the Pacific.

title: New Kid on the Block
description: Like a crocus peeping above the soil in early spring, viognier, a Rhone Valley grape with newly successful California counterparts, has established at least two East End homes: at Pindar in Peconic and Macari in Mattituck.

title: The Hurdles of Teaching the Deaf
description: SHANNON WEESE, a 17-year-old student at the New York School for the Deaf here, is studying journalism and drama at Woodlands High School in nearby Greenburgh. In turn, 12 Woodlands students are meeting their foreign language requirements by studying American Sign Language taught by an instructor from Shannon's school.

title: Deborah Pike And Erik Olsen
description: Deborah Jean Pike, the daughter of Melda Jean and David Pike of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Erik Jon Olsen, a son of Cecilia and Arthur Olsen of Westchester, Ill. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Helena Kuo Kingman, 86, Writer on China
description: Helena Kuo Kingman, the author of several books about China, died on April 25 at a hospital in Taipei, Taiwan. She was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, MURIEL
description: STEINBERG-Muriel. Truly a woman of valor whose love and strength have enriched every day of our lives. Our adoptive mother. With everlasting love, Stephen and Leslie Sachs Apollo, Arlyn and Karen

title: Diana Wyeth, Christian Hambrecht
description: Diana Caroline Wyeth, the daughter of Edith and N. Convers Wyeth of Oakton, Va., was married last evening to Christian Thomas Hambrecht, the son of Margaret and Edward Hambrecht of Marshalls Creek, Pa. Rabbi Laszlo Berkowits officiated at the Country Club of Fairfax in Fairfax, Va.

title: Temples of Blessed Excess
description: THE big blue M & M was starting to get on my nerves. ''Hey, baby, you look great!'' it cried out, as I walked around M & M's World, a four-story cathedral of candy and consumerism on the Las Vegas Strip. ''The glow of these M & M's does wonders for you! You should take some home and put them in every room in the house.''

title: Most Popular, Yes, but Most Likely to Succeed?
description: When it comes to stocks, popularity seems to be inversely related to future performance. That is the gist of a study by H. Bradlee Perry, a consultant at David L. Babson & Company, a money manager in Cambridge, Mass., with $20 billion in assets under management.

title: Backtalk; A New Land Of a Thousand Soccer 'Mias'
description: ''Mia! Mia! I'm open,'' Kristine Lilly shouts as she cuts inside the penalty area, a step ahead of her opponent, who happens to be me, a former college soccer player who has always dreamed of competing at the international level. Mia Hamm, slaloming her way down the left flank, doesn't even look up as she arrows a pass to her teammate with almost telepathic confidence. Lilly collects the ball without breaking stride and cheekily pushes it between my flailing legs. The goalkeeper lunges but it is too late. The ball is already rising off Lilly's foot and screaming into the goal.

title: Gun Proposal Takes a Turn As Democrats Show Divide
description: A proposal for mandatory background checks of buyers at gun shows that has the blessing of House Republican leaders and reflects the preferences of the National Rifle Association is being sponsored by a group of Democrats, including the most senior Democrat in the House.

title: Sports of The Times: Dancing From the Rafters at the Garden; For Knicks, a Night to Remember
description: They are now one of the great teams of the Garden, one of the epic teams of New York. The Eastern Conference banner will hang from the beams, but what really matters is the sound, the emotion of that Friday night in June, forever trapped under the rafters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, MAUREEN A.
description: HIGGINS-Maureen A. Of Clifton, New Jersey, long time Brooklyn resident died suddenly on June 1. Maureen was a free spirit, and a true and devoted friend whom we will miss. Ciao, Babe, till we join you and Donal for brunch in that big Rainbow Room in the Sky. Betty, Joan and Virginia

title: Even the Tennis Court Has a Glass Ceiling; Money Says It All
description: To the Editor:

title: The Warming of a Lucid Intellect: Boulez at 74
description: BY the 1950's, Pierre Boulez's reputation as a cutting-edge modernist composer and imposing musical intellect was already secure. During the next decade he also emerged as an orchestra conductor of probing insight and technical finesse, particularly in the French Impressionist repertory.

title: From Russia, With Love
description: Adopting Alyosha A Single Man Finds a Son in Russia. By Robert Klose. 165 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $22.

title: Diagnosing Fibroids Is Simple; Deciding What to Do Is Hard
description: WHEN Susan H., age 40, began experiencing excessive menstrual bleeding and almost constant pelvic pain and cramping, her doctor's diagnosis was straightforward and certain: She had multiple uterine fibroids, benign tumors that grow within the smooth muscle of the uterine wall or on the uterine surface.

title: Richard Morris, Jessica Greer
description: Jessica Lyn Greer and Richard Alexander Morris are to be married this afternoon at Lyndhurst, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Alfredo Borodowski is to officiate.

title: Whose 'Right to Bear Arms' Is It?; America's Radical Birth
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Here . . . So Is Fear of a Deadly Virus
description: A RARE mosquito-carried disease that has killed a few people in Rhode Island and Massachusetts is now considered a permanent health threat from Fairfield County to Stonington.

title: June 6-12; African National Congress Seals an Election Victory
description: Final election results showed that South Africa's ruling African National Congress, the party of outgoing President Nelson Mandela and President-elect Thabo Mbeki, was re-elected in a landslide on June 2, gaining even more Parliament seats than it got in 1994 during the country's first post-apartheid elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: $140,000 -- And a Bargain
description: It's summer, and another flock of recent high-school graduates is about to head off to the college of their dreams. The question now is how they'll pay for it. At first glance, this should be getting easier. Endowments have tripled in the past decade thanks to the stock-market boom. Most professors earn around $56,000, while underfed graduate students do so much teaching that they are unionizing in droves. But if you think this means tuition cuts are coming, think again.

title: Monthly Vintage
description: There are books of the month, fruits of the month, even cheese-cakes of the month. And now there is the New Jersey Wine of the Month. The appellation is a new one, just begun in April by the Garden State Wine Growers Association on its Web site. The May wine - wines, actually - were cranberry wine from Cream Ridge Winery in Cream Ridge and cabernet franc from Sylvin Farms Winery in Germania. For June they will be (apparently you can't rush a wine Web site any more than you can a good wine; the association is still getting the images together) a selection of white hybrids like aurora, Cayuga, chardonnel, rayon d'or, seyval blanc, vidal blanc and villard blanc. As in all months, the site will include some background about the grapes, suggestions for which foods to drink them with and information about visiting the wineries in the state that make them. The site is www.newjerseywines.com/wine-of-the-month.html.

title: Anointed Ones Become the Disappointed Ones
description: They were the anointed ones, the players who practiced together during the lockout as the Knicks were scattered across the country, with Patrick Ewing locked in a conference room and not even talking to Marcus Camby when he would run into him at the gym. The Indiana Pacers, with Michael Jordan finally out of the way, were an overwhelming favorite to represent the Eastern Conference in the finals this year, after falling just short in three of the last four seasons.

title: MetroStars Can't Find Goals or Victories
description: The MetroStars kept grabbing their heads in disbelief each time they missed an opportunity to score a goal. The chances kept coming, but the MetroStars failed to finish, and their inability to capitalize came back to haunt them at the end in tonight's game against the Colorado Rapids at Giants Stadium.

title: Victoria Davis, Thomas Baluk
description: Victoria Lynne Davis, a daughter of Kathleen and William Davis of West Chester, Pa., was married there yesterday to Thomas Christopher Baluk, the son of Sara and Thomas Baluk of Plymouth, Mich. The Rev. William Trader performed the ceremony at St. Maximilian Kolbe Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ms. Hemmerdinger And Mr. Goodman
description: Katherine Molly Hemmerdinger, the daughter of Elizabeth and H. Dale Hemmerdinger of New York, was married yesterday to Adam Jason Goodman, the son of Gail Goodman and Dr. Michael Goodman of West Islip, N.Y. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: The Promised Land
description: Between Memory and Desire The Middle East in a Troubled Age. By R. Stephen Humphreys. 297 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $29.95.

title: Greenback Blues
description: With the dollar now worth 10 cents, making it a coin makes sense. The issue of dollar coin or dollar bill may be made moot by the increasing use of credit cards, in any case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Palffy Deal Called Nearly Complete
description: The deal is not yet final, but it appears to be just a matter of time before Zigmund Palffy is traded to the Rangers, a National Hockey League executive said yesterday.

title: Auctioning Off the Treasures of Ralph Kramden and Scarlett
description: What price memory? How much of today's cash does it take to own a vestige of yesterday's passion?

title: The Changing Look Of Art Museums; It's No Longer Just What's on the Walls That Lures Visitors
description: NOT so long ago, museums were like temples -- temples dedicated to Art. Big, imposing and often neo-classical outside, they were hushed, darkened places, where people would reverently gaze at paintings and sculptures by dead white males, familiar mainly from textbooks. Hardly anyone went to a museum for fun.

title: Heartbreak Hotels
description: LAYOVER

title: For Poor Nations, Debt Is Bondage
description: To the Editor:

title: Gracyn Robinson, Peter Whitman
description: Gracyn Walker Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Davis R. Robinson of Washington, was married yesterday to Peter Townsend Whitman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Whitman Jr. of South Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. William P. Billow performed the ceremony at St. Ann's by the Sea Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Starr May Issue Report Critical Of the Clintons
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, will not seek indictments of President Clinton or Hillary Rodham Clinton but has tentatively decided to issue a final report about their behavior, several associates of Mr. Starr said this week. The report, which could land in the middle of Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign, might be ''blistering'' in its descriptions of her actions, one Starr associate said.

title: The Salmon Obsession Unsatisfied
description: A recent trip to Maine's remote and tumultuous Rapid River reminded me that I can become inordinately obsessive about catching fish, in this instance, landlocked salmon.

title: Lawyer Trades His Suit for a Priest's Robe
description: Joseph M. Everson 3d was sitting on a very hard rock inside a crumbling hut in the mountains of Peru, slicked with mud after an exhausting climb to give Roman Catholic communion to a peasant family, when his mind stumbled into a thicket of doubt.

title: As the Focus Group Goes, So Goes the Nation
description: THE NEW PRINCE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on May 30, about bargains in the Far East, misstated the location of the Peninsula Group's Palace Hotel. It is in Beijing, not Bangkok.

title: Style; The West End
description: The last time I visited the Napa Valley, I was gripped by a strange feeling of deja vu. The scenery was lush and the little towns quaint, but the traffic was nightmarish and getting a dinner reservation was worse. I had seen it all before, on a certain well-heeled stretch of eastern Long Island. Welcome to the Hamptons of the West.

title: F.A.A. Gives Computers Bigger Role in Security
description: IT may not be obvious to passengers, but the Federal Aviation Administration is trying to close three weak spots in airline security: relying on human judgment to spot suspicious passengers, allowing checked bags to catch a connecting flight when the suspicious passenger doesn't, and permitting baggage screeners to grow complacent.

title: Doctors Are Second-Guessing the 'Miracle' of Multiple Births
description: ALWAYS enthralled by record-shattering events, Americans were mesmerized by the birth of septuplets in 1997 and octuplets the following year. Each tiny infant's struggle from birth canal to home crib was reported and broadcast in detail, and the nation's heart swelled with empathy for the parents.

title: Posters and Toys: Back to a Futurist
description: THE Italian painter and designer Fortunato Depero came late to Futurism. Indeed, this energetic art style of vivid palette and dynamic images was four years old when, in 1913, Depero went to Rome to meet the founder of the movement, the poet Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, and to see the Futurist art of Umberto Boccioni and Giacomo Balla. The trip changed Depero's life.

title: Not for Bread Alone
description: Magazines from women's fashion books to general-interest publications hardly let a month pass without putting more movie and pop stars on their covers. Weightier publications compete for contributions by renowned writers. And all these celebrities are used to being treated like, well, celebrities. While a model might be happy with a few celery sticks, a celebrity requires prandial pampering, often to the benefit of New York restaurants and caterers.

title: Cast in Stone
description: In the Napa Valley, as in many places of surpassing beauty, the old and the new often become adversaries. But in this stone house -- first built as a distillery in 1904 and later becoming the country estate of a state senator and even a bed-and-breakfast -- old and new have formed a mutual-admiration society. The current owner of the house (which sits on 350 acres, 80 of them a vineyard) asked Marc LaRoche, an architect with offices on Bainbridge Island, Wash., and in San Francisco, to turn the place into a well-appointed but informal weekend house.

title: Friends for a Good Cause
description: Daniel Druckman, a percussionist with the New York Philharmonic, is not performing in today's concert at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood -- no drums allowed, especially in the songs by Ravel and Poulenc. But thanks to his large circle of friends, he won't be missed.

title: Attacking Military Excess, From the Executive Office
description: WHY must Bell Industries, a computer services company in El Segundo, Calif., go all the way to India to hire programmers? The company's co-chairman, Theodore Williams, thinks it is because America doesn't have its priorities straight.

title: Transformer Fails; Electric Capacity Cut
description: The Long Island Power Authority has temporarily lost 300 megawatts of electric capacity because of a transformer failure at its East Garden City substation.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Word & Image; The Information Tyranny
description: The Web nuts of America career around the Internet celebrating a new freedom to shout and spout anything into the ether: no more restraints on speech, they insist; no more hierarchy of thought. I hope they were watching old-time public television for just an hour last week, as Bill Moyers documented our society's slide into a new information tyranny, how corporate wealth is monopolizing debate, corrupting politicians and dictating policy. (The program will be rebroadcast tonight on WNET in the New York area.)

title: Corrections
description: On Language, the column on page 18 of The Times Magazine today, misstates the given name of the late journalist Meg Greenfield. It was Mary Ellen, not Mary Elizabeth. (Her nickname was derived from her initials.)

title: Turning Up The Juice
description: Love Juice is no bigger than a newsstand, but to NoHo's hot, hip and thirsty, it's a cool scene, even in the heat. Crowds are showing up for frosty drinks at the tiny juice bar, and because it's on a bleak stretch of Lafayette Street, at No. 371 near Great Jones Street, it's far enough from neighbors for music to blast day and night. ''It's a rock-and-roll juice bar,'' said Russell Jebbia (above), who opened Love Juice in an old gas-station kiosk in December. Mr. Jebbia, who once owned a SoHo boutique called the Eye, recently set up chairs outside Love Juice, creating an impromptu street scene. It is open daily from noon until 8 P.M., except Thursday through Saturday, when patrons keep it open until 10 or 11. Artists, musicians and locals stop by for chilled chai tea, guarana sodas, custom smoothies, what the menu calls ''hyper-caffeinated shock coffee'' and recorded music of bands like Massive Attack and Space Hog. ''It's a fantastic people-watching joint,'' said Jonny Cragg, Space Hog's drummer. ''I often swing by for Strawberry Speedballs. Russell always adds lots of love to his juice.'' DAVID KIRBY

title: Same Old Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, STEPHEN P.
description: DUNN-Stephen P. Died on June 4th, 1999 at home in Kensington, California. Born March 24, 1928 to the geneticist L.C. Dunn and Louise P. Dunn. Stephen struggled throughout his life with cerebral palsy. He was educated at Lincoln School of Columbia University, Columbia College, and Columbia University, where he received his Ph.d in Anthropology. His devoted parents provided him with the opportunity to travel in Norway, Sweden, France and Italy as a boy and young man. On October 6, 1956 he married Ethel Deikman an event they called the Great October Revolution. His brother Robert died in 1982. Stephen is survived by two nieces, a nephew and two great-nieces and a great-nephew. Stephen's earliest publications were books of poetry. Several of his scholarly publications were devoted to the Roman Jews. For the remainder of his life he was known as a researcher, translator and editor of Russian social sciences, producing four books on the Soviet Union and Russia, as well as over 100 articles and book reviews and millions of words translated from Russian. His wife, Ethel, plans to complete the books and translations he left unfinished and to issue a posthumous book of his poetry. He will be missed by all who loved him.

title: Trying to Halt the Push of the Bulldozers
description: FOR decades, Westchester County watched its farms disappear one by one as milking cows and apple orchards gave way to Cape Cods and Colonials in the march of suburbanization. But in the final year of the century, county officials are finally taking action to preserve what little remains of Westchester's agricultural heritage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, EUGENE J., RABBI
description: SACK-Eugene J., Rabbi. Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Beth Elohim. Beloved husband of Florence & the late Sylvia. Loving father of Robert and Steven. Father-in-law of Anne and Joyce. Devoted brother of Rose Serebreny. Adored grandfather of Deborah, Suzanne, and David. In lieu of flowers, donations to Rabbi Eugene J. Sack Building Fund of Congregation Beth Elohim, 8th Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn, NY 11215. Services at Congregation Beth Elohim. 8th Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn, NY. Tuesday, June 15, 1999 at 10:30am. For information call 718-768-3814.

title: Word for Word/Shakespeare's Latest Movie; Alas, Poor Titus. You're Bloody, Awful And Ready for Dismemberment
description: MOVIEGOERS who were recently seduced by the lyricism of ''Shakespeare in Love'' and ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' will see a starkly different side of William Shakespeare in ''Titus'' (short for ''Titus Andronicus''), starring Anthony Hopkins and Jessica Lange and directed by Julie Taymor. With more than a dozen murders, assorted dismemberments and the emperor Saturninus sitting down to a pie made from the bodies of his stepsons, ''Titus'' is Shakespeare's goriest play and, many critics feel, his worst. T. S. Eliot described it as ''one of the stupidest and most uninspired plays ever written.'' A 1923 production of ''Titus'' at the Old Vic was laughed off the stage. Observations on the play and disputations on its authorship over the centuries follow.

title: THE GUIDE
description: The Dignity of Labor

title: Gargling a Go-Go
description: At a time when some people spend as much on dental veneers as a year's rent, high-maintenance mouths need more round-the-clock care than merely popping a Certs. Flashy smilers are turning to Supersmile, products designed for dental wellness on the run. The manufacturers count Calvin Klein and Ivana Trump as clients. The line, newly available at the Bliss Spa, on the second floor of 568 Broadway (Prince Street), includes disposable plastic tongue cleaners ($3), resembling shedding combs, to scrape bacteria. There is a Lucite toothbrush ($8), meant to facilitate the American Dental Association's recommended 45-degree angle of brushing (and to look good in the restroom). And there are packet-cups of mouth-rinse powder ($20 for a box of 60); all you do is add water. ''It's portable fresh breath,'' said Diane Von Furstenberg, who said she uses Supersmile when traveling. ''It keeps my smile sparkling and my breath clean, all day long.'' But where do you carry a toothbrush in a wrap dress? ELLEN TIEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday, about the expected departure of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin from the Jefferson Hotel in Washington, where he has lived for six years, misstated his role in fund-raising dinners there. Mr. Rubin attended such dinners, but did not serve as host.

title: Making the Evolving Orchestra Fit to Survive
description: WHEN the Cleveland Orchestra was at Carnegie Hall last month, giving concerts led by its music director, Christoph von Dohnanyi, and a former principal guest conductor, Pierre Boulez, Ara Guzelimian, the hall's artistic adviser, took the opportunity to convene a public discussion. The two maestros and Joseph W. Polisi, the president of the Juilliard School, were asked to speculate on what orchestras might be like in the next century, as institutional bodies and as artistic machines.

title: Kosovars Venture Out, Finally, to Welcome NATO Troops
description: This was the first day in two and a half months, the people of this little village said, that they dared venture out to the road that runs only a few dozen yards from their doors.

title: Pernfors Avenges Loss to Connors
description: It had been 13 years since Mikael Pernfors found himself on the wrong end of one of Wimbledon's most memorable matches. Those memories were fresh in his mind yesterday as he stared across the net at his longtime nemesis Jimmy Connors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, PHILIP
description: FOLEY-Philip. On June 11, 1999. Native of County Kerry, Ireland. Beloved husband of Katherine (nee Lovett). Devoted father of Eileen Kohler and Dr. Mary McInerney. Loving grandfather of Patrick, Alanna and Thomas. Cherished brother of John in Ireland & the late Patrick. Reposing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball), Yonkers, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, 10:30 AM, St. Barnabas Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Phil Foley Memorial Fund, C/O Incarnation Children's Center, Pediatric Aids, 142 Audubon Avenue, New York, NY 10032 would be appreciated.

title: After 45 Years, Resegregation Emerges In Schools, Study Finds
description: Forty-five years after the Supreme Court ruling Brown v. Board of Education forced the desegregation of the nation's schools, a process of school resegregation is advancing across the country, especially for blacks in the South and for Hispanic Americans everywhere, according to a new Harvard University study.

title: Outlook Good For Johnson
description: Larry Johnson created an unsettling scene when he sprained the medial collateral ligaments in his right knee during the Knicks' Game 6 victory against Indiana on Friday night to advance to the league finals, but following a re-evaluation yesterday, the Knicks forward is expected to recover in time for Game 1 against San Antonio on Wednesday.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Brain Storm

title: Correction
description: An article on May 16 about a fund-raising event for the Gunn Memorial Library in Washington, Conn., misidentified the real estate agent who sold a house in Roxbury to Ellen McCourt and the author Frank McCourt. Verne Henshall represented the McCourts; Seymour Surnow was the listing agent.

title: A Fallen Bridge, A Raised Hurdle
description: What could the collapse of a highway bridge in Connecticut 16 years ago have to do with up-to-date bookkeeping standards? Quite a bit, when it comes to some controversial new rules that were approved last week by the Governmental Accounting Standards Board.

title: Hannibal the Cannibal

title: Jailhouse Confession
description: Wouldn't it be advisable for Randy Cohen (The Ethicist, May 23) to suggest to J.Q. of Florida that, if his circumstances are as he describes (in particular, his innocence), he seek legal assistance to overturn his conviction. The newspapers are full of stories these days about innocent people languishing in prison. The consolation of philosophy is appropriate treatment when there is no other hope.

title: Anthony Kim, Cynthia Chung
description: Cynthia Kyungbin Chung, a daughter of Alice and James D. Chung of Blue Bell, Pa., was married yesterday to Anthony Younghwan Kim, a son of Moonja and T. John Kim of Champaign, Ill. description: Anne Bowe Millard and Brewster Bermingham Carroll were married in New York yesterday afternoon. The Rev. John A. Kamas performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Just Wild And Crazy Geeks
description: THE way TNT's film ''Pirates of Silicon Valley'' tells it, the story of the computer revolution as we know it begins with Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak running in slow motion through tear gas during a student protest on the Berkeley campus in 1971. Of course, a chronology that TNT has sent out with publicity releases about the film notes that Mr. Job and Mr. Wozniak didn't meet until 1973, when they were both employees of Hewlett-Packard.

title: Nieuwendyk is Dallas's Star of Stars
description: The star forwards of the Dallas Stars are a star-crossed bunch who are quickly becoming the most significant constellation in the Stanley Cup finals. One who was injured and not certain to play tonight somehow managed to participate and perform with skill, grit and a little bit of malice. That was Mike Modano. Another, off to a great start in this series, left the game early with what may be a serious groin injury. That was Brett Hull, who had two goals in the first two games.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a proposed recreational complex in Bloomingdale Park on Staten Island misstated its size. The complex is projected to cover 12 to 15 acres, not 38.

title: Lukewarm Reaction To Lyme Vaccine
description: WHEN SmithKline Beecham announced last winter that it had won approval for a vaccine against Lyme disease, physicians and patients hailed the news with excitement and relief. Despite that initial flush of enthusiasm, however, hundreds of thousands of doses of the vaccine, called Lymerix, are sitting unused in physicians' offices.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged In Strangling Over Drugs
description: A 52-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with strangling his common-law wife after they argued over money to buy drugs, the police said.

title: Students' Moment of Truth
description: SEVEN floors of paintings, architecture, interactive media, sculptures, videos, animation, traditional and digital photography and calligraphy are on view at the Cooper Union in its 140th annual student exhibition.

title: Ms. Wallace, Mr. Nusbaum
description: Nora Ann Wallace, a partner in the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, and Jack H. Nusbaum, the firm's chairman, were married last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated, with the Rev. Aldo J. Tos, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: The Space Race; Why Is It So Hard to Find a Parking Spot in Manhattan?
description: HE concedes that others might call him a gadfly or consider him a tad obsessed. But to Thomas J. Hillgardner, a lawyer from Flushing, Queens, and the founder of a group called the Parking Justice League, it all comes down to civic responsibility and civil rights.

title: The Pleasures of the Festival, Pastoral and Other
description: HERE'S a little secret I wonder if it's wise for a critic to share: I often find that traveling to someplace new, or at least someplace not routinely familiar, puts me in a good mood for seeing performances. No wonder I like to pack my bags in summer and go off to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshire Hills of Massachusetts and the American Dance Festival, since 1978 at Duke University in Durham, N.C., but before that at Connecticut College in New London.

title: Alexandra Olmsted, Ly Tran

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Williamson, the dean of religious life at Princeton University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Knickerbocker Club in New York.

title: Old Baltimore Row Houses Fall Before Wrecking Ball
