In the evenings, their work done, families sat out on the sidewalks in webbed folding chairs with their beers, laughing while their children played around them.

title: Enhancing a House Through Color
description: FOR most homeowners, choosing the color for interior walls, ceilings and moldings is largely a matter of taste. The only considerations are whether a color may look good or where a particular hue might be used to create a desired effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, LOUISE HEMINGWAY BENTON
description: WAGNER - Louise Hemingway Benton. Died peacefully in her sleep in Paradise Valley, AZ. She was born in Chicago on July 29, 1937, the daughter of William and Helen Benton. She married Ralph C. Wagner on May 23, 1979, and they traveled frequently between homes in Fairfield, CT, Chicago, IL, and Paradise Valley, AZ. A kind and professional lady, Louise served as an executive at Encyclopedia Britannica. She served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Cradle Society in Evanston, IL. She was a member of the Women's Board of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Trustee of Plymouth Plantation, Plymouth, MA. She is survived by her husband, her sister Helen of Wisconsin, and two brothers, Charles of Evanston, IL, and John of Malibu, CA. She was a member of the Country Club of Fairfield and the Paradise Valley Country Club.

title: Competing Plans to Help Working Poor

Last year, their median total compensation was $13.9 million, up 27 percent from $10.9 million in 1996, according to Pearl Meyer & Partners, a consulting firm in Manhattan.

title: A Game Boy in the Cross Hairs

John Romero exemplifies the way in which the fantasy world of these games inflates self-esteem to illogical proportions, in his comments about waiting for a table and his imagined popularity in Japan. The important question is what happens when Romero's game-obsessed customers are not given the respect they expect. I think several of the school shootings answer that question.

title: Viennese Torte
description: The 1933 BITTER SWEET, a British version of Noel Coward's operetta, with Anna Neagle and Fernand Gravet, had more flavoring than this 1940 Hollywood cushioning for Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy (above with Curt Bois) - but no harm was done. The story faithfully follows the two lovers, who open a popular cafe in turn-of-the-century Vienna. MacDonald, in particular, makes the most of her role, as opposed to the kittenish performance of Ms. Neagle, and Eddy makes a stalwart lover. The musical theme is the popular ''I'll See You Again,'' and Coward's candy-box score suits this lavish production. The question is why Hollywood waited so long - Tuesday at 6 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: Van Gundy as G.M.? It Might Just Happen

But as his stature grows in New York, one wonders if the Knicks would dangle the dual role of general manager and coach in front of him after the team's stunning post-season run.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; There's No Substitute for Fieldwork
description: The pioneering Polish ethnographer Bronislaw Malinowski had an ambivalent attitude toward photography, which, he said, ''I hate above all other things.'' Yet he photographed extensively as part of his fieldwork in Kiriwina, one of the largest of the Trobriand Islands in the South Pacific. Beginning in 1914, Malinowski documented in five monographs, including the classic ''Argonauts of the Western Pacific,'' the beliefs, rituals and quotidian habits of the islanders. With great aggravation, he lugged around his ungainly photographic equipment -- a monstrous cross on the Golgotha of life.'' Nonetheless, Malinowski found photography to be an indispensible tool and took more than 1,000 pictures of the gardeners and animists whose traditional sula -- the inter-island trade of shells and other goods -- became, in academic settings, a widely used paradigm of traditional economic exchange. ''No other anthropologist of Malinowski's generation made photographs work so hard,'' Michael W. Young writes in MALINOWSKI'S KIRIWINA: Fieldwork Photography 1915-1918 (University of Chicago, $40). Nearly 200 previously unpublished photographs are arranged in 14 visual essays with headings like ''Magic'' and ''Mortuary Rites and Exchanges.'' Perhaps the most alluring sequence is ''Masawa Canoes and the Kula Quest,'' which depicts rituals associated with the shell trade and the construction of the islanders' boats, with their graceful sails of dried pandanus leaves sewn with awls of flying fox bone. Undoubtedly, this book will be of primary interest to those in the social sciences, but the engagingly written text and colorful quotations from Malinowski's letters, diaries and books will make it a pleasure for the general reader. Young, senior fellow in the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies at the Australian National University, makes the point that his book is, in many ways, less an objective study of the islanders than a portrait of Malinowski and ''his vision of his Trobriand world.'' Suzanne MacNeille

title: The Hokey Hipness of Wheat Grass

Feeling like Mrs. Dalloway on her errand to pick up flowers, I brought the thing home with me last week -- a fresh June morning on 10th Street -- a 4-by-7-inch box with sprouted wheat grass, wrapped in pale blue tissue paper from Spruce on Greenwich Avenue. Spruce is a flower store with a motto -- ''Our grass is greener!'' -- and it specializes in witty and ironic items like a pickle jar with daisies floating in three inches of water and boxes of wheat grass like mine, which sell for $25 each.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, MARVIN
description: LEE-Marvin. Age 98, of Ithaca, NY, died Thursday, June 10, 1999. He was born on March 31, 1901, in Brooklyn, NY. He received his bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute (Polytechnic University) in 1922, and served on the Polytechnic's Board of Trustees for many years. He was one of three founders of the BURNDY Corporation in 1925, and retired as the corporation's president in 1961. BURNDY is one of the foremost manufacturers of electrical connectors worldwide. He was an accomplished sailor and amateur radio enthusiast, with an original radio license dating to 1918. Marvin Lee is survived by his loving wife of 72 years, Annette F. Lee, of Ithaca, NY, son, Cornell Professor David M. Lee of Ithaca, NY (Nobel Prize Physics-1996), daughter Carol A. Metzger, of Kents Store, VA, grandson Eric B. Lee of Vestal, NY, grandson James M. Lee, of Boston, MA, and great-granddaughters Christina and Victoria Lee of Vestal, NY. A memorial service is scheduled for Monday, June 14, 10 AM, in Anabel Taylor Hall, at Cornell University. Memorial contributions may be made to the Polytechnic University.

description: Just when it looked as if things were calming down in Mets Manager Bobby Valentine's clubhouse, Rickey Henderson said yesterday that he would like to sit down with the manager and have Valentine explain some of his thinking to him.

title: Trickle-Down Prosperity; How Low the Boom Can Go
description: FOR the last eight years, the nation's economic boom, which has made so many Americans rich and self-confident, has been noteworthy for those it has left out: the people at the bottom of the ladder. Suddenly, that's changed. Unemployment rates among blacks and Hispanic people, though still high compared with that for whites, are at or near record lows. Joblessness among high school dropouts has fallen to about half the rate in 1992. And wages for the lowest paid are rising faster than inflation for the first time in decades.

title: Running Stag Wins Brooklyn Handicap
description: Running Stag, a horse with an international itinerary, made a successful trip to the United States yesterday when he won the 111th running of the Brooklyn Handicap at Belmont Park and equaled the race record set two years ago by Formal Gold.

title: INSIDE
description: SPECIAL TODAY

title: Words of Caution About a Hot Potato
description: AT health food stores, tiny tubs of wild yam cream sell well, despite their price ($20 or more). The lure is wild yam's reputation as a source of natural progesterone, a hormone that proponents of alternative medicine consider a palliative for menopausal discomforts.

title: Iberia, Beset by Delays, Cuts Flight Schedule
description: Spain's state-run airline, Iberia, has scaled back plans to expand its schedule in Europe and Latin America, canceling 900 flights, or 3.5 percent of its scheduled departures, in June. These include suspension of service from Madrid to Moscow and to London-Gatwick. The decision, announced in May, is an effort to reduce delays at Spanish airports, especially in Madrid. A recent labor agreement between the pilots' union and Iberia was seen as a step to ease the delays, which began in late March and have been frequent front-page news in Spain. But Iberia said the reduced June schedule was necessary because the situation was still not back to normal.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MY PHANTOM HUSBAND By Marie Darrieussecq. New Press, $19.95.

title: The Pressure's On, and It's in the Hole!
description: What's the most important putt you ever made? Some prominent PGA Tour players give their answers.

title: Sculpture With Aspects Captured in Portraits
description: AT the Upper View Gallery are the results of an unusual collaboration between a sculptor and a photographer. The sculptor, Wilfredo Morel, says that his overriding subject is life, in particular life with all of its viscissitudes. This is evidently also the view of the photographer John Henry, whose subject, at least for purposes of this exhibition, is Mr. Morel's work.

title: Brazil, High In Shootings, Is Proposing To Ban Guns
description: Over the outraged protests of a nascent gun lobby, a new state law prohibiting the sale of firearms has already gone into effect here. In Brasilia, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso wants to go even further: his Government has introduced fast-track legislation that would completely ban the possession of arms throughout this nation of 165 million people.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /SoHo; The Arts Give Way to Style and Fashion
description: SPACIOUS lofts in 19th-century cast-iron buildings and a thriving art scene have attracted creative people to SoHo for the last three decades.

title: '38 Hurricane Still a Lesson in Ruin
description: THE unnamed hurricane that slammed into the South Shore of Suffolk County on the afternoon of Sept. 21, 1938, with such force that it registered on a seismograph in Sitka, Alaska, is about to go into the record book as the Long Island storm of the century.

title: Study on Child Sex Abuse Provokes a Political Furor
description: Few people took notice last July when Psychological Bulletin, an academic psychology journal, carried a lengthy, jargon-heavy report titled ''A Meta-Analytic Examination of Assumed Properties of Child Sexual Abuse Using College Samples.''

title: Which Way to the Beach?
description: Fashion and the thermometer went in opposite directions last week. The season's first heat wave put people into striptease mode, with minimal fabric and lots of exposed skin. Some got right down to basic T-shirts, bared midriffs, backless halters and short, skimpy slip dresses. For others, it was a matter of dodging sun-shading parasols. The message was one of comfort and practicality, though a number of men seemed unfazed by the humidity and heat in their buttoned-up jackets and ties. The must-have accessories were designer status bags, platform slides and cell phones.

title: Enjoying Koreatown And Points Beyond
description: CHO DANG GOL

title: Not So Fast, 'Asbury Park'
description: Some rock-and-roll bands with regional followings wait a lifetime to be on an album that they did not put out themselves, and maybe break into the big time. Others who make the cut just wish they knew about it ahead of time.

title: SOAPBOX; Taken to School in the Schoolyard
description: ON a basketball Saturday in 1970, my friend Barry and I headed down the streets of Cranford past Droescher's Mill.

title: Board Members' Liability
description: ON May 27, a New York State appeals court issued a decision that put co-op and condominium board members on notice that they can be held personally liable for their actions as corporate directors. The court ruled that when board members are sued as individuals for actions they perform as directors, they cannot be reimbursed by their co-op or condominium if they are found liable for damages that are punitive in nature.

title: Bedlam on the Streets
description: As New York has speeded up its rate of discharging patients from state mental hospitals into unsupervised settings, is it any surprise that more and more homeless and disoriented persons roam our streets, parks and subway platforms? The stupidity of giving a bottle of pills to a man who cannot read and a crisis phone number to a man without a telephone is incomprehensible. Mental hospitals are a necessity for many. A well-run, competently staffed living arrangement is imperative for most.

title: SOAPBOX; A Dog's Life
description: I'M going to lose my dog. The veterinarian told me so a month ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Brash Defense Lawyer Shrugs Off Attacks on Tactics in Louima Case
description: Poor Marvyn Kornberg. Across the nation, the words ''sleazy'' and ''shameful'' keep popping up in close proximity to his name. Columnists call him mud, poison, liar. Fellow criminal defense lawyers ridicule his trial tactics as ''outlandish'' and ''stupid.''

title: Todd Waldman, Emily Fatula
description: Emily Katherine Fatula, the daughter of John Fatula of Philadelphia and the late Dian Fatula, was married last evening to Dr. Todd Alan Waldman, the son of Gay Waldman and Dr. Robert Waldman of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Greenback Blues
description: Jason Goodwin's attachment to the paper dollar (May 23) is as quaint as it is irrational. A dollar coin would have numerous advantages over the greenback. It would work better in vending machines. It would outlast dozens of flimsy paper dollars. Our Canadian neighbors have done away with bills of less than five dollars, substituting sturdy $1 and $2 coins, lovingly referred to as ''loonies'' and ''toonies.'' Paper-money enthusiasts have no need to worry: the $100 bill will remain the world's favorite mattress-stuffer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Collisions of the Sexes
description: From executive offices to offshore oil rigs, workplaces that were virtually ''men only'' just a decade ago have opened their doors to more and more women. Men and women alike have adjusted and adapted -- at times awkwardly, at times thoughtfully. The resulting tales can range from uproarious to touching. Send yours to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: June Boonyasai, Spencer Lehv
description: Numjit June Boonyasai and Spencer Austin Lehv are to be married this evening by Rabbi Susan A. Talve at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in St. Louis. Last evening, the couple had a traditional Thai ceremony at the Missouri Botanical Gardens in St. Louis.

title: Food; The Odd Couple
description: For a fragile moment each year, the produce of late spring and early summer co-exist -- luscious vegetables and glorious fruits that, individually, tend to be either sweet or sour, much like a romance of the spring- or summer-fling variety. In combination, however, they are both complementary and oppositional, more like a fine marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: How Grandma Got Better, From Bear Oil to Salt Up the Nose
description: WHEN the jazz singer Susannah McCorkle checks into the Algonquin Hotel in New York this month for her annual four-week engagement in the Oak Room, it will be with everything a chanteuse needs: eight clinging, glittery evening gowns; the perfect pair of gold dancing sandals; an ample supply of false eyelashes, and, for good health, a box of baking soda and a bag of salt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Among the Weeds, Survivors of the Winter
description: IT has proved to be a low-budget year so far for gardeners. Instead of making huge outlays at nurseries and garden shops, people have not been buying so many new plants.

title: Reading Too Much Into a Book
description: Nothing is so powerful and dangerous as a book, as I know from my own experience. In 1989 and 1990 I wrote a travel book, ''Balkan Ghosts,'' about what I saw and heard in the Balkans in the 1980's while living in Greece. In 1993, after a war had started in Yugoslavia, the book was used as an excuse against American intervention. President Clinton reportedly read it and inferred that the region's peoples had never lived together peacefully for very long.

title: Local Justice
description: Hadrian's Walls

title: BEST SELLERS: June 13, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The Shadow Story Of the Millennium: Women
description: Your issue did not present a full picture of women. That's fine, but call it what it is: white women through the millennium. Or is it not politically correct to be this honest?

title: Jill Tomlinson, Lawrence Mango
description: Jill Carolyn Tomlinson, the daughter of Barbara A. Tomlinson of Slatersville, R.I., and James L. Tomlinson of Versailles, Ky., was married yesterday to Lawrence James Mango, a son of James A. Mango of Bethpage, N.Y., and the late Carol R. Mango. The Rev. Edmond Nixon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Epiphany Church in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: The Ethicist; Should I Tell?
description: Out of town on business, in the hotel bar, I saw a good friend's husband entwined with another woman. If I tell, my friend will be devastated, and she might hate me for it. If I don't, I'm joining her rotten husband in conspiring to deceive her. Should I tell? /S.B., New York

title: Liberties; Lighten Up, Baby!
description: If Hillary Rodham Clinton runs for the Senate, she will be roughed up by a vengeful, two-fisted, single-minded prosecutor, a guy who actually enjoys slapping manacles on people.

title: Corrections
description: The byline and the reviewer identification on page 7 of the Book Review today, with the review of ''A Clearing in the Distance: Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the Nineteenth Century,'' misspell the reviewer's given name, as does the table of contents. She is Suzannah Lessard, not Suzanna.

title: If There's a Challenge, Fossett Will Be Up to It
description: Steve Fossett can't understand why yacht racers enjoy sailing America's Cup sloops. But show him a multihull with a deck made of netting and a cockpit the size of a bathtub, and you'll find a man with his sea boots on.

title: Jetting to India in Search of a Pattern
description: VIRGINIA WITBECK did a mannequin spin to show off her coat, a luminous garment of quartz-pink silk that she designed in India. Part of a collection she was showing at the Upper East Side apartment of a banker friend, it looked fit for a Mogul prince. And why not? It was, after all, cut from the cloth of her fantasies.

title: A Question of Beauty: Is It Good for You?
description: I have an image of perfect health. It's a photograph of a young woman smiling, her teeth white, her hair shining, her skin glowing, her body thin and muscular -- the sort of picture that appears on the cover of magazines like American Health. It's the true me, of course, the me if I did everything right and took an anti-aging pill.

title: Liz Layton, Robert Naylor
description: Liz Layton and Robert Mitchell Naylor were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ernest E. Gray at Johns Island Presbyterian Church in Johns Island, S.C.

title: Bordering on an Obsession
description: SOMETIMES it is no more than a bump in the road. Sometimes it's a bureaucratic labyrinth or a cash cow for impoverished economies. Sometimes -- although increasingly rarely in the post-Cold War era -- it is a physical, psychological and geopolitical chasm, still worthy of the wonderfully exotic term ''frontier.'' I'm talking about one of the unsung but, at least to me, most exciting parts of travel: borders. Countries and states are wonderful. But so are the places in between.

title: Lee Stein, Robert Attanasio
description: Lee Meredith Stein and Robert Joseph Attanasio were married yesterday in Milwaukee. Judge Ralph A. Fine of the Wisconsin Court of Appeals officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Joan and Jack Stein.

title: From Worker's Housing to Pint-Size Urban Enclave
description: Like a period movie set someone forgot to take down, the narrow three-story brick houses lining the cobbled street of Willow Terrace, west of Willow Avenue between Sixth and Seventh Streets, are of a different design and seemingly a different era, from the larger row houses and apartment buildings that surround them.

title: Using a Needle To Fix an Urge
description: BY applying a small electrical current to a nerve just above the ankle, doctors may one day relieve an embarrassing disorder: urge incontinence. Characterized by an uncontrollable, frequent, sometimes painful need to empty the bladder, urge incontinence is one of several forms of urinary incontinence that afflict more than 17 million, mostly female, Americans.

title: Elizabeth Mellen, Todd Harrison
description: Elizabeth Ann Mellen, a daughter of Mary Davison Mellen of White Plains and Francis J. Mellen Jr. of Louisville, Ky., is to be married this afternoon to Todd Samuel Harrison, the son of Elizabeth and Phil Harrison of Hattiesburg, Miss. The Rev. John Ballard is to perform the ceremony in Cladwell Chapel at the Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Louisville.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Choice Tables column on May 23, about restaurants in Brittany, translated ''pre sale'' incorrectly. The phrase, literally ''salt meadow,'' refers to lamb raised on salt marshes; it does not mean presalted.

title: Commercial Property /Brooklyn; At Gowanus Canal, Developers Plan $63 Million Mall
description: IN the days when the Gowanus Canal was best known for its foul odors, it would not have come to mind quickly as a site for an upscale shopping center. But the canal is cleaner these days, and it is in the middle of the affluent brownstone communities of Park Slope and Carroll Gardens.

title: The Sony Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Paradises Open Gates for a Day
description: AS dedicated avocational gardeners will attest, theirs is not a hobby for the fainthearted. It is hard work that requires discipline, physical stamina and imagination. Especially this week, when the owners of 10 East End gardens are preparing for the Garden Conservancy's Open Days tour on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, PAUL R.
description: BURTON-Paul R. On June 11, 1999, of Port Washington, NY. Husband of Elizabeth Burton. Father of Cynthia, Leslie, Celeste, Paul and Neil Burton. Grandfather of John and Lucas Cofer, and Kent Horsley. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY, on Sunday, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church, on Monday at 11:45 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; An Amusement Park on a Roller-Coaster Upswing
description: THREE years ago, after a decade of more ups and downs at the Lake Compounce amusement park than its 72-year-old wooden Wildcat roller coaster, the Pennsylvania-based Kennywood Corporation took over with a promise to return it to its former glory.

title: New Ventures: Born in Israel, Raised in U.S.
description: ISRAEL is called the Silicon Valley of the Middle East because so many new technology companies get started there. But the country differs from the California original in one crucial respect: Fledgling companies must leave the nest to thrive.

title: Spurs Cast Wary Eye On Knicks
description: It is easy to tag the San Antonio Spurs as the anti-Knicks, with their mannerly ways and wholesome backgrounds, powerful tandem of 7-footers and unencumbered skip through the first three rounds of the playoffs.

title: PULSE; Breezy Does It
description: Tennis clubs have pro shops for players who want last-minute fashions, so why not dance clubs? At Body and Soul, a Sunday afternoon dance party at Vinyl, 6 Hubert Street (Hudson Street), Ephrat Livni sells clothes to her fellow partyers, known for their multicultural chic and antidesigner style. At a table next to the coat check, Ms. Livni has hand-collaged T-shirts ($25 to $35), sarongs ($20 to $40), head wraps ($15 to $25) and other ''clothes you can dance in,'' she said. She sells them under the name Clothing From Planet (E).

title: Call It a 'Roadeo,' or a Busman's Holiday
description: For a living, Ralph Thomas drives the B8 bus out of the East New York depot in Brooklyn. Last Sunday he was off. But while others fished or loafed, Mr. Thomas climbed behind the wheel of a 40-foot bus and prodded it around a Randalls Island parking lot peppered with plastic cones, barrels and tennis balls.

title: Swiss Will Decide if Motherhood Warrants Salary Protection
description: The Swiss will decide on Sunday whether to provide new mothers with the kind of salary protections that every other Western European country affords women after they give birth.

title: June 6-12; A New Plan for Drug Coverage Under Medicare
description: President Clinton wants to expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs, and White House officials disclosed some details of the proposal. They also said, however, that they were still trying to figure out how to pay for it.

title: In America
description: An anti-loitering law that allowed the Chicago police to arrest more than 42,000 people from 1992 to 1995 was declared unconstitutional last week by the Supreme Court.

title: EZ-Pass to Be Phased In On Garden State Parkway
description: The EZ-Pass electronic toll system is scheduled to be phased in on the Garden State Parkway starting at the northernmost toll plaza in Hillsdale in late November or early December and working its way south, the state announced last week.

title: A Place for Tuscan Flavors in Cold Spring
description: THIS village has become so commercialized that it no longer seems a destination for the discerning. Yet, on recent spring evenings, the village, still empty of tourists, looked like the quaint old town that drew people here in the first place. The emporiums peddling spanking new antiques, scented candles or ubiquitous silver jewelry receded in the dusk, leaving the loom of Storm King Mountain and the sunset's afterglow on the silvery Hudson River. Although some of the character of the place has changed, much remains for eye and palate.

title: Ms. Kinzelberg And Mr. Owgang
description: Cynthia Gail Kinzelberg and Mitchell Ian Owgang are to be married today by Rabbi Israel Miller at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: The Trailblazer
description: The day came when Mike Dombeck was asked if he could straighten out the United States Forest Service, and although he had no history of rash behavior, he said yes. Now he's in charge of 191 million acres of national forest -- about 8 percent of the United States. It's a nice job, in theory, for someone who grew up roaming the north woods of Wisconsin. In practice, though, just about the only trail Mike Dombeck ever gets to wander anymore is the Heartburn Loop, from his office near the Washington Monument to the halls of Congress.

title: Testiness Over School Plan
description: Parents of students at a Brooklyn public elementary school that is scheduled for renovation are angry that, two weeks before school ends, they are not yet sure where their children will be taught next fall.

title: The Cost Of Recharging
description: Q. After 15 years of working in sales and marketing for a Fortune 100 company, I need to make a change. I will most likely seek a position in a similar field, but first I need a break from the pressure. I have all but decided to quit my job and take a two-month respite. But if I do so, how much more difficult will it be to find another job? And how can I improve my chances?

title: Now, the Lady Lunches
description: Having made her biggest splash in musical theater as Cassie, the quintessential gypsy who really needs that job in ''A Chorus Line,'' Donna McKechnie has realized a performer's near-impossible dream: she got a job without auditioning.

title: June 6-12; Court Frees Woman Who Threatened Cosby
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan overturned the conviction of Autumn Jackson, who was sent to prison for threatening to tell a supermarket tabloid that she was Bill Cosby's out-of-wedlock daughter unless he paid her $40 million.

title: Copenhagen
description: Time and again in Copenhagen, you're struck by the confidence of the Danes. Their exuberance is evident in the striking new architecture of the city's museums, and the surprises begin as soon as you arrive: at Copenhagen Airport, the dramatic new steel-and-glass Terminal 3 is covered by a 750-foot-long delta-shaped glass roof. Trains whisk passengers into the city (a six-mile trip) in 12 minutes (about $2.50, based on 6.80 kroner to the dollar) -- and, in July 2000, they'll run to Malmo, Sweden, in 35 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, SIDNEY
description: RICHMAN-Sidney. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Hal and Barbara, and Sherry and George. Cherished grandfather of Olivia, Alistair and Marissa. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: Whose 'Right to Bear Arms' Is It?; Militias Are Outdated
description: To the Editor:

title: How Blue Is Your Collar
description: IN her mid-30's and in mid-career, Solange de Santis, a business reporter with an Ivy League education and a crisp white-collar upbringing, became an auto worker.

title: A Pinot Noir That Only Tastes Expensive
description: Pinot noir makers in California, especially the Central Coast and the Russian River Valley in Sonoma County, seem to work Saturdays, Sundays and holidays to emulate their Oregon seniors.

title: The World: Letting the Chips Fall Where They May; High-Tech Exports Hit Antiquated Speed Bumps
description: BAD news for Chinese generals: The United States Commerce Department has just determined that the new Sony Playstation II, available later this year, is powered by an American-made chip so powerful that Washington would have to be notified before it could be shipped to China. If the final destination were a company, institute or household linked to the Chinese military, a lengthy review would be required to make sure America's most sophisticated technology does not fall into the hands of bomb makers.

title: The View From/Rye; Costumes and Festivities Mark School's 100th Year
description: THE centennial celebration of the Milton School here was, in the words of one participant, a ''charming'' event. Straight out of a Norman Rockwell canvas, it featured a little parade down the city's main street, children and grown-ups in turn-of-the-century (19th century, that is) costumes, red, white and blue decorations, a Dixieland band and lemonade, popcorn and ice cream.

title: June 6-12; Supreme Court Strikes Down Loitering Law Aimed at Gangs
description: Chicago's anti-loitering law, a model for cities seeking to reclaim the streets from violent gangs, was declared unconstitutional. By a 6-to-3 vote, the Supreme Court said the law gave the police too much discretion to sweep up innocent people in their fight against crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: N.B.A. EASTERN CONFERENCE CHAMPIONS: Dancing From the Rafters at the Garden; Houston, the Scorer, Rises to the Occasion
description: The game was glowing on the tube in the living room, but Alice Houston was searching for things to tidy up in the basement of her family's Louisville, Ky., home. Her son, Allan, was on the court creating rainbows that splashed into the net, but she was scouring the kitchen for another dish to wash.

title: Amy Smith and Brian Fuchs
description: Amy Claire Smith, a daughter of Janice and William P. Smith of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to Brian Charles Fuchs, the son of David C. Fuchs of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and the late Audrey Barrett Fuchs. Bishop John Palmer Croneberger of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony at the Church of the Atonement.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Insurance for Redevelopers of Polluted Sites
description: LAST year the state enacted the Brownfields and Contaminated Site Redemption Act, providing developers reimbursement of up to 75 percent of the cost of the completed cleanup if, among other things, the redevelopment project would generate new tax revenue exceeding the cleanup cost.

title: Women's Drugs: Big in Profits, Narrow in Scope
description: DURING the last year, the executives of some of the largest drug companies must have taken a marketing course or two from the Girl Scouts or the folks at the Miss America Pageant.

title: Helping Jews to Tackle Substance Abuse
description: HER voice was strained and cigarette-raspy, filled with anguish and despair as she recounted a past ruined by heroin addiction, homelessness and domestic abuse. The tears came when she spoke of her 5-year-old daughter, a pawn in a custody battle. She's not proud of her drug-filled past, littered with memories like the time she vandalized her parents' home or the time she bailed out of life and became a Deadhead, following the Grateful Dead around the country with a motorcycle gang.

title: Guys Aren't Alone in Sawing Logs at Night
description: A man and a woman are asleep in bed. Which one is snoring?

title: June 6-12; A Confrontation With the Pope
description: Pope John Paul II was back in his native Poland again, this time to focus attention on the 20th-century martyrdom of Christians and underline the broad themes of his papacy.

title: Oh Mom, Poor Mom
description: LAST THINGS

title: The Uses of Enchantment
description: THE BOY ON

title: Fresh Paint for Past Faces
description: Manny Vega stood atop a makeshift scaffold at 104th Street and Lexington Avenue, pressing the tip of his paintbrush to the azure sky.

title: No Sign Needed to Draw Crowds
description: ROBERT'S is terrific. It's the first big hit of the East End summer season. This charming Water Mill restaurant has been popular since opening in mid-April. A tablemate wondered aloud: ''How did everyone find this place? The small sign in front is certainly discreet.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Please stow your expectations securely in your overhead bins as they may shift during the trip and can fall and hurt someone -- especially me.''

title: For Poor Nations, Debt Is Bondage
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Prickly Pear of Queens

title: Correction
description: A brief report in The Guide last Sunday about a lecture on jewelry created by Jean Schlumberger misstated the date and the information telephone number. The lecture, by Pierce MacGuire, director of the Schlumberger collection at Tiffany, will be at 7 P.M. Thursday at Tiffany in The Westchester, in White Plains. Schlumberger jewelry will be on exhibition there through June 28. The telephone number is 686-5100.

title: Champions Of Good Causes
description: Raising money to help children, the poor, the arts and more.

title: A Mark of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Commander Seeks To Resolve Russian Role
description: Taking a tough line toward Russian troops who moved into Pristina without NATO's approval last night, the alliance's top general warned today that the commander of the NATO peacekeeping force had authority to order them to leave.

title: Almost True Confessions Of a Self-Delusion Addict
description: SOMEWHERE in the middle of the 1990's, taking care of ourselves became a virtue. This may be why a man I know who is promiscuous, a chain smoker and a junk food addict considers himself health-conscious because he religiously takes powdered shark-fin capsules.

title: Jody Bieber, Chad Graddy
description: Jody Michelle Bieber, a daughter of Caren and Ronald Bieber of Princeton, N.J., was married last evening to Chad Devon Graddy, a son of Joy Graddy of Memphis and John Graddy of Alpharetta, Ga. Rabbi Phillip Krantz officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Atlanta. The Rev. Helen Neinast, a United Methodist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Backtalk; In Buffalo, Disillusion Breeds Caution
description: Last week The Dallas Morning News sent a reporter to Buffalo as part of its effort to introduce its sunbaked readers to the mysteries of that strange foreign phenomenon, the Stanley Cup finals. What the reporter found, in contrast to the habitual cockiness of Dallas fans, was Buffalonian after Buffalonian picking the Stars to win the series, muttering muted thanks that the Sabres had at least got this far, and expressing the cautious hope that maybe, just maybe, if all the planets queue up properly in the firmament, the locals will scratch out victory and finally bring some positive national attention to their small corner of the Niagara Frontier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Elise Santaniello, Michael James
description: Elise Hope Santaniello and Michael Salvatore James were married on Friday by Msgr. Edward Ciuba at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: David Wells and Noel Ashman; Extra Innings Blowout
description: JUST as a birthday party for the former Yankee pitcher David Wells and his best friend, the restaurateur Noel Ashman, was coming into full swing at Veruka on Wednesday night, the guests of honor were nowhere near the SoHo nightspot. They were stuck in Flushing, Queens, awaiting the outcome of a deadlocked baseball game.

title: Deeply in Your Face, From Maintenance to Lasers
description: Juva Skin and Laser Center, a place that merges the medical treatments of a dermatologist's office with the esthetic regimens of a spa, opened last month at 60 East 56th Street (between Park and Madison Avenues).

title: It's Not Just Kids Who Flunk Spelling
description: The instructions for the English test taken this year by all New York fourth graders included ''check your work.'' But that is a lesson that has apparently gone unlearned not just among the two-thirds of the city's fourth graders who failed the test but also at the Department of Transportation, at least when it comes to the corner of Boerum Place and Pacific Streets.

title: Big on Short Game: Putting at Pinehurst Could Be Decisive
description: The speaker was David Duval. The subject was putting.

title: The Shadow Story Of the Millennium: Women
description: In an issue devoted to the changes and advancements in the status of women over the millennium, it was a shock to see that The New York Times still sees women as intellectually inferior. Do you truly believe that we need a cheat sheet for the crossword?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: INDIANA GOTHIC

title: Column on Jackson Heights Ignored Important Element
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Double Vision; Two Views Of Inhumanity Split the World, Even in Victory
description: IT was a signal week for the West, no doubt about it. Fifty-four years after the Holocaust revelations, America and Europe had finally said ''enough,'' and struck a blow against a revival of genocide.

title: They Also Act Who Only Sit and Listen
description: BRENDAN COYLE has spent almost 400 performances, his elbows propped on a bar, a lager or a whisky at the ready, listening to his fellow players in ''The Weir'' turn a litany of ghostly tales into a haunting study of collective self-revelation. But playing a bartender also named Brendan, Mr. Coyle never gets a story of his own, unless you believe -- as some do -- that Brendan's tale begins once Conor McPherson's play ends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the village of Pont-Aven in Brittany and the school of painting that originated there misstated the nationality of the collector Samuel Josefowitz. He is Swiss, not American.

title: No Hummels. But a Zen Zone, Magnetic Mezuzahs and Urban Hip
description: For affection or appreciation, gifts for all occasions are available at Tokens. The novelty shop, at 671 Ninth Avenue (between 46th and 47th Streets) was described by Jackie Anderson, an owner, as hip and urban.

title: For Employed Moms, the Pinnacle Of Stress Comes After Work Ends
description: SUSAN REICHE, a public policy manager at AT&T in Basking Ridge, N.J., can handle what work throws at her from 9 to 5. It's what life throws at her between 5 and 9 that pushes her to the limit.

title: A Guilty Plea To Posing as Notary
description: The owner of a Mineola process-serving company pleaded guilty to reduced charges on Monday to settle six criminal charges of posing as a notary and six of filing false documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALANT, WALTER S.
description: SALANT-Walter S. A memorial service will be held on June 21st at 2 PM in the Main Auditorium of Brookings Institution, 1775 Massachusetts Avenue, Washington, DC.

title: Celebrating The Ultra-Rich Computer Nerd
description: IN 1968 I had a college roommate who was the prototypical computer geek. He lived and worked at night and slept during the day. He was pale. He had a little light show rigged up to the stereo in our room. And what he did over in the engineering quadrangle with the mainframe computers was a mystery to all of us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLIAN, BESS
description: KROLIAN-Bess. On June 11, 1999. Born Worcester, MA. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Cherished mother of Linda and Dennis. Dear mother-in-law of Eleanor and Rene. Devoted grandmother of Tara, Michael, Elizabeth, Paul and Emily.

title: A Hands-on-the-Helm Leader
description: IT has not been a restful week for Michael R. Bonsignore. Since Monday, when Honeywell Inc., the $8.4 billion company he has headed since 1993, and Allied Signal told the world they planned to merge, it has been helicopters, airplanes, limousines, one after the other, shuttling him between Honeywell's Minneapolis headquarters and Allied's home in Morristown, N.J., with investor meetings in New York, Boston, Washington and Philadelphia in between.

title: Lawyers for Cherry Hill Rabbi Ask About a Mob Figure
description: Lawyers for Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, accused in the beating death of his wife nearly five years ago, last week asked the Camden County prosecutor's office to supply them with information on any interviews done with Joseph Merlino, a reputed Philadelphia mobster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, PHILIP EISINGER, II.
description: HOFFMAN-Philip Eisinger, II. On June 11. Beloved companion of Evelyn. Devoted father of Rick. Loving son of Betty G. Levene. Adored brother of Hilde Hoffman Agatstein, Julien P. Hoffman, Laurie Whitehill and Doug Levene. Services today 1:30 PM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: In the Golden Age of Teeth, a Smile Can Be Perfected
description: DENTISTS call them Hollywood Chiclets -- oversize, pearly white teeth that gleam so beautifully on the silver screen. Fifteen years ago, those celluloid teeth were most likely caps made of porcelain and gold, concealing filed-down tooth stumps, installed at a cost of thousands of dollars and many painful hours.

title: A Bridge Between a City and Its Self-Image
description: JEAN NOUVEL'S new design for a hotel and cineplex on the Brooklyn waterfront strikes me as one of the most imaginatively conceived pieces of architecture New York has seen in a long time. I've been groping for ideas to explain why. What makes a building contemporary? An impossible question to answer, but perhaps not a fruitless one to ask.

title: From the P.C.'s and Pens of Long Island; Tale of Colonial Intrigue Born of a Child's Writing
description: KATHERINE KIRKPATRICK has been working on ''Redcoats and Petticoats,'' her retelling of a true story of Revolutionary War intrigue on Long Island, for a long time. More than 20 years ago, as a fourth grader at Harbor Country Day School in St. James, she first penned the tale of Anna Smith Strong and the Setauket Spy Ring as an entry for a contest sponsored by the Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: Drunken-Driving Impoundments Overwhelming Nassau County
description: OCCUPYING three small rooms on the second floor at headquarters in Mineola, the Asset Forfeiture Bureau was a little-known and relatively quiet division of the Nassau County Police Department.

title: The Ground War That Was
description: Only at dawn, when a pink light softens the landscape, does the harsh terrain of the Albania-Kosovo border look anything but forbidding. On a day in early May -- weeks before the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, will accept a peace accord, when the war still seems as if it can go on for months -- the sky is clear and the air surprisingly crisp, the promise of a beautiful spring day. But in this part of the world, that's no cause for celebration. It's bombing weather, and the action starts early.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HENRIETTA (FEUER STEIN)
description: FRIEDMAN - Henrietta (Feuer stein). On June 11, 1999 in her 86th year of Aventura, FL. Died at home after a long illness. Retired New York City Elementary School Teacher. Devoted widow of William. Mother of Richard C. Friedman, M.D., Joseph Friedman, M.D., and Daniel Friedman, Ph.D. Admired by daughters-in-law Susan Mates, M.D. and Sue Matorin. Proud grandmother of Rebecca, Debra, William, Jeremiah, Heidi and Carla. Services Sunday, June 13, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, SHIRLEY
description: LIEBMAN-Shirley. Devoted and beloved sister of Carolyn Dorman, Howard Liebman and the late Arnold Liebman. Cherished sister-inlaw of Marilyn and Martha Liebman. Adored aunt of Allison, Phyllis, Judith Liebman, Cindy, Amy and Talia Amoyal. the sun and the moon will shine less brightly without Shirley. Funeral Sunday June 13th, 1:30PM at Gutterman's, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: How Much Will They Buy When Trading on Line?
description: Sure, some investors are obsessed with trading on line. But how much are Americans willing to bet in a single on-line trade without asking a financial adviser? The answer, according to a poll by Louis Harris & Associates, is $4,500, on average.

title: Food Out of Context
description: To the Editor:

title: What Struggle?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet Musical Victory At Pleasantville High
description: AND the winner for Outstanding Musical is: Pleasantville High School for ''The King and I.'' When Pleasantville swept the new Helen Hayes Theater Awards for high school musicals recently, triumphing over 17 other schools, the moment was sweet for Dr. Renato Vellutino.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, RICHARD L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Richard L. A good, great man, treasured and deeply missed. 6/13/98. Lovingly, HGR

title: No Excuses
description: To the Editor:

title: For 2 Women, Home Field Advantage
description: It's not the World Series. It's not the Super Bowl. But it's not chopped liver.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: For Physical Therapists, a Sudden Drought
description: IN his first year in the physical therapy program at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, Tony Woods saw advanced students receiving multiple job offers -- sometimes months before graduation. Mr. Woods, who had been a carpenter, was feeling good about trying a career change.

title: Easing Arthritis Pain
description: OF the 23 million Americans who suffer from either rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis, both of which primarily affect women, almost four million have received prescriptions for new anti-inflammatory drugs known as cox-2 specific inhibitors.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: Our Towns; Tank Gives Historic Zone The Shudders
description: BOB PINTO has to pause to knuckle the tears away when he talks about the honored dead and the recognition that he and his fellow veterans want to give them at the V.F.W. post here. Sammy Cohen, who lives down the road, swears that she will scale the courts to the highest branch to stop them, or at least, to stop what they have in mind.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WAITING FOR APHRODITE

title: Turning Cars Into Plowshares
description: In a rare twist for New York City, a parking lot has disappeared and been replaced by paradise. At least it must seem so to gardening enthusiasts in the East Village since the Chelsea Garden Center, which is to plant lovers what Zabar's is to food lovers, relocated its nursery to a former parking lot at the southeast corner of Bowery and Second Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, GEORGETTE
description: FRIEDMAN-Georgette. Beloved wife of Harold, cherished mother of Charles, Sherry and Barry, sister of Reva, Harold, and Beverly, grandmother of Brian, Mark, Andre and Matthew. To honor her memory, the family would appreciate donations to the American Lung Association.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SNOW MAN

title: Gambling, but without neon
description: With ever more expensive casino resorts elbowing one another aside for space on the Strip, it was a matter of time before one major resort decided to get away from it all. That is the aim at the Resort at Summerlin, which opens June 29 in northwest Las Vegas in the shadows of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area. For those who cannot do without neon, there will be a free shuttle to the Fashion Show Mall on Las Vegas Boulevard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Elizabeth Sheed and Robert Baldridge
description: FIVE years ago, Elizabeth Sheed attended a rummage sale and found an antique lace wedding dress with the hand-stitched beauty of an Amish quilt. ''One of my friends said, 'You have to get it,' '' remembered Ms. Sheed, now 40. '' 'You never know when you're going to need it.' ''

title: In Dharamsala, Becoming Ready for the Next Life
description: LAST fall, when Dr. Yeshi Dhonden, formerly the personal physician to the Dalai Lama, came to New York, a friend called me. ''He's specializing in breast cancer treatment,'' she said. ''I think you should go see him.'' I was surprised. Not that the Tibetans were treating cancer, but that word of it hadn't got out on the cancer grapevine.

title: Clinton Asks Congress to Support New International Trade Deals
description: President Clinton urged Congress today to help him forge new international trade agreements that would create a more open marketplace while making a stronger commitment to improving labor conditions around the world.

title: Foods Containing Many Promises
description: Vitamin-fortified Gummy Bears, herb-sprayed crackers and soft drinks enhanced with antioxidants are part of a growing class of foods nutritional experts are calling ''nutraceuticals.'' Also referred to as designer foods, functional foods and ''pharmafoods,'' these products either contain healthful ingredients naturally or are supplemented with ingredients whose purported health benefits range from cancer prevention to improved brain function.

title: Running Hot and Cold
description: Elementals

title: Scientists Now Envision Life Without Menopause
description: NO need to stockpile Tampax and O.B.'s in anticipation of a great increase in tampon demand.

title: Area Code 865 Begins Ringing in South Jersey
description: The new 865 area code, which covers half the residents of the old 609 code, is now taking calls. Bell Atlantic put the new code into effect yesterday to accommodate the demand for new numbers for faxes, cellular phones and other devices. Residents in the eight towns split between the 609 and 856 codes may have to dial three extra digits to call a neighbor, but will still be charged for a local call.

title: Assessing a Big Fish In a Fast-Growing Pond
description: SUDDENLY, the world seems smitten by the prospects of fixed-wireless technology -- the fast-growing industry niche that links users to high-speed telecommunications networks through disk-shaped antennae instead of expensive fiber optic or T-1 lines.

title: French 16-Year-Old Outruns A Field of the Youthful Elite
description: The Young Champions Tournament last month in Lausanne, Switzerland, brought together a selection of the most promising youthful competitors in the world of chess. Prominent in the group were Darmen Sadvakasov of Kazakhstan, the current junior world champion, Ruslan Ponomariov of Ukraine, at 14 the youngest grandmaster of all time, and Etienne Bacrot of France, 16, who defeated Vassily Smyslov in a match in 1996.

title: Mount Rainier Park Celebrating Centennial
description: Mount Rainier National Park, a pristine enclave of forests, glaciers and alpine meadows surrounding the Pacific Northwest's loftiest mountain, turns 100 this year. The centennial will be commemorated with a series of activities, both inside and outside the park.

title: Nell Uhry and Thomas Burdett
description: Eleanor Andreae Uhry, a daughter of Dr. Joanna K. Uhry and the playwright Alfred Uhry of New York, was married last evening at her parents' house in Morris, Conn., to Thomas Brian Burdett, a son of Joan and Gerald L. Burdett of Edgewater, Md. The Rev. Rex E. McDaniel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the ceremony, in which Rabbi Alvin M. Sugarman took part.

title: Jonathan Steinberg, Maria Bartiromo
description: Maria Sara Bartiromo, a daughter of Josephine and Vincent Bartiromo of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Jonathan Laurence Steinberg, a son of Barbara Steinberg and Saul P. Steinberg, both of Manhattan. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein will officiate at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Gayfryd Steinberg, in Quogue, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAUBART, DAVID
description: GRAUBART-David. On June 12. Age 97 years. Beloved husband of the late Lilly. Devoted father of Emily and Ronald Leder. Loving grandfather of Matthew Leder, and Adena and Jeffrey Muller.

title: Giant Artwork to Announce Time in Infinite Detail
description: A 27-story building on the south end of Union Square Park will soon be the location of New York's very own time machine, so to speak. Now taking shape on the face of the year-old luxury apartment house, which has a Virgin megastore on its street level, the Metronome, as the timepiece is called, will cost nearly $3 million.

title: Choosing Colors By Historic Accuracy
description: FOR most homeowners, choosing the color for interior walls, ceilings and moldings is largely a matter of taste. The only considerations are whether a color may look good or where a particular hue might be used to create a desired effect.

title: When Cats Scratch (And They All Do)
description: THERE are few actions more irritating than a cat clawing household furniture -- a truth even ardent cat lovers cannot dismiss. Though it can drive nearly anyone to distraction, there is an instinctive reality at hand, a reality, once understood, that provides solutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, ZACHARY
description: LAZARUS-Zachary. Suddenly at age 37. Of Virginia Beach, VA, formerly of Pelham Manor, NY. Son of Hon. Robert J. Lazarus, U.S. Administrative Law Judge, and the late Nona Lazarus.

title: Germany's Troops Arrive; Refugees Get to Cheer a Few
description: More than 1,000 German troops arrived here today, and the main street of Kukes swelled with refugees waiting to cheer them on as the first NATO forces to enter Kosovo from the Albanian side.

title: Double-Teaming
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Athletes With Old Bones
description: Six months ago the very thin ballet student limped into Dr. Jordan Metzl's office at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, complaining of pain in her left shin. ''She seemed healthy, except that she had never gotten her period,'' Dr. Metzl recalled. After diagnosing a stress fracture, he made a more serious discovery. At age 15, the dancer was in the earliest stage of osteoporosis, a bone-thinning disorder usually identified with post-menopausal women.

title: Why Not Chemicals?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Canadian Ham
description: IN the credits for ''Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me,'' the sequel to the inspired 1997 spy spoof, Mike Myers mugs through another elaborately choreographed dance number. The first time I heard this swinging instrumental by the Quincy Jones Orchestra, I could have sworn it was the theme music from ''Definition,'' a Canadian game show from the 1970's, whose idea of a grand prize was a Brother typewriter.

title: Brimming With Wealth
description: C. Everett Koop, 82, the bearded apostle of well-informed patients, critic of managed care and battler against health hazards from Big Tobacco to big bellies, once spoke disdainfully of big bucks. He was already a renowned pediatric surgeon when he joined the Reagan Administration, and as a crusading Surgeon General, he valued candor over political discretion. ''I did not come here having to prove anything to myself,'' he said in Washington in 1987, ''and I was not looking for a six-figure job afterward.''

title: On the Beach
description: AGAINST THE TIDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDONALD, ROBERT GEORGE
description: MacDONALD - Robert George. Robert George MacDonald, 36, of New York City, NY, died Sunday (June 6, 1999). Born on April 4, 1963, Rob grew up in Simsbury and was a former resident of Storrs and Willimantic. Rob attended the University of Connecticut and City College of New York. Rob was a romantic, philosopher and social activist who was instrumental in winning several civil liberty cases in New York City, NY and Chicago, IL. While living in Willimantic he founded and managed the Populist Pudding, an art gallery and night club. He is survived by his parents, Robert and Nancy MacDonald of Stamford, CT, a sister, Judith MacDonald-Lobato of Atlanta, GA, a brother, Douglas MacDonald of Vallejo, CA, and his maternal grandmother, Mrs. George Bustard of Chatham, NJ. A memorial service for family was held at Talcott Mountain State Park in Simsbury, CT Saturday, June 12. A memorial for friends and the public will be held at C.B. Gallery, 313 Bowery, New York City, NY on Thursday, June 17, from 7-10 pm. Donations may be made to Kids in Crisis, 1 Salem Street, Cos Cob, CT 06807.

title: The Shadow Story Of the Millennium: Women
description: I've never been able to fill in more than a handful of words in your crossword puzzle, until you supplied ''easy clues'' along with the regular ones. Would you be so kind as to continue this feature?

title: From Africa to Cuba to 'Shaft'
description: The yearlong Festival of Pan-African America at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center ends next weekend with a bang, or at least with a lot of percussion: African, Afro-Cuban, salsa and soul. On three consecutive evenings, the festival offers a lineup of big-name, Grammy Award-winning artists, all of whom have altered or, in some cases, revolutionized their genres.

title: State's Economy Under a Microscope
description: CONNECTICUT is still No. 1 in the nation in per capita wealth, but its population and jobs growth has been virtually stagnant over the past decade. Despite a strong economy and low unemployment, the state still has not recovered all of the jobs it lost during the recession earlier this decade.

title: For Poor Nations, Debt Is Bondage
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtney Molloy, Tadd Chessen
description: Courtney Ann Molloy, the daughter of Lucille Molloy Warner of Salisbury, Conn., and the late Michael W. Molloy, was married yesterday to Tadd Howell Chessen, the son of Carolyn L. Chessen of St. Louis and Dr. Douglas H. Chessen of Newport News, Va. The Rev. Robert P. Clements, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Hotchkiss School Chapel in Lakeville, Conn.

title: In Storrs, the Return of a Vintage Musical Enriched by Time
description: IF you are among those dumbfounded by the cheesy lineup of Broadway musicals on the Tony Awards television program last Sunday, and by the sheer tackiness, from conception to execution, of a show designed to show off the best of Broadway, take heart.

title: A Discredited President Returns to Mexico
description: Interrupting a four-year exile, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari visited Mexico today for the first time since his tumultuous departure in 1995, when he left behind a brother accused of murder, a country in economic crisis, and a presidential legacy under siege.

title: Stir Softly
description: SPRING LAKE reminded me of the movie ''Pleasantville.'' Everyone I encountered encouraged me, without prompting, to move on in. It is certainly appealing, with the main street stretching along the Atlantic as the rest of the community hugs an intimate lake festooned with ornate wooden bridges -- so appealing that a visitor might miss the Hewitt Wellington Hotel. That would be a mistake, as this lakefront Victorian, surrounded by gazebos, neatly mown grounds and lush seaside gardens, hides a culinary jewel. The restaurant there is so decidedly special that its own name implies its desire to remain anonymous: Whispers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-31

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LILI
description: MORRIS-Lili. On June 4, 1999. Loving wife of the late Chester. Cherished mother of Kenton. Beloved sister of the late Joyce K. Ward. Fond stepmother of Col. Brooks (Laura) Morris, U.S.A.F, Retired. Dear friend of Lori, Kira, Elizabeth, Jillian Bennett and Betty Smith.

title: Wendy Scott and Richard Cutler
description: Wendy Vandeveer Scott and Richard Shreve Cutler were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Timothy J. Mulder at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: A Marshall Plan, on the Cheap?
description: WHEN George Marshall died in 1959, he left strict instructions: No eulogies. But getting politicians to follow commands, even those issued by former generals, is tricky business. And these days nearly everyone is paying homage to the Marshall Plan, which rebuilt Europe and Japan after World War II and became the gold standard for reconstructing some very deconstructed corners of the Earth.

title: Where to Buy the Trees That Grow in Brooklyn
description: The recently triumphant community gardeners and other green-thumbed urbanites have a new place to shop: Root Stock. This Park Slope spot opened yesterday with a selection of flora, fauna, vegetation and outdoor furnishings. It is at 297 Seventh Avenue (between Seventh and Eighth Streets) and owned by Liz Becker and John Rattigan, who are landscapers, neighborhood residents and home gardeners.

title: Patricia Fall, Andrew Salamy
description: Patricia Madeleine Fall, the daughter of Dorothy Fall of Washington and the late Bernard B. Fall, was married yesterday to Andrew Anthony Salamy, the son of Shirley and Norman G. Salamy of Shrewsbury, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Lyndhurst Castle, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Scape Artist
description: A CLEARING IN THE DISTANCE Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the Nineteenth Century. By Witold Rybczynski. Illustrated. 480 pp. New York: Scribner. $28.

title: Editorial Observer; Albany Forgets How to Pretend to Legislate
description: The New York State Legislature has always posed a challenge to people who believe in the inevitable progression of human history. But critics who called it impervious to change are wrong. Lately the system has gotten worse.

title: Jill Akst, Craig Sheflin
description: Jill Deborah Akst, a daughter of Paula and George Akst of Oceanside, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Craig Louis Sheflin, a son of Virginia Sheflin and Dr. Eric Sheflin of North Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck in Kings Point, N.Y.

title: Protecting the Eggs by Using More Baskets
description: IN unfortunate consequence of the long bull market in stocks is that investors are paying precious little attention to asset allocation -- the division of their holdings between various asset classes like stocks, bonds and real estate. They have been lured by stocks' huge returns into thinking that equities are the only game in town.

title: With Run Against the Odds, Knicks Turn Fans Into Believers
description: The hardest word on 7-year-old Drew Beck's spelling test on Friday was ''believe.''

title: Stores, and People, Finding Joy in Birds
description: NOW that the windows are open, the early-morning chirping of birds is for many Long Islanders a melodious harbinger of summer. But Rudy Flesch wants people to pay closer attention to the birds in their backyards year-round. Most importantly: what do they like to eat?

title: The Same Old Songs? Not Necessarily
description: SUMMERTIME, and the operas are easy. What you hear, cheap or even free, is beloved Italian staples, and what you get is dirty looks for humming along. In summer, you can flit from one ''Butterfly'' to the next. Or ''Boheme,'' or ''Barbiere,'' or ''Carmen.''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: OPINION; Delight and Adventure On a Coney Island Trip
description: NOW that there's a halo over Times Square and people smile at each other on the subway, Manhattan just doesn't cut it for adventure anymore. For that, you have to take on the challenge of an outer-borough excursion.

title: Social Issues of the 90's and Icons of the 60's
description: Howardena Pindell:

title: Via Microtechnology, an Alternative to Glasses and Contacts
description: I'M lying on my back, clutching a stuffed toy elephant and a wad of wet tissues. My jaw is clenched, my limbs are tense, my shoulder blades are hot-wired to my chair. I am not having a breakthrough in therapy, though I am about to change my life. I am one moment away from having elective surgery on my eyes -- both of them -- and am well into white-knuckle territory.

title: Siren Song
description: TIPPING THE VELVET

title: For Poor Nations, Debt Is Bondage
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Shop Talk; The Show Must Go Off
description: What, if anything, do the creators of television shows owe the audience that has grown attached to their characters? And when it's time for the show to end, how much care must the writers take to let the fans down easy? Top writers from the recently canceled ''Homicide,'' ''Melrose Place'' and ''Another World'' (may the shows rest in peace) discuss how to kill the series without injuring the viewers.

title: POSTINGS: Free Exhibit in Central Park; The History Of Battery Park
description: ''Where New York Began: Envisioning the Battery,'' an exhibit featuring maps, photographs, models, renderings, postcards and movie stills tracing the history of Battery Park in lower Manhattan and its landmarked Castle Clinton, opens next Thursday at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park at 64th Street.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Audi TT; At Century's End, a Car for the Ages
description: THE postmodernism that swamped architecture in the 1980's lapped up on the shores of the automobile in the 90's. Starting with the Dodge Viper -- a riff on a muscle-car icon, the Shelby AC Cobra -- a series of cars have happily rummaged through the toy box of great design.

title: MUSIC; Toward Fresh and Friendly Concerts
description: WHEN the orchestra arrives at Vienna circa 1909 it turns back,'' wrote John Ash, an English poet living in New York. ''Farewell Gustav, great Arnold, Anton and Alban!'' his ''Orchestral Manoeuvres (in the Dark)'' continues. ''The orchestra is a kind of vehicle rolling back and forth across two centuries flattening Alps for our convenience.''

title: The World; The Spark of Hope In an Ancient Hate
description: DURING the flurry of NATO meetings that have accompanied the Kosovo crisis, a strange sight has been seen several times. The foreign ministers of Greece and Turkey, the alliance's bitterest rivals, have huddled for private talks.

title: Motor Vehicle Scheme
description: After a 15-month investigation, two Department of Motor Vehicle clerks in Yonkers, the owner of a Bronx driving school, a New York City correction officer and another man have been arrested on charges they issued false documents to illegal aliens and others in exchange for cash.

title: Reigning on the Parade
description: Arabs and Israelis. Serbs and Albanians. Donald Trump and Steve Wynn. Some things just aren't perfect together.

title: A Call to Protect a Wetland Wriggling With Amphibious Life
description: WHEN is a thing of beauty less than meets the eye? Ecologically speaking, a sparkling lake may pale beside its plainer cousin, the vernal pond.

title: Ideas & Trends: A Question of Identity; For Jews, a Little Push for Converts, and a Lot of Angst
description: TRADITION says that when someone interested in converting to Judaism knocks on a synagogue's door, the rabbi should turn him away -- not once but three times, to test the seriousness of the person's intent. Unlike Christianity, Judaism emphatically shuns proselytizing.

title: Slow Going On the Road
description: THERE'S a traffic jam in the Spaghetti Bowl. This tangle of highways at Las Vegas, including Interstate 15, which carries traffic to and from California, and U.S. Route 95, is being redone at a cost of $92 million in what Scott Magruder, a Department of Transportation spokesman, says is Nevada's most costly road project.

title: End of a Presidency (No, Not That One)
description: ON the final day of my presidency, martial law was declared. No one was allowed in without a little paper pass I had made myself. You do not know the feeling of power until you have stood at the border with a guard and kept out those who do not belong. And last Tuesday night, at a packed meeting, I gave it all up. It was emotional.

title: No Trouble For Leiter Against The A.L.
description: If only Al Leiter could pitch against National League teams the way he has pitched against American League teams in his last two starts, he might have a winning record and a lower earned run average.

title: Basket Master Class
description: With high-end gift baskets the latest chic party presents, Clyde's, a pharmacy and department store at 926 Madison Avenue (74th Street), is now helping customers to tap into their inner Martha Stewarts with basket-arranging classes twice a month. On a recent afternoon, students were atwitter as two Upper East Side women squabbled over how to position a teddy bear in a baby basket brimming with soaps, picture frames and bib sets. ''We start out with a room of affluent, dignified women, and they turn into a bunch of little girls,'' Carol Sage, the store's manager, said. The classes are taught by Renato Ferreira (far left below), Gabriela Nistor and Ms. Sage, who offer tips on measuring cellophane, making stuffed animals stand erect and choosing basket themes, from bridal to ballerina. Wrapping materials and instruction are free, but customers who want to keep their baskets pay for them and the items inside. Information: (212) 744-5050.

title: Whose 'Right to Bear Arms' Is It?; Enough Laws Already
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: The View From/Madison; Movie Theater May Be Small, But the Expectations Are Big
description: IN the era of malls and multiplexes, the opening of a new movie theater is about as noteworthy as another blade of grass in a lawn. But in Madison, the truly unique has happened. For the first time that anyone can remember, a new independent movie theater has opened for business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Aid Agencies Shift Focus To the Needs Inside Border
description: The refugees stopped arriving only three days ago, but now, like trying to turn around a battleship, the aid agencies handling the 120,000 Kosovo Albanians in this border town are having to reverse focus to the refugees' safe return -- plus preparing to feed and help shelter an estimated 500,000 Albanians still inside Kosovo.

title: Government Report Says 3 Nations Hide Stocks of Smallpox
description: A secret Federal intelligence assessment completed late last year concludes that Iraq, North Korea and Russia are probably concealing the deadly smallpox virus for military use, Government officials say.

title: Governors Island Attracts Various Development Ideas
description: The city is exploring more than a dozen development proposals for Governors Island, the defunct Coast Guard Base in New York Harbor that President Clinton promised to sell for a dollar if New York came up with a publicly beneficial use.

title: It's Vindication For Childs, Who Salutes Fallen Stars
description: So many thoughts were running through Chris Childs's head, so many emotions running through his body, he must have felt as if he were going to burst.

title: Streetscapes /890 Park Avenue; A Row-House Relic's Falling Fortunes
description: HALF cleaned, 890 Park Avenue looks even more bedraggled than it did before, the smears of half-dissolved white paint running down the rich brick and brownstone facade. This Victorian row house between 78th and 79th Streets has had a bumpy ride for more than a century. Will the next bump be up or down?

title: Bedlam on the Streets
description: Winerip's article on the problems caused by insufficient funds for housing and treating the mentally ill was on the mark. He contrasted this with more adequate funds for mentally retarded individuals.
