I believe this difference results not from the compassion of this or that governor but from how we as a society differentiate between mental illness and mental retardation. Retardation is viewed as resulting from genetics or an accident of birth. Mental illness is regarded as somewhere between devil possession and weakness of will. There is still the idea that, as General Patton suggested, a good slap could snap them out of it. As long as we blame the mentally ill for their disease and jail them for their actions, money for treatment will be minimal.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Family Doctor Has a Blurred Face
description: TIME was, family doctors were there for you through thick and thin. They immunized your children, prescribed antibiotics for your strep throat and visited you in the hospital after your appendectomy. It was not unusual for such relationships to last 20 years or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Preaching the Merits of a Multistep Program
description: JUST as the sun cuts through the early morning mist, Byllye Avery gets up, pulls on her purple sweatpants and purple sweatshirt and heads out for her walk. Her favorite route is Beech Forest Trail, whose soft sand path is kind to her aging feet. At 61, Ms. Avery keeps the pace of a younger woman, but stops now and then to coo over a clutch of fluffy baby geese or read the Latin name of a tree.

title: In the Region /Long Island; 5 Golf/Housing Projects Proposed or Under Way
description: FOR the last seven weeks, the 40-year-old Hauppauge Country Club golf course on Veterans Memorial Highway has been closed to make way for a totally redesigned course incorporating 105 detached houses on 6,000- to 10,000-square-foot lots.

title: SCOTT COOK
description: Scott Cook was a consultant at Bain & Company in the early 1980's, looking for a business to start, when his wife told him how much she hated balancing the family checkbook. Soon after, he founded Intuit, the maker of Quicken, a simple program to let people write checks on personal computers.

title: FILM; Appreciating the Flapper Who Put the 'It' in an Era
description: IF you try to imagine Mary Pickford in a spangled cocktail dress slashed to the thigh or a flesh-colored bathing suit, failure awaits you: the flapper's wardrobe wasn't designed for apparent virgins. From 1909 to the early 1930's, Pickford's long sausage curls and ruffled skirts, her little feet in black patent leather Mary Janes, the limpid nursery school gaze, all suggested an existence rinsed of sexuality. Yet the barely adolescent Clara Bow ''spent hours imitating'' Pickford before a mirror, according to Bow's biographer, David Stenn. The spotless image of Pickford, the permanent child, dramatizes the contrast between ''America's Sweetheart'' and Bow, the arch-flapper of the 1920's, born in 1907.

title: Old Charleston Navy Base With New Controversies
description: SPRAWLING on a spit of land beside the Cooper River, the 1,600 acres of the now-closed Charleston Navy Base have come to represent both an enormously valuable development opportunity and a continuing focus of charges, countercharges and commercial and political maneuvering.

title: Leader Leaves, to Mixed Reviews
description: Jerome H. Blue, the embattled leader of Roosevelt Island, resigned last week to become the State Human Rights Commissioner. Reactions from residents ranged from good job to good riddance.

title: Ayre of the Bronx Speeds to Victory
description: Sanjay Ayre of the Bronx, who attended DeWitt Clinton but did not compete for the school this year as a senior, won the boys' 400 meters in a swift 46.25 seconds last night in the Foot Locker national scholastic championships at North Carolina State in Raleigh.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Out of the Mouths of Bubbas
description: ''My South,'' Tom Franklin writes in the introduction to POACHERS (Morrow, $22), his debut story collection, ''is lower Alabama, lush and green and full of death, the wooded counties between the Alabama and Tombigbee rivers.'' It's territory populated with good ol' boys down on their bad ol' luck. Franklin, a son of Alabama who has never felt at home there, brings together an engaging collection of sympathetic losers caught in tough situations and almost-interesting jobs. A series of bad bets turns a factory foreman into his bookie's indentured servant. An alcoholic who lives off his successful younger brother is asked to do little bro' a favor: kill his sister-in-law's cats while she's on vacation. A ground-water contamination inspector, instead of shutting down a leaky gas station, conspires with the owner to cover up the mess in exchange for the pump jockey's stuffed dead rhino. In this last story, ''Dinosaurs,'' Franklin takes a Southern cliche -- the chain-smoking, oily-overall-wearing cinder-block station owner -- and turns him into a memorable character with just a few lines of dialogue. The old man answers the young inspector's remark about doing good for the environment with an incredulous snap: ''The environment?'' he says. ''Take you a good long look out the window yonder at the environment.'' With all these bad husbands, ne'er-do-well buddies and frayed marriages, it's as if the author kidnapped Raymond Carver's characters and set them loose in the Deep South. Franklin isn't challenging Carver's mastery yet, but with this satisfying collection he establishes himself as one of the region's more interesting emerging voices. Bruce Barcott

title: June 6-12; A Food Scare in Europe
description: Belgian animal feed tainted with dioxin caused a food crisis that scared governments around the world into banning many poultry, meat and dairy products from all European countries because of fears they contained the poison.

title: Bush Iowa Trip Signals Real Start Of 2000 Race for the Presidency
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas ended his shadow Presidential campaign today and flew to this state to directly declare his interest in the White House. His announcement effectively inaugurated what is shaping up to be the earliest and quickest Presidential nomination processes in recent American history.

title: Marisol Deluna, Jonathan Cole
description: Marisol Patricia Deluna and Jonathan Washburn Cole were married yesterday by Judge Arlene H. Hahn of New York City Housing Court at the New York Junior League.

title: Survival Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising Air Fares And Slashing Them, Too
description: The major airlines raised leisure fares 4 percent on June 2. But less than a week later, the increase was effectively rescinded when the airlines trimmed those fares by as much as 25 percent for off-peak summer travel and capped fares for round-trip travel on peak days at $498.

title: TO DIAL FOR
description: Toffs: (888) 746-4725; www.toffs.com.

title: Existential Eloise
description: To the Editor:

title: June 6-12; Theaters Move To Enforce Ratings
description: An organization representing the owners of most of the nation's movie theaters announced that they will begin requiring young people who are not accompanied by adults to show photo identification cards proving they are at least 17 years old when they try to buy tickets to R-rated films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Valentine Has Now Become A Legend in His Own Mind
description: There he goes again.

title: Estate Sale Treasures: A Report From the Trail in Greenwich
description: IT was high drama in Greenwich last weekend. For three days, at the estate of a ''world-famous Hollywood producer'' (according to a newspaper advertisement for the sale), what seemed like a cast of thousands pored over the contents of an elegant Norman-style mansion, hunting for a piece of history -- or a piece of anything if the price was right.

title: New Haven Festival Unfolds with Drama
description: AN International Festival of Arts and Ideas begins a 16-day residence in New Haven Friday evening with two dramatic presentations, several exhibition openings and an 8 P.M. concert by the jazz singing group Manhattan Transfer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: British Forces Reaching Kosovo Capital Find Russians, and Confusion
description: If NATO forces landing at the rain-swept airfield in the Kosovo capital expected to encounter resistance, they found it came today not from the Serbs but, however symbolically, from the Russians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, GILES S.
description: RICH-Giles S. A quiet jurist and gentle man who by his tireless scholarship and faithful devotion to the patent law, turned our American century into an inventive, productive powerhouse, to the benefit of us all. John A. Reilly

title: Teaching Johnny the Appropriate Way to Flirt
description: What follows is a very small story, lightly censored but entirely true, that comes with a lot of very big stories attached. The setting for the very small story, which we will refer to as the Milk-Bag Incident for purposes of the arguments it is likely to set off, is a public middle-school cafeteria in Duluth, Minn. The time of year is mid-February. Because it is lunchtime, numerous schoolchildren are crowded together at the tables with their food and their milk, which in Duluth is doled out not in cartons but in single-serving plastic bags with straws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: A Rebel With Red Hair Rumples Stuffed Shirts
description: NOT many films have inspired both a hair color and a conservative politician's campaign poster. But the German director Tom Tykwer's ''Run Lola Run'' certainly did.

title: India and Pakistan Hold 'Frosty and Tense' Talks on Kashmir
description: The Foreign Ministers of India and Pakistan met today for the first time since fighting broke out along their border last month, but did not agree on ways to lessen tensions between the two nuclear powers.

title: 60's Free Jazz for the Sonic Youth Crowd
description: THE band sharing the bill with Sonic Youth at the Seaport Atrium in lower Manhattan tonight isn't a guitar-driven downtown rock band in the same mold. The other band -- the headliners, actually -- will be the New York Art Quartet, a reconvened avant-garde jazz chamber ensemble whose second of two albums was released only in Holland more than 30 years ago, and whose original members -- the trombonist Roswell Rudd, the alto saxophonist John Tchicai, the drummer Milford Graves and the bassist Lewis Worrell -- subsequently fell by the wayside.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Dance Group Premiere

title: Q & A/Dr. Craig Etcheson; Keeping a Record Of Atrocities of War
description: GENOCIDE is an ugly word that lately has been used in the news everyday. Crimes against the Kosovar Albanians are fresh in television viewers' minds, and Dr. Craig Etcheson, the program director of the International Monitor Institute based in New Haven, expects to see even more.

title: India vs. Pakistan Again, but in Cricket Match, on Screen
description: THE SETTING -- At 5:30 A.M. last Tuesday, the streets of Jackson Heights were empty but the Eagle Theater was packed. An overcapacity crowd, 450 people, crammed into the theater to watch the World Cup cricket match between Pakistan and India.

title: Summer Garden Tours In Rhode Island
description: Visitors to Rhode Island this summer will have a chance to tour a variety of gardens, big and small, during the first annual Gardens Open for Blithewold tour. The event, which benefits Blithewold -- a 1908 mansion, garden and arboretum in Bristol -- is scheduled for one day each month, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., in June, July and September. More than 30 private gardens in all (at least 10 a day) will be showcased.

title: Boundless Choices, and No Tipping
description: I KNOW a place with more dishes and lower prices than just about any Long Island restaurant. Tipping is unknown, many selections are ready to be served when patrons walk in, and most others can be ready within three minutes.

title: Parents Take Their Concerns to the Schoolhouse Door
description: On Wednesday morning, Quadriyyah Abdur-Razzaqq stood outside the front door of Public School 92, on West 134th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, with her three children beside her. Ms. Abdur-Razzaqq, the president of the school's parents association, unfurled a large white banner that had a drawing of an open coffin and the words: ''Here lies your child. He died because he could not read the Don't Walk sign.''

title: New Distrust Clouds Talks Between U.S. And Moscow
description: American diplomats and military representatives today held talks with Russian counterparts about how to make the best of the de facto presence of some 200 Russian soldiers in Kosovo.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Encounter; Playing With Firearms
description: 'This,'' Tom Clancy said as he pulled a jet black semiautomatic rifle from his bedroom closet, ''is my home defense weapon.''

title: Believing Yet?
description: Maybe a few New Yorkers have known all along that the Knicks were bound for glory this year. But to most fans who have followed the team through a season of turmoil and injury, each playoff victory has seemed more unlikely than the one before.

title: IN PERSON; Carrying On A Family Tradition
description: IN front of Harris Smith's 115-acre sheep farm is a hand-painted sign on a plank nailed to a fence post. In the cadence of the old Burma Shave ads, it serves as a reminder to neighbors driving along the narrow country lane:

title: Sarah Wilson, Brian Wiley
description: Sarah Livingston Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Leighton Wilson of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Dennis Wiley, a son of Miriam Wiley of Chazy, N.Y., and the late Claude H. Wiley. The Rev. J. Merlyn Bilhorn performed the ceremony at the Road Church, First Congregational in Stonington, Conn.

title: THEATER; A Painful Part, but He's Glad It's His
description: DURING rehearsals for the London production of ''The Iceman Cometh,'' before the current Broadway run was even a pipe dream, Clarke Peters joked with a fellow actor, Tim Pigott-Smith, ''I wouldn't want to play this role in New York.''

title: Ideas & Trends; Drug Switching Saves Money, but There Is a Cost
description: WITH a brother who died of a heart attack and two parents who had strokes, it came as no surprise to Joanne Best that, at age 60, she had developed heart disease. The surprise came at the drugstore counter, when Ms. Best, of Concord, Calif., tried to refill her prescription for Norvasc, the medication that kept her blood pressure under control.

title: NATO TROOPS ROLL INTO KOSOVO; CONFUSION OVER RUSSIAN MOVE
description: Thousands of NATO troops with armored vehicles moved methodically into Kosovo today, hours after about 200 Russian soldiers infuriated and startled Washington by entering the Kosovo capital and taking up positions at the military airport.

title: Police Divers Seek Boy Missing in East River
description: Police divers searched the East River for more than four hours last night for a 13-year-old boy whose friends saw him go underwater about 6 P.M. while they were swimming off a bulkhead at North Third Street in Brooklyn.

title: In 'Super Max,' Terms of Endurance
description: Holding 378 of the nation's most dangerous prisoners here, the ''Alcatraz of the Rockies'' is as quiet as a monastery.

title: SOAPBOX; The Elusive CUNY Diploma
description: THE graduation rate at the City University of New York is far too low, and the university has the opportunity to act to raise it. The low rate was among the major criticisms leveled against the university by the mayoral task force, which formally issued its report last week. According to the university's latest statistics, only 42 percent of the regularly admitted first-time baccalaureate candidates, who enroll full-time in their first term, earn their four-year degree in eight years. Double the time, and not even half the students.

title: A Bike Message
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THEATER; A Has-Been's Time To Be Once Again?
description: It has been 23 years since Albert Innaurato's comic family drama ''Gemini,'' about identity, sexual and otherwise, was first seen in New York, at Playwrights Horizons. Reaching Broadway by a circuitous route in 1977, it ran there for four years. On Wednesday, a revival of the play opens at the Second Stage Theater, with a cast that includes Julie Boyd, Linda Hart and Michael Kendrick. In this article, Mr. Innaurato, the author also of ''Gus and Al'' and ''Coming of Age in SoHo,'' among other plays, remembers how ''Gemini'' reached the stage.

title: Weight Loss the Herbal Way: No All-Natural Silver Bullet
description: DEB KUNEY was desperate. Through diet and exercise, she had once trimmed 90 pounds from her 260-pound frame. But Ms. Kuney, a Silverdale, Wash., resident, had gradually regained two-thirds of the weight. So she decided to take herbal weight-loss pills, which she bought at a natural-foods store. The pills contained several ingredients, including ma-huang, an ancient Chinese plant better known in this country as ephedra.

title: Dick Morris, Say Hello To Mr. Wilde
description: WHEN the eminent politician Sir Robert Chiltern worries, he bites his lip, and for most of ''An Ideal Husband,'' the Oscar Wilde play that comes to the screen this week , he has plenty to worry about. He is threatened with exposure for having sold a government secret to a stock exchange speculator.

title: A Playful Way of Teaching About Trees
description: ''GIVE back time'' is how Judith H. Blau, a children's book author and product designer, refers to the Treeture environmental education program that she created in 1984 to teach children the value of trees.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In the Cook Islands, Ukuleles and Hymns
description: THE flight from Auckland, New Zealand, to Rarotonga, Cook Islands, is a short hop, only three hours and one time zone. But it's a journey as discombobulating as any undertaken by Alice in Wonderland. I departed for the Cooks on a Tuesday afternoon in March and I arrived on Monday evening.

title: Still a Blond Bombshell, but of a Certain Age
description: WITH Anita Ekberg, talk usually revolves around the Fountain of Trevi, a monument forever associated with the scene in ''La Dolce Vita'' in which she dances in its waters so alluringly.

title: The World; Nurturing Democracy From the Grass Roots
description: WHEN he was a much younger man, Jose Concepcion once found himself holding up a bullet and peering at it through his thick glasses. ''They are shooting at us,'' he said, more incredulous than afraid. That was 13 years ago in the Philippines, when Mr. Concepcion and other partisans of democracy were learning how to face down a dictator, and how a dictator fights back.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEEDS, MORTON
description: LEEDS-Morton. '''Tis better to drink life in one flaming hour and reel across the sun than to sip pale years and cower before oblivion.'' June 13, 1984

title: Sprewell Has Changed A Critic's Perception
description: He was running laps around the periphery of the court, skipping with glee as he stuck out his hands to the masses. Latrell Sprewell, offering a personalized thank you to the people who had supported him through his trials, sharing in the moment of triumph.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 16 about women's economic power misattributed a statement about the distribution of black and white women in the work force in the 60's and 70's and the success of Asian women in the work force since 1980, relative to that of black and Hispanic women. The speaker was William Julius Wilson, the writer and Harvard professor, not Marta Tienda, the writer and Princeton professor. Both were among those interviewed for the article.

title: Habitats /Westhampton Dunes; Amid Endangered Birds, A Nest for Weekenders
description: A SIGN warns drivers to move slowly. This is the nesting area of the least tern and the piping plover, endangered birds. Kill one, and the fine is $50,000.

title: From the P.C.'s and Pens of Long Island; Unveiling the Underbelly Of Life in East Hampton
description: AMY FISHER notwithstanding, Long Island's biggest claim to fame may just be the Hamptons. And with the concentration of money and power to be found there, it's no surprise that novels set in the Hamptons have become something of a mini-genre.

title: An Arts Colony Turns Up the Esthetics for Its 100th
description: THERE is something about Provincetown that makes you want to buy a purple smock, rent a studio and give mad parties on battered wharves,'' wrote Eleanor Early in her 1936 travel guide, ''And This Is Cape Cod!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Two Women's Claims to Be New Age Guru's Widow Complicate a Complicated Case
description: Accounts of fraud, bogus spirituality and sexual exploitation had given the battle over the estate of Frederick P. Lenz 3d, a popular author and New Age guru who killed himself on Long Island in 1998, all the melodrama a television producer could want.

title: Where's Your ID, Kid?
description: So, it's Saturday night at the movies. The ticket seller is taking forever, especially when the buyer has acne or green hair. Somebody starts to mutter, and a few customers threaten to boycott the theater's profitable golden popcorn. How long, then, will theater managers maintain their pledge made to President Clinton that they will demand photo ID's for young people trying to go to R-rated movies? The answer is probably until the public starts worrying about something other than violent entertainment and Congress stops threatening to curb media violence with unworkable and unconstitutional laws.

title: Looking Back on the 'Embodiment of Ecstasy'
description: A FEW years ago I was watching a revival of Twyla Tharp's ''Deuce Coupe'' (1973) at City Center. This landmark work took on the Beach Boys' music with sass and thrust Ms. Tharp's rugged post-modern dancers onto the stage with Joffrey Ballet dancers. It married high art and rebel art by featuring, as the set design, a group of teen-agers spraying graffiti on a scroll upstage. As I watched this scaled down and paler version, I mentally debated the wisdom of reviving a piece that was vital at an earlier moment in time.

title: When Medical Science Called, Why the Heck Did I Answer?
description: Abrilliant, dewy morning this spring found me indoors, lying under fluorescent hospital lights, intravenous tubes protruding from each arm, IV bags hanging from poles at my side and a hard plastic hood surrounding my head.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: On Language; Lookit
description: The Kennedy Library occasionally releases tapes recorded secretly by J.F.K. of conversations with other political leaders. In his San Francisco Examiner column, the hardballing Chris Matthews reported a familiar but curious locution on one of those transcripts. It will be semantically examined here for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Girl Is Killed as Coney Island Ride Breaks
description: A 17-year-old girl was killed and eight other people were injured late Friday night when an amusement park ride in Coney Island malfunctioned, hurling the girl from her seat and pinning her between one of the ride's cars and the tracks below, the police said.

title: Alison Cherwin And David Rich
description: Alison Gwen Cherwin, the daughter of Sherry and Joel I. Cherwin of Newton, Mass., was married in New York last evening to David Jonathan Rich, the son of Phyllis and Norman S. Rich of Lewisburg, Pa. Rabbi Samuel Chiel performed the ceremony at W New York, a hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the Juilliard School misstated the name of the institution that shares dormitory space with the school in the Rose Building at Lincoln Center. It is the School of American Ballet, not the American School of Ballet.

title: A Life, and Home, Changed by Stencils
description: STENCILING has come a long way from ''the poor man's wallpaper.'' In Colonial days, homeowners would offer room and board to itinerant stencilers in exchange for decoration, according to Denise A. Castello of Woodstock. In the 18th century, wallpaper shipped from Britain was expensive, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLL, FLORENCE (NEE YONDORF)
description: KROLL-Florence (nee Yondorf). On June 10, 1999 at the age of 80. Beloved wife of the late Herman, loving mother of Daniel, Nancy Kroll Margolis, Susan Kroll-Smith, and Jules, adoring grandmother of Aimee, Kara, Seth, Nicholas, Vanessa, Dana and Jeremy, devoted mother-in-law of Paul, Terry and Lynn, cherished sister-in-law of Bea and Hy Michaels. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice Of Westchester or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. Services were held on Friday, June 11th, 1999.

title: Local Heroes
description: WHILE the eyes of nearly every basketball fan in the area were on the Knicks-Pacers playoff game at Madison Square Garden Monday night, it wasn't the only professional basketball contest taking place in New York City.

title: A Traveler's Most Arduous Journey, to the Land of No Diagnosis
description: At the age of 37, I had never been ill. As far as I could remember, I had never even had the flu. Famous for my iron constitution and robust good health, I had been working for many years as a travel writer, happily trotting off to the South Pole, spending months in India without a moment's sickness and, when I was pregnant, making medical history by getting constipated in Bangladesh.

title: Ms. Richardson And Mr. Bonner
description: Wendy von Maur Richardson, the daughter of Susan and David Flather Richardson of Quogue, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Joseph Bonner, a son of Ann and Edward J. Bonner of Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Charles M. Cary officiated at the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Westhampton, N.Y., with the Rev. Hilary C. O'Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Suffolk Makes Move To Kill Tax on Clothing
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has passed a resolution to eliminate a 4.25 percent sales tax on most clothing and footwear.

title: Life's Wrinkles, Some of Them Ugly, Afflict the Beautiful, Too
description: ASK anyone: it is better to be beautiful. To be a ''dish,'' a ''knockout,'' a ''babe.'' To be an object of desire. To be the kind of woman who can silence a chattering room with a toss of her hair.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Alysia Contas, Angus Macaulay
description: Alysia Nichols Contas and Angus Alexander Macaulay 2d were married yesterday in Louisburg Square in the Beacon Hill section of Boston. Judge Jane Roth of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Wilmington, Del., officiated.

title: Wrong Again on Rates?
description: ALTHOUGH the stock market has exhibited relative indifference to the upward march in Treasury bond yields, rising interest rates are not good news for equities. In the simplest terms, higher bond yields -- currently 6.16 percent for the 30-year Treasury -- make those instruments more attractive than stocks to many investors.

title: Taste Schmaste! This Is Just About Laughs
description: One day long ago, before fire or the wheel, ancient man slipped on the prehistoric equivalent of a banana peel and fell on his fanny. And another ancient man laughed.

title: Betting on a Cancer Cure
description: Specialization is the trend in mutual funds. Exhibit A: Kinetics Holdings, a money manager in North Babylon, N.Y., plans to offer a new fund, called the Medical Fund and the Cure for Cancer Inc., that will invest in companies involved in cancer treatment and research.

title: Latin America's Birth Surprise
description: Four months from now, the world's population is expected to hit six billion. Although it will continue to soar for decades to come, the population would be far higher if the last 30 years had not brought a significant drop in fertility in many regions. The drop is not surprising in rich countries and newly wealthy East Asian nations such as Taiwan and Singapore. More remarkable is the fertility drop in Latin America. A Times article last week detailed the change in Mexico, and similar gains have been made throughout the region. In the mid-1960's, Latin American women averaged more than 6 children. Today the average is 2.9. The benefits of smaller families are seen not only in a better life for children and their parents, but also in an increased savings rate and less cost to the state.

title: Revisiting Separate but Equal
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURBAGE, HAL
description: BURBAGE-Hal. 6/14/84. Hard to imagine you at 70, though I'm sure you'd have done it very well. Miss you still. Always will. Stu.

title: 2 Phone Companies Get $55 Billion Bid
description: In a brash move, Qwest Communications International, a telecommunications upstart, made a $55 billion bid to buy the regional phone giant U S West Inc. and the Frontier Corporation, a long-distance company. The hostile offer exceeds the bids the two companies accepted from Qwest's rival, Global Crossing Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERNE, PAULA WILKINSON
description: STERNE-Paula Wilkinson. December 20, 1917-June 14, 1974. 25 years in a better place. I miss you Mama.

title: Holdsclaw at Garden Tonight
description: This is probably not how Chamique Holdsclaw envisioned her professional debut at Madison Square Garden.

title: Olympians Seek Voice in Changing I.O.C.
description: Athletes, like most other people, agree that the International Olympic Committee needs changes, and they have finally formed an organization to make themselves heard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADISH, ARTHUR
description: KADISH-Arthur. On June 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Elise; loving father of Kenneth; grandfather of Jonathan; dear brother of Betty. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, June 14, at 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: At Long Last, Some Brilliance Displayed Inside the Beltway
description: Two plays will forever be etched in the memories of the players and the crowd of 40,119 in today's international match between the United States and Argentina at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. The first was a penalty-kick save by Kasey Keller of the United States and the other was Joe-Max Moore's goal that gave the Americans a 1-0 triumph.

title: As NATO Pours In, Fearful Serbs Pour Out
description: An enormous column of Serbian civilians followed their army and police out of western Kosovo today, moving slowly on the narrow roads past an enormous column of Italian troops and armor moving the other way, toward Pec and Prizren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, GILBERT
description: MERRILL-Gilbert. How do you thank a man for a thousand laughs? Mel Finkelstein

title: 'Austin' Sequel Is Behaving Very Well At Box Office
description: Maybe it's the dumb sex jokes. Maybe it's the bathroom humor. Maybe it's the awful teeth and equally awful cranberry-colored crushed-velvet suit proudly displayed by the goofy hero.

title: A Flag-Waving Celebration of Puerto Rican Pride
description: Staggering slightly in the crush of admirers, Tito Puente, the 76-year-old king of Latin swing, strode up Fifth Avenue yesterday at the head of the 42d annual Puerto Rican Day Parade.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
description: The implications of the malicious software program that wove its way around the globe last week struck home for Bernardo Huberman, a physicist at Xerox, in the form of a terse voice mail he received at work on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, HENRIETTA
description: TURNER-Henrietta. On June 12, 1999, of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Robert L. Turner. Loving mother of Barry and the late Harvey Turner. Mother-in-law of Jane and Cindy. Cherished sister of Elias Adler, and the late Rose Einhorn and Gustave Adler. Adoring grandmother of Jacalyn, Adam, Robin, and Ari. Graveside services were held Sunday.

title: A Prize Play, a Dispute and a Benefit
description: Some of the biggest names in theater -- including the playwrights Terrence McNally, Tony Kushner and Paula Vogel -- are to come together tonight at a sold-out benefit at the Public Theater to celebrate the first play by a 17- year-old student, Samantha Gellar.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The whole thing is aimed at the sensibility of a 12-year-old boy and that's who advertisers want to reach, even if that 12-year-old is 24.''

title: Masur's Mahler, But Not Bernstein's
description: One thing that can be said of Kurt Masur as an interpreter is that he stands behind his conceptions of major works, even when his reading is at odds with the prevailing ideas about it. And since he tends to repeat the central works of the canon regularly, listeners can find out whether he has had a change of heart.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about an ergonomic device called Dr. Mouse, by Animax International of Norway, described it incorrectly. Dr. Mouse is a renamed version of the Anir Vertical mouse, not a new product.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Friday about the selection of an agency by Brandwise referred incorrectly to the billings and products involved and to the company's Web site. The billings, estimated at of $10 million, include public relations along with advertising. The Web site is not operating; plans call for it to begin in late summer or early fall. Along with consumer electronics, Brandwise will sell home products like appliances and lawn-care equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, GILES S.
description: RICH-Giles S. A quiet jurist and gentle man who by his tireless scholarship and faithful devotion to the patent law, turned our American century into an inventive, productive powerhouse, to the benefit of us all. John A. Reilly

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, JUDY C.
description: ROSENTHAL-Judy C. It is written in stone ''beloved, devoted daughter. We miss her strength, wisdom, wit and compassion.'' Mom

title: Rostropovich Abets Chicago Symphony's Shostakovich Binge
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra ended its season with a bang on Saturday evening. Or rather, with a clang, as echoes of the bell stroke that finally halts the seething, uninterrupted 70-minute progress of Shostakovich's 11th Symphony, ''The Year 1905,'' hung in the now reverberant air of Orchestra Hall.

title: 3 Democratic Women Lead on Gun Control
description: Almost every day, the three lawmakers hold a news conference, resurrecting the same pleas and plaints and seeming never to tire of their mantras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the killing of a popular Mexican comedian, Paco Stanley, referred incorrectly to Jacobo Zabludovsky, a retired news anchor who was hired by the Televisa network to lead coverage of the killing. He had not worked with Mr. Stanley as a host of variety shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Russian Astronauts Plead With Public to Save the Mir
description: The Russian Government couldn't do it. A shadowy British entrepreneur couldn't do it.

description: As campaign finance legislation languishes, Congress has gone on an all-out fund-raising binge driven by the battle for control of the House, competition for money with the Presidential campaigns and an early push by incumbents to scare off challengers.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reporter's Notebook; Revisiting History With the Pope
description: Finding herself once again at the spot where she and more than a million other Poles gathered 20 years ago to greet Pope John Paul II, Anna Jamroz, 42, could not help comparing the two Masses.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Sadly, Golan Settlers Concede Peace Could Mean Eviction
description: After 20 years in this leafy, peaceful farming collective, Yigal Kipnis has grown quite attached to the view from his tree-shaded back porch -- terraced hills undulating down to the Sea of Galilee.

title: Elie Gives the Spurs Their Edge
description: In January, after the National Basketball Association lockout ended and teams were scrambling to fill their rosters, the San Antonio Spurs' coach and general manager, Gregg Popovich, looked at his club and saw a hole the size of one of his marvelous 7-footers.

title: Data 'Brokers' Battle Critics of Deceptive Practices
description: When he entered the private investigation business nearly 20 years ago, James J. Rapp opened a company to do surveillance and other things that he did not want to talk about, particularly because its name, Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap, aptly described its operations.

title: Man Kills His Wife And Then Himself
description: A 24-year-old woman with an order of protection against her estranged husband was shot and killed by him early yesterday in her upper Manhattan apartment, the police said. The man then turned the gun on himself, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: Russia and NATO continued to haggle over the place of Russian troops in the peacekeeping operation as Russian soldiers blocked entry of British troops into Pristina airport. Presidents Clinton and Yeltsin discussed the issue but agreed only to talk again.

title: Lowe Names 2 To Top Posts
description: Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has as expected named two executives to top posts.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDES, NORA S.
description: MENDES-Nora S. On June 11, after a long illness. She is survived by her sister Julia Leavitt of San Francisco, CA; her son Jonathan of Brooklyn, NY; her daughter Barbara Misraje of Los Angeles, CA; and three grandchildren Oma Kunstler of Los Angeles, CA, Kerby Caudill of Redondo Beach, CA, and Marc Mendes of Brooklyn, NY. title: Compressed Data; A Bit of Flamboyance For an Internet Conference
description: What has Dennis Rodman got to do with the Internet industry? Until this week, almost nothing. But on Thursday, the flamboyant professional basketball star will take the microphone at the Web Attack Internet marketing conference in San Francisco.

title: Media Talk; Hopes for a Best Seller About Aging Nuns
description: As a young schoolboy at the Sacred Heart Catholic School in Redlands, Calif., David A. Snowden learned his lessons from stern nuns with a penchant for giving ''me a piece of their mind.''

title: No Longer Battle of Equals As Camby Faces Duncan
description: The first time they met, it was billed as the next big matchup, on a level with the battles between Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Russell. Now, when Marcus Camby sees Tim Duncan across the floor on Wednesday in the National Basketball Association finals, he sets it up as a matchup more like David versus Goliath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Qaddafi Gets a Warm Reception From Mandela
description: Making his first trip outside Libya since sanctions were lifted in April, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi landed in Cape Town today to visit his old friend Nelson Mandela.

title: In the Age of the Flapper There Was One Who Had It
description: Clara Bow's stardom lasted for only about a decade, through the 1920's and into the 30's, but that added up to 58 movies and an astounding popularity that bears comparison with Jean Harlow and Marilyn Monroe. Her winning ways are brought back in ''Clara Bow: Discovering the 'It' Girl,'' tonight's Turner Classic Movies biography.

title: Artists Must Act to Save Brooklyn Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: When Movies Become 'Product'
description: Showing the public relations savvy we expect from media moguls, the heads of the Hollywood studios declined to testify last month when the Senate Commerce Committee held hearings on ''marketing violence to children.'' So when television reported the story, viewers saw movie clips of Keanu Reeves facing off against evil, rather than a tape of an anonymous executive squirming in the witness chair. Films remained works of art, protected by the First Amendment, rather than mere corporate products to be regulated at Washington's whim.

title: Minimum Use of Force, And Maximum Confusion
description: It was only a matter of minutes after Sgt. First Class Mladen Fulir and the rest of his platoon from the 82d Airborne Division clambered from Black Hawk helicopters when the confusion and complexity of NATO's initial days of occupation in Kosovo became clear.

title: Treasury and Other Debt Offerings Are Scheduled
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, ZACHARY (''ZACK'')
description: LAZARUS-Zachary (''Zack''). Age 36, of Virginia Beach, VA, on June 11, 1999. Born in Buffalo, NY, he was the Executive Director of the Bruce Smith Charity Golf Classic. Survived by his wife Maria Lazarus; his father Judge Robert J. Lazarus of New York City; motherin-law Carmela Rocco; brother-inlaw Paul Rocco; and extended family-Bruce Smith, Gene & Erin Bunn, David Terry, Tommy Hill, Walter Myrdal, Ellen Rostov, Troy Clifton, Bill & Mary Pepe, Phil & Sheila Popolla and a host of friends and acquaintenances who knew and loved him. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, June 15, at 11 AM, at Woodlawn Funeral Home, Norfolk, VA. Burial will be at Woodlawn Memorial Gardens. The family will receive friends in the funeral home on Monday, June 14, from 7 to 9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Bruce Smith Charity Classic, 1225 Newmarket Drive, Virginia Beach, VA 23464.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROBART, DORIS (FLAUM)
description: GROBART-Doris (Flaum). Age 84. Of Paterson, NJ, on June 12, 1999. Wife of the late Samuel. Survived by her son Bernard, daughter Phyllis Mechanic Rossell, brother Mitchel Flaum, grandchildren Matthew, Halley and Sam. Services are Tuesday, 12 noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Where Have Television's Big Stars Gone?; Niche Viewers And Increase In Channels Dim Luster
description: Television has more channels than ever before, more prime-time shows than ever before, and, of course, more commercials than ever before. And yet, to the consternation of many television industry executives, the one thing it seems to have fewer of is one of the most essential commodities of the business: stars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, DAVID L.
description: NEWMAN-David L. It's been five long years, and you are greatly missed. We remember your enthusiasm in salesmanship, sports, and especially in art. Your paintings reach out to us each day and we respond with love. Ruth, Helen, Bob, Jonathan

title: Mentally Ill Woman Fatally Stabs a Stranger, the Police Say
description: A woman with a history of schizophrenia walked up behind a 76-year-old stranger on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon and, without a word, stabbed him fatally in the back and walked away, the authorities said.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce; For Internet shoppers, speed counts. So companies are constantly looking for ways to cut the Web page wait.
description: IN high-tech business circles, people often talk about how things happen faster in ''Internet time'' -- deals are made faster, technology changes more rapidly and companies succeed or fail in a much shorter time frame.

title: Coney Island Visitors Are Sparse and Careful After Fatal Accident on a Ride
description: ''Everybody's a winner!'' a weary barker, his voice competing with amplified hip-hop, hollered to the occasional passer-by on Stillwell Avenue yesterday. Natasha Alonso, 10, held a bag of cotton candy as she stood behind a fluttering cordon of police tape and gazed at the broken remains of her favorite ride, the Super Himalaya, which malfunctioned on Friday night, killing a 17-year-old girl and injuring eight other people.

title: Patents; Vegetable oil lubricant is biodegradable and said to be more efficient than petroleum-based oils.
description: EFFORTS to make cars more environmentally sound have centered on designing cleaner-running engines, and eliminating the need for gasoline in favor of electricity. But presumably any car will still have an engine made up of some moving metal parts, and that requires lubricants. Cars, like trains, lawn mowers or chain saws, rely on petroleum-based motor oils. And that brings those concerned about the environment right back to the drawing board. Even an electric car may produce toxic waste from motor oil.

title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Yellow Sea Dispute With the South
description: North Korea agreed today to talk to United Nations military officers in an effort to resolve the confrontation between the South Korean and North Korean navies in the Yellow Sea.

title: Playing With Our Food, Risking Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Santo Domingo Journal; Steeped in the Merengue, Amway, and Now Trash
description: Sitting in the balcony of his unfinished mansion high on a hill that overlooks the Arroyo Hondo River here, Johnny Ventura was the picture of contentment recently as family members came and went around him.

title: Clinton-Yeltsin Phone Call Fails to Solve the Puzzle
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia failed today to end the standoff between NATO troops and a small group of Russian troops in Kosovo but agreed that NATO and Russian military commanders should meet quickly to try to resolve the issue, White House officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, MARTIN G.
description: TAUB-Martin G. Devoted husband of Frances Israel Taub, deceased. Loving father of Richard, David and Linda. Loving grandfather of Andrew, Marc and Sandy, Josh and Lisa, Neela, and Zach. Loving great-grandfather of Jake. Died June 12, 1999, after a valiant struggle. Wine merchant extraordinaire, he had been founder of Gallo Wine Distributors, Inc., co-founder of Premier Wine and Spirits, and Palm Bay Imports. No matter what the adversities, he never lost his warmth and amazing wit. Intensely committed to family, he passed on that love to his children and grandchildren, as well as passing on his affection for bad puns. He will be sorely missed. Funeral Monday, June 14, at 11 AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury.

title: What Does Student Testing Really Measure?; Give Children a Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Report Expected to Criticize Response by Police to Brutality
description: With a final flurry of activity, Federal prosecutors are concluding a 20-month investigation into whether the New York City Police Department's response to brutality by its officers is so feeble that it breeds a climate that fosters acts of excessive force.

title: Searching Fruitlessly For Flaws In Spurs
description: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy has always kept a bit of his long years as an assistant coach with him. Preparing for a playoff series, he has always been able to dissect long hours of tape, finding a slight flaw in an opponent.

title: Swiss Approve Asylum Limits And Reject Maternity Benefit
description: Fearful of too many refugees flooding into the country, Swiss voters overwhelmingly approved tighter rules today for asylum-seekers and trounced a Government proposal for paid maternity leave.

title: 2 Serbs Fire At Germans, Who Kill Both Men
description: Two Serbs in a small yellow car opened fire this evening on a group of just-arrived German peacekeepers. The peacekeepers fired back, killing both men in a tense and unsettled second day of NATO's arrival in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORMAN, ESTHER S.

Funeral services Monday, 12:30 PM, at Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks, 310 Second Street Pike, Southampton, PA. Shiva at the home of Scott and Lori Borman.

title: Nisource Bid Is Rejected
description: Columbia Energy Group said on Friday that its board had rejected Nisource Inc.'s $5.7 billion buyout offer as too low. Nisource offered $68 in cash on June 7 for each Columbia share. Columbia responded that it was not for sale, though it would present the offer to its board. Nisource said it was disappointed but not surprised by the decision. Columbia's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $61.875.

title: Computer Systems That Move Money Pass Test for 2000
description: The computer systems that move trillions of dollars worth of currency a day among financial concerns in different countries performed well in a test of preparedness for the Year 2000 conducted over the weekend.

title: Doner Wins One, Burnett Loses One
description: Two advertisers have made decisions involving their accounts.

title: Compressed Data; More of the Same For Disney On-Line Chief
description: After seven years at the Walt Disney Company developing new Internet businesses, Jake Winebaum has decided to call it quits to do something different. His goal? To develop new Internet businesses.

title: Washington's Mayor Faces a Campaign-Finance Inquiry
description: So far Anthony A. Williams, Mayor of the District of Columbia, has committed few of the ethical and managerial blunders that characterized the previous administration, but now campaign-finance charges are threatening his squeaky-clean image.

title: Coin Dealer Is Top Pianist
description: Joel Holoubek, 30, a coin dealer from Paris, won the first International Piano Competition for Outstanding Amateurs yesterday, playing pieces by Ravel and Dutilleux before a packed auditorium at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth.

title: Putting Ellis Island and Other Aspects of the Immigrant Experience Into Song
description: Clara Longstreth and her New Amsterdam Singers have devoted themselves with both energy and consistency to contemporary American choral music, not only by programming lots of it but also by commissioning new scores. Two of the six works on the program Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall were commissions, and together they suggested a theme for the concert, which was called ''Seeking America: Immigrant Voices.''

description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. title: U.S. Seeks More Defense Technology Cooperation With Europeans
description: PARIS  While lauding the performance of NATO allies in Kosovo, a top Pentagon policymaker warned that European air forces would be unable to continue operating alongside U.S. warplanes in future conflicts unless they developed and procured new military electronics.

title: Internet Service Is Now the Talk Of Cable TV
description: At first blush, the National Cable Television Association's annual convention, which began here today, seems just like the group's shows of years past. For instance, the roster of exhibitors is dominated, as usual, by programmers -- MTV Networks, Romance Classics, the Game Show Network.

title: Bush, the Elder, Passes Political Baton
description: With the craggy Maine coastline at his back, former President George Bush -- poised, animated and displaying not a bit of regret -- stepped aside today to advance the Presidential ambitions of his son, Gov. George W. Bush. It was a poignant, if staged, familial passing of the baton, suggesting that a victory by Governor Bush in 2000 might redress the lingering memory of President Bush's defeat by Bill Clinton seven years ago.

title: A 30-Minute Drive Ends In the Hugs of Neighbors
description: A refugee from this town of old mosques and cobblestone streets crossed the border from Albania and drove home today. Zeqe Cocaj, 25, was nothing more or less than a prosperous baker, but he was cheered like a returning hero by the crowds of Kosovo Albanians who lined the streets here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HANNAH

But, from the array of politicians and the crowd of more than 100 cheering supporters, it had all the trappings of an initial campaign rally.

title: Johnson Says He'll Play, but Can't Say When
description: Larry Johnson pulled into the parking lot and creakily eased his way out of his car soon after the sun rose today. It was 6:30 A.M., but Johnson, in pain from his sprained right knee, had already alerted the team's trainer, Mike Saunders, to be ready to start treatment early. And so Johnson, hooked up to an electronic stimulation machine, then to an ultrasound, then packed with ice, then trying on braces, whiled away his morning, finally peeking at a videotape of the collision with Indiana's Travis Best that had put his availability for the National Basketball Association finals in doubt.

title: Rangers' Final Offer For Palffy Sways Isles
description: The Islanders and the Rangers appear ready to do business for the first time since 1972.

title: Just a Couple, Unaware The World Is Watching
description: Lovers tend to share a secret, even arcane language that it can be truly unnerving to overhear. In one of literary history's most notorious instances of eavesdropping, Ernest Hemingway found himself an unseen audience to an argument between Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, who talked in ways he had ''never heard one person speak to another; never, anywhere, ever.'' Hemingway wrote in ''A Moveable Feast'' that he never felt the same about the women again.

title: In Kosovo Villages, Signs of Massacres And of a Cover-Up
description: After weeks of unconfirmed reports from traumatized refugees, the first direct evidence that Serbian forces carried out mass killings in Kosovo -- and have tried to cover them up -- emerged today at this village, where freshly turned dirt lies just feet from a wall pocked with 10 bullet holes.

title: Manager's Words To Win (or Lose) By
description: If the Mets should wind up in the playoffs this season, however they make it, perhaps the words will become known as the Valentine Proclamation. It wouldn't rival the Emancipation Proclamation, but a few hours after their manager uttered the words, the Mets freed themselves from an onerous losing streak.

title: Sweepstakes Losing Charm For Magazines

And for years, the magazine industry has flourished with the help of those grand, empty promises, depending on them in the first half of the 1990's to generate a third of its new subscriptions.

He even fought a guy named Ted Bulley. Ruff's suggestive surname, blond mustache and high hairline could fit well in a roster of professional wrestlers like Hulk Hogan or Jesse Ventura.

She attended Wellesley College and was married to the late Benjamin Yates McCabe for thirty years. She was a sustaining member of the Junior League of Long Island and had been an active member of Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington. She is survived by her son, Lewis McCabe; daughter, Ellen Melton; and two grandchildren, Abigail and Taylor Melton. Friends may call at Austin F. Knowles Funeral Home in Port Washington, NY, Tuesday, June 15, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A funeral service will be held in her honor at Saint Stephen's Church in Port Washington at 10 AM, on Wednesday, June 16, 1999, with a burial following in Cold Spring, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers are suggested for The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc.

title: Editorial Observer; Japan's New Strength May Embolden the Fed
description: The Japanese economic revival is real, and the chances are good that it is going to last. That is welcome news for the world economy, particularly for other Asian countries. But it also makes it virtually certain that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at the end of this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.

Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Op-Art
Not Medieval but Eternal; In Its Sixth Decade, 'Carmina Burana' Still Echoes
description: One of music's most resilient creatures is on the loose again, making tracks across the landscape of mainstream entertainment. It leaves traces on the vaguely medieval choruses of John Williams's score to ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace,'' and a heavier imprint on ''Hate Me Now,'' the creepingly catchy hip-hop hit by Nas. Its rhythmic echoes even resound behind a recent promotion for the ''South Park'' film.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Hillary Brooke on Tuesday misspelled the names of two California communities. Ms. Brooke died at a hospital in Fallbrook, not Fall Brook; and she had lived in Bonsall, not Bosnall.

title: Kosovo and the Kremlin
description: Russia may no longer be a superpower, but it still has the means to bedevil the United States and NATO. It took the unexpected movement of only 200 or so heavily armed Russian troops into Kosovo over the weekend to disrupt NATO peacekeeping operations and to remind everyone that Moscow can thoroughly complicate the postwar scene in Yugoslavia. There should be no place in Kosovo for freelance Russian forces, but Moscow can play an important peacekeeping role if it will work in cooperation with NATO. The White House and the Kremlin urgently need to devise a way to make that coordination possible. To that end, Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin talked by phone for an hour yesterday and plan to speak again today.

title: Singers Whose Art Transcends the Songs They Sing
description: Wasn't it Barry Manilow who crooned ''I am music, and I write the songs''? What a terrible thought. If music had meant well by us, surely he or she or it would not have chosen that particular mouthpiece. And even if Mr. Manilow didn't write that song, surely music would have wanted us to have better songs and better singers.

title: Discovering Simple Truth In 'Anastasia'
description: Julie Kent approached the title role in ''Anastasia'' with her usual intelligence and sensitivity in a performance by American Ballet Theater on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. One would normally also cite Ms. Kent's technical gifts in this portrayal of Anna Anderson, who imagined she was the surviving youngest daughter of the assassinated family of Czar Nicholas II. But Kenneth MacMillan's three-act ballet, set to music by Tchaikovsky and Martinu, makes comparatively few demands in that area. The exceptions are an isolated pas de deux, quartet and trio in which every challenge is telegraphed by the awkwardness of the choreography.

Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. description: For Connected Computing, A Metaphorical Epidemic

title: The Knicks' Magical Run
description: The New York Knicks, a team that nobody thought would outlive the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, are now in the championship round, and their opponents, the heavily favored San Antonio Spurs, have got to be wondering, who are these guys? That is exactly what the Knicks' dazed and dazzled fans are asking themselves, and the only sure answer is that they bear no resemblance to the team they were two months ago, when their record was 21-21. Necessity, in the form of critical injuries, has forced them to use different combinations and play a more up-tempo style. They have become quicker, more creative, less selfish with the ball, and in so doing have defeated three playoff teams that were supposed to beat them, including the formidable Indiana Pacers on Friday night.

title: NATO Expands Its Force in Kosovo but Russians Still Block Airport
description: Russian soldiers occupying the Pristina airport blocked the entry of British troops today in an embarrassing impasse for NATO's nascent peacekeeping effort in Kosovo.

title: Marriages Made in Heaven, and Others
description: If the institution of marriage is to thrive into the coming century, it will need a more articulate defender and a more careful chronicler than Garry Marshall. He is proud that he and Barbara have been married for 36 years. May they have 36 more. But just because you've been socializing for decades, that doesn't make you a sociologist.

title: U.S. Cites Drop in Arrests for Drunken Driving
description: A Federal report says arrests for drunken driving have declined about 18 percent since 1986, suggesting a lessening of the problem, but a campaigner against drunken driving said people would continue to die on the roads unless more preventive measures were taken.
