description: LYPINSKI-Helen. Age 78, of Fort Lee. Formerly of Jersey City. Retired practical nurse for the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union Health Center in NYC. Daughter of the late Katherine and John Lypinski. Sister of Mary Bradbury, Clara Rivera, Frances Kujawski, Anna Jane Lypinski, and Stephan P. Lypinski, Esquire. Reposing Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Patti & Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main St, Fort Lee (201944-0100). Funeral Mass, Tuesday, 10 AM, Holy Trinity R.C. Church, Fort Lee. Memorials if desired to the Fort Lee Ambulance Corps.

title: Media Talk; Commercial Puts Reporter in Tight Spot
description: It's not real news, but it looks and tastes just like real news!

title: New Breed of Au Pair Packs a Shaving Kit
description: When the Rev. Claire Woodley-Aitchison and her husband, Michael, began looking for child care after arriving in Westchester County a few years ago, they thought about getting an au pair from overseas. They assumed it would be a young woman. ''We certainly wanted girls,'' Mr. Aitchison said. ''We tried all the tricks. It wasn't going to happen.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTROFF, SIDNEY
description: ESTROFF-Sidney. On June 11, 1999. He is survived by his wife Sylvia; children Karen and Michael Stutland; Paul and Michael Estroff; Amy, Marc and Harriet Herman; grandsons Bradley Stutland, Brian and Michael Herman; and sister Hilda. His humor and sharp wit will be missed.

title: Group Says New Drugstores Are a Menace to Main Street; As National Chains Move Into Downtown, Preservationists Fear for Historic Buildings
description: The men (and woman) at the Oswego Elks Lodge are pretty tight-lipped these days.

title: Media Talk; Esquire Editor Helps Uncover Carver Stories
description: The stories sat there for more than a decade, unseen and unread, in a writing desk that Raymond Carver's widow, the poet Tess Gallagher, just could not bear to open. But now they are out, at last: three previously undiscovered stories by Mr. Carver, the noted author of short stories.

title: Hints of Diversity Amid the Power Chords and Mayhem
description: Basic black and power chords are constants in heavy metal, and there was plenty of each at Ozzfest, the 16-band, 11-hour concert that appeared twice at PNC Bank Arts Center here. At Ozzy Osbourne's fourth annual summer roadshow -- featuring his reunited original band, Black Sabbath -- songs about death, the Devil, anger and rebelliousness were all good-time music for fans who came to jump and howl along. Bands performed on the center's main stage and on a smaller one in a field, where the size of the dust cloud measured the enthusiasm in the mosh pit.

title: Australia Is Chosen as Site for Spaceport : U.S. Firm Targets Reusable Rockets
description: SYDNEY  Kistler Aerospace Corp. of the United States has chosen to make Australia a key part of its program in the race to develop reusable rockets for launching communication satellites at a substantially lower cost than using today's expendable rockets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBMAN, SHIRLEY
description: LEIBMAN-Shirley. Never say goodbye, dear friend. Florence

title: I.B.M. Negotiator's Testimony Hits Microsoft Hard
description: The testimony last week of Garry Norris of I.B.M. supplied some of the most absorbing moments so far in the Microsoft trial. His litany of accusations was lengthy and specific -- threats and enticements to not compete against the Microsoft Corporation delivered at meeting after meeting. His charges were fleshed out with the dates, places and names, and backed up by his handwritten notes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the industrial designer Michael Lax on June 5 misstated the date of his death. It was May 25, not May 28.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ITS formal title is the 99th United States Open Championship, but it's really the Turtleback Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Artists Must Act to Save Brooklyn Waterfront; Small but Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: Developing a Repetition-Free Language for Web Transactions
description: Aiming to make shopping on the Web easier, a consortium of credit card companies, Internet merchants and developers of on-line payment technologies plans to announce today that its members have agreed to develop a standard for executing electronic commerce transactions.

title: Conservatives In Europe Gain Ground In Parliament
description: Europe's center-left governments suffered a sharp setback today as conservative parties gained votes and won enough seats to become the largest group in elections to the European Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: What Role for Russia?
description: Winston Churchill liked to tell the story of the man who tried to give the powder to the bear, and all the elaborate preparations he made to do so -- ''but the bear blew first.'' Decayed and decrepit though it is, the Russian bear blew faster than NATO when it came to sending peacekeepers into Kosovo. It taught us a lesson about speed and surprise -- and if it is true that NATO's advance into Kosovo was delayed to prepare for photo opportunities, then it was a lesson we badly needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: A Trip to Bermuda Awaits Winners in Memphis Trials
description: The knockout phase of the International Team Trials began yesterday in Memphis, with eight teams fighting for a chance to represent the United States in the world championships in Bermuda in January. A team headed by Nick Nickell has already qualified for one of the two American slots.

title: Why All the Fuss About Lou Dobbs?
description: The audience for CNN's nightly business program ''Moneyline News Hour'' -- 300,000 to 400,000 homes a night -- is so small that it would not be close to qualifying as one of the 100-most-watched shows on cable television.

title: Charges of Fraud and Revenge Mark Candidate's 3d Trial
description: John Kennedy O'Hara, a perennial candidate for elective office, describes himself as the target of a politically motivated witch hunt intended to destroy his political aspirations. After years of practicing law, he said, he has been disbarred and his finances have been devastated.

title: Playing With Our Food, Risking Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Generals Could Still Play Key Political Role : Indonesia's Military Is Down, but Not Out
description: JAKARTA  The Indonesian armed forces, for many years a bastion of political support for the authoritarian government of former President Suharto, declared that they were neutral in parliamentary elections held last week, helping to make the polls a genuine contest for the first time since 1955.

title: The Big City; With Guns, A Safer World For Women?
description: WITH Congress primed to pass gun-control legislation, New Yorkers may be tempted to feel smug. The rest of the country is finally starting to share the prevailing distaste in the city for guns. Urbanites seem to be triumphing over the plaid-shirted guys driving the back roads in pickup trucks with N.R.A. decals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. On May 27, 1999, at age 93. Beloved husband of Dawn Greene. Loving father of Patricia Humphrey and the late Cynthia Sue Greene & stepfather of Christina McInerney. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Joel Humphrey. Interment is private. Memorial service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, on Tuesday, June 15th, at 4PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Montefiore Children's Hospital.

title: Amid a June Tempest, Yankees Seek a Harbor
description: Andy Pettitte's coat-hanger shoulders slumped forward while he tried explaining another loss and why he surrendered many hits and runs to the Florida Marlins. Between his sullen answers, he would stare like a 10-year-old peering outside on a rainy day.

title: Independent Kosovo: Now Is Not the Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls Turn the Draft Into Battle of Attrition
description: When Wally Szczerbiak heard what was in store for him at the Chicago Bulls workout camp for potential college draft choices, he raised the dark eyebrows that accentuate his Montgomery Clift looks.

title: French Company Cashes In on Big Growth in U.S. Market : Private Jets:Join the Queue
description: PARIS  Private jets are the ultimate personal status symbol, according to the American novelist of manners, Tom Wolfe. In his current book, "A Man in Full," the developer Charlie Croker loves his Gulfsteam V, where his favorite seat in the forward cabin is soundproofed against the roar of the two BMW/Rolls-Royce engines that give the plane a global capability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: At the Venice Biennale, Art Is Turning Into an Interactive Sport
description: By the time the 48th Venice Biennale opens to the public here on Sunday, more than 30,000 museum directors, curators, dealers, collectors and art critics will have spent three days pounding the rough pavement of this dazzling city. They could be spotted milling around the cloistered gardens at the tip of Venice that have been home to the Biennale for most of its 104-year-old life, or perusing the breathtaking art spaces in the nearby Arsenale, the network of shipyards and warehouses where the Venetian fleets were once built. They looked, they listened and they debated the direction of contemporary art and the rising stars of the art world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Ilya Musin, Russian Conductor and Mentor, Dies at 95
description: Ilya Musin, the Russian conductor who taught a generation of maestros while remaining relatively unknown outside his own country, died on June 6 in St. Petersburg, Russia. He was 95.

title: In Japan, a 'Social Bargain' Women Never Made
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: John Lloyd, 51, an Archeologist
description: John Lloyd, a British archeologist who unearthed relics yielding new information about day-to-day living in classical times, died on May 30 in Oxford, England. He was 51 and had worked with Oxford University's Institute of Archeology for a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about violence in Nigeria misspelled the name of a village that symbolizes the demand by minority groups for more political power. It is Ungwar-Baki, not Ungwar-Bako.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UVEGI, SERENA
description: UVEGI-Serena. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club and Couples' Club mourn the passing of the beloved mother of our devoted member, Harry Uvegi. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Essay; The Wrong Way
description: Many of my readers are, in S. J. Perelman's phrase, ''afflicted with total recall.''

title: Trooper Kills Gunman Who Fired at Officers
description: A state trooper killed a man early Saturday who had fired 30 shots toward police officers and aimed a gun at the local police chief, the authorities said.

title: Here Comes the Sun!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: District of Columbia Debt Is Upgraded
description: The bond rating for the District of Columbia was upgraded from junk to investment-grade status by Moody's Investors Service today, the District's first investment-grade rating from the company in four years.

title: Suburban Sprawl Isn't Friendly to Bike Riding; No-Hassle Helmets
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, a Ring for Robinson or Ewing
description: David Robinson's life will be easier without Patrick Ewing to guard him in the middle this week. He can roam the key freely, have an inch or two more of room to shoot his left-handed rainbow jumper and not have to worry about defending against Ewing's fakes and fallaways on the other end of the court.

title: Goodyear Suspends Building of a Plant
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it was suspending construction of a $180 million Brazilian plant because of declining car sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UVEGI, SERENA
description: UVEGI-Serena. Beloved mother of Harry (Clarissa) Uvegi, Tommy Uvegi and Shiffy Shneller (Udi), sister of Maximillian Spell, passed away June 12. She is loved and will be greatly missed, especially by all of her grandchildren.

title: A Common Link in Failed Pregnancies
description: Refining the understanding of a crucial step in early pregnancy, researchers have pinpointed the time frame in which a fertilized egg needs to implant itself into the uterus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROBART, DORIS LEAH
description: GROBART-Doris Leah. The Officers, Board of Trustees, Congregation and Clergy of The Jewish Center of The Hamptons, mourn the passing of Doris Leah Grobart, beloved mother of Bernard Grobart, a devoted member of our Board of Trustees. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Joseph Oppenheimer, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKST, SONYA N. (SCHUCHALTER)
description: BAKST-Sonya N. (Schuchalter). On June 8, 1999. Loving wife of Meir. Devoted mother of Shani and Ari. Mother-in-law of Joseph and Sarita. Grandmother of Daniella and Zachary, sister of Ralph and Stuart.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Smart' Guns Prove Elusive

title: Idealistic As Ever, Without the Shock Value
description: Over time old avant-gardes become less fearsome than they were on arrival. Yet an avant-garde that doesn't depend on shock value need not become obsolete. Instead, it turns into both a messenger from the era that shaped its attempts to break free and a guardian of its favorite extremes.

title: NEXTLINK BUYS STAKE IN HIGH-SPEED INTERNET SERVICE
description: Nextlink Communications Inc., a local and long-distance telephone company based in Bellevue, Wash., said yesterday that it had agreed to take a 10 percent stake in Speedus.com Inc., which provides high-speed Internet access to businesses in New York. In addition to buying the $20 million stake -- two million shares for $10 each -- Nextlink agreed to buy space on Speedus.com's wireless network for another $20 million at the rate of $172,000 a month. Shares of Speedus.com, which is based in Brooklyn, rose 87.5 cents, to $6.1875. Nextlink, which was founded by the cellular telephone pioneer Craig McCaw, fell $4.9375, to $71.

title: Bid to Alter Lead Paint Law Splits Speaker and Council
description: The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, and some members of the Council's rank and file are at increasing odds over a bill that would clarify and strengthen the city's law to protect children from poisoning caused by lead paint.

title: A Splashy Drummer Renews Old Ties
description: Ever since the drummer Ronald Shannon Jackson disappeared from the New York scene, relocating to his hometown of Fort Worth, there's been an empty space waiting to be filled. Mr. Jackson fused jazz and rock about as well as anybody in the 70's and 80's, dodging the cliches and developing a tough, extreme performance style. He hired promising young sidemen like the guitarist Vernon Reid and the bassist Melvin Gibbs, and his enthusiastic, splashy drumming spoke for itself. He was an original blender of heavy music; two decades after his prescient example, metal has essentially turned into hard funk with roaring guitars.

title: Accompanied by Parent (or Ingenuity); Theaters Vow to Enforce Ratings; Teen-Agers Vow to Get In
description: It was Saturday night, movie night, in the suburbs. And the topic, aside from Austin Powers or ''The Phantom Menace,'' was the much ballyhooed crackdown on keeping viewers under 17 out of R-rated films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ST. LOUIS, MARIE
description: ST. LOUIS-Marie. Of New York, passed away June 10, 1999 after a brave struggle with cancer. She is survived by her son Marc St.Louis, her daughter-in-law Patrice Rushen and grandson Cameron, and her brother Jack Barrow. Born in Boston on April 5, 1928, attended Girls' High School and Simmons College. She worked for 37 years for Festival Productions, Inc., the company who created the Newport Jazz Festival among other major international jazz festivals. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 16 at 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., N.Y., N.Y. Burial is private in Great Barrington, MA. Donations in the name of Marie St. Louis may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Promotion Begins For Title Bout
description: Not since Neil Simon had ''The Odd Couple'' on Broadway has an Oscar and Felix combination caused as much of a stir in New York City as Oscar De La Hoya and Felix Trinidad did yesterday at the South Street Seaport.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; When Children and Guns Live Together
description: Gun owners who are parents tend to be more careful about storing their weapons than gun owners without children -- but both groups are more careless than they should be, according to a recently published study.

title: Kenneth S. Davis, 86, Biographer Of Franklin Delano Roosevelt
description: Kenneth Sidney Davis, the author of a four-volume biography of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, died on Thursday at University Hospital in Madison, Wis. He was 86.

title: Q & A
description: Wisdom Teeth

title: So Much In the Phrasing
description: Inevitably described as a night of ''divas in jazz,'' the Bell Atlantic Jazz Festival show at the South Street Seaport Atrium on Friday night proved the inadequacy of that stereotype. Although it did feature five splashy voices and willful approaches to the jazz songbook, each singer showed as much skill and sense as emotion in her virtuoso turn.

title: No Research On Cloning Of Embryos, Geron Says
description: The Geron Corporation, which has sponsored the leading research on primordial human cells, said yesterday that it was conducting research on discarded human embryos in the hope of learning how to convert the ordinary cells of a patient into stem cells that can be used for self-repair.

title: Mandela, With Touch of Grace, Paves Way for Successor
description: Looking solemn in a gray suit and silk tie, President Nelson Mandela watched South Africa's second post-apartheid Parliament get on with the business of democracy today and choose the man who will replace him as the country's leader, Thabo Mbeki.

title: HOECHST SHARE DISCOUNT
description: The German drug maker Hoechst A.G. said it would favor small investors later this month when it sells part of its 45 percent stake in Clariant A.G., a chemical company. Hoechst, said it would offer small shareholders a 2 percent discount over institutional investors in the sale, scheduled from June 21 through July 2. Hoechst is trying to build interest in its share sale amid a glut of offerings on German markets. Hoechst's current holding in Clariant is worth about $2.9 billion.

title: Sports of The Times; A Bizarre Springtime Keeps Going
description: AFTER staring at my screen saver for the past hour, I still cannot come up with an argument why the Knicks absolutely cannot beat the San Antonio Spurs in the finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. It's been 6 years and not a day goes by where I don't think of you Grandma. Love, Michael

title: Craft to Track Climate-Affecting Link of Sea and Wind
description: The continuous interplay between wind and ocean, whether as gentle as a kiss or as harsh as a slap, eventually affects almost everything else on earth through its influence on weather and climate. Yet, except for occasional sampling, this crucial interface between sea and sky goes mostly unmonitored.

title: Gala Shows Why Pushkin Inspired Composers
description: A music review about a writer would be odd were the writer not Aleksandr Pushkin, who was born 200 years ago this month. Pushkin himself had little interest in music, but the generations of Russian composers who came after him were fascinated by the operatic vividness of his characters and the lilt of the language used to depict them.

title: The Departing Chief of Police Says Officers Deserve a Raise
description: New York City's departing police chief, Louis R. Anemone, whose browbeating style was credited for both bringing down crime and elevating the blood pressure of many officers, said yesterday that the force he had ridden so hard deserved raises.

title: A Rampaging Man Is Beaten With a Bat
description: A mentally ill man who was yelling anti-Hispanic epithets, smashing car windows and attacking people at a Washington Heights bodega was beaten repeatedly with a baseball bat on Sunday by a man he attacked, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA. SYLVIA BERNSTEIN
description: BERNSTEIN-Sylvia. Sylvia Bernstein, loving and devoted mother of Allen J. Bernstein and Helene Morrison, and adoring grandmother of Stacey Stolar, died on June 13th after a long illness. She was a woman whose nurturing love, encouragement, strength and compassion shaped and enriched the lives of her children and her granddaughter. She took enormous pride in their many achievements, and always gave them her love, wisdom and unflagging support. Her endearing personality, warmth, wit and sincerity were cherished by her extended family and her many friends. The great void in her life was the loss of the love of her life, her dear husband Morty, who was taken from her and his loving family in 1974. She was known for her gracious hospitality, her infectious optimism and the diversity of her activitieswhich ran the gamut from golf to mah jongg. She was a woman of uncommon kindness, great dignity and unqualified love. And she will be missed.

title: Preventing Falls
description: To the Editor:

title: Holdsclaw's Homecoming Is Magical Night for Mystics
description: The last time Chamique Holdsclaw played at Madison Square Garden, she shot 2 for 9 and had 9 rebounds. That was last January when she was a college senior playing for the Tennessee Vols, who went on to defeat Rutgers.

title: At Qwest, A Chance To Become Really Big
description: A bit less than two years ago, just before Qwest Communications International Inc. first offered stock to the public, Joseph P. Nacchio, who had just left a top job at the AT&T Corporation, was asked what he meant to create in Qwest.

title: Tireless, Outspoken and Atypical, Mental Health Chief Rocks the Boat
description: If, as social scientists sometimes insist, the best predictor of future behavior is past behavior, then Dr. Steven Hyman was an unlikely candidate when the National Institute of Mental Health was searching for a director three years ago.

title: Opportunity Knocks, Milbrett Answers
description: Elsie Milbrett-Parham grew up on a farm, so she knew a drought when she saw one. And, in the early 1960's, there were few things more parched than opportunities for women in sports. Forget college scholarships. Her high school in western Oregon did not even offer varsity sports for girls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * About 14,000 NATO peacekeepers spread out over an anchor-shaped area of Kosovo, stretching from Pec in the west to Gnjilane in the east, with the capital, Pristina, at the head. Among them were about 1,000 marines from the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit who took up positions near the village of Klokot.

title: Energy East Set to Acquire CMP Group
description: The Energy East Corporation, the parent company of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, will acquire the CMP Group, the parent company of Central Maine Power, in a transaction valued at $957 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: After Rulings, Agency Alters Plan to Limit Air Pollution
description: Stymied by two court rulings setting aside clean air standards, the Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had a new way to force power plants in 12 states to cut pollutants that contribute to smog in the Northeast.

title: TV Arrangements Stall the Palffy Trade
description: What seemed like a done deal 48 hours ago is no longer guaranteed. The proposed blockbuster trade that would send the Islander scoring threat Zigmund Palffy to the Rangers has hit a snag.

title: Nortel Says Its President Will Resign
description: David L. House, president of the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada, the communications equipment giant, will resign as soon as this summer, Nortel said yesterday.

title: Suburban Sprawl Isn't Friendly to Bike Riding; What's Truly Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Consider Case on Public Aid to Religious Schools
description: Adding an important religion case to the docket for its next term, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution permits public schools to provide computers and other ''instructional equipment'' for use in religious school classrooms.

title: An Astaire Grace Note Tempers the Avowedly Mindless Fun
description: The New York City Ballet let down its hair on Saturday night at the New York State Theater in a program dedicated to music by American composers. There was no dark American searching for identity or new frontiers in any of the four ballets or scores, just for the most part enjoyably brainless fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, JACQUELINE
description: DONALDSON-Jacqueline. A graduate of Smith College and Columbia University. Lived a life surrounded by all things beautiful. Her love of art, literature, music, and animals helped her live well in spite of her long illness with cancer. Jacqueline was a loving, independent and intellectual person who I will miss greatly. She taught me the greatest lesson-to be happy with yourself. Rest peacefully my dear make-believe grandmother. Anne Valle

title: Mets Fall With Bonilla In, Olerud and Piazza Out
description: Getting runners on base has not been a problem for the Mets this season. Driving them home has. Tonight, with Mike Piazza and John Olerud given a rare day off together and Bobby Bonilla given a chance to play, the Mets left the bases loaded twice.

title: Poor Grades for Thigh-Reducing Creams
description: The act of slathering on expensive thigh-reducing creams, may provide an upper body workout, but users should not expect to see weight loss in their thighs, a new study reports.

title: Helping Students, And Teachers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Holocaust, if There Can Indeed Be an After
description: The profound, agonizing mystery of the Holocaust echoes through the generations and across international borders in the thoughtful and provocative new play at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Suit Against Oxford
description: In an action that legal experts said made an out-of-court settlement more likely in a shareholder class action lawsuit against Oxford Health Plans, a Federal district judge in White Plains has rejected an Oxford motion seeking to have the suit dismissed.

title: Hemingway Furniture: A Veneer of Taste
description: LAST week, Jack Hemingway -- yes, son of -- was here promoting the new Ernest Hemingway collection of furniture by Thomasville. As far as he's concerned, the guardians of civilization can just go wring their hands. Everybody else? Consider the hunky ''Kilimanjaro'' bedside chest with silver-finished hardware and paw feet, or a ''Catherine'' slipcover love seat.

title: A Jail Waiting to Explode?; In Suffolk, Warnings From Guards and Guarded
description: There are two ways to tell when dawn is coming if you are an inmate at the Suffolk County jail. First there are the lights -- they are turned up so the guards can serve breakfast. The other clue is the rattle of steel plates.

title: Roosevelt Mall Evacuated
description: The sprawling Roosevelt Field Mall was evacuated tonight when a fire broke out in a small basement storage room beneath the Sam Goody music store.

title: Fashion Loses a True Esthetic Eye
description: The death of David Seidner last week in Miami Beach brought an end to a talent that was far too individual, far too stubborn and classically obsessed to be conventionally successful, though he was. Rarely has a modern-minded photographer, whose work appeared regularly in the pages of fashion magazines and who poured out a steady stream of books and advertising images for clients like Revlon and Yves Saint Laurent, soared so freely while having one foot planted in the clay of the Greeks.

title: Satellite Tracking System Planned for Buses, but Subway Renovations Drag On
description: In a step toward the age of global communications, New York City Transit said yesterday that it would begin using satellites to track buses on six routes in Manhattan this fall. The experiment would be the first stage of a system allowing riders to check arrival times and recommended routes at bus stops.

title: Catholic Bishops Call for Overhaul of Stringent Drug Laws
description: The state's Roman Catholic bishops called on the Governor and the State Legislature today to overhaul New York's stiff drug laws, saying they have filled the state's prisons with addicts who would be better served in drug treatment programs.

title: An Achilles Heel, in the Knee
description: Last Thursday, 43 seconds into the New York Liberty's opening game, Rebecca Lobo jumped for a rebound, pivoted and fell to the floor clutching her knee and screaming in pain. An off-balance landing resulted in a torn anterior cruciate ligament, an injury that will require surgery and months of rehabilitation. For the Women's National Basketball Association star it means sitting out the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. The Board, staff and the entire Lincoln Center family deeply mourn the death of our cherished friend and supporter, Jerome Greene. Jerry was a longtime member of Lincoln Center's Board of Directors and Emeriti Council, and provided guidance and vision for all our activities for many years. He cared about Lincoln Center and its programs deeply, especially the Mostly Mozart Festival. His leadership and extraordinary generosity have ensured Mostly Mozart continuity for more than a decade and through his generosity he has left a legacy for hundreds of thousands of music lovers who have enjoyed and continue to enjoy this music series. We will miss his wisdom, warmth, integrity and his loyal friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to Dawn and their entire family. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: News Analysis; Abortion-Rights Groups Surprised by Whitman
description: Three and a half weeks after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders agreed to a law requiring teen-age girls to notify their parents before getting an abortion, the National Organization for Women and several abortion rights groups gathered outside the New Jersey State House today to stage their first public demonstration against the measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, ZACHARY
description: LAZARUS-Zachary. A tragedy beyond belief. Our thoughts and our love are with you now. Irving and Stella Newman

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PIKARSKY, MILTON
description: PIKARSKY-Milton. 3/28/24-6/15/89. Beloved brother, a very special man, ever loved, missed, remembered. Ruth

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHASE, ROBERT L.
description: CHASE-Robert L. 3/16/42-6/15/89. 10 years gone. 10 years remembered. Such a good heart. Such a great guy.

title: Changing Plans, Pope Decides to Visit Patriarch of Armenia
description: Racing to mend the centuries-old breach between Orthodox and Roman Catholic believers, Pope John Paul II has turned Vatican planning upside down and decided to go ahead with a previously canceled meeting with the head of the Armenian Apostolic Church in Yerevan after leaving Poland.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about possible hidden stocks of the smallpox virus misstated the party affiliation of Senator John Glenn of Ohio, who headed a committee that made public a Russian report on the virus. He is a Democrat.

title: The Next Starr Report
description: Kenneth Starr has apparently decided to tie up the many loose ends of his mammoth investigation with a final, detailed report on a range of questionable activities involving Bill and Hillary Clinton that disappeared from public view the moment Monica Lewinsky came along. According to the law and by precedents set by earlier independent counsels, the public deserves a final accounting, and Mr. Starr has the right to give his view on matters that did not rise to criminal indictments. But what he does not have a right to do is disrupt New York's Senate campaign, which is likely to include Mrs. Clinton. He should not time his report to the electoral calendar or slant it to present her in the worst light.

title: Graduating Into Prosperity
description: As college graduation season draws to a close, it is evident that the gap between the experiences and expectations of the graduating class and their commencement speakers has never been greater. The speakers for the most part grew up in a world of economic highs and lows. They, or their parents, lived through the Great Depression, or at least a series of recessions, and learned to write on a typewriter. Today's graduates have not seen a recession since they were in junior high school and may never have touched a typewriter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Practicality Is Biggest Foe Of ID Plan For R Movies
description: How are theaters going to enforce the plan announced last week at the White House to require teen-age moviegoers to show photo identification at R-rated films?

title: At Cablevision, a Game Is Always On
description: During the Knicks' celebration Friday night after winning the Eastern Conference finals, a beaming man named Marc Lustgarten bear-hugged ecstatic players. Lustgarten was not a mere suit leaping from a prime courtside seat, but the chairman of Madison Square Garden and vice chairman of Cablevision Systems, the ubiquitous company that is the Garden's principal owner.

title: That Mamet Boy Seems at Home on Unexpected Turf
description: From its appearance on the London stage in 1946, to the opening of a new movie version in April, ''The Winslow Boy'' has been a victory of professionalism over improbability. What began as a transformation of borrowed material by adroit stagecraft has lately become a demonstration of a movie maker's finesse in adaptation.

title: Debtor Countries Must Pay Up
description: To the Editor:

Surviving are a step son, Loring Devonch, a step daughter, Peggy Swingle, a sister, Mrs. William (Jane) Wieler, and close friend, Douglas McKay. description: The MSA National Foundation, a new organization devoted to curtailing tobacco use, is undertaking a review of their account with billings estimated at $150 million to $225 million.

title: Duval Hopes to Beat Blisters and Open Field
description: David Duval confirmed today that he would play in the United States Open despite burning his hand on a pot handle last Friday. But Duval said he might be hampered by lingering blisters on his right thumb and forefinger.

A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

Services Wednesday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Doris Rankin Saffer Memorial Fund, C/O Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: A Radical Computer Learns to Think in Reverse
description: When people hear the words ''computer scientist,'' they might imagine a white-coated figure carefully arranging chips into circuitry. Or they might picture a bleary-eyed programmer trying to exterminate a bug from glowing lines of code on a video screen. But at the upper reaches of the craft, computer science can be as ethereal and abstract as theoretical physics, driven by thought experiments as bold as those of Einstein, who imagined what it would be like to ride a light beam through the sky.

title: Environmental Spoils
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a girl who died when a ride in Coney Island malfunctioned referred imprecisely to the location of the accident. While the girl was part of a group that spent the day at the Astroland amusement park, the ride that failed, the Super Himalaya, is not part of Astroland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GERTRUDE A.
description: COHEN-Gertrude A. On June 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Devoted mother of Michael and Roger. Dear sister of Dorothy Schonberg. Loving grandmother of William, Karen and Alan. Services 11AM Wednesday at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

description: Taking his first formal step into next year's New Jersey Senate race, Jon S. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, will announce on Tuesday the formation of an exploratory committee that will be registered with the Federal Election Commission, his advisers said today.

We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Grandeur of the Baroque Tempered by the Renaissance
description: Most of the musicians in the New York Collegium are familiar to anyone who follows the period-instrument world, and several of the principal players have been involved with other attempts to establish a period-instrument orchestra in New York over the last 20 years. Why those earlier efforts have either foundered or have had trouble finding dependable financial support is a mystery, given the popularity of period-instrument performances. The best-case scenario, of course, would be to have several competing ensembles, each approaching the repertory from a different angle. But one is a start, and at the moment, the Collegium seems to be on solid ground.

title: China Aide Meets With Sect to Dismiss Crackdown Rumors
description: A senior Chinese Government official met representatives of the Buddhist Law spiritual sect today to deny rumors of an imminent crackdown, but also to warn them sternly against upsetting social stability, state television reported tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Henry Grunfeld, 95, Dies; Co-Founder of S. G. Warburg
description: Henry Grunfeld, a refugee from Nazi Germany who helped his fellow expatriate Siegmund G. Warburg build an investment banking empire that transformed the British financial world after World War II, died Thursday. He was 95.

title: No Refuge for Elks
description: To the Editor:

title: Mental Health Misstep
description: Last week's White House Conference on Mental Health, led by Tipper Gore, promoted mental health parity, the idea that insurers should be made to provide coverage for mental health problems just as they do for other illnesses. The proposal has strong Congressional support, and President Clinton recently extended mental health coverage to Federal employees. It also has long been a primary goal of patient advocacy groups and professional associations in the field.

title: Belgian Quits As Food Scare Brings Defeat At the Polls
description: Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene of Belgium resigned today after voters swept away his center-left coalition Government in elections on Sunday. The Government had been heavily criticized for its handling of a dioxin scare that cleared poultry, beef, eggs and butter from stores here and frightened countries around the world into halting food imports from Europe.

title: Stern Wants to Set Minimum Age
description: When he makes his state of the league address next Monday, National Basketball Association Commissioner David Stern is expected to press an agenda to mandate, with the aid of the players union, a minimum age for players entering the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Lakes Area Jealously Guards Liquid Asset
description: Stand on the southern shore of Lake Superior, looking out at its gently tossing, deep blue immensity, and it is hard to imagine anyone here ever feeling short of water.

title: Back to Basics With China
description: One of Washington's top diplomats, Thomas Pickering, is leading a team of American officials to Beijing to explain and once again apologize for the mistaken NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. Mr. Pickering's visit tomorrow should end the period of icy hostility brought about by this incident, which killed three Chinese journalists. In the coming days, Beijing should resume discussions with Washington on the World Trade Organization and other important matters that it has frozen since the embassy attack.

title: Avis Account Is Placed in Review
description: Avis Rent a Car in Garden City, N.Y., said yesterday that it had placed its account in review after 15 years at Bates USA in New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group. Billings were put at $30 million.

Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Foreign Affairs; NATO or BATO?
description: For many years the standard quip about NATO was that NATO existed to ''keep the Germans down, the Americans in [Europe] and the Russians out.'' In light of NATO's U.S.-led victory in Kosovo, though, that old cliche is going to have to be adapted. NATO's new mission is ''to keep the Balkans quiet, the Americans in and the Russians sweet.''

title: A Fountain of Youth, in Music Class
description: A new study has found that teaching healthy elderly people to play music decreases their anxiety, depression and loneliness.

title: Troops Find Scores of Freshly Dug Graves
description: American soldiers today sealed off areas around this small town in southeastern Kosovo where other NATO troops found what they said could be graves containing the remains of scores of civilians killed by Serbian troops.

description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Wal-Mart to Pay Billions for British Supermarket Chain
description: In its first foray into Britain, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. agreed today to pay $10.8 billion in cash for Asda Group P.L.C., Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, thwarting a rival suitor at the last moment and threatening other British retailers with a potentially devastating price war.

title: No New Clashes Reported As Allies Expand Control
description: NATO slowly expanded its control over a central swath of Kosovo today, pouring thousands more soldiers into major towns and villages but effectively ceding the airport here in the capital to about 200 Russian soldiers who defiantly occupied it three days ago.

Three years ago, Mateo Fernandez was fatally injured while driving to work, and his sons took over the business he had built.

title: British Industry Seeking a Share of Balkan Rebuilding Work
description: Three days after British troops led the NATO advance into Kosovo, British Government officials plan to meet Tuesday with business leaders to devise a strategy for securing reconstruction contracts in Kosovo. They will try to offset a widespread view that British companies lost out in the race to rebuild Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war eight years earlier.

description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Balanchine and Ives: Marriage of Mysteries
description: The New York City Ballet offered ''Ivesiana,'' one of George Balanchine's most unusual works, on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It is a suite to four pieces Charles Ives composed between 1904 and 1906, and each choreographic section is titled after the composition to which it is set.

title: In the Earth's Graveyards, Little Protection Against Theft
description: By way of introduction, Vincent Santucci patted his belt and said, ''As you may know, I'm the only pistol-packing paleontologist in the National Park Service.''

title: BRITISH DEAL FOR COACH USA
description: Pressing to become an international transportation operator, Stagecoach Holdings P.L.C., Britain's biggest bus and train company, said it had agreed to buy the Houston-based Coach USA Inc., the biggest American charter bus and tour operator, for $1.88 billion. The deal values Coach USA shares at $42 -- a 41 percent premium to the closing price on June 7. Stagecoach also said it would assume $638 million in Coach USA debt. Alan Cowell

title: U.S. Drops a Joint Venture For Internet Access to Its Data
description: The Commerce Department has officially pulled out of an Internet partnership with a private company after the project raised concerns about fee-based access to Government documents.

title: ESSAY; Worries of a Survivor of Foster Care
description: The Federal Government tells us there are 520,000 children in foster care, enough to fill the entire city of Seattle. And given the AIDS epidemic, that number grows daily.

title: Albany Budget Stalls, but Discord Stays in High Gear
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver had a rare meeting the other day, there was no shortage of unfinished business between the two foes. The discord they had bred in the Capitol had delayed the state budget and along with it decisions on many issues, from health care to drug policy to school violence.

title: FLEXTRONICS TO BUY FINNISH ELECTRONICS COMPANY
description: Flextronics International Ltd., a computer equipment maker based in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Finland's Kyrel EMS Oyj for about $102 million in stock. Kyrel, with 1998 revenue of $230 million and 900 employees, provides electronics manufacturing services in Europe and has plants in Finland and France. It specializes in telecommunications. Flextronics, which had sales of $1.8 billion in its most recent fiscal year, said it expected to take a charge of $3 million to $3.5 million when the acquisition is completed in the quarter ending Sept. 24. The deal is subject to Government approval in Finland. Shares of Flextronics rose $1.50, to $55.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, CELIA (NEE GOLDSTEIN)
description: LANE-Celia (nee Goldstein). On Sunday, June 13, 1999. Of Lake Hiawatha, formerly of Jersey City. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morris Lane. Devoted mother of Kenneth Lane and Dr. Benjamin Lane. Services 11 AM, Tuesday, at the Louis Suburban Chapel, 70 Hudson St., Dover, NJ. Interment at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MORRIS L., DR.
description: GREEN-Morris L., Dr. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University in Israel mourn the untimely passing of their esteemed member, Honorary Alumnus of the University and past Chairman of its Global Board of Trustees, Dr. Morris L. Green. In the few years we were privileged to enjoy his leadership and generosity, he did much for the University as a whole. In addition to the important role he assumed for the advancement of Torah Study in Israel and the Diaspora, which was exemplified by his chairmanship of BarIlan University's Ludwig and Erica Jesselson Institute for Advanced Torah Studies, Morris Green was especially devoted to the development of Hebrew Law for use in the modern State of Israel; this was his area of special interest and one of his enduring monuments for the future of the State of Israel. To his wife, Charlotte, and the entire family, we extend sincerest condolences. We share with them memories of an historic career of service to G-d, our people and all humanity. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Charles Dimston, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Melvin Stein, President, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President, Bar-Ilan University

title: Times Names a Columnist
description: Gail Collins, an editorial writer for The New York Times, has been appointed an Op-Ed Page columnist for the duration of the 2000 political campaign.
