title: BIG ORDER FOR EMBRAER
description: Latin America's leading aerospace manufacturer, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A., won orders for passenger jets potentially worth as much as $6.2 billion, fueling the Brazilian company's turnaround from a state-controlled behemoth. Embraer, as the company is known, won the orders mainly from European carriers like Crossair of Switzerland and Skyways of Sweden. In addition, Embraer said it would join with the General Electric Company and Honeywell Inc. of the United States to develop a family of 70-seat and 90-seat regional jets, which would be larger than its existing aircraft. The orders will result in a 15 percent increase in Embraer's work force, adding about 1,000 employees. The orders were announced at the Paris Air Show by Mauricio Botelho, above, chief executive of Embraer. Carlos Leoni R. Siqueira, chairman of the Embraer board, said the company would eventually have to sell more shares to help finance its expansion. On the news of the orders, Embraer's shares surged as much as 55 percent on the Sao Paulo stock exchange. Simon Romero

title: Wooten Is Let Go As Giants Plan Pacts
description: Giants free safety Tito Wooten, whose poor play and lack of conditioning last year incensed teammates and whose many off-the-field problems troubled the organization, was released yesterday.

title: MetroStars Yearning For Help From Abroad
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DROPS. The yen fell sharply against the dollar after the Bank of Japan sold yen for the second time in a week, curbing a rise in the currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.62 yen, up from 118.08 on Friday.

title: Investigators From Many Nations to Begin Search for War Crimes
description: War crimes investigators will enter Kosovo on Tuesday to start their most sweeping inquiry since conflicts began in the former Yugoslavia in 1991, tribunal officials said today.

title: Kosovo Rebels Savor New Role as Serb Troops Leave
description: As Serbian troops withdraw under NATO tanks and guns, rebels of the Kosovo Liberation Army are coming out of the mountains and forests to stake their claim to power.

title: As Bush Begins Campaigning in Earnest, Details Take Back Seat to Packaging
description: Peggy McDonald, a retired dental assistant who lives in this speck of a town on the New Hampshire seacoast, pronounced George W. Bush ''adorable'' when he showed up to give a speech today, then proceeded to raise a red flag about his candidacy.

title: Jazz and Movement Mingle At a Festive Cocktail Party
description: The American Dance Festival's new season, which is devoted to an unusually large number of premieres (16) and special events, has opened here with ''Out Some Place,'' a lively and inspired collaboration between the choreographer Bill T. Jones and the jazz pianist Fred Hersch.

title: Those Lips! Those Eyes! That Mojo's Working!
description: DANGEROUS KISS

title: The Unbuttoning of Al Gore: Act 1
description: Al Gore is walking up the path to a home here where 40 people have gathered to listen to his pitch. He has shed his blue suit (as per President Clinton's instructions) for a green polo shirt, khakis and cowboy boots. Spotting his host, who is wearing a tie and sports jacket, Mr. Gore calls out, ''I hope I'm not too informal!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Kosovo has been a watershed in so many ways. For Germany, it has represented a coming of age. For Europe, it has brought a crushing realization of the asymmetry of military power between it and the United States, and the need to do something about that.''

title: Novelty Act? Not if Things Go Their Way
description: Now that Cibo Matto has had its fun as a hip New York novelty, its ambitions have grown. Its four-night stand at the Mercury Lounge last week announced that the group is planning to break out of its in-crowd.

title: JAPANESE TELEVISION VENTURE
description: Two leading Japanese electronics companies, Canon and Toshiba, said in Tokyo that they would jointly develop and mass-produce large screens for television sets. The screens will use surface conduction electron emitter display technology to allow creation of large wall-mounted screens measuring more than 40 inches diagonally but only an inch or two in depth. The companies expect to produce 50,000 units a month by 2002. The technology will compete with plasma display panels, the predominant technology for flat-panel television screens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, MARIO J., ESQ.
description: MARINO-Mario J., Esq. On June 13, 1999, former Brooklyn District Leader. Beloved husband of Mary, loving father of Lisa Mislowack, Camille Nunez, and Maria Parrinello. Devoted grandfather of Bianca, Alexa, Nicholas, Natalie, Katie, and Grace. Resposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons, 1305 79 St, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:30 A.M. at Saints Simon and Jude R.C. Church. Entombment Saint John's Cloister.

title: No Toy, Shiny Gadget Captures Chaos in Light Beams
description: The apparatus is simple enough for a child to construct, and the kaleidoscopic images it generates fascinate onlookers with their dazzling complexity. But this is not a toy; it is a tool for studying the effects of chaos on light beams.

title: MAXXIM MEDICAL TO BE BOUGHT OUT BY MANAGEMENT GROUP
description: Maxxim Medical Inc., a medical products maker, said yesterday that a management group had agreed to buy the company out for about $800 million in stock and assumed debt. The buyout follows a 33 percent drop in the company's share price over the last six months. A group led by Kenneth Davidson, the company's chairman, president and chief executive, agreed to pay Maxxim shareholders -- with the exception of senior executives and some others -- $26 for each share, a 31 percent premium over Friday's closing price. The stock had fallen from a high of $29.75 in late December. The shares of Maxxim, which is based in Clearwater, Fla., rose $3.625 yesterday, to $23.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Hospitals Unit Found Liable In Birth Injury
description: A jury has ordered the Health and Hospitals Corporation to pay $76.4 million to a 12-year-old girl who suffered brain damage and other permanent injuries during her birth in what her lawyer called a botched delivery at Harlem Hospital Center. It was one of the largest malpractice verdicts ever recorded against the corporation, which runs the city's hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: At Home Abroad; Lords and Judges
description: Imagine that appointees to the Supreme Court of the United States were first made members of the Senate. Imagine that the justices heard arguments in a Senate committee room, announced their decisions on the Senate floor -- and in addition to deciding cases, could vote as senators on legislation.

title: On Center Runway, Boeing's Little 717
description: Boeing's centerpiece at the Paris Air Show here is not one of its famous wide-body jumbo jets but the newest and smallest member of its fleet, a stub-nosed little passenger jet called the 717.

title: In Ruined Village, a Mother Lives With Her Son's Blood
description: Shala Selvinaze pulled back a tatty wool carpet in her tiny living room to show precisely where Serbian paramilitary men slit the throat of her son, Ymer.

title: CONGRESSIONAL QUARTERLY TO BUY LEGI-SLATE ASSETS
description: Congressional Quarterly Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase some assets of Legi-slate Inc. from the Washington Post Company. Financial terms were not disclosed. Congressional Quarterly said it planned to buy an on-line information service and its customer base, and merge it into its CQ.com On Congress service, the successor to Congressional Quarterly's on-line Washington Alert service. Congressional Quarterly is a multimedia publishing company.

title: In a Culture of Sunbathers, Tips for Shielding the Skin
description: As warm and wonderful as it feels to bask under the rays of the summer sun, it is not very good for the body. In my teen-age years, we had tanning contests to see who could get the darkest the fastest. In my 20's, I slathered my bikini-clad body in baby oil to attract as many tanning rays as I could in the little time I had for sunbathing. Now, decades later, when I look at the spotted skin that has begun to wrinkle on my arms and legs, I cannot help wishing I had known then what I know now.

title: Report Scolds Bureaucracy for U.S. Nuclear Lab Lapses
description: Clinton Administration initiatives to tighten security at nuclear weapons laboratories are not being carried out fully because of bureaucratic arrogance and foot-dragging, said a scathing report issued today by a presidential review panel.

title: Gangs, Gambling and the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court does not lightly overturn Federal and state laws enacted with a worthwhile social purpose in mind. But in two of its latest rulings, the Court quite correctly struck down a Chicago ordinance intended to combat gang activity and a Federal law aimed at curbing the problems associated with legal gambling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Building brand loyalty for natural-food products is a tall order.
description: OVER the last two years, Irwin D. Simon, the chief executive of the Hain Food Group, has spent millions of dollars assembling an empire of natural-food products ranging from snack foods and soy milk to condiments like mayonnaise. His company made its latest acquisition in May, paying $70 million for the privately held Natural Nutrition Group and its collection of brands that include Health Valley cereals. The move lifted Hain's projected annual sales to $300 million, about triple what they were in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUMMER, JACK
description: ZUMMER-Jack. Died April 23, 1999. King Solomon-Beethoven Lodge No. 232 F&AM mourns the loss of its esteemed brother. Robert L. Lippmann, Master

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, THOMAS (EDWARD)
description: JENKINS - Thomas (Edward), Brother, F.S.C. age 85, of De La Salle Hall, Lincroft, New Jersey on June 14. He was born in NYC and had received the habit of the Brothers of the Christian Schools in 1931. He began his teaching career at Bishop Loughlin High School, Brooklyn, NY in 1935 and remained there until 1951 when he became the recruiter of the New York Province. In 1958 he was one of the four brothers who opened a new mission in Kenya, East Africa. He returned from his overseas apostolate in 1969. Since then he worked at Christian Brothers Academy, Albany, New York, St. Peter's High School, Staten Island, New York, and Christian Brothers Academy, Lincroft before entering De La Salle Hall in 1995. Calling hours will be held at De La Salle Hall, Lincroft Wednesday from 7-9 PM and Thursday after 2 PM. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at De La Salle Hall on Thursday at 7:30 PM. The Rite of Committal will be held at De La Salle Hall on Friday at 9:30 AM followed by interment at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, New Jersey. Memorial donations to De La Salle Nursing Development, 810 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, N.J. 07738 would be appreciated. Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold, NJ.

title: PHYSICIANS' SPECIALTY TO BE BOUGHT AND BECOME PRIVATE
description: The Physicians' Specialty Corporation, a physician practice management company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by TA Associates so that TA could take it private. TA Associates will pay $98.8 million in cash, and some of Physicians' Specialty's debt will be refinanced. Physicians' Specialty, which went public in 1997, specializes in treating diseases and disorders of the ears, nose and throat, and is affiliated with 92 physicians, a dentist, and other health care professionals in Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Illinois, New Jersey, New York and Ohio. It also owns a sleep-diagnostic laboratory company. TA Associates, based in Boston, manages about $2.5 billion in equity capital and specializes in management buyouts.

title: Mood Festive for Albanians As Thousands of Serbs Flee
description: Serbs left this city in the thousands today, jeered by ethnic Albanians who then danced on bridges and cobblestone streets and set about the business of wiping their city clean of the symbols of the Serbs.

title: Girl, 9, Is Injured In Brooklyn Fire
description: A 9-year-old girl was critically injured when she was trapped on the third floor of a burning building in Brooklyn yesterday, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DASSA, GABRIEL
description: DASSA-Gabriel. Age 97. Born in Salonica, Greece and a founding father of the Sephardic Jewish Center of Canarsie. Owner of Gabe's Sweet Shop in Canarsie and the Boardwalk at 72nd Street in Rockaway Beach. Gabriel was a volunteer at the Remsen Heights Senior Center and was a member of the senior choir. Beloved husband of the late Allegra, devoted father of Isaac, Julie Brill, and Marty. Father-in-law of Sylvia, Shelley, and the late Leon Brill. Adored grandfather of Marna, Marlene, Bonnie, Hal, Alyssa, and Glenn. Cherished great grandfather of Jason, Sheryl, Leon, and Allegra. Dear uncle and loyal friend to many. Services at 11 A.M. on Wednesday at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, corner 66th Avenue, Forest Hills. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: BECTON DICKINSON'S STOCK FALLS AFTER PROFIT WARNING
description: Becton Dickinson & Company, the nation's largest maker of syringes, said yesterday that its profit would fall short of Wall Street's expectations, setting off a 22 percent drop in the price of its stock. The company said its sales in Europe failed to meet its goals. Becton Dickinson has been buying niche companies to expand in Europe and emerging markets amid a slowdown in syringe sales, but investors fear that the new businesses are slowing. The company said revenue would be $30 million to $35 million less than estimates and profit would fall about 4 cents a share short of expectations in the fiscal third quarter, which will end June 30, and the fourth quarter. Shares in Becton, based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., fell $8.75, to $30.3125.

title: N.A.S.D. Is Expected to Start a Trading System for Japanese Stocks
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is expected to announce today that it will form an electronic trading system similar to its Nasdaq Stock Market to list and trade Japanese stocks, securities industry officials said yesterday.

title: Corbis to Acquire A Photo Agency
description: The Corbis Corporation, a privately held company that is wholly owned by William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, said today that it had agreed to acquire Sygma, one of the world's largest news photography agencies, as part of its plan to offer news and celebrity images to publishers and consumers over the Internet.

title: No Vindication, Just Victories, for Popovich
description: Just four months ago, the black and silver juggernaut known as the San Antonio Spurs seemed to be on the verge of collapse. Greatly talented and expected to contend for a National Basketball Association championship, the Spurs had a 6-8 record and were in danger of losing more than a playoff spot; their coach and general manager, Gregg Popovich, was in the kind of trouble that only Jeff Van Gundy can appreciate.

title: How to Stop the Spurs? Knicks Ponder the Ways
description: Chris Childs remembers the game with such clarity that he grimaces and shakes his head when recalling the details. The images of that debacle against the San Antonio Spurs -- almost 15 months ago -- are as fresh and focused as the film the Knicks watched today in preparations for Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREKSTONE, E. STEPHEN
description: BREKSTONE-E. Stephen. Attorney at Law of Dobbs Ferry, New York, suddenly on June 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Candida, devoted father of Barbara Carmenini, fond grandfather of Candace and Christopher. Mass 10AM Thursday, Our Lady of Pompeii Church, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting 79PM Tuesday and 2-4 and 7-9PM Wednesday at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to American Heart Association preferred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Is Alcohol Dangerous?
description: To the Editor:

title: After Stabbing, Earlier Case Questioned
description: A schizophrenic woman accused of fatally stabbing a 76-year-old man on a Brooklyn street was arraigned yesterday on a charge of second-degree murder in the same criminal courtroom where she had faced assault charges less than a month ago in another stabbing.

title: Hundreds in Complex Flee Gas Main Break
description: Several hundred people were evacuated from a Jersey City office complex yesterday after a construction crew accidentally ruptured a gas main, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Books to Help Sick Children Understand They Are Not Alone
description: When chronic illness is part of a child's life, the problems go beyond the physical symptoms. Children with illnesses like asthma, diabetes or cerebral palsy often feel isolated, ''different'' and lonely. Siblings have special problems, too.

title: Dead Man With No ID Found in Seat on Subway
description: A man was found dead in his seat yesterday morning on one of the city's busiest subway lines, the police said. Nearly everything about the man, who was removed from the No. 1 train when it arrived at the 96th Street station at 11 A.M., is a mystery, the police said.

title: Phone Calls To Russia Fail to End Stalemate
description: President Clinton and other senior American leaders spoke with their counterparts in Russia today but were unable to resolve the impasse over Russian troops that has marred the beginning of the peacekeeping mission in Kosovo.

title: Johnson Still Hopes to Play
description: Larry Johnson continued to rehabilitate his sprained right knee but did not practice with the Knicks yesterday, and he will not practice before Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals, waiting until then to make a decision on his availability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARBUCHO, JAMES A.
description: ARBUCHO-James A., 73, of Williamsburg, VA formerly of Englewood, New Jersey. Died Saturday, June 12, 1999. Mr. Arbucho was an agent Emeritus of Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, a member of the N.Y. Giants Baseball Association, 1949-52, and a World War II Navy veteran. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 16th at 11:00AM at St. Bede's Catholic Church in Williamsburg, Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAS, IRVING M., M.D.
description: LEVITAS-Irving M., M.D. Of Reston, VA., formerly of Westwood, N.J. on Thursday, May 27, 1999. Educated at Staunton Military Academy, Dartmouth College and the Down State University of Medicine of N.Y.C. Dr. Levitas was a Diplamate for the Board of Internal Medicine and a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. He was an Emeritus Clinical Associate Professor of Medicine at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of N.J. Dr. Levitas headed the first Cardiac Stress Test Center in N.J. which is centered in the Hackensack Medical Center. In conjunction with the Bergen Co. Heart Association he produced the movie ''It's Your Heart'' which was chosen best heart picture of the year and was exhibited at the Smithsonian Institute. In 1975, Dr. Levitas' book entitled ''You Can Beat the Odds on a Heart Attack'' was published. Prior to moving to VA. he was a Consultant to The Physicians Desk Reference and was a contributing editor of ''Medical Economics''. In retirement, Dr. Levitas wrote a column on medical subjects for the Reston, Va. Connection newspaper. He was the Health Advocate for N. Va. AARP and gave lectures at the Learning in Retirement Institute entitled ''Can You Slow the Aging Process.'' Dr. Levitas wrote and published various articles and books for Medical Journals and Magazines. He was also a U.S. Army veteran of World War II. He is beloved husband of Virginia Vennett Levitas. Devoted father of John H. Levitas, Betty Ann Rubin and Jane Susan Knox. Dear brother of Gladys Cooper. Services were held at Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ on June 1, 1999.

title: AMERICA ONLINE BUYS STAKE IN ASIAN WEB SITE OPERATOR
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had bought 10 percent of the China.com Corporation, a Web site operator based in Hong Kong that is about to sell shares for the first time. China.com, which is awaiting approval by United States regulators to sell shares on the Nasdaq stock market, runs bilingual English and Chinese Web sites in China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. America Online declined to disclose the purchase price. It already has an agreement with the China Internet Corporation, an affiliate of China.com, to start an Internet service in Hong Kong later this year.

title: In Secret Belgrade Talks, London Financier Seems to Have Helped Milosevic Accept Accord
description: A British financier, acting with the knowledge of the German and Finnish Governments, held secret negotiations with the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that appear to have helped the Yugoslav reconcile himself to the peace agreement announced on June 3, German and Swedish officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about concerns over consumers' financial privacy referred incompletely to the involvement of Memberworks, a telemarketing firm based in Stamford, Conn., in a suit filed against U.S. Bancorp by the Minnesota Attorney General's office. Although the suit contends that the bank illegally sold credit histories and other information to Memberworks, the firm is not a defendant in the case.

title: Brain Stem Cell Is Discovered, Twice
description: The elusive neural stem cell, the founding cell from which perhaps the whole brain develops, has at long last been discovered -- again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLL, FLORENCE
description: KROLL-Florence. The officers, members and staff of the America Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the death of Florence Kroll, mother of Jules Kroll and mother-in-law of Lynn Korda Kroll, a member of AJC's Board of Governors. Lynn is also a past recipient of the Harriet H. Jonas Award of AJC's Women's Campaign. We send heartfelt condolences to Jules, Lynn and the rest of the grieving family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Executive Director

title: Two More Deals Further Consolidate the Nation's Utilities
description: Consolidation in the nation's utility industry picked up speed yesterday with announcements of two big deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Debtor Countries Must Pay Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Irabu, Tough in Clutch, Steadies the Yankees
description: Hideki Irabu dug at the mud around the pitcher's rubber to gather his footing, wiped the perspiration and rain off his face with his glove and gazed in at the Rangers and kept challenging them last night. It was a rigorous night for Irabu, regardless of what his potent statistics were. The Rangers made Irabu work, Irabu worked relentlessly and the Yankees won, 8-2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UTTAL, EDNA NELSON
description: UTTAL-Edna Nelson. On June 13, 1999. Wife of Robert. Mother of Patricia, Richard and Steven. Grandmother of Hillary and Daniel Shifrin. Sister of Seymour Fiance and the late Elaine Plant. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Service today, 11 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. Shiva observed at the home of Patricia Nelson, 501 East 79 Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLISSEL, IRVING
description: SCHLISSEL-Irving, 83, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on June 12th, 1999. Beloved husband of Sally and the late Estelle, loving father of Ted, Jacqueline Marcus, Arnold and Steve, loving grandfather of Scott, Dara, Deborah Siegel, J.D. Siegel, Hagit, Karen, Doron, Sarah, Rebeccah, Leah, Jed and Esther, and devoted brother of Hannah Stein, Leon Shore and Toby Brooks. A much loved man of warmth and wit and a leading member of the Golden Lakes Village Jewish Center. Funeral services were held in West Palm Beach.

title: Hardly Out of Diapers and Now Into Yoga
description: I was the oldest one in the exercise class by nearly 30 years, and I'm only 36. As a yoga novice, Jack, my 5-year-old, was allowed to bring his mother along.

title: Warnings Are Ignored As Refugees Return Home
description: Ignoring warnings about land mines and armed Serbian troops, several hundred returning refugees slipped back through the closed border into Kosovo today by taking a dangerous path on a wooded mountainside as periodic gunfire rang out in the hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, MARSHA LEE
description: ABRAMS-Marsha Lee. Of Princeton, N.J. Former Executive Director of the Gray Panthers and longtime employee Bloomberg L.P. On June 11, 1999. Survived by husband, Sanford Abrams, brother, James Hayman, and sister, Jane Abbott. Service of remembrance, 4 P.M. Saturday, June 19, at Kimble Funeral Home, 1 Hamltion Avenue, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: Dow Rises, but Nasdaq Is Pulled Down by Internet Sector
description: Stock prices were mixed and activity remained subdued yesterday as traders and investors delayed putting money to work before an important inflation report that is scheduled for release tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMERMAN, SYLVIA
description: SOMERMAN - Sylvia. Former Mathematics teacher at Erasmus Hall High School. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Nathan Somerman. Devoted mother of Frances Somerman Soond, Eugene, and Martha Somerman Schiff. Adored grandmother of Paul and Eric Greenberg, Vincent and Kathleen Somerman and Daniel Schiff. Services today 9AM at the I. J. Morris Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Helping Students, And Teachers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Smart' Guns Proving to Be No Quick Fix for Firearm Violence
description: Seven years ago, a group of engineering students at Johns Hopkins University was given $2,000 and an assignment: build a ''smart'' gun, a gun that could be fired only by its owner. Using off-the-shelf equipment, they developed a prototype that, with wires hanging out of it, was neither attractive nor practical. But it worked.

title: Helping Students, And Teachers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Qwest Shares Plunge 24% In Bid's Wake
description: Shares of Qwest Communications International Inc., the upstart telecommunications company, plummeted 24 percent yesterday after investors panned its $55 billion bid for both U S West, the Denver-based local telecommunications concern, and the Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's long-distance companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Europe's Aim: Arms Parity
description: The Kosovo war has brought radical changes to the European continent, thrusting Germany into a leading military role not seen since 1945, galvanizing attempts to forge a common European defense policy and altering Europe's relationship with the United States.

title: No Budget in Albany But Discord Is Ample
description: When New York Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver had a rare meeting the other day, there was no shortage of unfinished business between the two foes. The discord they had bred in the Capitol had delayed the state budget and along with it decisions on many issues from health care to drug policy to school violence. Yet less than 15 cheerless minutes after the meeting began, it abruptly broke up with a familiar result: Each man was blaming the other for freezing the gears of state government.

title: Stock Tip Called a Fraud
description: Prudential Securities Inc. said today that a letter on company stationery urging the purchase of three small-capitalization stocks was inauthentic. The letter, written as a personal note, urges an unidentifited broker to buy stock in the China Food and Beverage Company, Tmanglobal.com and Transglobal Holdings Inc. ''Load up now or weep,'' it reads. ''Major announcements are coming out this month.'' Prudential, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said it had been told that more than two dozen copies of the letter had been received. ''The firm's research department does not follow these stocks and did not distribute letters suggesting their purchase,'' Prudential Securities said in a statement.

title: G.O.P. to Separate Gun-Control Measures From Juvenile-Crime Bill
description: House Republican leaders decided today to separate gun-control proposals from a piece of broader juvenile-crime legislation and put the measures in their own distinct bill, a surprising change in strategy that underscored the sensitivity of the issue and instantly gave rise to conflicting interpretations.

title: Smallpox: The Once and Future Scourge?
description: No one has come down with smallpox for decades. But in some respects it is potentially more dangerous than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, MARTIN G.
description: TAUB-Martin G. Devoted husband of Frances Israel Taub, deceased. Loving father of Richard, David and Linda. Loving grandfather of Andrew, Marc and Sandy, Josh and Lisa, Neela, and Zach. Loving great-grandfather of Jake. Survived by brothers Jack and wife Faye, Larry and wife Eleanor. Died June 12, 1999, after a valiant struggle. Wine merchant extraordinaire, he had been founder of Gallo Wine Distributors, Inc., co-founder of Premier Wine and Spirits, and Palm Bay Imports. No matter what the adversities, he never lost his warmth and amazing wit. Intensely committed to family, he passed on that love to his children and grandchildren, as well as passing on his affection for bad puns. He will be sorely missed. Funeral Monday, June 14, at 11 AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the House & Home section on Thursday about co-op boards in Manhattan that do not accept financial guarantees from the parents of apartment applicants referred to one building incorrectly. The co-op at 41 Central Park West has no such prohibition.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: 'Blues' Co-Creator Has a Stroke

title: Man Is Shot to Death as Guests Leave a Wedding Celebration
description: A wedding celebration ended in gunfire late Sunday night when an uninvited guest shot and killed one man and wounded another, the police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, LOU
description: BERNARD-Lou. Passed away June 9, 1999. Beloved father of Toni Ann. Devoted brother of Helen Sissenwine. A good man with a kind heart. May he rest in peace.

title: U.S. Suit Charges Bias in Nassau County Property Taxes
description: The Federal Government made good on a threat and sued Nassau County today, saying its antiquated method of assessing property taxes forced black and Hispanic homeowners to pay disproportionately high taxes.

title: Helping Students, And Teachers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Chief Says New-Age Economy Can Have Old Problems
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that increases in business efficiency could not counterbalance the strains on the economy forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: South Korea Sinks Vessel From North In Disputed Waters
description: South Korean naval forces sank a North Korean torpedo boat today as a fierce gun battle erupted in the Yellow Sea, and South Korea put its entire armed forces on combat-level alert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANLEY, KATHERINE
description: HANLEY-Katherine. June 15, 1994. Mom, 5 years have not lessened our loss nor diminished our love. The Children

title: Voters in Britain Rebuff Blair In Europe Parliament Election
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that his Government would stick to its pro-European stance despite the apparent rejection of that policy by British voters electing the country's 87 members of the European Parliament.

title: Judge Rejects Request To Jail Ex-Party Chief
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday asked a judge to jail the former chairman of the Dutchess County Republican Party while he awaits trial on extortion and conspiracy charges, saying he had attempted to influence the testimony of at least three potential witnesses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Hull Wants to Skate, Coach Wants to Wait
description: Even though Brett Hull said he would like to play against Buffalo on Tuesday night in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, Stars Coach Ken Hitchcock said today that he did not want to risk aggravation of Hull's groin injury. Hitchcock said that he might use defenseman Darryl Sydor or center Tony Hrkac in Hull's place as right wing alongside center Mike Modano.

title: Serbian Returnees Revel in Just Being Alive
description: Yugoslav soldiers leaned out of a civilian bus, waving and whooping noisily, as it swept down the main street bringing them back to this Serbian town today. People out strolling in the warm evening on the main square looked up and waved back.

title: Debtor Countries Must Pay Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburban Sprawl Isn't Friendly to Bike Riding
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: In Front but Not in Focus
description: In all my years in politics, I have never seen a campaign get off to a faster start. Equally important, I have never seen such a rush to judgment by Republican Party stalwarts and financial supporters. In the minds of many of these activists, George W. Bush, whom they barely know, is the inevitable nominee because he has name recognition and can raise the $40 million it will take to be nominated. They feel they had better get on board before the train leaves the station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, ELEANOR HEMPSTEAD
description: AVERY - Eleanor Hempstead. Died on Saturday, June 12 at her home in New York City. The caused of death was cancer. Mrs. Hempstead was the daughter of the late Waldo Allard Avery of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and the niece of the late Sewell Lee Avery of Chicago, who died in the office of chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward & Co. She was married once, to the late David Bill Hempstead, who produced and wrote some notable motion pictures during the late 1940's and '50's. It was he who persuaded Ginger Rogers to accept her first dramatic role in his production of ''Kitty Foyle'', for which she won the Academy Award. The Hempsteads were divorced in 1949. In her later years, Mrs. Hempstead devoted herself to a number of philanthropies, and was a generous donor to the Bronx Zoo, Planned Parenthood, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Mrs. Hempstead is survived by her two children, Avery Hempstead Lichtenstein of New York and Santa Fe, and a son, David Bill Hempstead IV of Pasadena, California. A memorial service is to be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st street) in Manhattan on Thursday, September 9 at 4PM. Only relatives, business associates and close friends of the deceased and her daughter are invited to attend.

title: East Timor Calmer For Autonomy Vote
description: This disputed province is growing calmer but still has a ''long way to go'' before those who support breaking away from Indonesia feel secure enough to vote in a referendum on independence, less than two months away, the chief United Nations official here says.

title: Resilient Computer Worm Is Continuing to Take a Heavy Toll
description: Computer researchers reported yesterday that a virulent computer program was spreading in a previously undisclosed way, generating new reports of significant loss of data by major corporations and individual computer users.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLEGIANCE TELECOM INC., Dallas, a provider of telecommunications services, agreed to buy Penncorp Financial Group Inc.'s Internet services provider, Kivex Inc., of Bethesda, Md., for $34.5 million in cash.

title: Phoning And Driving Don't Mix
description: BY now, he is as familiar a figure on the city landscape as the souvlaki vendor. He -- and the sense here is that men are more the issue than women -- is the fellow you see behind the wheel of a Lexus or some other car of suitable status, trying to negotiate New York traffic while talking on a cellular phone.

title: Defending the Meerkat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEROY, HAROLD
description: SEROY-Harold. Age ninty-seven, died at his home in Lake Worth, FL. on June 14, 1999. Formerly of Stamford, CT. Husband of the late Ethel. Survived by his son, Martin, his daughter, Raphaela, five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Interment Tuesday, June 15 at Menorah Gardens at 10AM, in West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEECH, ESTHER
description: PLEECH-Esther. On June 13. Beloved wife of Jerome, devoted mother of Nancy Tognan & Russel Pleech. Cherished grandmother of Melody and Armand. Dear sister of Abraham Weisman. Loving mother-in-law of Louis Tognan and Daryl Sparks. Service today, 11:30 A.M. ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: VIVENDI'S AMERICAN EXPANSION
description: In yet another of its seemingly endless acquisitions, Vivendi S.A. of France announced a deal to buy Superior Services Inc. for about $1 billion. Superior, which is based in Milwaukee, is the fourth-largest American waste-management company. Vivendi, France's biggest water utility, has expanded into environmental services as well as into media and telecommunications. Two months ago it acquired the U.S. Filter Corporation for $7.9 billion, making it the largest American water supplier to private corporations. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about the bidding for ''Aging With Grace,'' a book about nuns from the order of the School Sisters of Notre Dame, misspelled the surname of two elderly women to whose memoir it was compared. They were the Delany sisters, not Delaney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa prices slid as a flurry of sales by West African growers left candy makers well supplied during a seasonal lull in consumption. In New York, cocoa for July delivery fell $34 a metric ton, to $1,063.

title: Suspect in Loss of Nuclear Secrets Unlikely to Face Spying Charges
description: Three months ago, a research mathematician was dismissed from his job at the Los Alamos nuclear weapons laboratory for security violations. Today Federal authorities say it is most unlikely that the mathematician, who is at the center of the uproar over the suspected theft of nuclear secrets by China, will ever face criminal charges of espionage.

title: Assembly Prohibits Using Lottery Money on Prisons
description: A bill that would create a constitutional amendment barring state officials from spending lottery revenues on New Jersey's state prisons was passed yesterday by the Assembly.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Reuters in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about the initial public offering of Onlinetradinginc.com misstated the period for the company's annual revenue. It generated revenue of $3.5 million in the year ended Jan. 31, 1998, not for all of 1998.

title: Justices Strike Down Ban On Casino Gambling Ads
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously struck down a 65-year-old ban on broadcast advertising of casino gambling, ruling on First Amendment grounds that the Federal law ''sacrifices an intolerable amount of truthful speech about lawful conduct.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 65th St. & 5th Ave, NY, NY, 4pm on Tuesday, June 15th.

title: The Lore o the Irish
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: About New York; The Hydrants That Only Eat Parking Places
description: IT sounds like an urban legend, on a par with the ones about sewers teeming with alligators and spider eggs flavoring a certain brand of bubble gum. This is how it goes:

title: Energy Agency to Expand Role In Race to Map Human Genome
description: The Department of Energy intends to play a significant role in sequencing the human genome by decoding the DNA of three of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes. To meet this goal, it has leased 24 DNA sequencing machines for its Joint Genome Institute, the department said on Monday.

title: To Dine, Not Just Eat, for $10
description: TO visit El Fogon on a Saturday afternoon is to see East Harlem pass before your eyes. Politicians, musicians, writers and athletes descend on this tiny Puerto Rican restaurant just west of Third Avenue, exchanging jokes and gossip with Felipe Colon, the dapper co-owner, whose sole concession to the June heat is to shed his beret and ascot.

title: The Singer Is Real, but the Orchestra Cannot Hear Her
description: Producing opera is a notoriously expensive undertaking. The biggest budget item, especially for smaller companies, is hiring union orchestra musicians for rehearsals and performances. Many fledgling companies have been sunk by the expense.

title: Duncan, the VH1 of Superstars
description: Tim Duncan is thought to be drab and indifferent by almost all of the basketball-consumed public. He is said to be too boring to be the best player in the league, too passionless and polite to be the leader of the Gen X stars. His own coach, Gregg Popovich, has said that his extraordinary power forward has no ''MTV in him.''

title: Gore Terms Clinton Affair 'Inexcusable'
description: Vice President Al Gore says that President Clinton's extramarital affair with Monica S. Lewinsky was ''inexcusable'' and that the President lied to him, just as he had lied to everyone else.

title: UNISYS TO PURCHASE A COMMUNICATIONS SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pulsepoint Communications for about $100 million to broaden its array of computer management services for corporations. Unisys said Pulsepoint stockholders would get 0.176 share of Unisys common stock for each share held, making the deal worth $6.60 a share. Pulsepoint, which is based in Carpinteria, Calif., and had 1998 revenue of $25.4 million, develops software that enables users to get access to voice, fax and E-mail messages by PC or telephone. Shares of Pulsepoint rose 40.62 cents, to $5.9062, and Unisys rose 25 cents, to $37.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLARUSSO, SAM A.
description: COLARUSSO-Sam A. On June 14, 1999 aged 92 of Short Hills, NJ. Husband of Pauline (nee Ochner). Survived by four sisters, five nieces and nephews and five great nieces and nephews. Relatives & friends may attend the funeral mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ on Saturday, June 19 at 10 A.M. Visitation at Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, (corner Morris Avenue) Summit from 2-4 and 7-9P.M. on Thursday and Friday. Entombment in Gate of Heaven Chapel Mausoleum, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Colarusso Family Scholarship Fund, Development Dpt., University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Another Frosty Snow Maiden Proves Difficult to Thaw Out

title: From Macedonia, Over 2,500 Return as Mine Kills Woman
description: A woman was killed this morning by a land mine as she tried to walk back into Kosovo over a hillside near here, the first casualty of the journey home. As the number of refugees joyously returning home from here swelled, the death pointed up the validity of the warnings from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees about the dangers the refugees face as they return.

title: The Three Faces of Cabernet Franc
description: IN their hearts, all Frenchmen truly believe the old axiom that insists ''a wine's first duty is to be red.'' And yet there are parts of France where red wine definitely plays second fiddle. Champagne, of course, and Alsace, where riesling and gewurztraminer reign supreme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: From California, Home-Grown Vermouths With Character
description: THE way Andrew Quady saw it, vermouth was getting no respect. A few drops of dry vermouth are de rigueur in a martini, of course, as is a shot of the sweet variety in a Manhattan. And that was pretty much it.

title: Oracle Posts 31% Increase In Earnings
description: Confounding its critics, the Oracle Corporation reported revenues and earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter today that surpassed analysts' estimates.

title: Kosovo Landscape Lays Bare Serbs' Brutal Campaign
description: The Serbs' most brutal force in their campaign to drive out the Albanian majority from Kosovo fell on this city and a swath of villages around it in the shadow of the Accursed Mountains. Today, in a landscape of grave sites, burned homes, toppled mosque minarets and smashed shops, it became clear just how ferocious that campaign had been.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its NBC television network would invest an additional $25 million in the on-line direct marketing company Xoom.com Inc., potentially increasing NBC's stake in the NBC Internet venture to a majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESEROLE, HOLLIS N.
description: MESEROLE-Hollis N. (Jack). On June 11, 1999. Beloved uncle of Ronald and Russell Ploger. Memorial service will be at The Church of Saint Luke in the Field, 487 Hudson Street, NYC 10014, Saturday, June 19, 1999 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Jack's memory to The Church of Saint Luke in the Field.

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Scarsdale High Reopens After an E-mail Threat Closed It
description: Students at Scarsdale High School returned to the classroom today amid tightened security one day after officials there closed the school in response to an anonymous threat contained in an E-mail message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, CHARLES R.
description: KRAMER-Charles R. On June 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Karen (nee Gertzman) of NYC & Elmer, NJ. Loving father of Allyson (Chet) Knable and Hal (Cindy) Kramer. Dear son of Natalie K. (nee Gilbert) DeMarrais and the late Abe Kramer. Beloved brother of Alfred Kramer and Bayla Washburne. Adoring grandfather of Zachary Knable & Eric Knable. Graveside services Thursday, 3PM, Alliance Cemetery, Norma, NJ. Contributions International Leukemia Organization, 1907 Greentree Rd., Cherry Hill, NJ 08003. For Info. (Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ).

title: Muscovites Savor a Caper After Being Down So Long
description: As a military operation, it was insignificant. But as a symbol, there is no more potent metaphor for Russia's regard of the West than the image last weekend of 200 Russian soldiers seizing a Kosovo airfield, and then lining up armored personnel carriers to keep NATO troops out.

title: Year of the Donation
description: Buoyed by the stock market and sustained economic growth, private donors gave a record $18.4 billion to American colleges and universities in the 1998 academic year, according to the Council for Aid to Education.

title: F.B.I. Seizes City Records On Reservoirs
description: Responding to complaints that New York City officials had covered up the mishandling of hazardous materials in the water system, Federal agents swept through offices and buildings of the city's Department of Environmental Protection yesterday, seizing records and copying computer files.

title: Fair Share in Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Troopers' Union Torn Over Claims of Racism
description: Two months after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman issued a report confirming that the New Jersey State Police have routinely discriminated against minority drivers, the force was shaken by two new racial incidents today, when both the Acting Superintendent and the head of the officers' union came under fire for allegedly making offensive public comments about women, Latinos and blacks.

title: Abu Ghosh Journal; His Pot of Gold Gives a Sparkle to the Whole Town
description: Driving his gleaming black Cadillac through the rutted roads of this village outside Jerusalem, Jawdat Ibrahim talked about his miserable childhood. It was miserable even by the relatively abject standards of an Israeli Arab born 34 years ago in a country that considered him second class.

title: Editorial Observer; An Epidemic of Grins Hits the Granite State
description: George W. Bush is literally golden, with a ruddy glow that gives him the look of having been perfectly toasted. ''I know what matters is that a candidate have a positive, hopeful, upbeat, optimistic message,'' he said at a rally in New Hampshire this week, going on to assure the crowd that he himself was positive, hopeful, upbeat and optimistic as all get-out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATLIFF, FLOYD
description: RATLIFF-Floyd. The Rockefeller University community mourns with deep sadness the loss of our distinguished colleague and beloved friend, Floyd Ratliff. Dr. Ratliff was a pioneer in the study of the neural mechanisms of vision, particularly how the retina performs the task of analyzing and reducing the apparent chaos of incoming data. A valued member of The Rockefeller University community for more than 40 years, he will long be remembered for his contributions to the scientific understanding of the visual system, as well as for his deep commitment and skill as a teacher. Dr. Ratliff will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife and to his family. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard Fisher, Chairman Board of Trustees David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: With an Age Limit on Service, Hairdresser Faces City Action
description: A sign outside Michael Giovan, a small hair salon on East 53d Street, reads, ''Short Haircutting Specialist for Young Women,'' and the owner, Michael Jon Damico, means it. ''I'm very exclusive,'' said Mr. Damico, who acknowledged that he routinely turned away women over 25.

title: City Pays $59,000 to Settle Times Sq. Preaching Group's Suit
description: The Giuliani administration has agreed to pay $59,000 in an out-of-court settlement with a group of raucous street preachers who have been a fixture in Times Square for years and who sued the city last year, saying that the police had tried to stifle their message.

title: In School; Music Outreach's goal is to make young imaginations sing.
description: The cymbals crash, the bass drum booms, the lights flash and the students jump out of their seats, shouting with joy. When the West End Symphony's performance of ''Thunder and Lightning Polka'' by Johann Strauss Jr. is over, the auditorium at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College is a sea of 2,000 exuberant children 4 to 13.

title: Korean Fight At Sea Evolves Into Exchange Of Charges
description: An early morning firefight today in disputed waters in the Yellow Sea receded into a verbal clash, as North Korea demanded an apology and lashed out at South Korea for sinking one of its warships.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Curb Lawsuits From Year 2000 Bug
description: After months of partisan squabbling, the Senate approved legislation today that would limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures.

title: Trial Opens for Police Officer Who Shot a Squeegee Man
description: By the time the defense finished its opening arguments yesterday in the trial of Michael Meyer, a New York City police officer charged with shooting a so-called squeegee man a year ago, it had driven home several points. Officer Meyer had been a brave officer, decorated with a medal for valor. And Antoine Reid, the man he wounded, was a menacing nuisance with a crack habit and a criminal record.

title: Sports Wednesday: N.B.A. FINALS; Knicks vs. Spurs: A Preview
description: The Knicks have used adversity as their guidepost to the National Basketball Association finals. The San Antonio Spurs, on the other hand, have relied on a blending of exceptional talent to get that far. The two very different teams begin the four-of-seven-game championship series tonight in San Antonio. SECTION D

title: Jobless Rate Up to 4.7% In May;11-Month High
description: The unemployment rate in New Jersey rose to 4.7 percent in May, the highest level in almost a year, state labor officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: With Silicon Valley Bounty Comes Unease About Boom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JAMES G.
description: MURRAY-James G. The Capital Markets Credit Analysts Society notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of a dear friend and esteemed member. Jim will be remembered for the many contributions he made to the field of credit analysis. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Too Small and Too Few: It's All Just Too Perfect
description: The tumultuous parallel lives of the Knicks and the Spurs will cross on Wednesday night when the players duck out of the tunnel at the Alamodome and appear on the court of the National Basketball Association finals like lost twins reunited before a live audience.

title: CUNY Now Says Placement Tests Will Exclude Only 12% From Senior Colleges
description: Seeking to put a better face on their new remedial education policy, officials at the City University of New York revised an estimate yesterday on how many entering students would be excluded from bachelor's degree programs because they could not pass CUNY's placement tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

description: HEMPSTEAD - Eleanor Avery. Died on Saturday, June 12 at her home in New York City. The caused of death was cancer. Mrs. Hempstead was the daughter of the late Waldo Allard Avery of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and the niece of the late Sewell Lee Avery of Chicago, who died in the office of chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward & Co. She was married once, to the late David Bill Hempstead, who produced and wrote some notable motion pictures during the late 1940's and '50's. It was he who persuaded Ginger Rogers to accept her first dramatic role in his production of ''Kitty Foyle'', for which she won the Academy Award. The Hempsteads were divorced in 1949. In her later years, Mrs. Hempstead devoted herself to a number of philanthropies, and was a generous donor to the Bronx Zoo, Planned Parenthood, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mrs. Hempstead is survived by her two children, Avery Hempstead Lichtenstein of New York and Santa Fe, and a son, David Bill Hempstead IV of Pasadena, California.
