title: Foudy Is the U.S. Team's Renaissance Midfielder
description: Sometimes, the young girls approach her, and Julie Foudy sees a veil of surprise come over their faces. It is as if the girls had expected something larger than life from the United States women's soccer team, only to discover that their heroes are actually smaller than the balloons in the Macy's parade.

title: Soul Rhythms, not Gospel, In a Large Sacred Space
description: The soul-jazz organ style, practiced in Eastern Seaboard bars in the 1960's and 70's, is as ironclad as any sort of jazz ever played; few records of the genre transcend its cliches. But its esthetic limitations are counterbalanced by its inherent nature as a social music at a time when jazz was beginning a long withdrawal into intellectualism and concert halls. Even in the music's recycled life as samples that have shown up in dance tracks of the 90's, it's still made for the body.

title: Serb Troops Retreat By NATO Deadline
description: The Yugoslav military largely complied with NATO's demand to leave much of Kosovo by midnight yesterday, as thousands of soldiers withdrew from the Serbian province on tanks, trucks and tractors.

title: House Votes to Keep Limits on Number of Flights Into Kennedy and La Guardia
description: The House voted today to preserve limits on how many large commercial jets can fly into Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports every day, although, under the bill, small jets from small airports would fly in without restrictions beginning next March.

title: Ryder Names President
description: Ryder System Inc., a leading truck-leasing company, said today that it had named a former executive of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation as its president and chief operating officer, completing a management shake-up aimed at reversing a slide in earnings. The new president, Gregory T. Swienton, 49, was previously senior vice president at Burlington Northern, He will report to the chairman and chief executive, M. Anthony Burns, who is relinquishing the title of president. The chief operating officer position is new.

title: Pataki Lowers Bar for G.O.P. Presidential Primary
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Republican leaders are making it somewhat easier to obtain a spot on the ballot in the Republican Presidential primary in New York, responding to criticism that the party was trying to control these contests with arduous requirements that were a throwback to old-style machine politics.

title: Calendar
description: Restaurant Day and Week

title: Battle Over Internet Names Escalates
description: In the latest sign of escalating tension between the Internet's new oversight board and Network Solutions Inc., the company that controls the distribution and registration of Internet addresses, the board's interim chairwoman said today that the company was fostering unfounded criticism of her group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FAY, R.N.
description: COHEN-Fay, R.N. (nee Florence Silverman). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry, mother & motherin-law of Joel and Betty, Miriam & Jay. Adoring Bubbie of Michael, David & Scott, great grandmother of Madeline, loving sister, sister-inlaw, aunt and great aunt. Born in NYC on June 12, 1919, and died on June 15, 1999 in Clemmons, NC. Graduate of Bronx Lebanon School of Nursing, she worked with her husband in a Northeast Bronx family medical practice until his death in the mid 70's. Funeral Thursday June 17, 1999, at 10 A.M. at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Donations in her memory can be sent to The City of Hope, 30 West 26 Street, New York, NY 10010, for which she was a volunteer for many years.

title: CUBA
description: Six more baseball players have defected from Cuba, including two considered potential first-round draft picks. The players will go through tryouts before major league scouts next Thursday, Friday and Saturday in San Jose, Costa Rica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about Pope John Paul II's trip to Poland and his plan to visit the Patriarch of Armenia ended with an incomplete sentence. The passage should have read, ''While the Armenian patriarch is on good terms with Patriarch Aleksy II, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Aleksy is considered unlikely to change his steadfast refusal to meet with the Pope or invite him to Russia.''

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Unusual Dream Images Inspired by Some Furniture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Seattle Museum to Return Looted Work
description: The Seattle Art Museum will return a painting by Matisse to the heirs of a French Jewish art dealer from whom it was confiscated by the Nazis in 1941.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Victorian Women? From Mamet? Well, #@%*!
description: Move aside boys, with your gutter talk and con games and slovenly ways. It's girls' night out in Mametville, a time to give the other sex a chance to strut and fret its hour upon the stage. And don't expect a gaggle of tough broads with machine-gun mouths, either. These ladies are refined; they hang out in drawing rooms. And believe it or not, they talk as pretty as anyone out of Oscar Wilde.

title: Two Stars in a Brown Bag
description: TAKEOUT menus often seem so interchangeable that when something different comes along you can't help but take notice. That's the case with KUMQUAT , the dinner-delivery arm of Clementine in Greenwich Village, the two-star restaurant where John Schenk is the chef. His reputation for creativity alone makes it worth trying. While the menu is significantly simpler and less expensive than Clementine's, it offers unusual and intriguing selections.

title: Joseph Druffel, 60, Architect for the Poor
description: Joseph Druffel, a prolific architect of low-income housing in New York City for the last 25 years, died on Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on Thursday about quantum cryptography referred incorrectly to a new I.B.M. system. It is based on the different polarizations of photons, not protons.

title: A 10-Year Bet On Ken Burns
description: Contortions of envy may well ripple through the documentary filmmakers' world tomorrow. That is when General Motors plans to announce an unusual 10-year commitment to underwrite the future film projects of Ken Burns.

title: Serbian Orthodox Church Urges Milosevic and His Cabinet to Quit
description: In a rare direct challenge to President Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian Orthodox Church called for him to resign today, as Mr. Milosevic has thrown himself into an unusually energetic campaign to rally a disillusioned and depressed public.

title: TEREX AGREES TO ACQUIRE POWERSCREEN FOR $294 MILLION
description: The Terex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Powerscreen International P.L.C. for $294 million in cash to diversify its product lines. Powerscreen, of Dungannon, Northern Ireland, makes screens and crushers used to process quarried rock. Its shares rose 20 pence, to $191.5 pence. Terex, which is based in Westport, Conn., makes a range of construction and mining equipment. Powerscreen had sales of $362 million in the year ended March 31. Terex had sales of $1.23 billion in 1998. Terex's stock rose $1.5625, to $32.375.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about data showing strong Japanese first-quarter economic growth misstated the forecast of economists polled by Bloomberg News one day before the data were released. The forecast predicted the data would show Japan's economy had contracted by two-tenths of a percent, not eight-tenths of a percent.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Takes Top Honors
description: At the eighth annual show sponsored by the Association of Independent Commercial Producers in New York, paying tribute to work on television spots, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won the most honors in the agency category.

title: Preserving Culinary History
description: BETTY FUSSELL, a food writer best known for a book on the history of corn, says she often buys books rather than trying to use those in the New York Public Library. ''Everything is inaccessible,'' she said.

title: Ice Cream Truck Kills 8-Year-Old in Brooklyn
description: An 8-year-old boy died early yesterday morning after he was run over by an ice cream truck on his Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUFFEL, JOSEPH B.
description: DRUFFEL-Joseph B. Died June 11th, 1999, architect, graduate of University of Detroit. Survived by Sister Mary Hanaghan & brother Thomas H. Druffel and Linda Bresnahan long-time friend and companion also survived by Susan Sobey Druffel his sister-in-law and nephews Matthew and Michael Hanaghan and niece Mary Claire Hanaghan. Service Wed. 7PM, Church of St. Gregory the Great, 144 W. 90th St (Amsterdam Ave).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOPF, FRANK E.
description: KNOPF-Frank E. Of Manhattan. On June 15, 1999. Husband of the late Elsie. Loving father of David, Robert amd Richard Knopf. Dear brother of Frances Tremper and Helen Kames. Fond brother-in-law of Albert & Betty Melniker. Reposing Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, Thursday 10:30AM to 11:30AM. Funeral service 11:30AM. Interment Baron Hirsch Cemetery.

title: The Flower Was Never Just for the Bee
description: NASTURTIUMS in butter. Orchids in cheesecake. Rose petals with lobster.

title: In Death, a Pauper Finds Generosity
description: Jose Camacho was buried yesterday, not in the anonymous ground of a potter's field on Hart Island, where a city morgue was ready to send his unclaimed body last month, but in a grave of his own on the same hillside where Lou Gehrig, Tommy Dorsey, Ayn Rand and Sergei Rachmaninoff were laid to rest.

title: Goodman Straight Up, With a Twist of Lightning
description: Twenty-five years after jazz-repertory concerts became common occurrences, their logistics have become highly nuanced. At a concert honoring the work of a famous jazz composer, you often hear shrewd selections of little-known pieces strung together by a theme, or artful modern rearrangements of old favorites that steer familiar melodies through houses of mirrors. So Ken Peplowski's presentation of Benny Goodman's big-band music at the Kaye Playhouse, which opened the JVC Jazz Festival on Monday night, was a throwback to the beginning of the jazz repertory idea, when scholar-musicians simply gave an audience what it wanted.

title: A Spanish Old-Timer Where Garlic Is King
description: THE appeal of Sevilla, a venerable Spanish restaurant in Greenwich Village, is not hard to fathom. In fact, sometimes you can smell it a block away: garlic. Not just garlic, but GARLIC. Great clouds of it.

title: Senate Approves Bill On Year 2000 Bug
description: After months of partisan squabbling, the Senate approved legislation that would limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures. But the vote fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to override President Clinton's promised veto, which means further negotiations with the White House will be needed for the measure to become law.

title: Rangers' Chances Dim On Sealing Palffy Deal
description: The two general managers stood opposite each other outside the glass door of a hotel. Mike Milbury of the Islanders and Neil Smith of the Rangers stood near a brown trash can, its lid acting as a conference table. Behind the men was a wire fence that bore a red and white sign warning: Danger. Construction. Authorized Personnel Only.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Delta Air Lines' deferral of an order for 11 Boeing 777 aircraft because of a pay dispute with pilots misstated a comparison with other airlines. Delta's pilots have asked for $319 an hour to fly the 777, while Delta has offered them $239 an hour. Delta said its hourly figure, not the pilots', was 5 percent above what American Airlines pays its pilots, 25 percent higher than what United Airlines pays and 26 percent higher than Continental Airlines' rate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: When Push Comes to Shove, Gritty Sabres Get Even
description: A good Stanley Cup championship round took another determined step toward greatness tonight when the Buffalo Sabres evened the series at two games apiece with a 2-1 victory over the Dallas Stars in the happy bedlam of Marine Midland Arena.

title: Bush Draws Donations, And Conservatives' Fire
description: George W. Bush, the man in the monogrammed cowboy boots, reconnected tonight with the Yankee roots he so often plays down, at the end of a day on which his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination gave him his harshest taste yet of the political perils that lie along the campaign trail.

title: Serb Forces Continue Withdrawal, but Tension Remains
description: The Yugoslav military largely complied with NATO's demands to leave much of Kosovo by midnight Tuesday, with thousands of soldiers withdrawing on tanks, trucks and tractors.

title: Zucchini Bursts Into Bloom, And So Does a Cook's Imagination
description: MY kitchen counter had never looked so good. On top of my cutting board lay a great heap of flowers -- zucchini flowers. As large and pristine as lilies and as alive in color as tropical fruits, the blossoms looked like the remnants of a flower arranging session, not the lunch they would soon become.

title: CADENCE DESIGN AND ORCAD AGREE TO A $121 MILLION DEAL
description: Cadence Design Systems, a maker of software used to design computer chips, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the software supplier Orcad Inc. for $121 million in cash. Cadence will pay $13 for each share of Orcad, which is based in Beaverton, Ore. Orcad supplies software and services to electronics companies and had 1998 sales of $47.7 million. Cadence, with 1998 sales of $1.22 billion, said the deal would strengthen its computer-aided engineering and design operations. Cadence will also benefit from Orcad's recently announced Internet operations. Orcad's stock rose $3.125, to $12.625, while Cadence Design, which is based in San Jose, Calif., rose 25 cents, to $13.9375.

title: Don't Blame Teachers for Failings of Parents; Where One Learns
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: In Clinton, a New Place For Juice and Smoothies

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper prices slumped when the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia made no decision on closing three unprofitable mines. In New York, copper for July delivery fell 1.65 cents a pound, to 63.25 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: INSIDE
description: Koreas Trade Charges

title: Another Company Takes the 'Hong Kong' Out of Its Name
description: Score another one for globalism over localism. Hong Kong's local telephone company, Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., said today that it would change its name to Cable and Wireless HKT to tighten ties with its London-based parent company, Cable and Wireless P.L.C.

title: Residential Real Estate; A Mixed-Use Tower for Theaters and Apartments
description: Earth-moving equipment is to arrive next month at a huge vacant development site west of Eighth Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets to break ground for what will be the first new mixed-use high-rise of the decade in the far West 30's.

title: How the Knicks Turned Lemon Into Lemonade (and Maybe Champagne)
description: After the lockout came an unexpected trade. What followed were injuries, insecurities and an improbable run to the N.B.A. finals. By SELENA ROBERTS

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about the sodomy trial of former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim of Malaysia misstated the name of the Prime Minister. He is Mahathir Mohamad, not Mahathir Mahathir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CHARLOTTE TURK
description: WILLIAMS-Charlotte Turk. Remarkable woman whose sterling character, dedication to Jewish values and community service, and professional accomplishments deeply inspired her beloved family and friends. She served as a senior administrator in the U.S. Dept. of Labor and Coordinator of the Federal Regional Council. Her many charitable activities included leadership roles in the United Jewish Appeal, Hadassah, and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Charlotte's memory will forever be cherished by her brothers, Rabbi Dr. Samuel Turk and Herbert V. Turk; her children, Drs. Daniel and Marcia Williams, Drs. Naomi and Sylvain Weinberger; and her grandchildren, Harel, Marc, Stephen and Michael.

title: THE CHEF
description: SKATE is all about visual impact and texture. I love its dense, ropy flesh. It has a wonderful bite and flavor -- not as mild as sole but rather flavorful and meaty like monkfish. And it is also easy to cook.

title: Improved Woods Ready For a Serious Open Bid
description: At this point in Tiger Woods's young career, the United States Open is the major championship that has given him the most trouble.

title: GRUPO DINA PLANS TO SELL 61% STAKE IN MOTOR COACH UNIT
description: Consorcio G Grupo Dina S.A., a Mexican bus and truck maker, said yesterday that it would sell a 61 percent stake in its motor coach unit for $125 million to an investment group led by the New York-based Joseph Littlejohn & Levy Inc. as it seeks to lighten its debt load. Grupo Dina will keep 39 percent of the equity in the company, MCII Holdings Inc. of Des Plaines, Ill., which it said had revenue of about $1 billion and more than half the bus-making market in the United States and Canada. Joseph Littlejohn & Levy, which specializes in corporate revampings, said it intended to improve the unit's manufacturing operations, introduce new products, enter new geographic markets and expand the company's parts business.

title: Shareholders Charge Extortion in the Russian Far East
description: Foreign investors in the Far Eastern Shipping Company of Russia have accused a top politician of using extortion to try to wrest away their stakes in the concern, causing a shareholder rights scandal that is the latest of several to erode the weak faith remaining in the Russian equities market.

title: No Longer the Outsiders
description: The second day of training camp passed and Marcus Camby was spotted standing near the door of the gym while several teammates slipped by his lanky frame without two words to him.

title: ACX in Ceramics Spinoff
description: ACX Technologies Inc., which makes ceramics for the electronics industry and consumer-product packaging, said that it would spin off its Coors Ceramics Company subsidiary to focus its resources better in both businesses. Coors Ceramics, which had 1998 sales of $296.6 million, makes products for various industries. ACX Technologies, which had 1998 sales of $988.39 million, was formed by the Adolph Coors Company, the brewer, in 1992 and later spun off.

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Me, Me, Me: Self-Involved To a Fault
description: It's New Year's Day in Sag Harbor. After cranberry muffins for breakfast and brunch at the country club, Dennis is on one knee in the living room proposing marriage. His beeper sounds, and he dashes away to respond; after all, it's the President. Later he'll learn that he should have waited around for an answer -- or at least a reaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAN, JOHN J.
description: KEAN-John J., Msgr. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Peter Claver Church, Brooklyn, on June 13. Reposing in Queen of Peace Residence, 110-30 221st Street, Queens Village, on Wednesday, June 16, from 1 to 5 P.M. Mass of Transferral at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Therese of Lisieux Church, 1281 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, Thursday, June 17, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: W.N.B.A.: ROUNDUP -- LIBERTY; New York Ponders Its lack of Energy
description: It was one of those games that should have had the Liberty players oozing with emotion and intensity. But before a national television audience, and with its old coach and the league's most celebrated rookie as the opponent, the Liberty was flatter than a soda that had been left out too long.

title: From the Fringes To Everywhere; They Might Be Giants: On Film, the Web and TV
description: John Linnell answered the door of his bandmate John Flansburgh's work space in Williamsburg on Sunday with the slightly dazed grin of someone caught in the middle of the creative process. The two Johns, who make up the bravely offbeat pop duo They Might Be Giants, had been mixing songs in the room they call the kitchen, not because they think it is a cool rock name for a recording studio, but because that's where the stove was when Mr. Flansburgh lived there.

title: Planned Korean Share Issue Angers a Big U.S. Hedge Fund
description: A leading American hedge fund that has prominently invested in South Korea's rebounding economy is protesting a plan by the nation's biggest mobile phone operator to issue more shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, MARTIN G.
description: TAUB-Martin G. The National Conference for Community and Justice is deeply saddened by the passing of one of our respected leaders and former honoree of the Wine & Spirits Division. He was a long time friend and benefactor and we offer our deepest sympathy to his son David, and grandson Marc, along with the rest of the family. Wine & Spirits Division NCCJ Greater New YorK Region

title: Boom Mind-Set Deeply Etched in Chip Capital
description: In Silicon Valley these are the days of miracles and wonder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINERMAN NEWMAN, JANET
description: WEINERMAN NEWMAN-Janet. The League Treatment Center family extends our deepest sympathy to her dear sister Roberta Brodfeld and her family: her daughter Ivy Newman, husband Howard and their children April and Brian, and her daughter Randi German, husband Jay and their sons Kenny and Keith. We extend our sympathy to her loving mother Emma. A wonderful sister and loving mother, Janet was a gifted pianist who brought joy to all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MARION
description: MITCHELL-Marion. With deep sadness we note the passing of our beloved past President, past Treasurer, and first Emeritus member. Marion faithfully served the Auxiliary and the patients of Bellevue Hospital for 36 years. We shall miss her wise counsel and beautiful presence. Our heartfelt sympathy to her daughters Dr. Judith Gueron and Susan Mitchell and all her dear family. Jeanette E. MacDonald, President and the Board of Directors, Auxiliary to Bellevue Hospital

title: From Albania, Kosovars Begin Heading Back Home
description: More than 5,000 Kosovo Albanian refugees began a jubilant exodus back home today through this mountain border crossing controlled jointly by the Kosovo Liberation Army, the rebel group that fought Serbian forces in Kosovo, and NATO peacekeepers.

title: C.I.A.'s Artistic Enigma Yields All but Final Clue
description: It has stood in a courtyard inside the Central Intelligence Agency for almost a decade, a sculptural mystery inside an enigma.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Malvin dear I cannot believe it was 53 years ago/we became Audrey & Malvin. Miss you so very much. Love you forever. Audrey

title: Morgan 'Whistle Blower' Had Played Role Before
description: A self-styled whistle-blower whose dealings with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company put them both under criminal investigation has had a previous tussle with corporate America.

title: Gates Testifies, and the Republicans Seek to Forge Closer Links
description: Al Gore may not have invented the Internet, but he and President Clinton have honed their skills of extracting political contributions from Silicon Valley. Now, in a three-day ''High Tech Summit'' on Capitol Hill, Republicans are trying to show that they have the capacity to be even better friends of William H. Gates and his competitors.

title: A London Cook, A Global Perspective
description: I'M tired of gorgeous picture books that call for my very own kitchen staff before I can even get to the stove. I'm bored with over-the-top fusion cooking fatefully headed in the direction that spelled the decline of nouvelle cuisine.

title: 8 Charter Schools, 4 With Profit Goal, Are Picked by State
description: A state board selected the first eight charter schools for New York State yesterday, setting the stage for a new and hotly disputed system of taxpayer-financed schools operating outside the regular public school system. Four of them will be run by profit-making corporations, and one will be in a school building owned by a church.

title: Could Spurs Beat Bulls?
description: Steve Kerr, who played on the last three Chicago Bulls championship teams, likes his chances of winning a fourth straight title with the San Antonio Spurs. But Kerr, a 3-point shooting specialist, will not give his new team the edge over his old one.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: The Equitable Room?

title: Simple Salad, All Beefed Up
description: THE wonderful mesclun that is sold at some farm stands and Greenmarkets contains a variety of flavorful baby greens -- herbs, kale, dandelion, arugula, beet, turnip, mustard -- that have the potential for becoming a salad of great complexity.

title: Jackson Returning To Booth for ABC
description: Keith Jackson's brief retirement as the voice of college football for ABC Sports ended yesterday because he was asked to come back.

title: PRIVACY TALKS FAIL
description: The United States and the European Union failed to resolve a long-running dispute over privacy protection in electronic commerce. They had hoped for an agreement before President Clinton and the leaders of other industrialized nations met this weekend in Cologne, Germany. European officials rejected American proposals for a self-regulatory approach to corporate use of personal information. Under a European directive imposed in October, governments could theoretically be required to block companies from sending some information to the United States. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Sampras's First Victory: A Favorable Draw
description: The All England Club came up with a random draw for Wimbledon that yielded unremarkable first-round hurdles for the favorites, but after that, the hurdles turn complex for nearly everybody except top-ranked Pete Sampras. The five-time Wimbledon champion has to look all the way to the draw's other half to see anything resembling a grass-court ghost.

title: Rosa Parks Is Honored for Taking One Small Seat, One Giant Stand
description: Rosa Parks, the Alabama seamstress whose 1955 refusal to give up her seat on a Montgomery bus to a white man sparked the peaceful demonstrations of the civil rights movement, accepted Congress's highest honor today.

title: Drug Slashes Breast Cancer Risk, Study Shows
description: Final results of an international study reported yesterday show that a drug approved to fight the bone disease osteoporosis significantly decreased the risk of breast cancer among postmenopausal women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTOS, MARTHA V.
description: BARTOS-Martha V. The Trustees & staff of the Educational Alliance note with profound sadness the passing of Martha Bartos, our beloved Trustee and friend. Martha joined the Board in 1952 and remained active until her death. She was devoted to and a staunch advocate of the art school, camps, children's programs and our social services. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter Mary, her sons Armand and Michael and their wives, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Financial Competitors
description: Wasting no time in seeking to capitalize on the departure of Lou Dobbs from CNN's ''Moneyline'' program, CNBC announced yesterday that it was rushing to complete an expansion of its own evening financial news roundup to a full hour, from 30 minutes. Starting Monday, the program, ''Business Center,'' will begin at 6:30 weeknights, the same time as ''Moneyline.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, JAMES B.
description: BOSKEY-James B. On June 14, 1999, of North Caldwell, NJ. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of Elizabeth. Memorial service information may be found at www.iccbmt.org/memorial.htm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in James' memory to the Research Division of the Hospital for Special Surgery, NY City.

title: Mexican Chief Seeks to Insure A Nightmare Doesn't Recur
description: The former Mexican President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, was a political hero when he ended his term in 1994. But just a few weeks later, the peso dived, jobs and savings were annihilated, and Mr. Salinas was soon forced into disgrace and exile.

title: U.S. Offering Compromises On the Role of the Russians
description: In an effort to break an impasse over how Russian troops will operate in Kosovo, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen is to suggest to his Russian counterpart that the troops be allotted an ''area of responsibility'' within one of the five established NATO sectors, Administration officials said today.

title: In Woods of Georgia, Echoes of Balkan Terror
description: Hysnije Hoxha was studying the arrangement of spoons, fruits and other objects on a wooden table as her English teacher, Catherine Giller, circled vegetables around a wristwatch. ''Hysni,'' Ms. Giller asked, ''where is the watch?''

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 8 about the new Israeli Parliament referred imprecisely to Rabbi Chaim Druckman, a member of Parliament from the National Religious Party. While he did not serve in the last Parliament he is not a newcomer, having served from 1977 to 1988.

title: Union Settles Bias Lawsuit Over Jobs
description: The Iron Workers Union has agreed to pay $500,000 to 39 workers from minority groups to settle a longstanding Federal lawsuit contending that white workers were consistently given more, and better, construction jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARTI, IBANEZ, FELIX
description: MARTI-IBANEZ-Felix. A twentyseventh Memorial Mass in loving memory of Dr. Felix Marti-Ibanez will be celebrated at the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral on June 17th at 3 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBY, JAMES E.
description: APPLEBY-James E. III. Of New York City. Son of James E. & Susan L. Appleby, Jr., brother of Mark D. Services 10:30 AM Friday, Church of the Brethren, Mechanicsburg, PA. Visitation Thursday 7-9 PM, Malpezzi Funeral Home, Mechanicsburg. Memorials to Middlebury College Scholarship Fund, Middlebury, VT. 05753.

title: DNA Test Brings Freedom, 16 Years After Conviction
description: Just before he was sentenced to life in prison for a rape he did not commit, Calvin C. Johnson Jr. told the judge that his moment of redemption would one day come.

title: Drug Coverage Dominates Fight Brewing on Medicare
description: Senator Paul Wellstone talks about elderly Minnesotans forced to travel across the border to Canada to buy affordable prescription drugs. Representative Tom Allen of Maine talks about an elderly woman who stopped taking her medications because her husband was sicker than she was and they could not afford prescriptions for two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, PHILIP
description: ADELMAN-Philip. Born Busko, Poland, May 29th, 1897 and passed away quietly at home on June 14th, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Bella, devoted father of the late Stanley, and loving father-inlaw of Mary, cherished grandfather of Frederica and Anne, an inspiration to great grandchildren, Jacob, Amy and Isabel. Services at 11 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. & 76 St.

title: Subway Station Is Shut, But 'Bomb' Is Diaper Bag
description: The 72d Street subway station on the West Side was closed for more than an hour yesterday because of a false alarm over a possible bomb that turned out to be a diaper bag, the police said. The 1, 2 and 3 trains bypassed the station, one of the busiest in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINER, GLORIA B.
description: HEINER-Gloria B. On Sunday, June 13, 1999; age 77, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; wife of George Marshall Heiner; mother of Lynda G. Jamison & Susan G. Robinson, both of Pittsburgh, PA, George M. Heiner of Sierra Vista, AZ., and Nathaniel S. Heiner of Bethesda, MD. Funeral service is Thursday, 10:30 AM, Shadyside Presbyterian Church, Pittsburgh, PA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, Inc., 919 North Michigan, Suite 1100, Chicago, IL. 60611-1676. For further information contact H. Samson, Inc., 412-621-2800.

title: Arts Grants Awarded
description: Twenty-one public schools and 54 cultural organizations in New York City will receive a total of $3 million from a nonprofit group, the Center for Arts Education, for an array of arts programs from music to art to dance to video.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; N.A.S.D., in a joint venture in Japan, moves to create an around-the-clock, global stock market.
description: THE National Association of Securities Dealers took a big step yesterday toward the creation of an around-the-clock, global stock market with the announcement that it would team up with the Softbank Corporation to develop a version of its electronic Nasdaq Stock Market in Japan to trade United States and Japanese stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DEENA SUSAN
description: SCHWARTZ-Deena Susan. July 15, 1948-June 16, 1998. Today marks one year that you are gone but true love is everlasting. We will always miss you. Mom and Dad

title: From Alpine Italy, a Selected Short Subject
description: THE Val d'Aosta is Italy's tiniest region, a mere smidgen wedged tightly between the French and Swiss Alps. Compared with Tuscany, or even Liguria, it is a small voice in Italy's grand culinary opera, but it does have a song to sing. At La Grolla, on the Upper West Side, it gets an appropriately small stage on which to deliver it.

title: BOISE CASCADE IN DEAL TO EXTEND ITS DISTRIBUTION OUTLETS
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Furman Lumber Inc. for an undisclosed price to extend its distribution outlets across the United States. Furman owns 12 centers that sell wood products to lumber dealers, home-improvement retailers and industrial customers in the East, South and Midwest. Most of Boise Cascade's 16 distribution centers are in the West. Furman, based in Billerica, Mass., had fiscal year 1999 sales of $574 million. Boise Cascade, based in Boise, Idaho, said sales from its distribution system had increased 44 percent since 1995, to $861 million last year. The company had sales of $6.16 billion in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEBER, ELIZABETH P.
description: HOEBER-Elizabeth P. (Betty). Widow of Paul B. Hoeber, died at the age of 92 after a brief illness in her home in Oakland, Ca. on June 12, 1999. Born in Columbus Oh., she is survived by her sons, Paul of San Francisco, and Tom of Gold Hill, Or., and two grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: TURNING POINT FOR TRADE GROUP
description: The search for a new chief of the World Trade Organization is likely to be scotched and a new effort undertaken after the search committee of the organization failed to agree on either candidate, Supachai Panitchpakdi of Thailand or Mike Moore of New Zealand, representatives to the 134-nation group said in Geneva. Ali Mchumo of Tanzania, the head of the search committee, is ''at the end of his tether,'' one trade envoy said. The trade group has been without a leader since Renato Ruggiero of Italy completed his four-year term April 30.

title: Maligned Threesome See Pointing Fingers
description: Avery Johnson has been released seven times during his 11-year career. He was out of work when he was wearing a tuxedo at David Robinson's wedding.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASILE, ALFRED
description: BASILE-Alfred. Happy Birthday. Memories of you sustain me through the lonely days. Mario

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pat

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES TO BUY YANKEE GAS FOR $478 MILLION
description: Northeast Utilities said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Yankee Energy System for $478 million in cash and stock to expand into natural gas sales as its electricity markets open to competition. The offer values Yankee Energy at $45 a share, a 38 percent premium to Monday's closing price. Yankee Energy shareholders will get 55 percent in cash and 45 percent in stock. Northeast Utilities will also take on $201 million in debt. Shares of Yankee rose $7.43, to $38.93. Northeast Utilities shares fell 6.25 cents, to $17.25. Yankee Energy, with sales of $314.8 million in the 1998 fiscal year, has 183,000 gas customers in Northeast Utilities' service area in Connecticut. Northeast Utilities, which is based in Berlin, Conn., said no major layoffs were expected.

title: Kosovo Forces Retake a Town, Armed With Roses and Sad, Wan Smiles
description: The Kosovo Liberation Army took Glogovac this morning, holding an impromptu victory stroll down the ruined main street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Danone Glass Stake Sale
description: Danone S.A., Europe's No. 3 food company, said it was selling a 56 percent stake in its glass packaging arm to a management team backed by CVC Capital Partners, Europe's largest management buyout company, for about 4 billion francs ($630 million). Danone is spinning off BSN Emballage, ceding the controlling stake in it to CVC Capital while retaining 44 percent. The new company will be headed by Danone's Daniel Melin and his existing management team.

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Yes, I'm The Problem
description: Here's something that I've noticed: Good things happen when I'm not there. Coincidence? I think not.

description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

description: NEWS

description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Foundering, A Team Discovers Its Grand Spotlight
description: A very astute friend of mine made an interesting observation the other day. She compared the Knicks to the Olympic figure skater, Nancy Kerrigan, who once took a well-timed whack to the knee and then went on to the performance of her life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: U.S. Ports to Stay Open in Jan. 1, 2000
description: The Coast Guard said today that it will not close American ports on Jan. 1, reducing the probability that shipping will be disrupted by the Year 2000 computer problem.

title: Don't Blame Teachers for Failings of Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing to a New Health Care Beat; Latin America Becomes Ripe For U.S. Companies' Picking
description: Millions of people across Latin America are, for better or worse, getting a taste of American-style health insurance. Pushed by the rising expectations of a growing middle class, countries in the region are opening their government-dominated health systems to private companies, both domestic and foreign.

title: Business Travel; If you're going where the tracks go, the train can be a realistic, pleasant alternative to air travel.
description: OF course, the train doesn't have anywhere near the reach of the plane. But for business travelers who happen to be headed where the train tracks go, the railroad offers a realistic alternative to the dread airport departure lounge.

title: Strong A.B.A. Flavor Adds Spice to Finals
description: This is the Knicks' seventh visit to the National Basketball Association finals, but the first for the San Antonio Spurs, and the first by one of the four American Basketball Association teams swallowed up by the N.B.A. in 1976.

title: Politicizing the City Charter
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's plan to revise New York City's Charter is a political power play and a terrible civics lesson. The Mayor announced a new Charter Revision Commission yesterday that he hopes will consider what happens if he leaves office early. Under the current Charter, Public Advocate Mark Green would become the Mayor, and Mr. Giuliani clearly does not want one of his most vocal critics to take over if he is elected to the United States Senate next year.

title: Giuliani Looks Again at Charter, and a Foe
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had appointed a new commission to revise the City Charter, saying that he wanted to ''improve the process of government'' but leaving little doubt that he had a more precise goal: to deny Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, the right to succeed him automatically if he is elected to the Senate.

title: Rams Interview Hofstra's Coach
description: Jay Wright, the men's basketball coach at Hofstra for the last five seasons, was interviewed yesterday by Fordham's athletic director, Frank McLaughlin, for the head coaching position that opened last week when Nick Macarchuk left to coach at Stony Brook after 12 years at Fordham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MARION K.
description: MITCHELL-Marion K. Died in her sleep in her Manhattan home on Monday night, June 14, 1999. During her 88 years, her fierce devotion to Albert, her adored husband of 61 years, and to their family forged unbreakable bonds. She was a strong and elegant woman who loved travel, theatre, and New York City. She held on to her zest for living and fun until the end. Her memory will be cherished by her family and friends. She is survived by her daughters, Susan Mitchell of San Francisco & Judy Gueron of New York City, her grandchildren, Jonathan and Lincoln Mitchell, Michele Cohen and Nicole Gueron, their loving spouses, and her newborn great grandson Asher Sanders Mitchell. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Av at 76 St., Thurs, June 17 at 11:15 am.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are some people who are making the case that the Internet has changed the law of physics. But this is still a Newtonian world, and when you throw something up in this world, it's going to come down. ''

title: Times Square to Get New TKTS Booth
description: Among architectural icons, the jungle-gym-style TKTS booth at the epicenter of greater Times Square ranks among the most instantly recognizable and exuberant landmarks in the city.

title: Not From Mars or Venus But a Little Ol' Planet
description: THE MALE BODY

title: Henderson Leads Way As Mets Hit Six Homers
description: Rickey Henderson has two trademarks: the stolen base and the leadoff home run. Make that three, if you count the way Henderson always picks at his uniform jersey leaving the batter's box when he knows he has just hit a home run.

title: Bicoastal Bidding Ends; Jackson Goes to Lakers
description: The Nets offered him wheelbarrows of cash and the Knicks sold him on their future during a clandestine meeting. But in the end, Phil Jackson decided that the combination of Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant beat anything the New York metropolitan area offered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASE, VINCENT T.
description: CASE-Vincent T., Reverend Monsignor. Pastor of the Immaculate Conception and Assumption Churches, the Catholic Community of Tuckahoe, died on June 13, 1999 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was born in New York City on May 4, 1932, son of Lillian Marinelli and Philip P. Case. He attended P.S. 61 and 64 in Manhattan and Cardinal Hayes High School, Cathedral Prep, Cathedral College and St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers. He received a Master's Degree in Pastoral Counseling from Iona College after his ordination. He was ordained on May 31, 1958 in St. Patrick's Cathedral by Cardinal Francis Spellman and celebrated his first Mass the next day at the Church of St. Brigid in lower Manhattan. He served at St. Joseph's Church in Spring Valley from 1958 to 1964 and Corpus Christi Church in New York City from 1964 to 1976. He was appointed administrator of Our Lady of Grace Church, the Bronx in October 1976 and was appointed pastor there in 1981 and served until 1993 when he was appointed pastor of St. Bartholomew's Church, Yonkers, NY. On September 14, 1997, he became pastor of the Immaculate Conception and Assumption Churches in Tuckahoe, New York. Monsignor Case is the beloved brother of Paul Case of Hudson, New Hampshire and Lillian Guilbert of Larchmont, New York. He is the cherished uncle of Carol Ann Gelfer, Germaine Sullivan, Philip Case, Maureen Grier, Vincent Case and James Case. He is also survived by nine grand nieces and nephews. Monsignor Case will repose at Immaculate Conception Church Thursday, June 17 from 1:30-7:00 PM. Mass of the Holy Eucharist, 7:30 PM. Most Reverend Patrick J. Sheridan, Vicar General, Celebrant. Father James E. Burke, Pastor of Sacred Heart Church, Staten Island, NY, Homilist. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, June 18 at 10 AM. His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York, Celebrant. Father Lamont R. Hamilton, Pastor of the Church of the Holy Rosary, Bronx, NY, Homilist. Friends may contribute to Little Sister of the Poor, 3200 Baychester Avenue, Bronx, New York 10475 or the Covenant House, 427 West 52 Street, New York, NY 10019. For more information contact Westchester Funeral Home, 914-337-4585.

title: Real Estate Executive Accused of Loan Fraud
description: The president of a Red Bank real estate company became the seventh person yesterday to be charged in what Federal prosecutors are calling a scheme to grossly inflate the value of dilapidated apartments in Asbury Park and other New Jersey cities.

title: Dave Douglas and Mingus Band Lead Jazz Laureates
description: Dave Douglas, Sonny Rollins, Herbie Hancock and others are winners of the second annual Jazz Awards, announced Monday night in a benefit ceremony at the South Street Seaport Atrium. Voters for the awards include journalists who write about jazz, members of the recording industry and musicians.

title: Suburban Districts Seen as a Key In the Debate Over Gun Control
description: As the House prepared for a high-stakes, heavily lobbied debate on youth violence and guns, President Clinton and pro-gun forces vied fiercely today for the votes of a critical group of lawmakers from swing districts who could decide the outcome of gun-control measures.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Don't Get Angry, Just Walk Away

title: An Unconfirmed Bid for Caesars Casinos
description: The self-described owner of the world's biggest pornographic Web site, Ocean Fund International, contended yesterday in a release on PR Newswire that it had offered to buy the eight Caesars casinos from Park Place Entertainment for $3.6 billion in cash.

title: Dow Advances by 31.66; Inflation Data Are Awaited
description: Stocks inched higher yesterday in thin, convictionless trading in advance of an important inflation report scheduled to be released this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIGERMAN, JOEL
description: SEIGERMAN-Joel. The entire staff of Chavin Lambert Advertising is extremely saddened at the untimely passing of Joel Seigerman, loving father of our esteemed colleague and Senior Vice President, Jill Seigerman. He was a beloved principal, teacher and friend to many. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, daughters, son and grandson. Nick Chavin Lanny Lambert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, WALTER E.
description: MALONEY-Walter E. Of Convent Station on June 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Hilda Ruppert Maloney. Father of James Maloney of Chatham, John F. Donohoe of Short Hills, Thomas Maloney of Houston, TX, Claire D. O'Mara of New Vernon, Edgar Donohoe of New Vernon, Katheryn D. Schuessler of Doylestown, PA, William R. Donohoe of Cherry Hill, Anne D. Goldsmith of Morristown, Dr. Michael J. Donohoe of DeLand, FL, Walter Maloney of Cranford, Peter B. Maloney of Bozeman, MT, and the late Thomas Donohoe. Brother of Mary M. Sargent of Bronxville, NY. Also survived by 43 grandchildren and 19 great grandchildren. A Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at St. Thomas More Church, Madison Ave., Convent Station on Thursday, June 17, 1999 at 10:30 AM. Friends may call at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St. (Rt.124), Chatham, NJ, on Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Walter E. Maloney Scholarship Fund, Delbarton School, Morristown, N.J. 07960.

title: Women and Software
description: Douglass College, a pioneer in breaking down stereotypes that have deterred many women from pursuing a science education, is enlisting 24 senior Girl Scouts from 18 states in confronting a new barrier: computer software that seems tailored only for young men.

title: Liberties; Freudian Face-Off
description: Al Gore is the Tin Man: immobile, rusting, decent, badly in need of that oil can.

title: Sizing Up the Series: 8 Keys for 7 Games
description: In the lockout-shortened regular season, San Antonio and the Knicks never crossed paths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNICK, ADELE
description: TUNICK-Adele. Of Aurora, CO. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of Kenneth, Leslie Frisbie, Mitchell and Marc. Dear sister of Ruth Rich, Gladys Goldstein and Eleanore Miller. Loving grandmother. Services Sunday, 12:30, at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, N.J. Information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Bad form by the client? Or by an agency? It's a matter of perspective as Budget ends its review.
description: A FUNNY thing happened on the way to the end of a review for a large advertiser's creative account: the company and two agencies traded conflicting versions of the final rounds.

title: FRENCH BANK BIDS
description: The hostile bid by Banque Nationale de Paris for two other French banks, Societe Generale and Paribas, is expected to be raised when its board meets today. The move would be a response to Societe Generale's raising of its own bid for Paribas, to $21 billion. Societe Generale and Paribas, which had agreed to a merger, are trying to thwart a subsequent bid made by Banque Nationale, which offered $38 billion for both banks. Uniting all three institutions would create the world's largest bank in terms of assets. On Monday, Societe Generale sweetened its original offer to exchange five of its shares for eight Paribas shares by adding a $78 cash payment. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Earthquake Kills 14 in Mexico And Injures Dozens in Puebla
description: A strong earthquake rattled central Mexico today, killing at least 14 people and injuring dozens as buildings collapsed in and around the capital of Puebla state, east of Mexico City, authorities said.

title: In a Crisis, Coke Tries to Be Reassuring
description: Corporate executives live in fear of what happened to the Coca-Cola Company. Following reports that scores of Belgian children fell ill after drinking the company's trademark beverage, the Governments of France, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands ordered bans on Coke products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Tricked by the Knicks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN IS IN $650 MILLION DEAL
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the biotechnology company Sugen Inc. in a $650 million stock transaction that would bolster Pharmacia's development of cancer drugs. Pharmacia, based in Bridgewater, N.J., will exchange $31 of its stock for each Sugen share. Sugen has no drugs on the market currently. It is testing drugs aimed at shrinking tumors by blocking angiogenesis, the natural process whereby the body forms new blood vessels. Sugen, which is based in San Francisco, is 20 percent owned by the British drug maker AstraZeneca Group P.L.C., which said it would vote its shares in favor of the acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Volkswagen Gives DDB More Work
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with DDB Worldwide Communications Group, part of Omnicom Group, by awarding the agency's New York office the North American duties for the Bentley luxury-car brand. Billings for the account were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: TALKS ON IRON ORE
description: The world's second-biggest mining company, Rio Tinto P.L.C. of Britain, said it was talking to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia about merging their iron ore operations. Speculation has been rising that the two might merge their iron ore assets in Western Australia in a bid to expand in the $10-billion-a-year worldwide iron ore export industry. Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil accounts for a quarter of international iron ore trade.

title: Republican Mischief on Gun Control
description: House Republican leaders have already forgotten Speaker Dennis Hastert's pledge last month to support ''common-sense'' gun control. Instead of moving to strengthen and expand upon the handful of gun control initiatives heading for votes on the House floor this week, G.O.P. leaders have worked out a scheme to make it easier for lawmakers who take their cue from the National Rifle Association to vote against meaningful reform.

title: Coke Products Are Ordered Off the Shelves in Four Countries
description: In the biggest recall in Coke history, the Governments of France, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands have ordered products from the Coca-Cola Company off their shelves after dozens of people who drank the soft drinks became ill.

title: LOWER PRICE FOR NEWCOURT
description: The proposed $9 billion purchase of the Newcourt Credit Group, a commercial and consumer finance company based in Toronto, by CIT Group is unlikely to proceed as planned, the companies said. Newcourt reported lower-than-expected first-quarter profit in May, and CIT has reopened acquisition talks. CIT, based in Livingston N.J., had agreed to swap 0.92 of a share for each share of Newcourt. The shares of Newcourt have fallen from $26.625 at the time of the announcement in March to $15.125 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Peter Castenfelt, a financier who recently held secret talks with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, misstated his nationality. While he owns a London financial company, Mr. Castenfelt is Swedish, not British.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Just as the voluptuous proportions of the old Barbie dolls were criticized for setting unrealistic standards for young girls, Harvard researchers now say that the muscularity of GI Joe and Star Wars dolls may be creating a Barbie Syndrome for boys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Learning From the Ottomans
description: In the Balkans, the absence of war is only half a peace. The troops are in, but what then for Kosovo and Serbia, Albania and Macedonia? How long will the soldiers have to stay to maintain faith in peace tomorrow, too? Five years? Ten? Early in the conflict, Mirjana Markovic, Slobodan Milosevic's wife, publicly bequeathed the Serbian struggle in Kosovo to a generation as yet unborn. Thirty years, maybe?

title: Despite Gains by Opposition, Indonesian Race Is Uncertain
description: Even as the main opposition party appeared to be solidly ahead in the slow vote count one week after the parliamentary election, analysts today predicted a hard-fought battle for Indonesia's presidency later this year.

title: Hot-Hitting Davis and Jeter Demolish Rookie Pitcher
description: History dictated that Ryan Glynn never had a chance. For the Texas Rangers' right-hander to notch his first major league victory, he had to outpitch David Cone. Sixteen previous pitchers had sought their first victory when they faced the Yankee ace. Their record? 0-12.

title: Alienating Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Redemption Time: It's Up to You, New York
description: For most of the century as the Babe consumed everything and Sam Huff knocked down everybody and then Clyde and Dollar Bill created perfect harmony, the rest of the country came to hate New York teams. Justifiably.

title: Refuge for Kosovars in Serbian Monastery, After the Burning and Looting
description: As Serbian forces withdrew from western Kosovo, some of them burning and looting as they retreated, Father Iguman and Father Sava moved among them, asking them to spare the houses of their neighbors and bringing terrified Albanians here, to this revered Serbian Orthodox monastery near Pec.

title: Treatment Rooted in Culture; Tying Drug and Alcohol Programs to Immigrants' Backgrounds
description: For years, Mohammed Arif denied he had a drinking problem. He saw himself as an immigrant success story: he had mastered a new language, earned enough to support relatives back in his native Pakistan and fit right in when his fellow construction workers hit the bars at the end of the day.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * The Serbian Orthodox Church called on President Slobodan Milosovic to resign for the good of Yugoslavia.

title: Dead Man on Subway Is Still a Mystery
description: A man found dead on Monday morning on a Manhattan subway train has not been identified, and officials were still uncertain yesterday how he died, where he got on the train and exactly how long he was dead before anyone noticed.

title: It Isn't Over Until the Wedding Singer Sings
description: MICHAEL CORVINO wanted to sing opera from the time he was 18 and his voice teacher at City College gave him tickets to ''Aida.''

title: Building the Peace in Kosovo -- and in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson's Status Remains Uncertain for Game 1
description: Though Larry Johnson has been receiving round-the-clock treatment on his sprained right knee, he was unsure yesterday what his chances were of playing tonight.

title: Sahara Impasse: Line in Sand or National Border?
description: The sun beats down ever more harshly as summer approaches, raising noontime temperatures above 130 degrees. The desert is silent, the only movement tumbleweed blown by oven-hot gusts.

title: New Management for the Nuclear Labs
description: The Energy Department, in charge of America's nuclear weapons labs for the past two decades, has proved incapable of assuring security or effective management at these vital facilities. The Department's prolonged failure to pursue serious nuclear espionage allegations at Los Alamos and its resistance to last year's White House directive on improving security are only the latest alarming examples of a deep-rooted institutional problem. That is the scathing conclusion reached by a Presidential advisory board after a three-month review with full access to classified material. The board rightly recommends reorganizing nuclear weapons programs to establish clear lines of accountability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGANA, PHILIP E.
description: LAGANA-Philip E., Honorable, New York State Supreme Court Justice, on June 15, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife, Josephine (nee Schiro). Loving brother of Francis Lagana. Brother-in-law of Marian & Louis Modica. Beloved uncle of Dr. Gregory and Tish Lagana, Lorraine and Knick Irving, Janine and George Simeon, Dr. Charles and Lisa Modica, Lorraine & Anthony Schmidt and Dr. John and Christine Modica. Entombment Resurrection Mausoleum, Saint John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Brooklyn Law School will be appreciated.

title: Money Talks, If They Can Still Walk
description: Once, they were world champions spending money that never stopped. Now, as they come together, men in their 40's, they are hoping the sporting world will still want to watch them -- and pay for it.

Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: N.B.A. FINALS: NOTEBOOK; Telecast at the Garden
description: Madison Square Garden will have a live telecast of Game 1 tonight on a big screen at the arena. Tickets are $15 each and can be purchased at the Madison Square Garden box office, at Ticketmaster on-line (www.ticketmaster.com) and via Ticketmaster charge-by-phone.
