Lemos, Nicholas P. Lygnos, Penelope, Nicholas & Irene G. Lygnos. Reposing at McCagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ, Thursday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Friday at St. John the Theologian Cathedral, 353 East Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ 11:30 AM.

title: Floyd Ratliff Is Dead at 80; Linked Visual Arts to Science
description: Dr. Floyd Ratliff, a physiological psychologist and biophysicist who explored the depths of consciousness and perception, died on Sunday in Santa Fe, N.M., where he moved after retiring from Rockefeller University in New York. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, CELIA
description: LANE-Celia (nee Goldstein). On Sunday, June 13, 1999. Of Lake Hiawatha, formerly of Jersey City. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morris Lane. Devoted mother of Kenneth Lane, Heldentenor, and Dr. Benjamin Lane. Services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Drama Confronts an Awfully Familiar Bias
description: In Act II of ''Spinning Into Butter,'' the new play by Rebecca Gilman at the Goodman Theater here, the protagonist delivers a speech that has been stunning audiences into silence. The character, a well-meaning college dean named Sarah Daniels, has been unable to parse the tricky grammar of race relations in academia. At last her frustration explodes into an anguished monologue about her failure to accept black people, even after years of immersion in the doctrine of inclusion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Don't Blame Teachers for Failings of Parents; Testing Isn't a Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCHELLI, VINCENT
description: FORCHELLI-Vincent. Attorney. In Astoria. Suddenly on June 15, 1999. Dear father of Charles N., John F., and Kathleen Goode. Cherished grandfather of seven. Reposing at Farenga Funeral Home, 38-08 Ditmars Boulevard, Long Island City on Wednesday 7 to 9PM and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Religious service Friday 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFFER, DORIS RANKIN
description: SAFFER-Doris Rankin. On June 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Alfred Saffer. Loving mother of Bonnie Bernard and Linda Harris. Dear sister-in-law of Ben Wertkin. Cherished grandmother to Bianca, Marshall, Mackenzie, Betsy, Nicole and Bradley. Services Wednesday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Doris Rankin Saffer Memorial Fund, C/O Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Chancellor Leaving
description: The chancellor of the University of Texas system, William H. Cunningham, has announced that he will step down next year, probably to go into business.

title: Here's a Story. . . .
description: Though word has leaked out all over the television industry, NBC News refused yesterday to make official the news that it has hired as a co-host of its planned ''Later Today'' program no less a cultural icon than Florence Henderson, the once and forever mother Brady of ''The Brady Bunch'' and onetime purveyor of ''Wessonality'' in a memorable series of television commercials for Wesson Oil.

title: Ralph Lauren Wins Fragrance Award
description: The Fragrance Foundation in New York has presented its 27th annual Fifi awards, which include honors for fragrance advertising.

title: Not Even Hope Flowers In a Village of the Dead
description: Ajrulah Ramadani woke up early today in Albania, packed a small plastic bag of clothes and came back to Kosovo. He is a relatively prosperous man who lived here on a farm with his three brothers and their families -- 43 people in all -- and he wanted to see if anything was left.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR PARES ITS GAINS. The dollar gave up gains against the Japanese yen as investors moved out of United States assets ahead of a consumer price report. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.40 yen, down from 120.62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTTEN, WILLIAM EDWARD
description: TOTTEN-William Edward, 69. Of Key West, Florida on June 14, 1999. The son of Hazel Cook and John J. Totten (both deceased). He was born May 17, 1930 in NYC. Mr. Totten was Advertising Manager for several menswear divisions of Burlington Industries following his initial work experience as an NBC Page and Manager of NBC-TV Guide Staff at Rockefeller Center. He loved old houses and renovated a number of them as primary residences in Sag Harbor with his friend and long time companion, Richard R. Reynolds. Survived by his brother, John J. Totten Jr. of Rockville Centre, NY, nephews John J. Totten II of Littleton, CO., and Edward Totten of NYC, a niece Donna Schwartz of Seattle, Wa. & close cousin Hazel ''Teddy'' Grote of Melbourne, FL.

title: TOYOTA PREFERS CHINA
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation announced in Shanghai that it could start producing cars with the Tianjin Automotive Industry Company by 2001, anticipating a rise in private car ownership in China. Atsushi Sakamoto, Toyota's representative in Beijing, said the venture would produce 30,000 Toyota Corollas with 1.3-liter engines in its first year. Separately, a Toyota official based in Europe said the company had abandoned a plan to open a truck assembly plant in Russia because of economic and political instability there.

title: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY ACTIVE TOOL FOR $317.5 MILLION
description: Tower Automotive Inc., a leading maker of automobile panels and frames, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Active Tool and Manufacturing Company, a frame-parts producer, for $317.5 million to broaden its product line. The closely held Active Tool and an affiliate, the Active Products Company, have offices and factories in Michigan. Active had sales last year of $320 million to the Big Three auto makers. Tower, which had $1.8 billion in sales last year, is based in Grand Rapids, Mich. Its shares rose $1.25, to $23.1875.

title: Sotheby's and Amazon Join On Internet Auction Site
description: Five months after Sotheby's announced a $25 million initiative to begin its own on-line auction business, it has entered into an alliance with Amazon.com. The two will begin selling art and collectibles later this year.

title: Touch of Flu Leads Pope to Cancel Mass for Million Poles
description: Stunning the million Poles who were waiting for him in a rain-soaked meadow, Pope John Paul II canceled all his planned appearances today, sick with what the Vatican said was a temperature of 100.4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: CUNY: The Big Picture
description: As one of the largest universities in the nation, the City University of New York encompasses 11 four-year colleges, 6 community colleges and an array of graduate and professional programs from law to biomedicine. CUNY's John Jay College of Criminal Justice and Hunter College's School of Social Work are ranked among the top in the nation. But a task force led by Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the former Yale University president, painted a very different picture this month--a picture of an institution with a shrinking and aging faculty, an administration hobbled by mistrust and confusion and above all, an ill-prepared student body requiring too many hours of remedial instruction and far too many years to graduate. Still, a closer look at some key statistics suggests that the picture is not entirely bleak and that CUNY shares many characteristics, both positive and negative, with other universities. TOM ZELLER

title: Former Municipal Union Leaders Indicted on Vote Fraud Charges
description: In the latest indictments involving District Council 37, New York City's giant municipal union, two men who had been among its most powerful officials were charged yesterday with fixing a 1996 contract ratification vote. One of the two officials was also charged with stealing $1.6 million in union funds.

title: Accounts
description: * Kovel/Fuller, Los Angeles, was awarded two accounts: Health Network, Los Angeles, a new cable TV and Internet network that is part of Fox Entertainment Group, owned by News Corporation, with billings estimated at $10 million, and Pairgain Technologies, Irvine, Calif., a phone-equipment maker, with billings estimated at $7 million. Health Network had no previous agency; Pairgain had been at 2 by 4, Campbell, Calif.

title: BOEING JET ORDER
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, the world's biggest airline leasing company, ordered 50 of the Boeing Company's 737 jets and tentatively ordered 50 more. The list price for the first 50 is about $2.4 billion, but the usual discount for big customers was said to have been even larger because Boeing wanted to announce the order at the Paris Air Show. Steven F. Udvar-Hazy, the chief executive of International Lease, which is part of American International Group, would not comment on prices, but said, ''Timing is important when you buy.'' Laurence Zuckerman (NYT)

title: F.C.C. Says It Should Regulate High-Speed Access to Internet
description: Anxious cable companies got a boost yesterday when the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, William E. Kennard, said his agency, not local governments, should regulate high-speed Internet access.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, EDWARD
description: HERSH-Edward, M.D. Sadly we have lost our oldest brother, the patriarch of our family. A rare and wonderful human being, our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Najla, his children, and grandchildren. Albert and Bernard

title: District Settles With Principal in 6-Year-Old Case
description: The six-year legal battle that put a Westchester elementary school principal in legal limbo and led to legal bills of nearly $1 million, and whose almost Dickensian bureaucratic inertia embarrassed the school district that brought the case has reached a tentative conclusion.

title: Remote Control
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETHER, HALLIE FAIRBANK
description: SETHER-Hallie Fairbank, formerly of Larchmont, NY, died at the home of her daughter, JoAnn S. Bowes, in Lock Haven, PA, on May 21. She is the daughter of the late Clair Wesley and Ruth Herriott Fairbank of Pelham, NY. Survivors include another daughter, Nancy S. Masterson, of Sequin, TX, and four grandsons. She is predeceased by her daughter Bonnie S. Hasler and husband James Wendell Sether. Memorial service will be held at Larchmont Avenue Church on June 24 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Connecticut College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, BERNARD
description: GOLDBERGER - Bernard. On June 15, 1999. Beloved father of Alan and his wife, Louise. Devoted grandfather of Karlyn, and Robert and his wife, Susan. Cherished great grandfather of Jason, Jared, Arielle, and Jesse. Graveside services at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens, Friday 1:00 PM.

title: The Big City; Yankee Trash May Preserve Rebel Shrine
description: ''ROBERT E. LEE played as a child under this tree,'' Charles H. Carter 3d said on Tuesday, speaking of his first cousin five times removed. Mr. Carter was standing by the enormous willow oak on the front lawn of his home, Shirley Plantation, on a bluff above the James River.

title: Speculating? Highly Improper but It's Done, Old Boy
description: It is canny of the Mint Theater, at the end of a decade of stock market enchantment, to stage ''The Voysey Inheritance,'' a 95-year-old play by the British actor and director Harley Granville-Barker. Few theatrical works so shrewdly raise profound questions about the role of ordinary morality in the making of money, and none in English does it with such elegance and wit.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 30 about Arthur L. Schawlow, co-winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Physics, misstated the achievement for which he was cited. A reader pointed out in mid-May that it was contributions to the development of laser spectroscopy, not the development of lasers. (This correction was delayed for checking of several questions raised by the letter.)

title: Qwest Is Near to a Partnership with Cisco
description: Even as investors continue to digest Qwest Communications International Inc.'s unsolicited $55 billion bid to acquire U S West Inc. and the Frontier Corporation, announced earlier this week, Qwest is pushing ahead with deploying its advanced fiber optic communications network.

title: A Beach House In Malibu That Throws A Curve or Two
description: What is an architect to do when the husband is a modernist and the wife a traditionalist? Stephen Kanner of Kanner Architects in Los Angeles wed the two for Catherine and Peter Dussmann in this part bubbly, part formal, clapboard summer house on the beach in Malibu. It is, Mr. Kanner said, ''a traditional clapboarded beach house given a big spin.''

title: ALCATEL TO ACQUIRE INTERNET DEVICES FOR $180 MILLION
description: The French telecommunications giant Alcatel S.A. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Internet Devices Inc., a privately held maker of equipment for managing data networks and Internet connections, for about $180 million in cash. Internet Devices, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes products for networks that allow employees to dial into a corporate computer network from the Internet, eliminating long-distance calls and slashing the costs of maintaining a network. Earlier this year, Alcatel bought two other American Internet concerns: Assured Access Technology and the Xylan Corporation.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * NATO extended by 24 hours its deadline for the Yugoslav troop withdrawal from much of southern Kosovo, saying the Yugoslav Army was making a good-faith effort to pull out.

title: VIDEO MAKER DROPS OUT
description: The battle to replace the VCR has another casualty. Digital Video Express, the maker of Divx home-video systems, which allowed temporary viewing of movies on disk, is discontinuing operations. Consumers who bought Divx-enhanced players before June 16, 1998, can apply for a $100 rebate from participating retailers or by contacting the company at www.divx.com or (888) 639-DIVX.

title: BRAZILIAN INTERNET PURCHASE
description: Telefonica of Spain said it had bought a controlling stake in Nutec, an Internet provider in Brazil, in the latest example of consolidation in the country's fast-growing Internet industry. Telefonica paid an undisclosed amount for Nutec, which was owned by Rede Brasil Sul, a media group with a strong presence in southern Brazil that will maintain a minority stake in the company. Nutec's subscriber base, which more than tripled in the last year to 190,000 people in 95 Brazilian cities, is appealing to Telefonica in its aim to be the leading Internet provider in Portuguese- and Spanish-speaking countries. Simon Romero

title: Senator Vows to Note Donations in Debates
description: Hoping to breathe some life into moribund campaign finance legislation, Senator Russell D. Feingold announced today that in debates on legislation favored by interest groups he would make a point of identifying how much money those groups had given to candidates and parties.

title: Twang With Muscles: Shania Twain's Country
description: Shania Twain has a hard body. The muscles on the country-pop superstar's abdomen, whose display in midriff tops shocked Nashville and made her a heroine to women who lunch on Balance Bars, show the effort of someone who never skips the gym. Every aspect of Ms. Twain's show at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night emanated from that core: it was hyper-energetic, highly controlled and determined to astonish the lazy. Yet the effort Ms. Twain puts into being a superwoman dims her chance to make genuinely affecting music.

title: Analyze This: Figuring Fate Along the Road to a Title
description: Four world-class teams were fighting in Memphis yesterday for a chance to represent the United States in the world championships in Bermuda in January. At the midpoint of the semifinal stage of the International Team Trials, these were the scores by captain: Jim Cayne led George Jacobs by 20 imps, and Steve Robinson led Jeff Wolfson by 32.

title: China Arrests 2 Leaders of Farmers' Protest
description: Five months after riot policemen violently dispersed a huge demonstration by angry farmers in the southern province of Hunan, two of the farmers' leaders have been arrested and charged with serious crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ICOS CORP., Bothell, Wash., appointed Paul Clark its president and chief executive, succeeding George Rathmann, who retains his duties as chairman. Mr. Clark had been senior vice president at Abbott Laboratories.

title: Some Advice From a Legend
description: Jeff Van Gundy has often sought the advice of other respected coaches. Last week he didn't have to reach out. Instead, a legend wanted to talk to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, MARTIN G.
description: TAUB-Martin G. The members, Board of Directors and the officers of Metropolitan Package Store Association mourn the passing of Martin Taub. We extend to his family our deepest sympathies on their loss, and our sincere wishes that the many years of good memories will soon succeed their current sorrow. Al Platt, Chairman of the Board

title: Cohen Meets With Russian; Progress Seen On Troop Issue
description: After seven hours of intense talks, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and his Russian counterpart, Marshal Igor D. Sergeyev, said tonight that they had made progress toward a resolution of the touchy issue of Russia's role in the Kosovo peacekeeping force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Greene Breaks World Record in the 100 Meters
description: Little more than two weeks ago, after he had won the 200-meter dash in the Track and Field Association pro championships in Uniondale, N.Y., Maurice Greene talked about world records.

title: Choice Windows Shine In Out-of-the-Way Places
description: THE windows of Louis Comfort Tiffany are found in churches, cemeteries and in private homes like the former Ayer mansion in Boston (inset, below right and bottom), now the Bayridge Residence and Cultural Center. When water damage two years ago forced the removal of a drop ceiling, a Tiffany skylight was discovered. Now, the nonprofit center wants to raise $2 million to restore the Tiffany windows, skylight and exquisite Tiffany mosaics. ''We were living in this jewel box but didn't realize how important it was,'' said Marie Oates, the executive director. The building, at 395 Commonwealth Avenue, can be visited by appointment, (617) 536-2586, ext. 121.

title: Sotheby's and Amazon.com Strike a Deal to Sell on Line
description: Five months after announcing a $25 million plan to begin its own on-line auction business, Sotheby's has entered into an alliance with Amazon.com to begin selling art and collectibles later this year.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar gained against the euro after a report showed no inflation in consumer prices last month in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0305, down from $1.0425 on Tuesday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Prices for crude oil dropped after an unexpectedly large gain in inventories indicated ample supply for the summer driving season. In New York, crude oil for July delivery fell 61 cents a barrel, to $17.94.

title: My Bid? Lips and Envelope Are Sealed
description: IF he hadn't written that number and submitted it in a sealed envelope, with his heart pounding and his knees shaking, Richard Potter might not be getting one of the last great apartment deals in New York.

title: Scholars' Tool or a Web of Lies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Officials Investigated in Tax Evasion Case
description: German authorities are investigating the chief executive and five other current and former senior executives of Deutsche Bank A.G. on suspicion of helping clients evade taxes, the bank said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: General in Giuliani Reserve Hears the Call
description: AFTER four grinding years in the Giuliani administration, Randy M. Mastro resigned as Deputy Mayor last summer, saying that he sorely missed practicing law. Now, it seems, he sorely misses wielding influence over public policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGANA, PHILIP E.
description: LAGANA-Philip E., Honorable, New York State Supreme Court Justice, on June 15, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife, Josephine (nee Schiro). Loving brother of Francis Lagana. Brother-in-law of Marian & Louis Modica. Beloved uncle of Dr. Gregory and Tish Lagana, Lorraine and Knick Irving, Janine and George Simeon, Dr. Charles and Lisa Modica, Lorraine & Anthony Schmidt and Dr. John and Christine Modica. Reposing 25 and 7-9PM, at A. Torregrossa and Son, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn, corner of West Street, until Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Grace R.C. Church, 10:15 AM. After all, a recent news magazine poll here named him the country's musician of the century, ahead of Antonio Carlos Jobim, Milton Nascimento, Caetano Veloso, Gilberto Gil, the composer Heitor Villa Lobos and even Carmen Miranda.

Batteries are required, but worms, hooks and a fishing license are not. Neither are goldfish. The game, shaped like a spinning rod and reel, vibrates and bends when a fish ''bites.'' Reaching the tournament level of play requires a little practice; $24.99 at Toys ''R'' Us. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: WALTER SHAWLEE admits that in the 1960's, he frequently paraded around his Los Angeles high school with a slide rule -- ''the techno-guys' version of a broadsword'' -- protruding from his shirt pocket.

title: Coming to CD, the Compleat Alfred E. Neuman
description: Rather than waiting for Project Gutenberg to get around to it, Broderbund Software is rereleasing Mad magazine in digital form. Totally Mad, a set of seven CD-ROM's ($69.95; Windows 95 and later), contains the entire contents of the magazine from its inception in 1952 through December 1998, including all the work by its best-known artists, its movie and television parodies (''Gall in the Family,'' ''The Oddfather'') and animated versions of the famous ''fold in'' back pages.

title: Mr. Pataki's Campaign Reform Challenge
description: Amid the gloom that has settled over New York State's do-nothing Legislature this session, Gov. George Pataki yesterday offered a flicker of enlightenment. It came with his long-awaited campaign finance reform package, which the Governor wants in time for next year's elections. The package, announced as this session moves to a close, instantly sent grumbles through the Statehouse where legislators do little more than talk about reforming one of the least savory campaign financing systems in the country. But what the Governor has presented could be a starting point for real reform -- especially if the details match the promises and if the Pataki political clout is securely attached to it.

description: ASIA

title: An 'Old Blue Eyes' Dream Come True; A Fan Brings a Touch of Sinatra's Style to a Manhattan Nightclub

He was an awkward and lonesome kid, but the Sinatra songs could make him feel as if he had the world on a string and was sitting on a rainbow with the string around his finger.

title: Flowing Rivers, Sitting Ducks
description: THE colors are warmest in winter, when the sun's rays are low in the sky and envelop the stained-glass horizon in amber light.

title: As Session Ends, Little to Show, and Still No State Budget
description: The Legislature's 1999 session reached its scheduled end today with all the usual frenzy but none of the results, as lawmakers failed to make deals on most unresolved issues, and girded for a showdown over whether the state would keep paying hospital bills after Sunday.

title: New Labels for Old Mail

title: Goldberg Moser Gets Lucas Account
description: The film maker George Lucas has expanded his relationship with Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco by awarding the agency the account of Lucas Learning Ltd. Billings have not been determined.

title: The Beat Goes on Line, and Sometimes It's Legal
description: IF there is a ''Phantom Menace'' of the Internet, it's MP3, the compression software that enables CD-quality music to be sent on line. Like the film, MP3 comes with a considerable amount of hyperbole, promise and, alas, science fiction.

title: RAYOVAC IN $155 MILLION BID FOR ROV BATTERY BUSINESS
description: The Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $155 million for the consumer battery business of ROV Ltd., allowing Rayovac to reclaim control of its brand in most world markets. The closely held Miami-based ROV, originally a spinoff of Rayovac, holds rights to Rayovac's brand throughout Latin America, except Brazil, and in Africa, the Middle East and some Asian countries. In December, Rayovac bid $120 million for a controlling interest in the Latin American battery business, but it raised the bid yesterday to buy the entire division. Shares of Rayovac rose 25 cents, to $23.3125.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Making an Entrance Into an Eden
description: IT'S easy to forget that the domestic doorway was once a humble, utilitarian affair, innocent of any attempt to make a good first impression or, for that matter, any impression at all. In medieval castles, entrances were simply holding tanks designed to check the advance of sudden callers bearing arms and a grievance. Equally functional (and hardly more welcoming) was the cupboard-size entry porch common to early New England. It was a barrier against front-door drafts, as well as the only sensible place to put the staircase. Even in a less buttoned-up age, the front hall is likely to be the family repository of umbrellas, coats and the odd 10-speed.

title: Grass-Roots Politics Looks For an Opening in Serbia
description: When a small number of residents of Cacak gathered for a weekly prayer session during the NATO bombing campaign, they immediately came under police surveillance. When they started daily meetings in the Town Hall, the organizers were arrested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

description: The New York City Ballet's tribute to American music has opened up an unexpected trove of repertory gems. These are ballets that invite one in on their own terms, allowing the viewer to rediscover and savor them without fanfare.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration on Tuesday with an article about theater owners' plans to require photo identification cards for admission to R-rated films misstated the rating of ''Entrapment.'' It is PG-13, not R.

title: Clinton Presses Treaty to Ban the Worst Child Labor Practices
description: Appealing for a ''human face'' on the global economy, President Clinton urged the International Labor Organization today to adopt a treaty that would ban the most abusive child labor practices, including the use of children in pornography and prostitution.

description: ALABAMA 6, RICE 5

title: Refugees Find Nothing Left of Former Life but Cinders

There was a television set his 28-year-old son, Shaban, had bought for the family by working on construction jobs in Germany, along with a big music system, a refrigerator and a freezer to store food for the long winter.

title: Rugged Bumpers Are Not, Study for Auto Insurers Says

title: Economic Scene; A case for forgiving the world's biggest debtors their debts.
description: TANZANIA, half of whose population is illiterate, spends a third of its budget on debt payments and spends four times more on debt than it does primary education. Niger, where life expectancy is only 47 years, spends more on debt payments than it does on health and education combined.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Digital Recorder Offers Capacity in Hours, Not Minutes
description: Digital recorders have at least one great advantage over magnetic tape models: they have the ability to download your spoken thoughts into a computer for automatic conversion into printed text through voice recognition software. The drawback is that digital recorders generally measure their capacity in minutes, not hours.

title: Helms Has White House Worried About Its U.N. Nomination
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms, is refusing to say whether he will allow a vote on the long-stalled nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to be the American representative at the United Nations, raising the question of whether the nomination might die before it reaches the Senate floor.

description: In East Africa, they are dainty and meticulous, poking a twig into an anthill and then nibbling the insects one by one. They daub their bodies clean with napkins made of leaves, or give themselves a postprandial tickle with any stray object at hand.

description: Thabo Mbeki became South Africa's second post-apartheid President today, taking over this still racially divided country from Nelson Mandela, the man who, with unerring grace, steered it through a peaceful transition out of white supremacy.

description: For the last four days, Tom Dedaj has been going house to house in search of the unburied horrors of Kosovo.

title: Police Narrow Time of Death Of Man Found on Subway Train
description: The police yesterday released a sketch of the unidentified man found dead Monday on a Manhattan subway train, and said that he was last seen alive, talking to another man on the train, less then three hours before his body was discovered.

title: Tools and Pep Talks for Novice Investors
description: IN Homer's ancient world, Cassandra was a beautiful Trojan princess upon whom the god Apollo bestowed the gift of prophecy. But when Cassandra refused to repay his generosity with sexual favors, Apollo put a curse on her: her prophecies -- all of disaster -- would be accurate but nobody would understand or believe her.

title: A Futuristic Eye in the Sky At Vermont and Santa Monica
description: Will Anglenos ever get out of their cars and into the subway? Perhaps the Vermont/Santa Monica stop, above and below, will lure them below ground. Mehrdad Yazdani, who was the lead architect for Ellerbe Becket Los Angeles (he is now with Dworsky Associates), and Robert Millar, an artist, designed this abstract and elegant station with a large steel canopy, shaped like a giant eye, at its entrance. The surrounding 20,000-square-foot plaza is vivid with paving, benches and light poles, all in red. Purple plum trees add to the intensity, while glass paving blocks bring natural light into the station. It opened earlier this month, one of five new stations on the Metro Red Line, which will eventually include a stop at Hollywood and Highland, epicenter of the revived Hollywood.

title: Archer Daniels Executive Said to Tell of Price-Fixing Talks With Cargill Counterpart
description: A senior executive at the Archer Daniels Midland Company told Government investigators that he had held secret talks with an executive at Cargill Inc. to rig bids and prices in a huge food additive market, according to recently released documents.

title: Another CBS Web Stake
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it was acquiring a 30 percent stake in Thirdage Media Inc. for $54 million in advertising and other considerations to be spread over seven years. Under the deal, CBS will gain access to an Internet site whose content is geared to baby boomers. Thirdage, a closely held company that is based in San Francisco and runs the Thirdage.com Web site, will be advertised and promoted on CBS media, including radio and billboards, and will receive other consideration. CBS will also get warrants for an additional 5 percent of the company. CBS has been rapidly building its on-line holdings as its chief executive, Mel Karmazin, trades the CBS brand name and marketing power for stakes in a wide range of sites on the World Wide Web.

title: Bear Stearns Suit by S.E.C. Said to Be Near
description: Settlement talks have broken down between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Bear Stearns Companies concerning the firm's activities as a clearing agent for small brokerage firms that defrauded investors, according to people close to the investigation.

As a youngster, he often accompanied his father, a storied teaching pro, to Golf Digest schools here. As a three-time all-American at the University of North Carolina, he played here in the prestigious North and South Amateur, winning it in 1984.

description: WHEN the Sony Corporation put Aibo, its $2,500 robotic dog, up for sale on its Web site last month, John Wharton was determined to get one. After two hours of of trying to get past the congestion on the site, he finally placed his order.

description: Jim Brown, the former star running back for the Cleveland Browns, was arrested and charged with a felony count of making terroristic threats toward his 25-year-old wife, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Serial Killer Is Pursued By a Manhunt In Texas
description: In a search described as akin to looking for ''a needle in five haystacks,'' hundreds of Federal, state and local law-enforcement officers in Texas are hunting a serial killer believed responsible for the fatal bludgeoning of six people on or near railroad tracks.

title: PLUS: COLLEGE BASKETBALL -- HOFSTRA; Wright Will Not Leave for Fordham
description: The Hofstra men's basketball coach, Jay Wright, considered the leading candidate for the Fordham head-coaching position, pulled out of the running for the job Monday night after spending the day talking with the Fordham athletic director, Frank McLaughlin.

title: Trump's Giant Tower Near U.N. Attracts F.A.A's Attention
description: Those who say they are offended because they were not informed in advance about Donald J. Trump's new 72-story tower on First Avenue, mostly wealthy and influential people with diminished views of the East River and the United Nations, have been joined by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: GALILEO TO REPURCHASE BRITISH AIRWAYS' 6.7% STAKE
description: Galileo International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $307.7 million for a unit of British Airways P.L.C. that indirectly owns 6.7 percent of Galileo. The purchase is being made under a $500 million stock buyback program announced in April. Galileo, of Rosemont, Ill., runs a computerized travel reservation network that provides booking services for travel agents through its Apollo and Galileo systems. Galileo is 65 percent owned by an airline consortium that includes British Airways and is led by the UAL Corporation's United Airlines, with a 32 percent interest.

title: New Automated Strategies To Detect and Defuse Viruses
description: The widespread invasion last week by the file-devouring Explore worm underscored the networked society's vulnerability to malicious computer programs. But even as the computer underworld is devising increasingly sophisticated attacks, two major antiviral software companies -- Symantec, with its partners I.B.M. and Intel, and Network Associates -- will soon deploy new automated systems to aid in the speedy detection, analysis and defusing of viruses.

description: As universities race to establish research centers in the growing field of genomics, Princeton University yesterday announced a $35 million gift for its new Institute for Integrative Genomics. The gift will cover nearly half of the $75 million Princeton is trying to raise for the institute.

title: Clinton Vow to Congress Ends A Threat to His Nominations
description: President Clinton has promised to make no more appointments when Congress is in recess without notifying Senate leaders before the recess. In response, a Republican senator today withdrew his threat to block all Presidential nominations, including the nomination of Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers to be Treasury Secretary.

title: Neighbors Even Fences Wouldn't Muffle
description: The American family, according to Albert Innaurato, comes in two volumes: loud and extra loud. The former can be found on every block, arguing about credit cards and curfews and whose turn it is to take out the Pomeranian. But the extra loud, they're a special breed, the Green Berets of domestic warfare. They have titanic screaming jags at the breakfast table, in the backyard, on the telephone, at neighbors' weddings. They holler and cry and hug and start up the hollering all over again, because to communicate on reasonable terms is to go against nature. You might as well ask the hoot owl to stop hooting, or MTV to start playing Barry Manilow.

title: High-Quality Playback From Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer last week officially released Quicktime 4, the latest version of its multimedia software for Windows and Macintosh systems. Quicktime 4 (which can be downloaded from www.apple.com/quicktime) offers high-quality playback for both streaming and stored video and audio files, a component that can display video and image files in a wide variety of formats, and support for MP3 and other compression technologies.

title: Real-World Science From Internet Labs
description: THE sun was out and summer break was beckoning, but inside Girolann Accetta's classroom, her students were crowded around their computer screens, captivated by the image of a bug they had plucked from the Dodson Middle School garden a week earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 9 about ''Gertrude and Alice: A Likeness to Loving,'' a new play about the relationship between Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, referred incompletely to the editorship of two volumes of Stein's writings published last year by the Library of America. Harriet Scott Chessman was a co-editor, with Catharine Stimpson.

Stepfather of Jeffrey and Lois Grand & Marilyn Weinshel. Dear brother of Albert and Arthur Koweek. Cherished grandfather of Heather and Rachael Blake, Robert and Eric Grand, Evan and David Weinshel. Adored uncle and greatuncle. Service Friday, 11AM, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: In America; Defending The Status Quo
description: The state of Texas is not big on protecting the rights of the accused. And when it comes to providing lawyers for indigent criminal defendants, it is one of the most backward states in the Union.

title: J. F. Powers, 81, Dies; Wrote About Priests
description: J. F. Powers, who won a National Book Award in 1963 for his first novel, ''Morte d'Urban,'' and had a long career as a writer of sardonic but deeply compassionate fiction about Roman Catholic priests in the Midwest of the United States, died on Saturday at his home in Collegeville, Minn. He was 81.

title: Scholars' Tool or a Web of Lies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Snug Harbor History
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Ex-Police Officer Is Awarded $380,000 in Harassment Suit
description: A former Nassau County police officer who said he was subjected to nine years of incessant and often vicious harassment after his colleagues and supervisors learned he was gay was awarded $380,000 in damages today by a Federal jury.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's easy to sing, but it's not easy to do.''

title: Marines Seize Weapons of Kosovo Insurgents
description: After a tense standoff along a rural road, with helicopter gunships overhead, American marines confiscated the weapons of more than 100 ethnic Albanian insurgents and detained six of their leaders today in the most serious of a series of confrontations between NATO troops and the Kosovo Liberation Army.

title: STARWOOD FINANCIAL ACQUIRING TRINET CORPORATE REALTY
description: Starwood Financial Trust Inc., a commercial mortgage lender, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc., which buys corporate-owned real estate and leases it back, for $1.5 billion in stock. The New York-based Starwood, no relation to Starwood Hotels and Resorts, will pay 1.15 shares for each Trinet share. It will also assume $648 million in debt and $175 million in preferred shares. Shares of Trinet, which is based in San Francisco, slipped 12.5 cents, to $29.1875. Starwood plunged $20.875, to $34.125, in part because the acquisition will greatly dilute the shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLISSEL, IRVING
description: SCHLISSEL-Irving. We extend our deepest sympathy to our dear friend, Ted, Irving's beloved and devoted son. With much love always. Jacob, Kristina and Talia

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKNELL, NATHANIEL S.
description: BUCKNELL-Nathaniel S. (Nat), 44, died on June 7, 1999. He was an advocate in the fight against AIDS and all injustice. An artist, a dreamer, a friend. Deeply loved, he will never be forgotten. Good night, sweet prince. And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.

title: Cheering On a Home Team That's Away
description: Glenn Johnson had not been to Madison Square Garden since 1969. The 38-year-old banker does not remember who the Knicks played; but he does remember they lost.

title: VULCAN VENTURES TO ACQUIRE INTEREST IN OXYGEN MEDIA
description: The venture capital firm Vulcan Ventures Inc. said yesterday that it would invest as much as $100 million in Oxygen Media Inc., which is building Internet sites and cable television properties for women. Vulcan, owned by Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, would get a minority stake in the New York-based Oxygen and a seat on the company's board in return for its investment. The size of the stake was not disclosed. Oxygen also said that Mr. Allen's Charter Communications would distribute the Oxygen network, which is scheduled to begin broadcasting in 2002.

title: Brazil Auctions Oil Licenses, Yielding Some State Control
description: The Government ended Brazil's oil monopoly in a two-day auction that concluded today, overcoming nationalist resistance and recently weak petroleum prices to auction the first exploration licenses to big foreign companies.

title: Bronxville to End Prom Over Alcohol
description: Sometime during the last 20 years, school officials say, the junior-senior prom here changed from a simple rite of passage to a night of teen-age debauchery, with excessive drinking matched by increasingly garish spending. Now high school faculty members in this wealthy Westchester community have told parents and students they cannot control alcohol consumption at the prom and are unwilling to ignore it, as many other schools do. They want the prom to be eliminated for good, and the school board leadership has informally agreed.

title: The Burden of Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Swat Team: Twin Towers Maul the Knicks
description: The Spurs' cerebral Tim Duncan tilted his chin down and saw the ragged beard and the bulky knee brace on a tattered and hardly agile Larry Johnson.

title: U.S. Backs a British-Dutch Plan To Partly Lift Sanctions on Iraq
description: The United States has decided to support a British and Dutch proposal that would partly lift oil sanctions on Iraq if Baghdad answers outstanding questions about its unconventional weapons programs and cooperates fully with a new group of United Nations arms inspectors.

title: She Lives to Tell About Growing Up
description: THE GIRLS' GUIDE TO HUNTING AND FISHING

title: Sports of The Times; Combatants A Mystery Until Now
description: IT took too long, but Game 1 arrived at last, along with the news that Tim Duncan is as good as advertised. No surprise, really, or that Larry Johnson's sprained knee ligament miraculously healed. If we'd waited much longer for the finals to begin, Phil Jackson would've found a cure for Shaquille O'Neal's free-throw-shooting disease, or the common cold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMBUSCH, KENNETH R.
description: BAUMBUSCH-Kenneth R. Retired president of the John F. Murray Advertising Agency, formerly of Hastings on Hudson, NY in Tarrytown on June 15, 1999. Husband of Jeane, father of Peter, Richard and John. Brother of Shirley Bergmann and grandfather of eight. Funeral 10AM Saturday, June 19, 1999 at South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Colgate University, 13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY 13346 or National Stroke Association, 96 Inverness Dr East #

title: Die-Hard Liberal Soars In a City Left of Center
description: Not every Tom Ammiano idea rattles the seismically retrofitted corridors of City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPPERSMITH, HAROLD H.
description: COPPERSMITH-Harold H., Dr. Beloved husband of Estelle. Devoted father of Robert and Ruth. Cherished brother of Anne Marke. Loving grandfather of Chaya, Miryam and Laila. A physician afilliated with New York Downtown Hospital who practiced in New York City for over 50 years. Services Friday, 12 noon at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 152 2nd Ave, NY, NY. Donations to New York Downtown Hospital in memory of Dr. Coppersmith appreciated.

title: On His Day, Leopold Bloom the Outsider Is Saluted, Gaily
description: Today is Bloomsday, so thousands stalked the spirit of Leopold Bloom, the newspaper advertising salesman, the hungry relisher of innards of beasts and fowls, the cuckold, and the Jewish outsider who is the hero of James Joyce's enormous novel, ''Ulysses.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Will the Fed chief bare his chest when he discusses interest rates with Congress?
description: IAN SHEPHERDSON, the chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, is hoping for full disclosure today when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, testifies before Congress.

title: In Olympics Of Art World, Anything For an Edge
description: Even among the most unassuming art collectors, trying to look like a gallery worker is generally not a goal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Bill Would Ban Hunting Big Game on Little Plots
description: A bill that would ban so-called canned hunting has been sent to Gov. George E. Pataki for his signature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Old Balkan Hatreds
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JAMES G.
description: MURRAY-James G. Of Ridgewood, NJ, formerly of Park Ridge, NJ, died suddenly on Tuesday, June 8, 1999. James, son of the late James G. and Gertrude Murray was born in Jersey City, NJ. He is survived by his wife Carolyn (nee Ceru), his daughters Lorelei and Kristine, his sister Lois Andes of Wisconsin, his mother-in-law Marie, and his sister-in-law Adrienne. Jim was employed by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter as Senior Vice President and Director of Credit and Risk Management. A graduate of St. Peter's College, Jersey City, NJ, he was a CPA and member of the NJSCPA, AICPA, and the Capital Markets Credit Analysts Society. Jim was an active parishoner of St. Gabriel the Archangel R.C. Church in Saddle River, N.J., and a Fourth Degree Knights of Columbus of the Joseph F. Lamb Assembly. He served his country as a member of the Army Reserves. Jim was actively involved in the St. Peter's College Alumni Association, the New York Athletic Club, Knickerbocker Country Club, and the Friendly sons of St. Patrick. He was both a citizen of the United States and the Republic of Ireland. Known for his Irish sense of humor, Jim always made people happy. The family will receive relatives and friends at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Friday, 25 & 7-10PM. Funeral Liturgy will be at St. Gabriel the Archangel R.C. Church, Saddle River, NJ, on Saturday at 10:00AM. Final resting place will be at Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, NY. Memorial gifts to St. Peter's College, 2641 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, NJ 07306-5997 would be appreciated.

title: Scholars' Tool or a Web of Lies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Dr. Bruno Balke, 91, Innovator In Study of Physical Conditioning
description: Bruno Balke, a sports medicine innovator who preached a regimen of sensible exercise as an antidote to heart ailments, died on June 7 at St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction, Colo. He was 91 and had lived in Grand Junction in retirement.

title: Pope Visits His Birthplace And Memories Energize Him
description: His fever subsided, Pope John Paul II sought out the restorative powers of his birthplace today, fighting age by reminiscing about his youth in the small town of Wadowice.

title: In Beijing, Envoy Struggles to Persuade Chinese That Bombing Was a Mistake
description: Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering spent Wednesday trying to convince determinedly skeptical Chinese officials that the bombing of China's embassy in Belgrade on the night of May 7 was a mistake. But after listening attentively, the Chinese made clear that they were not persuaded, American diplomats said today.

title: Zero Inflation In May Sends Stocks Soaring
description: After haunting investors for weeks, the specter of inflation suddenly retreated -- at least for now.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCSWEENEY, EDWARD F.
description: McSWEENEY-Edward F. III (Dooley). Eight years later and you still own the first 15 minutes of every lunch or dinner conversation involving your original ''250 nearest and dearest'' friends. Dooley stories! Grace's Market even sells a jelly bean topped ''designer'' cupcake mix at Easter called ''Babycakes,'' no doubt just to further perpetuate your memory!!! Miss ya, Pal; See ya, JPK.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADIN, SIDNEY
description: SADIN-Sidney. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Graveside service Sharon Gardens, Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY on Friday, June 18, 1999 at 2PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: CONFLICTING JAPANESE DATA
description: The Bank of Japan said there was no reason to believe Japan's economy had ended its slump, even though figures released by the Government last week showed gross domestic product grew by 1.9 percent in the first quarter. In its monthly report, the bank said corporate investment, consumer spending and prices all continued to decline and that a sustained recovery in private demand was difficult to foresee. Last week's report on output suggested consumer and corporate spending had reversed their downward course, but statistics released on Tuesday for manufacturing output and retail sales indicated the opposite. Stephanie Strom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, EDGAR
description: BRAUN-Edgar, on June 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Inge. Loving father of Barbara, Jackie and Alan. Adored grandfather of Daniel, Alex, Maddy and Matthew. Dear brother-in-law of Lotte, Erich and Lisel. For information, call Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: COOPERSTEIN - Sylvia. The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring mourns the passing of our longtime activist, Sylvia Cooperstein. A member of our organization for more than 50 years, her dedication and tireless work in many leadership positions, including several terms on our National Executive Board, were an example for all. Our deepest condolences to her family. Mark Mlotek, President Robert Kestenbaum, Exec Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MARION K.
description: MITCHELL-Marion K. With deep sadness we mourn the passing of our beloved Aunt Marion. Her wise counsel over the years contributed to the success of our family business. Her caring, merriment and unfailing interest in us and our families enriched our lives. We will always miss her. We extend our sympathy to our cousins and partners Judy and Susan and their families. George and Steven Kaufman Kaufman Management Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: A Busy Day in Paris For a Havas Shop
description: Havas Advertising in Paris landed a large account yesterday and made an acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENSTEIN, ENID ROSALINDE
description: EISENSTEIN-Enid Rosalinde. June 17, 1953-May 12, 1977. Beloved daughter Without you No rose can grow No leaf be green If never seen Your sweetest face; No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything Be kind or fair, and you nowhere. Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends.

title: Queens Man Is Sought In Slaying at Wedding
description: The Nassau County police said they were seeking a 22-year-old electrician from Woodhaven, Queens, in the fatal shooting of a man at a wedding reception at the Masonic Temple in Hicksville late Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page subheading on April 30 about the impact of NATO's bombing campaign on Yugoslav forces misstated the alliance's position. While some NATO officials said the bombing had helped President Slobodan Milosevic heal his long-poisoned relationship with the officer corps, that was not NATO's formal position and NATO did not ''admit'' that the bombing had healed the rift.

title: Jackson Accepts a Big Offer, Citing the Lakers' Talent
description: Phil Jackson, scheduled to appear in Los Angeles on Thursday to help his former teammate Bill Bradley in his quest for a $200,000-a-year job, showed up a day early and landed a $6 million-a-year job for himself.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about discord in Albany over stalled budget negotiations misstated the date Gov. George E. Pataki was shown arriving for a news conference with the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno. It was June 8, not Monday.

title: Another Little League Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Without Much Data on Success, Mandatory Summer School Grows
description: Beginning its second year of expanded summer school, muggy Washington bought fans and bottled water when it realized it could not install air-conditioning in all its buildings. Boston has struggled to find transportation for its summer school students, because not all will attend their neighborhood schools. Los Angeles is deflecting criticism from teachers that summer school classes will be too large and the curriculum too vague.

title: DELAYS AT TRADE GROUP
description: Despite a clear warning that the current nominees for leader of the World Trade Organization were not gaining support, member countries refused to abandon their favorites during a meeting at the group's Geneva headquarters. In a sign of the tensions surrounding the race, Supachai Panitchpakdi, above, the Thai candidate, attacked Ali Mchumo, the representative from Tanzania, who has been trying to build a consensus around Mr. Supachai's chief rival, Mike Moore of New Zealand. Another meeting to resolve the impasse is planned tomorrow. Elizabeth Olson

title: New Labels for Old Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello, Kitty. Is It Really You?
description: I WAS in third grade when Hello Kitty landed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMPSTEAD, ELEANOR AVERY
description: HEMPSTEAD - Eleanor Avery. Died on Saturday, June 12 at her home in New York City. The caused of death was cancer. Mrs. Hempstead was the daughter of the late Waldo Allard Avery of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and the niece of the late Sewell Lee Avery of Chicago, who died in the office of chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward & Co. She was married once, to the late David Bill Hempstead, who produced and wrote some notable motion pictures during the late 1940's and '50's. It was he who persuaded Ginger Rogers to accept her first dramatic role in his production of ''Kitty Foyle'', for which she won the Academy Award. The Hempsteads were divorced in 1949. In her later years, Mrs. Hempstead devoted herself to a number of philanthropies, and was a generous donor to the Bronx Zoo, Planned Parenthood, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Mrs. Hempstead is survived by her two children, Avery Hempstead Lichtenstein of New York and Santa Fe, and a son, David Bill Hempstead IV of Pasadena, California. A memorial service is to be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st street) in Manhattan on Thursday, September 9 at 4PM. Only relatives, business associates and close friends of the deceased and her daughter are invited to attend.

title: When Big Books Dall a Little Flat
description: It happens in publishing more often than even sophisticated readers realize and certainly more than anyone in the business would like. There are great expectations that a particular book will break out and become a big-time popular success, its future guaranteed. Abundant press coverage and good reviews fuel that fire of anticipation. And then there's no ice cream cone at the end.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Coke's Chief Apologizes for Response on Contamination
description: Coca-Cola's top executive apologized to European customers today in response to a growing public outcry over its slow response to a soft-drink contamination that apparently made hundreds of people sick in Belgium.

title: Give Him Enough Rope, and He Can Furnish the Whole House
description: Meret Oppenheim, designer of the famed Surrealist furry teacup, might be amused by the hairy chest of drawers, below right, by Christian Astuguevieille, a French designer. Mr. Astuguevieille has spent more than 10 years making sculpture by enveloping furniture in rope. His designs, which draw on the art and the crafts of Africa and South America, range from the untamed, as in the two 39-inch-tall chests ($16,250, far right, and $25,500), to the relatively restrained, like the three stools, below left, wrapped tightly in cotton cord with a thick coat of paint ($975 to $1,075 each). Mr. Astuguevieille's furniture can be ordered from Jenny Armit, a new contemporary furniture store at 8210 Melrose Avenue, at Harper Avenue, in Los Angeles; (323) 782-9173.

title: 2 Found Guilty Of Payoff Plot In Injury Suits
description: The name partners in Staten Island's largest law firm were convicted yesterday of paying kickbacks to get settlements from insurance companies, the United States Attorney's office said. Prosecutors described the lawyers as participants in the widest ring of personal-injury insurance manipulation ever cracked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Tokyo Journal; A Sexy Economic Feud of No Interest to the I.M.F.
description: In the northwest of Tokyo is an area of a dozen square blocks that wakes up at noon and parties till dawn, where gamblers and gangsters run rings around the police, where prostitutes and strippers undress for success, where curses and quarrels are in Chinese.

title: Late Credit Card Payments Show Increase
description: More consumers made late credit card payments in the first quarter than in the previous three months, while the total of overdue credit card debt decreased, a bank industry study said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cargill Executive Named In Price-Fixing Documents

title: Black Clergy Press Whitman Over State Police Nominee
description: An association of black ministers warned Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders today of political retribution if they did not pick a new state police superintendent from outside the department. The ministers also asked Federal officials to appoint an independent monitor to insure that state police officers end the practice of racial profiling.

title: RAMBLING WITH: Witold Rybczynski; In Olmsted's Footsteps
description: AS boaters clunked their oars on the Lake, Witold Rybczynski folded his big frame onto a little chair by a tiny cafe table at the boathouse and talked about how he came to write about the man who created Central Park almost a century and a half ago.

title: Cable and Wireless in Talks With Local Japanese Phone Carriers
description: Having just beat the hometown favorite in a hostile takeover battle for the International Digital Corporation, Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British telecommunications company that is fast galloping across the globe, must now prove the battle was worth the cost.

title: The Burden of Testing; How to Help Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Tunneling Terrors

title: Airbus Wins Order From Leasing Company
description: Airbus Industrie said today that the International Lease Finance Corporation would buy as many as 60 single-aisle jets for as much as $2.4 billion, a contract that includes the European plane maker's first firm order for its new A318 jet.

title: Following a Tough Act; Nickelodeon Chief Quietly Builds on Celebrated Legacy
description: It was Nickelodeon's 20th-anniversary party at the Museum of Television and Radio in New York this month, but Herb Scannell, the chief executive of the children's TV network, promised to be brief.
