description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Pataki Wants to Extend Superfund, but With Looser Rules
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed today spending nearly $4 billion during the next 20 years to extend the state's main program for cleaning up toxic waste.

title: New Chips Can Be Fast on Their Feet
description: THE Pentium and Power PC chips that run most personal computers are the Swiss Army knives of the microprocessor world. They can take on a huge variety of tasks, but as anyone who has tried to carve a turkey using a pocket knife will attest, specialized tools make faster work of some jobs.

title: U.S. and Russia Extend Deal to Cut Threat From Old Weapons
description: Setting aside policy differences over Kosovo, Iraq and other contentious issues, the United States and Russia concluded an agreement in Washington yesterday extending for seven years programs to reduce the threat posed by nuclear, biological, chemical and other weapons of mass destruction.

title: Corrections
description: The By the Book column in the Dining section yesterday, about ''Fish,'' a cookbook by Sophie Grigson and William Black, misstated its price at Kitchen Arts and Letters in Manhattan. It is $45, not $55.

title: Kosovars Rush Home and Overwhelm Relief Workers
description: More than 12,000 cheering, stunned Albanians began their journey home today, in the first big wave of a reverse exodus of refugees who were driven from Kosovo in a Serbian campaign of terror.

title: Senate Approves Health Care for Disabled
description: By a vote of 99 to 0, the Senate today passed a bill that would expand Medicaid and Medicare so hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities could retain their health benefits when they return to work.

title: Bradley Takes On California, One on One
description: When the tall man talks, people tend to listen. They have to, because he speaks so softly.

title: Surprise! Jackson, Too, Can Play
description: Tim Duncan was outstanding and David Robinson was dominant defensively, but all of that was expected. What was not a certainty entering tonight's National Basketball Association championship opener was the sharp shooting of Jaren Jackson.

title: These Bed Partners Demand Their Own Identity
description: NIGHT tables have come a long way since Ward and June Cleaver bought their bedroom set with the matching bedside stands. Today, no such constraints apply. If space is limited, look for an interesting stool. Or a long chest that will fit at the end of the bed. Even a piece of hand-carved sculpture doesn't have to sit on a table; it can be the table.

title: Stocks Till We Drop
description: As I heard the final boarding call announced for my flight to Los Angeles, I saw a fellow passenger lingering at a free Internet-access computer, pecking feverishly at the keyboard. I peered over his shoulder: he was checking stock quotes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TSI INC., Shoreview, Minn., a manufacturer of measuring instruments, said that John Fauth, a minority shareholder with about 5.8 percent of the common stock, had offered to buy the company for $141 million, about a 23 percent premium to the closing price on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYGNOS, PENELOPE
description: LYGNOS-Penelope. In Athens, Greece on June 11, 1999. Beloved mother of George and Elli Lygnos, the late Peter Lygnos, and Anna Lygnos; loving grandmother of Penelope J. Mavris, Maria G. Lemos, Nicholas P. Lygnos, Penelope, Nicholas & Irene G. Lygnos. Reposing at McCagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ, Thursday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Friday at St. John the Theologian Cathedral, 353 East Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: U.S. Indicts 2 More Men In Bombing Of Embassies
description: Two men who the authorities say are leaders of an Islamic terrorist organization were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that they had a hand in the bombing last summer of two American embassies in East Africa.

title: Mexicans See a Call to Prayer In Quake Damage to Churches
description: The friar was climbing up the steep steps to his church for afternoon prayers on Tuesday when the bell towers began to sway and the great bells set to tolling by themselves. As he watched, ugly cracks coursed across the facade, then half of it collapsed with a crash.

title: INSIDE
description: Now, No Sign of Inflation

title: U.S. Indicts 85 in $100 Million Stock Swindle
description: Federal officials announced yesterday the indictments of 85 people who they said had swindled thousands of unwary investors out of more than $100 million by manipulating the stocks of small and start-up companies. Three of the suspects have ties to organized crime, they said.

title: Mental Health Parity Can Reduce Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: North Korea Suspends Contact With South
description: North Korea said today that it was suspending contacts with the South, a day after South Korean vessels sank one of its warships in the Yellow Sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, GAYNOR I.
description: JACOBSON-Gaynor I. The officers and executive staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourn the recent passing of Gaynor I. Jacobson, a very significant professional leader of the Jewish community whose influence was felt throughout the Jewish world. He was executive vice president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society from 1968 to 1981. His dedication and leadership in assisting Jews worldwide was universally recognized and he received honors from many nations, including Brazil and Israel. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Florence, and to his two daughters. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman of the Executive Stephen D. Solender, Acting President

title: Outcry in a Cradle of Architecture; Gehry, Planning a Chicago Design, Runs Into Skepticism
description: Rain was whiplashing downtown Chicago, and in a patch of land near wind-raked Lake Michigan, all that could really be seen was a herd of citrus yellow backhoes, along with mounds of fudgy dirt. But in the imagination of the architect Frank O. Gehry, who was seeing the site for the first time, the picture was altogether different.

title: Parables Old and New Lead Next Wave Festival Lineup
description: The singer and composer Laurie Anderson makes her directorial debut -- and introduces a new musical instrument -- in ''Songs and Stories From Moby Dick,'' which opens the Brooklyn Academy of Music's 1999 Next Wave Festival on Oct. 5. With Melville's text as a starting point, Ms. Anderson creates a modern parable using contemporary media, including a ''talking stick,'' an electronic device that audibly responds to the performer's gestures. The work runs through Oct. 16.

title: Al Gore as the Un-Clinton
description: All Vice Presidents have a special challenge when they try to run for President themselves. They have to campaign on the achievements of the outgoing Administration while also separating themselves from its failings. In one sense Al Gore's job should be a straightforward one. Practically everyone on the planet can identify the big defect in the Clinton Presidency, and Mr. Gore has gotten off to a brisk start in explaining how he would differ from Bill Clinton. In carefully calculated television interviews, Mr. Gore shed his role as the President's defender against what he once described as partisan attacks stemming from the sexual scandals of the Clinton White House. He now sees the Monica Lewinsky episode as ''inexcusable'' and tells reporters that he resented the ''wasted time'' the President's conduct caused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: BERNSTEIN-Sylvia. Sylvia Bernstein, loving and devoted mother of Allen J. Bernstein and Helene Morrison, and adoring grandmother of Stacey Stolar, died on June 13th after a long illness. She was a woman whose nurturing love, encouragement, strength and compassion shaped and enriched the lives of her children and her granddaughter. She took enormous pride in their many achievements, and always gave them her love, wisdom and unflagging support. Her endearing personality, warmth, wit and sincerity were cherished by her extended family and her many friends. The great void in her life was the loss of the love of her life, her dear husband Morty, who was taken from her and his loving family in 1974. She was known for her gracious hospitality, her infectious optimism and the diversity of her activitieswhich ran the gamut from golf to mah jongg. She was a woman of uncommon kindness, great dignity and unqualified love. And she will be missed.

title: Pakistan Advances To the Final
description: Pakistan beat New Zealand by nine wickets yesterday in Manchester, England, in a World Cup semifinal at Old Trafford, reaching the final for the second time in its history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCHELLI, VINCENT
description: FORCHELLI-Vincent. Attorney. In Astoria. Suddenly on June 15, 1999. Dear father of Charles N., John F., and Kathleen Goode. Cherished grandfather of seven. Reposing at Farenga Funeral Home, 38-08 Ditmars Boulevard, Long Island City on Wednesday 7 to 9PM and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Religious service Friday 10AM.

title: Optimism About Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Hat, an Old Hat And Then It's Hats Off
description: On a day that Bruce Benedict was, in a sense, asked to wear an entirely different hat as the temporary manager of the Mets, it made little difference that Benedict forgot his cap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSCH, FLORENCE
description: HERSCH-Florence. We shall constantly share our wonderful memories of you with Alexander and your beloved family. Ardith, David and Bob

title: Site-Seeing: Money Management for Women
description: SHE'S GOT IT TOGETHER: www.shesgotittogether.com A relatively new and still underdeveloped site from the publishers of Profit Magazine, but worth watching.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMERLING, WILLIAM C.
description: SMERLING-William C. Of New York City on June 15, 1999 at age 93. Highly respected life insurance consultant associated with Connecticut General for over 50 years was revered by his colleagues and clients. Beloved husband of Sylvia and the late Amelia. Loving father of Marjorie and Arnold Goldbaum, Nancy and Michael Fogel, loving stepfather of Doree Friedman and Karen Friedman. Adoring grandfather of Jay and Julie, Andrew and Stacey, Lauren, Cindy & Jon, Rafael and Angela, loving stepgrandfather of Paolo, Nina and Alexandra. Great grandfather to Benjamin, Sabrina, Alexander and Robin. Devoted brother of Louis R. Smerling and brother-in-law to Beverly Smerling, Pearl Goldsmith and Anita Eshay. Cherished uncle to his many nieces and nephews. His unqualified love and support will be missed by his family and many friends. Services at 1:30 on Thursday, June 17 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Celebrating the Designs Of Charles and Ray Eames
description: The exhibition on the work of Charles and Ray Eames now at the Library of Congress in Washington has whetted appetites for all things Eames. And now the Eames Office in Pacific Palisades has opened a new gallery in Santa Monica. Founded by Eames Demetrios, the couple's grandson, the gallery also sells some of their classic designs, like La Chaise (1948), above, now made available again in the United States by Vitra, the Swiss chair manufacturer ($5,815). The Eames Office Gallery also stocks a range of CD's, videos, postcards and books and will have temporary exhibits celebrating the Eameses' work and philosophy. The Eames Office Gallery is at 2665 Main Street, near Ocean Park Boulevard, in Santa Monica; (310) 396-5991.

title: Sixth Conference To Start in Fall
description: Army and Air Force will be among the seven teams making up College Hockey America, a new Division I league announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: What a Great Series: Is Anybody Watching?
description: Derian Hatcher, the captain of the Dallas Stars, is a big, tough, talented defenseman with an intimidating style and a rap sheet to prove it. Hatcher began the two-month Stanley Cup tournament under a five-game suspension because his vicious check put Jeremy Roenick of Phoenix into the boards and out of action with a broken jaw. In a previous game, Roenick's hard hit had hurt Mike Modano, the scoring star of the Stars. Hatcher's retaliation is the way hockey players sometimes settle such scores.

title: Trio of Design Shows At Fashion Institute
description: Design Times Three

title: Essay; 'Culture of Arrogance'
description: Computers at our nuclear laboratories are again being ordered to ''stand down.'' Our most secret work on our most powerful weaponry is coming to a screeching two-day halt.

title: Thinking Outside the Beige Box; The iMac May Have Put the Focus on Design But Flat Screens Are Inspiring PC Shapes
description: IF the millions of desktop computers in the world could be stacked into a great wall, the resulting construction might resemble some enormous Louise Nevelson sculpture dominated by one oppressive shape: the box.

title: The Wired Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Diabetes Device Approved
description: Minimed Inc., a maker of high-tech products to treat diabetics, said today that it had won Food and Drug Administration approval to sell its continuous blood-sugar monitor for diabetics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, C. ELIOT
description: PIERCE-C. Eliot, 84. Of Northeast Harbor, Maine. Died on Saturday, June 12th. in Bar Harbor, Maine. He is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years, Dora Redway Pierce of Northeast Harbor and by his son Charles E. Pierce Jr. of Manhattan and Salt Point, NY, his daughter Edith P. Murphy of Rockland, ME., his daughter Joan P. Uraneck of South Portland, ME, his son Benjamin R. Pierce of Devon, PA. and seven grandchildren. A private family service will be held in Northeast Harbor on Saturday, June 19th. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Maine Community Foundation/ Watershed Project, 245 East Main Street, Ellsworth, ME. 04605.

title: Lessons of the Balkan War
description: As NATO peacekeepers move into Kosovo, they are finding grisly evidence of Serbian brutality in nearly every town. The signs of mass killing and wanton destruction in places like Djakovica, Vlastica and Cikatova ought to give pause to those who fault NATO for confronting Slobodan Milosevic. Though definitive judgments on the war await further developments in the Balkans and the work of future historians, it is not too soon to conclude that the air offensive was just, and more effective than its many critics expected. As an exercise in military and political coercion, the campaign achieved most of its aims with limited civilian casualties. Perhaps most important, it demonstrated that the United States and its allies can act decisively in defense of democratic principles and against ethnic violence in Europe.

title: Hernandez Is Crisp, but the Yankees' Offense Is Stale
description: Orlando Hernandez had another effective outing for the Yankees and continued to prove that he can still be that same ornery and baffling pitcher who blazed through the American League as if it were the American Legion last year. His manager, Joe Torre, saw how much crisper the Yankees can look when their starter is reliable. Well, sort of.

title: Scholars' Tool or a Web of Lies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: I.M.F. OPTIMISM ON RUSSIA
description: Michel Camdessus, the International Monetary Fund's managing director, indicated that Russia could soon receive a badly needed loan that would help the country avert a default on its foreign debt. Russia and the I.M.F. agreed this spring to steps that would be the prerequisite for the release of about $4.3 billion. Speaking in St. Petersburg, Russia, Mr. Camdessus said Russia had made enough progress in carrying out the economic program that there was reason for optimism about extending I.M.F. support. Neela Banerjee

title: Microsoft Calls Its Own Character Witness
description: At its antitrust trial, the Microsoft Corporation today presented its leading character witness, a folksy, plain-spoken industry veteran who delivered a message that pleased Microsoft's lawyers but will surely make its marketing executives cringe.

title: Embracing Clinton at Arm's Length, Gore Formally Begins Run for President
description: Against a backdrop of small-town America, Vice President Al Gore took his first formal step out of President Clinton's shadow today, announcing his quest for the Presidency and pledging to ''bring a new wave of fundamental change to this nation.''

title: New Executive At Western Initiative
description: Michael Lotito, a longtime top media executive, is joining Western Initiative Media Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as the No. 2 executive domestically.

title: In a Bitter Cultural War, An Ardent Call to Arms
description: By the end of Representative Tom DeLay's pulpit-thumping, brimstone-seething exhortation against gun controls and the moral decay of ''liberal relativism,'' the evangelical clergymen assembled in the morning sunshine bathing the Capitol were moved to rounds of ''Hallelujah!'' and ''Amen, Jesus!''

title: A Handheld Device That Packs More Features on One Screen
description: Following Palm Computing's phenomenal success in popularizing handheld devices, a small company is trying to attract one of the few consumer groups that hasn't yet joined the cult.

title: MANAGEMENT GROUP AND INVESTOR AGREE TO ACQUIRE CPI
description: The CPI Corporation, a photography services company that runs Sears Portrait Studios, said yesterday that a management group and American Securities Capital Partners L.P. in New York had agreed to buy it for $376 million in cash to take it private. They will pay $37 for each CPI share, a 33 percent premium to CPI's closing price on Tuesday. CPI's board has endorsed the sale, and shareholders will vote on it in a meeting this summer. The company operates 1,029 Sears Portrait Studios and 152 Prints Plus stores, and had sales of $389.5 million in the 1998 fiscal year. Shares of CPI, which is based in St. Louis, jumped $6.8125 yesterday, to $34.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: FIFTH THIRD IN $2.4 BILLION DEAL FOR INDIANA BANK
description: Fifth Third Bancorp of Ohio said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CNB Bancshares for about $2.4 billion in stock to expand in Indiana. Fifth Third, based in Cincinnati, agreed to pay 0.8825 share for each share of CNB, the largest independent bank in Indiana, valuing the deal at $59.68 a share, a 44 percent premium based on Tuesday's closing prices. Shares of CNB surged $13.8125, to $55.25; Fifth Third fell $2.7813, to $64.8438. The purchase will give Fifth Third a total of $6.8 billion in assets and a 6.4 percent deposit market share in Indiana, making it the third-largest bank there, behind the Bank One Corporation of Chicago and the National City Corporation of Cleveland.

title: Speeding Up Communication By Saving Strokes on a Keypad
description: The new technology called T9 is not an ultra-high-speed telecommunications line. It's software that promises to eliminate the cumbersome and time-consuming chore of punching text messages into a wireless device.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLARUSSO, SAM A.
description: COLARUSSO-Sam A. On June 14, 1999 aged 92 of Short Hills, NJ. Husband of Pauline (nee Ochner). Survived by four sisters, five nieces and nephews and five great nieces and nephews. Relatives & friends may attend the funeral mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ on Saturday, June 19 at 10 A.M. Visitation at Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, (corner Morris Avenue) Summit from 2-4 and 7-9P.M. on Thursday and Friday. Entombment in Gate of Heaven Chapel Mausoleum, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Colarusso Family Scholarship Fund, Development Dpt., University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Indiana 46556.

title: Food Vendors Rally Against Prospective Restrictions
description: Hundreds of food-cart operators and other peddlers rallied outside City Hall yesterday morning in anticipation of a public hearing next week that could lead to vending restrictions on as many as 380 blocks across the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPLER, GERTRUDE 'TRUDE'
description: LEPLER-Gertrude 'Trude', age 91, of Lenox, MA, died Tuesday, June 15, 1999 in Pittsfield, MA. Wife of Morton M. Lepler, M.D. Survivors include two sons, Harold Lepler of Brewster, NY and Edward Lepler of San Francisco, CA; two grandchildren, Alicia Lovejoy and Jonathan Lepler. Funeral service, Thursday, June 17th, at 1 PM at Riverdale Temple, West 246th St. at Independence, Bronx. Interment King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY. For information, call Joseph Sparacio with Sparacio & DeMarco Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Avenue, Brewster, NY.

title: Armed Isn't Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Residency Restrictions Sink Housing Plan
description: A nonprofit developer of affordable housing has been denied $7 million in state and Federal aid because the City Council insisted that a proposed project be restricted to local residents, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: CABARET IN REVIEW
description: Singing Ellington And Swinging

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: A Magazine Article Stirs Team's Pot Before Game 1
description: Beneath the feel-good atmosphere created by the Knicks' opportunity to play for the National Basketball Association championship, there is lingering uncertainty over Coach Jeff Van Gundy's future and the impact his strained relationships with Latrell Sprewell and Marcus Camby may have on it.

title: Retired General to Oversee Security for Nuclear Weapons Labs
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson named a retired four-star general today to be the department's first security czar and announced that all normal operations at three nuclear weapons laboratories will cease for two days next week as part of an intensive review of security.

title: CENDANT TO SPEND UP TO $1.1 BILLION IN A NEW BUYBACK
description: The Cendant Corporation, a hotel franchising and direct marketing company, said yesterday that it would pay as much as $1.1 billion to buy back about 7 percent of its shares to bolster its stock price. The company said its board had authorized the purchase of 50 million shares through a Dutch auction, by which the offering price is gradually raised until enough shares are tendered; the company has set a range of $19.75 to $22.50 a share. Cendant, which is based in New York, rose 6.25 cents a share yesterday, to $19.8125. The buyback follows the repurchase of $1.6 billion of stock last month and is part of an effort to regain the confidence of investors after an accounting fraud scandal last year forced the company to restate three years of earnings.

title: The Poorer Half of Congress Reports the Assets of Its Members
description: While many of their constituents have enriched themselves by investing in the booming stock market, several of the House's most powerful members have missed out entirely on the decade's bull market.

title: A Patriotic Salute Right in the Bathroom
description: Scheduling some remodeling for the Fourth of July? This patriotic sink is pricey -- $13,000 -- but just think of it as $1,000 a colony. Made by a process called glass fusion, in which metal oxides like cobalt and chrome are infused into glass, the limited-edition basin is part of a flamboyant collection by Aquadreams. The store introduced the sink earlier this month and has actually sold one. Aquadreams, which offers other equally exuberant sinks and Italian bathroom fixtures, is at 8606A Melrose Avenue, at Huntley Drive, in Los Angeles; (310) 657-3131.

title: Striking Drug Bosses, Not Street Dealers, Pays Off, the Police Say
description: New York City has seen a dramatic increase in felony drug arrests because of an emphasis on arresting the leaders of narcotics gangs instead of the street-level dealers, police officials told a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: Technology Sector Spurs Nasdaq; Dow Rises by 189.96
description: Paced by the technology sector, which propelled the Nasdaq market to its biggest-point gain on record, stock prices soared yesterday after the Government reported that consumer inflation nearly disappeared in May.

title: Sports of The Times; Danes Are Hoping To Silence the Party
description: THE official video promoting the Women's World Cup begins with the Stars and Stripes. Then there is footage of Mia Hamm scoring a goal. Next come more Stars and Stripes. Then a tape of the Olympic gold-medal ceremony in Georgia in 1996. It is, shall we say, a trifle jingoistic.

title: Pataki Urges Money Limits In Campaigns
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed today that New York for the first time place significant restrictions on the way politicians raise and spend money. But the Governor waited to present his long-promised campaign finance plan until the last scheduled day of the Legislature's session, giving the measure -- unpopular among lawmakers anyway -- almost no chance of passage in the near future.

title: Deutsch to Handle Britannica Account
description: Encyclopaedia Britannica said yesterday that it had named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle the account of the Britannica.com Web site, which is scheduled to be reintroduced in September after a revamping. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $35 million.

title: Old Balkan Hatreds
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Clash May Ruin U.S. Reconciliation Bid
description: Two weeks before North Korean and South Korean gunboats opened fire on each other in disputed waters, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry spent three days in the North trying to get a government known for its paranoia to build a relationship with Washington.

title: Big-budgeted campaigns for auto racing and golf reach out to spectators and sponsors.
description: AS summer approaches, two sports organizations are running multimillion-dollar advertising campaigns to woo spectators, participants and advertisers.

title: Confusion on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying Homage to a Guitar Idol Who Sees No Cause
description: Sal Salvador, one of 14 guitarists who turned out at the Kaye Playhouse on Tuesday to honor their idol and colleague Johnny Smith, told the audience how he had imagined the show should start: with a lone young guitarist onstage, lit by a single light bulb, playing Johnny Smith-style arpeggios. But then he corrected his fantasy. ''Who's going to be able to play those arpeggios?'' he wondered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Pact Reached on U.S. Edition of 'Lolita' Retelling
description: In a case closely followed by publishers because of its implications for copyright law, a retelling of Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lolita'' from the nymphet's point of view, whose publication was abruptly canceled last fall, will go forward as a result of an unusual agreement worked out over the last six months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPORTE, ANITA
description: LaPORTE-Anita. The Board of Directors of the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York notes with great saddness the passing of Anita LaPorte, mother of ABO's Executive Director Nicholas LaPorte, Jr. A beloved mother, doting grandmother, devoted sister, she died on June 15 after a brief illness. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her children, Nicholas LaPorte Jr. and Deborah Lumba, grandsons Matthew LaPorte and Nicholas Lumba and sister Esta Giordano. Michael Kerr, Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairmen Jerome Belson, President

title: Legislature Votes For Open Scoring
description: In response to the draw that resulted from the questionable scoring in the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight unification bout at Madison Square Garden on March 13, both houses of the New York State Legislature voted late Tuesday to require open scoring in matches held in the state.

title: A Time for Ken Starr to Keep Quiet
description: Kenneth Starr is reportedly preparing to issue what one of his associates called a ''blistering'' final report about the Clintons' conduct -- perhaps in the middle of Hillary Clinton's Senate campaign. If this is true, Mr. Starr would be making a terrible mistake. Issuing a highly critical report would be an abuse of prosecutorial power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Circuit City Plans To End Divx Unit
description: Circuit City Group, the consumer-electronics retailer, said today that it would end its unprofitable Divx digital videodisk venture, resulting in a $114 million first-quarter charge.

title: A Mayor's Like-Minded Charter Panel
description: In announcing the appointments to his Charter Revision Commission this week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sounded as though he were shouting out roll call for the Giuliani fan club. At least 11 of the 15 members have either worked in his administration or served as his appointees to other boards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APTHEKER, FAY
description: APTHEKER-Fay. Entered into rest on June 15 in San Jose, Ca. Loving wife of Herbert. Devoted Mother of Bettina. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Joshua Kurzweil. Memorial Service to be held at Oak Hill Chapel of the Oaks, 300 Curtner Avenue, San Jose, California, on Sunday, June 20 at 2:00 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the inscription on the ''Kryptos'' sculpture at the Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in Langley, Va., misstated the given name of the sculptor. As the related article said, he is Jim Sanborn, not David.

title: Twisted Tales
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
