title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Pope John Paul II's recollections of Jewish friends in his hometown, Wadowice, Poland, and their suffering in World War II misstated the name of a boyhood friend in some copies. He was Jerzy Kluger, not Jurek Kruger.

title: Hockey Viewers Increase; N.B.A.'s Drop in Canada
description: ''Playoff Shocker: N.H.L. Ratings Soar; N.B.A.'s Tumble.'' That headline will never be seen in America. But such news would surely cause swooning at Fox and ESPN, where hockey ratings are on a perpetual diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Welfare Debit Cards Offer Benefits and Some Snags
description: A few days ago, Juliana Almonte walked into Bravo Supermarket in Washington Heights with a shiny new card that was supposed to make her life easier and erase forever the stigma of food stamps.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCH, BENJAMIN (TOMMY).
description: HIRSCH-Benjamin (Tommy). Our sweet and wonderful DAD, gone 35 years. You are in our heart and soul everyday. All our love, your children Audrey, Peter, Gary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, ROBERT H.
description: RAMSEY-Robert H., 89. Died Thursday, June 17, in Southbury, CT. He was the husband of Vera (Volkert) Ramsey of Southbury and loving father of Jill R. Edgar of Stamford, CT, grandfather of Christopher Edgar of Stamford and Timothy Edgar of New York City. He was predeceased by his son, Robert ''Sandy'' Ramsey. He was a retired executive for the Newmont Mining Company, St. Joe Minerals, and was editor-inchief of Engineering and Mining Journal.

title: Pataki Rejects Plan That Would Have Wiped Out a 20% Cut in LIPA Rates
description: For a day at least, there seemed the possibility that peace would break out between Suffolk County and the Long Island Power Authority, that Nassau County would get a $100 million gift to close its canyonlike budget deficit and that no one would have to pay higher taxes or electricity bills as a result.

title: New Lenders With Huge Fees Thrive on Workers With Debts
description: A year and a half ago, Doris Rude, a taxi driver who is partly disabled by a herniated disc, was living at the edge of her income of $300 a week and had just $5 in the bank. Then she received a $1,900 hospital bill. With poor credit and no money, she turned in desperation to a new, fast-growing American institution: The payday loan company.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Tacking Down Two Musicals

title: CISCO AGREES TO $407 MILLION ACQUISITION OF TRANSMEDIA
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Transmedia Communications Inc., a closely held maker of equipment that brings voice, video and data together in a single computer network, for $407 million in stock. Cisco, which makes equipment and software that link networks of computers, said it hoped to use Transmedia's technology to help combine Internet-based data with traditional voice communications. Both companies are based in San Jose, Calif. Under the agreement, Cisco will exchange 3.15 million to 3.85 million of its common shares for all outstanding shares and options of Transmedia. Cisco shares rose $1.125, to $117.375.

title: Coyotes, Turkeys And Bears, Oh My!; Suburbs' Spread Flushes Wildlife Into Populated Neighborhoods
description: After wandering at least 100 miles, a 175-pound black bear found its way into the heart of the business district of West Haven, Conn., about 2 A.M. on May 1.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 3Com, maker of the nimble Palm Pilot organizer, is seeing its stock price atrophy these days.
description: AT a trade show presentation a few weeks ago, Dr. Robert M. Metcalfe, a co-founder of the 3Com Corporation, and Eric A. Benhamou, the chief executive, engaged in a brief discussion over who was older. Mr. Metcalfe, it turned out, was.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Leaving Poland, John Paul Links the Country With Its Faith
description: Bidding farewell to Poland, Pope John Paul II made a stop today at his and his country's most venerated shrine, the Black Madonna of Czestochowa, a medieval icon of the Virgin Mary that for Poles also carries vast patriotic significance.

title: Forward Claimed Off Waivers
description: The MetroStars claimed forward Lawrence Lozzano off waivers from the Los Angeles Galaxy yesterday, and he is expected to join the team for Sunday's game at Kansas City against the Wizards.

title: Allied Irish Banks' Move Into Singapore Seen as Mixed Benefit
description: A major banking deal that at first looked like a clear-cut victory in Singapore's effort to become a financial center of Southeast Asia is getting mixed reviews among investors and analysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARDT, HAL, DR.
description: REINHARDT-Hal, Dr. On June 16, 1999. Beloved husband, loving father, grandfather and brother. We will miss you always

title: Negotiations On the Role Of Russia Intensify
description: With the key issue of the distribution of Russian forces in Kosovo still unsettled, American and Russian negotiators returned to the table tonight, with orders to work through the night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Friction on the Knicks Still Follows Van Gundy
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy's strategy has been questioned and yet the Knicks are in the finals. His weary appearance has been poked at, but he's still the one standing with his team just four victories from a title.

title: All You Need Is Love
description: Music is John Lennon's most famous legacy. But he also left a more private heritage: a father's love and the art it inspired, which was meant to be seen, not sung.

title: CHILE'S ECONOMY SHRINKS
description: The Chilean economy shrank 6 percent in April, its deepest contraction since the Government began collecting monthly data in the 1980's, as anemic demand for the nation's products in Asia and Latin America sapped a once-vibrant manufacturing sector. Chile's worst drought this century also contributed to the decline, as a shortage of water for hydroelectric dams led to brownouts that hurt factory output. The peso slid to 504.05 to the dollar, its weakest rate of exchange in almost four months. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: INSIDE
description: Holbrooke Faces Senate

title: A Couple of Nerds Trying to Take Over the World
description: The swashbuckling title ''Pirates of Silicon Valley'' is absolutely right for a film about the birth of the computer age. After all, the tale of the battle for dominance between Apple Computers and Microsoft is brimming with those age-old elements of high drama: invention, big bucks and backbiting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGANA, PHILIP E., HON.
description: LAGANA-Philip E., Hon. The Brooklyn Law School community notes with profound sadness the passing of New York State Supreme Court Justice Philip E. Lagana, a member of the Class of 1948. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Josephine, his brother, Francis, and his entire family. Paul Windels, Jr., Chairman, The Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Senate Panel Weighs Curb On Shipment of Garbage
description: Senators and officials from states with fast-growing landfills and highways teeming with out-of-state garbage trucks used a Senate committee hearing today to begin the latest push for legislation limiting the interstate flow of trash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Sports of The Times; Robinson and Spurs Are on Top of World
description: IMAGINE what it's like to be 7 feet 1 inch and looking down on the world from the highest of professional and personal posts. What a perspective to have gained on basketball, and life.

title: Confidence in Fed Spurs Gain in the Dow
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday as investors and traders grew increasingly confident that the Federal Reserve would decide the economy needed little more than a tap on the brakes to keep inflation under control.

title: Rate Increase Signaled
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve gave his clearest indication yet that the central bank will raise interest rates at the end of the month.

title: Grotesques And Clowns In Surreal Fantasy
description: Deep in the heart of every man, an angry, persecuted dwarf is screaming for revenge. But once that lonely inner dwarf realizes that everybody else also has a goblin trapped inside, redemption is possible. After all, human proportion is in the eyes of the beholder. And in the end, aren't all of us ''little'' people crying out for recognition and dignity in the rough-and-tumble traveling circus of life?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR.
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. The members of the Philosophy Department at Columbia University express their sadness at the death of their distinguished colleague Paul Oskar Kristeller. He contributed immeasurably to the prestige of our department and will be deeply missed.

title: Clinton Sees No Quick Effect Of Indictment on Milosevic
description: Still trying to sort out the untidy aftermath of the Kosovo war, President Clinton suggested today that the indictment of Slobodan Milosevic by the war crimes tribunal would serve to isolate Serbia on the international stage but would not immediately affect Mr. Milosevic's personal position in Belgrade.

title: Daughter Knows Best In a Horton Foote Play
description: Lives shatter quietly in the plays of Horton Foote, and momentous events are often signaled with nothing more dramatic than a murmur. In the opening scene of Mr. Foote's ''Death of Papa,'' now at Hartford Stage, it takes just a single word and an answering silence to establish a sense that for one 10-year-old boy, the world has fallen out of joint.

title: A Recluse Meets His Match
description: IF you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably want to know is what, word for word, is in those seductive letters that the middle-aged J.D. Salinger sent in 1972 and '73 to the young Joyce Maynard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: After five years of high points and low, Microsoft drops Wieden & Kennedy for McCann-Erickson.
description: A FIVE-YEAR relationship between the Microsoft Corporation and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., ended abruptly yesterday, as Microsoft dismissed the agency and shifted its corporate brand account, with billings estimated at $100 million, to McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, a newcomer to the company's roster.

title: The Pope Goes Home
description: The flu that intruded on Pope John Paul II's 13-day trip to Poland was a reminder of the frailty of the 79-year-old Pontiff, adding special poignancy to a visit already full of emotion. Poles, while rejecting many of the Pope's doctrinal orthodoxies, nevertheless revere the Roman Catholic Church, which for centuries has been viewed as the guardian of sovereignty in an often-subjugated land. Many Poles believe that no one did more than John Paul II to save Poland from Moscow's rule.

title: City Scenes That Evoke A Hopperesque Mood
description: Urban geometric wonders of light and shadow have long mesmerized photographers. In the 1920's and 30's, they were shown in elegant shades of grays and blacks by artists like Lee Miller. In the 40's, Harry Callahan mimicked their syncopated energy by creating stark black-and-white images out of strips of multiple exposures. And in the late 50's, Ray K. Metzker, one of Callahan's students at the Institute of Design in Chicago, began to take a leaf or two from his teacher's book.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Legislating for Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Photographer Remains in the Shadows
description: WALKER EVANS

title: Firefighter's Death Prompts Change in Equipment
description: The Queens blaze that killed a firefighter has prompted fire officials to equip a number of specialized squads with air tanks that hold more oxygen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOKAT, PETER A., M.D.
description: BOKAT-Peter A., M.D. Died June 16, 1999, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Mona. Devoted father of Nicole, Pamela and Wayne. Father-in-law to Jay Lindell and cherished grandfather of Noah and Spencer. Dr. Bokat's only sibling, Dr. Michael A. Bokat, died of cancer in 1968 at the age of 33. Dr. Jacques Bokat and Helen Bokat, his parents, each lived to 90 years old. Dr. Bokat worked as a child psychiatrist at Flushing Hospital's Mental Health Clinic for 24 years and was a consultant for several mental health clinics. He also had a private practice in Great Neck for more than 20 years. Dr. Bokat was appreciated by his co-workers and patients, many of whom considered him as much a friend as a physician. Dr. Bokat was very proud of his family-Dr. Nicole, who is a college professor and writer, Pamela who is entering her final year of medical school and Wayne who is a sports writer in Southern California. Dr. Bokat's wife Mona also works in the mental health field and has been a social worker at Long Island Jewish Hospital for 15 years. She and Peter were married for over 40 years and considered each other the best of friends. Dr. Bokat's love, wisdom and sense of humor combined with a humanistic approach to those he treated, was considtently genuine and heartfelt. He will be remembered and missed by all those who knew him. Memorial service will be held Friday, June 18th, 12 Noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. 516-487-9600

title: The Odyssey Of Homing
description: Homing pigeons have a radarlike ability to return to their coops over long distances at great speeds. Can they beat machines? To find out, a car raced the speedy Hercules from the Alleghenies to his Brooklyn roost, left, a contest of wheels vs. wings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONIER, TOM T.
description: STONIER-Tom T., Professor. 72, noted scientist and humanist of S. Egremont, MA. died at home, June 15, 1999. Survived by his wife, Judith, seven children and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 20th at 2PM at the Egremont Congregational Church, Main St, S. Egremont. Donations may be made to Hospicecare in the Berkshires, Inc. 369 South St, Pittsfield, MA 01201

title: Political Briefing; It's Presidential Talk, And Hatch Is Listening
description: The hot political talk in Utah is that Senator Orrin G. Hatch has not given up on the idea of seeking the Republican Presidential nomination next year and, in fact, has pretty well made up his mind to form one of those ''exploratory committees'' to test the lay of the political land.

title: Exploring Fashion, From Aspiring Art To the Real Thing
description: Many exhibitions qualify as uneven in one way or another. But few cover the distance from ridiculous to sublime with the breakneck efficiency of ''Exposing Meaning in Fashion Through Presentation.'' Not even its cumbersome title slows the show's rapid ups and downs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: BANKS' SHARES RISE
description: Shares in the mortgage bank Alliance and Leicester P.L.C. and the Bank of Ireland shot up, reflecting analyst assessments that both were vulnerable to new predators following the collapse of their merger talks. The deal would have created a $19.1 billion group, breaking new ground in cross-border banking deals within the European Union. Alliance gained 3.9 percent, to 912.5 pence, while the Bank of Ireland added 4.3 percent, to 1,121 pence.

title: 'Desire'
description: National Arts Club

title: The Divergent Progeny of Granddaddy Ives
description: ''River of Light,'' a Peter Martins ballet choreographed last year to a commissioned score by Charles Wuorinen, and ''Glass Pieces'' by Jerome Robbins, set to excerpts from the music of Philip Glass, shared the bill on Wednesday night at the New York City Ballet with a repeat performance of Robbins's ''Ives, Songs.''

title: Hints of a Mild Fed Action
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, signaled yesterday that the Fed would take only the tiniest of steps to push up interest rates when its Open Market Committee meets at the end of this month. That is likely to have only a mild impact on the economy.

title: 'Eve's Vocabulary' -- Paintings by Deborah Rosenthal, 1988-1998
description: Brookdale Center, Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion

title: The Pull of Home Outweighs The Dangers for Kosovars
description: Aid workers put up two big signs with red skulls at the border here today, and they are thinking about showing a videotape of a cow exploding in a minefield. But nothing, it seems, can dam the flow of Kosovo refugees: Ignoring all dangers, more than 13,000 refugees today squeezed through the crowded crossing point here on the way, finally, home.

title: Screaming Lord Sutch, 58; Eccentric Even for England
description: Screaming Lord Sutch, the leader of the Official Monster Raving Loony party, who delighted even the victims of his lampooning of British politics over three decades, has died in London. He was 58.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: BIO-RAD OFFERS $210 MILLION FOR SANOFI-SYNTHELABO UNIT
description: Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc., a maker of diagnostic tests, has offered to buy a unit of the French drug maker Sanofi-Synthelabo S.A. for $210 million in cash. Bio-Rad said late Wednesday that it was negotiating with Sanofi-Synthelabo and with Institut Pasteur, the research group that owns 25 percent of the business, called Pasteur Sanofi Diagnostics. An agreement would take Sanofi-Synthelabo a step closer to its goal of shedding all units that do not produce drugs, after the union last month between Sanofi S.A. and Synthelabo S.A. It would also give Bio-Rad access to the growing market for tests for infections such as H.I.V. and hepatitis -- which Pasteur Sanofi sells -- and access to European manufacturing plants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the trial of a police officer, Michael Meyer, who is charged with having shot a man in the Bronx while off duty, referred incorrectly to the weapon used in the shooting. It was a 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun, not a revolver.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES. Sugar prices climbed on expectations that increased buying by Russia and other importers would soak up some of the excess supply. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.23 cent a pound, to 5.52 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, C. ELIOT
description: PIERCE-C. Eliot, 84. Of Northeast Harbor, Maine. Died on Saturday, June 12th. in Bar Harbor, Maine. He is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years, Dora Redway Pierce of Northeast Harbor and by his son Charles E. Pierce Jr. of Manhattan and Salt Point, NY, his daughter Edith P. Murphy of Rockland, ME., his daughter Joan P. Uraneck of South Portland, ME, his son Benjamin R. Pierce of Devon, PA. and seven grandchildren. A private family service will be held in Northeast Harbor on Saturday, June 19th. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Maine Community Foundation/ Watershed Project, 245 East Main Street, Ellsworth, ME. 04605. A gathering for all friends and family will be held following the service at 3 PM at ''The Coffeepot,'' 131 Peabody Drive, Northeast Harbor, ME.

title: XOOM.COM ACQUIRES PARALOGIC FOR $34 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Xoom.com Inc., an on-line direct-marketing company, said that it had agreed to acquire the Paralogic Software Corporation of Mountain View, Calif., for $34 million in stock to expand its reach to on-line users who are interested in building their own Web pages. Paralogic's Anexa.com service allows users to create Web sites and communicate with others with shared interests through Web ''communities.'' Xoom.com, which is based in San Francisco and has more than eight million members, offers Web pages and E-mail to users who agree to receive advertising for products such as computer equipment.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Even Daly Is Dazzled By His Work in Round 1
description: Many people were stunned to see John Daly shoot a 68 today at the United States Open.

title: In Oregon, Jobs vs. Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: In Ruse at Border, Borrowed Children Ease Illegal Passage
description: Agent Griselda Vidrio had just wandered into the United States Border Patrol's processing center after several hours patrolling the weed-girded Rio Grande when she caught sight of the young Honduran couple and the 7-month-old baby in their arms.

title: For Spurs' Jackson, Depth Is the Key
description: Jaren Jackson of the San Antonio Spurs is not surprised that opponents often challenge him to sling 3-pointers from the outside. After all, he has had his doubters before.

title: Russians Land a Big One; F.A.A. Gives Stamp of Approval to Ilyusian Cargo Plane
description: Displayed proudly above the reception desk of the Ilyushin Aviation Complex office at the Paris Air Show here is a newly minted air-worthiness certificate from the United States Federal Aviation Administration. On June 2, the big, four-engine Russian Ilyushin IL-96T parked nearby became the first wide-body jet, other than ones made by Airbus Industrie and the Boeing Company, to meet F.A.A. safety standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, GEORGE
description: SHAPIRO-George. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our longtime member. We send our condolences to the family. Services at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre on Sunday, June 20, 1999 at 12:00 noon. Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi Jeffrey H. Greenfield, President

title: Knicks' Task: Hold the Miracles and Devise a Plan
description: The Knicks began Game 1 with the dreamy look of a team that had put its faith in fairy tale endings and wishes upon stars. If the team just believed hard enough, everything would come true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINERMAN, JANET
description: WEINERMAN-Janet. The colleagues and friends of Roberta Brodfeld send their love and condolences to her at the death of her beloved sister Janet. Roberta and Janet cherished each other. Our sympathy goes to Janet's entire family. Her mother Emma, her daugher Ivy Newman, husband Howard and their children April and Brian, and her daughter Randi German, husband Jay and their sons Kenny and Keith. A wonderful sister and loving mother, Janet was a gifted pianist who brought joy to all. All of the League Center family extend love and sympathy.

title: Double Vision: The Return Of Powers, Austin Powers
description: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: No Pill for Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: So, Is This Why Einstein Was So Brilliant?
description: After sitting in pieces in jars for more than 40 years, Albert Einstein's brain is poised to make yet another contribution to science.

title: Ruling Restricts Defense Lawyers Who Also Serve as Prosecutors
description: An appeals court has ruled that criminal defense lawyers should not be allowed to moonlight as municipal prosecutors in the same county, which could end a practice that experts said was unique to New Jersey.

title: Senators Bend Neutrality In Helping Mayor Giuliani
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani does not have the Republican nomination for the United States Senate yet, but it was hard to tell that from the way he was treated here tonight.

title: Political Briefing; Funny Things Happen To Quayle in Dixie
description: Maybe Dan Quayle should give up on scheduling trips to the Deep South to raise money for his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination next year.

title: Outcry Over Use of Hitler Quote in Yearbook
description: An outcry from parents over a high school senior's use of a yearbook quotation from Hitler's memoir, ''Mein Kampf,'' has led to a written apology from the student and the reprinting of some copies of the book.

title: Lome Journal; Trail of Brutality Mars Rebel's Return to Civil Life
description: Meet the aging fighter from the bush in his five-star hotel suite, the sitting room table covered with proposals to end the endless war and spare his life.

title: Foreign Affairs; Barak in A Hard Place
description: If you want to understand why Israel's Ehud Barak has had such a hard time forming a new government after winning a landslide victory last month, you can reduce it to one scene. Last week Israel's new Knesset, its Parliament, was sworn in. At the start of the ceremony all members were asked to stand and sing ''Hatikva,'' the Israeli national anthem. Nearly 30 of the 120 members of the Knesset weren't singing. These were the non-Zionist members, ranging from Israeli Arabs to ultra-Orthodox Jews, who share an ambivalence toward the secular Israeli state.

title: SUNY History Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Are 'Viruses' Naughty by Nature?
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES IN $1.65 BILLION DEAL WITH U S WEST
description: The Citizens Utilities Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy telephone properties from U S West Communications Inc. for about $1.65 billion to expand its telephone business. Citizens Utilities, a phone, electric, gas and water services provider based in Stamford, Conn., said it would buy 530,000 phone lines in nine states from U S West, the regional telephone company based in Denver. Citizens will have 1.7 million phone lines in 19 states when it finishes the U S West acquisition and a $664 million purchase of 187,000 phone lines from the GTE Corporation that was announced last month. The company said it would sell its utilities business to be solely a telecommunications company.

title: Jack Campbell, 82, New Mexico Leader From 1963 to 1967
description: Jack M. Campbell, a former governor of New Mexico, died on Monday in a retirement home in Santa Fe. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Sheraton Account Goes to DDB
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide said yesterday that it had awarded the account for its Sheraton brand to the New York office of DDB Worldwide Communications Group, part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $65 million.

title: Advocates for Immigrant Students Protest New English Exam
description: As 11th graders take a rigorous new Regents English exam today that will determine if they will graduate, advocates for immigrants warn that the test could be catastrophic for many who entered New York City schools with limited English and have tried to catch up in bilingual and intensive English classes.

title: Resegregation in the Schools Hurts All Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Prosecutor Nominated To Succeed Former Boss
description: New Jersey's senior Senator, Frank R. Lautenberg, yesterday recommended Paul J. Fishman, a former Federal prosecutor, to be the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Covert Plan Said to Take Aim At Milosevic's Hold on Power
description: President Clinton has approved a covert action program that calls for the Central Intelligence Agency to try to destabilize the Yugoslav Government of Slobodan Milosevic, United States officials said.

title: Stay in Kosovo, Orthodox Leaders Urge Serbs
description: At the Gracanica monastery, the holiest site in eastern Kosovo, leaders of the Serbian Orthodox Church and a NATO general joined tonight to implore about 2,000 anxious Serbs to remain in Kosovo rather than follow the thousands who have fled in long convoys behind withdrawing Yugoslav forces.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining section on Wednesday about Manhattan restaurants that serve outstanding dishes for less than $10 misstated the address of El Fogon. It is at 183 East 111th Street, not No. 83.

title: Michigan Lawmaker's Agenda Highlights a Split
description: Representative John D. Dingell faced the toughest vote in his long Congressional career: whether to ban assault weapons.

title: ANOTHER TELEFONICA DEAL
description: The Spanish telecommunications company, Telefonica, won approval from Brazil's stock market regulator for up to $330 million in public tender offers to buy the outstanding shares of four Brazilian wireless phone companies. Last July, Telefonica by itself bought the controlling stakes in two of them. For the other two, it bought control with its Spanish partner, Iberdrola, a power company. Telefonica, the largest phone company in Brazil, also announced this week the purchase of a controlling stake in Nutec, an Internet provider in Brazil. Juan Villalong, above, the company's chief executive, has been pushing Telefonica into Latin America. Al Goodman (NYT)

title: A New Course on Iraq
description: The stalemate over Iraq's illegal biological and chemical weapons programs grows increasingly dangerous. United Nations inspectors have been barred since last December, leaving Baghdad free to rebuild its stocks of deadly toxins, germs and nerve gas in secret. Under these circumstances, the Clinton Administration is right to give provisional endorsement to a new United Nations resolution sponsored by Britain and the Netherlands that may point a way out of the impasse. In doing so, Washington has put aside its counterproductive insistence that sanctions against Iraq must remain in place as long as Saddam Hussein holds power.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I understand that simply posting the Ten Commandments will not instantly change the moral charcter of our nation. However, it is an important step to promote morality and an end of children killing children.''

title: Resegregation in the Schools Hurts All Students
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINCIPAL FINANCIAL IN $1.4 BILLION BANK DEAL
description: The Principal Financial Corporation, a life insurance company based in Des Moines, agreed to buy Bankers Trust Australia Ltd. from Deutsche Bank A.G. for $2.1 billion (Australian), or $1.4 billion (United States), a spokeswoman for the German bank said yesterday. Deutsche Bank, which bought the Bankers Trust Corporation this month, is selling the Australian unit because it overlaps with its own business. With the acquisition, Principal will become one of the largest fund managers in Australia, where the pension market has been growing rapidly as a result of a Government push to increase retirement savings. BT Australia manages $41.1 billion (Australian) and has about 7 percent of the Australian funds market.

title: Graves Desecrated, Souls Sold to the Devil. Scary!
description: If Quentin Tarantino had gotten his directorial hands on ''Rosemary's Baby'' or ''The Exorcist,'' the results might very well have resembled ''The Day of the Beast.''

title: A Medal for Rosa Parks
description: With President Clinton, the Congressional leadership and a half-dozen aging warriors of the civil rights movement looking on, Congress on Tuesday awarded its highest civilian honor, the Congressional Gold Medal, to Rosa Parks, the heroine of the Montgomery bus boycott.

title: State Senate Approves Bill Protecting Clinic Access
description: The State Senate approved a bill tonight making it a crime to block access to abortion clinics.

title: There's No Ignoring Russians in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rallied against the dollar as hopes for economic recovery in Japan increased demand for the nation's securities. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.25 yen, down from 120.43 on Wednesday.

title: New Jersey Speaker Threatens To Block 'Smart Gun' Measure
description: Efforts to make New Jersey the first state to require so-called smart-gun technology on handguns sold in the state appeared to stall today, when the Speaker of the General Assembly indicated that he was unlikely to allow a vote on the bill.

title: Thriller With a Fetish for Motives
description: Murder on a military base was once a good enough pretext for a detective thriller, but nowadays it takes more. The prevailing sleaze quotient calls for kinks in a movie killing, and ''The General's Daughter'' is eager to oblige. So the title character is left worse than dead. She is found strangled, naked and spread-eagled, pinned by tent pegs in an exposed outdoor setting. And the camera lets her lie there for repeated long shots as the investigation begins. Though the search for a culprit holds surprises, this isn't one of them: the movie thinks she asked for what she got.

title: Racial Divide Found in Maternal Mortality
description: Though the nation's infant mortality rate has steadily declined over the last decade, the percentage of women who die in childbirth has remained essentially unchanged, and black women are four times as likely to die as whites, according to a Government study released today.

title: U.S. Says Photos Show North Korea Preparing for Missile
description: American intelligence agencies have uncovered evidence that North Korea is making initial preparations to test the launch of a ballistic missile later this summer, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUBACK, WILLIAM, PH.D.
description: KLUBACK-William, Ph.D. Beloved son of the late Benjamin and Hattie. Loving brother of Lois Michaels. Dear brother-in-law of Alan. Uncle and great-uncle. Services Friday, 11AM, at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside Bldg), 180 West 76 Street, Manhattan.

title: Khmer Rouge Killing Field Now a Projected Cargo Hub : In Cambodia, a Runway Forever Awash in Blood
description: KAMPONG CHHNANG, Cambodia  The hands that built the airport outside this provincial town are buried in the soft soil a few dozen kilometers away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, EDNA (NEWMAN).
description: BIRD-Edna (Newman). On Wednesday, June 16th, formerly of New York City. Wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Herschel N. Bird of NY and Marsha R. Bird and Leo Silvestrini of MA. Grandmother of Jennifer, Suzanne and Beth. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. & Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, June 20 at 10AM. Shiva will be private. Donations to the H.R.C.A., 1200 Centre St., Boston, MA. 02131. Information: Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Air Wars Won't Stay Risk-Free, General Says
description: The American general who ran the NATO air war over Kosovo warned today that it would be a mistake to think that just because the allies lost no lives in this one that future wars fought from the air would be risk-free.

title: Ford Raises Productivity At Its Plants
description: The big difference in labor productivity between American and Japanese auto makers in the 1980's, then a matter of considerable dismay in the United States, has been sharply reduced by Ford, but General Motors and DaimlerChrysler still lag, according to a comprehensive study released today.

title: South African Names Cabinet: Familiar Faces in New Posts
description: South Africa's new President, Thabo Mbeki, today named Jacob Zuma his deputy. The announcement ended speculation that Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the fiery leader of the Zulu Inkatha Freedom Party, would get the post in a move intended to strengthen peace between him and the African National Congress. Mr. Buthelezi remains the Home Affairs Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMAN, CISSY (GLORIA).
description: SHUMAN-Cissy (Gloria). Of Purchase, New York. Beloved wife of Norman. Cherished mother of Jane, Wendy, and Audrey and devoted mother-in-law of Bruce Nathanson. Loving grandmother of Florence, Andrew and David. Interment private. Memorial service at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, Rye, New York, date to be announced.

title: Dead Man Found on Train Was Visitor From Delaware
description: The man who was found dead on Monday morning sitting upright on a Manhattan subway train was identified yesterday by his family as a 36-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant who worked as a migrant farm worker in Delaware.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMPSTEAD, ELEANOR AVERY.
description: HEMPSTEAD - Eleanor Avery. We are saddened at the loss of Eleanor Avery Hempstead, a devoted supporter of Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic's Services on Eastern Long Island. Her commitment to reproductive healthcare and personal choice never wavered. We extend sincere condolences to her family. Reverend Mark Bigelow, Chair Rose Brown, Exec. Vice President Francine S. Stein, President/CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: 'Warning' Films: Sex and Drugs
description: ''Will tend to corrupt morals, will tend to incite to crime,'' said the New York Censors Board of Dwain Esper's exploitation films ''Maniac'' and ''Narcotic,'' which together with a new edition of Louis Gasnier's ''Reefer Madness'' have been released in a series from Kino International.

title: Rest of Kuwait (the Women) May Soon Get Right to Vote
description: Under floodlights in these sweltering nights, the men who gather to talk politics in outdoor tents are talking now about whether Kuwait will ever be the same.

title: Kellogg to Scale Back Hometown Operations
description: The Kellogg Company, seeking to break out of a prolonged slump, said yesterday that it might close part of a plant in its hometown of Battle Creek, Mich., and dismiss as many as 700 of the 1,100 workers there.

title: Undersized Knicks Face a Tall Order
description: After the Knicks practiced today, Larry Johnson was caught off guard -- a bit like trying to keep a pair of 7-footers away from the basket.

title: Reflections in Glass, Water and Wine
description: A treasury of priceless glass in a land of free-flowing wine: how good an idea is this?

title: 2 Koreas' Navy Vessels Circle Cautiously; U.S. Sends Ships
description: Ships from North and South Korea circled cautiously today in the Yellow Sea, where the two sides recently skirmished, but American ships were streaming toward the area in a display of force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: China Resettlement Plan Starts Debate Over Tibetan Culture
description: The World Bank today defended a proposed antipoverty project in a remote northwestern region that has been attacked by critics abroad as a threat to Tibetan culture, saying that many objections reflected misinformation.

title: Squeegee Man Tells of Shooting by Officer
description: A man shot last year by an off-duty police officer took the stand yesterday in the officer's trial on charges of attempted murder, acknowledging his own checkered past but saying that he was unarmed with his hands raised when the officer shot him. But during cross-examination, defense lawyers sought to paint the victim, Antoine Reid, as both chronically aggressive and a habitual liar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Falling Chunk of School Seriously Injures Construction Worker
description: A construction worker repairing the exterior of a Manhattan school was seriously injured yesterday when a large section of cornice broke off and struck him, officials said.

title: HOUSE VOTE DEALS A STINGING DEFEAT TO GUN CONTROLS
description: In a stunning victory for the National Rifle Association, the House early this morning narrowly approved a provision to regulate sales at gun shows that is substantially weaker than legislation passed by the Senate last month.

title: Lush Idylls in Never-Never Land
description: In 1925 a New York printing company called the House of Art estimated that one of its best-selling products, a lithograph of Maxfield Parrish's painting ''Daybreak,'' could be found in one of every four American homes. Even allowing for a titanic dose of hype, the statistic rings true. Like apple pie, the flag and indoor plumbing, ''Daybreak'' was, indeed, an American fixture.

title: Treasury Nominee Is Closely Questioned
description: During the height of the Mexican peso crisis in 1995 Lawrence H. Summers was the favorite target of the Senate Finance Committee. He was viewed as the scheming architect of an end-run around Congress that resulted in the $12 billion Mexican bailout. Some Republicans called for his resignation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLF, SYLVIA
description: WOOLF-Sylvia. On June 16,1999. Beloved sister of Martin Harmon and the late Harold Hertzog. Fond sister-in-law of Arlene Hertzog and Helen Harmon and of the late Rose Harmon and Edith Harmon. Loving aunt of Douglas and Joan Harmon, David and Rosalind Hertzog, Ona and Phillip Wexler, and Lawrence Hertzog. Great aunt of many nieces and nephews. Will be missed by her family and friends.

title: Toyo Tsuchiya -- 'Six O'Clock Observed'
description: Asian America Arts Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLARMAN, HERBERT E., DR.
description: KLARMAN-Herbert E., Dr. On Thursday, June 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Klarman (nee Monk). Devoted father of Seth Klarman of Brookline, Mass and Michael Klarman of Charlottesville, VA. Dear father-in-law of Beth Klarman and Lisa Landsverk. Devoted brother of Yetta Machtinger of Los Angeles, California. Loving grandfather of Ilana, Aleeza and Jeremiah Klarman, Muluwork, Rachel and Ian Klarman. Services at Sol Levinson & Bros. Inc., 8900 Reisterstown Rd, Baltimore, Md. (21208). 1-800338-1701 on Sunday, June 20 at 11AM. Interment Druid Ridge Cemetery, Pikesville, MD. Please omit flowers. The family has directed all contributions to Columbia College Fund, mail code 7730, 475 Riverside Drive, #

title: Beyond Bossa Nova: Notes From Today's Brazil
description: Take it as coincidence or take it as synchronicity or take it as one more affirmation of the ways musicians tune in ideas across boundaries and decades. The JVC Jazz Festival, which starts its major concerts tonight and runs through June 27, has two threads that connect its most promising events, two pervasive influences that should intersect at many different angles for 10 days.

title: Bill De Lottie and Cary Smith
description: Derek Eller Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Australia to Play Pakistan in Final
description: Australia tied South Africa in their World Cup semifinal at Edgbaston Cricket Ground in Birmingham, England, yesterday, earning a berth against Pakistan in the final on Sunday.

title: Delicately, Americans Patrolling The Peace
description: The two Black Hawk helicopters had not been in the air more than a few minutes this afternoon when the order came to check out a report that the Kosovo Liberation Army had set up a roadblock outside a hamlet called Pagonavic.

title: Giuliani Seeks Law to Make City Unions Show Spending
description: Saying New York City needs to do more to prevent corruption in its municipal unions, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani introduced legislation yesterday that would require the unions to disclose the details of how they spend their money.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: 'Me Tarzan' Returns, With New Friends
description: Every age gets the Tarzan it deserves. Now it's time for the animated version: one of the more exotic blooms in the Disney hothouse, with a supple, long-haired hunk for a hero (at right, with Jane), songs by Phil Collins and a graceful fusion of computer-generated imagery with sprightly, expressive drawing. This one finds new ways to swing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Tomb to Note Vietnam M.I.A.'s
description: Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War will be honored by an inscription on an empty crypt at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery, the Pentagon said today.

title: BANK ACQUIRES SECURITIES FIRM
description: The Montreal-based National Bank of Canada agreed to buy First Marathon Inc. of Toronto, Canada's largest independent securities dealer, for cash and stock worth $712 million (Canadian), or $488 million (United States). The National, Canada's sixth-largest bank, will merge First Marathon with Levesque Beaubien Geoffrion, a securities firm it owns. Combined, they have annual revenue of $600 million (Canadian), or $411 million (United States), and 2,700 employees.

title: Clemens Is Impressive, but It's Not to Be for Yanks
description: It was as if the Yankees were cursed like the Boston Red Sox, for one evening. When the first of Chili Davis's two line drives turned into a triple play last night, that was extraordinary bad luck. When his second line drive became a double play, that was plain weird.

title: In Oregon, Jobs vs. Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMERLING, WILLIAM
description: SMERLING - William. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Sylvia, his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and all his loved ones. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Ellen R. Saxl, President

title: New Refugees Join Those From Past Serb Wars
description: A jumbled line of tractors, horse carts and broken-down tanks stretched for nearly six miles into Serbia from Kosovo today, bringing thousands more displaced Serbs and a potentially troublesome burden for the Government in Belgrade.

title: Between the Bread
description: New Yorkers in a hurry reflexively reach for a sandwich, the perfect meal on the go. Here are a dozen places for great sandwiches. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOCCIA, NICHOLAS P.
description: MOCCIA-Nicholas P. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former Senior Field Vice President and respected colleague, Nick Moccia. His contributions to the strength and character of the company will be a guide for those who follow. We will deeply miss his wit, wisdom and warmth and extend our most sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Flynn, Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran, President & CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the settlement of a Federal discrimination suit against the Iron Workers Union misstated an element of the agreement. While the Center for Constitutional Rights, which represented the plaintiffs, estimated that the union would pay approximately $500,000 under the settlement, the final figure is subject to arbitration. The union has agreed to pay up to $1.1 million.

title: Stars Close In With Assists From Modano
description: This close and passionate struggle for the Stanley Cup could end as soon as Saturday, when the Dallas Stars could win the first championship in the 32-year history of the franchise. They scored a grueling 2-0 victory tonight over the Buffalo Sabres to take a lead of 3 games to 2 in the National Hockey League finals.

title: TAIWAN ORDERS DISMISSALS
description: Taiwan regulators ordered Fidelity Investments Management Ltd., a unit of the FMR Corporation, and Dresdner RCM Global Investors to dismiss two senior executives and bar them from holding any job in Taiwan's securities industry for five years. The Securities and Futures Commission said they had violated rules on providing information about unregistered mutual funds. It also suspended the operating license of Singapore's United Overseas Bank for a month for the same reason.

title: With Liberty and Prayer for All
description: There is no issue on which public opinion is more affirmative than the desire for a moment of prayer every day in the public schools. Nonetheless, the powerful minority of people who want no scheduled prayer in the schools insists on preventing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Frontier Board Discusses Bid By Qwest but Takes No Action
description: The Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's largest long-distance telephone companies, said yesterday that its board had discussed but took no action regarding the $13 billion unsolicited offer made by Qwest Communications International, the high-flying communications carrier.

title: Delving Into the Lore of Lucite
description: Design groupies, hold on to your fauteuils: the great decorator Elsie de Wolfe never designed a single piece of clear plastic furniture. And certainly not the major example that is continually attributed to her: a sparkling Lucite side chair with a plume-shaped back and a seat of luxurious silk velvet printed like an ocelot's pelt.

title: Greenspan All but Announces That an Interest Rate Rise Is Ahead
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave the clearest indication yet today that the central bank will raise interest rates by a quarter percentage point later this month.

title: Attendance Record Nearly Set
description: The second-largest crowd in the history of the N.B.A. finals took in Game 1 between the Knicks and the San Antonio Spurs on Wednesday. The Alamodome crowd of 39,514 fell just short of the 41,732 fans who watched the Los Angeles Lakers play the Detroit Pistons at the Pontiac Silverdome on June 16, 1988.

title: Donald Roller Wilson
description: Wright Gallery

title: Airlines, Being Pressed, Offer Modest Reforms to Customers
description: The nation's airlines announced a package of modest reforms today, including offering customers who call for tickets the lowest fare for which they are eligible.

title: A Versatile Game, and a Single-Minded Vision
description: Her mother exposed her to everything tap dancing, ballet, Little League -- but by age 10 Brandi Chastain was a soccer junkie. Forget ''The Brady Bunch.'' Chastain's idea of television fun was weekly highlights from the German Bundesliga.

title: Album of the Week
description: BLINK 182: ''Enema of the State'' (MCA Records). The makers of Top 40 pop are thanking heaven for the little girls whose appetite for generic Romeos is stimulating a music-business boom. But what's a little boy to do? Most adolescent males find the pinup boys repulsive. They need artists who understand that girls are a drag, parents are worse, and sometimes you're your own worst pimply-faced enemy.

title: Federal Panel Approves Indian Museum on Mall
description: The Commission of Fine Arts gave the Smithsonian Institution final approval today to build a museum dedicated to the American Indian on the Mall.

title: In a Race With Death, There's Only One Sure Winner
description: ''Run Lola Run'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 26. The film opens today in New York City.

title: Lucent Is Near an Agreement To Acquire Nexabit Networks
description: Continuing to push into the growing market for Internet equipment, Lucent Technologies Inc. is close to a deal to acquire Nexabit Networks Inc., a private maker of high-speed Internet switches, for between $600 million and $800 million, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Mickelson Shares Lead But May Not Stick Around
description: His wife is expecting a child on June 30, and until Tuesday morning, Phil Mickelson was not sure he would play in this year's United States Open. Winning a major championship is very important to Mickelson. But he said the birth of his first child, and the health of his wife, Amy, rank much higher.

title: Leiter and Mets Continue Dramatic Turnaround
description: Eleven days ago at Yankee Stadium, Al Leiter helped turn the Mets' fortunes around. Tonight, after his third successive strong outing, it looks as if Leiter might also have turned his season around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MARION K.
description: MITCHELL-Marion K. With deep sadness we mourn the passing of our beloved Aunt Marion. Her wise counsel over the years contributed to the success of our family business. Her caring, merriment and unfailing interest in us and our families enriched our lives. We will always miss her. We extend our sympathy to our cousins and partners Judy and Susan and their families. George and Steven Kaufman Kaufman Management Company

title: Odyssey of Homing: Tender Care Yields One Tough Racer
description: It's easy to be dazzled by speed. Man o' War. Secretariat. Citation. And Hercules, one of the fastest of them all.

title: Ancient Egypt Still Thrives
description: Twenty-one years after the Metropolitan Museum of Art created a sensation with its ''Treasures of Tutankhamen,'' a blockbuster exhibition that set the Met's all-time attendance record with more than 1.2 million visitors, the museum is bracing for a repeat performance. ''Egyptian Art in the Age of the Pyramids,'' a landmark show that has been four years in the making, opens on Sept. 16.

title: Residential Real Estate; Condo Shows Demand For Luxury Is Steady
description: The new owners who will start moving into the 20-unit condominium at 145 East 76th Street next month are part of a deep-pocketed group of apartment buyers being sought by developers of a string of Manhattan buildings that consist only of ''family size'' luxury condos intended to sell for an average of $1,100 a square foot.

title: New Video Releases
description: Patch Adams

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORKMAN, WENDY JANE.
description: WORKMAN-Wendy Jane. On Monday, June 14. Sarah Holland, Samm Carlton, Emily Morgan, Linda Van Ness, Chava Zucker, Joan Kaplan, Jim Kowal and friends mourn the loss of Wendy Workman, photographer of souls, indomitable spirit, and amazing friend. Funeral service on Sunday, June 20th at twelve Noon, at thePlaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 91 St. Contributions in her memory may be sent to: Dai Bosatsu Zendo, HCR 1, Box 171, Livingston Manor, N.Y. 12758-9732.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: BERNSTEIN-Sylvia. Sylvia Bernstein, loving and devoted mother of Allen J. Bernstein and Helene Morrison, and adoring grandmother of Stacey Stolar, died on June 13th after a long illness. She was a woman whose nurturing love, encouragement, strength and compassion shaped and enriched the lives of her children and her granddaughter. She took enormous pride in their many achievements, and always gave them her love, wisdom and unflagging support. Her endearing personality, warmth, wit and sincerity were cherished by her extended family and her many friends. The great void in her life was the loss of the love of her life, her dear husband Morty, who was taken from her and his loving family in 1974. She was known for her gracious hospitality, her infectious optimism and the diversity of her activitieswhich ran the gamut from golf to mah jongg. She was a woman of uncommon kindness, great dignity and unqualified love. And she will be missed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Compaq Projects a Loss And Plans a Reorganization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SHERMAN
description: DAVIS-Sherman. Of Manassas, Virginia, formerly of Long Branch NJ. Survived by several nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a graveside funeral service Sunday, June 20, at 10 A.M. at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Gill Lane, Iselin, N.J. For more information contact the Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Avenue, Westfield, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPPERSMITH, HAROLD H.
description: COPPERSMITH-Harold H., Dr. The Medical Staff of the NYU Downtown Hospital notes with profound regret the passing of Dr. Coppersmith, a highly respected and cherished colleague. He was an astute clinician and teacher, trusted and beloved by his patients and students, and treasured by his friends. He was a consummate physician who, by his practice and example, deftly charted a passage between the art and science of medicine. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Estelle, and to his family. We will miss his unfailing enthusiasm and good humor. Lester W. Blair, M.D. President, Medical Staff

title: Amid Strong Demand, Fidelity Raises $1 Billion in Bond Sale
description: Fidelity Investments sold $1 billion in long-term debt yesterday after strong demand from institutions, which for the first time got a detailed look at the fund company's finances.

title: U.N. Agency Adopts Treaty on Child Labor
description: The International Labor Organization today adopted a treaty meant to abolish the worst forms of child labor, one that includes a contested provision allowing people under 18 to serve in the military.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a woman with schizophrenia who was charged with murder referred incorrectly to a New York State Assembly bill to increase services for the mentally ill. It would appropriate $200 million to create 2,500 new beds in supervised-living residences, not in hospitals.

title: Average Suburban Family (Pet Rat and All)
description: ''Sitcom'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 9. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Antoine Pevsner
description: Peter Blum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MINA,(TOW)
description: HIRSCH-Mina,(Tow) Died peacefully after a short illness on May 12, 1999. Wife of the late Thomas. Survived by her children, Donald, Diana, Fred and Valerie, grandchildren David, Michael and Amy, five great grandchildren, nieces and nephews and many friends. She will be dearly missed.

title: FRENCH COURT ALLOWS BID FOR BANKS
description: A French court rejected a complaint filed by Societe Generale and Paribas that sought to reverse the approval by Paris stock market regulators of a hostile bid for the banks. Societe Generale and Paribas have been seeking to deflect a $38 billion takeover offer by Banque Nationale de Paris that came weeks after both banks had agreed to a friendly merger. The two banks argued that Banque Nationale's bid was invalid because it left investors uncertain of the final outcome. But an appeals court in Paris ruled that it was insufficient grounds for invalidating the bid.

title: In This Play, to Be or Not To Be Is the Easy Question
description: In Denmark these days, gentlemen prefer blondes. The Gertrude at Claudius's side in Richard Schechner's pop cultural mix-and-match ''Hamlet'' wears pearl-white halter-top dresses, puckers her lips coyly and speaks in the baby-doll cadences of -- boop-boop-ee-doop -- you know who.

title: Fox Broadcasting's Chairman To Lead Sports Media Unit
description: David Hill, chairman of the Fox Broadcasting Company, is leaving that post to become the chairman of a new entity, the Fox Sports Television Group, which will oversee all the worldwide sports media operations controlled by Fox.

title: Last-Minute Maneuvering Before Gun-Control Debate
description: Night was approaching and time was growing short to change the hearts and minds of lawmakers as three Democrats gathered for another of the week's relentless publicity offerings on gun control.

title: There's No Ignoring Russians in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilde as Sensitive Guy, So Wise and Insightful
description: Political blackmail, insider trading, incriminating documents, sex as a bargaining tool, potential trial by tabloid and sanctimonious public oratory masking frantic behind-the-scenes wheeling and dealing. In some ways, the world of Oscar Wilde's 1895 play ''An Ideal Husband'' seems awfully familiar. As Oliver Parker's likable, handsome but diluted film adaptation of Wilde's melodramatic comedy enfolds you in a dream world of grand Belgravia houses swarming with Victorian London's beautiful people, madly flirting and exchanging bons mots, it's easy to sink into a ''Masterpiece Theater'' fantasy of traveling back to a more civilized time and place. Life at the top has rarely looked or sounded more fabulously elegant.

title: TIRE MAKER REALIGNS DIVISIONS AND APPOINTS LEADERS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had reorganized its divisions and named leaders for them as it cuts jobs and forms ventures with Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd. of Japan. William Sharp, now president of global support operations, will become president of the North American tire division, taking over from Eugene Culler, who is retiring as executive vice president of North American operations. The current European division will become two units, one covering the European Union and the other Eastern Europe, Africa and the Middle East. Sylvain Valensi will head the European Union business, and Michael Roney will be in charge of the other unit.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * In Helsinki, after a second day of negotiations, Russian and American officials reached an understanding on several issues regarding Russian troops in Kosovo, but failed to resolve the issue of their geographical distribution.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELAWARE NORTH CO., which owns the Boston Bruins hockey team and runs concessions at arenas, national parks and airports around the country, said it would relocate its headquarters but remain in Buffalo, putting to rest talk that it was preparing to move its operations out of state.

title: 'Pearl Fishers,' 'Figaro' and 'Othello' in St. Louis
description: The Opera Theater of St. Louis, now in its 24th season, is like an exotic flower that blossoms in the spring, provides a brief splash of color and then disappears for a year. With a budget of $5.5 million, the company presents four operas -- typically one recent or commissioned work and three familiar ones -- staged by directors with international reputations and performed by singers who are young and promising but by no means inexperienced, supported by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLIN, BUZ (ALAN).
description: GITLIN-Buz (Alan). Of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Died at 52, after a long illness. Devoted son of Rose and the late Mac of Great Neck. He was the precious husband of Jane Samuels for almost 30 years and the adored and adoring father of Nikki. Beloved brother of Bruce Gitlin (Carol Schrager) and Susan Cherlin (Dr. Edward) and favorite uncle of many nieces and nephews. Funeral Friday, June 18th, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'' Woodbury, L.I. Contribution to N.S.U.H. Nephrology Division, 100 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021. His love and humor will forever be remembered.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Gov. George W. Bush's Presidential campaign referred imprecisely to a response by Elizabeth Dole to his comments about who should be appointed to judgeships. After Mr. Bush said that opposition to abortion would not be a litmus test for judicial nominees if he became President, a spokesman for Mrs. Dole said her appointees would have to share her ''general philosophy.'' The spokesman explained that although Mrs. Dole opposed abortion except in cases of incest, rape or danger to the pregnant woman's life, the candidate had not specifically cited abortion as an issue on which she and an appointee would have to agree.

title: XEROX WILL BUILD A $325 MILLION FACTORY IN IRELAND
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would build a $325 million factory to make inkjet printer parts in Ireland. The factory will consist of two plants totaling 170,000 square feet in Dundalk, where Xerox is completing a color-toner plant. The first, scheduled to open by the end of the year, will make ink tanks. The second, expected to open in the middle of next year, will make print heads. The plants will employ 1,000 manufacturing workers and engineers by 2003. Xerox will also add 300 customer service workers in Dublin. Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said in March that it was expanding its line of copiers, scanners, printers and fax machines to increase its share of the consumer office-machines market. Yesterday, its shares fell 31.25 cents, to $58.

title: Collecting A Curious Postscript To a Proud Brand's Tale
description: IN 1955, on the verge of collapse, Packard the luxury car maker that was sometimes called America's Rolls-Royce -- designed an elegant show car in response to loyal customers' requests for a Packard that resembled the ones of old. The $20,000 prototype was enthusiastically received but never made it into production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: On My Mind; Waiting for the Noose
description: This column has three motivations. One is to try to help save the lives of at least 13 Iranian Jews who will be hanged unless the Western governments, people and press pay attention. So far, there has been painfully little from any of the three.

description: Paul Kasmin Gallery

title: Safir's Approval Ratings Drop Sharply in Poll
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir has said the public opinion poll he really cares about is the one taken daily inside City Hall that has a survey sample of exactly one -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Sears to Push Apparel Campaign
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company in Hoffman Estates, Ill., said yesterday that a revised campaign to promote apparel sales would be created by both its lead agencies.

title: IVAX ACQUIRES 35% STAKE IN AN ON-LINE DRUGSTORE
description: The Ivax Corporation, a generic drug maker, said yesterday that it had bought a 35 percent stake in go2pharmacy.com, a new company in Albuquerque, N.M., that will sell discount generic prescription drugs, vitamins, herbs and other health care products on line. Terms were not disclosed. Forrester Research Inc. has said that the market for on-line drug sales will reach about $6.3 billion in five years, up from $213 million last year. Ivax, based in Miami, had $637.9 million in sales last year. Ivax shares rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $13.375.

title: A World of Their Own
description: Women's World Cup team capsules. After round-robin play, the top two teams from each group advance to the single-elimination quarterfinal round. By Jere Longman

title: Monkey Business: Rewriting the Jungle Book
description: Every age gets the ''Tarzan'' it deserves, from the gung-ho jungle swinger of Johnny Weissmuller's day to the culture-shocked repatriated Englishman of the 1984 ''Grey stoke.'' Now it's time for the Disney version: a supple long-haired hunk who so benefits from inter-species adoption that he thinks of himself as a differently abled ape. ''I'll be the best ape ever!'' this young Tarzan declares, courting the same A for attitude to which the movie itself aspires.

title: TOBACCO ADS BANNED
description: British authorities said that most billboard, newspaper and magazine advertising for tobacco products would be banned beginning Dec. 10, 1999 -- 18 months before a European Union deadline. Draft legislation also outlawed most forms of tobacco sponsorship beginning July 2003. The move had no big impact on tobacco company shares.

title: DIAMOND EXPORTS TO RESUME
description: De Beers said it expects to resume exporting diamonds from South Africa next week after it and the Government's gem assessor declared a truce in an 11-week tax dispute. The assessor, DVIC Valuations Ltd., has said that De Beers could be underestimating the value of the gems it sells abroad to save on taxes. De Beers denies any wrongdoing. Talks will continue as shipments resume.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Local is a restaurant that comes with a motto and a manifesto. The motto is ''evolved New York cuisine.'' The manifesto, printed at the top of the menu, announces that Local is intended to be a hangout, the equivalent of the old corner cafe patronized by brawny millworkers but revised upward to appeal to the toilers in the 21st-century knowledge industries, the sort of folk who don't flinch at a $24 lunch entree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Helms Prods Holbrooke And Receives A Concession
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms, said today that he believed that Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's nominee as chief diplomat to the United Nations, had ''violated the law several times.''

description: A counselor for troubled youths in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. -- who the authorities say killed at least three people while running a lucrative drug-dealing business in upper Manhattan -- was among 12 people indicted yesterday on Federal charges of racketeering, drug-dealing and murder, officials said.

description: Even though it means a tax increase, voters in the Elwood School District here turned out in record numbers on Wednesday and approved a referendum that will enable any of the district's 13,000 residents to get a full-service library card in six neighboring towns.
