title: Jousting for Dummies: A Manual for Medieval Life
description: A good deal of mystery still surrounds the vivacious 15th-century German manuscript known as ''The Medieval Housebook,'' part idyll, part real-life manual for the landed gentry. Its miscellaneous, completely secular content deals with such matters as astronomy, astrology, courtly love, chivalry, mining, metallurgy, jousting, warfare, recipes, medications, castle defense, animal husbandry and the trapping of men by female predators.

title: The New Key to Employee Loyalty May Unlock a Leased BMW
description: Forget dental benefits and stock options. When Al Galdi was searching for a perk to inspire employee loyalty, he wanted something a bit more, well, dynamic.

title: Applebee's Drops Incumbent Agency
description: Applebee's International in Overland Park, Kan., which operates 950 Applebee's Neighborhood Bar and Grill restaurants, has dismissed its agency of seven years, Wyse Advertising in Cleveland, by eliminating it from an account review. Billings were not disclosed, but Competitive Media Reporting reported that spending last year was $35.5 million.

Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Gervin and A.B.A. Saluted

It was a tribute not only to Gervin, whose silky playing style earned him the nickname the Iceman, but also to the American Basketball Association, the league that used a red, white and blue basketball before merging with the N.B.A. in 1976.

description: The nation's trade deficit in goods and services narrowed in April from March's record high as exports rose for the first time in six months.

title: Cardinal Hume Is Dead at 76; Leader of England's Catholics
description: Basil Cardinal Hume, who led the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales for 23 years, forging a renewed public role for the institution in a country where even the word ''Popish'' had long been a derogatory adjective, died yesterday in London. He was 76.

Adored uncle and greatuncle. Service Friday, 11AM, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Texas Executes Canadian Killer Despite International Pleas
description: A Canadian man who survived nine dates with death in 22 years on death row in Texas was executed today despite international pleas again to halt the proceeding.

title: COMPASS BANCSHARES TO BUY HARTLAND FOR $85 MILLION
description: Compass Bancshares Inc. said it had agreed to buy the closely held Hartland Bank N.A. for $85 million in cash to strengthen its banking network in Texas. With Hartland, its third acquisition in Austin, Tex., since 1997, Compass will increase its locations in Texas to 19. Hartland has $294 million in assets and six branches. Compass, based in Birmingham, Ala., has $17.3 billion in assets and operates 293 offices in Texas, Florida, Arizona and Alabama. Compass shares rose 25 cents, to $26.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, J.F.
description: POWERS-J.F. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Beijing Calls U.S. Explanation of Embassy Bombing 'Unconvincing'
description: One day after Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering presented Chinese officials with a detailed explanation of how NATO warplanes could have accidentally bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last month, the Chinese Government rejected it today as ''unconvincing.''

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Gore Returns to the Scene of a Flop
description: Al Gore returned to New York as an official candidate for President yesterday, hoping to reverse the fortunes of his last such outing, in 1988, when the state's primary drove him from the race and frayed his relations with his own party.

title: Arrest of 13 Iranian Jews as Spies Divides Factions in Teheran
description: The arrest of 13 Iranian Jews on charges of spying for the United States and Israel has emerged as a new focal point in the struggle between moderates and conservatives in Teheran.

title: Bowing Out With Youthful Strauss
description: Two foolproof standbys and an amiable curiosity sent New York Philharmonic subscribers home for the season on Wednesday. This final program at Avery Fisher Hall, to be repeated tonight, had Kurt Masur conducting the Prokofiev First and Beethoven Seventh Symphonies. Sarah Chang was the soloist for Richard Strauss's D minor Violin Concerto.

title: High Dudgeon Stalking Huge Judgments
description: ANOTHER ho-hum seven days in the legal salt mines for Thomas A. Moore, whose date book probably reads something like this: Friday, win $76.4 million verdict against New York City. Tuesday, win legal motion that helps insulate April verdict of $54 million. Yesterday, opening arguments, new trial.

title: Fire Set Next Door Burns A Clinic on Staten Island
description: A Brooklyn hospital's satellite clinic on Staten Island, which had been scheduled to open within two weeks, was badly damaged by a fire that was intentionally set Wednesday night, according to Brian Dickson, a Fire Department spokesman.

description: FORCHELLI-Vincent. In fond memory of Mr. Vincent Forchelli. Member of the Board of Directors of Queens County Neuropsychiatric Institute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Oscar for Short Documentaries Survives
description: Rescinding an earlier decision that drew heavy protest from well-known filmmakers, the board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has voted to continue giving separate Oscars for short documentaries.

title: Another Injured Knick
description: Chris Dudley put a scare into the already thin Knicks when he was unable to bend his injured right elbow early yesterday afternoon, but the swelling subsided to enable him to start Game 2 against San Antonio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, SAMUEL
description: LESSER-Samuel, 81, died June 17, 1999. Graduate of CCNY, class of '39. Beloved father of Anne-Gail Lesser Lufrano and Barbara Lesser-Tessmann. Devoted grandfather of Matthew, Reuben, Rachel and Elizabeth Lufrano. Services 10 AM Sunday at Cornell Memorial, 247 White St., Danbury, CT.

title: The Votes for Gun Control
description: KEY TO THE TABLES

title: Accord Is Reached on Integrating Russian Troops in Kosovo Force
description: Russia and the United States, ending three days of grueling negotiations, signed a military agreement today that integrates Russia into the Kosovo peacekeeping force, dividing most of the 3,600 planned Russian troops among three of five sectors led by NATO countries.

title: $45 MILLION PURCHASE OF DANKA BUSINESS HOLDING IS SET
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Danka Business System P.L.C.'s Omnifax business for $45 million in cash to increase its distribution channels and customers for fax products. Omnifax, which is based in Austin, Tex., and sells fax equipment, had sales of more than $110 million in the year that ended March 31. It has 600 employees. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., said the purchase would make it one of the nation's largest suppliers of business laser multifunction fax systems. Danka, which sells and distributes office equipment, said having a unit dedicated to selling fax equipment did not fit with its long-term strategy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PACIFICORP CORP., Portland, Ore., announced shareholder approval of a $7.9 billion takeover by Scottish Power, Glasgow, a leading British utility. The deal, announced in December, would form one of the world's largest power suppliers, with 7 million customers and 23,500 employees.

title: Politics Among Culprits In Death of Gun Control
description: For all the national horror at the carnage in Littleton, Colo., the sentiment could not keep gun-control legislation from collapsing on the House floor. All that was left this afternoon was a cloud of dust and a bitter political debate over who killed gun control in the House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. Happy birthday, sweetheart. You're always in our thoughts and missed so much. Remembered with love, Gene, children and grandchildren.

title: The Stage Turned Into a Circus, With Tricycle
description: ''The Unanswered Question,'' an 11-year-old work by Eliot Feld, is in effect the novelty of the mini-festival of American music at the New York City Ballet. Revived on Thursday night at the New York State Theater and worth a visit to today's matinee, the piece is as strange and charming as it was at its premiere.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORNMAN, IRENE
description: CORNMAN-Irene. Beloved friend. Naomi

title: COREL PROFIT
description: Corel, the Canadian software maker, said it would report a profit of 14 cents a share for the second quarter, a sharp reversal of the 14-cent-a-share loss recorded a year earlier. Corel, which is based in Ottawa, will release its quarterly results Monday. Its shares climbed more than 25 percent this week after its chairman, Michael Cowpland, said that the quarterly report would demonstrate ''strong profitability.''

title: Citing Low Scores, Crew Will Remove 5 Superintendents
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew has decided to remove at least five superintendents because he has lost confidence in their ability to lead and to improve student achievement, a top aide said yesterday.

title: Music Licenser Announces Agreement With Web Site
description: Delivering music over the Internet, long depicted by record labels as the illegal pastime of college students and pirates, won an important measure of legitimacy this week when ASCAP, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, announced a licensing agreement with MP3.com, one of the leading music Web sites.

title: Gore vs. Bush? Not So Fast; Candidate's Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, C. ELIOT
description: PIERCE-C. Eliot, 84. Of Northeast Harbor, Maine. Died on Saturday, June 12th. in Bar Harbor, Maine. He is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years, Dora Redway Pierce of Northeast Harbor and by his son Charles E. Pierce Jr. of Manhattan and Salt Point, New York, his daughter Edith P. Murphy of Rockland, Maine, his daughter Joan P. Uraneck of South Portland, ME., his son Benjamin R. Pierce of Devon, PA. and seven grandchildren. A private family service will be held in Northeast Harbor on Saturday, June 19th. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Maine Community Foundation/Watershed Project, 245 East Main Street, Ellsworth, ME. 04605. A gathering for all friends and family will be held following the service at 3 P.M. at ''The Coffeepot,'' 131 Peabody Drive, Northeast Harbor, Maine.

title: AEROPERU FUTURE
description: Continental Airlines' decision this week to drop plans to buy a stake in the troubled carrier Aeroperu has raised fresh doubts over the future of the airline. The grounded Aeroperu had hoped for a $30 million investment by Continental, which would allow it to resume service by next week and compete with LanPeru and Aero Continente. But after reviewing Aeroperu's books and being told by President Alberto Fujimori that chances were small of limiting competition in the industry, Continental withdrew its offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: At Graduation, Sweet Bird of Youth Takes Flight
description: Decked out in blue caps and gowns, the eighth graders took the stage in a sweltering gym packed with family members and local dignitaries. The guest speaker, Alice Turkel, a school committee member, compared them to the residents of the mythical Lake Wobegone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOONAN, MARGARET M.
description: CLOONAN-Margaret M. On June 18, 1999, at age 91. Beloved twin sister of the late Catherine and sister of the late Mary and Martin. Friends may call at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Epiphany R.C. Church, 2nd Ave. at 22 St., Monday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Ms. Browner Responds on Clean Air
description: Carol Browner, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has unveiled a rejiggered plan to improve air quality in the Northeastern United States. This will benefit residents in places like New York and New Jersey, which have long suffered from dirty air blowing in from the South and Midwest. It also sends a strong message that the Administration is not yet prepared to let two conservative Federal judges rewrite its clean air strategy.

title: INSIDE
description: Path Clears for Holbrooke

title: BIG ENTERTAINMENT IN INTERNET FILM DEAL
description: Big Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the motion picture, Internet and data properties of Paul Kagan Associates Inc., a media industry research and consulting firm, for $10 million. The deal gives Big Entertainment film industry research products and an on-line data base containing information on more than 67,000 films and television programs and a million members of the Hollywood entertainment industry, the company said. Under the agreement, Big Entertainment, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., will pay $9 million in shares and $1 million in stock rights.

title: All Is Ready, and the Stands Are Full
description: The Women's World Cup of soccer, once planned for small stadiums on the East Coast, will instead open today before what is expected to be the largest audience ever to attend a female sporting event in the United States.

title: Pataki Orders Gun Sellers At Shows to Check Buyers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would require a background check for anyone who buys a firearm at a gun show held on state property.

title: Andreychuk and Carpenter Released
description: In their first significant moves since being eliminated in the first round of the playoffs for the second straight year, the Devils signed a highly regarded young defenseman yesterday and released two aging former star forwards.

title: Lawsuits Are Prompting Calls for Changes to Clause in Nafta
description: A $970 million lawsuit against the United States Government by a Canadian fuel additive manufacturer has focused attention on a clause in the North American Free Trade Agreement that trade experts say may have to be rewritten.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Spurs Shoot, Miss, Win Easily Anyway
description: Less than two minutes into Game 2, Sean Elliott pulled up from 24 feet and launched an unsightly jump shot that smashed against the rim with a bang.

title: Corrections
description: A graph in Business Day on Tuesday tracking the ''advance-decline line'' on the New York Stock Exchange (the cumulative total of daily differences between the number of issues that rose and the number that fell) showed erroneous data from December through March. A corrected version appears today on page C4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: About New York; Landlord Role Causes Grief For a College
description: THE hallways of Teachers College at Columbia University form a maze so complicated that a visitor is tempted to pull out a compass before finally finding the two classrooms in Grace Dodge Hall that house the nonprofit program Brotherhood/Sister Sol.

title: Growing Signs That Serbs Removed Dead At Mass Graves
description: The blankets that villagers say they wrapped the bodies in before burial lie on top of the earth, empty. Alongside dozens of recently dug-up graves lie clusters of discarded surgical gloves.

title: Tougher, Stronger: Pinehurst a Dazzler
description: The conditions got tougher, the scores got higher and the leader board got even stronger. The first 36 holes of the United States Open have been intriguing, but the final two days should be memorable.

title: Mayor Confirms Newark Hired Son, but Assails Report
description: Mayor Sharpe James, in response to a newspaper article, acknowledged today that his youngest son was the latest member of the city's first family to land a job with the city government. But he went on to criticize errors in the article, charging that it was an effort to smear him and his family.

title: Team Chosen to Build Harlem Market
description: City officials announced yesterday that they had selected a development team to build a large supermarket on city-owned land in Central Harlem, but that they had left the politically sensitive decision of who will operate the store up to the developers. The decision means that the Pathmark chain, one of the losing applicants for the project, will have to compete with other supermarket operators to open a store at 145th Street and Bradhurst Avenue, a site that the company has had its eye on for more than a decade.

title: The Votes for Gun Control
description: KEY TO THE TABLES

title: When More Medicine Saves Money; One-Payer Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHENDELL, JACK
description: SHENDELL-Jack. Beloved husband of the late Lee. Loving father of Karen and Frank Schipani, Len and Marilyn Shendell. Cherished grandfather of Mia, Joseph and Jodi and great grandfather of Matthew and Allison. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Carl Orff's 1930's cantata ''Carmina Burana'' and its echoes in mainstream entertainment misstated the surname of the choreographer who staged it for the Pacific Northwest Ballet in Seattle. He is Kent Stowell, not Stoller.

title: Dingjiaergou Journal; Remains of a Day, Unearthed, Enrich Another
description: In Ding Yaohong's tiny sitting room, mud walls are etched with deep cracks and two tattered chairs vie for space with roosting chickens, signs of this remote region's desperate poverty. But the new centerpiece of the room, displacing a small, rotting table, is the valuable fossilized spine of an ancient spade-toothed elephant that Mr. Ding recently unearthed -- portending a more prosperous future.

title: Hiccup in Third Dooms Knicks
description: There was a moment in Game 2 when the Knicks had you thinking about how they got this far; a point near the end of the third quarter in which they trailed by only 3 points after playing so horrendously all night.

title: A Congresswoman Is Defiant in Defeat, and the G.O.P. Is Anxious
description: ''Let me go home,'' came the weary plea to the House from Representative Carolyn McCarthy as she watched her gun-control measure go down to defeat in the middle of the night, beyond the waking notice of most Americans.

title: In a Kosovo Town, an Experiment in Coexistence Ends After a Few Days
description: A few days ago, the Serbs here made a brave and unusual decision: They would stay in this hillside town, nearly 4,000 of them, and try to live again beside Albanians, even as their fellow Serbs fled the province in the tens of thousands.

title: Tort Reform: It's Lawyers Against the Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Charges for Worker Shock Youth Center Official
description: A counselor for troubled youths in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., who was accused this week of committing three murders as the leader of a drug-dealing gang in Manhattan, was an exemplary employee who had passed all background checks, the head of the youth center said today.

title: Regents Exam Tests Nerve, as Well as English
description: In their first crack at one of the new and stiffer high school exams that are meant to raise academic standards in New York, about 200,000 11th graders across the state took the first part of the revised Regents English exam yesterday, and many gave it mixed reviews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Living By the Books; Vermont Publisher Succeeds With Guides for a Simpler Life
description: On the second floor of a century-old brick theater building here, the staff at Chelsea Green Publishing has been puzzling over the phenomenon of ''The Straw Bale House.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, JOHN HENRY, M.D.
description: DOHERTY-John Henry, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn, with profound sorrow, the death of John Henry Doherty, M.D. As a resident and during his nearly 30 years on the medical staff at HSS, he provided the very finest quality orthopedic care to the Hospital's patients. During his 10 years as Assistant to the Surgeon-in-Chief, the Hospital thrived under his leadership. He will be greatly missed by all fortunate enough to have known him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Jack, James, Kathleen, Richard, Diane, Mary Jo and Thomas, and to his entire family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman Board of Trustees Russell F. Warren, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief John R. Reynolds, President & Chief Executive Officer

title: City Employees Charged In Benefits Scheme
description: More than two dozen municipal employees, including 15 school nurses, were arrested yesterday and charged with illegally collecting more than $70,000 in unemployment benefits over the last five years while working for New York City, authorities said.

title: AES IN PACT TO TAKE OVER NEW ENERGY VENTURES
description: The AES Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held New Energy Ventures, an energy services provider, for about $90 million to compete in American retail energy markets. AES, based in Arlington, Va., distributes electricity to nearly 14 million customers. New Energy Ventures, which is based in Los Angeles, has contracts to serve, among others, Rockefeller Center in New York and military bases in California. New Energy Ventures is owned by its senior management and by the Unisource Energy Corporation of Tucson, Ariz., a utility holding company, which owns the Tucson Electric Power Company as its principal business.

title: LEESON SENTENCE ENDING
description: A lawyer representing Nicholas W. Leeson said the 32-year-old British futures trader jailed in Singapore would be released July 3 and fly home to England after serving nearly three years of a six-and-a-half-year sentence for fraud and forgery. Mr. Leeson was arrested after making unauthorized trades totaling about $1.4 billion from Singapore. His actions set in train the events that led to the 1995 collapse of Barings, Britain's oldest bank. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Nefarious Goings-On In the Wilds of Allegory
description: Having warmed up its audience with three and a half weeks of Mozart, Verdi and Bizet, the Opera Theater of St. Louis presented the world premiere of ''The Merchant and the Pauper,'' an opera by Paul Schoenfield, on Thursday evening here at the Loretto-Hilton Center at Webster University. Mr. Schoenfield, an American composer who lives in Israel, is best known for virtuosic instrumental works that speak in the accents of jazz, blues, country fiddle tunes, klezmer and other folk styles. Lately he has been writing more copiously for the voice, and he does so with gracefulness, vigor and natural sense of line.

title: The Modern Gets to Keep Malevich Works
description: The Museum of Modern Art reached an unusual legal settlement yesterday that will allow it to retain 15 works by the artist Kasimir Malevich that it has held in safekeeping since 1935 in exchange for a cash payment to Malevich's 31 descendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMAN, CISSY (GLORIA)
description: SHUMAN-Cissy (Gloria). Of Purchase, New York. Beloved wife of Norman. Cherished mother of Jane, Wendy, and Audrey and devoted mother-in-law of Bruce Nathanson. Loving grandmother of Florence, Andrew and David. Interment private. Memorial service at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, Rye, New York, on Tuesday June 22 at 2:00 PM.

title: Beliefs; How much dissent is too much? Roman Catholic theologians and church leaders wage a war of words over the development of doctrine.
description: Two years ago, Bernard Cardinal Law of Boston denounced the Catholic Theological Society of America, the nation's leading professional society of Roman Catholic theologians, as ''a wasteland'' for its criticism of official church teaching.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * After three days of talks in Helsinki, Defense Secretary William Cohen and Russian Defense Minister Igor Sergeyev reached an agreement governing Russia's role in the Kosovo peacekeeping force.

title: ALPHARMA ADDS GERMAN GENERIC-DRUG BUSINESS
description: Alpharma Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the German generic-drug business of Schwarz Pharma A.G. for about $150 million in cash, expanding its operations in Europe. Alpharma said the business, Isis Pharma Group, has about 200 employees, including a 140-member sales force, and also give its product registrations and trademarks. No plants were included. About 80 percent of Isis Pharma's $75 million in annual sales comes from cardiovascular products, Alpharma said. Alpharma, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., has been buying generic-drug companies in Europe, seeking to establish itself as one of the Continent's top generic- drug makers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Widow of a Wealthy Man Is Indicted in His '93 Death
description: The marriage of Andrew G. Vlasto, 85, to a woman 57 years his junior lasted only three months before Mr. Vlasto, a member of a prominent Greek-American family in New York City, died.

title: GUN-CONTROL BILL REJECTED IN HOUSE IN BIPARTISAN VOTE
description: The House concluded a bitter, wide-ranging debate today over the seeds of violence among American children by rejecting, 280 to 147, a package of new restrictions on firearms that was significantly weaker than legislation approved by the Senate last month.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES' QUARTERLY NET EXPECTED TO FALL SHORT
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation, a leading builder and retailer of manufactured homes, said yesterday that its quarterly earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates by as much as 50 percent, and that it might sell the company. Shares of the company are down 52 percent in the last 12 months and fell 62.5 cents, to $12.125, yesterday. Oakwood, which is based in Greensboro, S.C., cited weak sales at both the retail and wholesale levels. The company also said it had hired Merrill, Lynch & Company to explore a sale or merger, including a buyout led by management.

title: China Says the Lama It Named Has Appeared in Tibet Capital
description: The 9-year-old declared by China to be the Panchen Lama, the second-ranking Tibetan Buddhist spiritual leader, has appeared in the capital of Tibet for the first time since his appointment in 1995, the state press reported today.

title: Tossing a King Overboard Keeps a Game High and Dry
description: Teams led by George Jacobs and Jeff Wolfson clashed yesterday in Memphis, in the final of the International Team Trials. After 90 deals of a scheduled 120, Jacobs led Wolfson by 1 imp. The winners will be one of the two teams to represent the United States in the world championships in Bermuda in January. Nick Nickell and his squad have already earned a position.

title: Louisiana Man Charged in a Robbery and Fatal Shooting in Queens
description: A 19-year-old Louisiana man was charged yesterday in a robbery and fatal shooting that fit a pattern of several crimes in the last two weeks in Queens, the police said.

title: Knicks Leave San Antonio Empty-Handed
description: It was early in the game, and Latrell Sprewell was in full intimidation mode. With a menacing glare, he was going to the basket hard and fast, like a rock from a slingshot.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I was in second grade, I felt I could be in elementary school for the rest of my life. But now, whoa! I've got to move on.''

title: Steal This Book: What the Bible and the Beats Have in Common
description: ''If I were asked what book is better than a cheap book, I should answer that there is one book better than a cheap book, and that is a book honestly come by.'' James Russell Lowell, poet and the first editor of The Atlantic Monthly, testifying before the United States Senate Committee on Patents on Jan. 29, 1886.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: The Mets Stay Hot as Benitez Catches McGwire Looking
description: On an evening that had previously belonged to a pair of 40-year-olds, Orel Hershiser and Rickey Henderson, the game all came down to one matchup. One very big matchup, indeed. In one corner was the 6-foot-4-inch, 230-pound Armando Benitez. In the other was the 6-foot-5-inch, 250-pound Mark McGwire.

title: When More Medicine Saves Money; Those Glossy Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the confrontation between South Korean and North Korean ships in the Yellow Sea referred incorrectly to the ammunition the South fired. It was 76-millimeter rounds, not .76-millimeter.

title: Witnesses Call Officer The Aggressor
description: Michael Meyer, the police officer on trial for shooting an unarmed squeegee man at a Bronx intersection last June, was described yesterday by witnesses as an aggressor with a hair-trigger temper who backed his victim across several lanes of traffic before shooting him in the chest.

title: Russia's Military Role in Kosovo
description: Provided no new hitches develop, the weeklong crisis over Russian participation in the NATO-led peacekeeping operation in Kosovo now appears satisfactorily resolved. Negotiations between top American officials and their Russian counterparts have produced an agreement that defines the zones where Russian troops will operate, the channels through which they will report to NATO's commander and their role at Pristina's airport.

title: Peeling Off Architecture's Tranquil Skin
description: On June 7 Sir Norman Foster received the Pritzker Architecture Prize. The ceremony was held in Berlin, where, by chance, Sir Norman's inspired remodeling of the Reichstag was completed in April. The Reichstag was topped off just in time to welcome the federal Government of a reunited Germany back to its prewar capital, and also to welcome the Pritzker's guests to architecture's toniest annual bash.

title: Squinting at a Web Book Academic Tool; Academic Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, PATRICK T.
description: KNIGHT-Patrick T. Former Secretary-Treasurer and President of Social Service Employees Union Local 371, on May 24. At the time of his death, Pat was an organizer for AFSCME. A strong proponent of participatory democracy, Pat contributed to the spirit and building of both Local 371 and the national union. A memorial service will be held June 21, 10AM, DC 37, 125 Barclay St, New York City.

title: Your Assignment: Fix New York's Schools
description: Rudy Crew, the Chancellor of New York City's public schools, occupies one of the hottest seats there is. Parents, teachers, the Mayor and many others have had criticisms of the schools, and suggestions of all sorts have been offered -- vouchers, tougher standards, year-round classes, bigger budgets. Here, an assortment of responses to the question, ''What would you do to improve city schools if you were Rudy Crew?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar and the euro rallied against the yen after the European Central Bank confirmed rumors that it had sold the Japanese currency. The dollar rose to 120.44 yen, from 119.25 yen on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOEHNER, FRED
description: GOEHNER-Fred. On June 18, 1999. Of New York City. Beloved husband of Amy Lennard Goehner. Dedicated dad to Nate and Joey. Devoted son of Eloise and Frederick. Dear brother Ann and Carol. A good friend and nice guy. Services 10:15AM Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in Fred's memory may be made to Cooke Center for Learning and Development, 475 Riverside Dr, Suite 730, New York, New York 10115.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL SERVICES IN AN EXPANSION
description: Integrated Electrical Services Inc., a leading electrical contractor, said yesterday that it had bought seven companies with combined annual revenue of $135 million, increasing its expected annual sales to $1.1 billion. Integrated Electrical, which provides electrical contracting and maintenance services, did not disclose terms. It had pro forma revenue of $470.2 million in the year that ended Sept. 30. Last month, it completed previously announced purchases of nine other companies with combined revenue of $90 million. The 16 acquisitions will give the company, which is based in Houston, new locations in Colorado, Delaware, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Pennsylvania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONYERS, HORACE J. (JOE)
description: CONYERS-Horace J. (Joe). On June 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee D'Arcy). Loving father of Dennis, Diane, Steven, David, Gregory and Liza. Cherished grandfather of Tara, Evan, Sarah, Andrew, Bryan, Julia, Allyson, Meaghan and Emily. Devoted brother of Sr. Elizabeth Anne Conyers FMM and Mary Emma. Mass Tuesday 10AM at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, Maple St., Brooklyn. Reposing at Joseph G. Duffy Inc., 255 9th St, Brooklyn. Visiting hours Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. The family request in lieu of flowers donations be made to Jamaica Hospital Pulmonary Rehabilitation Program, 718-206-8613.

title: Who Needs a Gun?
description: To the Editor:

title: Squinting at a Web Book; Too Many Monographs
description: To the Editor:

title: New Meter Is Said to Ease Parking, Once You Get Used to It
description: For the intrepid driver trying to park legally on Manhattan streets, here's a new test. What is a Muni Meter? (A clue: it's from Europe.) And how do you use it? (Another clue: it takes quarters, and be sure to take the receipt.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Kosovo Rebels Move Into Towns; Violence Is Reported
description: The Kosovo Liberation Army is setting up interim governments in a number of cities, moving rapidly to fill the civic vacuum.

title: Olazabal Punches Himself Out
description: Jose Maria Olazabal, this year's Masters champion, withdrew from the United States Open today after breaking his right hand Thursday punching a wall in his hotel room.

title: From the Midwest, No-Nonsense Moves
description: Since 1991 the Eisenhower Dance Ensemble has performed throughout the Detroit area, and on Thursday night it came from Michigan to Dance Theater Workshop. The program suggested that the troupe favors a hearty, no-nonsense way of moving.

title: Helping the Disabled Work
description: Sometimes a piece of legislation makes such obvious good sense that it commands support from all points on the political spectrum. That happened on Wednesday when the Senate voted 99 to 0 to pass the Work Incentives Improvement Act to allow disabled Americans to work without fear of losing health coverage under Medicare and Medicaid. The legislation would at last end the perverse financial disincentives in disability law that prevent people from becoming self-sufficient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Police Racism Charges Defy a Pattern
description: The Chicago police superintendent, responding to charges of racism in the department after the fatal shootings of two unarmed blacks in traffic stops here, said officers had violated department policy and announced that video cameras would be placed in patrol cars.

title: Democrats Are Left Straddling Mayor's Charter Review Plan
description: When City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi was asked this week about the panel Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has named to consider changes to the City Charter, he did not, in his capacity as a citywide elected official, offer an assessment. Instead, he referred the inquiry to his political consultant.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 11 about the soccer player Mia Hamm referred imprecisely to her goal-scoring record. She leads all players, male or female, with 109 goals scored in international competition, not in professional league games.

title: ABC Reaches Tentative Pact With Union On Contract
description: A tentative contract agreement was announced yesterday between ABC and the union representing hundreds of its camera operators, editors and other technical staff members nationwide, who have been involved in a protracted labor dispute that included an 11-week lockout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Oswald Tippo, 87, a Botanist And Chancellor at Massachusetts
description: Oswald Tippo, a former provost and botany professor at the University of Massachusetts and the first chancellor there, died on June 10 at a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Amherst. He was in Santa Barbara for a grandchild's wedding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Albany Notes; A Longer Lobbying Law, But Not a Tougher One
description: Break the law regulating lobbying in Albany -- by, say, failing to make public that shovelfuls of money were spent getting a bill passed -- and the state will mete out a penalty that amounts to say-you're-sorry-and-won't-do-it-again. So with the law expiring at the end of the year, some advocacy groups are calling on the New York Legislature to follow the lead of other states and set up a stricter system, with more enforcement and disclosure requirements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, LOIS H.
description: LIPPMAN-Lois H. Memorial service on Sunday, June 20th, 2PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: When More Medicine Saves Money; Don't Place Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Window for Woods Seems Wide Enough
description: HIS tee shot, as he likes to say, had ''flamed out'' to the right into the tall pines on the Pinehurst No. 2 course's 485-yard par-4 eighth hole, but when Tiger Woods got to his ball, he knew he had a shot off the pine straw.

title: Squinting at a Web Book; Accessible to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Concern About Coke Products Spreads to Spain and Germany
description: As health concerns about Coca-Cola products spread to Spain and Germany, the company's top executive flew to Brussels yesterday to try to solve the growing public relations problem that began a week ago when Belgians fell ill after drinking Coke.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the New York Philharmonic in Weekend yesterday misstated the birth date of Richard Strauss, whose D minor Violin Concerto was performed on Wednesday. He was born in 1864, not 1849.

title: Jews File Suit to Recover Assets in Poland
description: Eleven people, Polish Jews who survived the Holocaust or heirs of others who did not, filed suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to regain businesses and homes that they said the Polish Government had kept after the defeat of Germany in World War II. The property had been confiscated by the Nazis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, DOLLY WOLFSON
description: RAISLER-Dolly Wolfson. The adored wife of Robert K. Raisler, died peacefully on June 17, at her home in New York, surrounded by her loving family. She was the daughter of the late Solomon and Nechi Wolfson of Glasgow, Scotland, beloved sister of Rose Martin and Bebe Steinberg of London, and of the late Sam Wolfson, Sir Isaac Wolfson, Charles Wolfson, Jeannie Williams, Edith Hyman, Eva Gerber, Esther Levy, and Bette Shapiro. Dolly was a loving and devoted wife, a much beloved mother and sister, doting grandmother and aunt, and loyal friend. Her love, wisdom, generosity and encouragement enriched the lives of everyone. Dolly is mourned by her cherished husband of 42 years, Robert, her children Gordon, Steven and Lynn, her grandsons, Michael, Anthony and Joe, and by Joe's fiancee, Jordana Matthews. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81 Street), on Monday June 21, 1999, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Quibbling Over Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Tuesday about Chamique Holdsclaw of the Washington Mystics, in the Women's National Basketball Association, misidentified the Liberty player guarding her. The defender was Crystal Robinson, not Kym Hampton.

title: Gore vs. Bush? Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence Stone, 79, Historian Of the Changing Social Order
description: Lawrence Stone, a social historian whose broad view of the past helped transform historical studies, died on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTNEY, JOHN J.
description: COURTNEY-John J. On June 17, 1999. Retired General Superintendent of M.A.B.S.T.O.A. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee O'Connor). Loving father of Neal, Nora Doherty, Peggy McLaughlin and Eileen Pfingst. Cherished grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Michael and uncle of five. Reposing Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 79 pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue (at West 261st St.), Bronx. Mass of Christina Burial Monday 10AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Journal; Washington's Post-Littleton Looney Tunes
description: When Bill Clinton and Henry Hyde band together to protect the morals of America's youth, it must be time to lock up our daughters.

title: Danger Now Modano's Middle Name
description: A few years ago, when Mark Messier was a Ranger, he checked Mike Modano of the Dallas Stars so hard that Modano sustained a concussion. When the medics tried to lift Modano into an ambulance on a stretcher, they accidentally dropped him. So Modano knows that a hockey rink can be a dangerous place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Women's Soccer Trying To Crack a Granite Wall
description: THE great Pele was surrounded by children and besieged by adults. For a moment he was the acrobatic Cosmos star at midfield, surrounded, seemingly trapped. As a player he would simply spin, accelerate, explode and score. On this bright afternoon, there was no escape -- everywhere Pele turned there was love and reminiscences.

title: Editorial Observer; What to Do if Your Company Is Overvalued
description: Imagine yourself in the following position:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE COLOR OF SUSPICION
description: They say that they are colorblind. But police officers, white and black, use racial profiling. And they don't intend to stop. A report by Jeffrey Goldberg, in The Times Magazine.

title: DURAKON, MAKER OF TRUCK-BED LINERS, TO BE ACQUIRED
description: Durakon Industries, a leading maker of pickup-truck-bed liners, agreed to be acquired by the private investment fund Littlejohn & Company for about $99 million in cash. Littlejohn, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., will pay $16 a share in cash for the company, which also makes tow trucks and has five plants in the United States and Mexico. Its 1998 revenue was $192.3 million. Durakon has a contract worth $44 million to supply cargo-management products to the General Motors Corporation and no debt, said Gerald Marks, an analyst at Roney Capital Markets. Durakon's shares rose $3.50, or 29 percent, to $15.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANLEY, JOHN M.
description: MANLEY-John M. Born New York City, on April 4, 1919. Died suddenly at home in La Jolla, CA, June 18, 1999. He was a loyal son of Dartmouth College, a devoted husband, a loving father, an adoring grandfather. He is survived by his wife Carla of La Jolla, CA, his daughter Ann Schlesinger, and his grandson and namesake John Lewis Schlesinger. The family asks that any donations be made to Friends of Dartmouth Football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, ROBERT J.
description: GALLAGHER-Robert J. June 18, 1999, 61, of Darien, CT and Easthampton, NY. Beloved husband of Noreen. Loving father of Marie, Robert, Michael, Dennis, Kevin, Thomas and Brian. Dear father-inlaw. Cherished grandfather of six. Beloved brother of Paul and Kathleen. Reposing George Werst Funeral Home Saturday and Sunday, 7141 Cooper Ave, Glendale, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 10:15 AM, St. Pancras, Glendale, NY. Interment Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, Easthampton, NY.

title: Spurs' 7-Foot Stars Again Stop Knicks
description: The San Antonio Spurs, once again riding the offensive prowess of their star 7-footer, Tim Duncan, outlasted the Knicks for an 80-67 victory in Game 2 of the National Basketball Association finals last night at the Alamodome. The Spurs lead the series, two games to none, with Game 3 in New York on Monday night.

title: Ehud Barak: Serving by Waiting Out Opponents
description: Israelis abhor silence, and their Prime Minister-elect, Ehud Barak, has been as silent as a stone since his overwhelming victory a month ago.

title: When More Medicine Saves Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLARMAN, HERBERT E., DR.
description: KLARMAN-Herbert E., Dr. On Thursday, June 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Klarman (nee Monk). Devoted father of Seth Klarman of Brookline, Mass and Michael Klarman of Charlottesville, VA. Dear father-in-law of Beth Klarman and Lisa Landsverk. Devoted brother of Yetta Machtinger of Los Angeles, California. Loving grandfather of Ilana, Aleeza and Jeremiah Klarman, Muluwork, Rachel and Ian Klarman. Services at Sol Levinson & Bros. Inc., 8900 Reisterstown Rd, Baltimore, Md. (21208). 1-800338-1701 on Sunday, June 20 at 11AM. Interment Druid Ridge Cemetery, Pikesville, MD. Please omit flowers. The family has directed all contributions to Columbia College Fund, mail code 7730, 475 Riverside Drive, #

title: Russia Closes Posts on Border After Clashes With Chechens
description: Russia closed all but 10 of its 60 checkpoints along the Chechnya border today after nighttime firefights with Chechen rebels killed 7 Russian policemen and Interior Ministry troops and wounded 14 others.

title: PORTUGUESE BANK BIDS
description: The Portuguese Government announced its opposition to the bid by Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano, to pay $1.2 billion euros ($1.2 billion) for a reported 40 percent stake in Portugal's third-largest financial group, which is controlled by Antonio Champalimaud, and includes leading Portuguese banks such as Banco Pinto e Sotto Mayor and the insurance concern Mundial Confianca. Soon after Lisbon's decision was announced yesterday, the Banco Comercial Portugues, a leading private Portuguese bank, began a bid for shares in Mundial Confianca.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZZELLI, MARGARET SCRIPPS
description: BUZZELLI-Margaret Scripps, 77, of Sarasota, FL; died June 17, 1999 at her residence. Born on April 1, 1922 in Washington, D.C., she was the daughter of the late Robert P. Scripps and Margaret L. Culbertson. Mrs. Buzzelli was the Granddaughter of the Late E.W. Scripps, the founder of Scripps Newspapers, headquartered in Cincinnati, OH. Mrs. Buzzelli moved to Sarasota 24 years ago from Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Founder and President of Anabasis Rehabilitation Center in Sarasota, FL, was a graduate of Scripps College in Claremont, CA, and worked as a Journalist in the Pacific Theatre during WWII. Mrs. Buzzelli is survived by three daughters, Mary M. Peirce and Elizabeth A. Logan, both of Sarasota, FL, and Margaret E. McCabe of San Francisco, CA, Three Sons, Peter S. McCabe of Portland, OR, Charles K. McCabe of San Francisco, CA, and Robert A. Buzzelli of Sarasota, FL, One Sister, Nackey Scripps Loeb of Goffstown, NH, Three Brothers, Robert A. Scripps of Fredericksburg, TX, Charles E. Scripps of Cincinnati, OH and Samuel H. Scripps of Rhinebeck, NY, Seven Grandchildren and One GreatGrandchild. A Celebration of Her Life will be held on Tuesday, June 22, 1999 at 6:00pm at her residence. Memorial donations may be made to The Humane Society of Sarasota, Inc, 2331 15th St, Sarasota, FL 34237. For information concerning services call Toale Brothers Colonial Chapel, in Sarasota, FL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. Seven years gone, remembered with love, The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Gillette's Strengths in Razors Undone by Troubles Abroad
description: The Gillette Company has hit a wall even as its core business is growing.

title: McCall Urges Better Tracking of Those Leaving Welfare
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall added his voice today to the chorus of critics who have accused New York City and the state of failing to adequately track the fate of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who have left welfare in recent years.

title: Adobe's Shares Jump
description: Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. rose 12 percent today after the company, a maker of graphics software used by magazines and newspapers, said that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 61 percent, beating estimates. The company's shares rose $8.6875, to $82.5625 today, and are up almost 70 percent this year. Adobe, which makes the Pagemaker and Photoshop lines of software, said late Thursday that it beat profit estimates for the third straight quarter on cost controls and brisk sales of upgraded products such as Acrobat, which is used to send documents and publications over the Internet. It also said it would introduce an update of its Photoshop product in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: ABC and Union Leaders in Tentative Pact
description: The Walt Disney Company's ABC Inc. unit and leaders of most of its unionized broadcast and engineering workers said yesterday that they had reached a tentative contract agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: City Girls Take to Soccer, the Suburban Game; Women's World Cup Helps to Promote a Sport on Unfamiliar Turf
description: Adrice McMichael, 10, is nothing if not eager to learn this new game about kicking a ball into a net. In jeans and a white ''Urban Soccer Girl'' T-shirt that hangs to her knees like a dress, she runs determinedly after the rolling sphere, the rainbow of beads in her braids bopping behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Intel Announces a Delay, And Its Shares Tumble 5%
description: Shares of the Intel Corporation dropped by more than 5 percent today after the company informed personal computer manufacturers that a faster version of its Pentium III processor would be delayed by two months.

title: Casey's Surgery Goes Well
description: Don Casey, the Nets' interim coach for the final 30 games of the season, underwent surgery at the Hackensack Medical Center on Thursday to remove noncancerous fatty tissue from his stomach.

title: Sports of The Times; For Ewing, The Toughest Act of All
description: HE smiles and swears that he is wrapped up in rooting, just another well-dressed fan with a courtside seat. ''Just like the Indiana series,'' says Patrick Ewing, but you know this is an act, the toughest act of all, sitting so close that he can taste the finals, but not touch. The way the Knicks again couldn't touch Tim Duncan last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETCHAM, F. ROGERS
description: KETCHAM-F. Rogers. A longtime resident of Halesite, on June 18, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Judy Ketcham. Dear father of Dale K. Graves, F. Rogers Ketcham, Jr. and Kathleen K. Wikowitz. Cherished brother of William Lazell. Also survived by six grandchildren. Visitation Saturday, 7:00 to 9:00 PM and Sunday, 2:00-4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 PM at the A. L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Religious services will be held Monday, 10:00 AM, at the Old First Church of Huntington. Interment at Huntington Rural Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, MARSHALL
description: LYNN-Marshall. On June 16, 1999. Beloved father of Vanessa, son of Verda, husband of Sylvia, brother of Sandra. Served our nation valiantly in Vietnam. Attended Duke University and Northern Valley High School, Demarest, NJ, where in 1960 he was a member of the mile relay team that won the Penn Relays. Funeral Service Tuesday, June 22, at 10 A.M. at Volk-Leber Funeral Home, 449 Broad Avenue, Palisades Park, New Jersey, 201944-1593. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or Hackensack Hospice, of Hackensack, N.J.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR GAINS. Sugar prices climbed 6 percent on expectations that supplies in Europe could tighten before the current sugar beet crop is harvested. The October contract rose 0.36 cent, to 6.2 cents a pound.

title: Reprise? Mexico Starts Billion-Dollar Bank Bailouts
description: As a reminder that the banking system is still a worrisome weak link in Mexico's robust economy, a newly created federal bank insurance agency has initiated two huge bailouts reminiscent of bank rescues of just a few years ago.

title: Commission on Gambling Prescribes Broad Changes
description: The enduring battle over legalized gambling in the United States received a new blueprint today when the National Gambling Impact Study Commission released the results of its two-year, $5 million study into the social and economic impact of the gambling boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: For Grant, the Hype Seems Mightier Than the Reputation
description: Michael Grant is being marketed as this generation's next heavyweight champion, and he certainly looks the part. Grant is big and strong with a stiff jab, when he is inclined to use it. He is a young, clean-cut man who sings and plays the piano for his church choir in Philadelphia.

title: An Environmental Festival Returns to Its River
description: Starting in 1978, a music and environmental festival called Clearwater's Great Hudson River Revival was held every Father's Day weekend on Croton Point, a tree-studded peninsula 20 miles up the Hudson from Manhattan.

title: Bush Signs Bill Banning Anti-Gun Lawsuits
description: Gov. George W. Bush today signed into law a bill making it illegal for any of the state's cities or other local governments to file suit against gun manufacturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Escaped Murder Suspect Is Captured by Police
description: After nine days on the run, a 16-year-old murder suspect who escaped from a juvenile detention center in the Bronx was captured last night by the police, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about Ron Link, a theater director, referred incorrectly to his involvement with the 1974 Off Broadway production of ''Women Behind Bars.'' Mr. Link directed the play and served as a co-producer with Craig Baumgarten and Alan Eichler. Tom Eyen, who wrote the play, was not a co-producer.

title: Litton Reported Set to Admit Payments Guilt
description: Litton Industries has agreed to plead guilty to charges stemming from illegal payments it made to secure nearly $200 million worth of defense business in Greece and Taiwan, officials close to the case said today.

title: Cecil Morgan, 100, Leader of Louisiana Group That Impeached Huey Long
description: Cecil Morgan, a leader of the group of Louisiana state legislators that impeached but failed to convict the popular and populist demagogue Gov. Huey P. Long in 1929, died last Monday at his home in New Orleans. He was 100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOCCIA, NICHOLAS P.
description: MOCCIA-Nicholas P. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former Senior Field Vice President and respected colleague, Nick Moccia. His contributions to the strength and character of the company will be a guide for those who follow. We will deeply miss his wit, wisdom and warmth and extend our most sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Flynn, Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran, President & CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

title: Hedge Fund To Cash Out Original Stakes
description: Long-Term Capital Management, the giant celebrity-studded hedge fund whose near-collapse last fall sparked concerns of an impending global market failure, is preparing to redeem investments made five years ago by its original outside partners, wealthy individuals and institutions that will wind up getting, on average, considerably less than they would have earned in a plain-vanilla stock index mutual fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: A Transsexual Economist's 2d Transition; She Says Gender Determines One's Approach to Her Field
description: Michael Foley, third-generation owner of the Foley Fish Company, as Boston Irish as the Kennedys, and as charming, greeted Deirdre McCloskey with a kiss on the cheek and a gallantry. ''You look better than the last time I saw you,'' he said. And Deirdre melted, hugging him in gratitude and relief.

title: NATO Ties With Russia Soured Before Bombing
description: A few hundred Russian soldiers in Kosovo, commanded by a general who outranks the British lieutenant general who will be in charge of the 50,000 NATO troops there, have had the alliance tied up in knots since last weekend trying to figure out how Russians can be included without being under NATO command.

title: THOMSON OF CANADA TO BUY PEARSON'S LIBRARY UNIT
description: The Thomson Corporation, owner of Canada's Globe and Mail newspaper, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Macmillan Library Reference USA, a publisher of books for schools and libraries, from Pearson P.L.C. for $86 million in cash. Macmillan Library Reference's book lines include Scribner's Reference, Macmillan Reference and Thorndike Press. They are used by high schools, universities and libraries. The sale by Pearson, the world's largest educational publisher, is part of its plan to sell unwanted reference and business publishing units. Macmillan Library will be combined with Thomson's Gale Group, which publishes reference and research books for the library and education markets and does some electronic publishing. Thomson is based in Toronto.

title: Bob Bullock, a Titan of Texas Politics, Is Dead at 69
description: Bob Bullock, among the last of the earthy, string-pulling, hard-living political giants who used to sprout in Texas as thick as bluebonnets, died early yesterday at his home in Austin from what aides said was congestive heart failure. He was 69.

title: A Relaxed Pettitte Pitches Out Of a Slump
description: Maybe Andy Pettitte needed to see his father in a hospital bed again to give himself some perspective about his pitching slump. Maybe Pettitte needed to feel that queasiness in his stomach again to remind himself that baseball is merely a game. Maybe Pettitte needed to be shocked off the field in order to relax on the field.

title: Kaiser Permanente Is Shutting Down Its H.M.O. in the Northeast
description: Kaiser Permanente, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, said yesterday that it was closing its money-losing Northeast division, at the end of the year. The move affects 575,000 members in four states, including 29,500 in the New York suburbs of Westchester County and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RYAN, COL.GENE E.
description: RYAN-Col.Gene E. Seven years today. A toast to you.Fly high,love. Roz

title: An Idiosyncratic 'Ring' (Oh! the Rhinemaidens!)
description: Surely, of all operatic masterpieces the rich mythological tetralogy that is Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' invites imaginative production concepts. You can have a German Romantic ''Ring'' or a ''Ring'' that evokes antiquity. You can turn it into a children's adventure story or stage it as a liturgical mystery play. The sets can be elaborate or austere, incandescent or darkly grim. You could do it in modern dress, or in punk rock regalia or even let the Rhinemaidens slosh around in the river nude. Almost everything has been tried and, in theory, almost anything could work; that is, as long as the production has a conceptual unity to match the unity in Wagner's vision.

title: Airport Was Lost in Command Confusion : Faulty Allied Teamwork Helped Russian Dash
description: PARIS  The Clinton administration and NATO's strategic commanders wanted allied troops to mount a swift lunge into Pristina last week in time to thwart the Russian troops that gained possession of the airport there, according to U.S. officials in Washington.

title: TRADE GROUP DELAY
description: World Trade Organization delegates were unable to break the deadlock for a new leader yesterday, failing either to choose between the two candidates, or begin a new selection process. The 134-country trade arbiter decided to adjourn until early July after refusing suggestions that some kind of assessment, or vote, of support be taken to gauge the number of countries behind Mike Moore, the former New Zealand Prime Minister, or Supachai Panitchpakdi, Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.
