title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, AARON
description: BLOOM-Aaron died Thursday, June 17 in Branford, CT. He was born August 25, 1913 in New York City, son of Joseph and Frances Bloom. He grew up in Brooklyn and participated in the US Army invasion of Omaha Beach on DDay. He was predeceased by his wife of over 45 years, Shirley Beskind Bloom. He was active in the YMHA of Bergen County, New Jersey and the New York Wine and Food Society. He loved to play the violin and cello and most of all to sail. He is survived by two sisters, Eleanor Greene and Nettie Lebow, two children, Ben Bloom of Gilford, Connecticut, and Deborah Soifer of South China, ME, and their spouses, four grandsons and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held Monday, June 21 at 1PM at Curtis/ Sisk Funeral Home, 69 South Main Street, Branford, CT.

But because the duration of benefit is unknown and raloxifene can produce unwanted effects, experts cautioned against recommending it as an anti-breast-cancer drug except in clinical trials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODEA, TITUS
description: PODEA-Titus, 86. Died Thursday, June 17. Born in Youngstown, OH, on September 21, 1912, while his father, the head of the Romanian Orthodox Church in the United States ministered to the steelworkers of that area. After his family returned to Romania following World War I, he earned his Doctorate in Economics and a law degree, practiced as a journalist and authored a definitive book about the history of Transylvania. After returning to the United States during World War II, Dr. Podea served as the Executive Vice President of the Econometric Institute in New York. He served as an economic consultant to the governments of India and Romania. He and his wife, the late Mary Roos Podea, had consultative status at the United Nations representing the International Fellowship of Reconciliation for 45 years until the day of his death. They were members of the 15th Street Friends Meeting. His family and friends will keenly miss and are grateful for his civility, elegance, graciousness, his searching mind, and his effective contributions to world peace. He is survived by his sister Helen Bianca Podea, his niece Susanna Timoc, his nephew Alex Florescu, four grandnieces and nephews, his stepson Charles Roos, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Friends are invited to attend a viewing Sunday, June 20, from 2 until 5, at Charles Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th St. The family requests donations in his memory be sent to the Fellowship of Reconciliation, PO Box 271, Nyack, NY 10960 in lieu of flowers.

title: Streetscapes /The Gardiner-Tyler House, West New Brighton, Staten Island; Where a President's Widow Backed the Confederacy

When she was not involved in pro-Confederate activities, she was busy trying to reunite her family, scattered by the war. Now another family is reuniting in this grand temple-fronted house, as a new addition brings together three generations under one roof.

title: Big Screen to Cede to Big Muscles
description: For decades, moviegoers have watched films on the two screens of the Art Greenwich Theater, a two-story white-and-gray building on the corner of Greenwich Avenue and West 12th Street. But now plans are under way to gut the building and build an Equinox Fitness Club. While some in the neighborhood are already lamenting the loss of the movie house, others say they are worried that the fitness club would compromise the quiet mood and architectural integrity of their historic district.

''The significance here,'' he explained about having found the plant near a city stream, ''is that it does grow in an urban environment.''

title: Fighting Over Right to Drive on the Beach
description: It is just a three-mile strip of sand adjacent to a wildlife refuge. Yet for the past 10 years it has been a battleground where fishermen and Federal officials have fought bitterly over vehicle access.

title: Kosovars to Get European Help For Rebuilding
description: The European Union today announced plans to provide $1.5 billion during the next three years for the reconstruction of Kosovo as the West tried to map out a strategy that would channel money to the war-devastated area without giving financial support to a Serbia controlled by Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Some Summer Reading For the Grade School Set
description: Your grade schooler comes home with a vivid tale of a classroom visit from a woman in beach clothes toting a beach bag full of books. Should you: (a) fire off a letter to the school board about the need for a teacher dress code, (b) phone your child's pediatrician to discuss vacation anxiety or (c) plan to make frequent trips to the library this summer?

title: The More Hairless Ape
description: In the rising tide of male vanity, removing back hair may no longer be unusual, but now salons around town are depilating men with a fresh eye to detail. The treatments use wax and lasers to denude feet, hands and ears by coating hirsute areas with a thin film of warm wax, covering it with a piece of linen and then --argh! -- ripping it all off. At the Frederic Fekkai Beauty Salon (Fifth Avenue and 57th Street), an ear waxing is $16. The Oscar Blandi Salon at the Plaza (Fifth Avenue and Central Park South) provides a $75 package for waxing hands and feet. ''Forty percent of our customers are men,'' said Cindy Barshop, owner of Completely Bare, a spa on Madison Avenue (65th Street) that specializes in hair removal. ''A lot of executives and N.F.L. players come in for laser hair removal on their hands and feet.'' At the spa, whose clientele includes Stephen Baldwin and Howard Stern, laser treatments for small body parts are $150 a session, while waxing runs from $20 to $25. ''In the past, men were forced to do stuff like this in secrecy,'' said Mitch Marrow, a defensive lineman for the Carolina Panthers who lives in New York. ''They had to shave their feet in the shower or have their girlfriends shave their backs. But times have changed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, CHARLES E.
description: HECHT-Charles E. On June 17, 1999 in his 89th year, in Albany, N.Y. Born in New York City. Beloved husband of the late Rita (nee Rau) and the late Deola (nee Gairrett). Loving father of Bruce and Joy. Devoted father-in-law of Mary Ellen Scherer and Richard Moore. Adored brother of Miriam Pilzer and Dr. Irwin (Sulo) Hecht. He leaves a legacy of intellect, kindness and gentility. We will miss him. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice. Private memorial.

title: A Teen-Ager Is Fatally Shot And Another Is Hurt at a Party

description: It was the marriage of a prince who prefers to be called ''mister'' to a suburban girl turned downtown publicist bringing a commoner's touch to the starchy British monarchy.

title: And They Dance Their Terrible Dance
description: TO watch Pilobolus Dance Theater at work, you turn right at the Hudson River and drive north for two hours, past cider mills and deer crossings, until you come to this tiny village. Veer left at the white church and you'll find the Washington Club Hall, a high-ceilinged structure built in 1907 in which the Connecticut-based modern-dance troupe has rehearsed for the past quarter-century.

description: Mass tourism to the Grand Canyon started in 1901 with the construction of a Santa Fe Railroad spur to the south rim. Now, at the century's twilight, the canyon is returning to its mass-transit roots, breaking ground recently for the first light rail in a national park.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Catskill Comics; One-Liners for a New Generation
description: YOU know what they should call us?'' Freddy Roman asked. ''Funny comedians. Not Borscht Belt comedians.''

title: Serving Salad for 10 for What One Costs at a Fancy Restaurant
description: THE other day I had lunch in an expensive Manhattan restaurant that will remain nameless. My first course was a small salad, which consisted of diced avocado and slivered raw baby artichokes topped with Parmesan shavings served in a shallow bowl. What made it so good was the freshness of the ingredients, their unfussy preparation -- and the oil and lemon dressing. The only snag was the price: $21.95. But my outrage was tempered by the fact that the dish was so simple I knew I could easily duplicate it at home.

title: Lives; Fugitive in the Family
description: The private detective who gave me the phone number for my father offered no guarantees. ''It might just be a ghost in the system,'' he said, meaning a number that persists in a data bank long after the person it belonged to is gone. It has been eight years since I've seen my father and three since I've even known where he is. As his four children grew up, he came to see fatherhood as a debt that never stopped being collected, and turned into a fugitive of sorts, on the lam from us. When I was in my early 20's, shortly after my parents were divorced, when he had a home and I knew where it was, he drove me to the airport after a visit. Before I got out of the car, he opened his checkbook and started to write. ''It's O.K., Dad, I don't need money,'' I said.

title: Diocese Feels Shortage of Priests
description: FACED with one of the worst priest-to-parishioner ratios in the country, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre is looking for a few good men.

title: A Starry Array In the Village
description: BABBO ***

title: Group Keeping Tabs On Osprey Habits
description: THIS week, as schoolchildren are shrugging off their backpacks for the summer, some of the osprey nesting at the Nature Conservancy's Mashomack Preserve on Shelter Island will be donning theirs.

title: For the Coronet, 19th-Century Glory
description: If a boat could look like a homeless waif, the 133-foot schooner Coronet is a ragamuffin of the high seas. But beneath its scruffy exterior is a sailboat as vital to United States yachting history as a national monument is to the American archives.

title: A Guitar, and Catchy Tales of Blue-Collar Life
description: DANNY WHITE wields a mean guitar as he prances around the stage or jumps off an amplifier to dance with someone from the audience in a tiny, dark New Jersey club. He has style, and he has a better-than-average three-piece band behind him.

title: Episcopal Dioceses Select New Bishops
description: The Episcopal dioceses of Connecticut and Rochester in Western New York chose new bishops yesterday, with a candidate to become the church's first openly gay bishop losing in Rochester.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY; Warm-Ups for Summer
description: Summer hardly seems the ideal time for a velour sweat suit, and yet those shiny, crushed-cotton ensembles are turning up everywhere, from the basketball courts on West Fourth Street to the big booths at Joe's Pub. Gerry Ash, manager of Phat Farm (129 Prince Street), says he can't keep his shop's navy and gray (left) versions, $170, in stock. ''We can order a shipment of 30 or 40 pieces, get them in on Monday, and they'll be gone by the weekend,'' he said. For those who like a brighter leisure look, Fubu and Enyce offer them in red, white, beige and Carolina blue, also $170, at NoHo Transit, 665 Broadway (Bond Street), and Active Wearhouse, 514 Broadway (Spring Street). Seen on the backs of rappers like Jay-Z and Wyclef Jean, the suits hark back to the 1980's, the golden era of hip-hop, when big gold chains and boomboxes reigned, and Run-DMC rapped about Adidas. Jeremiah Johnson, 24, is a hip-hop lover who is not keen on velour's comeback. ''It reminds me of when I was a kid, but I don't think I could ever rock the suit again,'' he said. ''Just as long as Underoos don't come back, I'm cool.'' LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: DEMOCRATS MOUNT ATTACK ON G.O.P. OVER GUN CONTROL
description: Democrats are moving to capitalize immediately on the failure of the Republican-controlled House to pass even modest gun-control legislation, and promising to take the issue to the forefront of the 2000 Presidential campaign.

title: First Time for Everything
description: The light bulb, salt water taffy, canned soup -- no surprise, perhaps, that these things started in New Jersey. But there are plenty more New Jersey firsts, many unexpected, and now there is a book, appropriately titled ''New Jersey Firsts,'' documenting some of them. For example, there is the first Indian reservation (in 1758, in what is now Burlington County), the golf tee (invented by a Maplewood dentist in 1921), the first Mason jar, the first repeating firearm (Samuel Colt set up business in Paterson in 1836), the nation's first seashore resort (Cape May), and the first rock star on the cover of Time and Newsweek simultaneously (Bruce Springsteen). The book was written by two life-long Jerseyans, Harry Armstrong, president of Hudson Briarhill Enterprises, which publishes the regional monthly Golden Times, and Tom Wilk, an editor at the Courier-Post in Cherry Hill. The book, $9.95, was published by Camino Books in Philadelphia.

title: Spurs Say a Letdown Is Unlikely, Especially at the Garden
description: The San Antonio Spurs have three players with at least two National Basketball Association championship rings, two players who spent years moiling in the minor leagues before seizing the big stage, and accomplished college graduates with degrees in finance, mathematics, computer information systems and psychology.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 20, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Parents Demand School Aid
description: The air in the basement of Walker Memorial Baptist Church Wednesday night smothered like a hot towel, but the crowd of several hundred parents and children barely seemed to notice. They had a more pressing item on their agenda: the dismal performance of their public schools.

title: Happily Ever After: When Form Married Function
description: THE Bush Storehouse in Greenwich is part of a compound of six buildings that climb a hill (at this time of the year speckled with flowers and a vine-covered grape arbor) to an enviable view over the Miamus River.

title: POSTINGS: Upscale Madison Avenue Blockfront; Clustering 6 Boutiques
description: Six boutiques that are all part of the London-based Vendome Luxury Group are being clustered together under one roof, creating an upscale shopping center on a blockfront on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCRAE, FREDERIC A.
description: McRAE-Frederic A. Age 77, formerly of New York City and Sanibel Island, FL, died June 17 in Fort Myers, FL. A graduate of Dartmouth College, he served in the U.S. Army Air Force in World War II in China and was production manager for William Morrow Publishing for many years. Donations may be made in his name to Hope Hospice, 9470 Health Park Circle, Fort Myers, FL 33908.

title: With Careful Choices, a Pleasurable Meal
description: SINCE 1926 visitors from all over the world have come to Gurney's Inn in Montauk for its magnificent setting, rustic luxury and breathtaking ocean views. Yet the restaurants at Gurney's have not enjoyed the same reputation as the inn and spa. That is probably because the venerable Montauk institution relies primarily on hotel guests, all of whom are on the modified American plan, to patronize its dining rooms. This guaranteed core of diners relieves Gurney's of the need to compete with other restaurants solely on the basis of food and service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, PATRICK T.
description: KNIGHT-Patrick T. Former Secretary-Treasurer and President of Social Service Employees Union Local 371, on May 24. At the time of his death, Pat was an organizer for AFSCME. A strong proponent of participatory democracy, Pat contributed to the spirit and building of both Local 371 and the national union. A memorial service will be held June 21, 10AM, DC 37, 125 Barclay St, New York City.

title: U.S. Aims to Have 5% of Electricity From Wind by 2020
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson says he will announce on Monday a plan to produce 5 percent of the nation's electricity from wind by 2020, up from one-tenth of 1 percent now. Under the plan, the Federal Government, the nation's largest electricity customer, would rely on wind for 5 percent of its use by 2010.

title: Serb Police Exit Joking, But Menace Lingers On
description: The group of Serbian special police men all over six feet tall, thickset, dressed in green camouflage bearing the double-headed eagle of Yugoslav forces and unit patches -- was relaxed, joking, their automatic rifles propped against a wall.

title: Stars Work (Triple) Overtime to Win 1st Cup
description: The day before the Dallas Stars won the Stanley Cup with a goal in triple overtime by Brett Hull, Pat Verbeek was talking about the dreams of childhood. At 35, Verbeek has played almost half his life in the National Hockey League without ever before skating with the big, silver trophy. Like many of his Dallas teammates, Verbeek is a scarred old pro. And, like many veteran athletes, his outlook is part man and part boy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with a report about the marriage of Wendy Vandeveer Scott and Richard Shreve Cutler was published in error. It showed Ellen Joan Scott and William Louis Presutti, whose marriage is reported today.

title: Noriko Miyoshi, Andrew Quinton
description: Noriko Miyoshi and Andrew Francis Quinton were married on Friday at the First Presbyterian Church in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Blair Moffett performed the ceremony.

title: Q and A
description: Glasgow Design Fete

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 6 about Andrei Serban's new staging of Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelung'' misidentified the production's set and costume designers. The sets were created by John Coyne and the costumes by Bob Ringwood; none were by Robert Perziola.

title: Cincinnati
description: In Minneapolis, the overhead sky walks protect pedestrians from the winter cold and snow. In Cincinnati, the menace is the summer humidity. Which somehow puts Cincinnatians in mind of a good bowl of chili -- ''three way'' in the local vernacular, which means sauce ladled over an oval plate of spaghetti, smothered in cheese.

title: Seaplane Operator Addressed Noise and Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Bank Of Yesterday
description: YOU might call it Russo's revenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SHERMAN
description: DAVIS-Sherman. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sherman Davis, associated with The Times from 1951 until retiring in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHLER, HELEN
description: MISHLER-Helen. Died Friday, June 18, 1999 surrounded by her loved ones. Beloved wife of U.S. District Judge Jacob Mishler. She is survived by her daughter Gail and son-in-law Marty Unger; her son Bruce; daughter Sue and sonin-law Chuck Lubitz; Alan Mishler and Fran Mishler. Devoted grandmother to Sharyn, Debra and Rachel. Great grandmother to Tayler, Morgan, Ethan and Jagger. Her luminous, gracious and loving presence will be missed.

title: A Portraitist Who Blended Delicacy and Grandeur
description: SOMETIMES his royal patron was slow to pay, but in the main England was good to Anthony Van Dyck. He first crossed the Channel at age 21, summoned to the court of James I as the outstanding disciple of the magisterial Rubens and already a star in his own right. That brief stay, from late 1620 into early 1621, was a prelude to his reign as ''principalle Paynter in ordinary their Majesties,'' beginning in 1632. Charles I, a sovereign whose passion for art was no pose, made him Sir Anthony that same year. Apart from an interval back home in Brabant from early 1634 to early 1635, Van Dyck remained in England for the rest of his too brief life. Death claimed him at home in Blackfriars in 1641. His bones lie at St. Paul's.

title: Two Children Are Hit In Brooklyn Shooting
description: An 11-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl were shot outside a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, along with a 21-year-old man who the police said was the shooter's target.

title: Irabu Breaks a Smile, And Yanks Relax, Too
description: Hidden behind a language barrier, Hideki Irabu has been an enigma to his teammates, only occasionally attempting to traverse the canyon that separates him from other Yankees. But with smiles and gregarious gestures, Irabu is emerging from his shell, and whether the timing of this is a coincidence or not, he is also becoming a significant contributor in the club's rotation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, MATT S.
description: WARSHAW-Matt S. On June 15, 1999 at age 91. Devoted husband of Shirley. Loving brother of Rose and beloved father of Robert. Cherished grandfather of Felice, Suzanne, and Michelle, and great grandfather of Zachary, Justin, and Danielle. We love you and miss you.

title: Laconia Journal; Taming of a Rally Rankles the Bikers
description: Every summer, when three hundred thousand or so motorcyclists roar into this lakeside town for the granddaddy of all biker bashes, Deborah Gagman, a k a the exotic dancer Autumn Blaze, poses happily in the crowd with all who ask, positioning her pasties for best photographic advantage.

title: Holy Cow!
description: Those Damn Yankees The Secret Life of America's Greatest Franchise. By Dean Chadwin. Illustrated. 264 pp. New York: Verso. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMPSTEAD, ELEANOR AVERY
description: HEMPSTEAD - Eleanor Avery. Died on Saturday, June 12 at her home in New York City. The caused of death was cancer. Mrs. Hempstead was the daughter of the late Waldo Allard Avery of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and the niece of the late Sewell Lee Avery of Chicago, who died in the office of chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward & Co. She was married once, to the late David Bill Hempstead, who produced and wrote some notable motion pictures during the late 1940's and '50's. It was he who persuaded Ginger Rogers to accept her first dramatic role in his production of ''Kitty Foyle'', for which she won the Academy Award. The Hempsteads were divorced in 1949. In her later years, Mrs. Hempstead devoted herself to a number of philanthropies, and was a generous donor to the Bronx Zoo, Planned Parenthood, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Mrs. Hempstead is survived by her two children, Avery Hempstead Lichtenstein of New York and Santa Fe, and a son, David Bill Hempstead IV of Pasadena, California. A memorial service is to be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st street) in Manhattan on Thursday, September 9 at 4PM. Only relatives, business associates and close friends of the deceased and her daughter are invited to attend.

title: Where Balkans-Bound Turn
description: At Louis Overseas Travel on Arthur Avenue, Bosnian, Serbian, Croatian and Albanian immigrants from all over the metropolitan region turn to Luigj Shkreli for help in returning to their homelands.

title: Vagary of Nature
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Coach Learned of Abilities of Disabled
description: In this production of ''The Wizard of Oz,'' the Tin Man not only sang with Dorothy as she tried to find her way home, he also pushed her down the yellow brick road in a wheelchair.

title: Juvenile Crime Up, But Arrests Down
description: The number and violence of youth crimes is up in Suffolk County and the number of juvenile arrests is down, a county report on juvenile crime shows.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Saab 9-5 Wagon; A Swedish Excursion Into a Midsize Niche
description: SWEDES make good cars. Quick. Name a Swedish automobile maker!

title: Ms. Miller, Mr. Grandison
description: Julia Ingersol Miller, the daughter of Marion B. Miller of North Stonington, Conn., and Edward F. Miller of New York, was married yesterday to Timothy David Grandison, a son of Peg Grandison and Dr. Lindsey J. Grandison of Highland Park, N.J. The Rev. Mary Tiebout, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Woolverton Inn in Stockton, N.J.

title: Liberties; The God Squad
description: Talk about profiles in courage.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Heartland's Little Apple

title: Children's Books; The Right Stuffing
description: If you crossed ''Where the Wild Things Are'' with ''Madeline,'' HARRY AND LULU (Hyperion, $15.99; ages 4 to 7), written by Arthur Yorinks and illustrated by Martin Matje, might be what would happen. When Lulu asks her parents for a dog for the 40th time, they give her a toy poodle -- not the miniature but the stuffed kind. She throws a tantrum, kicks the toy and slams her door. Lucky for her, ''all children, even wild maniac children, deserve a wish now and then.'' But when Harry the poodle wakes her up with a squeaky bark, Lulu is having none of it: ''You're not a dog. You're just a stupid stuffed animal,'' she growls at him. They argue, Harry fails her dog biscuit test and goes wild for bagels instead, they argue some more, and Harry tells her he's going back to where he came from -- Paris. Lulu decides to go, too. She has the perfect beret to wear on their trip.

title: June 13-19; A Quake in Mexico Claims Lives and Priceless Buildings
description: Everybody in central Mexico feared the worst when the ground shook at 3:42 P.M. Tuesday, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, But unlike the earthquake in 1985 that killed as many as 10,000 people, this one will be remember for the damage it did not cause. By week's end, the death toll was 19. The toll on buildings was higher: in the state of Puebla, dozens of priceless gems of colonial architecture, including churches, were crippled.

title: U.S. Labor Stand May See Children Sent to War
description: To the Editor:

title: What You Don't Want To See in a Boss-to-Be
description: WITH the economy booming, the future's so bright for this year's crop of college grads that, as the song says, they gotta wear shades.

title: Denouement of a Family Feud?
description: LEAVE it to the Internet to jump-start the formerly famous. After making headlines five years ago as a key slugger in the Haft family's legal brawl, the eldest son, Robert M., has re-emerged selling vitamins in cyberspace.

title: Co-Favorite Has Trouble, but Squeaks By
description: China, the co-favorite to win the Women's World Cup, almost failed to win its opening first-round match today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Collision of the Sexes
description: From executive offices to offshore oil rigs, workplaces that were virtually ''men only'' just a decade ago have opened their doors to more and more women. Men and women alike have adjusted and adapted -- at times awkwardly, at times thoughtfully. The resulting tales can range from uproarious to touching. Send yours to On the Job, Money and Business,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Is He Getting Ready To Return to Belgrade?
description: As NATO troops rolled into Kosovo last week and Serbian troops rolled out, Milan Panic, who took time out from running ICN Pharmaceuticals to serve briefly as Yugoslavia's Prime Minister in 1992, shuttled around European capitals and the United Nations. His goal was to get rid of Slobodan Milosovic and rebuild Yugoslovia under a democratic leader, perhaps by the name of Milan Panic.

title: Commercial Property /Sales; Players Say Market, While Not 'Frothy,' Is Healthy
description: THIS time last year the real estate market was, in the words of one executive, ''frothy.'' Aggressive Wall Street firms were providing 90 percent financing for deals, reducing the amount of equity a prospective purchaser had to provide. Deals were plentiful and prices were climbing.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about garden tours on the Island misattributed a quotation from a woman whose garden in Springs is part of a tour sponsored by the Garden Conservancy, and included an erroneous name in the comment. The quotation was from Ann Stanwell, not her partner, Emily Cobb. Ms. Stanwell said, ''Little did we know that the daffodil bulbs Emily's father [not ''Ann's father''] gave us when we first moved in would be so important.''

title: Seeing the Familiar in Ever New Ways
description: ''FAMILIARITY doesn't breed contempt. It breeds admiration.''

title: Cabless in London: Stranded After Dark
description: ELEVEN P.M. in London's West End: The theaters have emptied. The movie crowd is spilling onto the streets. The pubs, regulated by Britain's licensing laws, are about to close. The one thing that's missing: a taxi ride home.

title: A Town Returns to Life With Albanians Alone
description: It is nearly impossible to find a Serb here anymore, a state of affairs that is novel for the Albanians and which the better side of Naim Spahiu, a 30-year-old driver, said was not good for Kosovo.

title: A Seafood Spot by the Harbor in Port Chester
description: IF a dark forest blocked travelers approaching the Pearl by land, the path might be more attractive than the industrial patch through which some diners must find their way. Unlike the gentrified eastern bank of the Hudson, this is a working waterfront, with cranes, rusty anchors and towers of lobster traps ready for serious use.

title: Bizarro World
description: TOUGH, TOUGH TOYS FOR TOUGH, TOUGH BOYS

title: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
description: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses.

title: Broadway Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking to Put Fatherhood in Its Proper Place
description: KING LEAR'S daughters didn't need a Father's Day to remember the old man. He was constantly in their thoughts. But, in 1925, Calvin Coolidge decided that fathers were no longer getting enough attention or respect. He proclaimed the national observance of Father's Day. Too late, of course: when we need a special day to remind us of something, it's already a lost cause.

title: Alison Brown, John Nathanson
description: Dr. Alison Suzanne Brown, a clinical psychologist in private practice in New York, was married yesterday to John Alexander Nathanson, an associate at Rogers & Wells, the New York law firm. The Rev. Dr. Sara G. Worcester performed the ceremony at the South Congregational Church in South Amherst, Mass.

title: Do We Really Need Another Starr Report?; Boost for Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Dreamland:

title: Unburdened by the World, Graduates Bid a Sentimental Farewell
description: Maryann DiPasquale is an effervescent girl, the perfect student council president, who bridges the cliques at Ramapo High School with her contagious smile. She wants her commencement speech to be as airy as cotton candy, full of inside jokes about seniors losing their coveted parking spaces because of a new teachers' contract and risking their diplomas by not paying library fines.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Shakespeare at Boscobel

title: The Story of A
description: A GIFT IMPRISONED The Poetic Life of Matthew Arnold. By Ian Hamilton. Illustrated. 241 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.

title: Children's Books
description: BACKWATER

title: A Gift for the Father of Invention
description: TO the innocent eye, my father seems a mild-mannered radiologist and suburban grandfather. By day, in his silver-rim glasses, wearing a lab coat with a calculator in the breast pocket, he looks like the kind of guy who would kick back with Scientific American.

title: Victorian Facade Reappears
description: Standing atop a scaffold high above the sidewalk on a recent Saturday morning, a laborer wielding a demolition saw began cutting into the fake-brick facade of Cannon's Pub on 108th Street and Broadway, the last of the smoky Irish bars that once abounded in this neighborhood.

title: Breaks Promise, Pays a Price
description: After months of maybe-maybe not pondering, Representative George R. Nethercutt Jr. of Spokane, Wash., finally made up his mind last week. He will seek a fourth term.

title: The Irrelevance of a Palestinian State
description: Meron Benvenisti is an Israeli Cassandra. Fifteen years ago, he confounded his fellow doves by the conclusion he drew in a study of the West Bank and Gaza. Israel had gone so far, he said, in settling the occupied territories and building roads and water lines and economic links that the process was irreversible. ''For the foreseeable future,'' he said, Israel would rule all of Palestine.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Flesh and Blood of War

title: Style; The World Is Her Cloister
description: Marla Weinhoff has always lived in a fantasy world. But even as a child she had fantasies of a different caliber than those of her schoolmates in Omaha. Why bother with mundane musings when you can sit on the lawn and build cities out of grass clippings? Or frame the block around your house with chains of knotted flowering clover.

title: Deana Jordan and David Sullivan
description: Deana Racine Jordan, the daughter of Josette Racine Jordan of Boca Raton, Fla., and a stepdaughter of the late Patrice Bernard Jordan, was married yesterday to David Bryan Sullivan, a son of Mary Lane Sullivan and John Sullivan of Cleveland. The Rev. Elijah White performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Oatlands, Va.

title: When Two Artists Work as One
description: 'Site Specifics '99'

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 13 about how pharmacists, at the behest of insurance companies, sometimes substitute a less expensive drug for the one originally prescribed, omitted the context for a comment by Kevin Colgan, a spokesman for Merck-Medco Managed Care, who said: ''The patient is accepting a benefit from their employer, and if they would like no management of their benefit, or no restrictions, they can always pay for it themselves out of pocket.'' Mr. Colgan was referring to an employee's entire drug benefit package, not to an individual prescription.

title: Children's Books
description: Gowanus Dogs

title: Is a Stock Offering Near At an On-Line Magazine?
description: Is Forbes Inc., publisher of the glossy business magazine, planning to sell its Internet jewels to the public through an initial offering?

title: Springtime for Hedge Funds
description: It's been a profitable spring for many hedge fund managers. In May, hedge funds outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the second month in a row that they have done so, according to Van Hedge Fund Advisors International, a consulting firm.

title: A Brutal Cure
description: Did a red flag go up for Lisa Belkin when she found that the mother of the victim of a terrifyingly resistant form of TB ''was working in a processing plant, loading food onto airline serving trays''? Recalling the case of Typhoid Mary, this sometime-passenger was prompted by Belkin's statement to commit to brown-bagging all meals on future flights!

title: A Light Rail Line Would Help the Bridge
description: Another way to ease traffic flow on the Tappan Zee Bridge [''Making the Best of a Congested Bridge,'' May 23] is to build a light rail line from Suffern to Port Chester.

title: UBS Is for Art Lovers
description: Last week, many wealthy collectors thronged Art Basel, the reknowned 20th-century art fair, which runs through tomorrow. Among them were Charles Schwab; Arthur Fleischer, the New York takeover lawyer; Mick Flick, a Daimler-Benz executive; Achille Maramotti, the owner of Max Mara, the clothing company, and Jochen Holy, a former owner of Hugo Boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Carroll Gardens' Drugstore Prescription
description: ''It's a huge white thing that would glow in the dark even without the lights on,'' said Brian C. Wrye, a resident of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, about a proposed design for a drugstore on President and Smith Streets. ''It would be perfect for Florida, but it doesn't belong here.''

title: A Super Fights for His Job
description: Now 51 years old, Gregory Lukomski went to work for the building management company in 1994, he said, first as the superintendent of an apartment house in Greenwich Village, later as a field manager with responsibility for 22 buildings. But in March, three months after he had a heart bypass operation, he was fired and replaced by a 32-year-old.

title: On Bended Knee
description: IT was the Fourth of July weekend, and Michael Seltzer was all set to ask the question that makes some men sleepless and others heady with anticipation. Fresh out of Cardozo Law School, he and Heather Alexander, a children's book editor, were about to move in together. They were starting to talk about marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Daddy, we miss you-your love, your wisdom. Our link to you will never be broken. Jaar-mel and Irik

title: Melissa Hieger, Michael Collins
description: Melissa Jayne Hieger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hieger of Crossville, Tenn., was married yesterday to Michael Hathaway Collins, a son of Margaret Collins of Rye, N.Y., and Albert Collins of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Ed Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Clermont, a historic house in Germantown, N.Y.

title: Q & A/Donald Gaskill; A Life of Helping Troubled Children
description: DONALD GASKILL has watched troubled youngsters at Boys Village in Milford for 22 years. Mr. Gaskill, 68, was a Marianist Brother for 20 years until he decided to leave the religious life and marry. He began his career helping others nearly 48 years ago at a children's home in New York. In an age where simple answers are often sought for complex problems, Mr. Gaskill has concluded that, ''There is no one way to treat these kids.''

title: Unsung Drummers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brutal Cure
description: Lisa Belkin's article (May 30) struck a chord. In 1944, my mother contracted tuberculosis. My father, an internist in Manhattan, sent her to a sanatorium in Saranac Lake, N.Y., where she stayed about eight months. After returning home, she appeared to be cured. But a few years later, in 1949, she had a flare-up of the disease. My father consulted Rudolf Nissen, a pioneer at that time in the surgical removal of the lung. He advised my parents that the only permanent cure would be removal of that portion of the lung that again showed signs of the disease. The surgery was successful, and although my mother remained in frail health for the rest of her life, there was no recurrence of the disease.

title: Minimalism Pares Down Romance in Shakespeare
description: IF you thought ''As You Like It'' was all about the sweet mysteries of love, get over it.

title: The Art of the Deal
description: MATISSE Father & Son. By John Russell. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, EVE
description: FREEMAN-Eve. Age 88. Social worker, therapist and teacher. Beloved wife of the late Lionel J. Freeman. Loving mother of Roger, Bruce and Leslie, cherished grandmother of Karen, Eric, Sara, Pam, Lynn and Ian and proudgreat-grandmother of Alyssa, Amy, Rebecca, Rachael, Jenna and Emily. Beloved ''Sis'' of Jay and the late brothers, Rufus, Louis and Bernie Chalson; and of sistersin-law Ruth, Nettie, Anita and June Chalson, and Fern Marja Eckman.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Restoring Yesterday's Stars to the Limelight
description: THE rich and various history of art in New York in the 1960's and 70's is being rewritten -- not at any of the universities where graduate students avidly pore over the origins of Pop, Minimal and Conceptual Art, nor at the uptown museums that seem content to keep reinvestigating acknowledged masters like Jasper Johns and Ellsworth Kelly, but at a hole-in-the-wall storefront gallery on Thompson Street. The gallery can't even open before 3 P.M. because its owner, a high school science teacher named Mitchell Algus, arrives only after his first workday ends.

title: More Than Sight Gags And Subversive Satire
description: CONTRARY to what the Hollywood tabloids and most community college vocational counselors would have you believe, the career of a media critic is not all glamorous beer and glitzy skittles. Hundreds of squinty hours might be spent watching television so one can grind a midweek column out of why nobody on television can properly pronounce the words ''temperature'' or ''February'' anymore. Months pass, wasted, trying to manhandle ''Geraldo'' and ''thong'' into a single sentence for your big cable-news-in-review essay. Days go by trying to puzzle out the title of that TBS network rattlesnake-horror movie called ''Silent Predators.'' Aren't rattlesnakes pretty noisy? Hence the name? Aren't they, in fact, one of the only predators on the planet to provide a clearly audible warning? (And our nation's educators wonder why those standardized test scores are so low.)

title: June 13-19; Wrong DNA, Wrong Man
description: Calvin Johnson Jr., 41, walked out of a life sentence for rape in Georgia after DNA evidence exonerated him. Sixteen years earlier, disregarding physical evidence pointing to his innocence, an all-white jury had convicted Mr. Johnson, who is black, based on hazy identification from eyewitnesses. His vindication gave new hope that such scientific evidence might help redress decades of racial imbalance in the Southern legal system.

title: Q. & A.
description: Mortgage Recording Taxes

title: June 13-19; This Is Why You're No Einstein Either, Sweetie
description: Grim scientists hunched over a dissected brain, calipers in hand -- it's a sepia-toned, 19th-century sort of image. Or something from a bizarre corner of 1950's science fiction.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, JOHN
description: GERSON-John. June 20, 1997. A second year without you. Miss you more and more as time goes by. All my love, E.G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALIN, ADA
description: MALIN-Ada. On June 18, 1999. Beloved wife of Boaz. Devoted mother of Amir and Rami, and motherin-law of Karen. Dearest sister of Natan and Dani, and sister-in-law of Ruti, Yakov and Fay. Cherished grandmother of Adam and Jenessa. A wonderful friend to all who knew her. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 N. Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: A Civil War-Era Submarine Surfaces in Sea Girt
description: A large black egg-shaped piece of cast iron about the size of a tiny apartment bathroom sits on a red steel cradle in a corner of the New Jersey National Guard Militia Museum in Sea Girt. The 46,000-pound vessel, called the Intelligent Whale, is a Civil War-era submarine and the latest acquisition of the military museum in the original armory at the National Guard Training Center.

title: Duncan, a No-Frills Guy Who's Beyond His Years
description: On most road trips, Tim Duncan packs the toys of choice for the Y2K pro athlete: a DVD movie player and a Sony PlayStation. He likes current cinema and mindless video games, often killing time on the team plane with the young reserve point guard Antonio Daniels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINSKI, LARILYNN M.
description: MALINSKI-Larilynn M. June 17th. Beloved daughter of John A. Malinski and the late Dorothy Marie. Loving sister of Jon and Blair Malinski. She was a flight attendant for 38 years with TWA. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: James Earl Jones Helps in 'Own Backyard'
description: JAMES EARL JONES, the legendary movie star and Tony Award-winning stage actor, does not understand why he is a news story. Munching on a salad at his son's school here, he peers skeptically at a reporter and then, pen in hand, glances back at the script lying on a table in front of him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIN, JACOB
description: SLAVIN-Jacob. Beloved father of Leontine Temsky of Nyack and Steve Slavin of Brooklyn, brother of Ted, grandfather of Eric and Jonah, great grandfather of Eleni, Elizabeth, Justine, Sophie, and Daniel. Jacob Slavin taught mathematics at Madison, Lincoln, and Brooklyn Tech from the mid 1930's through the late 1960's. His memory lives on in the hearts and minds of his family and students.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Brave New World
description: In 1900 the United States was still a nation whose artists, writers and social circles looked to Europe for inspiration and validation. When the country came of age, it did so amid the turmoil of two world wars, economic depression and the deafening clamor of industrialization. With THE AMERICAN CENTURY: Art and Culture 1900-1950 (Whitney Museum of American Art/Norton, cloth, $60; paper $40), Barbara Haskell has managed to create a remarkably seamless narrative of that era of disjunction and flux. Featuring supplementary essays by scholars of various arts, this survey of American cultural history places everything from tea sets by Tiffany to the color-field paintings of Mark Rothko, from the Gibson Girl to ''Citizen Kane,'' in historical context. Haskell, a curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art, shows how more than 1,000 wildly disparate works of art are in fact closely related to one another, all made either to document or to retreat from a new world of machines, stock markets, dust bowls and neon lights. What emerges is a portrait of a nation alternating between pitiful disillusionment and glorious confidence, always anxious to construct for itself a mythical history and a monumental identity. This book is no less a product of such anxiety than the cultural artifacts discussed therein; in its grandiose ambition to incorporate as much as possible within its fold while assigning all things a logical place, ''The American Century'' is itself a testament to this country's compulsion to assemble the fragments of its past into cohesive form. Christina Cho

title: You Got a Problem With These Souvenirs?
description: Tourists may prefer gift shops that sell miniature Empire State Buildings and Big Apple T-shirts, but according to Lorenzo Gori-Montanelli, owner of Curbstone, a company that makes New York City souvenirs, more subtle images appeal to natives.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Stett Trippe and Stacey Smith
description: Stacey Ross Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Rodney Smith of Southport, Conn., was married last evening to Edward Stettinius Trippe Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Trippe of Greenwich, Conn. Canon Alan Tilson performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda.

title: Democrats Antsy for Corzine To Run or Else to Run Away
description: They'll trot them out again Monday afternoon, a chorus line of seven Democratic candidates for the United States Senate who will strut their stuff in front of a room full of party bosses in hopes of winning some crucial endorsements.

title: Planning Our Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Charter Vote Is Assailed As Illegal
description: A loose coalition of legislators, school and union officials charged yesterday that New York State officials violated state law when they approved the state's first eight charter schools last week without providing a chance for public comment.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: WE WERE TIRED OF LIVING IN A HOUSE. By Liesel Moak Skorpen. Illustrated by Joe Cepeda. Putnam. $15.99. (Ages 5 to 9) Three children, two little boys and their older sister, are ''tired of living in a house,'' so they pack up what they need -- sweaters, socks, mittens -- and move out. They try out delightful locations -- a tree, a pond, a cave, the seaside -- and enjoy the special pleasures of each, collecting treasures along the way. Eventually, this being an entirely happy fantasy, they go back to live in the house. The jaunty illustrations of the intrepid children parading around with their accumulating baggage are very cute.

title: A Happy Ending
description: Was it a blow to crush the spirit of a budding entrepreneur? Hardly.

title: Court Says Atlantic City Police Don't Technically Exist
description: Any rumors about the nonexistence of the Atlantic City Police Department are premature, said Louis Toscano, an aide to Mayor James Whelan, despite an appellate court ruling this month that said that, technically, the 420-member department does not exist.

title: Lone Sub-Par Round Lifts Stricker
description: When Steve Stricker teed off in today's third round of the United States Open, he was six strokes off the lead. When he birdied the second hole, he was five behind. And when his 8-iron shot into the wind out of a fairway bunker from 136 yards spun into the cup on the 335-yard third hole for an eagle 2, he suddenly was only three strokes off the lead.

title: Rock and Classics, Too
description: THE Talcott Mountain Music Festival, nestled in a new home in Simsbury, opens this week with the first of four Friday night concerts as well as a program on Saturday. The Festival, the summer home of the Hartford Symphony, gets off to a start on Friday evening at 7:30, with Flash Cadillac, a 50's-style band that revives such oldies as ''Jailhouse Rock'' and ''Twistin' the Night Away.''

title: Development Program
description: Because more than 70 percent of jobs are created by small and mid-size businesses, the county's Industrial Development Agency has approved new assistance programs for companies owned by women and minority groups.

title: That Void in Cyberspace Looks a Lot Like Kansas
description: YOUNG men in the movies have been turning into God at a rate that should alarm monotheists. Last year, in ''Dark City,'' Rufus Sewell discovered he had the power to recreate the world just by turning his thoughts to it. This year, it's Keanu Reeves's turn. In ''The Matrix,'' he learns he is The One: someone born to flex his brain like Schwarzeneggerian biceps, making the walls bulge with his bulky intellection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKER, PAULINE
description: LASKER-Pauline. Passed away quietly at home on June 16, 1999. Beloved mother of Jerry and Michele Lasker and Meri and Burton Kaiser, beloved grandmother of Jonathan and Michael Lasker and Hal and Stacey Kaiser, beloved aunt of Richard and Vera Kaye, Alan and Angela Kaye, Stanley and Joan Markowitz and Marvin and Sally Markowitz and their families. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society and the Jefferson Market Regional Branch of the New York Public Library.

title: Backtalk; When the No. 1 Player And No. 1 Villain Are One
description: As an advertisement for herself, Martina Hingis's petulant performance in the French Open final against Steffi Graf two weeks ago gave cause for pause. Is the 18-year-old Slovak-turned-Swiss-turned-Florida-resident trading in her trademark precocity for pathology? Is she out to become the brattiest No. 1 since John McEnroe made a habit, and a living, out of on-court dysfunction?

title: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
description: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses.

title: What Came First
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AVERILL, BRETT
description: AVERILL-Brett. July 23, 1957June 20, 1995. My darling Brett, for now and forever, I'll always love you-Bill.

title: Fatherly Confusions
description: Perhaps those tickets to ''Death of a Salesman'' were the wrong Father's Day present after all. Get him what he really wants, the ads all say, but does he even know what that is, and if you gave it to him could he open it over breakfast in front of the family? Every possible present seems to carry the wrong message. Tie, wallet, belt, after-shave -- the customary gifts -- imply that Dad is something of an accessory. In fact, a strange obliquity often emerges when dads open their Father's Day presents, as if Pandora's box contained not a world of trouble but soap-on-a-rope.

title: With Late Sprint, Kasparov Wins a Third Straight Event
description: Garry Kasparov did not scale the heights of brilliancy in the Sarajevo International Tournament, as he had in his two previous outings, in Linares, Spain, and Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands. When it ended on May 26, however, he had run away with his third first prize in a row.

title: Katherine Rourke and Jed Bonnem
description: Katherine Marie Rourke and Joseph Edward Bonnem were married yesterday at the Church of the Annunciation in Washington. The Rev. Patrick Dempsey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Q&A/Dr. Glenn I. Bronley; The Role of Fathers in Raising Children
description: THREE decades after the birth of the women's movement changed the way many women look at their role as mothers, many men are still trying to come to terms with what their role as fathers should be, Dr. Glenn I. Bronley, a psychologist, said.

title: A Comfy Way Around the Mountain
description: THE highest mountains in Western Europe are Mont Blanc, in France, and Monte Rosa, in Switzerland and Italy -- the white mountain and the red. Like Snow-White and Rose-Red in Grimm's fairy tale, Mont Blanc is famous; Monte Rosa, the obscure second sister. Yet at 15,203 feet it is only an imperceptible 570 feet lower than Mont Blanc. And this ''red'' mountain is as white as Mont Blanc: its name derives from the rosy flush that suffuses its vast snowfields at dawn.

title: In Face of Danger, Teachers Can Still Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the Keepers of Oneida Don't Care to Share the Table
description: IT began in the 1840's as a rejection of the world at large, a breakaway utopian experiment that combined the dignity of work with the joy of sex amid the upheaval wrought by the Industrial Revolution. But it has evolved, primly enough, into the nation's largest manufacturer of stainless steel knives, forks and spoons.

title: Los Angeles Courts Help Fight Gangs
description: Incongruously close to some of this city's most affluent neighborhoods and a shell's throw from touristy Venice Beach and the azure Pacific, a gang war has played out over a decade, in which dozens have been killed and scores wounded.

description: Se Ri Pak has a simple mission for today's final round of the ShopRite LPGA Classic in Absecon, N.J. The native of South Korea, who sprang into prominence in women's golf last season, wants to win the tournament so she can present her father and coach, Joon Chul, the trophy as a gift for Father's Day.

title: Santiago Walk
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article on Santiago de Compostela. Although I have never made the pilgrimage, I thought Mr. Duffy did an excellent job of illuminating the highs and lows of such an endeavor.

description: TUCKER-Stephen H., Dr. After six years, missed and loved. Never to be forgotten. Happy Fathers Day. Your family

title: New Court to Handle Domestic Abuse Cases
description: THE first combined felony-misdemeanor domestic violence court in the state opened Tuesday here at the Westchester County Courthouse, and officials say there will be enough abuse cases to keep a judge occupied full time.

title: Consistency Is Not This Place's Forte
description: THE restaurants at Danfords on the Sound have had their ups and downs over the Port Jefferson inn's 14-year existence. The latest incarnation, 25 East-American Bistro, falls right in the center.

title: Lautenberg Rejects Pleas To Run Again for Senate
description: Fearing that they may not have a candidate who can defeat Christine Todd Whitman and retain a Senate seat their party has held for almost two decades, Democrats from President Clinton on down urged Senator Frank R. Lautenberg last month to cancel his plans to retire and instead run for re-election, Democratic officials say.

title: Chopin, the Day After the Opera
description: MUSIC history has its myths and its debunkers of myths. Beethoven wasn't quite the political idealist he seems in the story about tearing up the ''Eroica'' dedication when Napoleon crowned himself Emperor; Schubert wasn't a cheerful bohemian who died unknown. In the case of Chopin, it is so obvious that his melodies and arabesques sound like the bel canto opera of his day that conventional wisdom has him ''influenced'' by opera, especially by the long lines of Bellini. And the scholars have been at some pains to discourage the notion that he went to the theater in the evening and imitated what he heard there in the morning.

title: Laura Fortner, David Palmieri
description: Laura Lynn Fortner, the daughter of Carol and Douglas Fortner of Setauket, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Anthony Palmieri, the son of Joan and Anthony Palmieri of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Paul Wancura performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Caroline Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, IRVING
description: WARSHAW-Irving. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Toby. Loving father of Carole and Charles Steinfast and Harriet and Ronald Platt. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Dear brother. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 10:30 AM, Sunday.

title: Pioline Beats Ullyett
description: The former Wimbledon and United States Open runner-up Cedric Pioline beat the qualifier Kevin Ullyett of Zimbabwe by 6-3, 7-5 to win the Nottingham Open in England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, JOHN HENRY, M.D.
description: DOHERTY-John Henry, M.D. 73, died June 17, 1999. He was born March 28, 1926 to Frank Doherty and Marie Ormsby of Mt. Vernon. His brother, Frank Doherty, died January 1983. He attended Mt. St. Michael's High School, Bronx, Holy Cross College and New York Medical College. On June 24, 1950, he married Ann Marie Healey. He served at sea as a U.S. Navy medical officer in 1951. He interned at St. Vincent's Hospital, New York from 1949-1953 and did his residency in Orthopedic Surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York from 1953-1956. He was chief of the orthopedic section at the Veterans Administration Hospital, Bronx from 1956-1963. He was attending orthopedic surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery from 1963-1991 and assistant to the surgeon-in-chief from 1963-1973. He was chief of orthopedic surgery at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Bronx from 1990-1994 and medical officer/orthopedic consultant for the N.Y.C. Fire Department from 1992-1995. He was an orthopedic surgeon emeritus at the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was a member of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, American College of Surgeons, Scoliosis Research Society, Dysautonimia Association, S.I.C.O.T. and the New England Orthopedic Society. He was associate professor of orthopedic surgery at Cornell University Medical College. He is survived by seven children, Jack Doherty of Pelham, James Doherty of New Rochelle, Kathleen Burpee of Pelham, Richard Doherty of Dallas, TX, Diane Conover of Southport, CT, Mary Jo McGuire of Mamaroneck, and Thomas Doherty of Ramsey, NJ; and 14 grandchildren. He was a member of the Pelham Country Club and an avid reader, golfer, gardener and N.Y. Giants fan. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 914834-0144. Mass Monday 10 AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Contributions may be made to Hale House, 154 W. 122 St., NYC 10027.

title: Carlos Rios and Victoria Dryfoos
description: Victoria Anne Dryfoos and Carlos Eduardo Rios Uribe were married yesterday at the Beach Plum Inn in Menemsha, Mass., on Martha's Vineyard. The Rev. Arlene L. Bodge, a United Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: The Next Clinton
description: Your cover seemed calculated to portray a vulnerable Hillary Clinton -- a middle-aged boomer whose sad eyes and lined face betray the troubles she has seen. Well, save the empathy for those who deserve it: the travel-office employees, for example, who were peremptorily fired. As your article made clear, she and her mate are two of a kind, full of false piety and the cheap brand of compassion that is financed by extortionate taxes.

title: Hotel Phone Bill Can Be a Shock
description: HOTEL telephone fees are starting to climb again. Although phone fees vary widely from hotel to hotel, they have become one of the three areas where hotels are seeking bigger profts, along with in-room safes and valet parking.

title: Driving Parents to Anxiety
description: ''WITH all the kids passing away, it's affected me,'' said Rizzy Qureshi, an 18-year-old senior at Sachem High School's North Campus. ''I don't think death should be the norm.''

title: Inventing a Science and Technology Museum
description: PHILADELPHIA has the Franklin Institute. San Francisco has its Exploratorium. Pittsburgh has the Carnegie Center. Columbus, Ohio, with a population of 1.1 million, recently replaced its 35-year-old science center with a new, $125 million state-of-the-art facility.

title: Organist to Give Recital At Bronxville Church
description: FOR the last 40 years, E. Paul Deege has served West Center Congregational Church in Bronxville as organist and minister of music as well as teaching piano and voice privately and at the former Halsted School in Yonkers. Before his retirement next month, Mr. Deege is giving a final recital today at 2 P.M. at the Bronxville church. The program spans three centuries of masterworks for the organ by Bach, Franck, William Faulks, Jean Langlais and Leo Sowerby. There is no admission charge, but donations will be solicited.

title: Maris Williams, William Baker
description: Maris Sisco Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Williams of Centre Island, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Wendell Baker, the son of Jeanne Hobbs and Robert W. Baker, both of Baltimore. Malcolm MacKay, a Centre Island village justice, officiated at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. The bride's father, who is Centre Island's Mayor, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, FRANK
description: MITCHELL-Frank. Passed away in Sydney, June 16. Designer, artist and friend to many. He will be missed by all who loved him here and in Australia. Love forever, Leo and Steven

title: The Next Clinton
description: I have lived in New York City for 20 years and, in that time, have, with rare exceptions, voted for Democratic candidates. I would never, however, vote for someone -- Hillary Clinton or anyone else -- who had not spent at least several years in the state establishing a public record. Your article solidified my feeling, since, while coy about much, it makes clear that she is considering the race only to advance herself and that she looks upon the office as little more than a good career move.

title: Ms. Orenstein And Mr. Brown
description: Heather Lyn Orenstein, a daughter of Barbara and Michael H. Orenstein of New York, was married last evening to Andrew Myles Brown, a son of Barbara and Harvey M. Brown of Morganville, N.J. Rabbi Judith S. Lewis performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GETTINGER, PAUL P.
description: GETTINGER-Paul P. Our loving thoughts are with you today and everyday. We miss and love the dearest and most wonderfully devoted father. Martin and Gloria

title: Evert and Carillo Offer Advice
description: Tomorrow, family and children week begins on MSG, and one of the telecasts ( 8 P.M.) offers a tale from the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament. The event remains a prime testing ground for United States junior players. The feature includes interviews with former pros turned television commentators, Chris Evert and Mary Carillo, who caution players to hone their games and resist the temptation to turn pro immediately, as Venus and Serena Williams did.

title: Do We Really Need Another Starr Report?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thinking Post-Modern but Talking of Michelangelo
description: ON a recent trip to Italy, the choreographer Anna Myer visited museums and churches. After seeing images of the Virgin Mary, the Cross, the Crucifixion, cherubs and angels, she came away ''drenched in beautiful sculptures by Michelangelo.'' A year later, back in Cambridge, Mass., where she lives and works, she created ''In Italian,'' an 18-minute dance to the music of Vivaldi that her company, Anna Myer and Dancers, will perform at St. Mark's Church from Thursday through Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLADSTEIN, DR. ARTHUR
description: GLADSTEIN-Dr. Arthur. 3/3/226/20/94. 5 years of missing your unique self. From your loving Petunie.

description: Megan Irene Young was married yesterday to Russell Otis Wiese at the Church at Point O'Woods on Fire Island. The Rev. Carter Via, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

description: Juneteenth By Ralph Ellison. Edited by John F. Callahan. 368 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Do We Really Need Another Starr Report?; A Gratuitous Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Hardball With the 8-Year-Olds
description: WHEN I became head coach of my 8-year-old son's Little League team, I thought I understood hardball politics, having seen the underbelly of Capitol Hill as a staff director for a Congressional subcommittee. How wrong I was! I had no idea that the steepest learning curve would be grasping what some of the ''dad'' coaches knew instinctively, that the laid-back motto of the West Side Little League -- ''we're here to have fun'' -- for many coaches couldn't have been farther from the truth.

title: June 13-19; A New Indian Museum
description: The Fine Arts Commission, the esthetic arbiter of the appearance of what can be built in Washington's monument area, unanimously approved the design of the Smithsonian Institution's new National Museum of the American Indian. It will cost at least $110 million and is to open in 2002 on the last available site on the Mall. The museum's collection will include most of the holdings of the Heye Foundation in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOBOL, EVELYN G.
description: SOBOL-Evelyn G. A service of remembrance will be held Friday, June 25th, 1999 at 11AM at the NYU Heights Lounge, 24 Waverly Pl, N.Y. with reception immediately following. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the NYU Division of Nursing, 50 West 4th St, Room 429, New York, N.Y. 10012.

title: In the Region /Westchester; When Developers, and City Officials, Think Big
description: NOW that New Roc City, the entertainment/shopping complex, is nearing completion in downtown New Rochelle, Louis Cappelli, its developer, is considering another project there.

title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
description: Harry Potter returns to the Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry for his second year, and disaster looms.

title: Safety in Turkey
description: To the Editor: We know you make every effort to provide balanced and accurate information. But we believe the May 16 Correspondent's Report (''Safety Concerns Slow Tourism to Turkey'') was unfortunately inadequate in presenting a balanced picture of the issue of safety in Turkey.

title: Broadway Babies

title: Krista Lamprich, Gordon McClellan
description: Krista Leigh Lamprich and the Rev. Gordon Stuart McClellan were married yesterday at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Oklahoma City. The Rev. Dr. Michael D. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Fighting Tide Of Under-Age Motorists
description: BOBBIE PREISER stopped for a red light on Middle Neck Road in Great Neck recently and saw a friend of her teen-age daughter behind the wheel, even though she knew the girl would not turn 16 until the following month. Why was she driving?

title: With Words, Gore And Bush Stake Out The Middle Ground
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, declaring their candidacies for President, sound as though they are proclaiming the primary campaign over, the general election begun and the battleground designated as the moderate middle, with ideological extremes out of bounds.

title: OPINION; Career Counseling for Amy Fisher
description: SINCE being freed from an upstate penitentiary after serving time for attempting to kill her lover's wife, Amy Fisher has successfully avoided being stalked, mobbed or ambushed by Long Islanders fascinated by her crime of passion. Yet for the rest of her life Ms. Fisher will always wear the ''Long Island Lolita'' label, part of a defining image for a region that winces at our national stereotype of malls, Mercedes and middle-class tract homes. Sad to say, Ms. Fisher may find her kitsch image lasting far longer than her seven years in stir.

title: Tomorrow, the Sundial
description: Pocket watches, once the accessory of dear old Dad, have gone hip-hop. ''All the guys are requesting them for photo shoots and videos,'' said Andrea Lieberman, a music industry stylist who works with Sean (Puffy) Combs, Ricky Martin, Marc Anthony and other pop stars. ''Pocket watches add the perfect touch of class for men who are creative, fashionable dressers,'' she added. The most requested brand, she said, is IWC, one of the few remaining watchmakers that still manufacture high-end pocket watches. They are available at Cellini on Madison Avenue (53d Street) and Wempe on Fifth Avenue (55th Street). Prices range from $7,000 for a simple silver watch to $450,000 for a gold watch called the Grande Complication. (Mr. Combs recently bought a $9,000 silver model, right.) Marc Bernhardt, IWC's head of United States operations, said pocket watches are expensive because they are generally more precise than wristwatches. ''But their recent surge in popularity with younger people is clearly about the look,'' he said. ''People in the film and music industry want a watch that makes them stand out, no matter what the cost.''

title: The Scene Is Alive, If Not Always Kicking
description: AROUND 20 years ago, not long after John Pizzarelli decided he would be the next great jazz guitarist to come out of New Jersey, his father, Bucky Pizzarelli, also a jazz guitarist, told him that if he wanted to meet some of the most successful players in the business, he should accompany him on a daytime job.

title: Clash With Police Inflames Issue in Mexican Campaign
description: The fatal shooting of a young municipal worker this week by a police officer here provoked a rampage of partisan violence that could affect the outcome of closely watched gubernatorial elections next month in Mexico's most populous state.

description: THE River Cat Grill in Rowayton has the right idea for the millennium. Rather than the usual menu of appetizers and entrees, the new restaurant in a familiar locale offers a menu consisting mainly of starters. There is only one entree-sized (and priced) item on the menu.

title: POSTINGS: $11.5 Million, Six-Story, 28,000-Square-Foot Building; New Jewish Center at Columbia
description: Best known for not moving the New England Patriots to Hartford earlier this year, Robert K. Kraft has made possible an important move of a very different kind. By January, the physical center of Jewish life at Columbia University will move from cramped, decrepit and entirely inadequate basement space at Earl Hall into a new six-story, 28,000-square-foot building on West 115th Street, between Broadway and Riverside Drive.
