title: Ideas & Trends; Republicans Stalk a Slogan, Hunting for Themselves
description: W was the letter of the week -- as in the middle initial and nickname of George W. Bush, the Governor of Texas who announced his candidacy for President in a trip to Iowa and New Hampshire. But by the time Mr. Bush had made his way home to Austin, another letter in the alphabet was crowing for attention in this swift Presidential primary campaign: C, as in CC, the shorthand in the Bush campaign for ''Compassionate Conservatism.'' It was on that rhetorical ground, the son of the former President declared in the course of 10 speeches in three days, that his campaign for the White House would rise or fall.

title: Fledgling Ballroom Dancers Face the Music
description: THE SETTING -- Amid towering palm trees on the marble floor of the World Financial Center's Winter Garden, 100 city schoolchildren were doing the tango Tuesday night. That's what it looked like, anyway, at a competition sponsored by the American Ballroom Theater Company that also had students swing dancing and doing the rumba, the merengue and the fox trot.

title: Olympian Prices
description: To the Editor: In ''Sydney Sets the Stage for 2000 Olympic Games'' (Correspondent's Report, May 9), Edwin McDowell mentions the high cost of the six-night package from Los Angeles to Sydney. I spoke to Cartan Tours, the authorized representative for the Olympics, which advised that the least expensive six-day package costs $4,990 a person. The company estimated $1,200 for the air fare, leaving $3,790 for a bedroom in a private home. Therefore, a couple would be paying $1,263 a night to stay in somebody's house.

title: Only One Way to Vote On Byram Hills Issue
description: As our students take final exams, Byram Hills School District voters also have questions to answer. Foremost among them is whether we want to preserve the quality of education in this district. (The answer has to be yes.) Do the three propositions before the voters on Wednesday achieve that result? (Again, yes.)

title: Hamm Handles Hype and Americans' High Hopes
description: She is the face of women's soccer, the player the young girls squeal for, the one personality who has pushed through the glass ceiling of invisibility in a sport still trying to broaden its appeal beyond the weekend fields of suburbia.

title: Stacey Poster, Andrew Vogel
description: Stacey Ann Poster, the daughter of Joanne and Steven Poster of Wellington, Fla., was married last evening to Andrew Howard Vogel, the son of Eleanor and Mike Vogel of Old Westbury, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Great Literature. Period Costumes. That Is So Cool.
description: IN Oliver Parker's slick new screen adaptation of ''An Ideal Husband,'' one of Oscar Wilde's lesser-known stage comedies, all of the well-heeled characters, played by such of-the-moment film actors as Rupert Everett, Cate Blanchett and Minnie Driver, gather for an evening in the theater. The camera shifts fleetly from box seat to box seat, recording the stars' suggestive smiles and meaningful glances and helping to frame one of the movie's motifs, that in the social whirl of London 100 years ago, the privileged classes were as prone to the vanities and weaknesses of the heart, soul and purse as the beautiful people of today.

title: Ocean City Holds Back The Tide
description: The old Coast Guard station here, so rich in historic credentials that it made Preservation New Jersey's list of the state's 10 most endangered sites, is almost surely saved. Its cause was so popular that the City Council agreed to buy it from the developer who had planned to put three duplexes in its place at the corner of Fourth Street and Atlantic Avenue.

title: Confessions Of a Liberal Who Dared To Pack a Rod
description: I fired a semi-automatic. It's not as bad as it sounds.

title: From Zen Garden to Piazza, A Plaza Gets a New Look
description: The 25-year-old plaza at the foot of the World Trade Center has reopened after an 18-month renovation to give it what its designers say is a warmer and more inviting look.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, BENJAMIN
description: REEVES-Benjamin. A father for all seasons who was honest, responsible, courageous, generous, modest, devoted, & unforgettable.

title: In London, Fueling Flea Market Forays
description: IN his prologue to the recently released film ''Notting Hill,'' William Thacker (the Hugh Grant character) reminds us that on Saturdays on the Portobello Road ''hundreds of stalls appear . . . and wherever you look, thousands of people are buying millions of antiques.'' I am a member of that horde, an inveterate prowler of Portobello and the other street markets of London that specialize in antiques and collectibles.

title: Cassie Robbins, Thomas Clayton
description: Caroline Sutphin Wyckoff Robbins, the daughter of Margaret and E. Brooks Robbins of Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Armstrong Clayton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe D. Clayton of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. James H. Gray, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the United Church of Dorset and East Rupert in Dorset, Vt.

title: Making Himself at Home Wherever There's a Melody
description: BEHIND every great pop artist is a great backup group. Its leader, who may also sing and even play, is aptly called the M.D., for music director. Roberta Flack will be the one out front at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven, but behind her is a group directed by Shelton Becton, a mild-mannered but electrifying pianist who conducts, composes, sings, arranges charts and transforms ordinary tunes into blazing numbers that lift you off your seat.

title: At Princeton University, Jazz Is Now Taken Seriously
description: THINK of jazz impresarios, jam sessions and experimentalism, and Princeton University probably isn't the first place that springs to mind. Yet in the last 10 years, jazz musicians and critics have begun to sit up and take notice that Princeton is becoming a jazz center in its own right.

title: Ideas & Trends; Full Metal Dust Jacket: Books Are Violent, Too
description: SINCE the shootings in Littleton, Col., the tone of complaints about what children read has shifted dramatically from outrage about sexual descriptions to concern about mayhem on the printed page.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Chardonnay 101

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Glamourbrat
description: Diane Leslie's first novel, FLEUR DE LEIGH'S LIFE OF CRIME (Simon & Schuster, $23), offers a delicious and disturbing glimpse behind the high stucco walls of Hollywood, circa 1957. In one canyon dwelling, 10-year-old Fleur de Leigh competes with studio executives, fans and artwork for the attention of her parents. But her mother, Charmian, is busy plotting her move beyond ''The Charmian Leigh Radio Mystery Half-Hour'' and such movie credits as ''Ivan the Marriageable'' and ''Divorcee Ole!'' Her father, Maurice, lately ''reduced to producing television,'' shows more concern for his Cadillac and his ''authentic'' police badge than for his daughter. Left to a rotating cast of nannies, whose names serve as chapter titles, Fleur narrates her search for love from parental substitutes such as Glendora, ''too fat to be anything but a supporting character,'' ''glamour puss'' Bettina and the silent-era star Thea Roy. When one nanny -- an escaped mental patient -- tries to corner Fleur for surgery, only the bare-chested Moldavian gardener, Constantine, intervenes. Constantine relieves Fleur's loneliness with such commands as ''Fleur Leigh, put bathing suit on. Is going on sprinklers.'' But it's a tough coming of age for a girl dropped off at ''psychodrama'' workshops and ogled by tourists. Leslie -- who clearly knows the Hollywood she lampoons -- balances the sincerity of Fleur's narration with the superficiality of her surroundings, eliciting shivers of compassion. The antics can border on the slapstick, and the reader misses follow-ups to cameo appearances by cops, game-show contestants and a grandmother. But then so does Fleur, a heroine forced to make the most of her placement on maps of the stars. Nina Sonenberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTONOFF, BERNARD
description: ANTONOFF-Bernard. 72. G-d has another angel. We love you.

title: An Amiable Relic Puts to Sea
description: IN 1944 my pal Jerry, bound for an Army artillery unit in the Solomon Islands, steamed from San Francisco to New Caledonia on the troop ship Gen. J. R. Brooke and spent hours of his first days at sea listening over the rail for the sound of splitting seams. Among notions widely held during World War II was the idea that United States cargo and troop ships could quite casually split in two.

She is wearing an elaborate Kabuki-like headdress, chalk-white makeup and an imperious expression. Whose 10-foot-by-13-foot photograph is this, and why, though it has only recently appeared, does the woman look so familiar?

description: PARENTS take note: Matthew Wilder may be able to get your children to practice the piano. Or the saxophone, or violin, or guitar, or drums. And they may love doing so. The only rub? Home life may become loud.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gwen Hyman, Andrew Carmellini
description: SOME New York restaurant chefs dress in the fastidious style of their food, perfectly balancing colors and lines and garnishing their suit jackets with handkerchiefs popping from front pockets like sprigs of rosemary. Andrew A. Carmellini, the chef de cuisine at Cafe Boulud, prefers jeans and savors basketball and rock music as much as wines that cost more than a summer share in the Hamptons.

title: June 13-19; Prime Time for Casino Ads
description: Gambling casinos have a product to market, and radio and television stations are more than willing to sell them air time. But a 65-year-old Federal law made it illegal to broadcast advertisements for casino gambling.

title: Picking the Right Hose for the Job
description: THE ordinary garden hose has more uses than simply watering the grass. It can be used to wash the exterior of the house, the patio, the deck and the car. It is a necessary tool for bringing water to a place that may be away from a faucet, so you can mix cement without having to carry buckets of water to the construction site.

title: In Britain, Mining the Arts For Management Metaphor

description: Using the technology of maglev trains and rocket-launching motors, a new generation of rides makes a science of vertigo.

title: For Democracy in Unions, Pair Defies Labor Leaders
description: Although it could cause a showdown between union leaders and rank-and-file members here, Jamie Newman insists that a referendum she and another bus driver hope to have placed on the state ballot this November -- a measure that would instill more democracy in unions -- is ''as American as apple pie.''

title: The World: The World Takes Notice; Kashmir Gets Scarier

Islamic fighters have crossed the line that divides the state between zones of Indian and Pakistani control, and the Indian Army is waging a bloody campaign to drive them back. It is the latest battle in a conflict that has taken tens of thousands of lives over the last decade.

Finding bargains can be a full-time job though, and some, like standing-room (tickets for which can be bought on the day of performance from box offices for $15 to $25), require real energy. But high school students have certain advantages. Here's a sampling.

Idoni, referring to a cinema that will have an Imax theater, the first in the county, and 18 other regular screens. The theater is one of the anchors of New Roc City, a $190 million project that will include family entertainment and retail and mixed use development.

description: FERBER-Stanley. On June 19, 1999. Loving husband of Beverly. Cherished father of Caryl and Stacy. Dear brother of Marilyn Kopp and grandfather of Ariel, Rebecca and Sam. Services Sunday at Temple Beth El, Roxbury Rd., Stamford, CT. Call 516-482-3600 for time of service.

title: What's Wrong With This Picture?
description: ROBERT FRANCOEUR has an improbable resume: He is an ordained Roman Catholic priest who is married with two children and has made a career of the study of sex.

title: Santiago Walk
description: To the Editor: David G. P. R. Duffy's article on the Camino de Santiago de Compostela in Spain (''A Pilgrim's Rewards, Step by Step,'' May 30) gives a lively and informative picture of the pilgrim road. He walked the camino from St.-Jean-Pied-de-Port in France to Santiago at about the same time a French friend and I did last year. His average of 21 miles a day need not discourage would-be peregrinos. Many of us averaged fewer miles and more blisters per day, and still found the trip to be challenging and memorable.

title: Bush or Gore, But Who Cares?
description: It may seem like the Presidential campaign of 2000 is in full swing, given all the hoopla about Al Gore and George W. Bush hitting the campaign trail. But consider what the Pew Research Center, a major public policy study group, found when it sent its poll takers out a few days ago to test the nation's political pulse:

title: Food; Passion Fish
description: The pucker of a good lemonade is as much a reality check as it is an antidote to summer heat. Its sour flavor, like the itch of sunburn or the ache of well-used muscles, reminds us that there's a thorny side to the pleasures of the season.

title: 'Brief Interviews With Hideous Men'
description: You know the old story about how if you set a billion monkeys to work on a billion typewriters, one of them would eventually compose the complete works of Shakespeare? David Foster Wallace often writes the way I imagine that billionth monkey would: in mad cadenzas of simian gibberish that break suddenly into glorious soliloquies, then plunge again into nonsense.

title: Fetishist? Beatlemaniac? Just Call Me a Collector
description: I DID not attend Sir George Martin's recent lecture on the making of ''Sgt. Pepper,'' but not because I don't find the details of the Beatles' recordings thoroughly fascinating. Quite the contrary. But I had heard and read Sir George's account several times, and reports from earlier stops on his tour indicated that his talk, entertaining though it was, covered no new ground. Mainly, I was confident that the excerpts he played from the session tapes were already safely in my collection.

title: The Nation: Grade Inflation; New Math: No One Is Below Average
description: IN Lake Wobegon, Garrison Keillor's mythical Minnesota community, the women are strong, the men are good looking and the children are all above average. But who knew that those children were pawns of standardized testing?

title: The Color of Suspicion
description: Sgt. Mike Lewis of the Maryland State Police is a bull-necked, megaphone-voiced, highly caffeinated drug warrior who, on this shiny May morning outside of Annapolis, is conceding defeat. The drug war is over, the good guys have lost and he has been cast as a racist. ''This is the end, buddy,'' he says. ''I can read the writing on the wall.'' Lewis is driving his unmarked Crown Victoria down the fast lane of Route 50, looking for bad guys. The back of his neck is burnt by the sun, and he wears his hair flat and short under his regulation Stetson.

title: Ms. Weiss, Mr. Thompson
description: Meredith Lee Weiss, the daughter of Iris and Joshua Weiss of Hewlett Harbor, N.Y., was married last evening to Douglas Malcolm Thompson, the son of Margaret and John Thompson of East Liverpool, Ohio. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated and the Rev. Tanta Hendricks, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony at Milleridge Cottage, a caterer in Jericho, N.Y.

title: 'Brief Interviews With Hideous Men'
description: You know the old story about how if you set a billion monkeys to work on a billion typewriters, one of them would eventually compose the complete works of Shakespeare? David Foster Wallace often writes the way I imagine that billionth monkey would: in mad cadenzas of simian gibberish that break suddenly into glorious soliloquies, then plunge again into nonsense.

title: Cathy Klauber, Peter Cooper
description: Cathy Lynn Klauber, a daughter of Susan and Donald E. Klauber of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married on Thursday to Peter Lee Cooper, the son of Carol Wische and the stepson of Sande Wische of Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: May the Force Be With You
description: DEEP PLAY

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A CELIBATE SEASON

title: Cold Blue Blood
description: STRANGERS

title: Only Things Like Life and Death
description: IN the beginning, there is death. Eliza, a black servant noble in aspect, hearing morning doves, presages ''a sad day for us all.'' With the air of a one-woman Greek chorus transported to a Texas town in 1928, Beatrice Winde's eloquence as Eliza travels beyond ominous, ornate words. ''Death I knew would be at this house for somebody sometime today and it came,'' she tells the audience at Hartford Stage Company in the first moments of ''The Death of Papa,'' Horton Foote's coda to his chronicle of nine memory plays about a very extended family in Harrison (read Wharton) Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITELBAUM, LEWIS N.
description: TEITELBAUM-Lewis N. Age 60, suddenly on June 18, 1999. Beloved husband to Sooky, adoring father to Joshua and Noah, devoted son to Sylvia, loving son-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Handsome, funny, spirited and irreplaceable. Our hearts are broken. For funeral information call 718377-2700. Shiva at residence, 1435 E. 18th St, Brooklyn.

title: Do We Really Need Another Starr Report?; Beyond New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Auckland Recalled
description: To the Editor: ''Around Auckland, and into the Bush'' (Frugal Traveler, May 30) brought back two comical memories. Three years ago, I stayed at a very modest motel at $43 a night. When I returned from a day's touring I discovered that my bed had not been made. When I indignantly asked the motel owner about it, he asked calmly, ''Do you want to pay $53? That's what it costs with the bed made.'' I made the bed myself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIN, JOSE
description: ROBIN-Jose. Sutton Place Synagogue records with sorrow the loss of our esteemed member and Patron. Condolences to his beloved wife Margarita, children and grandchildren. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
description: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses.

title: Francine Everett, Striking Star Of All-Black Movies, Is Dead
description: Francine Everett, a singer, dancer and actress who was one of the stars of the all-black cast ''race'' movies of the 30's and 40's, died at a nursing home in the Bronx on May 27.

title: Spurs Say Letdown Is Unlikely At Garden
description: The San Antonio Spurs have three players with at least two National Basketball Association championship rings, two players who spent years moiling in the minor leagues before seizing the big stage, and accomplished college graduates with degrees in finance, mathematics, computer information systems and psychology.

title: Ms. Phalon, Mr. Baldassari
description: Arlene Joan Phalon and Michael John Baldassari were married yesterday in Hoboken, N.J. The Rev. Francis Sariego performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ann.

title: Crowning Your Successor
description: Q. I've been promoted, and one of my first new tasks is finding someone to fill my old job as a department head. The people in the department work well together and are technically all equals, but they see a definite pecking order -- and my first choice for the job is not the person they all assume is in line for it. Should I go with the better candidate, knowing that she and I will be resented, or suffer with a less capable manager in order to preserve group harmony?

title: Vitamaria Bosco, Francis Rocca
description: Vitamaria Bosco and Francis Xavier Rocca were married yesterday by the Rev. Guido Bottega at the Roman Catholic Church of San Rocco in Vicenza, Italy.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FINANCIAL DISTRICT

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALANT, WALTER S.
description: SALANT-Walter S. A memorial service will be held on June 21st at 2 PM in the Main Auditorium of Brookings Institution, 1775 Massachusetts Avenue, Washington, DC.

title: Kelly Crawford, Andrew Friendly
description: Kelly Ann Crawford and Andrew Friendly were married yesterday at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Whitney Burr, an Episcopal priest, officiated and the Rev. Robert Gregory, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: REBELS IN KOSOVO AGREE TO DISBAND, NATO OFFICERS SAY GROUP MUST SIGN ACCORD
description: With the last Yugoslav forces streaming out of Kosovo ahead of schedule, NATO commanders here have reached a tentative agreement with leaders of the Kosovo Liberation Army to gradually disband the rebel force, NATO officials said today.

title: The Nation; Congress Never Even Got to Vote to Ban This Weapon
description: DEBATE last week in the House of Representatives centered on the sale of weapons at gun shows, an issue that has drawn wide attention in the two months since the shootings at Columbine High School. In the end the House defeated legislation that Democrats and Republican moderates said had been hopelessly watered down by lawmakers who caved in to the National Rifle Association.

title: Gina del Carmen, Brooke Coburn
description: Gina Marie del Carmen, a daughter of Susan and Dr. Benjamin V. del Carmen of Lutherville, Md., was married yesterday to Brooke Bowen Coburn, a son of Cynthia M. Dusharm and Dr. Thomas B. Coburn, both of Canton, N.Y.

title: Job-Training Project Becomes Part of Unemployment List
description: Finally there were crowds at Treasures Thrift Emporium on Fourth Street near Seventh Avenue, but only because of the liquidation sale. Paperbacks went for pennies and a model of a giant aspirin tablet sold for a song as the thrift store marked its first anniversary last Sunday by going out of business.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column on page 77 of The Times Magazine today omits a byline. The writer was Molly O'Neill.

title: Children's Books
description: EXTREME ELVIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Sharing the Hopes and Fears Of the Class of '99
description: IT is a busy time for the class of '99: a whirlwind of giddy celebrations and tearful farewells.

title: U.S. Shoppers Shoulder The Weight of the World
description: EVERYBODY knows that the American consumer has been the high-octane fuel behind the nation's decadelong economic boom. Retail spending, after all, accounts for two-thirds of the output of the United States.

title: Gore: 'There Is a Hunger And Thirst for Goodness'
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's speech announcing his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President, on June 16 in Carthage, Tenn., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Despite the Fears, Inflation Still Refuses to Materialize
description: IS inflation rising in America? No, it is not. Just look at the numbers. Is it about to start rising? That depends on whom you talk to. Wall Street forecasters worry that it soon will, that America is still inflation-prone. But talk to the people who compile the monthly inflation numbers. They are singularly unconcerned.

title: Habitats/Woodside; Manhattanite Finds Sunny Studio in Queens
description: ANDREA SIEGEL lives in a pleasant studio apartment in Woodside, Queens, a neighborhood more typically home to blue-collar workers -- in recent decades immigrants from Ecuador, South Korea and Pakistan -- than to the well-educated children of the city's privileged class.

title: The Pulitzer Paradox
description: Having just completed my term on the Pulitzer Prize Board, I couldn't agree more with Max Frankel's complaint that most newspapers ignore the Pulitzer-winning stories published by other papers (Word & Image, May 30). The refusal to share with readers a great and important story, simply because it was produced by someone else, is both arrogant and professionally irresponsible.

title: Conducting A Chemical Experiment
description: FRANZ WELSER-MOST'S scheduled ascendance in 2002 to music director of the Cleveland Orchestra is hopeful news. Conductors and orchestras are sometimes about individual and collective personalities, but in some places, Cleveland among them, the subject is chemistry.

title: The Nation; Greenspan on Inflation: Wait, Don't Wait. Go Figure.
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, the Federal Reserve chairman, strongly hinted last week that the central bank will raise interest rates later this month to prevent the galloping economy from setting off inflation -- even though, he conceded, inflation remains inconsequential. ''Pre-emptive action can obviate the need of more drastic actions at a later date,'' he told Congress.

title: Making Movies
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Los Angeles'' (May 9) states that Hollywood is where the movie industry began. That may be so, but Biograph and Vitagraph had studios in New York City before there was any filming in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Market-Neutral Funds: A Category Stuck in Reverse?
description: One of the newer varieties of mutual funds is called ''market neutral.'' Such funds keep half their portfolios in stocks, usually chosen because of attractive valuations. The other half is sold short, meaning that the manager borrows shares and resells them, hoping they will fall in price so they can be replaced at a lower cost.

title: A Lunch Counter for the City's Powerful
description: IT was a day in early June, a day of unusual social synergy, when normally opposing planets orbited each other for a brief moment, aligned and then spun back away into their separate universes.

title: Travels With Dad, a Very Busy Vacationer
description: WHEN I was growing up, my family's annual winter week in the sun always began with Dad's ''dry run'' back to the airport. No one argued. We were used to vacationing with a man who couldn't relax. Aruba, Maui or Jacksonville, the destination hardly mattered. Calculating how much time to allot for the return trip (tacking on a few hours for unforeseen obstacles) was simply his way of settling in. Only when this chore was ''over with'' could he unpack his bulging suitcases.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-20-99: The Ethicist; Uncharitable View
description: The company I work for is active in several well-known charities, and yet many of my co-workers refuse to participate in any of our fund-raising activities. Aren't they just being selfish?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MOZART

title: Fruit Salad in a Glass
description: One litmus test of a truly savvy merchant is a bin of Le Pouy, formerly Domaine de Pouy. Cultists have stalked this zesty dry white since about 1986. That's when Robert Kacher, an innovative Washington, D.C., importer, first introduced it.

title: Co-op Boards And Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Virtual Trust; In Eden, a Snake. On the Internet, a Worm.
description: CYBERSPACE, which not so long ago was heralded as the arrival of Marshall McLuhan's long-awaited Global Village, has instead become Milton's Paradise Lost.

title: DataBank: June 14-18; Wall St. Returns to Its Winning Ways
description: For no apparent reason, Wall Street notched another impressive week under its belt.

title: When The Boss Tumbles
description: MY boss is in trouble. Last November, my third month as a fellow at the Harvard Divinity School, Ronald F. Thiemann, who brought me to the school, abruptly stepped down as dean to take an unexplained, and much whispered about, sabbatical.

title: IN MY... SATCHEL: KATE SPADE
description: Kate Spade, the designer of handbags, does not keep just one work satchel. She has many. ''One fills up with junk; I pull out the necessities like wallet and keys and just start again,'' she says.

title: Internet Slide Doesn't Faze Fund Holders
description: MANAGERS of Internet mutual funds can thank people like Lynette Kunz for making life a little easier.

title: The Next Clinton
description: I find the notion of Hillary running for the Senate exhilarating but am troubled that much of the focus of her campaign will take place downstate, in New York City and on Long Island. She needs to remember that there is life after Westchester County. Besides, there are more farm stands in Rochester than in Westchester.

title: An Eager Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Marketing, Tailgaters and Traffic
description: THEY drove in on the shoulder of the turnpike, past a traffic jam worthy of a Giants game or a Jets game. Their chartered bus roared past the soccer moms, the soccer dads, the orange-cone soccer players, the soccer freaks, which was only right. There would be no game without the talent.

title: Houston Juggles Rattles, Along With the Spurs
description: Allan Houston's main chore in the last week has been figuring out how to shake free from Mario Elie, the relentless San Antonio swingman who keeps tugging at Houston's jersey and his confidence. The playoffs being about adjustments, it is easily the second-toughest job the Knicks' shooting guard has this post-season.

title: Article on Rock Scene Omitted an Important Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Heidi Country, With French Food
description: THE great lightning summer getaway to the French Alps began as a timeout during the dream tour, a 30th wedding anniversary trip to France with our two sons. We reasoned that after days of togetherness exploring Normandy last July -- examining the Bayeux Tapestry, poking into nearly every pillbox on the Calvados coast and standing awe-struck in the great American cemetery at Colleville-sur-Mer -- it might be wise to separate for a while. Then, we could appreciate one another even more when we reunited.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALFANDRE, JULIAN E.
description: ALFANDRE-Julian E. June 21, 1940-September 8, 1997. Birthdays, two Father's Days of desperately missing you: your quiet eminence; your integrity of heroic proportions; your profound passion for the truth; your prodigious intellect. You-consummate, incomparable Dad. And, friend. Your namesake, Julianna, has arrived. You prevail in her gladness, in her opulent spirit, and heart stopping beauty. Rachel, Jimmy, David and Natalie

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Alone Under Par, Stewart Is Alone On Leader Board
description: After another torture test at the United States Open, Payne Stewart was alone at the top and alone under par.

title: Cutbacks by Oxford Unsettling to Clients
description: EUGENE GROSSMAN picked a good place to have a dizzy spell. The 74-year-old retiree was a volunteer in the gift shop at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, and when he felt ill one day in April he was put on a gurney and rolled from the gift shop to the hospital's emergency room, where he was told that he might need an invasive diagnostic test and possibly a pacemaker.

title: Summer School and No Books
description: WITH summer just a day away, most teenagers will want to hit the beach, the gas pedal or the mall, maybe even the job market. But hit the books? Not if they don't have to. Think again.

title: Bookend; It's Pretty, but Is It Broken?
description: THE English novelist Denton Welch loved to write about picnics and antiques. Unfortunately, as he learned early on, the peculiar modesty of these pleasures required some defense. ''Some people might call it precious,'' Welch's first publisher warned him, over a lunch of duck soup, plaice and mashed potatoes. ''But then I suppose that's my personality,'' Welch answered, bravely but with a croak in his voice.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY; R.I.P. the Loud Tie
description: For those who choke when it comes to choosing a cool tie, buying hip neckwear has never been easier: the plainer the better. ''Traditionally, we've always done better in the silk prints, but this summer the trend is just the opposite,'' said Robert Wood, United States retail manager of Thomas Pink. At its 520 Madison Avenue store (53d Street), lavender solids are most popular. Jonathan Skow, a Los Angeles-based stylist, prefers subdued hues, like a narrow black raw silk Prada tie he dressed Harry Connick Jr. in for a shoot for his new album and a narrow camel-color Helmut Lang tie that he bought to wear with a black or khaki suit. ''Men want something that is easier to look at,'' said L'Wren Scott, a costume designer and stylist, explaining the passing of the loud tie. ''Rather than some tie with animals or dots, something not too aggressive to the eye.'' But wearers can get in knots over size and shape. Fashion houses are favoring skinny, but downtown, ties are short and wide. KEVIN BISCH

title: Some On-the-Job Research
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt, a leading health policy pundit, professor of political economy at Princeton University and headliner on the lecture circuit, is the latest academic luminary to be recruited as a board member by an industry on his radar screen. He recently joined the board at Triad Hospitals Inc., a group spun off last month by Columbia-HCA Healthcare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTON, VIVIAN (NEE POTENZANO)
description: CANTON-Vivian (nee Potenzano). Peacefully on June 17, 1999. Predeceased in 1995 by her husband, Ralph Canton. Most recently of Port Washington, Mrs. Canton was a resident of Flower Hill, Manhasset, NY for 36 years. She was ardently interested in politics, public issues, finance, and genealogy. Mrs. Canton devoted her life to raising her children. She was the proud, beloved mother of Donald Canton of Pembroke, ME., and Elaine Canton of Manhasset. Mother-in-law of Robert Pacent. Cherished Nanny of Paige Canton Pacent. Also survived by three loving sisters, two loving sisters by marriage, and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial Mass will be held for family at St. Mary's Church, Manhasset followed by interment at Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to the American Cancer Society are welcome.

title: Video Battlers Stick by Their Games
description: Soon after turning on his computer, Alfredo Lambour, 15, shot and killed the same zombie six times, saw countless gallons of blood splatter and ran among the decapitated heads and other body parts that littered a fortress floor in the video game Quake II.

title: Paean to Peanut Butter; A Restaurant Gives Lunch Time a Lunch Box Flavor
description: Paul Aberasturi, the chief financial officer of a midtown textile company, and an associate, Matt Pfeufer, recently grabbed a taxi to lunch downtown. They wore conservative suits, as is their custom on work days. The men, both from Long Island, were as clean-cut as choirboys on Christmas Day. Successful, serious, suburban types.

title: Steven Friedman, Valentine Burr

Friedman of South Nyack, N.Y., and Dr. Stanley M. Friedman of Tenafly, N.J. Adrian Foster Cunard, a friend of a couple, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Finally, New Pedestrian Bridge Will Come to the Meadowlands
description: A pedestrian bridge connecting the parking lots at Giants Stadium and Continental Airlines Arena that was supposed to be replaced in the mid-80's is finally scheduled to close this fall when a larger and sturdier version will take its place.

title: Bricks, Mortar and Sociology
description: WHEN Nortel Networks consolidated its global headquarters in a renovated building in suburban Toronto in 1997, Roy Dohner, the vice president for real estate, wanted to see to it that the company changed its culture as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: When Beach Houses Changed East End
description: IN the 1960's, ''before all the spaces were filled in, before the traffic became intolerable,'' Long Island's East End was the focal point of a two-pronged revolution, says Alastair Gordon.

title: To Record, not Just Report, in Court
description: THE state's top administrative judge wants authority to expand use of recording devices in state courts, including some in Westchester, saying it will be both more efficient and fiscally wise.

title: Houston and Sprewell Playing a 2-on-12 Game
description: Marcus Camby was moving with the wobbly and awkward steps of a newborn colt as he drove into the paint and nearly fell down while twisting and turning, all in an effort to get off a shot that would find the net before David Robinson and Tim Duncan found it.

title: Katherine Hand, Jonathan Charlson
description: Katherine McKee Hand, a daughter of Elizabeth Howard Hand of Santa Ana, Costa Rica, and Elbert Osborne Hand 3d of Chicago, was married yesterday to Jonathan McCauley Charlson, the son of Audrey Holden Charlson of New Canaan, Conn., and Clifford William Charlson of Rochester. The Rev. Linda Packard performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Chicago.

title: Children's Books
description: NIGHT GOLF

title: June 13-19; The Koreas Sparring, Again
description: Two weeks after former Defense Secretary William J. Perry traveled to North Korea with a letter from President Clinton proposing a path to reconciliation between the two countries, the North responded by getting its fishing fleet and navy into a fire fight with South Korean ships along a disputed border. The North Koreans lost a ship and more than 20 sailors. America, though, may have lost a chance to convince Congress that sanctions on the North should be lifted in return for commitments from Pyongyang to give up their missile tests and other threatening programs.

title: The Catholic Convert
description: To the Editor:

title: When Cyberspace Was a State of Mind
description: In 1996, when TNT first approached him about doing a television movie on the history of the personal computer industry, Martyn Burke brushed off the suggestion. ''I told them I'd rather do a history of cornflakes,'' recalled Mr. Burke, a screenwriter, novelist and documentary filmmaker.

description: LIE IN THE DARK

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: The Cash Of the Irish Is Talking In Castles
description: FOR SALE: castles in Ireland and other grand piles from Kildare to Kilkenny. Starting prices: $2.5 million to $15 million-plus. Possible buyers: any of a number of Irish millionaires who, in a scant few years of economic lift-off, have suddenly displaced Americans and other foreigners as the prime purchasers of high-ticket real estate hereabouts.

title: Byram Hills Needs Support for Schools
description: The Pleasantville referendum has recently played a prominent role in your letters section, but another referendum battle is under way in Armonk, home of the Byram Hills school system. In March, a referendum to improve and expand the district's four schools was defeated by a mere 43 votes out of 3,300 cast, and a revised proposal is up for vote on Wednesday. This letter is to voice support for the referendum.

title: Million By Million
A Brain Is Just a Brain, Even When It's Einstein's
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Ways To Clean A Carpet
description: FINDING a carpet-cleaning service is as easy as looking for the letter ''C'' in the Yellow Pages. But finding a carpet-cleaning method that works for you might not be so simple.

title: Going Back Hoe
description: Gerritsen Beach doesn't have the name recognition of Borough Park, Flatbush or Coney Island, but this tiny Brooklyn neighborhood on a peninsula between Sheepshead Bay and Marine Park is the star of a Web site called Gerritsen Memories.

title: Getting in Shape to Take On the Garden
description: WHEN I was a nascent gardener in the late 1960's, there was a popular book called ''How to Have a Green Thumb Without an Aching Back,'' a revolutionary work expounding mulching and other low-maintenance techniques. It was later reissued under another title; I think I know why. The original title was an obvious contradiction in terms.

title: One Life Had Many Links To Firms That Endured
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Clinton
description: The next Clinton? Say it isn't so! James Bennet's (May 30) promotion of Hillary and her possible Senate run is yet another episode of our Clinton-esque nightmare. She is the other half of our dysfunctional first couple. Many of us are hoping that, come November 2000, the Clintons will go away and stay away.

title: Play Ball! 4 Hours and 372 Pitches Later, Mets Lose
description: ''Titanic,'' the movie, seemed like a trailer compared to this.

title: An Expert in an Inexact Science
description: WITHOUT question, he's the best known weatherman in Connecticut through his long association with the oldest television station in the state -- WTNH-TV Channel 8 of New Haven -- and through a daily weather column that runs in a half-dozen papers including the state's biggest, The Hartford Courant.

title: Hangover From a Merry Month
description: As Internet stocks hit new highs two months ago, a giddy fever swept through the corridors of on-line companies nationwide. Young entrepreneurs and their venture backers holed up in cramped offices, hatching plans to go public. The market for Internet stocks was searing and, they believed then, there was no better time to sell new shares to the dot.com-hungry investors who craved them.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE MESSENGER

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: The Next Clinton
description: Washington pundits have said that Hillary Clinton, as Bill's wife, has the toughest job in America, and Chuck Close's photograph seems to prove it. We see every nook and cranny in the poor woman's face. If Mrs. Clinton's advisers selected that portrait to help her gain a sympathy vote, she has mine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-20-99; The I.P.O. Boomers
description: Maybe two years ago, a friend and former colleague who had joined an Internet start-up hinted around that there might be a place for me there if I was interested. We didn't get into details, but it would have been a relatively senior slot, probably with equity in the company.

title: The Next Clinton
description: James Bennet could find few, if any, negatives in Clinton's candidacy -- not even in her nonresident status. The tone was set in the second paragraph when he gratuitously asked if she could ''survive a street fight with a nasty opponent.'' None of us can forecast who that opponent will be, so is Bennet suggesting that the G.O.P. candidate will be, ipso facto, nasty? Not to be outdone, your photo editor ran three flattering full-page pictures. And Hillary Clinton talks about a vast right-wing conspiracy.

title: The Wedding Alert
description: WHEN Cheryl Guibone sent out nearly 200 ''Save the Date'' cards to alert her family and friends of her July wedding in Newport, R.I., she didn't expect to hear from people so quickly. ''I got so many calls from everyone telling me how much they loved the card,'' she said.

title: A Quiet Island, Sans Solitude
description: IN my little yellow kayak, under a Hubbard's Repair Shop cap, I blend into the waterscape as I search for Federal agents. They should be easy to spot, youngish men and women in dark suits, slowly steering Boston Whalers as they sweep the Shelter Island shoreline with binoculars and whisper to their wrists.

title: Coach Learned of Abilities of Disabled
description: In this production of ''The Wizard of Oz,'' the Tin Man not only sang with Dorothy as she tried to find her way home, he also pushed her down the yellow brick road in a wheelchair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, THEODORE M.
description: KAUFMAN-Theodore M. Age 83, of East Hampton, formerly of Rockville Centre, on June 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Grace (nee Miller). Loving father of Kathy Greaves, Marc Kaufman and Alice Kaufman, and the late Barbara Levitt. Also survived by six grandchildren. Memorial service to be held at a future date in New York City. Memorial donations to American Cancer, or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 would be appreciated.

title: For Only the Boldest Legs
description: Spring belonged to granny chic, but in the fall Grandpa will get his turn as Holland & Holland's English hunting socks make a new kind of fashion statement on both men and women. The long cotton and Shetland wool socks, traditionally worn with hunting breeches and Wellingtons, are being shown slouched down or pulled up over the knee with sandals and shorts by magazines like Elle and Italian Vogue. The designer Daryl K used them in her fall show. ''You can totally break tradition with them,'' said Mouchette Bell, senior fashion editor at Mademoiselle. ''They work with everything from Birkenstocks to Mary Janes.'' The exactingly crafted socks appeal to fathers, too. Michael Kennelly, executive director of Holland & Holland Sporting Weapons Ltd., on 57th Street, off Madison Avenue, said that each pair, $75 to $135, is handmade by a team of English women who call themselves the Happy Knitters. Plying a 16th-century technique that makes the socks seamless, the knitters use eight needles for each sock, which takes a full day to complete.

title: New Hangars
description: Under a plan unanimously approved by county lawmakers, hangar space for private planes may be built at Westchester County Airport. William J. Ryan, a County Legislator whose district encompasses the airport, said the $20 million project would not lead to increased airport traffic. It will provide shelter for small, noncommercial private planes, which up to now have had to park outside, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANLEY, JOHN M.
description: MANLEY-John M. Born New York City, on April 4, 1919. Died suddenly at home in La Jolla, CA, June 18, 1999. He was a loyal son of Dartmouth College, a devoted husband, a loving father, an adoring grandfather. He is survived by his wife Carla of La Jolla, CA, his daughter Ann Schlesinger, and his grandson and namesake John Lewis Schlesinger. The family asks that any donations be made to Friends of Dartmouth Football.

title: A Girl Named Maria
description: ''Once upon a time there was a girl who dreamed of being on Broadway.'' That's how the dream-come-true biography of Laura Benanti, 19, begins in the playbill of ''The Sound of Music,'' which closes tonight on Broadway.

title: Civil War Re-Enactment Has Good Safety Record
description: Your article about a gathering of Civil War re-enactors on Long Island [''A Civil (War) Action,'' May 30] quoted a former member of my group, the Company H, 119th New York Volunteer Historical Association, who disparaged its safety record. The 119th has an excellent record regarding safety issues and practices. Safety regulations and practices presently in use have been in use for more than 10 years without incident.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Great River's High-Tech Center Begins to Hum
description: THE sprawling 355,000-square-foot structure on Sunrise Highway here, once owned by Northrop Grumman and now being renovated by new owners, may look like yet another manufacturing building undergoing an upgrading, but it is far from that.

title: Kristen Tassone And Joseph Grace
description: Kristen Jennifer Tassone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald V. Tassone of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Peter Grace, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Grace of Plandome, N.Y. The Rev. Richard G. Goss performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, N.Y., with the Rev. Paul F. Doyle, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, JACK
description: KANE-Jack. Beloved husband of Blanche Feinberg Kane, devoted father of Gordon and Isobel Kane, Helen and David Samuels, loving grandfather of Jonathan and Arlene, Felice and Doug, Joanne, Pamela, Leigh and Jill, great grandfather of Amanda, Orianna and Jared. Graveside service on Sunday, 11 A.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. Family will observe Shiva at Delmonico, 502 Park Avenue, New York City, on Sunday and Monday.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: If your summer weeks away from work go beyond basking on a beach, Dick Francis at hand, or lolling alongside a mountain lake with Danielle Steel, you could learn about the Civil War or how to cook haute or basse cuisine or even study real French. Thousands of Web sites offer educational trips, and you could spend an entire three-week vacation without getting to the bottom of them. But Shaw Guides can streamline the search.

title: Martha Millard, Henry Bennett
description: Martha Wright Millard and Dr. Henry Lee Bennett are to be married this morning in a Quaker ceremony at the Summit Monthly Meeting in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, TERRY (NEE STAVISKY)
description: GROSS-Terry (nee Stavisky). Beloved wife of Joel. Cherished mother of Ruth Picker, Avrum and Benedict. Devoted sister of Martha Bernstein. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. June 8, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, DOLLY WOLFSON
description: RAISLER-Dolly Wolfson. The adored wife of Robert K. Raisler, died peacefully on June 17, at her home in New York, surrounded by her loving family. She was the daughter of the late Solomon and Nechi Wolfson of Glasgow, Scotland, beloved sister of Rose Martin and Bebe Steinberg of London, and of the late Sam Wolfson, Sir Isaac Wolfson, Charles Wolfson, Jeannie Williams, Edith Hyman, Eva Gerber, Esther Levy, and Bette Shapiro. Dolly was a loving and devoted wife, a much beloved mother and sister, doting grandmother and aunt, and loyal friend. Her love, wisdom, generosity and encouragement enriched the lives of everyone. Dolly is mourned by her cherished husband of 42 years, Robert, her children Gordon, Steven and Lynn, her grandsons, Michael, Anthony and Joe, and by Joe's fiancee, Jordana Matthews. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81 Street), on Monday June 21, 1999, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Washington's Teen-Ager Curfew to Start Soon
description: With school out for the summer, teen-agers nationwide can look forward to two months of freedom and carefree summer nights. But not here in Washington.

title: The Wavy Borderline Between Free Speech and Foul
description: WHEN Timothy Boomer fell out of his canoe into the Rifle River in Michigan last summer, he did what many men would do -- he swore a blue streak. Unlike many men, however, he was nailed for it. A family was within earshot, and Mr. Boomer, 25, a computer programmer, was charged with violating a 102-year-old state law against cursing in front of women and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POGASH, SYLVIA NAMM
description: POGASH-Sylvia Namm. Died last Saturday, June 12, at the age of 89. Born in New York City, Mrs. Pogash was a longtime resident of northern New Jersey, before moving to Palm Springs, CA. She leaves her husband, Israel M. Pogash, her daughters, Susan Pogash of Chicago and Carol Pogash of Orinda, CA, and two grandchildren, Jacob and Rachel Wood.

title: William Kahane, Elizabeth Wright
description: Elizabeth Ann Wright and William Monroe Kahane are to be married today at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin will perform the ceremony.

title: Parking Rules a Headache in Atlantic Beach
description: HE hadn't even begun his day of sun and surf at the Sunny Atlantic Beach Club, but Michael Alon was already in a sweat. The Lawrence resident had loaded chairs, food, towels, toys and his family of six into his Suburban, dropped them off safely at the oceanfront club and cruised up and down Ocean Boulevard for half an hour, looking for a spot to park.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Cheers!
description: DRINK

title: Surveying The Shifting Phone-Deal Landscape
description: INVESTORS are excused if their wires are crossed by developments in the $1 trillion telecommunications business.

title: Southern Baptists Seek More Blacks
description: In its annual conference this week, the Southern Baptist Convention avoided, for the most part, its headline-grabbing rancor of years past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Miss Schoenberger, Mr. Zimmerman
description: Chana Rebecca Schoenberger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl I. Schoenberger of Bethesda, Md., is to be married today to Gary Efrem Zimmerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Zimmerman of London, Ontario. Rabbi Avis Miller is to officiate at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington.

title: Not Too Small to Take the Cake
description: Lilliputian members of wedding parties often steal the spotlight from the bridal couple, sometimes even mimicking them in miniature. Flower girls and ring bearers like these at the Conservatory Garden, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, suggest Victorian portraits. A 1-year-old in satin, net, lace and pearls (in oval below) drew applause from visitors to the garden. Many youngsters find the lawns perfect for releasing pent-up energy -- along with shirttails and vests -- while grown-ups order themselves decorously and endlessly into photo compositions.

title: Janis Eisenberg, David Kelman
description: Janis Heather Eisenberg, a daughter of Heidi Eisenberg and Dr. Marc Eisenberg of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married today to David Sean Kelman, the son of Donna and Paul Kelman of Atlanta. Rabbi Stephen Weisman will officiate at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-20-99: Questions for Jack Maple; Trust Games
description: Q:

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; A Host Who's Silly, Passionate, Gushing and Glad
description: THE first time Tom Cruise appeared on ''The Rosie O'Donnell Show,'' after she had talked about her mad infatuation with him on the air for months, he surprised her with pink and white roses, and a kiss on the lips. As they continued to embrace, the camera zoomed in on her reaction. ''Oh, my God, I love him,'' she mouthed. When they sat down, Rosie said: ''Tom, I don't know if you've been watching the show. I got a little crush on you. Does it scare you a little bit? I fear that I may frighten your entire family.''

title: Article on Rock Scene Omitted an Important Club
description: To the Editor:

title: June 13-19; An Ailing Pope
description: John Paul II fought age, flu and fretful aides to complete an exhausting 13-day trip to Poland, his eighth there. The Pope relived the early, euphoric days of his papacy, recreating masses that electrified the country in 1979, when Communism ruled. But the Pontiff, 79, also relived his childhood, making a nostalgic and restorative visit to his birthplace, Wadowice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Russian Roulette
description: AFTER THE COLLAPSE Russia Seeks Its Place as a Great Power. By Dimitri K. Simes. 272 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Starbucks Tries to Make Friendly Entry Into Bronx
description: The Starbucks empire finally percolated into the Bronx last week when a branch opened at 314 East Fordham Road (at Kingsbridge Road). The nationwide chain that is behind this decade's coffee revival, specializing in espresso drinks and pastries with 70 stores around the city, has chartered an alliance with the Bronx Writers' Center in an effort to maintain an abiding relationship with the surrounding neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, ROBERT H.
description: KAHAN-Robert H. Died of natural causes at age 80, on June 17, 1999. Loving husband, father and grandfather.

title: Amy Stiftel and James Sedlis
description: Amy Elyse Stiftel, a daughter of Helaine and Fredrick Stiftel of Wayside, N.J., is to be married this evening to Dr. James Elihu Mark Sedlis, the son of Joanna and Gabriel Sedlis of New York. Rabbi Jacob Friedman is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Goats Chasing Nudes, And Other Visions
description: SURREALISM, generally thought of as melting watches and men in bowler hats descending from the sky, began as a literary movement. In 1924, when the writer Andre Breton published his ''Manifeste du Surrealisme,'' he didn't bother to mention visual artists until he got to the footnotes. This was troubling. Some in the movement were not certain that painting could match Breton's ''pure psychic automatism'' of verbal expression, which he described as going beyond the constraints of reason and ''beyond any aesthetic or moral preoccupation.'' After a couple of years, painting that engaged in automatism and courted dreams squeaked through the Surrealist door as well. Today the painters -- Salvador Dali, Rene Magritte, Max Ernst, Joan Miro and Yves Tanguey, among others -- are thought to have stolen the movement away and run off with the prize.

title: Finally, House Plots for Sale
description: The news in Broad Channel these days is that the crabs are big, the fish are biting and the city is finally selling off the rest of the land to the residents.

title: On the Lookout for Mildew and Pests
description: Monitor roses, lilacs, dahlias, phlox and other susceptible plants for powdery mildew. At the first sign of infection, spray plants weekly with a mixture of one tablespoon of baking soda and three tablespoons of horticultural oil to one gallon of water. Be sure to drench plants and spray undersides of leaves.

title: Goldstein-Engle Rides Clear Round
description: Margie Goldstein-Engle of Wellington, Fla., rode Hidden Creek's Alvaretto to the only clear round within the time allowed in Gladstone, N.J., to win the sixth United States Equestrian Team selection trial yesterday for the 1999 Pan American Games.

title: The Tragic Side of a 'Comic' Diva
description: HECK, she'd even play the maid to be in a show. So says the foot-weary Broadway Baby of Stephen Sondheim's wisecracking show-biz lament. As luck would have it, Cecilia Bartoli has played three shows in that great big Broadway barn they call the Metropolitan Opera. And every time, she played the maid. First came Despina in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' then Rossini's Cinderella in ''La Cenerentola'' and, finally, Mozart's Susanna on her wedding day in ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' Should we be drawing conclusions?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ROSALIND ZIEPH
description: NEWMAN-Rosalind Zieph of Boynton Beach, FL, 97, on June 15. Beloved wife of the late Gordon H. Newman, loving mother of Joanne (Paul) Crown and the late Edwin (Evaline) Newman, cherised grandmother of Nancy and Valerie Crown, Scott (Judy) Newman, and Linda (Craig) Perl. Adored great grandmother of Rosalind, Gordon, Eric, Rebecca, Adam, David and Elizabeth. She will always live on in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ROBERT A.
description: STONE-Robert A. On June 11. Beloved husband of Kazuko. Devoted father of Dorian and Gem. Painter of Vanitas. A memorial will be held on July 11 in his studio.

title: Class and Glory As Teammates
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: TWO Broadway adaptations, a story with family appeal and a clever comedy of mistaken identity await movie buffs this week.

title: Part of the Family? It Depends on the Flowers
description: THIS is about relationships. The plant kinds.

title: Helping Parents as Children Leave for College
description: WHEN Lisa Charles considers the departure of her 18-year-old daughter, Tyler Morris, for college this fall, sometimes all she can do is cry.

title: The World; Latin America's Armies Are Down But Not Out
description: THE generals who once made and deposed presidents are now so marginal a factor in Brazil's daily life that a milestone went almost unremarked this month. When President Fernando Henrique Cardoso signed a bill merging the Army, Air Force and Navy ministries into a single Ministry of Defense headed by a retired senator, Brazil became the last member of Mercosur, the South American customs union composed of former military dictatorships, to place its armed forces under full formal civilian control.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZEIGER, SAMUEL
description: ZEIGER-Samuel. Missed daily and painfully for over 53 years. My love, cherished memories and gratitude are lifelong. Your son, Dick

title: Vikki Sloviter, Justin Wheeler
description: Vikki Amanda Sloviter, the daughter of Judge Dolores K. Sloviter and Dr. Henry A. Sloviter of Philadelphia, was married last evening to Justin Powell Wheeler, a son of Paulette Kempfer of Naples, Fla., and Steven Wheeler of Westport, Mass. The bride's mother, a member of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's father.

title: The World: Where Serbia Fits; Rebuilding Is Hard Without the Keystone
description: AS the fighting raged in Kosovo, Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and other leaders cast the latest Balkan battle as a moral imperative on the order of fighting Nazism. Much less forcefully stated was another goal: creating a Europe whole and free. Then Mr. Clinton, in his speech marking the end of bombing, invited Serbia to join what he termed ''this historic journey to a peaceful, democratic and united Europe.'' But he insisted Serbia would get nothing but the most basic humanitarian aid unless its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, goes.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; New Rentals to Blend With Jersey City Brownstones
description: WORK will begin soon on turning two long-vacant blocks at the southern edge of the historic Paulus Hook section of Jersey City into a rental complex designed, with input from the city and the neighborhood, to blend in with the area's brownstones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGGEBRECHT, MICHAEL
description: EGGEBRECHT-Michael. Wonderful friend and partner. You will always be loved and remembered. I miss you so much. Joel

title: Hopes and Fears of the Class of '99
description: In Westchester, the class of '99 has many faces. Here is what some of its members had to say when interviewed by Elsa Brenner.

title: Clearcutting Suburbia
description: COMING home with my family from a walk in the woods, I stepped out of the garage and stopped, in shock. The maple trees that had screened our backyard from the one next door had disappeared.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Playing in the Neighborhood column on June 6 about a conference on Chinese-American family life misstated the size of the Chinese-American population. Using census data, Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College, estimates that some 2.3 million people in the United States -- not 10 million -- consider themselves Chinese-American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Where's the Brothel? Near the Police Station
description: The Paper Mill Playhouse. The Mall at Short Hills. Stately homes from the 1870's developed by Stewart Hartshorn, the inventor of the spring-loaded window shade.

title: Tilling the Fields of Conflict Into Middle Age
description: ONCE an avatar of youthful rebellion, the writer Hanif Kureishi is probably best known in the United States for his screenplays for two 1980's art house films, ''My Beautiful Laundrette,'' an international hit that starred Daniel Day-Lewis as a gay street punk, and ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid.'' Both were fertile collaborations with the director Stephen Frears -- bright, pop evocations of a London miles off the tourist map, a world of gay and biracial sex, squatters and drugs. Now, seated in a theater cafeteria in Hammersmith and carefully watching his year-old son, Kier, crawl toward the exit, Mr. Kureishi, at 44, is, well, the very avatar of middle-aged rebellion.

title: Miss Menton and Mr. Fenwick
description: Margery Austin Menton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Menton 3d of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Charles Cuthbert Fenwick 3d, the son of Ann D. Stewart of Reistertown, Md., and Mr. Fenwick Jr. of Butler, Md. The Rev. Lloyd Aiken performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart.

title: Cod-Eating Codger Needs a Good Dousing
description: By all appearances John McRae is just another crusty codger who, with his wife, Bridget, leads a simple life in a rundown house on the Nova Scotia coast. But it doesn't take long for the couple's new 14-year-old friend, Amanda, to sense that something is a little off.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Planning Our Population
description: To the Editor:

title: New Bloomingdale's And the Disabled
description: Regarding the article about the remodeling of Bloomingdale's [''A Face Lift for Bloomingdale's in White Plains,'' May 9], the subject has been on my mind for quite some time -- however, not for the same reasons the management of Bloomingdale's has.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLSTEIN, HARVEY L.
description: PERLSTEIN-Harvey L. Daddy dear, our 39th Father's Day without you. We love & miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

title: Roosevelt Uneasy About Charter School
description: The announcement last week that the state Board of Regents had accepted an application from Roosevelt for one of the state's first charter schools did not go over well at the troubled Roosevelt School District.

title: Education Commissioner Wrong About Regents
description: There is no reasoning with Richard P. Mills, Commissioner of the State Education Department. He is pigheaded when he keeps insisting that all students must pass five Regents exams in order to earn a high school diploma [''Regents a Barrier to Vocational Education,'' June 6].

title: A Brutal Cure
description: What struck me as I read the article was that, while Dr. Marvin Pomerantz may be a brilliant surgeon, one of the few with the skill to excise a lung, his knowledge of that other old-time TB treatment, the rest cure, is curiously deficient. Rest cure meant exactly that: patients rested, and then rested some more, for months, even years until their TB was contained. I was appalled to read that someone with active TB was permitted to play soccer and tennis!

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-20-99: Test Run; The New Bronx Bombers
description: Curious about the newest development in baseball technology -- high-tech aluminum alloy bats, some filled with pressurized gas -- I took a shining pair to the Yankee clubhouse to see what the pros would make of them. The players reacted like teen-age girls greeting the arrival of Ricky Martin. ''Wow, this is incredible,'' said Andy Pettitte, the pitcher, cradling a Louisville Slugger jet black TPX Air Attack 3 in his hands. ''Are they highly illegal?''

title: Douglas Seale, 85, British Director and Actor
description: Douglas Seale, a British producer, actor and director whose 65-year career on both sides of the Atlantic brought him to the stage, films and television, died last Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan..

title: River Guardians Discuss Setbacks
description: Billy Joel took the helm of his new 65-foot-long boat, the Redhead, and with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at his side in the pilot's seat, led 50 environmentalists who keep watch on the nation's waterways on a tour of Peconic Bay.

title: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
description: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses.

title: Ellen Scott and William Presutti
description: Ellen Joan Scott, the daughter of Grete Garheim Scott of Brielle, N.J., and Walter G. Scott of Far Hills, N.J., was married on June 12 to William Louis Presutti, a son of Donna J. Sweet of Cuba, N.Y., and Joseph A. Presutti of Salisbury, N.C. The Rev. Kevin Gugliotta performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Miss Marcantonio And Mr. Reynal
description: Amanda Nancy Marcantonio, a daughter of Nancy Marcantonio of Southport, Conn., and the late Robert A. Marcantonio, was married yesterday to Michael Louis Reynal, a son of Carmen and Eric Reynal of Upper Slaughter, England. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: Sacrificial Murals
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Wheeler, Mr. Krasemann
description: Elizabeth Findley Wheeler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walton M. Wheeler 3d of Woolwich, Me., was married yesterday to Volker Krasemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horst Krasemann of Greifswald, Germany. The Rev. Richard Hall performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Wiscasset, Me.

title: Uncertainty Persists on U.S.-Moscow Dialogue
description: When the Clinton Administration invited Russia to help it out of the war in Kosovo, the idea was that the involvement in big game diplomacy would help maintain Washington-Moscow ties, and even improve the ailing relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKAS, GERDA
description: BARKAS-Gerda. 76, of Midlothian, formerly of West Palm Beach, FL and Branford, CT, died Monday, June 14, 1999. She was the widow of Emanuel Barkas. She is surviveb by her children Alex Barkas and his wife Lynda, Stella Royce and her husband Dan, Peter Barkas and his wife Jodi; her sister Inge Adam and sister-in-law Ruth Brandvain; five grandchildren Daniel, Jacqueline, Carolyn, Galia and Alizah. Services will be held at 11 A.M., Monday at the Bliley Funeral Home. Interment in Greenwood Memorial Gardens, Richmond, Virginia.

title: Cynthia Cox, Peter Roman
description: Cynthia Anne Cox and Dr. Peter J. Roman were married on Friday by the Rev. Sean Hogan at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in West Harwich, Mass.

title: There Goes the Island?
description: The battle among the millionaires who live on Fisher Island -- home to various retired chief executives, the financier Bennett S. LeBow, Oprah Winfrey and Mel Brooks -- continues over condomium development on this exclusive redoubt a short ferry ride from Miami Beach.

title: Does It Take a Manager To Raise a Child?
description: LEARNED to be a father the hard way. A year after my first child, Marian, was born, my wife got a job offer she couldn't refuse. But the job was 1,000 miles away.

title: Supermarket Out, Duane Reade In on the Upper East Side
description: For years, York Avenue from 86th Street down to Sutton Place has had just two supermarkets, D'Agostino and Food Emporium, which happen to be directly across the street from each other on the block between 79th and 80th Streets.

title: Secretive Colombian Courts Survive Protests Over Rights
description: For a decade, terrorism and drug trafficking cases in Colombia have routinely been sent to special tribunals that allow judges, prosecutors and witnesses to remain anonymous.

title: REBELS IN KOSOVO AGREE TO DISBAND, NATO OFFICERS SAY
description: With the last Yugoslav forces streaming out of Kosovo ahead of schedule, NATO commanders here have reached a tentative agreement with leaders of the Kosovo Liberation Army to disband the rebel force gradually, NATO officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETCHAM, F. ROGERS
