title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSEL, MELVYN B., M.D.
description: AMSEL-Melvyn B., M.D. We, The Board of Trustees, and Staff of Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center, and The Members of The Department of Surgery are saddened by the death of Dr. Melvyn Amsel, a long-time member of our Surgical Attending Staff. Dr. Amsel joined The Hospital in 1962 and retired in 1992. His major interests and commitment was to teaching surgical residents and medical students. He was Associate Director of The Surgical Residency Training Program, Chief of The Breast Surgical Service, and Assistant Professor of Surgery at The Albert Einstein College of Medicine. His outstanding academic and clinical contributions are a legacy to his professional career. We extend our condolences to his wife, Patricia; son, Scott; daughters, Sheri Laurel and Beth. Miguel O. Martinez, Chairman, Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes, President and Chief Executive Officer Milton Gumbs, M.D. Vice President Medical Affairs/Medical Director Paul H. Gerst, M.D., F.A.C.S. Director of Surgery

title: Mr. Wrong
description: THE LADIES' MAN

title: Two Katonah Shows About Photography
description: CARAMOOR, a Mediterranean-style palazzo completed in 1939, is one of Westchester's most unusual buildings. Lucie Bigelow Rosen and Walter Tower Rosen had the house built for them here as a summer home to house a significant collection of transplanted period rooms from a diverse selection of European palaces and villas. Besides their collection of antiquities, the Rosens also acquired works by artists from their time. A portion of the photographic work of one such artist, Arnold Genthe, is currently on display at the House Museum.

title: A Place They'd Never Been: the Theater
description: AS far as I'm concerned, every New Yorker is born with the inalienable right to ride the D train, shout ''Hey, lady!'' with indignation and grow up going regularly to the theater. After all, if a city is fortunate enough to house an entire theater district, shouldn't access to the stage life within it be what makes coming of age in New York different from any other American city?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Editorial Observer; Shuffling Through the Star Wars
description: White Americans make up about 80 percent of the population today. But people who identify themselves as ''white'' are a steadily shrinking majority, losing ground to Americans of Latin, Asian and African descent. The inevitable ''browning'' of America is happening fastest among school-aged children, where nonwhites will become the majority by the year 2050.

title: Disney Raises Prices; Other Parks Follow
description: For the second year in a row, Walt Disney World has raised the price of admission to its Florida theme parks. And once again, Universal Studios and Sea World are keeping up with the neighbors.

title: The Nation; Beyond the Trail Of Breadcrumbs
description: IN an unusual case that unfolded in Worcester, Mass., last week, a reputed mobster by the name of Vincent (Gigi Portalla) Marino went to court to find out whether the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration had secretly implanted a microchip tracking device in his body two and a half years ago during surgery to remove a bullet from his buttocks.

title: Digging History in New Mexico
description: WHEN the arbiters of urban refugee chic decide that a small Western town is the newest place for harmonically converging one's oneness, it is generally not a pretty sight. Barrios become Espressoland. Real estate becomes religion. Cowboys sing the blues.

title: Bush: 'Leave No One Out' As Nation Prospers
description: Following are excerpts from remarks made in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on June 12, when he announced his plans to run for the Republican Presidential nomination, provided by the Bush campaign:

description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Our Towns; Last Resort, And Roundup, For the Geese
description: THEY are to the suburbs what pigeons are to the city, only bigger, meaner, hungrier and dirtier. They are Canada geese, and here in Putnam County, the turf war between folk and fowl is about to get down to the pinfeathers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Just How Minor Should a Minor League Baseball Club Be?
description: Brooklyn started to look a little ungrateful to City Hall last Monday, when the city began the long process of public approval for a new Coney Island minor league stadium.

title: Sports of The Times; A Course With a Different Finish
description: AFTER Lee Janzen trudged off the 18th green with a 76 for a 13-over-par total of 223, he put Pinehurst No. 2 in perspective as well as on a pedestal.

title: Mr. DeLay's Power Play
description: That was one embarrassing week for Dennis Hastert. When the House blocked tough gun control legislation and then could not muster the votes for the pathetically weak measure that was left, the Speaker was nowhere to be found. It was bad enough to have to explain why his promise of ''common sense'' gun control legislation flamed out as the House surrendered to the gun lobby. Had he appeared in public, he also would have had to explain why he surrendered control of the House to Tom DeLay. George W. Bush and others, take note. Mr. DeLay -- fund-raiser, friend of lobbyists and nasty culture warrior -- has become the main voice of the G.O.P. in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD W.
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard W. 5/1/'28-8/1/'94. Happy Fathers Day to the most special Popa in all of our lives. We miss you and love you always and forever. Your children and grand children

title: The View From/Orange; For 42 Years, a Taste for Ice Cream Keeps Bringing a Town Together
description: EVERY town seems to have a place where people gather, a place that goes back generations and has become such a part of the community that no one could imagine it never being there.

title: Master of Motion and Emotion
description: WHATEVER the summer movies may bring, it is a safe bet that the most ravishing, romantic images onscreen this season will be at the Max Ophuls retrospective, starting on Friday and running through July 15 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center's Walter Reade Theater. This virtually complete selection of 21 Ophuls films, with many rarities and new prints, will be catnip for film buffs, who regard the divine Max as their patron saint -- perhaps because no other director in the history of movies wrung so much emotional resonance from cinematic technique. ''His camera could pass through walls,'' said Stanley Kubrick, referring to Ophuls's penchant for movement. The French New Wave, especially Francois Truffaut, regarded him as their auteur role model, because he had managed to impose a personal style in the face of producer pressures. A bon vivant who was subject to fits of depression, Ophuls dramatized the will to pleasure and its attendant humiliations.

title: Past Knicks Praise and Criticize
description: He was home in New Jersey, in more or less 3-point range from Manhattan, after recently having undergone back surgery, and so could hardly have been in the Knicks' lineup. Then again, he hasn't been in a Knicks' lineup since he retired from basketball 19 years ago, in 1980. But the memories of having been a part of a championship Knick team for Earl (the Pearl) Monroe, as well as for his teammates, remain vivid, and have been rekindled with the appearance of the current Knick team in the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Surfing On the Slippery Skin Of a Bubble
description: For a homeless shelter's annual charity auction not long ago, Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist, donated a breakfast with himself not long ago at Buck's Restaurant. Buck's is a bustling diner in Woodside, Calif., a single-intersection hamlet nestled into an oak grove at the base of the San Mateo County foothills. The booths at Buck's are upholstered in ocher Naugahyde and the menus have the feel of political-action newsletters and the owners are mighty proud of their coffeecake. Buck's also happens to be the place where Netscape and many other high-tech companies were hatched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Europe, Without America to Lean On
description: First we had a ''virtual war''; now come the instant lessons. Commentators and politicians have been tumbling over themselves to draw far-reaching conclusions from Kosovo. ''We'' won a famous victory. Bombing works. Germany is back in the saddle, led by ''War Chancellor'' Gerhard Schroder. It is a new beginning for NATO. Europe will emerge with a united military posture. The Western alliance will be radically rethought. It is the end of NATO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSMER, CHARLES J.
description: OSMER-Charles J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles J. Osmer, associated with The Times from 1967 until retiring in 1976.

title: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
description: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses.

title: Apres le Deluge
description: NOAH'S FLOOD

title: Lights Dim for Dance Studios
description: Two by two, the 30 women in Carolyn Webb's Afro-Haitian dance class jumped and shimmied across the floor while drummers pounded out seductive rhythms. But they won't be shimmying and drumming much longer, at least not at the Dance Space studio that has been on Broadway near Houston Street for 15 years.

title: Balkan Integration
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Who Imparts A Lens-Eye View

title: Greenspan Furthers Unemployment Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Call It the Big Uneasy: Rents Threaten Cajun Spot
description: After dishing out Cajun cooking and live music for eight years, the Louisiana Community Bar and Grill is likely to fall victim to lower Broadway's rising rents on July 31. Facing an increase to about $50,000 a month from $12,000, Marc Campbell, the general manager since its opening, said he was looking for a new site and ''unless something unusual happens, we will be out.''

title: Word for Word/Washington Guidebooks; Some Tips on Surviving an Internship Without a Grant of Immunity
description: IT'S been a year and a half since the word ''intern'' became a punchline, time enough, perhaps, to purge the national consciousness of tiresome jokes about fringe benefits and dry cleaning. And time enough for interns to resume their rightful place at the bottom of the office food chain, no matter how they got their jobs or how much money their parents gave the campaign.

title: A World's Fair On Madison Ave.
description: MORE than 100 cultures will coexist peacefully on Madison Avenue today as the International Cultures Expo-Fest and Celebration presents performances, informational booths, food, music, costumes and dancing.

title: Starr Brown, Stephen Sears
description: Starr de Forest Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Noel Brown Jr. of Bethesda, Md., and Stephen Truxtun Sears, a son of Sally Hale Taggart of Blue Hill, Me., and the late F. Fulton Sears, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Ohmer performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Leesburg, Va., with the Rev. William Hale, a retired Episcopal priest who is a cousin of the bridegroom, taking part.

title: Zvereva Rallies
description: Natasha Zvereva lost the first nine games before scoring an 0-6, 7-5, 6-3 victory over Nathalie Tauziat yesterday to win the Eastbourne grasscourt championship in England.

title: A Perfect Madness of Plants
description: The architecture of Dan Hinkley's garden on the Kitsap Peninsula in Washington State is native, shaped by old Douglas firs and a seeping bog. But in the cultivated understory, he has convened plants from all around the globe, reuniting the tribes of the botanical diaspora. More than 50 kinds of arisaemas -- called jack-in-the-pulpit in North America -- rocket from the soil, and one, Arisaema nepenthoides, stands fully erect, a single cobralike spathe beside a rotting stump crowned with ferns. Thirty-five varieties of Solomon's seals, or polygonatums, from China, Japan, Taiwan, Nepal and Sikkim unspiral from their early growth, and dozens of types of hellebore have just passed their prime. Throughout the garden, hydrangeas and viburnums are beginning to dispense their leaves; Stachyurus and Edgeworthia, winter-flowering shrubs from Asia, are leafing out. On some loops of the garden trail, where a Cardiocrinum giganteum thrusts its antediluvian seedpod six feet into the air, you almost expect to see a dinosaur wander past. Bud-break has stirred among an orderly chaos of growth-forms.

title: June 13-19; Hold That Coke
description: In the biggest recall in Coke history, four European countries ordered Coca-Cola products off store shelves after dozens of people in Belgium fell ill after drinking Coke. By Friday, despite an apology from Coca-Cola's chairman and an explanation that the problem originated at two European bottling plants, a ban on Coke, Sprite and Fanta remained in Belgium and Luxembourg. The Netherlands banned products handled in Belgium, and France demanded a recall of beverages from a plant in Dunkirk blamed for some of the incidents.

description: CLOONAN-Margaret M. On June 18, 1999, at age 91. Beloved twin sister of the late Catherine and sister of the late Mary and Martin. Friends may call at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Epiphany R.C. Church, 2nd Ave. at 22 St., Monday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Bob Briner, 63, Innovator in Tennis and Television
description: Bob Briner, a pioneer professional tennis administrator and later a television sports executive, died Friday night in his home in Greenville, Ill. He was 63.

title: Senator Dodd Marries Bank Executive
description: United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat of Connecticut, was married last night at his home in East Haddam to Jackie Marie Clegg, the vice chairwoman and chief operating officer of the Export-Import Bank of the United States.

title: Summer Flower Shows Multiply in England
description: Two new flower shows have been added to the British horticultural calendar, one in London, the other in Cheshire in northern England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LA SALA, ANDREW J., SR.
description: La SALA-Andrew J., Sr. On June 18, 1999. Beloved father of Stephen H. A. La Sala, Mary Louise Verni, Paula Alice LeFebvre and Andrew J. La Sala, Jr. Dear brother of Frank, Anthony and A. Stephen La Sala and dear grandfather of 11 grandchildren and great-grandfather of 15 great-grandchildren. Formerly of Bronxville, NY, Mr. La Sala was a mason contractor and owner/developer for the La Sala Contracting Corp., of which he was Partner and Secretary from 1935 to the present. He was a member of the Westchester Country Club, the New York Athletic Club, Columbus Citizen's Committee, Associated Brick Masonry Contractors of Greater New York, and a member of the Bricklayers and Allied Crafts Local 41. He was a proud recipient of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity Construction Man of the Year Award. He was an avid lover of opera and a former semi-pro baseball player. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. John the Baptist Church. Entombment at Woodlaw Cemetery. The family will be present Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Paul Verni Memorial Fund, Iona Preparatory, 255 Wilmot Rd, New Rochelle, NY 10804, are prefferred by the family.

title: Sampras Back on Firm Grass Again
description: The ritual gets more momentous every year. Each June, Pete Sampras makes a private pilgrimage to Center Court, the famed swatch of lawn that shines, on sunny days, like a square-cut emerald and will, after a two-week trampling, come to resemble a dust bowl. He pays his respects and prays that it will be his sneakers, seven rounds hence, that grind Wimbledon's best-loved lawn into oblivion.

title: A Philadelphia Star May Shoot Higher
description: After decades of being mired in urban doldrums, Philadelphia has resurged and prospered under the guiding hand of Mayor Edward G. Rendell. He is now ranked among the nation's best city leaders, one seemingly with a bright political future should he choose to shoot for higher office after he completes his present City Hall tour this year.

title: Taking Your Own Sweet Time to Pick Berries
description: IT'S a 90-degree day, the kind that sends people indoors seeking shade and a cool blast of air-conditioning. But not Don Brinker. His head topped with a straw hat with green visor, he works on his knees, plucking ripe strawberries from a patch in Warren County. For Mr. Brinker, a retired risk manager from Phillipsburg, berry-picking is a ritual performed four or five times year.

description: Once again, fashion flirts with Camelot.

Just 45 miles from New York City in Sussex County, it has sparkling clean air, nearly half its homes still use well water and many of its roads are fringed by woods and forests.

title: A Sport's Credibility Takes Another Hit
description: In 1983, Robert W. Lee Sr. quietly formed the International Boxing Federation. If the announcement lacked both drama and publicity, Lee did not lack for ambition: the I.B.F., he pledged, would be built from scratch with the idea that it would objectively rank the world's top fighters and create its own set of legitimate championship titles.

title: Not Just the Movie Anymore
description: FOR 20 years home video has thrived on a simple process: choose a movie, watch it, engage in some thought and discussion, move on. (What else do most people do with a movie?) Now, though, operating on the principle that nothing gets simpler, along comes the digital video disk (DVD) to immerse one in films to a degree that will intrigue some and repel others.

title: A No-Frills Guy Who's Beyond His Years
description: On most road trips, Tim Duncan packs the toys of choice for the Y2K pro athlete: a DVD movie player and a Sony PlayStation. He likes current cinema and mindless video games, often killing time on the team plane with the young reserve point guard Antonio Daniels.

title: In Chicago, Three Lakefront Museum Projects

title: G.E. Dispute Settled

title: June 13-19; G.M. and Ken Burns
description: That Ken Burns would continue to make well-received documentaries seems a safe bet. Still, General Motors took an unusual flier on Mr. Burns when it committed to 10 years of underwriting 35 percent of his future projects, sight unseen. G.M. has been the sole corporate underwriter for ''The Civil War,'' ''Baseball'' and Mr. Burns's newest, ''Not for Ourselves Alone: The Story of Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony,'' to be seen on PBS in November. Now Mr. Burns, and many freelancers who work with him, have some security and the luxury to explore projects in advance. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Safety in Turkey
description: To the Editor: With respect to the Correspondent's Report on Turkey: My wife and I and a group of 14 others recently returned from a three-week land and sea tour of Turkey and Greece. While in Turkey never once did we feel threatened, uncomfortable in our surroundings, or in any type of danger. We were made to feel at home everywhere.

Such is the case at the Stamford Art and Nature Center with the painting retrospective of Alberta Cifolelli spanning the last 50 years.

The Torah scroll, which contains the first five books of the Bible, is as revered as an object can be in Judaism -- carried with honor, dressed in the best finery a synagogue can muster, housed in a special ark beneath an eternal flame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANICK, PAUL M
description: CANICK-Paul M. Died June 16, 1999 in Norristown, PA from complications from diabetes. A native New Yorker, Paul served the city as Assistant Fire Commissioner from 1968 to 1971. Deputy Police Commissioner for Adminstration from 1971 to 1974, and New York City's first Deputy Commissioner of Finance from 1980 to 1986. He leaves three children, Thomas Canick, Jon Munroe and Julia Martin; three grandchildren, Max, Benjamin and Hannah; a brother Dr. Jacob Canick and a sister Pearl Solomon. He leaves too, a beloved fiancee, Virginia Jacqueline (Jackie) Reardon, who gave him life during his courageous battle with death. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Corrections

Only one aircraft was a jet -- the DC-8 that fell in Park Slope. The other was a Super Constellation, a propeller plane.

title: The Horrors of Kosovo
description: During the NATO bombing of Kosovo, when Serbia controlled reporters' access to the region, journalists could document atrocities only by interviewing the ethnic Albanians who had fled to refugee camps. News reports of their accounts usually carried the words ''could not be independently confirmed.'' They can be now. Journalists have fanned out through Kosovo, and the confirmation is horrifying. Ethnic Albanians offer reporters crumpled lists of the dead and lead them to burned mosques, the remains of bodies and fresh graves dug by friends and family to bury the victims.

title: Taxing Web Wallets
description: Last month, 14 million Americans bought something on the Internet. Taking advantage of what might be the last tax loophole, 99 percent of them did not pay sales tax. Without knowing it, most broke the law. States cannot force out-of-state sellers to collect sales taxes, but 45 require buyers to pay the tax anyway. Compliance is virtually nil. Today, a Congressional commission on electronic commerce takes up two key questions: How do we tax the Internet? Should we?

title: A Reclusive Rock Legend Returns, Nostalgic and Unbowed
description: ''Oooh-whoo.'' ''Wah-do-day.'' ''Diddit-dit-dum-de-doo-wah.'' ''Bow-bow-bow-b-b-b-bow.'' Those syllables meant a lot to Brian Wilson when he was composing songs for the Beach Boys. They were the sound of vocal harmonies, companionship turned into discipline and beauty. And Mr. Wilson used them to make complex chords metamorphose behind simple love songs or confessions of unbearable loneliness. With lapidary, compulsive craftsmanship, Mr. Wilson packed ideas into his three-minute songs: harmonies, orchestral arrangements, song forms that concealed improbable fantasias behind their hooks. His songs were revived in all their elaborate restlessness when Mr. Wilson appeared at the Beacon Theater on Friday night as part of his first tour without the Beach Boys.

title: Get the Lead Dust Out
description: Millions of gallons of lead paint brightened the nation's walls before lead was banned from paint almost 20 years ago nationally and almost 40 years ago in New York City. The bans were part of a national effort to end lead poisoning in children who ingest the dust when the old paint crumbles and a sticky leaden residue settles onto whatever is underneath. Even in small amounts, lead can cause permanent brain damage in younger children. Under court order to enforce or revise the city's lead abatement law by June 30, the New York City Council needs to address the issue of lead dust in housing as a continuing health hazard for young children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.
