description: LAMBERT-Evelyn. 81, died June 9, 1999, in Ojai, CA. Formerly of Eastchester, NY, Mrs. Lambert moved to Ojai in 1980. Former coowner/director of Kezar Lake Camp, in Maine. A world traveler, and active community volunteer, Mrs. Lambert is remembered with love by her sons Jonathan and Howard, four grandchildren and brother Howard Lewis.

title: New York Officials Start Scrambling for New Jobs as Term Limits Loom
description: It will be two more years until the vast majority of New York City's politicians will be forced out of their jobs by limits on how long they can stay in any one office. But the city's political landscape is already astir with the rustling of politicians making plans to keep their careers alive.

title: Media Talk; The Agony of a Disappointing Book Deal
description: In the summer of 1996, Joe McGinniss turned his back on a $1 million advance for a book on O. J. Simpson, parted with his longtime literary agent and headed for a remote Italian village, Castel di Sangro, to pursue his passion for soccer and an eight-page proposal for a quirky book about a quixotic local team.

title: Compressed Data; 'Techies Day' Is Aiming To Clear Up a Misconception
description: With the demand for technology workers expected to double in the next four years, and with the supply of such workers chronically low, the Education Department and several commercial partners are planning this week to declare Oct. 5 as National Techies Day. A Web site is already in place (www.techiesday.com).

title: From Siberia to Israeli Cabinet (No, He's Not Sharansky)
description: Yuli Edelstein is probably the only member of the Israeli Cabinet, much less the only one in a yarmulke, whose father is a Russian Orthodox priest.

title: Sports of The Times; The Longest Final Putt to Win the Open
description: ON the 18th green that was as hard as Payne Stewart's determination, the putt was 15 feet long, slightly uphill, with a slight break to the right.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Fatally Shot in His Car in a Dispute Over Parking
description: A 32-year-old man was shot dead behind the wheel of his car in Brooklyn early yesterday after what the police called a minor dispute over double parking.

title: Road, Sweet Road: Spurs Are Unfazed by the Garden
description: First, the good news for the Knicks entering Game 3: they're at home.

title: People
description: Rick Bonsall was named to the new position of management director for integrated communications at J. Walter Thompson New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C. He had been senior managing director at a WPP sibling, Hill & Knowlton, New York.

title: Milosevic Urges Serbs to Go Back to Kosovo
description: Hundreds of Serbs who had fled Kosovo, fearing vengeance from the Kosovo Liberation Army rebels, responded today to appeals from the Yugoslav Government to return to the province and to trust the security provided by NATO-led forces.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks S O S: Make Camby a Starter
description: ONCE again, the Knicks find themselves behind the eight ball. A pair of double-digit losses to San Antonio in the championship series has put the Knicks down by two games to none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GERTRUDE
description: PARKER-Gertrude, of Verona, NJ, died June 18, 1999 at the age of 79. Beloved mother of Patricia and Alan B. Abramson, Barbara Parker, and Bruce and Charlene Parker. Adored grandmother of Adam and Joshua Abramson and the late Jonathan Parker Abramson. Cherished wife of the late Abel Parker and the late Ben Spindel. Our world is greatly diminished and we will miss her dearly. Graveside services were held on Sunday, June 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
description: As 16,100 NATO troops rolled into Kosovo last week, 2,700 journalists signed up to follow them. Most of those journalists had been forced to watch the 78 days of bombing through the lenses of official video cameras and wanted to see things for themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITELBAUM, LEWIS N.
description: TEITELBAUM-Lewis N. Age 60, suddenly on June 18, 1999. Beloved husband to Sooky, adoring father to Joshua and Noah, devoted son to Sylvia, loving son-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Handsome, funny, spirited and irreplaceable. Our hearts are broken. For funeral information call 718377-2700. Shiva at residence, 1435 E. 18th St, Brooklyn.

title: Segregation Fight Was a Team Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: For Fathers, a Day to Relish Their Role
description: Jesus Papoleto Melendez, sometimes known as the poet laureate of El Barrio, stood in the placid green of a recently renovated community garden in East Harlem yesterday and explained that his son would not be able to attend this Father's Day poetry reading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAWRENCE
description: STONE - Lawrence. Professor Stone was an inspired and inspiring teacher and mentor. He will be missed. Our sincere condolences to his family on their loss. Miriam and Paul Slater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHOLTZ, LESTER, DR.
description: STEINHOLTZ-Lester, Dr. Died at his home in DeWitt, NY. He was born July 31, 1922, in New York City where he graduated from City College and NYU's College of Dentistry. His contributions over the years to the professions of oral surgery and dentistry as clinician, professor, mentor of young dentists, thinker and writer were numerous. He became Chief of the Division of Dentistry, Department of Surgery at SUNY in Syracuse and later Professor Emeritus in 1996 when he retired. He will be greatly missed by Eleanor, his wife of 53 years; as well as his daughter Ruth.

title: War-Crimes Experts Comb First Site on List
description: Dressed in masks and white coveralls, forensics experts with the international war crimes tribunal are collecting evidence in a house here where the bodies of perhaps three dozen Kosovo Albanians lie in charred heaps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Media; Summer Air, Thick With TV Updates
description: As surely as summer brings visions of beaches and barbecue grills, it brings reruns to broadcast television. And by making a big promotional fuss about their shows' season finales in May, the networks basically close up shop and tell viewers, ''See you in September.''

title: The Mind-Body Problem in an E-Mail Love Affair
description: THE METAPHYSICAL TOUCH

title: The Last Man Standing
description: With one last courageous putt, Payne Stewart won the United States Open, climaxed a day of high drama and created the signature moment of his career.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Future Bleak for Bill to Keep Health Records Confidential
description: Legislation to protect the privacy of medical records is dying under pressure from insurance companies, health care businesses, law-enforcement officials and others lobbying Congress to preserve their access to sensitive information on patients.

title: Potential Rival Remains Wary of Microsoft's Power
description: As Stephen M. Case, chief executive of America Online, contemplated making the biggest deal of his career -- the purchase of Netscape Communications -- he stopped for a moment last fall to ponder whether his company could finally afford to dump Microsoft.

title: Two Top Executives Join Pickett and TBWA
description: Top executives are joining two agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Tom DeLay Holds No Gavel, But a Firm Grip on the Reins
description: Representative Tom DeLay of Texas swears it's only the force of his personality that has everyone in Washington convinced -- mistakenly, of course -- that he's the guy running the House of Representatives while Speaker J. Dennis Hastert sends out for sandwiches.

title: Trying to Find Way, Yankees Get No Help
description: The Yankees have lost their compass, the magnetism that steered them safely through the crossroads that appear in every game. They have been a team that gets the big outs, but yesterday, there was David Cone making a costly pitch. They have been a team that gets big hits, as if they were blessed with a special power, but a botched umpire's call left them feeling fated.

title: Reform Urged as Condition For Yugoslavia to Get Aid
description: Leaders of the seven wealthiest nations and Russia outlined a plan today for ending eight years of war in the Balkans through a vast program of aid and political support, but said Yugoslavia must undertake ''democratic and economic reforms'' to take part.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Telecommunications Deals Confusing Many Investors

title: Why Are We So Eager to Make Up With China?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 26 about public relations support for the merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler gave an incorrect surname at one point for the manager of Golin/Harris International, a firm with partners who hold doctorates in history, economics, accounting, marketing and law. He is Richard J. Wolff, not Harris.

title: A Colombian Rebel Group Gains Notice, Loses Sympathy
description: The military muscle of the National Liberation Army has been weakened by a series of reverses on the battlefield, and the Government is ignoring its demands for peace talks. But the guerrilla group, Colombia's second-largest, has managed to thrust itself back into the center of national attention through a wave of kidnappings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, HARRIET V.
description: FALK-Harriet V. 77, of Fort Lauderdale, FL, and New York City, passed away after a courageous battle with cancer. Harriet was a longtime member of N.C.J.W., an active and a supportive member of the Fort Lauderdale Museum of Art, and a member of the Emerald Hills Country Club. She was philanthropic for many organizations. She was blessed with many dear friends from all over the world, and will be remembered for her wonderful sense of humor. Beloved wife of the late Morton Falk. Devoted mother of Jeffrey Falk, John Falk, and Helene (Alan) Leibowitz. Caring grandmother of David (Mayumi) Leibowitz, Sandy (Glenn) Rodney. Devoted sister of Helen Dubrow and Cecil Volk. Interment to be held Monday at 1 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY.

title: The Stars' Crown Arrives With a Footnote Attached
description: By delicious coincidence, the National Hockey League's board of governors will meet today in New York to discuss, among other things, the use of videotape replays to determine if goals should be nullified when an attacking player precedes the puck into the crease. The board could revoke a three-year-old procedure that has provoked a discordant debate, one that reached a boil over the weekend with a controversial conclusion to the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ALFRED, M.D.
description: BERMAN-Alfred, M.D. FACS. 88 years of age, of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Bernice for 53 years. Father of Steven and Wendy Berman of Vermont; Michael and Rachel Berman, and Peter and Jean Berman of New York. He was a devoted family man who took pride in his grandchildren, Megan, Travis and Josh, Ava and Eric, and Jason and Matthew. Dr. Berman was combat surgeon during WW II, and during his career served as Chief of Surgery at Flushing and Booth Memorial Hospitals. His life will be celebrated in remembering how he used his gifts and compassion to ease the suffering of others and save many lives. He will be remembered for his dedication to his golf game, his love of the New York Yankees, and for his great sense of humor. Chapel service Mt. Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY 11365, at 10:30 AM today. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: INSIDE
description: In Queens, Matadors Needed

title: From Echoes Emerge Original Voices
description: Recently I've been preparing a course for the fall semester, ''Strategies in Prose.'' My writing students, a cohort of fiction writers in the M.F.A. program at the University of Michigan, will read modern masterworks like ''The Good Soldier,'' ''To the Lighthouse,'' ''As I Lay Dying,'' ''A Farewell to Arms'' and ''Ulysses.'' As readers we will focus on aspects of technique, and the strategy for written assignments is that of emulation, the close copy and pastiche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Childs Has Misery and Company
description: For Chris Childs, there have been tougher championship situations than the predicament he and the Knicks find themselves in now: down two games to none to the San Antonio Spurs, in no small measure because of his offensive troubles. But Childs delivered an explanation yesterday for the optimism the Knicks still cling to.

title: Portuguese Bank Raises Its Offer for Insurer
description: Banco Comercial Portugues S.A. is offering about 2.42 billion euros, or $2.52 billion, a 79 percent premium to the current price, in its unsolicited bid for the insurer Companhia de Seguros Mundial Confianca S.A., hoping to thwart a rival offer by Spain's biggest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano S.A.

title: Gabbing on the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressman From Littleton Explains Vote for Gun Control
description: Tom Tancredo, a Republican with a libertarian streak, was elected to Congress last fall with donations that included $9,900 from the National Rifle Association, the group's largest contribution to a Colorado representative.

title: Splashy Conference Belies Stormy Outlook for PC Profits
description: As PC Expo gets under way this week at the Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, the show's organizers are sounding a theme of ''smarter, faster, cheaper'' and highlighting the trend toward powerful, portable devices that combine computing and telephony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: His Inexperience Is Still Showing Although Grant Wins Easily
description: After his bout with Michael Grant on Saturday night, Lou Savarese walked out of Madison Square Garden with two friends, and in true New York fashion, hailed a cab to the hospital to have his face stitched back together.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Woman Falls To Her Death From a Hotel In Manhattan
description: A guest at the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South flung jewelry and $38,000 in cash into the alley below her 29th-floor hotel room yesterday afternoon and then fell backward to her death from a window ledge, the police said.

title: Why Students Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; Drive-In Offers Cabbage and Promises of Popcorn
description: It is true that the men behind the first and only drive-in movie in Russia overlooked a few things, such as telling the audience that films are best viewed with headlights off. Also, popcorn. Somehow, a drive-in isn't quite the same munching on cabbage pie.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Liberty's Second Half Is Payback to Detroit Last Year
description: The banner in the New York Liberty locker room read: ''Aug. 19, 1999, Detroit 82, New York 68, Season Completed No Playoffs.'' That was then. Yesterday was different. In case the Liberty didn't get it, the banner let them know what was at stake: ''June 20, 1999, Detroit 3-1, New York, 3-1, First-place tie in Eastern Conference.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEIRO, PIETRO (LEE), JR.
description: DEIRO-Pietro (Lee), Jr. On June 19, 1999, at age 85. Founder of Pietro Deiro Publications. He pioneered and convinced popular songwriters to compose easy arrangements for the accordion. He was responsible for the development of the accordionist Tops in Pops, as well as composing and publishing accordion music himself. He was the President of the American Accordionist Association. Beloved husband of the late Ines Deiro. Loving father of Sandra L. Cattani and the late Peter Deiro. Devoted grandfather of Andrea, Christopher and Jessica. Dear brother of Blanche Pancotti. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, June 21, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 St., Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Peter Deiro Scholarship Fund at the Rice Catholic School.

title: Tobacco's Imprimatur Is Less Bold, but Still on Cultural Events
description: As part of the $206 billion agreement reached last year between tobacco producers and 46 states, cigarette companies agreed to sharply curtail the sponsorships of entertainment and sports events that they have traditionally used to spread the names and cachet of their brands.

title: Depardieu Revels Lustily in Revenge and Derring-Do as the Count of Monte Cristo
description: In the first of the many disguises adopted by the hero of ''The Count of Monte Cristo,'' Edmond Dantes pretends to be a corpse. Unjustly imprisoned for 20 years, Dantes sees a chance to escape by changing places with a kindly old priest who has died. When one of the guards hauling the body in a sack says, ''He's very heavy for an old man who was just skin and bones,'' we know why. Dantes is played by Gerard Depardieu, whose larger-than-life presence is just right for this enjoyably fluffy extravaganza.

title: Mall Builder Sees New Brooklyn, but Neighbors See Trouble
description: On a barren plot in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce Ratner plans to build a 400,000-square-foot mall that will resemble Ebbets Field, from the outside at least. Inside will be a complex full of suburban-style superstores and a movie multiplex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSBY, RUTH M.
description: GOLDSBY-Ruth M. of Wyomifsing, PA, and formerly of Chappaqua, NY. Died on June 19, 1999 of congestive heart failure at age 90. Survived by her husband for 65 years, Dr. A.R. Goldsby, and daughter, Jan Myers. Donations in her memory may be made to the The Chappaqua or Wyomifsing Public Library.

title: Crowd, On and Off Field, Forced Scurry to Scramble
description: It was the largest crowd to ever see a women's sporting event in the United States, larger than any crowd for a Giants game or a Jets game, larger than any audience ever at Giants Stadium except for the Pope. That would be Pope John Paul II of the Vatican, not Eddie Pope of D.C. United.

title: Poland Opens Door to West, And Chills Blow Both Ways
description: Like Poland itself, Ludomir Turkowski embraced capitalism and Western conveniences when Communism collapsed here 10 years ago.

title: Networks Deliver Smorgasbord to Fill Order for Young Viewers
description: Remember the episode of ''The Twilight Zone'' when a horrified woman discovered that a book written by space visitors called ''To Serve Man'' was actually a cookbook? Well, a book about the 1999-2000 season for the broadcast television networks could be titled ''To Serve Youth.''

title: New York Beckons Both of Us, Clinton Says
description: President Clinton said today that he and First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton intend to ''get a place'' in New York -- soon enough to allow Mrs. Clinton to use it as a residence if she decides to run for the Senate.

title: Dentsu Unit Acquires Rest of Canadian Unit
description: Dentsu USA in New York, part of Dentsu Inc., has acquired the 50 percent stake it did not already own in Dentsu-Cadence Canada in Toronto. Financial terms for the purchase of the shares, which had been held by Albert Barbusci, president and chief executive at Dentsu-Cadence Canada, were not disclosed.

title: Treasury Schedules Auctions This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of 52-week bills and a two-year note tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.

title: Ordonez and His Offense Deserve Credit for Victory
description: If ever a position player deserved a ''W'' beside his name in the box score, it was Rey Ordonez. And it was for his offense today, not his defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Everything In Ruins And Little To Eat
description: The villagers here began arriving back home last night, part of a flood of refugees racing back over the border from nearly three months in camps and makeshift housing.

title: Pak Eases the Pressure With L.P.G.A. Victory
description: With a horde of media from her native Korea descending upon the Seaview Marriott Resort here, Se Ri Pak was under enormous pressure today. The 21-year-old felt the burden of having to please an entire country, and she responded by winning her first tournament of the year.

title: L.I. Congressman's Gun Votes: Consistency or Calculation?
description: The hodgepodge gun-control bill that died on the floor of the House of Representatives on Friday was as much political Rorschach test as legislation. Turn it one way, and a congressman might look like a gun-control zealot. Turn it another, and he might look like a die-hard defender of the Second Amendment.

title: The Big City; This Hazard For Virginia Is Unreported
description: UNDER cover of darkness, the trucks rumble out from an industrial complex hidden in a wooded ravine.

title: Competitive Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Patents; In a world of cyber-this and video-that, can traditonal board games still gain attention?
description: IN the last year, dozens of patents have been issued to hopeful inventors who dream that their new version of the old-fashioned board game will one day become the next Monopoly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, IRVING T.
description: LEWIS-Irving T. On June 18, 1999, in his 93rd year. Beloved husband of Ann. Dear father of Patricia Braverman and Susan (Norman) Kominsky. Loving grandfather of Cary, Alice, Julie Reva and Andrew, and great-grandfather of Bryn and Finnley Wren. Services today, June 21, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing economic trends in Santa Clara County, Calif., credited a data source incorrectly. It was the VentureOne Corporation, not Venture One Economics.

title: Forget the Slow Burn, Johnson Goes Nuclear
description: Maybe it was the cresting frustration caused by a sprained knee that had limited him, a miracle touch that had deserted him and a talented Tim Duncan who had dominated him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: There, It's Just a Game; Here, an Experience
description: There are many ways to gauge the differences between the Knicks and the San Antonio Spurs, and all extend beyond comparisons of Chris Dudley's rim-clanking free throws to Tim Duncan's sweet bank shots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Panel Confirms No Major Illness Tied to Implants
description: An independent panel of 13 scientists convened by the Institute of Medicine at the request of Congress has concluded that silicone breast implants do not cause any major diseases.

title: When Movies and Politics Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving the Muse His Due, but Subtly
description: It's good to see that Cassandra Wilson's recent material with a Miles Davis theme, as it has developed in performance over the last two years, has less and less to do with Miles Davis. The jazz record and concert-making business is clotted with tributes to absent fathers, but Ms. Wilson has used Davis as background stimulus rather than as a model, freeing herself to make her own art her own way. She uses a few of his melodies, but otherwise she conjures him up by something like metaphor.

title: The Virtue of the Sidelines, With Time to Toy Around
description: Ten years after it got started, Pavement still makes its songs sound shaky. It could by now crank up its guitars in big resounding chords; it could notch up its tempos to push people around. Sometimes, briefly, it does, only to let the sound and momentum subside within moments. Its guitars slip out of unison, picking instead of chording and hollowing out the music. Stephen Malkmus, Pavement's main singer and songwriter, keeps his voice conversational, though he sometimes works up to an exasperated yelp. Pavement has held its place as a paragon of indie rock by refusing to project rock's illusion of authority.

title: Cracking the Genetic Code
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Salsa, Served Imaginatively, At a Central Park Premiere
description: The dance segment of the free, yearly Central Park Summerstage festival got off to a good-looking and provocative start on Wednesday night with the world premiere of Merian Soto's ''Asi Se Baila un Son'' (''How to Dance a Son''). The title refers to Son Montuno, the Afro-Cuban music and dance form that is the basis of salsa.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS AGAIN. The dollar rose against the yen after the Bank of Japan sold its currency for the fourth time in 11 days to stem gains that threaten a recovery. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.42 yen, up from 120.44.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Federal Judges Lose Battle Against a County Tax
description: For more than 10 years, two Federal district judges in Birmingham, Ala., have fought an occupational license tax imposed by Jefferson County on the earnings of all public officials and many other people who work in the county.

title: Kamal Eddin Hussein, 77, Figure In Coup Against Farouk in 1952
description: Kamal Eddin Hussein, a crusty Egyptian army officer who helped to overthrow King Farouk of Egypt in 1952, became a Vice President of Egypt and then clashed with two Presidents, died on Saturday. He was 77.

title: U.S. Said to Give Albertson's Approval on $8.3 Billion Deal
description: Federal officials have agreed that they will not block Albertson's Inc. in its $8.3 billion purchase of the American Stores Company, now that Albertson's has agreed to sell 144 stores in three states, people involved in the review said today.

title: Too Much Certainty
description: To the Editor:

title: To Be Real, or Don't U Know Brandy?
description: Just because Brandy has million-selling albums, the title role in a television show, movie parts and her face on fashion magazine covers doesn't mean she's grown conceited. Her show at the PNC Bank Arts Center here on Sunday, part of her first headlining tour of the United States, presented a girlish 20-year-old who was eager to please. She sang about falling in and out of love and about trying to reach a ''higher plane''; she joined her dancers in choreographed simulations of teen-agers at play. ''I just want to let you know that I'm real,'' she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Abroad at Home; The Question Of Evil
description: There can be no doubt, now, about the scale of Serbian atrocities in Kosovo. Western reporters and war-crimes investigators have begun to confirm what Kosovar Albanian refugees described.

title: Sun, Skin and Bones
description: To the Editor:

title: Post-Jordan Ratings In Prime-Time Torpor
description: Three weeks ago, NBC predicted that the absence of Michael Jordan would cause ratings for the National Basketball Association finals to slide by 25 percent.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, HRUSKA, LAURA
description: SILVERSTEIN - HRUSKA - Laura. 78, died June 12, 1999 following a protracted respiratory illness. Devoted daughter, wife and mother. She is remembered with love and respect by friends, family, members of the jewelry industry and residents of her community, Woodmere, NY.

title: Can Student Prayer Be Voluntary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REHNS, MAX
description: REHNS-Max. On June 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Lila. Devoted father of Michael and Alice. Cherished grandfather of Danny, Kenny, Scott, Heather, Jason and Brian. He will live on in our hearts forever. Services Wednesday, 10AM, from ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Three Teen-Agers Die in Car Crash on Rural Long Island Road
description: Three 18-year-olds, two of whom were scheduled to graduate from high school next weekend, died Sunday night when the car in which they were riding veered off a dark, winding rural road and struck a tree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Hewlett-Packard Ends Tie-In With EMC
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's No. 2 computer maker, has ended an agreement to sell computer-storage systems made by the EMC Corporation as Hewlett-Packard introduces its own competitive products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKNER, ABRAHAM, DR.
description: BROOKNER-Abraham, Dr. Died June 20, 1999 at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Blanche, adored father of Joan and Peter and grandfather of Adam. Until his retirement, he was a dedicated and compassionate physician and always a gentleman. Graveside services 1:30pm Tuesday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, N.J. The family will receive visitors at their home Tuesday evening through Thursday.

title: The All-Rise Method for Faster Meetings
description: Researchers at the University of Missouri wanted to test the theory that the way to make better, shorter business meetings was to take the chairs away. And sure enough, comparing outcomes for 111 meetings, they found that those conducted while the participants were seated lasted longer than meetings in which the participants remained standing. However, the quality of decision-making was the same for both formats.

title: Two Male Virtuosos, One With Tough Guy Charm
description: The stars were in alignment on Friday night, presumably in the heavens as well as on the Metropolitan Opera House stage, where Susan Jaffe and Jose Manuel Carreno swept through a triumphant performance of the American Ballet Theater production of ''Don Quixote.'' Ms. Jaffe and Mr. Carreno were at once glamorous ballet stars, perfectly matched lovers and bravura technicians, making affectionate fun of this galumphing ballet and their own saucy characters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: NATO's Peacekeeping Force, Defied by Both Sides, Struggles to Keep Order
description: For the third consecutive day, several dozen Serbs in civilian dress who call themselves ''warrior citizens'' prevented ethnic Albanians from entering the predominantly Serbian sector of this northern Kosovo industrial town today, jeering and threatening any Albanian who dared to enter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about the massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., referred incorrectly to a person who was quoted as having said in a telephone call to a television station, 'I just can't believe it is happening at my school.'' The caller told the station that he was Bob Sapin, a Columbine student, and he was so identified in the article. But last week a spokeswoman for the Jefferson County School District said that no one with that name had been enrolled at Columbine High, and the identity of the caller remains unknown.

title: ESSAY; A Doctor Discovers How to Talk to a Doctor
description: I recently found myself in a situation that to most doctors is more terrifying than a malpractice lawsuit -- being a patient myself.

title: Officer, Fired After Testimony Against Department, Sues City
description: A former New York City police officer filed a Federal lawsuit against the city yesterday, saying she was fired in retaliation for criticizing the Police Department before the City Council in April.

title: Metro Business; Ruling on Utility's Request
description: Northeast Utilities, New England's largest power company, should be allowed to refinance $3.3 billion in debt, $1.1 billion less than it has requested under Connecticut's deregulation law, state regulators said in a preliminary ruling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Bigger Crowds Watching Better Play
description: It is apparent after the opening weekend that the Women's World Cup will be something more than a three-week coronation for the United States, which must now face a Nigerian team that has Patience and Mercy in its lineup but not in its temperament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 9 about the crash of an American Airlines jet at Little Rock, Ark., misstated the workings of the system for automatic operation of the wing devices that reduce lift after a plane touches down. The system deploys the devices, called spoilers, after the wheels make firm contact with the ground and begin spinning, not when the wheels stop spinning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAF, JULES W. DR.
description: LEAF-Jules W. Dr. On June 21, 1999 after a short illness. World renown lecturer and artist of dentistry. Associate Professor at NYU College of Dentistry for many years. Co-Founder of the Levin School of Dentistry in Israel. Husband of the late Evelyn and Cecile, father of Dr. Robert J. Leaf of Mamaroneck, N.Y. and Dorothy Sollender of San Diego, Ca. Father-inlaw of Dr. Jeanette Leaf and Joel Sollender, brother of George Leaf, grandfather of Jeremy and David Leaf and Dr. Jonathan and Jeffrey Sollender, great grandfather of five children. Graveside services at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery on Tuesday June 22nd at 10:30am.

title: Shipping the City's Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Starr Report May Help New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the coming release of a Spike Lee movie called ''Summer of Sam,'' about David Berkowitz, the serial killer known as the Son of Sam, used an incorrect spelling in some editions for the surname of a former police sergeant involved in the case. He is Joe Coffey, not Coffee.

title: Can Student Prayer Be Voluntary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiding Secret Messages Within Human Code
description: The genetic code has been asked to do a lot of things, from insuring that a spider has eight legs to giving Elizabeth Taylor her violet eyes. But as far as is known, it has never been asked to spy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 22 about the indictment of Ihab M. Ali as part of the investigation of Osama bin Laden misstated the charge against Mr. Ali. It is civil contempt, for refusal to testify before the grand jury, not perjury. The case is being handled under a court order of secrecy, and the new information was confirmed only yesterday. Later developments are reported today on page B4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWRY, DONALD I.
description: LOWRY-Donald I. Died June 17, 1999, in Camden, ME, residing in Cincinatti for many years before retiring as a Senior Vice President for Proctor & Gamble, and moving to Naples, FL. He leaves his wife, Barbara, two sons, Peter H., and Samuel A., three daughters, Pamela L., of Boston, MA, Sarah L. Fasoldt, of Camden, and Amy L. Poole, of Chicago. Also survived by a brother, Ralph A., of Charlottesville, VA., and a sister, Dorothy MacDonald, of Louisville, KY. He served in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II, graduated from Harvard College in 1941, where he was a John Harvard Fellow.

title: Can Student Prayer Be Voluntary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells Working With Young Guards
description: The Jets do not have a guard today who has played a single down of pro football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, LOUIS J.
description: GLICKMAN-Louis J. Yeshiva University and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourn the passing of a distinguished philanthropist and communal leader, who was a YU Guardian and AECOM Founder. An honorary YU alumnus and a second generation University Trustee, he had chaired the Board of Trustee's Development Committee. Condolences to his wife, Helene, sons Adam and Warren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson AECOM Board of Overseers

title: Episode 1: The Phantom Film Studio; Hopes and Doubts Greet a Plan for Sound Stages at the Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: To skeptics it is too big, too far, too speculative and, coming at a time when sound stages are sitting empty across Los Angeles, altogether too much: the kind of boom-era bubble likely to pop as soon as it hits the first sharp object or dissonant breeze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGLIARO, FRANK J.
description: PAGLIARO-Frank J. Of Mt. Kisco on June 19, at 99, died at home after a short illness. He was a leader of the New York construction industry for more than 50 years. A resident of Mt. Kisco, he was a longtime member of its Beautification Committee. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, the former Anita Tabacchi; a sister, Mary Petrillo of Bronxville; two sons, Frank, Jr. of Burlingame, CA, and Leonard of Seattle, WA; four daughters, Anita and Carla of Livingston, MT, and Alix Barthelmes and Lisa Selz of Manhattan; six grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. A mass will be held at 10 AM Tuesday, June 22 at St. Francis of Assisi, Mt. Kisco. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Mt. Kisco Beautification Committee or to Hospice of Nothern Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLE, JOSEPH S., M.D.
description: MULLE-Joseph S., M.D. F.A.C.S. On June 20, 1999 of Jamaica Estates, NY. Born in Greenpoint on November 24, 1911. Educated at Boys High, he graduated from St. John's University in 1933. He received his medical degree from St. Louis University in 1937, specializing in orthopedic surgery. He served in the United States Army as a Lt. Colonel from 1941 to 1946. Former Chief of Orthopedic Surgery of Brooklyn State and Mary Immaculate Hospitals, and Director of Orthopedic Surgery at Catholic Medical Center from 1970 to 1982. In 1998 St. John's University conferred upon him the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. He was a member of the Knights of Malta. He was a member of Hempstead and Mariner Sands Golf Clubs. Beloved husband of the late Anne, loving father and father-in-law to Tony and Antoinette. Cherished grandfather of Joseph, Anne Marie, Thomas and his wife Caryn. Fond brother of Anthony of Nashville, TN and Catherine Schnakenberg of Wallingford, CT. Visiting will be held Tuesday 7-10 P.M. and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. at the R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home Inc (224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY). A funeral mass will be held on Thursday at 10:15 A.M. at the Immaculate Conception Monastery, Jamaica Estates, NY. Entombment will follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461-9955 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Giving Fairy Tales a Feminist Twist
description: In HBO's latest fracturing of fairy tales, ''The Three Little Pigs'' as reinterpreted by Tama Janowitz will be set in a girls' camp where ''You can never be too fat or too dirty.''

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: After Another Look, N.H.L. Ends Crease Replays
description: Less than two days after the Dallas Stars won the Stanley Cup in the third overtime on a goal from inside the goal crease, the National Hockey League eliminated the use of video replay yesterday to determine crease violations on goals, shifting the responsibility to on-ice officials instead.

title: Collaboration Of Hancock And Shorter
description: The saxophonist Wayne Shorter and the pianist Herbie Hancock have occasionally performed as a duo over the last two years since making an album together called ''1+1'' (Verve). The record of piano and soprano-saxophone duets is informal and casually intriguing; their JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night at Carnegie Hall felt listless.

title: Drugs May Ease Sickle Cell Crises
description: The worst part of sickle cell disease is the numbing, painful episodes that can strike any time, searing the body with waves of agony as cells in crucial organs, starved for oxygen and nutrients by blocked blood vessels, wither and die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGUIRE, JOAN DORIS
description: MAGUIRE-Joan Doris. Of Seaside Park, NJ on June 21, 1999. Mother of Joseph Bernard Maguire, Craig Richard Maguire, Christine Maguire Simmers and Jeanne Maguire. The family will receive friends at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home on Wednesday from 6:30 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Thomas More RC Church, Darien, CT 12 noon Thursday. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorials, Alina Lodge Foundation, Blairstown, NJ.

title: U.N. Committee, Under Pressure, Limits Rights Groups
description: Led by a small group of developing nations, a United Nations committee has inflicted major setbacks in recent days on human rights groups that seek to expose and combat political oppression.

title: An Outsize Life And Death For an Insider On 7th Ave.
description: Like many people who come to New York from somewhere else, who have a heightened attraction to the city's openness, Todd Oldham had an ideal, and it was John Badum. To Mr. Oldham, the Texas-born fashion designer who made his name in the early 1990's, Mr. Badum was a catalyst, a ringleader, someone who was not only openly gay but who was also constantly at the center of everything.

title: Grim Dose Of O'Neill Is Fund-Raiser For Democrats
description: When President Clinton and other politicians come to New York City to raise campaign money -- which they do frequently -- they tend to favor fund-raisers at elegant restaurants like Le Cirque 2000, or special performances of crowd-pleasing Broadway shows like ''The Lion King.''

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; Beware of Dead Rattlesnakes. They Bite
description: Spanish explorers in the 16th century first recorded the fact that dead rattlesnakes can bite, but that word has apparently not gotten around: two toxicologists in Phoenix found that 15 percent of the rattlesnake bites they treated in a 10-month period came from snakes that had been decapitated, shot or whomped until dead.

title: A Link Between Bicycles and Impotence?
description: Q. Can riding a bicycle lead to erectile dysfunction or impotence?

title: TRANSAMERICA SELLING MORTGAGE SERVICING BUSINESS
description: The Transamerica Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Transamerica Homefirst Inc. unit to the Financial Freedom Senior Funding Corporation for $200 million. Transamerica, based in San Francisco, is a financial-services company with 1998 revenue of $6.4 billion. Financial Freedom, based in Irvine, Calif., is a reverse-mortgage lender. In a reverse mortgage, a lender agrees to make monthly payments to a borrower, with the borrower's home equity serving as collateral for the loan. The equity is used to repay the loan when the borrower sells the home, moves out or dies. The ultimate source of repayment is the homeowner's estate. The agreement includes Transamerica Homefirst's mortgage servicing operations and its reverse-mortgage loan portfolio.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 10 about Pope John Paul II and a Polish family misspelled the family's surname and the name of the town where the meeting occurred. The family is Milewski, not Milweska; the town is Leszczewo, not Lesczewo. The caption also misidentified the region where the Pope grew up. It was southern Poland, not northeast.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Hometown May Honor Slapstick's Frizzy Icon
description: Lyla Budnick remembers her brother Louis Feinberg as a warm and caring family man, hardly the frizzy-haired, wild-eyed rapscallion the world knew as Larry Fine, one of the most famous of the Three Stooges.

title: Paradox or Not, Cholesterol in France Is on the Rise
description: Americans, famous for wanting their cake and eating it too, were delighted to learn that even though French foods seem to be rich in fat, much of it artery-clogging saturated animal fat, the French are not nearly as likely to be cut down in midlife by heart attacks. This intriguing phenomenon is called the French Paradox, and it has drawn comment, criticism and speculation for much of this decade.

title: A Surprise Before the Tip-Off: Camby Is a Starter
description: The roar during the pre-game introductions was of shock and pleasure. Was that Marcus Camby who had just run into the huddle full of starters, his chance finally come?

title: Getting Down to Basics Up in the Country
description: Gala opening night benefit concerts of summer festivals usually mean that along with the music the audience will hear speeches: odes to the arts, tributes to past achievements, exhortations to the future. A captive body of patrons and potential new patrons is too hard to resist.

title: Indonesia's Vote: Reformers May Be Disappointed
description: Indonesians have remained remarkably patient as they wait out the slow, confused counting of the parliamentary votes they cast two weeks ago. But it seems that whatever the outcome, the will of the people may in large part be denied.

title: Can Student Prayer Be Voluntary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBFINGER, MARTIN WILLIAM
description: HALBFINGER-Martin William. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Martin William Halbfinger, beloved father of its devoted member, Caren Besharim and extends heartfelt condolences to Caren and Shlomo, and the entire bereaved family. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Ed Leventhal, President

title: Juan del Regato, 90, an Expert In Radiation Therapy for Cancer
description: Dr. Juan A. del Regato, a pioneer in using radiation therapy to treat cancer, died on June 12 at Munson Medical Center in Traverse City, Mich. He was 90 and lived in a retirement home in Tampa, Fla.

title: Survey showing corporate executives' tepid support for advertising rings some alarms.
description: THE next phase of a major multiyear communications effort to promote the importance of advertising is getting under way -- and not a moment too soon, judging by the results of a national survey of top corporate executives.

title: Foreign Affairs; All in the Family
description: Jewish Jerusalem used to just be divided between secular and religious. Today the divide is so much more profound. This city is now part Teheran, part Palo Alto. It has one foot in cyberspace and the other in the Second Temple. Part of Jerusalem's youth have Bill Gates as their role model and another part the fiddler on the roof.

title: White House Memo; Laurels Elude President As Public Judges a War
description: Presidents can ordinarily expect a surge in public support when they commit American forces to a foreign conflict and an even greater reward in public approval when the war ends with minimal loss of American life.

title: The Spurs Lose Composure, and Game 3 Follows
description: The rowdiness of the fans and breadth of the situation were not supposed to rattle the reserved and typically unflappable San Antonio Spurs. Their experience and calm were supposed to eliminate the setting and scenario as an issue in Game 3 of the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Lead Paint Bill Is Attacked By Democrats
description: A bill intended to clarify the city's laws protecting children from lead paint poisoning, one that has the support of City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, came under vehement attack yesterday by Council Democrats, who said it favored landlords and the city over children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, HELEN G.
description: HAMBURG-Helen G. We extend our sincerest condolences to the family of Donald Hamburg on the loss of his mother and Jan's mother-in-law, loved by them and so many. Vera Stern, President Romie Shapiro, Co-Chair, Executive Committee

title: Give the Russians a Chance
description: Near the end of the first year of NATO's mission in Bosnia, the Russian brigade working with, and for, the American division was faced with a particularly difficult problem. Some Bosnian Muslims who had moved into the Bosnian Serb republic were behaving provocatively, and the Serbs were responding with threats of violence.

title: Try Carrots for Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, JOSEPH
description: SCHONBERG-Joseph. Died on Father's Day. Beloved husband of Adele. Cherished father of Karen (David), Richard (Jean). Adored Poppy of Dina and Max. Greatly respected by his clients and loved by his many friends. He will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Risky Move In the Spirit of Bogart
description: IS there the man or woman whose eyes have not teared at the end of ''Casablanca'' when Humphrey Bogart gives up the woman he loves so that she will stay with her husband and rid the world of Nazis? Is there the heart that has not melted at such selflessness?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: IN A BIG SHAKE-UP, CREW WILL CLOSE 13 FAILING SCHOOLS
description: Thirteen failing schools in New York City will be closed over the next two years, school officials said yesterday, as part of a shake-up that Chancellor Rudy Crew is billing as the biggest restructuring of the system in decades.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: America Online to Put $1.5 Billion Into a Hughes Alliance
description: America Online will invest $1.5 billion in Hughes Electronics as part of a wide-ranging alliance that will allow the on-line service to offer high-speed Internet access using the Hughes satellite data delivery system, the companies said today.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS TO PURCHASE ISRAELI CHIP MAKER
description: Texas Instruments Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Libit Signal Processing Ltd., an Israeli maker of chips and parts for cable TV and set-top boxes, for $365 million. The deal will enable Texas Instruments to expand its domination of the market for digital signal processor technologies into all segments of so-called broadband communications, which provide high-speed voice, video and data transmissions over traditional cable lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, ROSE
description: SOBEL-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Jerry. Loving mother of Tanya Le Bovici and son-in-law Ronald. Cherished grandmother of Marni, Jackie and Warren and great-grandmother of Jordan. Dear sister of Betty and Bob Friedler and Simon and Ruth Starr. Forever in our hearts and memory.

title: Next Starr Report May Help New York; Aid for the Clintons
description: To the Editor:

title: Togo's President, Africa's Longest-Ruling Leader, Tightens Hold
description: A year after winning re-election in voting that was widely considered tainted, President Gnassingbe Eyadema has continued to tighten his three-decade hold on his nation's politics, preserving his status as sub-Saharan Africa's longest-ruling head of state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, SAUL
description: LERNER-Saul. 85, of Brooklyn, NY. On Sunday, June 20, 1999 in Goshen, NY. Loving father of Lili Joseph. Devoted brother of Rubin Lerner. Also survived by two grandchildren and two nieces. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday (today) at 11:30 A.M. at Monroe Temple of Liberal Judaism, Monroe, NY. Burial will be in Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Monroe Temple or charity of one's choice.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Find There's No Place Like Home
description: THE Knicks were preparing to throw everything they had last night at San Antonio in an attempt to avoid a four-game sweep. The team was in a full-blown ''Win one for the Gipper'' mode.

title: Mellon Bank Offers Options to Workers
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said today that it was offering each employee 450 stock options over three years to align the interests of shareholders and company staff members.

title: Panel Calls for Study of Some Implant Risks
description: Members of an expert committee of scientists that assessed the safety of silicone breast implants formally issued their report today, calling for more research on risks of rupture and other local complications that can arise from the devices.

title: Sampras Brushes Aside The First-Round Jitters
description: The defending champion was worried about feeling like one, but only the grass was vulnerable today on opening day at Wimbledon. Pete Sampras's early round jitters proved fleeting, and the rest of the seeded shoo-ins stomped and skidded their way into the second round without any unmanageable slip-ups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERER, FREDERICK BENTLEY
description: BIERER-Frederick Bentley. Died June 21, 1999, at the age of 82, in New York City after a long illness. He was raised in Furth, Germany and joined The British Army in 1940, serving in the Pioneer, Commando, Tanks and Intelligence Corps. He emigrated to America in 1946, and married Sally Erlanger in 1950, who filled his heart. He founded the Bentley Industrial Corporation, a machine tool importing company that engaged his exceptional aptitude for finding solutions to life's problems, mechanical and othewise. Fred is survived by a grateful and happy family including his wife, three children, all of whom became physicians, their spouses and, as of now, five grandchildren. He enjoyed rich and long - lasting friendships throughout his life and, until his lasts minutes, was able to inspire and amuse those who loved him. The service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), on Thursday June 24, 1999, at 4 P.M. Family flowers only; donations may be made in his name to The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, 333 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10001, an organization that assisted his family's escape from Germany.

title: PHILIPPINE REQUEST

A top aide to the Philippine President, Joseph Estrada, said that request could lay the legal groundwork for Ex-Im Bank to confiscate four Boeing 747's, which it financed for the flag carrier.

Conduit, which is closely held, provides information-technology consulting. I-Cube's shares rose $2.0625 each, to $20.

Shareholders with more than 70 percent of Saga's shares accepted the offer of 135 kroner ($17.26) in Hydro stock and cash for each Saga share. In addition, Statoil owns 20 percent. The buyers will also assume about $2.3 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

ADC will exchange 0.358 of its shares for each outstanding share of Saville Systems, valuing the Irish company at $50.125 a share, or about $700 million, based on Friday's closing prices. Based in Galway, Saville Systems makes billing systems and software for telecommunications markets. It had net income of $27.1 million in the 1998 fiscal year on sales of $167.7 million. Shares of ADC, based in Minnetonka, Minn., dropped 6 percent, falling $3 a share, to $47.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM

He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.
