description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, DOLLY
description: RAISLER-Dolly. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dolly Raisler, an admired philanthropist and cherished friend of the Jewish community who enriched the lives of all those touched by her generosity. Her grace, wisdom, and kindness will be greatly missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to her beloved husband, Robert; her children, Gordon, Steven, and Lynn; her grandchildren Michael, Anthony, and Joe; and her entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Top Executives Are Removed At McKesson
description: In one of the drug industry's largest corporate shake-ups, the board of McKesson HBOC Inc. ousted some of its top executives yesterday, including its chairman, Charles McCall, over accounting irregularities at HBO & Company, a software maker it acquired in January.

title: No Freedom for Man Staying Silent in Terrorism Inquiry
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has refused to free an Orlando, Fla., man who was jailed last month for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating Osama bin Laden and his suspected role in worldwide terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, CHARLOTTE DANIELS
description: HARRIS-Charlotte Daniels. On June 19, 1999 of Flushing, NY. Kindergarten teacher PS 101, Queens for over 40 years. Bachelor of Music from the Curtis Institute of Music; Master of Arts from Columbia University. Wife of the late Hebdon. Very dear friend of Isabella R. Falcocchio. Graveside service Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY, Wednesday, June 23, 11:00 AM

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES TO BUY HOLOPHANE
description: National Service Industries, a diversified Atlanta-based manufacturer, signed an agreement yesterday to acquire the Holophane Corporation, an industrial lighting maker, for around $450 million in cash. Under the terms of the deal, National Service will pay $38.50 a share in cash for Holophane, which is based in Columbus, Ohio. Holophane's shares rose 34 percent, gaining $9.625, to $37.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange, while National Service fell $1.125, to $37.1875. National Service said the Holophane acquisition would strengthen its lighting business, accounting for 55 percent of its sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITAGLIANO, BETTE JANE
description: VITAGLIANO-Bette Jane. Died on June 20, 1999 at age 62. Beloved wife of Joseph and loving mother of Eric and Amy and stepchildren Laura, Mark, Paul, Lisa and Mary. Sister of Margie Bildersee. A warm, devoted lady loved by all whose lives she touched-and they are legion. Always ready to give support and solace to her friends and family, Bette will be forever in our hearts. Services are on Thursday, June 24, 11 am, at Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel, Hartsdale, NY and a memorial Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, June 26, 11 am at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Kennedy Boulevard at 81st Street, North Bergen, NJ. The family requests donations to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PANTRY INC., Sanford, N.C., a convenience store operator, agreed to buy the closely held R&H Maxxon Inc., Aiken, S.C., another convenience store operator, for an undisclosed amount.

title: The Fight for Human Rights
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday misstated the results of the New York Take 5. The correct numbers were 10, 15, 22, 25, 38.

title: Camby Doesn't Back Down, and Neither Do Knicks
description: It did not matter if Marcus Camby had the upper body of a coat hanger, he was not about to hand over his milk money to a star center with cargo room in his biceps.

title: TELSTRA STOCK SALE
description: The Australian Government will sell 16 percent of the Telstra Corporation, the nation's dominant telecommunications company, raising as much as $12 billion in one of the world's largest stock sales. The Government secured the votes of two key independent senators, allowing the legislation to pass in the Senate, 37 to 35. The sale, likely to be held in October or November, is expected to attract strong demand from investors.

title: New Spice for an Old Friend, the Milkshake
description: IN a neighborhood where smoothies boasting wheat grass and protein power reign supreme, who would expect to find a reinvention of the milkshake?

title: Liberties; Bushfellas
description: There's a story out of Hollywood that Francis Ford Coppola is wooing Leonardo diCaprio to play the young Sonny Corleone in ''The Godfather, Part IV.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GEORGE WOODROW
description: FRANK-George Woodrow. 82 years of age, of Princeton, NJ. Beloved husband of Irma R. Devoted father of George, Jr., (Woody) and Susan F. Daum. Dear grandfather of George W. Frank, III (Tripp), Andrew Frank, Nicholas Daum, Matthew Daum and great-grandfather of George W. Frank, IV (Drew). He was a graduate of The Hun School and Princeton University '38. Retired Lieutenant Colonel from WW II, Vice President of E&J Gallo Winery, and founder and first president of Hospice Care Network. Memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: A 900-Year-Old Ritual Stirs Waters Off Sicily
description: For more than 900 years the fishermen of this little island off Sicily have gone after bluefin tuna in the same ritualistic way. For the four weeks when the huge fish migrate through these waters, the men await a signal from their leader to begin the mattanza, a highly choreographed communal hunt with prayers and songs and rigid rules that is seldom seen around Sicily anymore.

title: Top General Would Speed Deployment For Kosovo
description: With acts of violence and retribution continuing in Kosovo, NATO's senior commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, said today that the allies should speed up the deployment of their troops to the Serbian province and suggested that more than the 50,000 peacekeepers originally planned might be needed.

title: Thrashers to Study Protected Lists
description: The National Hockey League has released its protected and available list of players from the 26 clubs that will be subject to the 1999 expansion draft, to be held on Friday in Boston. The Atlanta Thrashers will select 26 players, one from each club. The Nashville Predators, who played their first season, will be exempt from the draft.

title: Flamboyant Nigeria Plays Exuberantly
description: Nigeria is playing in its third Women's World Cup, so the team is no longer green, unless you count the hair of its top scorer, Mercy Akide. For her, Mercy is a name, not a virtue. Attack is the only style for a team that plays with joyous assertion and individual brilliance, one that needs a pit crew more than a coaching staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFEL, LILLIAN
description: SCHAFFEL-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, loving mother of Roberta Sklar, Bill and Ivan Schaffel. Adored grandmother of Brad and Doug Sklar and Alexander Schaffel. Dear sister of Phyllis Kirschner, Lenore Perry, Saul Rosenblatt and the late Ruth Kevy. Private services were held. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: A Strong Field Follows U.S. Open
description: In the past, the world's top golfers have used the Buick Classic as preparation for the United States Open. This year, they may use it to recover from the Open.

title: N.B.A. FINALS: NOTEBOOK; Spurs Are More Congenial
description: Larry Johnson did not make the All-Interview team, which was announced yesterday. But two members of the Spurs did make the first team, and a Knick and a Spur were named to the second unit.

title: Actors Taking To the Stage
description: Actors in television series usually have three months off in the summer. Some use the time to earn money, making a movie; some use it to spend money, taking a vacation. And then there are those intrepid few who tread somewhere in the middle, on the stages of Manhattan, taking their chances with the New York theater critics and paying public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: On the Move

title: Informal to a Fault
description: Recently my son graduated from college. As far back as I can remember, I imagined this day would be an event unlike any other. I prepared for the day, in part, by buying myself a new suit, which marked this occasion as important and special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN, HAROLD
description: CHRISTENSEN-Harold. Age 83, of Boynton Beach, FL, on June 17, 1999. He resided in Bronxville, NY for many years before retiring as Secretary and Director of Personnel for IBM World Trade Corporation in 1972. Predeceased by his wife, Gladys, and daughter, Lorna Black, he is survived by his daughter, Linda Graham, and five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUVIN, SARAH
description: TUVIN-Sarah. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Sarah Tuvin, our esteemed colleague. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Hingis Loses, And There's No Shoulder To Cry On
description: Her face was white as the chalk lines traced into the grass court underfoot, drained of its normal color by a combination of rage and disbelief and the premonition that she had seen a ghost across the net on Court One. Jelena Dokic was the ghost of the anxiety-free girl Martina Hingis used to be at 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, RUTH S.
description: EBIN-Ruth S. On June 18th,1999. Beloved wife and companion of David. Cherished mother of Jonathan. A woman of wise wit, rare flair-enhancing a-new, now absent/present, the ken of friends and all who knew her.

title: Magnet Schools and Class
description: A new book examining magnet schools finds they do what they are supposed to do -- encourage desegregation -- but cause another kind of segregation, that of class.

title: Austerity Plan to Test Schroeder's Government
description: FRANKFURT  Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder is due to announce Wednesday an unpopular austerity plan that political analysts view as the last chance for his shaky coalition government to revive Europe's biggest economy.

title: AAVID THERMAL TECHNOLOGIES IS IN TALKS TO BE ACQUIRED
description: Aavid Thermal Technologies Inc., which makes devices that keep computer chips from overheating, said yesterday that it was in discussions to sell itself to a private investment firm and intended to make a major acquisition. Aavid said an unidentified investment company had indicated that it was willing to pay $24.50 a share in cash -- Monday's closing price. The stock fell $1.875 yesterday, to $22.625, giving the company's stock a current value of $210 million. The company, based in Concord, N.H., also said it had signed a nonbinding agreement to acquire a company that it did not identify.

title: Bill Offers States Leeway on Education Aid
description: Republican leaders in Congress today unveiled an education bill that builds significantly on their previous efforts to give state and local governments ever broader discretion over the spending of Federal money.

title: Letting Hits Fall Where They May
description: Mike Piazza has not worn the same pair of socks or eaten the same meal or left for the ball park at the same time on consecutive days during his hitting streak because he believes superstitions are silly. Piazza has watched other players obsess over such trivial preparation, and he has promised himself that he will never be so compulsive.

title: Schools Chief Gives Himself a Strong C
description: On the eve of announcing the names of superintendents that he believes have failed the public school system and the children it serves, Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he also blamed himself for districts that have failed to show progress in raising school achievement three and a half years into his administration.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: This Bud's for Them; Anheuser-Busch Takes Closer Aim at Foreign Markets
description: When Anheuser-Busch decided to go full throttle into the Argentine beer market, it looked around for advertising opportunities and found one in the form of Marcelo Tinelli, Argentina's answer to Jay Leno with a little ''Candid Camera'' thrown in. Mr. Tinelli is on the air five nights a week, cracking jokes, interviewing guests -- and, in recent months, sipping Budweiser from a can in front of millions of viewers.

title: In Wake of Espionage, Debate On New Nuclear Arms Agency
description: The Senate and the Clinton Administration moved closer today to a drastic legislative restructuring of the Energy Department, but in Senate testimony Energy Secretary Bill Richardson continued to resist a key element, a proposal to create a new agency to oversee nuclear weapons programs.

title: N.B.A. FINALS: NOTEBOOK; Injury Hampering Childs
description: Chris Childs, who sprained his left knee during Game 3, sat out practice yesterday but said he planned to play tonight.

title: Loan for a Land Grab
description: The World Bank's board of executive directors ought to reject a loan package to China that would be used to relocate about 58,000 impoverished Chinese and Hui Muslim farmers to a remote area on the Tibetan plateau traditionally inhabited by Tibetans and Mongolians. In the past, China has used migration policies to tighten control over Tibetan areas and to diminish the viability of the distinct Tibetan culture. The World Bank should not be in the business of financing this destructive scheme.

title: MP3.Com Public Offering
description: The Internet music company MP3.com Inc. set the terms today for its initial public offering. The company said it would sell up to nine million shares of common stock for $9 to $11 each. The company's Web site is a major distributor of software related to MP3 technology, which compresses music into files that can be transferred through the Web and stored on personal computers or other electronic devices. MP3 has worried the music industry because it lacks copyright protection and a system for collecting royalties.

title: Sutton Place, Balducci's in Partnership
description: BALDUCCI'S and Sutton Place Gourmet have made it official. No money exchanged hands, but Balducci's has become a subsidiary of Sutton Place Gourmet. The deal is being called a partnership but some elements make it sound like a sale.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; From the Heart: The Fine Art of a Family Business
description: MATISSEFather & SonBy John RussellIllustrated. 415 pages. Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Baseball Greats Shine in New Fields

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Budget Finale in Albany
description: Without the pressure of deadlines, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature would be arguing about this year's New York State budget until Halloween. But since a raft of previously enacted Medicaid cost reductions are due to expire next Wednesday, wiping out savings that state and local governments were counting on, a strong incentive exists for all sides to reach an agreement soon. In a welcome step, Sheldon Silver, Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, has scaled back his spending demands. It remains for Mr. Pataki to compromise by dropping proposed cuts in school aid and health care payments and promising not to veto at least some of the items desired by the lawmakers.

title: Countrified And Dignified
description: A CD or book with the imprint of the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame has always seemed like nothing more than merchandise, a souvenir. But a CD or book with the yellow circular logo of the Country Music Hall of Fame, a museum here that predates the opening of the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland by more than 25 years, has always been an object of cultural value, a necessity in the collection of anyone who appreciates American music. The museum's output ranges from its impressively exhaustive Encyclopedia of Country Music to its CD of early Johnny Paycheck recordings, featuring some of country's greatest parentheses songs, like ''(Pardon Me) While I Go Murder Somebody'' and ''It Won't Be Long (and I'll Be Hating You).''

title: Ozawa to Quit Boston Symphony, Adding to a Void on U.S. Podiums
description: In an unexpected turn that opens another prime podium in the world of classical music, the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced yesterday that its long-reigning music director and leading conductor, Seiji Ozawa, would leave after the 2002 season to take over the baton at the Vienna State Opera.

title: Arts in America -- With Latin Flair (and Flare); Diverse Audience Presents a Balancing Act for Talk Show Host
description: The subject was ''I have the worst husband in the world,'' and the three couples dug into it with relish. The women complained that their husbands never took them out and were too jealous or boring; the men retorted that their wives denied them sex and would rather go out than take care of the children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVISKY, LEONARD P.
description: STAVISKY-Leonard P. Beloved husband of Toby. Devoted father of Evan. Services Wednesday, 1:45 PM, ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Of Fraud, Millions and One Who Got Away
description: In early March, a Mississippi regulator stumbled upon a curious statistic: Several insurers in the state were part of a group of companies that had funneled as much as $14 billion in stock trades through a Connecticut-based securities firm, paying just $40,000 in commissions.

title: Bull-Market Blind Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LABES, LEON M.
description: LABES-Leon M. Died June 23, 1989. Wife Peggy, brother Mike, and grandsons Eric and Evan love you and miss you. Love from your children, Barbara and Steven

title: Ex-Governor's Conviction In Fraud Case Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court overturned the bank fraud convictions of former Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona today, saying the trial judge had wrongfully dismissed a juror who disagreed with the others over Mr. Symington's guilt.

title: From Dad, a Week of Family Programming
description: WHAT inspired Josh Sapan, a media mogul with the unlikely distinction of being both tall and modest, to make the normally competitive leaders of 66 cable networks play nicely in the sandbox together, and agree to schedule family-friendly programs in prime-time hours this week?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Sara Lee Buys Wechsler
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said today that it had acquired the Wechsler Coffee Corporation, a privately held coffee and beverage marketer, for an undisclosed price. Wechsler Coffee, based in Moonachie, N.J., has annual revenue of more than $110 million. Sara Lee, the Chicago-based consumer packaged-goods giant, produces brands including Hanes, Sara Lee, Playtex and Hillshire Farms.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dutch Auction Fails to Enthuse Internet Stock Investors
description: Salon.com, an on-line magazine with meager revenue, went public with a whimper today, as investors continued to weigh not only the value of Internet issues themselves but also that of the instituions leading them to market.

title: Grey Canada Fills Vacancy at the Top
description: Grey Canada in Toronto, part of Grey Advertising, said yesterday that it had named John Clinton president and chief executive, filling positions that had been vacant since January, when Andy Krupski resigned.

title: Aniseed and Fennel Add a Lilt to Mussels
description: MY craving for fennel-scented steamed mussels stems from a day in southern France more than 20 years ago, when I sat in a bistro and was planning rather timidly to order a salade nicoise. Just then, a huge bowl of powerfully fragrant mussels was delivered to a man at the next table, and I boldly changed my mind. The hot mussels were essentially tossed with fennel and fennel seeds, which I could see, but the licorice bouquet and flavor were far stronger than that combination alone could provide.

title: Personal Dramas Aside, Yankees Win Easily
description: Baseball bends for births and funerals, and rarely bends any further. The game is played every day, and the players are expected to be ready, and to perform. Paul O'Neill, whose father is ailing, fulfilled both obligations today.

title: The TV Ratings Are Down
description: Game 3 produced a 12.1 rating, the highest of the Knicks-San Antonio series for NBC, but 25 percent below the comparable game last year between Chicago and Utah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LILLIE
description: LEVINE-Lillie. On Saturday, June 19, 1999. Of Washington, D.C. Loving and devoted sister of Evelyn Doliner of Hewlett, N.Y. and Ruth Edelson of West Hartford, CT. Also survived by nieces, nephews, grand nieces, grand nephews, a great grand nephew and many friends. Graveside services will be held Thursday, June 24th, 2PM at Mount Zion Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice. Inquiries to DanzanskyGoldberg Memorial Chapels, Rockville, MD. 1-800-281-1471

title: Rabbi Is Charged With Threatening a Witness in a Rape Case
description: A prominent Hasidic rabbi in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on felony charges that he made death threats against a woman scheduled to testify that her father had repeatedly raped her as a child, officials with the Kings County District Attorney's office said.

title: More Countries Studying Year 2000 Disruptions, U.N. Panel Finds
description: Disruptions from year 2000 computer problems are inevitable, but are not likely to be as widespread or serious as feared just six months ago, said organizers of an international conference that ended two days of meetings today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOUGER, MINNIE
description: TOUGER-Minnie. Dearest Min, we will miss you and always think of you with love. The Stayman Family

title: Love Forged In a Crucible And Observed In Cold Light
description: What is the secret of a happy marriage, especially one that flies in the face of social convention and is fraught with personal turmoil? The mysterious emotional chemistry that unites spouses from disparate backgrounds is a major subject of Jennifer Fox's absorbing 10-hour documentary, ''An American Love Story.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Ruling Prohibits Towns From Restricting Parks
description: A state appeals court has ruled that towns in New Jersey cannot restrict the use of their public parks to local residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Microsoft's Final Witness Asked to Rebut U.S. Case
description: A Microsoft lawyer today led the company's final witness at its antitrust trial through the long chain of charges that the Government has thrown at Microsoft through eight months of trial and asked him to rebut each of them.

title: Protectionism and American Steel
description: The Senate refused yesterday to go along with the House of Representatives in voting to impose import quotas to protect the steel industry. That is a welcome rebuff to protectionist impulses that remain strong even while the American economy is booming.

title: Paying for Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: For Brubeckians, Classical Brubeck
description: Dave Brubeck, one of the most durable brand names in the jazz concert business even as he approaches his 80th year, plays piano with a sound that dates from midcentury America, a time of heavy, sophisticated-looking things like bulbous cars and stereo system consoles that took up an entire living-room wall.

title: 11 Chains and Pendants Taken by Subway Robber
description: A subway-riding robber has snatched 11 chains and pendants from the necks of passengers on the Upper West Side in recent weeks, the police said yesterday.

title: Washington G.O.P. Turns Out With Glee to Greet Bush
description: Gov. George W. Bush was warmly embraced by Washington's Republican establishment today as he swept from a Capitol sit-down with senators to a meeting with about 100 members of the House majority and finally to a glittering fund-raiser attended by a veritable who's who of Republican power brokers.

title: KNOLL ACCEPTS SWEETENED BUYOUT OFFER OF $496 MILLION
description: Knoll Inc. agreed late on Monday to a sweetened cash offer from its management and Warburg, Pincus Ventures L.P. that values the outstanding shares at about $496 million. Investors would get $28 a share for the 17.7 million shares not owned by management and Warburg, which already hold about 60 percent of the company's stock. In March, Knoll's managers and Warburg offered $25 a share to take the company private. The company, based in East Greenville, Pa., makes chairs, desks and storage systems for offices. Knoll had about $948.7 million in revenue in 1998. Its shares rose $1.75 yesterday, to $26.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Metro Business; BASF to Close Plant In Upstate New York
description: BASF Corporation, the North American unit of Europe's largest chemicals maker, BASF A.G., said yesterday that it would close its dyestuff-manufacturing plant in Rensselaer, N.Y., as the company streamlines to meet competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: INSIDE
description: Hatch Enters G.O.P. Race

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO IS LOWER. The European single currency declined as optimism for recovery in Japan spurred traders there to sell assets priced in euros. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0320, down from $1.0345 late Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: The Right Tongs: Hands You Can Count On
description: JUST a few years ago, kitchen tongs were practically unknown to home cooks. Now, no one can live without a pair. But as useful as tongs can be, they are not the perfect tool for all tasks. Tongs can tear delicate foods, and the shape can make picking up thin slices of food maddeningly difficult.

title: Metro Business; Combining Cancer Drugs
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, maker of the No. 1 cancer drug, Taxol, said yesterday that it was seeking Federal approval for the use of Taxol with Herceptin, made by Genentech Inc., in the treatment of breast cancer.

title: Commercial Property; Ex-Swingline Plant Attracts New Tenants and Jobs to Queens
description: Last month, the Swingline stapler company closed its factory in two industrial buildings in Long Island City, Queens -- one of which it had occupied for 50 years -- and moved its operations, and 450 jobs, to Nogales, Mexico.

title: Editor in Chief of Self Magazine Quits
description: Rochelle Udell, the editor in chief of Self magazine, which is published by Conde Nast, a subsidiary of Advance Publications, resigned yesterday after four years, saying she would step down when the issue marking the magazine's 20th anniversary is published in September. A successor has not been named.

title: Frederick Sachs, 61, Doctor and Professor
description: Frederick L. Sachs, a physician, hospital administrator and educator long associated with Yale University and Yale-New Haven Hospital, died on Sunday at his home in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 61.

title: Neil Jacobson, 50, Researcher Of Marital Discord and Therapy
description: Neil Jacobson, a psychology professor at the University of Washington who was known for his research on domestic violence, marital therapy and depression, died on June 2 in his hotel room in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 50 and lived in Seattle.

title: ASHLAND CONSIDERS SELLING ITS BIG STAKE IN ARCH COAL
description: Ashland Inc., the maker of Valvoline motor oil, hired the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it consider options for its 58 percent stake in Arch Coal Inc., including a possible sale. Ashland owns about 22 million Arch shares, worth $297 million, based on Monday's closing price. Ashland said it might sell the stake in Arch, the second-largest United States coal producer, and use the proceeds in its chemicals and oil businesses. Ashland, based in Covington, Ky., near Cincinnati, had $6.53 billion in sales the last fiscal year. Arch, which is based in St. Louis and had 1998 sales of $1.43 billion, was created two years ago by the merger of the Arch Mineral Corporation and Ashland Coal Inc.

title: Business Travel; Two New Airline Alliances Are Aimed at Sharpening Competition
description: Two new airline alliances were announced yesterday, between Delta Air Lines and Air France, and among AMR's American Airlines, Swissair and Sabena World Airlines of Belgium.

title: Russian Financial Eclipse Is an Opportunity for Ford
description: Looking beyond Russia's severe economic problems, the Ford Motor Company announced a preliminary agreement with the Government today to begin construction in July of an automobile factory near St. Petersburg.

title: A Trade Show With Bordeaux Style
description: EVERY two years, representatives of the wine business from all over the world gather here at a weeklong convention called Vinexpo to meet, gossip, buy and sell, make deals and, of course, party. In many respects, Vinexpo, which ended on June 18, is just another trade show. But it's different in one important way.

title: TRENWICK AGREES TO BUY CHARTWELL, A RIVAL REINSURER
description: Trenwick Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Chartwell Re Corporation for $229 million in stock in a deal that will unite two relatively small reinsurance companies. Trenwick put the total value of the deal at $368 million and said that total included the assumption of Chartwell debt and Chartwell's purchase of $100 million in reserve protection. Both companies are based in Stamford, Conn. Trenwick will exchange 0.825 of one of its shares, or $23.82, based on Monday's closing price, for each Chartwell Re share. Shares of Chartwell rose $5 each, to $20.125, and Trenwick's stock fell $2.375, to $26.50.

title: Qwest Directors to Meet About Spurned Bid
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the chief executive of Qwest Communications International, prepared last night to meet with his company's directors about whether to revise Qwest's spurned bid for control of two telephone companies, U S West and the Frontier Corporation.

title: A Techno-Bistro With Sass and Style
description: JEAN-LOUIS PALLADIN comes to New York a riddle wrapped in a mystery, trailing a fragrant plume of foie gras and truffles. In France, he was the youngest chef to win two Michelin stars. In Washington, he rose to near-monarchical power at Jean-Louis, the city's equivalent of Le Cirque pre-2000. Now in his early 50's, he arrives in New York, hanging his shingle at the Time Hotel in the theater district.

title: Ebay Deal in Germany
description: Ebay Inc. said today that it had acquired the German on-line trading company Alando.de A.G. for an undisclosed sum. Alando.de, with more than 50,000 registered users, will operate under its current address before being changed to ebay.de later this year. It was Ebay's second move into Europe, where it already owns a British auctioning site. Ebay operates the most widely used American Internet auction.

title: Ruling Raises Hurdle in Bias-Award Cases
description: A Supreme Court ruling today in an important civil rights case made it unlikely that many employees who bring successful discrimination suits against their employers will be able to collect punitive damages, a remedy that Congress made available for the first time when it amended the Civil Rights Act in 1991.

title: . . . and Smoking
description: In one of the first classroom projects to be financed by the recent settlements with the major tobacco companies, student anti-smoking art organized by the Wolfsonian Museum in Miami Beach is on display there through Sept. 8.

title: American Home Settles Diet Drug Suit
description: The American Home Products Corporation, the fifth-largest drug maker in the United States, settled a lawsuit today contending that the fen-phen diet-drug combination caused the death of a 35-year-old Texas woman.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about programs that give elementary and high school students on-line access to scientific technology referred incorrectly to the Goldstone Apple Valley Radio Telescope Program. The cost is $975 per teacher for training and software; it is not free. And while universities may provide instructors to help with it in schools, the program is not available for university students.

title: National City Transaction
description: The National City Corporation offered today to buy back the 12 percent of National Processing Inc. it does not own for about $57.8 million in cash, three years after selling shares of the second-biggest United States credit card payment processor to the public. National City, the 11th-largest United States bank, is offering $9.50 a share for the remaining 6.08 million shares of National Processing. National Processing shares surged $2.3125, or 30 percent, to $10. Shares of National City fell 12.5 cents, to $65.25.

title: Becker Stretching Out His Final Wimbledon
description: Boris Becker, the war horse who put himself out to pasture two years ago but decided to tackle Wimbledon one last time, today pawed and pounded his way out of a two-sets-to-none deficit against Scotland's Miles Maclagan and into the second round.

title: Interest Rate Roulette?
description: Last Thursday, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, all but announced higher interest rates, and no one should doubt the wisdom of an upward nudge. How can a rate increase -- now expected next week -- be justified with inflation still difficult to detect with the naked eye? Let us count the ways.

title: At the Board; A young and muted voice on New York City's school board.
description: She talks like your typical teen-ager, sprinkling her conversation with ''awesome'' and ''like, you know'' and ''whatever.'' She listens to CD's by Dave Matthews and U2. She likes hanging out with friends.

title: The Lead Around Us
description: To the Editor:

title: States Limited on Institutionalization
description: Isolating people with disabilities in big state institutions when there is no medical reason for their confinement is a form of discrimination that violates Federal disabilities law, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Johnson Insists Knicks Are Not 'Mainstream'
description: Two days after he ignored a request by league officials to speak at an interview session, Larry Johnson provided a loquacious response to those who have cast the Knicks as an unlovable band of misfits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVAVY, ZVI
description: LEVAVY-Zvi. On June 20, 1999. Advisor, teacher, community leader and visionary. Happily and harmoniously married to the late Berenice (Bardin) for over 63 years. Adored and adoring brother of Sarah Weiss, beloved father of Bardin (and Sue-Ellen), doting grandfather of Raphael and Sara Beth. A fount of compassion, wisdom and sound judgement to the many who sought his counsel whether as certified public accountant, community leader or trusted friend. Loved, respected-and now missed-by all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Zvi & Berenice Levavy Fund of the Jewish Federation of Greater Middlesex County.

title: Old Sailor Turns to Clinton To Lose Label of a Mutineer
description: In the midst of World War II, an explosion on the naval base here killed 320 men, most of them the black sailors who were loading 5,000 tons of ammunition onto ships. The blast, on the Sacramento River northeast of San Francisco, tore two ships to shreds and was felt as far away as Nevada.

title: Chile Leader Moves to Aid His Economy, And Prestige
description: President Eduardo Frei of Chile overhauled his Cabinet and announced an economic stimulus package on Monday night in response to rising unemployment and increasingly tense relations with the military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: On an Inconspicuous Block, a Japanese Surprise
description: EAST 47TH STREET between Lexington and Third Avenues doesn't look like much of a block. The most conspicuous features are scaffolding and shuttered storefronts, but as I was walking by one day, I did notice something interesting: three Japanese restaurants, practically in a row. I haven't tried the other two yet, but if they are as good as Sushi Masa, I have a lot to look forward to.

title: Elliott Works Hard to Shed a 'Soft' Label
description: There are detailed manuscripts devoted to players' abilities -- and liabilities -- in this league. You can't find them at Borders or Barnes & Noble, and few assistant coaches would risk their jobs by handing over a copy. But like labels and perceptions, they're out there, imperfect career blueprints. The pages contain more information about a player's tendencies and weaknesses than any cable breakdown segment can show.

title: Ordonez Making His Case as Mets Rally to Win
description: Shea Stadium was dark an hour after the Mets trounced the Marlins, 8-2, last night, except for a message that was displayed across the mezzanine scoreboards in right field and left field. In bright orange letters, each scoreboard read, ''Vote For Rey.'' It was an appropriate plea.

title: Stronger Oversight of Mutual Funds Sought
description: The mutual fund industry's leading trade group is expected to recommend sweeping new rules to strengthen independent directors' oversight of funds, going beyond earlier proposals by Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lead Poisoning Tied to Child Tooth Decay
description: Children exposed to higher levels of lead have more problems with tooth decay, according to a new study that suggests that lead could account for as many as 11 percent of pediatric cavities.

title: HONDA'S DOMESTIC PROFITS
description: A big Japanese auto maker, the Honda Motor Company, managed to stay profitable, though only modestly, in the domestic market as robust sales overseas drove net income to a record 305 billion yen in the year that ended on March 31, the company's president, Hiroyuki Yoshino, said in an interview.

title: Stopping America's Most Lethal Export
description: Recently, Americans have shown great concern about the reported loss of classified nuclear secrets to the Chinese. But they should be just as outraged that their country gives away many other military secrets voluntarily, in the form of high-tech arms exports. By selling advanced weaponry throughout the world, wealthy military contractors not only weaken national security and squeeze taxpayers at home but also strengthen dictators and worsen human misery abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESER, GEORGE J.
description: WIESER-George J. Died on Tuesday, June 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Penny, father of Elizabeth and George, devoted brother of Sally. President of Wieser and Wieser Literary Agency, New York, NY. An extraordinary man who has touched many lives. Visiting hours on Wednesday, June 23, 1999 from 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Adams-Cordovano Funeral Home, 15 Church St (off Rt 6), Carmel, NY. There will be a funeral mass on Thursday, June 24, 1999, at the Sacred Heart of Jesus, Putnam Lake, New York, at 10AM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Usury on Payday
description: To the Editor:

title: A Filmmaker's Faith in God, if Not in Men
description: For many moviegoers there is almost nothing like sitting through a Neil LaBute film. Nothing more depressing on screen. Nothing more likely to induce despair, or more frightening, perhaps, for what it shows us about human beings. Sexual cruelty. Domination. Hatred. Mr. LaBute shoves them in your face.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, LORETTA B.
description: DENERSTEIN-Loretta B. The touch of her hand, her love and support, her wisdom, sense of humor and sweet smile are so dearly missed by her children and grandchildren. She lives in our hearts. Susan and Harris

title: 30 Are Charged In Bid Rigging On Co-op Work
description: The long-running scandal over corruption among apartment managers in New York City widened yesterday with the indictment of 30 more management-company owners, agents and contractors -- including the manager who helped draft ethics rules intended to clean up the industry five years ago.

title: World Bank and Treasury Nominee at Odds Over Loan to China
description: In a rare public conflict between Washington and the World Bank, Treasury Secretary-designate Lawrence H. Summers said today that the United States would vote against a disputed loan to China that would resettle poor Chinese farmers to land that Tibetans claim as their own.

title: To Authorities, 'Gifting' Club Is Just Pyramid Scheme
description: The club has a basic sales pitch to new members: donate $2,000 as a ''gift'' and, if all goes well, collect $16,000 in return.

title: An Old Solution, One-Time Revenue, Is Again Placed on the Budget Table
description: Despite a $2 billion surplus, Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature plan to resort to one-time sources of money, like selling assets or tapping little-known state funds, to resolve their differences on the state budget, the lawmakers and their aides said today.

title: A Great American Wine Swirls In Turmoil
description: THE question sounds like a line from an old radio script:

title: 7Up to Discontinue Its 'Un' Campaign
description: An unconventional $40 million campaign for 7Up that was considered crucial to improving its image and sales among consumers aged 12 to 24 is being changed. A successor to the campaign, by Young & Rubicam New York, which carried the theme ''Are you an un?,'' will be introduced in the fourth quarter.

title: Reactors Largely Free of Computers
description: The Deputy Atomic Energy Minister Valentin B. Ivanov has good reason to promise that Russia's 29 nuclear reactors will be free of the year 2000 computer problem in January. The reactors, it seems, are largely free of computers.

title: Boy's Family to Sue City Over Police Shooting
description: The family of a 16-year-old Bronx boy has filed notice to sue the city for $35 million, alleging that an officer with the Street Crime Unit violated the unarmed teen-ager's civil rights last month by firing a bullet into his abdomen during a chase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: What Core Curriculum?
description: To the Editor:

title: School Prayer Won't Teach Respect for Pluralism; Temples of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Houston's Calmness Is Very Cool
description: WITH all the sociological deliberation about who Latrell Sprewell really is and what these ornery and resourceful Knicks represent, there is one alluring image this spring that will endure more than others: Allan Houston, with the ball, shoulders stooped, eyes narrowed, face-to-face with a defender he is increasingly certain he is about to beat.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I guess I still can't believe I've beaten her.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Cable Mishap Cuts Off 5,200 Phones
description: An air-conditioning contractor mistakenly cut three major telephone cables at a Bell Atlantic office on Manhattan's East Side yesterday, leaving 5,200 nearby households and businesses without telephone service, a Bell Atlantic spokesman said. Service may not be fully restored until tomorrow, according to the spokesman, John Bonomo.

title: Political Briefing; At the First Hurrah, Bush Still Leads Gore
description: When Presidential candidates officially announce they are candidates or hit the trail for the first time, they always hope that all the hoopla will give them a bounce in the polls. So who got the biggest bounce out of all that announcing and campaigning last week, Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore?

title: Chevron Lowers Earnings After March Fire
description: The Chevron Corporation, the fourth-largest United States oil company, said loss of fuel production from its San Francisco-area refinery after a fire in March would lower second-quarter earnings by about $100 million, or 15 cents a share.

title: 3Com Posts Earnings Above Predictions
description: The 3Com Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that came in a penny above analysts' expectations based on strong growth in products used to manage data flow over networks.

title: SINGAPORE TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL
description: Preparing to compete under deregulation, Singapore's main telephone company signed a cross-marketing agreement with Cisco Systems Inc. Singapore Telecommunications' monopoly on fixed-line services will end next April when a new telecommunications consortium, Star Hub Ltd., begins operations. Under the new agreement, Cisco will sell the services of Singapore Telecommunications in Singapore, and the Singapore company will offer customers new services using Cisco technology to integrate voice and data communications over digital phone lines. Wayne Arnold

title: Political Briefing; California Primary: Conservatives Stumble
description: The Republican Presidential primary in California is a winner-take-all affair, which means that the winner collects every delegate in what is the largest pot of delegates in the nation. But in years past, the primary was held too late in the nominating season to have much impact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAF, JULES
description: LEAF-Jules. The officers and members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member, Jules Leaf. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his children and other members of his family. Samuel G. Weinberg, President

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN AIRLINE MONOPOLY
description: The Government-controlled holding group for Mexico's two largest airlines, Mexicana S.A. and Aeromexico S.A., is using illegal monopoly practices, according to the chairman of Mexico's anti-monopoly commission, Fernando Sanchez Ugarte. He said the holding company, Cintra, is charging as much as 30 percent above the market rate for flights to at least 26 destinations in Mexico. The company controls more than 70 percent of domestic flights. Rick Wills

title: Credit Card Dealer To Take a Charge
description: The Metris Companies, a marketer of credit cards to people with bad or limited credit histories, said today that it would take a one-time charge of $152.4 million for the conversion of preferred stock by a big investor.

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS WHO IS PROTECTED BY DISABILITY LAW
description: Resolving one of the most pressing questions of Federal disability law, the Supreme Court ruled today that people with physical impairments who can function normally when they wear their glasses or take their medicine generally cannot be considered disabled, and therefore do not come within the law's protection against employment discrimination.

title: Mass Grave, Now Empty, Called Massacre Evidence
description: Serbian forces dug up the bodies of some 100 Kosovo Albanians from a mass grave here late last month and carried the bodies off, the municipal official in charge of burials said today.

title: SALE OF TLC BEATRICE'S TAYTO UNIT TO FINISH LIQUIDATION
description: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Irish snack food company, Tayto, to Cantrell & Cochrane Ltd., an Irish beverage company, for a total price of $116.5 million. The transaction, expected to close this summer, will virtually complete the liquidation of TLC Beatrice, a company formed in 1987 through a $985 million buyout led by Reginald F. Lewis, who died in 1993. The company said it intended to distribute the proceeds from the sale, along with about $200 million in cash, to shareholders.

title: ALLTEL TO BUY LIBERTY CELLULAR FOR ABOUT $514 MILLION
description: The Alltel Corporation, which sells local and wireless telephone services to about six million people in the Southeast and Midwest, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Liberty Cellular Inc. for stock worth more than $514 million to add Kansas to its Midwestern operations. Alltel, based in Little Rock, Ark., will issue seven million shares to acquire Liberty, which has about 150,000 customers buying services under its brand names Kansas Cellular and Kini. Alltel will also assume about $90 million in Liberty Cellular debt. Shares of Alltel closed at $73.4375 yesterday, up 87.5 cents, before the agreement was announced. The combined company will have about $6 billion in sales and more than 24,000 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH (NEE WASSER)
description: BERGER-Ruth (nee Wasser). Beloved wife of the late Morton M. Devoted mother of Stephen Paul and Anna. Cherished grandmother of Marty and Eric. Dear sister of Max and Rose Wasser and Natalie and Milton Wasserman. Loving aunt of many. Service Wednesday, 11:30AM at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51 St, NYC.

title: Police Shoot Israeli Lawmaker, an Arab, During Protest
description: Azmi Bishara earned a dubious distinction when he visited a slum neighborhood here to join a demonstration by its Israeli Arab residents on Sunday night. He became the first member of Parliament to be shot with a rubber-coated metal bullet by the Israeli police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on June 14 about a Russian blockade of the airport in Pristina, Kosovo, referred incorrectly to the military personnel. They were not tank commanders; the equipment shown was an armored vehicle, not a tank.

title: But Generals Say Air War Achieved Alliance's Goal : NATO Misjudged Bombing Damage
description: PARIS  NATO officials acknowledged Tuesday that the alliance knocked out a good deal less Serbian military equipment in Kosovo than had been thought, but said that ultimately the air campaign was successful in forcing Belgrade to concede defeat without a ground offensive by allied forces.

title: Accounts
description: * Intelligent Life Corp., Palm Beach, Fla., which operates Web sites including Bankrate.com, to Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: A Return to Empire Would Be a Balkan Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHILOH INDUSTRIES , Mansfield, Ohio, a producer of steel products for the automotive and appliance industries, agreed to acquire MTD Automotive, Cleveland, a maker of platform systems for the automotive industry, from MTD Properties Inc. for $40 million in cash and stock.

title: Clinton Meets Refugees, and Pledges to Aid Kosovo
description: In the shadow of Kosovo, President Clinton came today to meet face-to-face with the people on whose behalf he had fought the war. He heard their stories of brutality and vowed that he would help make their homeland safe.

title: Governor Explains Wife's Lie to Customs
description: The First Lady of Florida was worried about how her husband would react to the fact that she had spent $19,000 on clothes and jewelry during a shopping spree in Paris, and that is why she told United States Customs Service agents that she had spent only $500, Gov. Jeb Bush says.

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Backs U.N. Payment, But More Hurdles Remain
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill today authorizing the payment of more than $800 million in back dues to the United Nations but cutting future American contributions to the organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIGER, BLANCHE
description: STEIGER-Blanche, age 89, on Sunday, June 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman L. Steiger, devoted mother of Roberta Keller and the late Richard Klein. Proud grandmother of Michael, Pari, Jordan and Russell. Great grandmother of Hunter. Dear sister of Hilda Wagner. Services and entombment were held yesterday.

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Therapy Eases Takeoffs; Learning to Conquer the Fun-Limiting Fear of Flight
description: Before Maureen Werner's flight takes off, she counts the number of children, priests, nuns and rabbis who are among her fellow passengers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: The Wedding Beat
description: It may not have been the wedding of the century, but the latest royal marriage involving the British royal family still proved to be a potent draw for several cable networks that carried it Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Thursday referred incorrectly to William P. Boardman, who was named chairman of Visa International. He also remains senior vice president at the Bank One Corporation. The entry also misstated the headquarters location of Visa International. It is Foster City, Calif., not New York.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about four deaths in an explosion in Kosovo on Monday referred incorrectly to the victims. They were two British Army soldiers in the NATO peacekeeping force and two civilians, not four British peacekeepers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODOFSKY, MIRIAM
description: GODOFSKY - Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Elias. Loving mother of Marilyn Schimmel and the late Laura Horowitz. Cherished grandmother of Mike, Ellen, Natalie and Jason. Dear sister of Pauline and Danny. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 9:30 AM Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Political Briefing; For Religious Right, It's a Crowded Field
description: Some conservative Republicans are beginning to worry that there are too many hard-right conservatives vying for the party's Presidential nomination. They fear a splintering of conservative clout, especially that of social and religious conservatives, who account for at least a third of the party's membership in many states and, when cohesive, can sometimes steer things their way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, THOMAS F.
description: COUGHLIN-Thomas F. On June 20, 1999. The Board of Directors, administration, staff and residents of Isabella Geriatric Center in New York deeply mourn the passing of Thomas F. Coughlin, our former President and Chief Executive Officer from 1977 to 1992. His contributions to Isabella will be long remembered and he will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his daughters Barbara Damon-Hill, Carol McKay and his entire family. Richard B. Harding, Jr., Chairman Mark J. Kator, Pres. and CEO

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Horses Euthanized After Stall Fire
description: Two horses had to be euthanized and a third was in serious condition last night after a fire raced through four stalls at Belmont Park .

title: Late Round of Selling Helps Depress the Main Indicators
description: Stock prices staged a broad retreat yesterday as a further rise in long-term interest rates and a late round of selling depressed the main market gauges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, LOUIS R., M.D.
description: WASSERMAN-Louis R., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our outstanding colleague. Dr. Wasserman served as the Director of Hematology for nearly 20 years and helped establish Mount Sinai as a leading center in this area. He was a world expert in the field of polycythemia and received numerous awards in research, clinical affairs, and teaching. He will be honored and remembered as one of the ''giants'' and for his commitment to excellence. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Julia and to his family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Cecilia Danieli, 56, Is Dead; Developer of Steel Minimills
description: Cecilia Danieli, who helped revolutionize the world steel industry by developing the compact steel mills known in the industry as minimills, died last Thursday of cancer. She was 56.

title: San Antonio Hears Lonesome Whistle Blow
description: Not wanting to belie their clean and wholesome image by complaining about the officiating in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals, the San Antonio Spurs heaped praise upon the Knicks yesterday while refraining from the most overt forms of referee bashing.

title: Breezy Access and Poses In a Garden of Delight
description: To look or not to look. That was the freedom Sara Rudner gave her audience on Saturday afternoon when she presented ''Dancing-on-View'' at St. Mark's Church. The work was scheduled to last four hours. But dancegoers were invited to see as much of it as they wished. They could stay for everything, watch for a while and leave, or come and go at whim.

title: Milosevic Takes Measures To Restrict Demonstrations
description: The Yugoslav Parliament is expected to meet on Thursday to lift the state of wartime emergency, but it will also retain certain restrictions, passing them into law, to deal with expected demonstrations by opposition parties, Yugoslav officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: BRAZIL BANK DEAL
description: The largest Brazilian bank not under control of the Government, Banco Bradesco S.A., expanded its reach in the consumer banking market with the acquisition of Banco do Estado da Bahia S.A., or Baneb, for $147 million. The purchase allows Bradesco to expand its business in Bahia, a state in northeastern Brazil. The sale of Baneb is part of a Government push to transfer poorly capitalized state banks to the private sector. Simon Romero

title: On-Line Broker Prices Shares
description: National Discount Brokers Group Inc. priced its sale of 2.6 million new shares of common stock at $33 apiece, raising at least $85.8 million for advertising and computers for the No. 10 on-line brokerage firm.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Stanley Cup Series Ratings Are Up
description: Dallas's triple-overtime victory in Buffalo in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals on ESPN produced a 3.51 rating and helped the cable network to a 3.09 average rating for Games 3, 4 and 6, up by 17 percent from last year.

title: Salinger Letters Are Sold And May Return to Sender
description: The saga of the hermitic author, the confessional writer, the love letters and the auction block came full circle yesterday and ended, at least in theory, happily for everyone.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Measure to Limit Imports Of Steel Is Killed by Senate

title: Our Towns; From Russia, A Showcase For Adoptions
description: IT was pure Hollywood corn. A dozen hopelessly cute children from the orphanage put on a show at a local church while country folks from miles around cheered and wept. Even Frank Capra might have left the scene on the cutting room floor.

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Day for Coca-Cola in European Illness Scare
description: The European crisis for Coca-Cola began to ease in France today, but the 15-nation European Union announced plans to carry out health inspections of its own in plants in Belgium and France that had produced soft drinks blamed for outbreaks of illness early this month.

title: S3 TO PAY $173 MILLION IN STOCK FOR DIAMOND MULTIMEDIA
description: S3 Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. for $173.3 million in stock. Diamond Multimedia, based in San Jose, Calif., makes programs for creating Internet media content as well as the Rio MP3 player. It had 1998 sales of $608.6 million. S3, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes graphics and video accelerators for computers and had revenue of $224.6 million in 1998. In the transaction, expected to be completed by the fall, Diamond Multimedia stockholders will exchange each of their shares for 0.52 share of S3. Based on S3's Monday closing price of $9.4375, the offer values each Diamond Multimedia share at $4.91, below the closing price on Monday. Shares of Diamond Multimedia closed yesterday at $4.75, down 93.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOISINGTON, NATALIE ELLIOT CARR
description: HOISINGTON-Natalie Elliot Carr. Of Huntington Station, NY on June 21st. Wife of the late Theodore Hoisington, also predeceased by first husband Walter Burke Coll. Mother of Dr. Richard Coll, Dr. Samuel Hoisington, I. Ashley Coll and Marjorie Coll Prepon; also surviving are 11 grandchildren and 1 great-grandchild. Funeral from Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Boulevard, Watchung, NJ on June 24th at 9:30 a.m. Followed by a Funeral Mass at St. Mary's Church, Watchung at 10:00 a.m. Interment Indian River Cemetery, Clinton, CT. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERER, FREDERICK BENTLEY
description: BIERER-Frederick Bentley. Died June 21, 1999, at the age of 82, in New York City after a long illness. He was raised in Furth, Germany and joined The British Army in 1940, serving in the Pioneer, Commando, Tanks and Intelligence Corps. He emigrated to America in 1946, and married Sally Erlanger in 1950, who filled his heart. He founded the Bentley Industrial Corporation, a machine tool importing company that engaged his exceptional aptitude for finding solutions to life's problems, mechanical and othewise. Fred is survived by a grateful and happy family including his wife, three children, all of whom became physicians, their spouses and, as of now, five grandchildren. He enjoyed rich and long - lasting friendships throughout his life and, until his lasts minutes, was able to inspire and amuse those who loved him. The service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), on Thursday June 24, 1999, at 4 P.M. Family flowers only; donations may be made in his name to The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, 333 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10001, an organization that assisted his family's escape from Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Such Fresh Ingredients: The Chef As Beefcake
description: THE advertisements are titled, ''famous chefs naked with their blender.'' The first one appeared in the June issue of Food Arts, a glossy trade magazine: Jean-Louis Palladin wearing nothing but some jewelry, his glasses and a strategically placed Vita-Mix.

title: A Deal to Demilitarize the K.L.A.
description: With Serbian troops gone from Kosovo, the most important challenge to peace in the province comes from the ethnic Albanian guerrillas, the Kosovo Liberation Army. On Monday, NATO and the K.L.A. agreed that the group would demilitarize more quickly than previously planned -- but in exchange, NATO would give ''due consideration'' to making the K.L.A. an army in the style of a National Guard. The agreement, while imperfect, will contribute to the safety of Kosovo's Serbian citizens and NATO peacekeepers by disarming the K.L.A. In the long run it may increase chances that Kosovo will enjoy moderate, civilian leadership.

title: Who Says Movies Aren't to Blame for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yield Rises To 6.06% For 30-Year Treasuries
description: Prices for Treasuries fell yesterday as corporate borrowers prepared to sell about $10 billion in debt. Traders and analysts also said that expectations continued to weigh on the market that the Federal Reserve will increase short-term rates at its two-day policy meeting next week.

title: THE CHEF; The Spirit of Summer, Captured in a Soup
description: A SINGLE vegetable brought to its essence -- that's the meaning of summer soup. Winter soups, with their soothing richness and warmth, tend to be a composition of ingredients -- beef-vegetable, chicken-noodle, chowder, minestrone.

title: To Fight Drinking . . .
description: Binge drinking at college is linked to a terrible toll on brains and bodies, on and off the highway. But a study at the University of Washington suggests that traditional warnings -- exhibits of wrecked cars or ''Dragnet'' melodramas -- are not effective for most hard-drinking students.

title: Terrorism Suspect Charges Toward Judge, but Is Tackled
description: A defendant in a Federal terrorism case leaped out of his chair in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday and raced toward the judge, causing chaos before he was tackled and subdued by a United States marshal.

title: Top Agent Loses Role At I.C.M. Talent Agency
description: For decades, Sam Cohn had been the premier film agent in New York, a shrewd, cantankerous and somewhat eccentric figure who represented some of the biggest movie stars and filmmakers in the business.
