title: Arena Negotiations Have Resumed
description: Talks between the Islanders and Nassau County about a new arena for the hockey team resumed yesterday, more than six months after the sides left the bargaining table.

title: Beware of Overtime Rule Changes
description: Proper praise for the champion Dallas Stars has been delayed long enough by the controversy over the Stanley Cup-winning goal by Brett Hull in triple overtime in Game 6 of the finals at 1:30 A.M. Sunday. And the National Hockey League's abolition Monday of the video review procedure for goal-crease interference has overshadowed other rules changes that could be even more significant. As the first week between seasons gains momentum, let us quickly run down the agenda, before the Hall of Fame announces its inductees today, before the N.H.L. hands out its awards tomorrow, before the Pittsburgh Penguins return to bankruptcy court tomorrow, before the Atlanta Thrashers draft their expansion roster Friday and before the best 18-year-olds are chosen in the amateur entry draft Saturday.

title: 32 Receive Grants From MacArthur Foundation
description: The annual grants popularly known as the genius awards announced yesterday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation were heavily weighted toward the New York area, home to about a third of the 32 recipients.

title: Pietro Deiro Jr., Music Publisher With Passion for Accordion, 85
description: Pietro Deiro Jr., a music publisher devoted to the expansion of the repertory for the accordion, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mario Soldati, 92, Film Director and Writer
description: Mario Soldati, a prolific Italian writer and film director, died on Saturday at his home in Tellaro, near La Spezia. He was 92.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: The Many Splendors of Paella
description: IN ''Paella! Spectacular Rice Dishes From Spain'' (Henry Holt, $27.50), Penelope Casas gives nearly 50 recipes for this single dish.

title: Dr. Louis R. Wasserman, 88, Authority on Blood
description: Dr. Louis Robert Wasserman, an authority on the diagnosis and treatment of blood diseases and the founder of one of the nation's foremost hematology training programs, died on Monday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 88 and lived in Sandy Hook, Conn.

title: Madrid Journal; The Hispanic World Speaks, and Spain Listens
description: Few places in Madrid are more exclusive than an austere mansion on Ruiz de Alarcon Street, just above the rambling Prado Museum.

description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Home Lender Settles Case Alleging Bias
description: The biggest home-equity loan company in the state agreed yesterday to settle a lawsuit planned by State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, who accused the company of violating the civil rights of thousands of minority residents in Brooklyn and Queens by enticing them into loans they could not afford.

title: Winter Welcomes Summer, and Invites the Crowd to Sit Back and Listen
description: The first long moments of the saxophonist Paul Winter's sixth annual Summer Solstice Celebration, which began a three-performance run at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Friday night, demanded something unusual: that the audience merely listen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O BRIEN, JOHN J.
description: O BRIEN-John J. Died June 20, 1999 at age 48 of melanoma. Employed at the New York Prebyterian Hospital-Cornell Medical Center as an Administrator. Former employee of Eastern Airlines. Survived by brother Michael, sister Pat and companion James.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CANADA PENSION PLAN INVESTMENT BOARD, Toronto, named John MacNaughton president and chief executive. He had been president of Nesbitt Burns Inc.

title: Commerce Report Describes Economic Benefits From Internet
description: The financial benefits of the Internet and high technology extend beyond the quick riches they have brought high-profile entrepreneurs and investors in recent years to the nation's economy as a whole, a new Government study shows.

title: In Solos, Anna Halprin Presents Herself
description: Since the 1950's Anna Halprin has been one of California's most influential dance artists, attracting students from across the country to her studio near San Francisco. She has increasingly devoted herself to exploring ways in which dance can foster personal growth and communal solidarity. On a recent visit to New York she led workshops on creativity and healing.

title: Food Retailer for Sale
description: The Fleming Companies, a large United States distributor of groceries, said today that it planned to sell its 20 Boogaarts Food Stores in Kansas and Nebraska because they do not meet the company's performance objectives. Fleming, based in Oklahoma City, hopes to sell the chain to independent retailers that it currently supplies.

title: Senator Hatch Says He Plans To Enter Race for Presidency
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah conservative who came to Washington to battle Democratic liberals but has moved toward the center on health and children's issues, said today that he would seek the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Sketchy Campaign Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Neighbors Attacked Neighbors, Justice Is Far From Easy
description: Frightened by Albanians streaming back into this central Kosovo town, Snezana Ivanovic and Sabrija Popic sought out a newly arrived British soldier on Saturday and asked for ''guarantees of protection.'' The two women, one Serbian and one Gypsy, feared retaliation as Albanians returned here to find their dwellings and shops looted or burned.

title: In Losing Its Party Location, A Magazine Gains the Buzz
description: WHAT: A party to celebrate the debut of Talk magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ALFRED, M.D. FACS
description: BERMAN-Alfred, M.D. FACS. 88 years of age, of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Bernice for 53 years. Father of Steven and Wendy Berman of Vermont; Michael and Rachel Berman, and Peter and Jean Berman of New York. He was a devoted family man who took pride in his grandchildren, Megan, Travis and Josh, Ava and Eric, and Jason and Matthew. Dr. Berman was combat surgeon during WW II, and during his career served as Chief of Surgery at Flushing and Booth Memorial Hospitals. His life will be celebrated in remembering how he used his gifts and compassion to ease the suffering of others and save many lives. He will be remembered for his dedication to his golf game, his love of the New York Yankees, and for his great sense of humor.

title: With bare legs in sight, Gillette begins its seasonal push to drive razor sales for women.
description: THE Gillette Company, seeking to take advantage of the bare-leg season of summer to increase sales of women's razors at a time when its overall business has stalled, recently began a $35 million advertising campaign for its Sensor Excel razor for women.

description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES. Sugar prices rose as stronger-than-expected demand from Russia absorbed increased exports from Brazil, the world's biggest grower. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.16 cent, to 5.98 cents a pound.

title: Harvard Gets Dutch Master Drawings
description: A trove of 17th-century Dutch drawings -- including works by Rembrandt, Pieter Bruegel, Adriaen van Ostade and Jacques de Gheyn 2d -- has been given to the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University by Maida and George Abrams of Newton, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, GERTRUDE
description: PARKER-Gertrude. Our heartfelt sympathy to our dear friends Patty, Alan, Adam and Josh Abramson on the loss of your beloved mother and grandmother. Laurie, Melanie, Elias and Marisa Kefalidis

title: F.C.C. Clears Vodafone Deal
description: Vodafone Group P.L.C.'s $77 billion purchase of Airtouch Communications Inc. won approval today from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Snagging 'Austin'
description: Continuing its efforts to corral many of the biggest box office movies for their first broadcast run, TBS announced yesterday that it had acquired initial broadcast rights to this summer's huge hit, ''Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLE, JOSEPH S., M.D. F.A.C.S.
description: MULLE-Joseph S., M.D. F.A.C.S. On June 20, 1999 of Jamaica Estates, NY. Born in Greenpoint on November 24, 1911. Educated at Boys High, he graduated from St. John's University in 1933. He received his medical degree from St. Louis University in 1937, specializing in orthopedic surgery. He served in the United States Army as a Lt. Colonel from 1941 to 1946. Former Chief of Orthopedic Surgery of Brooklyn State and Mary Immaculate Hospitals, and Director of Orthopedic Surgery at Catholic Medical Center from 1970 to 1982. In 1998 St. John's University conferred upon him the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. He was a member of the Knights of Malta. He was a member of Hempstead and Mariner Sands Golf Clubs. Beloved husband of the late Anne, loving father and father-in-law to Tony and Antoinette. Cherished grandfather of Joseph, Anne Marie, Thomas and his wife Caryn. Fond brother of Anthony of Nashville, TN and Catherine Schnakenberg of Wallingford, CT. Visiting will be held Tuesday 7-10 P.M. and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. at the R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home Inc (224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY). A funeral mass will be held on Thursday at 10:15 A.M. at the Immaculate Conception Monastery, Jamaica Estates, NY. Entombment will follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461-9955 would be greatly appreciated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about the renovation of the Central Synagogue in Manhattan by Hugh Hardy and the firm of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates included an erroneous date, supplied by the architect, for the earliest possible use of the sanctuary. It is the fall of 2000, not this fall.

title: Remedy for Yonkers Schools Is Rejected by Federal Court
description: In the latest turn in the complex, 20-year-old Yonkers school desegregation case, a Federal Court of Appeals said today that the school board and the N.A.A.C.P. had not proved that the wide gaps in academic achievement between white and minority students and the school system's low expectations for minority students were the results of segregation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BACHMANN, EMILE
description: BACHMANN-Emile. Dad, my heart aches in your absence, yet rejoices in your memory. Love, Karen

title: CALENDAR
description: From Now-Sunny Sweden

title: Senate Kills Effort to Impose Tight Limits on Steel Imports
description: The Senate killed a bill today that would have sharply restricted imports of foreign steel to the United States, a blow to unions and steelmakers and a victory for President Clinton, who had warned that the legislation would revive protectionism.

title: Lehman Brothers' Earnings Rise Above Expectations
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were far above analysts' expectations.

title: An Ancient Grain, Now Au Courant
description: THE cachet of peasant food in this country and in Italy just keeps growing. Farro is one of the more recent examples. As Americans have been discovering this whole-grain variety of wheat, Italians have been rediscovering it. It's now found in the best Italian restaurants, both here and in the mother country. And when it's cooked like risotto and served as farrotto, it may eventually displace arborio rice because it is not just ''new,'' but also a good source of fiber.

title: N.B.A. Seeking Changes In Rules
description: From the former Bad Boy point guard, Isiah Thomas, to the take-no-prisoners coach, Pat Riley, a 16-member committee of coaches, players and owners convened yesterday with essentially one job: to transform the roughhouse National Basketball Association back into an esthetically appealing game.

title: Lagging on Year 2000 Bug, Russia Starts Major Effort
description: Armed with thick repair manuals and rosters of experts, Russian officials have opened an all-out campaign to expel the so-called year 2000 bug from the nation's eight million computers, their microchips and their programs.

title: In the Eyes of the Beholder
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLER, IRA
description: HILLER-Ira, on June 23, 1999, at age 58. We deeply mourn the untimely death of our dear friend, after a heroic battle with cancer. Son of the late Edith and Morris Hiller, brother of the late Arnold Hiller, former partner of Yohalem, Gillman and Co. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. Services today, 10AM at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. Donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Marbury Is for Home Team
description: Stephon Marbury, the Nets' point guard who grew up in Coney Island dreaming of leading the Knicks to championships, attended last night's game as a guest of N.B.A. Entertainment.

title: Killings Rise 6% Over '98 As Other Crimes Decline
description: The number of killings reported so far this year in New York City has risen 6 percent over the comparable period last year, driven by an increase in homicides in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The rise comes as other types of crime continue to drop and six months after the city recorded its lowest annual number of homicides since 1964.

title: STATES ARE GIVEN NEW LEGAL SHIELD BY SUPREME COURT
description: Thrusting the doctrine of state sovereignty well beyond existing boundaries, the Supreme Court placed sharp new curbs today on the ability of Congress to make Federal law binding on the states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Credit for Macintosh
description: To the Editor:

description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As more planning goes into after-hours trading, the N.A.S.D. considers taking Nasdaq public.
description: EVERYONE agrees that after-hours trading is coming. But nobody seems to know when.

title: Ruling Upsets Advocates for the Disabled
description: Declaring that a majority of the Supreme Court fundamentally misunderstood the purpose of the Americans with Disabilities Act, advocates for the disabled began to scramble today for legal and political strategies to counter a Court ruling this week that limited the law's protections.

title: As Yen Weakens, Japan's Neighbors Begin to Worry
description: HONG KONG  As investors stampeded out of Asia in 1997, igniting a global financial crisis after Thailand floated its currency, many analysts concluded that the world had been too sanguine about foreign-exchange risk and its potential to wreak havoc on capital markets and national economies.

title: Sports of The Times; A Thin Line Exists Between The Fouling And the Playing
description: IF the National Basketball Association controlled track and field, the league would have devised a system by now to make sure the favorite runners win and the popular jumpers triumph.

title: Youthful Web Network Has a Modest Goal: Replacing TV
description: IN the back office of a Hollywood studio, Arlo Eisenberg, a 25-year-old with lamb-chop sideburns and fading black nail polish, was staring at a three-inch-square video clip on a computer monitor about in-line skating.

title: Lively Modernism in a Fishing Village
description: When the sun beats the rain, as it did over the weekend, and the wind does not chill your bones but rushes cloud patterns of navy blue and ocher across the North Sea, this little town on the Suffolk Coast can seem one of the best places on earth to be in early summer.

title: Tiffany in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NODELMAN, GEORGE
description: NODELMAN - George. Loving husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Jared. Cherished grandfather of Seth and Ilisa and great grandfather of Blair. A Graveside funeral is scheduled for Friday, 1pm at Beth David Cemetery Elmont, NY. For details call I.J. Morris at 516-486-2500

title: MULTEX.COM TO BUY RESEARCH COMPANY FOR $162 MILLION
description: Multex.com Inc., a distributor of investment research, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the on-line financial information provider Market Guide Inc. for about $162.4 million in stock. Multex.com, in New York, said that it would exchange one share for each Market Guide share. Multex.com's shares fell $2.3125, to $26.6875, while the stock of Market Guide, based in Lake Success, N.Y., fell $1.375, to $21.625. After the acquisition, Multex.com's investment research and earnings estimates will be available through Market Guide's Internet site and more than 100 other sources, including America Online Inc.

title: New Palm Shows Up, Unattached
description: THE 3Com Corporation's Palm VII handheld computer, which is now being sold only in the New York City area, is like one of those odd, futuristic devices that movie aliens are always accidentally leaving behind after they touch down briefly to abduct a few Earthlings. Later, someone finds it on the ground, pokes it a few times, lifts the built-in antenna -- ''Hmm, I wonder what this thing does?'' -- and jumps back in astonishment when the little box comes to life and magically displays the up-to-the-minute score of the Knicks game.

title: Few Tears Are Shed As Divx Joins the 8-Track
description: WHEN Circuit City announced the death of Divx last week, many people in the consumer electronics industry cheered because Divx, a hybrid DVD, may have been the most reviled new product in the modern history of the industry.

title: Renovating the Reichstag
description: Norman Foster has just won the coveted Pritzker Architecture Prize. Coming soon: Martin Pawley's ''Norman Foster: A Global Architecture'' (Universe/Rizzoli; $25), written before he won the prize and available, fortuitously, next month. Inside is the dramatic story of Mr. Foster's recent coup, the bold, symbolic $330 million renovation of the Reichstag in Berlin, right, with its inverted cone, below, called a ''daylight chandelier.'' Books can be ordered from (800) 522-6657.

title: Late Trading Moderates Early Losses in a Mixed Session
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday after late buying lifted the main gauges from their daily lows while long-term interest rates continued to climb.

title: Virtual Golf, Without the Caddies or Carts
description: PGATOUR.COM

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
description: Bolstering its cyberspace credentials, Lucent Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to sell up to $1 billion worth of equipment to Level 3 Communications Inc., the new long-distance communications carrier, for transmitting phone calls using Internet technology.

title: Home Theater Infiltrates High-End Audio's Hallowed Halls
description: FOUL winds are blowing through the hallowed halls of high-end audio. Some members of this closely knit fraternity are crawling into bed with the mongrels -- abandoning their principles, in the view of their colleagues, by succumbing to the temptations of the home theater movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASKELL, LISELOTTE
description: KASKELL-Liselotte, of Riverside Drive, died peacefully in her sleep on June 21, after a brief illness at St. Luke's Hospital. She is survived by three daughters and six grandchildren, all residing in Germany. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Even in Towns NATO Hit, Albanians Fault Serbs
description: Syl Shigjeqi stepped into the shower today through a hole in the wall of his house, up a ramp of rubble, over the faucet's skeleton, a shaving brush, soap and, somehow, teacups. There is no shortage of destruction in Kosovo, but here it is possible to see what NATO's bombs added to it.

title: Hitters' Row: Williams and Martinez
description: The Yankees wipe away the Tampa Bay Devil Rays like lint, so it's hard to accept everything they accomplish at face value. But there is no question the lineup changes made last week are helping Bernie Williams and the entire Yankee offense.

title: Sports of The Times; Spurs Earn Curtain Call On Broadway
description: THEY won it the way Red Holzman's old Knicks used to. The San Antonio Spurs claimed the game they needed at Madison Square Garden, sending thousands out into midtown late last night thinking the miracle run is all but over. They did without a celebrity show, without a Jordan or a Reggie to stylishly plant a flag in the heart of the home team. The Spurs spread the offense around but won with interior defense as imposing as the New York skyline.

title: A Festive End to City Ballet's Celebration Season
description: The New York City Ballet will continue celebrating its 50th anniversary at its summer home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in July. But this week's performances of George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' will bring the company's anniversary season at the New York State Theater to a close on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about legal action by the European Union against Belgium for its handling of the discovery of the cancer-causing chemical dioxin in food misstated the timing. The action began Monday, not Tuesday.

title: A Principal Finds a Way to Cope With the Perennial Turmoil in District 12
description: Althea Serrant, the principal of Community School 61 in the central Bronx, has a strategy for dealing with the problems perennially plaguing her bosses in District 12: She ignores them.

title: After Kosovo, Clinton Faces Domestic Issues
description: With the conflict in Kosovo more or less behind him and impeachment a fading memory, President Clinton is eager to reassert himself in the familiar realms of domestic policy and politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLEWELLYN DAVIES, POLLY PEARCE
description: LLEWELLYN Davies - Polly Pearce, widow of Ruthven Llewellyn Davies, in London, June 14, after a long illness. Beloved daughter of Moira Pearce Giddings and sister of Jane Pearce Carey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIGAN, SUSAN M.
description: COSTIGAN-Susan M. On June 15, 1999. Beloved daughter of Marie and Robert Casey. Cherished sister of Kathleen de Vries and Kevin Costigan. Memorial service 5PM Sunday, June 27th at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Memorial visiting from 3pm till time of service.

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: SKW TROSTBERG TO BUY CHEMICAL BUSINESSES FROM WITCO
description: SKW Trostberg A.G., a German company that is a leading maker of chemicals for the building industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy fabric-care chemical businesses from the Witco Corporation for an undisclosed sum to expand its chemical product range. SKW said it would buy most of Witco's Oleochemicals and Derivatives Group, which makes chemicals used in fabric softeners and other products for home and personal care. The businesses had 1998 sales of about $260 million, SKW said. Witco is based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Leiter Stacks The Deck For Mets
description: Seven superb innings, seven overpowering strikeouts and four victories in his last four starts have made it pretty clear that the staff's ace, Al Leiter, has found his way back into the Mets' deck. And oh how that deck has been stacked lately, as the Florida Marlins unfortunately discovered for the second straight game last night, losing by 6-3 to a team that has won 13 of its last 16 games.

title: Intern Sharing a Room At N.Y.U. Dies Suddenly
description: A Georgetown University student in New York on an internship was pronounced dead Tuesday evening after being found unconscious in her New York University dormitory room, the police said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP SHARPLY. Crude oil prices soared after weekly inventory data showed a sharp decline in stockpiles, signaling a worldwide glut is easing. In New York, crude oil for August delivery rose 70 cents, to $18.45 barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: French Court Rejects Suit By Dealer Linked to Nazis
description: A French court today rejected a claim for $1 million in damages brought by the Wildenstein family, the New York-based dynasty of international art dealers, against an American writer who suggested in a recent book that the French-Jewish family did business with Nazi officials during Germany's wartime occupation of France.

title: The Cashless Society?
description: To the Editor:

title: Troy's Repository
description: To the Editor:

title: Fabrics by Manuel Canovas In Everything but Name
description: A line of 20 boldly patterned, colorful fabrics by Manuel Canovas is arriving next month -- without fanfare and without the Canovas name. Some background: Last year, Colefax & Fowler bought the French fabric house of Manuel Canovas and the rights to his name. And so now, Mr. Canovas is designing cotton and cotton-blend fabrics for Osborne & Little using his wife's maiden name, Lorca. Manufactured in France, the luxurious fabrics are $75 to $125 a yard, to the trade only, at Osborne & Little in the D.& D. Building.

title: Lehman Fined $100,000 in Sale of Hot Initial Stock Offerings
description: Lehman Brothers, one of the nation's largest investment banks, has been censured and fined $100,000 as part of a settlement of regulatory charges that included an accusation that it failed to comply with market rules intended to insure that public investors get a fair share of hot initial public offerings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: DeLay and Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Stall Senate to Force Debate on Health Care
description: The Senate was paralyzed for a third straight day today as Democrats pressed for immediate consideration of legislation to define patients' rights within their health insurance plans. Republicans rejected the Democrats' timetable and terms, and leaders from both parties sought in vain to devise a way around the impasse.

title: Qwest Plans To Sweeten Hostile Bids
description: Qwest Communications International announced yesterday that it would sweeten its unsolicited offers for both U S West, the smallest of the regional Bell telephone companies, and the Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's largest long-distance companies, only days after both companies had spurned its advances.

title: Old Newsgroups in New Packages
description: THE ads are hard to miss. In one, a photograph of a crying newborn is shown next to a debate about circumcision (''My advice: do it before he has memory cells''). In another, a mustachioed woman (''plucking hurts too much'') is told where she can find a good place to have electrolysis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Van Gogh Fever Shifts to His New Amsterdam Home
description: When the Van Gogh Museum closed for renovation and expansion in September, the focus of Vincent worship shifted to an exhibition of ''Van Gogh's van Goghs'' traveling to Washington and Los Angeles. In Amsterdam, however, the artist's unwavering popularity simply assumed a different form, as $35.5 million was spent on preparing the museum to handle ever larger numbers of visitors.

title: Norman Hirsh, 64, Executive Who Oversaw Apache Copters
description: Norman B. Hirsh, who supervised the development of the Apache attack helicopters that were used extensively in the Persian Gulf war in the 1990's and recently in Yugoslavia, died on June 8 at his home in Coto de Caza, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: San Diego Journal; At a Nude Beach, Clothing Isn't Optional Anymore
description: In the sports shop at the Torrey Pines Gliderport, on a wind-swept bluff above the Pacific, a stack of curious signs hang for sale above the racks of brochures on hang-gliding and parasailing, with the cheery exhortation: ''Buy Me, $19.95.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, CHARLES KATZ
description: SHAPIRO-Charles Katz, retired professor of English, June 18, age 73. Survived by his dear friend Mary Bonsignore. An informal memorial service will be held Sunday, June 27, 2PM at The Riverdale/Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, 4450 Fieldston Road, corner Manhattan College Parkway, Riverdale, NY. 718-548-4445.

title: Plotting Corporate Futures; Biotechnology Examines What Could Go Wrong
description: Whether he is writing books, lecturing at universities or lobbying regulators and politicians, Jeremy Rifkin never misses a chance to argue that the biotechnology industry is leading the world toward environmental and social disaster. If he thinks it will help slow the industry down, he is quick to file lawsuits and promote boycotts or moratoriums.

title: Torre Listens To Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry, suspended from baseball last week, called the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, on Tuesday and spoke with Manager Joe Torre today, talking optimistically about how he feels and about the possibility of coming back near the end of the season, when he could be reinstated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Diamond MP3 Player Adds Listening Time
description: A good deal of the talk at this year's PC Expo, the annual computer fair in New York, was about MP3, the sound-compression software that has teen-agers' Internet connections humming and music-industry professionals nervous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: A Marriage of Pond and Pavilion in Idyllic Sacramento
description: WHAT could be more pleasant than relaxing in a sleek, glass-walled pavilion with views onto a rural backdrop of pond and meandering river, where the only disturbance is the croaking of frogs and the quacking of ducks? That picturesque conceit has been realized in this unlikely city, the politically active but architecturally dull state capital of California. Here, the homeowners, a businessman and his art-collecting wife, commissioned a contemporary house extension -- studio, gallery, office and living room -- that cantilevers over an artificial but pastoral pond on the banks of the Sacramento River.

title: The Big City; Lead Debate Raises Dust As an Issue
description: AFTER a rowdy public hearing on Monday, the City Council has revised its lead paint legislation and scheduled another hearing for today. A chief point of contention is the arcane matter of a dust test.

title: Doris, Heart of the Waldorf, Says Farewell
description: GEMUTLICH is not generally the term that comes to mind regarding the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, but that is true only for those who have not taken a stroll off the elegant Art Deco lobby and done a little shopping and visiting with Doris Motlin, the owner of Doris' Boutique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Essay; The Gorebush Era
description: Relying on poll numbers as they denounce reliance on pollsters, establishment politicians and the Boys on the Bus have leapfrogged primary elections to decide -- nearly a year and a half before Election Day -- that the contest is between George the Dubyuh and Albert the Gee.

title: From Parsons to the University of Virginia
description: Whenever a big school picks a new dean, the choice says something about shifting values. This summer, Karen Van Lengen, right, the chairwoman of the architecture department at the Parsons School of Design in New York, will replace William McDonough as dean of the University of Virginia School of Architecture in Charlottesville. (Mr. McDonough left to devote more time to lecturing and to the Institute for Sustainable Design, founded at the school.) The change signals a shift from redesigning materials to redesigning relationships.

title: Site-Seeing: Information for Golfers
description: Here are more sources of golf-related information and entertainment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: How Do They Do It? The Science of Sports, on Line
description: Skateboarders may have a reputation for being public nuisances, but even their most vocal critics must admit that some of their tricks are pretty cool. How, for example, do skateboarders manage to leap over chasms while still keeping their boards with them, seemingly stuck to the soles of their shoes -- a maneuver known as ''the Ollie''?

title: Lawsuits Lead Gun Maker To File for Bankruptcy
description: In the first sign of the impact of the growing number of municipal lawsuits against the gun industry, a well-known manufacturer of handguns has filed for bankruptcy protection, raising concern among city officials across the country that other firearms companies may also use bankruptcy to try to avoid the suits.

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Kerr Ross, 60, SUNY Arts Director
description: Patricia Kerr Ross, former director of the State University of New York's Programs in the Arts, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Albany. She was 60 and lived in Albany.

title: Marketers Name New Chief Executive
description: The American Marketing Associationan org in Chicago has named a new chief executive, Dennis L. Dunlap, to succeed Dennis Jorgensen, who resigned in November to pursue opportunities in the computer software industry. Mr. Dunlap, 55, had most recently been president of the Mobium Creative Group, part of the R. R. Donnelly & Sons Company in Chicago.

title: Goldman Sachs Profit Is Up 30% in First Public Quarter
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. reported its first quarterly results as a publicly traded company yesterday with a gain that exceeded analysts' forecasts.

title: In a time of lists and debating those lists, a new book chooses the 100 best TV commercials.
description: MAYBE it's millennial fever. Maybe it's the fact that television has reached maturity, at least chronologically if not emotionally. Or maybe it's just the fad for compiling lists. Whatever the reason, there has been a rush to designate the ''best'' commercials and advertisements ever made -- and an ensuing rush to debate the choices.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIPS. Japan's currency edged lower after the nation's top currency official warned that the central bank might sell more yen to stimulate growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.92 yen, up from 121.82 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Valentin's Home Run Lifts Boston
description: RED SOX 5, ORIOLES 0

title: Spurs Jump-Started By Johnson and Elie
description: Avery Johnson sat down at courtside after yesterday's pre-game shoot-around and begrudgingly did his duty. The San Antonio Spurs' 5-foot-11-inch fireplug did not want to talk to the news media, did not even want to talk to his teammates. But there he sat, with his arms folded and his jaw clenched, listening to reporters question his play and the play of his teammates.

title: Would School Prayer Satisfy Either Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH BANK TALKS
description: The Bank of France said the three banks involved in a protracted takeover battle have begun merger negotiations after nearly four months of deadlock. The chairmen from Societe Generale S.A., Paribas S.A. and Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. met at the Bank of France headquarters in the presence of Jean-Claude Trichet, Bank of France governor, a Bank of France spokesman said.

title: For Now, Prosecutors Can Work as Defenders
description: The State Supreme Court has delayed implementation of an appellate ruling that bans municipal prosecutors from working as criminal defense lawyers in the same county.

title: Salinger's Daughter Plans to Publish a Memoir
description: The daughter of the obsessively private author J. D. Salinger is preparing to publish a memoir of her childhood and relationship with her father.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSEN, LINDA
description: KISSEN-Linda. On June 17, 1999. Beloved cousin of Richard and Ann Kamholtz, Jules and Aileen Whitman and all of their children. Private services were held at Mt. Zion Cemetery. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHING, JOHN W.
description: PERSHING-John W. On June 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with vascular disease. Beloved husband of Sandra Sinclair Pershing. Devoted stepfather of Alyson Lloyd Taylor, and Robin M. Lloyd. Cherished grandfather of Hollis C. Taylor. A private investor in civilian life, he was a member of The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York, and The Society of Cincinnati. Following service as an enlisted man in The United States Marine Corps, he was a distinguished ROTC Military Graduate from Boston University and Commissioned in The United States Army, retiring after 35 years of service in 1998. A graduate of The Army War College, he had served in Special Forces, on the Staff of the Secretary of Defense and as a Special Assistant to The Chief of Staff of the United States Army. He was the grandson of General of the Armies, John J. Pershing, Commander of The American Expeditionary Forces in World War I. His brother, Richard W. Pershing, was killed in action during The Vietnam War. Service Monday June 28, 1999, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will be private at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The ROTC School Fund at Boston University.

title: After Conservatives' Trim, Transportation Bill Clears the House
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a $44.5 billion transportation spending bill today, after fiscal conservatives used a parliamentary maneuver to strike from it the money needed to pay for running the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Maybe the City Charter Could Use an Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining section on June 2 about halal meat shops referred incorrectly to the rules of food preparation they follow. Islamic law, which shares some common ground with the Jewish dietary laws of kashruth, forbids the consumption of meat from some cloven-foot animals but not others. It forbids pork, for example, but allows consumption of beef, lamb and goat. The article also referred incorrectly to a Queens street where halal stores are clustered. It is Main Street. (Ocean Parkway is in Brooklyn.)

title: In Arms Sales, Japan Coddles Its Own
description: Salesmen on the fourth floor of Marubeni Corporation's building were hunched over their desks late one night earlier this year, blearily working on a deal to sell foreign aircraft to Japan. Suddenly, there was a bang and the only trace was a perfect bullet-like hole in a window.

title: Would School Prayer Satisfy Either Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Upholds District Voting For Hempstead
description: The Second Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal District Court's February 1997 order that Hempstead, the largest municipality on Long Island, dismantle its at-large electoral system because it consistently excluded blacks from the Town Council.

title: Political Memo; South Carolina Gains Ground as Pivotal Primary State
description: For the next nine months or so, it will not be safe to sneak off to a barbecue lunch at Maurice's Piggy Park here, or to enjoy a quiet game of canasta at a neighborhood center for the elderly in Charleston, or to walk along the sand at Myrtle Beach. At any moment, the orderly pace of life in South Carolina could be interrupted by the heavy tread and blinding smile of a Republican Presidential candidate.

title: C.I.A. Analyst Questioned Target Before Chinese Embassy Bombing
description: A middle-level analyst in the Central Intelligence Agency raised doubts about whether military planners were zeroing in on the right building shortly before American bombs struck the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on the night of May 7, Government officials said today.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Fragrant Night Bloomers

title: Would School Prayer Satisfy Either Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Charlie Parker Admirer Takes On the Strings
description: The small body of work Charlie Parker made with string sections in the late 1940's and early 50's -- two records and some concerts -- sits uneasily in history.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Washington Mayor Fined on Disclosure
description: The District of Columbia's office of campaign finance fined Mayor Anthony A. Williams $1,000 today for not promptly disclosing two consulting jobs for which he was paid $40,000 in the summer of 1998.

title: Snyder to Spin Off Health Care Units
description: Snyder Communications in Bethesda, Md., which owns agencies including Arnold Communications, said yesterday that it would spin off the health care marketing services businesses that accounted for almost 40 percent of the company's revenue last year but only 30 percent to 35 percent of its pretax profits.

title: Cell Phone in the Corner Pocket
description: WHEN they presented their new fall collection recently, the SoHo designers who call themselves Orfi (for the Organization for Returning Fashion Interest) included one outfit that consisted solely of an enormous blanket. But despite the hard work of two models who appeared on stage with it over their shoulders, the blanket-as-clothing concept is probably not destined to be a big seller.

title: Real and Imagined
description: Three words are routinely invoked by opponents of gun control: the Second Amendment. So it was during the debate last week in the House.

title: Classic Nerdwear; Pocket Protector, Image Projector
description: THERE was no such thing as a nerd back in 1947, when Erich Klein opened a small factory on Chicago's North Side and became one of the first manufacturers to make plastic pocket protectors.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Tea Party Becomes Trendy

title: Supreme Mischief
description: The Supreme Court ended its 1998-99 term on two deeply disturbing notes. On Tuesday it significantly weakened protections afforded by a Federal law barring discrimination against people with disabilities. Yesterday, in three separate decisions delivered in a morning of high drama, it significantly strengthened the power of the states in the Federal system while weakening those of the Federal Government.

title: Clinton on Home Front
description: After more than a year of war and scandal, President Clinton is eager to shed the unaccustomed mantle of wartime commander and reassert himself in the familiar realms of domestic policy and politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKWELL, WILLIAM LESLIE, JR.
description: BLACKWELL-William Leslie, Jr. 4/07/29-6/15/99. Professor of Russian History at NYU. He is survived by close friend Fiorence Wineapple, three children, Anne, Leslie, and Theodore, and four grandchildren. Services on 6/24 at 2PM St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Microsoft's Final Witness Is Questioned on Payments
description: A Government lawyer began cross-examination of Microsoft's final witness in its antitrust trial today and quickly prompted him to disclose that Microsoft had paid about $250,000 for his testimony and related work.

title: No Choice for Crew
description: For much of his nearly four-year tenure as head of the nation's largest school system, Rudy Crew has steered a safe course, making few waves and moving slowly as he sought to maintain his hold on a loose armada of 32 community school districts and 1,100 schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERNS, ADRIENNE
description: MERNS-Adrienne. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the untimely loss of Adrienne Merns, beloved daughter of Sy Syms, a generous supporter and cherished friend who shares with his family a deep devotion to Jewish causes. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mr. Syms and his wife, Lynn; Ms. Mern's companion, Patrick, and their daughter, Chloe; Ms. Mern's mother, Ruth Merns; her sisters Marcy and Laura; and her brothers, Robert and Richard. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Fast on Their Feet in Dance and Sports
description: Culture is for esthetes. Sports are an American pastime. That tradition took root in America more than a century ago, as legend has it, when men were consigned to coveting open horizons and women to yearning for civilizing parlor musicales. The divide exists still, despite occasional reports of star athletes who trained in dance. Peter Pucci's new ''Pucci: Sport,'' which opened on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, may not reassure too many hard-core Knicks and Yankees fans. But Mr. Pucci and his engaging Peter Pucci Plus Dancers do establish one fundamental and provocative connection.

title: Serb Is Killed In Gun Battle With Marines
description: Local Serbs in civilian clothes opened fire tonight on a checkpoint run by United States marines here, provoking a firefight that left one Serb dead and two others wounded, one severely, American officials here said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: REPSOL GAINS CONTROL OF YPF
description: Spain's largest oil and energy concern, Repsol S.A., said it had gained control of YPF S.A., Argentina's largest oil company, after increasing its share to 62 percent of the stock through Tuesday. The move vaults Repsol into the world's top 10 oil companies. Repsol bought 15 percent of YPF in January and in April announced a $13.4 billion cash bid for the remaining 85 percent. A Repsol spokeswoman termed the takeover bid a success even if Repsol falls short of gaining 100 percent of YPF. Al Goodman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Mexico's Presidential Hopefuls Are All New Breed
description: An entire generation in Mexico has been governed by Presidents who had never won office before and who were chosen by their predecessors in part because of their Ivy League credentials and fluent English.

title: KOREAN LOANS SOLD
description: A Texas-based investment partnership, Lone Star Fund L.P., bought 1.04 trillion won ($896 million) of South Korean bad loans, in the country's biggest single sale of bad debt to date. Lone Star paid an average 50.6 percent of the loans' face value, a better price than expected. The sale, by the Korea Asset Management Corporation, indicates foreign investors are betting South Korea is recovering from its worst recession since the 1950's. Kamco raised $455 million from the sale, which consisted of 8,100 nonperforming loans from 3,100 borrowers.

title: Stickies and Highlighter Pens Are Put to Work on the Web
description: A new company called Keeboo is bringing yellow stickies and highlighter pens to the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Busy Fans Use Tricks to Keep Up With Knicks
description: Antsy and grim-faced, they shuffled into the Brooks Atkinson Theater last night for a performance of ''The Iceman Cometh,'' Eugene O'Neill's four-and-a-half hour epic. But their anxiety had nothing to do with the $100 seats or the extended playing time.

title: McCann Executive To Be Promoted
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it would promote a senior executive, effective Jan. 1.

title: Software Will Hold Your Hand When You Switch Computers
description: Making the transition from an old computer to a new one can be a hassle. You've got to redo your shortcuts, reorganize your desktop and reset the toolbars on your applications.

title: Debate Over Same-Sex Marriage Splits a Methodist Church Near Atlanta
description: With the Governor on one side and a prominent Congressman on the other, a leading United Methodist church in the Atlanta suburbs split this week in the latest case of what has become a crisis in the church on the issue of same-sex unions.

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Peace Overture in Turkey
description: The case of the Kurdish rebel chief, Abdullah Ocalan, confronts Turkey's leaders with a critical choice. The special state security court trying Mr. Ocalan for treason is expected to hand down its verdict in the next few days. He has acknowledged most of the charges against him and his conviction is virtually certain, with a mandatory penalty of death by hanging. But for weeks Mr. Ocalan, whose 15-year campaign of terrorism and violence has resulted in some 30,000 deaths, has been proposing a deal. Spare his life, he says, and he will work to persuade his militant followers to negotiate a peaceful solution to the Kurdish revolt.

title: Internet Camera to Capture The Best of Baby Videos
description: As if MP3 wasn't confusing enough, here comes MPEG-4. At PC Expo, Sharp Electronics introduced the Internet Viewcam, the first consumer product to use MPEG-4, a new video-compression format. That means you won't just be getting baby pictures over the Internet; you'll be getting baby video.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GEORGE W.
description: FRANK-George W. The board and staff of Hospice Care Network express their profound sorrow upon the loss of their longtime supporter, mentor and friend. A pioneer in regional hospice care, Mr. Frank was a founding member and first president of Hospice Care of Long Island, which later became HCN. He will be remembered for his wisdom, compassion and sincere concern for the welfare of others. Our deepest condolences to the family. Maureen Hinkelman, CEO John King, Chairman of the Board The board and staff of Hospice Care Network

title: Sending Up A Lesbian's Cutout Life Of Sorrows
description: There wasn't enough money in the scenery budget, apparently, to build an entire Vale of Tears. So the Five Lesbian Brothers settled for a ''necklace of tears.''

title: WESTFIELD AMERICA AND J. P. MORGAN FORM JOINT VENTURE
description: Westfield America Inc., a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to form a $500 million joint venture with J. P. Morgan & Company. Westfield said that J. P. Morgan would invest $130 million and assume $120 million in debt and in return take a 50 percent stake in two Westfield shopping malls, Shoppingtown Valley Fair in San Jose, Calif., and Shoppingtown UTC in La Jolla, Calif. The malls had combined sales of $831 million in 1998. Westfield acquired both centers last year when it bought a portfolio of property from the TrizecHahn Corporation. Westfield America, based in Los Angeles, is a real estate investment trust that owns 38 shopping centers in eight states.

title: Starr Could Call Hillary Clinton As Witness in the Hubbell Trial
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, may call Hillary Rodham Clinton as a witness in the criminal trial this summer of her former law partner, Webster L. Hubbell, a lawyer familiar with the case said today.

title: A Trip From the Jersey Shore to Lake Shore Drive
description: When a faxed invitation arrived from the women's national soccer team, Christie Pearce thought it was a joke. That was December 1996, and basketball was her primary sport at Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J. Soccer was something she did for fun. Monmouth's women's soccer team drew about 30 spectators a game, mostly parents, and until her senior season it did not have its own locker room. If players wanted their uniforms washed, they did it themselves.

title: Pataki Avoids Budget Issue In a Speech About Policies
description: Gov. George E. Pataki went to Detroit yesterday to promote his economic policies as a model for the nation, detailing his record of cutting taxes and reducing the size of government but skirting mention of the standoff back home over the state budget, now nearly three months overdue.

title: Correction
description: An editorial last Saturday discussing recent rulings by two Federal judges, Stephen Williams and Douglas Ginsburg, on the Administration's clean air policies misstated Judge Williams's first name and misidentified the court on which they sit. It is the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, not the Second Circuit.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Following The Bouncing Baton; Who's Conducting Which Orchestra? Why?
description: With the announcement on Tuesday that, come 2002, Sir Simon Rattle will be the next music director of the esteemed Berlin Philharmonic, at least one seat has been grabbed in the game of musical chairs among conductors vying for music directorships of some eight or so important orchestras.

title: Would School Prayer Satisfy Either Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Ousts Bank Board That Opposed Tax
description: In an effort to reassert control over unruly factions in the Government bureaucracy, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has dismissed the board of one of the largest Government-controlled banks after it opposed an important tax.

title: Joyce MacIver, Novelist and Playwright, 95
description: Georgette Scott, a novelist and playwright who wrote under the name Joyce MacIver, died on June 15 at her home in New York. She was 95.

title: For Women, Ideal Man Has 2 Faces, Study Finds
description: The face of Mr. Right may change from week to week, according to a new study that tracked women's preferences for male features at different stanges of the menstrual cycle.

title: If Printers Spout Garble
description: Q. What would cause a printer to print incorrectly with odd lines and letters, even though it looks fine on screen and prints O.K. from another printer?

title: Rift Threatens Tax Program Aiding Co-ops
description: A dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Sheldon Silver, the State Assembly Speaker, is jeopardizing a property tax break for owners of co-ops and condominiums, whose tax bills will increase by an average of $580 this year if the matter is not resolved soon.

title: SCOTTISH MUTUAL COMPANY SOLD
description: Britain's biggest retail bank, Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C., said it was acquiring the mutually owned life insurance and pensions company Scottish Widows for $11.1 billion. The deal, expected to be completed next year, creates Britain's biggest bank insurance group and the second-largest provider in the life, pensions and mutual fund market after the Prudential Corporation P.L.C. Analysts said they expected the announcement to act as a spur to widespread consolidation in the financial services sector in Britain. Some 900,000 of Scottish Widows 1.6 million members will receive windfall payments of $9,500. Warren Hoge

title: His Brain Measured Up
description: People have long wondered about the source of genius. Last week three neuroscientists claimed to have found it using a pair of calipers. After examining the brain of Albert Einstein, they said it had large and unusually shaped inferior parietal lobules, a seat of mathematical and spatial reasoning.

title: $600,000 Settlement Said to Be Awarded to Ousted Principal
description: A Westchester County elementary school principal who was dismissed six years ago in a squabble with her school board over teaching methods will receive a financial settlement worth roughly $600,000 and will have all charges against her dropped, a school official said.

description: Bear Stearns Accord Seen

title: Frank Pagliaro, 99, Concrete Contractor
description: Frank J. Pagliaro, a concrete contractor whose projects included the Chrysler Building and the New York Athletic Club in Manhattan, died on Sunday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 99.

title: Baker Sets Its Own Stage
description: ''Department store furniture'' is too young to be antique and too mass-produced to be pricey. Neither inherited nor commissioned, it has furnished most American homes this century.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Two Wireless Companies To Merge in $3 Billion Deal

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about technical challenges facing Internet commerce misstated the extent of a 14-hour service interruption at Intuit Inc.'s Turbo Tax site on April 12. It affected only the site's electronic filing function, not its tax preparation service.

title: Innovative Strategies Spur E-Sales Growth : Europe Closing Gap
description: LONDON  The days when Europe could be considered a backwater in electronic commerce, lagging years behind developments in the United States, are rapidly drawing to a close.

title: Towing Company Owner Admits Paying Police
description: The count of people pleading guilty or being convicted in a West New York police corruption case rose to 28 yesterday when a former towing company owner admitted her role in a kickback scheme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: A Holocaust Bloodhound Gently Tracks a Target
description: It has been 55 years to the day since Maurice Rossel, a young Swiss investigator for the International Red Cross, visited the infamous Theresienstadt concentration camp in Czechoslovakia and, in a masterstroke of Potemkin manipulation by the Nazis, wrote a glowing report about the ghetto amenities of its ''privileged Jews.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZSCHILD, DORIS
description: SCHWARZSCHILD - Doris. Be loved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother to Amy Ratzan and Judy Bean. Cherished grandmother of Debbie, Terry, Julie and Brian. Funeral services Thursday, 1 PM, at Union Fields Cemetery. I. J. Morris Dix Hills Chapel.

title: Voicestream and Omnipoint Announce $3 Billion Merger
description: The Voicestream Wireless Corporation and the Omnipoint Corporation, two regional wireless communications companies seeking to expand their national presence, said yesterday that they would merge in a cash and stock transaction valued at nearly $3 billion.

title: Young Man and Woman Shot to Death in Queens
description: A man and a woman were sitting on the trunk of a car in Queens last night when at least one person walked up to them, shot them dead, and ran off, the police said.

title: Bacardi Takes Havana Rum Suit to Spain
description: An international feud over the rights to the Havana Club rum trademark escalated today, as Bacardi Ltd. and the Cuban expatriate Arechabala family sued the Cuban Government and its joint-venture partner, Pernod Ricard of France, over use of the name in Spain.

title: American to Change Identity of Reno Air
description: American Airlines said today that it would combine Reno Air's routes, workers and planes into its business on Aug. 31, helping it face rising competition in the Western states.

title: A.M.A.'S DELEGATES VOTE TO UNIONIZE
description: The American Medical Association, which long considered itself an elite professional organization, voted yesterday to form a union for doctors in what it called an effort to level the playing field with powerful managed-care organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PREISS, EDMUND
description: PREISS-Edmund. Forever loved, forever remembered. Pearl, Byron, Sandi, Karah, Blaire Preiss

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Cloak, Dagger and Strong-Arming in the Russian Far East
description: Investors in the Russian Far East are used to working with risks: the currency is fragile, deposits disappear when banks close, and companies can be taxed out of existence before they show a profit.

title: 2 Charged in Illegal Fishing
description: New York State environmental police officers arrested a man Tuesday on charges of illegally catching and selling fish from Sheepshead Bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Judge Allows 2 Price Levels In Stock Plans
description: In a decision with broad implications for privately owned companies and their workers, a Federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that such concerns may use different methods to value company shares that workers buy outright and those that they purchase in a retirement plan.

title: Accounts
description: * Restoration Hardware, San Francisco, to Borders Perrin & Norrander, Portland, Ore., as the first agency to handle the account of the specialty home furnishings retailer. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Bigger and Fresher, Spurs Push Game Knicks to Brink
description: A rigid, misplaced jumper by the Knicks' Allan Houston licked off the rim and bounded up in the air late into a tense night, and the two 7-foot stars for the San Antonio Spurs popped up like two cymbals flashing and glinting in the air.

title: Mapping Every Structure in an Enormous Park
description: IN the past, when staff members of the Fairmount Park Historic Preservation Trust here wanted to find out about maintenance needed on a historic building, they would consult paper files in all sorts of offices, look at park maps that were 12 feet by 5 feet and tap into ''Mike's brain.''

title: Bear Stearns Is Seen Nearing Accord With S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Bear Stearns Companies are closing in on a settlement that would end a two-year investigation into the brokerage firm's securities clearing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, PALAMONA WILLIAMS
description: FERRIS-Palamona Williams, 83. Kent, Ct. June 19, 1999. Survived by husband Dr. Jeffrey Ferris, daughters Palamona A. and Mary C. Ferris, Eliza F. Hitchcock and granddaughter Amanda G. Ferris.

title: Metro Business; Pimco Sells an Affiliate
description: Pimco Advisors Holdings LP agreed to sell Columbus Circle Investors Inc. to the firm's executives, who had been negotiating for the last few months to pull away from Pimco.

title: RUMORS OF TRUCK DEALS
description: The world's largest truck maker, DaimlerChrysler A.G., denied a report that it was in talks to acquire Volvo A.B., while a separate report renewed speculation that Volkswagen A.G. is wooing the other Swedish truck maker, Scania A.B. Dagens Industri, a Swedish newspaper, said DaimlerChrysler would pay up to 160 billion Swedish kronor ($19 billion) in stock for Volvo, the world's second-largest truck maker. The report pushed Volvo shares up as much as 7.8 percent, and Scania shares up as much as 3.5 percent.

title: Making Up Their Beds and Hoping the Oysters Will Move In
description: This is about as simple as science gets: Spread 10,000 bushels of ancient oyster shells on the bottom of New York Harbor near the Statue of Liberty, and see if drifting oyster larvae settle there and grow.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's the Serbs who are guilty. We are glad the Serbs aren't here any more. May NATO live billions and billions of years.''

title: U.S. and North Korea Meet on Suspected A-Site
description: An American envoy met with high-level North Korean officials here today to report on the United States' recent inspection of a suspected nuclear-weapons complex in North Korea and to lay the ground for more talks later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLANT, NORMAN
description: GOLANT-Norman. Beloved husband of the late Sally. Loving father of Arlene and Lynne. Dear brother of Edith Rothblatt. Graveside services Friday, 10 AM, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Seeking Little League Skills at $70 an Hour
description: Hoisting a bat that looked huge on a 10-year-old, Benjamin Gold stood nervously at the plate under his floppy orange Orioles cap.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Bush Seeks Iowa Leverage In the Capital
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is trying to use the broad support for his Presidential campaign among the Republican political establishment in Washington to help him compete in a high-profile straw poll in Iowa in August.

title: Studentspeak Taken Seriously At Language Site
description: THE San Fernando Valley isn't the only part of California with its own slang. If you're a student in San Luis Obispo, for example, you may have spent the morning ''classing'' before meeting some ''slocalocals'' at ''Bubble Gum Alley.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAL, JOSE CARLOS
description: LEAL-Jose Carlos on June 23, 1999 at age 79. Retired ship owner of Rio de Janiero and New York. Died peacefully from complications of a stroke. He is survived by his beloved wife Judi, his loving granddaughter Julia Santos, stepson Steven Fox and a daughter and two sons from Rio de Janiero. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Tuesday, June 29, from 7-9pm, with a memorial service Wednesday, June 30 at 4:00pm. Interment private.

title: Simon Rattle Will Direct The Berlin Philharmonic
description: The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra today elected the young British conductor Sir Simon Rattle to succeed its chief conductor, Claudio Abbado, who is to step down from one of classical music's most prestigious posts in September 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, MILTON A.
description: SPITZ-Milton A. Beloved husband of Pierrette. Dear brother of Alvin. Brother-in-law of Eileen Spitz, Louis and Marthe Lebre, and Henri and Anna Lebre. Dear uncle and grand-uncle. Service today, 2PM at Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Caldor Selling More Stores
description: The Caldor Corporation, which is going out of business, is selling five more stores to a group that includes the Kmart Corporation, Federal Realty Investment Trust and Shaw's Supermarkets Inc., the discount retailer's bankruptcy lawyer, Cherise Wolas Kasica, said yesterday. United States Bankruptcy Judge James Garrity approved the store sales yesterday at a hearing in Manhattan. Caldor had other store sales in the works, Ms. Kasica said. Caldor said in January that it was going out of business.

title: Schools Decision Lifts a Burden for Yonkers
description: This city's Mayor exulted today over a Federal appeals court decision that found that Yonkers' prior history of school segregation could not be held responsible for racial disparities in academic achievement. And, the Mayor said, the ruling was an emphatic signal to a lower-court judge to give up his 19-year job of shepherding the local school system's destiny.

title: A Handheld True to Its Name, With a Keyboard for the Patient
