description: Though the latest handheld computers look and feel less like handhelds and more like notebook computers, with bigger keyboards and screens, Hewlett-Packard's recently released Jornada 680 aims for a happy compromise: a handheld that actually fits in the hand yet offers a keyboard almost big enough to type on.

title: Fire Official Calls Belmont Park Blaze Suspicious
description: A fire that consumed three stalls in a barn in Belmont Park and led to the deaths of three horses has been labeled suspicious by Nassau County fire officials.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IRIDIUM L.L.C., Washington, D.C., a global-communications services concern, terminated a contract to purchase Claircom Communications Group Inc., a provider of in-flight telephone services. Iridium had agreed in December to buy Claircom for $65 million.

title: Kurdish Rebel Links Revolt To Repression By Turkey
description: Speaking in his own defense at his treason trial, the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan said today that repressive measures imposed by the Turkish Government had driven him and his followers to take up arms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, LOUIS R.
description: WASSERMAN-Louis R. The faculty members of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health profoundly mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Louis R. Wasserman. Dr. Wasserman was a true giant among giants in the grand Mount Sinai tradition. As one of the founders of the subspecialty of Hematology in the United States, he was President of the American Society of Hematology and led the Polycythemia Vera Study Group, which made seminal contributions to the treatment of this disorder. Dr. Wasserman's powerful leadership made Mount Sinai a national leader in Hematology and established a rich tradition that continues to the present. He trained and mentored many of the leaders in Hematology throughout the world to carry on his rich legacy. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Julia, and to his entire family. Barry S. Coller, M.D., Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLISS, ROBERT N.
description: BLISS-Robert N. Beloved member of North Country Treetops community for over 60 years. Died peacefully at home on June 20th. He gave countless people inspiration and appreciation of the wilderness. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Robert Bliss Memorial Fund, Camp Treetops, P.O. Box 187, Lake Placid, New York 12946

title: WILL TAKE OVER 43
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew announced a shake-up of New York City's lowest-performing schools yesterday, encompassing 56 of the system's 1,100 schools and 9 of its 32 district superintendents. He said that to continue to allow schools to fail would be ''unforgivable.''

title: Apple Aid for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Asbestos Deal Voided
description: The Supreme Court set aside a $1.5 billion settlement of asbestos claims against the Fibreboard Corporation, ruling that claimants' lawyers' desires for a quick deal with huge fees may have conflicted with their clients' interest in a bigger deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, DAVID A.
description: HENDERSON-David A., 76, of Applewood Estates, Freehold Township, NJ, on June 20, 1999. Dr. Henderson was a graduate of Greeley High School, Greeley, CO, Class of 1941; received his Bachelor of Science and Master of Arts degrees from the University of Colorado in 1946 and 1951, respectively, and earned his Ph.D. in geography from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1963. A historical geographer by training, he was the author of Men and Whales at Scammon's Lagoon (1972), Journal Aboard the Bark ''Ocean Bird'' (1970), and many articles for scholarly journals. Dr. Henderson taught at Stanford, San Diego State University, the University of Arizona, and California State University, Northridge. After his retirement from academics, he was Resident Scholar at the Whaling Museum in New Bedford, Mass., until 1997. He is survived by a daughter, Andrea Henderson Fahnestock, of New York City and Locust, NJ. Memorial services will be held at 2 PM Friday, July 2, at Applewood Estates, Freehold, NJ, with Rev. Alan Gibson, Rector of All Saints Episcopal Church, Locust, NJ, officiating. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Colorado University Foundation, PO Box 1140, Boulder, CO 80306. For more information, contact Higgins Memorial Home, 20 Center St., Freehold, NJ.

title: Rem Koolhaas's American Hurrah
description: No building by the famed modernist architect Rem Koolhaas has yet been built in America. Why? Two decades of post-modernism ''made us unthinkable,'' he said. But the ice is breaking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, MARIE
description: HAYES-Marie. Dear colleague and partner passed away June 21. Mother of Joseph and Vickie. She was a loving, giving person and was always there to help no matter how difficult the task. Highly qualified as an accountant, she became an appraiser and suceeeded in that field. Known for her willingness to help others, she was kept busy night and day in her profession as well as personal matters. We will never forget you, you go with our love and blessings. Martin and Arlene Gross

title: Rudy Crew's Housecleaning
description: After holding students to higher standards, sending them to the purgatory of summer school and ending social promotion, Chancellor Rudy Crew has now taken aim at the the administrators he believes have failed these students. In a momentous shift of authority affecting many of New York City's worst schools, Dr. Crew has axed principals and superintendents, demonstrating a willingness to take risks with a dramatic, even showy action. The question is whether this promising change will settle into real educational improvement for students in the country's largest school system.

title: Advanced Micro to Report Larger-Than-Expected Loss
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that it would report a larger-than-expected second-quarter loss because of steep declines in the price of microprocessor chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Missing Man, Rare Bird And the Greater Mysteries
description: ANDES RISING

title: Swiss Holocaust Fund
description: Advertisements will run in some 500 newspapers around the world next Tuesday with a toll-free number and a clip-out coupon for Holocaust survivors and others to lodge claims to a $1.2 billion settlement agreed by Swiss banks last year, the World Jewish Congress said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOUGH, JOHN GRIFFITH
description: McCULLOUGH-John Griffith. Of Vermont and NY. Loving father, devoted friend, champion of music. We will miss you Big John.

title: F.B.I. Investigators at Sites of 2 Mass Killings
description: A team of F.B.I. forensic investigators began poring over two sites in Kosovo today in an effort to identify victims of two mass killings cited in the war crimes indictment of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, law enforcement officials said.

title: Struggling to Avoid a Loss On a Hard 4-Heart Contract
description: The United States will field two world-class teams next January, when the Bermuda Bowl world championship is played in the island where the series began half a century ago. One will be the team of Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, all of whom have won world titles.

title: For Mom, a House A Wolf Can't Blow Down
description: ON Feb. 10, when Gioang Huu Nguyen boarded Singapore Airlines Flight 25 from Kennedy Airport to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, he was a man in a hurry. He had one month to build his 76-year-old mother, Phung Thi Khu, a new house.

title: Parting Glances at a Pleasure Dome
description: AS deathbed scenes go, the last gasp of Chateau de Groussay was particularly lively. Helicopters landed and cars lumbered up the drive over 10 days in late May and early June, disgorging princes and potentates, designers and decorators in the posh suburban village of Montfort-l'Amaury, 30 miles south of Paris.

title: Albanians Loot and Burn, Aiming Wrath at Gypsies
description: French troops are barely keeping the lid on violence here, in the main city of their sector of Kosovo.

title: South Africa Official Attacked for Approval of Politicians' Lies
description: The new governor of a South African province, whose scandals he promised to clean up, came under fire today for saying that he felt it was acceptable for politicians to lie to the public.

title: Olympic Athletes Gather at the Capitol, Remembering the Games' Ideals
description: They gathered on the steps of the Capitol, more than 100 American Olympians -- from Fred Pollard, who has spent a lifetime describing how it felt to be a black man confronting Adolf Hitler at Berlin's 1936 Games, to Beth Botsford, a 16-year-old double gold medal winner in 1996 who was late for today's Olympic Day festivities because she would not miss her morning swim practice.

title: Long View From the Waterfront; Developer Has Pursued a Brooklyn Dream for 20 Years
description: Samuel J. LeFrak owns more buildings, Mortimer B. Zuckerman wields more political clout and Donald J. Trump boasts a higher profile. But no New York developer is more persistent than David C. Walentas.

title: Blind People With Eye Damage May Someday Use Chips to See
description: ELECTRONIC retinal implants are not the bionic eyes of science fiction, the sort that Geordi on ''Star Trek'' had, but they are getting closer. Work on these implants, which would be among the first marriages of computers and neurons, is progressing fast, researchers say, partly because of the increasing power of computer chips. Such implants may start giving blind patients limited vision within a decade.

title: Thoroughbreds for the Desk Set
description: DESK chairs, or task chairs, as they are now called in the trade (to distinguish them from those thronelike executive models), are no longer just pieces of furniture bought to match a desk. A good chair, the ergonomists tell us, is probably the single most important office tool.

title: The Kids Are All Right? Just You Wait, Parents Say
description: Thanks to an eagle-eyed tourist, four runaway New Jersey teen-agers were found unharmed today and returned to their suburban homes after six nights and five days wandering in Manhattan.

title: Swissair to Sell Its Delta Stake
description: Swissair, Europe's fifth-largest airline, said today that it would sell its 4.6 percent stake in Delta Air Lines, loosening ties with its longtime partner, which agreed on Tuesday to an alliance with Air France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH
description: BERGER-Ruth. The Officers, Members of the Board and Administration of OHEL, Bais Ezra and the Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved sister of Max Wasser, devoted Honorary President of OHEL. The Wasser family's tradition of selfless dedication to Jewish children and families in need around the world spans the generations. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman, OHEL President David Jacobson, Bais Ezra President Ronny Hersh, Lifetime Care President Moshe Zakheim, Chairman of the Board Mel Zachter, Executive Committee Chairman David Mandel, Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAKIS, PETER C.
description: TRAKIS-Peter C. 1965-1998. A year of great sorrow. We will always miss you. Love Mom and Dad

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From the Court's Decision Broadly Expanding State Sovereignty
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today placing sharp new curbs on the ability of Congress to make Federal law binding on the states. The vote in Alden v. Maine involving enforcement of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 was 5 to 4. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, in which he was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, as well as Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Justice David H. Souter wrote the dissent and was joined by Justices Stephen G. Breyer, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and John Paul Stevens.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Thompson And McHale Elected to Hall
description: John Thompson, who was never hesitant to speak out on issues ranging from race to college basketball eligibility standards during 27 years as Georgetown coach, joined Kevin McHale of the Boston Celtics yesterday as the headliners of the Basketball Hall of Fame class of 1999.

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Queries on Canceled Gala Lead to Mayoral Walkout
description: Facing persistent questions from reporters yesterday about why his administration had killed plans for a glittery magazine party at the city-owned Brooklyn Navy Yard, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tried several tactics.

title: Belgium Lightens Coca-Cola's Problems, but Questions Persist
description: The Belgian health authorities ended a 10-day ban today on products of the Coca-Cola Company, permitting it to resume production in Belgium of sodas that were blamed for 249 cases of vomiting, cramps and other illnesses that shattered European confidence in the world's best-known brand.

title: Doubts About MP3
description: To the Editor:

title: Cyber-Mogul at 25? You Can Dream
description: THE Web site cascades onto your screen. The design is slick. The content is impressive. The rhetoric is mesmerizing: ''You dream of creating your own business. You're fascinated by the high-tech industry, where fortunes are made and lost as businesses scramble to keep up with the latest technological innovations.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, JUDITH
description: BRODSKY-Judith. Precious memories remain. Our love-then, now and forever. Grace and Ruth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Tuesday about a stock option plan for employees of the Mellon Bank Corporation misstated the company's cost. If all employees exercise their options, the program will reduce earnings by 3 cents a share over about six years, not three years.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday about gun-control votes in the House of Representatives misstated the vote of Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan. Mr. Bonior voted against an amendment by Representative John D. Dingell to require background checks for people buying guns at gun shows and allow 24 hours to complete any additional investigation required. He voted for a competing amendment, by Representative Carolyn McCarthy, that would also require background checks for buyers at gun shows, but allow three business days for additional investigation.

title: ROVER RESCUE PACKAGE
description: The German auto maker BMW and the British Government announced a rescue package for the car maker's struggling Rover operation in Britain. Under the deal, the Government will contribute $243 million over six years linked to productivity improvement targets. BMW will inject about $2.4 billion into a new production facility at Longbridge in Birmingham, England, and the factory will be retooled so production can be doubled to about 500,000 cars a year. The deal is expected to save thousands of jobs at the Rover Longbridge plant, where a range of new models will be built, the company said.

title: Hingis Takes Rest to Study Next Step
description: Home is where her mother is, so that's where a despondent Martina Hingis flew today, a day after becoming just the third top-seeded woman ever to dissolve in Wimbledon's opening round. And where the 18-year-old Swiss star went, soap opera-ish rumors followed:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MELVIN DAVID
description: WEISS-Melvin David. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Retter), devoted father of Lee and James Maniolas, Sara and Giuseppe Sabbatini, Emily and Timothy Smith, cherished step-father of Nicholas Merrill, adoring grandfather of Nicoleta Maniolas, loving son of Rose Weiss and brother of Barbara Goldberg, caring uncle, in-law, and friend, died on June 22, 1999 from prostate cancer. Services Friday, June 25th at 10:45AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: To Protest Unwanted E-Mail, Spam Cop Goes to the Source
description: DO you ever find yourself wading through dozens of claims of baldness cures and offers to ''Make Money Fast at Home!!!'' while looking for E-mail in your In box from people you actually know? Is there any way to fight back against these unwanted spammers, who often hide behind hard-to-trace or false addresses?

title: Gaynor Jacobson Is Dead at 87; Helped Resettle Jewish Refugees
description: Gaynor Jacobson, a former world director of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, or Hias, who helped thousands of Jews leave Eastern Europe for Israel and other countries in the West in the World War II period, died on June 6 at a hospital in Sun City West, Ariz.

title: In America; Criminal Justice
description: George W. Bush put his vaunted compassion on hold Sunday night and vetoed a bill that would have modestly improved the abysmal quality of legal representation available to indigent defendants in Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVAVY, ZVI
description: LEVAVY-Zvi. With heads bowed, we are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend, Zvi Levavy. President of the Morris J. and Betty Kaplun Foundation, Mr. Levavy was an ardent supporter of The Open University of Israel. Heartfelt condolences to his family. May his memory be for a blessing. Irving M. Rosenbaum, Chairman Ingeborg Rennert, NY Chair Eric G. Heffler, Executive VP American Friends of The Open University of Israel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, STANLEY
description: FERBER-Stanley. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their friend and member, and extend their sympathy to his family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: PUB OFFER REJECTED
description: The world's second-largest liquor company, Allied Domecq P.L.C., rejected a bid of $:2.7 billion ($4.3 billion) from Punch Taverns Ltd. for its 3,500 British pubs, instead endorsing a lower offer from Whitbread P.L.C. The Punch bid ''does not give our shareholders access to the substantial synergy benefits and future growth prospects flowing from the Whitbread deal,'' Sir Christopher Hogg, Allied's chairman, said in a statement. Whitbread, the owner of T.G.I. Friday's restaurants and licensed maker of Stella Artois beer, is offering $:2.4 billion in stock for the pubs. That offer could be worth as much as $:3 billion once tax savings and long-term costs benefits are added to the value of its shares, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: HEALTHEON AND ITS MERGER PARTNER MAKE INTERNET DEALS
description: The Healtheon Corporation said yesterday that it would provide health care information to Yahoo Inc. under an Internet content and marketing agreement. Terms were not disclosed. Meanwhile, Healtheon's merger partner, WebMD Inc., said it would develop a health Web site with Reader's Digest Association Inc. Healtheon is acquiring WebMD in a stock deal currently valued at more than $8 billion. The combined company already has marketing and distribution deals with such outlets as Microsoft's MSN and WebTV, At Home's Excite, Lycos Inc. and Time Warner's CNN. Reader's Digest, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., said it had invested $13 million in WebMD as part of the pact. Healtheon's stock was up $5.75, to $88.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, LILLIAN
description: FREUNDLICH-Lillian on June 22nd, 1999 in her 87th year. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Dear mother of the late David Freundlich. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Kate. Loving mother-inlaw of Mary Ellen. Cherished sister of Dorothy (Samuel) Tolmach. Services Friday, June 25th, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Justices Throw Out $1.5 Billion Asbestos Settlement, Citing Possible Conflict of Interest
description: The Supreme Court today set aside a $1.5 billion landmark settlement that was to have resolved the claims of as many as 186,000 victims of asbestos poisoning against the Fibreboard Corporation, one of the leading makers of products using the fire-retardant substance.

title: Nextel to Receive a McCaw Cash Infusion
description: Nextel Communications Inc., a nationwide provider of wireless phone services, said today that it would receive about $278 million in cash next month from the exercise of stock options by the cellular pioneer Craig McCaw and his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Souped-Up Battery to Handle Those Power-Greedy Laptops
description: At three-eighths of an inch thick and a little larger than a sheet of standard office paper, the new battery from Electrofuel looks like a miniature welcome mat.

title: Judge Acquits Man Charged With Rigging School Board Vote
description: James Sullivan, a former official in Community School Board 10 in the Bronx, was acquitted in State Supreme Court yesterday of 57 felony counts that accused him of orchestrating the filing of hundreds of forged absentee ballots to assure victory for his patrons in a 1993 school board election.

title: New Army Chief Seeks Both Agility and Power
description: The new Army Chief of Staff vowed today to redouble the Army's efforts to become a more agile yet powerful force, acknowledging that the service was ill prepared to move 24 Apache helicopter gunships and artillery into Albania in the early stages of the Balkans air conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALL, HERMAN
description: DALL-Herman, cherished husband of Rebecca, devoted and loving father of Carol and Alan, adored grandfather of Nicole. A light is gone out of our lives. Services at Cedar Park Cemetery at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ, 1PM Fri., June 25.

title: VISIBLE GENETICS, SEEKING A PARTNER, COULD FIND BUYER
description: Visible Genetics Inc. has held talks with at least four bigger companies in the last month to find a marketing partner, and the discussions could result in the sale of the company, its chairman, John Stevens, said yesterday. Mr. Stevens said he had met with senior executives at Abbott Laboratories, Roche Holding A.G., Chiron Corporation and Bayer in the last month in a bid to find a partner to help his money-losing company sell kits that help doctors select the appropriate drugs for individual patients being treated for AIDS. The shares of Visible Genetics, which is based in Toronto, rose 87.5 cents each, to $17.875, giving the company a market value of $130 million.

title: Russian Success Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Operating Costs Are Down While Energy Capacity Is Up : Windmills Are on a Roll
description: PARIS  Most modern technologies seem to develop in leaps and bounds by overnight revolutionary discoveries. Not so windmills. The world's fastest growing form of energy production has developed through slow, incremental advances in technology as well as through changes in political attitudes over decades.

title: BANK OF AMERICA TO BUY BACK UP TO 130 MILLION SHARES
description: The Bank of America Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 130 million shares, or about $9.3 billion, of its stock. The buyback, to occur over the next 18 to 24 months, represents about 7.5 percent of its stock. The bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., had 1.74 billion shares outstanding as of March 31. Bank of America has assets of $614 billion and operations in 22 states and the District of Columbia. Its stock fell $1.1875, to $70.5625.

title: A Flying Tour Of New/Old Berlin
description: In the zippy German film ''Run Lola Run,'' directed by Tom Tykwer, a young woman sprints by the steel-framed Marschallbrucke, top, and under the brick-vaulted Oberbaumbrucke, above, down the Friedrichstrasse and across the famous Gendarmenmarkt square.

title: In Berlin, a Renovation Focuses Its Attentions On Past and Future
description: What's new about the New Berlin? Berliners are exploring different and exciting options for buildings, and Americans are jumping at the chance to build them. An expatriate American architect trained at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Rebecca Chestnutt, 41, did the $50 million Alexanderplatz train station renovation, above and left, with her partner, Robert Niess, 41, a fellow American.

title: In a Glass Box, Secrets Are Hard to Keep
description: HOW could a structure as transparent as the Farnsworth House hold a secret?

title: Economic Scene; Solutions can become problems for mental illness insurance.
description: THE White House conference earlier this month on mental illness highlighted the Administration's campaign, led by Tipper Gore, to achieve ''parity for all'' -- requiring health insurers to provide the same coverage for mental illness that they provide for physical illness. Bills in Congress would do the same.

title: Courier Has Been There, Done That
description: For starters, Jim Courier, whose habitual first-round departures from Wimbledon in the past three years had been made in obscurity on the hintercourts, had to remember how to make his bow to the Royal Box as he marched onto Center Court.

title: Loved Strictures In a Lenient Age
description: Upon learning of the imminent arrival of a new edition of The Elements of Style, Strunk and White's concise and to many seminal guide to American language, I went back to the current edition, and in 10 minutes of perusal I was reminded of things needed to sharpen one's writing skills. I was certainly struck with the realization that everyone who writes, whether it be books or journalism or corporate reports, should go back to this or a similar work every few years for a refresher. The fourth edition of Elements will be in bookstores in several weeks, and it could become an unlikely but tremendously amusing and helpful beach read.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Dharmsala Journal; As the World Heals, Tibet's Exiles Feel Forsaken
description: The improbable news of free elections in Indonesia has given Tibetan exiles like Thupten Samphel a deepening sense of melancholy.

title: Pitfalls of Office 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Freeze Funds Linked to Milosevic and 4 Others
description: Federal authorities today froze any funds in Switzerland belonging to Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, and four high-ranking associates who were indicted along with him by the international war crimes tribunal last month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSTRAU, IRENE
description: OSTRAU-Irene. We miss you as much as ever. Stanley and Bert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Top Players Competing For Ryder Cup Points
description: Imagine a United States Ryder Cup team this fall without Fred Couples, Justin Leonard, Tom Lehman and Lee Janzen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: 20 More Are Charged in Bid Rigging at Co-ops
description: In another step in the wide-ranging investigation of corruption in the management of co-ops and condominiums, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday the indictment of 20 waterproofing contractors, managing agents, architects and engineers who prosecutors say colluded to rig the bidding for millions of dollars of work at 94 buildings.

title: Maybe the City Charter Could Use an Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Houses Beckon, Senate Awaits
description: AS the rumors drift along tiny Main Street here like a fog that just won't lift, the citizens of this bucolic town are gearing up for the onslaught of stone-faced Secret Service personnel, paparazzi and television vans.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a poll of corporate managers involved in Year 2000 computer projects misstated the position of Gary Beach of CIO Magazine, which was a sponsor of the poll. He is the magazine's publisher, not its editor.

title: Would School Prayer Satisfy Either Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, ARNOLD
description: GREENBLATT - Arnold. The Board of Trustees of Temple Hillel of Flatlands announces with great sorrow the passing of President Arnold Greenblatt. He will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife Betty; his children Susan and Mark Miller and Ruth and Marty Cole; grandchildren Evan and Jason Miller and Lauren Weissler; sisters Clara and Judy and brothers Ernest and Robert.

title: CUMULUS MEDIA BUYS NINE RADIO STATIONS FOR $51 MILLION
description: Cumulus Media Inc. said yesterday that it had bought nine radio stations for $51 million in Alabama, Texas and Florida. Cumulus bought five stations featuring rap and hip-hop music in the Mobile, Ala., area for $25 million; a contemporary music station and a country music station in the McAllen-Brownsville-Harlingen area of Texas for $17 million; and two stations, one featuring classic rock and one talk-formatted station, in Pensacola, Fla., for $9 million. Cumulus, which is based in Milwaukee, said it had no stations in those areas prior to its most recent purchases. Its stock rose 43.75 cents, to $17.

title: Quicktime's Virtues
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Knicks Use Heft, But It's Useless
description: The Knicks had been careful before Game 4 not to brag about their defense on David Robinson and Tim Duncan, no matter how few shots Duncan had taken in the fourth quarter of Game 3, no matter how little of a factor he was.

title: In Kosovo, Beginning the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Tours, Icons and Exhibitions
description: Starck Objects

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, STUART
description: WEISSMAN-Stuart. 6/24/98. His courage, strength and love is missed by his family and friends. Stuart will never be forgotten, his memory will remain in our hearts forever. Weissman/Priven Family

title: It's Heart vs. Height, and Knicks Fall Short
description: It was early in the fourth quarter last night, and Latrell Sprewell received a basic entry pass from Allan Houston in the low post. Maybe eight feet from the basket, he turned what was shaping up to be another bland possession into great theater.

title: Back to the Classics
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rare Edison Recordings To Be Played and Copied
description: Thousands of musical works recorded by Thomas A. Edison haven't been played for 70 years because they are just too fragile. But starting on Monday, the Edison National Historic Site in West Orange will begin transferring the recordings onto compact disks and recording tape with equipment bought with a grant from the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences.

title: Coke Bottling Site in France Is Given Clean Bill of Health
description: The French authorities lifted a ban today on canned Coca-Cola soft drinks produced at a bottling plant here, saying they had found no evidence of contamination to explain an outbreak of nausea by people who drank them in Belgium early this month.

title: Louis Diamond, 97, a Pediatrics Legend, Dies
description: Dr. Louis K. Diamond, who developed a revolutionary transfusion method to save newborn babies with Rh disease, died on June 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 97.

title: Rising Costs Pushing Film Production Abroad, Study Says
description: About 27 percent of American movies and television series made last year were filmed outside the United States to save money, costing the nation the equivalent of 23,500 full-time jobs and more than $10 billion, according to a study being released on Friday by two Hollywood unions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'BRIEN, LOIS
description: O'BRIEN-Lois. September 10th, 1942-June 25th, 1996. We miss you more than words can say. Not a day passes without our thinking of you. You live in our hearts. Jack and Jeremiah

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Sports of The Times; Please Note: Money Shot, Money Player
description: THEY give you this target, a huge glass board, and they paint thick white lines in the middle, right above the cylinder in which you would like the ball to drop. They do everything but write in the words: Aim Here, Win Valuable Prizes.

title: For Knicks, One Last New-Look Offense?
description: The Knicks have tweaked the lineup and shifted the load with each bit of attrition. They needed more scoring, so Latrell Sprewell became a starter again. The team's stamina flagged, so Marcus Camby got his first start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: For the Love of Money And the Risks of Making It
description: Ewan McGregor was sexy as an unusually cheerful Scottish heroin addict in ''Trainspotting.'' Ewan McGregor was sexy as a Jane Austen country gentleman singing duets at the pianoforte with Gwyneth Paltrow in ''Emma.'' Ewan McGregor is even a little sexy as the young Obi Wan Kenobi, grossly overshadowed by Liam Neeson's character, in ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace.'' But Ewan McGregor is not even remotely sexy as a panicked futures trader in ''Rogue Trader,'' a new Cinemax movie about a very young man who singlehandedly, accidentally brings down the oldest merchant bank in the world. And it's not just the dreadful black-and-yellow-striped jackets that Mr. McGregor's character and his financial team wear to work.

title: Some Doctors See Relief In Plan for A.M.A. Union
description: The weekly managers' meetings at the Family Physicians Group, a private practice here, almost always include a lot of angry discussion about the increasing frustrations of dealing with health maintenance organizations and other managed-care insurance companies.

title: NALCO CHEMICAL SAYS IT IS CONDUCTING MERGER TALKS
description: The Nalco Chemical Company, the world's largest producer of water-treatment chemicals, said yesterday that it was in talks over a possible merger. Nalco shares rose $3.625, to $40.875. Nalco, based in Naperville, Ill., did not specify the company it was negotiating with or what type of deal it was discussing. Nalco, with annual sales of about $1.57 billion, makes water-treatment chemicals for municipalities, paper companies, steelmakers and other companies. Slower demand in Asia and Latin America and stagnant growth in the paper industry drove prices lower the last year, hurting profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSEN, LINDA
description: KISSEN-Linda. On June 17, 1999. Beloved cousin of Richard and Ann Kamholtz, Jules and Aileen Whitman and all of their children. Private services were held at Mt. Zion Cemetery. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDGE, ELLIOTT RUSSELL
description: HEDGE-Elliott Russell. Bremen, Maine. Died June 23,1999. Services private. Retired Senior VP, Merchants National Bank, Boston

title: One Network, Two Analysts: A Study in Contrast on NBC
description: Doug Collins strode rapidly across the Madison Square Garden hardwood Wednesday night before Game 4 of the National Basketball Association finals. When he stopped, Collins, an NBC Sports analyst and former N.B.A. coach, sounded overly caffeinated, overly excited. Only his brush cut lacked conspicuous animation.

title: Commander Is Expected To Be Named Police Chief
description: Chief Joseph P. Dunne, who directs the Police Department's Housing Bureau and has spent much of his career policing his native Brooklyn, is expected to be named Chief of Department, according to several people with knowledge of the selection process.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POST, SHELDON
description: POST-Sheldon. September 5, 1936 -June 25, 1988. Founder, Chelsea Pines Inn. Chairman, NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Board member, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah and Caring Community. Friend, lover, family member, community leader. As we celebrate the 30th anniversary of Stonewall, we remember and celebrate Sheldon and all our friends and loved ones who have gone before us in the ongoing battle against AIDS. From Stephen Sondheim: ''Sometimes people leave you halfway through the wood. Do not let it grieve you. No one leaves for good. You are not alone. No one is alone.'' Sleep well, my beloved, and know that as long as we live, you too will live. Jay Lesiger

title: An Old Political Feud Shapes a Battle for a District Leader Job in Manhattan
description: The job of a district leader, the lowest rung on the ladder of political offices, is not typically the object of intense competition. But there is an exception in northern Manhattan, where a battle is escalating between the camps of two longtime political adversaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: French-Fry Heaven
description: No doubt about it, New York is french-fry crazy. Here are 12 of the best places to indulge. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: THAI HOTEL BATTLE ENDS
description: In an improbable end to an improbable takeover battle, an American-born Thai entrepreneur fended off Goldman Sachs Group, which had hoped to acquire control of the Regent Hotel of Bangkok. The entrepreneur, William E. Heinecke, attracted less than 3 percent of the shares with his final offer of 43 Thai baht, or $1.17, a share. But Goldman failed to go above 50 percent. Goldman, which had offered 48 baht, or $1.30, a share, ended up with a 40.5 percent stake -- making it the Regent's largest, but not controlling, shareholder.

title: Leaders of Kosovo Rebels Tied to Deadly Power Play
description: The senior commanders of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which signed a disarmament agreement with NATO, carried out assassinations, arrests and purges within their ranks to thwart potential rivals, say current and former commanders in the rebel army and some Western diplomats.

title: U.S. and Airline to Examine Accident Cluster
description: Federal safety officials said yesterday that they planned to investigate why American Airlines, the country's second-largest airline, has had more accidents in the last six years than any other major domestic carrier. The announcement comes in the aftermath of the crash of an American jet in Little Rock, Ark., that killed 10 passengers and a pilot earlier this month.

title: Does Faith Have A Public Role?; A Starting Point
description: To the Editor:

title: SOFTBANK VENTURES
description: Japan's Internet powerhouse, the Softbank Corporation, said it would set up two on-line businesses in toys and investment advice, along with three new venture capital funds that could invest up to $1.6 billion in start-ups in the country's fledgling Internet industry. Softbank is teaming with the Bandai Company, Yahoo Japan and five others to sell toys on line and will be joined by the Microsoft Corporation, Directadvice.com and other companies in offering financial advice to investors.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, RALPH
description: ALTMAN-Ralph. Died June 23rd, 90 years of age. Brother of David R. Altman; uncle of Rosalind Warshauer and Emily and Dara Altman; great uncle of Lionel and Samantha Warshauer and Asher Lennon. He spent his entire life helping others, especially his mother Yetta and his late sister Pearl. A former NYC school teacher, he was paticularly patient and giving to children. Ralph prized his close relationship with family and friends, particularly John Carver. We will all miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Game Blocker To Be Installed On Windows
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to introduce a feature in its Windows operating system allowing users to determine what kinds of games can be played on the computer. Such a feature could enable parents to keep a game with gruesome violence, offensive language or nudity from being played, based on the game's content rating.

title: Microsoft in Deal for Swedish Company
description: Skandia Insurance A.B., the top insurer in Scandinavia, said today that it had accepted a bid from the Microsoft Corporation of 1.1 billion kronor ($130 million) for Sendit A.B., a Swedish software maker, paving the way for a takeover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Urban Gorillas
description: The Congo Gorilla Forest at the Bronx Zoo is the ideal place for two similar but mutually suspicious species to get to know one another. Yesterday, after the official opening ceremonies, a cluster of sophisticated New York humans eyed a female gorilla through one of the exhibit's new glass windows. The silky creature, who seemed unimpressed by cameras and credentials, suddenly began clapping her hands. Instantly, the well-dressed humans responded with vigorous hand-clapping of their own -- more evidence, it seems, that the Bronx Zoo has thought of everything. These 19 gorillas will not only enjoy a healthy vegetarian diet and more urban living space than Donald Trump, but also a steady flow of humans to entertain them.

title: Odyssey of Loss and War in a Land of Languid Beauty
description: In 1968, on her 24th birthday, Barbara Sonneborn, the director, writer and producer of the unforgettable documentary film ''Regret to Inform,'' learned that her husband and high-school sweetheart, Jeff Gurvitz, had been killed in Vietnam. ''We regret to inform'' began the telegram. Eight weeks earlier, her husband had left the United States to fight in Southeast Asia. He died during a mortar attack at Khe Sanh while attempting to rescue his radio operator.

title: Ungodly Goings-On in a Forsaken Town's Church
description: With its rapid pretitle images of a young couple in bed in the morning light, of soberly dressed men and women filing into a church, of a woman fleeing from a house into woods, of a young man donning the garb of a clergyman and delivering a sermon from the Book of Job before bluntly dismissing his disgruntled congregation, ''The Broken Giant'' cloaks itself in an immediate air of theological profundity and secular mystery.

title: A Model for Penn Station Is on View at the Modern
description: A model of the proposed design for the new Pennsylvania Station has been placed on view at the Museum of Modern Art. The display will remain on the fourth-floor landing outside the museum's architecture and design galleries until Aug. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Taking the Fed's Measure; Focus Shifts to the Central Bank's Long-Term Agenda
description: Is it 1994 all over again, the beginning of a prolonged series of interest rate increases intended to wring inflationary pressures out of an economy that is threatening to overheat?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRYZAK, ROSE M.
description: KRYZAK-Rose M., on June 24, 1999, in her 100th year. Beloved wife of the late George; devoted mother of Ann and Tom; caring mother-in-law of Joel and Betty;. loving grandmother of Greg, Jean, Judd, Rebecca, Lauren and Jaime; adoring great-grandmother of Jacqueline; cherished aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, June 27, 3PM at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Contributions may be made to the ''Rose Kryzak StateWide Legacy Fund'' c/o StateWide Senior Action Council, 275 State St., Albany, NY 12210.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, BESS
description: GRUBER-Bess, at the age of ninety-five, Thursday, June 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leon, loving mother and mother-in-law to Norma, Sandy, Lucille and Sheldon; grandmother to Lauren, Alexandra, Bruce, Barry, Jennifer and Rachel; great-grandmother to Danielle, Dylan, Kathleen, Joshua, Alexa, Rebeka, Bryan, Jacob, Jonah and Kelvin. Services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY on Sunday, June 27 at 10:30 am. We were indeed blessed to have had her with us for so long. She will fondly be remembered as a warm, gracious and elegant lady.

title: U.S. Move Has Hong Kong Worried It Will Lose Trade
description: Fears about Hong Kong's future as an Asian trading post have grown here in the days since the United States Senate moved to tighten controls on exports to this former British colony in response to a Congressional report on military espionage and China.

title: Compassion, the Political Liability
description: Has compassion become a Republican virtue? Seems like it.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'Amy's View' Without Its Star

title: INSIDE
description: Union Victory a Milestone

title: National News Briefs; Hint of Compromise On Gun-Control Measure
description: Less than a week after House Democrats voted against a gun-control package rather than accept what they said were soft terms in a measure to regulate gun shows, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, seemed to open the door at least a crack today to some sort of compromise on that point.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a deal under which the food store Balducci's in Greenwich Village has become a subsidiary of Sutton Place Gourmet misstated the store's age. It is 53 years old, not 83.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, RANDEE
description: LEWIS-Randee. 4/30/57-7/15/70-Tammuz 11. Lewis/Hurwitz

title: Serbs Flee While Albanians Loot, And Marines Find Peace Is Tricky
description: If the United States marines who have taken over this remote part of southeastern Kosovo came to forge peace between Kosovo's Serbs and Albanians, the result was anything but.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SEYMOUR
description: BLOOM-Seymour. Of Valley Stream, NY, died peacefully at home on June 22. He is survived by his loving wife Mildred and family. In his memory, donations may be made to Temple Gates of Zion, Valley Stream.

title: Uncertainty on Implants
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew Plans National Search to Fill Jobs After Shake-Up
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has hired a private firm to help conduct a nationwide search to fill vacancies in the ranks of principals and superintendents that he created with his shake-up of the city's lowest-performing schools, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: How Everyone Can Win at Lotto
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERNS, ADRIENNE IRIS
description: MERNS-Adrienne Iris. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds express their deep sorrow on the tragic and untimely passing of the beloved daughter of Sy Syms, our former Chairman of the Board and ardent supporter, and Ruth Merns, and stepdaughter of Lynn Syms and sister of Marcy, Laura, Robert and Richard. Our hearts go out to the bereaved. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and may her memory be for a blessing. Gideon Patt, President & CEO Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg, National Campaign Chairman Howard Hirsch, New York Regional Chairman

title: Uncertainty on Implants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, JOAN
description: HERTZ-Joan. Beloved wife of Hamilton, loving mother of Jonathan and Eric, adoring grandmother of Lisa, Michelle, Stephanie, and Allison. An inspiration and paragon of strength to all. Services Sunday, 9:30AM at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: City Council Panel Approves Revised Safeguards Against Lead Paint
description: After a long day of public testimony and some tense back-room negotiations, the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee approved legislation yesterday to clarify the laws that are supposed to protect children from poisoning caused by lead paint.

title: Album of the Week
description: MISSY MISDEMEANOR ELLIOTT: ''Da Real World'' (Gold Mind/ EastWest), and THE CHEMICAL BROTHERS: ''Surrender'' (Astralwerks). Two of the finest party albums of 1997 were Ms. Elliott's future-minded rap and rhythm-and-blues debut, ''Supa Dupa Fly,'' and the Chemical Brothers' big-beat electronic rump-shaker, ''Dig Your Own Hole.'' But the party has ended for both of these acts: in the intervening years, their style has been widely imitated and, partly in response, both have forced themselves forward, darkening and mellowing their sound, indulging in many (perhaps too many) collaborations and, in the case of the Chemical Brothers, sampling Ms. Elliott's music.

title: Suspect in Embassy Bombings Avows Innocence in Letters to Relatives
description: A Texas man accused of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in attacks against Americans said in recent letters to his family that he was innocent and accused American officials of not acting quickly enough to prevent the bombings of United States Embassies in Africa last August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALL, HERMAN
description: DALL-Herman, cherished husband of Rebecca, devoted and loving father of Carol and Alan, adored grandfather of Nicole. A light is gone out of our lives. Services at Cedar Park Cemetery at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ, 1PM Fri., June 25.

title: NABISCO IS CLOSING HOUSTON BAKERY AND CUTTING 450 JOBS
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the largest United States cookie and cracker maker, said yesterday that it would close its Houston bakery by Nov. 20, cutting 450 jobs. Nabisco, maker of Oreo and Chips Ahoy cookies and Ritz crackers, said the closing followed a study showing that its existing bakery capacity exceeded its needs. It has also closed a Pittsburgh plant as part of a companywide reorganization put in place by its chief executive, James M. Kilts, to tighten systems and production. A Nabisco spokesman said that the company hoped that Houston would be the final plant to close, but that the company would again re-evaluate its baking needs at the end of the year.

title: Political Briefing; As the World Turns, The Fordices Fight
description: In our last installment, Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi had just returned from vacationing in France with a woman not his wife and had demanded a divorce. His wife, Pat, had responded that she did not want to dissolve a marriage of 44 years and intended to remain ensconced in the Governor's Mansion. She said the other woman, Ann Creson, an old flame of the Governor, would just have to wait her turn. Mrs. Fordice then offered ''apologies for being a partner in a marriage that has become a source of embarrassment for Mississippi.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Union Victory at Plant in South Is Labor Milestone
description: Workers at the nation's largest tex tile plant a huge brick fortress of resistance to labor organizing in the South -- apparently ended a 93-year epoch on Wednesday night and voted to allow a textile workers union inside the walls to represent them.

title: Big Winner In Shake-Up
description: Perhaps the biggest winner in the shake-up of the school system announced by Chancellor Rudy Crew on Wednesday was a player whose role was largely behind the scenes: the teachers' union.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: * The State Department announced a $5 million reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of anyone wanted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, including President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Saint Clair Cemin
description: Cheim & Read

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Internet's lure spurs a round of real and imagined deal making.
description: ON the Internet almost anything is possible.

title: The Face of Evil, All Peaches and Cream
description: Evil wears an all-American glow in Neil LaBute's ''Bash: Latter-Day Plays,'' which opened last night at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. The characters in this transfixing evening of monologues have that sheen of idealized, corn-country wholesomeness that Madison Avenue has always put such a premium on: clear skin, sparkling eyes and teeth to make an orthodontist cheer. To look at, they're the human equivalents of a glass of milk.

title: The Belgrade Bombing Mystery
description: Seven weeks after NATO bombs hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Congress and the American people have yet to receive a full explanation of the mistaken attack. The absence of information only compounds the original error and fuels speculation that the bombing was deliberate. The White House should insist that the various agencies involved, including the Pentagon, which has just announced its own review, pull together everything they know and make a public presentation as soon as possible.

title: Student Strike in Capital Jarring All of Mexico
description: The student strike at Mexico's biggest university began on April 20 as a protest against a plan by the administration to make those who could afford it pay tuition.

title: Morgan Stanley Earnings Rise Above Expectations
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, demonstrating strength in its securities trading and credit card businesses, posted second-quarter results yesterday that beat analysts' expectations.

title: MINING COMPANY TALKS
description: Mexico's largest mining company, Grupo Mexico S.A., said it was in acquisition or merger talks with seven mining companies in Canada, the United States and South America. The company declined to name the companies or the cost of a possible transaction. But three United States copper mines owned by the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia could be sold to Grupo Mexico for a as much as $400 million, according to a report in the Internet edition of The Australian Financial Review.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Political Briefing; The Preview in Iowa Is Drawing a Crowd
description: Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucuses are still seven months off, but the frequency with which Presidential candidates are showing up in the state makes it seem as if the big event is nearly at hand. And in a sense it is.

title: High Court Sends Claim Of Disability To Rehearing
description: The United States Supreme Court followed up its new, restrictive views limiting protections for disabled Americans yesterday by setting aside a lower court ruling in New York that said state officials had discriminated against a law school graduate with a reading disorder who failed the state's bar examination five times.

title: Three Unions Say Conflicts Will Delay Merger
description: The planned merger of three of the nation's largest industrial unions -- the auto workers, the steelworkers and the machinists -- has stumbled into major problems, with the machinists deciding to move more slowly toward merger than the other two unions.

title: The Coke Stomach Ache Heard Round the World
description: Sixteen days ago, Sasha Cockx bought his midday Coke at the School of St. Mary and flipped back the bottle cap to collect the token underneath. Collecting 500 points -- one from each small bottle, three from a large one -- could produce a cellular telephone for only about $75, the 14-year-old scholar said. It is a prize he is not likely to collect.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about the United Nations' decision to delay a vote on the future of East Timor misidentified the independence campaigner who said he supported the decision. It was Jose Ramos-Horta, not Jose Alexandre Gusmao. The report also referred incorrectly to Mr. Gusmao. He is not a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. Mr. Ramos-Horta shared the 1996 prize with Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo, another East Timorese advocate.

title: China to Get World Bank Loan Despite U.S. Objections
description: The World Bank overruled the United States today and approved a $160 million antipoverty loan for China. However, it agreed to delay financing for the resettlement of 58,000 farmers in a traditionally ethnic Tibetan area until an independent review board determines whether the program meets the bank's environmental and resettlement standards.

title: $19.5 Billion Budget Set By Lawmakers in Trenton
description: Blessed with a robust economy and more than $450 million in unexpected revenues, the New Jersey Legislature today approved a $19.5 billion budget that provides modest property tax rebates, increases school spending and sets aside $98 million in state funds to preserve open space.

title: Sao Paulo Journal; Can a Melodic Priest Be Good for the Church?
description: His debut CD has sold more than three million copies, and when he takes the stage here, supported by a four-piece electric band and two backup singers, thousands of his admirers greet him with roars and applause. But Marcelo Rossi is not a pop music idol: he is a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Reprieve for Inner-City Miami Cab Company
description: Society Cab, which has had six drivers shot to death in the last 20 years while providing the only taxi service in Miami's tough, inner-city neighborhoods, has won a reprieve from a Miami-Dade County ordinance that had threatened to put the 50-year-old company out of business.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Left His Heart On Madison Avenue

title: Does Faith Have A Public Role?; Religion and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about School District 12 in the Bronx, whose superintendent was removed this week by Chancellor Rudy Crew, misidentified Yvonne Malcolm Spears. She is interim acting assistant principal of Public School 195, not acting principal.

title: Residential Real Estate; Chelsea Factory Plans to Go Condo
description: For most of this century, the neo-Renaissance industrial building at 126 West 22d Street housed offices and light manufacturing operations. Now it is becoming the neighborhood's latest loft condominium.

title: Three Ring Faces Better Than Honour
description: The Triple Tiara series for fillies got off to a controversial start earlier this month when Three Ring survived an interference complaint in the homestretch and won the Acorn Stakes by a head over Better Than Honour. The two fillies were named yesterday as co-favorites in a field of seven for tomorrow's $250,000 Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont Park, the middle race in the series.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They took all our things. Now it is our turn to take all of their things. ''

title: 5 Iraqis Are Released From U.S. Detention Center
description: After being held for two years in a detention center in Los Angeles, five Iraqis were freed today and reunited with their families here, where they will be allowed to find jobs and stay until another country agrees to give them permanent political asylum.

title: Does Faith Have A Public Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Irish Struggle For a Visual Poetry To Call Their Own
description: The Irish have a big presence in New York right now, and St. Patrick has nothing to do with it. Four prominent institutions -- uptown and down, as well as in Long Island City, Queens -- have conspired to put quite a bit of Irish culture on display, forming what is being called an ''Irish Arts Celebration.''

title: Pretty Much In the Dark And Minus The Humor
description: Everything connects and everything dissolves in the songs of the Beta Band, a Scottish group that played to a packed Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night. Listening to the Beta Band's albums creates the impression, not entirely unwarranted, that its members like to spin obscure records and share stoned-out jokes, as if their idea of a good time was comparing outtakes from out-of-print B-movie soundtracks. Their recordings are collectors' showcases. Like Beck, Prince Paul and other 1990's hipsters, they segue from option to option, from folk-rock to burbling synthesizers to gruff rap to pop-up sound effects, making transitions with droll ingenuity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are 1.8% Higher on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market edged up 1.8 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the stock market, said yesterday.

title: New Trial Is Sought By Ex-Officer
description: Seeking to win a new trial for Charles Schwarz, one of the police officers convicted in the Abner Louima case, defense lawyers asserted yesterday that prosecutors had failed to turn over evidence the defense said showed that Mr. Schwarz had played no role in the torture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVISKY, LEONARD P.
description: STAVISKY-Leonard P. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of New York State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky, distinguished 1945 graduate of City College, former faculty member and administrator at City College, Brooklyn College, Kingsborough Community College, and Queensboro Community College and former member of the New York City Council. He was an unwavering supporter of accessible and high quality public higher education as chairman of the State Assembly Education Committee and as ranking minority member of the State Senate Higher Education Committee. His vigorous advocacy for CUNY in the Legislature will be long remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Toby, son Evan, and the entire Stavisky family. Herman Badillo, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Christoph M. Kimmich, Interim Chancellor

title: Gates Memo Deals a Blow To Microsoft
description: The absent star made a final appearance in the Microsoft antitrust trial today when a Government lawyer introduced as evidence a comment by William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, that knocked the legs from under his legal team's most important defensive strategy.

title: R. G. Neumann, 83, Diplomat Fired by Haig From Saudi Post
description: Robert G. Neumann, whose dismissal as the American Ambassador to Saudi Arabia in 1981 revealed fissures in President Reagan's first foreign policy team, died of cancer in Los Angeles last Friday. He was 83.

title: Charles Henri Ford -- 'Printed Matter 1929-1969'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: National News Briefs; A Second Gun Charge Filed in Littleton Case
description: A man already charged with selling the handgun used in the killings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., was charged on Wednesday with another firearms violation, possession of a shotgun with a sawed-off barrel and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, PRESTON H.
description: LONG-Preston H. Died peacefully on Wednesday, June 23rd. Ambassador at large to the UN. Member of Finance Committee for the election of President Reagan. Former officer of J.O.B. Beloved brother of Gene Long. Brother-inlaw of Phyllis Long of New York City. Dear uncle of Betty Kelsey and Jackie Horn of Charlottesville. Beloved brother of deceased Dr. Rolfe Long and sister Marie Balz. Services to be held at The Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, on Friday June 25th at 11am. Donations in his memory can be sent to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson St. NYC, NY 10002-8201, or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Romuald Hazoume
description: The Project

title: All Israel on Line; Not Against Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Arrested in Killing Of Man Found on Beach
description: Two men were arrested yesterday in the killing of a 19-year-old man who was found beaten and drowned on a beach in Queens on Tuesday, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, ELIZABETH H.
description: RAYMOND-Elizabeth H. On June 22, 1999, at Canaan, CT. Longtime resident of Pelham, NY. Past editor at Interiors magazine. Mother of Abigail R. Salaway. Donations to the Bissel Fund, c/o Kenny Funeral Home, 860-364-5709.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES IS BUYING SPRING RAM FOR $129 MILLION
description: U.S. Industries agreed yesterday to buy the Spring Ram Corporation, a British maker of bathroom and kitchen products, for $129 million in cash to bolster its Jacuzzi Inc. whirlpool-bath unit. Spring Ram makes acrylic-jetted baths, shower enclosures, counter tops and other bathroom items. The company has annual revenue of about $280 million. Last month, the board of U.S. Industries, which is based in Iselin, N.J., approved the spinoff of its diversified businesses, which include vacuum cleaners and auto interiors businesses, to focus on its bathroom products business and two other units: the Lighting Corporation of America and USI Hardware and Tools.

title: Thompson Buys Specialized Agency
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C., said yesterday that it had acquired Dazai Advertising in San Jose, Calif., which specializes in technology accounts. Financial terms of the deal were undisclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAAB, EUGENE
description: RAAB-Eugene. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eugene Raab, associated with The Times from August 1964 until retiring in April 1980.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Safety; G.M. Develops Sensor To Make Trunks Safer
description: AFTER 11 children died last summer in separate incidents in which they became trapped in car trunks, General Motors and other companies set out to design a release inside the trunk. They did, and G.M., which developed a big yellow handle that is illuminated when the trunk is closed, made a $50 kit including the handle available at its dealerships.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
description: The heated accusations of monopoly, the lively E-mail flavored with capitalist aggression and the spirited testimony alleging and denying misconduct came to a close today as the last witness stepped off the stand in the Microsoft antitrust trial, eight months after proceedings began.

title: Unionized Medicine
description: The American Medical Association has taken on the managed care industry with its vote to create an affiliated labor union for doctors who are salaried employees. The decision was surprising for a hidebound organization whose members have traditionally and sometimes arrogantly presented themselves as part of an elite profession as opposed to members of a workers' group. But unionization seems inevitable as doctors seek ways to recover their clout against powerful health plans. For consumers, unionization may be a positive force if doctors use collective bargaining to negotiate for improved patient services rather than merely for higher physician pay.

title: Medicare Drug Plan Worries Democrats
description: Medicare officials said today that they had told the White House that its initial hope of offering coverage of prescription drugs for a premium of no more than $25 a month was unrealistic.

title: Top Obie Award Goes to Arnold
description: Arnold Communications in Boston took top honors, winning Best of Show, at the 57th annual Obie Awards for creative excellence sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.

title: Television Ratings Down
description: NBC's ratings for the National Basketball Association finals continued to falter during Game 4 of the Knicks-Spurs series, which produced a 12.0 Nielsen rating, down by 37 percent from the comparable game last year, when Chicago played Utah.

title: Battered by Nigerians Early, Hamm Delivers Knockout Punch
description: Sixteen jittery minutes into tonight's match against Nigeria, Mia Hamm had been knocked down at least three times. When a Nigerian player tried to help her up, Hamm turned her back, clearly furious with the hard tackling. Soccer's greatest female player was about to begin a little hammering of her own.

title: DNA Leads to Arrest in '73 Slaying in New Haven
description: In an unsolved murder case that has haunted New Haven for 26 years, authorities using DNA analysis arrested a 56-year-old auto mechanic yesterday and charged him with stabbing Concetta (Penny) Serra to death in a parking garage in 1973.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL MAKING IT HARDER TO SEIZE PROPERTY
description: An unusual coalition of liberals and conservatives persuaded the House of Representatives to approve legislation today to make it much harder for Federal and state law enforcement authorities to confiscate property before they bring criminal charges in narcotics and other cases.

title: Argentine Politics-Soccer Case Reverses Field
description: The boundary between politics and soccer can be extremely fine in Argentina, especially when it comes to the travails of Diego Maradona, the former World Cup sensation and on-again, off-again political ally of President Carlos Saul Menem.

title: Atlanta Selects Its Team Today
description: The newest member of the National Hockey League, the expansion Atlanta Thrashers, will select its team for next season in the expansion draft today at the Fleet Center in Boston.

title: F.B.I. Team Looks for Evidence of Massacres
description: F.B.I. forensic teams began sifting through evidence this morning at two houses that are believed to be massacre sites in hopes of helping the prosecution of Slobodan Milosevic and other Serbian leaders charged with war crimes.

title: Van Gundy Says His Return Has Been Assured
description: Jeff Van Gundy yesterday gave the clearest sign that he will return as Knicks coach next season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: POLISH BANK PURCHASE
description: Ireland's largest bank, Allied Irish Banks P.L.C., made another major investment in Polish banking and financial services. Allied Irish Banks bought 80 percent of Bank Zachodni from the state treasury for $580 million, about 15 percent more than analysts had expected.
