In 1991, Allied Irish Banks bought 60 percent of the Wielkopolski Bank Kreditowy. Bank Zadochni is Poland's ninth largest, in terms of deposits, and has 6,981 employees.

title: Toba Khedoori
description: David Zwirner

title: David LaChapelle
description: Tony Shafrazi Gallery

title: Renaissance For a Quirky Designer
description: Jean Royere has never been a household name, until now. This French decorator, furniture and lighting designer, who lived from 1902 to 1981, was a great success in his day. But he was nearly forgotten after death.

title: The Irish Struggle For Visual Poetry
description: The Irish have a big presence in New York right now, as several prominent institutions put quite a bit of Irish culture on display in what is being called an ''Irish Arts Celebration.'' Modern and contemporary Irish art can be surveyed in exhibitions at three sites, including the Grey Art Gallery at New York University, where Sir William Orpen's ''Ready to Start: Self-Portrait'' (1917), right, is among the 20th-century figurative paintings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JOYCE P.
description: DAVIS-Joyce P. On Tuesday June 22, 1999 of Arlington, VA. Sister of Jeanne L. Atherton of San Diego, CA. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY on Tuesday June 29 at 2pm. Murphy Funeral Home, Arlington, VA.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Courtroom Testimony Ends In Microsoft Antitrust Case

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES IS BUYING INTERNATIONAL COMFORT
description: The United Technologies Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the International Comfort Products Corporation, a maker of air-conditioning systems and other products, for $490 million. It will also assume debt of $230 million. International Comfort, based in Nashville, had annual sales of $733.5 million last year. It makes air-conditioning and heat pump systems, gas and oil furnaces, air handlers and accessories under a variety of brand names. United Technologies will fold the company into its Carrier Corporation unit, which had 1998 sales of $6.9 billion. Under the agreement, United Technologies will pay $11.75 for each of International Comfort's shares, which rose 68.75 cents yesterday, to $11.4375. United Technologies fell $1.50 a share, to $63.25.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: On My Mind; Slaves, Stay Out
description: Very quietly, without a word about it on paper, the United Nations is creating a new human rights policy for the organization and putting it into operation one step at a time.

title: 3 Serbs Found Slain at University in Pristina
description: A Serbian professor and two Serbian workers at the University of Pristina were shot to death overnight in a classroom building, according to the school's dean.

title: Teaching Children To Be Afraid
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

title: Two Victims In U.S. Raid Reportedly Were Spies
description: The American bombs that struck the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on May 7 destroyed the compound's intelligence-gathering nerve center, and two of the three Chinese killed were not journalists but intelligence officers, American officials and a Western diplomat said today.

title: Gannett Offers $1.5 Billion In British Deal
description: After more than a decade in which foreign investors, from Robert Maxwell to Conrad Black, bought newspapers in the United States, the Gannett Company reversed the trend yesterday, offering about $1.5 billion in cash plus assumed debt for Newsquest P.L.C., a regional newspaper publisher in Britain.

title: Compliments Of a Friend
description: At his death on Feb. 1 at 91, the philanthropist Paul Mellon left the National Gallery of Art in Washington the largest gift in its history: $75 million in cash plus more than 100 pictures, many of them masterpieces by artists like van Gogh, Manet, Cezanne, Monet and Renoir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Humans Found Closer Yet to Animals
description: For over three decades, basic texts in biology and psychology have informed their readers that humans' internal clock works differently from other animals'.

title: Jan Matulka
description: Richard York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Chicago Board of Trade Aligns With Eurex
description: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade approved an alliance with Eurex, clearing the way for the first trans-Atlantic link between the world's two biggest derivatives exchanges.

title: BRITISH ARMS CUTBACK
description: Europe's biggest arms company, British Aerospace P.L.C., said it would close a plant and airfield, cut 2,200 jobs and take after-tax charges of $:190 million ($300 million) this year and next, to improve its plane-making efficiency. British Aerospace will take a charge of $:145 million this year and one of $:45 million in 2000. The company will soon complete the acquisition of Marconi, to create the world's third-biggest aerospace and military company after Boeing and Lockheed Martin.

title: Maestro of Enthusiasm and Musical Cliches
description: YOU could call Ray Castoldi an organ player, but professionally speaking, he is more complex. As the Knicks' organist since 1989, Mr. Castoldi, a former nightclub deejay from Connecticut, has evolved into part basketball expert and part rock-concert producer with enough digital hardware to fill Madison Square Garden with gangsta rap and Wurlitzer-era classics that he simply calls ''Charge!'' and the ''Bullfight Song.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYGNOS, PETER N.
description: LYGNOS-Peter N. Memorial Service of remembrance will be held by his wife Anna and his children on Sunday, June 27, 1999 at 10 AM, St. John the Theologian Cathedral, 353 E. Clinton Ave., Tenafly, NJ.

title: Agencies mark gains and losses as large marketers make decisions on shifting accounts.
description: EVEN with hundreds of Madison Avenue executives away in Cannes, France, for the 46th International Advertising Festival, accounts have been moving around at a hectic pace.

title: Hearst Ends Its Search For an Editor
description: After months of speculation in the notoriously gossipy magazine world, Cathleen P. Black, the president of Hearst Magazines, has plucked the next editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar from the ranks of an archrival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: BELLSOUTH AGREES TO $5 BILLION CONTRACT WITH NORTEL
description: The BellSouth Corporation agreed yesterday to buy at least $5 billion of equipment and services from the Nortel Networks Corporation, as it seeks to update its worldwide networks with Internet technology. Nortel based in Brampton, Ontario, will supply BellSouth with equipment to handle wireless, data and Internet traffic over a 10-year period. BellSouth, based in Atlanta, is the dominant local telephone service provider in nine Southeastern states. It expects to sign a contract, the biggest ever for Nortel, by July 31. This year, it plans to spend $1 billion on Nortel gear.

title: Coca-Cola Acts Slowly but Credibly
description: Big international companies often seem to be operating on autopilot, and are therefore slow to sense when something has gone badly wrong that threatens not only immediate losses but the company's reputation, which is a brand-name company's most important asset.

title: Chamber Music as It Was
description: Chamber music, as its name implies, is music meant to be performed in chamber-size rooms. Historically, such performances were informal. When Mozart and some friends got together to play string quartets, they were taking part essentially in sight-reading sessions for the musicians involved, with sometimes an extra listener or two. And they were usually playing in someone's living room. Even when the idea of chamber music concerts took hold, these still tended to be private affairs in smaller spaces, at most a wealthy musical amateur's elegant salon with chandeliers, satin sofas and floor space for additional chairs.

title: A Father's Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Ray Charles Concert Is Canceled
description: The singer Ray Charles has canceled his performance tonight at the JVC Jazz Festival at Avery Fisher Hall because of acute laryngitis.

description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Lebanon Guerrillas and Israel Trade Rocket and Air Strikes
description: Israeli fighter planes bombarded Lebanon on Thursday night and early today while Shiite Muslim guerrillas fired rockets into northern Israel, with the exchanges reportedly leaving two Israelis and six Lebanese dead and dozens wounded. The action was a severe step-up in the conflict in southern Lebanon at a moment of political transition in Israel.

title: Martin Ramirez -- 'Previously Unseen Works'
description: Phyllis Kind Gallery

title: Threatened but Unruffled, a Persistent Beauty in Sea, Sky and Sand
description: By the sea, by the sea: That's where city dwellers long to go for renewal and inspiration, for play and the sweaty joys of a little publicly sanctioned voyeurism. It was not always so. For centuries the sea was a far cry from frolic and a close call with fear. The Lord destroyed all creatures once, by making the ocean rise up. The sea remained fearsome to journey on, fearsome to live near and home to monsters, one of which swallowed Jonah whole. Centuries later, some suspected that if Columbus ventured too far out he might sail off the edge of the earth into oblivion.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOG PRICES FALL. Hog prices slumped on concern that pork supplies are overwhelming demand as retailers promote beef for cookouts. In Chicago, hogs for July delivery fell 1.1 cents, or 2.1 percent, to 50.675 cents a pound.

title: The In-Laws as Outlaws
description: ''My Son the Fanatic'' begins with a social debacle as the parents of a young couple meet for the first time. The young woman's father, a high-ranking English police officer, is visibly aghast at the prospect of Pakistani in-laws like the taxi driver Parvez and his wife, Minoo. These two ought to be equally horrified by their host, but their many years in the industrial north of England have taught them to be accommodating no matter what. So the film, directed by Udayan Prasad and written with delicacy and wry humor by Hanif Kureishi, begins at the breaking point, the moment when that docile attitude is about to change.

title: Queens Is Where The World's Music Comes Together
description: If the term world music makes you think of wide-eyed, long-haired bohos noodling on the dance floor of a SoHo nightclub in their latest ethno-chic garb, then get yourself quickly to Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Protests Supplanted By Praise; Trump Place Becomes Real, and Even Popular
description: New Yorkers protested it, disparaged it, fought it with vitriol and lawsuits. Now they are moving into it.

title: Independent Mothers Aren't Alone
description: Sympathy and affection are the hallmarks of ''And Baby Makes Two,'' a narrowly focused documentary about a group of single New York women eager to have children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSTA, CHARLES J.
description: BUSTA-Charles J., 51, of New York, NY and Monkton, MD on June 21, 1999. Charles, known as CB was a graduate of Cathedral Latin High School, Class of 1966, and received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Dayton, Dayton, OH, and Master of Arts degree in Journalism from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL. He started his career at Noxell Corporation, a division of Proctor & Gamble Company. Most recently, he was an Executive Vice President, General Manager of Revlon Professional USA. He was a member of the board of directors of the Baltimore Tool Company and the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Bonnie and son of Charles and Ann Busta. Devoted father of Caroline. Cherished brother of Kathleen Kolick, and James and Richard Busta. Funeral services will be held at the Chapel of the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore, MD on Saturday, June 26, at 11am. Donations can be sent to the Charles CB Busta Lecture Series, Office of the President, College of Notre Dame of Maryland, 4701 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21210.

title: Battles With Umpire Do Not Distract Spencer
description: The last thing Shane Spencer needed tonight was to find himself in a crossfire of nasty words between the home plate umpire, Joe Brinkman, and the Yankee dugout. But there he was, a semi-innocent bystander, getting plugged with obscenities by Brinkman as he tried to get a hit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

description: SQUIRE-Helen Friedman. Beloved wife of the late Judge Sidney. Loving mother of Walter and Jason. Cherished mother-in-law of Dr. Sara Abramson. Devoted grandmother of Harrison, Russell, Zachary and Andrew. Service Friday, 12noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to DOROT, Inc., 171 W. 85 St, NY, NY 10024.

title: J. R. Kennedy, 87, Ex-Executive at Celanese
description: James Ross Kennedy, a former vice chairman of the Celanese Corporation of America, died on June 17 at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 87.

title: CITATION AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY CLOSELY HELD KELSO
description: The Citation Corporation, a metal-castings maker, agreed late yesterday to be acquired by the closely held Kelso & Company for about $644 million, including assumed debt. The transaction values Citation shares at $18.10 each, or about $325 million. The stock closed yesterday at $14.125, down 25 cents. Citation also said it expected to earn about 28 cents a share in the fiscal third quarter, which ends Sunday, short of the 40-cent average estimate of five analysts polled by the First Call Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, JOHN J.
description: O'BRIEN-John J. The New York Presbyterian Hospital is deeply saddened by the passing our dear friend and colleague, John O'Brien. Mr. O'Brien joined the Hospital in 1990 and served as Director of Admitting at the New York Weill Cornell Center. His warm personality, dedication and commitment made him a joy to work with. We join all those who knew him in mourning his loss, and extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman & CEO Kathryn Martin Senior Vice President & COO Andrea Castellanos Vice President for Operations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Ames Finds Going Easy at Westchester
description: It has been a difficult year for Stephen Ames, who has encountered more problems off the golf course than on it.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The wood fire burns nonstop at Beacon, a stylish new town house restaurant where just about everything gets roasted except the ice cream. Waldy Malouf, Beacon's chef and partner, was left without a stove when the Baum-Emil Group lost its lease at the Rainbow Room last year, but the abrupt change of scenery seems to have liberated him in this new Baum-Emil venture.

title: David F. Hawke, 75, American Historian
description: David Freeman Hawke, professor emeritus of American history at Lehman College of the City University of New York and author of several widely admired books about people and events in the American Revolution, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Madison, Conn. He was 75.

title: Trade Agency Finds Web Slippery With Snake Oil
description: Snake oil salesmen have been around for ages. But they are proliferating in the electronic age, according to the Federal Trade Commission, which announced today that it had identified hundreds of Web sites promoting phony cures for 30 ailments, including AIDS, multiple sclerosis, liver disease and cancer.

description: The Thin Red Line

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Federalism Awaits '00
description: The angry language from the Supreme Court about this week's federalism cases almost suggested that the issue had the vitality it enjoyed in the first 50 years of the Republic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about conductors vying for music directorships of some eight major orchestras misstated the day Sir Simon Rattle was elected to lead the Berlin Philharmonic. The announcement was made on Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: Knicks Limp Their Way Into Hearts
description: IF you have been following the playoff fortunes of the New York Knickerbockers basketball franchise, you may be forgiven an impression that unfolding before you is not a series of sporting events, but rather an extended psychodrama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, LILLIAN GROSS
description: PLATT-Lillian Gross.Died June 23, 1999 in Belfast, Maine. Born in New York on June 1, 1912, she resided in Neponsit, N.Y. for many years. She is survived by her children Jane of Liberty, Me., Wendy of Briarcliff Manor, NY and Jeffrey of Davis, Fla. and six grandchildren. Funeral services are private.

title: The Face and Soul of a Barrio
description: OR more than two decades, the photographer Camilo Jose Vergara has been taking portraits of American cities, or rather of parts of American cities that almost nobody wants to see. The primary subjects of his 1995 book, ''The New American Ghetto,'' were poor, gutted, socially roped-off neighborhoods in Newark, Detroit, the Bronx and elsewhere. The pictures, accompanied by a diaristic text that read like a tolling of bells, constituted a bad-dream architectural saga of things falling down, walls mostly, in slow motion, brick by brick, or in one big, jolting, bulldozer-induced boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFF, BEATRICE
description: KAUFF-Beatrice. Devoted mother of Merle Marcus and Peter Kauff. Loving mother-in-law of Jillian Kauff and Paul Marcus. Adoring grandmother of Andrew, Gregory and Jennifer Strauss. Cherished sister of Helen Hite. Beloved wife of the late Hy Kauff. She was a woman of charm and grace. Her love, wisdom, generosity and encourgement enriched the lives of all who knew her. Our world is greatly diminished. Services Friday, June 25, Riverside Funeral Home, Hollywood, Florida.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Mortgage On the Hoof

title: Lemieux Can Keep Penguins in Pittsburgh
description: A United States Bankruptcy Court judge granted approval yesterday to Mario Lemieux's plan to keep the Penguins from either leaving Pittsburgh or having their players dispersed to other teams in a special National Hockey League draft.

title: City Board Approves Increases for Rent-Stabilized Apartments
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted 5 to 4 last night to approve a 2 percent increase for one-year leases and a 4 percent increase for two-year leases on rent-stabilized apartments, the same increases approved for four of the last five years.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: TUBOSCOPE AGREES TO BUY NEWPARK RESOURCES
description: Tuboscope Inc., which provides services that remove waste during oil drilling, agreed yesterday to buy Newpark Resources Inc., an oilfield waste disposal company, in a transaction valued at $638 million in stock. Each Newpark share is to be exchanged for 0.65 share of Tuboscope, a bid valued at $9.26, based on Tuboscope's closing share price yesterday of $14.25, down 6.25 cents. Newpark was trading at $10.75, up $1.375, before trading was halted. The combined company, which would have annual sales of $800 million, would be better able to serve oil companies seeking to hire one company that can provide a range of drilling and disposal technologies.

title: My Life as a Dog: In His Master's Death, a Dog Feels Life's Vagaries
description: TIMBUKTU

title: Pearson Will Sell Its Stakes In the 3 Houses of Lazard
description: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. said yesterday that it was selling its holdings in three Lazard investment houses in a deal that analysts said would enable both Pearson and Lazard to become more competitive by focusing more closely on their primary businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Foreign Affairs; Blackjack on the West Bank, Surreal in Israel
description: Israeli-Palestinian relations have entered into a bizarre twilight. Quite simply, thanks to the Oslo peace process, Israelis and Palestinians have finally become psychologically disconnected enough in their daily lives to be more concerned with their respective internal politics than each other. Yet, in reality, they are physically more connected than ever.

description: On April 28, with the sun setting outside their elegant Hilton Hotel conference suite in downtown Jackson, Miss., the key figures in what was, on paper, a vast philanthropic and insurance empire gathered together for the first and last time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSOW, FLORENCE
description: LESSOW-Florence. Devoted wife of the late Jacob, loving mother of Judith Lessow-Hurley, cherished grandmother of Jacob Hurley, sister of Leo Kaplan. Funeral services today 2PM at I. J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, NY

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HIRSCH SPEIDEL INC., Providence, R.I., a maker of watchbands and jewelry, said it was laying off nearly 200 workers, almost half its work force of 420, because of lagging sales.

title: Even in Fog, That City On a Hill Dazzles
description: More than any other, this is the city that Americans fantasize about. No one leaves his heart in Salt Lake City. No one calls Baltimore Baghdad by the Bay, as Herb Caen, the city's six-day-a-week poet laureate for more than 50 years, called San Francisco.

title: All Israel on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: PUNCH PERSISTS IN PUB DEAL
description: The privately held British company Punch Taverns said it was determined to win the battle for Allied Domecq P.L.C.'s pubs, despite Allied's rejection of its bid of $:2.7 billion ($4.2 billion) in cash in favor of a $:2.4 billion stock offer from Whitbread P.L.C. Allied Domecq rejected Punch's bid late on Wednesday, and Punch formally began its offer yesterday. It also disclosed that it would sell up to 650 of Allied's pubs and its 25 percent stake in Britannia Soft Drinks to Bass P.L.C. for $:985 million if it succeeded in its bid.

title: Manhattan Man Charged In Baseball Bat Killing
description: A 24-year-old Manhattan man has been charged with fatally beating a Bronx construction worker who had rampaged down a Washington Heights street, breaking car windows and yelling at people, the police said yesterday.

title: Julius Tobias, 83, Abstract Artist Known for Minimalist Sculptures
description: Julius Tobias, a Manhattan painter and sculptor who was best known for the abstract, gallery-filling Minimalist environments he created in the 1970's, died on June 16 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Demise of Divx Clears the Field
description: However the collapse last week of Divx, the alternative digital video disk, affects the spread of DVD, it at least relieves confusion for consumers and perhaps increases the inclination of studios and other distributors to commit more films to a new medium that several months ago seemed to be getting tangled in a format war.

title: Celebrating a Departure, With a Bow to the Body
description: And so farewell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Metro Business; New Kickback Charge
description: A former purchasing agent at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. was charged yesterday with taking $83,200 in kickbacks in exchange for steering the beverage company's business to a supplier of advertising and display materials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHING, COLONEL JOHN
description: PERSHING-Colonel John W. On June 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with vascular disease. Beloved husband of Sandra Sinclair Pershing. Devoted stepfather of Alyson Lloyd Taylor, and Robin M. Lloyd. Cherished grandfather of Hollis C. Taylor. A private investor in civilian life, he was a member of The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York, and The Society of Cincinnati. Following service as an enlisted man in The United States Marine Corps, he was a distinguished ROTC Military Graduate from Boston University and Commissioned in The United States Army, retiring after 35 years of service in 1998. A graduate of The Army War College, he had served in Special Forces, on the Staff of the Secretary of Defense and as a Special Assistant to The Chief of Staff of the United States Army. He was the grandson of General of the Armies, John J. Pershing, Commander of The American Expeditionary Forces in World War I. His brother, Richard W. Pershing, was killed in action during The Vietnam War. Service Monday June 28, 1999, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will be private at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The ROTC Scholarship Fund at Boston University.

title: U.N. to Send Team to Iraq That Excludes Inspectors
description: The United Nations has agreed to send a team to dismantle a laboratory in Baghdad, but, in a victory for Iraq, the team does not include technical experts from the special commission charged with disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, PATRICIA KERR
description: ROSS-Patricia Kerr. The Board and Staff of the New York Foundation for the Arts is deeply saddened by the death of our friend and colleague Patricia Kerr Ross, the former director of the State University of New York's Programs in the Arts. We extend our deepest condolences to her family, and her many friends and colleagues. She will be deeply missed by the artists and arts community throughout the State. Theodore S. Berger, Executive Director Penelope Dannenberg, Director of Programs

title: Piazza Takes a Day Off
description: With his hitting streak over, Mets catcher Mike Piazza took yesterday off to recover from a slight concussion he sustained in Wednesday night's game with the Florida Marlins. ''It was more of a mental rest than a physical rest for me,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, SYLVIA
description: GELLER-Sylvia. Died June 23, 1999. Beloved mother of Marshall and Cheryl Geller and mother-inlaw of Renee Geller. Adoring grandmother of Brian, Corinne, Dean, Julie and Elizabeth; proud great grandmother to Sage Austin Geller and Reece Morgan Geller. She will always live in our hearts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about the sumo wrestler known as Musashimaru, the second American to achieve the sport's top ranking in Japan, misstated the record of another American, known as Konishiki. He did not win two consecutive tournaments in 1992 or at any time. The article also misspelled the name of a retired grand champion. He is Chiyonofuji, not Chiyonafuji.

title: Mets Focus On Game, Not Scores, For Sweep
description: The Mets agreed beforehand not to watch the scoreboard, not to worry about what the National League East-leading Atlanta Braves were up to in their afternoon game against Montreal. And for most of the afternoon Livan Hernandez and the Florida Marlins made sure the Mets paid attention to what was unfolding yesterday on the dirt and grass of Shea Stadium.

title: Electronic Bond Broker Is Set to Open
description: Brokertec Global L.L.C. said today that it planned to open as an electronic bond brokerage firm, backed by seven of Wall Street's biggest fixed-income dealers.

title: A Complete Robinson Looking for Validation
description: Everyone, besides the Knicks and their faithful fans, seems to be gearing up for the validation of David Robinson. It is as if all his individual achievements -- his placement in 1996 among the 50 best players in National Basketball Association history, his Most Valuable Player award in 1994-95 and his eight All-Star Game appearances -- will finally be legitimized if the San Antonio Spurs win the championship this season.

title: Chamber Music in a Setting That Fits
description: A 102-foot steel barge docked near the Brooklyn Bridge provides a place where music lovers can experience the intimacy of chamber music as it was in Mozart's time. This is the home of Bargemusic, which offers concerts that delight not only the ear but also the eye, offering a spectacular view of Manhattan.

title: How Everyone Can Win at Lotto
description: To the Editor:

title: So What Color Is Death?
description: Death is served on a salver in ''Tales From a Traveler,'' and when the man to whom it is offered -- he has lived unchanging for 499 years, 11 months and 30 days -- tips up the silver dome covering it to get a peek, he cries out: ''Damn! It's green!'' Red, blue, almost any other color would have been preferable. Well, life is like that. And for an hour he is free to accept this green death, or he can just ignore it and it will go away when he turns 500 and he will get another half a millennium.

title: Does Faith Have A Public Role?; Gun Is No Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Churning in a Self-Pity Bath Sure Can Whip Up the Suds
description: With her sullen, downturned mouth, hollow, haunted eyes and air of tattered glamour, the New Zealand actress Rena Owen suggests a Down Under descendant of the 40's Bette Davis via the late-60's Jeanne Moreau. Ms. Owen's majestic, wrecked beauty lent an extra poignancy to her portrayal of a battered wife in Lee Tamahori's harsh domestic drama ''Once Were Warriors.'' And it adds a tinge of divalike grandeur to her portrayal of Katie Keen, a fading international pop star, in Garth Maxwell's ramshackle sudsfest ''When Love Comes.''

title: Why Give Up? Knicks Shooting To Make History
description: Two months ago, the Knicks were a cautionary tale, not characters for a storybook. They were caught in the political Garden games between Ernie Grunfeld and Coach Jeff Van Gundy, mired in discord and performing selfishly on the floor. They were an embarrassment, a collection of misfits assembled for a league-high $68 million, a team of stars on the verge of a humiliating collapse. They became an allegory on how money corrupts.

title: Becker, at Home on Center Court
description: If tennis years unfurl like dog years and Boris Becker, Wimbledon's head watchdog, says that has always been the case with him -- it means he has been torching the turf of his favorite lawn for 105 years.

title: In Recurring Debate, House Votes to Ban Flag-Burning
description: Continuing the culture war that dominated the debate on gun control and youth violence last week, the House of Representatives this week fought its perennial battle over flag-burning.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: In the Nick Of Time

title: Holbrooke Defends Dealings With Milosevic but Admits Administration Errors
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, whose Senate confirmation as chief American diplomat at the United Nations is all but assured, today defended his repeated dealings with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia because ''my job was not to make moral judgments.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIX, JANE GRIFFIN
description: DIX-Jane Griffin. Died June 23, 1999 in Hightstown, NJ, age 89. Longtime resident of Princeton, NJ. Widow of William S. Dix, Princeton University Librarian, 1953-1975. Survived by children Martha Dix Graham of Yorktown, VA, William Shepherd Dix of Princeton, NJ, and Mortimer Griffin Dix of Berkeley, CA. The memory of her warm friendship and family love will remain with those who knew her. Graveside service 11:00 AM Monday, June 28 at Princeton Cemetery, Princeton, NJ.

title: Rap Fans Rush Gates At New Jersey Arena
description: Rap fans trying to get into a sold-out concert at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., last night rushed the gates, prompting the state police to close the doors, the authorities said. No one was arrested or injured.

title: Sports of The Times; 'No Wonder He's No. 1' in World
description: ON the 565-yard, par-5 fifth hole at the Westchester Country Club, David Duval's drive seemed to be soaring toward a landing strip somewhere in New Rochelle before it hopped to a stop.

title: Does Faith Have A Public Role?; Double-Barreled Message
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; U.S. Seeking to Expand Drug Offender Programs
description: In a fresh effort to break the cycle between drug abuse and crime, the Clinton Administration is pushing to expand the testing and treatment of drug offenders whose addiction led them to collide with the criminal justice system.

title: BRAZIL CUTS RATES
description: Brazil's central bank cut its main lending rate to 21 percent from 22 percent as the Government continued to encourage an economic recovery. The reduction, the ninth consecutive cut since March, is key to efforts to narrow the budget deficit, since lower rates translate into a lower Government debt load. The Finance Minister, Pedro Malan, left, said this week that rates should decline to less than 10 percent after inflation by the end of the year. A gasoline price increase of 10 percent, announced yesterday by the Finance Ministry, caused concern about inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAL, JOSE CARLOS
description: LEAL-Jose Carlos. We mourn the passing of our cherished friend. We will miss his wisdom, his spirit, his warmth and his wordly charm. Marilyn and Jack Fields

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: State Settles a Lawsuit Asking Broker for Money
description: State officials said yesterday that they reached a settlement with the stockbroker Robert E. Brennan, from whom the state had sought more than $1 billion in a lawsuit accusing him of cheating investors.

title: LATIN INTERNET STAKE
description: A consortium that includes the Bear Stearns Companies; the Quantum Fund, headed by George Soros, and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Dallas investment firm, said it had paid $44 million for 35 percent of El Sitio, the Internet access provider. El Sitio, which had sales of $1 million last year, has 300,000 registered users and has bases in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, Uruguay and the United States. A Hicks associate, Cesar Diaz, said the fund considers El Sitio ''the main gateway serving the Latin American market.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNIVEN, CHARLES
description: McNIVEN-Charles. The members of the Board of Trustees, Women's Committee, staff, alumni, and more than 6,000 members of the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club wish to extend their deep sympathy and condolences to wife, Mary, daughter, Patty, and other family members at the recent demise of Charles ''Buster'' McNiven. Mr McNiven, after graduating from Springfield College, devoted 40 years of his life to improving the quality of life of America's most disadvantaged young people. During these years, he worked for Boys Clubs in Springfield, MA.; Tonowanda, N.Y. and from 1949 to 1979 as the Executive Director of Kips Bay Boys Club now known as the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club, Bronx, N.Y. During his tenure as Executive Director at Kips Bay, Mr. McNiven was influential in assisting the Board raise the funds to move the Clubhouse in 1969 from Manhattan to its present location in the South Bronx. From 1979 to 1998 he served as a Trustee of the organization. Thanks to his contributions as both a Professional Worker and Board member, thousands of children have a safe and positive Boys & Girls Club to attend and have been presented with opportunities to develop their life skills and become caring, productive, and responsible citizens. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club, 1930 Randall Ave, Bronx, N.Y. 10473.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Saturday about Pope John Paul II's appointment of three new bishops in Vietnam misspelled the name of the city in central Vietnam for which Pierre Nguyen Soan was named bishop. It is Qui Nhon, not Quy Nhon.

title: What Happens When a Little Boy Meets a Very Big Baby
description: It's awfully early in the career of Adam Sandler to find him sharing the screen with a heart-tugging, scene-stealing 6-year-old. Besides, the cute kid in Mr. Sandler's movies is usually the star himself. But as the film world's latest $20 million, 800-pound gorilla, he can do whatever he likes, even if it's a flimsy sentimental comedy with more product plugs and fewer laughs than might have been hoped for. The director, Dennis Dugan, who also directed the much funnier ''Happy Gilmore,'' has said, ''I'd work with Sandler if he called up and said, 'I've got an idea to dramatize the phone book.' '' On the evidence of ''Big Daddy,'' that's not such a joke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Johnson Responds To Walton
description: The horn to signal the end of the interview session sounded twice, but Larry Johnson kept talking even as his Knicks teammates were stretching before yesterday's practice. What subjects so engrossed him? Slaves and Bill Walton.

title: Councilman Is Named City Finance Commissioner
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday appointed Andrew S. Eristoff, one of only seven Republicans on the City Council, as his Commissioner of Finance.

title: Accounts
description: * California State Automobile Association, San Francisco, part of the American Automobile Association club serving Northern California, Nevada and Utah, to Highway One, part of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications unit of the MacManus Group, to handle its account, which had been at the Seattle office of Bozell Worldwide, part of the Bozell Worldwide unit of True North Communications. Billings for the association account were estimated at $11 million.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROL, JULIO
description: PROL-Julio. Foremost teacher of the Spanish classical guitar in New York, died at Lenox Hill Hosptal of a stroke on June 4. Professor Prol was born in La Coruna, Spain. He studied with Andres Segovia and many accomplished musicians of his time. He served in the U.S. Army in World War II. Because of an injury, he abandoned a concert career to teach and was beloved by his many students and proteges. He was a Fellow of the Society of the Classical Guitar since 1956. He is survived by his daughters Tani, Candela, Gizelle and his sons Antonio, Sherwell, the painter Rick Prol, and two grandchildren.

title: Yearbook That Shocked
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUER, IRVING
description: MAUER-Irving, M.D., F.A.C.S. This notice is to advise of the untimely death of Dr. Mauer on June 9, 1999. He was a gifted, resourceful orthopedic surgeon. In lieu of an official notice from the Hospital for Joint Diseases where he trained and served, this is to alert his colleagues and friends of his passing. Murray E. Burton, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DALLAS, A.
description: LEWIS-Dallas, A. MD. Franklin Hospital Medical Center's Medical Staff record with profound sorrow the loss of Dallas A. Lewis, MD. A former President of the Medical Staff and current President of the hospital's Medical Board, Dr. Lewis was appointed Chief of Franklin's Division of General Surgery in 1997. Sincere condolences are extended to his family, friends and patients. Edward S. Orzac, MD, Medical Director Franklin Hospital Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar was lower against the euro as United States stocks and bonds fell on concern that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates several times. The euro settled in New York at $1.0397, up from $1.0330.

title: Saudi Told to Pay Damages in B.C.C.I. Case
description: A Federal judge today ordered a figure in the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal to pay nearly $1.2 billion in damages to investors defrauded in the case.

title: All Israel on Line; Barak's Real Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Durable-Goods Orders in May Rebounded With a 1.4% Rise
description: Orders placed with factories for durable goods rose in May for the second time in three months, further evidence that manufacturing is pulling out of last year's slump, Government figures showed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Squeegee Man Scared Him, Officer Says
description: A police officer testified yesterday that he shot an unarmed squeegee man at a Bronx intersection last June because he ''felt scared.''

title: Without Dad Around To Disturb Her, Lucic Upsets Fourth-Seeded Seles at Wimbledon
description: A year ago, Mirjana Lucic sneaked away from Wimbledon determined to sever all ties to her father/coach, Marinko, a taskmaster she has accused of mental and physical abuse. The Croatian prodigy, now 17, had won her first professional event at 15 only to find her career imperiled by family discord by the time she turned 16. According to Lucic, the pressure inflicted on her by her father was so crippling it rendered her little more than a listless puppet on the tennis court.

title: National News Briefs; 'Sleepwalking' Defense Fails to Save Killer
description: A Phoenix man who said he stabbed his wife 44 times and drowned her while he was sleepwalking was convicted of first-degree murder today.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: ECLIPSED
description: Thirty years ago the Soviets lost the race to the moon. They might have won -- if only they had acted like good Communists. A report by Bill Keller, in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONDARAS, ANASTASSIOS
description: FONDARAS-Anastassios, died at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on June 24, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife Elizabeth; two daughters Kristina Fondaras Lamont of London and Antonia Fondaras of Washington D.C.; two sisters Anna Safilios and Fofi Trezos both of Athens; a niece Dina Safilios Rothschild; and six grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 29 at 12 noon at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St. and the burial will be in Athens, Greece. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Pasteur Foundation. FONDARAS-Anastassios. The Institut Pasteur expresses deepest sympathy to Elizabeth R. Fondaras, devoted Chairman of the American Advisory Board of the Pasteur Foundation, upon the passing of her husband and our dear friend. Philippe Rouvillois Chairman of the Board Maxime Schwartz Director General Francois Jacob Nobel Laureate and Chairman Emeritus of the Board Marie-Helene Marchand Secretary General

title: Empty Seat Hinders Talks to Keep Peace in Bronx; Albanian Teen-Agers Resist Joining Group That Eases Gang and Ethnic Tensions
description: Before Broadway ever imagined a Shark or a Jet, Robert DeSena knew all there was to know about turf and colors, about ethnic feuds and the sting of a punch thrown in a rumble.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: KNICKS' MAGIC RIDE IS OVER
description: On one end of the floor, Latrell Sprewell's head was rocking to and fro, his cornrow braids flopping like a spoiler on a souped-up racer. Ten-footer. Good. Three-pointer from the top of the arc. All net.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Officer's Intent Debated at Shooting Trial
description: A day after a police officer testified that fear had led him to shoot an unarmed squeegee man at a Bronx intersection, prosecutors and defense lawyers battled over the reality of that fear while the judge in the case tried to pinpoint the officer's intentions before he fired the shot.

title: Copper Hits a One-Month High On News of U.S. Mine Closings
description: Copper rose yesterday to a one-month high after the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the world's second-biggest producer, said that it would close unprofitable United States mines in a move aimed at shrinking a global surplus.

title: Investors to Get 40% of French Daily
description: Carlyle Group Inc., a United States private equity firm with $4 billion to invest, and a group of European investors reached an agreement today that could give them 40 percent of Le Figaro, France's largest daily newspaper.

title: Thrashers, and N.H.L., Seem Cool to Olympics
description: The Atlanta Thrashers, who chose their first roster in the expansion draft today, are the junior partners in the 28-team National Hockey League, at least until Columbus and Minnesota join next summer. But the Thrashers' corporate backing and executive lineup suggest that this fledgling franchise could already be an influential player in hockey's boardrooms, perhaps on major issues such as Olympic participation in 2002 in the Winter Games at Salt Lake City.

title: Bengals Sign Mack For Two Years
description: The Bengals have signed Tremain Mack to a two-year contract. The 24-year-old kick returner spent the final four games of the 1998 season in jail after being convicted of driving under the influence for the second time in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LILLIAN
description: ROSNER-Lillian. A lovely and lovable mother to her children and son-in-law, adored sister and aunt. Always thoughtful, brave, selfless in her actions, and delightful in company. Hard to imagine someone who could be missed more than Lillian. Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., Sunday, June 27th, 12 noon.

title: WHITEHALL TO BUY REAL ESTATE PARTERSHIPS FROM MCNEIL
description: Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P. agreed yesterday to buy 19 real estate partnerships from McNeil Real Estate Management Inc. for $644 million in cash and the assumption of mortgage debt. Whitehall is a $2.3 billion fund managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company. McNeil's properties are primarily apartments but also include some retail, office and other properties. McNeil decided to look for a buyer last year after fighting off a hostile tender offer for the partnerships from Carl C. Icahn.

title: W. R. GRACE TO BUY AND SELL A MEDICAL STAFFING COMPANY
description: W. R. Grace & Company agreed to buy Nestor Healthcare Group P.L.C.'s stake in Cross Country Staffing, the largest medical staffing company in the United States, and then sell the business to a private firm for about $150 million. Nestor, Britain's biggest nursing employment agency, said it would sell its 34 percent stake in Cross Country Staffing to Grace for $54 million. Grace, a United States-based specialty-chemical maker, said it expected to net $96 million after buying out Nestor and selling both companies' interests to Cross Country's management and the private equity firm Charterhouse Group International Inc.

title: HBO Won't Renew Wimbledon Deal
description: HBO Sports has decided not to renew its contract to carry the Wimbledon tennis championships after the conclusion of the current tournament.

title: Aides Say Clinton Is Angered As Gore Tries to Break Away
description: President Clinton is angered and hurt by Vice President Al Gore's conspicuous efforts to distance himself from Mr. Clinton's behavior in the Monica Lewinsky scandal, according to Presidential aides and advisers. They say the Vice President's words have created a friction that never before existed between the two men.

title: Sports of The Times; As of Now, Summer Is Officially In Session

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, FRED C.
description: TRUMP-Fred C.. Husband of Mary MacLeod Trump. Father of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump, Jr. Grandfather of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump, III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump, Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great grandfather of Andrea Trump, Cristopher Trump and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday and Monday, 3-5:00 and 7-9:00 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Ave. at 29 St., Tuesday, 11:00 AM. Interment private. Contributions in memory of Fred C. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, NY 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76 Ave., New Hyde Park, NY 11040. TRUMP-Fred C. The employees and staff of Trump Management express their profound sorrow at the passing of Fred C. Trump, their beloved leader and employer for more than a half century. His contribution of affordable housing, lifetime employment, charitable donations and his kindness and generosity to all significantly improved the lives of millions of New Yorkers. We dedicate ourselves to his philosphy-be loyal to family, friends, and employees, work hard, always strive toward a new goal, and use the power of positive thinking. Our sympathies, thoughts, and prayers are with him, his family and all his friends. TRUMP-Fred C. The Lindenbaum family mourns the loss of its longtime and cherished friend. Fred was a master builder and a major philanthropist who had great vitality and joy in life. As a special friend of Bunny's he occupied a unique place in our families history. He changed the face of Brooklyn and Queens the way Donald has changed the face of Manhattan. With Fred, a handshake was worth more than a contract. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mary, Maryanne, Donald, Robert, Elizabeth and their entire families. Belle, Linda, Sandy Lindenbaum TRUMP-Fred C. The management and staff of the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, FL. and Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, FL. wish to express their deepest sympathy to the family of Mr. Fred C. Trump. Mr. Trump spent many happy days at Mar-a-Lago and will be sincerly missed by all who had the privilege of meeting this fine gentleman. TRUMP-Fred. Dearest Donald our deepest sympathy on the loss of your father and our most heartfelt condolences to your family. Carolyn, Frank, Phillip, Dan, and The Staff at Trump National Golf Club TRUMP-Fred C. We mourn the loss of Fred C. Trump, father of our longtime client and colleague Donald J. Trump and extend our deepest sympathy to Donald and the entire Trump family. Rosenman & Colin, LLP

title: ABC's Use of Hidden Cameras Is Ruled Invasion of Privacy
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that journalists' use of hidden cameras in a workplace can be an invasion of privacy, upholding a verdict against ABC News over a story about telephone psychics.

title: Corrections

title: ANSWERTHINK CONSULTING AGREES TO BUY THINK NEW IDEAS
description: The shares of Answerthink Consulting Group Inc., a technology consulting and services concern, fell 14 percent yesterday after the company said it would buy the Internet marketer Think New Ideas Inc. for $231.2 million in stock to expand its services. Answerthink shares fell $4.0625 each, to $23.6875, after touching $21.9375 earlier. Analysts attributed the plunge in share price to investor concern over the profitability of the New York-based Think New Ideas, which has posted a loss in each of the last three years. Answerthink, based in Miami, had 1998 sales of $102.7 million. Shareholders of Think New Ideas will get seven-tenths of a share of Answerthink common stock for each share of Think New Ideas stock. Shares of Think New Ideas fell 68.75 cents, to $15.8125.

title: In Kosovo, Peace Requires Partition

title: The Rough Landing We Give Refugees
description: When Ethel Krupnik was 12, soldiers broke into her home near Vilna, Lithuania, in the middle of the night and shot her father dead as she and the rest of her family cowered in the kitchen. Her mother, fearing that Ethel would be killed in turn -- her education, including the four languages she spoke, made her seem threatening to neighbors -- sent the girl to a cousin in New York.

description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. title: Ban on Ordaining Homosexuals Is Upheld
description: An effort to repeal a law that effectively bars ordination of gay men and lesbians in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) was defeated by a 3-to-2 ratio yesterday by the church's General Assembly, the top policy-making body.

title: PEPSI-COLA PUERTO RICO AGREES TO BUY TWO BOTTLERS
description: The Pepsi-Cola Puerto Rico Bottling Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two Pepsi-Cola bottlers for $309 million in stock in a move that would make it Pepsico Inc.'s third-largest anchor bottler. Pepsi-Cola Puerto Rico will issue 65 million shares for Delta Beverage Group Inc. of Memphis and Dakota Beverage Company of Fargo, N.D. Both companies are closely held. With $530 million in revenue in 1998, the combined company would be Pepsico's third-largest bottler behind Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. and the Whitman Corporation. Pepsi has been promoting consolidation among its bottlers to speed distribution of its products and reduce marketing costs. The agreement was announced after the close of trading in New York.

title: Mr. Clinton Looks Home
description: After an all-consuming detour to press the war in Yugoslavia, and with only 18 months left in office, President Clinton has returned to his domestic agenda. Its emphasis, Mr. Clinton indicated yesterday at his news conference, is to get a budget deal with Congress that shores up Medicare and Social Security, while passing gun control and protections for patients in health maintenance organizations. He will also work to alleviate poverty in parts of the country that have not benefited from the economic boom. The President's new drive on these issues is welcome. It is not clear that the partisan rancor left over from impeachment, and extending into the recent gun control debate, will allow for compromise. But with the distraction of the war fading, it will be worth a try.

description: The closely decided Federalism cases at the Supreme Court this week not only enlivened the debate about the relationship between Congress and the states but also profoundly changed the rights of two categories of people: state employees and holders of patents and copyrights like inventors, authors and composers.

description: After Israel's most severe bombardment of Lebanon since 1996, a tense calm reigned along the border between the two countries today as civilians on both sides waited for the next rocket or bomb to fall.

description: DALLAS-Lewis. title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC AND CHESAPEAKE TO COMBINE TISSUE UNITS
description: The Georgia-Pacific Group, the second-largest paper producer in the United States, will combine its commercial-tissue business with the Chesapeake Corporation's Wisconsin Tissue and pay Chesapeake $730 million for a majority stake in the partnership. Georgia-Pacific will own 90 percent of the business, which will sell tissue products to hospitals, restaurants and other customers. Chesapeake said it would use the cash to buy back between four million and seven million shares of its common stock, pay off debt and finance acquisitions.

title: Campbell Soup Says Profits Will Fall Below Estimates
description: Acknowledging more trouble in its soup business, the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would not meet analysts' earnings expectations for this quarter and that it planned to reorganize its soup operations.

description: The question was inevitable and Bobby Valentine knew it was coming. Is this, the Mets' manager was asked hours before tonight's game with first-place Atlanta, the first meeting between the division rivals this season, a big series?

title: China Facing A Long Road
description: No team from among the 16 in the Women's World Cup will cover more miles during the tournament than China. So no one could blame the Chinese for skipping a walk-through yesterday at Giants Stadium designed to acclimate them to the grass for today's clash with Australia.

title: The Supreme Court Tightens the Noose
description: The uproar over the Supreme Court's end-of-term decisions reinforcing its preference for states' rights obscured another distressing trend -- the Court's increasing willingness to overlook unfair procedures in death penalty cases. In two miserable decisions shortly before it recessed, the Court was so eager to speed executions that it ignored serious flaws in trial and sentencing proceedings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Signed Nuremburg Laws to Go on View
description: In the closing days of World War II in 1945, American troops of the 90th Infantry Division entered Eichstatt, a German town. Tossing grenades as they moved down a building stairway, the soldiers found a vault containing a package marked with the wax seals of the Third Reich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Forests The Way They Used To Be
description: In these days of computer-based global climate models, ecosystem experiments like Biosphere II and airborne analyses of ozone holes, it is easy to overlook a basic truth about nature: understanding its history is just as important as examining its present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSTA, CHARLES J.
description: BUSTA-Charles J.., 51, of New York, NY and Monkton, MD on June 21, 1999. Charles, known as CB was a graduate of Cathedral Latin High School, Class of 1966, and received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Dayton, Dayton, OH, and Master of Arts degree in Journalism from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL. He started his career at Noxell Corporation, a division of Proctor & Gamble Company. Most recently, he was an Executive Vice President, General Manager of Revlon Professional USA. He was a member of the board of directors of the Baltimore Tool Company and the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Bonnie and son of Charles and Ann Busta. Devoted father of Caroline. Cherished brother of Kathleen Kolick, and James and Richard Busta. Funeral services will be held at the Chapel of the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore, MD on Saturday, June 26, at 11am. Donations can be sent to the Charles CB Busta Lecture Series, Office of the President, College of Notre Dame of Maryland, 4701 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21210.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Looks for Ways To Seize on the Economy
description: The nation's long run of prosperity has left the Republican Presidential candidates with a crucial strategic choice: embrace the strong economy as their own, look for the dark side or change the subject.

title: Accounts Differ About Man Who Died in Police Custody
description: A Hackensack man died in police custody on Wednesday night, but witnesses and law enforcement officials yesterday gave differing accounts of the incident, with two people saying the man was held down and beaten by officers.

title: Yanks Win Typical Baltimore Barnburner
description: BALTIMORE, June 25 -- When the Yankees and Orioles face off in Camden Yards, they do not play baseball. Rather, they produce the missing link of sport, infinite contests of artless wonder.

title: Berlin Holocaust Memorial Approved
description: After a decade of increasingly fraught debate over the place of memory in a society now two generations removed from the Nazi era, the German Parliament approved a plan today for the building of a vast memorial in the heart of this city to the six million Jewish victims of the Holocaust.

title: BBC Chooses Ally of Blair As Director, To Tories' Ire
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the august public broadcaster that boasts of high-quality programs and neutral politics, stirred passionate debate today by appointing as its new head a millionaire Labor Party supporter associated with ''Baywatch'' and a puppet called Roland Rat.

title: Political Notes; 2001, a Campaign Odyssey, Hits the Air Waves
description: The race for mayor is two years away, but the prospective candidates have already started raising money and glad-handing fellow officials at political dinners. While the campaign activity for the 2001 elections has escalated, none of the candidates had taken to the air waves -- at least, until this week.

title: Girl From Ipanema: Krall's Bossa Nova
description: There was a moment at Diana Krall's JVC Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night when every breath in the house seemed suspended. It came when this sultry-voiced singer and pianist turned away from the keyboard and, accompanied by Russell Malone's warm, flesh-toned guitar chords, performed the title song of her newest album, ''When I Look in Your Eyes'' (Verve). The song, a little-known gem by Leslie Bricusse from (of all places!) the 1969 film score of ''Dr. Doolittle,'' is an ode to deep eye contact and the primal feelings exchanged by two people gazing at each other and contemplating their life together.

title: Clinton Prods Congress Over a Four-Bill Package
description: President Clinton challenged Republicans today to work with him on domestic legislation so ''this summer should be a season of progress,'' but made clear that he was just as willing to blame them for failure as to share credit for success.

title: Israel Moves To Coalition, And Changes Are in Offing
description: Natan Sharansky, the Russian immigrant leader, will be the next Interior Minister, wresting control of the powerful ministry from the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, which has held it for years.

title: Lockheed Sale Of Assets Put At $1 Billion

The sale is aimed at winnowing out noncore businesses and, perhaps, provide some lift to a stock that has fallen more than 30 percent during the last year.

The other is an owlish Italian canon law scholar who serves as an emeritus judge on the Roman Rota, the court of appeals of the Holy See.

title: Clinton Underestimated Serbs, He Acknowledges
description: President Clinton acknowledged today for the first time that he had underestimated Serbia's ability to withstand the NATO bombing campaign.

title: The Rural Life; Waiting for Thunder
description: The dogs hear it in the distance before I do and so do the horses, a dry dislocated thump, thunder from far away. One moment there is no wind, the air still and damp. The next moment the wind is turning corners where there are none, lifting and coiling the barnyard dust. Wind flails the leaves on the sugar maples, revealing their silver undersides. It scatters spent hickory flowers in drifts. The sky blackens, and I can almost hear rain begin. But then the wind drops and the front unravels over the western ridge, where the weather comes from. Blue sky intervenes. A clear night threatens once again, Venus hanging peaceful in the dusk.

title: Nasdaq in Talks With Shanghai Exchange
description: The Nasdaq stock market and the Shanghai Stock Exchange are forging closer ties, a continuation of Nasdaq's strategy of raising its profile overseas.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the yen on speculation the Japanese Government will consider further measures to stimulate the country's economy. The dollar settled at 121.43 yen, down from 121.78 on Thursday.

description: As the setting of an uprising that ignited the gay civil-rights movement 30 years ago, the former Stonewall Inn and the tangle of little streets around it in Greenwich Village have earned a listing on the National Register of Historic Places.
