title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Can J.C. Penney Evolve?; One Minor Problem: Darwin Doesn't Take Rain Checks
description: In mid-May, James E. Oesterreicher, chief executive of the J. C. Penney Company, stood before shareholders at the annual meeting and predicted that prosperity was just around the corner.

title: Fred C. Trump, Postwar Master Builder of Housing for Middle Class, Dies at 93
description: Fred C. Trump, one of the last of New York City's major postwar builders, died yesterday at a hospital in Queens. He was 93 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Tight Honors at Loose Ends Pose Problems for Declarers
description: It is a word that has many meanings: they include dense; close-packed; fixed securely; fully-stretched; strict; difficult to manage; close; scarce; stingy, and drunk. In bridge, tight means an honor combination lacking low cards, and the diagramed deal is perhaps a record in this area. North-South has queen-ten tight in three different suits.

description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHING, COLONEL JOHN W
description: PERSHING-Colonel John W.. On June 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with vascular disease. Beloved husband of Sandra Sinclair Pershing. Devoted stepfather of Alyson Lloyd Taylor, and Robin M. Lloyd. Cherished grandfather of Hollis C. Taylor. A private investor in civilian life, he was a member of The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York, and The Society of Cincinnati. Following service as an enlisted man in The United States Marine Corps, he was a distinguished ROTC Military Graduate from Boston University and Commissioned in The United States Army, retiring after 35 years of service in 1998. A graduate of The Army War College, he had served in Special Forces, on the Staff of the Secretary of Defense and as a Special Assistant to The Chief of Staff of the United States Army. He was the grandson of General of the Armies, John J. Pershing, Commander of The American Expeditionary Forces in World War I. His brother, Richard W. Pershing, was killed in action during The Vietnam War. Service Monday June 28, 1999, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will be private at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The ROTC Scholarship Fund at Boston University. PERSHING-John W., Holland Lodge #

title: 6 U.S. Embassies in Africa Closed Temporarily
description: Several American and British embassies in Africa remained shut today in response to evidence that they might be under surveillance by terrorist groups planning an attack, Clinton Administration officials said.

title: In a Change, Nissan Opens Annual Meeting to the Press
description: The Nissan Motor Company permitted outside news coverage of its annual shareholder meeting today for the first time, a sign that even the most traditional Japanese businesses are moving toward the greater disclosure and openness expected by foreign investors.

title: Distinctive and Exhaustive, Mandela's Successor Speaks
description: South Africa's new President, Thabo Mbeki, signaled today that he had his own way of doing things as he opened the legislature with a speech outlining dozens of initiatives from privatization efforts to tough new laws against racketeering, money laundering and illegal weapons.

description: The Brazilian percussionist, singer and band leader Carlinhos Brown is too big for a concert hall. He puts all his energy into what he does; it's a nonstop, jackhammer energy, stay-up-for-a-week energy.

title: New Choreographers in a New Setting
description: The ''Evening Stars on Stage at the Twin Towers'' program on Wednesday night at the World Trade Center Plaza was cause for rejoicing on two counts. One was the magnificence of this welcoming new site for free outdoor dance. The other was the program itself, a showing of five dances developed in the Limon Dancers Choreography Project over the last year. Created with the idea of encouraging dancers of the Limon company to try their hand at choreography, the project has gotten off to an imaginative and professional start.

description: Acknowledging a past wrong can be a formidable task, whether for an individual or an institution -- not least for religious organizations.

title: KOREA FIRST IS 'NONVIABLE'
description: South Korea has designated Korea First Bank a ''nonviable financial institution,'' making it a candidate for an additional injection of public money. The bank was one of two nationalized by the South Korean Government as part of a $57 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund. The Government is now negotiating the sale of the bank to Newbridge Capital Ltd. but has twice postponed the deal because of differences over price. Stephanie Strom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SAMUEL M. MD.
description: BLOOM-Samuel M. MD.. On June 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Zita. Loving father of Lloyd and Betty. Dear grandfather of Michael and Benjamin Berson and Henny Bloom. BLOOM-Samuel M., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague and Associate Clinical Professor Emeritus in the Department of Otolaryngology. Dr.Bloom completed his residency in 1939. From 1941 to 1946 he served as a member of the United States Medical Corps and was honored with a Bronze Star for his outstanding service. He returned to Mount Sinai where he became active in clinical practice and teaching. He will be fondly remembered for his courage as well as his warm and gentle humanity. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Admin BLOOM-Samuel M.D. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Samuel Bloom. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Alisa Doctoroff, President

title: NATO Chief Wants Fast Action on Kosovo Police Force
description: Refugees are flocking back to Kosovo, which has been increasingly plagued by deaths and violence, leading the top NATO commander to call for an international police force to keep order in the province.

description: To the Editor:

title: Something for Everyone In a Vocal Smorgasbord
description: Avery Fisher Hall was only a little more than half filled for Tuesday evening's JVC Jazz Festival concert featuring a triple bill of Manhattan Transfer, Anita O'Day and Kevin Mahogany. Theoretically this appeal to different constituencies might have filled the house. Manhattan Transfer, the long-running vocal quartet that funnels everything from Lambert, Hendricks and Ross to the Beach Boys into a close-harmony blender, cultivates a middle-of-the-road pop-jazz audience. Ms. O'Day, one of the last great surviving swing divas, has a core audience of jazz nostalgists. Mr. Mahogany connects the vocal traditions of Joe Williams and Billy Eckstine with the melismatic pop-soul of Luther Vandross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Coors Bid in South Korea
description: The Adolph Coors Company said today that it had bid to acquire the Jinro-Coors Brewing Company of South Korea, an insolvent brewer that accounts for a sixth of the nation's $3 billion beer market, for an undisclosed amount. Coors, one of the largest United States brewers, owned a third of Jinro until pulling out last year. Chase Manhattan Asia Ltd. is auctioning the brewer on behalf of its creditors.

title: IBP TO BUY THORN APPLE VALLEY FOR $112 MILLION
description: Thorn Apple Valley Inc., a meatpacking company that was forced to seek bankruptcy protection after recalling about 30 million pounds of possibly tainted meat, said IBP Inc. had agreed to buy its slaughterhouses and other assets for $112 million. IBP, the world's largest meatpacker, will keep Thorn Apple's plants open and retain the company's employees, Thorn Apple said in a statement. The purchase, which includes $2.5 million in assumed debt, is subject to bankruptcy court approval and will not result in any cash for Thorn Apple shareholders. Thorn Apple, a maker of bacon, hot dogs and lunch meat, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code on March 5. The company ran short of cash after the January recall.

title: Time Warner-Viacom Book Deal Said to Be Near
description: In yet another sign of the pressure to merge that is reshaping the publishing industry, Time Warner Books and Viacom's Simon & Schuster are in serious talks to form a joint venture for their book operations covering such aspects as warehousing, marketing and sales.

title: Extra Benefit At a Benefit Is the Fun
description: Ballet galas can be cumbersome affairs, long on glitter and short on substance. There was not much choreographic substance to ''In Homage: A Tribute to Families With AIDS,'' a benefit on Thursday night at City Center for Self-Help Community Services and its new Family Home Care program. But the event was nonetheless a great deal of fun, a sleekly staged, spirited benefit filled with stellar performing.

Beloved wife of the late Leon, loving mother and mother-in-law to Norma, Sandy, Lucille and Sheldon; grandmother to Lauren, Alexandra, Bruce, Barry, Jennifer and Rachel; great-grandmother to Danielle, Dylan, Kathleen, Joshua, Alexa, Rebeka, Bryan, Jacob, Jonah and Kelvin. title: Perry and Maggert Share Lead
description: HARRISON, N.Y., June 25 -- Chris Perry has a father who pitched in the major leagues and an uncle who is in the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: STARBUCKS BID FOR WILLIAMS-SONOMA IS REPORTED
description: The stock of the kitchenware retailer Williams-Sonoma Inc. jumped 17 percent yesterday after it was reported that the company had turned down a takeover offer earlier this month from the Starbucks Corporation. Shares of the San Francisco-based Williams-Sonoma closed at $34, up $5 each. The San Francisco Chronicle reported yesterday that Starbucks, the Seattle-based coffeehouse chain, was named by people ''close to the company'' as the bidder. No price was given. Neither company would comment on the report, and analysts cautioned against assuming that a deal would happen.

title: Astra Deal Is Sign of Revival in Indonesia
description: In the financial subplot of Indonesia's political transformation, few events have demonstrated the progress and pitfalls as clearly as the agreement this week between PT Astra International and its creditors on how the company will pay back more than $1 billion in debt.

title: Chief of Frito-Lay Unit Is Named President of Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc., the second-largest United States soft-drink company, said today that it would promote Steven S. Reinemund, chairman and chief executive of its Frito-Lay snack-food business, to president of Pepsico.

title: Long Road For a Short, Wild Season
description: THEY said that this lockout-shortened season would be a blessing, a five-month sprint instead of a seven- or eight-month marathon. In fact, this has been the longest short season in National Basketball Association history. And for the Knicks, the wildest.

title: BRAZIL'S UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: Unemployment in Brazil fell to 7.7 percent in May from 8 percent the previous month as exporters in the textile and paper industries hired employees. The decline, a surprise to most analysts, was largely attributed to cheaper Brazilian products in foreign markets after the devaluation of the currency earlier this year. The clothing and textile industry registered the largest work force growth of any sector, with a 10.6 percent increase. Simon Romero

title: About New York; Virtue's Nice, But a Reward Is More Help
description: HIS admirers say that Eric has concerns about the publicity, and understandably so. After living on the streets for so long, he does not want to risk disrupting the peace of his home. Besides, there are people in prison because of him; no sense in giving them ideas.

title: In Kosovo, Peace Requires Partition
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbor Tied to Killing of a Harlem Personality
description: A year after Ruby Jean Johnson, a glittering personality of Harlem's jazz heyday, was beaten, raped and strangled in her home, the police yesterday arrested a neighbor in her death.

title: Filling School Gaps
description: Now that Chancellor Rudy Crew has removed so many administrators from New York City's worst schools, he faces the far more difficult task of replacing them. Finding good candidates to do these thankless jobs will not be easy, which is why he has hired a headhunting firm from Washington State to scout for replacements. But the Chancellor and his vocal critic, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, will now have to address the underlying problem -- the educator brain drain, particularly to the suburbs.

title: U.S. Offers Up to $5 Million In the Pursuit of Milosevic
description: The United States has offered a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the arrest and conviction of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and others indicted by an international tribunal for war crimes in the Balkans.

title: How Can New York City Fix Its Schools?; Suburbs' Answer

title: Sticking Points in a Mets-Cablevision Deal
description: Negotiations for Cablevision Systems to acquire the Mets are continuing but will require the resolution of certain unspecified matters before the deal can be concluded, a person involved with the talks said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. IS PROPOSING A SPECIAL DIVISION FOR HUNTING SPIES
description: The F.B.I. is proposing to create a division devoted solely to rooting out spies, part of a Government-wide review of counterintelligence following suspicions that China tried for two decades to steal nuclear secrets, Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD - Eileen. Treasured wife of Herbert, after a long and devastating illness slipped away on June 24, 1999 just four days after our 65th wedding anniversary. She was the mother of Migs Woodside and Lewis W. Bernard, grandmother of Geoffrey, Debbie, Adam and Claire. Great-grandmother of Rebecca and Emily. Eileen was a Leo, and lion-hearted in her more than 60 year struggle with an ever painful and threatening eye problem. She had a passion for Old Master Drawings, British antique yellow porcelain, Battersea and Bilston enamels, Regency furniture and visiting Trust Houses. She was a member of the drawing committee at CooperHewitt Museum, a trustee at AllenStevenson School, a Vice-President of Playschools Association, and a Vice-President of the Jewish Welfare Board during the war years, and worked as a USO hostess at the Emanu-El canteen. She was a member of the Board of Directors of Womens' Division of Federation and the American Jewish Committee. She was devoted to ballet, good music, opera, travel, stimulating lectures, museums, and hostessing, with great flair, happy parties at our 911 Penthouse. Eileen was a wonderful daughter, concerned mother, and anyone who knew her and worked with her realized how inspiring she was and always gave of herself to the utmost. Contributions in her memory to the Museum Acquisitions Fund of Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65 St, NY, 10021 would be appreciated by her family. Good night ''Blithe Spirit'', sleep well, ''Fairest of the Fair''. You deserve it. Herbert BERNARD-Eileen. With profound sorrow and deep sadness the Rabbis, Officers, Trustees, and the members of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York record the passing of Eileen Bernard, beloved wife of our colleague and friend, Herbert C. Bernard. A woman of exquisite beauty and incomparable grace, she walked among us with rare and beautiful loveliness. Her external charms were exceeded only by her internal capacities for thoughtfulness and devotion. For 65 years Eileen and Herbert walked at each other's side, bringing joy to themselves and pleasure to all whose lives they touched. The museum bearing their names, at Temple Emanu-El, will endure among their many legacies as a blessing. With Herbert, his children, and grandchildren, we mourn Eileen's passing, while giving thanks to God for her life and memory. Rabbi B. Sobol Rabbi David M. Posner Rabbi Richard S. Chapin Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich David E. Marrus, President

title: Profit Reports Help Equities Post First Gains in a Week
description: The Dow Jones industrial average yesterday eked out its first gain in a week after a report showed first-quarter profits rose almost 50 percent faster than previously estimated with little sign of inflation.

title: Trenchant Americans Look Ahead After Beating Nigeria
description: The Americans had been warned about the voracious Nigerian attack. Possess the ball, Coach Tony DiCicco had told his players. Keep the defense intact. Don't let a track meet break out in the middle of a soccer match.

title: Judge Upholds and Extends Commuter Tax Repeal
description: A State Supreme Court justice upheld and even extended the State Legislature's repeal of New York City's tax on commuters who live in the state yesterday, ruling that the city could no longer collect the tax from residents of New York, Connecticut, New Jersey or any other state.

title: Spurs Win Title as Knicks' Dream Ends
description: The Knicks' magic carpet fell to earth with a disheartening thud last night when a potential game-winning shot by the indefatigable Latrell Sprewell fell to the floor as time ran out on Game 5 -- and their miracles expired.

title: A Vote That May Haunt Congress
description: It would be best for both parties if Federal lawmakers revisited the issue of gun control before the 2000 elections.

title: Casey Gets Nod To Be Nets' Coach
description: The Nets' long and somewhat peculiar trek toward naming a head coach ended yesterday when the team announced that Don Casey would continue in the job. The decision ended a seven-week search that never seemed to include more than two candidates: Phil Jackson and Casey, who served as their interim coach the second half of the season.

title: 2 Charged With Murder Of East Village Advocate
description: The police have arrested two suspects in the death of Armando Perez, a longtime community advocate in the East Village who was killed in Queens in April. Two other suspects are being sought, officials said last night.

title: For Now, We Need Arms Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: George E. Keck, 87, Chairman In Hard Era at United Airlines
description: George E. Keck, an industrial engineer who briefly headed United Airlines during some of the airline's most turbulent years, died in his sleep at his home in Milwaukie, Ore., a suburb of Portland, on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. He was 87 years old.

It will be held today only, at 10 A.M.; it will not be repeated tomorrow. Information: (212) 629-8813.

title: Easing Strain, North Korea Releases Tourist to Seoul
description: North Korea today released a South Korean tourist detained earlier this week on charges of trying to lure North Koreans to defect. The move is expected to ease Korean tensions, which have been rising since a clash of warships in the Yellow Sea last week.

title: HUNTER DOUGLAS TO PURCHASE COMFORTEX
description: Hunter Douglas N.V., the world's leading maker of window blinds and coverings, agreed yesterday to buy one of its rivals, the closely held United States company Comfortex, for an undisclosed price. The Rotterdam-based Hunter Douglas, which markets the Duette and Silhouette brands, said Comfortex, which has annual sales of $65 million, will be a separate unit of its North American division, based in Upper Saddle River, N.J. Comfortex sells to independently owned custom-window retailers and wholesalers. It employs about 500 people. Hunter Douglas has about 13,500 employees and operates 136 companies in more than 80 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, DEREK
description: LINDSAY-Derek. The Faculty and Staff of the Chemistry Department of the City College of New York deeply regret the loss of our long-time friend and colleague, Professor Derek Lindsay. Professor Lindsay, an outstanding experimental chemist and a recognized authority in the area of electron spin resonance spectroscopy, joined our Department in 1978 with a Ph.D. from Harvard University. He was a respected member of a community of scientists striving to understand how metals form and how their properties arise as metal atoms come together in small clusters. Professor Lindsay was held in high regard by his students and colleagues, and they will miss him. At this very difficult time, we extend our condolences and sympathy to his wife, Margaret, and mother, Sylvia.

title: Mastercard Will Let Banks Move Its Logo
description: Mastercard International Ltd.'s board has voted to allow member banks to move the Mastercard logo to the back of the credit and debit cards they issue, giving the banks more opportunity to promote their own brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Is a Holocaust Skeptic Fit to Be a Historian?
description: LONDON, July 25 -- Can a writer who thinks the Holocaust was a hoax still be a great historian?

title: Houston Can't Find His Game At Finish
description: At the end of Game 5, Allan Houston and Larry Johnson were standing by, the two Knick veterans watching one of their new brethren trying to extend their improbable season.

title: Saying Goodbye to Their 'World'
description: At first, Donna Evers just wanted to have a quiet lunch so she could mourn with friends as she said goodbye forever to the people she had loved so long.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The problem New Hampshire is experiencing is being experienced across the country. Some people have said a Medicaid card is like a hunting license: it gives you the privilege of going out and hunting for a dentist. ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOKE, ALTAIR MACHADO
description: COOKE-Altair Machado. Departed this earth on Thursday, June 24, 1999 at her home in Colts Neck, N.J. We remember her courage, kindness, her zest for life and love for her family. Loving wife of Robert A. Cooke, Jr., devoted mother of Robert A. Cooke, III, Celia M. Cooke and Dr. Claudia M. Cooke. Loving grandmother of Michael. Mrs. Cooke was raised in Rio de Janeiro. She married Robert Anderson Cooke, Jr. of New York in 1945. A President of the Rumson Garden Club, she became an Honorary Member for 30 years of outstanding service in the world of horticulture and flower arranging. She also achieved her Life-Master ranking with the American Contract Bridge League at the age of 75. Memorial Service at Christ Church Episcopal in Middletown, N.J., 90 Kings Highway, Middletown, NJ07748,Sunday, Jun 27th at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Christ Church Outreach Fund, at address above.

title: A Guilty Plea in an Insider Trading Case
description: A man who spent five years in hiding in Europe evading United States insider trading charges pleaded guilty yesterday to profiting from confidential information provided by a former Morgan Stanley & Company stock analyst.

title: For Educator Fired by Crew, Small Gains Were Not Enough
description: Walking through Public School 202 yesterday, Robert E. Riccobono saw programs taking seed that began under his superintendency of District 19 in the East New York section of Brooklyn. He watched elementary school pupils participating in a literacy program devised at Johns Hopkins University. He spoke with a former teacher who had become an assistant principal under a program for training administrators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Ages Late, Bronze Horse By Leonardo Comes to Life
description: Five hundred years ago, Leonardo da Vinci's long-held plan to cast a 24-foot-tall bronze horse for his patron, Duke Ludovico Sforza of Milan, crumbled when invading French troops used the full-size clay model for crossbow practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUMMER, HOWARD, RABBI
description: KUMMER-Howard, Rabbi. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. He was Rabbi of Temple Ezrath Israel in Malden, MA for many years until his death. He was President of the National Association of Jewish Chaplains at the time of his death. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Nancy, children Rabbi Judy, Naomi and Daniel, brother Seymour and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: INSIDE
description: Poor and Toothless

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, ROBERT J.
description: BURKE-Robert J.., of New Rochelle, died on June 24, 1999 in New York City. He was 56 years old. Robert was born to Francis J. and Georgina McGarry Burke on May 18, 1943 in Bronx, NY. Mr. Burke served in the US Navy as a Quarter Master aboard the USS Intrepid from 1961-1964. He was the President of Queens Surface Corporation, the largest private bus company in NYC. Survived by his wife of 32 years Myra Moore Burke, loving father of Meghan Burke and Martin Burke, dear son of Georgina and the late Francis J. Burke, brother of Kenneth Burke, grandfather of Eily and Alanna Priest. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Flower Funeral Home, Inc., 714 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, NY. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday 10:30AM at St. Barnabas Church. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Robert J. Buuke Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Mt. St. Michael Academy, 4300 Murdock Ave, Bronx, NY 10466. BURKE-Robert J. The Bus Association of New York State mourns the untimely passing of its President and friend Bob Burke. Bob was a gentleman who cared as much about the riding public as he did for his family. Everything he did in life was with grace and class. He fought his battle against illness with uncommon strength. His loss is a great one for all of us. Our heartfelt condolences to Myra and the family. Eugene J. Berardi, Jr. Stan Brettschneider Ed Gallagher Vice Presidents Arthur Jerry Kremer, Counsel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Emily Drugge, Sean Bryan
description: Emily LeRoy Drugge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Everett Drugge of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Sean Marshall Bryan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Bryan of Grayslake, Ill. The Rev. Bernard Camire performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Sophie Bryan, Lawrence Hollins
description: Sophie Wentworth Bryan, a daughter of Joan Moseley Frost of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Gray MacWhorter Bryan 3d, was married yesterday to Lawrence Baldwin Hollins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. and Harry B. Hollins 4th of Northport Me. The Rev. Alastar Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: Aimee Felton, Jonathan Freedman
description: Aimee Jo Felton, a daughter of Rhetta Felton and Dr. Maxwell Felton of Manhattan, was married last evening to Jonathan Lee Freedman, a son of Norma and Nordau Freedman of Co-op City in the Bronx. Rabbi William Kloner officiated at the Feltons' country house in Fairfield, Conn.

title: At Shelter for the Homeless, Children Find Their Voices in Writing Poetry
description: SOMETIMES it is difficult for a child, any child, to be heard over the clamor of the world around her.

title: Alpine Appetites
description: ALTHOUGH many flock to the shore in June, I find mountainsides decorated with farmland, cows and weathered barns to be just as strong a lure. Northwest Jersey quietly offers a perfect escape from congestion and stress. My entry into Sussex at sunset was absolutely beautiful, with nary a car in sight. And as the evening air chilled, my stomach began clamoring for German food. For at the end of the journey lay Bernhard's Red Mill.

title: New Threat to Eastern Bluebird
description: The Eastern bluebird, which returned to nesting grounds in western Long Island five years ago after a 50-year absence, remains a determined if tenuous resident in a sprawling meadow nature preserve here, fighting off sparrow hawks and Wall Street bulls.

title: One Person's Trash Turns Into Another's Treasure at Yard Sales; For Sister-in-Law: A $4 Box of Dishes
description: NOT for me -- I wouldn't be caught dead with it in my house! -- but maybe for someone else.

title: Ruling Says Nonresidents Can Use Town Park
description: The use of Roe Field Park in Haledon cannot be restricted to residents only, according to a state appeals court decision issued last week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Easy Clues
description: Congratulations on adding a second set of clues that can be used to solve the Sunday puzzle (June 6). One favor: please don't call the second set of hints ''easy clues.'' Just as things are getting good for us second-rate puzzlers, do we have to be reminded of our lesser intellects?

title: Community Boards: From Battery to Inwood
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; meetings are usually held on the third Tuesday of the month but the next meeting is July 27, 5:30 P.M.; 90 Beekman Street, Southbridge Towers, Community Room. Board chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Habitats/235 East 49th Street; Selling an Apartment Without Using a Broker
description: WHEN Carol Scheer decided to sell her studio apartment without using a broker, she learned a few things about New Yorkers. For one, they are polite in small and unexpected ways. ''They would ask if they could open the closet doors,'' she says.

title: June 20-26; Musical Conductors
description: Call it musical chairs for conductors: Seiji Ozawa, who has led the Boston Symphony Orchestra since 1973, announced unexpectedly that he would quit after the 2002 season to take over the podium of the Vienna State Opera. A day later, the Berlin Philharmonic selected Sir Simon Rattle, who recently stepped down from the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in Britain, to wield its baton after Claudio Abbado retires in 2002.

title: Colette Kimbrough, Walther Bohne
description: Colette D. Kimbrough and Dr. Walther H. O. Bohne were married yesterday by the Rev. Dale R. Lind, a Lutheran minister, at St. Hubert's Chapel on Lake Kinnelon in Kinnelon, N.J.

title: A First Step Together
description: For generations, Jewish weddings have been punctuated by the sound of glass shattering under the foot of the bridegroom and a shout of ''Mazel tov!'' But now some of the stomping heels are higher than they ever were, as a growing number of brides are hoisting up their gowns and crushing the glass in unison with their husbands. ''I'm seeing more and more brides wanting to break the glass,'' said Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff of Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J. ''About 20 percent of the couples I marry go for it. Thirty years ago, it was virtually never done.'' Breaking the glass, a reminder of the destruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem in A.D. 70, is a growing trend for brides in Reform and interfaith ceremonies but is largely shunned by traditionalists -- and by women fearful of a mishap in delicate shoes. ''If the glass is wrapped properly with a reasonably thick napkin, it shouldn't be a problem,'' Rabbi Kroloff said. For safety-first brides, West Side Judaica, 2412 Broadway, near 88th Street, sells an easy-to-break glass presealed in a cloth bag, for $20.

title: Dirt Flies in Parks Agency's Battle With Mountain Bikes
description: Alley Pond Park is prized by naturalists for its miles of dirt trails that wend through verdant forests, over steep ridges and along glacially carved ponds. Mountain bikers flock to it for the same reasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Blair Schwartz, David Drucker
description: Blair Dana Schwartz and David Bruce Drucker are to be married this evening at the Plaza Hotel in New York. Rabbi Fred Hyman is to perform the ceremony.

title: The Sea Yields Fossils Galore
description: ''YOU fishing, or you digging rocks?'' asked the cheerful clerk at Parrsboro's hardware store, where we ventured in to buy a rain suit. It was a dispiritingly gray Nova Scotia day of the sort in which it's wise to inspect your boots for freshly sprouted fungus before slipping them on. ''Digging rocks,'' I replied. Then we stepped out into the early autumn drizzle to meet up with our guide.

title: China Bests Australia, And Russia Advances
description: The Chinese walked onto the field at Giants Stadium this afternoon holding hands, then proceeded to soundly defeat Australia, 3-1, in the Women's World Cup. Perhaps the Chinese are imitating the Brazilians, who captured the men's World Cup in the United States in 1994, holding hands before every game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESSER, MAXWELL
description: DESSER-Maxwell. A gentleman by nature, so gracious even in receipt of things which were so plainly his due. Lt., USN Signal Corps during WWII. An artist by trade and affection, a National Academician in the National Academy of Design and a Dolphin Fellow and officer of the American Watercolor Society. Too many who would mourn him are already gone, especially his cherished wife Mary, and his brother Leon, who was sustained for years in Mac's tender care as he faded. Stu

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Dressing Up, or Down, for the Occasion; Use Your Words
description: To the Editor:

title: MacArthur Grants Go to 3 in the State
description: A Rutgers University historian, an AT&T researcher and a Princeton University architect are among the 32 recipients of this year's MacArthur Foundation awards. The awards, often called genius grants, include stipends of $200,00 to $375,000 over a five-year period given by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation to encourage creativity in a wide range of fields.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMARI, MARINA
description: AMARI-Marina. 3/25/55-6/24/98. You are in our thoughts & hearts. We remember your courage, intelligence, friendship, cheerful spirit. -Your Family

title: A Small Paper's Big Splash
description: Although it is only a short walk from the hustle and bustle of Yankee Stadium and Supreme Court in the Bronx, the hilly neighborhood of High Bridge has rarely received the same attention from the news media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHING, COLONEL JOHN W.
description: PERSHING-Colonel John W.. On June 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with vascular disease. Beloved husband of Sandra Sinclair Pershing. Devoted stepfather of Alyson Lloyd Taylor, and Robin M. Lloyd. Cherished grandfather of Hollis C. Taylor. A private investor in civilian life, he was a member of The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York, and The Society of Cincinnati. Following service as an enlisted man in The United States Marine Corps, he was a distinguished ROTC Military Graduate from Boston University and Commissioned in The United States Army, retiring after 35 years of service in 1998. A graduate of The Army War College, he had served in Special Forces, on the Staff of the Secretary of Defense and as a Special Assistant to The Chief of Staff of the United States Army. He was the grandson of General of the Armies, John J. Pershing, Commander of The American Expeditionary Forces in World War I. His brother, Richard W. Pershing, was killed in action during The Vietnam War. Service Monday June 28, 1999, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will be private at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The ROTC Scholarship Fund at Boston University.

title: Want to Buy a Stock Market?
description: ON its face, it's hard to imagine a less appealing investment: the No. 2 company in a cyclical, capital-intensive business, rapidly losing market share to newer, more nimble competitors not subject to its strict Federal regulation.

title: A Shoe on the Other Foot
description: Dennis D. Dammerman, the longtime General Electric finance chief who recently became chief executive of the relentlessly profitable GE Capital Services unit, has a no-nonsense, tough-guy reputation.

title: June 20-26; Researching the di Caprio Effect
description: Seldom does one piece of research touch on so many burning issues, starting with: How come women think a waif like Leonardo di Caprio is the cutest ever one week, and then line up for craggy-faced Sean Connery the next?

title: Youth Crime
description: The county has adopted a strict policy for enforcement of newly passed amendments to the Youth Crime Prevention Law. The law now requires anyone selling spray paint, box cutters and laser pointing devices to restrict sales to people 18 or older and to post notices to that effect. Elaine M. Price, director of consumer protection, said inspectors from the department will visit stores to make sure the notices have been posted and to impose penalties of not less than $150 and not more than $500 if violations are found. The notices are available through the Department of Consumer Protection.

title: Bringing Home the Many Tastes of Italy
description: SOME of the most lasting memories of a vacation include food. In Italy, it might be the crackly crusted pizza enjoyed on the Piazza dei Signori in Verona, the sprightly salad of assertive greens at an outdoor cafe in Santa Margherita or the creamy, rich tiramisu at a mountain lodge in Sardinia.

title: The Next Clinton
description: I had hoped to vote for a Democrat, and preferably a woman, as candidate for the Senate from New York (James Bennet, May 30). It is regrettable that Representative Nita Lowey, who would be admirably suited for the position, has withdrawn her bid to make way for a celebrity carpetbagger from Arkansas. Our state should have stricter requirements, including at least three years of New York State income-tax payments as a qualifying prerequisite to stand for the Senate. Hillary Rodham Clinton's only qualification is chutzpah.

title: June 20-26; Another Hat in the Ring
description: With most of the Republican establishment treating George W. Bush's Presidential nomination as a fait accompli, and 10 other candidates already in the field, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah announced that the time had come for him to run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, ELIZABETH H.
description: RAYMOND-Elizabeth H.. On June 22, 1999, at Canaan, CT. Longtime resident of Pelham, NY. Past editor at Interiors magazine. Mother of Abigail R. Salaway. Donations to the Bissel Fund, c/o Kenny Funeral Home, 860-364-5709.

title: June 20-26; House Bill Makes It Harder To Seize Property
description: A surprising coalition of liberals and conservatives on the House Judiciary Committee persuaded the House to pass a bill that would sharply limit the power of the police and prosecutors to confiscate property in narcotics and other criminal cases. The measure marked the first time in nearly 30 years that Congress had taken away from law enforcement some of the vast powers it approved at the height of the war on drugs.

title: Giant Western Murals: Tall in the Saddle
description: When the bucking broncos leap from their stalls at the Fourth of July Rodeo in Toppenish, Wash., the spirit of the event will be echoed by the mounted cowhand in the 16-by-20-foot mural on the other side of town. In this town of 7,500 in the Yakima Valley, two and half hours east of Seattle, nearly 60 huge murals on the sides of buildings record the history of the rodeo and the West.

title: The Rise and Fall of Edward Doyle Sr.; A Teamsters Icon Who Could Deliver Votes Is Forced to Resign His $172,000-a-Year Post
description: FOR 15 years, Edward Doyle Sr. has been the most powerful labor leader in Westchester, treated with adulation by truck drivers proud that they earn more than $50,000 a year and with deferential regard by the county's leading contractors and political leaders who crave his good will.

title: All-Year Benefit Is Seen In New Haven Festival
description: Inspired by the success of the Special Olympics World Games here in 1995, Anne Tyler Calabresi had a vision she believed could help start a cultural and economic renaissance in this troubled Ivy League city.

title: Amy Brown, David Staas
description: Amy Elizabeth Brown, the daughter of Mary and Thomas Brown of New York, was married yesterday to David John Staas, a son of Joan Staas of Annapolis, Md., and Jack Staas of McLean, Va. The Rev. Maurice O'Mahony performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Montecito, Calif.

title: Conveying a Classic Back To Its Lavish Origins
description: MAKHAR VAZIEV, the new director of the Kirov Ballet, calls ''The Sleeping Beauty'' the St. Petersburg troupe's ''visiting card.'' But the Petipa-Tchaikovsky masterpiece is more than an introduction to his company. ''It's the most important ballet in the repertory,'' Mr. Vaziev says. Created in 1890, ''Sleeping Beauty'' remains the touchstone of 19th-century Russian ballet style. Disguised as a tribute to the splendors of the French court, ''Beauty'' is actually a summary of the Russian Imperial Ballet's considerable late 19th-century achievements. The Kirov (known in Russia today as the Maryinsky Ballet, its name before the Revolution) will show its sumptuous new version of ''Beauty'' at the Metropolitan Opera House for four performances starting tomorrow night. The ballet's choreography has been restored from dance notations made in St. Petersburg in the first decade of this century, and the sets and costumes recreated from original designs for the ballet.

title: Most Beach Towns Say Ads Detract
description: Snapple, Snapple, Snapple, Snapple. That's the first impression beachgoers get when they gaze upon the summer sands.

title: Firing Up An Idea Machine; Enron Is Encouraging The Entrepreneurs Within
description: TWO words sum up the management philosophy of the Enron Corporation, according to its president, Jeffrey K. Skilling: loose, and tight.

title: Avoiding Wedding Rush Hour
description: Cathy Klauber always wanted a traditional New York hotel wedding. But when Peter Cooper proposed to her last December and she started searching for a place for the reception, it looked like their engagement was going to last a lifetime. ''Saturday nights were booked for a year and a half,'' Mr. Cooper said. Unwilling to wait that long, Ms. Klauber, like more and more Manhattan brides, booked her wedding for a Thursday night. On June 17, the couple had a black-tie affair with 200 guests at the Essex House on Central Park South, with their first choice of band, photographer and florist. ''Everything was just more flexible,'' Ms. Klauber said. ''You didn't get the freelance photographer --you got the first string.''

title: Crime
description: In SOME DEATHS BEFORE DYING (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23), that daredevil stylist Peter Dickinson sets himself the formidable task of solving an undisclosed crime whose principal players are dead, near-dead or dotty. He executes this feat with extraordinary grace and skill in a story that exists only in the buried memories of people who have been living a collective lie. To make it even tougher, his sleuth is a 90-year-old Englishwoman who is lying on her deathbed, paralyzed and practically speechless.

title: Fighting Over Parking Spaces; Crunch Is a Result Of Government Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: The End of the World
description: THE FIRST WORLD WAR

title: Revising a Gold Standard
description: What? A mere million dollars? Such a bundle may no longer be enough to qualify its lucky owner as wealthy -- even if the person you ask about the cutoff point is the one with the million. When Neuberger & Berman, the investment management and mutual fund company, surveyed 204 affluent Americans about their attitudes toward wealth and estate planning, it found that many respondents set a higher bar.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE MARVELOUS ADVENTURES OF PIERRE BAPTISTE

title: Another Latin Boom, But Different
description: THE streets of Times Square were slick from a spring rain as the actress Jennifer Lopez leaned forward in the backseat of her chauffeured sedan and pointed to a nondescript brick building in a neighborhood where giant ads for movies, theater and music vie for attention. ''That's the studio where I used to go to dance classes,'' she said. ''I used to take the No. 6 train downtown from the Bronx. I was about 18. It was about making the transition from this girl in Castle Hill who could have been a lawyer to dancing, singing and auditioning, letting the artist in me come out.''

title: Private Jets for (More of) the People
description: ON paper, Richard T. Santulli seemed an unlikely candidate to revolutionize the elite business of owning private jets. Raised in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, where his family lived with one set of grandparents and across the street from the other, he did not take his first plane flight until his honeymoon in 1966.

title: A Model Who Can Walk Tall in the Kitchen
description: COOKING with cleavage is not an everyday occurrence in my kitchen. Neither is cooking in heels. But when a model is involved, it seems, anything is possible.

title: For Spurs, One Title Just Is Not Enough
description: The quiet and composed Sean Elliott wanted to bask in the moment. He wanted to be consumed by the grandeur that surrounded winning the first National Basketball Association championship in the San Antonio Spurs' 26-year history. He wanted to savor the jubilation, the sense of accomplishment, the squirting of the champagne.

title: Bloomsbury Bios
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CHILDHOOD

title: With Jury Duty, She's Heard All the Excuses
description: ''DO you open your mail?'' Claire Felice asked again and again. ''Did you get the first two notices?'

title: Neither Heat Nor Poor Soil Stays These Sages
description: THE virtues of salvias, or sages, are well known to gardeners. Few plants are more reliable and trouble-free, even if grown in dry spots with less than perfect soil.

title: Right Out of the Closet
description: PARTY CRASHER

title: From the Louvre To the Sewers
description: France was slow to join the cyberworld, but all the basic information that a visitor to Paris needs can now be found on the Web.

title: Avant-Boheme
description: Fashion as fun and self-expression is flourishing east of SoHo and south of Houston Street. This downtown area of New York City is the haute bohemia. The streets are lined with independent, highly creative designer boutiques, restaurants, coffeehouses and home furnishing stores. The area stretches east from Lafayette, Mott and Elizabeth streets to Orchard, Stanton and Ludlow between Prince and Houston.

title: Into the Unknown
description: Stanley Crouch was on the mark when he recognized the journey for the junket it was. It is clear who was the novelist here, as Richard Ford filled 212 column inches compared with the journalist Crouch's terse 36. It is also clear that Ford was looking for absolution for the faux pas of his earlier years, while Crouch saw the trip as a cold, wet gimmick, and gave it the short shrift it deserved.

title: 40 Years of Wheeling, Dealing and Mealing
description: The first word Thursday night at New York's Four Seasons, which was celebrating 160 seasons as the setting of as many transactions as the stock exchange floor, came from the architect Philip Johnson, about why the restaurant and his design for it had survived. ''They have good management and good food; all I could do was give them the background,'' he said on the way in. Mr. Johnson, regularly found at a Grill Room (not Pool Room -- more on this later) corner table for lunch, soon agreed that he was too modest. ''Of course, I had something to do with it. I'm quite a good architect.''

title: Katherine Miller, Benjamin Danson
description: Katherine Irene Campbell Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Campbell of Scranton, Pa., was married yesterday to Benjamin Richard Danson, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Danson of Princeton, N.J. A Quaker ceremony was held at the couple's home in Llanerch, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DALLAS, M.D.
description: LEWIS-Dallas, M.D.. It is with great sorrow that the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System notes the passing of Dallas Lewis, M.D., who was Chief of the Division of General Surgery at Franklin Hosptial Medical Center and a long time member of the hospital's medical staff. Dr. Lewis embodied the hospital's dedication to excellence in medicine. Our deepest sympathies go to his family. Lawrence Scherr, M.D., MACP Chief Medical Officer North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Shirov's Sharp Queen Sortie Ignites a Tactical Firefight
description: There's a lot to be said for the tactical approach. Harassing the opponent at every turn when you have the initiative throws him off stride and elicits errors. And if you can carry this off in a daring way, so much the better. It puts doubts in his mind. Is there some chance that he can punish you for irresponsible adventurism, or must he adopt a defensive posture and struggle against a dangerous attack?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Stop Your Whining
description: To the Editor:

title: For Ukraine, He's a Native Son, Regardless
description: SAY this much for nationalism: its cultural salvage missions, however perversely motivated, can yield up fascinating flotsam. In a new recording, a group of singers and instrumentalists from Lviv -- formerly Lvov and, before that, Lemberg -- in newly independent Ukraine has lovingly resurrected ''Alcide,'' an opera by Dmitri Bortniansky, a distinguished native of the Ukrainian village of Glukhov who never thought of himself as a Ukrainian, and who spent most of his life trying to forget he ever saw the place.

title: An Open Mind on Interest Rates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Exiled in Maine, The Creator and Prisoner of 'Love'
description: IT is typical of the contradictions that define Robert Indiana that he fled New York for an out-of-the-way, fog-drenched Maine island, only to buy the biggest, brashest house in town.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Amy Sohn; The Flirt's Progress
description: AMY SOHN surveyed the midriff-baring crowd indifferently milling about the bar at Drinkland, an East Village lounge with swirling Austin Powersesque decor, and lamented the very unshagadelic scene. ''Everyone wants to hook up, but they want to maintain the air they don't,'' she said.

title: New Magic for Old Sound
description: IT was an eerie encounter, hearing the high, pianissimo string harmony rippling into clear presence over the familiar contrapuntal weave of Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra. Experience suggested that not even the most expensive compact disk players could extract that luminous layer of sound from a conventional CD, no matter how painstaking the mastering process. But here was an ''ordinary'' disk playing in a moderately priced machine, and delivering music as transparent, vital and complete as one expects to hear in a good concert hall.

title: The Spirit of Deco Rises From the Dead
description: NEW YORK is witnessing a small invasion of major French talent. Earlier this year, Philippe Starck, the most gifted designer of his generation, moved to New York. If this town cared as much about design as it does about baseball, there would have been a ticker tape parade in his honor. Even if Mr. Starck does no more than remodel a few extra Ian Schrager hotels, his relocation here is an important cultural event.

title: For Some, the Game Is Up
description: Less than a minute after Joseph P. Angelastro, 15 years old, dropped three quarters into a shoot-em-up video game at the Pavilion Theater on a recent weekend afternoon, an usher, John Cruz, also 15, shooed him away.

title: In Her Hands: All the Dreams And Dresses Of the Big Day
description: THE expression ''Every bride is beautiful'' is more than just a sentiment for Lydia Colombo of Stratford. It describes her life's work as a couture dressmaker, having personally been responsible for creating hundreds of beautiful brides for more than 25 years.

title: June 20-26; Loan to China Approved
description: It seemed like a no-brainer for the World Bank: Give China a loan to move 58,000 poor farmers -- volunteers only, please -- to more fertile land in western China. But there was a hitch: The land was partly settled by Tibetans. Congress and the Administration protested that the project would help China dilute the presence of ethnic Tibetans in the area.

title: Heesun Min and Daniel Lee
description: Heesun Min, a daughter of Ok Hui and Chung Sik Min of Palisades Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Hoen Lee, the son of Dr. Sunhee C. Lee of Seoul and the late Dr. Kyu Jong Lee. The Rev. Terry Yae, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Emmaus Mission Church in Closter, N.J.

title: Liquor License and 'Coffee Lounge' Don't Mix, State Says
description: They complained for months about the prospect of a bar opening on their block, and fretted when the city awarded it a certificate of occupancy. But residents and officials in Chelsea are now expressing relief. At a hearing on June 16, the State Liquor Authority orally denied a liquor license to the Fresh Organic Coffee Lounge, a club proposed for a former garage at 217 West 20th Street.

title: A Sacred Evil
description: THE HOLOCAUST IN AMERICAN LIFE

title: QUICK BITE/Bayonne; A Pleasant Change of Pace on Broadway
description: For a change of tempo and cuisine from the diners and fast-food emporiums along Broadway, Bayonne's main drag, there is Jo-Cino's, a small cafe nestled between a mirror refinisher and a delicatessen.

description: Salty Dogs

description: To the Editor:

title: Designer's $2.5 Million to Improve Camps
description: A group of half a dozen teen-age boys from Harlem wandered through fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger's clothing showrooms in midtown Manhattan, asking him questions about specific items they saw.

description: SLIGHTLY CHIPPED

description: To the Editor:

title: Jeter and Posada Giving Torre Reason to Pause
description: Derek Jeter grabbed the back of his left thigh after running out a hit today and grimaced, a scary sight to his teammates, who feared that he might have torn his hamstring. ''Everybody was panicking,'' said Luis Sojo, the Yankees' veteran infielder.

title: First Lady in a Messy Fight On the Eve of Her Campaign
description: Since the collapse of her health care project in 1994, Hillary Rodham Clinton has seemed to retreat from the gladiator pit of high-profile policy issues, devoting herself instead to less visible topics like foster care and adoption.

title: Hey, That's Not James Taylor
description: Would you like to view the schedule of concerts at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel? It must be on the Internet. Sure enough. A search comes up with pncbankartscenter.com. But the site isn't really the art center's, which is actually artscenter.com. And it provides more than a look at Brooks and Dunn in cowboy hats or even Cher in a skimpy outfit. Someone out there created the bogus address, which connects automatically to whitehouse.com, a pornography site (one that schoolchildren looking for information on the Clintons' residence regularly stumble across). And there may not be much the Arts Center can do about it.

title: The Site From Ipanema, And Lots of Carioca Spirit
description: As befits a city that ranks as one of the most beautiful and fascinating in the world, Rio de Janeiro is the focus of numerous Web sites in English, more than I anticipated. Many are of high quality in terms of text and visual content, with sharp graphics and even snatches of the music that defines Rio. Three sites in particular stand out, each for a different reason.

title: In America; America Is Ready
description: In the introduction to his book ''Making a Killing -- the Business of Guns in America,'' Tom Diaz writes:

title: N.H.L. Has Duty To Enforce Rules
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jared Epstein, Francesca Rosenberg
description: Francesca Rosenberg was married last evening to Jared Matthew Epstein at Studio 450 in New York. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman performed the ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: They Are to Rise, at Last, on 42d St. Between 11th and 12th; The 15-Year Story Of 2 40-Story Towers
description: How does a developer measure time, when time just seems to stretch on and on and on?

title: Kristin McGovern, Matthew Sonne
description: Kristin Lee McGovern, a daughter of Mary Lynne and Kenneth McGovern of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married there last evening to Matthew Mulford Sonne, a son of Sally and Christian Sonne of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Rev. Martin Amos officiated at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church, and the Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Cromey, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Jean Kindred, Chris Wilmerding
description: Marjorie Jean Kindred and John Christopher Wilmerding were married yesterday in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Flagler Memorial Chapel at the Millbrook School.

title: Prints and Drawings Highlight Niche in Contemporary Culture
description: FEW artists have the chance to take their creativity out into the wide world outside museums and galleries and make a direct impact where ordinary people live their lives. Christo comes to mind, with his penchant for wrapping buildings and other structures to make them be seen freshly. But his projects are deliberately temporary. When Richard Haas paints a facade, fool-the-eye style, transforming it utterly, it is for keeps. He has developed pigment that never fades.

title: One Place Sex Is Seldom Taken Seriously
description: SEX may mean a great deal in our lives. But somehow it doesn't count for very much in our drama. No, I have not forgotten about the stacks and stacks of plays whose plots turn on romance, or on adultery or incest, or the newer ones that work gay or feminist changes on these well-worn themes. Western theater is peopled with distinctly sexual characters: Oedipus, Gertrude, Camille, Willy Loman. But the plays they appear in are not primarily about sex. Plays -- serious mainstream works by serious writers that shed light on the role of sex in the human drama -- are actually few and far between.

title: Article on Bottle-Diggers Glorified Theft of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYDE, LOUISE J.
description: HYDE-Louise J.. Of North Salem, NY, died on May 26 at her home at age 86. Ms. Hyde was a World War II pilot, a trailblazer in cross-country air racing, and a 30-year resident of North Salem. During World War II, she served as a Women's Airforce Service Pilot (W.A.S.P.), earning the rank of lieutenant. Throughout her military career, she served as an Engineering Test Pilot, troubleshooting ''War-Weary'' B25s. When the W.A.S.P.s disbanded after the war, Ms. Hyde became involved in air racing. She raced in The Powder Puff Derby, a women's-only crosscountry air race and served on the Board of Directors of the All Women's Trans Continental Air Race. Most recently, she worked as a real estate broker for RenwickWinterling of Bedford, NY. She also served on the Board of Directors of the Hammond Museum, a cross-cultural center and stroll garden in North Salem. Family and friends remember Ms. Hyde and her late husband, Gordon E. Hyde, a World War I pilot, as an adventurous couple who shared a passion for flying and sailing. Ms. Hyde is remembered with love for her kindness, indomitable spirit and generosity toward all the lives she touched. Ms. Hyde is survived by two stepdaughters, Barbara H. Crafford of Santa Cruz, Calif and Harriet H. Mauck of Farmington, Conn, nine step-grandchildren and 15 great-step-grandchildren. Donations can be sent in Ms. Hyde's name to the W.A.S.P. Endowment Fund, c/o Texas Women's University, P.O. Box 425618, Denton, Texas 76204-5618.

title: MUSIC; With a 1-2-3, 1-2-3, 1-2-3, Vienna Honors a King
description: RETURNING to the city of the allegedly blue Danube this spring was, for this writer, a sort of hajj to the mecca of Unterhaltungsmusik: entertainment -- or, if you will, pop -- music. The Austrian authorities, with enormous historical evidence to back their theory, would have the world believe that Vienna was the birthplace not only of music's classical wing but also of its ''light'' division, because the Strauss family came from and remained loyal to Vienna.

title: Beating the Lines At Crowded Airports
description: THOSE long lines at United States airports are not just on the runways. As the number of airline passengers swells -- to 614 million last year, up from 488 million in 1993 -- and airports remain the same size, waiting in line has become a frustrating experience. The airlines, hearing growing complaints and eager to cut costs, have begun adopting new techniques to speed people on their way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, ROBERT J.
description: MARGULIES-Robert J.. Untimely death 1962-1999 (Attorney). Beloved brother, borhter-in-law and uncle. Cherished grandson of the late Estelle Margulies. Adored great-nephew of aunt Diane and family. We love you Rob and will miss you today, tomorrow and always. Aunt Diane

title: Shaker Simplicity Comes to Wilton
description: THE simple, graceful lines of Shaker furniture holds great appeal for the contemporary eye. Chairs, tables, cabinets, desks and household objects made in the 19th century by members of this unique communal sect fetch handsome prices at auctions and antique shows and continue to influence designers and craftsmen.

She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: VIRTUAL DRUGGISTS: A special report.; Internet Prescriptions Boom In the 'Wild West' of the Web
description: Dr. Leandro Pasos was 68 years old and struggling to make a living when, about a year ago, an unusual advertisement in a Seattle newspaper caught his eye. Doctors with active licenses, the ad said, could earn up to $10,000 a month doing ''fully automated on-line medical reviews.''

title: Did Student Atheists Show Tolerance?; Christian Minority
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region /Connecticut; Ridgefield Considers 680-Acre Mixed-Use Project
description: THE Town of Ridgefield is considering a proposal to build a $600-million mixed-use development on 680 acres -- 620 acres in Ridgefield and 60 acres in Danbury. The property, called Bennett's Pond, appears to be the largest single tract of undeveloped land in Fairfield County.

description: KRASNER-Oscar. 83, on June 12, of prostate cancer. Retired 1981 after 25 years as Director of The Krasner Gallery on Madison Avenue. Survived by wife, Joanna, and daughter, Jenny.

description: An animatronic Elvis -- dressed in a jewel-studded jumpsuit and crooning his greatest hits -- will be one of 100 wax figures at Madame Tussaud's Las Vegas, opening in Las Vegas on July 8. The attraction is the first Madame Tussaud's in the United States -- there are others in Amsterdam and Australia, and a New York version is scheduled for late 2000 in Times Square.

title: A Summer for Fans of Schubert
description: FOR those with a fondness for Schubert, this is going to be a great summer. Not only will they find many of his works at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah -- including a performance today of the Two-Cello Quintet -- but also at the Sarah Lawrence Summer Festival in Yonkers, which is scheduling many Shubert songs, piano works and chamber pieces. The first of the seven recitals in Marshall Field House at the college takes place today at 4 P.M. with the violinist Sungrai Sohn and the pianist Walter Winterfeldt collaborating on the three Sonatinas along with Tchaikovsky's ''Melody'' and the Wieniawski ''Legende.''

title: Julia Ix, David Genovese
description: Julia Ryan Ix, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Ix of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Rocco David Genovese 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Genovese 3d of Darien, Conn. Msgr. Kevin M. Wallin performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich.

title: June 20-26; A.M.A. to Form Union
description: Long before H.M.O.'s came along, Americans envied doctors for their incomes and independence. But in this age of managed care, doctors have started to sound like blue-collar workers, complaining about shrinking incomes and being pushed around. As a result, the American Medical Association has approved a startling resolution to form a union to help the many doctors who believe banding together is the only way to stand up to managed-care companies.

description: NEW WORLD, NEW RULES

title: Two Airlines Seek Timelier Passengers
description: Passengers on United Airlines and US Airways flights who are running late to the airport will have to run a bit faster to make their flights under new policies designed to have more planes arrive at their destinations on time. Both airlines are trying to close plane doors five minutes before the scheduled departure time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

description: THE beating of a butterfly's wings in one hemisphere, it turns out, really can cause a hurricane in the other.

title: Goodbye, Red. Hello, Rover!
description: I HAVE been asked for a valedictory, a final digest of the wisdom acquired during the last six years here as well as a truthful explanation of why I am coming down off the column. You wish. This is still New York and I have Newsheimers disease. Be grateful for what little I remember.

title: You Can Go Home Again, And to the Beaches
description: As a onetime resident of Sydney who sneaks back annually during the down-under summer, I found surfing the Web to explore my former city as a vacation place a revelation. On Yahoo's Sydney Web site, travel .yahoo.com/destinations (click on the Oceania heading or search for ''Sydney''), I found solid, sometimes imaginative information, on sightseeing, restaurants, transportation, hotels and best of all, the beaches.

description: THERE is Cannes, and there is Connecticut. And the trendiest women of Fairfield County -- some might call them ''fashionistas'' -- can certainly compete not only with their Gallic counterparts but also with their sisters in the Hamptons.

description: Audrey Ellen Thurm, a daughter of Carol Thurm and Dr. Joel Thurm of Davidson, N.C., is to be married today to Dr. Edward James Seiler, a son of Rochelle and Felix Seiler of Netanya, Israel. Rabbi Chaim Stern is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Chinese Art With Character
description: TO pass through the Art Museum's gallery dominated by European Baroque paintings to the adjacent featured exhibition on Chinese calligraphy is to go from dramatic, fleshy forms that often enact some familiar episode from Western civilization to extremely lean ones that are mute to the uninitiated.

title: One Mayor's Two Jobs Revive an Old Debate
description: Mayor make that State Senator -- Sharpe James is fond of saying that if you want something done, get a busy person to do it. These days, Mr. James is a very busy man.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Valerie Beth Edelson and Matthew Thatcher Smith referred incorrectly to the mother of the bride. She is not ''the late.'' She lives in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., with her husband, Harry Edelson. The report also misstated her first name. She is Jonelle Edelson, not Dorothy.

title: A Warm Welcome, But It's All Relative
description: New Delhi's summer weather is ''warm,'' according to the Web site of the Government of India Ministry of Tourism, www.tourism inindia.com. ''Warm,'' of course, is a relative term. Boiling water could be said to be warm. So, too, could a forest fire, a spewing volcano and smelted iron. The summer temperature in India's capital often hits 115, which, for me, is a bit hotter than warm.

title: Truancy for Adults
description: Summertime is here, and the living isn't as easy as it should be. Have you ever creatively fibbed to excuse yourself from work? And just what were you up to instead? Or have you ever caught anyone else playing hooky, and what did you do about it? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Closing Down an Empire, Gracefully
description: As a managing partner at a major accounting firm in the early 90's, Alan J. Bowers had done his share of swimming with the sharks of leveraged buyouts and arbitrage on behalf of corporate clients. He usually watched from a safe distance and was never part of the food chain himself.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 6 about artists in Provincetown, Mass., misspelled the name of an art teacher who had a school there. He was Hans Hofmann, not Hoffman. The article also misstated the years in which Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko visited and referred incorrectly to their role in an exhibition organized by Mr. Hofmann's students. Pollock and Rothko visited Provincetown frequently in the 1940's, not in the 1930's. Although they had several works in the first Abstract Expressionists' exhibition in Provincetown in 1949, they did not help organize it and did not study under Mr. Hofmann.

title: First a Hatchery, Now Hope for Oysters
description: THE state is establishing a shellfish hatchery in the Noank section of Groton in an attempt to save Connecticut's indigenous stocks of oysters and an economically significant industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSON, JANET SIEGEL
description: CHRISTENSON-Janet Siegel. Died suddenly on June 6. Loving sister and sister-in-law of Brenda and Herb Jacobson, devoted aunt of Kim and Jeffrey, grand aunt of Madeleine Anne.Her husband of 25 years, Hugh Rolf Christenson, passed away December 1996. Jan will be deeply missed by her many friends and professional colleagues in the library community, where she served in NYC and San Francisco as a public librarian, and in NYC as a school and academic librarian. Contributions may be sent to a charity of your choice.

title: Trading In Bonds On Line, At Last
description: IT was a bold experiment in cyberspace finance, and at 11:30 one recent Tuesday morning, it was about to be tested in the real market.
