Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Nassau Seeks Seizure Of Scofflaws' Vehicles
description: Laws allowing seizure and sale of cars owned by repeat parking violators were proposed last week by the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta.

title: Teacher Salaries Rank Second Highest in Nation
description: New Jersey teachers ranked second to Connecticut in average salary for the school year 1997-98, the same ranking both states had for the previous school year, according to a survey released last week by the American Federation of Teachers.

title: Chinese With American Heartland Slant
description: A STRIKINGLY beautiful restaurant with tasty food and moderate prices, P. F. Chang's China Bistro has replaced the Brooklyn Diner at the Source, 1504 Old Country Road, in Westbury (222-9200). Although Chang's menu is Chinese, its soul and spirit are American. The American heartland mind-set of this Arizona-based chain is revealed in its menu descriptions and the approach of its servers. Pork dumplings are described as Peking raviolis, even though ravioli is not a best seller in Peking. No doubt someone at the corporate office thought Americans would understand the reference. The restaurant's American spin is also evident and much appreciated at dessert time, when splendid versions of Western favorites like cheesecake and chocolate and pear tortes, rather than the stock canned pineapples, kumquats almond cookies and pistachio ice cream, are offered. Less appreciated is the obviously programmed patter of the non-Chinese waiters (there was not an Asian face at Chang's on the staff or among the diners during my visits) that starts with the sauce ceremony in which the waiter solemnly explains the use of soy sauce, mustard, vinegar and chili paste. That might play in Peoria but for New Yorkers who grew up eating Chinese food, a pedantic lecture about how one mixes mustard into soy sauce is unnecessary and a little silly. Additionally, our earnest waiter asked us if ''everything was all right'' and if we ''were enjoying the food'' about every 10 minutes while water glasses remained unfilled and dirty dishes remained uncleared.

title: States Chasing Sales Taxes Down the Internet Highway
description: IT is one of the more vexing economic issues of the Internet age: how to insure that state sales tax revenues are not eviscerated by the shift to on-line retailing, where borders are all but meaningless and sales tax collection is spotty at best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, FRED C.
description: TRUMP-Fred C.. Husband of Mary MacLeod Trump. Father of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump, Jr. Grandfather of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump, III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump, Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great grandfather of Andrea Trump, Cristopher Trump and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday and Monday, 3-5:00 and 7-9:00 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Ave. at 29 St., Tuesday, 11:00 AM. Interment private. Contributions in memory of Fred C. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, NY 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76 Ave., New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

title: A Name Is a Name Is a Name
description: When Bruce Berkowitz, chief financial officer for Gotham Capital Management, a Manhattan-based hedge fund, was arrested last week on charges of defrauding his company of up to $5 million, another investment fund manager and firm suffered, too. David P. Berkowitz, co-founder of the $550 million Gotham Partners fund, also in Manhattan, heard plenty from worried investors and managers of companies in their portfolio -- including Jonas P. Lee, chief executive of Giftcertificates.com. Mr. Lee got a phone call at 2 A.M. from a friend warning him that his lead investor was in deep trouble, then checked the news on line to discover that it was someone else's trouble.

title: A Consistent Exception to the Rule
description: FISCHER BLACK, the late economist, made a remarkable statement in 1971. Professor Black was a father of the efficient-markets hypothesis, which holds that no adviser or system can beat the market consistently. But after analyzing the track record of the Value Line Investment Survey, he conceded that it was a big exception. He concluded that almost all Wall Street firms ''would improve their performance if they fired all but one of their security analysts and then provided the remaining analyst with the Value Line service.''

title: Four Rapes Likely Committed By Same Man, the Police Say
description: The rapes of two 12-year-old girls in the Bronx last week were probably committed by the same man who raped another 12-year-old and a young woman in the borough this month, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Rough Turf, Even for the Streetwise
description: THE Imperial Credit Commercial Mortgage Investment Corporation, a real estate investment trust, has properties spread from a suburb of Paris to sun-drenched Las Vegas, Nev. But its fate is likely to hinge on what happened earlier this month in a conference room at a Marriott hotel in Torrance, Calif.

title: Not Just Another Working Girl
description: GROWING up, Elise Henning did all the right things. She attended the Ethel Walker School, made her debut at the Junior Assembly, spent her junior year in Geneva and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. When she returned to her parents' home in New Canaan, Conn., she asked her father, a Wall Street commodities trader, if she could go to law school.

title: Sarah Orne and Matthew Herring
description: Sarah Powers Orne, a daughter of Marjorie and Frank W. Orne of Marblehead, Mass., was married there yesterday to Matthew Eugene Herring, a son of Carol P. Herring and H. James Herring of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John P. Potter performed the ceremony at the Old North Congregational Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD - Eileen. Treasured wife of Herbert, after a long and devastating illness slipped away on June 24, 1999 just four days after our 65th wedding anniversary. She was the mother of Migs Woodside and Lewis W. Bernard, grandmother of Geoffrey, Debbie, Adam and Claire. Great-grandmother of Rebecca and Emily. Eileen was a Leo, and lion-hearted in her more than 60 year struggle with an ever painful and threatening eye problem. She had a passion for Old Master Drawings, British antique yellow porcelain, Battersea and Bilston enamels, Regency furniture and visiting Trust Houses. She was a member of the drawing committee at CooperHewitt Museum, a trustee at AllenStevenson School, a Vice-President of Playschools Association, and a Vice-President of the Jewish Welfare Board during the war years, and worked as a USO hostess at the Emanu-El canteen. She was a member of the Board of Directors of Womens' Division of Federation and the American Jewish Committee. She was devoted to ballet, good music, opera, travel, stimulating lectures, museums, and hostessing, with great flair, happy parties at our 911 Penthouse. Eileen was a wonderful daughter, concerned mother, and anyone who knew her and worked with her realized how inspiring she was and always gave of herself to the utmost. Contributions in her memory to the Museum Acquisitions Fund of Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65 St, NY, 10021 would be appreciated by her family. Good night ''Blithe Spirit'', sleep well, ''Fairest of the Fair''. You deserve it. Herbert

title: Style; Upwardly Mobile
description: In Vincente Minnelli's movie ''The Long, Long Trailer,'' Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz suffer the shame that has been hitched to trailer living ever since the Depression turned a recreational activity into a cheap way to survive. Playing a dignified young couple, they are mocked by other drivers, then scorned by the suburban relatives they are visiting when they accidentally back their 30-foot land yacht into their home.

title: Wartime Lies?
description: THE UNITED STATES AND BIOLOGICAL WARFARE

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Beast With Two Books
description: Elephants have had an extraordinary pull on the human imagination since the Stone Age, a fact made abundantly clear in ELEPHANTS: A Cultural and Natural History (Konemann, $39.95), by Karl Groning and Martin Saller. Combining a crammed though somewhat haphazardly organized text with stunning illustrations and photographs, the book chronicles the evolution of elephants and their history in folklore, myth, commerce and the arts. There is much that amazes -- elephants can run up to 25 miles an hour, eat up to 375 pounds of vegetation a day, are as intelligent as dolphins and go out of their way to avoid stepping on small creatures in their path -- though perhaps only the most ardent enthusiasts will thrill to learn that an elephant's appendix is five feet long and small intestine 82 feet long. The book unflinchingly reports human abuse of these beguiling animals, a grim record stretching from ancient Rome, where elephants were pitted in amphitheaters against starving lions and leopards, to the 20th century, when hunting for sport and ivory caused a dramatic decline in the elephant population, from five million at the end of the last century to around 500,000 today. AFRICAN ELEPHANTS (Abrams, $49.50) is a revised edition of the wildlife photographer Reinhard Kunkel's 1982 book, ''Elephants,'' which combines glorious photographs with vignettes drawn from many years tracking his quarry across the savannas of eastern Africa. The impressionistic text is clearly written by a man who loves his work, whether he's watching his subjects take dust baths or peering at the scarab beetles that scurry about an elephant's dung (an adult drops about 200 pounds daily). The photographs range from striking vistas of adult and baby elephants rumbling through the wilderness to tender close-ups that focus on a small patch of weathered skin or the creature's absurdly delicate eyelashes. There is a sadness at the heart of this homage, however, which takes full note of the depredations and loss of habitat that have doomed the elephant to a marginal existence.Scott Veale

title: Into the Unknown
description: Ah, it is wonderful to feel so entitled -- to everything (''One if by Land, Two if by Sea, Three if by Rollerblade,'' by Edward Zuckerman)! Clearly, that is the lesson of Elf Authentic Adventure, the extreme sports event organizer, highlighted in your latest millennial issue. If something is possible, no matter how pointless, we should do it.

title: Louisiana-Inspired Dishes in a No-Frills Spot
description: TUCKED away at the end of one of old Rye's narrow streets, High Street Roadhouse here has the unpretentious facade of a speak-easy. First timers might have trouble finding the place, and when they do find it, they might not know it. But those who like flavorful, Louisiana-inspired dishes in no-frills surroundings -- and judging by the crowd at the bar and in the dining room, many do -- will be glad they found the way.

title: POSTINGS: 25 New Collection Offices in the City; Property Tax, Without Lines
description: Property-tax payers who want immediate proof of payment but don't want to stand in line at city offices can now pay their residential or commercial real estate taxes at one of 25 storefront collection offices throughout New York City operated by Cashpoint, a private company.

description: Beverly Dashnaw Madden and David Rogers Waters were married on Friday evening at Christ Church in New York. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman performed the Methodist ceremony.

title: Another Metro Meant To Be Memorable
description: THE giant caterpillerlike entrances to the Metro, this city's subway system, are made of glass ribbed with steel and alive with light. Symbols of a city reborn, they beckon riders with their sparkle by day, their glow by night, all part of the design signature of the British architect Lord Norman Foster, the winner this year of the Pritzker Architecture Prize.

title: It Takes a Big Tree to Get a Little Recognition
description: By the banks of the Musconetcong River, in a quiet corner of a cornfield off Route 57 in rural Warren County, stands a towering red oak tree, the biggest in the state, according to a New Jersey Forest Service brochure.

title: Gary Kasmer and Kate Meyers
description: Anne Kathryn Meyers, the daughter of Mary Ann and John Meyers of Wynnewood, Pa., was married yesterday to Gary Joseph Kasmer, a son of Barbara and Gary Kasmer of Springfield, Pa. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Siasconset Union Chapel on Nantucket Island.

title: The Meddler Against Cruelty
description: LEGEND has it that Henry Bergh, a member of a prominent New York shipbuilding family who served in a United States delegation to Russia under President Lincoln, jumped out of his carriage in 1863 to stop a peasant from beating his cart horse. Three years later, he started the A.S.P.C.A. as part of a wave of social reform in which he also helped found a movement to protect children. Bergh will be a major figure in an exhibition called ''Heritage of Care: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals,'' starting Saturday at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: A Hymn to Extravagance, in Love and in Filmmaking
description: LIKE one of Yves Tanguy's infernal machines, Leos Carax's ''Amants du Pont Neuf'' was a movie seemingly designed to self-destruct. A hymn to the annihilating power of l'amour fou, the film was interrupted twice during production, first for a year when the leading man broke a leg, later for another year when the money ran out. It eventually took three years to complete, then met an uncomprehending public when it came out. (After it showed at the 1992 New York Film Festival, The New York Times critic Vincent Canby called it ''one of the most extravagant and delirious follies perpetrated on French soil since Marie-Antoinette played the milkmaid at the Petit Trianon.'') According to Mr. Carax, a resentful producer deliberately set the price for American theatrical distribution too high and also prevented the film from being released on video in France.

title: PULSE: WEDDING EDITION; For Diamonds, Plump Is O.K.
description: Engagement rings, despite their intimations of timeless love, eternal connubial harmony, et cetera, are just as susceptible to the vagaries of trendiness as those Jimmy Choo slides in your closet. Two years ago, the timeless setting was the bezel-set diamond in a platinum band. This year, it's the cushion cut -- a diamond that looks like a big plump cushion, with a rectangular girdle, curved sides and rounded corners. An older style cut that marries the emerald-cut shape with the fire of a brilliant round diamond, cushion cuts are also desirable because they're hard to find. ''Years ago, everyone had to have a pear-shaped diamond engagement ring,'' Carol Brodie, a vice president at Harry Winston, said. ''Ten years ago, it was round. Now it's all about the family of geometric shapes, square cuts, emerald cuts and cushion cuts.'' Timelessness and bliss are costly. At Winston, cushion-cut engagement rings start at $25,000, for a one- to two-carat stone; the most popular sellers are five carats plus. ALEX KUCZINSKI

title: Data Bank; Let the Fed Chess Match Begin
description: It's tricky playing chess with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. Just when he lures you into a comfort zone by moving a pawn, he can easily turn to knights, bishops and rooks for a surprise attack.

title: The Next Clinton
description: As a registered Democrat, a feminist and a lifelong resident of New York, I would dearly love to be enthusiastic about Hillary Clinton's possible run for the Senate. However, I recoiled when I read her comment that ''we all, we all got through that,'' referring to the ''humiliation'' that finally made her a hero to many Americans. I am not sure who she was alluding to in the ''we all.'' I did not ''get through that.'' I was disgusted by it, outraged by it, but I have never got through it, in terms of resolving it, nor would I wish to, since the behavior will always be unacceptable.

Bush of Texas made a triumphant visit to Capitol Hill last week, Congressional Republicans grabbed hold of him as if he were a life raft that could sail them all to victory. title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; What Do I Owe You?
description: In A VAUDEVILLE OF DEVILS: 7 Moral Tales (Delacorte, $24.95), his seductive new story collection, Robert Girardi offers seven post-modern parables that range wildly over space and time. Taken together, they reveal the ethical predicaments of a Nazi SS officer, a knight, a computer geek, a deep-sea diver, a vintner, a public defender and a translator. Girardi sifts through his characters' doubts and demons while mapping complex cultural terrain. From the expatriate community in Yemen, where a German cabaret singer tries to erase his past, to the boardroom of a Seattle start-up poised for an acquisition by a Japanese company, the international backdrops contribute to a sense of confused identity and conflicted duty. Questions about what we owe others -- our children, our neighbors, even our ancestors and our gods -- haunt the book and lend it an insistent apocalyptic tone. The stories tell of the temptations of power and authority, as well as the real-life costs of empathy and compassion. Here, the normal rules seem inadequate. When a desperate attorney lands a big case defending an especially heinous member of the Russian Mafia, he gains much-needed confidence by engaging in profound self-delusion. And when a middle-aged Neapolitan countess lusts after an aimless American, she embroiders a beastly fiction in order to trap him. Girardi, a skilled storyteller whose novels include ''Madeleine's Ghost'' and ''Vaporetto 13,'' writes sensuous prose that unapologetically invokes the supernatural. Although moral in theme, these frank, erotic tales are never moralistic. Illustrating the compromises that ordinary people make gradually, almost imperceptibly, ''A Vaudeville of Devils'' exposes the subtle art of the Faustian bargain.

title: Conversations/Ken Alibek; Finding Penance in Going Public About Making Germs Into Bullets
description: HIS English halting, his hand never far from a cigarette, Ken Alibek sat in his office near Washington on a gray day about a year ago and said he would readily give up his life if that were what it would take. He told of a death threat. A serious one. But his demeanor in recounting the incident was calm, even peaceful. In hours of interviewing and talk, and in subsequent conversations over the course of a year, he seemed to be a warrior with an eye not so much on victory as on redemption, a man trying to make amends for a dark past.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Land Ho at the Aquarium
description: Since its opening in 1992, the New Jersey State Aquarium has introduced one new aquatic exhibit after another. But its focus is shifting inland this week as it opens the Camden Children's Garden on Saturday. The four-acre plot of land, to be operated by the Camden City Garden Club, serves as an educational playground, offering a variety of interactive horticultural exhibits.

title: Heard It Before
description: To the Editor:

title: Valerie Losito, Brian Gallagher
description: Valerie Ann Losito, a daughter of Rita and Frank Losito of Apex, N.C., was married yesterday to Brian Peter Gallagher, a son of Patrick J. Gallagher of Ross, Calif., and the late Lucille S. Gallagher. The Rev. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Lyndhurst Castle in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-27-99: The Ethicist; Madison Avenue Medicine
description: Is it right for doctors to advertise? Does it compromise their ethics, or are they and the public protected by the 'truth in advertising' laws? -- Rudy Svezia, Englewood, N.J.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Public golf is nuts. To play on the weekend, it's insanity. The fairways overlap, balls flying everywhere. It's like a firing range out there.''

title: Editorial Observer; George W. Bush Crams for the White House
description: When meeting with his policy experts, many of them alumni of his father's Presidency, George W. Bush is said to project an air of confidence if not entitlement. ''I am going to be the next President,'' he declares, according to one adviser. ''I need your help, not to become President, but to be a good President.'' By all accounts, the Texas Governor who studied at Yale and Harvard is not only running hard for the White House. He is also cramming for it like someone facing the ultimate final exam.

title: Montreal: Two Wheels, Few Hills
description: PICTURE a long, narrow body of water shimmering with poplars, grass stretching to hedgerows, occasional stands of willow and honey locust. And in the distance an iron bridge, smokestacks, brick warehouses, railroad tracks. A painting by Pissarro? Not exactly, for this land and cityscape extends about eight miles and has a piste cyclable (bike path) running right through it. Now a park developed by the Canadian Government, with colorful banners proclaiming every kilometer or so, ''more than a bike path, a historic site,'' the Lachine Canal once lay at the heart of Montreal's river commerce.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: This week's movies include a colorful underwater sci-fi adventure, a great director's island salute, an amusing tale of brainy competitors and a Kipling fantasy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, MADELINE
description: HIGGINS-Madeline. September 13, 1907-June 25, 1999. Beloved friend, historian and scholar. Survived by nephews David and Gerald Horkan and their families in Dublin, Ireland. Funeral mass Monday, 10 AM, at St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43rd St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: A Eurailpass Gift For the Big Four-O
description: Users of Eurailpasses who turn 40 in 1999, the 40th anniversary of the first Eurailpass, will receive a 40 percent discount on train fares. The passes are offered by the national rail systems in 17 European countries, and are good for travel in all 17.

title: When Drug Trials Equal Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOFF, MAXINE, M.D.
description: ROSOFF-Maxine, M.D.. the Medical Staff and Board of Directors of New Island Hospital mourn with profound sorrow the untimely loss of our esteemed colleague. Dr. Rosoff was a member of our Medical Staff's Department of Medicine/Cardiology for the past 11 years and was the Director and Co-Director of the Coronary Care Unit since 1991. We will miss her greatly. Arnold Prywes, M.D. Chairperson, Medical Staff Paul Seale, President & CEO

title: Insuring Women's Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Now They Both Feel Good
description: Papa's got a brand new moneybag. For a concert last night in New York, James Brown, the Godfather of Soul, had plans to welcome on stage David Pullman, whose Pullman Group investment firm raised about $30 million for Mr. Brown by issuing bonds based on future royalties. Besides becoming the Underwriter of Soul, Mr. Pullman has sold bonds for David Bowie and Ashford & Simpson.

title: It's Art, It's Water, It's . . . Loot
description: One night in the middle of May, somebody stole four jugs of Jan Baracz's water from a parking lot at Wooster and Grand Streets. ''Maybe they were thirsty,'' he said.

title: A Century of Black Film
description: THE 25th season of the Newark Black Film Festival, one of the nation's longest-running festivals of its kind, opens on Wednesday with a lecture by the film maker and photographer Gordon Parks and a screening of his film ''The Learning Tree.'' Billed as a retrospective, this year's festival offers a summer lineup of what it considers to be the best of black cinema in the 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: A Poet of the Emotions Breaks His Silence
description: CINEASTE maudit what does that mean?'' asks Leos Carax, the French filmmaker of his generation most often accused of being one. ''It's something made up by the press, I think.''

title: Kahane Corn, Jeffrey Cooperman
description: Kahane Rachel Corn and Jeffrey Todd Cooperman, television producers in New York, were married yesterday at the Pratt Mansion in New York. Cantor Robert Bloch officiated.

title: In the Region/Long Island; 4 Office Projects Under Way to Meet Strong Demand
description: ENCOURAGED by continued demand from office tenants who need more space to accommodate growth, several developers have started major buildings in the expectation that the office market will still be strong when they complete construction.

title: A Death to Melanoma Inspires a Crusade
description: THIS summer, as you head to Jones Beach or anywhere else in the sun, Colette and Patrick Coyne want you to remember a few things:

title: June 20-26; Senate Kills Steel Bill
description: No one has Washington wired like the steel lobby. At least, that's what everyone thought. For a year Big Steel has been complaining about big imports. It got the Clinton Administration to crack down on Japanese, Korean, Russian and Brazilian steel ''dumped'' in the United States at super-cheap prices.

title: A Crusader Who Lets Her Heroes Be Human
description: THE painting is called ''Forming the Fifth International.'' On one side of the oversize canvas sits Rosa Luxemburg, the Polish-born socialist leader assassinated in Berlin in 1919 when she was 48. On the other side, a figure from a different era, is Alice Stevens, an aged, infirm, nursing-home patient who died in 1985 at age 89. Rosa is weightless, a black and white projection. Alice is heavy, pink and fleshy. Rosa stares out at the viewer; she seems to intuit her imminent martyrdom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, TONY
description: MICHAELS-Tony. June 25, 1999, After complications of coronary artery disease. Beloved friend, we remember him for his generosity, humor, dignity, spirit and kindness. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in memoriam to Save the Childrens Fund. A private service will be held at a later date.

title: Fighting Over Parking Spaces; Crunch Is a Result Of Government Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, a Plan to Fix the Big Bottleneck; Good News for Drivers, But Some Want Work Scaled Back on Q Bridge
description: PROJECTS to rebuild and expand bridges originally built decades ago often receive little opposition from residents, who accept the short-term disruptions that the work brings as necessary to smooth traffic flow and sustain economic growth over the long term.

title: Lynn Monahan, William Mennen 4th
description: Lynn Anne Monahan and William G. Mennen 4th were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. J. Oscar McCloud, a Presbyterian minister, at the Roxiticus Golf Club in Mendham, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUND, LUCAS
description: FREUND-Lucas. ''Tis better to drink life in one flaming hour and reef across the sun than to sip pale years and cower before oblivion.'' June 27, 1997. We profoundly miss and love you. Mom, Dad and Charlotte.

title: Where Bikers and Others Get High-Test Fuel for the Road
description: Sticky Fingers, a bakery on First Avenue between Seventh Street and St. Marks Place, has pretty cakes and pyramids of cookies in the window, and usually a line of motorcycles parked outside. While the pairing of bikers and confections ''scares off some people,'' says the owner of the bakery, Ricky Diaz, ''it attracts others.''

title: The Minimalist
description: THE ARCHITECTURE OF YOSHIO TANIGUCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACHMAN, ARTHUR, PH.D.
description: BLACHMAN-Arthur, Ph.D.. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, died June 25 of cancer at the age of 73. Arthur was the husband of Lucy and father to three sons Eric, Neil and Jeremy. He was also the beloved grandfather of five: Natan, Renana, Shaul and Meier of Ber Sheva, Israel; and Abigail of Houston, TX. He was the father-in-law to Hannah and Lauren. In his memory donations can be made to the American Cancer Society or the Westchester Choral Society.

title: Ms. Atterbury, Mr. O'Keefe
description: Winifred Atterbury, a daughter of Winifred Buono Atterbury of Newtown Square, Pa., and George R. Atterbury of Glendale, Calif., was married yesterday to Sean Bradley O'Keefe, the son of Katherine and Harold O'Keefe of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Gerard Reedy performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Savior in New York.

title: City of Skyscrapers and Sister Carrie
description: EVER since I first read Theodore Dreiser's rich, detailed descriptions of Chicago in his novel ''Sister Carrie,'' I've thought of the city as the place from which much of the modern American character has sprung. I wanted to explore its rectilinear sprawl of avenues and vast fields of railroad tracks as Sister Carrie had in 1889, on foot, hiking up and down the broad avenues lined with impressive factory buildings and fine department stores with ''great plate glass windows'' filled with ''silk, woolens, lingerie and fine feathers.''

title: Teamsters Local With History of Corruption Sees Accusations of Wrongdoing Fly Again
description: Teamsters Local 810 has tried for the last four years to shake a dark history of corruption, nepotism, embezzlement and bribery that cheated its 6,500 members out of wages and benefits. But the local's leaders have once again been accused of wrongdoing, this time by each other.

title: Boy, 6, Killed in Fall From the 10th Floor
description: A 6-year-old boy in foster care fell to his death yesterday from the window of a 10th-floor apartment in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Teacher Wins Award
description: Looking back at a 32-year teaching career, Richard Lavino said last week that he wants to be remembered most for ''making the classroom an exciting place.''

title: One Person's Trash Turns Into Another's Treasure at Yard Sales; Scouring to Outfit That Beach House
description: IT was shaping up as a typically busy weekend in an atypically busy spring -- lots of yard work, trips to two airports, a visit by our daughter. So, when I told my wife, Eileen, I had turned down an opportunity to be paid to scour yard sales, she understandably exclaimed, ''Are you nuts?''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; The Ming Dynasty Comes to Staten Island
description: Long ago -- between 1368 and 1644, to be precise -- Chinese scholars specializing in literature, mathematics and Confucian philosophy could find the tranquillity they required in thousands of refuges called scholar's gardens. Unfortunately, only 60 of these gardens still survive in China, with just 19 open to the public.

title: Cementing a Relationship
description: How can a cement sidewalk last for only a few weeks?

title: Peacekeepers, at Last, Reopen Pristina Airport
description: Two weeks after the first NATO peacekeepers arrived in Kosovo, the first military aircraft landed here today at the province's main airport, which NATO commanders said could soon open to regular flights.

title: Last Act in Yonkers
description: After 19 years, the curtain may finally be falling on this city's marathon saga of school and housing desegregation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSTA, CHARLES J.
description: BUSTA-Charles J.., 51, of New York, NY and Monkton, MD on June 21, 1999. Charles, known as CB was a graduate of Cathedral Latin High School, Class of 1966; received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Dayton, Dayton, OH, and Master of Arts degree in Journalism from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL. He started his career at Noxell Corporation, a division of Proctor & Gamble Company. Most recently, he was an Executive Vice President, General Manager of Revlon Professional USA. He was a member of the board of directors of the Baltimore Tool Company and the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Bonnie and son of Charles and Ann Busta. Devoted father of Caroline. Cherished brother of Kathleen Kolick, and James and Richard Busta. Donations can be sent to the Charles CB Busta Lecture Series, Office of the President, College of Notre Dame of Maryland, 4701 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21210.

title: Nicole Tucker, David Keith
description: Nicole Rachel Tucker, the daughter of Natalie Klein Tucker of New York and John W. Tucker of Burlington, Vt., was married on Monday to David McKay Keith, the son of Kathleen and Quentin Keith of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Richard Yu, a minister of the Church of Universal Life, performed the ceremony on the beach at Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven.

title: Ms. Burnham, Mr. Herdeg
description: Caroline Anne Burnham, a daughter of Alice and William W. Burnham of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Fell Coolidge Herdeg, a son of Judith and John A. Herdeg of Mendenhall, Pa. The Rev. Laura J. Ahrens, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Parish in Noroton, Conn.

title: As Easy as It Is Flavorful: High-Heat Searing on the Grill
description: I AM not one of those gung-ho grillers who is happy to cook entire meals outdoors as soon as the thermometer hits 65 degrees. The grill is wonderful for, well, grilling. I use it for searing many kinds of meat, seafood, poultry, game, vegetables and, sometimes, fruit, imparting a smokiness and an appetizingly browned, crisp finish.

title: A Disney Builds a Yacht for Transpacific Race
description: It would seem that Roy E. Disney, a yachtsman as well as Walt Disney Company executive, would have more in-house choices than Pinocchio had shoes to figure out what to call his racing boats. But the 69-year-old Disney ended up choosing Pyewacket, a name belonging to the fanciful Siamese cat in the 1958 movie ''Bell, Book and Candle,'' which wasn't a Disney film.

title: Alexandra Llewellyn, Tom Clancy
description: Alexandra Maria Llewellyn, a freelance journalist, and Tom Clancy, the author, were married yesterday by the Rev. Andrew Meade at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

description: MOTHER OF PEARL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pat

title: The Nation: Stealth Design; You're Not Getting Older. Products Are Getting Better.
description: Age isn't the only thing creeping up on the baby-boom generation. Consumer product design and marketing are too, like wolves on cattle.

title: The Glory and Gamble Of Creating an Index
description: LATELY, it seems, media outlets everywhere -- from trade publications to glossy magazines to Internet sites -- have been turning out stock indexes at a rapid clip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOFF KLEIN, MAXINE H.
description: ROSOFF KLEIN-Maxine H.., M.D. On June 24, 1999 of Jericho, N.Y. Beloved wife of Dennis. Devoted mother of Jonathan and stepmother of Danielle. Adored daughter of Shirley and the late Dr. Stanley. Dear sister of Robin Seplowe. Service Sunday 2PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: The Aura Of the Aura
description: Bill bradley had come home again, almost. to st. louis, just up the mississippi from Crystal City (where, as you know if you've heard his stump speech, there were 96 in his graduating class, along with one stoplight and 3,492 souls all told). Here, more than anywhere, he is an American hero, the good kid who worked hard, minded his manners and grew up to be a Rhodes scholar, a New York Knick, then a New Jersey senator. And now, who knows, maybe even President.

title: Vessels That Held Fragrances Make a Bouquet of an Exhibition
description: IT is fortunate that history is odorless, because the past was rather foul-smelling. As bathing was limited in pre-plumbing days, the use of perfume to mask body odor was common. The earliest bottles of the ancient world were undoubtedly made to hold scented oils or fragrances for social benefit.

title: Typical Americans
description: WHO'S IRISH?

title: Wendy Betel and Joshua Heller
description: Wendy Joy Betel, a daughter of Ellen and Edward Betel of West Bloomfield, Mich., is to be married today to Rabbi Joshua Zvi Heller, the son of Dr. Lynne E. Heller and Rabbi Zachary I. Heller of Newton, Mass. The bridegroom's father is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Adat Shalom in Farmington Hills, Mich.

title: Charging Mallon's 63 Leaves Her One Behind
description: Meg Mallon glanced over her shoulder toward the 18th green at DuPont Country Club, rolled her eyes and let loose a laugh.

title: Q & A/Joy Wulke; Nature Champions the Millennium
description: JOY WULKE's vision for the millennium digs deep into the positive territory of the natural world and its sensorial gifts. Ms. Wulke, a 51-year-old artist, received a master's degree of environmental design from the Yale School of Architecture in 1974. She is an environmental sculptor, a project coordinator for Art in Public Spaces with the Connecticut Commission on the Arts and is the founder of Projects for a New Millennium, which began in 1994 to demonstrate the kinship between art and science.

title: The Stuff of Legend In a Brazilian Slum
description: EVEN before he emerged as a torchbearer of the Cinema Novo movement here in the 1960's, the director Carlos ''Caca'' Diegues yearned to film the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice. Over the years, he admits, as he was working on the 13 movies on his resume, including ''Bye-Bye Brazil'' and ''Xica da Silva,'' images of what a Brazilian version of the myth would look and sound like constantly filled his imagination.

title: Jaye Miller, Steven Dougherty
description: Jaye Miller and Steven Dougherty were married yesterday at Riverside Church in New York by the Rev. Keith Boyer, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Restoring My Love To Beauty
description: MEN just don't clean their cars the way they used to. Since the founding of Levittown in 1947, suburban men have been expected or required to spend every summer Saturday morning in the driveway, washing their precious vehicles with sponge and detergent, and finishing off with hose and chamois. Every month, a coat of polish had to be applied, and every year the whole mess was cleaned off with a finish restorer, and the cycle would start all over again.

title: McDonald's Approved For Hampton Bays
description: Without waiting for the completion of a development plan for the area, the Southampton Town Board has approved an application for a McDonald's restaurant on Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays.

title: Dressing Up, or Down, for the Occasion
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Pay A Price To Draft Czech Wing
description: On a draft day filled with a furious flurry of high-level deals, the Rangers moved up twice in the picking order, the Islanders played a pat but full hand and the Devils took one of the hindmost picks in the first round.

title: Teen-Ager's Quest: Going in the Wind to Sydney
description: This is Amanda Clark's downwind summer, probably her last chance to improve without pressure, of finding out without penalty how far she can push before she flips. She is 17 years old, your basic amateur. She buys her own shoes.

title: In the Heat, 11 Players Within 3 Of the Lead
description: It was hot on the golf course. It was crowded on the leader board. And when the third round of the Buick Classic concluded today, the outcome of the final round was difficult to predict.

title: Federal Power, Undimmed
description: Lacking any dramatic new conflict about individual rights, the Supreme Court turned to states' rights, ending its term last week with a set of 5-to-4 rulings that many, including dissenting Justices, said tipped the balance between state and Federal power sharply to the states.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with the Portfolios, Etc., column, about possible effects of an increase in interest rates, misstated the history of the Federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks since March 1997, when it was raised to 5.5 percent. The rate has been lowered three times since then, to 4.75 percent, it has not been flat. Here is a corrected chart.

title: 3 Get Medal of Valor For Kidnap Rescue
description: The last time Officers Steve Cassese, Pete Lang and Mike Marsala (shown left to right) saw Caryn Lieber, she had been shot twice after having been abducted from her East Meadow home. But she has recovered from her wounds and was on hand for June 17 ceremony at which the three officers were presented the Nassau County Police Department's Medal of Valor for saving her life.

title: From Queens Tables To South America
description: 18 DE JULIO+

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Rockaways, Queens; Ethnic Diversity and an Economic Gamut
description: THE 11-mile-long Rockaway Peninsula, flanked by Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, has a diversity of cultures and communities so great that only the beach itself provides a unifying theme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGS, WALTER J.
description: BIGGS-Walter J.. 78, on June 9, 1999. Of respiratory failure, after a brief illness. Founder of hospital publications and publisher of medical aspects of human sexuality and hospital medicine. Served honorably as a United State Naval Officer during World War II, graduate of St. John's University. Survived by his son Walter Biggs Jr., his daughters, Barbara Schade and Joanne Biggs and his granddaughter Carlota Biggs-Rubio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, BESS
description: GRUBER-Bess. Our condolences to the Goldsmith family. Such a beautiful lady will be missed. The Biblowitz Family

title: Dorrit Thomas and Todd Morley
description: ALTHOUGH J. Todd Morley is the chief executive of Links Securities, an investment bank, and looks like a model in a Ralph Lauren advertisement, friends say he is more likable than enviable. He doesn't smoke cigars. He's polite to waiters. He takes calls from old friends with low-paying jobs. He's 38, yet never tries to act older or wiser. He recently considered redecorating his office with Bob Marley posters.

title: Amy Wilson, David Flannery
description: Amy Elizabeth Wilson, a daughter of Nancy and James Wilson of Scranton, Pa., was married there yesterday evening to David Jude Flannery, the son of Louise and Edward Flannery, also of Scranton. Msgr. J. Peter Crynes performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Church.

title: An Internet Miracle: A $21 Hotel Room
description: A hotel room in Tokyo for $21? It seems incredible, but the Hotel New Koyo charges just 2,500 yen for its smallest single rooms, including service charge and tax. In a city where a fine melon can cost more than $100, that is an extraordinary find, and I turned it up through a Web site called Planet Tokyo at www.pandemic.com/tokyo.

title: INSIDE
description: China Moves on Hong Kong

title: More Years for Heirs To Benefit From I.R.A.'s
description: The Internal Revenue Service has approved a significant tax break for some people who want to leave the money in their Individual Retirement Accounts to two or three generations of heirs.

title: Fractured Skull Is Fatal to Three Ring
description: In a shattering accident in the paddock at Belmont Park yesterday, Three Ring, one of the country's most accomplished fillies, was euthanized after she reared while being saddled, flipped and fractured her skull.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASH, ARTHUR
description: NASH-Arthur. 52, on June 21, 1999. To my cherished friend Arthur, whose laughter, smiles, warmth and unconditional love transformed my life. You will be in my heart forever, and always remembered as a beloved husband, father, son, brother, uncle and friend. I miss you so much. Ronny

title: Brooklyn Union Gas Cuts In-Home Repair
description: AS of Thursday, Brooklyn Union, the gas company that succeeded the Long Island Lighting Company, will no longer repair gas appliances for its 450,000 customers on Long Island. The Public Service Commission ordered the action two years ago after plumbing and heating companies complained that utilities in the state had an unfair monopoly over such repairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, ELIZABETH (NEE SPITZER)
description: LANG-Elizabeth (nee Spitzer)., 97, April 2, 1999. Born in Vienna. Studied social work. Emmigrated to the U.S.A. 1939. Worked with NYANA and Louise Wise Services. We will remember her for her perennial optimism and her love of life and people. Her nephew Michael (Langer) Livni, Kibbutz Lotan, Israel; niece Lucy Laufer, Vancouver, BC and grand nephews Dvir, Nimrod and Sivan Langer; Dan and Ron Laufer.

title: Coping When Two Incomes Become One
description: MARK A. and Anastasia B. Edmonston are the sort of people credit card companies hate and mutual fund managers love.

title: In Canada, a Resort Town by a Bay
description: A NEW BRUNSWICK transportation official once told me almost wistfully that he lived in the ''drive-through province.'' I would have heartily agreed -- the hours I've logged on New Brunswick highways on my way to Prince Edward Island each summer tended to confirm the joke -- except for our memorable stays in St. Andrews.

description: This season's N.B.A. draft, scheduled for Wednesday at the MCI Center in Washington, has no clear-cut No. 1 choice, but here are the likely top five selections.

description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Commercial Property/Julien J. Studley; Finding a Way to Figure Out the Real Cost of Leases
description: IN the late 1980's Julien J. Studley, the chairman of the brokerage firm that bears his name, noticed an unusual development: even though demand for office space was weak and landlords were clamoring for tenants, the asking rents for properties kept rising. ''For two years the market fell, but rents seemed to keep increasing,'' he said.

title: Rebekah Sturges And Jack Harris
description: Rebekah Hale Sturges, a daughter of Caren Vignos Sturges and Sheldon Sturges, both of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Jack Gwynne Emmet Harris, the son of Heidi Vanderbilt of Benson, Ariz., and Jones Harris of New York. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Asticou Inn in Northeast Harbor, Me.

description: IN this age of professional athletes and poster boys, plastic presidents and rock-and-roll stars, it is often easy to forget about the people behind the people. That is probably never more true than for those who make the instruments that others use to make music.

title: A Rose Is a Rose, and 1,200 Varieties Are 1,200 Varieties
description: There are hundreds of fragrant roses in full bloom in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden at this time of year. Scott Canning, the garden's rosarian, can regale visitors with the stories behind the names of a good many of them.

Zesiger of New York and Albert Zesiger of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Jacob Carver, a son of Kristin Carver and the Rev. Robert Carver of Tacoma, Wash. The Rev. George Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., with the bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Political Memo; Bush Is on Easy Street Early in His Campaign
description: Two weeks have now passed since Gov. George W. Bush first hit the campaign trail. And his poll numbers just keep getting better, the crowds keep on coming, and the money keeps on rolling in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, JOSEPH
description: KIMMEL-Joseph. On June 24, 1999, of a brain tumor. Beloved and proud husband of Gloria. Worshipped and cherished father of Tracey, Sharon and son-in-law Bert. Adored grandfather of Matthew and Jan. His charm, wit and personality will be sorely missed. Private services. Contributions can be made in Joseph's name to the American Cancer Society. KIMMEL-Joseph. We mourn the loss of our former member, Joseph Kimmel, whose happiest days were spent at the Old Westbury Country Club. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Gloria, and children. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club

title: Turning a Photographer's Vision Into Choreography
description: HISTORY has neglected Arnie Zane, co-founder of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. His partnership with Mr. Jones produced the paradigmatic post-modern repertory of the 1980's, but after his death from AIDS in 1988 and the notoriety of Mr. Jones's subsequent career, Mr. Zane faded into a shadow legend, invoked less as artistic innovator than tragic hero.

title: A Stubborn One
description: THE bloodstain that marks the spot where Armando Perez fell can still be seen on 24th Street in Long Island City, Queens, just south of 34th Avenue. The half-moon-shaped stain lies midway between the curb and an old maple tree, within sight of the Ravenswood housing project where Mr. Perez's wife, Marianne Kunitz-Perez, was waiting for him when whatever happened to him happened.

title: The Calm After a Storm in the Attorney General's Office
description: WHEN Governor Whitman asked reluctant lawmakers to approve the appointment of her besieged attorney general, Peter G. Verniero, to the State Supreme Court in May, she offered an enticing argument. She told Mr. Verniero's critics that his likely replacement, the popular chief counsel John J. Farmer Jr., would do a better job of handling the thorny issue of racial profiling by the State Police, people close to the lobbying say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Streetscapes/The Cooper Union Building; New York's Biggest Brownstone to Regain Old Look
description: NOW, the giant, brownstone walls look like they were attacked by a monster from a Stephen King novel, with huge claw marks scraping the stones down to the backing. At the 1859 Cooper Union Building, at Astor Place and Fourth Avenue, architects and conservators are pursuing a new direction in preservation, as they repair New York's biggest brownstone with the aim of having it look anything but ''like new.''

title: Joe Redington, Co-Founder Of Dog Sled Race, Dies at 82
description: Joe Redington, who died Thursday at the age of 82 at his homestead in Knik, Alaska, near Anchorage, did not get to mush until he was in his late 30's, but when he did, he realized something that no one else had thought of: if you organize a 1,100-mile dog sled race, even if you don't have any sort of grubstake at all, interesting things could happen.

title: Bob Grant or Senate? Talk-Show Host Ponders as Whitman Squirms
description: As one of talk radio's original angry white males, Bob Grant of WOR-AM has enjoyed considerable notoriety and won high ratings by making inflammatory comments about the people who upset him. They tend to be poor, politically liberal or black.

Leung, was married yesterday to Eleftherios Emanuel Rouvelas, the son of Marilyn and Emanuel Rouvelas of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Constantine P. Efstathiu performed the ceremony at the Nativity of Christ Greek Orthodox Church in Ignacio, Calif. A traditional Chinese tea ceremony was held at the reception in San Rafael, Calif.

title: Longest Shot Is in Just Reaching the First Tee
description: Almost every Saturday night, Ron Bucci, a chiropractor from Tarrytown, kisses his wife and three children goodbye and drives the family van up to Mohansic Golf Course, where he sleeps in the parking lot with carloads of other men from Westchester County.

title: Jennifer Spofford and Penn Sanger
description: Jennifer Barclay Spofford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Nicholas Spofford of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Penn duPont Sanger, a son of Mrs. Peter D. Sanger of Sanibel, Fla., and the late Mr. Sanger. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Vevey
description: About every 20 years, the quaint Swiss village of Vevey, on the northeastern shore of Lake Geneva, honors a new generation of winemakers. Last held in 1977, the Fete des Vignerons has been sponsored by the local brotherhood of winegrowers since the 17th century. This summer, more than half a million visitors are expected to descend on tiny Vevey (population 16,000) for an 18-day extravaganza, from July 29 to Aug. 15.

title: Marilyn Nonken, Jason Eckardt
description: Marilyn Claire Nonken, a pianist, and Jason Keith Eckardt, a composer, were married yesterday at the Box Tree restaurant in New York. Dr. Bob Kaufmann, the interim senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: Chimpanzees With Culture
description: After examining the results of 151 years of chimpanzee research, a team of primatologists recently concluded that certain behavioral variations among groups of chimpanzees could only be called cultural. That is, they have the ability to pass on the results of observation and learning -- something that was believed to be a solely human attribute. Now a group of sleep investigators, led by Dr. Charles Czeisler at Harvard University, has published its finding that human circadian rhythm -- the internal clock that regulates sleep and waking -- does not, as was once believed, differ widely from the circadian rhythms of other animals.

title: An Exception To Banning Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching The Hearts Of Texans
description: MANAGED CARE and Government cost-cutting are forcing medical schools to retrench. But Kern Wildenthal can point out the window of his 11th-floor conference room here to the three medical research towers he has built over the last five years at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center -- and describe plans for three more. The buildings and programs they house reflect his talent for separating Texans from their millions.

title: If You Speed in Harrison, the Town Wins Big
description: OFFICER Dennis O'Keefe can usually estimate how fast a car is going before its speed has a chance to register on his radar gun.

description: Desperate to find talent in any corner of the earth, more than a dozen teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, had scouts in Costa Rica the past few days scrutinizing the latest catch from Cuba.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with the Portfolios, Etc., column, about possible effects of an increase in interest rates, misstated the history of the Federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks since March 1997, when it was raised to 5.5 percent. The rate has been lowered three times since then, to 4.75 percent; it has not been flat. A corrected chart is on page 8.

title: Little-Known Imprints Are a Bookstore's Entire Lexicon
description: On a recent Tuesday evening, Gary Hustwit sat at his desk in the Norfolk Street storefront between Delancey and Rivington Streets, where he sells arcane titles by little-known publishers. Signs taped to the wall read ''Buy Indie Books in Here'' and ''Dear Shoplifter, Please Go to Barnes & Noble.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUIRE, HELEN FRIEDMAN
description: SQUIRE-Helen Friedman. Beloved wife of the late Judge Sidney. Loving mother of Walter and Jason. Cherished mother-in-law of Dr. Sara Abramson. Devoted grandmother of Harrison, Russell, Zachary and Andrew. Services were held. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to DOROT, Inc., 171 W. 85 St., NY NY 10024.

title: Lives; 'I Never Thought I Was Going to Be a Part of Gay History'
description: What has happened to me since the riots? Well, I became a junkie for many years. And then I got off of junk and ended up hustling the streets again. (Even then I was working hard for the movement.) Then I moved to Westchester, and I ended up having lovely jobs in food service. My lover Frank and I bought a house. Unfortunately we went into crack and we lost it. That's how I ended up homeless. So I moved to a pier in the West Village.

title: Fugitive From Time
description: Anthony Lappe (May 23) calls Charles Hill a guest of the revolution in Cuba. Well, let's reframe this, shall we? Charles Hill is not a guest; he is an escapee from justice. Lost in the lament over Hill's future is the gloss over the lives that have been traumatized. Two police officers dead, another police officer and an F.B.I. agent injured and a planeful of passengers terrified. Also lost in the narrative was any sense of outrage at the criminal violence inflicted on innocent people as a result of Hill's behavior.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-27-99: Word & Image; Memoir of A Memoirist
description: There is life after a memoir, most immediately an education in the business of bookselling. Never mind the name of my book; this is not a sales pitch. It's a report on a writer's journey through the commercial jungle in which superstores daily devour independent family stores and the Web has now begun to chew up the chains.

title: Union Trying to Stop Presses at Printing Company
description: Their leaflets urge Sony to ''stop the baloney.'' And the members of Local 1-L of the Graphic Communications Workers of America who distribute them have become a regular presence outside the corporation's Madison Avenue headquarters and at local electronics retailers in recent months, urging passers-by to boycott Sony products.

She was predeceased by her husband of 60 years, Dr. Benjamin G. Lipton who died in 1986. Fay Lipton was the cherished mother of Alice Eckstein, June Kreisberg and Brian Lipton, mother-in-law of Gerald Kreisberg, Harry Eckstein and Lois Lipton, grandmother of Lee, Amy, Mark, Martine, Evan and Mia, great grandmother of Nicole, Kelsey and Daniel.

Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

Boiko was a history teacher at Francis Lewis High School in Fresh Meadows, NY and was Chairman of the History Department at the Francis Parker School in San Diego. Boiko played against Chico and Harpo Marx at the Barclay Bridge Club in Flushing. Memorials to the Albert Shanker Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Jeffrey Huart, United Federation of Teachers, 260 Park Ave So., NY NY 10010, attention: Bernard Boiko Memorial. www.bobko.com/bernie

It seems remarkably thorough. For English-speakers, I'm afraid, the choices are a bit frustrating.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Mercedes-Benz S500; The Next Big Thing
description: HUGE, heavy and haughty, bristling with technology under its slab-sided styling, the Mercedes-Benz S-Class has been a global symbol of power and success for princes and prime ministers, generals and godfathers, capitalists who have conquered markets and revolutionaries who have come to power.

title: Aid for Hospitals
description: Eight Westchester hospitals are among 91 in New York eligible for $250 million in aid obtained from the Federal Health Care Financing Administration. The money is the first installment in a five-year, $125 billion package known as the Community Health Care Conversion Demonstration Project to help hospitals complete the transition to managed care.

title: Caroline Gilman, John La Voie

The Rev. Joseph W. Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: How to Succeed In Art
description: Chris Burden began his career with a literal bang. His ''Shooting Piece'' required a friend to fire a bullet into his left arm from a distance of 15 feet. Perhaps that's why, when we recently met at the University of California at Los Angeles, I found it hard to imagine him patiently sitting through faculty meetings. Time does strange things. You wait long enough and even the most outrageous rebels end up grading papers and sharing career tips with students.

title: Making You Hear the Bumps In the Night
description: WHEN Hill House, the monstrous, lonely setting of Shirley Jackson's 1959 novel ''The Haunting of Hill House,'' greets its newest tenants, it is not with a welcome mat. ''Around them the house steadied and located them,'' Jackson wrote, ''and small eddies of air and sound and movement stirred and waited and whispered.'' A team of psychic investigators have come to test the mansion's reputation as a haven for supernatural phenomena, but it is they, not the ghosts, who are being measured. ''The Haunting,'' directed by Jan De Bont, is the second film adaptation of Jackson's novel (Robert Wise directed a 1963 version), and once again Hill House is meant to sound as frightening as it looks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

description: Weeks

description: THE DEPOSITION OF FATHER MCGREEVYBy Brian O'Doherty.Turtle Point/Books & Company/Helen Marx, $25.

title: CLINTON PLANNING TO CUT LONG-TERM COST OF MEDICARE
description: President Clinton will try to reconcile two seemingly contradictory goals next week when he unveils a plan to cut the long-term cost of Medicare while expanding the program to cover prescription drugs, Administration officials said today.

title: Blimey! New Yorkers To the Manners Born
description: IT was Robert Burns who noted what a remarkable gift it would be to see ourselves as others see us. As a Londoner who has just spent over a year living in New York but who is now safely back in England, I'm in a good position to bestow a gift of this nature on New Yorkers. With due warning, then, that something well meant but vaguely unpleasant is coming, I now have to deliver a huge blow to the pride New Yorkers take in being rude and feisty, and that is to tell you that in comparison to Londoners, you come across as exceptionally polite and extremely well behaved.

title: New Gray Market In China Loosens Grip on Publishing
description: In the cramped basement offices of the Alpha Book Company, metal desks are stacked with manuscripts and a large poster of a chimp in a red blazer headed ''The Boss'' dominates the room. Here, two 30-something editors, both with American graduate degrees, skirt a legion of rules and regulations in order to bring out surprisingly provocative books in a country where, officially, all publications are state owned and controlled.

title: From World's Radio Astronomers, a Simple Plea: Shhh!!!
description: Scientists studying the heavens have long been bothered by the more mundane activities of other earthlings. They have fled to remote mountaintops to escape the light of the cities. They have adjusted their radio instruments to cope with the growing avalanche of television towers, cell phones, pagers, microwave ovens, garage-door openers and the many other ground-based gadgets that emit radio waves.

title: Benjamin Harris, Hilary Grand
description: Hilary Morgenthau Grand, the daughter of Anne and Paul Grand of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married on Friday to Benjamin Heilbrun Harris, a son of Robie H. Harris and William W. Harris of Cambridge, Mass. Judge Pierre N. Leval of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York officiated at the summer home of the bride's parents in Chilmark, Mass.

description: DARN. I should have bought the troll. It was a marvelous little wood-and-straw concoction, a sure conversation piece. But I met up with it on the first stop of my whirlwind tour through Dobbs Ferry, at a church-basement rummage sale, and it was $8. Couldn't bust my budget. Had to pace myself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPERRY, ROBERTA
description: SPERRY-Roberta. Four years, you never leave our minds. Our love always. Mickey, Peter, Bonnie, Mackie and Ricki

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: To Cut Delays, I.N.S. Checks Cases by Hand
description: After falling further behind than ever in reducing the snarled backlog of citizenship cases, local immigration officials have forsaken their problematic computer system and begun processing 120,000 mislaid naturalization applications the old-fashioned way -- by hand.

title: Cristina Mariani, Marshall May
description: Cristina Neill Mariani, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Mariani of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married last evening to Marshall Dixon May, a son of the late Helen Payn May and George W. May Jr. The Rev. Alan E. Tilson performed the ceremony at the Anglican Church of the Holy Trinity in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda.

title: Cone Is in Command, And Yanks Remain Hot
description: The humidity here today made breathing feel as if you were leaning nose-first into the spray of a boiling tea kettle, and the Yankees' players reminded themselves to drink water and retreat to their air conditioned clubhouse whenever possible. About 90 minutes before today's game, however, David Cone flopped onto the dugout bench, legs splayed in front of him, as if he were happily relaxing at poolside.

title: Brecht's Company Finally Follows Him to America
description: A NAKED man crouches atop a glass case containing a whirring engine. His bare torso is painted white; his red tongue extends in a bestial snarl. Schubert's song ''Erlkonig'' plays in the background, replacing the recited polemics of Adolf Hitler that had filled the auditorium before the curtain rose. Hitler quotes and Nazi salutes may seem like strong stuff to American audiences, but in Germany, the critics complained that the production wasn't radical enough.

title: Getting Off Lightly On Notary Fraud
description: A brief article on June 13 reported that Norman Yellon, a process server accused of falsely notarizing documents, had been fined $795 and given 25 hours of community service after pleading guilty to disorderly conduct.

title: Ensnared in Logistics, U.N. Lags in Asserting Control

title: Stonewall Veterans Recall the Outlaw Days
description: THE Stonewall Inn, where a police raid in June 1969 sparked an uprising by a handful of drag queens and rabble-rousers and ushered in the modern gay rights movement, is by far the best known hangout from the days when being gay meant being a social outlaw. But Greenwich Village had other spots, too, where gay men and lesbians sought a modicum of safety and privacy. Many of these places have perished, as have many Stonewall veterans who frequented them. But a few remain.

title: Allison Weinberg And Jason Barro
description: Allison Dianne Weinberg, a daughter of Prof. Sharon Lawner Weinberg and Steven Weinberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Jason Russell Barro, a son of Judy Anne Barro and Prof. Robert J. Barro of Weston, Mass. Rabbi Kenneth Chasen officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZ, MARGARET
description: SALZ-Margaret. Died suddenly on June 20, 1999, Mrs. Salz was born in Berlin, Germany and was a longtime resident of Gramercy Park, New York City. She was a very special person. The twinkle in her eyes and the radiance of her smile were more brilliant than the jewelry she loved and worked with every day. She enriched many lives and although she did not make her 100th birthday, her spirit will stay with us all forever and ever. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Some Plants Leave Home to Get Respect
description: SOMETIMES the values of particular plants are not recognized until someone with keen knowledge can assess their value. This sort of cycle has happened to many of this country's native plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Using Needle and Thread to Tell a Story
description: A SHOW called ''The Storyteller's Art: Contemporary Embroidery'' at the Brookfield Craft Center is an invigorating meeting of imagination and discipline. The past several decades have seen a blurring of the lines between the fine arts and crafts, and the trend is accelerating.

title: Going From Trash to Treasure
description: If your eyesight is good enough to spot a dandelion on a suburban lawn, you should not have any trouble finding a yard sale in Westchester. They are everywhere, every weekend.

description: To the Editor:

title: Croquet, Anyone?
description: Same old story: Boy proposes to girl, girl loses her mind over registering. To give couples an easier system of gift registry, in March, S. Gregg Renfrew brought the London-based Wedding List Company to New York, at 29 East 73d Street. At the antiques-filled town house, couples sip champagne (or Diet Coke) and sift through Bernardaud china patterns and more eclectic items. A picnic basket backpack and croquet sets are the most popular items, Ms. Renfrew said, adding that she registers about 10 brides a week. The Wedding List will start a Web site this summer, where friends of the bride and groom can log on, type in a price range, and click on the item of choice, including exclusive bridal fashions like Jimmy Choo wedding shoes and embellished pashmina bridal shawls. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Boy Is Murdered, and State Passes a Tough Witness Law
description: THE murders of a woman and her young son in Bridgeport last January did more than shock the state for their cold-blooded cruelty. They also persuaded legislators to deal with the shortcomings of the state's witness-protection program, a haphazard system that virtually allowed individual police departments to do as they pleased.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, LILLIAN E. (BETTY)
description: CAMPBELL-Lillian E. (Betty). On June 24, 1999. Wife of the late Henry J. Campbell, Jr. Survived by Dr. Barbara A. Yonai and Nancy E. Chiesa. Donations can be made to the American Red Cross. Friends may visit Sunday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Rd., New Hyde Park, NY. Religious service at the funeral home Monday, 10 AM, with interment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: From Green Slime, Thus Grew Nickelodeon
description: Scientists believe that all life may have originated in some great prehistoric molecular stew. The same could be said of Nickelodeon, except that the medium wasn't primordial ooze: it was more like green slime.

description: 'Government should welcome the help of faith-based institutions,'' Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said in 1996. In April of this year, a spokesman for his brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, told The News and Record of Greensboro, N.C., ''The Governor supports faith-based initiatives.''

description: I am writing in response to the opinion piece by Rosalie Osias that appeared on June 20 [''Career Counseling for Amy Fisher''].

title: Strategies On Metering For Water
description: IN 1988, the New York City Department of Environmental Protection announced a program designed to change the way property owners would pay for water used in their buildings. Within 10 years, officials said, every residential building in the city would be required to have a water meter; owners would be billed according to the amount consumed, rather than by the ''frontage'' method, which was based primarily on building size.
