title: There's No Coverage for a Bad Review
description: AS acrobats twirled inches above the heads of the audience, Jolyon Stern saw countless potential disasters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONDARAS, ANASTASSIOS
description: FONDARAS-Anastassios. Died at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on June 24, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife Elizabeth; two daughters Kristina Fondaras Lamont of London and Antonia Fondaras of Washington D.C.; two sisters Anna Safilios and Fofi Trezos both of Athens; a niece Dina Safilios Rothschild; and six grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 28 at 12 noon at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St. and the burial will be in Athens, Greece. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Pasteur Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: A View From/Fairfield; Residents Question School Plan
description: SCHOOL districts around the state are wrestling with the issue of overcrowding and several have weighed whether to relieve the strain on their high schools by creating a separate school for 9th graders, sort of a yearlong air lock for freshmen to prepare them for the demanding environment of high school.

title: Refugees' Concert, Minus Refugees
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will play a July 4 pops concert at Fort Dix, after all. It just won't be for the Kosovar refugees it was originally planned for. When the deal was first hatched in May, there were 3,100 refugees at Fort Dix. The orchestra, eager to provide a special event, planned a concert and signed on the musicians.

title: Essay on Special Education Used False Premises
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing With Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: For Retailers in Some City Centers, Gentrification Is a Four-Letter Word
description: FOR 70 years, Hippodrome Hatters has sold handmade hats to fashion-conscious shoppers from a small store on North Eutaw Street on this city's West Side. Lou Boulmetis, who took over the business from his grandfather, has seen the area, once the center of Baltimore's retail trade, suffer through a long decline: the departure of old-line department stores, a rise in crime and the erosion of once-glorious retail facades.

title: Taking Children To Exotic Places
description: BEFORE I was married, in 1991, I traveled as much as I could in what was then called the Third World. My husband, Jinx, shared my fondness for these regions. We were determined that having children wouldn't slow us down, so after our first daughter, Allie, was born in 1992, we took a trial vacation to the Baja peninsula for a couple of weeks, albeit with a rented house as our base. When Allie was 18 months old, we departed for six months in Central America. Our second child, Katherine, was an infant when we took off for three years of combined work and vacation in Southeast Asia.

title: A Looming Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing Keeps Waiting For His Parade Float
description: THE first Knick to walk away from the celebrating San Antonio Spurs was the man who had not had an opportunity to stop them. Patrick Ewing came through the tunnel late Friday night at Madison Square Garden, a 7-footer many years in the habit of gazing upward to avoid eye contact in moments like these. Ewing turned right, strode stiffly down the hall and into the locker room, where he waited for the others to come and shake hands.

title: From High School to Real World; For Graduates Skipping College, the Future is Now
description: For most high school seniors, the months leading up to graduation mean decisions about where to go to college. But for Johana Santos, Anthony Rose, Angel Ramos, Michael Loza and Coreen Reid, all seniors at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx, the decisions they had to make were about what to do instead.

title: The World; Alive and Ailing in the Balkans
description: NEARLY a decade after the old Yugoslavia began to break up, President Clinton visited the thriving, peaceful land of Slovenia a week ago, followed quickly by a visit to bedraggled Albanian refugees waiting to return to Kosovo.

title: Leigh Berman, William Duvall
description: Leigh Anna Berman, a daughter of Donna and James Berman of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. William Lane Duvall, the son of Virginia and William H. Duvall of Richmond. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Colombia Adjusts Economic Figures to Include Its Drug Crops
description: Taking a step that is generating heated criticism in Washington, the Colombian Government has begun to include income earned from growing illegal drugs in the way it calculates the size of the nation's economy.

title: Bang Your Drum Loudly
description: YOUNG entrepreneurs know the rule: To get ahead, you have to be noticed. And once you discover how, you have to make every one of your 900 seconds of fame count.

title: Breathe Deeply: It's Time For Draft
description: Your class for the 1999 National Basketball Association draft (if they had stayed in school): Kevin Garnett, Shareef Abdur-Rahim, Vince Carter, Stephon Marbury, Ron Mercer, Paul Pierce and Jason Williams.

title: Melba Moore Traces Her Up-and-Down Journeys
description: THE glory days and bum times of Melba Moore can be tracked in headline speak.

title: Dana Colley, Andrew Corsello
description: The Rev. Dana Jeanne Colley and Andrew Kennard Corsello were married yesterday in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church in New York. Canon David W. Perry performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, MARCIA
description: SCHUMAN-Marcia. On June 25, 1999. Beloved wife of Bernard. Loving mother of Elinor and Robert. Adoring grandmother of Sonia and Jonathan. She will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 2:30pm at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, HORTENSE G.
description: FARRELL-Hortense G.. 96, of Jacksonville, FL and formerly a long time resident of Delray Beach, FL, passed away on June 22, 1999. Mrs. Farrell was a graduate of Manhattanville College and was past president of the alumni association. She is survived by sons, Thomas J. of Jacksonville, FL and Martin D. of Cave Creek, AZ. Daughters, Marianne Morgantini of Farmington, CT and Hortense (Bunny) Gorman of Riverdale, NY; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. She is predeceased by her husband, Thomas, in 1974. A funeral Mass will be celebrated on June 28 at St. Vincent Ferrer Church. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home

title: The Humbling of the Megastars
description: JULIA ROBERTS, in a television interview promoting her hit movie ''Notting Hill'' recently, said she could slip out of the house and go unrecognized at the market and the laundromat. The laundromat? When was the last time anyone making $20 million a film went to a laundromat? Let's not quibble about the details (even in cramped New York City, plenty of middle-class people have washers and dryers in their buildings). What matters is that Julia Roberts wants the public to think she goes to the laundromat, just like them.

title: A Culture of Trial, Despite Error
description: LOU L. PAI'S last assignment at Enron had all the hallmarks of a career maker.

title: Guides to Famous People And Family Fun
description: Vancouver, much like Seattle, its near-neighbor to the south, likes to boast that it is its nation's most tech-hip city. So it's no surprise that a prospective visitor to Canada's great western metropolis can find a ton of useful, interesting and quirky information about the city on the World Wide Web.

title: Q. & A.
description: Notifying The Super Of a Guest

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Backtalk; How Wimbledon Can Save Face and Save Money to Afford Equal Pay
description: Wimbledon has come up short. Even though it looks to the outside world that the greatest Grand Slam of them all is a pretty ritzy show -- with British royals in fancy hats, sterling silver trophies, and bows and curtsies at the presentation ceremonies -- it would seem, nevertheless, that swanky Wimbledon is over budget. How else do you explain that the women's champions and runners-up do not receive prize money equal to the men's?

title: So Many Choices, So Many Glitches
description: There are so many Web sites about London that it should be easy to find one that satisfies basic tourist needs: clear, concise information about where to stay, what to do and the like. But I tried three, and was beset with frustration at every turn. They were either too commercial, too sparse on information, or too full of glitches to make the cybertrip worthwhile.

title: A Bill Would Let Pets Be Remembered in Wills
description: Pet owners could rest in peace under a bill that would allow them to set up court-administered trusts to pay for the care and feeding of their dogs, cats or other animals.

title: Achoo!
description: THE POLLEN ROOMBy Zoe Jenny.Translated by Elizabeth Gaffney.143 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $20.

title: U.S. Is Said to Have Known Of China Spy Link in 1995
description: Senior White House officials were informed that China might have stolen American nuclear secrets nearly a year earlier than the Clinton Administration originally disclosed, according to current and former United States officials.

title: Elizabeth Abramowitz, Robert Stoll
description: Elizabeth Rose Abramowitz and Robert Samuel Stoll, students at Columbia University, are to be married today. Rabbi Toni Shy will perform the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

title: Teen-Ager's Death More Than 'Bad Luck'
description: In the article ''Driving Parents to Anxiety'' [June 20], one of the causes of traffic fatalities involving young drivers is described as ''bad luck.'' Dangerous intersections without traffic lights increase the chance of bad luck.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Plainsboro, Clustering for Conservation
description: A 255-ACRE former dairy farm in the west central portion of Plainsboro that was once the home of Elsie, the Borden cow, is being transformed into a single-family home community designed so half the site will be developed and the other half devoted to recreation and open space.

title: In the Latest Fray Over Access to the Internet, Three Los Angeles Commissioners Resign
description: The struggle between the nation's cable television operators and Internet service providers over high-speed access to cyberspace has roiled city politics in Los Angeles, where three political appointees have resigned in a debate on policy over the issue.

title: Eclipsed
description: If you can't get to the moon, Baikonur is not a bad approximation. The rocket range that bills itself as ''the Biggest Cosmodrome in the World'' is a bleak expanse of pitted flatlands, unbearably cold except when it is unbearably hot and impossibly remote.

title: For Sprewell and Duncan, There Is Life After Jordan
description: At the end of this five-month sprint, Latrell Sprewell had nowhere to go. Trapped underneath the basket with two seconds left, his man-to-man shootout with Tim Duncan would go down to the buzzer. He took one dribble away from trouble only to find more waiting for him on the left baseline, the awesome twin towers from San Antonio closing in on the Knicks' swingman the way the Spurs were closing in on a title.

title: Gored-Tex
description: ''Beware of enterprises that require new clothes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, IDA JOAN
description: HILL-Ida Joan. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY, on June 24, 1999. Survived by husband Harold T. Hill and daughter Marilyn E. Hill, both of Briarcliff Manor. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Theresa Church, Briarcliff Manor, Monday, 10 AM. Interment Rose Hill Cemetery. Contributions to Phelps Hospital Hospice appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Sandra Wertheimer and Jeremy Primer misstated the former position of the mother of the bridegroom, Dr. Blossom Primer, in English and women's studies at Rutgers University. She retired as an adjunct instructor, not a professor.

title: A Congressman Feeds Off His Novel
description: Every politician is a relentless self-salesman every day in this city, re-glossing the product even as it frays in the cutthroat marketplace of candidacy. Which is why Representative Peter T. King had a certain merry smile this week when he returned to the House floor fresh from a high-profile radio interview about his latest entry in the political hopper: a novel, not a bill.

title: Longer Lives With AIDS Mean Facing New Worries
description: WHEN Lisa Landi was diagnosed with full-blown AIDS in 1991, she weighed 80 pounds and was not expected to live. Today, thanks to protease inhibitor drugs, Ms. Landi, 33, is healthy enough to work part time, and to have other concerns -- like what to do now that her company has gone out of business.

title: Listening to the Shouting About Shooting
description: On a Friday night at the Cook County Medical Center in Chicago, ''the knife and gun club'' is in session in the trauma unit. That evening, six shooting victims, several of them teen-age gang members, will arrive for treatment. One boy has been shot in the back. He saw no one, or so he tells investigating officers. Later they display the lettering on his jacket, ''Insane Cullerton Deuces,'' and predict the matter will be settled on the street, most likely with another shooting.

title: On Politics; Roukema Doesn't Hesitate To Take Shots at Her Party
description: ''I'm worried how this is going to look,'' Representative Marge Roukema was saying to a reporter the other day, standing in front of her big desk with its panoramic view of a sun-draped Capitol dome. ''I'm afraid I'll look like I'm down on my party.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPPING, IRA
description: TOPPING-Ira. Beloved husband of Gloria (Karlin-Newell). Proud father of Stephen (Debra) and Peter. Devoted brother of David (Diane). Loving grandfather of Lindsay, Jason, Carson and Michael. Stepfather of Robert Newell, Shelley Fishman and Laurie Sparks (Harry), and step-grandfather of Melanie Fishman, Jackie and Emily Sparks.

title: Generous Portions to Fuel Travelers on I-95
description: SAYBROOK Fish House in Old Saybrook has been around a long time, but continues to offer fresh seafood with great consistency in a low-key setting at affordable prices.

title: Checking the Doctor Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk Bond Upgrade; Nassau Rating Teeters
description: As Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta tries to close a two-year budget gap projected at $300 million, Suffolk County has received a favorable report from a bond rating agency that calls the county's financial outlook stable.

title: The World; Coca-Cola Hopes Things Go Better With 'Sorry'
description: UNLIKE love, being in business sometimes means having to say you're sorry. Last week, the chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company issued one of the more elaborate public apologies by an American business leader. In newspaper ads in Belgium Tuesday that followed an outright ban on the company's products after reports of people becoming sick, M. Douglas Ivester said ''I'm sorry'' or ''we regret'' or ''I apologize'' five times.

title: 'Once Upon a Number'
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Alicja Barahona; 29 Hours 55 Minutes To Run the Sahara
description: ALICJA BARAHONA is one of those people who does not give up without trying once she makes up her mind to push herself to do something. So while her friends may have thought she was a little crazy, Mrs. Barahona, a resident of Greenburgh, last April journeyed to Morocco where she competed in the Marathon des Sables, a 140-mile running race lasting six days in the Sahara.

title: Jersey City Fire Creates A Spectacle From Afar
description: A huge, smoky fire in Jersey City broke out last night in a vacant wax factory, drawing onlookers from the nearby New Jersey Turnpike and prompting alarmed phone calls from Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: Press Aide For Campaign Is Appointed By First Lady
description: On the verge of starting a summer of nearly nonstop travel across New York State, Hillary Rodham Clinton announced yesterday that she had hired a press secretary for her Senate exploratory committee. It is her first high-profile campaign appointment and a clear sign that Mrs. Clinton is shifting her attention from being First Lady to laying the foundation for a prospective Senate race.

title: An Open Mind on Interest Rates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerith McElroy, Mark Freidberg
description: Kerith Moonan McElroy, a daughter of Rosemary McElroy of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and the late John Joseph McElroy, was married at her mother's house last evening to Mark Howard Freidberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeffrey P. Freidberg of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. Sharon Bledsoe, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, in which Rabbi Ari Fridkis took part.

title: On the Road to 2000
description: Urban or rural, Southern Hemisphere or Arctic Circle: Those are some of the choices for would-be travelers planning to greet the year 2000 away from home. Following is a sampling of the packages and tours available. Prices are per person, double occupancy, unless otherwise noted; prospective travelers should be aware that deposit and refund policies can be strict.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-27-99; Poolside Polemics
description: Bill Clinton is into his seventh year as President of the United States. He cannot be re-elected to that office, and he is not likely to run for another one. His impeachment and trial were carried out by people who, whatever their other shortcomings, cannot be accused of understating the case; but his acquittal was greeted with loud public approval. No one is going to try that again. And anyway, what would be the point? Clinton is the lamest of lame ducks. But there are currently three books about what a creep he is on the New York Times nonfiction best-seller list. One of those books (''Betrayal,'' by Bill Gertz) is from a right-wing publisher (Regnery), one (''No One Left to Lie To,'' by Christopher Hitchens) is from a left-wing publisher (Verso) and one (''All Too Human,'' by George Stephanopoulos) is from a publisher

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a woman's portrait painted on a wall above Simone, an East Village restaurant, misstated the location. Simone is at the corner of First Avenue (not First Street) and St. Marks Place.

title: A Country Now Ready to Listen
description: LATE one night a few years ago, Robert Ferris Thompson, who as a professor of African and African-American Arts at Yale University is considered the dean of African studies in the New World, was at S.O.B.'s, the Manhattan club whose name stands for Sounds of Brazil. He was standing next to an English rock critic. ''What am I doing in this white skin?'' the critic asked in a moment of self-doubt.

title: Keeping Up With Jones Beach; A City on the Sand for 8 Million, Silicone Singles to Kite Flyers
description: THERE are more than 1,200 miles of shore on Long Island, but for millions of people who come here to frolic in the sand and surf there is only one beach.

title: Old (Becker) and New (Stevenson) Usher Wimbledon Into Week 2
description: Boris Becker's Wimbledon swan song is showing signs of becoming an aria. The 31-year-old German, a decade removed from the last of his three Wimbledon championships, continued to turn back the clock and take control of Center Court like a playground bully. And it's not just his adoring fans, a legion of flag-waving, face-painted zealots; his opponents seem caught up in the spell as well.

title: Elizabeth Cotter, Michael Schlax
description: Elizabeth Anne Cotter and Michael Patrick Schlax were married last evening at the Jette Gallery of the Colby College Museum of Art in Waterville, Me. Judge Morton A. Brody of the United States Court of Appeals for the Main District, in Bangor, officiated.

title: Beijing Overturns a Hong Kong Court Ruling on the Residency Status of Immigrants
description: In a move that has profound implications for Hong Kong's legal system, China today overturned, in effect, a local court ruling that granted residency here to more than a million people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, GERALD (JERRY)
description: SCHWARTZ-Gerald (Jerry)., 94, a long-time resident of Miami Beach, moving from Great Neck, NY. Passed away at home on June 23, 1999. Widower of Sarah, he is survived by children Dr. Robert Schwartz, Pittsfield, MA; Marcia (Dr. Jason) Zellner, Coconut Grove, FL; Linda (Joel) Negrin, Mamaroneck, NY; Alice (James) Levenson, Scarsdale, NY; 11 grandchildren; four great grandchildren. He was an avid golfer and traveler. Originally in the textile dyeing and finishing business, he went on to build nursing homes and was builder of the Woodcrest Club in Syosset, NY and the Canyon Club in Armonk, NY. Contributions in his name may be made to St. Vitas Hospice or the charity of your choice. Services were held in Florida.

title: Justine Wruble, Peter Fahey Jr.
description: Justine Danielle Wruble, a daughter of Judith Dalton of Winchester, Mass., and Bernhardt Wruble of Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to Peter Matthew Fahey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fahey of Sands Point, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Hildene, the Robert Todd Lincoln house in Manchester, Vt.

title: Spurs Fever
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Balancing Act in a Wheelchair
description: I THINK this must be paradise. A hundred-year-old villa, whitewashed stucco and a red roof, up on a hilltop overlooking vineyards and sunflowers and cypress trees, the dusty vistas of Tuscany in August. The house has a big kitchen with a vaulted brick ceiling, a spiral stone staircase and an ivy-covered outbuilding where we hang our laundry, which, when dry, is stiff as cardboard but smells like the sun.

title: Family Ties
description: THE VIEW FROM ALGER'S WINDOWA Son's Memoir.By Tony Hiss.Illustrated. 241 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Finally, State Will Test Firefighter Applicants
description: For the first time in nearly 20 years, the New Jersey Department of Personnel will give a statewide Civil Service exam to applicants for jobs as firefighters.

title: Barbara Sibert, Mark Vonnegut
description: Barbara Maria Sibert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Sibert of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Vonnegut, the son of Kurt Vonnegut of New York and the late Jane Cox Vonnegut. The Rev. Cynthia A. Good, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in Harrison Otis Apthorp Memorial Chapel at Milton Academy in Milton, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: ON MY... BOOKMARKS; WILLIAM E. KENNARD
description: For all of the private-sector millionaires being created by the Internet revolution, no one wields more power in the world of communications today than William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE DISAPPEARANCE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 13 about community school board elections misstated the procedure. Voters may rank as many candidates as they wish. Nine is not the limit, but is the number of seats to be filled in each district.

title: Rules Regulating Oil Industry Are Mired in Debate on Ethics
description: After Mobil Oil settled a lawsuit last year charging that it had underpaid the Government for drilling rights, one of the public interest groups that filed the suit shared its award with two Federal employees who had long complained about oil company royalty payments.

title: Into the Unknown
description: How odd that, in Richard Ford's torment over the secret he dared not name to his rivermate Stanley Crouch during their raft voyage, he utterly ignored the literary and historical irony of his plight. The novel that serves as pretext for this current dialogue between a black man and a white man is famous, if not infamous, for the way the idyllic friendship between Huck and Jim is laced with the casual racism in Huck's vernacular speech and his pervasive use of the ''N'' word. Huck's speech, offensive even in its own day, enables Twain to critique the kind of social and moral confusion that Ford struggles with today. So what has changed?

title: Police Say Killer Had Help
description: WHEN Josephine Lee, a witness against two brothers charged with killing a Bridgeport mother and her young son earlier this year, was sentenced late last month in Federal court on a drug charge, the proceeding was completed with remarkable haste, an indication of how sensitive the murder case has made law enforcement officials to the protection of witnesses.

title: Workhorse Utilities Get Another Look
description: THE world is often a strange place, but the marketplace is supposed to be rational.

title: Batter Up
description: Molly O'Neill's Food column (May 30) on Ted Williams and his culinary ideas was a pleasure to read (and reread). It gave those of us who think so much of the man some additional insight into his thought processes. Great!

title: Lisa Solomon, Gabriel Pivawer
description: Lisa Margaret Solomon and Gabriel Pivawer are to be married this evening by Rabbi David Gelfand at the Essex House in New York.

title: Tale of Two Lost Souls Finding One Another
description: ''YOUR money or your life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINDQUIST, CAROL SIMON
description: KINDQUIST-Carol Simon. Died June 4, 1999 in Gunnison, Colorado at the age of 83. She is the daughter of Robert E. Simon, Sr. and Elsa Weil Simon, sister of Elizabeth Fox of Ithaca, NY, the late Helen Steinberg of Riverdale, NY and Robert E. Simon, Jr. of Reston, VA, mother of David E. Kindquist of Berlin, MD, Elspeth K. Kelsey of Foxboro, MA and Cathy E. Kindquist of Gunnison, CO and grandmother of Christopher, Jason and Jeremy. A devoted and beloved mother, sister, aunt, grandmother and friend, she will be sorely missed.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about high school graduates misidentified the organization that gave an award to Luis Ortiz. It was Student Advocacy of Elmsford, not the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LILLIAN
description: ROSNER-Lillian. A lovely and lovable mother to her children and son-in-law, adored sister and aunt. Always thoughtful, brave, selfless in her actions, and delightful in company. Hard to imagine someone who could be missed more than Lillian. Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., Sunday, June 27th, 12 noon.

title: Self-Promotion, Made Easier
description: Q. Some years ago, I left the corporate world to start my own public relations firm. Most of my work involves writing and media relations. I love what I do, but since my divorce two years ago, I've had trouble making ends meet. My clients seem happy, but I obviously need to do a better job of attracting new business. Any advice?

title: The Dictator's Cut
description: SERGEI EISENSTEIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, DONALD E.
description: MEAD-Donald E.. On June 14, 1999. Born in Peking 1921, he attended schools in Shanghai and most happily, the Kuling American School in China. After graduating from Cornell and war-time service in the Navy, he spent the next thirty plus years in the Far East, primarily Manila, where he represented Standard Vacuum Oil Company and Lubrizol Corp. Retired Upper Saddle River, he was an enthusiastic sportsman, avid tennis player, and member of the Ambulance Corps. Survived by his wife, Cynthia, and children, Jennifer Mead Sullivan of New York City, Elaine Alexander of Ithaca, NY and Donald E. Jr. of Brooklyn, NY. He leaves five grandchildren, Christina, Kathleen, Nicholas and Zachary Alexander and Sarah Sullivan. Burial private. Donations may be made to Upper Saddle River Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Saddle River, NJ 07458. In his memory a celebratory party will be held later.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Crime Issue Pays in Crucial Governor's Race in Mexico
description: One week before gubernatorial elections in Mexico's most populous state, several opinion polls indicate that Arturo Montiel, the candidate of Mexico's governing party, has a modest lead over his rivals in a race considered the final testing ground before a presidential vote next year.

title: Sports of The Times; Captain Is Gentle, But Tough Enough
description: HE'S known as Gentle Ben, and he is. That's why some people are wondering if Ben Crenshaw is too nice to be the Ryder Cup captain. He disagrees.

title: Jennifer Marvel, Steven Spear
description: Jennifer Vanderhoef Marvel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvel of Watch Hill, R.I., was married there yesterday to Steven Dyke Spear, the son of Dr. JoAnn Palmer and H. Dyke N. Spear Jr., both of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Mark K. J. Robinson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: Into the Unknown
description: Poor Stanley Crouch. While he gushed about finally feeling like one of the (white) guys, Richard Ford was holding out on him -- big time (''In the Same Boat'' and ''Black Like Huck,'' June 6). Ford spent the boat trip agonizing over whether to confess to Crouch that he, Ford, used racist language way back in the 1980's. The purpose of the trip, after all, was to wrestle with the knotty issues of race while replicating Huck and Jim's Mississippi raft journey. Ford chose to remain mum because of his ''fear of being cartoonishly, publicly oversimplified, at being turned into a man whose worth and character were judged only by race, a man seen only incompletely, no longer free to be however good I might be.''

title: Real Furnishings For Imaginary Flowers
description: Amaran is a new store in the East Village selling rare and antique furniture. The name comes from ''amaranth,'' one of whose meanings is an imaginary flower that never dies. The owners, Sonia Gomez and Ivan Tonkin, liked the definition but not the ''th.''

title: June 20-26; Salinger Letters Are Sold
description: Joyce Maynard, the tell-all journalist who once had a romance with the obsessively private author J. D. Salinger, put 14 of his letters up for sale at Sotheby's. She had already been criticized for publishing a memoir about the author.

title: Lose That Plumber Look And Bulk Up, Beautiful
description: From the Desk of Giancarlo LaMans, Director,

title: World Premiere For a Piano Quartet
description: THE opening event of this year's Norfolk Chamber Music Festival is this afternoon at 3 when the Turgeon Piano Duo offers Saint-Saens's ''Carnival of the Animals.'' The program also lists Milhaud's ''Scaramouche'' and Bizet's ''Children's Games.''

title: Exploring the Shifts and Styles of Marsden Hartley
description: ''Marsden Hartley: American Modern''

title: The Nation; More Power Was Supposed To Grease These Skids
description: WITH its preference for crossfire over consensus, harangues over handshakes, the New York Legislature has long engaged in an us-versus-them tribalism that influences everything -- from the favors it bestows on constituents to the allocation of water coolers in the Statehouse. Now, though, the coarse political customs here have become so entrenched that state leaders have been all but unable to perform their most fundamental duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMEZANO, HY
description: GORMEZANO-Hy. The officers and staff of Hadco Aluminum and Metal Corp regret the passing of their President Hy Gormezano. Services Sunday, June 27th 1PM Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Left-Hander Stands Out This Time for Fine Play
description: Steve Flesch is one of the few left-handers on the PGA Tour, but today he stood out because of his fine play.

title: Cracks in Alliance to Fight Higher Rents
description: When tenants of the Cooper Gramercy, a high-rise at East 23d Street and Second Avenue, learned last year that the building's rents would no longer be regulated and could double or even triple, they drew together in shock and disbelief.

title: Undemocratic Elections
description: It is election season abroad. In the past few weeks, voters in eight nations have chosen parliaments or presidents. In several cases -- Israel, Nepal, Slovakia, South Africa -- citizens enthusiastically participated in a democratic choice of new leaders. In other places like Indonesia and Nigeria, elections marked a step toward democracy but were not completely fair. In Togo and Malawi, they were openly fraudulent. As the world is increasingly discovering, not all elections are equal, and some merely create the illusion of democracy.

title: Witness Protection
description: I COULD TELL YOU STORIES

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about museum expansions in Chicago misidentified the architect of an addition to the Shedd Aquarium. The lead architect was the firm of Esherick Homsey Dodge & Davis. Ralph Johnson of Perkins & Will was the associate architect.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for RAY GOLDBERG; Under the Food Scares, A Credibility Problem
description: MAD COW disease. Dioxin contamination. Now, a scare over Coca-Cola. Shoppers in Europe might be forgiven for hesitating before even setting foot in a grocery store.

title: Poetic Ability Desirable but Not Essential
description: How many Americans know they have a poet laureate? Or can name him? Starting in 1937 there was a Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress; then, in 1986, a formal laureateship was created, with Robert Penn Warren the first appointee. The term was originally for a year, and then became renewable. There have been eight laureates since Penn Warren, including Mark Strand, Joseph Brodsky and Rita Dove; the incumbent, Robert Pinsky, has just been confirmed for a third term, a record.

title: Millions in Property Tax Relief, but Critics, Too
description: AFTER decades of Long Island's groaning under one of the nation's heaviest local tax burdens, nearly 600,000 homeowners have signed up for a program that will shrink their collective tax bills by about $500 million a year.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 27, 1999
description: Weeks

description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Camp Followers
description: Say what you will about minimalism, but in the context of trailer living, less is definitely more.

title: Liberties; Beach Blanket Lingo
description: There must have been something interesting in that Clinton yakathon. But every time the President was asked at his Friday press conference why he is so polarizing, whether he is responsible for coarsening the culture or if it bugs him to be trashed by his Vice President, he vanished into a nattering nimbus of positivism.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BEDFORD PARK

title: June 20-26; Senate Backs U.N. Payment
description: The United States took a big step toward paying nearly $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations. The Senate voted 98 to 1 to pay the arrears in exchange for a reduction in the overall American contribution to the United Nations from 25 percent to 20 percent of its budget.

title: A South African Diamond
description: If the bad news is that South African producers, in lock step with overseas counterparts, are rushing headlong into chardonnay, a white that mostly runs the gamut of A to B, the good news is that chenin blanc has sprung up as the country's most promising white.

title: OPINION; Taxes and Garbage as Partners
description: TAXES and garbage: what do these two irritating issues have in common? The less you pay of one, the more you have of the other.

title: Steep Learning Curve
description: It's called Teaneck, so the place ought to have its own tea, right? That's the logic used by Roseanne Ponchick, who uses the subject of tea to expose her second graders at Whittier School in Teaneck to history, geography and, mainly, math. About 10 years ago she decided to illustrate big numbers by collecting a million tags from tea bags. Since then, her classes have gone way over the mark and are approaching a billion. In the process of soliciting tags, she talked to John Harney, president of Harney & Sons Tea Company, in Salisbury, Conn., who found Miss Ponchick's logic compelling and offered to produce a Teaneck Tea. The mango-flavored brew has been available for more than five years now, and profits from sales have bought 315 books for the school so far. Miss Ponchick is still collecting tags, which can be sent to her at Whittier School, 491 West Englewood Avenue, Teaneck 07666. The tea, $5 for 24 bags, is available from the Harney company, (800) 732-8463. We suggest drinking it in a Glassboro glass and serving it with a Cranbury muffin.

title: Mystery on the Saltwater Flats
description: David Blinken stood high above the water line in Napeague Bay, on the poling platform rising above the outboard engine of his 20-foot flats skiff. Balancing himself with a 20-foot-long black pole, he raced his thick legs as a mild swell rolled the boat, causing the platform -- a panel of white fiberglass hardly larger than your typical bathmat -- to tilt. It was a stunt worthy of a circus, and I imagined that Blinken was a 1,000-pound baby elephant, dressed in a pink tutu. Blinken's excited voice quickly dispelled the fantasy.

title: Thea Rhodes, Eugene Dolan Jr.
description: Thea Avery Rhodes and Eugene Patrick Dolan Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Charles Cesaretti at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J.

description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

Weber of Ocala, Fla., and Dr. Weber of New York. The Rev. Whitney H. Burr performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham.

description: ROSNER-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Leon, died peacefully at home on June 26, 1999. Beloved sister of Clarence Seid, and sisterin-law Florence; aunt to Jane and Carol; great-aunt to Susan and Mark; great-great-aunt to Jeri, Brian, Evan and Allison.

title: Peter Abeles, 75, a Leader In Australia's Business World
description: Peter Abeles, a Hungarian who fled to Australia after World War II and as a transport executive became one of his adopted country's most powerful business leaders, died on Friday at his home in Sydney. He was 75.

title: Frightening Echo in Tales Of Two in Subway Attacks
description: On the crowded Manhattan subway platform that evening, everything happened too fast, witnesses told the police.

title: Tough Year Is Projected For Farms Of Russia
description: A blisteringly hot summer and the reverberations from Russia's economic crisis have taken a devastating toll on the nation's crops, making it likely that Moscow will appeal for American food aid, according to Russian and American officials.

title: Paying for Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Free Pills for Geezers?
description: ''Free milk for babies'' was the battle cry of social reformers a century ago. Today the bumper sticker of those pressing for inclusion of prescription drugs in Medicare might read ''Free Pills for Geezers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, LEON
description: PEARL-Leon. Son of Benzion and Helen Pearl. Husband of Roslyn for 46 years; father of Janet, Barry, Kenneth and Carl; grandfather of Seth and Stephen; Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Hofstra University, died on June 26, at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY. He was 77. Dr. Pearl was born in Poland, served in the U.S. Armed Forces in World War II, and held the Ph.D. in Philosophy from New York University and the J.D. from Hofstra Law School. He joined the Hofstra Philosophy Department in 1960, serving as Chair from 1989 to 1992. He authored two books, ''Four Philosophical Problems,'' and ''Descartes,'' as well as numerous articles in prestigious journals. He will be missed by family, friends and colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: A Memorable Run
description: The laws of basketball finally caught up with the New York Knicks Friday night, when their thrilling and improbable run at the National Basketball Association championship ended in a 78-77 loss to the San Antonio Spurs. They were too short and too banged up to compete against a taller, healthier ball club that genuinely deserved the title. Yet when the Knicks were finally done, when Latrell Sprewell missed a last-second, off-balance jump shot, the crowd at Madison Square Garden gave them a winners' ovation. They deserved it. Despite crippling injuries, the Knicks somehow contrived to defeat three favored teams in the playoffs and give an honorable account of themselves in the finals.

description: It was not a threat, said Wardah Hafidz, one of Indonesia's toughest social activists; it was a simple statement of the country's new balance of power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSMAN, LEON
description: GLASSMAN-Leon. On Friday, June 18, 1999. Of Manhattan, NY, formerly of Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of the late Irene (nee Starr). Caring brother of Dr. Samuel Glassman. Loving uncle to Jeffrey Lavikoff, Nancy LavikoffBurr, Janice Glassman-Curnick and Joan Glassman-Kaye. He served in the Army during WW II and did tours of duty in Africa and Europe. He was an avid stamp and rare coin collector. Graveside services 2 PM, on Monday, June 28, 1999, at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. For information, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd, Union, NJ.

Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 28 at 12 noon at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St. and the burial will be in Athens, Greece. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Pasteur Foundation.

description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Morocco's King Loosens His Grip, and Holds On
description: As King Hassan II approached a royal gala in El Badiaa palace here recently, huge studded doors swung open, guards in flowing white robes and red fezzes snapped to attention, and guests erupted in resounding hurrahs: ''Long live His Majesty the King!''

title: Asbestos Cases In for Overhaul By Lawmakers
description: After the Supreme Court threw up its hands in exasperation last week, Congress is preparing to begin debate on Thursday on a measure that would overhaul the way the legal system resolves lawsuits brought by people harmed by asbestos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: In Ulster, Hints of a Shift to Save Peace Effort
description: David Trimble, the First Minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, said today that the stalled peace effort in Ulster could be saved by a simple statement from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, that the I.R.A. is committed to disarming by May 2000.

title: Patents; A Supreme Court decision leaves many innovators disgusted, angry and outraged.
description: LAST week's Supreme Court decision granting states immunity from patent infringement cast a pall over what might be called the innovation community, summed up in the melancholy grumblings of a Chicago patent lawyer, Peter Tryzna, who declared that Wednesday was ''not a good day for innovators in America, but it's a great day for thieves.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

Cherished grandfather of Nicholas and Andrea Pezzillo, Lily Blackwell and Casey Labatt-Simon. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, June 28, 7-9 PM. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Man Charged as Robber Of Novelty Shops
description: A man was arrested yesterday and charged with carrying out a string of robberies at novelty shops and antique stores in Manhattan, each time clad in a pinstripe suit and pink suede shoes, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; United States Has a Plan: Don't Play It Safe
description: THE women don't do scoreless ties. This was important enough for Tony DiCicco to bring it up at halftime last night, with the North Koreans suppressing the Americans' normal vitality.

title: Point, Counterpoint in the Microsoft Trial
description: The last of 26 witnesses stepped from the stand last week in the Microsoft antitrust trial. They were the human voices in a case brimming with other evidence -- videotapes and transcripts from hundreds of people, and thousands of E-mail and other documents running to more than two million pages.

description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. title: Media Talk; Report on Television, Rebuttal on the Web
description: The concept of letters to the editor has new meaning on the Internet, where E-mail reactions can fly back and forth almost instantly. Now CBS News has added another twist, posting a lengthy list of objections from the subject of one of its investigative reports on Cbsnews.com, the news division's World Wide Web site.

title: 30 Years After Stonewall, Diversity Is Shown in Gay Pride Parade
description: Firefighter Tom Ryan walked soberly down Fifth Avenue yesterday, the Fire Commissioner at his side, the Mayor a few feet ahead, and a gyrating, feather-bedecked moving carnival of gay Brazilians behind.

title: PRO FOOTBALL; Phillips's European Vacation Is Over
description: The Frankfurt Galaxy defeated the Barcelona Dragons to capture World Bowl '99 today by 38-24, ending the N.F.L. Europe season while setting the stage for Lawrence Phillips's return to the National Football League.

description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Charm and Boisterous Rock-and-Roll
description: Perhaps the highlight of the Guinness Fleadh on Saturday on Randalls Island came at midday on one of the festival's smaller stages. There, backed only by an acoustic guitar, Tommy Makem bellowed a stentorian ''Four Green Fields,'' the hallowed Irish leave-us-alone-with-our-beauty ballad he wrote in 1967, as the audience members pumped their hands in the air and sang in spellbound unison. Shortly afterward came the festival's low point: on the main stage, Hootie and the Blowfish -- the very name may evoke a desire to yawn and move on to the next article -- took ''Black Magic Woman'' on a journey that was too long, too bumpy and had no destination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD - Eileen. Treasured wife of Herbert, after a long and devastating illness slipped away on June 24, 1999 just four days after our 65th wedding anniversary. She was the mother of Migs Woodside and Lewis W. Bernard, grandmother of Geoffrey, Debbie, Adam and Claire. Great-grandmother of Rebecca and Emily. Eileen was a Leo, and lion-hearted in her more than 60 year struggle with an ever painful and threatening eye problem. She had a passion for Old Master Drawings, British antique yellow porcelain, Battersea and Bilston enamels, Regency furniture and visiting Trust Houses. She was a member of the drawing committee at CooperHewitt Museum, a trustee at AllenStevenson School, a Vice-President of Playschools Association, and a Vice-President of the Jewish Welfare Board during the war years, and worked as a USO hostess at the Emanu-El canteen. She was a member of the Board of Directors of Womens' Division of Federation and the American Jewish Committee. She was devoted to ballet, good music, opera, travel, stimulating lectures, museums, and hostessing, with great flair, happy parties at our 911 Penthouse. Eileen was a wonderful daughter, concerned mother, and anyone who knew her and worked with her realized how inspiring she was and always gave of herself to the utmost. Contributions in her memory to the Museum Acquisitions Fund of Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65 St, NY, 10021 would be appreciated by her family. Good night ''Blithe Spirit'', sleep well, ''Fairest of the Fair''. You deserve it. Herbert

title: Croatia's President Polishes a National Myth
description: For a leader whose small Balkan state is months behind in pension payments, cannot save banks from collapse or stem mounting discontent, Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, is rather preoccupied with national myth.

title: Realistic Rules on Computer Exports
description: There are good reasons for restricting American exports of high-performance computers to countries that might put them to dangerous military use. Computing power is increasingly vital to the production of advanced nuclear and conventional weapons and missiles. Last month's Cox Committee report details the potential dangers to national security from overly permissive computer export rules.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PHELAN, ARNOLD H.
description: PHELAN-Arnold H. 7/9/39-6/28/89. Your spirit, energy, love, honor, generosity and outrageousness are with us daily. We miss you. Terry, Jackie, Becca and Judy

title: Anastassios Fondaras, 81, Admiral Who Became an Investment Banker
description: Anastassios Fondaras, who went from a career in the Royal Greek Navy and later in Greece's private shipping industry to international investment banking, died on Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York. He was 81.

title: Deal-Making Adds the Spice to a Cajun Senator's Career
description: SENATOR JOHN BREAUX of Louisiana smells some action, some movement, maybe, down the road, the possibility of a deal. This makes Mr. Breaux a happy man, because he loves making deals.

title: A Quieter New Yorker; Under New Editor, Less Buzz, Less Lunch. But Will It Work?
description: David Remnick -- the editor of The New Yorker magazine and Pulitzer Prize winning author -- wanted to talk to a reporter over breakfast. But where? Mr. Remnick, a self-scrutinizing former newspaper reporter who understands the art of the dramatic setup, had doubts about the message his chosen venue would send.

title: Friday Harbor Journal; Serenading the Whales (Who Seem to Like It)
description: If you think about it from the whales' point of view, said Fred West, ''mostly what they get from us is a lot of engine noise. And that's certainly not the best human beings have to offer.''

title: Media Talk; High Hopes for an Old Book in a New Cover
description: With the shelf life for most new books only months, can a publisher right a marketing mistake three years after publication by reissuing a book with a new cover, a new title and an angle linking it to a best seller?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Shig Kariya, 84, China Importer Who Helped Found Mikasa Inc.
description: Shig Kariya, one of the founders of Mikasa Inc., the big tableware company, died on Friday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: An Album Recycled In Homage to Miles Davis
description: You like jazz? Then you love Miles Davis's ''Kind of Blue'' -- of course you do. So what could possibly be wrong with this picture: a supergroup sextet of contemporary musicians who don't normally play together, each one with a connection, stylistic or otherwise, to a player on the 1959 record, performing all of its tracks one evening during the JVC Jazz Festival?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IRVING E.
description: GOLDBERG-Irving E. On June 27, 1999. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Services 3 PM, on June 30, 1999, at Roosevelt Cemetery, Roosevelt, NJ.

title: A Different Breed of Saturn
description: The car company that grew up by pretending it did not know its parent company, the General Motors Corporation, is starting a family of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, CATHERINE (KITTY)
description: REILLY-Catherine (Kitty). On June 27, 1999, of Garden City. Loving wife of the late James J. Reilly. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Jim & Molly, Daniel & Lita, Christopher & Alison and the late Thomas Reilly. Cherished grandmother of nine and sister of Eleanor. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St., Garden City, Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, Wednesday, 10:45 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021, in Catherine's name appreciated.

title: Serbs Free 166 Albanians, Ending Families' Anguish
description: Milazim Kelmendi walked through the gate of his house on Saturday and took his family completely by surprise. They had last seen him on May 7 when he and dozens of other men were taken away by the Serbian police, and were convinced that he was dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDE, DANIEL F., SR.
description: GARDE-Daniel F., Sr. (Retired, Federal Bureau of Investigation.) On June 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary A. (nee Callahan). Devoted father of Daniel F., Jr., James C., Mary E. Meeks, Anne and Lawrence J. Garde. Father-in-law of Kathy Garde and Jack Meeks. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Fond brother of Henriette Loehfelm. Funeral from The ''McManus Funeral Home,'' 2001 Flatbush Ave, Wednesday, 10:15. Funeral Mass 11 AM, at Our Lady Help of Christians Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Monday 7-9, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9. Dan set an example of fidelity, bravery, integrity and love during 60 years of marriage and 50 years of service to the FBI family. We love you, Dad.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Offenbach: A Silly Plot Made Bright
description: One has to admire Yves Abel's devotion to L'Opera Francais de New York, the company that he started in 1988 and that offered a magnificent, spirited staging of Offenbach's ''Grande-Duchesse de Gerolstein'' at the Kaye Playhouse last week. Mr. Abel has been conducting at the Metropolitan Opera and Glyndebourne in recent years, so L'Opera Francais is clearly of limited utility in building his career. But he founded the company with a mission -- to perform neglected French works -- and built it from a shoestring operation into an enterprise that attracts young, experienced singers and a solid following.

title: A Permanent Home For American Folk Art
description: Fifteen years ago the Museum of American Folk Art left its rented brownstone at 49 West 53d Street in Manhattan, near the Museum of Modern Art, in search of a permanent home.

title: Stunned Parishioners Mourn Priest Found Killed in Church
description: The intruder wore a white, hooded robe, as if playing dress-up as a priest. When he was startled by an early-bird parishioner, he bolted from the sanctuary, leaving behind a dead Roman Catholic priest wrapped in a green and gold banner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRENS, DANIEL J.
description: BEHRENS-Daniel J. On June 2, 1999 of cancer, just short of his 82nd birthday. W.W. II Army veteran (Staff Sgt.). Beloved son of the late Theresa Behrens and Solomon B. Behrens. Cherished brother of Stanley (Jessica), Philip (Deb) Behrens and Evelyn (Nat) Rosenfeld. Loving uncle and great-uncle. ''He fought the good fight''.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAFIELD, MATURIN LIVINGSTON, JR.
description: DELAFIELD-Maturin Livingston, Jr. Age 42 on June 25, 1999, in Ramona, CA. Survived by his mother Barbara Reed Delafield and his father Maturin Livingston Delafield Sr., both of Princeton, NJ.

title: Police Arrest Rape Suspect, Found Hiding Under a Bed
description: A suspect in four Bronx rapes, including attacks on three 12-year-old girls, was captured Saturday night after he tried to elude the police by breaking into a Staten Island apartment and hiding under a bed, the police said yesterday.

title: Brazilians Take to the Web With Uncommon Speed
description: Pierre Schurmann, one of Brazil's Internet barons, did not know things would develop so fast.

title: Big Deal for Dell Due With Boeing
description: The Dell Computer Corporation, the biggest direct seller of personal computers, plans on Monday to announce a three-year agreement to supply PC's to the Boeing Company worldwide.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Impartial Justice
description: The Independent Counsel Act will expire on Wednesday, and unfortunately most members of Congress would just as soon see the law fade into history. But that response unwisely assumes that Kenneth Starr's protracted investigation of President Clinton ought to be the measure by which the law is judged. Without an independent counsel law, power to investigate the President and other high officials would revert back to the Attorney General, who cannot credibly oversee inquiries into the highest levels of the administration of which he or she is a part.

title: Big Freeze Blights a Citrus Crop, and the Lives of Workers
description: When winter threw a fit last Christmas, slamming through the Central Valley and scaring the life out of the citrus groves, people here were sure 1999 was over.

title: A Tricky Opening Lead Helps the Swedes in Malta
description: The European Open Team Championship ended on Saturday in Malta, with Italy taking the title. This was a slight surprise, because the winning team did not include the stars who won the world title in Lille, France, nine months ago.

title: Libel Wrangle Over Milken Book Drags On
description: The first chapter in this long-running legal soap opera dates back to 1991 when the fallout from Wall Street's insider trading scandals sent Michael R. Milken, the junk bond king, to Federal prison and inspired a best-selling book about carriage trade criminals, ''Den of Thieves.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELWRIGHT, JOSEPH BALCH, M.D.

title: With Birdies All in a Row It's Inkster's Day
description: Time and again, Juli Inkster tapped into an inner reservoir of strength and found the big shot she needed. Time and again, she made an important putt and accentuated it with a tight-lipped smile, and followed a disappointing miss with a grunted lecture to herself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, SOPHIE
description: LERNER-Sophie. The Young Israel of Great Neck expresses its deepest sorrow on the passing of Sophie Lerner, wife of our devoted member Ed, mother of our esteemed Rabbi Yaacov Lerner and Abby, mother of David and Esther, and grandmother of Shayna, Yehudit, Zahava, Yosefa, Shimon, Benyamin and Penina. We all feel a great sense of loss because Mrs. Lerner captured the hearts of our entire shul serving as everyone's ''Bubbi,'' and showering us with her boundless love and kisses. Michael Frank, President

title: Americans Go to the Bench And Result Is Still First-Rate
description: On a night when four starters rested, the United States overpowered North Korea, 3-0, while operating on a reserve tank. This is a team with such depth and resourcefulness that, had they formed their own team, the backups might have reached the quarterfinals of the Women's World Cup as assertively as the regulars.

title: Hatch Faults Administration In China Spying
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who last week became the most recent candidate to enter the race for President, today condemned the Clinton Administration's handling of national security affairs, saying, ''We're not taking counterterrorism as seriously as we should.''

title: The Formula Is Simple: Place Egos on the Shelf

title: Shalala Plays Down Cost Of Clinton's Medicare Plan
description: Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, moved today to head off criticism of the cost of President Clinton's plan to help buy prescription drugs for older Americans, saying that the new Medicare benefits ''will not be as generous as people think.''

title: Next Card to Issue Planet Out Visa
description: Next Card Inc. in San Francisco, which issues credit products like the Next Card Internet Visa card, and the Planet Out Corporation in San Francisco, which operates a Web site aimed at gay and lesbian computer users, have signed a joint marketing agreement valued at up to $11 million to introduce Planet Out Visa cards. Planet Out will advertise the card and seek customers on its site (www.planetout.com) and in mailings and at events; Next Card will pay Planet Out a fee for each card holder signed. The agreement is being described as one of the largest in the gay and lesbian market.

title: Microsoft, Running Scared
description: Last October the Justice Department and 20 states opened their antitrust case against Microsoft, accusing the company of having a monopoly in the software that runs most computers. Though the judge who is hearing the case has not reached a decision, and probably won't until the fall, after nine months of testimony Microsoft has certainly been bloodied in the court of public opinion.

When the free-agent signing period begins on Thursday, they can quickly obtain Theo Fleury, Valery Kamensky and Sylvain Lefebvre from Colorado, Tim Taylor from Boston, Joe Juneau from Buffalo, Pat Verbeek from Dallas, Ulf Samuelsson from Detroit and Stephane Quintal from Montreal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: PLUS: W.N.B.A. -- LIBERTY 72, STING 58; Weatherspoon Sparks Victory
description: Her energy seemed to overflow to her Liberty teammates. For thrilling five-minute spurts yesterday, it was as if there were five Teresa Weatherspoons on the floor. Behind Weatherspoon's 7 points, 11 assists and 6 steals, the Liberty quickly shook off the rust from a week off and beat the Charlotte Sting, 72-58, before 13,337 at Madison Square Garden. The Liberty (5-1) heads to Detroit tonight with a three-game winning streak.

title: Kurt Weill's Heritage: Honor Replaces Scorn; A German City Performs His Jewish Opera
description: For lovers of great melodies, Kurt Weill is the composer of ''Mack the Knife'' and ''September Song.'' For fans of 1940's musical comedies, he wrote the scores of ''Street Scene'' and ''One Touch of Venus.'' For operagoers, he bequeathed at least two classics to the modern repertory with ''The Threepenny Opera'' and ''The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODINOV, MAE
description: ODINOV-Mae. Irreplacable mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, friend and colleague, resigned her position in the world ''unequivocally'' as she put it, on June 26, 1999. She was too busy managing an office, attending the opera, movies and museums, to realize her time was running out. She always had time for people from all backgrounds, races and religions, and time to share all the fun she found in life. Twice widowed, she knew deep sorrow, but she also knew good talk, good times and joy. Her laughter filled the room and the hearts of all who heard it. She was smart and funny, a great talker and a great listener. Her life is one to celebrate. Mae asked that those wishing to remember her forego flowers and instead donate in her honor to the Houston Hospice or to the hospice of their choice. Friends are invited to a celebration of Mae's life on Monday, June 28 between 4-6 PM at the Jewish Community Center, 5601 S. Braeswood, Houston, TX.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHAN, DONALD H.
description: MAHAN-Donald H. Architect, on June 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Margaret; loving father of Donald, Jr. and Paul; devoted grandfather of Madeleine and Camille. Memorial service on June 30 at 2PM, Church of the Holy Spirit, Lake Forest, Illinois.

title: 3-Week Delay In Opening Up Internet Name Registration
description: The protracted effort to introduce competition into the lucrative business of registering Internet addresses has been delayed for at least three weeks because of escalating tensions among the Clinton Administration, its handpicked successor for running the global network and the Government contractor that has had a monopoly on the business.

description: When Dennis Stokes, a Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing executive, was shot to death in 1993 in a nearby suburb, Forest Lake, an Anoka County detective gave his theory of the murder to a local television station: It appeared Mr. Stokes's widow, Terri, killed her husband with a shotgun blast while he slept in their bed.

Show Jumping Championship yesterday in Gladstone, N.J. As a result of their performance in the championship and six other trials held over the past month, they will lead the United States Equestrian Team, which will ride at the Pan American Games in Winnipeg, Manitoba, next month.

title: Becker and 3 Teen-Agers Make Week 1 Their Own
description: A soap opera on some days, a nostalgia festival on others, and suspiciously rain-free through Week 1, Wimbledon has been nothing if not a portent that the more things change, the more they stay the same. Although this may be his final joy ride, Boris Becker still gallops around Center Court with the impunity of an overgrown Napoleon. And although this may be their first brush with Grand Slam success, ruthless little girls still stop at nothing to grab the brass ring of the fast-track carousel they have been hoisted onto by ambitious parents.

title: Giant Fraud Claims First Corporate Victims in Insurance Industry
description: The effects of a giant insurance fraud involving a Connecticut money manager are rippling across the industry and have already claimed their first two corporate casualties.

title: Godfather of Soul Delivers A Spectacle
description: James Brown does whatever he wants. Who would argue? Not the audience at the JVC Jazz Festival performance at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. Bedazzled college kids, natty soul brothers, spunky grandmas and slick executives with their ties loosened were united in adulation and a mighty urge to dance. They defied the officious ushers who tried to keep them in their cushioned seats, erupting at the slightest shout or hip twitch from the Minister of the New Super Heavy Funk.

title: Editorial Observer; It's Time for Honest Ads From State Lotteries
description: In the United States it is illegal to print or broadcast untrue ads. If the new box of detergent has half as much detergent as the old one, but costs only a little less, the soap company cannot claim that buyers are getting more for their money.

title: New Hope on Ending Civil War in Congo
description: Talks on ending 11 months of war in Congo received some fresh impetus when a draft cease-fire document was completed. If defense and foreign ministers from a group of African countries approve it, a peace summit meeting of African heads of state would be called, officials said.

title: As Pixie Dust Wears Off, Knicks Look Ahead
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., June 27 -- The boy was draped in an old John Starks jersey and stood no higher than a vertical leap. With a slithering move, he sneaked into a crowd of reporters gathered around Larry Johnson and nearly tilted over from the bulk of the basketball he hugged.

title: Where Prison Plans Cast a Pall Unto the Heavens
description: When residents in this economically hard-pressed town vote on Tuesday on whether to allow construction of what will be Vermont's largest prison, the fate of the annual stargazer convention may be decided as well.
