title: New Republicans May Be Just Like the Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Graham's Choreography Without the Context
description: The seeming paradox of Martha Graham's dances is that you don't have to understand them to know what they are about. Thus, when four couples in the Martha Graham Dance Ensemble rushed onstage on Friday night at Marymount Manhattan Theater, the intensity of the moment spoke for itself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELSEN, ESTHER
description: FELSEN-Esther. June 3, 1921June 28, 1998. Missed and remembered every day with love. Dave, Alan, Leslie, Diane, Joel and Beloved Grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, RICHARD LAWRENCE
description: HALPERN-Richard Lawrence. 5/18/48-6/28/92. Always loved, never forgotten. We miss you. Dad, Mother, Roberta

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Ginger Rogers Opposite James Cagney? In Your Dreams!
description: It is embarrassingly clear, if you study The Hollywood Reporter's current list of the world's most bankable actors, that neither movie makers nor movie audiences give a damn about conventional romances or unconventional women. There are 3 women on the list of the 18 said to have Maximum Star Power, and only one of those, Jodie Foster, regularly makes films in which she is the cerebral and solitary action hero.

title: Lost Souls, Not So Different From Their Creator
description: For a bunch of burned-out souls, the travelers along that lonely road known as the Camino Real are sending off plenty of sparks. The inaugural production of the Williamstown Theater Festival's new season finds the bright bounce and energy, not to mention a gutsy sense of humor, in a thickly poetic allegory of expiring hopes and trampled ideals.

title: A Mingling of Genres and Cultures
description: For 12 years the American Russian Young Artists Orchestra has brought together music students from both countries, ages 17 to 26, for training programs, performances and world tours. Since Leon Botstein took over as music director in 1995, the musicians have gathered every spring at Bard College, where Mr. Botstein is president, to work and prepare their programs. They had been together for only three weeks before their concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The ones up north, there are some great sounds for a jazz musician. Some of them sound like Charlie Parker. They do completely intellectual things. I've heard stuff up there that would knock your socks off.''

title: Germans Plan Curfew as Crime Rises in a City
description: German forces here announced today that they would impose a curfew at night to cut down on lawlessness, which continues around Kosovo in the form of slayings, burning of houses and looting.

title: Carving His Likeness on Newsprint
description: Ancient Roman rulers had their likenesses carved in stone, Renaissance princes and Dutch burghers had theirs painted on plaster or canvas. Now, in the media age, prominent people carve their likenesses on new publications: Martha Stewart, the life-style guru, created a magazine about life styles; Steven Brill, the reporter-turned-entrepreneur-turned-media baron, started a magazine about the media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Accounts
description: * Seattle Filmworks, Seattle, a mail-order film processing company, to Bozell Worldwide, Seattle, part of True North Communications, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $12 million.

title: Perils of States' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Bunker Brilliance And 3 Late Birdies Win for Waldorf
description: Running out of holes, and running out of opportunities, Duffy Waldorf picked the perfect time for a birdie binge.

title: New York Study Finds Gay Men Using Safer Sex
description: Gay men in New York City have significantly reduced their levels of risky sexual behavior, and the number of men infected with the AIDS virus has dropped sharply over the last 15 years, city health officials said in issuing findings yesterday from the largest survey ever of gay men's sexual health.

title: Looking Extremely Moderate
description: While other states debate gun-control laws, Connecticut is about to get a gun-seizure law, intended to disarm dangerous people before they fire. By promising to sign the measure, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, is providing one of the starkest illustrations yet of how far some G.O.P. officials are going in an effort to change their party's face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: INSIDE
description: Tears for a Slain Priest

title: Science in the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Down Memory Lane in Racing Stripes
description: Tom Gensler hits the ignition and the Chevy big-block jumps to life. Boom, ba-ba-ba-room. Boom! BOOM! The noise is deafening. It sounds like a tiger wrestling with a grizzly bear, but Mr. Gensler loves it. Like a proud father, he listens intently and folds his arms across his chest. ''It's Friday night,'' he said above the roar. ''I live for Friday nights, you know? Always have. Always will.''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Dinner for a Presidential Library, Contributions Welcome
description: Quietly, at a French restaurant on the East Side of midtown Manhattan on Monday evening, President Clinton, the most effective fund-raiser ever to occupy the White House, plans to embark on the most ambitious fund-raising campaign of his long political career.

title: Hoedspruit Journal; Out of a Failed African Circus, a Lion of Legend
description: When Elsayed Hussein Akef fled Mozambique in 1996, abandoning his bankrupt Akef Egyptian Circus and leaving its lions, tigers, horses, dogs and last sick python to starve to death, he must not have realized what he had left behind.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Issues Go Beyond Price For Frontier and U S West

title: Van Horn Prepares the Nets For Contract Negotiations
description: On Thursday, Keith Van Horn will be eligible to begin contract negotiations that could keep him in New Jersey for the next seven years. He believes those talks should be a mere formality, that in his two years with the club he has shown he deserves the maximum amount of money available. Therefore, he does not plan to get involved in any haggling. If the Nets do not put the right offer before his eyes within one week, Van Horn says, they will risk losing him.

title: Sign of Success: Jeter Sits Out, But Sojo Homers
description: Before batting in the ninth inning today, Luis Sojo turned to teammates on the Yankees' bench and predicted he would hit a home run, which is like Ross Perot guaranteeing he is going to be elected President or Larry Johnson promising he is going to utter something noncontroversial. Sojo had not hit a home run in nearly two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, DAVID
description: KRAMER-David. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Personal Character Goes Only So Far
description: James Madison once wrote that if all men were angels, government would not be necessary.

title: The Big City; A Data Island To Narrow A Silicon Gap
description: WILLIAM TUCKER, who is one of the more prescient people in New York, has an idea for transforming the city's economy. It came to him one day as he was bicycling from home across the Brooklyn Bridge to Silicon Alley, the downtown enclave of new technology companies.

title: Damage to Serb Military Less Than Expected
description: NATO warplanes demolished the Yugoslav Army's World War II-era base here. In what was left of the motor pool, 18 military vehicles, including one armored personnel carrier, were scattered today in charred, twisted heaps.

title: Paulson's Game Hits Next Level
description: At 36 years old, Dennis Paulson is a former national long-driving champion, a veteran of the Asian and Nike Tours and a guy who says he might have won more tournaments earlier in the decade had he not damaged his shoulder in a thrill-seeking dive off a 60-foot cliff.

title: While Green and Jones Dash, Hartwig Sets U.S. Pole-Vault Mark
description: Maurice Greene and Marion Jones won their 200-meters finals at the United States Track and Field Championships today, but they had to share the loudest cheers with Jeff Hartwig's American record in the pole vault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Risky Business
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A. O. SMITH TO BUY ELECTRIC MOTOR UNIT FROM MAGNETEK
description: The A. O. Smith Corporation, a maker of motors for air- conditioners and water heaters, said yesterday that it would buy Magnetek Inc.'s electric motors unit for about $250 million to sell a wider range of motors. Magnetek, which is based in Nashville and makes electric motors for pools, spas and air-conditioners, said last month that it would sell the unit and use the proceeds to repurchase shares and pay down debt. The unit had about $367 million in 1998 revenue. A. O. Smith, which is based in Milwaukee, said the acquisition, its third in two years, would increase motor sales to $1 billion next year and increase its replacement motor business.

title: Big French Water Company To Acquire Nalco Chemical
description: In a deal that will create the world's largest water treatment company, Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. of France will acquire the Nalco Chemical Company for $4.1 billion in cash, or $53 a share. Suez will also assume about $400 million in Nalco debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Success at Poor Schools, Despite the Odds
description: Schools with high numbers of impoverished children can nevertheless do well on standardized tests if they are led by hard-charging principals willing to work long hours to improve teaching and learning, says a new report on 14 high-achieving schools in some of New York City's poorest neighborhoods.

title: Likud Decides Not to Join A Coalition Led by Barak
description: The rightist Likud Party withdrew from coalition talks with Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak today, announcing that it would not join his government and was headed for the opposition.

title: A Windfall's Promise
description: The new era of government surpluses forecast last January has suddenly grown bigger and brighter. Over the next 15 years, President Clinton announced yesterday, the Federal Government will produce surpluses of $5.5 trillion, a cool $1 trillion higher than January's number. The President also offered some ideas about how to spend this windfall. In terms of broad intent, his proposals are not much different from those he unveiled five months ago. But in important details they are much improved. Mr. Clinton has also left the door ajar for discussion of broader tax cuts down the road. That is a political necessity, given Republican control of Congress, and positions the President to argue for tax relief for low- and middle-income families. But Mr. Clinton has no intention of cutting a deal on taxes until Congress addresses his main priorities.

title: Frontier Still Weighing Bid From Qwest
description: The Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's largest long-distance telephone companies, said yesterday that it was continuing to evaluate the unsolicited offer made two weeks ago by Qwest Communications International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Seagate Technology Sees Profit Shortfall
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the leading maker of computer disk drives, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of estimates because of weak demand and falling prices, a trend it expects to continue into the first quarter.

title: One Man's Ties Aided a Scheme To Bilk Insurers
description: One of the mysteries about Martin R. Frankel, the man authorities suspect of orchestrating a spectacular insurance fraud, is how a financier who almost never left his well-guarded Greenwich, Conn., mansion befriended corporate and religious elites on two continents.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS. Sugar prices fell on signs that demand from Russia may be drying up at a time when growers in Brazil are harvesting a bumper crop. In New York, sugar for July delivery fell 0.14 cent, to 5.95 cents a pound.

title: For 'Bouncers,' a Chance for the Gold
description: As a preschooler, Jennifer Parilla often climbed onto her parents' bed and jumped as high as she could. ''I loved the feeling of flying,'' recalled Ms. Parilla, of Lake Forest, Calif. Then, when she was 5, she began lessons in the sport of trampolining.

title: At Gene Therapy's Frontier, the Amish Build a Clinic
description: This was not the typical audience for a medical conference, but then again, this was no typical conference. At an inn set in the lush farmland of Lancaster County, doctors attending scientific lectures earlier this month were joined by young Mennonite and Amish couples, the women in bonnets and the men in suspenders, babies fussing in their laps.

title: Foreign Affairs; This Is the Big One
description: Memo to: President Mohammad Khatami of Iran & Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China

title: A $10 Million Gift for Conservation at the Morgan
description: In a small space that was once J. P. Morgan's nursery, two full-time conservators spend their days caring for the Morgan Library's extraordinary collection of works on paper in cramped quarters and on a shoestring budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, FRANK
description: KLEIN-Frank Owner of Carnival Creations Inc. Passed away Sunday, June 27, 1999. At his home surrounded by his wife, children and grandchildren. Funeral services are to be held Tuesday, June 29, 1999 at Riverside Chapel, 1495 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y. at 12:15PM.

title: Whitman Quietly Signs Bill Limiting Teen-Age Abortions
description: Avoiding the kind of public fanfare that she often uses when she signs major legislation, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law today the first significant restriction on abortion rights in New Jersey in more than 20 years, prohibiting a girl younger than 18 from obtaining an abortion unless her parents are notified.

title: Wily Mixer Of Cool Jazz, Brazilian Pop And High Art
description: For pop stars persevering into middle age, maintaining critical and popular success is a tough business: it depends upon cultivating a number of different personalities, and reshuffling them for each concert or record. Year after year, the audience grows wiser along with the performer, demanding the complexity that age is supposed to lend the truly gifted. The Brazilian singer Caetano Veloso, whose concert at the Beacon Theater closed the JVC Jazz Festival on Sunday, is the paradigm of such a pop star. At 56 he's got a world-class singing voice, an old-fashioned gift for high-quality songwriting and an enigmatic public personality; indeed, he seems to be one step ahead of this process, using his wiles to cultivate the perfect audience.

title: Unseeded Dokic, Age 16, Marches to Quarterfinals
description: She's sweet 16, but here on the courts of Wimbledon, where a succession of showers compromised the progress of the Round of 16, Jelena Dokic continued to unveil a take-no-prisoners scheme today that vaulted her into her first Grand Slam quarterfinal.

title: Interleague Games Too Lucrative to Lose
description: The upstart Cincinnati Reds sweep a four-game series from the Houston Astros and supplant them in first place. The second-place Seattle Mariners take two of three from Texas and move a game closer to the first-place Rangers. The second-place Mets win the first game of a three-game series with the first-place Atlanta Braves but then lose the next two games, winding up with a net loss of a game in the standing.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Photographers Versus Spike Lee

title: A Little Gehrig Fantasy for Really Big Dollars
description: In historic terms, it is a sacred relic worn by a 36-year-old man two years from death. The size 46 pinstriped suit is slightly faded, the fabric soft to the touch, but heavy for summer wear. Yet even on a steamy morning, you're tempted to hop the No. 4 train to 161st Street, sneak into the local ball park and try it on.

Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, GILMAN
description: KRAFT-Gilman, president and owner of Performing Arts magazine, died June 27 following a brief illness. Mr. Kraft founded the theater program magazine in 1966, when the Music Center opened. The publication serves the Orange County Performing Arts Center, the UCLA Center for the Performing Arts, The Pasadena Playhouse, The San Francisco Opera and Ballet, and over 40 venues throughout the state of California. Mr. Kraft was born in New Jersey in 1926, the son of immigrants. He and his brother, the late political columnist, Joseph Kraft, were raised in New York City and attended the Fieldston School. Mr. Kraft served in World War II as a Japanese linguist. At 25, after graduating from Columbia College, Mr. Kraft founded The Reader's Subscription, an intellectual book club, enlisting as editors Lionel Trilling and Jacques Barzun. The Reader's Subscription brought back into print Nathaniel West's ''The Day of the Locust'' and James Agee's ''Let Us Now Praise Famous Men,'' as well as works by Chaucer and many others. Mr. Kraft was then recruited to revive the flagging Broadway program service, Playbill, which he owned and operated for nearly 10 years. In 1966, Kraft moved his family to Los Angeles, where he served the arts community for over 30 years and speculated in commercial and residential real estate. He is survived by his wife, Ruth; his children, Richard Kraft, Dana Kitaj, Susan Pelosa, and Frank Pelosa; and his grandchildren, David, Stephanie, Christopher, Alden, Nathan, Rachael, Joseph and Samuel. A memorial service will be held at 10 AM Thursday, July 1, at the Skirball Cultural Center, 2701 N. Sepulveda Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90049, 310-440-4500. In lieu of flowers, please contact Performing Arts magazine at 310-551-1115 regarding charitable contributions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Politics Can Use Some Compassion; Faith and Goodness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: SHATTERED LIVES -- A special report.; Caring Parents, No Answers, In Columbine Killers' Pasts
description: The father of one of the boys was asked some years ago to jot down his life's goals in the memory book for his 20th high school reunion. His answer was succinct, straightforward, and, it seemed, not unrealistically ambitious: ''Raise two good sons.''

title: Activism Off the Court; Where Winning Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Directionally Challenged
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: SEGA STOCK PLUNGES
description: The stock of Sega Enterprises Ltd. plunged to a record low after a Japanese company cut its credit rating on Sega, Japan's No. 3 maker of home video-game machines, to one notch above ''junk'' status. Sega fell 141 yen, or 8.8 percent, to a record close of 1,468, after hitting 1,360 yen earlier. Japan Rating and Investment Information Inc. cut its rating because of weak sales of Sega's Dreamcast game machine in an increasingly competitive market.

title: BOYD GAMING TO BUY LAKE MICHIGAN RIVERBOAT CASINO
description: The Boyd Gaming Corporation, owner of the Stardust Resort in Las Vegas and 10 other casinos, agreed to buy the Blue Chip Casino, a riverboat in Michigan City, Ind., for $273.5 million to enter the Chicago-area gambling market. Boyd will pay $255 million for the riverboat casino and another $18.5 million for a hotel and parking garage that is under construction and will be attached to the casino complex. Closely held Blue Chip, one of five riverboats operating in Indiana along Lake Michigan, has 1,330 slot machines and 58 table games. The casino is about 60 miles from Chicago. Shares of Boyd, which is based in Las Vegas, were up 81.25 cents, to $6.3125.

title: BRAZILIAN PRIVATIZATION CANCELED
description: Brazil's Government has shelved plans to privatize the brokerage arm of the country's largest financial institution, Banco do Brasil, on concern that pessimism about Latin America's financial markets would sap interest in the transaction. The unit is Brazil's largest fund manager, with roughly $15.2 billion under management. Separately, Banco do Brasil, which is state-controlled, sought to calm investors over press reports that it could suffer substantial losses if federal authorities decide not to roll over 5.1 billion reais, or $2.9 billion, of regional government debt securities. Simon Romero

title: Sunglass Makers Complete a Deal
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said today that Luxottica Group S.p.A. had completed the purchase of its Ray-Ban unit for about $640 million cash and that as a result, the company expected a gain of about $120 million, or $2.10 a share, in the second quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHRENWEND, GERTRUDE F.
description: DOHRENWEND-Gertrude F. Of Riverdale, New York City, died on June 26th, 1999, in Allen Pavillion, at age 98. Daughter of Edmund and Johanna Funke, of New York. Beloved wife of the late Gustav J. Dohrenwend, Jr., mother of Bruce P. Dohrenwend, married to Catherine Douglass and Doris Dohrenwend, a resident of Toronto. Graduated from Smith College, Phi Beta Kappa, and until recently a tireless worker on behalf of Riverdale Neighborhood House. Family and friends will gather at 1 P.M. on June 30th, before the burial in The Saint Francis of Assisi Chapel of The Gate of Heaven Cemetery, in Hawthorne, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your charity of choice.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article Sunday incorrectly compared Supreme Court votes last week and last month on states' rights cases. A 7-to-2 opinion last month in a California case upholding Federal rights included three Justices who were in the majority of a 5-to-4 vote last week upholding states' rights.

title: Is Incredible Shrinking Chip Nearing End of the Line?
description: Bonsai trees, dolls, toy soldiers, models, bracelet charms, chihuahuas, funerary amulets: their attraction is in their size. The brain seems to be wired to love miniature things.

title: Clasping Rage but Keeping the Ladies at Arm's Length
description: JONATHAN SWIFT

title: Galileo Plans Buyback
description: Galileo International Inc., the big computerized-reservation system, said today that it would buy back up to $122 million of its stock from affiliates of its airline shareholders. The company, which is based in Rosemont, will repurchase 2.8 million common shares from the affiliates, which include United Airlines, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Alitalia and TAP Air Portugal. The buyback, part of a $750 million stock repurchase program, will increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding.

title: Colombia Devalues Peso by 10% in Emergency Decree
description: Hurt by a steep economic decline and speculative selling pressure on the peso, Colombia devalued its national currency by 10 percent in an emergency decree that took effect today.

title: Joint Phone Venture Wins an Approval
description: The AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. have won Federal antitrust clearance for their planned $3 billion joint venture, a Justice Department spokeswoman said today.

title: Organizers of Tour de France Hoping to Make a Champion
description: That hum coming from the headquarters of the Tour de France is an ancient mantra: It's not champions who make the Tour; it's the Tour that makes champions.

title: The Clinton Library
description: Every modern President, beginning with Herbert Hoover, has established a separate library in his home state to house his papers. These facilities are built with private money, and Bill Clinton, who wants to see a $125 million library, museum and public policy center in Little Rock, Ark., is already working on his. While Mr. Clinton is not directly soliciting contributions, he seems to be engaged in what might be called the softening-up process. During a visit to New York City, he scheduled a private dinner yesterday with about 40 potential donors. News accounts suggested that Mr. Clinton would share his plans for the library, and that the guests will receive a follow-up call from the fund-raisers.

title: Shares Rise in Slow Trading In Advance of Fed Meeting
description: Stock prices staged a broad advance yesterday, helped by a rally in the bond market. But with the Federal Reserve beginning two days of policy-making meetings today, the pace of trading was subdued.

title: Metro Business; Utility Is Sued Again
description: The officers of Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. and the company's auditor, Arthur Andersen, face another shareholder lawsuit accusing them of wasting the utility's assets.

title: ABC and Affiliate Stations Reach Financial Agreement
description: After months of often rancorous negotiations, ABC and the board representing its affiliated stations struck a deal yesterday that will bring the network some much-needed cash to pay for the heavy costs of professional football, while the affiliates will receive more commercials to sell in prime time.

title: Drug Benefits Up to $2,500 Are in Plan For Medicare
description: A Medicare beneficiary could eventually get up to $2,500 a year in Federal money to help buy prescription drugs under President Clinton's proposal to expand the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FAY D.
description: COHEN-Fay D. On June 27, 1999. Best friend and beloved wife of the late Samuel Z. Cohen. Devoted and loving mother of Rabbi William and Yehudit Cohen, Judith and Rabbi Irwin Borvick. Cherished grandmother of Aviva and Joey, Nachman and Miriam, Sari and David, Elli and Shoshana, Gedaliah and Fayge, Eton and Nechama, Yonina and Danny, and Tanchum. Adored and loving Granny to 32 great grandchildren. Dear sister of the late Louis Desick, Mildred Gaynor and Esther Wang. Dedicated accountant for over 50 years, she counseled friends and family with wisdom and compassion. Ardent supporter of YESHA Heartland Campaign, and the Brighton Beach Mikvah. Shiva will be observed until Sunday morning.

title: Quick Action Eases Sting of Poison Ivy
description: You can get it mowing the lawn, whacking weeds, petting the dog, hiking through the woods, burning logs in a fireplace, gardening, retrieving a lost ball, using the great outdoors for a toilet, putting clothes in the washing machine or removing your shoes. ''It'' is poison ivy, a source of misery for half the people who make contact with its allergenic sap and a potential problem for many more people who are not yet sensitized.

title: CLINTON OUTLINES PLAN FOR SURPLUS; G.O.P. SUSPICIOUS
description: President Clinton laid out his proposal today to use the fast-growing Federal budget surplus to eliminate the national debt while shoring up Social Security and Medicare, and left open the possibility of a deal with the Republican-led Congress over its demand for big tax cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Projects for Kennedy and Newark Approved
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved yesterday nearly $2.5 billion in projects at Newark and Kennedy International Airports that are expected to ease airline congestion, shorten waits for passengers and create thousands of jobs.

title: A Union March on Alabama; U.A.W. Is Facing Uncommon Odds at Mercedes Plant
description: Steven H. Merrill was one of the first auto workers Mercedes-Benz hired as it geared up to build sport utility vehicles here in 1994. He has gotten steady raises and a two-month training trip to Germany. He even met his wife on the assembly line.

title: U.S. Consumers Earning More, Spending More and Saving Less
description: Spending rose in May at a faster pace than incomes, helping prolong the economic expansion as consumers go deeper into debt, Government figures showed today.

title: Teacher Is Attacked Over a Bad Report Card
description: A Brooklyn woman and her 12-year-old daughter attacked the girl's teacher yesterday for giving her bad grades, the police said. The mother, Brenda Smith, 44, was charged with assault, and the daughter with juvenile delinquency, said Jerry Varson, a police spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: A Restless Artest Is Ready for Plunge
description: He has worked with a National Basketball Association conditioning coach and run on a treadmill set at 40 percent incline.

title: Tensions Simmer Around a Black Sect in Georgia
description: When members of a black religious group moved here from Brooklyn in 1993, their purchase of 438 acres of pasture about 10 miles outside town stirred up gossip and some apprehension, but residents were more curious than frightened.

title: STAAR SURGICAL EVALUATING $210 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Staar Surgical Company, which makes implantable replacement lenses and other devices used in eye surgery, said yesterday that it was evaluating a $15-a-share cash buyout offer from an undisclosed suitor. The offer values Staar, which is based in Monrovia, Calif., at $210 million, if all of its 14 million outstanding shares are acquired. The shares of Staar fell 25 cents each, to $13.625.

title: Mixed Results at Congo Cease-Fire Talks
description: Negotiations to end the 11-month-old war in Congo inched forward today as foreign and defense ministers of all the nations involved in the conflict met in Zambia to discuss a draft text for a cease-fire.

title: In a Wave of Balkan Charity Comes Drug Aid of Little Use
description: Last month, Project Hope, the American medical charity, shipped $1.5 million worth of emergency supplies to the Kosovo refugees. But relief workers, eager for certain kinds of antibiotics or insulin, sometimes found Chap Stick, Preparation H and anti-smoking inhalers -- given by American companies that got a generous tax break for the donations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Cubans Released From Contracts
description: Like other Latin players who have been signed illegally, two Cubans have been declared free agents because the commissioner's office has found that the Los Angeles Dodgers improperly signed them.

title: HUBBELL REPORTED TO AGREE TO PLEA ON STARR CHARGES
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, has reached a plea agreement with Webster L. Hubbell, lawyers close to the case said today, in which Mr. Hubbell will plead guilty to a felony charge of lying about the role he and Hillary Rodham Clinton played in a questionable Arkansas land deal.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Troubled Mexican Steelmaker Talks of Merger
description: Mexico's largest steel manufacturer, which defaulted on $1.9 billion of debt two months ago, announced today that it was discussing a proposed merger with one of the country's largest industrial conglomerates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: For 4 Schools, a Somber Time on Last Day
description: It was the last day of classes in New York City's public schools yesterday, and for teachers, students and parents at four elementary schools, it was a bittersweet one.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Beijing Journal; Group's Morning Exercises Are Politically Suspect
description: Just after 6 A.M., they amble one by one on to the small plaza just outside Purple Bamboo Park, each depositing a seat cushion next to a decorative urn.

title: Human Imprint on Climate Change Grows Clearer
description: As evidence that the earth's atmosphere is warming continues to accumulate, scientists are making slow progress toward an answer to the big question raised by the evidence: how much of the warming is due to human activity and how much to natural causes?

title: Citing Foe's Money, Democrat Ends His Bid for a Senate Seat
description: Representative Frank Pallone Jr. today ended his exploratory bid for the Democratic nomination in next year's United States Senate race, saying he could not overcome the huge financial advantage of Jon S. Corzine, a political neophyte whose wealth has made him a formidable challenger.

title: Brewing Pure Science From Raw Alchemy
description: Sir Isaac Newton, the founder of physics, spent a quarter-century dabbling in alchemy and searching for occult powers, toiling late into the night, at times dozing off next to a bubbling flask. And he was in good company.

title: 2 Funds Settle Insider Trading Charges
description: Two Swiss investment funds agreed yesterday to pay almost $11 million to settle United States charges that they made insider trades in the stock of Elsag Bailey Process Automation N.V. before the company's takeover by ABB Ltd., the world's largest electrical-engineering company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 19 about NATO's military relations with Russia misstated the rank of Col. Gen. Viktor M. Zavarzin, the commander of Russian peacekeepers in Kosovo. His rank is three stars, not four, making him the equivalent of a British or American lieutenant general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Selling Saint Laurent to Daughters Who Lunch
description: ''I'm usually in New York for five hours,'' Alber Elbaz was saying last week, on Monday night, in the middle of a whirlwind week of public appearances and private dinners to promote him as the designer of Yves Saint Laurent ready-to-wear. ''I get here, and I'm right back on a plane. And I get jet lag going from New York to New Jersey!''

title: LG BOWS OUT OF AUCTION
description: South Korea's fourth-largest conglomerate, LG Group, once considered the domestic company with the best chance of taking over the troubled Korea Life Insurance Company, said it would not join the third auction for the insurer because it wanted to concentrate on improving its own finances. Still, Hanwha Group, the nation's eighth-largest business group, said it would bid. The Financial Supervisory Commission said foreign companies are also in the running. The Government set a minimum price of 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) for Korea Life.

title: By Design; Good Hair Day (Skin, Too)
description: With the coming Fourth of July holiday, summer weekending gets into high gear with outings under the sun. Luckily, there are beauty products designed to protect or enhance the skin and hair in hot weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Repertory Ballet Names a Director
description: Graham Lustig has been named the new artistic director of the American Repertory Ballet, formerly Princeton Ballet, and its school in New Brunswick, N.J., effective on Thursday. He succeeds Septime Webre, who is now the artistic director of the Washington Ballet.

title: Panel Criticizes Extent of Arafat's Power
description: Yasir Arafat, president of the Palestinian Authority, has concentrated executive power so completely in his own hands that he personally approves all senior officials' vacations and their per diem expenses, an international study released here today found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLEMAN, JOSEPH
description: ENGLEMAN-Joseph Of 101 Bickford Drive, Extension, Avon, Connecticut, died on June 27th, 1999. Devoted husband of sixty years of Claire (Scheib) Engleman. Beloved father of Carol and Michael Kligfeld of Woodbridge, CT, and Nancy and Stu Katz of Burlington, CT. Cherished grandfather of Dr. Jennifer Jaeger, Adam Kligfeld, Cheryl Mirer, and Jessica Katz. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Mr. Engleman received his Bachelor's and Master's Degrees from Bernard Baruch College, City College of New York, and was a partner in the firm of Engleman & Volkman, C.P.A. He was a long-standing Board member, New York Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, of B'nai Brith Hillel Foundation at Brooklyn College, and a former national Hillel Commissioner. He was a founding president of Jewish Association of College Youth (JACY). Until his death, he served as the lay spiritual leader of Laurel Gardens, Avon, CT. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the Philippines and having fought in the battles of Bataan and Manila. Funeral services will be at 1:30 PM, Tuesday at the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George Street, New Haven, Connecticut, with interment to follow in the Sharon Gardens, Hawthorne, NY. Memorial contributions may be sent to the B'nai Brith Hillel Foundation, 1640 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC, or to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, 27 Allendale Dr., North Haven, CT. 06473. A period of mourning will be observed at 9 Dickenson Drive, Woodbridge, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, FRED C.
description: TRUMP-Fred C. Husband of Mary MacLeod Trump. Father of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump, Jr. Grandfather of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump, III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump, Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great grandfather of Andrea Trump, Cristopher Trump and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday and Monday, 3-5:00 and 7-9:00 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Ave. at 29 St., Tuesday, 11:00 AM. Interment private. Contributions in memory of Fred C. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, New York 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNET, JOHN REINHART
description: BENNET-John Reinhart Of Cambridge, MA, formerly of NYC, on June 26, 1999 after a brief illness in the 92nd year of his age. Husband of Silvia Strong Bennet. Father of Helena Prentice Bennet and David La Tourette Bennet. Services at the convenience of the family.

title: Embattled Essex County Prosecutor Stripped of Control Over Budget and Staffing
description: The State Attorney General has stripped Essex County Prosecutor Patricia A. Hurt of control over her budget and staffing and has given that authority to one of his aides for an unspecified period.

title: Senator's Widow Named To Run for His Seat
description: The Queens Democratic Party selected Toby Ann Stavisky yesterday as its candidate for the State Senate seat that had been held by her husband, the late Leonard P. Stavisky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Deo Is All Alone At Two Under Par
description: Mike Deo has been coming close, but he has not tasted victory in a major golf tournament in the metropolitan area. The 22-year-old Deo took another step toward that first title yesterday when he was the medalist with a two-under-par 70 in the first round of the 1999 Ike, the stroke-play championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the final episode of ''Another World,'' a soap opera canceled by NBC after 35 years, misidentified the character who appeared with framed pictures of the show's actors in the final scene. She was Rachel, not Felicia. The article also misstated the name of the character who was killed by his brother in an earlier episode. He was Ryan; no character was named Brian. The broadcast time was also misstated; it was at 2 P.M., not 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Big Visions for the West Side; Architects Turn Imaginations Loose on the Rail Yards
description: For developers and architects, it has long been the juiciest prize in Manhattan, a squalid corridor of rail yards covering 12 square blocks and stretching from the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue to the Hudson River. But what should be built on it?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIPS. The dollar rose against the euro after a consumer spending report gave more evidence of United States economic strength. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0351, down from $1.0428 on Friday.

title: Groups Debate Role of Milk In Building a Better Pyramid
description: With the deliberations in full swing for revisions of the Federal Dietary Guidelines for All Americans, to be reissued next year, what started as a controversy is fast progressing into a contentious argument: should the Government be recommending dairy products as part of a balanced diet, given that once most nonwhite people leave childhood, they cannot easily digest those products?

title: Political Memo; Mayoral Trio Can Still Hit All the Notes
description: No one expected the scales to fall from the eyes of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani simply because a trio of Jacob Marleys from administrations past had come to skulk outside his door. In fact, most people anticipated that he would react dismissively -- and he later obliged.

title: AMERICAN TOWER TO BUY UNISITE, A RIVAL, FOR $165 MILLION
description: The American Tower Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire privately held Unisite Inc. for $165 million and $40 million in assumed debt. The transaction will add Unisite's 600 wireless communications towers to the more than 2,000 broadcast and wireless towers that American Tower owns and operates. Unisite, based in Tampa, Fla., currently owns and operates 400 towers and expects to build another 200 towers before the deal closes. American Tower, which is based in Boston, had revenue of $103.5 million in 1998. American Tower's shares slipped 25 cents, to $23.25.

title: Gasoline Prices Are Down
description: Average gasoline prices at the pump fell 1.1 cents last week, to $1.113 for a gallon of regular, self-service gasoline. The drop, according to an Energy Department survey of 800 service stations, was the second in three weeks.

title: Seats and Cycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Secret of Abalone's Remarkable Strength Is Found
description: The world is awash in space-age materials, from the graphite panels of an airplane wing to the honeycomb sandwich of a skateboard. To the list can be added the shell of an abalone, that rock-dwelling creature, about the size of a steam iron, that lives in shallow waters off the West Coast and elsewhere in the Pacific.

title: Young People Open to H.I.V. Testing
description: Jennifer Jako once had a ''not me'' attitude about AIDS.

title: Disability Games
description: Last week's decision by the Supreme Court to narrow the definition of disability and limit the Americans With Disabilities Act is unlikely to clarify how we handle the disabled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD-Eileen The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center note with profound sorrow the passing of Eileen Bernard, beloved wife of our esteemed trustee, Herbert Bernard. She will be long remembered by all who knew her as a woman of culture who loved art, music and dance. We convey our deepest condolences to her husband; her children, Migs Woodside and Lewis W. Bernard; grandchildren, Geoffrey, Debbie, Adam, and Claire; and her entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Transforming Rock Genres With a Reflective Voice
description: Chrissie Hynde acted like a real person the other night at the Bowery Ballroom, as she has over 20 years in a business she thinks is full of nonsense. ''This is a showcase,'' she announced, about to explain why a celebrated band like her Pretenders was playing this relatively small venue. Then she uttered a good-natured expletive and dove into ''Nails in the Road,'' from the band's just-released eighth album, ''Viva el Amor!'' (Warner Brothers). The strategies of her latest comeback were only distracting her from the chance to get rocking.

title: Show Biz and Romance in the Age of the Cakewalk
description: A lively theatrical curiosity is taking on a new life on the Lower East Side.

title: WITCO CANCELS OFFER TO SELL PETROLEUM ADDITIVES UNIT
description: The Witco Corporation, a maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it would withdraw its offer to sell its petroleum additives business because of its pending $2 billion merger with the Crompton & Knowles Corporation. Witco, based in Greenwich, R.I., announced its plan to sell the business on May 5. Although the move attracted ''significant interest,'' the company said, it will instead include the business in its combined portfolio with Crompton & Knowles, another maker of specialty chemicals. Earlier this month, the companies said they had agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at $1 billion, plus nearly $1 billion in assumed debt. The newly formed Connecticut-based company will be called the C&K Witco Corporation and have sales of about $3.9 billion.

title: Arms Sales Pit Industry Against U.S. Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGGAR, VICTORIA
description: NAGGAR-Victoria Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: When the Truth Is as Elusive as the Cure
description: One afternoon recently when I was working in my outpatient clinic, a middle-aged woman came to me with a surprise. The severe lower back pain and leg pain and numbness that had plagued her for months, making it impossible for her even to sit in a chair on recent clinic visits, had all but disappeared. She informed me that she had canceled her back surgery scheduled for later in the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, JOSEPH E.
description: COLEMAN-Joseph E., MD, PhD, 68, of Ridge Rd., Hamden, Ct., formerly of Orange, CT. died June 28, 1999 in the Yale University Health Service. Dr. Coleman is survived by his wife Phoebe Newman Coleman of Hamden, sons Michael Newman Coleman and Samuel Hopkins Coleman both of Bridgehampton, N.Y. and daughter Julia Heath Coleman of Denver, Co. and brother George Lawrence Coleman of Ocala, FL. He was pre-deceased by his twin brother Robert Coleman. Dr. Coleman retired from the Yale Molecular BioPhysics and Bio-Chemistry Dept. where he had been chairman from 1976 to 1982. Interment will be in the family plot in Bridgehampton, N.Y. at the convenience of the family. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced. For information Smith Funeral Home, 135 Broad Street, Milford, CT.

title: Clintons Look for Money and a Home
description: President Clinton came to New York yesterday to raise more than $1 million for Democratic candidates running for Congress next year. But one of the better-known of those potential Democratic candidates, Hillary Rodham Clinton, skipped the event, spending the day looking for houses in New York City and Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLOW, BEATRICE (ALPERT)
description: GITLOW-Beatrice (Alpert). Loving & supportive wife, sweetheart and counterbalance of Abraham. Devoted & caring mother of Allan (Deanna) and Howard (Shelly). Loving and devoted grandmother of Jessica Jacobs (Steven), Elissa Gitlow (Jason Hecker), and Ali Gitlow. Great friend to many. Born October 8, 1917 in Suffern, New York, and died June 27, 1999, at age 81 in Miami Beach, Florida. Bea traveled the world and created exquisite needlepoint art. She was a great listener. Bea had a wonderful life and was content. Her wisdom included: ''Happiness is being married to your best friend.'' Services will be held at 11:15 A.M., Tuesday, June 29, 1999, at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: Zesty Barbecue, Without Carcinogens
description: Cooks know that marinating a steak before grilling improves flavor and tenderizes. Now, scientists suggest the technique decreases the production of carcinogenic compounds in meats and fish cooked at high temperatures.

title: 9th Wonder of World: For Yanks, It's Rivera
description: The instant Shane Spencer's ninth-inning home run cleared the fence in left-center field last Friday in Baltimore, Mariano Rivera pushed himself off the bench in the visitors' bullpen. An iron ball was in his right hand.

description: The all rocketed off Shannon MacMillan's right foot from 19 yards out as it always does, sharply and with biting movement, diving nastily and finally short-hopping into the North Korean goal on Sunday night.

title: Adelphi Head Is Courted to Run CUNY
description: Herman Badillo, the chairman of the City University of New York, said yesterday that he is actively pursuing Matthew Goldstein, president of Adelphi University and a former president in the CUNY system, to be CUNY's next chancellor.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Three drug companies are moving to dump their agricultural units as worldwide sales decline.
description: THE American Home Products Corporation, the current ne'er-do-well of the pharmaceutical industry, is having a hard time selling its troubled agricultural division, analysts said yesterday, because two of the most likely buyers -- Novartis A.G. and the Astra Zeneca Group -- are also trying to sell theirs.

title: USA GLOBAL TO BUY CVF TECHNOLOGIES FOR $100 MILLION
description: USA Global Link Inc., a closely held provider of international telecommunications and electronic-commerce services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the CVF Technologies Corporation, a developer of electronic-commerce technologies, for $100 million in stock. USA Global, based in Fairfield, Iowa, said the combined company, to be called Global Online Inc., would concentrate on international business. The combined company will employ 245 people and have 3,775 sales agents in more than 170 countries and territories. Shares of CVF, based in New York, fell $1.125, to $4.875.

title: India and Pakistan Far Apart in War of Words and Weapons
description: Seven weeks into an ever-intensifying war of words and weapons, India and Pakistan today could not even agree about whether a Pakistani envoy had come to New Delhi over the weekend to deliver a diplomatic message.

title: Charismatic's Half Brother a Survivor
description: While the then-unknown Charismatic was training to become an instant American celebrity by winning the Kentucky Derby, a half brother named Squall Watch, who was even less heralded, was being readied for sale at a meat auction last March.

title: Bodies Torn From a Grave Leave a Trail Of Evidence
description: It seemed a strangely peaceful, pastoral site, this mass grave, nestled in rolling hills of verdant farmland, the green brightened by splotches of other colors -- red poppies, purple thistles, white Queen Anne's lace and a half-dozen or more shades of yellow -- the only sound the chirping of songbirds.

title: Peterson, Right-Handed and Right On
description: Sometimes a liability can be turned into an asset. Take the case of Oscar Peterson, one of the most virtuosic of all jazz pianists. After a stroke six years ago that partly immobilized his left hand, leaving him unable to conjure the rumbling musical earthquakes of old, he refused to give up. Instead, he perfected a sparer, more melodic style concentrated in his right hand, and developed a group sound that allowed the bass and drums to fill in more of the bottom end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Inquiry Deals a Fresh Blow To Chirac's Troubled Party
description: President Jacques Chirac has an electoral lease on Elysee Palace until 2002, but some people are wondering whether the political party he founded to get himself to the presidency will last that long.

title: Arts in America: Very Far Off Broadway but True to the Spirit; A Festival in Alaska Draws the Guiding Lights for a 40th Anniversary
description: Edward Albee arrived by seaplane. His flight into Anchorage, 250 miles to the west, had been delayed in Seattle, so he missed his connection to the commercial puddle-jumper that would have gotten him here in time. He was late for the production of his 1961 play, ''The American Dream,'' at the annual theater conference that (uncomfortably for him, as it happens) bears his name.

title: Much Maligned but Still the Champ: Hot Dogs

Rick Sebak, whose ''Ice Cream Show'' must have clogged acres of arteries, turns his attention tomorrow night to what he calls America's favorite fast food as gobbled from carts and stands, at counters and in diners, and to the gobblers who claim that their towns boast the hottest dogs anywhere.

title: Intel Investment in London
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's biggest computer chip maker, will invest $48 million in an Internet server center in London to establish its first electronic-commerce hub outside the United States. The center will have as many as 5,000 computer servers channeling millions of Web pages each day and will be built in the next 12 months, according to the Invest in Britain Bureau in London. Servers help manage computer networks.

title: FIRSTFED FINANCIAL TO BUY NICHE BANK FOR $47 MILLION
description: The Firstfed Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Professional Bancorp Inc., a California bank holding company, for $47 million, or $23.50 a share. Professional Bancorp, based in Santa Monica, is the parent of First Professional Bank, which provides financial services for health care industry professionals. Under terms of the deal, Firstfed will also acquire privately held Network Health Financial Services, which provides management and marketing services for the health care industry. Shares of Professional Bancorp rose $2.75, to $20.75, and Firstfed fell 43.75 cents, to $18.

title: Car-Finding Software Deal
description: Protection One Inc., a maker of security alarms, said today that it had agreed to sell a unit that makes software to track stolen or lost cars and trucks by satellite to the closely held ATX Technologies Inc. for about $28 million. Protection One is 85 percent owned by Western Resources Inc. ATX, based in San Antonio, is developing technology to help drivers find cars and get directions.

title: In South Florida Canals, Revival of Rare Crocodiles
description: The airboat moved through the dark and rain with a sound like rolling thunder as a powerful searchlight stabbed into the murky shallows of the nuclear power plant's cooling canals, turning the calm water a shimmering gold. The beam of light settled on a pair of red, glowing eyes, and the airboat rumbled up to a fat, gray, salt-water crocodile, eight feet long.

title: AVNET TO BUY ELECTRONICS DISTRIBUTOR FOR $647 MILLION
description: Avnet Inc., one of the world's largest distributors of electronic components and computer products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the electronics distributor Marshall Industries for about $647 million in cash and stock. Avnet, which is based in Phoenix, said it would pay $39 a share in either cash or its own stock for each Marshall share and assume $193 million in Marshall's debt. Marshall's stock jumped $15.6875, or 78 percent, to $35.8125. Avnet said that Marshall, which is based in El Monte, Calif., and its subsidiary, Sterling Electronics, would be folded into its electronics marketing unit. Marshall had sales of $1.7 billion in its most recent fiscal year, and Avnet is expected to have sales of $6.3 billion in its current fiscal year, which ends Friday. Avnet's stock was down $2.625, to $45.1875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Team Detects Neutrino Fired Through Earth's Crust
description: A team of Japanese, American and Korean scientists announced yesterday that they had for the first time fired a neutrino particle through a 155-mile slice of the earth's crust and recorded its arrival at the surface.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SAMUEL M., M.D.
description: BLOOM-Samuel M., M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Samuel M. Bloom, M.D., Associate Clinical Professor Emeritus in the Department of Otolaryngology, who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than six decades. Dr. Bloom joined Mount Sinai as an Intern in 1935 and was appointed a Clinical Assistant upon completion of his Residency in 1939. During his long career in clinical practice and teaching, he served Mount Sinai in numerous capacities that advanced our mission of excellence in patient care and medical education. Recognized by and active in many organizations devoted to his specialty, Dr. Bloom was a Fellow of the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, the American College of Surgeons, the American Laryngological, Rhinological and Otological Society, and the New York Academy of Medicine, an Associate of the American College of Allergists, and Treasurer and a member of the Executive Committee of the American Academy of Facial, Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. He will be remembered fondly not only for his achievements, but also for his devotion and personal warmth, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Zita, to his children Lloyd and Betty, to his grandchildren, and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President Joel Bauer, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: In Times Square Gridlock, It's Not the Heat, It's the Celebrity
description: Some 113 years ago, when the Statue of Liberty began advertising New York's affection for huddled masses, probably no one envisioned just how much of a multitude might show up one muggy day in midtown, or that so many of them would come carrying cameras in cars or stretch limo.

title: Restraint on Rebuilding Serbia
description: As NATO peacekeepers struggle to quell ethnic violence in Kosovo, the West is considering the larger job of reconstruction in the Balkans. The initial impulse to limit aid to Serbia while Slobodan Milosevic remains in power is right. Some humanitarian assistance is justified, but no money should go to Mr. Milosevic or his Government.

title: BREWERY BATTLE POSSIBLE
description: Britain's largest regional brewer, Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries P.L.C., said it was considering making a bid for Morland P.L.C., a British brewer, that could surpass Green King P.L.C.'s offer. Wolverhampton & Dudley's board has requested information about Morland ''with a view to investigating the possibility of making an offer at a higher price than that already recommended by the board of Morland,'' it said. Green King, the maker of Abbot Ale, agreed earlier this month to pay $:145 million ($230 million) in cash and stock for Morland, which makes Morland Original Bitter, Old Speckled Hen and Morland Old Masters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLMAN, JOSEPH A.G., ESQ.
description: KELLMAN-Joseph A.G., Esq. Died in Los Angeles on June 24th, 1999. Mr. Kellman was born in New York City on December 7, 1906. He graduated DeWitt Clinton High School in Manhattan after attending New York University. He received his Bachelor of Law from St. John's University in 1928 and was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1930. Mr. Kellman who was known to all as George, practised law in New York until enlisting in the United States military during the Second World War, serving with the 783rd Battalion of military police, handling prisoners of war. After his military discharge, George joined the American Jewish Committee as Director of its Fact Finding Division. In that post, he monitored and exposed numerous hate groups and Anti-Semitic organizations such as the Ku Klux Klan and George Lincoln Rockwell's American Nazi Party. An acknowledged expert on this subject, he frequently lectured across the country and wrote for publications such as; The New Leader, The American Jewish Yearbook and others. In 1943 he married his beloved wife, Verona Kramer, who died November 1996. He is survived by his son, television and feature film producer/director, Barnet Kellman, his daughter-in-law, actress Nancy Mette and his grandchildren, Kate, Eliza and Michael Kellman. The funeral services were held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, New York, Monday, June 28 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to the Cedars/Sinai Hospice Program, 444 South San Vicente Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA. 90048.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, CEDRIC LOUIS
description: ROBINSON-Cedric Louis Born Hartford, CT. December 21, 1915. Died Windsor, Connecticut, June 27, 1999. Dealer in rare books and historical documents. In 1946 he established Cedric L. He was an early member of the Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America; a past member of Connecticut's Acorn Club, and NYC's Old Book Table. He was a nationally recognized authority on rare books and documents on American History, with clients that included the Smithsonian Institution and the Library of Congress. He leaves his wife, Regina M. Robinson, son Richard and daughterin-law Lisa of NYC, son William and daughter-in-law Margaret of Guilford, Connecticut, grandchildren John Benjamin Robinson, Anne Elizabeth Robinson, Philip James Robinson and other relatives. A memorial service will be held at Carmon Funeral Home, 807 Bloomfield Ave, Windsor, CT., at 11 A.M., Wednesday, June 30, 1999. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the UConn Dept's of History Excellence Fund at Dept. of History, U-2103, University of Connecticut, 241 Glenbrook Road, Storrs, CT. 06269-2103.

title: Cool Dissonances of the 60's vs. Neo-Swing

It was to be a three-act bill sponsored by Blue Note Records in honor of the label's 60th anniversary. But with the cancellation of Ray Charles's concert at Avery Fisher Hall the same night, the opening band for that show, Royal Crown Revue, was added onto the Blue Note show.

title: Stonewall, Then and Now
description: Gay politics today are dominated by men and women in business clothes, representing buttoned-down organizations like the Human Rights Campaign, Log Cabin Republicans and the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund. But the movement that looks so mainstream in 1999 was born at a bar in Greenwich Village 30 years ago this summer. When police harassed gay patrons of the Stonewall Inn in June of 1969, the patrons stood their ground and touched off three nights of fierce civil disobedience -- prominently featuring men in drag. Within a year, the name ''Stonewall'' had become synonymous with the struggle for gay civil rights and full protection under the law.

title: Corrections

Rent stabilization was enacted in 1969; it is the rent control law that dates from 1943. The article also referred imprecisely to the working of the newer law. It regulates individual apartments, not buildings.

title: THE CHEF
description: EVERY summer, Mom took us to visit my aunt and uncle, who owned a tavern in Gambrills, Md. There, we ate soft-shell crab sandwiches: blue crabs just after they had molted, fried and served on two slices of bread with lettuce, tomato and tartar sauce. I still love the multi-flavored, textural experience of a soft-shell crab sandwich -- the crispy shell, the meaty interior and the flavorful mustard, tomalley and roe.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper rose for a fourth day on signs that a world surplus that sent prices to 12-year lows in May was shrinking. In New York, copper for July delivery rose 1.1 cents, to 70.8 cents a pound.

title: SEQUENT COMPUTER SHARES UP ON REPORT OF I.B.M. TALKS
description: The stock of Sequent Computer Systems Inc. rose 25 percent yesterday after it was reported that the company was in talks to be acquired by I.B.M. Sequent's shares closed at $17.5625, up $3.5625 each. The Wall Street Journal reported that discussions were in an advanced stage and that a deal could be announced in the next few days. Sequent, based in Beaverton, Ore., sells high-end mini-supercomputers made by combining multiple chips from the Intel Corporation. This allows Sequent computers to crunch numbers quickly, a key selling point for data base applications. Sequent's stock market valuation is $737 million, and the company is expected to have 1999 revenue of about $840 million.

title: Agreement to Buy Railway

It will buy the outstanding stock in the railway, which had 1998 revenue of $13.4 million, from CSX, Norfolk Southern and other shareholders by July 31. Rail America, which is based here, will also receive the line's locomotives, cars and equipment.

title: OFFER RAISED IN PUB WAR
description: The closely held British company Punch Taverns Group Ltd. raised its unsolicited bid for 3,600 Allied Domecq P.L.C. pubs to $:2.85 billion ($4.5 billion). The British leisure concern Whitbread P.L.C., meanwhile, is pursuing a plan to buy back up to 10 percent of its own stock to improve the value of its rival bid. Punch, a closely held company, said its new offer is equivalent to 272 pence a share, 20 percent above Whitbread's offer, which has a total value of about $:2.4 billion. Allied Domecq shareholders will weigh Punch's offer at a meeting Friday.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation is introducing its first large, broad campaign today to promote I.B.M. computer servers, describing the server as a ''magic box.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, BARNETT A., M.D.
description: GREENE-Barnett A., M.D. Age 91, beloved and loving husband for 66 years of Lee, died on June 28, 1999 at University Hospital at Stony Brook following open heart surgery. Barney was the devoted father of Stuart, who predeceased him in 1997, and of William, whom he inspired into medicine; father-in-law of Sherry and Beverly; and grandfather of Douglas, Stephanie and Bradley and of Ilyssa, David and Lauren. He was an indomitable spirit whose intellect, humor, generosity and force of personality made him unforgettable to all who knew him and successful at all he touched. He worked his way through City College graduating Phi Beta Kappa and through NYU Medical School graduating Alpha Omega Alpha, becoming the first board-certified anesthesiologist in Brooklyn. He served in the Army Medical Corps in World War II in North Africa and Italy and emerged a major with a Bronze Star. He loved medicine and anesthesiology, built a 25-physician practice in 6 community hospitals in Brooklyn & became a nationally known expert medical witness. But mostly he loved Lee, his partner in ballroom dancing and in life. They danced through life together and epitomized that combination of romance, zest for life and shared interests that made them a pleasure to behold and a treasure to emulate. Lee, her family and their friends are bereft without him. His funeral is on Wednesday, June 30, 1999 at 1:30 PM, at Boulevard Chapel in Hewlett, 516295-3100. The family will sit ''shiva'' and receive visitors at Dr. Barnett Greene's home at 10 Washington Avenue, Lawrence, New York. The hours will be from 1:30 PM-5 PM & 6:30 PM-8:30 PM Thursday, 1:30 PM-4 PM Friday, 7 PM-9 PM on Saturday and 1:30 PM-5 PM and 6:30 PM-8:30 PM Sunday through Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Stony Brook Foundation for either the Stuart Greene Lectureship Fund or the Stuart & Sherry Greene Education Fund (please specify), C/O Stony Brook Foundation, 201 Administration Building, SUNYStony Brook, Stony Brook, New York 11794-1188.

title: From Southern India

Unlike the places on Sixth Street, which mostly serve northern Indian and Pakistani food, Madras specializes in the vegetarian cuisine of southern India, pungent, vividly spiced food that can make carnivores forget they're not eating meat.
