Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Karekin I, Armenian Patriarch, Dies at 66
description: Catholicos Karekin I, the spiritual leader of Armenian Orthodox Christians worldwide, who faced the enormous task of reinvigorating his ancient church after the fall of Soviet Communism, died yesterday at his pontifical residence in Echmiadzin, near the Armenian capital, Yerevan. He was 66.

title: Have Barbecue, Will Travel: Tracking Sauces Down South
description: NOT everyone sees red as the color of barbecue sauce. Just as barbecue is defined as pork in some states and beef in others, the liquid used for basting and flavoring can vary from region to region. And ketchup is not at all as common as one may think.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, GARY
description: ROSENZWEIG - Gary. Sutton Place Synagogue extends sincere condolences to our devoted member William Rosenzweig on the loss of his beloved brother. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Giants' Brown Hurt in Crash
description: Gary Brown, the Giants' 1,000-yard rusher, was knocked unconscious and sustained a concussion last Saturday night in his hometown of Williamsport, Pa., when his motorcycle was involved in an accident with an automobile that left the scene, the Williamsport police said.

title: Share Prices Rise Yet Again As Fed Decision Is Awaited
description: Stocks staged another broad advance yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index moved close to their record highs.

title: First SoHo, Now NoHo: Panel Designates a Historic District
description: A chunk of lower Broadway and its surrounding streets, incorporating everything from the Public Theater to bits of Silicon Alley to the Angelika Film Center, are part of a new historic district designated yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD-Eileen. The Officers and Members of the Women's Campaign Board of The American Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of Eileen Bernard, valued member and benefactor of the AJC. To her grieving family, her husband Herbert, her son Lewis, her daughter Margret-Sue, her grandchildren Geoffrey, Debbie, Adam and Claire, and great-grandchildren, Rebecca and Emily, we extend heartfelt condolences on the loss of a warm and caring woman. Ruth R. Goddard, Honorary Chairman, Women's Campaign Board, The American Jewish Committee Stephanie Saft, Chairman, Women's Campaign Board, The American Jewish Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Phone Merger Approved, Subject to Unusual Rules

title: Hershiser's Classic Sports Network
description: He is two and a half months from his 41st birthday. But for one night, Orel Hershiser demonstrated that every now and then he can pitch as if he were still in his 20's and dominating the National League.

title: A Broken Heart (Tongue in Cheek)
description: How might such witty obscurities as Dave Frishberg's ''I Want to Be a Sideman'' and Johnny Mercer's ''My New Celebrity Is You'' fit into a cabaret suite about the mending of a broken heart? If you catch Susannah McCorkle's delicious new show, which plays through July 17 at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, you'll find out. Keeping her tongue lightly in her cheek, the pop-jazz singer weaves 16 numbers ranging from Antonio Carlos Jobim bossa novas to Bessie Smith and Billie Holiday signature songs around a monologue about a sensitive urban Everywoman recovering from a broken relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MAX
description: STEIN-Max. In his 97th year. Husband of the late Florence, father of Dr. Harry L. Stein, his wife Sandy, and Irene Friedman, her husband, George. Grandfather of Dr. Laura, Dr. Peter, and wife, Susan, Dr. Andrew, Nancy and husband, David, Jennifer, Bruce, Richard, and Susan. Great grandfather of Rachel, Emily, and Robert Woolf, Elizabeth Stein, and Alexander Adelson. A one-of-a-kind person who will be missed by many. Funeral services on Wednesday, June 30, at 10 A.M. at Garlick Funeral Home, Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Scudder to Cut Jobs in Shift to Internet
description: The Scudder group of no-load mutual funds plans to close offices and lay off up to 120 employees in an effort to improve sales by shifting emphasis to the Internet.

title: Council Set to Vote On, if Not Resolve, Lead Paint Issue
description: For New Yorkers who thought the city had solved its lead paint problem a generation ago, the recent goings-on at City Hall must seem baffling. For weeks, the City Council has been caught in a fractious debate about a bill up for a vote today that would supersede the city's 17-year-old lead statute and, its supporters say, finally help prevent childhood lead poisoning.

title: Nazi Victims Get Details on Compensation Claims
description: A campaign began today to inform victims of Nazi persecution how to claim compensation from a $1.25 billion fund set up by two Swiss banks.

title: Life Sentence In the Killing Of an Officer
description: In a strange twist to a tangled murder investigation, the confessed killer of a policewoman was sentenced today to life in prison without parole, after arguing that he was innocent and was coerced into pleading guilty.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: U.S. Takes Precautions On Belgian Food Danger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, ROBERT K.
description: HENRY-Robert K. Rest in peace, son. For information, call McGowan Funeral Parlor, 914-429-2130 Nancy and Frederick Henry

title: A Sputter in the Coke Machine; When Its Customers Fell Ill, a Master Marketer Faltered
description: As the Coca-Cola Company tries to regain its footing in Europe after a contamination scare that caused the biggest product recall in the company's 113-year history, executives have made a rare admission: mistakes were made in manufacturing.

title: Culture Shapes Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: High Speed Plus Luxury On the Rails
description: Amtrak unveiled its hope for the future today, the continent's fastest train, which is to begin running late this year from here to New York and Boston. The railroad is hoping to create a nationwide demand for reliable, fast and luxurious trains among travelers who will pay a hefty ticket price to avoid driving or flying.

title: In Latest Blow to Prosecutor, Essex Board Denies Budget Increase
description: The Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders declined today to increase the budget of the embattled County Prosecutor as she had requested. The board members also revealed that they had joined a chorus of other critics of the Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, by asking the State Attorney General to audit the spending of her office.

title: Marshall Wayne, 87, Olympian Who Riled Hitler in '36 Games
description: Marshall Wayne, who displeased Adolf Hitler by winning gold and silver medals in the 1936 Berlin Olympics and who was later shot down over Italy fighting the Nazis, died June 16 in Hendersonville. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUY, ARTHUR R. (ARTIE)
description: GUY-Arthur R. (Artie) on June 29, 1999. Vice President of the Alumni Office at Cardinal Hayes High School. Owner of Vinegar Hill. Loving husband of Alice Marie (Micky) (nee O'Donnell). Dear father of Jennifer, Arthur David, Edward and the late Daniel. Adored grandfather of Samantha, Daniel, David and Kerri. Beloved brother of Edward and John. Cherished uncle. Reposing at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214 Street, NYC on Wednesday 7-9PM, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Good Shepherd RC Church Saturday 10AM. Interment will follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cardinal Hayes Alumni Assoc, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx, N.Y. 10451.

title: Year 2000 Problem Held Minimal for City Services
description: Year 2000 computer problems are unlikely to prevent residents of the New York region from getting water, food and health care, from completing their commuting, or from getting rid of their wastes, according to three studies to be issued today by the Regional Plan Association.

title: Ever a Voice of Protest, Radio KPFA Is at It Again, but With a Twist
description: The trouble at radio station KPFA has come to this: when two folk singers scheduled to perform as a duo on Sunday afternoon arrived at the building, armed security guards would only let one of them inside.

title: City's List of Outlawed Pets Provokes Yowls of Protest
description: Ferrets, wombats, vultures and dozens of other species fell victim to a quality-of-life crackdown of sorts yesterday, when health officials approved a highly specific list of animals that are outlawed as pets in New York City because they are ''wild, ferocious, fierce, dangerous or naturally inclined to do harm.''

title: Accounts
description: * Dreyfus Corp., New York, the mutual funds unit of Mellon Bank Corp., to DeWitt Media, New York, to handle media duties for its account, which had been at Grace & Rothschild, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. The creative duties were recently shifted to Holland Mark Martin & Edmund, Boston.

title: Preserving the Best of Each Season, in Small Batches
description: LET'S face it: Great-Grandma would not recognize home canning today. For most of us, it's not driven by the need to fill the pantry before the onset of winter (or the year 2000), nor is it much of a money-saver.

title: Energy East Is Seen in Deal To Acquire CTG Resources
description: In a move signaling further consolidation in a deregulated utility industry, the Energy East Corporation is expected to announce today that it will buy CTG Resources, the holding company for the Connecticut Natural Gas Corporation, for about $355 million in stock and cash, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: NBC Rehires Albert 2 Years After Firing Him
description: Marv Albert returned to NBC Sports yesterday to call National Basketball Association games nearly two years after a trial filled with embarrassing details about his sex life led the renowned announcer to plead guilty to a misdemeanor count of assault and battery. NBC discharged him on the day he entered his plea.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; Coming Khmer Rouge Trial Rouses Jail's Ghosts
description: The ghosts seem to think this old schoolhouse belongs to them, thumping and moaning, crying out for help, offering themselves for sex, turning themselves into white cats.

title: About New York; Sharing Baby Proves Rough On 2 Mothers
description: PERHAPS it was foolish to think that a simple, happy ending could resolve a story that was anything but simple, yet when last we left the Fasanos of Staten Island and the Rogerses of Teaneck, N.J., they seemed to have managed just that.

title: Teams Find Lean Pickings In the Draft
description: Jerry Krause has been in sleuth mode for a week, trying to uncover the one clue that will return the Chicago Bulls to respectability. If he was not administering a three-hour psychological test to Maryland's junior all-America guard Steve Francis, the Bulls' general manager was dispatching an assistant coach to Rhode Island in search of the elusive Lamar Odom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARICK, FLORENCE A.
description: ZARICK-Florence A. Chairwoman of Saint Nicholas Home, on June 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn. A religious service Friday 10:00 AM Saint Nicholas Cathedral.

title: Robbers Hit Zedillo Presidential Guard, Kill 2 and Steal Payroll
description: In one of the most brazen criminal attacks in memory here, armed robbers ambushed elite soldiers of the Presidential Guard two blocks from Ernesto Zedillo's presidential residence today, stealing a $50,000 military payroll and killing an army lieutenant and a sergeant.

title: UNITED RENTALS BUYS 12 COMPANIES; PLANS TO SELL SHARES
description: United Rentals Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired 12 companies in 11 states with annual revenue of $125 million. Terms were not disclosed. United Rentals, based in Greenwich, Conn., rents equipment, including forklifts, generators, pumps and hand tools. It had annual revenue of $2.63 billion last year. The company also said it had agreed to sell $100 million of series B perpetual convertible preferred stock to affiliates of Apollo Management L.P. of New York. The preferred stock is convertible into about 3.3 million common shares at $30 a share. Proceeds from the sale will be used to reduce debt. Shares of United Rentals rose $2.125, to $29.1875.

title: Making A Point With Smut And Laughs
description: Ask any self-respecting third-grade boy what is the funniest thing in the whole wide world, and he might tell you (in different words, of course) that it is the nether region of the human body. In its spontaneous and sometimes noisy release of noxious fumes, which turn out to be (gasp! chortle!) flammable, the posterior operates according to its own natural laws. These laws are diametrically opposed to the orderly rules laid down by grade school principals and soccer moms who are constantly nagging you to stand in line, wash behind your ears and smell nice for granny. But as any third grader will tell you, chaos can erupt from below at any moment to throw a pall over the nicest little tea party.

title: Political Briefing; An Ex-Wrestler Goes To the Mat for Reform
description: Jesse Ventura wants to reform the Reform Party.

title: 2 Officers Charged in Theft Of Street Vendors' Wares
description: Two police officers assigned to a unit that enforces street-peddling laws were indicted yesterday on charges that they stole counterfeit merchandise from illegal street vendors and then sold it to other vendors in midtown.

title: THAI BANK TALKS NOT DEAD
description: Thailand's central bank said talks would continue with Standard Chartered P.L.C. of Britain on a takeover of Nakornthon Bank, but it left open the possibility of soliciting new bids. Uncertainty about the negotiations led to a sharp drop in Thai banking shares. Under a proposal by Standard Chartered in April, the Bank of Thailand's rescue fund was to put 13 billion baht ($354.5 million) into Nakornthon Bank and then Standard Chartered was to put in 6.2 billion baht for a 68.4 percent stake. But Thai authorities rejected the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: COMMNET CELLULAR TO SELL IOWA STAKES FOR $83.3 MILLION
description: Commnet Cellular Inc., a cellular phone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stakes in several Iowa service areas to Midwest Wireless Communications for about $83.3 million in cash. Midwest will also assume $3.4 million in Commnet debt. Commnet said its 27 partners were also selling their stakes in the territories to Midwest, which provides wireless phone service in Minnesota, in a transaction valued at $141 million. Other partners will receive equity stakes in Midwest, Commnet's chief financial officer, Andrew Gardner, said. Commnet, based in Englewood, Colo., wants to reduce its debt and sell properties on the geographic edge of its network.

title: MacDonald Wins Ike by a Shot
description: Ken MacDonald no longer has to be content with winning last year's New Jersey State Open. MacDonald, 21, captured the Ike, the stroke-play championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association, yesterday at Hollywood Country Club in Deal, N.J.

title: The Court's Attack on Federalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Court Sentences Kurdish Rebel Leader to Death
description: A Turkish security court today sentenced the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, to death for his 15-year campaign against the Turkish Army.

title: Utility Puts Off Stock Sale
description: GreenMountain.com, a company in Burlington, Vt., that uses the Internet to sell electricity generated from renewable sources, has postponed a planned initial public stock offering, company officials said today. The company, which had delayed the offering from last week, said today that current market conditions were unfavorable. GreenMountain.com was founded by former employees of the Green Mountain Power Corporation, a utility company based in Vermont that sells electricity generated from renewable resources like solar and hydroelectric power.

title: Sizzling, And Sputtering, And No Charcoal
description: THIS is addressed to the hibachi haters of the world, which is to say everyone who finds crude little charcoal grills so dirty, slow and inconvenient in countless other ways that they can wreck any holiday weekend.

title: Vexing Party, Clinton Backs Year 2000 Bill
description: Infuriating many Democrats, the White House today reached a basic agreement with Republicans in Congress on legislation to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer breakdowns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: A Cruel Scheme to Curb Abortion
description: Don't be misled by the label. The benignly titled ''Child Custody Protection Act'' scheduled for House action today is in fact a cold-hearted piece of legislation that would jeopardize the health of desperate young women seeking abortions and potentially imprison adults who help them. The bill also flouts the Constitution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, FRANCIS J., REVEREND MONSIGNOR
description: EVANS-Francis J., Reverend Monsignor. June 28, 1999. Pastor Emeritus of Our Lady of Grace Church, Howard Beach, N.Y. Beloved son of the late Aloysius and Mary Evans. Loving brother of Mary Virginia Donnelly and Betty Evans of Greenwich, Ct. Reposing Casey-Porrello Funeral Home, 100-18 159 Ave, Howard Beach, NY on Tuesday from 7-9:30PM and Wednesday 2-4PM. Mass of Transferral Wednesday, 7:30PM at Our Lady of Grace Church. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:30AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: CALENDAR
description: Franks and Wine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT MERGER
description: Acquisition talks between Tyco International Ltd. and the world's No. 1 fire-extinguisher maker, Williams P.L.C., are said to have stalled. Tyco, the world's top security and fire-systems maker, wants Williams's equipment lines, which include Yale and Chubb locks, analysts have said. Tyco, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, and Williams, based in Derby, England, broke off similar discussions in November. Tyco is the world's biggest maker of industrial valves, undersea fiber optic cable and electrical connectors. Williams's shares fell after The Wall Street Journal said Tyco was balking at its asking price.

title: Insurance for Viagra Spurs Coverage for Birth Control
description: Viagra, it turns out, has a political side effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFTERY, JOHN V.
description: RAFTERY-John V. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died in North Beach, NJ on June 12, 1999. Professor Emeritus of English at Pace University. A dedicated teacher and good friend to many, Professor Raftery inspired and touched many people with his love of life, knowledge and the English language. A recipient of the Kenan Award for Teaching Excellence, he served as chairman of the New York Faculty Council at Pace for 13 years and retired in 1992 after 30 years at Pace. He also taught at NYU, the City College of New York and the American Institute of Banking. A World War II veteran (Army), he was a meteorologist with the U.S. Weather Bureau from 1948-1957 and was a founder of the local chapter of the American Association of University Professors at Pace. He was a graduate of NYU in 1959 and 1961 and also a member of the Medieval Academy of America and AAUP. A beloved and devoted husband, he will be lovingly remembered and deeply missed by his devoted wife, Lynn Bellamy. Father of Catherine D. Smith of California. Brother of Thomas L. of Flushing, New York. Survived by his nieces, Denise and Nancy, and two grandchildren. Memorial services will be 7:30 to 9:30 PM, on Wednesday, June 30, at the Thos. L. Shinn Funeral Home, 10 Hilliard Drive, Manahawkin, NJ. Mass will be at 11 AM Thursday, July 1, at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 4700 Long Beach Blvd, Brant Beach, NJ. Contributions may be made ''in memory of Professor John V. Raftery'' to Pace University, C/O Office of University Advancement, 1 Pace Plaza, New York, NY 10038, Att: Donna DeBlasis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, HARRY L.
description: FINK-Harry L., 91. Died on June 27 in Sarasota, FL. Born in New Bedford, MA, educated in NYC. Worked for Plymouth Shops for forty years. Survived by loving wife, Helen, devoted son and his wife, Matthew and Ellanor, adored grandchildren, Nina, Owen, Emily, 3 sisters and 2 brothers. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of S.W. Florida.

title: Seeking a Reading on an Immigrant Past
description: A curator found them while going through one of the old tenement apartments at 97 Orchard Street in the fall of 1993: about six business cards buried in the floorboards and behind the kitchen wall.

title: Campus in Cyberspace
description: Unext.com, an Internet company that recently joined with Columbia Business School to sell business-education material supplied by Columbia, has added Stanford, the University of Chicago and the London School of Economics to its list of academic providers for profit.

title: Embattled Bankers Trust Chairman Resigns
description: Frank Newman resigned today as chairman of the Bankers Trust Corporation, apparently isolated and powerless after Deutsche Bank A.G. acquired his company for $10 billion early this month.

title: Canada's Close Ties to Cuba Fraying Over Human Rights
description: The cozy relationship between Canada and Cuba that has so infuriated American Presidents and Congressional leaders has sunk to its lowest point in years, principally because of Cuba's continuing record of violating basic human rights.

title: $72 BILLION DEAL OF PHONE GIANTS CLEARS BIG HURDLE
description: Federal officials said today that they had tentatively agreed to approve the $72 billion acquisition of the Ameritech Corporation by SBC Communications Inc. provided that the new company not only open its market to competition but also offer local telephone service in 30 cities outside its existing region.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SULZBERGER, EDWARD
description: SULZBERGER-Edward. On June 30, 1988. Of blessed memory for eleven years. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIEDER, ETHEL
description: WIEDER-Ethel. June 30, 1906-January 5, 1999. Remembering a very special woman with our deep love and affection. Always in our hearts. Amy, Gene, Joey and Nancy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, LILLIAN
description: ISAACS-Lillian. January 25, 1908June 28, 1999, some two months after her husband, Abe, at 91, on April 22. A wonderful, loving woman, a gentle soul. The Good One. Beloved mother of Stan and Dianne Dunne. Loving mother-inlaw of Bobbie and Tommy, adoring grandmother of Peter, Michael, Nancy, Ann, Ellen and great-grandmother of Laura, David, Danny, Jeffrey, Sara and Andrew. Devoted sister of Jessie Yablonsky.

title: Rain Rules the Courts As Wimbledon Waits
description: After a glitch-free opening week that whittled the men's and women's singles fields down to 16 contenders each, Wimbledon wore rain like a second skin today. Not a single ball was struck in competition, the first total shutdown at the All England Club since 1997, when the first Thursday and Friday were submerged.

title: Treasure Islands In a Sea of Wine
description: IF you're in the mood to buy a book, there are two kinds of store. You can go to Barnes & Noble and get a good price on a popular title. But if you're a bookish sort, a reader who prefers Thomas De Quincey to Tom Clancy, your feet instinctively take you elsewhere. Wine is the same way. Stores like Garnet and Astor cover a broad swath of territory at competitive prices. They serve an important purpose. But they are not the only places to buy wine.

title: California, Here Bush Comes, a Moderate on Immigration and Racial Quotas
description: George W. Bush plunged into the most-populous state today for the first time as a Presidential candidate. And he immediately cast himself as more temperate than most Republican leaders here and in Washington on two ballot measures that have roiled his party: immigration and affirmative action.

title: A 4-Hour Kirov 'Sleeping Beauty' for the 90's (That Is, 1890's)
description: Longer is not necessarily better. There is much to admire in the striking stage designs and superb musical aspects of the Kirov Ballet's new production, almost four hours long, of ''The Sleeping Beauty.'' There is, especially, the added historical interest of sets and costumes based on the original 1890 designs. But what could have been a dazzling and radical revival lumbered in as a wounded behemoth on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Congo Cease-Fire Talks: Little Incentive to Proceed
description: After days of optimistic pronouncements that a cease-fire was imminent in Congo, a weary South African delegate conceded today, ''Nobody knows how long these talks will last.''

title: A Glimmer of Hope in Ulster As Peace Deadline Looms
description: Negotiators today turned their hopes of meeting an imminent deadline for resolving the impasse threatening the Northern Ireland peace agreement to a long-awaited report on whether paramilitary organizations are willing to disarm.

title: Business Travel; As U.S. air fares continue to climb, more corporate travelers are turning to the Internet.
description: AS air fares continue their seemingly never-ending climb, more business travelers are going to the Internet to find discounts, a practice that is creating problems for some employers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHING, JOHN WARREN III, COLONEL
description: PERSHING-John Warren III, Colonel. The Board of Governors and members of The Leash in NY note with profound sadness the passing of their fellow clubman, Colonel John Warren Pershing III. United States Army Reserve Retired on June 23, 1999. A former Governor of The Leash, Jack was an outstanding gentleman, sportsman and soldier. He will now rest in Arlington National Cemetery with his brother, Richard, and his grandfather, General of the Armies, John J. Pershing. The Membership of The Leash

title: JAPAN'S ECONOMY IMPROVES
description: Japan's household spending rose at its fastest pace in almost three years last month while the jobless rate fell for the first time in 11 months, as consumer confidence showed signs of a revival. Spending by salaried workers rose 3.9 percent from April, seasonally adjusted, the Management and Coordination Agency said, the third consecutive rise. At the same time, the unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent in May as total employment rose by 110,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the United Nations' efforts to set up a civil administration in Kosovo referred incorrectly to Sergio Vieira de Mello, the Brazilian diplomat who is Secretary General Kofi Annan's special representative to Kosovo. He did not run the United Nations mission in Cambodia; Yasushi Akashi of Japan did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Commercial Property; Courtyard Is Rising With New Look
description: Big things are happening at the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue. Bigger even than the four-foot-high golden letters -- T, R, U, M, P -- that now encrust the snowy marble columns at the base of the 50-story tower, reflecting its new ownership.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Vongerichten in Village

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRYZAK, ROSE M.
description: KRYZAK-Rose M. Presbyterian Senior Services mourns the loss of a dear friend, Rose Kryzak, the 1996 recipient of ''The PSS Maggie Kuhn Award.'' Rose's life and legacy will long be remembered.

title: The Court's Attack on Federalism; Not a Free Ride

title: Less Would Be More: Jazz Festival Blues
description: Where there is jazz, there are inflated expectations. Jazz is patriotism, American genius, our home-grown cultural aristocracy. People who really love jazz routinely misunderstand the scale of its popularity; they wonder why the pride of American culture doesn't have a large audience.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growing competition among Web portals in Brazil misspelled the given name of the president of Sky3, an on-line marketing company in Latin America. She is Louana d'Oliveira, not Laura.

description: The Jets, who fell one victory short of the Super Bowl last season, have re-signed 24-year-old defensive tackle Jason Ferguson, one of the ingredients in their success in 1998. No terms were disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: What NATO Victory?
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Pulling Out the Stops In the Rush to Be First
description: For years, New Hampshire had a law that required its Presidential primary to take place in the early spring of each Presidential election year, no fewer than seven days before any other state's primary. That meant, usually, that sometime in late February or early March, a week after Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucuses, New Hampshire would hold the nation's first primary.

title: N.T.T.'S STOCK SOARS
description: Shares in Japan's telecommunications giant, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, rose to their highest level in nine years after Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a daily Japanese business newspaper, reported that N.T.T. would introduce a flat monthly fee of about 10,000 to 15,000 yen for unlimited Internet usage in certain areas around Tokyo and Osaka on a trial basis. N.T.T.'s shares rose by 40,000 yen to close at 1.41 million, the highest close since January 1990.

title: Attorney General Taking Control As Independent Counsel Law Dies
description: Corruption investigations of Presidents and high Government officials will change significantly on Wednesday at midnight with the expiration of the law that gave the country the Whitewater prosecutor Kenneth W. Starr and 19 other independent counsels over the last two decades.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Immigrants Help Defeat L.I. Bill Banning Street Job Markets
description: To the cheers and applause of nearly 100 Latino immigrant workers and their families, the Suffolk County Legislature rejected a bill today that would have banned day laborers from the roadside job markets they use to find work.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''His problem is that he does not want to accept that his father died. He may have thought that---- I don't know what he thought. ''

title: Beyond Primary Colors: Bold New Ice Creams
description: THE heat is making people do weird things to ice cream. Crazy things. Flavors like bay leaf, oatmeal, Serrano chili, Sichuan peppercorn, honey-blossom water with dates.

title: Untimely Delay for Mr. Holbrooke
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is today set to approve the long-delayed nomination of Richard Holbrooke to be chief American representative to the United Nations. Full Senate confirmation could take place before the July 4 recess. But Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa now threatens to delay the nomination over an unrelated civil service dispute. Mr. Holbrooke's presence is urgently needed at the U.N. The majority leader, Trent Lott, should advise Mr. Grassley to drop his obstruction.

title: Metro Business; Meat Company Is Sold
description: Performance Food Group, a wholesale food distribution company based in Richmond, Va., said yesterday that it had acquired State Hotel Supply Company, a closely held meat-processing company in Newark, to expand in the New York City region and add custom-cut steaks to its products. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SAMUAL M., M.D.
description: BLOOM-Samual M., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Bloom joined the staff in 1935 and for over 50 years distinguished himself as teacher and clinician in his chosen field of otolaryngology. Devoted to his patients whom he cared for with expertise and compassion and a conscientious mentor who touched the lives of countless students and residents, he was respected by his peers and loved by his patients. During W.W. II, while serving in the phillippines with the U.S. Medical Corps, Dr. Bloom was captured and held in several military prison camps. Handicapped by a completely inadequate medicinal supply and starvation rations, he worked tirelessly and faithfully to curtail the physical and mental deterioration among fellow prisoners. For the heroism which he demonstrated, his dauntless spirit, untiring devotion to duty and unwavering courage, Major Bloom was awarded a Bronze Star Medal. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Avi Barbasch, M.D., President Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D. Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, Treasurer

title: Oberon Lacks in Height, But Hardly in Altitude
description: Tom Gold, a soloist in the New York City Ballet, is too electrifying a dancer to remain hidden under a bushel. Nonetheless he has waited several years to step into one of the major roles in the company. As a new Oberon in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' on Sunday afternoon, he was very much in his element.

title: Consumer Confidence Is Highest Since '68
description: Consumer confidence rose in June to the highest level in more than three decades, suggesting to some that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates more than once to rein in spending.

title: Latin Growth Weakens, With Joblessness Up
description: Despite brighter-than-expected economic performances in Brazil and Mexico, a spate of new economic data around Latin America in recent days suggests that the recession gripping the region will be deeper and more prolonged than most economists had expected.

title: CISCO IN $435 MILLION DEAL FOR COMMUNICATIONS CONCERN
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Stratumone Communications Inc. for $435 million in stock. Stratumone, based in Santa Clara, Calif., develops semiconductor technology that Cisco said it planned to use for building next-generation high-speed data networks. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., makes routers, switching equipment and software for computer networks. It has annual sales of about $11 billion. Cisco has previously worked with Stratumone, and it made a minority investment in the company in January. Shares of Cisco gained 56.25 cents, to $62.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

description: One Senate. Two Clintons.
