description: Not Your Usual Runway Walker

title: Thousands Protest Milosevic In City Devastated by Bombs
description: In the first major anti-Government demonstration since NATO stopped bombing Yugoslavia, 10,000 people packed into the central square of this war-damaged manufacturing city today to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Improving Medicare
description: President Clinton's Medicare reform plan, if approved by Congress, would constitute the most substantial change to Medicare since its creation in 1965. Although no reform can instantly improve quality and increase cost-efficiency in the enormous program, Mr. Clinton has delivered a well-considered proposal that can shore up Medicare without heedlessly expanding costs or creating chaos for 39 million beneficiaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, FRED C.
description: TRUMP-Fred C. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow to Donald Trump on the passing of his beloved father, Fred. We also would like to extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire Trump family. May his memory be a blessing. The Principals of Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc. Barry M. Gosin Jeffrey Gural Aaron Gural James D. Kuhn William G. Cohen Ronald E. Goldberger Arthur H. Lerner Arthur Rosenbloom Marlene Post

title: Hellman and Hammett, Sturm und Drang
description: Although the biographies of Lillian Hellman and Dashiell Hammett, carried in tandem on tonight's American Masters series, are linked by romance and politics, fame and hard knocks, they are studies in contrast.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: HUDSON UNITED BANCORP TO PAY $425 MILLION FOR 2 BANKS
description: Hudson United Bancorp, the second-biggest bank based in New Jersey, agreed to buy two banks for a total of $425 million in stock. Hudson, based in Mahwah, N.J., said it would buy the Philadelphia-based Jeffbanks Inc. for about $371 million, paying 0.95 of its shares for each of Jeffbanks' shares. The offer values Jeffbanks at $33.19 a share. Hudson United also said it would buy Southern Jersey Bancorp, based in Bridgeton, N.J., for about $54 million, paying 1.26 shares for each Southern Jersey share. That values Southern Jersey at $44.02 a share. Southern Jersey shares surged $14 each, to $37.75; Jeffbanks rose 93.75 cents, to $28.0625, and Hudson United shares fell $3.1875, to $31.75.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Big Board In a Settlement With S.E.C.
description: The New York Stock Exchange did not adequately monitor independent floor brokers who illegally profited from trades, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITT, JACK
description: SITT-Jack. The partners and staff of Grant Thornton LLP extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Sitt family. Jack was a special person, thoughtful, generous and kind to everyone. He had a strong love and commitment to his family and friends. A true gentleman, his presence will be missed. Larry Baye Joel Burzin Jessica Butler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the Palm VII hand-held computer misstated the Web address for Palm.Net, which provides wireless E-mail and Internet services for Palm VII users. It is www.palm.net.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVER, SADIE GREENSTEIN
description: GRAVER - Sadie Greenstein. ''Chickie.'' 97, of Los Angeles, CA, formerly of NYC, on June 26. She was adored by everyone who knew her. She was the dear wife of the late Lou Graver, beloved mother of Judy Graver Isaksen (Allan), grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; By any other name, could China.com be so confident?
description: IN the helium-filled world of Internet investing, a lot can ride on a new company's name. When that name is China.com, you might reasonably assume its stock would float on gossamer wings.

title: Yankees Find the Dominating Clemens, and a Left Fielder, Too
description: It is understandable that Roger Clemens has not been elated with his four-and-a-half months as a Yankee. He has not consistently pitched like a five-time Cy Young Award winner or even like the best starter on a powerful team. Clemens has been decent, not dominating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, HARRIET
description: ISAACS-Harriet. Beloved wife of David, loving mother of Carrie Gamsey, Claudia Frankenberg and Karen Isaacs. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Jamie, Robyn and Eric. Loving sister of Michael, Steven and Susan. Services Thursday 12 noon at RiversideNassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Nassau's Bonds Deemed Riskier By Credit Rater
description: Nassau County's financial problems took a significant turn for the worse today when Standard & Poor's downgraded the county's bonds to the lowest investment-grade category, and delivered a scathing critique of the county's fiscal management.

title: Wal-Mart Wants to Buy Savings and Loan
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's biggest retailer, is seeking permission from Federal regulators to buy a savings and loan association so it can offer low-priced financial services to its customers.

title: Vouchers Bounce Back
description: Cleveland's two-year-old voucher program has been passed again and signed back into law, this time without the legal flaw that caused the Ohio Supreme Court to overturn it last month.

title: South Carolina Again Fails to Rein In Video Poker
description: The video poker industry here is the largest in the country, with 34,000 gambling machines blinking and beeping in virtually every town in South Carolina. Its growth has exploded because of an absence of any serious regulation, but once again today, the State Legislature failed to agree on a method of bringing it under control.

title: Synovus Increases Offer
description: The Synovus Financial Corporation said today that it would increase the amount of stock it would pay for the Merit Holding Corporation to compensate for an 8 percent drop in its share price since it agreed to buy the bank in March. Synovus said it would pay $115 million in stock, exchanging 1.0537 to 1.4132 shares for each of Merit's, depending on its share price when the agreement closes.

title: Ventura: Few Words, But More Home Runs
description: The figures on Mount Rushmore might be more quotable than Robin Ventura when it comes to talking about himself.

title: Boy on Long Journey Told Tales, Police Say
description: The 13-year-old boy who said he traveled solo from Honduras to New York in search of his father manufactured much of what he told the police and people who helped him, officials and the boy's relatives said.

title: 2 INVESTMENT FIRMS TO BUY BIG FLOWER FOR $1.9 BILLION
description: Big Flower Holdings Inc., the largest printer of advertising inserts in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to a $1.9 billion cash and stock buyout by two investment firms: the Thomas H. Lee Company of Boston and Evercore Capital Partners L.L.C., which is headed by Roger C. Altman, the former Deputy Treasury Secretary. Under the deal, shareholders of Big Flower will receive $30 in cash and $5.25 in stock for each Big Flower share held. Big Flower's founder and chairman, Theodore Ammon, together with other executives, will retain holdings in the company and continue to run it. Big Flower's shares were down $3.9375, or 11 percent, to $31.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAINE, THOMAS P.
description: DRAINE-Thomas P. Died June 20, 1999 in Portland, OR. Survived and missed by his wife, Dolly Rieck Draine of Portland, OR; his children, Bruce Draine of Princeton, NJ and Kathleen Draine of Sandy, OR; and his two grandchildren, David and Alexander Draine of Princeton, NJ. Buried June 22, 1999 at Willamette National Cemetery in Portland, OR. with a Navy honor guard. Family suggest donations to the American Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Predictor of Success
description: Pretend you are a college admissions officer and take this test, offered by Clifford Adelman, senior research analyst at the Department of Education. Which of these criteria is most likely to predict whether a high school student will go on to earn a bachelor's degree: a) grade-point average, b) test scores or c) quality of the high school's curriculum?

title: A Paranoia in Which Even the Fridge Is Suspect
description: The youngish woman who walked into the Pantheon Theater's building in front of me was wearing a sleeveless, low-cut, skintight dress short enough to pass for a swimsuit. This made me nervous because the Pantheon is on the second floor of Show World, one of those X-rated establishments that has added a souvenir shop and other G-rated offerings to comply with new guidelines in Times Square. Going to see David Haupt schein's ''Persecution of Arnold Petch'' requires walking through a doorway on 42d Street with a Show World canopy, something I don't really want my colleagues to see on their way to the Port Authority bus terminal.

title: Hearing the Results of Music Lessons
description: They applauded Philip Glass as if he were a rap star and greeted the first notes of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony with a gasp of delighted recognition.

title: Microsoft Offer On Net Service
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the world's largest software maker, is offering new subscribers who sign up for its MSN Internet access service a $400 credit to buy a personal computer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a business consultant's dealings with Martin R. Frankel, a Connecticut money manager who is a fugitive in a fraud investigation, referred incorrectly to the connection of Kroll Associates, a private investigation firm, to the case. Kroll has ties to Thomas J. Corbally, the business consultant, not to Mr. Frankel.

title: Golf's Unwanted Runoff
description: To the Editor:

title: How Not to Spend the Surplus
description: My father, an Italian immigrant, lived through the Great Depression and, like countless others, never forgot its lessons. His advice was born of that experience: ''Never take the good times for granted; always save something for the future because you just never know what can happen.''

title: Senate Agrees on Framework To Weigh Patient's Rights Bill
description: After more than a week of intense partisan feuding that plunged the Senate into paralysis, Republicans and Democrats reached an agreement late today on how and when to consider legislation to give patients new guarantees from their health insurance plans.

title: U.S., Strong on Paper, Is a Match for Europe
description: Ben Crenshaw was in a hotel meeting room yesterday, watching a video that recalled some of the great moments in Ryder Cup history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILCH, TODD DAVID
description: PILCH-Todd David, 7/1/61-1/15/99. Happy Birthday in Heaven. There isn't one day that goes by that I don't miss you. I will never stop thinking about you & wondering if you are okaythat's what big sisters are for. With all my love, Sue

title: Taming the Free-for-All of On-Line Music
description: It was June 22, and Leonardo Chiariglione had a 33-page document in his hand that nobody liked. The record companies thought it was too open-ended, the electronics manufacturers thought it was too restrictive and everybody knew it was too long. These groups had been struggling toward a final version for six months in meetings around the world, and only eight days remained before they were due to present the entertainment world with their initial solution to the most perplexing problem to hit the music business in their generation.

title: 'Family Guy' Loses Sponsors
description: Fox's new animated show ''Family Guy,'' which had the makings of a new hit during its run on the air this spring, is in trouble with a list of important advertisers, some of which have already pulled commercials from the series.

title: CLINTON LAYS OUT PLAN TO OVERHAUL MEDICARE SYSTEM
description: Following up on a promise to preserve Medicare for the aging baby-boom generation, President Clinton today proposed fundamental changes in the program's structure to make it more like private health insurance and to add coverage of prescription drugs, a benefit long sought by the elderly.

title: Political Memo; Albany Democrats Savor Request for County Bailout
description: When enduring economic hardship, New York City has usually turned to the state for assistance, and the reception from the many suburban Republican lawmakers in Albany has rarely been gracious. Why can't the city live within its means, they disdainfully ask, as if lecturing a ne'er-do-well neighbor who has sought a handout once too often.

title: Trying to Rise Above the Wreckage
description: A horse named Zekan waited outside, harnessed to a cart. Shan Salihu, 64, was upstairs -- if that word applies to a building so demolished that no stairs are left -- tossing down the pieces of wood that will make his new house.

title: Digital Music Standard Raises Host of Questions
description: Although members of the music and electronics industries described standards announced on Monday as a watershed for distributing music over the Internet, numerous obstacles could very well prevent the personal computer from becoming the jukebox and record store of the future.

title: Sports of The Times; A Kiss, a Headstone and a Filly Named Three Ring
description: THERE has been a death in the family. Barry and Sheryl Schwartz are just getting through.

title: Has Risk of AIDS Really Decreased?
description: To the Editor:

title: In France, a Rumble Is Heard: 'Vive Gallo'
description: FOR an American winemaker, France is the belly of the beast, a virtually impenetrable market. From Bordeaux to Burgundy, from Champagne to Beaujolais, American wines are about as popular as some new strain of vine-eating bug.

title: Time Warner Names Financial Officer
description: Time Warner Inc., the world's largest media company, said yesterday that it had named Joseph Ripp as its new chief financial officer, replacing Richard Bressler, who was named to head the company's expansion on the Internet.

title: The Gasoline-Powered Raise
description: What's a business to do when it can't hire and retain enough qualified workers? Economists, who have been described as often wrong but never in doubt, have a ready answer: simply offer higher salaries!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: NATO and Kosovo Rebels In an Orderly Confrontation
description: NATO troops here thought they had a big catch today when they came across eight armed men in a cafe, all wearing the uniform and insignia of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, DEREKE
description: HARVEY-Dereke. Died on June 27, 1999 in Brandon, Vermont in her 70th year. Daughter of the late Nancy Jay Harvey and the late Alexander Duer Harvey. Dear sister of Phoebe Harvey Frackman of Greenwich, CT. Devoted aunt of Daphne Jay Bell, Alexandra Bell Witten, Frederick T. Bell and David A. Frackman. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Political Briefing; A Victim of Gaffes Is Now Keeping Score
description: Dan Quayle, out on the Republican Presidential campaign trail again, no longer mangles ideas and lines as he did in the past. Certainly there is nothing yet to top the spelling of potato as ''potatoe'' or proffering that a mind is a terrible thing to ''lose,'' as opposed to ''waste.''

title: Verinque Reinstated
description: Exercising its power as the governing body of bicycle racing, the International Cycling Union yesterday ordered the Tour de France to reinstate a French rider who had been banned from the event because of his notoriety in a continuing drug scandal.

title: Egypt's Leader, in U.S., Hails Change in Israel
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today hailed the imminent changeover of Government in Israel as a ''new dawn'' in the Middle East, a remark that reflects the view of the Clinton Administration as it prepares to step up its campaign for a comprehensive peace between Israel and all of its Arab neighbors.

title: Correction Officer Indicted in Jail Assault
description: A Nassau County correction officer was indicted yesterday on charges of striking an inmate during a strip search in a courthouse jail, causing the prisoner to suffer a punctured ear drum.

title: Two for the 'Moneyline'
description: Moving quickly to fill the gap left when Lou Dobbs resigned three weeks ago, CNN yesterday named new co-anchors for ''Moneyline News Hour,'' the early-evening business news program that Mr. Dobbs created and anchored for 19 years. One newcomer is an old hand at financial news, Stuart Varney; the other is Willow Bay, the co-anchor of two CNN prime-time programs, ''CNN and Fortune'' and ''CNN and Entertainment Weekly.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Corrections
description: The ''Revisions'' column in the arts pages on Monday, about the greatest American movie stars, included one pairing erroneously among the actors and actresses who received the same ranking on the American Film Institute's lists but never appeared together in a film. Spencer Tracy and Marlene Dietrich, who each ranked ninth, did appear on screen together -- in ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' in 1961.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONFELD, PAUL F.
description: KRONFELD-Paul F. Died June 29, 1999. A retired New York City employee, he was 58 years old. He resided in Yonkers, New York and formerly in Brooklyn. Survived by brother, Arnold I. Kronfeld, nephew, Stephen, niece, Sherri, and good friends, Lee and Laura. His kind nature and sense of humor will be missed. Burial is today, at 10:30 A.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: PINNACLE AGREES TO BUY 1,850 TOWERS FROM MOTOROLA
description: Pinnacle Holdings Inc., which rents space on communications towers to companies in the southeastern United States, agreed to buy 1,850 towers from Motorola Inc. for $255 million in cash, adding sites across North America. Buying towers in clusters allows Pinnacle to attract wireless carriers looking to expand their coverage in certain geographic areas, analysts have said. Shares of Pinnacle, based in Sarasota, Fla., rose 50 cents each, to $19.625, before trading was halted. Shares of Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., rose $2.50 each, to $94.375. The news was announced after the close of trading in New York.

title: Bush Raises $20 Million; Bradley's Tally Is Robust
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has accumulated at least $20 million in just four months, raising more money, more quickly, than any Presidential candidate in history. But the most surprising early windfall has gone to former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who has raised more than $11 million to close the money gap with Vice President Al Gore.

title: Vere Bird, 89, Who Led Antigua to Freedom
description: Vere C. Bird, a child of the slums and a Salvation Army drummer who carried the Caribbean island of Antigua to independence and then sired the family dynasty that has led and dominated the country ever since, died on Monday in the capital, St. Johns. He was 89.

title: Investing Limited At Auditing Firm
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest accounting and consulting firm, told about 10,000 managers yesterday to sell investments in companies that the firm audits.

title: Still Dazed, The Knicks Mull Over The Draft
description: Stocked with a roster full of players who just finished an enchanted ride to the N.B.A. finals, the Knicks seem set for an encore next season. No major changes necessary.

title: Sobrero of U.S. Made It in Fits, Starts and Trips
description: Kate Sobrero realized that women's soccer had crossed a new threshold of popularity last week as she sat on the American team bus following a 7-1 victory over Nigeria in Chicago. A college friend from Notre Dame, Julie Maund, was tailgating in the parking lot at Soldier Field, talking to Sobrero by cellular phone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTKIN, ANNE G.
description: KOTKIN-Anne G. In her 95th year, on June 29. Beloved mother of Howard and Marcia, adored grandmother of Dr. Michael and Lori, Julie and Dr. Harold and Lori J., cherished great-grandmother of Richard, Mitchell, Lindsey and Rebecca. Services today, at 2 PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Keeping Tables Level: A Device That Helps Waiters Cope With the Wobblies
description: DESPITE the thickly padded carpet and David Rockwell's carefully selected furnishings, our corner table at the Berkeley Bar and Grill wobbled as if it were on a backwoods porch. We summoned the waiter.

title: Harlem Neighbors Split Over Fate of Prison Amid Brownstones
description: For years, the homeowners of Mount Morris Park, a brownstone-filled historic area in central Harlem, have agitated for the closing of a women's prison in their midst. So they were elated when the budget proposal put forth by Gov. George E. Pataki in January said that the prison would be closed and its residents transferred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Gadgets, Bond Girls and Men in Chaps
description: The latest inevitability to hit the movie screen has its blockbuster credentials firmly in place: Will Smith, July 4th weekend, ''Men in Black'' director, swell gadgets, huge Erector set toy spider, chart-bound hip-hop title song behind the closing credits. Not to mention cheesecake (Salma Hayek in a corset), comical cross-dressing (Kevin Kline in a corset) and enough schoolboy double-entendres to bring out the 11-year-old in the most circumspect sage.

title: At Midnight in Belfast
description: The issue of disarmament has long been the most important obstacle to peace in Northern Ireland. The insistence of Protestants that the Irish Republican Army turn over its weapons, and the I.R.A.'s refusal, have wrecked previous chances at peace. The Good Friday peace agreement postpones the problem, simply committing all the parties -- most importantly, Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing -- to doing what they can to get their allies to give up weapons.

title: Nets Will Sit Back and See Which Way the Picks Fall
description: The war room at the Nets' Champion Center will not be teeming with excitement during the National Basketball Association draft on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOIFER, FRANK
description: SOIFER-Frank. Age 94, of North Miami Beach, FL, formerly of New York, died June 28, 1999 at home. Loving husband of the late Ruth and the late Sunny. Cherished father of Janet Paul, and son - in - law, Robert. Devoted grandfather of Dr. Richard Paul, Debra Rappaport, and Stephanie Paul. Great grandfather of Cory, Sam, and Griffin Rappaport, and Jordan, Brandon, and Jillian Paul. Loving brother of Sally Adler, and Herman Soifer, and of the late Beatrice Harkavy and the late Lena Tamny. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Thursday, July 1, 1999 at 11:30 A.M. Contributions in his name may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Poll Says Many Children Don't Use Insurance Plan
description: A poll released yesterday by Rutgers University shows that 73 percent of eligible families are aware of New Jersey's subsidized insurance program for children, but only 35,000 of the state's 95,000 eligible children are enrolled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEDICIS PHARMACEUTICAL CORP., Phoenix, a pharmaceutical company, sold a range of skin care products to Bioglan Pharma P.L.C., London, a drug development company, for $40 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: In Manhattan, the 646 Area Code Is Correct, but Somehow Wrong
description: Expect your friends and relatives to misdial your phone number. Be prepared to explain when other Manhattan dwellers ask if you live in another city -- or another state.

title: A Rural Italian Stage, a Complicated Script
description: IT'S really very simple, the waiter explained. You can have the $45 Colina Express menu, in which case everyone at the table orders a la carte, or the $55 Colina Country Menu in four courses, with everyone sharing an assortment of first and second courses. Then there's the monthly regional tasting menu at $65, with wines to match for an additional $20, and, of course, the chef's tasting menu, priced at $75.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the yen as Japan's benchmark stock index rose to a 20-month high, raising demand for the Japanese currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.06 yen, down from 121.21 on Monday.

title: Duke Foundation Gives the Arts $5.5 Million
description: The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation has announced $5.5 million in awards to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Appalshop, Dance Umbrella and the Library of Congress for the creation of the Martha Graham Archives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROARKE, MARY
description: GROARKE-Mary. On June 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Thomas M. Dear mother of Kevin P. and his wife Susan, Ann, Desmond T. and his partner Thomas Earnor. Cherished grandmother of Joanna, Daniel and Ellen. Sister of Kathleen Quinn and sister-in-law of Stephen. The family will receive friends at the Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saint John's Church, Friday, 9:45 AM.

title: Sampling the Surprisingly Assertive Cuisine of Tibet
description: TIBETAN cuisine has never made much of a splash in New York. Though a handful of Tibetan restaurants do exist, few people have any idea about the food beyond a vague notion of spare meals of root vegetables. Nor is it easy to learn about Tibetan cuisine; even an authoritative guide like Charmaine Solomon's ''Encyclopedia of Asian Food'' (William Heinemann, 1996), covers Sri Lanka, Singapore and Malaysia, but not Tibet.

title: How a Poetry Critic Becomes Loved
description: REMEMBERING RANDALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANON, EDITH RUBIN
description: GANON-Edith Rubin. On June 28, 1999, in Stamford, Conn., at age 93. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Marilyn and Jan Breslow. Grandmother of Noah & Nicholas Breslow. She spent thirty-five years in the Cleveland Public Elementary Schools as teacher, Assistant Principal and Principal. Her ebullient personality, courage, optimism, and resourcefulness were a model for all to live by. She will be greatly missed.

title: Latin-European Meeting Ends With Vague Commitment
description: The first summit meeting of Latin American and European nations ended here today with leaders of the world's second- and third-largest trading blocs unable to agree on a timetable or an agenda for negotiations for a free-trade agreement. They opted instead for a much vaguer ''strategic partnership'' and a commitment to ''encouraging the increase and diversification of trade.''

title: INSIDE
description: Peace Moves in Ulster

title: Where Pretty Is Cool ... ...for Boys, That Is
description: TOKYO  Five years ago, the Japanese gasped when they found out that young men had not only taken to shaving their legs and chests, they were also using skin lotion, facial packs and taking four showers a day.

title: J. Walter Thompson hires an executive to help brand the agency.
description: IN another high-profile hire, J. Walter Thompson is naming a top executive to a new post with duties that include marketing the agency itself.

title: U.N. Meeting Splits Sharply On Limiting Population
description: With time running out, a 180-nation conference struggling to repair a shattered consensus on limiting world population growth was still divided today over issues ranging from abortion and family planning to sex education in schools.

title: What NATO Victory?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; PURCHASE BY TELMEX
description: Mexico's largest phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, purchased the Dallas-based Comm South Companies, a local service telephone company with 177,000 clients. The $75 million deal made through the Telmex subsidiary Topp Telecom Inc., is the Mexican company's fifth major foreign investment this year. Three acquisitions were in the the United States, while the other two were in Puerto Rico and Guatemala. Rick Wills

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: General Mills Expects Double-Digit Growth
description: The nation's second-largest cereal maker, General Mills Inc., is expecting low double-digit earnings growth encouraged in part by time-saving packaging innovations, the company's chairman and chief executive, Stephen W. Sanger, said yesterday.

title: What NATO Victory?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, FLORENCE
description: BERNARD-Florence. Of Fort Lee. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Robert Bernard, Susan Sabean, mother-inlaw of Moe. Beloved friend of Anna Sun. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, New Jersey Thursday, 10 AM. (1-800-322-0533). She was the best.

title: United States Entries Just So-So
description: The 160th anniversary Henley Royal Regatta begins five days of racing on Henley-on-Thames in England today with questionable prospects for both the weather and the American crews entered in the 17 separate cup events that constitute this regatta.

title: Slavery as a Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: New Deal for Van Gundy? Not Likely
description: Dave Checketts, Madison Square Garden's president, is expected to wrap up interviews with players over the next day or so and then meet with Jeff Van Gundy. While Checketts has assured Van Gundy of his return, one Knicks official said that doesn't mean a contract extension will be offered to the head coach.

title: Queens Jury Spares Life Of Police Officer's Killer
description: After four hours of deliberation, a Queens jury decided to spare the life of a 22-year-old man convicted of murdering an off-duty police officer and the owner of a Queens check cashing business in a 1996 robbery.

title: Beets For Skeptics
description: COMMERCIAL canners probably don't want you to know this, but beets can be eaten raw, and they're delicious. They're not as approachable as an apple, but my suspicion is that even beet-haters will like them raw in this salad. Uncooked beets are less sweet and earthy than they are when boiled or roasted.

title: Group Finds a Way to Offer A Hepatitis C Drug for Less
description: Advocates for people with hepatitis C have found a way for patients to bypass a major drug company and buy an expensive medication, Ribavirin, at far below the usual price.

title: How Rocky Jones Got Her Captain's Bars
description: THE guys in Rocky Jones's crowd were giving up Thursday nights at Captain Walter's -- the most popular hangout in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn -- to study for a fireman's exam? Ms. Jones, a high school graduate and a secretary, was bored and underpaid too, but Thursday nights were important. To rile the guys, she took the test without prepping.

title: It Seems the Cards Do Lie; A Police Sting Cracks Down on Fortunetelling Fraud
description: The green awning outside the quaint storefront at 130 West 10th Street advertises ''psychic,'' but the 37-year-old fortuneteller who calls herself Pamela Miller probably will not answer the door anymore. On Thursday at 3:15 P.M., the police said, she was arrested for making a woman in her 40's believe she had a curse and taking $50,000 of her money over three years to get rid of it.

title: Political Briefing; Clinton as Senator? The Plot Thickens
description: People in Arkansas, as in the rest of the country, seem more amused than anything else by the rumor that President Clinton might run for the United States Senate from his home state in 2002, a year after he leaves the White House. Most were still trying to digest the possibility that his wife, Hillary, might run for the Senate in New York next year when the rumor first hit.

title: Corrections
description: A listing with the On the Road column in Weekend on Friday, about visiting San Francisco, misspelled the surname of the chef of the Zuni Cafe. She is Judy Rodgers, not Rogers.

title: Lighthouse Holdings Buys Primo Angeli
description: Lighthouse Holdings in Chicago, which owns diversified marketing services agencies, said yesterday that it had acquired Primo Angeli Inc. in San Francisco, a branding design consulting company. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ROBERT MURR
description: PHILLIPS-Robert Murr. Of Stockbridge, MA, formerly of Cincinnati, OH., and New York, N.Y., on June 29, 1999. Cherished husband of Sue Ochs Phillips. Loving & nurturing father of Scott and Debbie and Pepper & Valerie; special person in the lives of Larry and Lynn, Jacki & Jan, and Carol and Bruce. Doting grandfather of Callie, Grace, Sophia, Nellie, and Micah. Treasured brother of Ann and Bob Friedman. Everyone will miss his gentle caring and wry humor. A Service Thursday, July 1, 1999, at 11AM at Hevreh of Southern Berkshire. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: W.T.O. COMPROMISE PLAN
description: The Australian Trade Minister, Tim Fischer, left, said an effort was being made to work out a compromise between the two contenders vying to lead the World Trade Organization. Meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, with other trade ministers from the 21-country Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, Mr. Fischer met separately with the Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand, Supachai Panitchpakdi, and the New Zealand opposition politician Mike Moore -- the two competitors for the post. Both were said to favor a term-sharing arrangement under which Mr. Supachai and Mr. Moore would take turns as director general.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: 3 Sleepers Could Be Eye-Openers
description: Andy Panko slipped into Chicago early this month for the National Basketball Association's predraft camp with little notice. In Chicago, they were dreaming about the top pick in the draft, so fans did not camp out outside the Moody Bible Institute for a peek at a 6-foot-9-inch shooting guard who would not be the first pick. The Bulls have the top pick in today's draft. But Panko is good enough to have drawn scouts to Division III Lebanon Valley College, an 1,100-student campus in Annville, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLOW, BEATRICE
description: GITLOW-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Abe Gitlow, who was the dean and guiding spirit of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance (later the Stern School of Business). Bea was an invaluable assistant to Abe and a partner in all aspects of his life. The University mourns her death and shares with Abe and his family their grief and sorrow. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts pages yesterday about the opening of the Vail Valley Music Festival today in Colorado misstated the role of a participant. Marin Alsop is music director of the Colorado Symphony, which played on opening day, not music director of the festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATHKOPF, JULIUS
description: RATHKOPF-Julius. The partners of Herrick, Feinstein LLP extend their deepest sympathy and condolences to Stephen Rathkopf, our dear colleague and treasured friend, on the death of his father. Stephen, our heartfelt thoughts on your great loss are with you, your mother May, your sisters Ronnie and Phyllis and the grandchildren.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS
